column2: PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 14. -- The Wage Earners' Journal of Phillipsburg, Penn., which has for several years been published in the interest of the bituminous coal miners of Central Pennsylvania, in its last issue comes out boldly in favor of Pattison for Governor. In a leading editorial the Journal says it favors Pattison because he is the friend of workingmen. As proof of this, the editor continues:

WASHINGTON, Sept 14. -- Nothing except the Tariff bill has caused so much discussion during the past week as the new bill for an apportionment of the Congressional representation under the new census. There have been reports, from time to time, that the House Committee on the Eleventh Census was preparing a bill.

There is every indication that the coming Winter will be an exceedingly lively one for amateur photographers. Both the Camera Club and the Society of Amateur Photographers have laid out programmes of length and of great variety of subjects to be studied, while there will be frequent lantern-slide exhibitions. There was never more interest taken in the subjects. Hundreds of new amateurs will have work to show and talk about.

HELENA, Mon., Sept. 14. -- J.O. Green, son of Dr. Norvin Green of New-York, who started for New-York last night, gave the first particulars that have been received here of the drowning of Robert Ray Hamilton in Snake River, near the south end of the Yellowstone Park. The region is remote from any settlement or telegraph station, and Green, who identified the body, has communicated the fact only to the family in New-York.

Mr. KENNEDY of Ohio will probably seek to-day a chance to defend his famous speech on the subject of the two Judases, but it is also only too probable that he will seek it in vain. It is not impossible that Mr. KENNEDY'S very plain reference to Senator PAYNE may have incited Mr. ENLOE, Democrat, to move yesterday that the House humbly apologize for Mr. KENNEDY'S remarks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- After all the fuss that has been made by the Republicans about the speech of Representative Kennedy on Quay, and the energetic efforts of the Pennsylvanians to prevent its publication in the Record, it was left for a Democrat to bring in the resolution to condemn the utterances of Kennedy as a breach of the decorum of the House.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 15. -- After several weeks of negotiations the Adams Express Company has at last obtained control of the Earle Prews Express Company. The transfer has greatly surprised business men and the public in general. The New-York and Boston Express has also been absorbed by the Adams Company, although to the public the fact is not generally known.

The British taxpayer is to swallow his usual dose this year as the result of the annual naval manoeuvres. In Germany, when an addition to the military budget is wanted, a war scare about France or Russia serves the purpose very well, and after the appropriation is voted the dark clouds that have been summoned up are allowed to roll away.
BUENOS AYRES, Sept 15. -- Senor Hernandez has been elected Governor of Entre-Rios.

LISBON, Sept. 15. -- The reassembling of the Cortes to-day caused great excitement throughout the city, as a stormy debate on the Anglo-Portuguese treaty was expected. Shops and offices were closed and thousands of citizens of all classes wended their way to the Parliament buildings, which were besieged by an enormous crowd, clamorous for admission, hours before the session opened.

An exhibition whose chief charm and principal merit were novelty was given at Nible's Garden last night. A theatrical representation which can boast of genuine novelty is certain to command public attention, and the appearance of the Rosenfeld Brothers' Company of dwarf actors and actresses will hardly fail to arouse interest.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -The manau, ers of tile Veatern railroads were advised to day by the Inter-State Commerce Commission that the order reducing grain rates from the Missouri River anc points beyond was further suspended until Oct. 1. The communication came in response to the request of the man. agers that t later date thn Sept 15 be named to allow the railroads ample time in vlfich to prepare their trlff.

HARTFORD, Sept. 15. -- The preliminary work of the Democratic State Convention, which will be held to-morrow, is now in progress, and the outlook is favorable for the nomination of a successful ticket. The best of feeling prevails, and the delegates are working harmoniously for the interests of the party.

Elections for the purpose of adopting or rejecting constitutional amendments do not, as a general thing, bring out a large vote. The people of New-Jersey will have an opportunity on the last day of this month to vote on an issue of this nature and one of the most important that has ever been brought before them.

READING, Penn., Sept. 15. -- This city is alive with Democrats to-night, and the indications point to an immense attendance at the annual convention of the Democratic Societies of Pennsylvania here to-morrow. The Democratic standard bearers, ex-Gov. Pattison, ex-Lieut. Gov. Black, and William H. Barclay, will arrive to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock and will hold a reception at the Mansion House.

The Hon. ELLIS H. ROBERTS, United States Sub-Treasurer in this city, expressed to a reporter of the Evening Post yesterday his views and opinions upon one of the measures adopted by Secretary WINDOM for the relief of the money market. We reproduce his observations, which we commend to the attention of financiers, tax-payers, protectionists, and schoolboys:

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- The sale of season tickets for the tenth season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra was begun in Music Hall to-day. There was a large attendance of ladies and gentlemen, notwithstanding the storm. The bidding was very lively and the prices ranged very high -- much higher, it was stated, than ever before.

The Philadelphia, flagship of the North Atlantic station, under command of Rear Admiral Bancroft Gherardi, left the mud of the Wallabout at 9 A.M. yesterday, and a little later came to anchor off Stapleton, S.I. The ship was watched by an admiring thong as she passed under the bridge and stood down the river amid the tooting of steam whistles and waving of handkerchiefs from wharves and river craft.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The Passaic County Republicans this afternoon nominated Joseph H. Quackenbush for Sheriff with little opposition, he having carried the primaries by overwhelming majorities. Mr. Quackenbush was defeated three years ago by 1,800 majority, although the county is usually good for that much Republican majority.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15. -- Mr. John Joyce, ex-Clerk of the Courts, has come forward and paid into the County Treasury over $4,000 that should have been paid upon his retirement from office. The County Treasurer, as well as his predecessor, and the County Auditor, who have drawn fees claimed to be illegal, have materially changed their line of defense, and are manifestly bidding for public sympathy.

A horrible sight was disclosed to the crowd at the Park Theatre last night as they were coming out of the theatre at Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street at 11:15 o'clock. Upon the electric-light pole opposite the theatre, on the southwest corner of Thirty-fifth Street, with his legs strapped to the standard, was a lineman, and one glance told the story that another man had fallen a victim to the deadly electric-light wires.

ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- A nice legal question is being considered by Superintendent of Public Instruction Draper. It is in relation to which of two school districts is entitled to school moneys coming from the western terminus of the Poughkeepsie Bridge. They are in Lloyds, Ulster County, and each is anxious to receive the big slice of the amount the bridge property is taxed for school purposes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The meeting of the glass manufacturers, to be held at the Auditorium to-morrow, promises to be a lively affair. The document drawn up at the last meeting, and intrusted to a committee of five, which was to secure signatures of firms not represented at the meeting, has not been signed by all.

As a contribution to "harmony" the speech of Gen. C.S. Warren on taking the chair as permanent President of the recent Republican Convention in Silver Bow County, Mon., is, perhaps, unique. This is all of it, as printed in the Butte Inter Mountain, a Republican paper: "Gentlemen of the Convention and Republican Friends: It has been well and wisely said that 'Time makes all things right.'

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Commissioner Raum was to-day again before the special House committee which is investigating the charges against him. Mr. Cooper asked him whether there was a sub-company of the Universal Refrigerator Company in this District.

HELENA, Mon., Sept. 15. -- The Democratic State Convention met here at noon to-day. It was the best attended of any that the party has ever held and the delegates were all very enthusiastic. For months the sentiment throughout the State has been in favor of W.W. Dixon of Butte as the nominee for Congress, but he has always said he could not run.

CHIOAOO, Sept. 15. -- The CaiYlle market was fairly active to[day and best natives sold 510o higher. 0careen to fair natives and range 0stile were without material change. The demand for "handy" grades ad "good" shippers was brls The quaUty of the offerings was rather poor. Dressed Beef men bought 1,384, Ib Steers at $5, and exporters and shippers paid as high as $5.10 for 1,411 to 1,4541 Steers. Natives soldprlncipally at $10$4.80.

In accordance with custom the Democrats of the Third Assembly District of Westchester led off yesterday with the election of eight delegates to the Congressional Convention, which will meet some time between to-day and the 10th of October for the purpose of nominating a candidate to succeed William G. Stahlnecker, who has represented the district three times.

The annual report of the Boston and Maine Railroad Company to June 30 shows: Gross earnings, $14,587,000; balance after deducting operating expenses, $5,249,300; net income after total deductions, $1,160,600; surplus for the year, $501,600; total surplus, $2,024,500.

Still another drama of the sea, a result of the hurricane of Aug. 31 and Sept. 1, was reported yesterday morning by the French liner La Normandie. Sunday afternoon just before 3 o'clock, while everybody on board the steamer was on deck watching the steamers Runic and Eider going by on their way to Europe, the watch reported a crippled ship six miles to the southward flying signals of distress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- A bill to forfeit the charters of the Chicago Gaslight and Coke Company, the People's Gaslight and Coke Company, the Consumers' Gas, Fuel and Light Company, the Consumers' Gas Company, the Equitable Gaslight and Fuel Company of Chicago, and the Chicago Gas Company was filed this noon in the Circuit Court clerk's office by Corporation Counsel Hutchins on behalf of the city of Chicago as complainant.

Dispatches from Ohio say that "the new Window-Glass Trust is almost ready to go into operation." We find in the Pittsburg Commercial Gazette a description of the plan of the Trust, introduced by the assertion that "the window-glass manufacturers' combination to control production and the markets of the United States is no longer problematical, but an accomplished fact."

Charles B. Young, the sixteen-year-old son of G.W. Young, Assistant Superintendent of the Maritime Exchange, was at his home, 34 Orange Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, suffering from the results of a peculiar accident. Last Saturday the boy was on his way home from L.H. Bigelow Co.'s office, 24 Liberty Street, where he is employed.

SING SING, Sept. 15. -- Schuyler Hamilton of this village, brother of the late Robert Ray Hamilton, to-day received two letters from the scene of Hamilton's death. One was from John D. Sargent, the keeper of the ranch at which he was staying, and the other from Cassimir De R. Moore of Sing Sing, who had gone out there for a visit.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 15. -- The Republican State Convention will be held in this city on Wednesday, and to-morrow evening the delegates will have matters all arranged. Gov. Bulkeley will be here, possibly to supplement with his presence the work that Alderman Patrick McGovern and others have been doing among the ring politicians during the past week.

SOUTHAMPTON, Sept. 15. -At 6 o'clock this morning the military paraded, while the police guarded the dock gates. Few men were allowed within until 11 o'clock, when the lockout notices were withdrawn and all except the Royal Mail and Union Companies engaged the requisite number of hands. At noon work was commenced in earnest, and the masters held a meeting, but adjourned without reaching an agreement.

The members of the Grant Monument Association, and especially the members of the Executive Committee, upon whom devolved the somewhat delicate duty of selecting a design for a memorial structure from among the several drawings submitted by architects in competition, are much gratified to find that their choice has been generally commended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Nearly the entire day in the House was consumed in disposing of the troublesome question of what to do with that speech of Representative Kennedy on Matt Quay. The Republicans, with a comical assumption of seriousness, talked about whether it should be kept out of the permanent edition of the Congressional Record, just as if their decision would make any difference to the country.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 16. -- An important sale has been made in Milwaukee that means a great deal considered in connection with the moves of railway companies. The Shea and George Company's docks and freighthouse in Erie Street have been sold for $800,000 to the Wisconsin Central. It is a part of the plan of the corporation to secure a foothold in Milwaukee for yard and station purposes.

It is no longer denied that brick is "sneaked" into this market from yards that are pledged not to ship in quantities sufficient to supply the present needs of the market. Yesterday's receipts amounted to quite 3,000,000 brick, of which only 1,660,000 were reported to the local committee whose duty it is to keep track of the supply.

William's Bridge, Westchester County, tried the new Saxton ballot-reform law yesterday and pronounced it a success. Several hitches and quandaries arose, the natural result of a new and untried law, but the officers having the matter in charge had plainly profited by the mistakes made at Rockaway a week ago and were determined to make its operation successful.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 16. -- Dr. J.O. Green of New-York arrived in Louisville last evening on a short visit to his friends and relatives. He has just returned from Montana and the Yellowstone National Park, where it was his sad misfortune to find the remains of Robert Ray Hamilton, who was drowned in Snake River.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Politics are having a great deal to do with the selection of a Director General for the World's Fair. The leading candidates, Col. Davis and Gen. Hastings, are Republicans, but the Democrats of the Board of Commissioners are showing a disposition to rally around Gen. Stevenson, and the name of Col. McKenzie of Kentucky, also a Democrat has been thrown into the hat.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 16. -- A dinner was given last night by the city of Stockholm to the officers attached to the United States steamer Baltimore, which conveyed the body of the distinguished inventor, John Ericsson, from the United States to this country. Two hundred guests, including the Ministers of State, military and naval officers, and leading civilians were present.

The Minneapolis Journal answers squarely to the assertion made during the Maine campaign by Reed, McKinley, and Lodge that the Tariff bill was put through the House in answer to a popular demand for its passage. It says: "It was whipped through by Speaker Reed and Congressman McKinley, no opportunity for any serious discussion being given and most of the amendments being entirely rejected.

The Secretary of the Treasury has offered to use his influence, and presumably that of the Administration, with the conference committee of the House and Senate on the Tariff bill to secure a postponement of the date at which importers will be required to pay the duties on their goods in bond. He is said to be confident that this influence will be decisive, and that the date will be put off to Feb. 1.

The projectors of the contemplated new line from Lake Hopatcong, N.J., to the "Great Notch" on the New-York and Greenwood Lake Railroad have secured from the Central Railroad of New-Jersey promises of co-operation, and will be able to lessen the cost of construction by using the Central tracks from the Rockaway station to the lake.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- The Standard severely attacks the American meat-inspection law. "A more outrageous encroachment," it says, "was never framed in any civilized country. It is rendered the more irritating by the fact that it is to be carried through Congress with the Tariff bill, which aims at a practical exclusion of European and Canadian products from American markets.

The old adage in regard to curses like chickens coming home to roost may occur to Mr. BLAINE these days. Mr. WINDOM, the successor of Mr. FAIRCHILD in the Treasury Department, has been struggling for the past week with the problem of how he could mitigate the evils of Government interference with the money market.
BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- The following letter from Mr. Blaine is furnished for publication:

ONEONTA, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Although rain started in at an early hour this morning and continued the greater part of the forenoon, there was quite a good-sized crowd on the grounds of the Central New-York Fair Society at 1 P.M., the hour advertised for the joint tariff debate between Mark D. Wilber and ex-Congressman Horr.

Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday signed an order transferring to the United States courts two suits brought by Ehud N. Darling of this city against Gen. Benjamin F. Butler. The suits were recently begun through Mr. O.F. Hibbard, Mr. Darling's counsel, and when brought to trial they will, if successful, compel Gen. Butler to account for his proceedings in regard to certain land transactions, which had their beginning about twenty years ago.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 16. -- The work of the Democratic Convention was not completed until a late hour this afternoon, but it will stand the closest scrutiny. The renomination of Judge Morris of New-Haven, who received 303 votes against 93 in favor of James W. Hyatt of Norwalk on the only ballot ordered, being informal, was a thoroughly gratifying result.

The decisive vote by which the House refused to concur in the Senate's amendment to the General Deficiency bill making an appropriation for the French Spoliation claims doubtless disposes of those unfortunate claims for this session if not for the present Congress. They have had a curious run of luck.
Mayor Grant yesterday addressed a request to the Board of Education for detailed information about the accommodations provided for school children. He desired the board to report to him:

The Anchor Line steamer Caledonia, that arrived in port yesterday, also brought news of the ship Challenger, that met with such fearful loss in the Sept. 1 cyclone. She passed the ship at 6 o'clock Sunday evening, four hours after the Normandie did, and also offered assistance, but hail it refused, with thanks. The Challenger was then heading north-northwest, and staggering slowly along before a light southwest breeze.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 16. -- Chalmers L. Dick, formerly Chief Burgess of Johnstown, Penn., died suddenly this morning, aged thirty-four years. It was the great flood of Johnstown that brought Dick into national prominence. His term as Burgess had recently expired, and he was turned to as one to head the relief work. He was the first man to bring help from the outside to the sufferers.

DENVER, Sept. 16. -- The delegates to the semi-annual meeting of the American Association of General Passenger and Ticket Agents arrived here this morning on a special Chicago, Burlington and Quincy train of Pullman sleepers in charge of General Passenger Agent P.S. Eustis.

The district committees of the Tariff Reform Congressional League met last night in the small hall of the Cooper Union to determine the action to be taken by the league to secure the nomination of fit and capable candidates for Congress. There was a large attendance and great interest was shown in the proceedings.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 16. -- Sir Ambrose Shea, Governor of the Bahamas, is still in the city on business with the Dominion Government. From the frequency of his conferences with the Cabinet it soon became apparent that his mission here concerned more than the question of Canadian mail steamers touching at his little colony. The political sentiments of Sir Ambrose are well known.

The plans outlined in THE TIMES yesterday by which it is proposed to divide the contributions to the Grant memorial at Riverside Park in such a way that the structure shall represent a tribute from the entire people of the country excited widespread comment, and was most heartily approved by all who took occasion to discuss it.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A convention of delegates from county and town farmers' leagues in the State of New-York for the purpose of organizing a State farmers' league was called to order at 12:15 P.M. to-day at the Leland Hotel. L.D. Collins of Watervliet was chosen Chairman and Samuel Thomas of Granville was made Temporary Secretary.
MADRID, Sept. 16. -- A fire broke out at 10 o'clock last night in the Palace of the Alhambra, in Granada. It originated in the Alberca Courtyard and soon spread to the galleries.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- This is the big day at the State fair. The attendance is large, many persons coming on special trains, as well as from the vicinity, notwithstanding the bad condition of the grounds from last night's rain. The Hon. Chauncey M. Depew spoke to as large an audience as could get within hearing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Does Speaker Reed mean to usurp the veto power? He has appropriated nearly every other power within his reach, and now some of the members, who are anxious about the River and Harbor bill, are wondering if he proposes to kill it by refusing to sign it and send it to the President.

Judge George W. Greene, the distinguished jurist of Orange County to whose acumen as a legislator is to be credited the elastic charter under which the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company is incorporated, and his loyal coadjutor, Charles H. Swan, who have been entertaining each other with philosophy and typewriter practice respectively all Summer while waiting for a few more subscriptions to come in, were in high feather yesterday.

The Republican organs that are defending the action of the Republicans in the Senate Finance Committee and their party associates in the Senate with respect to the sugar duties must believe that their readers have neither memories nor common sense. These journals have recently admitted that the Senate has done what the Democratic Ways and Means Committee did in 1888.

The responsibility for the discontinuance of the method of disposing of Government funds by depositing them in national banks belongs pre-eminently to the Hon. James G. Blaine, for it was he who "deaconed off" the attack which was made upon it in 1888. Other men, with smaller skill at misrepresentation and mendacity, were associated with Blaine in this attack.

Mr. Henry E. Abbey returned from Europe yesterday on the Ems. He was accompanied by Mrs. Abbey and his private secretary, Mr. Charles F. Chatterton. Mr. Abbey was looking remarkably well when seen by a reporter for THE TIMES, and said that his general health had never been better. He had spent most of the time abroad in London and Paris, and spoke freely of his business ventures for the coming season.

LONG BRANCH, Sept. 16. -- R. Percy Dobbins, D.S. Brown, D.M. Hildreth, Mrs. Alice Bradley, Dr. J.P. Pemberton, G.W. Pach, Newberry Havens, Mortimer Hendricks, and William Campbell were the nine Ocean Avenue property owners who met Mayor Woolley and live of the six members of the Long Branch Commission this afternoon to discuss plans and schemes for the preservation of the Ocean Avenue bluff.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Census Bureau to-day announced the result of the count of the population of the State of Connecticut by counties as follows:

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 17. -- A railroad is in process of construction from Evansville, Ind., through Kentucky and Tennessee to Chattanoaga, that will be extended to Atlanta and from thence to the South Atlantic coast. This line makes the distance seventy-six miles shorter between Chattanooga and Evansville, via Chattanooga, to Atlanta and the Atlantic coast.

Miss Marion Child lcAndrew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. MoAndrew of Staten Island, was married at 2 P. iL yesterday to iIr. Percy lorth Graham of London, England, in St. John's Protestant Episeoval Churclx at Clifton, 8. I., by the Rev. Dr. John C. Eccleston.

The "straight ticket" men were probably in the majority at the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee held last evening. This will give some temporary joy to Elder SHEPARD -- otherwise the decision of the committee that the Republican County Convention shall be held Oct. 2 has little significance, and will probably have still less influence in shaping the city and county canvass.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- The World's Fair Commission met this morning, and President Palmer announced his election of the Executive Committee. This committee will name a Director General, and by virtue of its position will be the most important in connection with the exposition. The committee will no doubt be accepted by the commission without opposition as named by the President.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Sept. 17. -- In accordance with general expectations, the Republicans of this, the Eighth Ohio Congressional District, in convention at Carey, nominated ex-Gov. Charles Foster as their candidate for Congress. A telegram was read in the convention from the ex-Governor asking that his name be not considered, but the delegates disregarded these expressions, and, suspending the rules, nominated him by acclamation.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 17. -- It will not be many days before a big political battle will begin in this district, the Sixteenth, and this city of Canton, the home of Major William McKinley, will be the theatre of the hottest contest ever waged between the two great parties in Ohio. For Ohio this one is just as important from a party standpoint as was the one in Maine.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- The Republican State Convention has adhered pretty closely to the forecast in to-day's TIMES. With the single exception of the success of Major Gould over Auditor Ladd, all the offices have been distributed as foreshadowed, and the cut-and-dried proceedings were of the kind that are becoming so depressingly familiar in this State.

A notable change for the better was made in the cast of "The Cleaenceau Case" at the Standard Theatre last night. Miss Sybil Johnstone assumed the role of Iza and invested it with at least a semblance of the character suggested in the lines. In the first scenes the actress was highly successful in creating the illusion of girlish ingenuousness and inexperience.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 17. -- One of the most terrible tragedies that ever occurred in Portsmouth took place to-night, and the city is in a fever of excitement. A mob of several hundred people surrounds the tenement house 6 Middle Street, where the bodies of three dead persons partially attest the extent of the crime.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 17. -- The tendency of the labor vote toward Robert E. Pattison, the Democratic nominee for Governor, has alarmed the managers of the Republican Gubernatorial campaign, and they have devised a scheme to turn the tide in another direction. Many of the principal leaders of the coal miners have openly declared for the Democratic candidate, and not a few prominent men in other branches of organized labor have taken the same stand.

The bill which has been introduced into the Senate by Mr. INGALLS to amend the act passed half a dozen years ago for the government of Alaska has a purpose more specific and more important than its language may show. It gives to marine and revenue cases the right of appeal from the District Court of Alaska to the Circuit Court of Oregon.

Since Chairman J.F. Goddard resigned his position at the head of the Western Passenger Association, speculation has been rife as to what he intended to do. Dispatches from Chicago show that he is to become Chairman of one of the largest associations in the United States.

Baron Jose Ma Munoz of 27 East Twenty-sixth Street and his wife and young son were passengers on a down-town Fourth Avenue car that left the Grand Central Station at 2:30 o'clock Tuesday afternoon. Dr. E.P. Stein, who is stopping with friends at 30 East Fifteenth Street, rode down town on the same car.

The Southampton dock strike is much the most serious "labor difficulty" of recent times in England. There have been much more serious troubles. Mere riot is not pleasant or creditable to anybody concerned, but the deliberate atrocities planned and executed by the trades unions in Sheffield were very much worse than a street fight, even on a much larger scale than the street fights in Southampton.

The concurrence of the House in the Senate resolution authorizing the President to appoint RICHARD H. JACKSON of Alabama as an ensign in the navy secures a specific reward for conspicuous gallantry. Young JACKSON was on board the Trenton during the hurricane at Samoa in which that vessel was lost.

pHU, ADELmaXA, Sept. 17. -- Owing to the nnfavorable eather the Grand Circmt races arranged for to-day ut Point Breeze Park were postponed. The track vas very heavy at noon, when the rain ceased and the sun cme out. If there are no more showers the footing wfil be dry to-morrow. The hree postponed events are the 2:33 clas trotting, 2:18 elate pacLug, and 2:20 class trotting.

President Wilson of the Board of Health yesterday sent a letter to Mayor Grant answering the Mayor's letter of the 10th inst. regarding the census figures. In his letter President Wilson incloses elaborate schedules on the death rate of the city of New-York and the total number of deaths since 1879, as well as all estimates of the population that have been made by the Health Department between 1879 and 1890.

MEIPHXS, Tenn., Sept. 17. -- The funeral of Mrs Hary J. Persons, wife of William H. Persons, one of the wealthiest men in this city, who was supposed to have committed suicide yesterday, ook place to-day. The body was en route to the cemetery, followed by a procession a mile long, when a Sheriff's pesse arrived and took charge of the remains,

WORCESTER, ass., Sept. 17. -- The old ticket of last year, headed by ]Russell and Corcoran, will be renominated to-morrow at the Democratic State Convention, with only one or two possible changes. There is a fair showing of delegates on the ground.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Republican programme required that to-day should be spent in trying to get up the Langston-Venable contested election case, and the programme was successfully carried out, but with very little assistance from the Democrats.

The Republicans of Massachusetts, New-Hampshire, and Connecticut held their respective conventions yesterday. There was striking uniformity in the tone of their proceedings, and the Massachusetts convention may be taken as a sample of all. The party is plainly intoxicated by the success in Maine, as was inevitable.

Delamater says that Blaine is mistaken, very much mistaken, in thinking that there is not a line in the McKinley bill which, if the bill should become a law, would give American farmers additional market for their produce. He says that when the bill becomes a law it will give our farmers markets where they may sell $250,000,000 more a year than they are now selling.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Ex-Congressman Roswell G. Horr of Michigan and ex-Collector of Internal Revenue William A. Beach of Syracuse debated the tariff question at the Lewis County Fair here this afternoon. The attendance was not large owing to the weather and the fact that recent floods destroyed nearly all the highway bridges in four towns adjoining.

There is a Drospeet of a cessation of the steady downpour of rain, and with pleasant skies today there will be good sport for the patrons of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, even if the track is hcmvy, The Algcri 8takes, for t-we-year-aids, andthe Culver Staks, for all ages, boh at tkreequarters of a mile, are the fixtures to be docidecL

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17. -- The formal opening of the college was held to-day in Marquand Chapel, where President Patton addressed the students in a few words of practical application. He appealed to the Sophomores to avoid all attempts at hazing and that which savors of "rowdyism." He spoke of the high state of manliness which had recently been manifest in Princeton, as well as in other large universities.

The present rainstorm is the greatest known with one exception since the establishment of the Signal Service Bureau. Yesterday was the eighth day of the storm, and from noon of Tuesday to noon of yesterday the rainfall was greater than that of all the other seven days combined. The rainfall for that twenty-four hours amounted to 4 1/2 inches, as against 6 1-10 inches for the entire storm.

Two or three days ago it pleased President Albert Gallup of the Department of Public Parks to send publicly to Samuel Parsons, Jr., the Superintendent of Public Parks, the following rather caustic letter. It has an air of chilliness that caused people to shrug their shoulders. "Certain individuals" meant Tammany's votes, as everybody well knew:

The official statement submitted to the Mayor by the Board of Health will be taken by every disinterested person as entirely conclusive. That is to say, the irresistible inferences that are drawn from the vital statistics and the statistics of building show that the population of the city has been very grossly underestimated by the officials employed to enumerate the people.

As the bark Shenir of Glasgow, from Demerara, was lying off Bedlow's Island yesterday morning, striking her topgallant masts so as to be able to pass under the bridge to her dock. John Margarets, able seaman, aged twenty-four years, fell from the maintopmast stay, struck the rail aft on his head, and fell into the water, sinking immediately. The body was not recovered.

The local political campaign for the Fall of 1890 was practically begun yesterday. Both the Tammany Committee of Twenty-four, or its Executive Committee, and the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee met and selected dates for the conventions. The Tammany committee met in the afternoon and the Republicans in the evening.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 17. -- The Utah Commission has forwarded to the Secretary of the Interior a long report of its operations and proceedings for the year ending Sept. 1, 1890. The principal feature of the report is the recommendation of further legislation in support of the existing laws. After reviewing the elections held in Utah since their last report the Commissioners say:

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday in the Mayor's office and found plenty of pressing business awaiting its attention. Police Commissioners Martin (Tammany) and Voorhis (Voorhis Democrat) were there to present the estimate of their department for the expenses of the forthcoming election. The total amount asked for all election expenses (including the election of a Congressman in Register Fitzgerald's place in the Sixth Congressional District last Winter) was $464,743, divided as follows:

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- The eighth annual convention of the State Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association was called to order in Union Hall this morning at 11:35 o'clock by President George G. Campbell of Syracuse. Four hundred delegates from various organizations in the State, representing a total membership of 30,000, were present. Mr. Campbell addressed the convention.

Does Senator ALDRICH realize the situation he has made for himself? He is an avowed protectionist and Republican. He is a business man, capable and experienced. He knows as well as any man in the Senate, perhaps better, how sensitive is the money market to any action of Congress directly or indirectly affecting it or threatening to affect it.

J. Phinney of Chicago, who, with Mrs. Phinney, was relieved by Custom House officers of a considerable quantity of valuable dress trimmings upon landing from the Normandie recently, called upon Col. Dudley F. Phelps, Deputy Collector, in charge of the law division of the Custom House, yesterday, and frankly admitted that he and Mrs. Phinney intended to smuggle the goods which were seized.

Willard F. Robinson has brought suit in the United States Circuit Court against V. McCracken, George A. Evans, and W.V. McCracken to recover four-tenths of one-half of the profits realized by the defendants in the construction of the Toledo, Saginaw and Muskegan Railroad. The defendants contracted to do work in constructing the road and were to receive in payment $1,600,000 of capital stock and $1,600,000 of bonds.

At the games of the Manhattan Athletic Club, to be held to-morrow on the club's grounds, Fifty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue, the championship medals of the old National Association of Amateur Athletes, won in 1888, will be presented. This is good news for the athletes who competed in that championship meeting.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- John D. Rockefeller has just given $1,000,000 more to the Chicago Baptist University in addition to the $600,000 which he contributed previously. This munificent offer was laid before the Board of Trustees of the institution to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Langston is not yet a member of the House of Representatives. The Republicans have brought the contest between him and Venable, the smiling member, to a vote, but it sticks at that point for lack of a Republican quorum, as the Democrats have persisted all day in compelling the Republicans to furnish the votes from the Republican side.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 18. -- The Rev. R.B. Porter, pastor of the Cross Roads Presbyterian Church, near Allegheny, has just been suspended from the ministry for not less than two years. This sentence has been imposed upon him by the Allegheny Presbytery for knowingly violating the laws of veracity and of moral honesty and for obtaining goods under false pretenses.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 18. -- Gov. Gordon's denunciation of Col. Macune, head of the Farmers' Alliance, and Col. L.F. Livingston of the Georgia State Alliance has so accentuated the differences between the Governor and the farmers that his defeat is now almost a foregone conclusion. The papers are filled with attacks upon the Governor's business abilities to such an extent that the campaign now promises to degenerate into one of mud slinging.

The report comes from Washington that the Republican members of the conference committee have concluded to adopt the "reciprocity" amendment of the Senate. If that shall prove to be the case, we have no doubt that it will become a law, for Mr. HARRISON is not likely to have any ideas on the subject and still leas likely to act on them in opposition to the dictates of the party leaders.

The discussion which has gone on in the Senate this week upon the establishment of a United States land court for settling private land claims in certain States and Territories -- Nevada, Colorado, Wyoming, New-Mexico, Arizona, and Utah -- touches a subject which long ago ought to have received the attention of Congress.

Frederick S. Gibbs, Assemblyman from the Thirteenth Assembly District, was expelled from the Republican County Committee at its meeting in Webster Hall last night by a vote of 443 to 85. This absolutely banishes him from all regular affiliation with his party. He was kicked out at the end of one of the most remarkable wrangles that ever disturbed the peace of a County Committee meeting.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- President Manvel has downed President R.R. Cable of the Rock Island in retaliation for the latter's bitter attacks on the Atchison menagement for the last six months. It was officially announced to-day that the Atchison Railroad had secured control of the Colorado Midland, running from Colorado Springs, on the main line of the Atchison and Rock Island, to Grand Junction, where it connects with the Rio Grande Western.

The election of Gen. CARLOS EZETA as President of Salvador has been followed by popular rejoicings that are very significant. But his present triumph is only the corollary of his success in the field against a country so much larger and credited with greater military resources. It was natural for Salvador to ratify a policy which under EZETA'S leadership had yielded so much military prestige.

John M. Gilroy, fifty-three years old, was found dead under his own truck in Madison Square yesterday, afternoon by Policeman Bell of the Nineteenth Precinct. There was a bad out on the back of his head, and it was at first supposed that the death was accidental, but investigation showed that there had been a quarrel between Gilroy's son, John, and a rival truckman named Joseph Nugent of 116 East Eighteenth Street.

Although there are no stake events to be decided at the Brooklyn track to-day the six races to be run have tilled so well with horses so evenly matched that the sport will be as lively as if the stars were to be contestants. The entries and weights for the several events are as follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 18. -- The work on the new United States revenue steamer intended for the Texas coast is so far progressed that the builders, Charles Reeder Sons, confidently expect to launch the vessel in December or January next.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- At the races here to-day Sunol trotted a mile in 2:13 1/4, the fractions being 0:32 1/2, 1:06, and 1:39 1/2. Guy trotted in 2:12 1/2, the fractions of his mile being 0:33, 1:06 1/4, and 1:39 1/2. The summaries of the other races are as follows:

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The one topic in London to-day is the news from Ireland of the arrest to-day of several prominent Irish Nationalists. The general feeling is one of profound surprise, as the Government had kept its secret so well that no hint of its intended action had reached the public. No explanation of the reasons for the Government's course has as yet been vouchsafed.

The Collector of Customs at Buffalo has just been taught a lesson which might with propriety and advantage to the Government be brought home to a good many other office holders in the service of the Nation. Under the tariff law now in force tools, household goods, and personal effects of immigrants coming to this country are admissible free of duty.

ABILENE, Kan., Sept. 18. -- "These investments yielded about 18 per cent.: but then Senator Ingalls is a personal friend of mine," said Banker C.H. Lebold in his testimony regarding the investments of John J. Ingalls in Western farm loans.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18. -- The trouble that has been growing for two months among the Democrats of the Eighth Congressional District culminated to-day in a double-barreled convention and two nominations. John J. O'Neil is far and away the most popular Democrat in the district. The Congressional committee, however, has fought him bitterly, but not in the interest of any particular man.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18. -- Gov. Jackson this afternoon presented to Commander Dennis W. Mullan, United States Navy, a handsome gold watch, with chain and charm, voted him by the Maryland Legislature at its last session in appreciation of his gallant service at Samoa. The present was purchased from Hennegen, Bates Co. of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- The subject of reducing the number of passenger and freight trains at present running between Chicago and the Missouri River was to have been discussed to-day at a meeting of the General Managers of the roads interested. Attendance at the meeting was somewhat meagre, however, and the matter was referred to a committee to arrange a plan of action.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- The most sanguine weather prophet would not have ventured to forecast so perfect a day as this has been. A fresh breeze and a warm sun dried up the track at Point Breeze, and thirteen capital heats were decided. The 2:18 class pace required six to it, but the 2:33 class trotting is still unfinished, although seven heats have been decided.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Princeton Theological Seminary opened to-day with an increased number of students. Ten students from other seminaries have made application for the Senior Class and twelve for the Middle. Owing to the great increase it will be necessary for about sixty "Seminoles" to room in town. The authorities are making great efforts to obtain gifts for a new dormitory in the seminary to accommodate the students.

The ring ticket in Hudson County has been made up. Boss Davis, the active head of the ringsters, wanted his Under Sheriff, John McPhillips nominated for Sheriff. Boss McLaughlin wanted Edward F. McDonald, whom the Senate unseated last Winter, nominated for Congressman. Davis had agreed to support Col. McAnerny for Congress, and McLaughlin had promised his aid to ex-Sheriff Heintze for Sheriff.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 18. -- Political revolutions seem to be the order of the day in South Carolina, and the Republican State Convention which has been in session here for two days illustrates this fact. Like a previous assemblage of the opposite party, the result of this gathering has been to overthrow those who have heretofore controlled it and replace them with new leaders.

The stables of the Gambrinus Brewing Company, of which George, Jacob, and Valentine Loewer are the principal owners, were set on fire at 6 o'clock yesterday morning by the bursting of a tank used for heating pitch, and thirteen horses and two stablemen perished. The stables, in which was a cooperage, were in a one-story frame building known as 530 to 534 West Forty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- From to-day's action of the National World's Fair Commissioners and from a canvass of the commission it can be stated that a majority of that body is finally and irrevocably opposed to the double site for the World's Fair, and that on Saturday next a resolution will be offered and adopted requesting the Chicago Directory to tender Washington Park, or what is generally known as South Park, as a site.

The arrests of representative Irishmen yesterday seem to have been as silly as they were outrageous. Our Dublin dispatch, in giving a clear account of the performance itself, offers an explanation of it in the way of a suggestion that the arrests were made just at this time for the purpose of preventing the departure for this country of Messrs. DILLON and O'BRIEN.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 18. -- The second day of the State Republican Convention was devoted to the reports of the Committee on Credentials. The majority report seated sixty-two "gang" delegates and fifty-five "anti-gang" delegates in the 117 seats reserved for the Arapahoe County delegation. The minority report favored the admission of the entire anti-gang delegation, representing the tax-payers who are tired of the machine politics of the so-called State House gang.

There was plenty of brick in the market yesterday, but there were few purchasers. It was stated by manufacturers' agents and general dealers alike that the latter were fully supplied, and that there were several cargoes lying at the various docks for which there was no present demand. Brick had come down in almost unstinted quantity since Sunday, and yesterday five more barges and several schooners brought full cargoes into the general market.

Senator BLAIR, in strict uniformity with his reputation for making speeches chiefly in behalf of measures that are either useless or worse, has addressed the Senate this week in support of an amendment to the Constitution for giving the District of Columbia representation in Congress. In fact, he proposes not only representation in the House but even in the Senate and in the Electoral College.
On page 63 of the amended McKinley Tariff bill now in the hands of the conference committee there is the following line:

Because they loved one another Emile Rossi, beautiful and talented young actress of Amberg's company, and Gustave Koch, a clever crayon artist, killed themselves early yesterday morning. That the young couple were desperately enamored is evident, but what barrier prevented their marriage and thus induced them to destroy themselves does not clearly appear.

Both the New-York clubs started for Pittsburg last evening. All of the League men, with the exception of Esterbrook, accompanied the clubs. Hatfield, Gore, and Keefe were left behind by the Brotherhood team. Gore is still suffering from his sore leg, and Keefe's hand is so bad that he cannot handle the ball with his accustomed skill. Hethinks that it is advisable to take a rest.

Dlon Boucicanlt died very suddenly lnhis apartment at 103 West Fifty-fifth Street at 5:10 o'clock last evening. Aft. Bouoioault had not been a wen man for many years, and of late he has shown many signs of /ailing health He was seventy-eight years old, according to the record of the books of theatrical biography.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 18 -- The Democratic State Convention, which met in this city to-day, was the most harmonious delegate body that ever met under the auspices of the party in this State. Not a ripple disturbed the even flow of procedure in the channel marked out by the State Central Committee.

The lobbyists, of one kind and another, are hard at work in Washington striving to exert some influence upon the Republican members of the tariff conference committee. It may be recalled that some of them have been very successful heretofore in convincing these same legislators that their arguments were irresistible.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- William T. Hunter, who is interested in cattle ranches in Montana, Wyoming, and Dakota, takes such a gloomy view of the cattle business in the West that he is endeavoring to formulate a plan which will help the raisers. He says that what is known as the combination or trust has been steadily working against them, and that in a short time they will find themselves without money, cattle, or homes.

Two army societies have just held their annual reunions -- the Army of the Cumberland at Toledo and the Army of West Virginia at Parkersburg. The former was one of the largest organizations in the civil war, next to the Army of the Potomac, and its fame is associated with some of the greatest battles of the West, including Stone River, Chickamauga, and the storm-of Missionary Ridge at Chattanooga.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The Riverside Gun and Rifle Club had fine weather for its opening shoot to-day. The skies were clear and a pleasant breeze blew from the southwest. Although the club has not had any regular shoot since last Spring the members did remarkably well, their scores being up to the average. John Cooper, the youngest member of the club, was in fine form, breaking 38 out of 40 targets.

Now that the disagreements of the House and the Senate as to many important tariff duties have been intrusted for settlement to a conference committee, the lobbyists appear not only to be at work at the Capital but also to be exerting considerable influence upon the utterances of certain newspaper organs of the Republican Party.

Renewed interest in the question whether the Police Board will give the County Democracy its election inspectors and clerks was awakened yesterday when Chairman C.C. Baldwin of the County Committee of the County Democracy sent the following communication to the Police Commissioners:

Mr. John C. New, United States Consul General to London, arrived here yesterday on the steamship City of Berlin. He was met at the Inman pier by his son, who had journeyed from Indianapolis to give him the key to the political situation in Indiana. Both registered at the Gilsey House.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19. -- A heavy track and a light rain interfered with the sport here to-day. The sale was of little importance. S.A. Browne Co., Kalamazoo, Mich., paid $1,200 for Uleora, a mare by Elial, and J.M. Lewis of this city bought a Patron filly, Prefix, for $1,100. The summaries of the races are as follows:
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Advices from Hiogo state that the Turkish man-of-war Ertogrul has foundered at sea and that 500 of her crew were drowned.

The races to be run at the Brooklyn track to-day are of a character to insure fire-class sport. The meeting of Kingston, Tenny, Los Angeles, Tournament, and Prince Fonso in the First Special is alone sufficient to draw a big crowd, for Kingston's ability to defeat Tenny at a mile and a quarter, provided the latter will run kindly, is much doubted by many shrewd horsemen.

The denial by the Germans in Zanzibar of the recent report that a proclamation permitting the slave trade had been issued at Bagamoyo and Daressalaam is a relief, although it was hardly to be supposed that the report was literally correct. But the entire abolition of slavery in Zanzibar' is an affair only of the future.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 19. -- "Boodle" flowed freely among the Republicans at the State Convention which adjourned at 2 o'clock this morning after a session of two days and two nights. Facts were learned to-night which give the key to the defeat of Ellery M. Brayton for the State Chairmanship and the election of Alonzo Webster.

Expert Wheeler of the Board of Electrical Control made his report to that body yesterday on the death of Lineman Kopp, who was killed at Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street Monday night. He held that Kopp was responsible for his own death because he failed to wear rubber gloves, which the United States Company, on whose wires he was at work, had provided for him.

John De Witt Warner, Chairman of the Tariff-Reform Committee of the New-York Tariff-Reform Club, was placed in nomination last night as a candidate for Representative in Congress from the Eleventh Congressional District. The nomination was unanimously bestowed by the members of the Tariff-Reform League in that district.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- All three of the Assembly district conventions in Onondaga County are to be held early next week, and a most thorough test of the strength of the machine, headed by Senator Hiscock on one side and Representative Belden on the other, will be the result. The plans of Hiscock and Plattseem to be to defeat all three of last year's Assemblymen for renomination.

Although two months have passed since the squadron of evolution returned from Brazil, the future movements of that fleet are still matters of complete uncertainty. For a short time, judging by the large number of ships lying at this port, the department contemplated the careful selection from among them of a fine fleet, the purposes of which were supposed to be similar to those of the white squadron in Mediterranean waters.

The question of rentals for ducts in the subways laid by the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company was vigorously discussed before the Board of Electrical Control yesterday. Engineer Kearney of the board was directed some time ago to take the evidence of the electric light companies on the present charges, and he presented his report yesterday.

There is something very symptomatic in the campaign document just issued by the Republican Congressional Committee and described in one of our Washington dispatches. It has a title page bearing the portraits of GRANT and LINCOLN, and it recites the achievements of the Republican Party.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Advices from Hiogo state that the mail steamer Musashi Maru has been lost off Cochi, and that all of her crew, with the exception of one Japanese, were drowned.

READING, Penn., Sept. 19. -- A terrible accident, attended by great loss of life, took place this evening near Shoemakersville, Berks County, on the main line of the Reading Railroad. The train was what is known as the Pottsville express, leaving here at 5:42 P.M. The point where the accident took place is about fifteen miles from this city and about half a mile from Shoemakersville.
Mr. Charles G. Eddy of Roanoke, Va., Vice President of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company, was in the city yesterday.

Mr. Irving M. Scott, President of the Union Iron Works of San Francisco, which built the United States cruisers Charleston and San Francisco, is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Mr. Scott told a reporter for THE TIMES last evening that he had asked for a resurvey of the course over which the San Francisco ran on her recent trial trip.

Four pistol shots were heard in the basement entrance of 11 St. Mark's Place about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Half a dozen men rushed for the entrance. There, leaning against the wall, was a German woman bleeding from two wounds, one in her right cheek, the other in the top of her head. She was crying pitifully over and over again, "I want to die."

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The arrest of Irish leaders yesterday fills a conspicuous place in the newspapers throughout the United Kingdom this morning. Various explanations are surmised to account for Mr. Balfour's sudden stroke. The commonest one on the part of the Liberal press is that its object was to prevent Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien from going to America to arouse American sympathy and solicit American aid.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- At a meeting of the National World's Fair Commissioners this morning the report of the Executive Committee was read by the Secretary as follows: ...
DUBLIN, Sept. 19. -- John Cullinane and Michael Dalton, members of the National League, have been arrested.

There was good racing at Brooklyn yesterday. There were no stakes to be run for, but there were good fields in every race and some very close finishes, too close to satisfy the speculators in some instances. This was notably the case in the first race, in which Taylor landed the Maxim colt a winner by a head from Syracuse, the latter heating the Lady Jane colt by the same scant distance.

The mystery of the disappearance from the safe of the Hotel Vendome of the $17,000 belonging to Bookmakers James C. Carlin and R. Saunders was cleared up yesterday when Detectives Sheldon and Hanley arrested Henry Cassin and Oscar Matthews, two of the hotel bell boys. Thoroughly frightened at being arrested, one of the boys confessed that they had stolen the money, throwing the tin box in which it was contained away.

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- Boston's city departments are to be investigated by a committee of the Citizens' Association. This is not due to any specific charges of corruption or mismanagement, but a feeling that a useful inquiry could be made which took shape some time since in an invitation to Mayor Hart to visit other cities with a committee of citizens.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The downpour of rain which has been continuous for about ten days in the Hudson River Valley has, with the aid of a hot September sun, ripened much of the Concord grapes which painstaking fruitmen have said would not ripen this season. This unexpected increase in the yield will raise the percentage to an average of 75 per cent. of the largest output on record.

A contest has been begun in the Surrogate's Court over the will of Mrs. Catharine Rice, who died June 24 last, two days after the will was executed. Mrs. Rice had two sisters -- Mrs. Marcella Williams and Mrs. Ann E. Hornback. Mrs. Williams was remembered in the will, and Mrs. Hornback, having been entirely overlooked, begins the contest. The estate is small.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- The Chicago race meet was inaugurated to-day at the new quarter-mile track at Parkside. The curves of the track are so small that the Western men had a decided advantage over their Eastern competitors. The day was cold and windy and prevented fast time. The summary of events is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- "If any man will take this and read and believe it as he should he will be a good Republican." This was the little speech with which "Boss" Clarkson presented a correspondent of THE TIMES with the campaign document just issued by the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee.

There was a curious coterie at dinner together in the cafe of the Hoffman House last night. The party was made up of Mayor Hugh J. Grant, Edward Murphy, Jr., of Troy, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee; Tammany Police Commissioner James J. Martin, John R. Fellows, the County Democrat, who is District Attorney, and Jacob Hess, Republican.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Three days have been consumed by the majority of the House, which has been a majority only in name, in the endeavor to seat John M. Langston, whom the Committee on Elections elected to the House after the Governor of Virginia has certified that F.C. Venable was elected.

TRENTON, Sept. 19. -- Richard W. Goodchild, who was sent to the Trenton Lunatic Asylum eight months ago for treatment, met with a horrible death this morning. A keeper of the institution had charge of the inmates out on a country road for their usual morning walk, and among the number was Goodchild, who was formerly a wealthy resident of Bayonne, Hudson County.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20. -- If Harvard is to defeat Yale at football this is certainly the year. Harvard, with practically her last year's team, can devote her time almost wholly to the development of team play and learning new tricks, which to a team that has played together one season will be a decided advantage.

Heinrich Zoellner, the newly-engaged musical leader of the German Liederkranz, was given a formal reception last evening at the clubhouse in East Fifty-eighth street. President Julius Hoffman welcomed Herr Zoellner to the club. The Reception Committee had shown the Hudson to the new leader in the afternoon from the Riverside Drive, and in his response to President Hoffman he declared that, in his opinion, the Hudson equaled the Rhine.

HANOVER N.H., Sept. 20. -- The football team has been in practice for a little more than two weeks, and under the coaching of Capt. Gill of Yale it is expected that the eleven will be the strongest that ever entered the contest for Dartmouth. James Fasset, the big centre-rush; Humphreys, half-back, and Capt. Odlin, full-back, are the only men on last year's team who are not back this year.

MARIA THERESA AND CATHERINE OF RUSSIA. -- The amount of esteem and admiration awarded by M. de Linge to the two sovereigns was equal, but its form and its nuances differed widely. For Marie Therese he professed a tenderly respectful sentiment, recognizing in her an almost magic power of attraction, far beyond anything her great rival had ever exercised.

Astonishment was the portion of William Stitt yesterday. He was arrested in a restaurant down town, and when he wanted to know on what authority the arrest was made he was shown a commitment for contempt of court issued four years ago. Bail cannot be taken in such cases, and so Mr. Stitt went to Ludlow Street Jail.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- During an exciting personal encounter in a crowded restaurant-saloon tween two noted gamblers to-night, each fatally shot the other. The contestants were William Haggerty and James Connorton.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,255,350, as follows: Currency 6s, $6,354,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $29,973,900; 4 per cents, $103,927,450.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- It has been customary with Princeton professors no less than with the students, to lay aside to a great extent their cumbrous volumes during the Summer months and enjoy a genuine vacation. This has by no means been an exceptional year.

A correspondent of the Montana Farming and Stock Journal has been visiting the inscribed rocks in Tulare County, about eighteen miles cast of Visalia. They are paintings in red, yellow, black, and white, generally on the under side of rocks, where they are protected from the weather. "The paints were of a peculiarly durable character, for in the most sheltered spots the colors are as if just laid on, and stand out with startling distinctness.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Already there have been eighty-four applications for admittance to the Freshman Class of Rutgers College, the largest in the history of the institution.

It seems that the Count of PARIS has not abandoned his visit to this country, but yesterday held a conference with "a number of his leading adherents" at Folkestone. It was announced a few weeks since that the unpleasant feeling aroused by the McKinley bill was such that he thought best not to come, as any royal or would-be royal person might refrain from visiting a country at war with his own.

Everybody knows that the Autumnal demand for money to move cotton and corn is aggravated by the position of the United States Treasury in our finances, yet neither statesmen nor business men have intelligence enough to insist upon the only remedy -- the abolition of the sub-Treasury system.

THE CAFE PROCOPE. -- Francis Procope, a Sicilian, became noted as a retailer of good coffee at the St. Germain fair, when the beverage was first introduced into France. In 1688 the society of French comedians bought the old racket ground of L'Etoie in the Rue des Fosses, St. Germain, and built a theatre there.

After nine years spent in gaining fame and fortune in Europe, Mr. Hiram S. Maxim, the inventor of the automatic gun and the smokeless powders which bears his name, and who is now striving to solve the problem of aerial navigation, has returned to his native land. Time has not dealt unkindly with Mr. Maxim.

The social orchestra played during the past week at Lenox, and in that lovely retreat among the Berkshire Hills now just donning their Autumn robes the gay world will find its chief interest and centre of pleasure for the next fortnight, or until the voices of the suburbs, now beginning to pipe to their wandering residents and yearly guests, become too pronounced and enticing to be longer resisted.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 20. -- Intelligence was received from Cherokee Nation, Indian Territory, to-day to the effect that the question as to who constitutes the legal citizens of Cherokee Nation is beginning to create bad feeling among the tribe. Heretofore the question has been practically dormant. The full-bloods, numbering over 18,000, have dominated public affairs, and the negroes and adopted citizens have quietly submitted.
The following passengers arrived yesterday on the Umbria, (Cunard Line,) from Liverpool:

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The sear and yellow leaf and the end of Richfield's boarding season have come. The rain lasted well into the week and then cleared into fine weather, but there are not many guests left to enjoy it. A few are still making merry at the Spring House and will remain the rest of the month.

SARANAC LAKE, Franklin County, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The season for Summer visitors to the Adirondack region is nearly over. The hotels are no longer compelled to turn away would-be guests for want of rooms to accommodate them, and the coaches and trains going out of the woods are much more heavily loaded with passengers and baggage than those coming in.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 20. -- Harry Leigh of this city and John S. Seymour of Norwalk, the committee appointed by the Democratic State Convention to wait upon ex-Judge Luzon B. Morris and inform him of his nomination for Governor, performed their mission to-day. Judge Morris accepted the nomination, expressed his approval of the platform adopted by the convention and said:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20. -- Newport has settled down into the quiet of its Autumn life. The cottagers are still here. Hardly half a dozen have left for their Winter homes. Their handsome equipages are seen on the avenue and other fashionable thoroughfares in as large numbers and as great splendor as at the height of the season, but socially the season is dead.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Brakeman Michael Gillen, who was stationed in the middle of the train which was wrecked, arrived in this city this afternoon, but little the worse for his terrible experience. He had with him his cap and lantern, both of which he had managed to save. He tells this story of the wreck: "I was sitting in the front end of the first ladies' car, talking with Judge Stephens of Pottstown.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 19. -- The Farmers' Alliance in Alabama has become a regular "Jack-in-the-box." Not content with bobbing up in the political arena a few months ago and scaring the old-time politicians out of a year's growth it is just now creating consternation in business and financial circles.

The organization meeting of the North River Bridge Company, which was incorporated some time ago by special act of Congress, was held Friday at 20 Nassau Street. All the incorporators were present either in person or by their authorized representatives. The minimum amount specified in the incorporating act, $1,000,000, was shown to have been subscribed, and the stockholders proceeded to the election of the following Board of Directors:

The Pope takes his villeggiatura in the garden of the Vatican, a little park of thirty-five acres, where he passes his days mostly in the Casino of Pins IV., receiving great enjoyment from the care of his garden. His health is, notwithstanding reports to the contrary, excellent, and his vigor and activity for a man of his age are remarkable.

Judge Job H. Lippincott, the presiding Judge of the Hudson County (N.J.) Sessions, has been puzzled to know why Prosecutor Winfield has not utilized the time of the court by calling the untried election officers to the bar. He is disturbed, too, by the failure of Sheriff Davis to arrest some of the rascals for whom capiases had been issued.

SHAKESPEARE'S GHOSTS. -- We cannot doubt that Shakespeare, like his contemporaries, believed in ghosts, while we do not. How, then, can we say that he is true to nature, when he makes Hamlet or Brutus or Macbeth see ghosts, talk with them, and thereby in all respects believe in them? Skeptical arguments against the reality of ghosts were not unknown to Shakespeare's contemporaries.

Mr. Augustin Daly returned from England last night on the Umbria. He was accompanied by Mrs. Daly and Miss Ada Rehan. Mr. Daly is in excellent health. He has gained materially in weight and his complexion has a ruddy glow, which is quite foreign to its general appearance.

The Barge Office Registry clerks work at least ten hours every day in the week, Sundays included, and work longer on the days when an immigrant rush comes along. They have no days off, and are not paid for overwork, so they sent a petition to Col. Weber, the Superintendent of Immigration, yesterday, asking him to at least give them every other Sunday off.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Six weeks of assiduous golfplaying on the St. Andrew's links in the bracing Fifeshire air have toned Mr. Balfour's languid system up to such a degree of ardor that there were rumors the other day that he was going to get married forthwith. It seems that these observers mistook the symptoms.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept 20. -- The annual convention of the Baptist churches of this State will be held at Middletown, beginning on Monday, Oct. 13, and continuing through two days. The work will conclude with the annual assembly of the State Baptist Social Union, the most influential organization of clergymen and laymen in the denomination in Connecticut.

There is a very comic dispatch touching the behavior of the Grenadier Guards at Bermuda. It will be remembered that this particular petal of the flower of the British Army was exiled to Bermuda because it had become intolerable in London. The "Horse Guards," that is, the headquarters of the British Army, is not commonly supposed to contain a very imposing amount either of military science or of common sense.

THE LAUREATESHIP. -- Lord Tennyson is still with us. It would be as impertinent as ill-omened to say any word of one's own notion, save to wish that he may stay with us as long as possible. But he has himself spoken in words which, if words have any meaning, are in the nature of a solemn farewell.

The feature Of Fall millinery showing the most enterprising effort after novelty is seen in the department of felt hats. Both in colors and shapes and in minor details there is evidence of unusual care having been given to their designing. So varied and peculiar are they in outline that before they have run the inevitable gantlet of printed description their designers will be convinced that "comparisons are odious."

The Census Superintendent, Mr. Porter in commenting on the census of the city of New-York, says: "A recount of the city, certainly above Fortieth Street, where the population has increased 80 per cent., and where the total population June 1, 1890, was 707,697, would hardly be deemed necessary by the most enterprising advocate of a recount."

Professor Ainslie Grey had not come down to breakfast at the usual hour. The presentation chiming clock which stood between the terra cotta busts of Claude Bernard and John Hunter upon the dining room mantelpiece had rung out the half hour and the three-quarters. Now its golden hand was verging upon the nine and yet there were no signs of the master of the house.

CHANGES OF TRADE AFTER THE DISCOVERY OF AMERICA. -- The maritime discoveries of the Portuguese and the Spaniards at this epoch brought about an economic revolution of a most remarkable character. The surface of the world available for purposes of trade was doubled, commerce was turned into new channels, the medium of exchange was increased fourfold.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Partisans are always suspicious, and that may account for the comment made by some observant persons, Democrats, of course, that Mr. John S. Clarkson and Mr. W.W. Dudley of the Republican National Committee are both hovering about the conferrees of the House and the Senate on the Tariff bill as if they were greatly interested in the outcome of the deliberations of those gentlemen.

Every one has been talking for the last week about Hugh McLaughlin's frank statement that he would rather see the entire local Democratic ticket beaten than recognize the German Democratic General Committee. This is the same stand that he took years ago against the old Jefferson Hall organization, and he maintains that he was right then and is right now.

Somebody is doing some very tall romancing in regard to the subway system and its cost. Whether it is the electric light companies which rent the subways or the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company which collects the rents for the subways, the former seems to be very anxious to have settled.

The political situation, as developed during the past week, is well calculated to interest politicians as well as persons who are not politicians. The dates arranged for the County Conventions -- Oct. 2 for the Republicans and Oct. 10 for Tammany -- indicate that the Republican leaders have left plenty of time for adjournment, and that Tammany thinks that the opposition will have shown its hand by Oct. 10.

The Champlain Canal is sixty-six miles long, but included in the Champlain system are the Glens Falls feeder, twelve miles long, and the pond above Troy Dam, three miles, making eighty-one miles of navigable water. The canal proper extends from Lock 3 on the Erie Canal, between Cohoes and Troy, to Whitehall, at the southernmost end of Lake Champlain.

Some time ago a reward was offered for the best essay on the extirpation of the mosquito, and, if we remember rightly, the reward was given to a lady who succeeded in showing pretty clearly that the only practicable way of getting rid of the troublesome insects was by knocking down their houses, so to speak, and laying waste the villages of their habitation.

For several years past a thorough series of tests has been in progress on the various railway lines in France with the view of getting an efficient system of electrical signaling apparatus for announcing the passing of railway trains at distant points. Much ingenuity and knowledge have been displayed, but out of fifty plans submitted and tested only two inventors have succeeded in establishing their claims.

Having had various opportunities to see the working of the departments here with reference to the employment of men who served their country during the dark days of the rebellion, I am more than ever convinced of the injustice done to them and forcibly reminded of the doggerel written some years ago, which runs as follows:

The usefulness of a summary of what is known concerning the ancient inhabitants of America accounts for a new edition of the work by the Marquis de Nadaillac. The volume, edited by Mr. W.H. Dall of the Smithsonian Institution, appeared six years ago, a few years after the French original.

It is now a little over forty years since Sir Henry Austen Layard began his remarkable excavations in the mounds of Mesopotamia. His second expedition (1849-51) was devoted almost exclusively to the huge mound Koujunjik, on the Tigris, directly opposite Mosul, and it was here that he made his most extensive discoveries.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- The interest in Schliemann's excavations at Hissarlik, the site of ancient Troy, has recently been revived by the persistent attacks of the skeptical Capt. Boetticher, who fails to see in these ruined cities more than the remains of a fine necropolis. In the course of the past year the question under dispute has been twice considered by investigating commissions appointed for that purpose.

LOOSE THE BANDS OF THY NECK. -- My mother used to tell a story of a curate in a Norfolk parish, where the rector was nonresident. One Sunday, just as the curate had entered the reading desk, the rector came into the church, and sent him a note to the effect that he wished to preach, but had forgotten to bring his bands.

SARATOGA, Sept. 20. -- Saratogians are settling down to normal village life and planning industriously for next year's campaign. In addition to the three enterprises noted last week still another improvement scheme is being put on a footing. Saratoga's roadways are a part of her stock in trade, and their poor condition is a cause for comment and complaint.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 20. -- The bitter attack made upon Senator Matthew Stanley Quay by Congressman Kennedy of Ohio has created nowhere more widespread discussion that here in Harrisburg, where for years Quay and his nefarious transactions have been well known, and it is a question whether Quay is any more to blame for what he has accomplished than the people of the State who have allowed him to accomplish it.

These two volumes are made up of short biographies of the six artists who were, with perhaps a single exception, the masters of modern French landscape painting.
