Of Corot and Millet the materials presented of late have been endless, and the American public are perhaps better acquainted with their lives than the rest of the world.

The Star Fire Insurance Company has really got into print now and in no enviable way. It is openly charged by one of its most influential stockholders that there has been fraud, criminal fraud, committed, and that the total assets of the company, declared last January to have then been almost $240,000, amount to-day to something like $1,500.

A year has elapsed since M. Maxime Rucheron, who evidently even then had an inkling of what was going on behind the scenes, things which M. Terrail-Mermeix -- to give the Deputy of the Seventeenth Arrondissement of Paris his full name -- is now revealing to a disgusted public in his "Coulisses du Boulangisme, "or" Boulangism as seen from the wings," sounded a note of warning.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20. -- Gen. Grierson's insane son has been found. About a week ago Brig. Gen. Grierson arrived in St. Louis from Los Angeles, Cal., in search of his son, who, according to a telegram he had received at his California home, had made his escape from a private insane asylum at Jacksonville, Ill. He spent several days in St. Louis and then went on to Jacksonville.

The Philadelphia, just on the eve of her official speed trials, has had another accident. This time it was the air pump -- not an irreparable break, to be sure, but enough to prove, if any proof is needed, that the cruiser is weak in the minor details of her construction. This is entirely the fault of the builders.

RIVERSIDES, Conn., Sept. 20. -- The Riverside Yacht Club had its annual pennant regatta today. The weather was favorable for a race of small boats, and ten started. The courses were seventeen miles for the large and eleven miles for the small classes. The race between the Al-cede and the Wayward was so close that it is as yet undecided. The Wayward will have to be remeasured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Over two months ago, when the Senate Committee on Fisheries began its investigation into the affairs of the United States Fish Commission, THE TIMES advised its readers to refrain from passing judgment on the work done by the commission until the latter had been heard from. The motive for the charges made against the commission was so apparent that this seemed to be the only fair course to take.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 20. -- This has been another gay week. The tennis tournament, dinner parties, the assembly balls, the Stokes dancing party, the meeting of the archery club, and other entertainments have completely occupied the time of the cottagers every day and evening since Monday. The weather has been the worst possible, as it rained every day up to Thursday, so that driving through the country was next to impossible.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- The last of the bicycle circuit of race meets was held here to-day at the new Parkside track. The wind prevented fast time being made, and the sharp corners of the track was a great handicap on the Eastern men, who, with the exception of E.J. Willis, New-York Athletic Club, won no prizes.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20. -- The annual tub parade, which took place in Lenox this afternoon, was the most successful ever given. There were thirty-five carts in line, trimmed most elaborately with golden rod, Autumn leaves, hydrangeas, gladioli, and wild asters. Mr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes led the procession in a victoria, followed by three beautifully-trimmed buckboards and carts, containing members of the Stokes family and their guests.

The dilemma presented to the House of Representatives by Mr. ENLOE of Tennessee seems to have been ingeniously constructed for the discomfiture of the Republicans in general and of the Speaker in particular. Mr. KENNEDY'S observations on the moral character of Senator QUAY were at once congenial and shocking to many of his fellow-Republicans.

SMITH'S BASIN, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- A study of the Champlain Canal would hardly seem to require any familiarity with the Canadian canals, yet when THE TIMES'S correspondent boarded the Fred H. Wilkins, Capt. Lewis Pike, at Whitehall at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon and started south through the Champlain, he found himself on a load of pine lumber taken on board at Ottawa one week ago last Wednesday.

Handling fleets in action and the general subject of signaling are points that are just beginning to receive their due consideration in all navies. The Constructive Departments, in designing recent ships which are to act as flagships, have not thought out sufficiently where the Admiral should be stationed in action so that he may have a clear, all-round view of the ships composing his fleet, as well as those of the enemy.

If ex-Gov. FOSTER goes to Congress from the Eighth District in Ohio, where he was nominated last week, the Window-Glass Trust will have another Representative in the House. In one of the reports of the proceedings of the managers of this Trust recently published by the Pittsburg Commercial-Gazette, a well-known Republican journal, the following statement was made:

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The presentation of "Ravenswood," as Mr. Herman Merivale's dramatization of "The Bride of Lammermoor" is called, at the Lyceum Theatre tonight is chiefly interesting as showing bow completely Henry Irving dominates the English stage. His first appearance before the footlights was greeted with such applause as I never before heard in London.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 20. -- Postmaster Eaton anticipates no trouble in enforcing the Anti-Lottery bill. "In fact it will not need enforcing," said he, "for I have it from reliable and direct sources that Mr. Morris has instructed the company not to attempt a violation in a single instance. Newspapers are issuing two editions, the mailable one being without the lottery advertisements.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Being among the clouds was a painful reality to many people who have resolved to spend the remainder of the month of September in the Catskills, until Thursday, but on that day the mist that had hung for nine days over mountain and valley was dispelled by bright sunshine, and now it can be said that Autumn in the Catskills is all that can be desired.

READING, Sept. 20. -- At 6 o'clock to-night work was stopped by the searchers for bodies in the wreck at Shoemakersville, on the Reading Railroad, and it is now believed that all the dead have been taken out. The last body to be taken out was that of the engineer, John White of Pottsville, who was pinned under the locomotive.

TOPEKA, Sept. 20. -- There is trouble in Kansas and much political uncertainty. Two years ago there was a Republican plurality of 82,000. This year there is a chance for 25,000 Democratic majority. This is not a prediction, but it is as safe to assume as that there will be a Republican victory.

The ball tossers of the New-Jersey Athletic Club are the amateur champions of the East. They won that proud title by defeating the Columbia Athletic Club team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Columbia boys are from Washington, and they came here fully confident of defeating the New-Jersey boys. They, apparently, underestimated the playing abilities of their rivals as the latter outplayed the visitors at every point of the game.

Having repeatedly read in THE TIMES articles on the correct taking of the census, I, have thought of the following plan which I beg to propose through your paper. As in the past the most serious difficulties have been experienced in the larger cities, my suggestions are applicable only to them.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The heavy Wells-Fargo express train on the Erie Railroad eastward bound crashed into the rear of a coal train at 12:10 this morning at a point two miles west of this city with disastrous results. The coal train bad stopped while the locomotive of a train ahead was taking water, but had neglected, it is said, to send back a flagman.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 20. -- The Iowa Railroad Commissioners to-day directed the Attorney General to bring suits in equity against the Iowa Central, the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific, Chicago and Northwestern, the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, and the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railways to enforce their order requiring joint rates to be put in force in Iowa.

The spectacle of Mayor Patrick J. Gleason of Long Island City enacting the role of a Judicial magistrate was witnessed yesterday when he had ex-Postmaster James A. McKenna and his brother, Joseph E. McKenna, arraigned before him charged with assaulting Real Estate Agent George F. Payne on Thursday night in the rooms of the Jeffersonian Democratic Club.

In 1862, at the Vaudeville Theatre in Paris, Labiche and Martin produced "Lee Petite Oiseaux." In 1889 Sydney Grundy's "A Pair of Spectacles." founded on that French comedy, was brought out at the Garrick Theatre in London by John Hare, who played the principal part. "A Pair of Spectacles" is not, of course, "Les Petits Oiseaux."

Last Monday the market had one of those spasms which are said to bring it as near to panic as it can get without actually getting there. Since then it has been trying to recover itself. There was no great liquidation, the total of transactions for the day being less than 340,000 shares; hence there is little ground for confidence that the bottom has been reached.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The Congressional Convention of the Republicans of the Sixth Congressional District of New-Jersey met in Commonwealth Hall, East Orange, this afternoon, and nominated Elias Mulford Condit of West Orange for Congress. The convention was not harmonious, and when a motion to make the nomination unanimous was made a volume of noes went up.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- A grand parade of the troops engaged in the army maneuvres was held this morning near Eiobholz, in the presence of Emperors Wilham and Francis Joseph, the King of Saxony, Chancellor von Caprivi, and Count Kalnoky. At the conclusion of the parade, Emperor William gathered the officers in a group and addressed them, commending their efforts in the field.

The house of the Atalanta Boat Club was gayly decked with bunting yesterday afternoon, and a barge filled with spectators and flying the colors of the club was lashed to the float. It was "Ladies' Day" and the forty-third annual regatta of the Atalanta Boat Club, and about 3,000 persons witnessed the races. The tug Van Cott followed the boats. The Harlem was alive with barges, gigs, needlelike shells, and small craft of every description.

ON THE BORDER LINE OF INSANITY. -- An old gentleman, with no great position to keep up and an income of at least 15,000 a year, wept tears of real grief at his only son's extravagance as evinced in the purchase of a two-and-ninepenny pocketknife. "Ninepence was enough for a knife in my young days," whined the heart-struck father.

Since the almost universal adoption of high-pressure steam, rapid combustion of fuel, and consequent rapid evaporation of water, the greatest trouble of the marine engineer has been how to keep his boilers clean. The use of fresh water is an absolute necessity; the use of salt water for a few hours would cripple most modern boilers for life.

The forty-eight-hour test of the electric-light plant on board the United States dynamite cruiser Vesuvius will begin to-day under the supervision of Lieut. Lucien Flynne, United States Navy, the electrical expert attached to the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The test will be very complete, as the entire installation will be thoroughly tried for insulation, resistance, and efficiency.

DUBLIN, Sept. 21. -- The Nationalists held a meeting to-day at Swinford, County Mayo. Although rain was falling, a large crowd was present. Two hundred policemen and 150 soldiers were on the ground. Mr. John Dillon made a speech, in which he denounced the Government's tactics in dealing with Nationalists.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Gov. Bulkeley's first words after the announcement of the ballotin the State Convention at New-Haven Wednesday was made to him were: "I am more pleased with this result than I should have been had my name been placed again at the head of the ticket."
MONTREAL, Sept. 21. -- Minister of Finance Foster has speedily followed Sir John Macdonald in declaring that Canada has nothing to fear from the operations of the McKinley bill.

The New-York Sun yesterday morning published the confessions of Reed, Cain, and Buett, three of the five men arrested for complicity in the recent attempts to wreck trains on the New-York Central Road. The conspiracy upon which the details of these confessions throw light is the most cold-blooded affair in the history of modern times.

Dr. Wolfred Nelson, who has spent a number of years at Panama, has just returned from Paris, where he completed a series of investigations concerning the present status of the canal. Dr. Nelson says that the feeling in Paris regarding the Big Ditch is one of profound despair. Le Grand Francais, figuratively, has been dashed from his pedestal, while as President of the Geographical Society of France he no longer presides.

The Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., pastor of the Twenty-third Street Baptist Church, preached to a very large congregation at Association Hall yesterday morning, taking as his subject "Crumbling Creeds." The sermon was preceded by a few remarks upon the Federal Election bill, it being Mr. Dixon's intention to touch in this way every week upon topics of current interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21. -- The Democratic National Committee ought to devote serious attention to the situation in California. If the Democrats do not elect four out of six Representatives, their entire State ticket, a majority in both houses of the Legislature, and, by consequence, a United States Senator to succeed Stanford, the fact will be due to scandalous treachery and inexplicable apathy in their own ranks.
In his defense of the changes made by the Senate in the sugar schedule at the request of the Sugar Trust, Mr. ALDRICH says:

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept 21. -- The Republican primaries throughout New-Castle County yesterday afternoon attracted very little attention and a light vote was polled. In this city Thomas B. Smith, for many years Treasurer of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company, was nominated or Representative without a contest. He is a very acceptable candidate, but is not a Higgins man.

Of course, there is something ungracious in publicly discussing the succession to an office that can become vacant only by death. But when the incumbent of it is in his eighty-first year it is quite out of the question that such discussion should altogether be suppressed. In the case of the laureateship of England, at any rate, the English periodicals have not been able to refrain themselves from it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The first case under the new lottery law of refusal of admission of a newspaper to the mails because it contained a lottery advertisement occurred at the city Post Office here early this morning. The Anti-Lottery act was signed by the President Friday, and the Post Office Department yesterday sent to the city Post Office instructions with respect to the execution of the law.

The peach season of 1890 is almost a thing of the past. Not for thirty years has there been such a failure. With the exception of a few orchards in Huntingdon, Morris, Warren, and Sussex Counties, N.J., the peach trees of that State have been barren. The great peach-growing sections of Maryland, Delaware, and Pennsylvania have also been without peaches.

The confession of the wretches who have been arrested for wrecking trains upon the New-York Central Roads establishes an extensive and appalling conspiracy. It is especially appalling because the motive of it was revenge upon the management of the roads, while most of the victims of it, if it had been successful, would have been men and women and children against whom the wreckers had no spite at all.

TRENTON, Sept. 21. -- The Congressional canvasses are rapidly taking shape. In some of the districts the ticket has been made up on both sides, and in most of the others the shadows of coming nominations are so palpably cast before that the veriest novice can safely predict results. The only two districts in which the situation leaves room for speculation are the Sixth, which is in Essex County, and the Seventh, Hudson County.

With the close of the grand trotting at Philadelphia ends a long campaign that has furnished its share of sensations to that branch of sports. Cleveland, with its splendid track, which always attracts the best class of horses and favored by the choicest weather, has again borne off the palm for average speed and record breaking.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21. -- The Republicans of Maryland are still fighting like cats and dogs. The State Central Committee passed an order abolishing the City Executive Committee, but the City Executive Committee refuses to stay abolished, and it has issued a call for a meeting to-morrow night for the purpose of holding primaries for City Council nominations.

Rount G. Samuels of Arkansas, a colored man, says: "I have turned Democrat for the simple reason that I believe the interests of the races in the South are identical. The Republican Party has promised us everything and given us nothing. We have fought our neighbors long enough. Democracy may not give us anything, but when we vote that ticket we will have the consolation of knowing we are standing by our personal friends."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- There is a good reason why Mr. Clarkson and Mr. Quay are regarded as not cordially agreeing about the campaign this Fall. They are working at cross purposes. It is not generally known and Mr. Clarkson cannot be expected to advertise the fact all over town or in his campaign paper, but it is so.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Some time ago there was received by the House of Representatives from the yearly meeting of Friends of Indiana a memorial asking the co-operation of the United States Congress with other powers against the slave trade in Africa. This memorial was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and by that committee referred to Representative John F. Andrew of Massachusetts.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Prof. William R. Harper arrived home from Chicago late last night. When asked whether he had decided to accept the Presidency of the new Chicago University he said:

Autumn excursions to the suburban districts are now in order for the amateur photographers. Several Autumn views have been taken recently by members of the Society of Amateur Photographers. The weather, however, has been anything but favorable for photographic purposes, and the rain has largely interfered with good work.

There is every indication that if the Democratic State Committee, which meets at the Hoffman House to-morrow, should attempt to deprive the County Democracy of what it regards as its rights in reference to the successor to Police Commissioner John R. Voorhis, who resigned just before the last election as a member of the Democratic State Committee, a bitter feud in the Democracy of this State will ensue.

M. Albert Sorel says of Mme. de Stael that she was "a beautiful genius rather than an artist in literature and in history." It is a clear definition, and it happily finishes, after Sainte-Beuve, Benjamin Constant, Count d'Haussonville, and Lady Blennerhasset, in the most intelligent study made of her, the literary portrait of one who "personifies one of the noblest epochs of the French mind."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 21. -- The opening of what promises to be the most exciting campaign ever held in the Second Congressional District of this State took place last night at Searcy, where two or three thousand people assembled to hear a joint debate between C.P. Breckinridge and the Rev. Isom P. Langley, the former the Democratic and the latter the Union Labor candidate for Congress from that district.

MECHANICSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The log of the Fred H. Wilkins, on which a correspondent of THE TIMES is traveling south through the Champlain Canal, ended at Smith's Basin at noon yesterday. Winding through a canal so crooked that it suggests a brook more than a course laid out by engineers, the Wilkins makes her way south.

BRADFORD, Penn., Sept. 21. -- It is expected that ex-Senator Emery's address, which is to be delivered in the Opera House in this city next Friday evening, will have an important influence upon the candidacy of Mr. Delamater for the Governorship of this State.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- At 8 o'clock to-night a switch engine on the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad ran into the rear of an excursion train on the Illinois Central Road near Eighteenth Street. The collision resulted in a frightful tragedy. Within half an hour four mangled bodies had been dragged out of the heap of broken timbers and twisted iron that marked the spot where the collision had taken place.

Politicians, like another class in society with which this is not their only quality in common, need long memories and have, generally, rather short ones. It is only a few weeks since the Ways and Means Committee of the House, under the urgent influence of Mr. BLAINE, resolved to put a tax on hides.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- During the past week discount rates stiffened under the influence of a full demand and expectation of a rise of the Bank of England rate. Three months' discount was quoted at 4 and short at 3 1/4. On the Stock Exchange dealings were limited. Dear money and preparations for the settlement opening on Tuesday made business yesterday almost nil.

Every Democrat of prominence in town was in waiting last evening for the appearance of Gov. David B. Hill, the vicarious boss of the Democratic Party in this State. Members of Congress from Washington, legislators from remote parts of the State, office holders from Brooklyn and New-York, and followers from everywhere haunted the corridors of the Hoffman House until the tidings were brought to them that he had arrived.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- When the big factories in this city and in Cohoes were blowing their whistles at 6 o'clock to-night to indicate that the day's work was done the canalboat Fred H. Wilkins was switching around at the end of a hawser attached to a side-wheel tug and trying to find a place to rest her weary head, so to speak.

An open letter addressed to Robert D. Benedict and urging his nomination for Congress in the Third District, Brooklyn, was widely circulated yesterday. It was signed by such influential men as B.G. Neff, David H. Houtaling, D.O. Tatum, R.M. Whiting, William Harkness, Lowell M. Palmer, T.C. Cronin, G.G. Reynolds, Samuel Duncan, N. Cothren, A.P. Higgins, W.H. Beard, H.W. Wheeler, George Wilson, John J. Anderson, Dr. George A. Ostrander, Edmund C. Fisher, and W.C. Vosburgh.

F.W. Houghton, Superintendent of the Maritime Exchange of this city, and E.R. Sherwood, Secretary of the Maritime Exchange of Philadelphia, are to meet in Washington to-day, and will consult with a number of representative statesmen as to the possibility of passing in both the Senate and the House some such resolution as the following:

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- The motion to quash a count in the quo warranto proceedings brought in the name of the people on relation of Francis B. Peabody against the Chicago Gas Trust Company was decided this morning in favor of the petitioner by Judge McConnell.

Some of the Farmers' Alliance people down South are advocating a project which, it is no extravagance to say, fairly overreaches in absurdity the famous Sub-Treasury scheme. It is a financial project the general plan of which is the issue of Treasury notes, to the amount of $1,000,000,000, to loan to such people as wish to borrow and are willing to pay 3 per cent. a year for the use of money.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 22. -- John T. Rossell was Chairman and Benjamin F.S. Brown of Matawan was Secretary of the Third Congressional District Republican Convention at Freehold to-day. John Kean, Jr., was nominated by acclamation. Mr. Kean is well known as the President of the National State Bank at Elizabeth, President of the Elizabeth City Gas Company, and as closely connected with other Elizabeth institutions.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22. -- The Denver express of the Keokuk and Northwestern Railroad and the trains of the St. Louis, Kansas City and Colorado Road came into St. Louis over the Wabash tracks, which pass through Forest Park just within the city limits. The Denver express, due at 7:20, had the right of way, but was ten minutes late.

Several of the Republican leaders down in Tennessee recently took possession of the Republican candidate for Governor, Mr. Lewis T. Baxter, and urged, begged, and entreated him to "ignore the Force bill" in his speeches. To this petition Mr. Baxter replied that ignoring that which neither his judgment nor his conscience approved was something which he could not undertake to do.

The latest rumor in the baseball world is to the effect that Ward and the managers of the Brooklyn League Club are to combine and have only one representative -- the Players' League -- in Brooklyn next season. This rumor comes from Pittsburg, where many other silly reports have originated this season. All of the managers of the Bridegrooms are out of town at present and could not he seen last evening.

It was natural that the large body of clergymen who took part in the conference on muncipal reform yesterday should lay much stress upon the moral and religious aspects of local government, but, after all, moral considerations apply about as much to politics and government in general as to the management of local affairs.

It is not at all a matter for "political capital" but a matter for sincere and general regret that the census taken under the supervision of Mr. PORTER should be so untrustworthy as to be almost completely worthless. In so far as it misleads anybody who resorts to it for information it is considerably worse than worthless.

A translation into the American language on Labiche's "Les Petits Olseaux," called "Goggles," was presented last evening at the Fifth Avenue Theatre. In a letter addressed to this Journal, the translator, Mr. C. A. Byrne says he saw Labiche's comedy last Summer at the Theatre Francais, where it was put forward for a short time, probably because of the great success of Sydney Grundy's English comedy founded on it in London.
TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 22. -- Margaret Mather's engagement at the Academy of Music, billed for this week, terminated very suddenly this afternoon. In fact, it ended before it began.

Michael Pascocello, a barber of 76 Sixth Avenue, threatens to bring a suit for damages against Manager Turner of the Twenty-third Street Theatre. According to the story told by Pascocello, he went to see a performance of "All the Comforts of Home" on the 9th inst., and purchased places in the balcony.

The festival of Turn Vereins, which has been going on for the last three days at Washington Park, Sixty-ninth Street and East River, was closed yesterday, and last evening the victorious contestants received the laurel wreaths and diplomas. The first event of the day was the swimming race over a mile course. In this the time made was very fast, owing to the fact that the swimming was with the tide.

In the Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon, after a number of petty criminal cases had been disposed of, the Clerk called "Lawrence against Lawrence!" In response to the call, a dark-haired woman of forty-five took the position in front of Judge Duffy which custom has assigned to the person representing the prosecution.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Residents of the borough of North Plainfield were surprised this morning to find freshly-dug holes along the curb lines of their principal thoroughfares. The purpose of the excavations was quite apparent, and some of those who object to having poles erected in front of their property promptly grasped their shovels and filled up the openings.
The Berlin correspondent of the London Economist, writing on the 9th inst., gave the following information about sales of steel rails manufactured in Germany:

The funeral services of Dion Boucicault, dramatist and actor, were held yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Houghton officiated. The regular funeral service of the Protestant Episcopal Church was read. There was nothing further than this in the ceremony. The church was filled to overflowing and there was a large crowd in the churchyard and in the street.

The steamer Cepheus of the Iron Steamboat Company's fleet took an excursion party to Fire Island Sunday. It was to have left Fire Island upon the return trip at 3:15 o'clock in the afternoon. Failure upon the part of a considerable number of the excursionists to come on board at the scheduled time for starting home made the start about twenty minutes late.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The thirty-second annual fair of the New-Jersey Agricultural Society opened on the grounds at Waverly, just beyond Newark, to-day. The day was mainly devoted to getting the exhibits in order, and the attendance was not large. To-day will really be the first day of the exhibition. The fair is one of the most attractive the State Agricultual Society has yet arranged.

Again the Brooklyn Jockey Club offers to racegoers a programme made up of eight races, the first and sixth races on the regular card received so many entries that they had to be divided. There are two stakes also to be decided, the Willow, for two-year-old fillies, and the Fulton, for three-year-olds. The card will therefore furnish sport enough and to spare for even the most ravenous racegoer. Following are the entries and weights:

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from New-Haven last night said: "After several weeks of negotiations the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company has purchased the Union Wharf, and the transfer was made to-day. The price paid was $100,000. E.M. Reed, Vice President of the railroad company, was made President of the new wharf company.

The Hartford Post announces, with proper local pride, the appointment of Mr. LEVERETT BRAINERD of that city to be Chairman of the committee of manufacturers for the World's Fair in Chicago. Mr. BRAINERD is an eminent and useful citizen, but he deserves rather condolence than congratulation upon the honor that has befallen him.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 22. -- Republicans had hoped that the nomination of Gen. S.E. Merwin for Governor would draw from the Prohibitionists many votes this Fall, particularly of those who were driven into the third party by the candidacy two years ago of Morgan G. Bulkeley. That this will not be the case was the conviction expressed by the speakers at the Prohibition Congressional Convention held in this city today.

No one could complain for lack of sport at the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday. In fact, there was a surfeit of it, for eight races were run, and that really seems a little too much of a good thing, particularly when we have six days' racing weekly from one year's end to the other. But the crowd present had no cause of complaint because of any delay.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The jury in the case of William W. Allen, ex-Superintendent of Mails in the Buffalo Post Office, who is charged with stealing money letters, came into court to-day, reported that they were unable to agree, and were discharged. The jury had been out since 1 P.M. Saturday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 22. -- The victory of the Schneider all-steel and nickel-steel armor plates over the Cammell compound steel and iron plate which was won on the Annapolis proving ground last Thursday was clinched to-day when an eight-inch projectile was fired at the centre of each plate, equi-distant from each of the four six-inch shots fired Thursday.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- The commission to revise and codify the fish and game laws of the State, consisting of Robert B. Roosevelt, Deputy Attorney General Edward G. Whitaker, and Gen. R.U. Sherman, spent some time during the month of August in examining some of the waters of Long Island. The commission gave a public hearing at Sayville, and made practical tests and examinations of the Great South Bay.

The irritation of Speaker REED was not appeased nor were his difficulties in the Venable-Langston case solved by the caucus of the Republicans of the House yesterday. The Speaker has got himself into a most uncomfortable state of anger and has brought the business of the House to a standstill through the operation of his own celebrated "business" policy.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Sept. 22. -- A project that is to be put into active operation, according to a member of a railroad engineering corps who has been stopping in this city the past week, is the proposition to build a railroad along the Delaware from Water Gap to Port Jervis. The new line is to be known as the Port Jervis and Water Gap Railroad. Kittatinny Route, and will be independent of all other lines.

Notwithstanding the slight rain which began falling exactly at 4 o'clock yesterday, the time announced for the auction sale of seats and boxes for the opening night of the Garden Theatre, the Fifth Avenue Auction Booms were crowded by prominent people anxious to bid for the choice of places. Mr. C.F. Whitmore was the auctioneer.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- One by one the thinking manufacturers and merchants of the Republican Party are coming into the Democratic field. This year promises many new converts to the Democratic ranks. S.B. Locke of the Somerville Iron Foundry and John E. Sylvester of the Somerville Spike Works of Somerville, Mass., have recently announced that they will step aside from the Republican ticket this Fall and will vote for William E. Russell.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- The delegates of the Republican Leagues of the State met in annual convention to-day. Every seat in the lower part of the house and balcony was filled. As soon as the convention was called to order President Edwin S. Stuart delivered his annual address, and a recess was then taken until 2 o'clock.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Rooms yesterday, Tuesday, Sept. 23:

One of the series of benefit games for Charles Hunt, the manager of the Prospect Park Ball Grounds, was played at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday between the Sun and TIMES nines. Mr. Hunt is an old ball player. For some years past he has had charge of the numerous diamonds at Prospect Park, where thousands of young men took their first lessons in the national game.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 23. -- The politicians of the Republican Party in the West are complaining that the Farmers' Alliance is making a strange variety of demands. This is unquestionably true, but their very strangeness is evidence of the sore pressure and necessity that lie behind them. One demand most criticised is that the Federal Government shall warehouse farm products and issue certificates against them, to be used as currency.

This week promises to be a notable one in the fruit market in New-York from the fact that the heaviest supplies of the season, so far as California fruit is concerned, will arrive and be disposed of at auction. In Monday's sales were included over six thousand boxes of peaches, which sold at from $1.50 to $2.50 per box, and the last of the Bartlett pears for the season, which realized for select boxes 3.10.

The meeting of the Democratic State Committee in this city and the dedication of the Thomas Jefferson Building in Brooklyn yesterday afforded occasion for a good deal of declaiming upon Democratic doctrine and still more arraigning of the Republican Party. There was considerable justice in the arraignment, but it was accompanied by so much partisan fustian as to be in a great degree deprived of effect.

" All the Comforts of Home," now drawing crowded houses at Proctor's Theatre, is a delightful exaggeration of those household episodes which not infrequently make home everything but the haven it should be. As a contrast to this, there is every day presented at a place of entertainment in New-York attributes and conditions of that perfect home life which poets sing of and so few attain to.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 23. -- The article in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Sept. 15 concerning the disgraceful condition of the United States Navy Yard at this place has been made the subject of an official inquiry. Secretary of the Navy Tracy wrote to Commodore A.W. Weaver, Commandant, under date of Sept. 17, requesting him to make an explanation of the facts cited in THE TIMES'S article.

There was a grand rehearsal of the operation of voting under the new ballot law at the Town Hall of Jamaica, L.I., last night. The performance commenced at 7:30 before a large and select audience of voters. The doors being opened revealed a wooden voter clad in cotton cloth. There were also voting booths, and to the right of them the tribunal of the ballot distributors.

It was learned yesterday that the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius will meet the Philadelphia at New-London or at Gardiner's Bay. It was originally intended that the Vesuvius should accompany the larger ship, but owing to the delay in the former's electric light test her departure was delayed. The Philadelphia got steam up yesterday afternoon, and will leave her anchorage off Clifton, S.I., this morning bright and early.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 23. -- Lord Stanley, Governor General of Canada, made an important reference to the McKinley bill at the opening of the Central Fair here to-day. The invited guests included Sir John Macdonald, the Premier, and leading members of the Dominion Government, United States Consul General Lay, Sir George Baden-Powell, London, England, and Sir Terence O'Brien, Governor of Newfoundland. Lord Stanley, among other things, said:

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23. -- The dead body of the young woman found drowned at Locust Point yesterday was identified to-day as Mina a Boehm, niece of Dr. Adolph Boehm, a well-known physician of this city. The manner of Miss Boehm's death remains a mystery. Miss Boehm was twenty-six years of age. Her home was in Brunewick, Germany, and she was born in the Hartz Mountains.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23. -- The thirty-third annual festival of the Worcester County Musical Association began this afternoon under the most favorable circumstances. The weather was of a most delightful character, the day being sunny and yet cool. The audience was therefore a large one, filling the large auditorium of Mechanics' Hall, which seats 2,000 persons, to its utmost capacity.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The Inman Line steamer City of New-York, Capt. Watkins, which sailed from New-York Sept. 17 for Liverpool, was signaled off Browhead at 9:55 o'clock this morning. Thirty-five minutes later the White Star Line steamer Teutonic, Capt. Irving, which also left New-York on Sept. 17 for Liverpool, passed the same point. The City of New-York sailed from New-York twenty-nine minutes ahead of the Teutonic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- After a week spent in trying to get a quorum in the House, the Republicans, who have had a majority of twenty-three members before to-day's session began, managed to get a bare quorum, and at once elected two colored men to take the places of white men who had been elected by the voters of districts in Virginia and South Carolina.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 23. -- Ex-Senator William W. Eaton of Hartford, who presided at the recent Democratic State Convention, visited New-Haven to-day and dined with ex-Judge Luzon B. Morris, the Democratic candidate for Governor. The ex-Senator is enthusiastic over the prospects of a Democratic victory in Connecticut this Fall and said:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23. -- The Republican Convention of the Ninth Congressional District was held to-day, and the outcome is very much in the nature of a political sensation from the fact that it retires Nathan Frank to private life. Chauncey I. Filley did it. Filley has been after Frank's scalp because Frank assisted materially in frustrating Filley's projects for political advancement.

Having succeeded in getting a quorum of its own complexion, the Republican majority of the House of Representatives yesterday not only turned over to Mr. LANGSTON the seat to which Mr. VENABLE was elected in Virginia, but proceeded without a chance for discussion or consideration to give the seat of Mr. ELLIOTT of South Carolina to his colored opponent, MILLER.

A tamer, more spiritless meeting of the Democratic State Committee can scarcely be imagined than that which took place at the Hoffman House yesterday morning. Contrary to general expectation, peace reigned supreme, and so overpowering was this predilection that the committee went so far as to appoint a sub-committee of five on "harmony" to promote a union of the Democratic factions in this city on Congressional and Assembly nominations.

There have been outbreaks of prudery from time to time in various villages upon this continent that have excited the wonder of intelligent foreigners, and indeed of intelligent natives. In fact, these outbreaks have occurred in places that the census classes as cities and large towns. It is a good many years since an aesthetic citizen of Norwich, Conn., excited the horror of his neighbors by exposing a scantily-draped statue in his back yard.

The steamship Elbe of the North German Lloyd. Line was docked yesterday afternoon at 4-o'clock, and the first passenger to land from her was William Walter Phelps, United States Minister at Berlin. He was accompanied by Mrs. Phelps, and it was, therefore, not surprising that there should be a number of pretty Jersey girls upon the dock to whom he was allowed to give osculatory greetings.

How can the Republican leaders any longer deceive their partisan followers as to the real relation existing between their party organization and the Sugar Trust? We might fill columns of THE TIMES with extracts from Republican journals in which this Trust has been described and denounced as a Democratic concern. That has been the cry of some of them for more than two years.

PANAMA, Sept. 23, via Galveston. -- A most disastrous fire broke out at Colon (Aspinwall) very early this morning. It consumed the greater portion of the town, destroying three-fourths of the place, including the most important business houses.

Capt. Abram Van Pelt, who had served forty-two years as a Sandy Hook pilot when he retired from the service seven years ago, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, 6 Boyd's Hill, Stapleton, S.I.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 23. -- Pawtucket today issued its programme of festivities, by which it is proposed to celebrate the centenary of cotton manufacture in this country by Samuel Slater. The date is itself in doubt by nearly a year. The State has dealt very liberally by the little city, which is sometimes carried by its ambition to ludicrous lengths, and even responded to a call for $3,000 additional, after having generously granted $10,000.

In the course of a speech at Atchison, Kan., the Hon. Charles Robinson, the Democratic candidate for Governor, said: "The principal national issue of the campaign ought to be and doubtless will be the tariff. There are other reforms to be considered in the interest of the people, and I shall take them up earnestly and in their place, but the question of the tariff must remain the great issue.

Mr. Henry Watterson, fresh from "the headquarters of nowhere," to use his own expression, and looking the picture of rugged health, is in the city for a few days. On Friday he will be the guest of the Massachusetts Reform Club at a dinner in Boston, and on that occasion will discuss Mr. Blaine's reciprocity scheme and the sectional question.

Herr Johann Most was to have delivered one of his fire-eating harangues and to have presided at a meeting at the Labor Lyceum, Myrtle Street, near Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, but at the request of Mayor Chapin Police Commissioner Hayden and Chief of Police Campbell prevented the assemblage of his friends and sympathizers, who were ready to applaud the vaporings of the noted Anarchist.

The industrial schools of the Children's Aid Society long since ceased to be an experiment. The wisdom of their founder and their extreme usefulness in a city like New-York have been demonstrated by the success they have achieved, and by the character of the children whose wants they have relieved and who have been trained and partially educated under their auspices.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The post-mortem examination of the body of Marie Hock, the actress, who died Sunday, revealed the fact that death was not due to poison, but was probably hastened by the powder given to her.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Chairman Andrews of the Republican State Committee said to-day that the Republicans would forestall Senator Emery's charges against Senator Delamater, which are to be made at Bradford Friday night. Later in the day the following documents, which are said to be copies of those which Senator Emery intends using, were given out:

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Sept. 23. -- The trial of Birchall for the murder of Benwell in Blenheim Swamp was resumed to-day. The first thing relation to the case at the opening of the court was the presentation of the Grand Jury's finding in the case of Mrs. Birchall, accused of being accessory to the murder of Benwell. In this case the Grand Jury returned no bill.

The recent publishing relations between England and the United States are more intimate than ever. The familiar names of English publishing houses are seen in New-York, and American houses are extending their domain beyond the sea. In England this movement began really with the publication of the American illustrated popular magazines, which was both a surprise and a delight to the English public.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 23. -- To the surprise of everybody the heterogeneous State Convention of Greenbackers, Union Labor, and Farmers' Alliance men held here to-day was a pretty successful one so far as numbers present and interest were concerned. Nearly all the Congressional districts and one-third of the counties were represented. The outcome of the day was the organization of a new party with the comprehensive appellation of "People's Party."

The abandonment of some of the old coins is a good step to take in preparation for the proposed introduction of new designs. The Senate has just concurred in the House bill to discontinue the coinage of the one-dollar and three-dollar gold pieces and the three-cent nickel piece, so that it will soon be a law. A sufficient objection to the latter two coins is that they do not conform to our decimal system.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The tariff debate between W.W. Curry of Indiana and John E. Russell of Massachusetts was one of the chief features of to-day at the Otsego County Fair. The large audience, composed mostly of farmers, listened in breathless silence to the eloquent speakers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- To-morrow, if everything goes as the members of the Tariff Conference Committee hope, the conferrees will finish their work on the Tariff bill, and on Thursday the report will be made to both houses. According to reports from members of both conference committees the conferrees have agreed on everything but the sugar schedule and the duty on binding twine.

WEEDSPORT, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- But few people went to the fair grounds to-day, and it is doubtful if at any one time there were over twelve hundred on the grounds. Of these not more than three or four hundred, probably not four hundred, went near the stand where Everett P. Wheeler of New-York and Major Pangborn of New-Jersey discussed the tariff issue.

Only five non-commissioned officers apparently are to present themselves this year for final examination at Fortress Monroe, after having passed their department examinations for appointment to the grade of Second Lieutenant. This is a marked contrast with the round dozen of a recent year.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- The Independent State Republican Committee, composed of 100 prominent Republicans and representing nearly every county in the State, to-night issued the following address:

As was pointed out in THE TIMES yesterday morning, the cablegram announcing the departure of the cruiser Baltimore from Stockholm for this country was a mistake. The ship is under orders to proceed to Lisbon and await further instructions, which, it is generally thought, will confine her to the Mediterranean squadron throughout the Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- Judge M. Russell Thayer, President Judge of Common Pleas Court No. 4, the most scholarly as well as the ablest Judge on the Philadelphia bench, to-day rendered an elaborate decision holding that Tolstoi's "Kreutzer Sonata" is not an obscene book. Charles Arentzen and other book peddlers were arrested at the instance of the Law and Order Society for selling the book.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24. -- The eighty-first annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions will be held in Plymouth Congregational Church, this city, begining Oct. 8 and ending 13. The citizens of the city, irrespective of denomination, have opened their homes for the coming guests, and the wholesale invitation sent out months ago will result, it is expected, in making the coming session the largest in the history of the board.

It will be generally conceded that President CLEVELAND'S tariff message was the greatest of all the public services he was able to render. This ought to be conceded quite independently of one's opinions upon the merits of protection or the need of revenue reform. It ought to be conceded by men who believe in high protection, not "for revenue only," nor even from partisanship because it is a part of the Republican creed.

ALBANY, Sept. 24. -- Attorney General Tabor, on behalf of Warden Brush of Sing Sing Prison, has been served with notice to show cause before the United States Supreme Court at Washington Oct. 14 why the decision of Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court, denying the petition of Shibaya Jugiro, who is in Sing Sing Prison awaiting execution by electricity, for a writ of habeas corpus, should not be corrected.

The features of the racing at the Brooklyn track to-day will be the Woodlawn Handicap, at a mile and three-sixteenths, and the Oceanview Stakes, for three-year-olds, at a mile and an eighth. The four other races have a good lot of entries, so that there will be plenty of sport, even though, aside from the two fixtures, the card promises nothing sensational. The entries and weights for the several races are as follows:

The taunt of Speaker REED in his Philadelphia speech that while the Republicans have been pushing their measures through the House of Representatives the Democrats have stuck to their seats "as peacefully as so many lambs" has reminded the latter that for eight months before the Venable-Langston contested election case came up it was in their power to break a quorum and block the partisan designs of REED and his supporters any day.

Although the full consequences of the competitive trial at Annapolis may not yet be apparent, its more important effects are already beyond doubt. Homogeneous steel, probably with a small percentage of nickel alloy, is to be the material for plating our war vessels instead of the compound of hard-steel face and wrought-iron back which is found in the British and to a greater or less extent in other European navies.

A team of five noted English amateur athletes, representing the Salford Harriers, arrived here yesterday on the Majestic. The athletes were accompanied by J.H. Hardick, who will act as their manager. Their object in coming to this country is to enter into joint meetings with the Manhattan Athletic Club in various sections of the country.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Ella May Bennett, who is to be ordained to the ministry, to-morrow night, was examined in the Universalist Church to-night as to her qualifications and knowledge on religious subjects preparatory to her ordination. She is the first woman on Long Island to be ordained to the ministry. The examination was public and took place in the Universalist Church, which was crowded with people.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- A young woman, richly dressed, alighted from an Erie Railroad train at Belleville, a suburb of Newark, last evening and asked first how she could get a train to New-York, and then, in a melancholy voice, whether there was a river near. Told that the Passaic was less than a quarter of a mile distant she walked away.

Neither in the North nor in the West has the Farmers' Alliance made the brilliant conquest that it has in the South. In the Eastern and Middle States it has done scarcely more than establish outposts. In Connecticut, however, it has made headway, and in Vermont, too, its hand is visible; in fact, it took part in the recent campaign, and worked to such purpose that two of its candidates were elected to the Legislature.

From the report of Messrs. Jesse Spalding James W. Savage, George E. Leighton, and Rufus B. Bullock, the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, which was yesterday submitted to the Secretary of the Interior, the condition of the road's business since the last report appears to have improved. The Directors say:

Mr. A.U. Sheldon, who has been associated for several years with the large shipbuilding establishment or John Elder Co. and more recently with the Vulcan Construction Works at Steitin, Germany, has been passing a few weeks in this country on a tour of inspection to see how far we have actually advanced in the art of modern shipbuilding on this side of the ocean.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 24. -- J. Woodward Haven and R.S. Palmer gave an elaborate ball to-night at the Schermerhorn Assembly Room. Mrs. W.B. Ogden, sister of G.G. Haven; Mrs. Barlow, wife of Gen. Barlow, and Mrs. John E. Parsons received the guests. The hall was elaborately and tastefully trimmed with roses, palms, laurel, and the cereals of the season tied up in sheaves with red ribbons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The Senate has at last passed the bill to relieve the United States Supreme Court of some of the work under which its docket is swamped by establishing a Circuit Court of Appeals in each circuit. It is so changed from the House measure that it will have to be considered again by that body, and there is, therefore, little chance that it will become a law this year.

In the month of June last, what the London Times calls "the greatest engineering achievement which English enterprise and skill have as yet attempted on the banks of the Nile," was quietly brought to a successful termination "No flourish of trumpets heralded the event" says that journal, "and it may be doubted whether the general public have any but the vaguest possible idea of what has been accomplished.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Representative Kennedy of Ohio was subjected to ensure by the House to-day for abusing Quay and the Senate, and he took it with something like the pride manifested by Mr. Bynum of Indiana when he was more formally criticised for a much less serious offense.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The cruiser Baltimore is not on her way home from Sweden, as was announced in cable dispatches this morning. She has left Stockholm on her way to Kiel, the German naval port, where she will be put in dock to have her bottom cleaned and painted. When this is done she will proceed to Lisbon, Portugal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Under the leadership of Mr. Carlisle, who was following the advice of Mr. Randall, when he was on his sick bed never to rise from it, the Democrats persisted, from the beginning of this session of Congress until the vote was taken on the Langston-Venable election case, in "sticking to their seats" instead of pursuing another course.

A ridiculous indorsement of the ridiculous Republican straight-ticket scheme was given at the Federal Club last night. It can not be fairly called a meeting of the club. There were not more than twenty-two members present at any time, and there are 150 in the club. The tabled resolution demanding a straight ticket inspired by eccentric Col. E.F. Shepard was called up for discussion as soon as President Charles L. Bidwell took the chair.

It is estimated that there are in Paris and the Department of the Seine 30,000 persons -- chiefly women -- engaged in the various washing and ironing establishments which abound in that district. These people have a great grievance just now with respect to which their "Syndicat de la Blanchisserie" is preparing a petition for presentation to the Chamber of Deputies as soon as it reassembles.

NEW-YORK. The articles of incorporation of the Union Veteran Memorial Association were filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office. The object of the association is to erect a memorial building in this city, to be used for veteran societies, both army and navy, and as a place of deposit for papers and relics. Among the Trustees are Floyd Clarkson, E.L. Viele, Ira M. Hedges, Henry A. Weeks, and C.H.T. Collis.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 24. -- The annual meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League will be held in this city Oct. 1 and 2. The annual address will be delivered by the President, George William Curtis, at Tremont Temple, Wednesday evening, Oct. 1, at 8 o'clock.

If the old exhilarating and healthful pastime of bowling, or "tenpins" as those unfamiliar with it vaguely call it, continues during the next five years to gain admirers as it has in the last five years, the sport will have more active devotees than ever participated regularly and actively in a game that has become popular in this country.

C.B. Richard Co., bankers at 61 Broadway, trapped a very clever young forger yesterday. This person, Ewin Mindt, or Mendel, called two weeks ago on M.J. Drucker, an importer of skins at 176 William Street, and said he had just arrived from Hamburg, and that his parents spoke frequently of Mr. Drucker as an old friend.

ROME, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- One of the most interesting Assembly District Conventions ever held in Oneida County was the Third Assembly District Republican Convention, held in Holland Patent yesterday, that resulted in the renomina- of Russel Smith Johnson, the strong anti-Platt representative of the district.

The one hundred and seventh annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal churches of the diocese of New-York is being held in this city in the Church of the Holy Trinity, at Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street. The opening session occurred yesterday morning. At 10 o'clock divine services were held, during which Bishop Potter delivered his charge, taking for his subject "The Offices of Wardens and Vestrymen."

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 24. -- If the slim Republican majority in the House of Representatives at Washington is not reduced by at least three it will not be the fault of the Nebraska Alliance men and Democrats. At the present time there is a revolt in the Republican ranks, and, looking at it in the best possible light, it means defeat for the party which has hitherto dominated Nebraska politics.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24. -- There was one noticeable thing about the second concert of the music festival, which took place this afternoon. That feature was the disposition of the audience. The concert was much below the average symphony concert as known in Boston and New-York. Yet it was too good for the audience. The solo numbers alone interested the large assembly which gathered in Mechanics' Hail.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- "Jump for your lives! We're going into the river!" The driver of Lincoln Avenue car No. 178 of the North Chicago Street Railroad Company threw open the front door of his car at 12:45 this morning, and with a face as white as snow said these appalling words to his passengers, a dozen or more in number. The passengers made a wild rush for the doors.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- In pursuance of a call issued by Theodore P. Rynder, Chairman, the Executive Committee of the Union Labor Party met here to-day for the purpose of discussing the advisability of placing a ticket in the field this Fall. The meeting was secret, and at its conclusion it was announced that it had been decided to place the following ticket in nomination:

It may be a surprise to the the consumers of this country to learn that the McKinley Tariff bill, now in conference, has virtually a provision in it that takes ostrich feathers out of the dutiable schedule and puts them on the free list.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24. -- The Democratic Bennett Law League has prepared an address, which will be sent out to the press of the State as well as to Democrats to-morrow. About one thousand Democrats have sent in their names to Timlin and Ryan, the leaders of the movement, up to date, and new names are being added daily.

Steam yachting is always referred to as a pleasure in which only men of money can indulge. It is, indeed, an expensive luxury, when considered from the point of view of the majority of our steam yachtsmen, although the cost of building and maintaining a steam or naphtha launch, in which a man can have no end of fun, is comparatively small.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The News's Tipperary correspondent declares that a marked change occurred in the demeanor of the police when Mr. Morley issued from the court on the appeal of several voices imploring him to come to save the people. Evidently the police had no desire to treat the English Commoners with discourtesy.

The followers of John R. Voorhis met last evening at Webster Hall, in Eleventh Street, near Third Avenue, and went through the formalities of launching a new political organization under the name of the "Democratic Organization of the City and County of New-York," and perfecting its county organization. Twenty delegates were present from each Assembly district except the Twelfth and Twenty-first, and there was no lack of enthusiasm.

DUBLIN, Sept. 25. -- Patrick O'Brien, who was arrested at Cardiff on Tuesday, was brought to this city yesterday and placed in prison. The police refused to give any information as to when he would be taken to Tipperary for a hearing, but late last night the Nationalists learned that he would be conveyed thither by the morning train to-day, when they at once made preparations to give him worthy escort.

August Belmont went down to the Brooklyn Jockey Club race track yesterday to see his pet Raceland run in the Woodlawn Handicap. Mr. Rowe, who trains for the Nursery Stable, had told Mr. Belmont that the horse was never better in his life. That was what he told him over at Sheepshead Bay a couple of weeks ago when Tristan beat the Belmont crack.

The steamer Normannia of the Hamburg-American Line left for Germany yesterday, carrying among her saloon passengers Dr. Willis J. Bickford, Prof. E.J. Bosworth, Dr. and Mrs. F.J. Campbell, Henry A. Cassebeer, Count Douglas, Victor Hellbronn, Octavio Knauth, Count de Martino of the Italian Embassy, Dr. and Mrs. B.L. Rhein, Director General Leo Strippelman, Charles H. Steinway, Capt. G.W. Walker, and John Tiebout.

Undue haste can scarcely be charged against the proposal to explore and survey Alaska. It is now a quarter of a century since we bought a realm larger than the thirteen colonies for about two cents an acre, and yet only the fringe of it is known even to the hardy pioneers who sail its rivers and climb its mountains in the perennial search for wealth.

The Count of PARIS was placed between the horns of a very disagreeable dilemma by the publication of the facts of the intrigue which the Royalists have been carrying on with the Boulangists. Of course it had been known for a long time to all well-informed observers of contemporary politics, outside of France as well as in it, that BOULANGER was but the stalking horse of the Monarchists.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 25. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day there was filed a bill that promises to result in a most interesting contest at the October term of that tribunal. The plaintiff is the United States, and the defendants are the coal companies doing business in Nashville and the dealers who sell the product of their mines to the people of the city.

There is no doubt that a large majority of the people of this city are convinced that good municipal government can never be obtained through the rule of Tammany. The only way to defeat that rule is through a union of all anti-Tammany forces, irrespective of party considerations, and the opportunity is now presented for securing such a union in the most effective manner.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25. -- The refusal of the majority of the artists to attend Mr. Walter Kennedy's reception last night was the theme of much animated conversation in this city today. Only two of the artists attended the reception. These were Mrs. Bloomfield Zeisler and Mrs. Jennie Patrick Walker. Mrs. Zeisler arrived last night and knew nothing about the concerted movement among her fellow-artists.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 25. -- The Republicans of this unbreakable Republican State for the second time since statehood was assumed met in convention in this city in the Tacoma Theatre to-day to nominate their next Congressman. There was no question about the choice. The present Congressman, John L. Wilson of Spokane Falls, was nominated this evening by acclamation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Republican Congressional Convention met at the Clinton House to-day, and owing to contesting delegations from Seneca County a lively fight occurred, which lasted all the afternoon and caused an adjournment till to-morrow. There has been a large delegation of politicians from the surrounding counties, among them being noted Senator Fassett of Elmira, the Hon. I.W. Cole of Watkins, and Senator Sweet of Waterloo.

The overthrow of the Rev. SHIRLEY W. BAKER, Premier of Tonga, by Sir JOHN THURSTON, Governor of Fiji, will probably end certain troubles which have for several years worried the worthy natives of the Friendly Islands. Mr. BAKER went to Tongatabu as a Wesleyan missionary, but became Prime Minister of the King. Nearly all the islanders, including the monarch, are christianized, thanks to the successful labors of the Methodists.

The Hon. John Jay lies in St. Luke's Hospital, suffering from a fracture of the neck of the left femur, an injury that he received yesterday in neighborhood that is becoming noted for its serious street accidents. Mr. Jay was knocked down in front of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartfort Railroad waiting rooms in Forty-second Street by a horse attached to a four-wheeled cab driven by Nicholas Gibney of 328 East Thirty-seventh Street.

STONEY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Union Hall, in this village, was thronged to-night with ministers and persons identified with the Universalist Church, the occasion being the ordination to the ministry of Mrs. Ella May Bennett of this place. Unusual interest was manifested in the event, as Mrs. Bennett is the first woman to be ordained to the ministry on Long Island.

There has been sent to THE TIMES a circular issued on the 9th inst. by FOSTER, STEVENS Co., hardware merchants of Grand Rapids, Mich., "a firm which handles," we are told, "more hardware of the cutlery, glass, and tin class than any other in the State." The house was established by the late WILDER D. FOSTER, who for many years represented the Grand Rapids district in Congress as a Republican.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- "The Oswego Canal should be abandoned; its days of usefulness are over," said one of the best-known canal men in the State the other day.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- After the most bitterly-contested battle on record in the annals of Congressional conventions in the Twelfth Ohio District, Col. William E. Doan of Wilmington, Clinton County, was nominated at 3 o'clock this morning at Washington Court House, the disposition of the delegates being to remain in session until a nomination was made.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Howard G. White was renominated for the Assembly at the First District Convention this afternoon by acclamation, the Platt-Hiscock faction making no opposition and thereby acknowledging their cause a forlorn one, Representative Belden's faithful henchmen having secured the organization of the convention for prudential reasons. Mr. White addressed the convention and gave a pointed thrust at Hiscock and Carroll E. Smith, the editor of the Syracuse Journal, the Senator's mouthpiece.

A good many Irishmen in this city and Brooklyn were glad to read in THE TIMES yesterday the announcement that Michael Davitt proposed to print in his paper, the Labor World of Dublin, a complete expose of the plots concocted in Ireland and America by "Red Jim" McDermott.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Sept. 25. -- The first witness in the Benwell murder trial this morning was S.B. Fuller, manager of the Imperial Bank here. He identified the signature, "F.A. Somerset" on certain checks as that of the prisoner, who opened an account with the Imperial Bank on the 10th or 11th of December, 1888. He identified also certain letters put in evidence as those of the prisoner.

It was understood in Washington last night that the tariff conference committee would report this morning an agreement upon all the amendments in dispute. The compromise in the sugar schedule is this: The Senate gives up its duty of 30 cents per hundred pounds on sugars from No. 13 to No. 16 and the House consents that the Trust's protective duty on refined sugars shall be increased from 40 cents to 50 cents per hundred.

Castle Garden had the pleasure yesterday afternoon of once again being the scene of the deliberations of the Commissioners of Emigration. It will have the pleasure but once again -- on the afternoon of Oct. 8 -- as after that the Commissioners will auction off their chattels and take themselves to a smaller, more modern, and better-furnished office.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The gate returns show that the attendance to-day at the annual fair of the Orange County Agricultural Society, now in progress at Port Jervis, numbered over 12,000 persons. There were special attractions not down in the programme to draw the crowd in the presence of Gen. W.T. Sherman on the fair grounds and the debate on tariff reform.

There is danger that relief of the Supreme Court of the United States will be again postponed on account of the changes made by the Senate in the bill as it passed the House. Both branches of Congress have given their approval to the plan for intermediate courts of appeal in the several circuits, which is the most rational and effective method of relief that has been proposed.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 26. -- The policy holders of the Charter Oak Life Insurance Company can reasonably count on the declaration of a dividend within six months. The funds now held by the receivers, Isaac W. Brooks of Torrington and E.A. Stedman of this city, exceed $400,000.

For nearly three hours last evening the Campaign Committee of the Business Men's Republican Organization was closeted in executive session in the rooms of the Ohio Society, 236 Fifth Avenue. Col. W.L. Strong, the business Republican who is regarded with so much affection by all the members of the organization, presided. Many stirring speeches were made, mostly in regard to the advisability of the organization declaring itself in favor of a straight Republican ticket.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 26. -- It was reported here early this morning that George B. Graham, one of the wealthiest and best-known citizens of Baltimore, had attempted suicide at his country place, eight miles from the city. Mr. Graham is a millionaire. His mother was the sister of Gen. George S. Brown of the banking firm of Alexander Brown Sons.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- The steamer El Sol will be launched at noon to-morrow, from the shipyard of William Cramp Sons. She has been built for the Morgan Louisiana and Texas Steamship Company, forming part of the South ern Pacific system, and is intended for service between New-York and New-Orleans. She is for the carriage of freight only, and will have no accommodation for passengers.

A meeting of the stockholders of the Star Fire Insurance Company was held yesterday at the Board of Fire Insurance Brokers, 67 William Street. There were present about sixty men, representing nearly one thousand five hundred shares of stock. These gentlemen listened to a report from their special committee appointed to look after the interest of the stockholders, and composed of James Clark, Henry Robertson, E.S. Bailey, W.G. Fleming, and Joseph Wood.

A glance at the navy list of vessels in commission to-day does not tend to impress one favorably with the formidable character of our available fleet The first-rate vessels now in active service are the Chicago, Baltimore, and Philadelphia The Newark and San Francisco belong to this list but they have not been put in commission.

The Police Commissioners had a busy session yesterday. The duties imposed upon them by the new ballot law occupied considerable of their attention. They disposed of one contract -- that for 5,000 ballot boxes -- which they awarded to C.F. Hodson, who offers to make them for $6.50 apiece. They discussed the matter of having the 18,000,000 ballots printed, but came to no conclusion.

The Committee of Four appointed by the People's Municipal League to recommend candidates to the Executive Committee put in a hard day's work yesterday. It met in a down-town office in the afternoon and at the headquarters in the Victoria Hotel in the evening. It will be ready with its report by Monday night, when it will be given to the Executive Committee.

England's experience of the responsibilities that attend her protectorate of Zanzibar has begun promptly after her assumption of it. Germany, having yielded all claims to the control of Vitu under the recent agreement, is naturally excited over the account of the massacre of eight of her subjects there by the natives.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- On account of the rain the adjourned tariff debate was not as largely attended as it would have been with pleasant weather. As it was, nearly 1,000 persons were in attendance when the meeting was called to order, and nearly all remained for over two hours. The Hon D.G. Griffin of this city presided, and the Hon. W.A. Beach of Syracuse spoke first for the tariff-reform side.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 26. -- A crime resembling in its details the murder one year ago of Annie Leconey was brought to light late this afternoon by the finding of the body of Mrs. John Miller in a dense woods near her home, in Delaware Township, this county. Frank Lingo, the burly negro who was suspected of the murder of Miss Leconey, is locked up charged with causing Mrs. Miller's death.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Henry Watterson got a very warm reception, which he returned with a very eloquent address, at the dinner of the Massachusetts Reform Club at the Brunswick tonight. He was evidently in the best of spirits when he met the guests and members of the club to-night. It was wet without, but cheery and brilliant enough in the banquet hall, where a distinguished company was gathered.

A genuine case of smallpox that has been in the city for over a week turned up at the Barge Office yesterday. It had developed in the person of Bridget Conyer, twenty years old, who came over from Galway to Beston in the steerage ten days ago. She felt ill and feverish when she landed, but came on the following day (Sept. 16) to her sister in this city.

Few sessions of Congress in recent years have yielded so many important measures of military legislation as the current one. Among these, at an early stage, were the appointment of an Assistant Secretary of War, the conferring of brevets for Indian campaigning, and the new systems of selling discharges, of retaining pay, and of granting furloughs and releases at the end of the third year of enlistment.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Gov. Hill had a great reception at Franklinville Fair to-day. In spite of a drizzling rain a crowd of about eight thousand people gathered and vigorously applauded a speech in which politics was carefully eschewed. The Governor left the Iroquois Hotel, Buffalo, about 7:45 A.M., in time to catch the 8:15 train for Franklinville, reaching his destination about 10:30.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 26. -- Justice Miller, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day, rendered a very important decision in the Dictionary dispute that is now agitating the book trade. Merriam Co. brought suit against a large number of publishers to prevent them from selling reprints of Webster's Unabridged Dictionary of 1847. Merriam Co. are successors to the original owners of the copyright, and claim to still control the publication.

Interest in the proposed exploration of the remains of ancient Delphi will be revived and deepened by Dr. CHARLES WALDSTEIN'S lecture upon the subject at the Law School lecture room of Columbia College next Tuesday evening. We have recently set forth the purposes and hopes of the American Archaeological Association in undertaking this work of excavation.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26. -- William Stewart, Manager of the Kingston and Montreal Forwarding Company, and Frank Owen, General Freight Agent of the Ogdensburg (N.Y.) Transportation Company, waited upon Sir John Macdonald yesterday, and urged that the Government announce at once whether canal tolls would be refunded upon grain carried down the St. Lawrence River to Montreal but transshipped at Ogdensburg.

COMBLESKILL, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- It was thought last night when the Democratic Convention for the Twenty-fourth Congressional District, in session here, adjourned after a day's unsuccessful balloting, that some arrangement would be made during the night by which a nomination would be effected this morning. The first ballot this morning, however, showed no change, the vote standing: Beckwith, 11; Van Horne, 15; Pindar, 11.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26. -- The Earl and Countess of Aberdeen arrived here this morning from Hamilton, and they will remain here until Monday evening before proceeding to British Columbia. Since his arrival at Quebec he has lost no time in renewing a closer acquaintance with political affairs in Canada, both by interviews with leading public men and by a study of Canadian journalism.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The tariff debate at the Schenevus Fair Grounds for to-day between the Hon. Mark D. Wilbur of Brooklyn for tariff reform and the Hon. W.W. Curry of Indiana on the high-protection side was widely advertised, and but for the rain, which started in at a very early hour, would have been largely attended. Great interest was manifested in the debate for miles around.

We published yesterday extracts from an interesting circular sent out by certain wholesale merchants of Grand Rapids, Mich., to their patrons in the retail hardware trade, in which explanations were made as to the higher prices recently demanded for axes, saws window glass, and other products.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The death of eight-year-old Willie Major, a farmer's son, from excessive cigarette smoking is reported from Bound Brook. The boy had for over three years been a victim to the habit. He would stay away from home several days at a time, eating nothing but the herbs and berries of the neighborhood and smoking constantly.
