CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- A meeting of the committee of railway officials having under consideration the subject of a uniform bill of lading will be held Oct. 8. The Chairman, F.H. Kingsbury, has sent a communication to the various commercial Exchanges and to the traffic officials of those railroads that refused to adopt the form recommended by the Trunk Line Association, requesting their views as to the proper construction of a uniform bill of lading.

The classes in voting under the new ballot law which Tammany politicians are conducting in the liquor saloons, which constitute the favorite resorts of Tammany voters, are a good thing. A large proportion of Tammany voters need instruction in order to vote by a system which requires the exercise of the smallest amount of intelligence.

Since J.F. Goddard retired from the Third Vice Presidency of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, a few months ago, his prospective employment has been the subject of much comment and guesswork on the part of Western newspapers. When Mr. Goddard left the Atchison he was made Chairman of the Western Passenger Association, but soon intimations were heard that he intended to resign that place in order to accept one much more lucrative.

The history of old Fort Riley, which is being transformed into the finest army post in America, dates back to Sept. 21, 1852, when Gen. N. S. Clarke, commanding the Sixth Military Department, appointed a board, consisting of Capt. E.A. Ogden, Capt. L.C. Easton, and Lieut. J.C. Woodruff, to decide upon a site for a military post near the junction of the Smoky Hill and Republican Rivers in Kansas, says the Kansas City Star.

The important addition which was made to the new fleet of armored cruisers that Spain is building to resume her place among the naval powers and to create a powerful squadron of cruisers, gunboats, and torpedo vessels to protect her trade and colonies is the first of three sister vessels which the Spanish Government has contracted for with the new shipyards of Messrs. Martinez Rives and Palmer of Bilboa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- After much tribulation the Tariff bill has been reported from the conferrees of the Senate and the House. The House waited impatiently for it to-day, but it was not until 5:10 that Mr. McKinley and his associates on the House conference committee came into the House to be greeted by a faint round of applause from the Republicans, who no ticed their arrival.

" One Summer day we were going to a morning wedding, and Lieut. Grant was also invited. He came for us on horseback, and asked my brother's permission to drive me, in exchange for his saddle, to which he gladly consented. The day was beautiful; the roads were a little heavy from previous rain, but the sun shone in splendor.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Sept. 26. -- The trial of Birchall for the murder of Benwell was continued to-day. Miss Cromwell of Eastwood testified that on Feb. 17 she went to the station to meet some friends. She met Birchall in the lane coming from the Brantford Road to the station. He was dressed in a navy-blue short coat and a black cap. His shoes were muddy and his trousers were turned up.

Dan Floweree says that Congressman Carter's final acceptance of his renomination reminds him of an incident of the early days. It was customary for physicians at that time to prescribe whisky for all known diseases. One day Myles Cavanaugh, whose likes and dislikes are pretty well known to most Montanians, was taken sick.

BRADFORD, Penn., Sept. 26. -- The Opera House was crowded to-night to hear the long-promised speech of ex-Senator Lewis Emery, Jr., in reply to Senator Delamater's York speech denying the charges of corruption that Emery made against him before Delamater was nominated for Governor by the Republican State Convention.

ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 26. -- Warrants were sworn out to-day by J.B. O'Meara, a prominent citizen, for the arrest of J.J. Keely for assault and battery, threatening his life with a loaded pistol, and striking him in the face, and against the Rev. Father J.W. Lynch, pastor of St. Andrew's Catholic Church, for being accessory to the assault.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Division of Wealth, Debt, and Taxation of the Census Bureau, of which Mr. T. Campbell Copeland has charge, has just finished the detailed report of the indebtedness of the counties of New-York State. The information in regard to the State is contained in the following table:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- Though the rain a falling there has been a fair attendance to-day at the National Prison Congress in the Scottish Rite Cathedral. Ex-President Hayes was in the chair. The first thing on the programme was the reading of the report of the Standing Committee on Criminal Law Reform by Mr. Charles Reeve of Plymouth, Ind.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 26. -- It was learned here to-day that the Republicans will positively place a full State ticket in the field against Tillman. The air has been full of all kinds of rumors since the adjournment of the Republican State Convention, but their exact plans were learned to-day from an authoritative source.

RED BANK N.J., Sept. 26. -- The Democratic primaries to elect delegates to the County Convention at Freehold, N.J., on Monday next will be held to-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock, and the indications point to some interesting political circuses. The convention is held to nominate a State Senator, County Clerk, Sheriff, and three Coroners.

" So far as stocking the inland lakes with fish is concerned, the hatching experiment in this State is a flat failure," said H.W. Welcher, ex-Superintendent of the hatcheries. Mr. Welcher is a practical fish hatcher, having been connected with Seth Green's establishment years ago. He came to Wisconsin to hatch fish for W.K. Fairbank, at Lake Geneva, and was finally induced to take charge of the State hatcheries.

DUBLIN, Sept. 26. -- The streets of Tipperary were thronged with people until a late hour last night discussing the exciting events of the day. As little real progress had been made toward a disposition of the cases against the arrested Nationalists, and as the general impression created by the court's rulings was not one complimentary to the tribunal's sense of fairness, there was much speculation as to what the morrow would bring forth.

Cold winds from the northwest have ruffled the Atlantic and the waters of the numerous bays near the city, in the course of the week, and have sent a chill through the anglers, warning them that the fishing season for 1890 is fast drawing to a close. In some respects it has been a good season, and in others an unsatisfactory one.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- There is just now a lively row between the Johnstown Flood Relief Commission and the Local Board of Inquiry which was formed just after the great flood of May 31, 1889. The local board's duties were to accumulate such data as would be useful in distributing the funds so generously donated by the whole country.

According to the authorized expounders of the doctrine of Protection, high duties on imports enable American manufacturers to pay high wages to their workmen -- see Republican national platforms and the public utterances of BENJAMIN HARRISON, WILLIAM McKINLEY, THOMAS B. REED, FRANK HISCOCK, NELSON W. ALDRICH, and other Republican statesmen.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- A few days ago the Inter-State Commerce Commission rendered a decision regarding the rates to be charged for shipments of oil in barrels loaded in ordinary cars as compared with oil in tank cars. The case was brought against the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad by small competitors of the Standard Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The naval board, of which Commander Theodore F. Jewell was senior member, appointed to conduct the recent trial of the Patrick torpedo, has submitted a favorable report, in accordance with which the department has accepted the three torpedoes made under contract.

The terms of twenty-eight United States Senators, twelve of whom are Democrats, expire upon the 3d of March, 1891, and there are two States -- Idaho and Wyoming -- which are as yet unrepresented in the United States Senate. The list of Senators whose terms end in 1891 is as follows:

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 26. -- The Pennsylvania Prohibitionists are among the most hopeful of all the politicians in the Keystone State. They have their headquarters in Scranton, where State Chairman H.D. Patton is preparing for an aggressive campaign, and in a few days more an army of orators will be denouncing King Alcohol all over the Commonwealth.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Hon. Milton Delano, Congressman from this district, sends an open letter to the Republican positively declining to be a candidate for re-election, on the ground that he cannot afford another term in Washington. The letter is in reply to a petition of many old soldiers of his district asking him to accept a renomination. He has been Chairman of the Pension Committee in the Fifty-first Congress.

The people of Halifax are probably justified in the inference they draw as to the good condition of the defenses of their city, shown during the simulated attack upon it by the fleet of Vice Admiral WATSON. It is true that this fleet was such as would hardly be sent into the harbor to run the gantlet of its batteries, torpedo craft, and mines in actual war.
MELBOURNE, Sept. 26. -- The strike of the wool shearers is not general. The squatters are suing their work people for breaking their agreement.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26. -- Intelligence has reached here from British Columbia that the Governments of Great Britain and the United States have established a "modus vivendi" in respect to Behring Sea, which will have effect during next year or until negotiations looking to a complete settlement of the seal-fishery dispute can be carried to a satisfactory conclusion.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept 26. -- The dead-lock in the Twenty-eighth Congressional District Republican Convention was broken this afternoon on the three hundred and seventy-first ballot, Schuyler County being the first to change. The skillful moves of Senator Fassett and his co-workers led to this result, and in the absence of Col. Noyes, the nominee, Mr. Fassett was called upon for a speech.

The Laramie Republican says the buffalo-hunting expedition organized in that city includes J.C. Robbins, Jack Hills, John Woodruff, and Frank Kelley, who are accompanied by a couple of the most expert lassoers in the country. Their object is not to slaughter the herd, but to lasso them and take them alive to Laramie. The herd has been seen by several different parties during the past year, and its haunts are pretty well known.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- Paris is having such delicious scandals every morning coming from the Boulanger case that the shooting month of September is entirely lacking in its usual city dullness. The regular highlife Jenkins pictures this annual chateau sojourn as a sort of permanent seductive paradise of folly and pleasure, with bird-killing as a mere luxurious incident, since every one knows that it is far cheaper to buy a partridge than to bag it.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 27. -- The 1890 edition of the quinquennial catalogue will go to press within a few weeks.

There is some honest difference of opinion about the merit of the acting of Mrs. E.A. Eberle in the part of Hesbiah in Mr. Bernard's play tried at the Twenty-third Street Theatre last Thursday. "I've seen hard-working, narrow-minded women on farms who looked and talked just as she does," said one spectator after the performance.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27. -- It is whispered that the Democratic Congressional Committee, under the leadership of Congressman Wiley, will make great efforts to retain the Thirty-third' New York District in the Democratic column, and neither expense nor pains to that end will be spared. The district is not too strongly Republican, and factional differences may be as disastrous this year as they were two years ago.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27. - Weary of deceit, the Rev. A.M. De Ford, the Methodist minister from Hortonville, to-day confessed his crime of attempting to pass bad money and signified his intention of pleading guilty to the charge. He story is calculated to excite pity. Two years ago he came to Milwaukee and bought some second-hand books. In one he found a twenty-dollar bill which proved to be a one-dollar bill.

THE APPLE. -- The virtues of the apple as a fruit have been celebrated from time immemorial, and few fruits have so many legends associated with them. The garden of the Hesperides was the garden of the golden apple, just as our Avalon is the Isle of Apples. "Of all fruits," it has been written, "the apple seems to have had the widest and most mystical history.

CHIVALRY. -- Chivalry must not be confounded with the feudalism out of which it emerged. It was an ideal, binding men together by common spiritual enthusiasms. We find the ground material of the chivalrous virtues in the Teutonic character. As described by Tacitus, the German races were distinguished for chastity, obedience to self-imposed laws, truth, loyalty, regard for honor more than gain, and a reverence for women amounting to idolatry.

A BUSINESS IN SNAKES. -- The number of deaths from snake bite in our great eastern dependency and the difficulty of coping with the matter have often been commented upon. It has also been pointed out that many unrecorded deaths in out-of-the-way places must occur, and thus add to the number of victims.

The friends of Mr. Joel Chandler Harris of Atlanta will grieve to know that his bright little boy, Linton, died in West End Sunday morning. He was just seven years old. The man who has written so tenderly of children, delighting old and young by the weird, touching myths of the Southern farms, has many sympathetic hearts in the hour when father and mother are bowed down.

Liverpool grain freights have been dull in New-York shipping markets lately, and for perhaps the last six weeks a majority of the steamship lines have been carrying grain, on occasions, free of charge or else purchasing coal as ballast for ports in the "U.K. and Cont.," to use a technical term coined by shippers, otherwise expressing the "United Kingdom and Continent."

ALBION, N.Y., Sept. 27. - Mr. McKinley having sent word from Washington that he would be unable to fill his engagement here for the tariff debate at the county fair, and Mr. Mills declining to come on without the Ohio man, Mark D. Wfio ber of Brooklyn appeared on the scene to advocate the cause of tariff reform. This he did in an address of reat force and in eloquent language.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Nothing but Senator Paddock and the President now stand between the Tariff bill and the tariff law.

A good many persons have related their experiences in attempting to become great tragedians. It is not often, however, that the narrative is so interesting as that of a correspondent of the Pall Mall Gazette, who says: "It is just seven years ago. I was a governess in ladies' school at a fashionable watering place on the south coast.

MONTREAL, Sept. 27. -- To-day's championship meeting of the Canadian Amateur Athletic Association proved a veritable Waterloo for both the Canadian competitors and the English visitors. The Americans swept the field. Not a single first prize was won by any of the Canadian or English competitors, and only one of the Salford Harries was placed.
Since champagne was first made in France in the year 1718 no essential modification of the original method of manufacture had been introduced until the discovery of Adolph Reihlen.

The public in general, and the public of the Northwest in particular, must be considerably fatigued by the action of the Senators and Representatives from that region on the Tariff bill. This fatigue will be increased by the declaration of some of them that they mean to vote against the bill as it has been reported from the conference committee.

The new Garden Theatre, at Madison Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, one of the departments, in fact, of the Madison Square Garden enterprise, was thrown open to the public last night. It is a beautiful house. In its construction and appointments the architect and builder have shown themselves abreast with the times. Every modern improvement possible in theatre building is there.

Nothing could be more salutary in an educational way than the tariff debates throughout this State, which were brought about by the efforts of the Reform Club of this city. They bring before farmers and others who have little opportunity for a real study of the tariff the facts and arguments which they most need.

The killing of Gen. Barrundia on the Pacific Mail Company's steamer Acapulco at San Jose de Guatemala recalls scenes and incidents preceding the killing of Gen. Barrios on the battlefield of Chalchuapa April 2, 1885. "The history of the late President Barrios," said a gentleman yesterday who has lived long in that country, "was a remarkable one.

It was a curious muddle altogether, so curious that the principal actor in it accepted the situation as it stood, having quite wit enough to perceive the utter inutility of making any effort to set the matter straight. This is how it really was:

Senator EDMUNDS writes to the Burlington Free Press that the Vermont delegation represented to the Tariff Conference Committee that there was no "substantial ground" why producers of maple sugar should not be subsidized as well as the sorghum sugar makers and the makers of the beet sugars.

Under the direction of Special Treasury Agent Charles S. Wilbur a peculiar case of alleged attempt to smuggle outlery into this port is being investigated by the Treasury officers. Last Friday afternoon, "acting upon information received," Mr. Wilbur sent Officers Britton and Hussey upon a special visit to the North German Lloyd steamship Lahn, lying at her pier in Hoboken.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- There is to be a general increase in conductors' salaries on the entire Northwestern system. The management of the road has been in conference for several days with a committee of the conductors. The conductors are now paid from $83.33 to $116 a month. They demanded an increase and classification, making the pay of the various grades $115, $125 and $135 a month respectively.

Within a few months the price of pig lead in this country has advanced about 35 per cent., and it is now so high that orders have been sent to London for between 2,000 and 3,000 tons. Pig lead is to be imported, in spite of a duty of 2 cents a pound, which was equivalent last year to an ad valorem rate of 71 12 per cent.

In spite of the disagreeable state of the weather there was a fair-sized crowd at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday. Betting was exceedingly brisk, and as the favorites won nearly all the races, the bookmakers did not have it all their own way. On the contrary they were hit heavily on the Chesapeake and Reporter victories.

The fog that now veils the field of local politics in uncertainty will be partially cleared away during this week. Many things will transpire that will put a different light on things that have already become public property, and by the end of the week the politicians will know pretty nearly what the fight is to be, and how and by whom it is to be made.

It is typical of our provincialism, and especially of the weakness of Americans resident abroad, that the Protestant Church of the Holy Trinity erected in Rome by Americans should have been designed by an Englishman, the mosaics supplied by an Italian, and the cartoons for the mosaics made by Burne Jones or London.

Alfred B. Thieme, who served as an enumerator while Mr. Porter was making his alleged census, said to a TIMES reporter last evening that he could account in a measure for the obviously incorrect statement as to the population of the city of New-York which emanated from the Census Bureau at Washington. "

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 27. -- A meeting of students interested in tennis was held this week to form a tennis association. Hitherto only class directors have been elected, and all matters pertaining to tennis have been attended to by them. Now permanent officers will be elected for one college year, a constitution and by-laws drawn up, and a more active interest taken in this sport.

Washington Ritter, cashier for Lapsley Gallup, stock brokers at 80 Broad Street, has absconded with $1,840 of the firm's money. Although a married man, he has gone away in company with a young woman named Mamie Zoan. Ritter entered the service of Lapsley Gallup eight years ago as an office boy and was gradually advanced, until about four years later he was appointed cashier and confidential clerk.

" Sweet are the uses of adversity," it is said. If not sweet, they have proved at least wonderfully transforming in two cases recently under the writer's notice. In each instance the wife living in affluence has suddenly become an almost destitute widow, and has done as so many other unsupported women have, established a boarding house.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Rev. George W. Raeburn, who for three years past has filled the pastorate of the Universalist Church at Clinton, N.Y., has resigned the charge for the purpose of taking a special course in theology and the classics at Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Hiscock contingent of the Republican Party in Onondaga County are happy to-night, having gained one victory out of the three Assembly conventions. William Kennedy, Senator Hiscock's candidate against Willis B. Burns for renomination in the Second District, was nominated. The fight has been a lively and bitter one, and it is claimed that money has been used to influence delegates on both sides.
BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The completed report of Herr Miguel, Prussian Minister of Finance, will be presented to the Emperor Tuesday.

The football teams of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn and Stevens Institute of Hoboken began their Fall campaign yesterday on the grounds of the Crescent Athletic Club at Bay Ridge, L.I. The Crescents are the strongest football men in this vicinity, and they start out in their season's work with the addition of one well-known player to their team, and good prospects of all their old men taking part in the most important games.

PARAGRAPHS FROM A MEDIAEVAL SERMON 1320. -- The philosopher Pliny says in his book that there is a fish in the sea called faste, whose nature is such that it sweetens the salt waters as they enter its mouth, whereby it deceives the little fishes, which follow the sweetness coming out of its mouth, and as soon as they come near enough to him are presently swallowed up.

About the time cold weather comes on many of the workingmen of this city will feel the effects of the foolish and wicked "brick boycott." It will not be due to any fight or to any direct refusal to "handle" or to sell bricks, but an inevitable consequence of the check upon building operations that has been already produced.

THE CLARK ELM. -- It is a magnificent specimen, standing in Lexington, and known to many, for its home is amid scenes which are memorable in Revolutionary annals. It is on the premises of the Clark-Hancock house, whose history is summarized in this tablet: "Built 1698; enlarged 1734.

All the signs point to some lively fights in the twelve Assembly Districts of Kings County, of which the Democrats now hold nine and the Republicans three. The latter feel certain of their ability to retain control of the Ninth and the Eleventh District, and, with John Y. McKane's help, of the Twelfth, represented in the last Legislature by Charles J. Kurth, one of McKane's proteges, but for all that a Republican.

SARATOGA, Sept. 27. -- With a couple of the big hotels open, the Saratoga season still continues a restricted existence. This week, however, the Grand Union has boarded up its doors, leaving the United States alone in its glory. Everything in the way of Summer enterprises has closed except this hotel and the Windsor, which offers no further hospitality after breakfast on Monday.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Sept. 27. -- The case for the defense in the Birchall trial was continued this morning. Dr. Mearns, the first witness called, said he had heard the medical testimony given by three doctors for the Crown. He did not agree with Dr. Welford that rigor mortis would set in so soon as stated. It would take generally, he believed, from five to six hours in a healthy young man.

The leading characteristic of this season's millinery richness of ornamentation, an elaboration and showiness of effect that have not been equaled in recent years. Analyzed, this trimming shows an endless variety of new details.

The first of the series of games for the amateur championship of the United States was played on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-Jersey and Detroit Athletic Club teams. To the delight of the Eastern athletic fraternity the New-Jersey boys won, and they now hold the lead in the race for championship honors. They have only to secure one more victory to be crowned champions of the country.

LONG BRANCH, Sept. 27. -- The Summer guest who recently gave Long Branch the pleasure of his presence and the benefit of his patronage is gone. The long lines of cottages between Seabright and North Long Branch, and between the West End and Elberon, have closed their doors and put up their Winter shutters.

JOHN BULL AND THE GERMANS. -- It is difficult to discover the reason for our intense unpopularity in Germany, for the Germans themselves are unable to assign any tangible cause for it. We seem to reproduce in their minds the immortal Dr. Fell, for it is unquestionable that "the reason why they cannot tell," or, if they could, they prefer not to do so.

THE PLAZZA DI NAVONA. -- The Piazza di Navona has its shops and palaces and florid churches at its four sides, marble seats set about it, statues here and there, and gigantic fountains dating from the time of the fifth Sixtus, whom Master Pasquin nicknamed Summus Fontifex instead of Summus Pontifex.

A bunch of strawberries, large, ripe, and luscious, their long stems bound together with dainty ribbon and their rich crimson bodies partly buried in fresh green leaves whose gentle fragrance recalls the breath of Spring. Such is the delicacy with which Mrs. Diamond-Lace may regale her chosen guests in midwinter.

LENON, Mass., Sept. 27. -- It is estimated that there are more people in Lenox now than have ever been here before. Every cottager has full quota of guests, and the hotels and boarding houses are filled.

MALARIOUS AFRICA. -- Malarial fever is the one sad certainty which every African traveler must face. For months he may escape, but its finger is upon him, and well for him if he has a friend near when it finally overtakes him. It is preceded for weeks, or even for a month or two, by unaccountable irritability, depression, and weariness.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Sept. 27. -- A Union Pacific box car, loaded with ties, contained a dead and a dying man when an extra freight reached Cheyenne shortly after noon to-day. The dead body was taken to the morgue and that containing life to the hospital, where it was soon learned that a bullet in the brain would allow him to live but a short time.

In retiring to private life Prince Bismarck has been able to read with his own eyes the things usually not printed about a man until he is dead. If the formal obituary article has been denied him, he has at least seen newspaper reviews of his life, newspaper estimates of his place in German and European history, and any amount of anecdotes and reminiscences, some due to the newspapers, some to other mediums of publicity.

DUBLIN, Sept. 27. -- There is no abatement of interest in the trial of the conspiracy cases against the Nationalist leaders now in progress at Tipperary. The proceedings yesterday created a very general impression that the Government was deliberately trying to prolong the trial as far as possible. The adjournment took place yesterday afternoon before Mr. Ronan, for the Crown, had finished his opening speech.

The bank statement yesterday showed the almost unprecedented increase for one week of over $12,000,000 in the surplus reserve. It was due to the extraordinary Treasury disbursements. A large increase had been looked for, but nothing so large as this. The effect on the market should have been to stimulate prices. The actual result was that prices declined.

IN A FRENCH CHATEAU. -- There is usually plenty of gayety going on in the country places around Paris. Not so in the provincial chateaus, where the great families of the old aristocracy now spend a considerable portion of the year. The shooting season brings visitors and consequent animation for a short time; but the simplicity of the usual home-life would astonish English preconceived ideas.

By the will of Robert Marshall, filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's office, the Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church in America, the Board of Foreign Missions of the same church, the Presbyterian Board for the Relief of Disabled Ministers and the Widows and Orphans of Deceased Ministers, and the Presbyterian Hospital will receive $5,000 each.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- It is hardly fair to assume that the taste of the Chicago public is for trashy dramatic performances, though the bills offered at the various theatres during the week just ended would seem to indicate such a condition of affairs, and the outlook for the coming week is no more promising. But one down-town theatre has presented an attraction which was conceived with any other purpose than to cause laughter.

MR. PRESIDENT AND GENTLEMEN: At the International Congress in London in 1881 Robert Koch demonstrated in King's College his (then) new method of cultivating microbes upon solid media. The illustrious veteran Pasteur was present at the demonstration, and at its conclusion exclaimed, "C'est un grand progres, Monsieur." How vast have been the extensions of our knowledge which have resulted from that great step in advance!

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27. -- Yale University is now in a very close contest with Harvard that is not in the usual line of Yale-Harvard contests. It is a struggle for first place in the point of attendance, and it seems that, as in all other contests, Yale will be the winner.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- If a certain Irish constable's baton had chanced to be a couple of inches longer on Thursday these succeeding fifty hours would have been quite sufficient time for the downfall of coercion in Ireland. By just that tiny margin John Morley escaped having his head laid open in the crush of a police charge in front of the Tipperary Court House.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The people remaining in the Catskills who are so fortunate as to be domiciled in farmhouses and boarding houses where grate and stove fires can be lighted have enjoyed themselves during the past week. Althought nights and mornings have been cool, bright sunshine has been the rule, and the views in the clear air delightful.

A FEW HINTS FOR COLLECTORS. -- A few hints of a general character may be useful to the collector whose knowledge has not yet been bought in the market of practical experience. Let him avoid, in the first place, a servile following of the fashion. Let him avoid giving an extravagant price for anything.

LONGEVITY. -- When the French Ministry some twenty-five years ago, issued a circular to all its Prefets making inquiries as to the conditions most favorable to longevity, all the reports agreed in naming a well-to-do condition of life as most important, if not quite indispensable. It should also be borne in mind that the most wonderful cases of longevity are almost invariably reported from countries where verification of the asserted facts is impossible.

The Republicans of Richmond County held their County Convention yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the German Club. Stapleton, S.L., and elected the following delegates to the Congressional Convention of the First District, on Oct 8: C.L. Hubbell, William Cole, L.C. Alston, J.L Daley, James P. Eddy, George Cromwell, John T. Furman, and Richard Tilson.

The conduct of the trial of the accused Nationalists at Tipperary confirms the explanation that suggested itself of their arrest. It is not to be supposed that Mr. BALFOUR or Lord SALISBURY had any personal malice against Messrs. DILLON and O'BRIEN. The arrests must have had their motive in some view of public policy, meaning party policy.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Cornell University will not open its doors until Tuesday next, but already many students have arrived and these, together with several hundred sub-Freshmen, make things very lively on the campus and in town.

LAKEWOOD, Sept. 27. -- Lakewood claims, with some right to the distinction, to be the great Northern Winter resort, with as much emphasis on the adjective as is consistent with the proper deportment of one so young. Certainly Lakewood now has a much clearer title to being the foremost of similar resorts than it had when the claim was first set up, and which is visibly more proper now than it was a year ago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The closing session of the week at the Stock Exchange was an active one, with the interest pretty equally divided between West Chicago Street Railroad, Canal and Dock, and Street's Stable Car Line. The first opened week at 134, buyer 30, with sales at 133 regular, and worked up gradually to 134 34 regular, with sales at 136, buyer 60.

FLOWERS, PERFUMES, AND INSECTS. -- Perfume serves to attract insects. Artificial flowers were attached to branches of trees by Nugeli; some of these he scented with essential oils; insects were attracted to these in an unmistakable manner, while others which he left unscented were almost neglected.

A GREAT DOG. -- The Newfoundland dog is a particular favorite of mine. He is the most magnanimous fellow in the world, and small dogs may insult him with impunity unless a river happens to be near, when one too venturesome and impudent will sometimes experience an involuntary bath.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Provisions at night, in spite of continued selling by Hutchinson, in spites of free receipts to-day, and in spite of big estimates for Monday, showed only a very slight decline. January Pork opened at $11.60 and closed at $11.55. May opened and closed at $12.15: January Lard opened at $6.42 12 and closed at $6.40 @ $6.42 12: January Ribs opened at $5.60 @ $5.62 12 and closed there.

Examination of the bill passed by Congress allowing service in the civil war to count as double time in making up the thirty years required for the retirement of enlisted men shows that it applies only to the army and marine corps, instead of to the navy also, as the language of the earlier report had suggested.

The most interesting thing is amateur athletics in the course of the last week, aside from the contests at Montreal yesterday to decide the Canadian championships, was the advent of the five English athletes who comprise She team sent to this country by the Salford Harriers of England. Their arrival in this city Wednesday, reported in Thursday's TIMES, created no little stir in athletic circles, awakening a new interest in international competition.

The readers of Armand de Pontmartin, faithful readers of the Gazette de France, founded in 1631, who heard his voice, were surprised. It was weak, thin, shrill, a voice to sing to a clavichord painted by Boucher, a "voix de vieille." The mind behind it was vigorous and sure of itself, because it was a mind well trained which was loyal to its trainor.

HARTFORD, Sept. 27. -- The reappearance of ex-United States Senator William W. Eaton of this city in the politics of the State is looked upon as a source of decided strength to the Democratic Party. The convention of the Democracy, which was held hers Sept. 16 for the selection of State candidates, was eminently an Eaton body.

It was announced a little time ago on high authority that blonde hair was going out of fashion. The right dye seems to have been a difficulty, and the difficulty in some cases seems to have been almost insurmountable. Those whoso taste for blonde beauty is incurably active will have their prejudices so far considered that mahogany color will be interposed between dirty yellow and the dark brown or darker brown of the future.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 27. -- The prospects of the Yale football team for this season have been changed somewhat by the decision of W.P. Graves, '91, not to return to college. Graves was one of the strongest and most experienced of the old players, but was not on the team last year on account of the injuries which he sustained in practice.

About the origin and prices of this valuable production from the queen of flowers the most fabulous stories used to prevail. People fancied it to he a product of India or Persia and valued it -- "every drop a ducat."

IS CHRISTIANITY IMPRACTICAL? -- The fundamental doctrine of the Christian life is love. The Christian millennium is peace. But it is Christendom that maintains the vast standing armies; and when the International Peace Congress meets in London this Summer and proposes disarmament, the good-natured reply of Christendom is: "Well -- yes -- perhaps -- some time," with a smile of amused incredulity, as when a child seriously asks for the moon.

THE HEBREW HELL. -- The names of hell in Hebrew are, according to a rabbinic commentator, seven. It is called Abaddon, or Destruction, according to Joshua ben Levi, in the passage "Shall Thy loving kindness be declared in the grave or Thy faithfulness in destruction?" (Psalm lxxxviii., 11.)

The practice drills of the engine and hook and ladder companies constituting the working force of the Fire Department were resumed last week for the season, and will be continued daily, except Sundays, until Nov. 1. Upon the results of these drills (which are to a certain extent competitive, inasmuch as all the companies must go through the same series of movements) will depend the standing and rating of the companies for 1890.

ORAL AND WRITTEN TRANSMISSION. -- Bishop Colenso lays very great stress on the numbers assigned by the Old Testament to the children of Israel on their passage through the desert, and observing on the practical difficulties which such a multitude must encounter on a march, treats the case as one which materially impugns the general credit of the history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,325,850, as follows: Currency 6s, $6,453,000; 4 1/2 per cents., $29,594,400; 4 per cents., $104,278,450.

Everything is collected nowadays. Books and paintings, bill posters and skulls, weapons and playbills, articles of clothing and musical instruments, furniture and bric-a-brac, autographs, paints, stuffed animals, coins -- there is no end to the list. Zoological, botanical, palaeontological, geological, mineralogical, anthropological, and ethnological collections are the natural and inevitable result of study and research.

John James Ingalls sits in the Vice President's chair behind the great polished mahogany desk. He is listening to the speaker carelessly, apparently, but whenever a question is asked him, his reply is quick and to the point. The heat and close atmosphere of the Senate Chamber produce but a slight impression upon him; he is cool and unconcerned.

THE FUTURE INFLUENCE OF WOMEN. -- It is well known that females are largely in excess of males in our existing population, and this fact, if it were a necessary and permanent one, would tend to weaken the selective agency of women, as it undoubtedly does now. But there is good reason to believe that it will not be a permanent feature of our population.

THE CLEVER LAGADO PROFESSOR. -- It will be remembered that in Gulliver's renowned travels he visited the Grand Academy of Lagado. The first professor into whose studio Gulliver was conducted had been for eight years engaged upon "a project for extracting sunbeams out of cucumbers, which were to be put in vials, hermetically sealed, and let out to warm the air in raw, inclement Summers.

LONG BRANCH, Sept. 27. -- All last night and all day to-day the political strife between the Democratic factions has been growing in intensity and bitterness. Ocean Township is flooded with circulars and posters issued by both factions, in which the dishonesty of both faction, in which the dishonesty of both is proclaimed.

EGYPTIAN OBJECTS IN WOOD. -- A special feature of all collections of Egyptian antiquities is the excellent preservation of the objects in wood. Not only are the tools and implements in almost the same state as when last used by the artisans or husbandmen, but delicate little articles for the toilet or for some ornamental purpose retain their carving in all its pristine freshness.

Mr. and Mrs. William Mosley Hall of 330 West Thirty-third Street last night celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. Their home, which was handsomely decorated for the occasion, was filled with a throng of friends, old and young, eager to express their good wishes and listen to stories from Mr. Hall's rich store of reminiscences.

WHY THE PARROT IS SO CLEVER. -- In India the jays and crows come together from many miles round to spend the night in company with the parrots in the bamboo thickets. When the parrots start hunting they display the most wonderful intelligence, prudence, and capacity of coping with circumstances.

The people of Grace Methodist Church on Jersey City Heights are discussing a letter sent to Mrs. Joseph Autenreith by the Church Official Board. The letter complained that Mrs. Autenreith's two daughters disturbed the public service by their conduct, and begged her to exercise her parental authority over them.

If Col. Hain, Manager of the elevated railroads, would put a phonograph in the elevator building at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Eighth Avenue, and after leaving it there for a Week would turn the crank, he would hear a medley of complaint more forcible than elegant from hundreds of the residents in that neighborhood who use the elevators to reach their trains.

The average Eastern man doesn't have any idea of this Western country. Eastern men are very much surprised when they come out this far and find that we look just like other people that they have met. They have an idea that we are living altogether in "dug-outs," and that it is not safe for one to venture fifty yards from his house without running big chances of being scalped before he returns.

Twenty-second Regiment troubles have latterly forced themselves to the front, to the exclusion of pretty much all other matters military. Under ordinary circumstances the proposed field day at Van Cortlandt Park, which the commanding officer of the First Brigade has arranged for the latter part of October, would command attention.

NYACK, Sept. 27. -- Notwithstanding the heavy rain yesterday, the annual fair of the Rockland County Agricultural and Horticultural Society ended very successfully at Spring Valley. The most important events of the day were the bicycle races, which were participated in by wheelmen from several well-known city clubs and some from other counties in this State.

Prosecutor Winfield of Hudson County yesterday confided to a reporter the interesting fact that he will move none of the indictments against the indicted election officers in Hudson County till after the approaching elections. The progress of these trials during the canvass was expected to be a great boom to the citizens' movement for the overthrow of the ring.

I have read with great interest the letters from your correspondent on the canalboats "Arbutus" and "F.H. Wilkens." They show a knowledge of the subject and call attention to some of the many abuses existing in the canal trade.

Secretary and Mrs. Blaine, their son-in-law, Walter Damrosch; Mrs. Damrosch, and Stephen B. Elkins breakfasted together at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday morning. They sat late at table. About 11 o'clock Mr. Blaine made his appearance in the parlor, where a number of people ware waiting to see him. Bernard Biglin was there, as were several other Republicans of greater or less importance.

Mott Street's Chinese residents had a pretty good time yesterday and last night. It would have been a very merry season, indeed, for Mott Street had the weather been clear, but as rain and clouds had things all their own way there were serious drawbacks to properly celebrating a festival which really requires a free and uninterrupted view of the moon to be successful.

The thousands of persons who lined Fourteenth Street last night from Third Avenue well-nigh to Sixth were those who had been turned away from the doors of the Academy of Music, where the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage was announced to speak. Early in the evening the rush began, and half an hour before the doctor arrived, with a escort of his Brooklyn parishioners, all the seats in the spacious Academy were filled.

The Senate's passage of its bill to advance Chief Engineer MELVILLE one grade, with resulting advantages of pay, and also to present medals to the survivors and to the heirs of the deceased members of the unfortunate Jeannette expedition, is a rather tardy tribute to memorable services and heroic endurance in the path of duty.

Mr. Robert C. Brown of 21 Murray Street, who is well known for the quality of his cigars, the delicacy of his humor, and the gentleness of his voice, is the victim of a misdirected kindness. While Mr. Brown is not a hotel man himself he is the intimate friend of every metropolitan boniface, and is generally regarded as one of the hotel set.

Among the passengers that came in on the French Liner La Bretagne from Havre yesterday was M. Quesada, a young native of Venezuela, who is a graduate of the College of the City of New-York, and who has been sent on by his Government as its Consul at Philadelphia. Several of his old college friends met him at the pier.

Dr. Prudden writes a plain and comprehensible book on "Dust," intended not so much for scientific persons as for the heads of families, who are, or should be, responsible for the proper maintenance of places of habitation. Ignorant man has for ages been considered as a stupid grumbler because he said "What is dusting?

The Fall and Winter season of lantern-slide exhibitions and experimental illustration of photographic subjects has already begun, though there yet remains a couple of months for active outdoor work with the camera. Some of the best pictures are obtained at this season, and often a good light accompanies the warm Autumn days.

County Clerk Edward F. Reilly died suddenly yesterday morning at 6:30 o'clock. So unexpected was his end that the first intimation of it will be given to many of his intimate associates by the newspapers this morning. He had been ill for some time, but until late Saturday night his friends were not seriously alarmed.

The Annapolis armor trial ended last Monday, and before the week was out Congress had appropriated $1,000,000 for the purchase of nickel ore and nickel matte to combine with steel in making plates for our new war ships. As the naval appropriations had already been made at this session, an outlay so large was a marked tribute to the success of the nickel-steel plate in the competitions.

The handsome three-hundred-and-fifty-thousand-dollar steel steamer Algonquin of the Clyde Line arrived in this city yesterday morning on its maiden trip fresh from the Cramp yards at Philadelphia. The steamer was launched July 19 and is now fully equipped for active duty. Capt J.W. McKee was in charge, and Mr. B.F. Clyde, with a party of fifty invited guests, was on board. Sixty men composed the crew.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 28. -- The machinery that is to construct a new Constitution for Kentucky is not moving as smoothly as a ball-bearing bicycle by any means, and, from present indications, in from four to six months' time an unsatisfactory job will be turned out by the convention that will in all probability be rejected by the people when it is submitted for ratification at the polls.

The Hebrew penitential season of Yom Kippur came to an end last evening, and with the setting of the sun the celebration of the great Jewish Feast of Tabernacles was begun in all the temples and synagogues. This is the thanksgiving festival of the Jews, and the services yesterday, which was the eve of the feast that is to be celebrated to-day, were very impressive.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Regarding the report of the dissolution of the Envelope Trust, Elisha Morgan, President of the Morgan Envelope Company, says that the trouble began a month ago, when some of the manufacturers were found to have violated their agreement by selling under the schedule of prices fixed by the trust.

A meeting of the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church of this city win be held next Friday evening to consider a letter of resignation from the pastor, the Rev. Richard D. Harlan. The call for this meeting was read yesterday morning. A few "knowing ones" expected it, but to most of the congregation the news that their pastor had written a letter of resignation was surprise.

The Cleveland Leader, which is regarded as the representative of Mr. McKINLEY, gleefully seizes upon something the sugar planters of Louisiana have said about the "decline in prices of sugar which will ensue upon the adoption of the new tariff," and triumphantly points to it as an expert opinion that "the McKinley Tariff bill is going to materially reduce the price of sugar."

The Brooklyn German Democratic General Committee held its usual Sunday meeting yesterday at Arion Hall, Wall Street, Eastern District. President Henry Fuehrer was in the chair, and Julius Reimann was Recording Secretary. About sixty delegates from the different ward clubs were present.

When an accident occurs on a railroad, in a factory, or elsewhere, one of the first questions is, Who is to blame? Often it is very important question to the corporation concerned, and always there is sure to be some anxiety, trouble, and annoyance before all the wounds are healed.

There will be so few peaches here this week that they will scarcely be noticed in the market. Most of the peaches now offered for sale are from California. They have the merit of not decaying very rapidly, and of making pleasing store decorations. They sell very slowly, few persons buying them more than once during the season.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Sept. 28. -- The war of the Bishops, which convulsed the Christian Evangelical Association of the United States last Winter and Spring, and resulted in the successive expulsion of all three of the rival Bishops -- Dubbs, Bowman, and Esher -- has taken on a new phase here in Pennsylvania.

The extension of time granted to the cattle men for removing their live stock from the Cherokee Outlet should silence complaints on their part. The notice that they must go by Oct. 1 was itself a long one; now they have two months more, it being required, however, that half of their stock shall be away by the end of the first month.

Against the entreaties and the warnings of his party friends, Senator PADDOCK adheres to his heroic resolution to vote against the conference Tariff bill because it retains the objectionable duty upon binding twine. The eyes of the country will be fixed upon the Nebraska Senator until the vote in the Senate has been taken, and if he falter not he will win the applause due to a courageous and creditable act.

TRENTON, Sept. 28. -- The special election on the proposed amendment to the State Constitution is to be held Tuesday. It needs to be generally understood that a vote for the amendment is a vote for the reopening of the doors to special legislation for cities. The ballots to be used at the election have been sent by Secretary of State Kelsey to every County Clerk in the State.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The News, commenting on the McKinley bill, says: "We are, happily, old hands in contests of this kind, and will not be driven by any provocation to the suicidal policy of resorting to either reciprocity or retaliation. The enterprise of our traders will find in one corner of the globe -- in Asia, Africa, or on the Continent of America -- more than sufficient to compensate for this incredibly foolish measure.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 28. -- A strong web of circumstantial evidence is being woven around Francis Lingo, who is now confined in the county jail here, on suspicion of having brutally murdered Mrs. Annie Miller near Merchantville on Thursday last. When questioned by Prosecutor Jenkins on Friday night after he had been arrested, Lingo denied positively that he had been near the woods in which the body was found.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The action of Congress in promptly authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to expend a million dollars in the purchase of nickel ore or nickel matte has placed the Navy Department in a position that will enable this Government to have a virtual monopoly of the use of nickel steel for armor plates and projectiles, so long as the supply is practically limited to the output of the Sudbury (Canada) Mine.

Mr. Augustin Daly's company of players, fresh from their successful London engagement, will open the twelfth regular season at Daly's Theatre, and the twenty-first of Mr. Daly's managerial career in New-York, Tuesday evening, Oct. 7. The plans of Mr. Daly are seldom allowed to be made known before he is ready for their publication, and those for the coming season are no exception to the rule.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Fowler Brothers' packing house at the stock yards was damaged by fire this morning, causing a loss to the amount of $690,000. The fire originated at 1:30 o'clock in the morning in the packing room or the engine room adjoining. The firemen worked against obstacles from the start. Water had little effect on the grease-soaked floors, and the fire soon reached the tank room, where thirty-two tanks of lard were stored.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 28. -- Henry W. Oliver was requested on Saturday to give his opinion of the new Tariff bill as reported from the conference committee and passed by the House. Mr. Oliver was a member of the Tariff Commission of 1882. In every battle over a tariff bill since and for years before, Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee have advised with him and given great weight to his judgment.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- There was a great surprise in store for the friends of Congressman Belden this morning when it was learned that the man whom they had yesterday opposed for the nomination for member of Assembly, William Kennedy, was an anti-Platt man and would not support that person. Mr. Kennedy says to-day that all his affiliations are with the Belden element of the Republican Party of this county.

In the House debate on the conference report on Saturday Mr. PETERS of Kansas, while criticising certain portions of the bill, "gave his adherence to its general features. He deprecated tariff agitation and expressed the wish that a law could be enacted making it a penitentiary offense for any member to introduce a bill for the revision of the tariff during the next ten years."

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- During the past week discount was in good demand and firm at 434 to 514. A prolonged period of dear money is expected. The increasing home currency requirements, if accompanied by a further drain of gold, will cause a further advance of the Bank of England rate. On the Stock Exchange business was restricted; the general tone was gloomy.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 28. -- The experiments with armor plate for the navy during the past week at Annapolis have been watched with close attention here, and the bill passed by the House on Thursday appropriating $1,000.000 to enable the Secretary of the Navy to purchase nickel ore or nickel matte for the manufacture of the nickel-steel armor is especially gratifying to a number of Northern Ohio capitalists.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 28. -- A special from Zanesville, Ohio, says: About 1 o'clock this morning a most disastrous freight wreck occurred on the Baltimore and Ohio, near Pleasant Valley, a short distance west of this city. Orders were given east and west bound freight to pass at Black Hand, but Operator Keelty at that place failed to deliver the order to the east bound train.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Bids were opened at the Treasury Department to-day by a committee of which Assistant Secretary Batcheller is Chairman for the sale of a site for the proposed new Appraiser's Stores in New-York City. There were six bidders, as follows:

William B. Curtis of the New-York Athletic Club returned yesterday from Montreal, where he acted as judge in the annual Canadian athletic championships decided Saturday afternoon. When interviewed by a TIMES reporter, Mr. Curtis said: "The feature of the meeting was the 120-yard hurdle race between H.L. Williams of the New-York Athletic Club and A.F. Copland, Manhattan Athletic Club.

The fifth annual Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg excursion to New-York, planned for Tuesday, Oct. 7, promises to be a very large affair. There will be eight special trains, and it is expected that between 2,000 and 3,000 pleasure-seekers will be brought to this city. The trains will all come to New-York over the West Shore Road.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 29. -- The most important feature of to-day's session of the National Prison Congress was the report of the Prison Committee, which was drawn up and presented by Warden A.A. Brush of the Sing Sing Prison, New-York.

Bishop Potter, assisted by many clergymen, yesterday afternoon laid the cornerstone of the new St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, which will stand on the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street. The procession which moved from the old church, beside which the new one is to be erected, was led by the vested choir, under the direction of W.O. Williamson, organist and choirmaster.

Mrs. Agnes Robertson Boucicault arrived in New-York yesterday on the Servia. She was dressed in deep mourning, but looked remarkably well considering the fact that she had arisen from a sickbed to make the voyage. Mrs. Boucicault has a sweet, motherly face, and there are many traces of her former beauty. She looks much younger than her age, which is fifty-seven years.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- A petition was filed in the Orphans' Court of this city to-day by the heirs of Benjamin Franklin, praying that the sum of $100,000 now held by the Board of City Trusts, and known as the "Franklin fund," be turned over to them, the ground for the claim being that the provisions of the will are in violation of the law, and therefore void.

Very quietly the Holland Society's agents have, during the past few days, been marking out the old landmarks and sites of buildings long swept away connected with the early history of New-York City. The task of pointing out the sites of these landmarks has been undertaken by the Holland Society, as noted in THE TIMES at the time the step was determined upon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29. -- Bright sunlight, with an Autumnal crispness in the air that sent the blood thrilling through the veins of every celebrant, were the accompaniments of the morning of the first day of the celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of the introduction into the country of cotton spinning by power by Samuel Slater, in the city of Pawtucket.
ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- From the monthly bulletin of the State Board of Health for August, just published, this statement is taken: ...

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. and Miss Greenleaf of Boston and Lenox gave one of the most enjoyable and successful germans of the season at the great Greenleaf cottage to-night. The house was beautifully decorated The great music room was decorated with palms and tropical posted plants. The great fireplace and mantel, the largest and most elegant in Lenox, were decorated handsomely with Autumn flowers and foliage.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 29. -- The little steam yacht F.L. Norton is now at the shipyard of the Pusey Jones Company, in this city, receiving the finishg touches preparatory to starting, early in November, upon what is generally con-considered a very hazardous, if not foolhardy, journey across the Atlantic Ocean.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Mr. John Morley spoke at St. Helen's to-night to a large audience. He gave a graphic account of his experiences during his recent tour of Ireland, referring particularly to the condition of affairs in Tipperary and to the scenes in which he himself took a personal part.

Congress met last December and the House of Representatives chose Mr. THOMAS B. REED its Speaker. That statesman has occupied himself ever since in overthrowing not only all the traditions of the House itself, but all the traditions of representative government. The docility with which his fellow-members of his own party have backed him up indicates that these persons do not expect ever to be in the minority again

Monday has generally been considered an "off day" in racing up to the present year. Now there do not seem to be any off days. People crowd to the race courses, rain or shine, and keep things lively, as well satisfied, so far as the regulars are concerned, to see a lot of selling platers run as to witness contests between the very best of the horses in training.

Had the Gloucester schooner Davy Crockett followed the memorable advice of the hero whose name she bears, probably she would not be in her present plight, with confiscation imminent. The offense with which she is charged in the Dominion courts is, as the dispatches state, that of violating the treaty of 1818 by fishing within the three-mile limit.
363 ADELPHI STREET, BROOKLYN, Sept. 8, 1890. William C. Wallace, M.C.:

There are reports abroad that the Western Union Telegraph Company is seeking to influence the nomination and election of members of the Assembly in this State, with a view to securing legislation in favor of refunding the taxes paid under the corporation tax law prior to the amendment which limited the tax on capital stock to the amount employed within the State.

The answer of Mr. DELAMATER and of the Republican organs of Pennsylvania to Senator EMERY'S charges is that Mr. EMERY is a "Mugwump" and his charges are "malicious lies? As a refutation of the charges this answer seems to lack completeness, but it is easy to make -- far easier, of course, than detailed examination and disproof.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept., 29 -- Lewis M. Griffin, a prominent tobacconist here, was found dead in his bed this morning with a bullet hole in his skull and a revolver lying by his side, one chamber of which was empty. Mr. Griffin had committed suicide, caused, it is supposed, by ill health. He was a widower of thirty-eight, an was well connected and leaves property worth probably $50,000 or $60,000.

If there is a failure of the Democratic organizations of the city to unite in the nomination of candidates for Congress and the Assembly it will be due to Tammany's supercilious treatment of the County Democracy's offer of a conference on the subject. Instead of being accepted, it was turned over to a sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee, which has nothing whatever to do with local nominations.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 29. -- The Shenango Valley News, one of the most influential Republican papers in Mercer County, carries the Republican State ticket at the head of its editorial column, and leads the next column with these reasons why Republicans should oppose Senator Quay:

There seems to be no doubt that a successor to County Clerk REILLY will have to be elected at the regular election of the present year, the vacancy in the office being filled until Jan 1 by appointment of the Governor. This is the fair interpretation of the various provisions of law bearing upon the question.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept 29. -- The long-pending contest between the Blodgett and Abbett factions for political control in Monmouth County ended in the Democratic County Convention here to-day. It was evident before the convention met that the Blodgett men would take possession of it, and this they did, but not without a struggle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Unless the Democrats are making one of the most secretive of "still hunts" to capture the Fifty-second Congress, the opinion is justified, that is frequently expressed here by Democrats of undoubted earnestness and zeal, that there is no "hunt" whatever in progress, and that if the next Congress is to have a Democratic majority it will be there by act of Providence and not by political management.

The outrageous conduct of the magistrate, SHANNON, in insisting upon his right to sit in judgment on his personal enemies, is resented, as strongly as justly, by the defendants arraigned before him. Their remonstrances will probably not have any effect. From a political point of view it is to be hoped they may not.

One-half of John H. Shults's Parkville trotting stock was sold at auction yesterday at Parkville, L.I. Although there were hundreds of bidders, representing the best stables of the country, it was eminently a breeders' day. The prices were fair, but not high. They ranged between $190 for Katie Robinson and $7,600 for Edith R.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Chief of Police Hopper received information this afternoon that John Keen, a resident of Plane Street, Newark, had committed suicide Sunday night in the Van Dyke House, a Bowery lodging house, in New-York. Keen's story is an unusually sad one. He had five little sons and daughters under twelve years of age at his neat home in Newark.

The following was the only sale effected a the Exhange and Auction Room yesterday, Monday, Sept. 29: Richard V. Harnott Co. sold, by order of the Sheriff, three six-story brick buildings, with plot of land 127.2 by 100, 1,230 to 1,240 Amsterdam (10th) Av, northeast corner of 75th St. for $75,000, to A.L. Spencer.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29. -- Senator Vest came to the city this morning, and to-night he formally opened the State Democratic campaign by delivering an orthodox Democratic speech before a large audience. In an interview he said he believed the McKinley bill would be signed, and that it was bound to strengthen the Democratic Party.

Detroit's champion amateur team defeated the New-Jersey boys at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the contest for the amateur championship of the United States is even. The Detroits and New-Jerseys have each won a game. Yesterday's contest, like that of Saturday, was marked by brilliant playing and the visitors won by their superior work in the latter part of the game.

Mr. HENRY W. OLIVER of Pittsburg has returned to that city from Washington, where he "was in consultation," the Philadelphia Press says, "with the framers and managers of the new Tariff bill," who "advised with him and gave great weight to his judgment." We published yesterday morning his opinions as to that measure.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 29. -- The Prohibitionists in this State will nominate candidates this year in each of the Congressional and Senatorial districts and a Judge of Probate and a Sheriff in each county. In the Second and Fourth Congressional Districts the nominees have already been selected, C.M. Whitmore of Meriden being the candidate in the Second and Lyman D. Baldwin of Plymouth in the Fourth.

DUBLIN, Sept. 29. -- The eyes of all Nationalists continue to be fastened upon the court at Tipperary, where Messrs. Dillon, O'Brien, and their fellow-prisoners are undergoing trial on the charge of conspiring to prevent payment of rent to Mr. Smith-Barry, landlord, of Tipperary.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 29. -- Political Portland was all stirred up to-night by the news of the appointment of Col. F.N. Dow to the office of Collector of this port. Col. Dow was supported by the two Maine Senators and by Mr. Blaine, while Speaker Reed and his friends gave their active support to the Hon. Weston Milliken.

Col. Elliott F. Shepard, a member of the Union League Club, came upon a Great Truth yesterday, and printed it in his evening newspaper on the page that is read, because it is amusing, and is opposite the page that bears the Colonel's tips on the races. High up above his leaded wisdom it ran in this way:

It is possible that Mr. PADDOCK will not stand alone on the Republican side in opposition to the conference committee's Tariff bill, for the fact that the Northwestern Senators agreed that a bill placing a duty on binding twine should not have their votes appears to have some weight in Washington.

When the Atchison secured control of the Colorado Midland it was generally expected that another big deal would follow that. Now the news comes from Chicago that the Atchison has secured an option on the Rio Grande Western, running from the terminus of the Colorado Midland and Denver and Rio Grande at Grand Junction, Col., to Salt Lake City and Ogden, Utah.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Onondaga County Republican Committee organized this afternoon, and by its action an out-and-out Belden man was chosen for Chairman, a victory of much note over Senator Hiscock and the machine. Hiscock and his lieutenants have taken it upon themselves for many years to name the officers of the County Committee, and so to have the handling of the campaign funds.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- The following is a list of the companies in which Fowler Brothers whose Stock Yards were burned Sunday morning, were insured:

Some unusual phenomena were observed by Capt. John Newman, commanding the bark Kelvin, during his recent cruise in the East Indies. On his voyage from Singapore to New-York his track lay through Sunda Strait, which separates Java from Sumatra, and through which passes a large portion of the trade of China, also most of the trade of Batavia and other ports in the Java and China Seas.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Sept. 29. -- This was the last day of the trial of John Reginald Birchall, who was charged with the murder of F.C. Benwell, in Blenheim Swamp, in February last. Preliminary to the speeches this morning some evidence was taken.

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- Rumors are floating in from all over the State that the Western Union Telegraph Company is manifesting the greatest interest in the nomination of candidates to the Assembly, and that in some districts promises of a pecuniary character have been held out to certain men in expectation of their assistance at Albany during the forthcoming session of the Legislature for the notorious Western Union Tax Grab bill.

Edward Lauterbach, one of the Directors and the legal adviser of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, yesterday explained to a TIMES reporter the object of the company in proposing to issue $10,000,000 of stock. He said it was coming to be considered a better plan for the financial management of large corporations to have as small a sum in fixed charges to pay annually as possible.

With the full choral service and imposing ritual of the Episcopal Church, Bishop Henry C. Potter, assisted by the Right Rev. G.F. Seymour, Bishop of Springfield, Ill.; Archdeacon Smith, the very Rev. Dr. Fairbairn, President of St. Stephen's College; Dean E.A Hoffman of the General Theological Seminary, and the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Hoffman, the rector, consecrated the new Episcopal Church of All Angels, corner of Eighty-first Street and West End Avenue, yesterday morning.

LOUIVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30. -- Col. Zeb Ward, one of the most prominent citizens of Arkansas, and Scott Newman, Jr., a local politician, were indicted by the Jefferson County Grand Jury yesterday on charges of swindling the city on a granite contract. The indictments charge the obtaining of money under false pretenses and obtaining the signature to the City Treasurer's warrant, on which the money was paid or to be paid, on false pretenses.

In the course of his excellent speech on the Tariff bill Mr. CARLISLE pointed out yesterday that in the sections which are commonly supposed to contain provisions for reciprocal trade Congress empowers the President to retaliate upon our own people whenever certain foreign Governments shall do certain things.

The Board of Directors of the New-York Central Railroad met yesterday, listened to the reading of a report for the nine months ended June 30, and declared a quarterly dividend of 1 per cent., payable Oct. 15. The financial statement for the quarter ending Sept. 30 (partly estimated) shows gross earnings, $9,130.000; operating expenses, $6,254,674; net earnings, $2,875,325; interest charges, $2,082,000; profit, $793,325; dividend just declared, $894,283; deficiency, $100,957.

" Col." Elliott F. Shepard woke up yesterday morning to find the town talking of the evidences of eccentricity which he gave on Monday. He devoted half a column of space to an ingenious attempt to prove that the newspapers which had criticised his breach of good faith and good manners in publishing his notice about the suspension of members of the Union League had been actuated by a desire to injure the club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- An effort is to be male before Congress to increase the working force of the Inter-State Commerce Commission by the appointment of Deputy Commissioners, who are to be placed in the large railroad centres like Chicago, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Kansas City, St. Paul, Denver, Galveston, and San Francisco. The points at which it is deemed necessary to locate deputy Commissioners include over twenty cities.
WOODSTOCK, Vt., Sept. 30. -- The Hon. Frederick Billings, ex-President of the Northern Pacific Railroad, died at 10 o'clock this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Only the President's signature is now lacking to make the Tariff act of 1890 the law of the land. The final vote on the adoption of the conference report was taken in the Senate late this afternoon, and when the Vice President announced that the vote stood 33 in the affirmative and 27 in the negative the long contest was ended.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- At the Cobleskill Fair to-day J.J. Curry admitted that the tariff tax was levied upon certain imports for the purposes of government. The Government is supported by the tariff and internal revenue, which have produced a surplus which it was the duty of the Government to reduce by law. The McKinley bill does this.

Surrogate Ransom yesterday handed down a decision refusing to admit to probate the will of Thomas J. Monroe, better known as the "Harlem Hermit," Mr. Monroe died Jan. 15, 1889, at the age of seventy-four, leaving an estate valued at about $500,000. By his will his entire estate was to be received by George O. Grennell, who had acted as his attorney and confidential adviser.

ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- The State Court of Claims convened in its Fall term shortly before noon today. The hearing was continued on the claim of John Snaith for $40,000 as a balance which he claims is still due him from the State on his contract to replace the Assembly ceiling. Deputy Attorney Generals Maynard and Hogan appeared for the State, and Counselor Frothingham for Snaith.

ALBANY, Sept. 30. -The State Board of laUroad Commissioners has granted the application of the Rookaway Village Railroad Oompany for leave to susnend the operation of Its road from Nov. 1, 1890, to May 15. 1891.

DUNELLEN, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Eight thousand clay pigeons were smashed by the marksmen at the opening of the Middlesex Gun Club tournament to-day, and 20,000 will be shot at to-morrow. Besides the many that have been broken, several score have been missed, for the springs of the traps in use on the grounds are of the strongest, and even the best marksmen are puzzled at the speed of the frail, but artful artificial birds.

Nothing could have been more fortunate for the cause of home rule in Ireland than the presence of Mr. JOHN MORLEY during the disturbance at Tipperary. We will not go so far as to say, with one or two of the Liberal London newspapers, that it would have been fortunate if Mr. MORLEY'S own head had been broken by the random and promiscuous clubbing of the police.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Contracts amounting to nearly $15,000,000 will be divided up between two or three shipbuilding made as a result of the bids to be opened in the office of the Secretary of the Navy to-morrow, for the construction of armored battle ships Nos. 1, 2, and 3, of 9,000 tons displacement each, and protected cruiser No. 12, of 7,500 tons displacement.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 30. -- Ex-Congressman S.B. Dick of Meadville passed through Pittsburg this evening on his way East. "Through the Northwest it is Delamater we Republicans are after," said Mr. Dick. "Delamater is a man who believes the end justifies the means and he will go to any extreme to accomplish his purpose. He is utterly unscrupulous.

The hearing by Justice Lawrence in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday of the application for a writ of mandamus compelling the Police Commissioners to appoint County Democrats as inspectors of election, dividing the Democratic appointments between Tammany Hall and the County Democracy, for nearly two hours turned the court room into a political stamping ground.

The campaign contributors' Tariff bill now goes to the President for his signature, which will speedily be affixed to it, and the favored manufacturers, many of whom -- as Mr. OLIVER, the trusted adviser of the two committees with respect to the most important schedule, admits -- proposed and made the rates which affect their products, will begin to enjoy the profits of this legislation.

The Providence and Stonington Line have reduced their fare to Boston and all points East, beginning with to-day. The present passenger steamers of the Providence Line will make their last trip for the season Saturday, Oct. 4, after which the steamer Massachusetts will take her place on the Stonington Line, leaving New-York from Pier 36 North River Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday, in connection with the Narragansett.

The Boston Journal mendaciously informs its readers that the law under which United States Supervisors of Elections are appointed for the city of New-York this year is "practically the same as that law which Democratic orators have grown red in the face with denouncing and against which Democratic papers have shrieked as a 'Force bill.'"

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 30. -- The United States Naval Academy will begin its forty-sixth scholastic year to-morrow. The academy was founded in 1845 by the Hon. George Bancroft, Secretary of the Navy, in the Administration of President James K. Polk. It was formally opened Oct. 10 of that year under the name of the Naval School, with Commander Franklin Buchanan as Superintendent.

MOUNT MORRIS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- A brutal and unprovoked murder was committed in the principal street of this village last night. William Joslyn arrived here yesterday morning from Mount Clemens, Mich., to visit his daughter. At about 10 o'clock last night, while standing in front of the Scoville House conversing with two gentlemen, a gang of half a dozen roughs came along and attacked him, knocking him down and kicking him brutally.

The excuse which the Police Commissioners have had for failing to appoint matrons to have supervision of female prisoners at the police stations during the present year has been that no funds were provided for the purpose in the appropriation for the department.
