The excuse is somewhat lame, as authority to make the appointments was given by the Legislature more than two years ago and no appropriation for the purpose has ever been asked for.

ATCHISON, Kan., Sept. 30. -- An extraordinary exodus of people from Western Kansas is taking place on account of the crop failure. The rush is so great that the railroads have sent agents into the country to work for business. All who can buy an outfit travel overland, while others take passage on the railroads.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 30. -- The enforcement of the anti-lottery law is now going on at the New-Orleans Post Office. Major Eaton got tired of waiting for an official notification of the enactment of the law or instructions how to enforce it, and so he had an interview with the United States District Attorney, talked with Inspectors Sharp and Sullivan, and straightway devised his own plans.

The Democrats of Westchester County believe that if the proper men are nominated they can capture two of the three Westchester districts in the next Assembly. They regard the First and Second Districts as belonging to them, but waive the Third for the reason, as they say, that it is impossible to defeat a combination headed by two such powerful Republicans as Chauncey M. Depew and Gen. James W. Husted.

It is announced that Lieut. L.N.B. WYSE has obtained from the United States of Colombia an extension of the time for completing the Panama Canal, probably adding six years to the present concession, which ends in 1892. Meanwhile the commission of engineers appointed by the liquidator of the Panama Canal Company has made its report upon the condition of the enterprise.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The Provision pit was to-day enlivened by the covering of a considerable short line put off about a forthnight ago by Singer. About 10,000 bbls of Pork and 5,000 tos of Lard were covered at about the same figure at which they were originally said. The line a week ago showed considerable profit. This week's small Hog movement advanced prices until this profit had all disappeared.

The Guion Line seamer Arizona started for Queenstown early yesterday morning with these persons among her saloon passengers The Roy. and Hrs. A. H. Ewing, the Roy. and Mrs. H. D. Griswold, the Roy. and Mrs W. H. Hannum, Franklin Hailer, the Roy. J. M Irwin, the Roy. Father Matthew, and Capt. E. Why-, burn.

Ex-Mayor Hewitt was not at Chickering Hall yesterday morning to call the American Institute of Mining Engineers to order for its second day's work, so Vice President Eckley B. Coxe of Drifton, Penn., performed that duty. Many others followed Hr. Hewitt's example in staying away. There were not 150 men at either session, though there are about six hundred American and foreign gentlemen in town supposed to be here for the special purpose of attending.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Who colored women employed in the Moorestown Canning Factory went on the warpath Saturday with such terrible earnestness that two men nearly lost their lives at their hands.

FREEHOLD, Sept. 30. -- After-convention echoes indicate that the troubles of the Monmouth Democracy have only begun and are ominous of disaster to the ruling as well as the dissenting faction of the party. The bad blood between the Abbett and Blodgett partisans which had been simmering for two months previous to the convention reached the boiling point yesterday, and there are no signs to-day that the temperature has decreased.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30. -To-day was chtF dren's day at the Inter-State Fair, and the public schools were closed to enable the pupil to attend. Fully '20,000 people were on the grounds, and many special features were presented.

The story that the Oliver Wolcott was to be ordered to Oonalaska with directions to seize vessels engaged in sealing within Behring Sea, has perhaps derived some plausibility from the Ottawa dispatches that several Victoria "poachers" are to make a second trip, the Triumph having already sailed for that purpose.

Seldom in the history of the city of New-York has a more truly representative assemblage been gathered together than that which attended the funeral services of Gen. Abram Duryee in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Lenox Avenue ad One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, yesterday. The attendance of military men intent on honoring his memory was almost without precedent on any similar occasion.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 30. -- The campaign in Iowa is now fairly on. Both State Committees have had their headquarters hare open for soma time, with a force of clerks busily engaged in writing letters, receiving reports, and mapping out the work for the local organizations. On the part of the Democrats the speaking campaign will be formally opened by the great tri-State rally at Keokuk, Oct. 4.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 30. -- The three Republican papers of this city all make editorial comment on the appointment of Col. Dow as Collector. The Advertiser this evening criticises the appointment as follows:

Perfect racing weather for this season of the year, a crowd numbering about ten thousand people, and seven good races were the features of the cloning day of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's meeting. In spite of unfavorable weather and other adverse conditions, the meeting has been a thorough financial success, as well as a success from a sporting point.

Between 7,000 and 8,000 persons attended the Westchester County Fair at White Plains yesterday. Awards of premiums were made in many of the departments. Among the first prizes awarded were the following:

The political resolutions of the Baptist Assembly in London are more significant than perhaps they seem to most Americans. The real strength of the "Unionist" movement in England -- the whole strength, it may be said, of Liberal Unionism -- is the religious prejudice of English Protestants against Irish Catholics.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 1. -- An athletic meeting was given here to-day on the grounds of the Detroit Athletic Club by the Detroit and Manhattan Athletic Clubs and Salford Harriers of England. Two thousand people witnessed the contests, and about $1,200 was taken in at the gate. The English athletes did not show up in very good form.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Mr. George S. Batcheller of New-York, who has been an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury since the beginning of the Administration, has been confirmed as Minister Resident and Consul General to Portugal, to which he was yesterday appointed by the President, and he will leave here for his post at Lisbon after the usual time allowed for instructions.

The real convention of the iron and steel men of the Old and New World who took part in the sessions of Monday and Tuesday, held under the auspices of the American Institute of Mining Engineers, began yesterday in the annual meeting of the Iron and Steal Institute of Great Britain. The session was held, as the others have been held, in Chickering Hall.

The favorable report made by the House Committee on Commerce upon Mr. COVERT'S bill to authorize the construction of a tunnel under the waters of New-York Bay between Middletown, on Staten Island, and New-Utrecht, on Long Island, is the first step toward the consummation of that measure, and probably the others will be duly taken.

The Republican County and Assembly conventions in Queens County were held in the Town Hall, at Jamaica, L.I., yesterday, and were largely attended. The County Convention was called to order by Edward Dowling, and William J. Youngs of Oyster Bay was made Chairman. Charles A. Stearns of Long Island City was nominated for District Attorney; Joseph E. Frith of North Hempstead received the nomination for County Treasurer.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The second installment of Michael Davitt's revelations concerning the dynamite plots will be published to-morrow. It deals largely with the exploits of McDermott, (Red Jim,) tracing his movements from the time he left New-York.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1. -- The Republican managers held a secret conference here this afternoon to consider the outlook for the campaign. The most remarkable feature of the meeting was the absence of Hartford representatives of the party. Only two Hartford men, Charles H. Lawrence of the State Central Committee and ex-Congressman John R. Buck, were admitted to the conference.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 1. -- This has been a most interesting day in Lenox. The Duffers' Tennis Tournament has been going on all day, and the prospects are that Mr. Burden will win. The cottagers and members of the Lenox Club have been out in force to see the games on the Lenox Club courts.

The mighty discord of shrieking steam whistles that sent echoes up and down the valley of the Hudson yesterday at noon were the welcoming salutes for the new steamer Plymouth of the Fall River Line, one of the largest boats, and in many respects the best of her kind in the world. Yesterday was the day fixed for the engineer's trial trip.

Gen. Mark D. Wilber of Brooklyn, who, as a representative of the Reform Club, has been engaged in a number of the tariff discussions which have taken place at New-York county fairs, was in Brooklyn a day or two ago and gave a reporter of THE TIMES some account of the discussions in which he had participated.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- In a leading editorial Col. A.K. McClure, editor of the Times, will say to-morrow:
The following 39 w9.8 trn-nsAe,tod at the ]xchange and Auction Boom yesterday, Wednesday oct. 1.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1, -- The annual town elections in this state, with the exception of the towns of New-Haven and Bridgeport, will take place Oct. 6. The principal officers to be elected will be the members of the Board of Selectmen, Town Clerks, Collectors, Assessors, and Boards of Relief. The choice of Justice of the Peace has been carried over, under the law of 1889, to the November election.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 1. -- The National Prison Congress adjourned to-day to meet in Pittsburg in October, 1891. The feature of to-day's session was the address by T J. Chariton, Superintendent of the Indiana Reform School for Boys, on "The Similiarity of Reformatory and Prison Work."
CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- It was given out officially to-day that J.F. Goddard is to be Commissioner of the Trunk Line Association in the place so long held by Albert Fink.

GARDINER'S BAY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- The glitter of the new cruiser Philadelphia does not appear to be all gold. Having managed to disable her machinery twice on the run from Philadelphia to New-York, her departure from that port for final speed trials was delayed several days by another mishap. Now a defect in the steam steering gear will deter the cruiser from giving an exhibition of speed over the official course.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 1 -- The carrying capacity of nearly all the Canadian railways is being taxed to the utmost in the mad desire of Canadian exporters to escape the provision of the McKinley bill. The barley shipments from Ontario during the past month have been enormous. Prices have advanced from 50 to 75 cents a bushel since the 1st of last month.

The disappointment experienced in the recent voyage of the Baltimore to Sweden and in that of the Charleston just before from Hawaii to the Pacific coast teaches a lesson which other nations long ago learned. Neither of these vessels exceeded an average of eight knots. Yet the Charleston at her maximum should be good for between eighteen and nineteen knots and the Baltimore for between nineteen and twenty.

With the end of September the anti-Socialist law in Germany has expired by its own limitation, having been in existence and more or less in operation for twelve years, for it was passed in 1878. At first its duration was limited to less than three years, and it is upon the whole fortunate that it was extended.

Mr. Sothern's first extra matinee at the Lyceum Theatre yesterday afternoon attracted a throng composed principally of ladies that filled the house to the doors, and "Standing room only" was announced before the curtain rose. These extra Wednesday performances of "The Maister of Woodbarrow" are to be continued throughout the Sothern engagement.

Edward F. Reilly was buried yesterday with ceremonies such as rarely attend the funeral of one so young. Not the political body alone of which he was so conspicuous a member, but his neighbors and personal friends as well paid the last formal tribute of respect and affection in imposing numbers.

With the incoming of the Fifty-first Congress the Republican Party found itself for the first time in several years in control of both houses and of the Executive department of the Government. The use it has made of its power during the long session just closed gives the Democratic Party an opportunity such as it could hardly have hoped for to appeal to the people for renewed confidence and support.

VIENNA, Oct. 1. -- The Emperor of Germany arrived here this morning. Emperor Francis Joseph, accompanied by Archduke William and Archduke Renier, met him at the railway station. The greeting of their Majesties was affectionate. Among those present at the station was the Burgomaster of the city, who received Emperor William's thanks for the warmth of his reception.
There was a decided increase in the attendance at Dundee Park yesterday. Five races were decided, and, with the exception of the opening event, the favorites were beaten. The results were as follows:

The American Institute's opening last night was attended by all the success that its promoters could have wished. The entire building was filled. Many of the exhibitors have not yet completed their displays, but they were all at work last night and the booths will be thrown open to-day in all their old-time attractiveness.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- There is much speculation here to-night over the discharge of seven well-known employes of the New-York Central Railroad. They are men who have long been in the service and have held responsible positions. As they do not belong to the Knights of Labor, all are puzzled as to the cause of their discharge. The order is said to have come from New-York.
ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Gov. Hill has appointed Gen. Roger A. Pryor to succeed Judge Larremore in the Court of Common Pleas. Judge Larremore's resignation took effect to-day.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- At least 4,000 people assembled at Pre-emption Park Fair Grounds this afternoon to listen to a tariff debate between the Hon. William E. Russell, ex-Congressman from Massachusetts, who spoke for tariff reform, and W.W. Curry of Indiana, the exponent of Chinese-wall theories. Curry spoke first and was listened to with studious attention.

Since France and Holland have very sensibly concluded to settle the question of boundary between French Guiana and Dutch Guiana by arbitration, the Emperor of Russia consenting to act as the referee, why should not England and Venezuela resort to the same method for settling the disputed boundary of British Guiana? The three Guianas have experienced many changes of ownership.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 1. -- The plans for the Hillsborough County Court House, which is to be built in this city, have been completed by the architect, J.A. Wood of New-York City, and those who have examined them say that if they are followed the result will be a building which will be graceful in outline, beautiful in design, substantial, and serviceable.
" We are assembled because we are not satisfied with the Municipal Government of the city of New-York and because we reside in New-York."

Marshall Ayres, to whom the commission firm of Sawyer, Wallace Co. assigned, yesterday filed the firm's schedules in the Court of Common Pleas. With the schedules were also filed the schedules in the individual assignments of Samuel A. Sawyer, Thomas Miller, and David L. Wallace, who composed the firm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The article in THE TIMES of to-day upon the necessity for more activity on the part of the Democrats, if they expect to win a majority of the elections in the Congressional districts, has attracted the attention of many Democrats at the capital, and the necessity for heeding its suggestions is freely admitted.
The racing at Morris Park will be continued to-day, the entries and weights for the several events being as follows:

The first session of the Fifty-first Congress expired yesterday in an uncommonly tame and uneventful fashion. It simply "petered out." The Senate spent most of its time in executive session and in taking recesses while the odds and ends of business were being gathered up by the clerks. In the House there was no quorum, and nothing of consequence could be done without unanimous consent.

Members of the Democratic-State Central Committee of Connecticut who have lately visited New-York have expressed themselves as thoroughly satisfied with the outlook for Democratic success in the Nutmeg State. They say that the McKinley tariff law will materially injure Connecticut manufacturers, and that the latter are strongly arrayed on the side of the Democracy and tariff reform.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1. -- The managers of the Republican campaign in Minnesota would feel much more comfortable these days if they could accurately estimate the real vote that will be given the Alliance State ticket. The uncertainty in this respect is causing the State Central Committee and the candidates more worriment than any other one thing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The minority of the special House committee appointed to investigate the charges against Pension Commissioner Raum -- Messrs. Lewis and Goodright -- have united in the preparation of a report setting forth their opinion of the results of the investigation.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry appeared in Albany to-day in yachting costume. He left his yacht Electra at Poughkeepsie and came up by train to preside over a State convention of humanitarians composed of delegates from the several societies for the prevention of cruelty. The convention lasted all day and resulted in the formation of a State organization which is to hold a convention in Albany once a year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Bids were opened at the Navy Department to-day for the construction for the Navy of three coast-line battle ships and one protected triple-screw cruiser, provided for by act of Congress approved June 30, 1890. There were two classes of bids for the battle ships, one for their construction according to department's plans and the other according to the bidder's plans. The bids were as follows:

The Detroit and the New-Jersey Athletic Club baseball teams met again yesterday for the third time. The New-Jerseys won. Of the three games played the New-Jerseys have taken two. They have only to win one more game to be the amateur athletic baseball champion of the United States.

Altogether, fourteen books have been returned to the Mayor's office from the police census takers so far and the total number of names received is 13,891. The books were receipted for by Secretary Speer and the names were counted by several persons. W.H. Olcott, the special agent of the Washington Census Bureau, watched the proceedings in the Mayor's inner office.

There is something like consternation in the offices of the Appraiser and the Board of General Appraisers over the fact that the newly-enacted Tariff bill is to go into effect next Monday. No copies of the act, official or unofficial, had reached either office yesterday, nor had either office received official information that any change in the tariff laws had been effected.

Although the proselyting work of the Church of Latter-Day Saints goes steadily on, as occasional arrivals from Europe of flocks of its dupes remind us, yet one of its pillars is certainly tottering. The proclamation recently put forth by the octogenarian President of the Mormon Church admits that the days of polygamy are already numbered.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- Miss Eleanor Hardy, daughter of Mr. Alpheus A. Hardy of Chestnut Street, and Mr. Denis Bunker, the well-known artist of New-York, were married in Emmanuel Church to-day by the Rev. Leighton Parks.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- To-day was the greatest one in the history of the Inter-State Fair, and more than forty thousand persons were present in the afternoon. It was politicians' day, and well-known men from all over the State paid their respects to Gov. Leon Abbett of New-Jersey and Gov. Biggs of Delaware, who held a reception in the afternoon. Nearly every office holder and almost every candidate in the State was here.

A meeting of workingmen was held at Clarennon Hall last evening to extend moral and financial support to the striking cigarmakers of Binghamton. Samuel Gompers made a speech and two young women from Binghamton took up a collection. Resolutions expressing the sympathy for the strikers of those present and calling upon the Governor "to exercise his judgment and power in the premises" were adopted without dissent.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The Democratic Convention for the nomination of a candidate for Congress from the Fifteenth District was held here this afternoon. The convention was composed of twenty-eight delegates from Orange, fourteen from Sullivan, and fourteen from Rockland. Ex-Assemblyman W.H. Clark of Orange County presided.

The card for yesterday's races at Morris Park was not a particularly brilliant one, yet it had sufficient drawing power to induce about 6,000 people to make the trip to the track. The feature of the day's sport was the race for the Woodburn Handicap, at a mile, in which seven horses accepted the weights and made the contest for the purse.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Oct. 2. -- This was a day of extreme excitement in the Legislature, the occasion being the consideration of the bill for the permanent location of the Territorial capital. The lower house yesterday passed the bill locating the capital at Oklahoma City. Before action had been taken on the bill in the upper house a motion in the lower house to reconsider the action of yesterday was adopted.

DUNELLEN, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Excitement over the tournament of the Middlesex Gun Club is running so high that the marksmen have grasped the opportunity offered to extend the tournament another day, and have arranged for one of the biggest sweepstakes on record. It will take place Saturday, beginning at 10 o'clock in the morning.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- The campaign in Ohio and the Sixteenth Congressional District, now represented by Major McKinley, was opened to-night by the Democrats at a monster meeting, at which Gov. James Campbell made an address. The Governor was tendered a reception at the residence of the Hon. John Sherrick, and afterward was escorted to the Tabernacle, which was filled by several thousand people.

It is now a settled fact that the Brotherhood people have agreed to purchase the Cincinnati Club, and representatives of the new organization are in Cincinnati for that purpose. The price asked at first was thought to be too steep, but after mature consideration the Brotherhood people decided that they wanted Cincinnati in the circuit and they do not propose to allow dollars and cents to stand in the way.

The attendance at the Westchester County Fair at White Plains yesterday was larger than on any previous day. There were about 10,000 persons present. The weather was excellent and some of the races were very close. Among the awards were the following:

" I have no reply to make to any criticisms of any newspapers regarding the course of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee," said Congressman and Chairman Roswell P. Flower yesterday afternoon. Mr. Flower had just returned from Washington, and a reporter for THE TIMES had questioned him concerning the charges of inactivity so generally preferred against his committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The Princeton supporters have been trying to find out for some time what Capt. Poe thinks of Princeton's prospects in football and what men will constitute the team, but all his answers are unsatisfactory and by no means confident of victory over the "blue." He says there is rather a dubious outlook, since only four of last year's team have returned to college.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. Oct. 2. -- A man known as T.J. Henderson died yesterday afternoon at the house of a Mrs. Pannell, who owns a little farm near the city. Before he died he confessed to her that he was Charles William Quantrell, the famous Missouri outlaw, who was supposed to have been killed in a fight with Federal soldiers in Kentucky near the close of the war.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The "sectional war" in passenger rates in which the Rock Island, Santa Fe, and Missouri Pacific have indulged for some time past, was brought to a close to-day. At a meeting of representatives of a number of Western lines an agreement was reached, canceling the troublesome roundtrip rates from Kansas City, the States of Kansas, Nebraska, and Colorado to Chicago and return.

Richard Croker yesterday declared that the adjournment of the People's Municipal League convention showed that the leaders of the anti-Tammany forces were disorganized, and that they could not bring about a union that would have a fighting chance. This is what he declared in public, but as a matter of fact the Tammany leaders were very nervous yesterday.

We are sorry to see that the Hon. HENRY CABOT LODGE of the Sixth Massachusetts District has returned from Washington in bad temper. He made a speech at the convention that renominated him at Lynn on Wednesday evening, and he wasn't sweet. Here is one passage from his speech:

RANKIN, Ill., Oct. 2. -- Congressman Cannon does not mean to let the Republican press of his district bolt his nomination without feeling the weight of his displeasure. The editor of a small paper published in this town is suffering for his independence. He excited the wrath of the Cannon bosses, and they have sent the fiat forth that the paper shall be suppressed.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 2. -- Collis Lovely, the labor leader who left the convention held in Philadelphia recently by Mr. Rynder to nominate himself the Union Labor Party's candidate for Governor, was to-day shown an attack made upon him by Frank Buch, a Rynder man of Philadelphia, and extensively printed in the Quay organs.
BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- The annual address of Mr. George William Curtis last evening gave the note of the sentiment of the Civil Service Reform League at its meeting to-day.

Col. F.K. Hain, Superintendent of the elevated railroad, thinks that he has "got square" with the people in the vicinity of Second Avenue and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street who permit their neighbors to bring suit against the road and recover $12,000 for damages to property by the propinquity of a convenient station. If the station is a nuisance, argues the Colonel, it will be taken away.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- A train robbery occurred this morning on the Cincinnati, Sandusky and Cleveland, between Carey and Urbana. Immediately after the train left Urbana two masked men, with cocked revolvers, entered the express car and compelled the Adams Express messenger, A.L. Scadder, to throw up his hands. They then tied him securely and robbed the safe of packages containing several thousand dollars and other valuables.

Here is a circular which, though it bears date Oct. 1, was not issued until yesterday afternoon. No employe of the New-York Central Railroad Company who is a Knight of Labor will need to read between the lines to discover its meaning:

James Toner, aged forty-one, of 7 Charlotte Street, Boston, a disbarred lawyer, was shot and probably fatally wounded, in the Boston Hay Market yesterday, by John Gazzolo, an Italian. Toner was executor of the estate of Charles Gazzolo, a brother of John, and between the latter and Toner there had been bad blood for some time, owing to the latter's alleged mismanagement of the estate.

The adherents of the straight Republican ticket project presented their case to the Republican County Convention, which assembled in Webster Hall, on East Eleventh Street, last night. Their orators were accorded a most respectful hearing. Their utterances were received with sufficient applause to show that they had a very good sprinkling of followers in the body of delegates, who, as a whole, were overwhelmingly opposed to the straight ticket.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 2. -- A.J. Parker, '91, is the winner in the preliminary tennis tournament at Yale, and he will assist the college champion in the intercollegiate tournament which will begin in this city next Monday. He defeated Fowler, '91, in the finals, the score standing 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 0. Parker is an expert player and a strong rival of Champion Huntington.

The iron and steel men who are here attending the international congress of their own and kindred industries had a busy time yesterday. About a hundred of them got up very early, and after breakfasting joined an excursion under the charge of Mr. J.B. Mackintosh to the plant of the Consolidated Gas Company, at Twenty-first Street and Avenue A.

About one hundred and forty members and guests of the Electric Club sat down last night to the first of the Fall and Winter series of dinners given by the club in its comfortable quarters, 17 East Twenty-second Street. Senator Plumb had intended to be present, but at the last moment he sent his regrets by telegraph.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Republican Congressional Campaign Committee is not relying upon a "still hunt" to win the elections of members of the Fifty-second Congress. On the contrary, the committee is working with all its might, and without any special care to hide the fact, with the expectation of letting everybody know that there is to be an election, and that the Republicans expect to carry it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- N.O. Murphy, the Acting Governor of Arizona Territory, has filed with the Secretary of the Interior his annual report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1890. He says that he is unofficially informed that the eleventh census places the population of the Territory at 57,600, exclusive of Indians and military reservations, and with those who live on reservations (not Indians) the population of the Territory will probably exceed 60,000.

John Gibb, the merchant who resigned from the Kings County Republican General Committee a week ago because he could not stand the McKinley bill, returned to town yesterday, and was questioned in regard to his sudden departure from the Republican Party. He was not very much inclined to talk, and would not admit that he was really out of the party for good.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 2. -- The Independence Belge says that the McKinley Tariff bill insures the failure of the World's Fair at Chicago, as it will be a needles and hopeless expense for Europeans to send exhibits there.

In accepting the long vacant post of chairman of the Trunk Line Commission, Mr. J.F. Goddard did not accept any divided authority. His scope of authority will be fully equal to that exercised by Albert Fink, covering both the freight and passenger departments, but it is not likely that the duties of Mr. L.P. Farmer, the Chairman of the passenger department, will be curtailed.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Oct. 3. -- The excitement over the capital location, which reached its climax yesterday, continued to-day. After the demonstration against Messrs. Daniels, Perry, and Nesbit last evening had subsided, S.R. Mitchell, City Attorney of Oklahoma City, sent this telegram to one of his friends at home: "Your representatives were mobbed on the street to-day. Send 100 armed men."

The award of one of the battle ships, under this week's bidding, to the Union Iron Works of San Francisco, and of the other two and the protected cruiser to CRAMP SONS of Philadelphia, has been decided upon. The latter firm presented the lowest bids for two battle ships, while for one ship the Bath Iron Works of Maine, now building two 1,050-ton gunboats for the Government, was next lowest.

The first number of the Ballot Reform Weekly, a journal devoted to the interests of voters, was issued last Tuesday. The paper is published by the Manual Publishing Company. TIMES Building, and is edited by Joseph C. Ryan. Judging from the initial number, it will be of great value as a means of instructing voters in all the minutiae of the new ballot law.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- In response to the invitation of the Young Men's Republican Club, Speaker Thomas B. Reed came to New-Haven this evening and spoke to an audience which filled the Hyperion. There was little that was new in his speech, and not much enthusiasm. One-half of his auditors were Democrats who went to the Hyperion to see what sort of a looking man Reed was. Among other things he said:

For the first time in the memory of the court officers several members of the Grand Jury for September as they were discharged for the term yesterday broke into applause, and for the first time in many years the majority of the members of the Grand Inquest brought in an indictment in direct opposition to the advice of the Recorder and District Attorney.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3. -- The venerable historian, George Bancroft, is to-day quietly celebrating his ninetieth birthday at his home.

The opinions of Mr. JOHN E. SEARLES, Jr., Treasurer of the organization commonly called the Sugar Trust and a gentleman thoroughly acquainted with the sugar refining industry and tariff legislation affecting it, furnish an interesting commentary upon the attitude of Mr. HISCOCK in the Senate Finance Committee toward the sugar duties and upon the appeals of the so-called independent refiners of Philadelphia.

Brooklyn's League team had very little difficulty in defeating its opponents from Pittsburg yesterday. It was a loosely-played game. The Pittsburg made a dozen errors and little Pinkney distinguished himself by making four misplays at third base. After the third inning, when the Bridegrooms took the lead, it was evident that they could win as they pleased.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The Lincoln Independent Republican Committee, which comprise among its members a number of eminent preachers, this evening issues an address to the clergymen of the State, saying:

The tangle in which Behring Sea diplomacy has become involved is matched by the new complications in supplying the market with seal furs. Last year the catch of the Pribylov Islands was about double that of the Copper Islands, on the Russian side of the sea; but this year the result has been reversed, the Russian islands yielding about three times as many as the American.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- The Democratic State Central Committee has decided upon a short and sharp campaign in preference to one covering several weeks, and the mass meetings of the Democrats will not begin until about Oct. 20. This will give the party about two weeks during which speakers of national reputation will be heard.

New-York can contemplate the present extremely unpromising aspect of the World's Fair with equanimity and even with gratitude that it is exhibited in Chicago. There is really no reason for supposing that we should have done much better with it. We should probably have had a site much sooner than a site was determined upon at Chicago, but the present squabble, which suspends all preparations, would have been as likely to occur here as there.

Any division that may exist among the Democrats of this city upon municipal questions ought not to interfere with union in support of candidates for Congress. The Democratic position with reference to national affairs is more clearly defined and more solidly supported by the party than it has been for many years past, and Congressional elections should be determined entirely by national issues.

The sale of the Klamath River Reservation, which was provided for shortly before the adjournment of Congress, will settle a controversy which has lasted a long time. The reservation was set apart thirty-five years ago. Afterward, Congress made a new plan, for placing the Indians of California upon four reservations in that State, permitting any existing lands occupied by them to be used, if deemed expedient, under this new plan.

A story of the Jack Sheppard or Claude Duval type was told at Police Headquarters yesterday morning by Charles Pape, a dealer in men's furnishing goods in Ninth Avenue. Late Thursday morning a pale, seedy-looking man entered Mr. Pape's shop at 114 Ninth Avenue and asked to have a five-dollar bill changed.

Some of the Republican stump speakers in the West are already urging the people not to study "the details" of the new tariff law. "It is not at all necessary, as ex-Gov. OGLESBY suggests," says the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, "for the people to make an analytical study of each particular provision of the new Tariff bill in order to decide upon its real and substantial merits.

One of the newspapers misquoted Wheeler H. Peckham's address at the People's Municipal League's Convention last Wednesday night, making him appear to say that pilfering from the city treasury had jumped from 10 per cent. to 75 per cent. under the present Tammany administration. Mr. Peckham's remarks about the asphalt pavement contracts were also mixed up in the report.

John E. Searles, Jr., Treasurer of the Sugar Refineries Company, says that he has no doubt that the effect of the McKinley Tariff bill will largely increase the business of the Sugar Trust, inasmuch as the removal of the duty on raw sugars will reduce the cost of sugar to the consumer very nearly or quite 2 cents per pound, and the tendency will be to stimulate consumption.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The Republican State Central Committee to-day elected W. J. Campbell to the place on the National Committee made vacant by the resignation of Col. George R. Davis. There were two announced candidates for the position, and one other who received some votes on the first ballot.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The indefinite postponement of the big one-hundred-dollar-entrance fifty-live-bird sweepstakes was a great disappointment to the participants in the Middlesex Gun Club tournament, and especially to those who had planned to take part in the event. Elliott, the live-bird champion of the United States, had hoped to compete in this affair with the champions of other States.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The Democratic Assembly Conventions will be held next week, when all the Assemblymen are expected to be renominated, as follows: Aaron E. Johnson in the First District, William D. Campbell in the Second, and Charles H. Ivins in the Third.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The error by which Section 30 of the Tariff act passed by Congress was left out of the law signed by President Harrison may prove annoying to the Republican manager in districts containing large tobacco manufacturing concerns.

DUNELLEN, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The sixth annual tournament of the Middlesex Gun Club came to an end to-night. For the first time in the history of the club the weather has operated against success. Torrents of rain fell last night, the 2,000 pigeons left after yesterday's live-bird sport were drenched in their coops, and 400 of them were killed by the water.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday once more listened to arguments on the application of the County Democrats for a mandamus to compel the Police Commissioners to appoint one-half of the Democratic election inspectors from the County Democracy. W. Bourke Cookran had filed a return to the petition, asserting that the Police Board intended to do its whole duty and preserve the rights of the people by appointing non-partisan boards of inspectors.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The excursion rates on the mountain-climbing railroads have attracted much travel to the Catskills.

There was a little trouble at the dock of the Clyde Steamship Company at the foot of Roosevelt Street Friday afternoon, of which some exaggerated reports got into circulation. The steamer Cherokee was to sail for Fernandina, Fla., and the reports had it that a strike of her firemen delayed her departure for several hours. As a matter of fact, it was not much of a strike.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Princeton College students had a night off in Trenton last night. At about midnight the police were informed that a party of young men in ulsters were tearing down business signs on State Street, and a squad of officers was sent out. The policemen soon returned with six young men, who gave their names as Piersall Humphrey, James L. Jones, George S. Tryson, James H. Dorr, J.T. Jenkins, Samuel Smith.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The corrupt practices of Gov. Hill's lieutenants in political matters covering a period of several years past pale into insignificance when compared with the movement now on foot to steal every election district in this city. The Common Council, which, with the Mayor, numbers twelve Democrats and three Republicans, appointed inspectors of election for every district in the city regardless of any right of the minority.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- Niagara rejoices to-day over the commencement of the tunnel which, by the development of power that it will bring, will place her in a position to be rightly termed the "Manchester of America." The first sod was lifted at 10:42 o'clock this morning by C.B. Gaskill, President of the Niagara Power Company, the implement used being a nickel-plated shovel.

PAYMENT IN KIND. -- Richard de Betonye was the representative of the City of London in the Parliament held at York by King Edward III. in 1828 . Taking a fancy to a certain coverlet furred with maniver, valued at eight marks, which had come somewhat mysteriously into the possession of the City Fathers, he was allowed to take it in part payment of the expenses he had been put to in his parliamentary capacity.

The Count of PARIS has shown good sense and good taste in separating his visit to this country absolutely from contemporary French politics. There are not wanting evidences to show that it would be possible to organize a more or less imposing French royalist demonstration in New-York if he would permit himself to be made the object of it.

THE STAGE IN SHAKESPEARE'S DAY. -- An Englishman visiting Venice about 1605 wrote in a letter from that city: "I was at one of their playhouses, where I saw a comedy acted. The house is very beggarly and base in comparison with our stately playhouses in England; neither can the actors compare with us for apparel, shows, and music."

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 4. -- The Trinity football eleven came down here to-day evidently determined to beat Wesleyan or lay up all the team. Wesleyan won by a score of 12 to 5, after one of the roughest games ever played here.

The Republicans of the Twenty-fourth Assembly District were to have nominated candidates for the Assembly, for Aldermen from the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, and for Commissioner of Street Improvements last night; but they did not do it. The convention called for the purpose to meet in the Melrose Turn Hall, in Cortlandt Avenue, near One Hundred and Fiftieth Street, was called to order, with about twenty persons present, and Edward Healey was installed as Chairman.

The Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee of Maryland should be called upon to prove certain statements which appear in his address to the voters of his State. One of the most glaring misstatements which he makes is in reference to the bayonet bill, concerning which he says: "It is claimed by some that it is a Force bill, substituting bayonet for popular will.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 4. -- The college year opened last Thursday with the largest attendance in the history of the institution. The Freshman Class numbers 78, and several have entered the upper classes, making the total number for the year about 250. The Faculty has, during the Summer, revised the entire course of study and made some important changes and additions.

" Nine people out of ten," said a well-informed real estate man yesterday, "would probably be willing to bet off-hand that the most costly building in the city is below Chambers Street. The splendid improvements in down-town property within a few years quite justifies this popular impression. The most expensive building in the city -- excluding, of course, Federal and municipal buildings -- is the Central Park Apartment Company's property, known as the Navarro flats.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- All other topics of public interest in the British Islands have been dwarfed by the news of how America, with characteristic energy, has set to work to raise money to fight famine in Ireland. Every one you meet talks about it and is moved by it in some way to wrath if he be an admirer of Mr. Balfour's, and to joy if he likes humanity better.

These are the days when, under cover of effusive greetings, every woman stealthily inspects every other woman's gown, seeking for ideas worth reproduction. In these stolen glances the sleeves are, this Autumn, the first noted, owing to the considerable measure of curiosity current as to whether they are to be a more or less conspicuous feature of the costume than heretofore.

A good many circulars are finding their way into public scrutiny nowadays from as many different sources, announcing new prices for various commodities that have for many years been without change. In all cases these "new" prices are synonymous with higher prices, and the inevitable reason that is assigned is the McKinley bill.

Some of the Tammany drillmasters who are engaged in training voters in the use of the ballot under the new law are telling them that if they cannot read and write they may swear that they are physically disabled from preparing their own ballots, and will then be allowed to take a friend into the compartment to do it for him.

It is estimated that fully 2,000 additional seamen will be required in the navy before one-half of the new ships now building are ready for the pennant. This may be news to the navy as a whole. It is the realization of what several prominent naval officers have considered a foregone conclusion for some time. The strength of the naval establishment is at present 10,000 men.

That our transatlantic kinsmen form a majority of the annual visitors to Stratford-on-Avon, to the birthplace and mausoleum of Burns, and other literary shrines in the old country, is a circumstance which should be recorded to their praise. Americans, it appears, are almost the only persons who think it worth while to visit, in still semi-rural Highgate, the last resting place of Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

THE TIRESOME DEBATE. -- People are fond of asking why nobody reads the debates now. The answer is simple. They have read them all before. And what is still more to the purpose is, that our Parliamentary orators have spoken them all before. The future is discounted as well as the past repeated by these hard-pressed disputants.

HARTFORD, Oct. 4. -- Trinity defeated the Amherst Agricultural College team 30 to 0 last Saturday. The football management have the following dates fixed: Oct. 4, Wesleyan at Middletown; Oct. 11, Wesleyan at Hartford; Oct. 15, Yale at Hartford; Oct. 18, Amherst at Amherst; Oct. 25, Williams at Williamstown; Oct. 29, Amherst at Hartford; Nov. 4, Cornell at Hartford; Nov. 11. University of Vermont at Hartford; Nov. 13, University of Rochester at Hartford.

Miss Marion Gasguoine Haines, daughter of the Hon. S.A. Haines of Netherwood, N.J., was married yesterday noon to Mr. Constantine P. Ralli, son of the late P.C. Ralli, Esq., of London, England, in the Church of Our Saviour at Netherwood. The Rev. Dr. George R. Vanderwater, rector of St. Andrew's Church, Harlem, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. S.P. Simpson of Netherwood.

When Benjamin Harrison was a Senator from Indiana he lived at 1,013 Fifteenth Street and afterward at 825 Vermont Avenue. The first is a plain residence facing the stable belonging to Representative Hitt of Illinois and the second is an equally unpretentious brownstone boarding house opposite the Arlington Hotel.

M. Mermeix might as well cease writing his "Coulisses du Boulangisme," but he has promised sixteen articles to the Figaro, and the end is not yet. He has succeeded in discrediting Boulanger and the Comte de Paris, and, so far as they are concerned, he is simply flogging a pair of dead horses, not to say asses.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- The discussion which has been conducted by the newspapers here on the question of the admission of American pork into France is dying out in a measure, and that topic is now being replaced by general denunciations of the McKinley Tariff bill. The more important journals on the side of the Government seem still to be not unfriendly to the withdrawal of the decree of prohibition against American pork.

Montaigne was grateful that he lived in a century which was "not soft, languishing, or unoccupied." Erasmus was a prince in it, loved, envied, hated, condemed, with all the activity of that extraordinary epoch. A calm judgment of him then was not to be expected. There were no critics; there were only friends or enemies. M. Feugere counted in 1874 thirty-nine works before his own devoted to Erasmus.

During the past week the various classes have filled up, almost all the students having removed their conditions and re-entered their classes. The total number in the college at present is about 210, and the membership of the Stevens School is much larger than usual.

A week ago, in the face of an extraordinary bank statement, the market closed weak and drooping. The bear party said if it could not hold up when the evidence was presented that the money stringency was over, there was no help for it. But on Monday morning it was found that the market was oversold. This appeared from the active borrowing demand for stocks in the loan crowd.

Mr. Klauser's book will be extremely interesting to all who have studied harmony and the theory of music. In some respects it is one of the most satisfactory works on the structure of music with which we have ever met. All students of the tone art are aware of the difficulties which surround the early steps along the path of harmony.

The writer of the series of essays in the North China Herald on "The Natural History of the Chinese Girl," to which reference has already been made, has some interesting observations on divorce in china and its consequences to the wife. Chinese law, he says, recognizes seven grounds for the divorce of a wife -- childlessness, wanton conduct, neglect of husband's parents, loquacity, thievishness, jealousy, malignant disease.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 4. -- The death of Elias C. Boudinot in this city Saturday removes one of the most conspicuous men of the Cherokee Nation and of the five civilized tribes. For thirty years he has been the most intelligent Indian in North America.

Although dullness prevailed in the real estate market during the last week there were signs of activity in isolated cases, which served to encourage dealer in the hope that, after all, the season may be redeemed and that business may be done in the course of the next two months which shall in part atone for the inactivity which has rendered the offices of brokers very dreary places of late.

THE JEWS AND THE BOOK. -- The Jews, perhaps exclusively among the early peoples, distinguished broadly between the matter and the corporeal form of a book, between its soul and its body. They alone conceived the idea of using the material form of the words and letters as an instrument for insuring the conservation of the contents.

HOW AN OCEAN CABLE IS MADE. -- Let us first see what a submarine cable is and how it is made. To do this a visit must be made to the enormous factory on the banks of the Thames, a few miles below London. Here the birth of the cable may be traced through shop after shop, machine after machine.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- The Democrats of the Sixth Congressional District have set all precedents in their State aside, gone out of their territory, and nominated Dr. William Everett of Quincy, the well-known independent, against Henry Cabot Lodge. Their action was taken this afternoon in convention at Charlestown unanimously and by acclamation, after a stormy debate which lasted about an hour.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4. -- Harvard played her first important football game of the season on Jarvis Field to-day against Dartmouth, and won it by a score of 43 to 0. The Harvard eleven was made up as follows: Rushers -- Cumnock, (Captain,) Upton, Heard, Cranston, Blanchard, Newell, and Lee; quarter back -- Dean; half backs -- Corbett and Lake; full back -- Trafford.

A TRUE STORY WITH A MORAL. -- It was on a west-sid block up in the thirties that a red flag floating from one of the brownstone houses about ten days ago caused a flutter of excitement among the housekeepers of the neighborhood, and in particular in the breast of a pretty little matron who lives directly opposite 41, where the danger signal was hung to the breeze.

DENVER, Oct. 4. -- The Glenarm Hotel was taken possession of by the Sheriff yesterday, Mrs. G.H. Stanton and Miss Le Stine Connors, who opened it two years ago, charge Clerk H.C. Meckel with being the cause of their failure. Meckel has vanished, and experts are trying to unravel his marvelous system of bookkeeping. Mrs. Stanton says the amount of his defalcation will never be known, but it must be very large.

Dr. Thomas Hunter of the Normal College addressed a very large gathering of teachers at a meeting of the "School of Pedagogy" at the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, adjoining the University of the City of New-York, yesterday morning. Dr. Howard Crosby will address the same body on Saturday morning next on "The Teachers in Politics."

Prof. H.J. Messenger, Jr., has been succeeded as Associate Professor of Mathematics by Prof. D.A. Murray of Dalhousie College, Canada, and Johns Hopkins University. Prof. W.K. Gillett, a graduate of the university, takes his place as Professor of French and Spanish, this chair having been vacant since the death of Prof. Charles Carroll, in February, 1889.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- If the National Civil Service Reform League were the organization of a political party it would not be formidable. Its friends could not hope, its opponents need not fear, much from it. The league is composed of all the State and local associations, the members of which are invited to the annual meeting. In theory the votes are taken by associations -- one to each.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, Oct. 4. -- The different societies of Rutgers College are taking in new members from the Freshman Class very rapidly.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 4. -- The Berkshire Hills in October have always been her most attractive card, and the Autumn of 1890 is no exception to the general rule. The frosts have painted the landscape earlier than usual this year, and the golden and red leaves of the forests on every hand seem, somehow, to have more of a charm than ever.

OTTAWA, Oct. 4. -- The political destiny of the Dominion continues to occupy the attention of the Canadian press. Since the Quebec Telegraph declared for annexation with the United States, Government newspapers are considerably agitated over the annexation spectre and declare that treasonable utterances should not be tolerated in a British colony. A controversy is now being waged from Halifax to Vancouver.
BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The lapse of the anti-Socialist laws has led to a renewal of the discussion regarding Emperor William's attitude toward the Socialist question.

" ALL ENDS IN MIRE." -- Rousseau was a compound of "mysticism and sensuality"; no law was sacred to him but the gratification of instinct. He grafted every virtue upon a vice. He treated adultery as one of the fine arts, and abounded in theatrical sentiment while forwarding his children to the Foundling Hospital, duly as they arrived.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4. -- Again this university town has awakened from the sleepiness of vacation time and Harvard has begun her two hundred and fifty-fifth year. Never were the prospects for a successful year in every way brighter. An increased number of students, increased corps of instructors, and increased facilities of all kinds make the outlook a most cheerful one.

So soon are men forgotten when dead that it seems proper here to recall the fact that the subject of this memoir was for fifteen years repeatedly in the public eye, here as well as in Great Britain, as an English clergyman under repeated prosecution for ritualistic practices. Mr. Mackonochie had become engaged in such an inevitably losing contest that the result was to be foreseen long before it came.

THE UNDERFED BRITISH SOLDIER. -- Recruits when they join the army first cannot be too well fed; because, coming as they do from a class which, as a rule, is irregular in its habits, after undergoing a regular system of drill and a regular manner of living, they are more hungry at meal times than they otherwise would be.

OHINEMOTU. -- Here are the first hot springs in New-Zealand, and wonderful things indeed they are. Waters bursting and boiling out of the bowels of the earth, throwing themselves in transport many feet into the air, and falling back to the ground in a shower of diamond drops that glint and glimmer against a dark and steamy pillar of fog.

The sterner sex is not commonly supposed to take much interest in the "higher education" of the softer. The reason of course is that the male of our species values the female as he finds her companionable and agreeable to himself, and it is very doubtful whether in most cases her attractiveness in this respect is increased with an increase of intellectual culture beyond a certain point.

A PERFECT GORGE -- ECCLESIASTICAL. -- A lavish entertainment was, according to quaint old Thomas Fuller in his "Church History," provided in 1470 by "George Nevill, brother of the great Earl of Warwick, at his installment into the Archbishopric of York.

Some astute observers of local politics were wondering yesterday if W.J.K. Kenny, Supervisor of the City Record, was not being considered by the Tammany leaders as a possible candidate for County Clerk, to fill the vacancy left by the death of Edward F. Reilly. The theory that Tammany might put Mr. Kenny forth as their candidate was base on the excellent record that is claimed for Mr. Kenny as Supervisor.

ADVICE TO WOMEN WHO STUDY ART IN PARIS. -- Whether the lady students of the present will develop later into being such excellent artists as their precursors have proved to be in the past is a moot question. The Julian and Collo Rossi system has caused most of the best-known artists to close their ateliers again to women.

On account of the several injunctions that have been served upon the Trustees of Union Free School, Port Richmond, by Mr. John Decker, the Tax Collector has been unable to collect the school tax and the Trustees find themselves without funds to pay the teachers or purchase books and stationery.

WHORLS. -- It is passing strange to find Dr. Schliemann's now celebrated "whorls" figured and described in an old treatise as the broutia, and ombria of old. The brontia fell with the thunder, and the ombria in tempest and rain without thunder: otherwise they were identical, and had all the properties of the toadstone, the belemnite, and the serpent's egg: parrying the thunder and neutralizing poison.

ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- State Entomologist Lintner recently received from a Gouverneur lady an interesting parasite on the common house fly. "It is not uncommon to find half a dozen on a single fly," the sender writes. They are exceedingly small, being no larger than the puncture in a piece of paper by a small-sized pin point, yet they are seen readily because of their light vermilion color.

The sun is now hastening southward at highest speed through the sign of the Scorpion, as though anxious to get rid of so unpleasant a companion, a fact only too apparent as gradually-decreasing daylight and an increasing chilliness of the atmosphere tell us that we have the colder half of the year to pass through before we can again welcome him north of the equator.

CHAMELEONS. -- Chameleons of one species or another can generally be seen in the reptile house at the Zoo, it being a rare event for the society to be without one -- at the present time they have no less than eight. But they attract but little attention from visitors, and indeed are not very interesting-looking animals, as they sit stolidly on the plants provided for them in their cases, generally without moving.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 4. -- The indignation meeting held to-day to protest against the nomination of the Democratic county ticket without Ewing Patterson being on it for County Clerk was a dismal failure. Only about twenty-five men took part in the meeting, while there were about one hundred spectators, chiefly Republicans, who had gone in to see the fun which it was expected would occur.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- After a most successful engagement of three weeks the J.C. Duff Opera Company has left. The big Auditorium will remain deserted until Thursday night, when Eduard Strauss will commence a brief season. The Duff engagement has been all that the most captious critic could ask in the line of Gilbert and Sullivan operas, and has been a success financially.

An ardent admirer of the United States is Sir Ambrose Shea, Governor of the Bahamas, who has passed the last few days in this city. Sir Ambrose is a typical Englishman -- tall, well proportioned, and wearing a look of health which amply supports his declaration that life in the Bahamas is very delightful. He is apparently about sixty years of age.

My attention having been called to an open letter addressed to the Press, under date of Oct. 1, by one of the late enumerators, allow me a few words in reply. Mr. Messenkope asserts that I must have lacked energy, as he, Mr. M., had accomplished his task in less than the given time. But Mr. M. fails to give us one important item, viz., the number of persons he enumerated in that time.

Three steamships sailed for Europe yesterday, the Eider, Servia, and Ethiopia, carrying about 260 passengers, and three, the Gallia, City of Chicago, and Werkendam, arrived, bringing 475 first cabin passengers. The lists in full are given below:
" What becomes of all the old corks?" asked a stout man the other day as he leaned idly against the bar of a down-town restaurant and lazily sucked a mint julep through two long golden straws.

The humane societies of this State have accomplished an incalculable amount of good in the past. and the community owes them a debt of gratitude. If their officers have occasionally been called to account by the press and public for the exhibition of a surplus of mistaken zeal in some directions, this fact in no way detracts from the merit of the general work of the societies.

SHERBROOKE, Quebec, Oct. 4. -- Upon resumption this morning of the trial of Remi Lamontagne for the murder of Napoleon Michel, Leda Michel, widow of the murdered man and sister of the prisoner, again refused to testify. The court ordered her return to jail and that she be brought down Monday morning, when, if she still refuses to testify, sentence for contempt of court will be passed upon her.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Rain and fog had a bad effect on the attendance at the athletic sports, in which the representatives of the Salford Harriers of England and the Manhattan Athletic Club of New-York contended with members of some of the local clubs. No records were broken, but the races were, on the whole, fairly fast and well contested. About five hundred people were present.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 4. -- Another electric horror occurred this morning a few minutes after 8 o'clock on the roof of the building at the corner of Camp and Gravier Streets.

THE BARD OF HOPE. -- Mary Russell Mitford, when writing to her father in 1809, said, "I would give ten years of my life to write 'The Battle of Hohenlinden." When Washington Irving visited Abbotsford in 1817, Walter Scott told him that Campbell did not think much of "his glorious little poem of Hohenlinden," calling it "a drum and trumpet sort of thing."

PRICE OF A GOOD-QUALITY WIFE. -- As for the "money' in use among the Solomon Islanders themselves. Mr. Coote gives a curious account. It consists of strings of shell-beads about the size of shirt buttons, well made, and strang in fathom lengths of two kinds -- "red" and "white" money. This is the base of the currency, above which come dogs' teeth, which are the gold of their coinage.

The Western Mail, an English newspaper, a few weeks ago said: "We are able to state that a powerful syndicate has been formed for the purpose of taking steps to open up a new route between England and America. The name of the syndicate is the North Canadian Atlantic Railway and Steamship Syndicate, Limited, its Chairman being the Right Hon. Sir Henry A. Isaaes, Lord Mayor of London.

Senator John H. Mitchell of Oregon is going home for the first time in thirteen months. He left Oregon in September, 1889, and, owing to the long session of Congress, has not been able to cross the continent since.

ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- From 75,000 to 100,000 farmers, probably two-thirds of whom are Republicans, heard an abundance of sound tariff reform doctrine in the course of the Reform Club's county fair campaign just closed. The courageous tons assumed by the Reform Club's speakers in the early meetings of this campaign as preserved throughout.

THE READY-MADE ANECDOTE. -- It is remarkable that, since his death, so little has been heard of Delane. In his day he was quite one of the great men of London, and doubtless a life of him would have been written ere this, were it not that the Times objects to the publication of matters relating to its private affairs.

ON BOARD UNITED STATES FLAGSHIP PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- It would be difficult to find a more vivid illustration of naval progress than is afforded by the new steel cruiser Philadelphia when taken in comparison with the wooden steam frigates and corvettes of our navy. The contrast between the two is as sharply drawn as black and white.

Recorder SMYTH'S rebuke of the Grand Jury for finding an indictment against his advice, after they had applied for it, is doubtless deserved. Nevertheless, it does not present the whole case. Nobody can read the conspiracy section of the code and then read the published accounts of the persecution of the brickmakers Verplanck's without being brought to the conclusion that this action is prohibited and made punishable by that section.

During the National Encampment in Boston an old comrade with silvery hair was led into the Cyclorama of Gettysburg by a bright-faced little miss. The old man sat down, while the child described to him the features of the picture. Occasionally he asked her a question, and slowly shook his head as if in doubt of the accuracy of her account.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 4. -- The Rev. K.B. Glidden, who has occupied the pastorate of the Congregational church at Mansfield Centre for the past twenty-two years, has resigned. He is one of the most prominent clergymen in Eastern Connecticut, and has represented the town of Mansfield in the Legislature.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 4. -- At a meeting of the Philips Club the following-named officers were chosen: President -- W.B. Segur; Vice President -- F.W. Lakeman, '92; Secretary -- Barnard, '91; Treasurer -- Hall, '94. The Executive Committee consists of Lakeman, '92; Gunnison, '92; R.L. Doring, '91, and W.W. Eaton, '92.

The straight Republican ticket delegates to to the Republican County Convention may have an opportunity to test their exact strength at to-night's Republican County Convention. The meeting is called for the purpose of receiving the report of the Committee on Contested Seats, which has the Cowie-Gibbs dispute over the primary election in the Thirteenth Assembly District in hand.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- The Record to-morrow morning will devote a page to a review of the operations of the Soldier's Burial bill, which was vetoed by Gov. Pattison. An unsuccessful attempt has been made to prejudice the soldiers against the ex-Governor because of this veto.

The cruiser Philadelphia, flagship of the North Atlantic station, accompanied by the gunboat Petrel, dropped anchor yesterday morning off Tompkinsville, S.I. The Philadelphia underwent her battery trial Saturday in Long Island Sound, and the tests were highly satisfactory. Not a bolt started nor a seam opened, and beyond the smashing of a pane of glass in the wardroom hatch no damage was sustained by the heavy firing.

Interested listeners, numbering 1,172 by actual count, gathered at Association Hall, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, yesterday morning to hear the Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., pay his respects to Richard Croker, Tammany Hall's chieftain. The subject of the discourse was "Our Uncrowned King -- The Silent Sovereign of the City." Mr. Dixon said:

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 5. -- Great interest is taken in the intercollegiate tennis tournament which will begin here to-morrow morning, and the men who will represent the eleven colleges entered are arriving to-night. The entries in singles is the largest ever received in an intercollegiate tournament, twenty-six men being entered, while the double list numbers thirteen.

TRENTON, Oct. 5. -- The Democrats expect to gain two of the Congressional Districts that are now represented by Republicans at the approaching election. The delegation consists now of Bergen, Buchanan, Beckwith, and Lehlbach, Republicans, standing for the First, Second, Fifth, and Sixth Districts respectively, and of Geissenhainer, Fowler, and McAdoo, Democrats, representing the Third, Fourth, and Seventh Districts.

One of the principal industries just now in South Jersey is the gathering of the cranberry crop, and thousands of people are busy picking the berries. The crop is considered the largest ever grown in the State and the berries are of good size and fine flavor.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- The passage of the McKinley bill has caused great activity among the consumers and dealers in Canadian products in this part of the State. The big seed houses in Jefferson County have been doing their best to get in this season's crop of peas and beans before the new tariff wiped out the larger part of the profits of the business.

It is doubtful if a more diversified programme than that which was followed out yesterday by the Comte de Paris and his party could have been arranged. At 7:30 o'clock they arose and, half an hour later, with the exception of the Duc d'Orleans and the Duc d'Uzes, who breakfasted at the Knickerbocker Club, they sat down to breakfast in the dining room of the Windsor.

The police of the Twenty-third Sub-Precinct Station, at the Grand Central Station, have a very interesting "green-goods" case on hand. The facts are very few, owing to the disappearance of the complainant and the refusal of the defendants to talk. Saturday evening Detective McMahon was standing in the New-York Central waiting room when a well-dressed man approached and asked him where a policeman could be found.

The annual meeting of the New-York Academy of Anthropology will be held to-morrow evening at 9 University Place. Officers will be elected and an address will be made by the President. The regular course of semi-monthly lectures will be begun Tuesday evening, Oct. 14, when J. Stewart Hopper will speak on "The Ethnology of the Chinese."

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- On the Boerse the week past prices generally were depressed, but mining shares were steady. Laura Mine shares closed yesterday at 156. On the Frankfort Boerse also prices were depressed. Prices were firm on the Vienna Boerse.

The inspiring influences of Ruskinism are abundantly exhibited in the curious experiment now going on in Keswick under the superintendency of the vicar and his wife, Mr. and Mrs. Rawnsley. It consists in the establishment in that little centre of life -- in the Lake Country -- of a "School of Industrial Art and Ruskin Linen Industry," wherein hand-spun and hand-woven textile fabrics are produced, as well as woodcarving and metal repousse work.

Mr. HENRY C. LEA of Philadelphia, an ardent adherent of the Republican Party in the past, be it remembered, has supplemented his scathing arraignment of "Boss" QUAY with a letter addressed to QUAY'S candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, GEORGE W. DELAMATER, which is calculated to make even the callous integument of that person tingle.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- Since the disastrous train wreck at Quincy, Mass., the Old Colony Railroad has been the subject of many alarmist reports, partly inspired, no doubt, by the vengeful feeling of those who suffered injury in the accident and have since been trying to get a liberal money compensation for their wounds.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 4. -- Much interest has been expressed this Summer in regard to the Summer Shelter of Morristown, which receives poor children within its hospitable doors and keeps them for two weeks of light-hearted enjoyment and rest from the hot streets of New-York, where so much misery is to be found, especially in Summer.

The 6th of October is each year more and more observed by our fellow-citizens of German birth or descent as German-American Day. The occasion for commemoration is the landing of the first German immigrants in this country -the beginning of an influence destined to become exceedingly important after two centuries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- Henry C. Lea, one of the most prominent Republican business men of Philadelphia, has sent the following letter to Senator Delamater, the Republican candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 5. -- The letter of Judge A.C. Haskell, a synopsis of which has appeared in THE TIMES, advocating the placing of an opposition ticket in the field against that nominated by the Democratic State Convention, has borne its expected fruits. The issue was joined yesterday. The anti-Tillman Democrats of Marion met and nominated a county ticket separate and distinct from the regular county ticket.

HARTFORD, Oct. 5. -- The fifth annual convention of Christian Workers in the United States and Canada, which will be in session here for one week, beginning Nov. 6, will be the most important religious assemblage in the State during the year. The Rev. R.A. Torrey of the Chicago Evangelical Society is the Chairman, and the Rev. John C. Collins of New-Haven the Secretary of the General Committee in charge of the convention.

There never was a period in the history of Tammany Hall when its leaders were keeping so completely under cover as to their plans and purposes as they are now. Alongside of them "Brer Rabbit" was nowhere in the matter of laying low. It is evident that Richard Croker has placed all of the Committee of Twenty-four under injunctions of the strictest secrecy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker has sent to the House Post Office Committee, under date of Sept. 25, a long letter intended as a final argument before the committee in favor of the postal telegraph scheme which be submitted to the committee and with regard to which he has heretofore been heard.

Mr. WILLIAM MCKINLEY, Jr., has been renominated by the Republicans of his district in Ohio, and his friends appear to think that a large sum of money is needed for the campaign. They are collecting funds from the protected manufacturers in and near Pittsburg who are willing to yield up some of their "fat" for the chief maker of the two Tariff bills that are to be so useful to them.

Fair photographic weather has prevailed lately with one or two exceptions. The Saturday visits to the Bronx River and suburban resorts were many, and the young men armed with permits and cameras who went to Central Park formed a considerable number. Photographic excursions have not been very popular this Summer and there were few large ones.

Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Kendal, the well-known English players, arrived in this city yesterday morning on the Eturia. They were accompanied by their daughter Daisy, a young lad who has just finished her education in France, and they went at once to the Victoria Hotel, where they occupied their old quarters. At 2 o'clock in the afternoon they gave a sort of informal reception to the representatives of the local newspapers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 5. -- The Republicans of the Second, Third, and Fourth Congressional Districts in this State will hold their conventions this week, the Third occurring on Wednesday, Oct. 8, and the Second and Fourth on Thursday. The State Republican League will hold a meeting at Meriden Wednesday, the day prior to the Second District Convention.

The police of Washington are strengthening themselves somewhat at the expense of the army. The vacancies in that force are habitually supplied, we believe, by men who have served either in the army or the navy. Indeed, the law requires that it should be so recruited, the original intention being to give the Union veterans the preference for appointment.

Two queer natural history fairy tales reach us from Scotland. At Haddington last week a cat gave birth to four kittens, and with her offspring took up her abode in the garden summer-house. Three of the kittens were removed, and the lady of the house on visiting the Summer house the next day was surprised to find that the fourth kitten had also disappeared. Search was made, but to no avail.

Powell Clayton made a remarkable speech in the Republican Congressional Convention of the Second Arkansas District when the question was pending whether or not to forgive Langley, hitherto the Republican as well as the Union Labor candidate for Congress, his condemnation of the Force bill and to continue supporting him. Clayton took the ground that Langley must have the support of Republicans in order to accomplish the defeat of Breckinridge.

" Mme. Angot" closes its career at the Casino next Saturday evening with a record of sixty performances, and the full company will start on its traveling tour directly after the performance to fill long engagements in Boston, Chicago, and Philadelphia. The theatre will be closed next Monday evening and will reopen on Tuesday, Oct. 14, with the production of "Poor Jonathan."

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- The republic has certainly been strengthened by the Boulanger developments, which, thanks to Mermeix duels and to Canivet and Rochefort fisticuffs, do not seem likely to grow monotonous. People talk very little of the matter here; there is, however, an intense, subdued feeling of indignant shame, with a pleasant assurance that the republic is safer than ever.

The announcement of President WOODRUFF at the semi-annual conference of the Mormons in Salt Lake that he has talked twice recently with JOSEPH SMITH in the spirit and once with BRIGHAM YOUNG, and they told him that the triumph of Mormonism is at hand, is of little consequence except as showing the depth of superstition into which the Mormons have fallen when such a statement can be made in the crowded Tabernacle unchallenged.

In entering her Majesty's Dominion of Canada we encountered the Custom House agents of the Dominion, and the encounter, as has been told, was brief and pleasant. Not a key was turned in a trunk, and the baggage of the party was admitted free to Canada with no more trouble than was involved in a smile and a cheerful word. On leaving the Dominion the experience of THE TIMES'S man was almost as cheerful.
