A correspondent writes to the Pall Mall Guzetie as follows: "A few miles from the city of Toledo there is a small township called Arges. At the commencement of the year its population was nigh 500 souls; its Mayor, or 'Alcalde,' is Don Rufiano Jimanez -- an extensive lime burner, deservedly enjoying the popularity and confidence of his fellow-villagers.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The Democratic primaries for the election of delegates to the convention which will nominate a successor to the late Freeholder William H. Lamb, who died two weeks ago, will be held to-morrow night, and a lively time is expected. The party is split into two factions in this city, which are known as the Hartford and anti-Hartford factions.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 5. -- Fire broke out at 4 o'clock this morning in a frame residence in this city occupied by John McBee, 1,578 Iowa Street, and before assistance arrived Mrs. McBee and two children were suffocated. Another child was rescued in an unconscious state, and McBee escaped through a window.

The return of Gen. S.V. BENET, Chief of Ordnance, to his desk at Washington, after a prolonged Summer vacation, will doubtless be followed very soon by the appointment of the board to select a new magazine rifle. Provision for this purpose was made by Congress long ago, and the selection of the board has been awaited with some impatience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The conference of steel-makers and shipbuilders with the Secretary of the Navy, which was to have been held at the Navy Department Wednesday, has been postponed until Oct. 16, an account of the contemplated absence of Secretary Tracy from the city.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The business men of Asbury Park and Ocean Grove are greatly excited because of new and unexpected developments in the Frank Patterson alleged forgery cases. Ex-Judge Samuel T. Hendrickson and William W. Conover, both of Red Bank, were the financial backers of Patterson for several years prior to his arrest on Sept. 6, 1884, and indorsed notes for him aggregating upward of $100,000.

The Supreme, Superior, and Common Pleas Courts opened for the Fall term yesterday after the long Summer vacation, and the corridors and court rooms of the County Court House were once more crowded with lawyers. Not much was accomplished in any of the courts beyond getting through the calling of the calendars and making ready for business on the morrow.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 6. -- The annual town elections were held throughout the State to-day, except in New-Haven and Bridgeport. A cold rainstorm caused an unusually light vote. Enthusiasm was shown only in a few towns where close contests were expected, and even there the elections resulted about as usual.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- "We are just in the midst of the work of sending out documents for the people to read," said the Secretary of the Republican Congressional Committee to-day, "and we hope to be through by the 15th of the month."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Congressman Richard Vaux, who was elected last Spring to fill the unexpired term of Samuel J. Randall, to-day accepted the independent Democratic nomination for the full term in a letter in which he said:

By an overwhelming vote the Republican County Convention in session last evening at Webster Hall practically came out for a fusion ticket. It also expelled the delegates of the wicked Gibbs, and conferred the representation of the Thirteenth Assembly District upon those of the Cowie-Sprague faction.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 6. -- Grand Master Sargent of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, who is President of the Supreme Council of the Federation of Railway Employes, to-day issued a call for the meeting of the council at Houston, Texas, Thursday next, to consider the threatened strike on the Houston and Texas Central Railway.

The annual meeting of the Trustees of Columbia College was held yesterday afternoon. A great deal of routine business was transacted, and President Low presented his annual report, the reading of which was listened to with much interest. Concerning the reorganization of the college into a university, the President said:

DUBLIN, Oct. 6. -- When the magistrate's court at Tipperary reconvened this morning, all the accused, with the exception of Mr. O'Mahony, who is ill, were present, but their counsel, Mr. Redmond and Timothy Healy, were absent in consequence of an important engagement which demanded their attention elsewhere.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 6. -- The weather was far from auspicious here to-day, and this fact kept many people from witnessing the opening matches in the intercollegiate lawn tennis tournament which was commenced here this morning. The courts were a trifle damp, and after seven matches had been played it commenced to rain, and play was postponed until to-morrow morning at 10:30.

There is not much reason for distrusting the sincerity of the renunciation of polygamy by the Mormons. The declaration made at their General Conference in Salt Lake yesterday is as comprehensive as it is explicit. The official prohibition by BRIGHAM YOUNG'S successor of any marriages in violation of the law of the land was ratified by a unanimous vote.

The Sub-Committee on "Harmony" of the Democratic State Committee held its first meeting at the Hoffman House last night. The ostensible purpose of it was to secure, if possible, a Democratic union on nominations of Congressmen and Assemblynmen.

Without preliminary fuss or oratorical introduction, the Senate Committee on Cities resumed the business of investigating the municipal departments of this city in Part II, of the Superior Court at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Senator Fassett took charge of the Legislature's machine, and William M. Ivins was on hand to direct the operations of the probe.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6. -- At 9 o'clock this evening a whisky-crazed negro wielded a revolver and knife in such a manner that Policeman James Brady is dead and Officer Thomas Gaffney is in the hospital in a dying condition. One negro is clubbed so that he will die, and another is shot in two places.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 6. -- Politicians in Iowa place a good deal of faith in the statement recently published in a Washington paper that J.S. Clarkson, late First Assistant Postmaster General, is slated for a mission to China. They see in this, as in most everything that Mr. Clarkson undertakes, a scheme of greater or less proportions.

DETROIT, Oct. 6. -- James M. Turner, Republican candidate for Governor, is out this afternoon in a defense against the charges brought against him last Friday by J.F. McElroy, Superintendent of the State School for the Blind. It is fully as long as his accuser's statement, and is, as a whole, what the lawyers would term a plea of confession and avoidance.

There is a great deal of trouble among the city officials and the several boards of the Long Island City Government arising from different interpretations of the provisions of the city's charter, neglect of the Board of Aldermen to make necessary appropriations, and intestine strifes due to the several political factions seeking to get the upper hand in the local political arena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Within the next week the Navy Department will advertise for proposals for three more vessels -- the Ammen harbor-defense ram, the 750-ton torpedo gunboat, and another first-class torpedo boat.

J.F. Hickey, who keeps a saloon at Cottage Place and Bleecker Street, had a little experience with passers of counterfeit money Sunday night which he will not soon forget. Mr. Hickey was standing in front of his saloon about 9:30 o'clock when two men named Frank Smith and Edward Fox approached and asked him to change a two-dollar bill. Hickey did so.

ASBURY PARK, Oct. 6. -- A Cream Ridge ox, weighing 1,800 pounds before he was dressed, was placed on the spit near to Educational Hall at l2:05 o'clock this morning, and was still roasting when W.L. Wilson, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the State Democratic Society, announced at 11:25 o'clock that the regular session of the meeting would be deferred until 2 P.M.

While Mr. MCKINLEY'S collectors are taking the contributions of the grateful manufacturers in the Window-Glass Trust to a blocks-of-five fund that is to be spent in his district, they may read in the newspaper that represents his interests in Ohio the assurance that the Republican Party has overthrown all Trusts by its so-called Anti-Trust law.

The Republicans of Richmond County, S.I., are so thoroughly frightened by the secrecy maintained by the Democrats as to the lines on which they shall conduct the coming campaign, as well as to the candidates that shall be put forward for the various offices, that the Republican Nominating Convention, which was fixed for to-morrow in Erastus Wiman's Casino at St. George, will probably not be held until next Monday.

A long and earnest conference of the chief executive officers of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company was held yesterday to consider the statement of grievances presented by the employes a few days ago to Second Vice President Thomas. Toward evening a message was sent to the committee of employes that the company would make a formal reply to their communication on Thursday or Friday of this week.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 6. -- The Comte de Paris is expected to arrive here Thursday. In the following letter, addressed to the Exchange Hotel, he engages apartments for himself and party:

In order to secure a better showing of thoroughbreds than the National Horse Show Association has been able to obtain in past years, Dr. W.S. Webb has increased the association's prize of $200 for thoroughbred stallions, three years old or over, by offering an additional prize of $100 in plate, making the first prize $300. W.T. Lawson also offers a prize of $100 in cash or plate for the best thoroughbred stallion for getting hunters.

In the Building Bureau yesterday plans were filed for the erection of a brownstone building covering 941 to 947 Fifth Avenue and 2 to 10 East Seventy-sixth Street. This building is to be erected by the Congregation Beth-El, and will cost $210,000. Other plans were filed for a five-story brick for the Educational Alliance Society, at the southeast corner of East Broadway and Jefferson Street, to cost $120,000.
DUBLIN, Oct. 6. -- The conference of the Irish Nationalists called by Mr. Parnell was held in this city to-day.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 6. -- German-American Day began inauspiciously. The clear sky of last night became overclouded in the early morning hours, and soon there were some heavy showers. As the morning advanced, the intervals between the showers became shorter until finally there was a continuous and heavy downpour. This rain put a stop to further decorations and detracted very much from the beauty of those already up.

Some days ago we pointed out that within a few months the price of pig lead had risen about 40 per cent. owing to the new Treasury regulations restricting the admission of silver-lead ores from Mexico and to the impending exaction of a prohibitory duty on those ores. It was also shown that orders for several thousand tons of lead had been sent to Europe. The Engineering and Mining Journal of the 4th inst. says:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The main points of the annual report of Green B. Raum, Commissioner of Pensions, made public to-day, are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- A large number of letters and telegrams have been received at the Treasury Department in regard to the new tariff law which went into effect to-day, and Assistant Secretary Spaulding and General Appraiser Tichenor devoted the entire day to their consideration. One of the most troublesome questions was in regard to the construction of Section 50 of that law, reading as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6. -- The Ohio and Mississippi and the Vandalia to-day met the three-dollar rate to Cincinnati and return previously announced by the Big Four, and the three roads are now selling tickets both ways at that rate. The Ohio and Mississippi also announce a rate of one fare for the round trip from Louisville, Burlington, Iowa, Hannibal, Quincy, and Peoria.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 6. -- The Republican State Central Committee has made a careful review of the situation, and from all that can be gathered never in the political history of Minnesota has there been a time when the situation was more mixed or when it was more difficult to foreshadow the vote.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -- Mount St. Elias must take a fail. It is not 19,500 feet high, as given in Uncle Sam's books, but 5,000 feet less. This discovery was made by the United States Geographical Survey under Prof. Russell, and information of it was brought here by Mark Kerr, who was associated with Prof. Russell in the expedition.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- There is a complicated state of affairs at the Custom House here. Legally, according to Collector Beard, the Custom House was closed Saturday afternoon at 3 o'clock, and the goods on all foreign vessels arriving after that hour were subject to the rates of the new Tariff bill, though the Treasury circular of its provisions had not been received.
TORONTO, Oct. 6. -- A partial confession of Birchall and some general statements on the Benwell murder case by the doomed man, published in the Globe to-day, created fresh interest in the case.

The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Monday, Oct 6: tiehard V. Hartnett Co., under a foreclosure decree, George W. Van Heesen. ESQ., referee, sold the two.story brick dwelling, with lot 15 by 100, 1,092 East 19/th St, south side, 115 fee%east e Southern Boulevard, for $2,000, to Charles Ward, trustee, , plaintiff.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- The Lincoln Independent Republican Committee to-day sent an open letter to President Harrison, inclosing their appeal to the voters of Pennsylvania to vote against Delamater, and a pamphlet which they have also distributed throughout the State. In their letter to the President the committee say:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The announcement that came through THE NEW-YORK TIMES from New-Orleans that the engagement of Alfred Wilkinson of this city and Miss Winnie Davis of Beauvoir had been broken caused much comment and surprise here. When the engagement was first announced the wedding was put down to take place last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Inspector General of the army has received a long report from Lieut. Col. R.H. Jackson in regard to the encampment of the National Guard of the State of New-York at Peekskill from July 5 to Aug. 23 last. He gives in detail the results of his inspection and observation, and compliments the different departments for their efficiency.

Police Justice Kenna's formal announcement that he was a candidate for Sheriff stirred up his friends in Brooklyn yesterday and they made a bee line for "Boss" McLaughlin. Three delegations called on the "Great Whittler" at his office in the Willoughby Street auction rooms, and urged Kenna's selection. The first was composed of Germans, more or less representative, who assured McLaughlin that Kenna would not be cut by German Democrats.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- The shock of the explosion at Wilmington this afternoon was plainly felt in many sections of this city. To those indoors it resembled the rumbling of distant thunder or the moving of heavy furniture, and the rattling window frames caused many people to rush to their doors and windows. The shock was also felt at Millville, N.J.; Chester, Penn., and other points, thirty to thirty-five miles distant.

Senator Hearst's lucky star still shines brightly. His colt Tournament yesterday won for him at the Morris Park track the Hickory Stakes, for three-year-olds, which was the most valuable stake of the week, and worth $13,100 gross to the winner. The fact that the track was sloppy and just suited to this colt's action made the race practically a walk-over for him.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 7. -- The crop estimates agree generally in placing the Spring wheat yield of Minnesota and the Dakotas at about 90,000,000 bushels. It is conceded that about 20,000,000 bushels will be required for seed and local consumption by farmers. Deducting this, there remain 70,000,000 bushels. The millers of Minneapolis are expected to consume about 30,000,000 bushels during the year, and this reduces the supply to 40,000,000 bushels.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The International Literary Congress met here to-day. Jules Lemina, the permanent Secretary, presented a report on copyright in America. He regretted the defeat of the May bill, proposing an international copyright law, and attributed its defeat to the prevailing unquenchable antagonism to England and the antagonism at home between the Eastern and Western States.

The story told by the manager of Hammerstein's Opera House in Harlem is one that very intimately concerns the repute of the Fire Department in general and of Chief BONNER in particular. It seems clear that the manager has been persecuted, under a very thin pretext of enforcing precautions for the safety of his theatre.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 7. -- With the campaign fairly under way, both parties confidently claiming victory, and the Prohibitionists running a cold-water side-show that may simply attract enough votes to turn the scales between the two leading contestants, the result of the coming election in Delaware is a matter of grave uncertainty that only the counting of the ballots can reveal.

We said a day or two ago that the manufacturers in the Window-Glass Trust, from whom large sums of money have recently been collected by agents of Mr. MCKINLEY for use in procuring his re-election, were well served by Mr. MCKINLEY in the preparation of the duties on glass in the new Tariff bill.

In the saddling paddocks at the Westchester track yesterday Col. S.D. Bruce sold at auction seventeen thoroughbreds, the property of the Castle Stable. With the exception of Bermuda, Thorndale, and Diablo, small prices were realized. The latter brought the top price, John Campbell securing him for $9,000. He is supposed to have been acting for the owners. The lots sold, with the prices obtained, are as follows:

DANVILLE, Ill., Oct. 7. -- The route of the Presidential party through Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois to-day has been marked by the assembling of large crowds at the stations, to many of which the President made a few remarks, thank ing them for the greeting extended to him. The principal event of the day was the reception of the Presidential party at Terre Haute.

Yesterday was the first day of registration in this city and Brooklyn, and notwithstanding the disagreeable weather there was an increase of nearly 10,000 in New-York, as compared with the first day last year, and of nearly 20,000 in Brooklyn. It is evident that the fear that the ballot-reform law would deter voters from exercising the franchise is ill-founded.

The conference committees of the three anti-Tammany organizations -- the People's Municipal League, the County Democracy, and the Republicans -- met in Parlor 2 of the Brunswick Hotel at 8:30 o'clock last night to arrange plan upon which all the anti-Tammany forces could effect a union. Each of the conference committees was a sub-committee of the special committees appointed by the three conventions.

According to reports from England, two large insurance companies of Liverpool, the Royal and the Queen, both of which do a big business in this country, will probably be consolidated. In the United States they limit themselves to fire risks, but in England they write both fire and life insurance. Manager Edward F. Beddall of the Royal received a cablegram last week calling him to England, and he sailed last Wednesday by the Majestic.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Miss Ann O'Hara, forty-six years old, went to New-York to do some shopping yesterday, and had a dress fitted. Not returning at 7 P.M., Superintendent Babcock of the Linden race track, whose housekeeper she is, and who was waiting for her at the station with his carriage, left word to have her come home in a hack, and drove back to Linden.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- The Democrats of the Sixth District and of the State are elated to-night over the official announcement that Dr. William Everett of Quincy has decided to accept the Democratic nomination for Congress against Henry Cabot Lodge. The committee appointed to wait upon him and notify him of his nomination went down to Quincy this afternoon.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 7. -- A panic was caused here last night by a rumor that a fresh revolution had broken out. The troops were called out and detachments of cavalry patrolled the streets during the night. The Minister of War went to Palermo Park, where the troops were mustered. Gen. Roca, Minister of the Interior, remained in President Pellegrini's residence until 9 A.M. to-day.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 7. -- The Directors of the Colorado Midland met behind closed doors at Colorado Springs yesterday. The outcome of the meeting was an arrangement for a joint meeting of the Directors of the Midland and Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Roads, to be held at Topeka, Kan., Oct 10, when all details for the consolidation of the Midland system with the Santa Fe will be perfected.

The inefficiency of the Excise Department under the present methods was illustrated more forcibly than ever before the Senate Committee on Cities in Part II. of the Superior Court yesterday. If there is any merit at all in the way the excise laws are now administered it would take a microscope to discover it. Senators Fassett, McNaughton, Stewart, and Ahearn sat as the court of inquiry yesterday.

Two more steamers dame into port yesterday with their cargoes afire, as was the case with the Clyde liner Iroquois, which arrived last Friday. They were the Alamo of the Mallory Line, from Galveston, and the Ciudad Condal of the Spanish Transatlantic Line, from Havana.

The testimony of Commissioner KOCH before the investigating committee yesterday did not put the administration of the Excise Board in any more favorable light than the admissions of Mr. FITZPATRICK. He stated without reserve that the patronage of the department is distributed in the interest of Tammany Hall, not as a matter of duty or obligation, but rather as a "matter of gratitude."

MILLERSBURG, Ohio, Oct. 7. -- Mr. McKinley arrived this noon, opening his campaign in the Sixteenth District. Throwing away a domestic cigar which he had been enjoying on the train and wrapping the folds of the Inverness cape made of domestic goods about him, he stepped down to receive the greetings of the forty or more friends, the sifted few of the 1,952 people in Millersburg who had come to the station to meet him.

There was a large attendance yesterday at the services in honor of the twentieth anniversary of the Southern New-York Baptist Association, held in Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street. In the association are nine out-of-town churches, fifty-six churches being in the city. The association has for its object the cultivation of fraternal sympathy, the promotion of spiritual welfare, and the establishment and strengthening of Baptist churches within its bounds.

There can be little doubt that the "grip" which played such sad havoo last year has not only left its effects upon a great many, but seems to be returning in various localities. All physicians report that there is an alarming prevalence of heavy colds, accompanied by all grip symptoms. Many people take cold easier than before; others are troubled with weak eyes, headaches,

Worn out with the discussion of many difficult problems, incident to the putting into operation of the new tariff, Collector Erhardt was not at the Custom House yesterday, the brunt of the battle falling upon Special Deputy Collector Couch. The second day of the life of the new law was even more wearisome than the first, the offices of the chiefs of the Custom House being thronged throughout business hours with inquiring merchants and brokers.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The project to construct a ship canal across New-Jersey from the Delaware to the Atlantic has brought all the way from South America a young engineer of established reputation now visiting in Plainfield. Some months ago he received an urgent message summoning him from the mountain mines, where he had been developing a fortune for himself and others, to embark in this Jersey scheme.

Little Portugal must be convinced of the peculiar aptitude which John Bull has for presenting his numerous claims against her at inopportune moments. In the midst of her Cabinet crisis he has made a peremptory demand for the payment of indemnity for the seizure of a steamer by a Portuguese subaltern last year.

The men of Life-Saving Station No. 1 at Sandy Hook had a busy time of it Monday night and yesterday morning in the heavy weather and high sea that prevailed. Their work began at 9:30 o'clock in the evening, when, in spite of all her crew could do, the fishing smack Scotia came staggering into the shoal water and struck, the heavy seas breaking over and tilling her instantly.

The high-tariff organs that were urging their readers a few days ago not to study "the details" of the new tariff law are now telling them that prices will not be raised by the new duties. The assertion that certain prices will advance is made, they say, to mislead supporters of the protective policy.

The members of the American Society of Railroad Superintendents came together in the Hotel Brunswick yesterday, the occasion being the society's nineteenth meeting. Mr. C.S. Gadsden, Superintendent of the Charleston and Savannah Railway and President of the society, called the convention to order, and Mr. C.A. Hammond, Superintendent of the Boston, Revere Beach and Lynn Railroad, was at his post as Secretary.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 7. -- The proclamation of Gov. Campbell convening the Legislature in extraordinary session still continues to be the leading topic in political circles and places of resort. During the four years of war there was no necessity for it, and never but once before in the history of the State has a special session been called. This was fifty-five years ago.

Thursdays in October are to be known as "Social Thursdays" at the Manhattan Single Tax Club, 73 Lexington Avenue. To-morrow night there is to be an hour or so of "Illusions and Delusions." The anniversary celebration will occur on the 16th, there will be a "Book Party" on the 23d, and on the 30th Julien T. Davies will lecture on "The Absolute Liberation of Personal Property from Taxation."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 7. -- For two weeks a posse of officers employed by the Southern Express Company have been following Rube Burrows, the noted train robber and outlaw. They followed him across the country from Florida into Marengo Country, Ala., where he was captured at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

The outcome of the work done by the State Committee's Sub-Committee on Harmony at its long meeting at the Hoffman House Monday night was the topic of general discussion among the politicians yesterday. "Tim" Campbell's friends did not like it at all because there is not to he a union in the Eighth District, Amos J. Cummings's friends were equally chagrined because there is not to be a union in the Ninth District.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 7. -- The Congressional fight in this State is now fairly on, and it promises, in each of the four districts, to be one of the hottest campaigns ever waged between the two great parties on West Virginia soil.

There was an important meeting of boot and shoe manufacturers yesterday at the Metropolitan Hotel. It was called by the Boot and Shoe Manufacturers' Association of New-York, and included the principal representatives of the trade in New-England and the Eastern States. The purpose of the meeting was to take action upon the important subject of guaranteeing the material of the boots and shoes sold and the question of prices and credits.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The Republican Convention for the nomination of candidate for Congress for the Fifteenth Congressional District was held here to-day. It was a harmonious but not an enthusiastic convention. A great majority of the delegates came here with a determination to renominate the present Representative, the Hon. Moses D. Stivers, who was confessedly the only candidate with whom they could have a fighting chance in the district.

A new puzzle has been sprung upon the inoffensive people of this weary world. It is an innocent-looking affair, and an inexpensive one withal, but more deadly than "pigs in the pen." This latest brain-racking device consists simply of three columns of figures, arranged thus:

Competitions for nominations in the various Assembly districts in this city are about as lively just now as human ingenuity and activity can make them. A number of the members of the present Assembly are candidates for re-election, but it is on the cards that not more than 50 per cent. of the delegation, as now constituted, will be returned.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The parties in the wheat pit have been disturbed somewhat by the advance in the past five days of 6 cents. Bloom, Comstock, "English" George Smith, Logan, Mitchell, and Hutchinson started the advance for 98 1/2 cents last Wednesday. That was the day when Hutchinson announced that bottom for the crop had been touched.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 7. -- It was a foregone conclusion that the Republican Conventions to-day would renominate Congressmen Spooner and Arnold, and the proceedings were consequently somewhat of the cut-and-dried order. Aggressive Republicanism seemed to be the keynote, and both conventions "whooped" for Speaker Reed and his methods at every opportunity.

It is rather surprising that so little discussion should have been aroused by the order of the New-York Central Railroad explaining its position with regard to the Knights of Labor. There have been expressions of dissent from the regular and avowed organs of the order, but these have seemed to be merely perfunctory.

The force of the admirable editorial in to-day's paper, "Rising Funds for McKinley," is impaired by the indefiniteness of the statement that "in the conference committee Mr. McKinley insisted upon the rates in his bill, and the result was a compromise by which the duties now imposed on common window glass were retained."

The news of a famine in Ireland, which is denied by the Tory press and magnified, it may be, by the papers devoted to home rule, offers only one in a series of phenomena common to Europe. The violence, the heartlessness, the anger with Americans who propose once more to help the famished in Ireland, spring from class hatreds as old as the world.

John St. John of Chicago, a shoemaker, thirty-three years old, was shot and killed by Marshal De Mars, a saloon keeper, yesterday morning. It seems that St. John, the saloon keeper and his wife, and Mrs. Benson, the saloon keeper's sister, were drinking together, and that a drunken row occurred and De Mars shot St. John twice in the head. Both women and De Mars have been arrested.

The Court of Appeals yesterday handed down a decision in the case of W.P. Abendroth of 280 Pearl Street against the Manhattan Railway Company and the New-York Elevated Road, which has been in the courts since 1883, affirming the order of the General Term of the Superior Court which reversed the judgment of the Special Term dismissing the plaintiff's complaint. Judgment absolute is rendered against the elevated road.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- George R. Davis, Director General of the World's Fair, has issued the following address to the press of the United States:

The disposition to be made of the Twenty-second Regiment rests in the hands of the Commander in Chief. The alternative propositions submitted to the Board of Officers of the regiment Monday night as to whether they would send forward their resignations or become a contracting party to the disbandment of the organization are still in abeyance.

There have been many recent signs of the approaching disintegration of the ring that in Hudson County has brought so much odium upon the Democracy of New-Jersey. serious division on the question of the County Jailership has arrayed Boss "Denny" McLaughlin against Boss "Bob" Davis, who is believed to be the head of the ballot-box stuffers and plunderers who have had the county at their mercy for the last two three or years.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- The nomination of Hamilton Fish, Jr., at Carmel yesterday means a great deal more than appears on the surface. It means, to begin with, that the anti-Platt members will hold the balance of power in the next Assembly if it is Republican, and they will be a small power in themselves if the Assembly happens to be closely Democratic, particularly in bills that require a two-thirds vote.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The Hon. J.J. Belden was unanimously renominated for Representative in Congress to-day by the Republican Congressional Convention for the Twenty-fifth District. Mr. Belden made a speech in which he praised the action of Congress, and declared that the record of the Republican Party in the Fifty-first Congress was the source of unqualified pride and admiration to every true Republican.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- The Cabinet has charged M. Roche, Minister of Commerce, to frame a bill to introduce in the Chamber of Deputies fixing a maximum tariff upon exports into France, and giving the Government power to make concessions to those countries whose Governments, in their tariff laws, favor French products.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 7. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Thirteenth Senatorial District of the State of Connecticut was held in this town to-day. John S. Seymour of Norwalk was the choice of the convention, and in response to an invitation to address the delegates he read a paper favoring an inland railroad extending from the State of New-York to Rhode Island, to be built by the State.

A very pleasant neighborly greeting was given to the Hon. William Walter Phelps, United States Minister to Germany, at the rooms of the Englewood Club, in the new Lyceum Building at Englewood, N.J., last night. The affair was gotten up by Mr. Phelps's friends and neighbors, without regard to politics, purely as a welcome home.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Fruit growers along the Hudson River and throughout the Wallkill and Esopus Valleys have harvested the best of their Concord grape crop and are now busy cleaning their vineyards of the imperfect clusters which were left during the harvest of the choice fruit. The season nearly closed has been a remarkable one.

There are some very queer stories being told about the causes which led to the failure of Oscar Hammerstein to open his big new Harlem Theatre Monday night, as he had intended to do. The story of the failure was told in yesterday's TIMES, but yesterday that story was supplemented by statements which seem to place those members of the Fire Department personally connected with Mr. Hammerstein's venture in anything but an enviable position.

The Hon. Leland Stanford of California and Mrs. Stanford returned from Europe yesterday on the Teutonic. They went abroad last May in search of health, and were both successful in finding the object of their search. Senator Stanford was troubled with vertigo and rheumatism. Mrs. Stanford suffered from a nervous ailment. They went directly to Kissingen, where they submitted to the regulation treatment for five weeks.

The opening of Hammerstein's new theatre in Harlem is indefinitely postponed. An inspection of the building and its appliances was again made yesterday by Chief Bonner and Superintendent Brady of the Fire and Building Departments, and they found, so they declared, many defects in the arrangements of the theatre which would prevent its opening until they had been remedied.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Adjt. Gen. Porter returned to his office here to-day, but was non-committal regarding the complications in the New-York City branch of the National Guard. He said that everything was still in embryo, and as yet he had not given out a suggestion as to the outcome of the Twenty-second Regiment matter.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- There was a moderate attendance at Pimlico this afternoon when the Autumn meeting began. The rain of yesterday made the track heavy, and King Tosca was the only one of the heat runners to lower his record. Belle Ferguson came to grief in the fourth heat of the 2:40 trot, when her cheek broke and she tore her quarter.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- A dispatch to the Times from Buenos Ayres says that the reports of an impending revolution are without foundation. There is no reason to fear trouble. The city and the whole country are tranquil.

Net earnings amounting to $7,312,725 were shown in the report for the fiscal year 1890 submitted at the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday. This is an increase of more than one million dollars over the net earnings of the previous year. After paying interest and dividends the Western Union will have a surplus, according to the Treasurer's report, of $1,441,582.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- The Republicans of the Nine-teenth Congressional District nominated Edward A. Durant, Jr., to-day. Mr. Durant is forty-one years old, a native of this city, and is engaged in the commission business. He was one of the New-York Electors who cast their vote for Harrison. Gen. Charles Tracy, who now represents the district, has been renominated by the Democrats.

The Society of the Free Baptist Churches of the United States continued its session yesterday in the First Free Baptist Church of Brooklyn, at Marcy Avenue and Keap Street. The morning meeting was in charge of the Educational Society. The prayer service was led by the Rev. H.J. Brown of Spencer, Iowa. This was followed by the report of the Rev. G.A. Burgess, Corresponding Secretary, who gave reports from ten schools and colleges.

If Mr. DAVID A. WELLS can overcome the slender plurality of 748 by which his present opponent, CHARLES A. KUSSELL, was elected in 1888, the Third Connecticut District will be represented in the next Congress by a man better equipped than any other member likely to be in the House for the discussion of customs taxation in its theories and practice.
LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, replying to an inquiry as to the real condition of affairs in Ireland, writes as follows:
My attention has been called to the following statements by your London correspondent. Referring to the Irish famine of 1880, he says:

The figures of the census are a suggestive comment on the State-making and State-rejecting legislation of Congress at its recent session. New-Mexico, which was not allowed to enter the Union as a State, is now shown to have a population of 144,862 when the count was made, while Wyoming, which was admitted, has only 60,589, and Idaho only 84,229.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- It will not be the fault of the Republican Congressional Committee if the father of the McKinley tariff act is not returned to the Fifty-second Congress. The committee is devoting special attention to the gerrymandered district, believing that to re-elect McKinley under existing circumstances will be worth more to the party than the return of any other dozen Republican Representatives.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- Yale defeated Wesleyan here to-day at football by a score of 34 to 0, but as two of Wesleyan's best players were unable to take part in the game the victory was not so overwhelming as it seems. Wesleyan played a good game, bat Yale's rush line was the heavier and her team excelled in interference. Yale's team showed up poorly, her rush line being weak.

Chairman Roswell P. Flower and Senator Gorman of Maryland have been in consultation the last two days concerning the work of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Mr. Flower said last evening that the committee had every reason to be satisfied with the outlook. While talking with a reporter for THE TIMES Mr. Flower produced one of the fraudulent circulars entitled "Under Which Flag?" which the Republicans are scattering over the country.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- In the Circuit Court to-day C.G. Tousey, son of Sinclair Tousey, deceased, sued Graham Sterling for $5,000 damages, charging the defendant with attempting to murder him. The affair occurred in August, 1889, while the two were sitting in a hammock at Mr. Tousey's residence, Clinton Corners.

GALESBURG, Ill., Oct. 8. -- President Harrison arose early this morning, but he was not early enough to escape the thousands of Peorians who had assembled around his hotel in that city. At 7 o'clock the band serenaded the President, and a few minutes later the Mayor and City Council, accompanied by the Grand Army of the Republic posts and a company of the Illinois National Guard, appeared to escort him to the train.

The trial of an action in which much hard feeling among members of the Mellen family is involved was begun yesterday before Justice Patterson and a jury in the Supreme Court. The plaintiff is Mrs. Mellen, the widow of Abner Mellen, Jr., who died in March last, and the action is for the partition of the real estate at 204 Fifth Avenue, 510, 518, and 520 East Seventeenth Street, and 8 Mulberry Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 8. -- The eighty-first annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Mission opened this afternoon in Plymouth Congregational Church with about 125 corporate members and not less than 1,000 delegates present. Western Congregationalists predominated, but New-York and New-England are very well represented by leading men of both sides.

The conference or the sub-committees of the three anti-Tammany organizations at the Brunswick Hotel yesterday kept the politicians in a state of feverish excitement all day, and sent them to bed last night utterly in the dark as to what the anti-Tammany ticket would be. With the conferrees it was a day of the hardest kind of work.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald has made a report to Gov. Hill upon the first execution by electricity in this State, that of William Kemmler, at Auburn, Aug. 6, 1890. The report first gives the details of Kemmler's death, so fully stated at the time, and the post mortem appearances of the body. It then continues as follows:

The Board of Managers of the Cotton Exchange has prepared an amendment to the bylaws of the Exchange, and the members are asked to take action on it at noon, Monday, Oct. 20. The amendment requires that the Quotation Committee for Spot Cotton shall meet at the Exchange on each business day at 2 P.M., except on Saturdays, when it shall meet at 11:45 A.M.

YORK, Penn., Oct. 8. -- The Independent Republicans of this city and county held a rousing demonstration in the York County Court House this evening. The house was packed to overflowing with one of the largest audiences ever gathered here. There was great enthusiasm throughout. Major H.S. McNair, a battle-searred veteran, presided and made a short speech.

The General Time Convention, composed of representatives of the various railroads in this country, met at the Hotel Brunswick in this city yesterday afternoon. The business, which was mostly routine, was transacted in secret session. Col. H.S. Haines of Savannah, Ga., presided, and Mr. W.F. Allen of this city was the Secretary of the meeting.

After a contest marked by brilliant work the Detroit amateur ball players defeated the New-Jersey Athletic Club nine, and won the amateur championship of the United States yesterday. They were highly pleased with their success, and as the train for Detroit rolled out of the Grand Central Station last night their yells and cheers could be heard for some distance.

There will be an interesting contest in the Sixth Congressional District of Massachusetts, where one "scholar in politics" is pitted against another, and the result will be, in the language of the late THOMAS CARLYLE, "significant of much." There is a wide difference between both the scholarship and the politics of Dr. WILLIAM EVERETT and Mr. HENRY CABOT LODGE.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 8. -- William Sprague, Jr., only son of the ex-Governor and ex-Senator of Rhode Island, and the only grandson of Salmon P. Chase, Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury and ex-Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, committed suicide in his lodgings in this city probably some time during Monday night.

Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision in the test suit of William Van Valkenburg against Controller Myers for a mandamus to compel the Controller to pay him weekly under the weekly payment law. He holds that a mandamus cannot be issued, as Mr. Van Valkenburg does not belong to the class which the act was intended to protect.

The National Board of Steam Navigation concluded its nineteenth annual meeting, begun Tuesday, yesterday afternoon. The President announced as the Committee on the Law of Libel Messrs. J.W. Bryant of New-Orleans, F. W. Vosburgh of New-York, J.B. Coyle of Portland, J.A. Henderson of Pittsburg, J.D. Parker of Cincinnati, and J.E. Massergale of St. Louis.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 8. -- The revolution against Tillman has taken definite shape all over South Carolina. The movement to run Judge A.C. Haskell against Tillman is discussed on the streets here, as secession was discussed before the war. Opinions, pro and con, are expressed with a vehemence that implies deep feeling and earnest action.

The report of Dr. MACDONALD to the Governor on the execution of KEMMLER is an impartial and instructive paper. There seems to be no doubt that KEMMLER was unconscious of pain within a very few seconds after the electric current was applied to his body, a very much shorter time than any man was ever killed in by hanging.

MOLINE, Ill., Oct. 8. -- The wedding of Miss Anna Deere, eldest daughter of Charles H. Deere, of Moline Ill., and William D. Wiman, son of Erastus Wiman, the well-known New-York financier, was solemnized in the Congregational church at 7 o'clock this evening. It was a brilliant affair. The service was celebrated by the pastor, the Rev. Mr. Morgan.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 8. -- Rube Burrows, the notorious outlaw and train robber who was captured in Marengo County yesterday afternoon, was killed by one of the men who were guarding him at Linden this morning. He was captured by John McDuffie, J.C. Carter, and two negroes. A special from Demopolis, Ala., gives the following details of the Killing:

Gratitude is not generally believed to form a component part in the make-up of racegoers. And the ears of the clerk of the weather must have tingled and burned yesterday from the way visitors to Morris Park were talking about him. It is rarely so striking a difference of weather is seen as that of yesterday compared with the two previous days.

The hearty praise accorded to the encampment of the National Guard of New-York at Peekskill this year is all the more gratifying from the fact that the inspecting officer, GEN. R.H. JACKSON, has performed the same duty during several previous Summers. Hence, had there been any falling off this season from the standard of the Peekskill camp, which is admitted to be very high, it would presumably have been the subject of comment.

VIENNA, Oct. 8. -- The Neue Freie Pressc says that a conference has been held by Dr. Dunajewski, Austrian Minister of Finance; Dr. Wekerle, Hungarian Minister of Finance, and the Directors of the Austro-Hungarian Bank to consider the financial situation resulting from the recent silver legislation in the United States.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- After a two-days' postponement the Inter-Collegiate Lawn Tennis Association to-day continued its annual Fall championship tournament. The courts of the New-Haven Lawn Tennis Club, on whose grounds the meeting is being held, are of earth and consequently but little effected by wet weather. Columbia's hopes were in a measure shattered when it became known that E.P. MacMullen, one of her representatives, would not be able to play owing to illness.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Oct. 8. -- A tragedy enacted at a ranch on the Sweetwater yesterday took from his scene of action a man who for five long years has waged relentless war on the rustlers and desperadoes who infest that region. The fight with this class was only varied by an occasional collision with a small settler resenting the encroachment of the big cattle outfit managed by this aggressive, alert cowboy owner.

Miss Elizabeth Peyton Norton, daughter of Mr. Ex Norton of New-Brighton, S.I., was married to Adolph J. Outerbridge at 8 o'clock last evening. The marriage ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Huchins of Heighten Bright Reformed Church, assisted by the Rev. Pascal Harrower of Port Richmond. The bride wore a dress of heavy white silk, trimmed with pointlace and orange blossoms.

FLORENCE, Oct. 8. -- A banquet was given here this evening in honor of Premier Crispi. The Premier said he was unable to deliver a speech that would serve as an election programme, because no decision on the subject had yet been taken.

FAIRMONT, West Va., Oct. 9. -- That this place is destined within a very few years to be the centre of one of the largest coal and cooking operations in this country is very rapidly becoming apparent, and within a year there will in all probability be 5,000 men employed in coal mining and coke making within a radius of five miles of this place.

The residence of Charles A. Tucker, at Orange, iT. i J', of the Tucker Electrical Construction Company I of New. York was entirely destroyed by fire yestor. ,lay morning. The house was owned by Dr. q-'homas 14ainey of this city. The damage is estimated at $18.000. The furniture and tixureswere entirely ruined. The house was a new one and had been ocespied b3' Mr. Tucker but four months.

Daly's Theatre was crowded to the doors last night when the third performance of "New Lamps for Old" was given. The Duchess of Marlborough and Mr. Arthur Leary, with a large theatre party, occupied two of the proscenium boxes, while another was occupied by Mr. and Mrs. George Gould and some friends. There were many other well-known faces in the audience.

The word "canvass," as applied to counting and making up the returns of votes at an election, is rather vague in its meaning, and there is a chance for a difference of opinion as to the exact intent of the provision in the ballot law requiring that "the votes for the several candidates shall be canvassed in the order in which they appear upon the several ballots."

Racing enthusiasts, including betting men, bookmakers, owners, trainers, and hangers-on generally, will have something to talk about for days to come. It is all owing to the defeat of Raceland yesterday at Morris Park by Eon, and Sallie McClelland's crushing defeat for the Fashion Stakes by Banker August Belmont's smart filly, La Tosca.

The Evening Post has done a good thing in prodding the Executive Committee of the Republican Congressional Committee concerning the "extracts" attributed by that body in a "campaign document" to the London Times and the London Standard. These extracts are still less like the journalism of London in style and still more like that of the wild and breezy West than those that were used in the campaign of 1888.

Republican Senators continue to predict, with great show of confidence, the passage of the bayonet bill during the next session of Congress, and it is undoubtedly true that it is the present intention of the radical Republicans in the Senate to take the bill up early in December and to push it toward its passage with all the strength that they can command.

The question of obtaining a charter for the General Conference of the Free Baptist Churches of the United States was the most important that came up at the meeting of the Conference Board which closed the convention of Free Baptist societies in the First Free Baptist Church of Brooklyn yesterday.

James M. Dougherty, the insane man who once persecuted Mary Anderson with his attentions, walked into the main office of the Flatbush Insane Asylum a few minutes before 6 o'clock last night and, almost without a word of warning, shot and killed Dr. George W. Lloyd, the Assistant Superintendent. The murderer effected his temporary escape with the greatest ease. Two or three hours later he was captured near the New-York entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 9. -- South Carolina is now without a straight political party. The Democracy has been shattered, and the Republicans will amalgamate with one of the factions claiming to be the straigt-hout Democracy. One hundred and sixty-four men, representing nineteen counties, assembled here to-night and nominated the following State ticket in opposition to that nominated by the Democratic Convention:

The public interest was confined to the Twelfth District, where Watson's intention of carrying off the nomination had become well known. A big crowd was in the Twenty-fifth Ward Wigwam in Reid Avenue when the delegates were called to order. It was evident that Watson would win, but Kurth's friends gave him a fight for it.

The sting of yesterday's ring convention in Hoboken to ratify Boss Davis's choice of John J. McPhillips, his Under Sheriff, as his successor in the Sheriff's office, was all in its tail. The convention was made up of city and county officials, who all owe their places to the boss's favor, and everything went off according to programme.
Democratic conventions were held in the four Congressional districts of Kings County yesterday, and in all the greatest harmony prevailed. The following candidates were selected unanimously:

The result of the conferences between the committees of the People's Municipal League and the Republican and County Democracy organizations and the action of the league convention at Scottish Rite Hall last night place before the people of this city an anti-Tammany ticket which combines all the elements of strength and ought to give the utmost satisfaction to those who seek the overthrow of the corrupt oligarchy which now rules the city.

New-York seems to be doubly afflicted -- first, by the absurd policy of the present Administration and power at Washington relative to the tariff and almost all other business problems, and, second, by the fact that in New-York City we have the unfortunate regime of Tammany Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Some of the money that is to be used for the benefit of the Republican Party in Ohio is being filched from the pockets of the department clerks and other Government employes here who have been appointed from the State of Ohio. Local leaders are busy "squeezing" them, and they intend to take away enough to make their visit worth while.

The New-York Telegraphers' Club will have its second annual ball at the Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue, next Wednesday evening. The occasion will be given additional interest by the presentation of a handsome brooch, given by the Hon. James D. Reid, United States Consul to Dunfermline, Scotland, to Miss Kittie Stephenson, the winner of first prize in the ladies' class in the late fast sending tournament.

Dr. HOWARD CROSBY was examined by the Senate investigating committee yesterday as an expert on excise laws and their administration in this city. He had a poor opinion of the present laws and a poorer one of their present administration. In a general way he advocates making the laws more specific and more restricted and giving the Excise Commissioners less discretion in their application.

There are many signs that the census taken by the police will not be very much more complete than that taken by the Census Bureau. The facts adduced in their own defense by the officers of the Board of Health are entirely conclusive that the population of this city reaches 1,700,000.

The greater portion of the German Army and Navy has been armed with the new rifle in the course of the last few months, and the issuing of the weapon continues. This is the fifth change of arms made by the German Government in the last fifty years. In point of effectiveness the new arm is deemed equal to the French Lebel. The Germans consider it superior.

Since the ballet-reform law was passed there has hardly been a point raised regarding its interpretation that is of such general interest to voters as the one raised by THE TIMES yesterday in regard to the method of canvassing the ballots. There have been questions of more vital importance, but the speed with which the votes are canvassed and the results made known is a matter that appeals strongly to New-Yorkers.

For such a task and such a trust Mr. SCOTT is abundantly qualified by his intimate familiarity with the mechanism of the City Government, by his uprightness and integrity, and by his habit of going about official business in a straightforward fashion. In the twofold aspect of candidate and of possible Mayor, he realizes the necessarily high ideals with which the Municipal League entered upon its work last June.

As was foretold exclusively in THE TIMES, a conference was held yesterday by the representatives of the three leading baseball organizations and efforts are being made to form a treaty of peace. The object may not be accomplished in a week or in a month, but the indications are that when the championship series begin next season baseball will be on its old footing.

The Senate Committee on Cities closed its investigation in the Excise Department yesterday and began with the County Clerk's office. The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby was called by William M. Ivins to give expert testimony in relation to excise administration. At the outset Dr. Crosby in response to Mr. Ivins's question, said:

A special dispatch from Boston says: "An opinion involving millions of dollars, according to the attorneys, was given by Judge Colt in the United States Circuit Court to-day in the cast of the Pullman Palace Car Company against the Boston and Albany Railroad Company and others. The bill in this case alleges infringement of letters patent granted May 14, 1889, to George M. Pullman for a new improvement in solid vestibule connection between railroad cars.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 9. -- The long-expected report of the investigating committee of nine appointed last year to "inquire into the methods of administration pursued at the headquarters of the American Board at Boston and to recommend changes which appear to be needful," was made to the board in session here this morning through its Chairman, the Rev. George Leon Walker, and was a unanimous one.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- It is growing more apparent every day that the Democratic ring in Cincinnati and its friends will lay every obstacle in the way of Gov. Campbell, and, if possible defeat him in his efforts to have the Board of Public Improvements in Cincinnati abolished by the Legislature that will be convened on Tuesday next in special session for this purpose.

The sixteenth annual examination of the Nautical School of New-York took place yesterday on the schoolship St. Mary's, at anchor in the East River opposite the foot of Thirty-first Street. The ship has only recently returned from a European cruise, and the boys of the various classes were consequently well prepared in a practical way for the tests to which they were subjected.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 9. -- The court-martial held at Bermuda on account of the war ship Pylades running ashore resulted in the Captain being reprimanded and the engineer dismissed from the ship. Three sailors were also court-martialed. One of the men imprisoned broke some rule and received eighteen lashes. He was afterward tried and got twelve months' imprisonment and his discharge.

Miss Saletta May Pressinger was married to Mathew Kane Miller, at the residence of the bride's mother, 139 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, yesterday. Miss Pressinger is the daughter of the late Capt. Augustine E. Pressinger of the Seventh Regiment. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Edward L. Clark, pastor of the Church of the Pilgrims, assisted by the Rev. A.R. Macoubrey of San Mateo, Fla.

The contention of the Republican orators that their party is the party of intelligence is very old. In the main it is true, in the sense that the Republican Party comprises more than its numerical proportion of intelligent men. These men cling to it from the force of association, derived from a time when the boast was well founded in another sense.

When the second installment of the charges of Davitt's Labor World against William R. Hoare, the British Consul at this port, were read to that gentleman yesterday he specifically denied every assertion made by Mr. Davitt as to his connection with "Red Jim" McDermott and also as to any knowledge of such a person as Matt O'Brien, for whom he was said to have secured a position in the New-York Post Office through Inspector Newcombe.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 9. -- The Fifth National Encampment of the Union Veteran Legion continues to be full of interest to the distinguished soldiers in attendance at to-day's session. Commander Read of St. Louis presided. Reading, Penn., was selected as the place of holding the next encampment, and Oct. 9, 1891, was fixed as the date.

Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday assigned to E.A. Kent the task of considering whether or not Miss Esther Gracie Lawrence should have expended on her support and maintenance in her proper social position the whole of her share in the income from the estate of her grandfather, William Beach Lawrence. Miss Lawrence's general guardian is her uncle, James G.K. Lawrence.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9. -- The first joint session of the British Iron and Steel Institute and the American Societies of Engineers and Iron and Steel Manufacturers was held in Carnegie Hall this morning. The meeting was a success beyond expectation. The visitors from abroad assembled in large numbers on the floor of the hall, and the galleries were filled with ladies.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The stock market was a scene of wild excitement to-day. At the opening Canadian Pacific declined 1 per cent. from last evening's closing price. Erie fell 1/2, Erie second consols 1 1/4, Illinois Central 4 1/2, Mexican ordinary 1/2, St. Paul common 2 1/4, New-York Central 1 1/4, Pennsylvania 1/2, and Reading 3/4.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- It is a curious circumstance that while the apple crop of Orange and Sullivan Counties is otherwise almost a total failure, two trees which enjoy a wide celebrity on account of their age and size and peculiarities of bearing return, as usual, a large yield of fruit. The two trees in question are ancient landmarks of the Minisink region, and are pronounced great curiosities by pomologists.

Ex-Attorney General R.A. Ayres of Virginia is staying at the Everett, Mr. Ayres enjoys the distinction of having spent six days in jail in 1887 for violating the order of Judge Bond of the United States Circuit Court not to bring suit against persons who had tendered State bond coupons in payment for taxes. Mr. Ayres held that the State law obliged him to bring the suits, and he made it a test question.

While the Senate Committee on Finance was going over the McKinley bill, the Senate voted that the committee should be required to explain and defend in its report each proposed change of rates. This was done upon the motion of Mr. PLUMB. Therefore the committee prepared for the information of the Senate a large volume of tariff statistics, with "notes explanatory of proposed changes from present law," as the title page says.

Five hundred Republicans, one-half of whom were delegates to the County Convention, assembled last evening at Webster Hall in East Eleventh Street, near Third Avenue, for the purpose of considering the report of the Committee of Twenty-four, which had originally been appointed to secure a fusion ticket, that was first put in the field by the People's Municipal League at its convention Wednesday, and published in THE TIMES yesterday morning.

Six good races were decided yesterday at Morris Park over a track that was still heavy from the recent heavy rainfalls. The weather was threatening about noon and no doubt deterred a number of fair-weather racegoers from making the journey, yet the improved programme attracted a large throng, and the bookmakers had no cause to complain of lack of business.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Until this evening it was generally believed by Princeton men that a game of football with Harvard would be absolutely impossible this season, owing to a misapprehension in regard to Harvard's proposition to Yale at the last Springfield conference. But a letter has been received from the Harvard Athletic Association requesting the Princeton management to correct the error.

DUBLIN, Oct. 10. -- The case of the Crown against William O'Brien and John Dillon, who are charged with conspiracy in inciting tenants not to pay their rents, was again called in the magistrate's court at Tipperary this morning. Messrs. O'Brien and Dillon have hitherto been present at all the hearings, but this morning when the court opened they did not appear.

ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- To-day some definite information of the action of the Commander in Chief of the State forces and his Adjutant General, relative to the row and consequences thereof in the Twenty-second Regiment, was made public in these brief sentences:

After years of effort lineal promotion for subalterns in the army is assured, and they are put on the same footing in this respect as other officers below the grade of Colonel. The change applies at the start only to Second Lieutenants, but gradually through their promotions will extend to First Lieutenants.

Both the Democratic and the Republican City and County Conventions will be held in Brooklyn to-day. The Democrats will meet in the new Thomas Jefferson Building, while the Republicans will have to put up with the dilapidated old Athaeneum, in Atlantic Avenue. Both County Conventions will be held at 3 P.M., and both the City at 8 P.M.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10. -- Four races occupied the afternoon at Pimlico to-day, three of them being ended before the daylight was gone. It was bright and hot, and the crowd was again large. Horicon won the 2:22 class, left from yesterday, in another heat, trotting to a new record of 2:20 12. Great Eastern, the favorite for the 2:25 class, got two heats and was then beaten cleverly by the local trotter, John W.

This is Tammany's ticket. Richard Croker and his coterie selected it, the Tammany Committee of Twenty-four agreed to it yesterday afternoon, and last night the Tammany County Convention, held in the Fourteenth Street Wigwam, obeyed instructions without a murmur and confirmed it. The convention itself was a mere form, a tedious farce.

At a meeting of the New-York Yacht Racing Association at its rooms, Twenty-second Street and Sixth Avenue, last evening, the Executive Committee reported the election of the Oceanic Yacht Club of Jersey City a member of the Association. The resignation of the Cedar Point Yacht Club of Saugatuck, Conn., was accepted.

Under the auspices of the People's Municipal League, at Chickering Hall, last night, the Archdeacon of New-York, the Rev. Dr. Alexander Mackay-Smith, eloquently denounced the rule of Tammany Hall before an assemblage composed of citizens disgusted with the present system of municipal government. Gen. John Newton presided, having the Rev. Father Thomas J. Ducey on his left and Archdeacon Mackay-Smith on his right.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Justice Samuel F. Miller, of the Supreme Court of the United States, was stricken with partial paralysis of the left side this afternoon about 3 o'clock, while on his way home from the Capitol, and is now at his home on Massachusetts Avenue.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 10. -- Chauncey I. Filley, the big Republican boss, has been laying wires so effectively that he has politics in Missouri all mixed up, and it is gradually dawning upon the people that he has things fixed so that he has a fair chance for succeeding Senator Vest in the United States Senate. Filley began the campaign in those counties in this State where the Democratic majorities are very small.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The October estimates of yield per acre for the entire breadth of cereal crops, as consolidated by the Department of Agriculture, are as follows:

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 10. -- The President held a reception early this morning at St. Joseph, where his train stopped for half an hour, and where he addressed a large crowd. Here he was met by a reception committee, including Gov. Humphrey, ex-Gov. Osborne, Chief Justice Horton, and Col. James Burgess, which acted as his escort over the State line and until Topeka was reached.

The renomination by the Democrats of Mr. WILLIAM J. COOMBS in the Third Congressional District (Brooklyn) against Mr. WALLACE, the present member, ought to secure to the voters of that district a really competent Representative. There is no district in the State in which the business interests of New-York City and of the entire country are more largely centred.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 10. -- The results of to-day's deliberations of the American Board show that it is to be officered by the same men next year, that there is to be no immediate change in its corporate form of government, and that the board intends that hereafter theological examinations of candidates shall be made by the Prudential Committee and not by Secretary Alden.

James H. Dougherty, who shot and killed Dr. George W. Lloyd, Assistant Superintendent of the Kings County Insane Asylum at Flatbush, Thursday evening, was taken from the Oak Street station house yesterday morning to the Tombs Police Court, where Justice Kilbreth, without any delay, turned him over to the Brooklyn authorities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Classification has been the sole thought of exposition managers during the week. The committee of the commission has been laboring all the week and has completed and adopted a plan of twelve departments, or groups. They are:

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 10. -- James M. Dougherty, the murderer of Dr. Lloyd, was a picturesque character in this section in 1884, when he came out this way to string the wires of the Postal Telegraph Company. At that time his brain was bursting with what he called "the Dougherty motor," an invention with which he expected to revolutionize and outstrip electricity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A pretty fair sample of the sort of stuff with which the Republican managers hope to befuddle the people who are to go to the polls next month is the latest document issued by the Republican Congressional Committee.

The subfluvial banquet designed to celebrate the completion of the St. Clair River Tunnel is a refreshing novelty in conception among affairs habitually commonplace. A table a thousand feet long, laid in the big cylinder itself, which is to be lighted with electricity and placed, too, so as to be half on the Canada side and half on ours, the Chairman bestriding the boundary line, at least makes a striking appeal to the imagination.

Members of the Real Estate Exchange are already much interested in the annual election, which will occur in December. Although that event is yet two months distant, the issues are pretty well defined, and both sides have become very active in soliciting proxies and otherwise in preparing themselves for a vigorous contest for control.

The Autumn season at the Young Men's Christian Association, at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, has opened with an unusually large attendance of young men. New members may still be admitted to the classes up to Oct. 15. Any young man of good character may join, and is welcome to call and visit the building before joining.

Just what is going to be the result of the trouble between the Erie Railway system and its employes was not even suggested by anything that occurred yesterday. The forty-three engineers, firemen, conductors, brakemen, and switchmen forming the committee of the Federated Board of Erie Employes were as glum and sullen a looking lot of men after reading the ultimatum as could be imagined.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- A circular has been issued by the Government denying the report that fever prevails to an alarming extent among the Grenadier Guards, who are now stationed in Bermuda, and that a large number of deaths have occurred. The circular states that there has been only one death from fever in the regiment.

Congressman Walker's speech at the Massachusetts Club the other night was like one of those reversible garments which looks better "the other side out." This is peculiarly true of his peroration, in which he said: "I believe that right-minded men were one-half exhausted and worn out, not by legislative work, but by the revolting and disloyal -- I had almost used a stronger word -- conduct of members of the Fifty-first Congress.

While the leaders of the People's Municipal League were a little in doubt Friday night as to who William H. Corsa, the nominee for Sheriff, really was, inquiries made yesterday established the fact that he is a good man to run for the office, and has an excellent record. Mr. Corsa was born in this city in 1844 and entered the Free Academy in 1858.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- The intercollegiate tennis tournament was continued here to-day, and first place was decided in the singles, and Harvard will thus hold the cup for this year. The great match of the day was between O.S. Campbell, the Columbia expert, and F.H. Hovey of Harvard. This match was played in the afternoon and was witnessed by many spectators.

Frederick S. Gibbs startled the Cowie-Sprague faction last night with a flank movement of the most adroit nature. When he had accomplished his purpose and was safely entrenched in his little Round Top his adherents hailed him as General; many were clamorous for calling him another Bonaparte.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Advertisements for proposals have been issued from the War Department, under the provisions of the Fortifications act of the last session of Congress, for furnishing the Ordnance Department of the army with twenty-five eight-inch, fifty ten-inch, and twenty-five twelve-inch steel guns, and ammunition for their test or proof, all to be of American manufacture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- In his opinion, rendered yesterday to the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning the withdrawal from bond free of duty of goods warehoused under previous law and made free by the new law, Solicitor Hepburn says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Associate Justice Miller of the United States Supreme Court, who was stricken with paralysis yesterday, is still living, but his death is expected at any moment. At 10 o'clock to-night his physicians reported that he was sinking very rapidly. They will be surprised if he lives through the night.

Some years ago two farmers of Polk County lost their wives by death. They naturally felt lonesome, and in due time began to think a second wife in each household would be a most excellent addition thereto. They were neighbors and friends, and each had a family of children, including one or more grown daughters. After careful consideration, each took the other's daughter as his second wife.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11. -- There was a dramatic scene in the Tennessee Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South to-day at Pulaski when the name of D.C. Kelley, D.D., was called. The conference was hearing reports of preachers and passing characters.

The new iron-clad Sardegna was launched yesterday morning at Spezia in the presence of the Duke and Duchess of Genoa, the Minister of Marine, and an enormous crowd which had arrived from all parts of Italy. The launching was perfectly successful, and took place in the midst of the greatest enthusiasm. The Sardegna is of the same type as the two first-class battle ships Re Umberto and Sicilia.

PLAYING "RIP" IN THE CATSKILLS. -- There is in the village of Catskill a Rip Van Winkle Club. This society did me the honor to invite me to act the character in their town. I accepted, and when I arrived was met by the worthy President and other members of the club, among whom was young Nicholas Vedder, who claimed to be a lineal descendant of the original "Old Nick."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11. -- The season has already begun and the fashionable quarters of the city have again assumed their accustomed appearance of life and activity. It is uncommon for society here to plunge into the excitement attendant upon dinners and luncheons immediately on returning from its outing, and a few weeks are usually passed in indolent repose and in reflecting over the gayeties which have lately been experienced at seaside and mountain resorts.

It was getting late; the last omnibus had gone, and the few remaining pedestrians in the Euston Road were hurrying homeward, anxious to leave that dismal thoroughfare behind. The footsteps, gradually growing fainter, seemed to leave a greater desolation, though one man at least appeared to be in no hurry as he strode listlessly along, as if space and time were of one accord to him.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Gen. Robert Lenox Banks, President of the Lake George Association for the Protection of Fish and Game, says that not so much opposition is met with by the association in enforcing the laws as during the first years of its existence. Now the stanchest friends of the association are the dwellers on the lake and some of its former opponents.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 11. -- Although many of the cottagers have left Bellevue Avenue still presents a lively appearance every pleasant afternoon.

In one of the current monthly magazines Prof. SHALER returns to certain fascinating theories regarding the kind of men hereafter to be expected to swarm in different parts of North America. Formerly it was the fashion to generalize from the natural characteristics of a region to the special sort of human being proper thereto. But later naturalists were more cautious, feeling that there were insufficient materials at hand whereon theories could be built with safety.

DUBLIN, Oct. 11. -- It is definitely known that Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien were not among the passengers who sailed on the steamer La Bourgogne from Havre for New-York to-day. There is no trustworthy information as to how they left the country, but the theory that they went on board a yacht and boarded a steamer outside is a favorite theory.

The ways of "lovely woman" when she calls to her aid the telegraph service, together with a glimpse into a disordered household, were both shown at the Twenty-third Street telegraph station, near Fifth Avenue, on a recent afternoon. It was close upon 4 o'clock when a young woman, tall, well dressed, and considerably agitated, appeared there and, seizing a blank, wrote rapidly for a moment before she stepped over to the man in charge.

Deputy Collector Dudley F. Phelps, in charge of the Ninth, or Law, Division of the Custom House, is at present deliberating upon a question raised by the new tariff law, which is of great importance to importers of kid gloves.

The new volume in the Adventure Series takes one to North Africa, among the Barbary Corsairs and the semi-savage Mohammedans of Morocco. Thomas Pellow is a worthy comrade to Robert Drury of the "Journal in Madagascar," and of John Shipp, whose "Extraordinary Military Career" was reviewed in this journal some time ago.
