NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 11. -- Ten days ago it was considered that the Republicans had a fighting chance of success in the First and Second Congressional Districts, which include the city of New-Orleans. Influences are now at work, however, which are rending the party in twain, and it is quite likely that before election day there will be two candidates in both the First and Second Districts of the city.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Daniel Randolph, a Park Avenue farmer, found two young sportsmen gunning in his woods this morning, and ordered them off the premises. Instead of obeying him they jeered in derision, and he tried to drive them away with stones. A fight resulted, in which one of the trespassers struck him over the head with the butt of his gun and felled him senseless to the earth.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Yesterday the discovery that Mr. Dillon and Mr. O'Brien had quit the country created widespread interest which has rather increased than abated to-day. Other things even more startling are to occur early next week, which will give a sensational turn to the whole Irish situation. Just what they are to be is a well-kept secret and only a hint that they are forthcoming has reached me.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- Blondes are going to suffer terribly -- natural blondes, dyed blondes, oxygenee blondes; no one will escape the coming curse of Sarah. In "Tosca" Bernhardt turned the fashions of the world over to the First Empire; half the globe is still there. In "Theodora" she imposed jewel belts and Byzantine patterns.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Charles L. Porter filed a bill in the Circuit Court this morning asking for a receiver for the Chicago Glycerine Manufacturing Company, organized in 1889 with a capital stock of $50,000. Complainant says he subscribed for 249 shares, Augustus Byram for 428, and W. Church, James Doyle, and George Smith for one share each.
RUSSIAN SECTS. -- Russia is a conglomeration of races, some of which are more or less akin, while others have no connection at all.

In the old Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, next to the University Building in Washington Square, the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby yesterday morning addressed the School of Pedagogy. The announcement of his subject as "The Teacher in Politics" drew a very large number of public instructors to hear him, and there were enough others in attendance to fill the church to the doors.

If any one had suggested the possibility of ladies being received in aristocratic male clubs a few years ago he would have been considered a most promising candidate for Bedlam. Despite this fact two of the most fashionable and exclusive clubs in New-York and one club of the same character in Brooklyn now make provision for the reception and entertainment of the wives and daughters of their members.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Oct. 11. -- The chapter of the Beta Theta Psi Fraternity, which formerly existed at Rutgers College but whose charter was revoked in 1885, will probably be revived, as a number of students have signified their willingness to enter its circle.

PARIS, Oct. 11. -- The agitation over the new United States tariff law was greater than ever during the last week. The wildest ideas as to the scope and effect of the law were prevalent. Lyons virulently remonstrated against heavily-increased duties on silk, Bordeaux was equally excited about wine, and the whole of France was in a condition of extreme irritation and apprehension, which was reflected by the newspapers.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 11. -- G.H. Downing, a York business man whose home is in Morristown, threatens to bring suit against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company for ejection from a train. He offered Conductor Slack of the Hackettstown express a thousand mile book from which the cover had been torn so that there was no way by which the original owner could be known.

At the old mortar which stood out under the poplar tree near her cabin door Haum Dilcie was singing her camp-meeting hymn and beating rice, the heavy pestle, in her strong arms, moving in time with the refrain, sometimes coming down with a more than ordinarily emphatic thud, accordingly as she felt "bound for Canaan's sho'."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11. -- The Autumn meeting at the Pimlico track ended this afternoon with some of the best racing of the week. The 2:20 pacers were well matched, and it was not till the seventh heat that the struggle was over. Vittelo, who won the first heat and made a record of 2:16 3/4, did not get another until Queen Gothard, King Toska, and Caesar had earned new honors all below 2:20.

Adjt. Gen. Porter said yesterday in reference to the settlement of the Twenty-second Regiment troubles that the two field officers, Col. Camp and Lieut. Col. King, and seven Captains of the regiment had tendered their resignations to the Commander in Chief. The other three Captains had declined to resign, their companies had been disbanded, and those Captains are now supernumerary.

The Rockaway Hunt people had a day of jolly sport at Cedarhurst yesterday. The weather was fine for an outing, the racing was unique, and the attendance was large. The Rockaway Hunt Club house is an attractive place at all times. The fun is unrestrained and the hospitality is unlimited. It was especially pleasant yesterday.

During the last week the Cunard Steamship Company, represented by its agent, Vernon H. Brown, and the Treasury Department, represented by Collector Joel B. Erhardt, have been engaged in a tug-of-war, with the result that the steamship line "which never lost a life" has come out ahead and with colors flying.

Tournaments, those sham battles of the Middle Age, tempered with the pantomimicry of courtesy, the brutality of the chivalry. It was a military organization the element of which was the lance furnished, composed of a knight, (chevalier,) two men-of-arms, several squires, pages, and varlets -- a total of three to fourteen men on horseback.

The prevalence of tuberculosis in several of the finest herds of cattle in New-Hampshire may cause the enactment in that State of effective laws for the inspection of dairy farms and the protection of consumers to whom milk from such farms is sold. A few weeks ago the disease was discovered in a herd belonging to the State, and more recently two large herds on farms near Manchester have become infected.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 11. -- The Yale football team played against Lehigh to-day on the Yale field and won by a score of 26 to 0. Although the score might not indicate it, the contest was a hot one. The game was rough and aggressive from the beginning, as was shown in the bloody faces and ugly cuts, especially in the case of Lehigh's left guard.

GABORIAU'S RASCALS. -- It was reserved for Gaboriau to strike out the new line which has been followed since he wrote "L'Affaire Lerouge" by hundreds of his countrymen and of ours. He elaborated, if he did not invent, the romance which turns entirely on the detection of a crime. He glorifies and idealizes the exploits of the elite of the handful of men who control the dangerous masses of Paris.
There is nothing surprising in the present ferocious attempt to destroy a man so upright and so spotless as Mr. Grant.

Allen W. Thurman, who is acting the part of the mediator in the baseball conference, left for Columbus, his home, last night. He will return next week to preside at the meeting to be held in this city. It was learned yesterday that Mr. Thurman was elected Chairman and Charles H. Byrne Secretary of the conference committee.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The Cornell eleven defeated the University of Rochester 98 to 0 in a game consisting of three-quarter and half-hour halves. The Rochester eleven was much lighter than Cornell's and could do nothing with the Cornell rush line. All their work was done by their half-backs. The Rochester men were not well posted on the rules and there were continued interruptions to discuss points.

There are several books upon Washington life and Washington etiquette which endeavor to lay down many rules, where, as a matter of fact, few, beyond those which obtain in society everywhere, exist; and the strenuous endeavors of certain newly-arrived officials to be polite according to rule are frequently the subject of ridicule. A certain new bureau chief read in one of these books that a first visit should be returned immediately.

That malodorous organization, "The New-York Juvenile Guardian Society," composed of one D.F. Robertson (an alleged "reverend") and a few good-hearted but very gullible persons, has again, after repeated exposures, thrust itself before the public eye, preparatory to another swoop upon the purses of charitably-inclined persons for the replenishment of the larders of the irrepressible Robertson and his numerous hangers-on.

After several unsuccessful attempts Mr. Hammerstein last evening formally opened his Columbus Theatre in East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street in the presence of an audience that completely filled the spacious interior. It was late in the afternoon before his success in obtaining a license had become known in Harlem, but the news spread rapidly with the arrival of the evening papers, and long before 8 o'clock a crowd had gathered about the theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Republican Congressional Committee's particular pamphlet pet is a little book of eight pages entitled "The New Tariff," and the exuberance of its style is well epitomized in the line, "To scatter plenty o'er a smiling land," which follows the heading, inside of quotation marks.

Dr. J.B. Hamilton, Surgeon General of the United States Army, landed from the North German Lloyd steamer Saale yesterday morning, having been absent from this country about two months. When his attention was called to the report that he went abroad for the purpose of attaching a physician to the seaport Consulates of the United States in England and on the Continent, he said that there was no foundation for it.

WORK. -- One of the most decided and characteristic utterances on the subject of work is that of George Henry Lewes. It sounds like a veritable trumpet blast to summon young dreamers from a too long straying in flowery paths and moonlit groves. "There is in the present day," he says, "an overplus of raving about genius, and its prescriptive rights of vagabondage, its irresponsibility, and its insubordination to all the laws of common sense.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The cornerstone of the new buildings of the Paterson General Hospital was laid this afternoon by Grand Master Mann of the Grand Lodge of New-Jersey Freemasons, assisted by a full corps of officers of the Grand Lodge. There was a parade participated in by upward of 400 Freemasons, and two or three thousand members of other societies and public school children.

It will not be so easy for men of moderate means to make both ends meet the next year as it has been the last. The new Tariff bill of the Republican Party has taxed nearly everything made in this country, and, what is strangest, nearly everything used in making ether things. In the case of imported goods the advance in price will be direct and unavoidable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Now is the time for the Manhattan Athletic Club of New York to crow, and her representatives are taking advantage of their turn to whoop things up. Several hundred men wearing the pretty "cherry diamond" of the club are having a jollification here to-night over the result of the National Amateur Athletic Union's championship of the United States, contested on the grounds of the Columbia Athletic Club.

THE LAST TRUMP -- BRASS OR SILVER? -- A conection of mine for whom I have an affectionate regard, a clergyman, though once and officer in the army, and who lives in constant expectation of "the Lord's coming," was telling me one morning at breakfast of the wreck, off the coast of his parish, of a small vessel which he considered had been purposely run on some rocks for the sake of the insurance money.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- The speech of Signor Crispi, the Italian Prime Minister, at Florence, is an indirect admission of the Figaro interview, which irritated Austria by showing too open anxiety for financial reasons to conciliate France. King Humbert is said to have conveyed a hint to the Prime Minister that he had gone a little too far in this direction.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 11. -- A large crowd came out to the grounds of the New-Haven Lawn Tennis Club this morning to witness the final match in doubles in the intercollegiate tournament. The weather was excellent for tennis, the day being cool and cloudy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- "Fraud, Theft, and Assassination," in fiery-red letters, is the heading of a double-sheet poster which the Republican Congressional Committee is sending down into the Second Arkansas District, where the unseated Breckinridge is again running for Congress, doubtless hoping that, if he should once more be elected, he would be fortunate enough to hold his seat.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- John Boyer, aged twenty-eight, under a five years' sentence for burglary, was being taken from Buffalo to Auburn Prison this morning when he escaped from Deputy Sheriff J.C. Veling of Buffalo, who had him in charge. As the train was pulling out of this station Boyer asked permission to visit the water closet.

THE NEW TESTAMENT IN CHINOOK. -- I once listened to a missionary, a good man but deficient in humor, narrating to a group of Indians the weird tale of Christ's betrayal and Peter's denial of his Master in a free paraphrase of the apostolic narrative:

M. Jules Simon makes an energetic appeal to his fellow-countrymen to put an end to the generally absurd, but sometimes tragic, custom of dueling. "I should like to know," he says, "what a duel proves beyond the fact that So-and-so has had a better fencing master than somebody else, or else that he was in better condition than his adversary on the day of the encounter.

The week has been one of weddings and suburban sports. Seldom in the social history of the city have there been six successive Autumn days so filled with events matrimonial. While none of the events has been remarkably notable, or united couples of unusual distinction in the society world, they have none the less been pleasant, attractive, and pretty incidents of the social year.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 11. -- A curious complication has arisen in the settlement of the estate of Edward Langevin, the many times million aire, who died suddenly three weeks ago. It was agreed that there was no will, and the widow had arranged with the St. Paul Trust Company to administer the estate, but yesterday she withdrew from the agreement and announced that there was a will.

Indications regarding a large proportion of the aboriginal inhabitants of what is the United States to-day seem to show that in the remote past the Indians had made their greatest advance toward semi-civilization. To lay down a general rule of this kind would be, however, presumptuous. There are many questions of vital importance of an ethnological character which are yet vague and undetermined.

ST. Louis, Oct. 11. -- President Harrison has come and gone, and the comment on every hand is that the reception was cold and utterly without enthusiasm. On every side are heard comments on the striking contrast between the welcome given Harrison and the grand greeting given Grover Cleveland when he came West.

LAKEWOOD, Oct. 11. -- The arrival of an unexpectedly large number of guests at the opening of the season last week gave strength to the previously-made prediction that Lakewood's growth and popularity as a Winter resort are neither ephemeral nor fleeting. The faith of capitalists in Lakewood was well illustrated in a letter to THE TIMES two weeks ago.

HARTFORD, Oct. 11. -- The centennial of the Connecticut State Medical Society, for which extensive preparations are now in progress, will be the most important event in this State in 1892. The establishment of the first insane retreat in the United States, and also of the first institution for the education of the deaf and dumb in this country, must be credited to the Connecticut Medical Society.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 11. -- The Canadian branch of the Imperial Federation League is inviting an expression of opinion on suggestions in favor not only of the objects of the association in general, but of the policy specially advocated by the branch in Canada of promoting such tariff changes as would give to each part of the empire advantages in the markets of all.

Ex-Assistant Postmaster General Clarkson of Iowa is very happy in his home relations. He has three sons, the eldest, Coker, being about twenty years of age, and the youngest, Grosvenor, about ten. Harold Clarkson is eighteen years old. The General had some pretty hard knocks in his youth, and made up his mind that his sons should have the benefit of his experience.

Twelve months have elapsed since the elections held in France in September, 1889, shattered the fabric of Boulangism. Still, people in general did not seam to have realized the hollowness of the sham until M. Mermeix took the public behind the scenes of the stage on which Boulanger has proved himself so poor an actor -- so poor, indeed, that he can find none so poor to do honor to his memory.

There are to be several fairs held in this city the coming Winter, all of them for worthy objects, and all of them with attractions of greater or less variety. One of them, however, is to be unique in many of its particulars, especially in the object for which it is to be given. It is a fair in aid of the Teachers' Mutual Benefit Associaton.

Only one newspaper, the Sun, has a word to say in Grant's favor. All the others are either silent on the subject, or strongly opposed. As for the Sun's support, we show in another column what that is worth by giving our list, with Grant and his semi-criminal supporters at the end, of the rascals and shady political characters whom the editor of the Sun has taken to his bosom during the past twenty years.

When the people begin to complain about the increased price of carpets, they should remember that the change in the tariff on carpet wool was made as the result of the agreement of two groups of persons -- the Ohio politicians, who profess to represent the wool growers, and the representatives of the manufacturers of carpets.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Theatrically the week has been one of interest and the various playhouses presenting new attractions have held overflowing audiences. Lawrence Barrett's appearance at the Chicago Opera House was the signal for a nightly gathering of this excellent actor's admirers. Mr. Barrett's return to strength and health and the eradication of the throat trouble which interfered so seriously with his stage work seem to be complete.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The Rev. J.H. L. Zillman has resigned the rectorate of Christ Episcopal Church, at Warwick, N.Y., and will engage in mission work in New-York City.

Twice the market has fallen and twice it has rallied the past week, and there is yet discouragement because the rallies are less than they should be after such liquidation. Monday was a low day, lower than the break on the previous Saturday. In the afternoon there was recovery, and it seemed that the worst was over, for the week at least.

The procession of vehicles on the East Drive of Central Park is a very marked contrast to what it was two month ago. In August there was scarcely a well-horsed and well-appointed equipage to be seen on the drive, unless haply that of some citizen who was spending the Summer in Europe and had left his horses in town, thereby enabling the coachman to give an airing to the cook.

The best card of the meeting was presented at Morris Park yesterday -- a card in which every event promised close and exciting finishes and which contained a most attractive array of entries. But, alas! the large crowd which put in an appearance with the expectation of witnessing the various races fought out to the bitter end was disappointed on account of the bad condition of the track.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11. -- With the Thanksgiving contests little more than a month away, football is of chief interest in the athletic circles at Yale, but the other sports are no neglected. The players are active, and the aspirants for boating honors next Spring practice every day in the gymnasium tanks or in shells on Lake Whitney or the Quinnipsic River.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 11. -- President Byrne and Parsons met here to-night and made the following agreement to govern the coming world's championship:

The Secretary of the Navy has advertised for proposals for the construction of ten Diehl-Gibson compasses or compensating binnacles. This instrument is the invention of Lieut. Diehl Naval Superintendent of Compasses, and his assistant, Ensign John Gibson. Briefly, the officers claim that by their arrangement of compensating magnets all the local magnetism of the skip can be counteracted.

Furriers' catalogues have so enlarged the study of zoology that ladies looking over them with a view to purchasing find themselves hopelessly bewildered and often are grossly deceived. "What's in a name?" is answered by a furrier who holds up a pretty muff and says: "Would the ladies buy it if we called it skunk?"

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 11. -- Some comment has been excited in commercial circles here by the announcement just made by the American importing house of Seeger, Guernsey Co., whose home office is in New-York, that it has opened a branch office in London for the purpose of supplying its Mexican customers with goods of European manufacture.

HARRISVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The season for deer shooting in the Adirondacks, which is now drawing to a close, is acknowledged to have been a good one by all the sportsmen who have traversed this part of the forest region. It has been many years since they have had such good shooting as they now enjoy in the northern portions of Herkimer and Lewis, and the southern part of St. Lawrence County.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 11. -- Representatives of the Yale and Harvard Navies met at the Massasoit House in Springfield to-day and discussed the question of changing the place for the annual Yale and Harvard 'Varsity boat race. Yale was represented by Capt. Brewster and President Townsend. The Harvard delegates were Capt. Perkins of the crew and Manager Brooks of the Boat Club.
CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The Putnam County Democrats held their convention in the Court House here to-day and nominated James E. Warner of Brewster's for the Assembly.

WHAT CAMPBELL MADE FROM HIS POEM. -- After forming many projects and failing to find congenial occupation, Campbell determined to devote all the time that he could spare from bread winning to complete a poem for publication. How he made a living then and what he hoped to accomplish may be learned from the following passage:

The condition of the real estate market still gives hope to holders of property, because of late there have been evidences of sharp activity and advancing prices in certain isolated sections of the city; while at the same time those who are looking for a decline in prices are still so confident in their opinions that they are unwilling to enter the market while property is held as high as at present.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 11. -- Applications for the appointment of Federal Election Supervisors are now coming in from all the Republican and close Democratic counties in the State, and it has become evident that there will be a systematic attempt upon the part of the Republicans to overawe and keep away from the polls the class of voters whom they have been accustomed in State campaigns to buy.

In the course of a quarrel Friday over the sale of a liquor store John G. Jones, a real estate broker of 23 Chambers Street, fired a shot from a revolver at Owen Collins of 510 West Forty-ninth Street. He was arrested, and in the Tombs Police Court yesterday was held in $1,000 bail for examination.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 11. -- At the regular meeting of the Intercollegiate Football League at Springfield the following schedule of games was arranged: Nov. 1, Dartmouth-Bowdoin, at Hanover; Nov. 1, Amherst-Technology, at Boston; Nov. 4, Williams-Bowdoin, at Portland, Me.; Nov. 8, Williams-Technology, at Boston; Nov. 8, Amherst-Bowdoin, at Amherst; Nov. 15, Williams-Amherst, at Williamstown; Nov. 15, Dartmouth-Technology, at Hanover; Nov. 19, Dartmouth-Amherst, at Amherst; Nov. 22, Dartmouth-Williams, at Williamstown; Nov. 27, Technology-Bowdoin, at Portland, Me.

The first sermon preached by the Rev. R. Heber Newton, rector of All Souls' Church, Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, this Fall, was delivered at yesterday morning's service in the presence of a congregation which filled the beautiful church. Mr. Newton talked about "What We Want in Municipal Reform," and every word he uttered was listened to with the deepest attention.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 12. -- It has frequently been whispered that Senator Quay is ready and anxious to "unload," or rather to free, himself from his colleague, Senator Cameron, who is a candidate for re-election. A story sent to the Pittsburg Times by a staff correspondent from Washington seems to confirm the rumor. It is to the following effect:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The Democratic campaign book, the publication of which has been so long delayed, will be ready for distribution early this week. It is almost too late in the campaign to get the document into general circulation, and, indeed, it is issued more for the benefit of Democratic stump speakers than for the general public.

TRENTON, Oct. 12. -- There are two Congressional districts in this State where Mr. Flower's Congressional Campaign Committee might be of service to the Democratic cause; but the campaign in both is going along with blissful ignorance, among the managers, of its existence. They embrace, too, the chief industrial communities in the Commonwealth.

President Harrison, while on his Western tour, does not talk politics, he says, but in spite of his disclaimer, he does talk politics wherever he goes, and to talk politics is what he goes for. Tariff he ignores, because he is not bright enough to devise a method of talking tariff to Western farmers which, as a Republican, he may safely adopt.

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- The political atmosphere in Northern New-York generally, and in Saratoga County particularly, may be said to be humid, with storms gathering below the horizon and sending their lurid sheets of advance light to bewilder the voter and interested onlooker. The chief causes of this disturbance are vicious representation, machine work, bossism, bribery, and corruption.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- A special to the Ledger from Kinkora, N.J., says: Five persons were drowned in the river near the sluice and the Knickerbocker icehouses at this place this afternoon by the capsizing of a boat. They were Solomon Fletcher, aged thirty-two: John Fletcher, aged twenty-two; Angelo Fletcher, aged twenty-four; Cheafus Merry, aged forty-three, and Alonzo Cannon, aged twenty-two.

Gen. Don M. Dickinson of Michigan, who so efficiently discharged the duties of Postmaster General during the Administration of President Cleveland, is in New-York for a few days on private business. He was seen yesterday in his rooms at the Hoffman House by a TIMES reporter and was asked to say how he viewed the political situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The three armor plates tested at Annapolis a few weeks ago have been removed from their oak backings, and the backs of the plates and the backings have been carefully examined by the Trial Board, which will make its final report to the Secretary of the Navy in a few days.

The Cunarder Aurania was the victor of the last westward race for the season with the Anchor liner City of Rome, which ended off Sandy Hook yesterday morning. She made the trip in 7 days 1 hour and 12 minutes, against her rival's 7 days 3 hours and 13 minutes. The very slow time made is accounted for by the heavy weather and head seas that the steamers met most of the way across.

The buffalo-bunting expedition organized in Laramie suggests by the very character of its quest the extent to which the extermination of this fine race of animals has been carried on. The effective execution of the laws prohibiting the killing of them came too late, as they are now unknown in regions where they were once found by hundreds of thousands.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 12. -- The Pittsburg Times will publish to-morrow a dispatch from ex-Senator Lewis J. Emery, Jr., in which he confirms the publication of the names of the gentlemen hitherto known as X, Y, and Z. The dispatch reads:

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- News of the latest swindle by Americans in London gives to Chicago the credit of sending out the parties who succeeded in duping the Englishmen. The parties perpetrating the swindle were E.J. Field and W.W. Miller, both men well known in Chicago.

Our Paris dispatches yesterday gave a sketch of the views regarding the commercial relations of France and the United States entertained by M. LOCKROY, a Republican leader of influence. They are a singular illustration of the way in which a sanguine Frenchman, sincerely desirous to maintain friendship in every possible manner with the only other great republic of the world, can be deluded by mere words.

In these three lectures the Oxford professor treats of seven subjects, all closely related in the science of language. We cannot say exactly whether Prof. Max Muller's conception that all European and Indian languages are derivable from the Sanskrit has had that expansion which had been hoped for.

The attention of Congress at the coming session is likely to be earnestly invited to the fact that this city has outgrown its Post Office. Both the Treasury Department, which owns the building, and the Post Office Department, which operates the labor conducted within it, are fully convinced of the inadequacy of the accommodations for the purposes required of them.

We have shown that Mr. MCKINLEY'S agents and collectors approached the manufacturers in the Window-Glass Trust with confidence, because he had procured for them higher duties even while they were perfecting their Trust and making four successive advances of their ring price. But the story was only half told.

The plan of the Louisiana Lottery people, now that the facilities of the mail have been forbidden them in the prosecution of their nefarious business, to utilize the express companies of the country for the distribution of their circulars and tickets will miserably fail if the State authorities do their duty in the matter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- There has been little change in Justice Miller's condition since the early morning. All day the physicians and watchers have been gathered around his bedside momentarily expecting dissolution, and it has only been owing to his wonderful vitality and recuperative powers that he has lived through the day.
TIPPERARY, Oct. 12. -- O'Mahoney is seriously ill and will be unable to appear in court. The magistrates will, therefore, be compelled to adjourn the trial or to omit his name from the indictment.

The success of Gen. SOUZA, after many attempts, in forming a Cabinet should relieve Portugal to some extent from a prolonged period of political fluctuation and anxiety which at one time threatened grave consequences. It was on the 17th of September that the old Ministry resigned, and almost immediately disturbances began here and there in Lisbon.

In most large cities the candidacy of a man like Hugh J. Grant for Mayor would be regarded as an amusing campaign episode and nothing more. This would be especially true of such a candidacy after the candidate had posed as the city's Chief Magistrate for two years. It is only treated seriously here because Grant has at his back the mighty machinery and the corrupt political methods of Tammany Hall.

One of the most interesting papers read at the annual convention of the Photographers' Association of America is always that upon the progress of photography during the year. At the recent convention in Washington it fell to the duty of W.H.H. Clarke, editor of the St. Louis and Canadian Photographer, to recount what advance had been made in the science since the last convention.

A pistol shot roused the resident members and servants of the Delta Phi Club, 5 East Twenty-seventh Street, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and on a bed in a front room on the third floor they found Walton O. Kernochan, who was twenty-seven years old, and the son of the late John A. Kernochan of Pittsfield, Mass., and 182 Madison Avenue, dead.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 12. -- A few days ago a fire occurred on board the British ship Wileysike. Only four bales of cotton were damaged, when the crew promptly extinguished the flames. The fire occurred in the hold, and no cause could be given for the accident.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The October term of the United States Supreme Court will begin tomorrow morning. The familiar face of its oldest member, Justice Miller, will be missing. In the last four years and more there has never been a full bench, save for a very brief period last Spring. Justice Wood's long illness kept him away for many months.

There is a sculptor of Danish birth at Chicago, Johann Gelert by name, but it is seldom that statuary comes this way from the workshop of an artist of Denmark. At 80 Fifth Avenue, however, a group in Carrara marble is shown which was chiseled by one of the foremost Danish sculptors, Prof. Diderichsen of Copenhagen.

It is not surprising that a business house established in Mexico some years ago for the introduction there of manufactured goods from this country should now turn its attention to Europe, and open an office in London, with the intension of supplying European goods to its Mexican customers. In fact, it would be surprising if an enterprising house with such a history should not now take such action.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 13. -- The Congressional contests in Iowa are the chief subjects of political interest in this State just now. Democrats feel confident of electing their State ticket, and a great many Republicans concede that this confidence is well founded. That they will gain several Congressmen is equally certain.

The disposition of the Twenty-second Regiment troubles was further simplified yesterday by the promulgation of a special order from General Headquarters at Albany releasing from arrest Capts. Hart, Demarest, Preece, Thurston, Finch, and Maidhof. This action reinvests the "six Captains" with the military functions of which they were deprived by the action of Col. Camp in placing them under arrest.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 13. -- If any hopes were entertained that Mr. Reemelin, the President of the Cincinnati Board of Improvement, would resign at the last moment, thus giving the Governor an opportunity to revoke the proclamation convening the Legislature, they were not fulfilled. The Cincinnati Board still holds on, and at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning the General Assembly will be in session.

A year ago William Lessure dug a well near his house. The volcanic rock that underlies the alluvial deposit in all this Palouse country was thrown in pieces beside the well. Mr. Lessure's only son, some thirteen years old, began finding beautiful stones in the volcanic formation. His father said it was glass, but the boy persisted.

NYACK, Oct. 13. -- Engineer Winfield Requa of the Northern New-Jersey Railroad had a narrow escape from instant death this morning. At about 7:30 o'clock his train up was running rapidly between Homestead and Tyler Park, when, while stepping from the tender to the cab, he was by the motion of the train hurled to the ground.

Missouri politics is mixed this year, and nobody can predict what the Legislature will be. The prospect is that the members will be of seven kinds -- Democrats, Republicans, Union Laborites, Farmers, Alliancists, Prohibitionists, Independents, and representatives of the People's Party. In Contemplating the situation interest centres in the query, What will the action of the Legislature be as to the United States Senatorship?

" Voluntary contributions" is the term Tammany is applying this year to political assessments. Voluntary contributions sounds very much better than assessments, but the Tammany candidates will find out, if they have not done so already, that it is all in the sound. Richard Croker does not like the word assessment.

Dispatches concerning the condition of business on the Paris Bourse during last week say that it is understood that the Colombian Government demands "a very heavy payment" from the Panama Canal Company for the extension of time for which Lieut. WYSE has been negotiating. The opinion is expressed that if Colombia shall persist in the demand the result will be the final winding up of the company.

Judging by the crowd that tried to force its way into the Supreme Court Chambers, yesterday morning a much more than usual public interest has been aroused by the arrest of Mrs. Cornelia V.E. Miller and Mrs. Priscilla Field, who were taken from the Coleman House Saturday night by Inspector Byrnes's detectives on information from England that they were the wives of the principals in a London banking fraud.

LITTLE HARBOR, N.S., Oct. 13. -- The wreck of the bark Melmerby, which took place off here last night, was one of the most heart-rending affairs that has ever occurred off the Nova Scotia coast. The only survivors are the pilot, who took the bark down the Gulf of St. Lawrence from Quebec, and two sailors who swam ashore.

Dr. Walter M. Fleming, a well-known physician, with an office at 45 Broadway, and Gen. Milton S. Littlefield, a contractor, living in the Hotel Lincoln, are under indictment for grand larceny, in extorting money from Mrs. Josephine Stephani, whose son, Alphonso Joseph Stephani, a few months ago shot and killed ex-Judge Clinton G. Reynolds.

MEADVILLE, Penn., Oct. 13. -- Capt. John Morris is a crippled Union soldier. Ever since the war he has been compelled to walk with a crutch and a cane. Six years ago Capt. Morris was nominated by the Republicans of Crawford County for County Treasurer. The county then had 1,500 Republican majority.

The statement in our Washington dispatches yesterday of the embarrassment suffered in the Civil Service Commission for the want of competent examiners ought to make any intelligent Congressman blush. In the late session Mr. McKINLEY, the Republican leader in the House, declared that his party was committed to nothing, not even protection, more strongly than to civil service reform.

The Board of General Appraisers, sitting at this port, yesterday promulgated its decision upon the constitutionality of the act of May 9, 1890, by which the Secretary of the Treasury was "authorized and directed to classify as woolen cloths all imports of worsted cloth, whether known under the name of worsted cloth, or under the name of worsteds or diagonals, or otherwise."

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Oct. 13. -- Four of the Oneida and Otsego Assembly District Democratic Conventions, held last week for the nomination of candidates for the Assembly and for School Commissioner, named women as candidates for the last-named post. This is the first time in the history of either Oneida or Otsego County that any woman has been made a party candidate for an elective office.

Something more than a year ago Weng Dy, a Chinese gardener in Oakland, died, leaving an estate valued at $240. Public administrator James Stanley secured letters of administration on the estate, and this morning he presented his account for settlement. There is $20 to be distributed. Attorney C.L. Colvin appeared to represent the heirs of the decedent in China. He produced a letter written by the mother of the deceased, which, translated, reads as follows:

The questions that will come up to-day in the management of the Clearing-House Association are exceedingly important. They have been discussed, more or less publicly, and with a good deal of warmth on both sides since they were raised early in the year. We are persuaded that the discussion has been useful.

It was a day of sensations at Morris Park yesterday. The only fatality occurred during the running of the third race, in which Father Bill Daly's colt Best Boy fell and broke his right foreleg while coming down the toboggan slide track, the jockey, Lambley, breaking his collar bone. The horse was shot, as there was no chance of the fractured limb ever being healed.

The promised investigation of the shady methods of the Juvenile Guardian Society was not made yesterday afternoon. Robertson sent word to the "Finance Committee" that the books were not yet ready, saying that they were in the possession of an expert, but would be at the disposal of the committee this afternoon.

Tammany will get cold comfort from Controller Myers's letter of acceptance received yesterday by the league. It is brief, but the Controller speaks to the point. Although the nominee of Tammany as well as of the triple alliance, Mr. Myers unhesitatingly declares his cordial support of the league ticket. His letter follows:

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 13. -- Lacking the power proposed to be conferred by the Federal Elections bill, and which they would use to the fullest extent were it possible, the Republicans of Delaware have determined to make the most of the existing Federal statutes relating to the election of Representatives in Congress, and with the aid of Federal Supervisors and United States Deputy Marshals will endeavor to secure a victory at the polls.

Census returns from eight districts came in yesterday, raising the total number of names to 1,697,329, an increase over the total June enumeration of 183,828 names. Three districts are yet to be reported. It was said at Police Headquarters that these districts would average as high as any yet turned in. One of the districts comprises Little Italy, in the Nineteenth Ward, from which the returns are confidently expected to reach 4,000 names.

Few people have any knowledge of the native copper of Michigan, what it is, where it is obtained, or how it is procured and prepared for market, nor is the magnitude of the industry understood. Last year there were produced 105,586,000 pounds of refined copper, which, at 17 cents per pound, about the price of copper at this writing, would amount to the sum of $18,045,620.

HARTFORD, Oct. 13. -- At the session of the Supreme Court of Errors in this city to-morrow, an opinion will be filed by Chief Justice Andrews and Associate Justice David Torrance, in the Seventh Ward election case, dissenting from the opinion of Judges Carpenter, Loomis, and Seymour, by which the Republican Alderman, H.B. Philbrick, has been unseated in favor of the Democratic candidate, Major William H. Talcott.

HALLE, Oct. 13. -- At to-day's session of the Socialist Congress Herr Bebel reported that the solidarity of the party had greatly increased since the Socialist Congress was held in Paris. The party now owned 104 trade organs, which had 600,000 subscribers. The finances were in a satisfactory condition, and each year showed an increase in the receipts.
Francis M. Scott, the People's candidate for Mayor, formally accepted his nomination in the following letter of acceptance, which was sent to Wheeler H. Peckham last night:

William P. Cannon was before Justice Ford in the Tombs Police Court yesterday charged by the Bottlers' Protective Association with having 10,000 bottles in his cellar, in violation of the Bottle act. He does business at 800 to 804 Seventh Avenue. This charge, in connection with one recently made at the Yorkville Police Court, gives him 37,304 bottles to account for, on which he can be fined $1 each.

HARTFORD, Oct. 13. -- The situation occupied by the Republican Party in this State at present, with the most important local election in years only three weeks off, reminds the old managers here of a thoroughly ludicrous event that occurred in the campaign of 1872. The political tide was running low at the time, and the effect of a grand rally at Allyn Hall was proposed as an offset.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Gen. W.W. Belknap, Secretary of War during President Grant's Administration, was found dead in his bed at about 9 o'clock this morning. It is believed that death occurred between 1 o'clock Saturday night and 9 o'clock Sunday morning.

The Games Committee of the National Cross-Country Association met in the clubhouse of the Manhattan Athletic Club, 524 Fifth Avenue, last night to arrange for its contests to occur at Morris Park Nov. 4. The junior cross-country championship, left undecided at the meeting last April, will be contested at 1 P.M., and only the men who started in the event in the Spring will be allowed to compete.

DEPILTO, Sept. 10. -- At San Juan I met a mining Superintendent for an English company holding properties near this town of Depilto, close to the Honduras frontier. He had lived in the country many years, and was able to give me most valuable information concerning the mineral wealth of the departments of Segovia, Chentales, and that of Tegucigalpa, with which the two former are geologically connected.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- All the curiosity regarding the reported broken engagement of Miss Winnie Davis, "the daughter of the Confederacy," and Alfred Wilkinson of Syracuse was alleged this afternoon when the young gentleman announced in person that it was true. It was first reported from New-Orleans, but the Wilkinson family would neither affirm nor deny the report.

In Lower Canada, if anywhere in the world, the Count of PARIS might expect to find a warm welcome not in his character of volunteer or in his character of military historian, but in his character of pretender to the French throne, although there is no such piece of furniture. The Count's progress has not thus far been over a path strewn with roses.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13. -- An elopement on a locomotive was the romantic way a young couple of this city chose to bring a courtship that had been fairly smooth to a close. William E. Trudeau, a Main Street clerk, and Miss Beatrice Harrig, daughter of a railroad engineer, were the participants in the novel affair, which occurred about 3 o'clock this morning.

There will be a mass meeting in the large hall of the Cooper Union to-night for the ratification of the people's municipal ticket, and it ought to be the occasion for an emphatic expression of public opinion in favor of reform in the City Government. Assurance that the meeting will be one of exceptional interest is given in the fact that an unusual number of prominent citizens will make brief and pointed speeches.

I have been much interested in reading the article by Sir Nathaniel Barnaby, K.C.B., on the protection of iron and steel ships against foundering from injury to their shells, published in THE TIMES of Oct. 10.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Justice Miller of the Supreme Court of the United States died at 10:52 P.M.

The first meeting of the New-York Presbytery since the Summer vacation was held yesterday morning and afternoon at the Scotch Church. It was opened with the usual devotional exercises, in the course of which the Rev. A.H. Harshaw prayed for purity in politics in this city. The election of Moderator and Temporary Clerk of the Presbytery immediately followed the calling of the roll.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 13. -- A dispatch was received here this afternoon by Consul General Frye from North Sydney from the Captain of the fishing schooner Samuel R. Crane, stating that he had picked up at sea British torpedo boat "No. 62," abandoned but in good condition. No mention is made of the crew of the boat, which numbered about twenty men.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 13. -- Senator Quay was here to-day on his way to Philadelphia, where he is going to take charge of the campaign of his man Delamater. He was in an unusually good humor, and talked in a free manner about the political situation. He said:

In the settlement of the complications in connection with the several cases of disbandment, courts-martial, , which have recently arisen in the National Guard a new point has come to the front, and one which promises to prove a knotty problem before it is solved.

It was next to the last day of the disastrous Fall meeting at Morris Park yesterday. The heavy rainfall kept many from visiting the race course. The non-attendants lost little, for the racing was commonplace in the extreme and the track a sea of mud. The class of horses contending was naturally commonplace, and the racing not of the stake order.

I was in error in one respect in quoting the advertisement of the Troy dealer. I said the advance was 10 to 30 cents per yard. I will be exact now. Frear, the Republican dealer, advertised in the Troy Times Saturday, Oct. 4, as follows:

BUFFALO, Oct. 14. -- Across the river at the hamlet of Fort Erie are a reunited husband and wife, and they are sorry the newspapers know anything about it. The husband is Achille Phillion and the wife was Treasurer of the Phillion "Spiral Tower" Company. This was a variety company, taking its name from the daring air performance of the husband.

Returns from the three election districts necessary to complete the enumeration of the census came in yesterday and make the population of the city 1,710,715. This exceeds the Census Office returns of 1,513,501 by 197,214. Little Italy, in the Nineteenth Ward, from which 4,000 names were expected, turned in 5,195, and two districts in the Twelfth Ward reported 2,780 and 5,411 names respectively.

BUFFALO, Oct. 14. -- A Donnybrook Fair isn't a circumstance to the riot that marked the Democratic First Ward caucus to-day, and in the midst of it was the Hon. William F. Sheehan, leader of the Democrats in the Assembly and Gov. Hill's right bower. He was supported by several of his creations, among them a dairy inspector and a section Superintendent of the Erie Canal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- The resignation of Chairman Faithorn was not acted upon at to-day's session of the Western Freight Association, but will be taken up at the meeting of the Western and Northwestern Divisions to-morrow or next day. Further time was given the committees having in charge the uniform bill of lading and the division of through rates from points in Indiana and Illinois to points west of the Mississippi River.

The New-York Clearing House Association disposed yesterday of the question which has been agitating it for some time as to whether or not outside banks should be permitted to clear through the association's banks. There were two reports before the association. One, signed by the majority of the committee recently appointed to inquire into the situation, suggested that there be restrictions or practical prohibition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Navy Department has completed all the details of the plans for twin-screw armor-plated harbor-defense ram upon the plans of Rear Admiral Ammen, retired. The vessel is cigar-shaped, and, but for her armored conning tower, smoke pipe, and ventilators projecting from her turtle-backed deck, she would have much the appearance of a huge whale laying upon the water.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Congressman Geissenhainer accuses Amos Clark, the Republican candidate for Representative in the Third New-Jersey District, with misrepresenting him in regard to his course in looking after the Elizabeth Public Building bill.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The funeral of Mrs. Catherine Booth, wife of Gen. Booth, who was known as the "Mother of the Salvation Army," took place to-day and was made the occasion of a great demonstration by that organization. The weather was exceedingly disagreeable, a murky fog enveloping the city, but despite this thousands of people assembled in the streets to witness the funeral procession.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 14. -- The independent movement against Quay rule and the foisting of Delamater on the people is spreading among the old soldiers. The Rev. J. Franklin Coae, a prominent Methodist divine, ex-Presiding Elder of this district and an old soldier, has written to Chairman Porter of the Republican County Committee, explaining why he cannot vote for Delamater.
HALLE, Oct. 14. -- At to-day's session of the Socialist Congress it was decided that the Socialists should seek to obtain their objects only through the enactment of laws by Parliament.

Col. Elliott F. Shepard has been suspended from the privileges of the Union League Club. At Monday night's special meeting of the Executive Committee, called for the purpose of taking final action upon the charges brought against Col. Shepard of "ungentlemanly conduct," it was voted with substantial unanimity to suspend him for a period of ten days.

Richard Barker, the stage manager, arrived in New-York on the Aurania Monday, having spent but two weeks in England, where he went to see the first production of "Carmen Up to Data" by the Gaiety company, and to complete arrangements for assuming the management of the Gaiety companies in this country. Talking to a TIMES reporter yesterday, Mr. Barker said:

The irrepressible HUSTON, Treasurer of the United States and aspirant for about everything, comes to the front to claim the Assistant Secretaryship of the Treasury made vacant by the transfer of Mr. BATCHELLER to the Diplomatic Service. Ever since HUSTON connived at the queer tricks practiced in this State to cheat the Prohibitionists of their organ, he has felt that his merits were ignored.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 14. -- The Revision Committee of the Presbyterian General Assembly closed its first session to-day to meet again in Washington Feb. 4. The committee met here on the 7th inst. in the library of the Western Theological Seminary. Of the twenty-five members all but Dr. Hastings of New-York and Barker Gummore of Trenton, N.J., who were unable to attend on account of sickness, were present.

The Commissioners of Fisheries for the State of New-York met yesterday in their office in Fulton Street. There were present Eugene Blackford of New-York City, President of the commission; A. Sylvester Joline of Tottenville, W.H. Bowman of Rochester, Henry Burden of Troy, and Edward P. Doyle, clerk and engineer for the commission.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 14. -- The Ohio Legislature convened in extra session at 10 A.M., and after the reading of the call a joint committee waited on the Governor, who submitted a message, which was read, referred to the Judiciary Committee, and a recess taken to 2:30 P.M.

The most curious argument thus far used in the Congressional campaign is one found in several Western Republican papers, notably the Globe-Democrat of St. Louis, to the effect that the people ought to give the Republicans a fair majority in the next House because it may be necessary to do the tariff work over again, and "the Republican Party is the only party which has the ability to settle the tariff question right."

LEXINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Thirty-four head of trotters sold at Woodard's sale here to-day for $16,760, an average of $493. The only fancy price was for the five-year-old bay filly Leona, by Electo, dam Wiota, by Cassius M. Clay, Jr., being sold to J. McGuire of New-York City for $1,100.

Every expectation was met in the great mass meeting of the Municipal League at the Cooper Union last night. The great hall was crowded to the doors, and while the audience was made up largely of the more staid and sober citizens it was full of enthusiasm. Mr. SCOTT was received with great warmth and made a solid and businesslike speech.

A careful and interesting article in Monday's TIMES exhibited the disadvantages at which the Post Office in this city is operated by reason of the lack of room for its operations. Even if the service were as good as it could possibly be made under the existing conditions, the conditions would prevent it from being completely satisfactory.

The officers of the Republican organization in the Fifteenth Assembly District have issued a valuable guide to voters of that party, which is equally serviceable for voters of other parties. It is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Justice Miller's chair was draped heavily in black this morning when the Supreme Court met. An air of sadness pervaded the court, from the Chief Justice down to the messengers. The Chief Justice announced the death, and the court immediately adjourned until Monday next. All the District Courts ad journed to-day out of respect to the deceased jurist.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Ottawa, Ontario, yesterday, says: "Senator James A. Pierce, Brooklyn, N.Y., interviewed Sir John Macdonald, Minister of Railways, to-day in regard to the Ottawa and Morrisburg Railway project. The American capitalists represented by Senator Pierce are anxious to take hold of the project and complete it, provided they can get control of the franchises granted by Parliament on reasonable terms.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 14. -- As predicted in a dispatch to THE TIMES last night, an order in Council has been passed removing the export duties upon spruce logs and pig logs, and also the export duties upon shingle bolts and pine or cedar or cedars capable of being made into shingles. The proclamation appeared in an extra of the Official Gazette.

A large number of the heirs of Robert Morris, the millionaire of the Revolution and Washington's financial agent during the darkest days of the struggle for American independence, have decided to bring an action for the recovery of a large tract of land in the western counties of this State, said to embrace 1,204,000 acres, and estimated to be worth something like $50,000,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The Post has particulars which leave but little doubt of the total loss of the Boston ship Magellan, with her entire complement of officers and seamen, together with a valuable cargo. The owners of the Magellan, Messrs. Hemenway Browne, whose offices are in the New-York Life Insurance Building, on Milk Street, received letters from their agents at Valparaiso to-day, giving full details of the disaster.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The city of Newark took her first practical lesson in ballot reform to-day. Her charter election was the first held in the State after the manner directed by the act passed by last Winter's Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Pittsburg says that until the meeting of Quay, Cameron, and Cooper, and several leaders from different parts of the State in Philadelphia last week the Napoleonic leader of the Pennsylvania Republican machine had entire faith in his ability to elect Delamater.

Register FITZGERALD in his examination before the Senate committee yesterday gave no satisfactory explanation of the fact that the receipts of the Register's office have fallen off so largely since the system of devoting the fees to the payment of expenses was abolished, while the cost of maintaining the service has greatly increased.

The Clearing-House Association yesterday decided the question of permitting its members to make exchanges for banks, bankers, and trust companies not members of the association by the adoption of the report of the minority of tile committee that has had the matter under study. The following is the resolution:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- While primarily intended for use in the pending Congressional contest, the Democratic campaign book, which finally made its appearance to-day, contains a great deal of matter which will be as valuable two years hence as now. Unlike the flashy campaign book of the Republican Congressional Committee, it does not start off with a dozen false claims on its very cover.

In the course of an illustrated article describing the new triple-screw, steel-protested cruiser No. 12, the Iron Age of Oct. 9 publishes the following from the pen of Horace See, the well-known engineering authority:

The convention of Socialists at Halle has drawn a needful distinction between Socialists and Anarchists by adopting a resolution declaring that they would seek to obtain their objects only through parliamentary agitation. This is what our own POWDERLY calls "working for educational and legislative advantages."

Adjt. Gen. Josiah Porter reached the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., from Albany promptly at 8 o'clock last night, and had a long and friendly conference with Col. John T. Camp, Lieut. Col. William V. King, and Capts. George E.B. Hart of Company K, William A. Preece of Company A. George F. Demarest of Company G.N.B. Thurston of Company E, James Finch of Company H, and W.J. Maidhof of Company B.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 14. -- The Journal's (Fargo, N.D.) special says: "T.S. Underhill, one of the Railroad Commissioners of North Dakota, resides at Antelope, west of the Missouri River, where he is interested in stock raising, and reports a somewhat deplorable condition of affairs among the ranchmen of his district resultant from the recent almost unprecedented prairie fires.

The two political parties were equally represented at the hearing of the Senate Committee on Cities yesterday, Senators Fassett, Republican, and McNaughton, Democrat, representing the committee. Senator Fassett announced that hereafter Senator McNaughton and himself would sit as a quorum when necessary, and that Senator Stewart's absence in Europe would not interfere with the work.

There was enthusiasm in the large hall of Cooper Union last night such as is manifested by public assemblages only on rare occasions. Vigorous applause and ringing cheers marked every period in the earnest speeches that were made in favor of Francis M. Scott and municipal reform.

The nomination of John De Witt Warner for Congress in the Eleventh Congressional District was indorsed in the most emphatic manner last night by the Eleventh Congressional District Tariff-Reform League at Wendel's Assembly Rooms in West Forty-fourth Street. There was a very large attendance.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 14. -- To-day the State Convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union began a four days' session in this city. The two factions in the union which have been at war with each other for the past year or two -- the "Loyal," or those who stand by the National Union, and the "Non-Partisan," or those who have disclaimed allegiance to the national organization, will renew their fight.

The silver dollar and five-cent piece in nickel are to be changed from their present ugliness and made, it is hoped, things of beauty. The Treasury Department has given notice that designs may be submitted. The difficulty in approaching the old Greek coins in character and beauty arises very materially from the greater swiftness of movement in coins from one hand to the other under our systems of finance.

An interesting case was tried on appeal yesterday by Collector Joel B. Erhardt in his office at the New-York Custom House. During the latter part of September Edward C. Coleman, a Custom House inspector, was charged with having received money at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, this city, from an English traveler, and he was dismissed from the Customs Service.

Duncan Cameron, the owner of 1,200 shares of Sugar Trust stock, obtained an injunction yesterday from Judge Pratt in the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, against the Trustees of the Sugar Trust, so called, restraining all parties connected with the concern from proceeding further with the plan of reorganization and from parting with any of the assets of the trust.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 15. -- The Tennessee Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South to-day closed its session at Pulaski. The Committee of Trial, appointed by Bishop Hargrove in the case of the Rev. D.C. Kelley, D.D., charged with having abandoned his pastorate at Gallatin, after his nomination for Governor by the State Prohibition Convention, submitted its report.

Everybody loves flowers. The man who says he doesn't belies his nature. At some time in life he has plucked or has had given to him a flower which charmed him, and for the nonce caused his thoughts to drift away from the gross, material things of every-day existence into shady nooks and shadowy dells.

Dr. Greene of 35 West 14th St., New-York, gave another of his great course of free illustrated lectures in Chickering Hall last evening. The lecture was private to men, and the vast audience followed with closest attention the important and weighty utterances of this famous physician, whose wide experience and thorough knowledge of these subjects have made him perhaps the best known and most successful physician in this country.

The provisional estimates of the expenses of the Police Department for the year 1891 were adopted by the Board of Police yesterday and were sent to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for consideration. The following are the chief items:

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Chicago comes to the front again as indirectly responsible for the conception of the plan that has within the past few days brought a certain Mrs. Cornelia V.E. Miller and another certain Mrs. Priscilla Field into unenviable notoriety and made them acquainted with Police Headquarters in New-York.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 15. -- Judge A.C. Haskell and the other candidates placed in opposition to the regular ticket put forward by the State Democratic Convention were to-night indorsed by a convention of sixty-five negroes representing four-sevenths of the counties of the State.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- What proved to be the most disastrous fire that has visited Syracuse for many years was discovered in the Leland Hotel at 12:30 o'clock this morning. It is now 2 o'clock, and the fire is still burning fiercely, although the entire Fire Department, consisting of nine engines, is working hard to save further loss of life and limb.

The local adult organ in its editorial columns yesterday sounded a frantic protest against the increase in the prices of several articles, and declared that the importers and merchants were raising their prices without cause, just to prejudice the tariff in the eyes of the people. In another column a fairy tale was told about a new American industry springing into existence as a direct result of the tariff.

HARTFORD, Oct. 15. -- Without reference to politics, the election in this State Nov. 4 will be one involving important interests. The great number of offices to be filled, the changes in Judgeships and State Commissions, and the reversal in numerous instances of public policy will render the election one of more than common note.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Secretary Tracy has decided to add sixteen feet to the length of the department designs for the three new battle ships, instead of twelve feet, as proposed by the Cramps. This will make the total length of the ships 348 feet, and the displacement will be increased to 10,100 tons at the normal load line, being a gain of 700 tons.

Another shift of the scenes in the never-ending comedy of horse racing takes place to-day. The New-Jersey Jockey Club opens the gates of its compact course at Elizabeth this afternoon, where the public will find a good track, much improved over that of last Spring, with an enlarged betting ring, perfect railroad facilities, and such added conveniences as experience has suggested as necessary.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 15. -- The ship Tacoma from New-York, which was so long overdue that she was given up as lost, arrived in port yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- While there is no doubt that the star of Gov. Campbell shines brighter to-night than at any previous time since the Legislature convened, and that he is master of the situation, there is also no doubt that his failure to make some specific charges against members of the Cincinnati Board has injured his political future.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15. -- Articles of agreement of the American Brewing Association of San Francisco were filed yesterday. The purposes of the association are "to conduct a brewery for the manufacture of beer and malt liquors, buy and sell lumber, conduct a bottling and cooperage business, equip and navigate steamers and sailing vessels, purchase and hold shares of stock of other concerns, and buy and sell real estate."

Some of the Western Republican newspapers which opposed the McKinley bill as strongly as it was opposed by any newspaper in the country are now saying that the bill, having become a law by the action of the Representatives of the Republican Party, loyal Republicans must accept it, kissing the rod and blessing the hand that has applied it.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 15. -- The Pittsburg Presbytery of the Reformed Presbyterian Church today had under consideration the disciplining of some of its members for promulgating a more liberal church platform.

There is shown in a Washington dispatch of the Post a ridiculous, and at the same time an unfortunate, result of Congressional meddling with business in the recent silver law. Under the provision of law requiring the Director of the Mint to issue quarterly a statement of the value of foreign coins, the value of the Austrian florin was fixed on Oct. 1 at 42 cents.

The "flight" of DILLON and O'BRIEN will be a fruitful theme for the Tory and Unionist journals of England. It ought rather to be a topic for the Gladstonian and home rule newspapers. In a general way it is extremely discouraging to the political prospects of a rising statesman to be known as a fugitive from justice.

LISBON, Oct. 15. -- The Regenerados and Progressists have agreed to maintain an expectant but benevolent attitude toward the new Ministry. The Cabinet has announced its determination to prohibit the Republican press from using scurrilous language regarding the King of Portugal or against Great Britain.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Desirable native and range Cattle sold at 5@10c higher to-day. Trade was active and the quality improved. About 30 loads, averaging 1,362 to 1,702 lb, sold as high as $5@$5.25. Poor to choice natives sold at $2.80@$4.90, bulk at $3.65 @$4.60. Western rangers sold at $2.10@$3.65, and through Texas at $1.25@$1.90, Bulls and Cows, and $2.25@$2.90 for Bulls and Steers.

Luther L. Kellogg appeared before the Park Commissioners at a special meeting yesterday and argued in favor of awarding to Thilemann Co., at their figures, $136,258.50, the contract for building two miles of sewers in Tinton Avenue and adjacent streets. Engineer Myers said he was of the opinion that Thilemann Co.'s bid was $15,000 too high. The matter was laid over until the next meeting.

The Charity Organization Society has issued an official statement concerning its relations to the Juvenile Guardian Society, which further affirms THE TIMES'S exposures of the mismanagement of the Guardian Society and the disrepute of Manager Robertson. In the course of this statement Mr. Kellogg says:

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad has closed the biggest year in its history. To-day was held the first regular monthly meeting of the Board of Directors after the closing of the fiscal year, which was on the last of September. The figures for the whole year, as given to-day, were: Earnings, $24,392,881; increase, $3,089,880; expenses, $17,014,060; increase, $2,203,216; net increase, $886,664.

Adjt. Gen. PORTER seems to have resorted to a revised form of "the judgment of SOLOMON" in his treatment of the Twenty-second Regiment's dissensions. He called upon the field officers and Captains to place their resignations in his hands, or otherwise the regiment would be disbanded. Of the Captains six promptly tendered their resignations under this alternative, and three refused, while one was absent in Europe.

With the four large ships authorized at the last session of Congress already provided for, the Navy Department is now devoting its attention to the two smaller ones, the torpedo cruiser and torpedo boat, and also to the ram which has so long been under consideration. This last is ready for bids, after many years' delay.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Boom yesterday, Wednesday, Oct. 15:

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- The throng attending the hearing of the Andover case by the Supreme Court was, if possible, greater to-day than yesterday. Every seat was occupied, and many persons stood for hours patiently listening.

If the Republican majority in Congress at the recent session had enacted a simple law to the effect that all goods in the United States should in every transaction be sold at higher prices and bought at lower prices until a Democratic Congress should have been elected, it would have put in a plain and intelligible form the idea its members seem to have had in their heads.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The twenty-first annual meeting of the New-York Branch of the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society was held in Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, East Orange, to-day. The meeting was attended by ladies representing the conferences of Central New-York, Erie, Genessee, New-York, Eastern New-York, Troy, Wyoming, Newark, and New-Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Late trains to-night and early trains to-morrow morning are expected to bring to Washington a large number of American ship builders and manufacturers of steel, who are to have a conference with the Secretary of the Navy to-morrow forenoon.

The continued examination of Register FITZGERALD yesterday before the Senate investigating committee made it still more clear that the business of his office is very loosely managed. The Register admitted that he employed men for political reasons and on Tammany recommendations, without taking any means to ascertain their fitness for the duties to be performed.

How Mr. De Lancey Nicoll has persuaded himself to accept the Tammany nomination for the District Attorneyship passes our comprehension. In the first place, it was proposed in the convention by Deputy Commissioner of Public Works ($6,000 per annum) "Barney" Martin, the former partner of "Red Leary," the burglar, and was seconded by Civil Justice ($6,000 per annum) "Pete" Mitchell, the former partner of Sharkey, the murderer.

There will be a special matinee in H.C. Miner's Fifth Avenue Theatre this afternoon, and half of the net proceeds will be given to the "Little Mothers'" fund now collecting for the purpose of giving a series of free entertainments to these little nurses and housekeepers this Winter. The programme for this afternoon consists of the play "Princess Zilah." Marguerite St. John will take the part of Marsa Lazlo.

Tammany's administration of the Register's office got a very black eye indeed from the Senate Committee on Cities yesterday. It was clearly shown that the office is in need of a vigorous overhauling. Senator Fasset opened the session single-handed. Senator Ahearn dropped in a little later and looked out for the interests of some of his friends in the Fourth Assembly District.

Mr. Charles P. McClelland, who was nominated for Assemblyman by the Democrats of the First Westchester District Tuesday afternoon, had a curious experience in the course of the day. The convention met in the forenoon and it became apparent at once that there was an earnest desire that Mr. McClelland should make the race against J. Irving Burns, the present Republican Assemblyman.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- The license of the Park Theatre was revoked to-day, on the ground that "The Clemenceau Case," as produced by Sybil Johnson and the rest of the company, is immoral. The action was taken at the request of several Aldermen who saw the play last night.

DUBLIN, Oct. 15. -- During the proceedings at Tipperary to-day, Mr. Healy, one of the counsel for the defendants in the conspiracy case, was handed a telegram. Tearing the envelope open, he found it contained a dispatch from Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien, announcing their safe arrival at Cherbourg, France, to-day.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The Varsity football eleven had a hard tussle with the University of Pennsylvania's team here to-day in what was called a "practice game." As a matter of fact, the contest was as severe and as earnestly contested as though it had been a championship struggle, and the result is that several more Princeton men are on the injured list.

The political campaign in Brooklyn was enlivened yesterday by a piece of genuine news. It related to an alleged failure to comply with that section of the new ballot law making it necessary to file certificates of nomination with the County Clerk. The time for filing such certificates expired on Wednesday, and the Republicans of Flatlands aver that their Democratic opponents failed to obey the law.
Will you permit me through your columns to ask Mr. Le Lancey Nicoll the following questions:

When the war broke out, and Mr. Lincoln called Fremont back from Paris and sent him as a Major General to command the Department of the West, it was frowned on by the party chiefs, who feared a Presidential bee in Fremont's bonnet as a result of his former candidacy, and by the "regular officers" of the army, who still disliked him.

The President is mistaken if he supposes that Dudley is working for Harrison while he lscampaigning in Indiana this Fall. Dudley has no intention of helping Harrison to a second term. A short time ago he sent some of the certificates which the ]National Republican Committee sells at $10 each to a person who considers that he has been shabbily treated by the President.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The mortal remains of the late ex-Secretary of War, William W. Belknap, were to-day interred in the Arlington National Cemetery, in ground tendered for the purpose by the War Department. The religious services were conducted in St. John's Episcopal Church, which has been the scene of the funerals of so many persons prominent in the political, military, and social life of Washington.

Another grist of tin-plate lies arrived in New-York night before last, all the way from Pittsburg, and was given a position of honor in the columns of the Tribune. Three tin-plate plants would certainly be built at Pittsburg and four others might be built. Besides a Pittsburg company would build machinery for tin-plate plants. So ran the latest yarns from the tin-plate lie centre.

Tammany's pet boast that it has reduced the tax rate to 1.97, and should be kept in power for that reason if for no other, fared badly at the hands of the Senate Committee on Cities yesterday. The 1.97 tax rate was shown to be a complete humbug. It has cost more to run the city during the last two years than it has for a long time before.

Racegoers welcomed the opening of the New-Jersey Jockey Club at Elizabeth yesterday. From the far-reaching stretches of Morris Park to the compact track where every part of the race was visible was a most agreeable change. So, too, was the change from jockeying and queer racing to actual contests between the horses, in which the best horse was forced to win.

A wordy quarrel took place yesterday at the Tombs Police Court between Anthony Comstock and ex-District Attorney John M. Coman. Comstock has been after policy men lately and thought he had caged one in the person of Edward Newton, who works at 87 Dey Street. The trouble between Comstock and Coman occurred when Comstock told Newton to step to one side of the prisoner's pen, as he wanted to talk with him.

There is a certain naivete in the discussion upon religion at the congress of the Socialists in Halle. One delegate "held that religion must he a private matter, especially when a combat against the Catholic Church was being carried on."
