The orator seems to mean that it is so necessary the Catholic Church should be "downed" that the help of all persons, of any religion or of none, should be welcomed.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- William O'Brien and John Dillon, who succeeded in evading the Irish police last week with the intention of proceeding to America to lay the cause of Ireland before the people of that country, and who arrived at Cherbourg yesterday, reached this city this morning.

The Ferncliff stud of brood mares, imported and native stallions, belonging to Mr. William Astor, and several other mares and stallions were sold at Hunt's Point yesterday afternoon by William Easton, auctioneer for Tattersalls Co. The bidding was lively and the prices obtained exceptionally good. Wealthy breeders from many different States were present, and so men of moderate means were shut out from successful bidding by their more fortunate competitors.

ELLENDALE, N.D., Oct. 16 -- One of the most exciting features of the present-campaign is the rivalry between the two principal railroad corporations of the State, the Northern Pacific and the Great Northern. Railroad influences have always been felt to some extent in the politics of the State and Territory, but this Fall the representatives of the two companies named are taking a direct interest in all important movements.

The People's Municipal League has taken from the annual record of Senators and Assemblymen issued by the City Reform Club some valuable suggestions to voters and issued them in the form of a circular, with a diagram of a voting place under the new law and a reproduction of the people's ticket to be voted for at the coming election.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16. -- In the course of an interview on the effect of the McKinley bill this evening Mr. I.W. Morton, Vice President of the Simmons Hardware Company, said some interesting things. His company controls the largest single hardware concern in the country, and he spoke by the card.

The shutting off of all electric lights in this pity, supplied by the underground cables of the Brush Electric Illuminating Company, the United States Electric Lighting Company, the United Electric Light and Power Company, the Manhattan Electric Light Company, and the Harlem Electric Lighting Company, was prevented yesterday by injunctions served on the consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Oct. 16. -- A very interesting and somewhat romantic marriage occurred here yesterday -- that of Mr. Arthur English and Mrs. Lucy B. English, the former of St. Louis, the latter of Chicago. Mrs. English was formerly Miss Lucy Temple, a belle of this city, daughter of Mrs. Kate Temple, now of Chicago. In her girlhood she married a Mr. Boyd of Burlington, Iowa, but was soon left a widow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- The market at the Stock Exchange opened firm with some little advance in prices, but a strong pressure to realize soon manifested itself, and the closing showed marked declines in some instances. West Chicago Street Railroad opened at 131, regular, and 131 1/2 buyer 30, with Hammond, Frank, and Koch as buyers, and Henrotin, Evans, and Breeze selling.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Provisions were advanced somewhat by the strength and increased activity in Corn Pork showed at one time an advance of 12 1/2c, Lard of 7 1/2c, and Ribs of 10c. January Pork opened at $11.72, touched $11.85, and closed at $11.80@ $11.82 1/2. January Lard opened at $6.47 and closed at $6.55. January Ribs opened at $5.72, touched $5.80, and closed at $5.77.
Indeed, the one well-founded complaint against the present Mayor is that he failed to keep the pledges he made in the matter of appointments.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16. -- The anticipated rupture in the Iowa Women's Christian Temperance Union came to a head to-night There are now two State organizations, one swearing allegiance to Mrs. J. Ellen Foster and the other to Frances E. Willard and the national organization. The session to-day was a stormy one.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- The State Superintendent of Banking has issued a statement showing the condition of the banks of the State of New-York on Sept. 27, 1890. This statement, when compared with that of twelve months ago, shows some wide differences. Now there are 166 banks doing business under State authorization; a year ago there were 149. Of this increase New-York City is credited with 5, from 43 to 48.

The annual meeting of the stockholder of the Northern Pacific Railroad was held yesterday and 620,600 shares of stock were represented Thomas F. Oakes, President of the company, submitted a report which showed that for the year ended June 30, 1890, the gross earnings, including receipts from branch roads amounted, to $22,610,500, operating expenses $13,089,136, taxes $374,600, net earnings $9,146,756, other receipts $1,341,172; total net income, $10,487,928.

Cigar dealers, especially those who have a pretty regular run of custom, have not yet advanced their prices to the scale which will obtain when the new tariff law is fully understood by them. Of course there has been some advance in the rates charged in stores depending on transient trade, but even in these places the limit has not been reached yet. All the dealers agree that prices will go up.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 16. -- The twenty-first annual meeting of the New-York branch of the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society, which opened in Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, East Orange, closed this afternoon.

About one-third of the space reserved for editorial articles in the high-tariff papers is now filled daily with arguments and assertions designed to convince readers that prices are not rising and have not risen. This is a matter about which the citizen who buys goods and has brains will surely have a well-settled opinion based upon his own experience.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The Council of School Superintendents convened at 9:30 o'clock to-day. Resolutions were adopted indorsing the State Library Association, whose objects are to secure legislation to encourage the formation and support of public libraries, and approving the plan for providing public and school libraries advocated by Superintendent Draper.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 17. -- United States Senators Wade Hampton and M.C. Butler have returned to this State to assist in pouring oil on the troubled sea of politics. It is conceded now that very much depends on them in the work of steering the ship of state to a safe port.

Speaker REED has gone out to Ohio to aid Major MCKINLEY. Though Ohio is not so far from Tennessee that the voters of the latter State cannot get reports of Mr. REED'S speeches, he is defending the Force bill in entire disregard of the protest of the Republicans of Tennessee. The Speaker probably thinks the Force bill good politics for Ohio, and takes his chances on the discontent of Southern Republicans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The Union National Bank began an attachment suit to-day against the Peters Salt and Lumber Company of Manistec, Mich., which failed yesterday. Attachments were levied on surplus securities held by the Commercial and American Exchange National Banks of this city. The Union National claims to be amply secured on the paper of the firm which it holds.

Visitors to the New-Jersey Jockey Club track yesterday not only found themselves in an unexpectedly large crowd, but also found a much better track than could have been expected after the heavy rain of Thursday night. Toward the end of the racing the track had dried out so that there were few heavy spots for the horses to race through.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Donald D. MacLaurin, for seven years pastor of Immanuel Baptist Church in this city, has been called to the pastorate of one of the oldest and richest Baptist churches in America, the Church of the Epiphany, at Madison Avenue and Sixty fourth Street, New-York City. Last month Dr. MacLaurin took a trip to New-York, and by invitation preached two sermons in the Epiphany pulpit on successive Sundays.

While Mr. MCKINLEY was at work in Washington for the Window-Glass Trust he found time to do something for the Crockery Compacts, so called, and we presume the members of these combinations have been not less grateful than were the manufacturers in the Window-Glass Trust when they were approached by the collectors to whom Mr. MACBETH declined to give any money.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Dr. and Mrs. Paxton, with the professors of the Theological Seminary, tendered the entering students a reception in the parlors of old Seminary Hall this evening. About two hundred were present.

The Department of Taxes and Assessments has generally stood well in the public estimation, and President COLEMAN has on more than one occasion stood up valiantly for the city against the exactions of the State Board of Assessors, and has also been a consistent champion of public economy in the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

Among the most desirable offices that the people of Westchester County have to confer by their votes are the three School Commissionerships. The Commissioners get a salary of only $1,200 a year, for a term of three years, but they have a good patronage, for in their hands rests the control of all the schools and the licensing of all the teachers.

Congressman Dorsey of the Third Nebraska District is candidate for re-election. He is a Republican, and is the regularly nominated candidate of his party in a district which in 1888 gave him a plurality of 11,170 over his Democratic opponent and a majority over all of 6,454. This year it is by no means certain that Mr. Dorsey will be elected.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 17. -- The rapid approach of election day brings little of encouragement to the Milwaukee managers of either party. No one of them will venture an estimate of the majority to be given for either side. Surface indications are that the Republicans will carry the State by anywhere from 15,000 to 50,000 plurality, with substantial reasons for the wide discrepancy in numbers.

Franklin File and his wife, Sarah E. File, were allowed yesterday by Judge Ehrlich, in the City Court, to change their name to Fyles. The old Holland way of spelling his name, Mr. File stated, was Fyles, and he and his wife wished to follow that spelling, and not the modernized form.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- If United States Treasurer Huston is correctly reported by a local newspaper man with whom he has been talking, he has no faith in President Harrison's renomination. Mr. Huston declares that, unless the Republican Party in Indiana makes some unpardonable blunders, some insane errors, the State is going to be carried for the Republican ticket by a plurality larger than that of 1888.
DUBLIN, Oct. 17. -- T.D. Sullivan, Timothy Harrington, and T.P. O'Connor will join Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien in Paris. They intend to sail Oct. 25, instant.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17. -- The trotting and pacing here to-day was witnessed by a large crowd. The track was in good condition and the sport fine. The unfinished pace from Wednesday was won by Pickaway in 2:18 1/4, and the unfinished 2:40 class by Dave Wilson in 2:24 3/4. The 2:24 class, pacing, was unfinished because of darkness. The summaries follow:
Under the heading "A Curious Fact" the Boston Traveller says editorially:...

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Considerable progress has been made during the week in shaping the work of the Columbian Exposition. Secretary Dickinson of the Executive Committee will begin a session at noon to-morrow, which will last three or four days, and dispose of many matters preliminary to the general meeting of Commissioners on Nov. 18.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Acting Secretary of the Treasury Batcheller issued a circular to-day removing the prohibition of importation of neat cattle from any part of the world, subject to the regulations of the Secretary of Agriculture. He also removes the prohibition of importation of hides of neat cattle from the several countries of North, Central, and South America.

Mr. H. McK. Twombley declined yesterday to talk about the published statement that he had been trying to acquire a controlling interest in the Philadelphia and Reading Road for the Vanderbilt people. The general belief among Wall Street men versed in railroad matters was that if Mr. Twombley ever entertained the idea of buying out the Reading syndicate he had abandoned it.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Star, Mr. Thomas Power O'Conner's paper, says it is alleged in clerical circles that the summoning to Rome of the four Archbishops in Ireland is a mere formality, necessary to the fulfillment of their duty of presenting themselves to the Pope once every five years.

" Die Wilde Jagd" was played at Amberg's Theatre last night, notwithstanding that Judge Barrett had issued an injunction Thursday, on the application of Augustin Daly, to restrain Gustav Amberg from producing it. Two lawyer's clerks were on hand with the restraining order when the doors opened, and when they had sought in vain for Mr. Amberg in the vestibule they bought tickets and sought for him in the auditorium, but also in vain.

The golden jubilee of the Right Rev. John Loughlin, D.D., Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn, began last night with a monster reception at the Brooklyn Rink, in Clermont Avenue. It was one of the most imposing ecclesiastical demonstrations in the history of the City of Churches. The vast building was packed with 7,000 persons, and standing room was difficult to find.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- It is only necessary to spend two hours in Albany to learn how torn are both political parties. Patronage and Frank Hiscock are the sources of discord among the Republicans and Gov. David B. Hill and his methods among the Democrats.

We published yesterday a circular received by a Western merchant from the American Knife Company of Thomaston giving notice that the price of that company's cutlery had been advanced 12 1/2 per cent. on account of changes in the tariff laws. The Minneapolis Farm, Stock and Home publishes a notice which it has received from the American Shear Company, manufacturers of pocket cutlery and shears at Hotchkissville, Conn.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 17. -- Private advices from Washington indicate that Mr. Blaine is ready to resume negotiations on the subject of the Atlantic fisheries. Lord Salisbury has also expressed a similar desire. This intelligence is received with great satisfaction in official circles, where the opinion is entertained that a satisfactory settlement will be reached before the Presidential election.

FISHING WITH CORMORANTS. -- At no great distance from us, perhaps a quarter of a mile, a light flickered over the water. On our approach we could distinguish a man connected with it, who apparently walked on the dark surface. He was evidently a fisherman or a shrimper, and his movements had all the strangeness of some long-legged aquatic bird.

The high-tariff organs that have been urging their readers not to believe the evidence of their senses and of their pocketbooks as to higher prices now begin to "hedge," as betting men say, and are preaching the doctrine that low prices are comtemptible and high prices greatly to be desired.

There are strong indications that there will be another row in baseball circles. It has just leaked out that the rank and file of the Brotherhood have been combining for the purpose of protecting their interests. This means that some of the players are not satisfied with the work of the backers of the Brotherhood, or in other words they do not want to consolidate, preferring to go it alone.

The Comte de Paris and his suite were the guests of Gen. Daniel Butterfield yesterday. The party sailed up the Hudson on Gen. Butterfield's yacht General, took breakfast at Gen. Butterfield's country home near Cold Spring, just opposite West Point, then crossed to West Point and witnessed an exhibition drill by the cadets, and returned to the city by a special train over the West Shore Railroad, arriving at 6:45 P.M.

The practice of selecting candidates for cadetships to Annapolis and West Point by competitive examinations has been found extremely convenient by many Congressmen. It relieves the Representative of the onus of favoritism and at the same time confers privilege on many, if the right to compete can be termed a privilege.

An interesting story was told in the Detective Bureau yesterday by Acting Inspector McLaughlin. It appeared that in the Summer of 1886, while Mrs. Alice Bostwick, wife of Walter B. Bostwick of 6 East Fifty-eighth Street, was stopping with her daughter at Black Rock, Conn., they became acquainted with Samuel W Lewis, who pretended he was a prosperous broker and lived at 192 President Street, Brooklyn.

After a remarkably successful season of six months at the Madison Square Theatre, Richard Mansfield's engagement will come to an end next Saturday night, when the one hundred and fiftieth performance of "Beau Brummell" will be given. In commemoration of the event a unique and valuable souvenir will be presented to the audience. It is a fac simile of Beau Brummell's handwriting, being a letter written by him while in exile at Calais.

" The times have been, that when the brains were out, the man would die," exclaimed Macbeth. The time has been that when the campaign was over the accounts of the committee survived. This, though quite as strange as the persistence of life in a man who has been brained, is, in a single instance at least, strictly true.

The celebration of Bishop Loughlin's golden jubilee was continued yesterday at the old cathedral, St. James's, in Jay Street, Brooklyn. It was this building that was partially destroyed by fire some time ago, but it has been completely renovated and decorated. The interior was filled with flowers, and plants and tall palms stood in all the niches.

A number of adventurous voyages have been made in times past in mere cockle shells of boats, but the greatest of them all is that recently successfully accomplished by Capt. Jorgensen, who, having made an invention for saving life at sea, straightway put it to the severest possible test by traveling in it from England to Adelaide, Australia.

The man from Maine who is now dividing the leadership of his party with James G. Blaine is a man over six feet in height. The table by which he was standing exactly measured the diameter of his portly form at that distance from the ground. His shoulders are narrow in proportion. His forehead is receding, while the back of his head is high and well developed.

L.E. Myers, the once famous runner, seems to be greatly worried over the performance of John Owen, Jr., Detroit Athletic Club, at Washington, when Owen ran 100 yards in 0:09 4-5. Mr. Myers is the most enthusiastic of a handful of men who, for reasons known only to themselves, are throwing discredit over Owen's run by claiming that he beat the pistol two yards at the start.

The eccentricities of Tammany's government of the city of New-York are illustrated in the small things of the several departments as well as in the great. The fact that an Irishman could remote this city and obtain office almost as soon as he arrived at Castle Garden has been made the subject of innumerable jests and has furnished the basis of many excellent humorous stories.

Barnegat! There are two sides to it, the bay side and the ocean side. Very different ideas are aroused according to the side from which it is viewed. On the one hand are visious of keen enjoyment, of active, health-giving outdoor amusement, of hunting and fishing, of sailing over blue waters, while the foam of the flying cat flashes in the sunshine and the blood courses merrily through the veins.

A very well-pleased party of excursionists reached Jersey City last evening, after a two days' trip over the picturesque Lehigh Valley route. As guests of the Lehigh Valley Road, and under the special guidance of General Passenger Agent Byington, they had enjoyed a very agreeable 500-mile run.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 18. -- The Mayor called the City Council together in special session at noon to-day, and submitted to them the following message:

William Steinitz, the world's champion at chess, entertained the members of the Manhattan Chess Club last evening by playing twenty-six simultaneous games of chess. That is, he was pitted against twenty-six players, each of whom sat behind a chess board while Mr. Steinitz walked from one to the other, responding to the move made by the player.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 18. -- George A. Butler, President of the Tradesmen's Bank, a day or two ago sent in his resignation as a member of the Republican League, a social club composed of many of the leading citizens of New-Haven, all of them Republicans.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct 18. -- Amherst defeated Trinity at football here to-day by a single point. The game was exciting throughout, and was rough at times. In the first half Stewart of Amherst was ruled off the field for slugging, Delabarre taking his place.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18. -- At last the Cary Athletic Building, on Holmes Field, just across the street from Jarvis, has been finished. The elevens have used the place to dress in for sometime, but it is only within a week that the work has been completed. Harvard athletes and the students wanting physical training had great advantages in the Hemenway Gymnasium, but the Cary Building, as it is called, is a most valuable addition.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- Mr. A.M. Field, manager of the Boston Museum, has received a letter from J.B. Mason, the missing leading man at that playhouse, intended in explanation of his somewhat mysterious disappearance from this city last Monday. After expressing deep regret for his action, he says: "My brother is a sick man -- desperately so -- and my first duty is toward him.

Mr. E.S. Auchincloss, one of the owners of the seventy-foot sloop yacht Katrina, returned recently from abroad. While in England Mr. Auchincloss had a talk on yachting matters with George L. Watson, the well-known designer. The question of international yacht racing came up, and Mr. Auchincloss got a pretty clear insight into the position English yachtsmen hold at present in regard to future races for the America's Cup.

Police Justice Taintor, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday held Charles B. Leef, a collector for George Ringler Co.'s Brewery, for trial on a charge of appropriating to his own use money that he had collected. It is charged that there are discrepancies in Leef's accounts amounting to $2,800. Leef declares that he is innocent.

Pygmalion, the ancient artist, could not be more overjoyed when his statue became transformed into a lovely woman than the heirs of the late Mme. Artaud, who recently died in Paris, when they discovered a considerable fortune carefully hidden away in the interior of a common plaster of paris reproduction of the famous Venus of Milo. The history of the sudden find is curious and entertaining.

Mr. Charles D. Hine, Secretary of the State Board of Education, has presented to Gov. Bulkeley his report for the year 1889-90. The most interesting single feature of the report is the conclusion of the investigation of the schools of New-London County. The following (given in the report in fac simile of the handwriting) shows how a number of scholars, whose age and teaching are stated, wrestled with a sentence that was dictated to them:

How far the patched-up peace in the Twenty-second Regiment troubles extends beneath the surface is the query which is just now of chief concern in military circles. The assurance that the differences which have divided the Board of Officers and proved the occasion of discord in the organization for close upon two years have been settled in a night, and permanently disposed of, is accepted with incredulity.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Now that the safe arrival in Paris of the two heroes of the escape from Ireland has allayed the growing anxiety of their friends and put a stop to the frenzied search of shipping by Mr. Balfour's police, it is time to inquire why Mr. Dillon and Mr O'Brien should have taken so violent a course of action as a flight implies.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Whatever doubts may have prevailed as to whether the "floaters" would be taken care of at the coming election have been dispelled by the assurance that the doughty Judge Muller will, accompanied by the usual soapbox, put in an appearance in the well-known star chamber on East Water Street two weeks from Tuesday.

In THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Aug. 24 of this year was published an article entitled "Under the Czar's Empire." It was the translation of what was deemed the more important portions of a volume which contained the legislative acts of the Russian Empire relating to the Jews. This translation was "perfectly colorless, and an endeavor was made to follow the exact meaning of the Russian text."

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 18. -- So far as this State is concerned the Republicans have abandoned all the Congressional districts except three. This line of policy is probably not approved by the national leaders, but is pursued solely in obedience to the dictates of Mahone. With this policy in mind Mahone induced the State Committee at its last meeting to leave to the District Committees the question whether further nominations should be made.

M. de Saint-Amand's present volume on Josephine is the second work of his on Napoleon's first wife thus far published here in translation. His first work, issued early this year, was devoted to the days of the Consulate, (1799-1804.) The present embraces the years extending from her marriage to the Consulate, (1796-1799;) a third, which is in press, will cover the years when Josephine was Empress. (1804-1809.)

If rhetoric would destroy the "drink evil," the Prohibitionists of New-York would make short work of it. They are asking the readers of newspapers and others in the city the following flaming questions: "Why should high-minded Republicans have aught to do with the struggle now going on to put one or two Democrats in power?

Perhaps everybody does not know that there are 128 hotels in this great and growing town. The Official Hotel Directory for 1890 gives the names of that number of New-York hotels, and next year ten or twelve more names will have to be added to the list. The hotel industry in this particular locality is growing at a remarkable rate.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Oct. 18. -- A special car left this city at 5 o'clock this morning conveying a committee of citizens who went to Burlington to meet the family and friends accompanying the remains of the late Justice Miller, and to act as an escort to the body to this city. The funeral train left Burlington at 7:30 o'clock, and arrived here shortly after 9 o'clock.

The investigation into the methods of assessing property for taxation in this city has no particular bearing upon the question of municipal expenditures, except to show that arguments based upon a reduced tax rate are frequently delusive. There are just two questions of special significance in regard to the financial administration of the city.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- At the meeting of the Northern Conservative Union at Newcastle today Mr. Balfour renewed his attack on Mr. John Morley, who, he said, had assailed him with the charge of absenteeism from his post, ignoring the fact that, while he (Mr. Morley) was Chief Secretary for Ireland for six months, he was in Ireland precisely five days.

Six steamships sailed from this port for Europe yesterday. The Anchor Line steamship City of Rome sailed for Liverpool and had among her passengers Robert E. Burns, Capt. Joseph Hutchinson, Mrs. Oscar Hardin, Mr. and Mrs. Adrian B. Travers, the Misses Travers, the Rev. and Mrs. Andrew Watson, W.H. Dewells, and Sir William Irrol.

Of the offices to be voted for at the coming election there is none that exceeds in importance that of District Attorney, and it is therefore quite necessary that all good citizens should vote for him who gives the best assurance that he will perform the duties of this office satisfactorily.

The remains of Johann Christoph Gluck, the great composer, were exhumed this morning at the Matzleinsdorf Cemetery, where they have rested since 1787, and reinterred this afternoon at the Central Cemetery, in the Musicians' Corner, near those of Beethoven and Schubert, and close to the Mozart monument. The grave was in a disgraceful state.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 18. -- One of the finest games of football ever seen in this vicinity was played here this afternoon between the Yale 'Varsity eleven and the eleven of the Orange Athletic Club. Great interest was centred in the game, as every one considered that its outcome would reveal much of the future of the present year's championship in both the Intercollegiate Association and American Football Union series.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The football management has thus far been very unfortunate in arranging dates for local games. The game with Rochester last Saturday is the only one thus far played, and there appears to be no prospect of any other in the near future. The eleven is working hard and will be in excellent shape for its Eastern trip.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The Hudson River fruit crop has about been gathered, and the work of cleaning up the farms for the Winter season has been commenced. The season has been remarkable in many respects. Fruit men are surprised at the enormous output of Concord grapes, and are not slow in acknowledging that they were wide of the mark when they predicted a crop failure.

LONG BRANCH, Oct. 18. -- The electric railway schemes of the present and their probable effect upon the future of Long Branch make almost as interesting a topic for an exchange of views as the county election. The railway schemes prove to be much more comprehensive than was supposed when Mr. R. Percy Dobbins submitted his project to the people and the Board of Commissioners.

The annual report of George M. Pullman, President of the Pullman Palace Car Company, contains many interesting facts aside from the financial statement already published. The average number of names on the pay roll at Pullman for the past year was 4,582, and the aggregate amount of wages paid was $2,738,019, making an average for each person employed of $596.

The largest crowd that has ever been at the Elizabeth track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club, except on election day a year ago, was at the track yesterday to see the races. The crowd numbered between 10,000 and 15,000, and with fine weather, a good track, large fields of horses, and lively betting, the crowd had an enjoyable day's sport.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- The theatres have done more than an average business this week, and some of them have been remarkably successful. The second week of Lawrence Barrett at the Chicago Opera House saw much larger houses even than the first, when no complaint could have been made. "Francesca da Rimini" and "Rienzi" were presented, and the seating capacity of the theatre was taxed at every performance.

An exhibition game was played at Staten Island yesterday between the New-York League and the Corinthian Athletic Club nines. As was expected, the professionals won with ease. At times, however, the Corinthian boys played good ball and altogether made a creditable showing against Mutrie's aggregation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 18. -- John Dean Benton, known all over the country as a maker of gold and silver models of machinery, gunboats, , died in East Providence this morning aged sixty-six years. He was born in Fort Independence, Boston Harbor, and learned the trade of a jeweler before the war. He contracted rheumatism in the hands during the war and was discharged for disabilities.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 18. -- The trotting races here to-day were extremely exciting. Nancy Hanks won her race in grand style, while it took seven heats to decide the 2:20 class, the fifth heat of which was declared no heat on account of a foul. Winslow Wilkes won the unfinished 2:24 pace, postponed from yesterday in 2:14 1/2 and 2:17 1/2.

Four little tame ducks have cost the county of Cascade about $8,000. On the 22d day of August last year James W. Gibbs and Frank Gray went in a boat from Great Falls up the Missouri River to Sand Coulee. They had a gun along and were loaded for duck. Wild duck were rather scarce, however, so, seeing four tame ones on the place of Neils P. Loburg, Gray shot them.

An anomaly is presented in Brooklyn Republican politics to-day, and a condition of affairs exists within the party lines that is very unique in its way. The machine is controlled absolutely by one faction in the party, while the opposing faction rules all the nominating conventions and forces its candidates upon the party at large.

The most distinctive ideas in the fashioning of gowns this Autumn are the extensive use of the princesse, the variety of its modifications, the devotion to the three-quarter coat in its multiplied forms, and the almost frantic rage for the corslet and gamp in their individuality and as a motive.

HARTFORD, Oct. 18. -- The Sheriff and Senatorial nominations in the State have been practically made. Yesterday the Democrats of the Hartford Probate district, one of the largest and most important in the State, nominated ex-Judge J. Hurlbut White, selecting the strongest candidate which the party contains in the district.

The Society for the Suppression of Vice succeeded yesterday in breaking up one of the most dangerous gangs of "green-goods" men that ever operated in this city. Two of the principals, who gave their names as Sam Ward and Isaac Rosenthal, were arrested, and paraphernalia of their trade that nearly filled an express wagon was taken from their rooms in West Fifty-ninth Street to Police Headquarters.

Some years ago a distinguished and eccentric New-York journalist offered a unique entertainment to a noble British tourist in the form of a dinner, at which Mr. Phineas T. Barnum and Mr. Martin Farquhar Tupper, then visiting our shores, were the only other guests. It was by the indiscretion of the veteran showman that an account of this banquet strayed into the public prints.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- The most successful Fall handicap athletic meeting ever held in Princeton took place this afternoon at the annual meeting of the University Track Athletic Association on the 'Varsity grounds. The new track was in perfect condition, and the day, without a breath of wind, favored record breaking.

OTTAWA, Oct. 18. -- Great interest is being taken here in the visit to Gloucester, Mass., by the Hen. Robert Baird, M.P., of the Newfoundland Government, who is urging Gloucester fishermen to petition Congress to admit Newfoundland fish and products free into the United States in return for free access to the bait, ice, and outfitting privileges of the American coast to American fishermen.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- The Salford Harriers of Manchester, England, made their first appearance in the East on the Players' League baseball grounds in this city to-day. The contests were international in character. The Manhattan Athletic Club of New-York was represented by a strong team, which carried off the greatest number of the honors.

Owners of real estate on Staten Island have recently been greatly annoyed, and some innocent persons have been outrageously swindled, by a gang of operators whose tricks seem thus far to have gone unpunished. The scheme of these operators has been to lay claim to certain lots or parcels of land under an alleged title by descent from the original Dutch proprietors, and to offer them for sale at prices calculated to tempt the unwary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Navy Department to-day issued an advertisement inviting proposals for the construction of a harbor-defense ram of 2,050 tons, a torpedo boat of 112 tons, and a swift torpedo cruiser of 750 tons.

The Tammany leaders are furnishing what ought to be a strong argument against their organization in their manner of raising campaign funds and the use they are putting them to. Public employes in the various departments and members of the fire and police forces are directly assessed, while the brewers and saloon keepers are called upon as usual for their contributions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18. -- Gov. Campbell was deserted by his party friends to-day. A great pressure was brought to bear to change the Governor's mind, but he stood firm upon one proposition, that being the abolition of the existing boards in Cincinnati. He compromised with the Democratic members and agreed to appoint a non-partisan Board of Improvements, saving at least one-half of the working force in the employ of the board from discharge.

THE CHINESE TO RULE -- Lord Wolseley believes that the Chinese are the coming race, and that they will overrun the world the moment a great General or law-giver arises among them. For 300 years the Chinese have been ruled by "the simple method of having all the more active, capable, and progressive heads shorn off by the Tartar".

PARIS AND BALZAC. -- As Dr. Johnson could not live away from Fleet Street, so Balzac was ever returning to the beloved mud and dust, the rain and flickering lights, the crowds on the boulevards, and the loneliness of those dismal cutthroat streets which he has shown as in a stereoscope at the beginning of the "Histoire des Treize."

The week has been almost entirely devoted to weddings. The bells have been ringing in the steeples almost without cessation since Sunday last, and rarely has an October week witnessed so many matrimonial events. These affairs, which have interested so many thousands of people, have been duly described in THE TIMES every morning, and there is no need in this column to repeat their details.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- There is never any story to a theatrical revue, and were there any connection between the incidents, the burlesque would not justify its title. Messrs. Clairville and Boyer, the authors of "En Scene, Mesdemoiselles," produced last evening at the Renaissance, are honest men, and they have not belied their trust.

BEATEN TO A MUMMY. -- The phrase "beaten to a mummy" has been familiar to me from my youth up, and I have always understood it as equivalent to beaten to a jelly. Does it not refer to the medicinal substance formerly known as mummy, which kept its place in our dispensatories until pretty late in the last century.

SARANAC LAKE, Franklin County, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The Adirondack region as a Winter resort is an idea with which many people are not yet familiar. Yet that is the hue which this particular part of them is just now taking on. The Summer visitors are gone, the hunting season is nearly over, the forests are rapidly losing their Autumn foliage which has made them surpassingly beautiful, yet this village is not deserted.

HARTFORD, Oct, 18. -- Ex-Congressman Robert I. Vance of New-Britain was here this afternoon, and completed arrangements for three speeches in the State during the campaign by Gov. Hill of New-York. The first is to be made here Tuesday evening, with Judge Morris, the Democratic candidate for Governor. One will be made at New-Haven and one at Bridgeport.

A stranger visiting Washington and walking the streets a few minutes before 9 o'clock in the morning would be surprised at the crowds of people he would see, but if, by chance, he should be on those same streets at a few minutes after 9, he would find them practically deserted. Like large factories, the Government departments require the presence of their employes promptly at a certain hour.

ROME, O ct. 7. -- Pope Leo XIII, is known to the world at large as one of the most enlightened pontiff's who ever sat in the chair of St. Peter, and also as a far-seeing and sagacious statesman. But there are few save the familiars of the Papal Court who are aware that the venerable chief of the Catholic Church is a skillful and enthusiastic sportsman.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 18. -- News received from Tushkahomma, Choctaw Nation, where the Choctaw Legislature is in session, is to the effect that the legislators are considering many questions of general interest, and that all fear of trouble growing out of the prospective contest for the Governorship between Governor-elect Jones and B.F. Smallwood is at an end. Jone has been installed.
The total value of city real estate sold at the Exchange and Auction Room for the week ending yesterday was $739,000, as against $247,435, the figures for the week previous.

LENOX, Oct. 18. -- This has been a comparatively quiet week in Lenox, as there have been no balls or other large entertainments, but the cottagers have been making it up by having dinner parties, oyster suppers, small dancing parties, driving parties, and various other entertainments. Many of the cottagers are preparing to leave and by the time snow flies, which is usually about the middle of November, there will be but few left here.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct 17. -- The Athletic Association of Rutgers College is in luck. Recently it was notified by the executors of the estate of Christopher Meyer to vacate the grounds it now uses for athletic purposes, and though it got an extension of time, the managers were worried because they did not know where to get new grounds.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 18. -- Admiral D.D. Porter and family have returned from Jamestown to Washington, and ex-Secretary of the Navy and Mrs. W.C. Whitney and George Bancroft and family from this city to Washington for the Winter. Admiral Porter and Historian Bancroft were both in feeble health and had to have special arrangements made for their comfort during the journey.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 19. -- The coils are tightening around the Matranga party of Sicilians, as the assassins of the late Chief of Police. The Provonseanos, who had been convicted of lying in wait to murder the Matrangas, on testimony which Judge Baker declared to be unworthy of belief, in granting them a new trial, have given their version of the matter. When asked who shot the Chief of Police they replied: "Matranga, sure."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The scientific expedition sent out last Spring, under the joint auspices of the National Geographic Society and the United States Geological Survey, for the purpose of exploring the region about Mount St. Elias, Alaska, has returned. Mr. Russell, who organized the expedition and had charge of the work, is now in Washington, and has furnished the following picturesque sketch of the work of his party:

In the course of the investigation into the operations of the City Government by the Senate Committee one significant case has been brought out which shows the utter futility of mere statutes to secure good management of public affairs. This was the case of a deputy in the Tax Commissioner's office.

The subject of the Rev. R. Heber Newton's discourse at All Souls' Church yesterday morning was: "Why We Want Municipal Reform," and his church was crowded to the doors. He found an appropriate Scriptural text in Nehemiah ii., 3: "Why should not my countenance be sad when the city, the place of my fathers' sepulchres, lieth waste."

Dorothea Dix had no ambition to become famous; for public distinction she had, in fact, real dislike. When Mrs. Hale desired to include her in the well-known book on distinguished women, she declared that notoriety was her special aversion, and that "nothing would interfere more seriously with the real usefulness" of her mission than to insert something about her in that work.

-- John Murray of London places among his announcements of Autumn publications "Jenny Lind, the Artist, 1820-1851," the same being a memoir of her early art life and dramatic career prepared from original papers in the possession of Mr. Goldschmidt by Canon Scott Holland and W.S. Rockstro. The work will be published with portraits and other illustrations and will comprise two volumes.

The signs that QUAY is to be beaten in Pennsylvania ought to be very cheering to the men who are fighting Tammany in New-York. The cases are of much the same kind. In Pennsylvania QUAY has named DELAMATTER for Governor, partly to "vindicate" his precious reputation, but chiefly to keep control of the power and patronage and plunder of the State Government.

Readers of THE TIMES know that a difference of opinion existed between two famous writers of English verse, both good judges of scenic beauty, as to what ought to be considered the fairest spot in Ireland.

The St. Louis Globe-Democrat hears that "the Brussels carpet manufacturers have formed a Trust and are increasing prices on account of the advantages offered them by the McKinley law." "If this be true," it continues, "then the Republicans in Congress will be compelled to give their early and careful attention to these men."
A few days ago the New-York Press published the following from a correspondent, with an answer:

According to the latest reports of MAHONE'S tactics in Virginia, he has concluded to make no nominations for Congress in seven of the ten districts of that State. His particular purpose is to deprive the mulatto J.M. LANGSTON, in the Third District, of a regular Republican indorsement, and compel him to run as an independent, in which case he can readily be defeated.

Amateur photography retains a strong hold upon the affections of those who have once bought a camera and have become initiated into the mysteries of developing dry plates. Very few give it up in despair, and the result has been that there were never so many photographers as now. Both societies of amateurs in this city report increased memberships this Fall, and that too without any effort being made to secure new members.
The following report, dated July 21, by Commander Walcot, on the naval defenses of South Australia, has been laid before Parliament at Adelaide:
St. Cecile Lodge, No. 568, F. and A.M., will confer the second degree to-morrow afternoon at 1:30 o'clock in Tuscan Room, Masonic Temple.

Patrolman Henry Fenker of the Thirty-third Preeinot, in Morrisania, was struck by a thunderbolt while on duty yesterday morning, and, strange to say, he is yet alive. Fenker reached signal Box 66 just at the moment when a thunderstorm which had been threatening for some minutes burst. He took hold of the handle of the box and was just turning it when a great streak of lightning flashed across the sky.

The United Service Club has been very prosperous since it moved into its clubhouse at 37 West Thirty-first Street, and its membership has increased to such an extent that already the quarters are being found to furnish insufficient accommodations. Preparations are being made, therefore, looking toward the securing of a more commodious house.

Although the biographies of his younger and more famous brother have made the name of Mr. Frederick Tennyson known to many who might not otherwise know it, it is safe to say that not one in a thousand who have read the works of Alfred knows those of Frederick, and not very rash to say that these latter are even less known than those of the late Mr. Charles Tennyson-Turner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- At no time since the passage of the civil service law have the various Republican State associations whose membership is made up of Government employes at Washington been so active as at present.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 19. -- Chairman George E. Mapes of the Independent Republican State Committee, on being asked to-day for his opinion on the State campaign, said:

Various questions have been raised as to the meaning and application of certain provisions of the new ballot law, some of which are due to honest doubt, but more to a desire to find some way of evading the law. There is a curious controversy going on just now as to the proper manner of folding the official ballot.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Mr. Gladstone will be accompanied by his wife throughout his tour of Scotland. They left Liverpool this morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The circumstances surrounding Luther Cary's 100-yard race Saturday afternoon have been thoroughly investigated. A prominent athlete, a graduate of Princeton College, who was at the games, says that in conversation with Cary immediately before the race, Cary told him he was in perfect condition, and was confident that he would break or at least equal the world's record.

Subjoined will be found a large amount of information, easily comprehensible, as to the practical workings of the McKinley tariff, all of it answering to the questions whether the tariff imposes a tax upon American consumers and whether greater burdens are put upon the people of this country by the new tariff law than they were bearing previous to its going into effect.

It will be an excellent thing for the taxpayers of New-York County to keen an eye on the provisional estimate which Register Fitzgerald has made out for the expense of conducting his office for the coming year, and also to watch the disposition which the Board of Estimate and Apportionment shall make of that provisional estimate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Mr. A.B. Mullet, one of the best-known architects of this city and for many years Supervising Architect of the Treasury Department, shot himself this evening at his residence.

In the examination of President COLEMAN of the Department of Taxes and Assessments before the Senate committee yesterday the incongruities and inequalities of the assessment of personal property in this city were once more brought out in a striking manner. It seems to be a matter over which the department has practically no control.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- When the Chicago limited swept into the station at 5 o'clock this afternoon, Col. John S. McEwen, Assistant Adjutant General, nearly broke his neck in jumping from the swiftly-moving train in order to alight near a group of Syracuse Democrats who had come to the station to pay their respects to Gov. Hill, who was on his way to Ohio to make a few speeches.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Corporation money and Senator Farwell's checks cannot insure a Republican majority in both houses of the General Assembly. The McKinley bill and the independent movement among the farmers may give the Democrats enough votes on joint ballot to elect Gen. Palmer.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- The Lincoln Independent, Republicans held a grand mass meeting in favor of Pattison for Governor at the Academy of Music to-night. The building was crowded from pit to dome. A number of strong speeches were made and enthusiastically applauded. Men who have been Republicans all their lives advocated the election of the Democratic candidate for Governor in order that the Republican politics of the State may be cleansed and purified.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Mr. Morley addressed his constituents in Newcastle this evening. He said he had promised when at leisure to write a history of England from 1886 to the next general election, but he despaired of being able to please Mr. Balfour in so doing. Mr. Balfour's arguments in his recent speeches were mainly Tu quoque, misrepresentations and irrelevancies.

One of the hardest fights for Congress is the one going on in the Sixteenth Ohio District, now represented by Major MCKINLEY. In 1888, on the Congressional vote in the four counties now composing the district, the Democratic majority was 1,500, though CAMPBELL'S majority for Governor last year was 3,000.

The mangers of the Irish ring campaign in Hudson County, N.J., took a step yesterday that will probably array the whole German population of the county against their ticket. The Jeffersonians or independent Democrats had met in convention and nominated among others ex-Mayor Herman L. Timken of Hoboken for Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day decided the case of the Poughkeepsie Iron Company, complainant, against the Boston and Albany Railroad Company, the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, and the Connecticut River Railroad Company defendants, involving relative rates on pig iron from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Youngstown and Cleveland, Ohio, to New-England points, and also relative rates from Poughkeepsie and other furnaces in the State of New-York to New-England points.

Patrick H. McCann, Richard Croker's brother- in-law and the man who furnished such interesting material for the Senate Committee on Cities last Spring, walked into Part II. of the Superior Court while the committee was in session yesterday morning and sat down at the lawyer's table. He was there simply as a spectator and not as a witness.
Senator John G. Carlisle of Kentucky delivered in the Senate on Tuesday, Sept. 30, his great speech against the McKinley Tariff bill. It is herewith printed in full.

Quite apart from the mission on which he goes, Mr. GLADSTONE'S "stumping tour" in Scotland presents a spectacle of which his countrymen have every reason to be proud. Such a physical feat as is involved in so much traveling and public speaking is very remarkable for a man who is close upon his eighty-first birthday.

It is a curious fact that when ex-GOV. PATTISON examined carefully the laws and the Constitution of Pennsylvania in order to determine in what way a reform of the ballot system could best be secured he found that the secrecy of the ballot was rendered practically impossible by the Constitution. The Constitution declares: "All elections by the citizens shall be by ballot.

" It is true the advances which have been made in duties were altogether inexcusable," says that prominent Republican paper, the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, "and will call for correction in the next Congress if the Republicans retain control of the House." If the Globe-Democrat desires that the influence of the protected manufacturers shall be exerted in support of Republican candidates for Congress, it should carefully avoid such predictions as this.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 20. -- The police have all the time insisted that there were five men in the party of assassins who murdered Chief Hennessy, and they asserted that they had four of these behind prison bars the next day. They have been searching diligently for the fifth man, and last night Manuel Pietro, an Italian living on Julia Street, near Barrone, was selected as the man.
We herewith submit a partial list of recent advances in prices on goods in our stock. These advances are not only in consequence of the new tariff, but they are absolutely compulsory under it.

The Democratic State Committee would like very much to get rid of Pat Gleason, the Mayor of Long Island City, who has been convicted of assault and who is committeeman from the Queens Congressional district, but it sees no possibility of doing so at present. Gleason's action in the present campaign has shown the committee that he is in politics for the sole purpose of furthering his personal interests.

The second week of the Brooklyn campaign opened yesterday, but there was no evidence of activity on the part of the politicians. No one appears to be paying much attention to the city and county tickets, and all interest seems to have been concentrated on the Congressional and Assembly fights. The Democrats are pleasingly amazed at the strength exhibited by Mr. Coombs, their candidate in the Third Congressional District.

Activity is again manifest among the Trustees of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine who have charge of the erection of the great cathedral on One Hundred and Tenth Street, and meetings are once more being held. At the last meeting Architects Potter J. Robinson, Hines, La Farge, and Kent, William Halsey Woods, and Hess Buck were called upon to hand in the finished designs on or before Nov. 1.

The Treasurer of the People's Municipal League is making an appeal to the citizens of New-York for funds to meet the expense of an active and vigorous canvass between now and the day of election. The league has no office holders to draw upon and it makes no assessment upon candidates. It depends upon voluntary contributions from the people for its expenses.

J.B. Sargent, New-Haven, Conn. -- It is a gigantic fraud on the American people. It will continue restricting our commercial relations wits foreign countries, prevent us from enlarging our markets and employing more men.
The Hon. Carl Soburz addressed the Massachusetts Reform Club by invitation last evening in Boston on the McKinley Tariff act. His speech in full is as follows:

BOSTON, Oct. 20. -- Carl Schurz had a great reception to-night from 300 of the most distinguished living representatives of Massachusetts gathered around the table of the Reform Club at the Brunswick to hear him discuss "The Present State of Public Affairs." Crausten Browne presided, and his introductory speech was the only one besides that of the guest of the evening. Mr. Browne spoke particularly of the mission of the club. He said:

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The storm that prevailed along the North British coasts Saturday was followed by a dense fog. Vice Admiral Sir Michael Culme-Seymour and the 240 officers and men belonging to the British fleet who were left on shore at Scarborough Saturday morning, when the squadron put to sea to escape being blown ashore, made an attempt to rejoin their vessels this morning.

Mr. Horace White lectured last night before the Young Men's Tariff-Reform Club, at 12 West Thirty-first Street, on some recent published statements from Mr. Andrew Carnegie concerning the tariff, for the purpose of demonstrating that Mr. Carnegie, though he understands how to make steel rails at a profit, does not know much about the tariff and still less about early American history.

The selection of Judge JOSEPH F. DALY as Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas by his associates of the bench is a well-merited compliment to a hard-working and conscientious jurist. No selection could have been made that would have given more general satisfaction to the bar, or been hailed more approvingly by the citizens of New-York whose interests are so largely in the keeping of the Court of Common Pleas.

It was expected that Company B of the Seventy-first Regiment would be disbanded last evening, but a dispatch from Albany in the afternoon stated that the intention had been postponed until Oct. 31. Quite a number of the members of tde company believe that in the meantime Capt. Belknap will resign, and that by this means the difficulties now besetting the company will be settled.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 20. -- Increased confidence on the part of the Democrats and a corresponding depression on the part of the Republicans have been the features of the political campaign in Delaware during the past week. The Democrats are aggressive and have so forced the fighting that the Republicans are on the defensive.

" Q C.B. Co." -- The House had eighteen contested election cases before it, in seven of which the Republican contestants were seated. Two cases remain to be decided. The right of eight sitting Democrats to their seats was confirmed, and the seat of one Democrat (Breckinridge) was declared vacant. The only contest in the Senate was that from Montana, and the Republican claimants from that State were seated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The first meeting of the new Washington Jockey Club will begin at the track at Benning's Station to-morrow. There will be twenty bookmakers on the ground and a successful meeting seems assured. J.J. Burke of New-York will be the presiding judge, a position he has filled satisfactorily at Chicago, St. Paul, and Kansas City during the past Summer, and James Rowe will act as starter.

The application of Duncan Cameron to make permanent an injunction obtained against the Sugar Trust, Kidder, Peabody Co., and the Central Trust Company, came up before Judge Pratt, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for argument. John L. Hill appeared for Mr. Cameron and was opposed by Edward M. Shepard and Elihu Root.

Pete De Lacy, the New-York gambler, who is now fighting the race tracks because, he says, they interfere with the business of his fare bank and other gambling establishments, paraded about the New-Jersey Central Railroad stallion yesterday armed with a big revolver and a full-moon smile. The revolver was to protect himself from expected assaults by bookmakers.

The attempt of the high-tariff papers to withhold from the rank and file of the party the fact that the prices of many kinds of goods have been advanced by the new tariff is one of the most curious of all exhibitions of partisan activity. At this time this movement for the rejection of evidence afforded by the senses and the pocketbook is assuming a new phase.

The speeches of Senator CARLISLE and of Mr. CARL SCHURZ, with the verified statement of facts as to the advance in the cost of living directly produced by the Republican tariff legislation, which we present to our readers this morning put the issues involved in the pending Congressional elections very clearly.

CHICAGO, Oct. I. -- A special dispatch from Harvard, IlL, says: "Charles Armbtrong, for forty years one of Harvard's most prominent citizens, has proved to be a defaulter, having robbed his clients of $25,000. He has always borne an unblemished reputation, but now it is learned that for years he has been practicing systematic frauds.

Yesterday the Board of Alderman authorized the adoption of a suitable grade on One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street from Bradhurst Avenue to the bluffs below St. Nicholas Avenue. Supervisor Kenny was instructed to use the Council Chamber, when not otherwise occupied, for the purpose of tabulating the police census reports.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 21. -- The third annual session of the Protestant Episcopal Missionary Council began in Trinity Church this morning. Eighteen Bishops, twelve missionary Bishops, and twenty-three ministers, representing all the Protestant Episcopal churches of the country, were present.

Many of our readers will recall the shameful story of the depredations of JAY HUBBELL of Michigan upon the civil service when he was Chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee and when he plunged his hands deep into the pockets of every Government employe in Washington from the Secretaries of departments to the deputy scrubwomen.

Naval Cadet T.F. Ruhm has been detached from the Enterprise and ordered to a special course of study in naval architecture in Glasgow, Scotland; Naval Cadet R.P. Hobson has been detached from the Chicago and ordered to a special course of study in naval architecture at Paris, France; Naval Cadet George H. Rock has been detached from the Chicago and ordered to a special course of study in naval architecture at Glasgow, Scotland.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment began its consideration of the budget for 1891 yesterday, and set aside about $11,000,000 to meet the requirements of four departments of the City Government.

A new move in the contest over the will of Mary Agnes Gordon, by which strangers would receive her estate of $500,000 to the exclusion of numerous relatives, was made yesterday before Surrogate Ransom. Allan McCulloh, from the office of Alexander Green, the attorneys for the Mercantile Trust Company, the executor of Miss Gordon's will, applied for the appointment of a commission to take testimony in Paris, where Miss Gordon died in May last.

The leaders of the Fenian Brotherhood have been holding the first convention of the organization in two years in Paterson, N.J. They concluded a three days' session on Monday night. Owing to the oath-bound nature of the organization nobody not a member has known much about the objects of the Fenians or their excuse for existence, except a professed hatred of England on general principles and a somewhat dimly-defined idea of liberating Ireland.
The following letter, to which was attached the signature of Hugh J. Grant, was yesterday received by Bartow S. Weeks, Chairman of Tammany's Committee on Notifications:

Gen. Nelson A. Miles, United States Army, commander of the Department of the Missouri, was in town Monday. Gen. Miles is Chairman of the new Cheyenne Commission appointed to negotiate with the Pine Ridge band of Cheyennes in South Dakota and the Tongue River Cheyennes of Montana for their removal to some other reservation.

The people's candidate for Mayor addressed four public meetings last night, beginning his evening's work at 8 o'clock in an east side hall, and concluding it at about 10 o'clock in a west side Baptist church. In each place he met a company of intelligent and earnest citizens to whom he explained the issues of the great fight that is making against Tammany Hall and the re-election of Mayor Grant.

The Church of the Transfiguration ,was the i scene of a very pretty wedding at 4 o'clock yes' terday afternoon, when Miss Adelaide Burlow Harry, daughter of Mrs. Emily Bucknor Hurry, was married to Mr. George Henry Kent, a young business man of this city, and a son of Robert R. Kent of Boston. The Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton, pastor of the church, officiated.

Excursion rates formed the chief topic of discussion at the meeting of the General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines in this city yesterday. It is the desire of the trunk lines, as expressed by their passenger agents, to have some general understanding regarding the making of excursion rates, in order that there may be greater uniformity of action on the part of the different roads.

HARTFORD, Oct. 21. -- The annual school enumeration in this State will be completed this week. The law relating to the subject was changed by the Legislature of 1889, and the first census of children of school age under the enactment was taken last October. Prior to that time it had been taken on the 1st of January in each year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The trial of the new gunboat Concord will take place early next week. The Secretary of the Navy to-day appointed the following-named officers a board to conduct the trial: Capt. Silas Casey, Commander O.A. Batcheller, Commander R.B. Bradford, Chief Engineers A.J. Kiersted, B.B. Wharton, and Ralph Aston, and Naval Constructor W.H. Varney.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Secretary Windom has sent a long communication to the Executive Committee of the National World's Fair Commission, calling attention to the lavish expenditures for salaries of officers and expense of committees. He advises curtailment in every possible way if the commission expects to get through the year without a large deficiency.

Mayor GRANT'S letter accepting a renomination at the hands of Tammany Hall has been prepared with a degree of care and a display of ingenuity, and with an absence of showy rhetoric, which indicate that a more skillful and sober pen than that of BOURKE COCKRAN was employed in its composition.

An era of obtenebration has somewhat abruptly set in at Richmond, Va. The Dispatch of that city, an adult and steady-going newspaper, has suddenly discovered that the "alliance" of Democrats with Republicans in the New-York City election contest "alarms us," that is, them, for it was adown the editorial spinal marrow that this cold thrill of alarm was creeping when detected and exposed.

The funeral of the Rev. Joseph FranstoH, vhich took place yesterday morning, attracted great crowd to St Peter's Roman Cathollo Church, in Warren Street, Brooklyn. The bulk of the people were poorly dressed, and a few were literally in rags, but no one looked at his neighbor's clothes or apparently cared about anything except to pay the last tribute of respect to a man who had ministered to the parish for nearly thirty years.

There was the usual crowd of racegoers at the Elizabeth track yesterday afternoon, even though there was a certainty of a heavy track and so of some scratching. Owners were so anxious to race, however, that, except in the fourth race, the scratches were few and the sport was as good as could be expected under the circumstances.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- A wild-eyed man with long hair appeared in the Secretary of State's office this morning and served on Deputy Secretary of State Benedict a mandamus issued by Judge Ingraham to show cause why the certificate of Frederick Bennetts, the Socialist labor candidate for Congress in the Fourteenth District, should not be received and filed in his office.

A Milwaukee dispatch in an afternoon paper contained a report that the consolidation of the Adams and United States Express Companies had been agreed upon and was to be effected by increasing the $12,000,000 capital stock of the Adams to $22,000,000, and exchanging $10,000,000 of it for a like amount of the stock of the United States Company.
Tax matters and tax methods occupied the attention of the Senate Committee on Cities again yesterday. Unless there is a change of plans, the committee will adjourn Friday until after the election.

The demand of the Mayor for a recount of the inhabitants of this city by the Census Bureau is the demand of almost its whole population. That there is very little civic pride in New-York is a truism, and a very disagreeable truism to people who have had occasion to make appeals to that quality in behalf of any good cause.
Sir Moreil Mackenzie, the imperial doctor and highest known authority on the throat and lungs, has just published a pamphlet in which he gives advise to public speakers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 21. -- The Republicans of Ohio are in great glee over the extra session of the Legislature convened by Gov. Campbell to remedy the evils of city government in Cincinnati. It gives point and force to what the Republican journals have said in the past about Democratic incapacity and blundering, and the changes will be rung on it unceasingly from now until the first Tuesday of November.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 21. -- Two years ago the Republicans carried the Twentieth Congressional District -- the counties of Saratoga, Schenectady, Montgomery, and Fulton and Hamilton -- under the prestige of a Presidential election and plenty of boodle by 3,301 plurality, every county returning a majority for John Sanford, the nominee of the party.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Mr. Gladstone addressed an audience of 5,000 persons in the Corn Exchange at Edinburgh this evening. Ireland, he said, continued to eclipse all other subjects. The country now fully recognized that the Irish questions must be settled before others.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The demand for contributions to the Republican campaign funds which was received by Ohio clerks yesterday was dated from the headquarters of the Republican State Committee, Columbus, Ohio, and signed by the Executive Committee of that organization. There was a meeting of the Ohio State Association last night, which had been advertised as a public affair, but from which all persons not members were barred out.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- It is not the fault of Florence Tyler of Butler, Ill., that Eugene F. Mease was not murdered by her hands. Miss Tyler walked into Mease's room, at 295 West Lake Street, last evening and shot him down. The most sensational feature of the shooting is the fact that Mease was married last Saturday to Miss Tessie Raymond, and the young couple had just started housekeeping at the number given above.

In this morning's issue of THE TIMES Mr. Russell, the organizer of the recent expedition to Mount St. Elias, is reported to have said that "St. Elias, instead of being the highest point in North America, is in reality a second-rate mountain. Its elevation, instead of being 19,500 feet, as previously considered, is about 13,500".

Mr. George M. Hester, the lawyer, of Cleveland, Ohio, who has been engaged by the Ohio heirs of Robert Morris, for a contingent fee of $3,000,000, to prosecute their claim to $50,000,000 worth of land in the western part of this State, has as yet made no move toward invalidating the title of the present holders of the property in question.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The sale of the Utica Herald occurred at noon to-day in the office of that paper. Exactly nine individuals, all Uticans, including Mr. Roberts, were present. The smallness of the attendance and the brevity of the proceedings excited comment. John G. Gibson, on behalf of Surrogate Bright, made objections to including Oneida County among the debtors of the concern.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- "Send none but terriers!" Thus wrote Gov. David B. Hill to his Utica heeler, David Dishler, a few weeks before the Democratic Convention met at Syracuse a year ago to nominate State officers, alluding to the character of the delegates to represent Oneida County. The sentence is full of significance. It demonstrates how absolute was Hill's confidence in Dishler as a boss and as a Hill follower.

Had the large hall in Cooper Union been elastic last night it would have been distended to more than double its normal size by the thousands of earnest citizens who wanted to attend the great ratification mass meeting of the County Democracy. As it was, not more than one-half of the persons who went to Cooper Union were able to get into the hall.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22. -The Yale'Varsity eleven defeated the Williams team at football to-day by a score of 36 to 0, although weakened by the absence of Cap. Rhodes, ftartvell, tIeffelfinger, and MoClung. The Williamsmeu, however, had not fully recovered from the effects of their game with Harvard last Saturday.

DEAR SIR: I beg to acknowledge the receipt of a notification stating that at the general convention held at Tammany Hall on the 10th day of October, 1890, I was nominated for the office of District Attorney.

The ratification meeting of the County Democracy at the Cooper Union last night was overflowing and enthusiastic. Ex-Mayor GRACE, who presided, not only highly commended the reform movement and the candidates of the People's Municipal League, but very effectively punctured the pretensions of Tammany as the repository of the Democratic faith in this city.

The public-spirited women of this city have for some years past exerted themselves in various ways to improve the conditions that surround the lives of the people. They have worked for the abatement of nuisances, for the better protection of health, for the improvement of the condition of the dwellings of the poor, and very recently in behalf of cleaner streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- A special dispatch to the Ledger from Mount Holly, N.J., says: "A desperate robbery and attempted murder was committed in Mansfield Township, Burlington County, last night. The victim was Louis Golstine, aged twenty-one, employed as a machinist at the printing press works of R. Hoe Co., New-York, and living at No. 221 Second Avenue, that city.

James McLean, President of the Colorado, Utah and Pacific Railroad, has been in this city for several days, and he has arranged with the Manhattan Trust Company to get financial aid in the building of his new railroad from Denver to Salt Lake City. Mr. McLean will go home prepared to let the contracts for the work of construction. The surveys for the new road were completed last August.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes was run at the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day over the new Cambridgeshire course, the last mile and a distance of across the flat. The race was won by M. Ephrusse's three-year-old filly Alicante, by Hermit, out of Madeira. Capt. Mochell's three-year-old colt Belmont, by Bean Brummel, was second and G. Masterman's three-year-old colt Tustig, by Edward the Confessor, third. There were twenty-nine starters.

The National Civil Service League has made public a partial report of a committee appointed by it last Winter to inquire into the removals and resignations of Postmasters under the present Administration. The report shows that Assistant Postmaster General Clarkson's activity in decapitating Postmasters was in no way overestimated, and that he was justly entitled to the praise which his brilliant party service won.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- Herbert Welsh, Secretary of the Lincoln Independent Republican Committee, has sent a letter to Robert T. Lincoln, Minister of the United States to England, in answer to the one sent by Minister Lincoln to Chairman Andrews of the Republican State Committee, objecting to the use of the name of Lincoln by the Independents. In his letter Mr. Welsh says:

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The Parliamentary election in the Eccles division of Lancashire to-day resulted in a victory for the Gladstonians. Mr. Roby, the Liberal candidate, secured 4,901 votes and Mr. Egerton, Conservative, 4,696. In the preceding election the Liberal candidate received 3,985 and the Conservative 4,277.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- "Johnny" Hope, who was sentenced to Sing Sing Prison by Judge Cowing in July 1879, for twenty years for participating in the Manhattan Bank burglary, was released from the prison this morning, and walked out a free man. About 9 o'clock a special messenger arrived at the prison and handed a large envelope to Warden Brush.

I herewith hand you a cutting from yesterday's edition of the Dry Goods Chronicle, and desire to draw your attention to the following clause, viz.: "It is a well-known fact that trials have been made with native-grown flax, and that the results have been satisfactory as far as low-class linens, such as crashes, , are concerned."

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 22. -As the effects of the McKinley bill become more apparent in various sections, the Canadian press waxes more indignant at the peary which is excluding Canadian pro:leers from the United 8tares, Though lumber shipments have been stimulated by he removal of the expor duty on los, there is no denying the fact that the volume of trade between the two countries will henceforth show a steady decline.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The annual meeting of the Trustees of Cornell University was held to-day in Morrill Hall. The Trustees from out of town present were Andrew Carnegie, Pittsburg; Superintendent Draper, Albany; David S. Jordan, Bloomington, Ind.; Hiram W. Sibley, Rochester; Frank H. Hiscock, Syracuse: W.C. Kerr, New-York; D.E. Salmon, Washington.

MONTREAL, Oct. 22. -- For the first time on record the American shipbuilders of the upper lakes have sent a divided steel steamer down the canals to Montreal to be reconstructed here previous to proceeding to New-York.

The result of the contest for reform in the Municipal Government will depend largely upon the extent to which the legal voters of the city are registered on Friday and Saturday next. The registration of the first two days indicates that if the proportion is carried out the number of names upon the lists will fall 40,000 below that of two years ago, though the number of legal voters has considerably increased.

A protest against the operation of the McKinley tariff law is being prepared by counsel acting for a large number of the most prominent merchants of this city. They have been in correspondence with Senator McPherson, Senator Carlisle, and the best legal talent of the country, the result of which is that they have determined to fight the bill on the following grounds:

The football team of the University of Pennsylvania gave an exhibition of "slugging" at Brotherhood Park yesterday afternoon before about 300 persons. The men on the team were supposed to be playing a game of football with the Columbia College eleven, but in the struggle of the two teams very little football was displayed.

There has been a change of plans in the arrangements for the Senate Committee on Cities. The idea of adjourning to-morrow till after election was abandoned yesterday, and when the committee adjourns to-morrow it will be to meet again on Monday.
