The investigation, in all probability, will be continued close up to election day, much to the disgust of Tammany Hall.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 22. -Wesleyan defeared Amherst at foothall on the campus this afternoon in one of the closest and most spirited football contests that has been played here this season. The game was well played and Interesting from start to finish, and the teams were so evenly matched that the result was very muoh in doubt until the very last.

Twenty steel columns for the machinery of the Maine have been condemned by a naval inspection board. The defective columns were found to be full of blow holes. They were furnished by the Standard Steel Works of Thurlow, Penn. New columns have been ordered. They will be made of wrought steel. The detective ones were made of cast steel.

We alluded the other day to the case of PERRY, appointed to be deputy under the Tax Commissioners, as showing Tammany's utter disregard for the requirements of the civil service law. We find, as the facts develop, that it is not merely an instance ou this particular vice of Tammany, but that it is a striking and characteristic example of the rottenness of the whole system.

The Japanese Government is having constructed at the yards of the Messrs. James and George Thomson, Clydebank, Scotland, a most efficient cruiser to be known as the Chiyoda. The Chiyoda is designed for the Japanese Imperial Navy.

In about eighteen months from this time the Columbian Exposition at Chicago ought to open its doors to the public. The preparations for every world's fair that has done any credit to the country in which it was held have been very far advanced when the opening of the fair was so nearly reached.

It seems, according to the chief Republican organ of Philadelphia, that the question of an early session of Congress is not yet settled by the President. That anxious officer is said to be still studying the problem solely, according to the organ, with reference to the best interests of the country.
What paper is that printed in that little brick building over there -- the building all plastered over with mortgages? That is the Sun.

The seventh annual meeting of the New-York State Medical Association began yesterday morning at Mott Memorial Hall, Madison Avenue near Twenty-seventh Street, and will continue to-day and to-morrow. There were 104 physicians registered as being present, a larger number than ever attended any previous annual meeting.

The Forest Commission of the State of New-York met yesterday at the office of Sherman W. Knevals, in the Mutual Life Building. Commissioners Knevals, Townsend Cox, and Theodore Basselin were present, as was Warden Samuel F. Garmon. The session was very interesting, as it was devoted entirely to a discussion of the proposed establishment of a State park in the Adirondacks.

When Mayor GRANT said to the Notification Committee of Tammany Hall on Tuesday night, "I have this day written a letter of acceptance," he said what everybody who is in the least acquainted with his capacity knows was not true. The document to which his name was appended was never written by him.

There was no conference of the baseball representatives yesterday. The Players' League insisted on having half a dozen men on the committee, and the League and Association men refused to grant the request. The result is the baseball war still rages, and, as was predicted, the whole Winter will be occupied in bringing about a settlement.

It is a pity that Judge CULLEN did not send the Mayor of Long Island City to the penitentiary, and it is not clear why he did not. Confinement for five days is better than nothing, but a fine of $250 is nothing at all to a Mayor who can raise that amount in a few minutes from the criminal resorts that have flourished and prospered under his mild and genial sway.

TIPPERARY, Oct. 22. -- Mr. David Sheehy, member of the House of Commons for South Galway, who is one of the defendants on trial here on the charge of conspiracy, and who was yesterday adjudged guilty of contempt of court and sentenced to one week's imprisonment, was taken to-day, under a strong escort, from this place to the Clonmel Jail, where he will serve his sentence.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 23. -- Rumors of new paper and of the sale of the Commercial Gazette have been as common as roses in June for months. The new-paper talk has a solid basis. Foraker's friends throughout the State felt more or less sore over the persistency and regularity with which the Commercial Gazette, after Mr. Halstead's departure for the East, failed to know anything about their favorite.

The jury in the condemnation appeal suit of the Point Breeze Ferry Company against the Bergen Neck Railway Company in the Hudson County (N.J.) Circuit Court returned a verdict of $14,397 yesterday. The suit is another of the well-known appeals of the Currie heirs from the decisions of the Commissioners appointed to condemn rights of way across their property in Bayonne.

The two World's Fair committees resumed their session yesterday afternoon at the Gilsey House, and devoted the entire meeting to a work almost entirely devoid of anything like tangible results. It must have become apparent, by this time, to the gentlemen composing these committees that they are without the ways and means necessary to a complete preparation for the foreign exhibit at the fair.

Day by day the Senate Committee on Cities is adding to and intensifying the fierce light it has thrown on Tammany's administration of city affairs. Each day's hearing emphasizes in a startling way the absolute inefficiency of the government as it is now administered, and almost every line of evidence is an imperative demand for a change of hands.

TIPPERARY, Oct. 23. -- In the Magistrate's Court here to-day the prosecution asked that the summonses issued against Mr. Harrison, member of the House of Commons for the Midland Division of Tipperary, and a number of others on charges of assault in connection with the recent disturbances here, be withdrawn. It was stated that the Crown intended to prosecute the accused at the Assizes.

Johnson Blakeley Creighton of the firm of J.B. Creighton Co., stock brokers, 72 Broadway, committed suicide at his office between Wednesday night and yesterday morning, by taking morphine. Despondency brought on by financial troubles is said to have caused Mr. Creighton to take his own life.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 23. -- A peculiar story was told to Justice Milligan concerning twelve-year-old Mary Mulligan. Two days ago the three-year-old daughter of George De Long of Willow Street disappeared. It was assumed that she had wandered into the woods, and a searching party started out to look for her. She was finally discovered in a house on Claremont Avenue minus nearly all of her clothing.

A more disagreeable day for racing than yesterday could not well be imagined. The rain came down in torrents, blew all through the grand stand, and forced the men under cover in the betting ring for shelter, while the women huddled together in the inclosed rooms at the clubhouse. The track was more like a canal than a race track and the racing was of course a travesty on sport.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- Whatever may be the result of the contest between Pattison and Delamater for the Governorship -- and the signs multiply daily that Quay's candidate will be buried under a political landslide -- it is almost a certainty that the Democrats of Pennsylvania will increase their Congressional representation at the coming election.
ALBANY, Oct. 23. -- The following are extracts from opinions of the Attorney General, constructing the new ballot law:

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- The action taken by the Trustees yesterday in establishing a school of philosophy is destined to place Cornell in the front rank of colleges of the world in the study of philosophy and ethics. Prof. J.G. Schurman, Dean of the new school, to-day expressed himself as very sanguine of great success in this line of work.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- Four persons employed at the Quaker City Dye Works, Howard and Oxford Streets, this city, were poisoned to-day in a peculiar manner. Two of them will die. The victims are: Bernard Hughes, aged nineteen years, 1933 Palethorp Street; James Tighe, forty-six years, Waterloo Street, above Cumberland; Walter Spellman, thirty-seven years, 605 Somerset Street, and William Eberhardt, seventeen years, 1,323 Howard Street.

Mr. T.B. REED has not been before an audience this Fall that he has not boasted of the great advance mad in the "business" capacity of the present Congress over that of all preceding ones. If the boast were founded on fact we should not be inclined to find any fault with Mr. REED'S exhibition of vanity in connection with the achievements of the Fifty-first Congress.

Two years ago Mayor Abram S. Hewitt was the candidate of the Citizens' Party and the County Democracy for re-election. He was bitterly opposed by Tammany Hall, though the candidate of that party when elected. In the light of two years of Tammany's Mayor, Grant, who was then running against Mr. Hewitt, these extracts from the latter's letter of acceptance sound like prophecies:

Peter De Lacy, the Bowery gambler, who, with one or two clergymen in Elizabeth who are probably in ignorance of the real character of the man, is conducting a crusade against the race tracks in Union County, N.J., is in serious trouble. Just after finishing his lunch at Ward's restaurant, in Elizabeth yesterday, he was arrested by Sergt. Hess of the Elizabeth police on a charge of conspiracy.
PARIS, Oct. 23. -- Sardou's version of "Cleopatra," written for Sarah Bernhardt, had its first production this evening at the Porte St. Martin Theatre.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- Michael Brazill, an aged and respected resident of the suburban town of Desplaines, was murdered by three tramps last evening. He went into his barn on Desplaines Avenue to feed his cow, when the three men, who had been concealed in the building, sprang upon him. One of them struck him on the head with a coupling pin, almost braining him.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 3. -- The Earl of Aberdeen, ex-Viceroy of Ireland, returned here to-day from a trip over the Canadian Pacific Railway to British Columbia. He sails with Lady Aberdeen for England from New-York on Saturday. He was waited upon here to-day by the President and Vice President of the Ottawa branch of the Land League.

A St. Louis merchant has received a letter from one of his New-York correspondents announcing an advance in the prices of goods used for church upholstery and pew cushions. Says the correspondent: "A few days ago we received through the Custom House from Chemnitz, Germany, a case of worsted damask (the goods are not made in this country) costing in Chemnitz $382.

VERSAILLES, Ky., Oct. 23. -- Senator Joseph C.S. Blackburn was thrown from a buggy here at 3 o'clock this morning and received serious injuries. Mr. Blackburn, accompanied by his friend, Andrew F. Steele of this place, was driving home from Lexington. The night was so intensely dark that it was impossible to see where to drive.

The Prohibitionists last evening gave a reception to William T. Wardwell at Clark's, in Twenty-third Street. Mr. Wardwell is Chairman of the Prohibition County Committee and also the candidate of that party for Controller.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 23. -- The Morning News to-night received a special despatch from Way Cross concerning the so-called riot in Coffee County. L.B. Varne leased a lot of land from the Way Cross Lumber Company just over the Ware line in Coffee County and recently began operations for working it for turpentine this Fall.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Mr. Gladstone spoke at West Calder to-day. He referred to the result of the Eccles election as a forecast of the triumph of the Liberals in the coming general election, which, if the present ratio of gains continued, would give them a majority of ninety. Recurring to the Irish question, he objected to the name "Separatist," as applied to the Home Rulers.

The sixteenth annual meeting of the Society of United Hebrew Charities was held in the basement of the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, last evening. After prayer by the President, Henry Rice, the report of the Executive Committee, giving in detail the work accomplished during the last year, was read.

Mr. STEPHEN B. ELKINS has made what the Tribute calls "a valuable contribution to the campaign" in the shape of a speech delivered in Wheeling, West Va., on the tariff. The Tribute's full report of the address shows that Mr. ELKINS had a great deal to say about tin and tin plate, beginning with this assertion.

A report comes from San Francisco that an appraisement of the Southern Pacific Railroad property is soon to be made at the instance of Mrs. Hopkins-Searles, who is said to be represented by the law firm of Butler, Stillman Hubbard of this city. It is current gossip in San Francisco that Mrs. Searles wants to sell her stock in the railroad and put her money into securities with coupons attached to them.

Half a hundred persons interested in affairs electrical met in Prof. Chandler's room in the Colombia College School of Mines last evening and listened with attention to the lecturer of the evening, Lieut. Bradley A. Fiske, United States Navy, who spoke on "The Modern Electrician in Time of War." The lecture was given under the auspices of the New-York Electrical Society.

The Jeffersonian Democratic candidates of Jersey City will not be able to present themselves in opposition to the ring ticket in Hudson County this Fall. County Clerk McLaughlin's refusal to recognize their certificates of nomination or to supply them with the official tickets which alone can be counted on election night, has already been noted.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 23. -- Assistant Secretary of the Interior Bussey addressed a Republican meeting here to-night. He came from Washington as a substitute for Postmaster General Wanamaker. Arrangements had been made to give the latter a great reception in anticipation of his giving Candidate Delamater a boost. At the last hour Mr. Wanamaker pleaded illness and sent Mr. Bussey.

The first half of the Fall meeting of the New-Jersey Jockey Club will be brought to a close this afternoon with the usual card of six races. The entries and weights for the several events are as follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The convention of the American Institute of Architects war resumed this morning, Mr. W.W. Carlin of Buffalo presiding.

We present this morning a carefully-authenticated account of the tripartite agreement between "Boss" CROKER, DE LANCEY NICOLL, and the Wine, Beer and Liquor Dealers' Protective Association of this city in regard to the Tammany candidacy for the office of District Attorney. It is the most disgraceful political bargain which has come to the surface in a long time, and of the three parties to it Mr. NICOLL appears in altogether the worst light.

In a lecture delivered last evening before the New-York Electrical Society, Lieut. BRADLEY A. FISKE of the navy showed, by many practical suggestions, how the ability and enterprise displayed by the electricians of the day can be made of most excellent service to the Government in time of necessity.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23. -- Prof. Caspar Hodge of the Theological Seminary announces this evening that two prizes have been offered by Mr. Alexander Maitland of New-York City, a son-in-law of ex-President McCosh, to be awarded to members of the Middle Class for the best exegesis of some assigned portion of the New Testament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- The traffic committee, composed of representatives from the Adams, Wells, Fargo Co., American National, Northern Pacific, Pacific, Southern, and United States Express Companies is holding a meeting here. There will be no advance in Western rates with perhaps one or two minor exceptions. Last year the rates to one or two points west were reduced, and possibly the old rates will be re-established.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- In reference to the alleged activity of the political associations, especially in the matter of raising campaign funds among the Government employes in Washington, Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt to-day said that the commission would pursue the same course it did last year.

PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 23. -- Apathy may prove fatally dangerous to the Democratic Party in Virginia, unless there is a quick and determined revulsion of feeling and a decided change in managerial policy and tactics. The people are overconfident and, for this reason, they are overestimating the strength of the Democratic organization.

Mr. Emile Berliner of this city has perfected his invention, the gramophone, and claims that it is the greatest sound reproducing machine in existence. Mr. Berliner is the inventor of the transmitter used on the telephones of the Bell Company, and is still retained by the company as one of its electricians. He first exhibited the gramophone, not then brought to perfection, in Philadelphia, May 16, 1888, before the Franklin Institute.
To many conscientious voters the choice between the two candidates for Mayor is a perplexing one.

The question of the constitutionality of the new tariff law was the leading topic in importing and manufacturing circles yesterday. Counsel for the importing houses who have determined to attack the validity of the law in the courts, went ahead yesterday in the preparation of their case just as if no public opinions had been expressed upon the matter.

The reason why football has not been in the past the favorite American game is that Americans generally have not understood the rules or the positions of the players, and hence have been unable to appreciate the fine points of the play. While this, of course, is not true of the college-bred man per se, it is almost invariably true of the general public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- "Grover Cleveland arrived in Washington this morning" was a message telephoned to New-York this forenoon. The man at the New-York end thought the message was "Grover Cleveland died in Washington this morning." In less time than it takes to write about it telegraph messages began to pour into Washington asking for particulars of the ex-President's death.

Superintendent of the Census Robert P. Porter arrived from Europe yesterday on the Lahn, and is now at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. On him it will largely depend whether or not New-York gets a recount. When the question was put to him by a TIMES reporter he answered very emphatically:

Mr. GUNNING S. BEDFORD, "Acting" District Attorney, was before the Senate investigating committee yesterday. An effort was made to obtain from him some explanation of the treatment accorded to excise cases in his charge. It was successful so far as concerns the facts, but a failure as to the explanation of motives.

Fishermen have now only the striped bass left to practice their favorite sport upon, but the game, such as it is, is abundant and vigorous enough to make up for the departure of the other species. The storm of a week ago proved the signal for the blue and weak fish to turn their noses toward the deep water, while the recent northeaster has driven out even the last stragglers.

VALLEJO, Cal., Oct. 24. -- Two sailors accidentally started a fire in the basement of the steam engineering storehouse at the Mare Island Navy Yard this afternoon, and in an instant the combustible matter stored there was a mass of flames, and the sailors were just able to escape. The trap doors were shut down, but so intense was the fire that the entire building was soon enveloped in flames.

About fifty men interested in the project of securing for Harlem a wholesale market, where small tradesmen can buy their supplies and where farmers from Westchester County and Long Island can take their produce without coming to some of the down-town markets, met in Smith's Hall, at 2,007 First Avenue, between One Hundred and Third and One Hundred and Fourth Streets, last evening, and organized the Harlem Market Company, with a capital stock of $50,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- An old-fashioned northeast storm has prevailed in this section since last night, the high wind making it the most disagreeable and aggravating storm for pedestrians that has occurred for many a day. It was most violent along the water front, although no damage is reported within the city limits. At Revere Beach the wind and high tide played sad havoc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- One of the subjects likely to occupy President Harrison's thoughts while he is on his proposed duck-shooting expedition next week is the vacancy on the Supreme Court Bench caused by the death of Justice Miller. There is no expectation that he will announce his selection before Congress meets in December.

The Manchester (N.H.) Mirror says that the opening speech of the campaign in Manchester was delivered by Congressman Greenhalge, and that it was an "eloquent and candid appeal to the patriotism, good sense, and sagacity of his hearers." The Manchester people have undoubtedly been imposed upon by some person in disguise. It certainly was not Greenhalge who delivered the address in question; he does not deliver speeches of that kind.

The ninetieth birthday of Germany's great soldier, Count VON MOLTKE, does not occur until to-morrow, but its celebration will begin to-day, which has been made by imperial order a holiday in all the public schools of the empire. And to-night a great torchlight procession will parade the streets of Berlin, in which the schools, the trades, the army societies, and the veterans are to take part.

Although Old Improbabilities at Washington promised to coax the stars into view last night, the shades of the late Mr. Tweed must have pulled the string behind his back, so that when the people's candidate for Mayor got ready to sally forth it was raining cats and dogs. Nothing daunted, Mr. Scott put on his cork-soled shoes and his long mackintosh and jumped into his carriage between the drops.
There is no question that the cost of Croton water should be reduced to the taxpayers from year to year. But the receipts show a remarkable increase.

The actual driving out of business of a firm of importers of woolens is a novel effect of the McKinley bill. It is, we believe, unprecedented in the history of tariff legislation in this country. The importers in question, Messrs. BERNHEIMER, SON Co. of this city, explain that they are forced to quit business because there is no longer any profit in handling the goods in which they have hitherto dealt.

A Washington dispatch in the Tribune yesterday asserted that Chairman R.P. Flower of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee had raised $300,000 as a campaign fund, and quoted Mr. John S. Clarkson as saying that he knew a heavy Democratic corruption fund had come into existence. Mr. Flower smiled when he read the fairy tale.

In the letter of acceptance which the best brains that Tammany could hire prepared for Mayor GRANT, credit was claimed for all the public improvements that had been devised before he came into office, and that had been carried on by departments in which anti-Tammany men still predominate, and for all the progress the city has made in spite of the temporary drawbacks of the Tammany incubus.

An Associated Press dispatch from Philadelphia last night said: "The important announcement was made this afternoon that an alliance between the Reading Railroad syndicate and the Vanderbilt interests had finally been effected and that hereafter the Vanderbilts will be represented in the Reading management.

According to the circular given out by Mr. FLOWER and printed in another column, the Republican managers have adopted a suggestion made to them in these columns some months since. They have a list of "registered contributors," holding certificates arranged in series, and to be honored in some way on presentation at Washington.

The hearing before the Senate Committee on Cities yesterday was in many respects one of the most remarkable ever held by that body. It brought Col. John R. Fellows, District Attorney, to the stand, and his evidence contributed some very interesting matter to the history of the Aldermanic boodle cases.

The Sultan of Vitu may yet give the British as much trouble as Chief BUSHIRI gave the Germans. Under the recent compact Vituland, which the Germans had so counted upon holding that they had organized a colonial society for that special region, was taken from them. Vitu was the starting-point of Dr. PETERS in his journey up the Yanu River, in order to establish a claim to the region in the rear of that port.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Mr. Ryan, the United States Minister to Mexico, telegraphs that Leandro Hernandez has been appointed as the representative of the Mexican Government on the Intercontinental Railway Commission and is now on his way to the United States. It is understood that the Mexican Government will appoint a second Commissioner at once.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien, accompanied by Mrs. O'Brien, leave Paris to-night by a special steamer train for Havre, where they will embark to-morrow morning on the steamer La Champagne, which sails to-morrow for New-York.

Some days ago it appeared by the dispatches that there was a very considerable difference among the French Canadians of Montreal upon the question of entertaining the Count of PARIS. This was a surprising piece of information, for if there is anywhere in the world a "Bourbon" population, in the literal as well as in the figurative sense of the word, that population is to be found among the French Canadians.

In 1857 Mr. HENRY WILSON of Massachusetts, afterward Vice President with Gen. GRANT, presented the claims of the woolen manufacturers of New-England in the following form: "They ask you now in the adjustment of the tariff to adopt the policy of admitting duty free the wools, the dyestuffs, and all those articles that enter into their manufactures."

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 24. -- General Williams, a negro boy seventeen years old, shot and killed the five-year-old son of J.R. Roberson, white, five miles from Miller last Monday. The negro was sitting by the roadside near Roberson's house eating chinquepins, with a gun across his lap. The child snatched a few nuts and ran. Williams fired into his stomach, causing instant death.
Resent political events in St. Louis have moved our influential Republican contemporary in that city, the Globe-Democrat, to make the following remarks under the title, "The Political Brigand":

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The Delta Upsilon Convention continued its session to-day. The place for holding the convention in 1891 was decided in favor of Harvard College, and for the convention two years hence Colby University, Waterville. Me., was selected.

Mr. De Lancey Nicoll is evidently of the opinion that a simple denial of the explicit charges against him printed in THE TIMES of yesterday is all that is necessary to restore to him the confidence of such persons as until their publication believed in his personal integrity, if they doubted his political morality. Mr. Nicoll made such a denial, as of course he would, but he stopped there.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 24. -- Another sensation overwhelmed the police this morning. The body of a murdered Italian was found floating in a sack in an eddy in the river just below Kinnerville, by some negroes who make a living by catching driftwood. There is every indication that another foul crime has been committed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The week has been marked by sensations at both national and local headquarters of the Columbian Exposition. At the former Secretary Windom's letter, applying air brakes to the National Commission, was the absorbing subject of discussion among members of the Executive Committee. While the Commissioners felt that Secretary Windom had addressed President Palmer under a misapprehension of the facts, they deemed it expedient to comply with the spirit of his suggestions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- A story is told to-day, and vouched for as true, which illustrates once more the petty meanness of the present Administration in general, and of President Harrison in particular, in a peculiarly repulsive way. The visiting iron and steel men from Great Britain are expected to pay this city a visit to-morrow, and preparations have been made to give them a fitting reception.

EAST PEPPERELL, Mass., Oct. 24. -- A big fire was discovered this morning at 2 o'clock in the shoe factory of Leighton Brothers, and soon the whole building was ablaze. A high wind was blowing and the flames spread rapidly to a row of wooden boarding houses. Help was called from the surrounding towns, the old apparatus of this place being insufficient. Nashua was called upon and responded with some of her trucks and men.

When the Board of Estimate and Apportionment began its session in the Mayor's office yesterday morning, Police Commissioners Voorhis, Martin, and McClave were on hand with the estimates for running the Police Department in 1891. The modest sum of $4,818,878.28 was demanded.

LETTER OF TOLSTOI'S ON DEATH -- From Lyef Tolstoi to A.A. Phet: "Oct. 17, 1860. * * * I think you already know what happened. On Sept. 20 he died, literally in my arms. * * * Nothing in my life made such an impression on me. He used to say truly that there is nothing worse than death.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 25. -- Secretary of State Blaine arrived here from Pittsburg at noon today. He was met at Alliance by a reception committee from Canton and escorted to this city over the Pennsylvania Railroad. A crowd greeted Mr. Blaine with loud cheering as he alighted from the train, and followed his carriage to the home of Major McKinley, whose guest he was during his stay here.

Will the police authorities consider the propriety of stationing an officer to protect the lives of those who have to pass across Printing House Square to the bridge? There is hardly a day goes by that in the crowded hours some one does not very narrowly escape injury there, while "accidents" are of frequent occurrence.

MATAWAN, N.J., Oct. 25. -- The monthly shoot of the Midway Gun Club was hold yesterday. The first prize, a gold badge, was won by James Van Brockle, and it becomes his property, as he has won it four times in succession. Two other matches followed, and both were won by Van Brockle. Van Brockle is one of the best live-bird shots in the county.

I have a friend who is a newspaper man and a bit of a cynic. I met him upon the steps of the Astor House one afternoon last week. He was in a discursive mood and the subject of his discourse was luck. Something has gone wrong with him and he was saying things about his luck that would not look well in print. He moralized thus:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 25. -- To all intents and purposes Senator Brice has assumed the leadership of the Democracy in the present campaign, and has been visiting all of the Congressional districts. In answer to the inquiry, "What do you think of Democratic prospects of success in Ohio?" Mr. Brice replied:

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- It did not take the amusement-loving public a long time to recognize a good thing in Francis Wilson's production of "The Merry Monarch." It was a "go" from the very first night. When it was announced for a Chicago run, popular expectation rose to such a point that the advance sale was the largest ever known in the local history of comic opera.

The Storm which raged all Thursday and Friday was felt very seriously at sea, as was shown by the reports of incoming vessels yesterday. The report that the Obdam had been ashore on Long Island proved to be untrue, although the ship was badly tossed about in the hurricane. Her commander, Capt. Bakker. reported that he was thirty miles southeast of Fire Island at the time she was supposed to be ashore.

The Corinthian Yacht Club of New-York announces the conditions of its third annual sweepstakes. Although this race is not to be sailed until the season of 1891 the announcement is made thus early in order to stimulate the building of yachts, particularly with regard to the construction of forty-six-foot boats.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- Congressman Crisp of Georgia, prospective Speaker of the next House in case of a Democratic majority, spoke in Faneuil Hall to-night, devoting himself mostly to the tariff, and especially its influence on the condition of Massachusetts wage earners. The hall was crowded.

There has never been a more extraordinary announcement in a civilized country than the announcement that Mr. BALFOUR, the Chief Secretary for Ireland of the British Government, has gone to that island "to make a personal investigation of truth of the statements regarding the condition of the potato crop."

CAMERON, West Va., Oct. 25. -- Gov. Hill and party, accompanied by T.S. Riley, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee; Gov. Fleming, and others, left Wheeling at 7:30 o'clock this morning on a special train provided by the Democratic State Committee over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, consisting of a drawing-room car and Calvin S. Brice's private car.

HARTFORD, Oct. 25. -- An attempt to foreshadow the character or extent of the railroad legislation that will come up in the next Legislature, which will meet here in January, would be futile at the present juncture. It may be safely stated, however, that the Housatonic Company's contest for the elimination from its charter of the provision that in effect prohibits the building of branch lines will be renewed.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 25. -- On account of Yale's arriving late her football game this afternoon with Amherst only lasted three-quarters of an hour. Two halves were played, one of thirty minutes, and the other fifteen. Yale found Amherst harder to beat than she expected, and it took fifteen minutes before McClung scored the first touch-down for Yale.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Mayor William Cowie, a Republican, exploded a bomb here this afternoon when he issued an edict that all hotel and saloon bars in Syracuse should remain closed, front and rear, from 12 o'clock on Saturday nights until 5 o'clock on Monday mornings. This is an act that has caused excitement, not only among the liquor men, but the politicians as well.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25. -From a review of the political situation in the tate, vithin nine working days of the election, it is clear that the Democrats have the lead, with the prospect of carryin the 6taf ticket on the popular vote, secua-qng three of the four Congressmen from the State, and of winning an increased representation in the State Senate.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25. -- The first biennial report of the Shellfish Commission in this State, which is now being arranged by Dr. William M. Hudson of this city, will show that the State's total receipts from the public oyster lands for the year ended June 30, 1889, were $8,578.41. The disbursements for the same period on account of these lands amounted to $5,153.13, leaving a balance of $3,425.28 for the Treasury.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 25. -- The Ladies' Athletic Club was fully reorganized at a recent meeting by the re-election of the officers of last season and the reconstruction of the Advisory Committee, as follows: Mrs. C.H. Kimball, Mrs. S.S. Beard, Mrs. S.D. Davis, Mrs. C.W. Stone, Mrs. F.P. Freeman, Mrs. D.B. Plumer, Mrs. S.B. Ferris, Mrs. Terry, Miss Ferris, Miss A. Dashiell.

There is a woman in this city whose wealth, position, and goodness fill her life with social and charitable occupations. But for more than six months it has been impossible to procure her presence anywhere' on Saturdays. She has told one or two intimate friends the reason:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 25. -- W.J. Howard, the Philadelphia lawyer, and ex-General Solicitor of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, continues his attack on the so-called city ring and the Duquesne Traction Company, in which many of its members are interested.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- A pretty blonde actress is making trouble for Dan McCarthy, star and manager of the "True Irish Hearts" company, which is playing at the Grand Opera House. Miss Florence Hastings was, up to Oct. 6, the leading lady of the company, having, as she says, played for sixty-one performances without a word of dissatisfaction from McCarthy.

The Government and the city have never yet entered into a trade for real estate, but it is not improbable that something of the kind will be proposed in connection with the movement on the part of the Post Office authorities on the one hand and the Beard of Estimate and Apportionment on the other for the removal of the Post Office to an up-town site and for the construction of a new municipal building.

It was reported yesterday that the importers of Havana tobacco are organizing a formal and determined demand for either a change in the new tariff law as relating to tobacco, or else an interpretation or decision upon the section of the law referring to tobacco which will enable them to import that article. As the matter now stands they say that imported tobacco seems to be shut out of the market.

A curious and interesting theory of the will, or rather of what is known as firmness of will, is that the man who has strength of mind and follows fixed plans that he has laid down for himself, and whom nothing but absolutely insurmountable obstacles can prevent from accomplishing them, is simply self-hypnotized.

The results of the recent inquiry into the methods of the Tax Department should arrest the attention of all thoughtful minds. No element of city government has so important and direct an influence on the prosperity of a city and the lives and fortunes of citizens as taxes and their proper or improper imposition. In New-York City it affects primarily the pocket of from sixty-five to seventy-five thousand taxpayers.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- At the Fall session of the Classis of Orange of the Reformed Church, held last Tuesday at Pine Bush, the Rev. A.M. Gliddon, late of the Wyoming Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, was formally received and ordained to the ministry of the Reformed Church. He was then assigned as stated supply for one year of the Reformed church at Wurtsborough, N.Y.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- "L'Art de Tromper les Femmes," the new play at the Gymnase, is an immense success, in which the authors, Messrs. de Najac and Paul Ferrier, have trifling share. The burden of the work was given to M. Noblet, and, thanks to one of the most inimitable impersonations that I have ever seen on any stage, the comedy is booked for a Winter's run -- up to holiday season at all events.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- The new Tariff bill was issued to the Chamber of Deputies to-day. It dwells upon the tendency toward protection displayed by most nations. It refers especially to the high tariffs of the United States, Canada, and the South American States.

THE REALITIES OF WAR. -- Those who know the galleries of Versailles will hardly fail to remember Horace Vernet's important picture of the taking of Constantine. This great canvas has merits which are patent to every one, but to estimate it at it proper worth it is necessary to study its scheme carefully and to compare it with earlier and contemporary battle pieces.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 18. -- A bill has been submitted to Congress proposing that companies issuing insurance policies of whatever description in this country shall thereby acquire a legal domicile here and become exclusively amenable to the local tribunals. All such companies, says one of its clauses, shall be subject to the laws and authorities of Mexico, both as regards the form and essence of their contracts and the pledges offered for their fulfillment.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- This glorious Autumn weather, instead of keeping every one in the country, has sent back to Paris a large number of people much earlier than usual. The calendar in high life almost marks January. The Summer has been restful, in contrast with the previous exhibition season, and presumably it has been rather dull under the turret roof of the chateau home.

Sayings by the impressionist Degas are reported by George Moore in the Magazine of Art. To Gerome, who had criticised one of his pictures: "I suppose it is not 'Turkish' enough for you, Gerome!" To Whistler: "My dear friend, you conduct yourself in life just as if you had no talent at all." And concerning Whistler: "You cannot talk to him; he throws his cloak around him -- and goes off to the photographer."

SYRACUSE, Oct. 25. -- Syracuse, politically, is to-day the most picturesque city in the State. It is the possessor of the junior United States Senator, the Chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, and the Chairman of the Fassett investigating committee. It is the residence of the man who made Frank Hiscock United States Senator, and whose voice will decide the contest for United States Senator next January if the Assembly happens to be Republican.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Oct. 25. -- George F. Nipps, who lives near Ardmore, Indian Territory, was to-day in this city and detailed the extent of the gold excitement in the Arbuckle Mountains. Mr. Nipps has not caught the "gold fever," and talks in a conservative manner of the rich finds that have been made. For twenty years he has lived in that Territory, and he is one of the wealthiest "squaw men" in that country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Lehigh University played two games of football at Princeton to-day. The contest between the Freshman teams took place at noon and resulted in a victory for Princeton by a score of 34 to 0.

The person who made the wager referred to will lose his money. If a voter makes oath before the inspectors that he is physically unable to prepare his ballots, he may take one person into the booth to help him. In all other cases the law says he must be absolutely alone in the booth.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 25. -- Judge Shires of the United States District Court to-day made an important ruling involving the Iowa prohibitory law. The matter came up on a petition of habeas corpus in which E. E. Spickler of Carroll County was plaintiff. Spickler was adjudged guilty of contempt of court in Carroll County on Sept. 12, but an injunction had been issued against him in the District Court.

It was nearly 3 o'clock one morning recently when several men came out of a restaurant in the Bowery above Grand Street. One of them had an immense rat trap in his hand, and in it, making frantic dashes against the wires, was a big fat rat, whose jaws were fringed with long white whiskers.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- Nearly twenty thousand persons took part to-night in the torchlight procession which began the celebration of the ninetieth anniversary of the birth of Field Marshal Count von Moltke. All classes of the people were represented. The participants were artistically grouped by prominent painters and sculptors.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -- A remarkable expression of bird intelligence has been manifested by a robin at Westville. Early in the Summer of 1889 Mrs. A.R. Burwell, who resides near the end of the New-Haven and Westville horse-car line, found the young robin in her dooryard. It had fallen in its first attempts to fly and was rendered helpless by the injury.

Apart from the mere question of purity, good wine is, perhaps, a matter of taste; nor is this a matter of fashion, but of good judgment, and if we find that a kind has received the commendation of connoisseurs we may at least try it with confidence.
NEWPORT, Oct. 25. -- Peleg Hall has rented his house on Bellevue Avenue for the season to Robert L. Cutting of New-York.

The real estate market is showing signs of a revival of activity. It may be a question whether the improvement in business is superficial or substantial. The fact remains that a much better feeling prevails among those who deal in real estate than was the case earlier in the season, and that in some quarters there seems to be a basis for hope that the activity may continue.

DUELING IN FRANCE. -- Dueling is popular still but, if a death occurs in the contest the survivor and the seconds are obliged to fly the country for a time, for not only will magistrates punish, but juries will convict, and the civil courts are ready to award to the injured relatives crushing damages.

The stores are as full of "Paris novelties" as of ladies. Among the pretty trifles light as air (unless weighed in the financial scale) offered under this, to the shopper, irresistible title are the filigree flowers of non-tarnishing silver wire. They are intended for evening wear on the dress or in the hair, and might have been made to crown the Queen or the Fairies so ethereal are they.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- The sale of liquor in clubs ostensibly formed for social or athletic purposes is one of the most obstinate forms of resistance to the Massachusetts restrictive laws. The last Legislature passed a law forbidding the existence of such clubs, but it was not applicable to clubs already chartered.

People who attended the Strauss and Seidl concerts in the new Madison Square Garden would hardly recognize that place of amusement since it has undergone the changes made in preparation for the coming annual exhibition of the National Horse Show Association of American. The stage of the Garden has been removed, the flooring has been taken up, and the place has been changed from a concert hall to an arena.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The generous gift of the Hon. H.W. Sage and the action of the Trustees in appropriating it for the establishment of the Susan E. Linn Sage School of Philosophy has been the most important event of the week. The foundation of this new department was laid four years ago, when Prof. J.G. Schuman took the Chair of Philosophy.

I dare say that not one-half of our population east of the Mississippi River has ever heard of Butte, or can tell where it is if they have. Yet it is the most productive locality on the face of the earth. The fabulous caves of Aladdin or the famed isle of Monte Cristo cannot compare with it for richness. Statistics show this.

The iron steam yacht Catarina, owned by Mr. E.D. Morgan, which went ashore Friday on the rocks off Matinnecock Point, thereby crushing a hole in her bottom, was an interesting sight yesterday. She lay heading about west-north-west, with a slight list to starboard, on the rocks about an eighth of a mile off the abrupt bluff of the point.

The suit of York, Strong Co. against Judge Miles Beach of the Court of Common Pleas to recover a balance of about $15,000 alleged to be due on a running account which the Judge had with the bankers on stock transactions, was tried yesterday in Supreme Court, Special Term, before Judge Barrett. Briefs will be handed up by the lawyers before the case is decided.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Diagrams of the first target practice on the cruiser Philadelphia have just reached the Navy Department. The practice was at Gardiner's Bay, Oct. 4, with six-inch, three-inch, and one-inch rapid-fire guns, and the results were remarkable.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The Utica Herald, which was chiefly owned by Ellis H. Roberts, the United States Sub-Treasurer in New-York, was sold Wednesday, and at the same time a list of the creditors of Ellis H. Roberts Co. was made public. There are some familiar names in the list. The heaviest creditor is Congressman George West, $17,000. Ex-Senator Warner Miller comes next with a claim of $12,000.

It is a common impression that a change of men in the City Government can only give momentary relief, even if the new men be themselves of the best order. City affairs have undergone so many changes, and the system under which they have been conducted has been, intentionally or from ignorance, so often confused, that our citizens have come to feel that radical and permanent reform is practically impossible.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- The commission of the Reichstag to which were referred the labor hills will resume its sittings Nov. 4. Time will thus be given for a complete discussion of the measures before the reassembling of the Reichstag in the first week of December. The ultimate shape and fate of the bills depend largely upon the Government's tact in securing a majority.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 25. -- For several days there have been well-defined rumors of a systematic scheme on the part of the Republicans to bribe voters at the coming, election, but the new election law so carefully guarded against bribery that such a thing as an organized effort in that direction was regarded as an impossibility.

Police Justice White, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday continued the examination in the case of Mrs. Goepp, the wife of ex-Judge Goepp, and her two sisters, Delia and Mary Silk, charged with having set fire to their residence, 33 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street. Pieces of kerosene-soaked plastering were put in evidence, and several members of the Fire Department gave testimony corroborative of that of Chief of Battalion Short.

Ever since Francis M. Scott was placed in nomination for Mayor by the People's Municipal League ex-Mayor William R Grace has been as busily engaged in the work of the campaign as he ever was when a candidate himself. He was found at his office in Hanover Square yesterday afternoon "up to his ears," as he put it, in the business of the canvass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circutation, $140,237,150, as follows: Currency sixes, $6,672,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $28,391,700; 4 per cents, $105,173,450.

All Manhattanville turned out last night and helped the People's candidate for Mayor to wind up his first week's campaign in a tumult of enthusiasm. Mr. Scott reciprocated their attentions by giving them a vigorous talk on rapid transit that warmed the cockles of their hearts and sent them home to dream of wonderful things to come.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The near approach of the opening of Parliament, which, by the way, has been further prorogued to the 25th of next month, has had the customary effect of bringing the great party orators back from their holidays to unburden themselves to their speech-ridden constituencies.

That obscure German Baron who raised himself to the eminence of King of Corsica, only to die in want and to find decent burial at the hands of strangers in London, made an admirable subject with which to begin a series of biographies devoted to men who have helped to raise the world's applause.

THE KESTREL -- The kestrel is a very early riser, and hunts far into the twilight hours, frequenting the neighborhood of fields and ricks. He is a very handsome little bird, when viewed at close quarters, (as you may sometimes view him when feeding,) with the smallest curved beak and talons: his lovely red-brown mottled plumage enhanced in color by his gray tail and white throat.

Brooklyn League players are on a fair road to win another championship. By the most skillful kind of work this Summer they outplayed their opponents in the League and they are engaged in a similar task just now with the Louisvilles, who won the champions of the American Association. The contest is for that title known in baseball parlance as the world's championship.

The second case in which the Court of Appeals rendered its decision also arose in Buffalo on the suit of one KIP, ex-Secretary of the City Civil Board, for salary for services rendered. The suit was brought because the Common Council cut down the appropriation asked for by the Mayor for the expenses of the commission to a nominal sum.
BOSTON, Oct. 26, -- The l'ew-England TariffReform League has issued an address to the voters of New-England placing plainiybefore them the iues railed by the McKinley bill

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26. -- The Coroner's jury that had been summoned in the case of Anson Garneau of Lockport, N.Y., remained in session till late last night, and brought in a verdict that the deceased "came to his death by a pistol bullet, how fired or by whom they did not know."

Prof. Felix Adler spoke before the Society of Ethical Culture in Chickering Hall yesterday morning on the moral issues involved in the campaign of the People's Municipal League, and announced that he would follow up the subject next Sunday. There was not a vacant seat in the hall when Prof. Adler began his address.

The work of the Ladies' Committee in aid of the People's Municipal League has been extraordinarily successful. The movement itself is extraordinary, and here quite unprecedented. It has done substantial service already in raising funds and awakening interest among voters not easily reached through the ordinary channels of political activity.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 26. -- The Lynn Gas and Electric Company suffered a serious loss at 2 A.M. to-day at their electric light power station on Pleasant Street, by the shattering of the large flywheel, 20 feet in diameter, on the 500 horse power Corliss engine, used for running the arc lights for street lighting.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 26. -- Judge James P. McTeer, a member of the bar of Virginia, and who happened to be on the Louisville and Nashville train coming to this city to-night, furnishes the following:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Minnesota has a solid Republican delegation in Congress, and is generally regarded as a pretty reliable Republican, State. None of her five members of the House of Representatives received less than 1,800 more votes than his Democratic competitor, and from this figure the majorities two years ago ranged up to 10,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 26. -- Mahone is manifesting very little interest in the political fight this year. Even in the Fourth District, where his bitterest enemy, John M. Langston, is making such an active canvass, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee is apparently indifferent. His seeming apathy there, though, is accounted for here by the fact that he is afraid to take part against the colored independent candidate.

TEMPLE, Texas, Oct. 26. -- Two hundred and eighty thousand gallons of water confined in the steel stand pipe broke loose at about 3 o'clock Friday morning and flooded the town. Immense sheets of boiler steel, hundreds of pieces of scaffoldings, houses, barns, fences, and all the debris of the surrounding neighborhood went floating and crashing in all directions.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Maggie Taylor, twelve years old, and Henry Kammann, aged about twenty-one years, were both in the employ of Thomas R. Morgan, a gardener on Eagle Rock Avenue, Millburn, just across the line from West Orange and near the Orange Reservoir. The girl was a niece of Morgan's and of ex-School Commissioner Austin J. Curtin of this city.

Statistics are doubtless always important, but they are only interesting when they disclose and measure departures from the ordinary course of events. There are several such instances in the last Treasury bulletin, and they acquire added significance when collated with other facts which interpret them.

A large number of amateur photographers went down to the seaside Saturday to get surf pictures and such tokens of the work of the recent storm as were possible. The day was not a good one for picture making, and no remarkably excellent views were obtained. Often after a storm neat little bits of seaside scenery are to be obtained along the coast, in which wreckage forms a feature.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church preached yesterday morning on the present condition of municipal affairs in this city. The text was found in the eighth verse of the twelfth Psalm: "The wicked walk on every side when the vilest men are exalted."

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 26. -- Trouble has arisen between Mr. Hersch, the American Minister, and the Porte over the arrest of an American subject on suspicion of being implicated in Armenian revolutionary plots. The accused man is a graduate of Bowdoin College. He came to Turkey during the Administration of President Hayes to found an American college, but the project fell through and he has since remained here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Ex-Alderman William P. Whelan was shot and mortally wounded early this morning by George H. Hathaway, a gambler. The tragedy occurred at 4 o'clock in Mat Hogan's saloon and restaurant at 336 State Street, a rendezvous for the sporting people of both sexes.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 26. -- By some mysterious process a mass of the confidential letters addressed to Chairman Mack of the Republican State Committee from the workers in various parts of the State has come into the hands of the Democratic Committee. These letters all tell the same woeful tale of Republican apathy and prospective defeat of the State ticket and the candidates for Congress in several districts now represented by Republicans.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., Oct. 26. -- Mrs. Brannen, the St. Louis woman who two weeks ago jumped from a train near this place and escaped to the woods, has at last been found. While Brent Mead was looking for a horse near Pinneckin this morning, he thought he heard a woman groan. He made a search, calling, but received no answer.

An analysis of the registration figures brings assurances to everybody interested in the cause of honest municipal government and the election of the ticket headed by Francis M. Scott that a decisive victory awaits them on election day. Mr. Scott himself said yesterday that the registration indicated clearly that the league ticket would be elected with a good majority, and the utmost confidence in success prevailed among all the anti-Tammany leaders yesterday.

The South Reformed Dutch Church, Third Avenue and Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn, began yesterday the celebration of its fiftieth anniversary with appropriate exercises, which were continued through the day and will be resumed to-day. The church was crowded. Flowers banked the pulpit and back of the altar were the floral figures in blue on a ground of white "1840-1890," in the form of an arch.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The celebration of the ninetieth anniversary of the birth of Count von Moltke was continued to-day. At 9 A.M. the Count was serenaded by the Teachers' Choral Society and he received the congratulations of his relatives. At 9:30 he received army officers, officials, and the members of the general staff, who came in a procession.

The Florida Farmers' Alliance men are not quite so unreasonable in respect to their prescription of the qualifications which the next United States Senator from their State must have as are their brethren in Georgia concerning a similar matter. The Florida Grangers do not insist that a person shall be tabooed who will not agree to support the Sub-Treasury bill.

The remarks of Senator SHERMAN from time to time about Trust combinations and the tariff deserve attention not only because of his prominence as a legislator, but also because they fairly represent the insincerity and double-faced policy of his party with respect to Trusts. We have heretofore quoted from official reports of the Senator's speeches his curiously contradictory or evasive utterances upon this topic.

In the report of the General Land Office one of the most striking passages is the acknowledgment of the inefficiency of existing laws to prevent the destruction of the timber on the public lands. It appears that the most valuable public property of this sort is fast disappearing under the two-fold ravages of fire and the depredations of lumbermen.

There will be a good and fast track at Linden this afternoon, and, as the entries are numerous enough to insure good fields of starters, there will be good sport and some sharp finishes. The horses named for the several races, with the weights they will carry, are as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 26. -- The present campaign in Missouri has disclosed a political arrangement that is significant. It resulted from Chauncey I. Filley's successful manipulation of the Republican Party, and its purpose is important.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 26. -- Mobile suffered severely by fire to-day, the buildings consumed being a shingle mill, three cotton compresses, and five cotton warehouses, with 5,630 bales of cotton; the Gulf City Oil Mill, the Mobile Ice factory, three steamboats, eleven loaded and five empty freight cars, two coal and wood yards, a freight station, with a small amount of freight, and six wharves.
The London Engineer of a recent date published the following in a letter from its correspondent in Sheffield:

There is no doubt that the failure of New-York to come up to its great opportunities as the commercial metropolis of the American Continent has been due to the lack of capacity and integrity in the conduct of its public affairs. The Tammany ring rule of twenty years ago and its consequences have been a serious blight upon its progress in all that graces and adorns civic life.
Mr. Wheeler H. Peckham, Chairman of the People's Municipal League, has addressed this open letter to Mayor Grant:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The registration of Buffalo complete is 46,905, which is believed to be 90 per cent. of the voting population. The registration in 1889 under the old law was 54,578, and the vote in 1889 was 41,952.

The last week of the Brooklyn campaign promises to be of great interest, owing mainly to the big meeting that is to be held in the Clermont Avenue Rink on Thursday night, when Carl Schurz will speak on the KcKinley bill in order to aid Mr. Coombs's canvass. This will really be the formal wind-up of the long and strenuous fight made by Mr. Coombs in the Third District.

By the new tariff law a duty of one-fourth of a cent per pound is imposed on sulphuric acid, commonly called oil of vitriol, very large quantities of which are used in the arts and in the manufacture of fertilizers. This acid had been on the free list. We have already pointed out that the proviso concerning the free admission of sulphuric acid of a certain mentioned specific gravity was merely a trick.

Tammany has now but one argument, a single appeal. Mayor GRANT'S letter of acceptance has been riddled, the "claims" upon which he bases his appeal for a reelection have been shown to be spurious, and his defenders and apologists have been driven from one position to another until, battered, beaten, and demoralized, they have taken refuge in their citadel.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Following close upon the failure of E. B. Holmes comes the assignment of another big planing mill firm, Clark Patridge, proprietors of the Queen City Planing Mill, which was executed to James N. Byers as assignee to-day. Clark Patridge did a business aggegating probably $250,000 a year, and employed 130 hands.

There was an election for Trustees of the Rev. Dr. Talmage's Tabernacle in Brooklyn last night that was exciting. There were two tickets in the field, and what lent special interest to the contest was an attempt of the opposition to unseat Treasurer John Wood, who, with State Senator James W. Birkett and William B. Mead, were the regular nominees indorsed by the pastor and their fellow-Trustees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Commissioner Morgan of the Indian Bureau in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior says it has become the settled policy of the Government to break up reservations, destroy tribal relations, settle Indians upon their own homesteads, incorporate them into national life, and deal with them not as nations or tribes or bands, but as individual citizens.

OTTAWA, Ontario., Oct. 27. -- It is estimated the 4,000,000 bushels of Canadian barley was shipped to the United States before the McKinley bill went into force. The barley crop in Canada this year is estimated as being one-third smaller than last year. In 1889, Canada exported 11,000,000 bushels to the United States.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 27. -- At the mass meeting called to-night by the Committee of Fifty appointed by the Mayor, Edgar H. Farrar, Chairman, submitted an address in substance as follows: ...

In that speech at Wilmington, Ohio, Mr. JOHN SHERMAN boasted of the enactment of the so called anti-trust law and said: "Senators from Eastern States, where these combinations mainly exist, shared in the opposition and succeeded in carrying amendments that would have defeated the objects of the bill.

The Executive Committee of the First Voters' Organization is hard a work increasing the membership of the association anal choosing men for duty at the polls. They will form a very valuable section of the 4,000 volunteer workers who will protect the results of the con test for reform on election day. The General Committee met last night at 7:30 o'clock and transacted routine business.
The estimates of the Park Department and the Corporation Counsel's office of moneys required to meet expenses in 1891, were considered yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

The Republican brethren out in Colorado are not dwelling "together in unity," and this is peculiarly true of those particular Republican brethren who are editing the party newspapers. For example, the Denver Times alleges that the "dearest desire and the chiefest aim" of the editor of the Republican is to defeat the re-election of Senator Teller.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 27. -- The usually quiet neighborhood surrounding the village of Monroe, about twelve miles from this city, has been in a state of great excitement yesterday and to-day. Yesterday morning Capt. N.W. Seeley, aged eighty-three years, one of the most respected residents of that locality, was found lying on the barn floor with a rope around his neck.

The big job of printing the official ballots for the coming election is progressing satisfactorily, although it is yet far from being completed. Mr. Kelso, who has charge of the printing of the ballots, said yesterday that, while the multiplicity of ballots was so great that the possibility of mistakes and hitches was increased, no one need have any fear that the printing would not be done satisfactorily, both as to form and time.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 27. -- The Connecticut secret ballot law will be put to a crucial test for the first time at the State election one week from to-morrow. The statute has been tried at two October elections throughout the State and at the municipal elections during the current year, but its operations have not been exemplified when important State interests have depended upon the decision at the polls.

A circular letter was issued from the passenger department of the New-York Central Railroad yesterday announcing an important concession for the benefit of pupils and teachers of New-York schools residing at local stations on the Hudson River Division as far north as Poughkeepsie, and on the Harlem Division as far north as Pawling.

" Hygiene in the Public Schools" was the topic of a special report read by Dr. Henry D. Chapin at the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the County of Now-York last evening. The meeting, which was very largely attended, was held in the new building of the Academy of Medicine, 17 to 21 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- A lengthy decision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission was announced to-day in the case of George Rice against the Southern Pacific Company, the Union Pacific Railway Company, the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company, and others, in reference to rates on petroleum and its products to California points, as affected by the long and short haul clause of the act to regulate commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Ex-President Cleveland to-day made his argument before the Supreme Court as associate counsel for James Wallace Peake in what is known as the New-Orleans drainage case. The public curiosity to see and hear the ex-President appeared to have been whetted by the failure to reach the case last week.

The wind was so raw and cutting yesterday that only about three hundred people visited Washington Park to see the Brooklyns and Louisvilles contest for the world's championship. The Louisvilles won. They did it by hitting Terry with good effect all through the game. Terry was not apparently in good condition, for, besides being touched up in a lively manner, he made two wild pitches.

There is not much brotherly love between the members of the Abyssinian Baptist Church (colored) and the church now known as the Antioch Baptist Church, formed by members who deserted from the first named. The Rev. William Spelman was once at the head of the Abyssinian Church, whose house of worship is at 166 Waverley Place. In 1885 he left, being, his opponents say, deposed much against his will.

The arrangements for Mr. Carl Schurz's reception in Brooklyn on Thursday night were changed yesterday and the meeting at the Rink was abandoned. Mr. Schurz will address a meeting of Germans in the Warner Institute on that evening, repeating in German a portion of his recent Boston speech. That will be the only big meeting of the week.

Senator HAWLEY'S paper, the Hartford Courant, is annoyed by what it calls the "false statements" about the new tariff that are published "by the free-trade newspapers." It takes to task one of its neighbors, the Hartford Times, for having said that the duty on linseed oil under the old law was 7 cents a gallon, while in fact it was 25 cents.

DETROIT, Oct. 27. -- A.M. Henry, assignee of R.G. Peters, the Manistee lumberman who failed a fortnight ago, has filed his schedules. The liabilities of the Peters Salt and Lumber- Company are shown to be $584,377 as firm liabilities and $1,455,285 as Peters's personal debts, making a total of $2,039,662. Preters's assets as listed show $3,630,016, of which $1,700,000 is in stock of the Peters Salt and Lumber Company, the value of which is problematical.

At the meeting of the Board of Managers of St. Luke's Hospital, held at the hospital last evening, the following general officers of the board were elected for the year: President -- George Macculloch Miller; First Vice President -- Percy R. Pyne; Second Vice President -- Henry A. Oakley; Treasurer -- Gordon Norrie, and Secretary -- Benoni Lockwood.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- Ex-Gov. Robert E. Pattison, Democratic candidate for Governor, who is being supported by great numbers of independent Republicans, this morning swore out warrants charging James Elverson, President of the Inquirer Company; Charles H. Huestis, editor of the Inquirer; Clayton McMichael, editor and proprietor of the North American, and W.F. Jorean and J.J. McClaurin of the Harrisburg Call with criminal libel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- A decided falling off in the volume of east-bound shipments is shown in the statement for last week. By all roads leading eastward from Chicago the combined through and local traffic aggregated 68,057 tons, against 67,363 for the preceding week, an increase of 694 tons, and against 71,066 for the same period last year, a decrease of 3,009 tons.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The Passaic County Grand Jury came into court this afternoon with forty-one indictments, and retired to continue their business. It was rumored that bills were found against the Clifton race track and the bookmakers on the races there. The most extraordinary reports have been in circulation to-day regarding the prodigious efforts made by the race-track people to procure a reconsideration of the vote by which the indictments were found.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 27. -- The Republicans in this State are in desperate straits, and are turning to James G. Blaine to help them out. After a great deal of persuasion Mr. Blaine was induced to promise to make a speech at Philadelphia next Saturday evening.

The following election returns since 1874 show that, when the anti-Tammany forces are united as they are this year, they have a majority over the largest possible Tammany vote. The last Mayor ever elected as a Tammany candidate, with a majority over all opponents, was William H. Wickham, who ran in 1874, against Wales, Republican, and Ottendorfer, Independent.
EDINBURGH, Oct. 27. -- A. meeting of Liberals was held here to-day, at which Mr. Gladstone delivered an address.

The interruption to passenger and other traffic in Chambers Street is a serious disturbance to travel and business. With a feeling that this should be removed as far as possible and conviction that it may be remedied to a great extent, I beg to offer the following:

A good track, a big crowd of people, good, smart racing, and an overturning of several of the favorites were the features of the racing at the Linden track yesterday. Badge and the Trellis colt were the only two favorites to win the money for their backers, and the latter was only an even favorite with Mr. Sass in the big field of twenty horses that ran in the five-and-a-half-furlong scramble.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The special committee appointed to consider the recommendations of the American delegates to the International Marine Conference gave a hearing at the Treasury Department to-day.

William H. Crane and his company will begin rehearsals of "On Probation" at the Star Theatre to-day. Louis Massen, formerly a member of A.M. Palmer's Madison Square Theatre Company, has been specially engaged to play the leading juvenile part. The play will be presented at a special matinee, the date of which has not yet been absolutely fixed, but which will be about the middle of next month.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- In its leading editorial to-morrow the Times will say:

" Reckless Temple," the play written by Augustus Thomas to suit the personal peculiarities of Maurice Barrymore, and to serve as a medium for the exhibition of his artistic skill, was produced at the Standard Theatre last evening in presence of an audience predisposed in favor of the piece, and evidently determined that Mr. Barrymore, who is a deservedly popular man, should have a triumph.

It is not very clear what the Count of PARIS intends to accomplish by his royal progress among his lieges of Lower Canada. To be the object of homage is in itself gratifying to the human mind, and the Count of PARIS is perhaps especially in need of a balm for his self-complacency, which has been much ruffled by the manner in which the disclosures of his support of BOULANGER have been received.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Alderman John McLennan, a stanch Republican and a well-known lawyer, was arrested this afternoon, taken before Justice Mulholland, and held for examination to-morrow on a charge of taking a bribe. The arrest has caused intense feeling, more so on account of the complaint being made by Mayor William Cowie, a Republican, but of the Hiscock stripe.

Evidences of the indecent haste and blundering inaccuracy with which the Republican Protective Tariff bill was pushed through the Senate and House of Representatives continue to accumulate. In one of the ten divisions of the Appraiser's department it has been discovered that several articles which formerly figured extensively in the statistics of importations from foreign countries have been left entirely out of the schedules in the new law.

The family of Charles A. Vanbokkelen, who died in 1885 from the effects of imprisonment at Port an Prince, Hayti, have received a first payment of $10,000 on account of an award for $60,000 to which the Government of Hayti has acknowledged its liability. Remaining payments will be made semi-annually by bonds duly authorized for that purpose.

One of the questions asked of Postmasters removed by Wanamaker and Clarkson in the course of the first year of the Harrison Administration by the committee of the National Civil Service Reform League investigating the subject was whether any cause was given for the removal. In only 47 out of 356 cases reported was any cause assigned for the removal.

It was the heavy-laden JOB who was prodded to express the desire that his adversary had written a book. We are not aware that Mr. WARD MCALLISTER is anybody's enemy, though no doubt those low-born churls whose daughters he felt himself compelled by conscience to exclude from the Family Circle Dancing Class are his enemies.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28. -- "The two most important issues in this campaign," said Chairman J.T. Ellison of the Democratic State Committee to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-night, "have been, I think, the force bill and Langston. The tariff has, of course, played an important part, but the most active and effective issues are probably the two named."

Beautiful Linden Park was crowded yesterday to see another fine day's sport over the track which is as popular as any in the country. The usual six races were on for decision and they furnished high-class sport and good, sharp betting, as the fields were so large and so evenly matched that several horses in each race were heavily backed.

Thomas H. Smith, nominated by the County Democrats for Civil Justice in the Third Judicial District, yesterday wrote a letter to Edwin L. Abbott. Chairman of the County Democracy Convention, at which he was nominated, declining the nomination on the ground that if he ran it would only help to swell the Republican majority, while he desired to see a Democrat elected.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Dr. Joel G. Justin of Syracuse, the inventor of a shell for throwing dynamite from a common piece of ordnance, is not to have all the honors for himself in that line. The hillsides of Geddes that rise above a deep ravine in the old Wadsworth Farm spoke loudly yesterday afternoon of further success in the throwing of dynamite projectiles.

HARTFORD, Oct. 28. -- The Republicans will not be destitute of money for the final days of the campaign, if the plans which have been inaugurated for the collection of assessments or contributions by the State Central Committee are carried out. For two weeks money has been the chief thing required for advancing the interests of the State ticket.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Business on the Stock Exchange to-day was quiet and prices generally were lower. West Chicago Street Railroad opened at 127 34 regular and closed at 127 34, buyer 30, with intervening sales at from 127 34 to 127 regular.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Neither of the races down for decision at Point Breeze Park to-day was finished, five heats being had in each without a decision. The races will be finished to-morrow. The summaries:

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The whereabouts of W.S. Whorton, who has been engaged in the money-lending business in this city for several years, is troubling a number of citizens, and particularly the Chicago Trust and Savings Bank and the United States Loan Company. For over a week Whorton has not been seen, and his wife and creditors have finally concluded that he has left the city.
The estimated expenses of the Street-Cleaning Department, the County Clerk's office, and the Register's office for the year 1891 were passed upon yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The big steel cruiser Newark, the latest vessel of the new navy, built by the Cramps of this city, will start down the Delaware River on her initial trip to-morrow morning. At present she is lying alongside of the south wharf of Cramp's ship yard with coal and provisions on board sufficient for a cruise of a week's duration and furnaces lighted under the huge boilers in the fireroom.
