In the case of the application for a mandamus to compel the Police Commissioners to have two ballots printed containing the names of the independent candidates for Assemblyman and Alderman in the Nineteenth Assembly District, in order that they may have the advantage of being upon the ticket of both parties, Judge INGRAHAM is reported as expressing himself in a manner to indicate that he did not consider that to be their right.

If there was any doubt as to which way the great body of the German vote is going in the pending municipal election that doubt was settled at Cooper Union last night. Such a demonstration of the German citizens of New-York has not been seen in many years. It testified powerfully to the deep hold which the issues involved in this city election have taken upon their minds.

An unusually brilliant wedding yesterday was that of Miss Frank Vanderbilt Crawford and J. Frederick Talcott, a recent graduate of Princeton University. Miss Crawford is the daughter of Robert L. Crawford, and the niece, by marriage, of Commodore Vanderbilt, the last wife of the latter being Mr. Crawford's sister, the namesake of the bride of yesterday.

APALACHICOLA, Fla., Oct. 27, via Chattahoochee, Fla. -- Yesterday forenoon fire was communicated to the Kennedy Mill from the slab pit. In a few moments all was a sheet of flame. While the Kennedy Mill was roaring and cracking, the old icehouse, four blocks away, caught fire, then the Kimball Warehouses, the wharf, the lumber in the mill yard, and finally the Kimball Mill.

Tammany Hall in its essence is a political trust, administered in secret, sometimes by a single man and at other times by a small clique of men, for the purpose of securing the spoils of office for themselves and their followers. In this country of universal suffrage there is no safety in secret political societies against which Washington in his farewell political address uttered an impressive warning.

LONG BRANCH, Oct. 28. -- The political situation in the Third Congressional District was never more interesting than it is now. The element of doubt, which has rarely entered so largely into the contest there, increases daily, and the factional differences in both of the great political parties are surely gaining in strength and importance as election day approaches.

A prominent lady of New-York City, who was entertaining some friends at her home recently, became considerably aroused at the remarks of a gentleman, who spoke of women as the "weaker sex." Straightening herself up, she said:...

Quoting Mr. Cleveland's reply to the newspaper man who asked him if the report was true that he had suddenly died, the Kansas City Times says, by way of comment: "Mr. Cleveland has reason to feel better at this time than ever he did in his life. The cause of tariff reform, of which he is the most conspicuous representative, appears morally certain of fresh conquests throughout the country.

The Democratic managers in Brooklyn were inclined to be excited yesterday at the account in yesterday's TIMES of how David A. Boody and the tariff-reform question were being neglected in the Second Congressional District. At headquarters it was given out that a "still hunt" was being made for Mr. Boody. These "still hunts" have not brought down much game in other parts of the country, and some of Mr. Boody's friends want something more satisfactory.

It was to the Liquor Dealers' Association that DE LANCEY NICOLL, Tammany's candidate for District Attorney, pledged himself not to press excise cases, promising to leave all such matters in the hands of the liquor dealers' good friend BEDFORD. The association promptly and enthusiastically ratified the nomination of Mr. NICOLL.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The advocates of an extra session of Congress have been keeping rather quiet lately, but they have now brought out a new argument. This is to the effect that an extra session is necessary this year to prevent an extra session of the Fifty-second Congress next Spring.
DUBLIN, Oct. 28. -- Mr. Balfour, who arrived at the Island of Achill yesterday, passed the night at the residence of the parish priest.

Louisville's ball team won another game from the Brooklyns yesterday, and the series has ended in a "tie," each club having won three games. It was decided yesterday to postpone the two remaining games to the Spring, when the contest is to be decided. This was done on account of the disagreeable state of the weather for ball playing.
Mr. SCOTT made a very direct and pointed answer in his speech to the Lincoln Republican Club on Monday evening to the Tammany charge that he has been an office holder for many years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Ever since the passage of the act of Congress Oct. 1, providing for a system of examinations to determine the fitness for promotion of all officers of the army below the grade of Major, there has been great anxiety among all the officers to know what scope the examination would have and the rules that would be prescribed by the President for conducting them.

HOOPESTON, Ill., Oct. 28. -- Two years ago Joseph Cannon carried this town and township over his Democratic opponent for Congress by 169 plurality. His friends say he will beat J.S. Busey next week by 50 plurality, and Busey's friends say they will wipe that out.

Secretary Tracy is showing a very generous spirit to officers who are hesitating between resigning from the navy or continuing in the service. Many of the bright officers of the navy are constantly having tempting offers to resign and take remunerative positions in civil life. Not a few progressive business men of the country recognize that the training of a navy officer fits him for handling men in civil as well a military life.

What is Democracy, true, straight out, pure, and undefiled? Is it the Tammany brand of the article? Is "DICK" CROCKER, partially-reformed tough and impenitent bribe taker, the type of what a Democrat should be to be reckoned "pure"?

The letter of Secretary Noble to Mayor Grant, denying the application for a recount of the population of the city of New-York, reached the Mayor's office yesterday. While the Mayor was busy with the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a type-written statement of his opinion of the letter was prepared and given to the press.
Every voter of this city who votes for Hugh J. Grant for Mayor votes against the Force bill and protests against its passage.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 28. -- "How many men do you employ?"

Superintendent of Public Instruction John Jasper was questioned yesterday afternoon by a TIMES reporter about the report of Dr. H.D. Chapin to the New-York County Medical Society on the sanitary condition of many of the public schools Mr. Jasper said the buildings referred to were mostly in the lower part of the city and had been standing from thirty to sixty years.

The petition of crockery and glassware importers of this city and Philadelphia asking the trunk lines to make a reduction in west-bound freight rates for that class of goods has not been considered favorably by the official Classification Committee. The members of that committee believe that the present rates on crockery and glassware are low enough, and they are not disposed to change the figures.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- The State Convention of the Prohibition Party met in Masonic Hall in this city this morning, T.W. Burger of Union County, Chairman of the State Executive Committee, presiding. Nearly one hundred delegates were present. The principal feature of the morning session was an address on the ballot-reform law by the Rev. Dr. Graw, editor of the Temperance Gazette.

A ratification meeting that culminated in a debauch was held last evening by the constituents of Tammany Hall in the Fourteenth Assembly District. It was as unique a circus, as disgraceful an orgie, as one could have witnessed in an old-time Five Points dance hall, yet its avowed object was to ratify and strengthen Tammany Hall's municipal ticket among the voters of the Fourteenth District.

Commissioner BEATTIE of the Street-Cleaning Department wants something over a million and a half of dollars for the ostensible purpose of cleaning the streets of this city next year. The Board of Estimate and Apportionment is not at present disposed to be quite so liberal as he desires, though it is ready to make a very liberal allowance for street cleaning.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- As a result of the examinations which have just been held, the following members of the Freshman Class are in the first division in both mathematics and classics:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Mr. E.O. Leech, the Director of the Mint, makes the following statement in regard to the Treasury purchases of silver bullion and the causes of the recent decline in the market price of silver:

MONTREAL, Oct. 28. -- Last May, when the Longue Point Insane Asylum was burned, it was believed that over 100 people were burned in it. Many patients escaped, but it was supposed they had all been recaptured. Among those in the asylum, but missing, was the wife of Amadee Gauthier, a farmer of St. Laurent. It was thought she had been burned.

Gen. BUTLER, on his way to inspect his mining property in the West, tells the people of St. Louis that he is "a protectionist from head to heel." We understand that the old politician never looks at that paragraph in the tariff law which relates to bunting without feeling that if he should not adhere to the principles of protection he would be an ingrate.

The Sun could have done the people's cause no better service than it rendered yesterday in publishing figures showing the amount of the tax bills of Mr. SCOTT'S father and of prominent members and workers of the Municipal League under Mayors GRACE, HEWITT, and GRANT. The gentlemen chosen for the Sun's purpose, besides Mr. SCOTT'S father, were ex-Mayor GRACE, Mr. PECKHAM, and Dr. HOWARD CROSBY.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 28. -- More than ordinary interest has been aroused throughout Canada in anticipation of the Dominion Government's motion with regard to the separate school question and the abolition of the French language as an official language in the courts and Assembly of Manitoba Province. Both were the subject of Province legislation last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The racing at Benning's was continued to-day, the favorites turning the tables on the outsiders for change. The only rank outsider to win was Iceberg at 20 to 1, but he was backed by the local bettors because he has a habit of winning here at about these odds at every meeting. The steeplechase for gentlemen jockeys was the most ridiculous sort of a farce.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 28. -- The Red Cross Line steamer Portia arrived this morning with flags flying at half mast. Capt. Ash reports that he left New-York Saturday at 2 P.M., and outside encountered heavy seas, the effect of the recent gale on the coast. They had good weather Sunday, and yesterday morning was fine and calm. Several of the crew were engaged in washing decks, among whom was Mark Day.

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- Two eminently respectable, highly-cultivated, and pre-eminently erudite carpetbaggers are making a spirited contest for the representation of the Sixth Massachusetts District in the Fifty-second Congress.

John Bulger, an engineer in the Fire Department, attached to the fireboat Havemeyer, but temporarily attached to Engine Company No. 29, in Fulton Street, died at Chambers Street Hospital yesterday afternoon. Monday evening, in responding to an alarm from Maiden Lane, Bulger rode on the tool box of the tender of the engine.

The Fassett committee has abandoned the investigation of the affairs of the Police Department, as a department, until after the approaching election. This was done in deference to the wish of the Police Commissioners, and meets with the approval of Mr. Ivins, who stated that to burden the department with an investigation at this time would seriously interfere with the manifold duties imposed on the Police Department by the new ballot law.
The following is an extract from a letter received by a lady of Plainfield, N.J., from her friend Mme. Louise Kossuth Ruttkay, Kossuth's sister:

A sale of silks to which the dry goods trade has looked forward for a long time with deep interest was held yesterday in the auction rooms of Field, Chapman Fenner, in Broadway. It was the largest silk sale ever held in the country, and it was full of significance. Not for many years have American manufacturers been risking the chances of a public vendue of large quantities of their product.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Mr. Gladstone arrived at Dundec to-day and was presented with the freedom of the city. In accepting the honor Mr. Gladstone made an address, in which he referred to the commerce of the city, which, it was said, was threatened by the adoption of the new Tariff bill by the American Congress.

The representatives of New-York's shipping and commercial interest who went to Washington on Saturday last with the object of presenting their views upon the establishment of a Marine Board, or Department of Commerce, to the commission appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to take evidence upon this subject, have returned to New-York after spending two pleasant days in the capital.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 29. -- General Master Workman Powderly announces in an evening paper that he will vote for Robert E. Pattison, the Democratic candidate for Governor, because of that gentleman's emphatic declarations in behalf of a Constitutional Convention for the speedy realization of ballot reform.

We despair of seeing the Republican tariff orators "get together" on the question whether "cheapness" is or is not a good thing. President HARRISON has never recanted his expressed opinion that you generally find a cheap man inside of a cheap coat. Congressman LODGE ardently champions this view, declaring in his speech at Medford last week that cheapness made "cheap men and women."

In the drawing room of Mr. James Wilson's residence, at 272 Madison Avenue, a 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Miss Lily Wilson, his daughter, became the Countess Lewenhaupt. The groom was Count Claes Lewenhaupt, a First Lieutenant of Hussars in the King of Sweden's bodyguard, and the eldest son and heir of Count Adam Lewenhaupt of Sjoholm. The Rev. Roderick Terry of the South Reformed Dutch Church of this city conducted the services.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Harvard made a score of 51 points to-day against the Wesleyan football eleven in less than the full time. The ground was soft and slippery, and a cold rain began to fall about the middle of the game. These drawbacks, together with the decisions of the umpire and referee, which were uniformly against Harvard, formed a serious handicap for large scoring.

STONINGTON, Conn., Oct. 29. -- The new edifice of the First Baptist Church of Stonington, over which body the venerable Dr. A.G. Palmer presides, was dedicated to divine worship to-day by services which were attended by a number of distinguished clergymen and a large gathering of people, despite the storm.

An instructive paper on the subject of "Electric Welding Applied to the Manufacture of Projectiles" was read by Lieut W.M. Wood, United States Navy, before the Society of Arts, Institute of Technology, Boston, on the evening of Oct. 23. In the course of his lecture Lieut. Wood described the present process in the construction of projectiles, and endeavored to show how much is gained by the electric welding process.
" To assert that the poor man has to pay more for carpets because of the increased duty is incorrect," said the Philadelphia Press of Thursday last.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- At 3 o'clock this afternoon Magistrate O'Brien's office was crowded by politicians and others to witness the proceedings in the criminal libel suit instituted by ex-Gov. Pattison, Democratic candidate, against Clayton McMichael, the editor and publisher of the North American, and James S. Elverson, publisher of the Philadelphia Inquirer, for the publication of an article entitled, "Turning on the Light."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- Miss Julia Marlowe's physicians stated to-day, what they had feared before, that she was suffering from typhoid fever. The disease was doubtless contracted during her tour in the West, and has developed itself slowly since her arrival here. Her illness will necessarily be long and tedious, and all her dates for this season nave been canceled and the company will disband.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Miss Mary Butterworth, daughter of Representative Butterworth of Ohio, was to-day married to Mr. Haughwait Howe of the State Department.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The registration under the new law has effected a surprising result in the local lists of voters, and the Democrats are hopeful of cutting down to a great extent the big majorities which for years have operated to make Plainfield nominally a Republican stronghold.

British agents in the United States and Canada are reported to be negotiating for an immediate supply of nickel ore for the use of the British Navy. This is a direct outcome of the recent Annapolis test, and information comes that the British Admiralty proposes to strip as rapidly as possible all war ships now in English ports having compound armor.

The biggest mouth in New-York can be seen occasionally in Central Park. When in repose it is not a sightly object, but when it is opened to it widest extent the spectacle is enough to make a person shudder. Caliph, the big hippopotamus, is the owner of this mouth. At present he is in retirement owing to the interesting event which occurred in his family a short time ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- If there is any one Democrat in Congress the Republicans are anxious to defeat next week it is Representative William L. Wilson of the Second West Virginia District. His record in the House of Representatives is one that his party is justly proud of and of course it is particularly distasteful to the Republicans.

The rules of intercollegiate football are the same this year as they were last, with a few exceptions. In relation to a fair catch, the provision has been made that if the catcher, after making his mark, be deliberately thrown to the ground by an opponent, he shall be given five yards unless this carries the ball across the goal line.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 29. -- Judge Gresham of the Federal court to-day decided the suit of Walker Olters of Terre Haute charging infringement of patent in the use of the Bragg fire alarm device. The invention consists of a gong and a contrivance that unfastens the halters of the horses and drops the harness upon them by electricity when an alarm is sounded.

ONEONTA, Oct. 29. -- The Twenty-fourth Congressional District this Fall is considered debatable ground. It was the home of Congressman David Wilber, and he never had any trouble to carry it for the Republicans. If the party was weak at this end of the line Warner Miller could be relied upon from the Herkimer side to swell the Republican majority sufficiently to hold the district firm.

The Commonwealth Party of the city of NewYork has issued an open letter to Tammany Hall. After stating that its principles are those of the true Jeffersonian Democracy, the Commonwealth Party challenges Tammany to a joint discussion of the following questions:

The first movement since the campaign opened against the lawless ring that holds Jersey City in its grasp was made yesterday, and the accused ringster will have to answer to a United States Grand Jury in Trenton, instead of a Grand Jury at the Court House on Jersey City Heights.

If Tammany wins, the next Governor of this State will be a Tammany man or a Republican. Drunk with triumph and arrogance, Tammany will stride into the convention with a whip in one hand and a knife in the other. If it cannot rule with the whip, it will ruin with the knife. If Tammany's candidate is not made the convention's candidate, it will bolt and elect a Republican, as it did in 1879.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 29. -- Thomas A. Edison is the latest American who has turned his attention to the Sudbury nickel district. Officials of the Canadian Geological Survey state that the inventor will soon begin to develop mining properties adjacent to the mines owned by the Standard Oil Company. Mr. Samuel G. Burn, the expert sent out by Mr. Edison, was here a few days ago.

Mr. SCOTT is making a magnificent canvass. His short and pithy speeches are winning votes for him and for the people's cause wherever they are heard or read. He is thoroughly acquainted with city affairs, he knows Tammany from centre to circumference, with all its crookedness, and he treats the topics of his speeches with clearness, force, and ability.

It is really a pity that electricity cannot purify that variety of sewage known as practical politics. On plain, ordinary filth it has been shown to accomplish remarkable effects, but it must be admitted that in the extreme case just mentioned it is well nigh powerless. Were it otherwise there would be, around the nether pole of society, a dense deposit of ex-officials a few days hence.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 29. -- There will be no general federation of locomotive engineers with brakemen, firemen, conductors, and other railway employes. As stated last week, a majority report favoring federation, presented at the Brotherhood Convention in this city, was defeated. Since that vote was taken the convention has spent considerable time discussing the question, and has finally decided not to federate with any other organization.

At their meeting yesterday the Aqueduct Commissioners authorized the Controller to pay O'Brien Clark, the contractors, $10,248.29 for work done on Shaft 24 of the new Aqueduct. The estimate of the firm was $12,194.16, but the repairs found necessary cost the board $1,945.87, and this was deducted from the amount.

Progressive action was taken by the stockholders of the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railroad yesterday at the company's office, 47 Broadway. Of the 50,000 shares of stock 30,946 shares were represented, and by a unanimous vote the Directors were authorized to build two important extensions of the road and to establish additional terminal facilities in Indianapolis.

The attention of the musical world in general, and of New-York in particular, will be drawn in a few days to a case which will be called for trial in the Court of Common Pleas in this city. The suit is that of Miss Maud Powell, the violinist, against Victor S. Flechter, who pretends to be a dealer in old violins, and who does business at 23 Union Square.

Tammany is counting upon deriving great advantages from the use of paster ballots. It expects all its illiterate and its stupid followers to use these as a means of making sure that they vote the Tammany ticket, and it may be that it expects its inspectors to know whether they have done so or not by the thickness of the ballot voted.

The remarkable statement of a Republican office holder about the census of this city, printed in another column, would be deemed still more remarkable if we were at liberty to give the office holder's name. That Mayor GRANT has bungled the city's case is not only antecedently probable, but was shown by Secretary NOBLE'S opinion, which showed nothing else.

Urbach's Morrisania Hall, at One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Third Avenue, was hardly big enough to contain the citizens of the annexed district who gathered there last night to welcome the People's candidate for Mayor. Rockets scraped the sky, Roman candles pierced holes in the clouds, and red and blue lights gave a kaleidoscopic aspect to the landscape. A brass band blew out music of all kinds.

The estimates of the Board of Education and of the Fire Department of moneys required to meet expenses for the ensuing year were considered yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. The Board of Education asked for $4,561,444. Of this sum $3,098,000 was for the salaries of employes of primary and grammar day schools, as against $3,000,000 granted last year.
So it is Senator ARTHUR P. GORMAN, is it, who says that
Tammany grasps the hand of the Country Democrat with the cordiality of deeply interested affection.

The Fassett Committee began to probe into the affairs of the Fire Department yesterday and devoted the entire morning and afternoon sessions to that task. Two of the Commissioners were examined -- President Henry D. Purroy and Anthony Eickhoff. Mr. Eickhoff's testimony showed him to be comparatively ignorant of the workings of his department. Mr. Purroy on the contrary, was a most pugnacious witness.

The two horses procured by the County Commissioners for the Towson Fire Department have been named Tom and Bob, out of compliment to Commissioners Thomas Todd and Robert Magruder. One of the horses belonged for years to an engine company at Highland-town. He takes his beer with the relish of a regular, and holds the glass between his lips while sipping the fluid.
Elections will be held in thirty-nine States on Tuesday, Nov. 4, as follows:

Although Mr. Blaine's speech is only an oft- repeated chestnut as to the great things a protective tariff has done for the country, yet when these chestnuts are served up as a new dish by so eminent a statesman and leader of a great party he deserves an answer.

The close of the racing season of 1890 was commemorated in an enjoyable way by a rltner given by Pierre Lorillard last evening, at the Union Club. A genial company of influential turfmen surrounded Mr. Lorillard's hospitable board and there w ere unbounded good fellow- ship and mutual congratulations upon the suoi oess of the last season.

Sturdy work for the cause of municipal reform was done in this city last night. No less than fifteen rousing meetings sent up their enthusiastic voices in favor of the ticket headed by Francis M. Scott. Could a single individual have looked in upon each one of these meetings he would have gone home with a rock-bound faith in the success of the anti-Tammany forces.

William H. Haworth, contract agent for the Ocean Steamship Company of this city, has invented an "order-pad calendar," which has been welcomed very warmly by consignors and consignees of freight. The consignee having one of these calendars details to the consignor and when he wants his goods shipped and retains a stub, still attached to the calendar, showing a full record of the transaction. Transportation men find the device a great help.

The fog of dullness that has hung over the Brooklyn campaign so far was brushed aside temporarily yesterday by a breeze that carried with it the news that Col. "Harry" W. Beard, the ponderous Republican leader in the Twentieth Ward, had decided to vote for John Courtney for Sheriff. It was also said that he had bolted from Wallace in the Congressional fight, but this he denied.

An article appearing in THE TIMES of Oct. 29 entitled "In Answer to Dr. Chapin" contains several statement intended to explain and palliate the bad hygienic condition of a number of the primary schools that were recently the subject of a report to the New-York County Medical Society. The Superintendent of Buildings is here reported to have stated that improvements in No. 20 cannot be obtained unless the atmosphere in the vicinity is changed.

READING, Penn., Oct. 30. -- The pronounced intention of the Reading Railroad Company to compelits employes to vote the Republican ticket and its deal with Senator Quay and his agents to force the defeat of Pattison are received with the greatest indignation all over Eastern Pennsylvania. To-day four of the foremen of the company's shops in this city were arrested for intimidating voters. The warrants were sworn out late last night.

The Bergen Reformed Church, Jersey City, was the scene of a brilliant wedding last evening. Arthur Brigham, son of the late Congressman Brigham, led to the altar Miss Ella Woodhull Brown, daughter of Capt. Joel W. Brown. The church was tastefully decorated with palms and potted plants. The Rev. Cornelius Brett, pastor of he church, performed the ceremony.
" Did it ever occur to you, my friend, what a cumbersome piece of machinery the military legal code is? The civil code has been continually simplified, but the military never."

BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- Private advices awaken new hopes that the crew of the Boston ship Magellan, which was wrecked on the night of Aug. 6 by collision wJtll the new Bath snip St. Mary, off Cape Horn, may have been saved. The ship James Drummond, Capt. Curtis, which arrived at San Francisco Oct. 5 from Philadelphia, furnishes the following report:

OSKALOOSA, Iowa, Oct. 30. -- The eampalgn is at fever heat in the Sixth Iowa District. Mayor Lacey, the Republican cmadidate, anticipated an easy victory, as there wore four candidates in the field. It now looks as if Mr. Engle, the Union Labor candidate, was practically out of the race and it was a contest between Farmer White, Democrat, and Lacey. Two years ago Lacey had 800 majority.

While Mr. JOHN CONNELLY, Assemblyman for the Nineteenth District and the Tammany candidate for re-election, has made a very fair record at Albany during the last three sessions, the County Democracy has put up a candidate who is specially qualified to represent that district in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A well-known Republican leader not now in office, but prominently connected with the Congressional Campaign Committee, has received from the Hon. Theodore Roosevelt, Civil Service Commissioner, a contribution of $50 to be used for legitimate campaign expenses in any Congressional district where it is needed. Ex-Gov. Hugh Thompson, also a member of the commission, has sent in a contribution in aid of the Democratic cause. In conversation to-day Mr. Roosevelt said:

The Gem Piano and Organ Company of Washington, N. J., has made an assignment to Judge Morrow of Relvidere for the benefit of its creditors. The liabilities are from $20,000 to $25.000, with estimated assets of from $/S),000 t $115,000. The principal creditors are the 1Veedham Piano and Organ Company, the first National Bank of Washington and Senator Wyckoff.

The Columbia College football eleven won its first victory of the season yesterday at Brotherhood Park in a one-sided contest with St. John's College. Few spectators were present owing to the unfavorable condition of the grounds and temperature.

The Tammany organ still insists that taxes are not higher under Mayor GRANT'S low tax rate. Let us use the Sun's own illustrative cases of three wealthy gentlemen whose property Tammany did not venture to assess at an increased valuation, compared with three cases in the Seventh Ward, where the homes of the poor abound.

As a result of the obscurity and uncertainty of the tariff law in its relation to knitted wool underwear and hosiery, all the entries of imports of that character since Oct. 6 remain in the Collector's office unliquidated. The Appraiser and the Naval Officer have differed in their respective constructions and application of the law, and the Collector finds himself, or has thus far found himself, unable to decide between them.

Chief Supervisor of Elections John I. Davenport has begun the systematic work of running down the irregular and false registrations, and he says, with the complaints thus far secured, that the number of irregularities will run far ahead of anything he ever saw in this city. The colonization is unusually heavy, and the crowded districts show remarkable evidences of registration in duplicate and of fictitious names.

Yesterday the Board of Estimate and Apportionment nearly completed the work of making the provisional estimates for the various city departments for 1891. So far it has granted $34,715,595.27. After deducting $2,500,000, the amount estimated for the general fund, the total will be about $32,215,595.27. Minus the general fund, the sum appropriated in 1889 was $30,580,624.61.

The affairs of the Sugar Trust occupied the attention of Judge Pratt for nearly five hours in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. It was the date set down for the argument on Duncan Cameron's motion for receiver, and promptly at 10 o'clock half a dozen eminent lawyers filed into court. John E. Parsons, Elihu Root, and Edward M. Shepard represented the trust and were accompanied by Theodore and Henry A. Havemeyer and Treasurer Searles.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 30. -- Ex-Gov. Warmoth, Republican candidate for Congress in the First District, delivered his first campaign speech to a New-Orleans audience to-night. Washington Artillery Hall was completely filled, about one-third of the audience being white men.

The pretense of Tammany that taxes have been reduced under the administration of Mayor Grant would be too absurd to be worth notice were it not for a studied and ingenious attempt on the part of the Tammany managers, through their newspaper mouthpiece, to make it appear that taxpayers have been really benefited by the present municipal administration.
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The Times will print in to-morrow (Friday) morning's paper the following interview with Mr. H.M. Stanley:

" That's what all smokers are coming to," said a passenger on a Broadway car recently, pointing to a well-dressed gentleman on the front platform who smoked a pipe. "Can't afford cigars now," he added, "tariff put 'em up too high."

A German trade paper that represents the manufacturers of woolen goods assorts that the German Ministry of Commerce has "warned" these manufacturers against the "espionage" of American Consuls, who have recently sought, when legalizing invoices, to obtain information regarding the cost of making the goods under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Haughwait Howe, who was yesterday married to Miss Mary Butterworth, daughter of Representative Butterworth of Ohio, died to-day of pneumonia. After the marriage ceremony yesterday Mr. Howe appeared to be greatly relieved in mind and to suffer less pain than for some time previously. Toward evening, however, he grew rapidly worse. Throughout the night he was delirious and struggle succeeded struggle.

The Director of the Mint, Mr. E.O. LEECH, is undoubtedly right in his defense of the Treasury dealings with silver. There has been no evidence whatever of any favoritism shown by Treasury officials with reference to the purchases of silver, and yet it will be impossible to convince interested persons that there is no ground for suspicion.

Next to honest and capable administration, the most pressing need of this city is rapid transit. In his speech to the people of the annexed district on Wednesday evening Mr. SCOTT candidly and accurately described the legislative dead-lock on this subject last Winter:

President PURROY of the Fire Department made some interesting admissions before the Senate investigating committee yesterday. He claimed to have instituted many reforms in the Fire Department after he had been expelled from the Tammany organization, as it was much easier for one who is outside of the organization to do reform work than one who is inside.

The Hon. Carl Schurz delivered a campaign address to an audience of German workingmen and tradesmen last night at Warner Institute in Brooklyn. The meeting was held under the auspices of the German Democratic Club and was a great success. The popularity of the great orator was attested by an attendance which was never equaled in that hall and by an outburst of welcoming cheers that fairly made the windows rattle.

The Republicans are united and active in support of Mr. SCOTT and the People's ticket. "The Republicans understand that the fight is against Tammany," says Mr. PATTERSON, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee, and there is no love lost between Tammany and the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- To-day's races at Benning's closed with a six-furlong heat that was full of excitement. Bookmaker J.J. Carroll was assaulted by a man who claimed to have been insulted by him. Several others who shared the offense tried to get at Carroll, and the combined efforts of the police alone saved him.
The Dallas (Texas) News of Oct. 26 prints the following letter from ex-President Cleveland, declining the invitation to attend the Texas State Fair:

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The German steamer Russia, Capt. Schmidt, from Hamburg to New-York, returned to Falmouth to-day, having in tow the Ger man steamer Albingia, from Hamburg for West Indian ports. The latter's shaft is broken.

The plague of the high tariff is its uncertainty. On July 30, by the Nerada, there arrived in New-York certain goods of rubber and wool. The Collector classified and assessed them as dutiable, a part at 45 cents a pound and 10 per cent. ad valorem, and a part at 40 cents per pound and 35 per cent. ad valorem.

The singular habits of the buzz saw are but imperfectly comprehended in the editorial rooms of the New-York Sun. For two days the little wanton boys of our contemporary have been toying with this great instrument of division and severance. Their shouts of glee were heard in Printing House Square.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Oscar Gallnski of New-York committed suicide at Green's Hotel, this city to-night, by blowing out his brains. About 8 o'clock employes of the hotel detected the odor of escaping gas, which was traced to the room occupied by Galinski. After knocking on the door and receiving no response the special officer forced an entrance and opened the window.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- M. Roche, Minister of Commerce, explained the new Tariff bill to the Tariff Committee to-day. The object of the maximum and minimum system, he said, was to avoid inconveniences connected with the most favored nation clause in any treaty with a foreign power. The Government might make a bad bargain in granting benefits in such a clause to a nation yielding but slight advantages to France.

ROME, N.Y., Oct 30. -- Dr. Joel G. Justin of Syracuse, the inventor of the Justin dynamite shell, has not by any means given up all hope of the success of his invention, although he has blown up two big guns in his recent experiments. In fact, the doctor is more determined than ever to succeed in throwing large quantities of dynamite by the force of gunpowder.

In his appeal to the Republicans of this city on Thursday night to vote for reform in the Municipal Government Senator FASSETT spoke of the responsibility of Tammany for the failure of the movement for holding the World's Fair in this city and of the effort to secure action in favor of rapid transit from the last Legislature.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The Argus will publish to-morrow the following interview with ex-President Cleveland on the political situation sent to it by its New-York correspondent:

OTTAWA, Oct. 31. -- The members of the Iron and Steel Institute and the German Steel Association arrived this morning from the Sudbury nickel mines. The civic reception to-day concluded with an "at home" in the Russell House this evening. Sir John Macdonald, Premier of Canada; Sir John Thompson, and other Cabinet Ministers were present.

Quiet confidence in the election of the ticket headed by Francis M. Scott was noticeable among all the leaders of the anti-Tammany forces last night. There was nothing boastful in what they had to say. In this respect they differ from the Tammany leaders, who are making a point of claiming the election by ridiculous majorities for the simple purpose of encouraging their disheartened followers.

Among the travelers who arrived from Europe yesterday was William Steinway, the piano manufacturer, who went abroad on July 3 in the same steamer that took Chauncey M. Depew and John H. Starin to Europe on their Summer vacation. Mr. Steinway would hardly be known by his friends, having during his absence shaved away his beard and improved remarkably in general physical appearance.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 31. -- A private telegram from Salt Lake City, Utah, announces that the body of Detective James E. Murphy of Columbus was found to-day near Ogden. Murphy mysteriously disappeared at Ogden Sept. 23, while en route to san Francisco. It is suspected he was murdered.

On Tuesday, the 28th inst., the Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered the provisional estimate of the Register of this city for the year 1891. He asked, among others, for the following appropriations of the people's money:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- There was considerable discussion in the Navy Department to-day in regard to the condemnation of one of the cast-steel propeller struts of the armored cruiser Maine on account of the discovery of a blowhole in the metal nearly as large as a man's hand.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31. -- Taking effect Nov. 1, 1890, the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern will be operated in three divisions as follows: The Missouri Division will include: Main line, St. Louis to Poplar Bluff, Belmont Branch, Bismarck to Belmont and Columbus. Cairo Branch, Poplar Bluff to Bird's Point and Cairo. Jackson Branch, Allenville to Jackson.
Yesterday was a great and growing day for the people's cause. Jack's beanstalk was a slow and reluctant plant compared with the expansion and upward thrust of Mr. SCOTT'S canvass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Secretary of the Interior Noble and Superintendent of the Census Porter learned this morning that statistical and documentary proof of the gross inaccuracy of the census count of New-York City would probably be presented to the Secretary before night. This afternoon Mr. Porter issued census bulletin No. 12 giving the completed enumeration of the people of the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The Hon. George E. Mapes, Chairman of the Independent State Committee, to-day issued his final address to the Republican voters of Pennsylvania saying:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The twelfth in the series of census bulletins was issued to-day on the population of the United States. The bulletin says:

The Commissioners of the World's Fair are extremely desirous of having present at Chicago a number of naval vessels at the opening of the exhibition. Should the Navy Department feel inclined to comply with a request of this nature, the vessels to be sent would necessarily be restricted to those capable of passing through the Canadian canals.

The desperate efforts of Mayor Grant and his friends to make a decent showing in the tax books were brought to grief yesterday by an exposure of the misleading methods of Tammany's management at the hands of President Coleman of the Department or Taxes and Assessments. The Tammany powers have decided to let nothing stand in the way of a tax rate about as low as that which was declared last year.

There is but one way of hunting the coon. Hunted only at night, to follow him the boldest rider must dismount, yet he who risks neck and limbs, or melts or freezes for sport's sake, and deems no sport manly that has not a spice of danger or discomfort in it, must not despise this humble pastime for such reason.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The question of legalizing gambling on race tracks has become a live issue in New-Jersey politics, and in Union County great numbers of clergymen have taken the matter up with promising results. The latest feature has thrust itself into the canvass for the State Senatorship between Frederick C. Marsh, Democrat, and John C. Rankin, Jr., Republican.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The creditors of John H. Conant, ship broker, 103 State Street, under the style of John H. Conant Co., and manufacturer of indurated fibre ware at Watertown under the style of the Watertown Indurated Fibre Ware Company, met to-day. The liabilities are $210,000, of which $72,500 is secured and $137,500 unsecured.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.. -- An afternoon paper says: "Reports have again been put into circulation of important negotiations in progress between the Baltimore and Ohio and the Northern Pacific Road for an agreement offensive and defensive, which, consummated, will practically amount to a consolidation of the two systems.It is said that a close traffic contract has been drawn up and agreed to by both roads, covering both freight and passenger business.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 31. -- Feb. 1 of the present year the Anchor Manufacturing Company of this city issued 800 bonds of $500 each, amounting to $400,000, to Hugh H. Edwards of New-York as Trustee for a large number of creditors in that city. The bonds were to become due in five years, and carried semi-annual interest at 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct 31. -- The Census Bureau today issued a preliminary report on the production of steel in the United States during the year ended June 30, 1890, prepared by Dr. William M. Sweet, Special Agent, under the direction of Mr. Frank R. Williams, Expert Special Agent of the Division of Manufactures.
The Queenstown correspondent of the Liverpool Mercury telegraphs to that journal of Oct. 22:

Francis M. Scott stood on the crowded platform in Lenox Lyceum last night and amid a tempest of applause surveyed an assemblage such as is seldom brought together in this city by political issues. It was a magnificent assemblage in size, in intelligence, in earnestness, and in enthusiasm. The amphitheatre was crowded and the anti-Tammany sentiment of the meeting was expressed in no uncertain way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The funeral of Haughwout Howe, the bridegroom of a day, took place this morning from the headquarters of the International American Conference, on Vermont Avenue. The funeral services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Bartlett of the Presbyterian church, the clergyman who Wednesday made Mr. Howe and Miss Butterworth man and wife.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- George E. Mapes, Chairman of the Independent State Committee, after a careful canvass of the State, makes tonight the following estimate of majorities by counties at the election next Tuesday for Governor. As will be seen by the following table, Mr. Mapes estimates Pattison's majority in the State at over 30,000:

In the main, the representation made by the Governor of this State against the injustice that is believed to have been done to the State by an inaccurate census of the city is discreet and judicious. The Governor might, perhaps, as well have abstained from considering the partisan aspects of the question. In discussing them he lays himself open to an unpleasant retort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- C.D. McCoy acted as starter here to-day, Mr. Rowe having been called back to New-York to look after Mr. Belmont's colt Potomac, which is ill with pneumonia. J.J. Carroll has been refused the book-making privilege at the track for the rest of the season. The horse Hercules, who was pulled in a steeplechase recently, has been ruled off the track.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The clothing trade was thrown into a spasm this morning by the failure of the firm of Leopold Brothers Co., manufacturers of and dealers in wholesale clothing at Quincy and Franklin Streets. Twenty-six confessions of judgment were entered up against the firm in the Superior Court for sums aggregating $149,000.

The thirteen-year-old boy, John Anthony Anido, who shot his little brother Willie, eight years of age, at their home, 594 Park Avenue, Thursday, was yesterday remanded to await the result of the shooting, which is expected to be fatal. Detective Campbell, who made the arrest and investigation, says that the shot was undoubtedly accidental.

It was currency reported yesterday that "Reckless Temple," the new play at the Standard Theatre, would be withdrawn from the stage of that house next Saturday evening, and that "The Clemenceau Case" would be presented there again on the following Monday. Mr. J.M. Hill, the manager of the Standard Theatre, would not deny this statement last night.

Striped-bass anglers -- and they are about the only anglers left around the city now -- were bothered by the big storm this week, the effect of which was noticeable upon the waters several days thereafter. The storm did not drive out the fish, but it brought with it such a high tide that the fishing was practically estopped. As a result, the bass have not got into good biting trim again.

The people of this city are perfectly willing to spend $35,000,000 every year for the maintenance of courts and school and parks and public buildings, for the building of sewers and the care of streets, for the Police and Fire Departments, and for the salaries of their chosen servants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Princeton College Football team came to Washington to-day and gave the team of the Columbia Athletic Club a lesson on how to play football The game was played at the club's grounds on Analostan Island, and was watched with the greatest interest by from five hundred to seven hundred persons, a large percentage of whom were ladies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Frederick N. Atwood of this city has invented an airship with which he claims he will be able to travel at the rate of seventy miles an hour. A company with a capital of $200,000 has been organized to build and test it. The ship he has built and the principles he has patented differ from all others yet invented.

It has been brought to the attention of many citizens whose notice it would ordinarily have escaped that there is a "Prohibition" municipal ticket. The information has been conveyed by large posters and also by circulars and leaflets left at the houses of the voters. There is a liquor ticket in nomination that has altogether too much chance of election. Of course it is the ticket of Tammany, which is another name for liquor dealing.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Oct. 31. -- The tanning industry, which was for years a thriving business in Monroe County, is now on the decline. The citizens of Sciota, which was long known as Tannersville, are much exercised just now because of the contemplated closing of the Kistler tannery at that place. This was the only industry in the little village, and of course the employes of the establishment had to seek work elsewhere.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The most important news of the week in connection with the World's Columbian Exposition is the approval by Secretary Windom of the appointment of 115 lady managers, which will bring to the city on Nov. 18 a distinguished body of women. They are presumably the fittest representatives of the sex that the different States afford.

In the British Colonial Pocket Atlas, a work by one of the best known of English geographers, there is a map of the world on Mercator's projection, which shows the British Empire colored in red. On a map which shows all the water as well as all the land even the greatest empire does not appear to occupy as large a proportion as one might think.

Rumors about the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad continue to circulate in Wall Street and in Philadelphia. The newspapers in the last-named city are still working out the theory that the entry of M. B. Hollins into the powerful Reading syndicate means that the Vanderbilts are figuring to secure control of the property.

The sharp pursuit of Congressman JOHN W. CANDLER in the Ninth Massachusetts District by his opponent, Mr. GEORGE FRED WILLIAMS, has brought out some very interesting facts concerning an important change in the tariff -- the removal of sulphuric acid, commonly called oil of vitriol, from the free to the dutiable list.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- A young Russian named, Kelchosky, who succeeded in making his escape from Siberia after having served fourteen years there, has arrived in this city. He was arrested in Vilna, when only eighteen years of age, on suspicion of having in his possession revolutiondry documents and of being concerned in a conspiracy against the Government.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- No basis for the adjustment of rates on hogs and packing house product from the Missouri River to Chicago has been agreed upon. The committee appointed to labor with the Chicago and Alton people for the purpose of obtaining their consent to an advance in the product rate was compelled to report a failure to the adjourned meeting of the Western Freight Association to-day.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 31. -- The Commercial Gazette change does not take place to-morrow as announced. Mr. Morchead, who was to have had $300,000 of Mr. Halstead's stock, explains it in this way:

The insincerity of JOHN SHERMAN'S professions with respect to Trusts and similar combinations is again shown by his labors in behalf of ex-Gov. CHARLES FOSTER, who is a candidate for Congress in the Eighth District of Ohio. Mr. SHERMAN has taken pains to go to Findlay, which is in the district, and to make earnest speeches there for FOSTER.

The Linden Park Association have every reason to be gratified with the patronage accorded them. There was a big crowd at the track yesterday, and there was as good sport as any one could wish to enjoy. The Elizabeth people were out in force, and a gay party of the best people of that city occupied the boxes and had a jolly day's sport.

DUBLIN, Oct. 31. -- Mr. Balfour drove to-day from Costello Lodge, the residence of Police Commissioner Byrne, at Carrarve, to Galway. Upon his arrival at the latter place, he received a large number of the representatives of the local trades, who made suggestions to him for remedying the distress in the western counties of Ireland.

No better answer to the scoffs of the French press, when the painting by MILLET called the "Angelus" was captured at auction by an enterprising Yankee, could well be found than the purchase of the "Angelus" from that same Yankee by the French Government. A patriotic lady of Rheims bough a painting by MILLET which equally patriotic experts assured her to be superior to the "Angelus" and presented it to the Louvre.

The Church of the Transfiguration, Twenty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue, was completely filled yesterday afternoon on the occasion of the "Vespers of the Dead" for the faithful departed, annually held on All Souls' Day since 1873 by the Guild of All Souls, of which the Rev. Father J.O.S. Huntington is the chief representative in this city.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 1. -- This morning the new Board of City Affairs, appointed in place of the Board of Public Improvements displaced by the special session of the Legislature, met in Mayor Mosby's office. In a body, headed by the Mayor, they proceeded to the rooms of the Board of Public Improvement and found the doors locked. A clerk on the inside was requested to open the outer door.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The Yale Senior football team played a game here to-day with the eleven of Siglar's Preparatory School. The game was hotly contested and was characterized by much line playing. The Yale eleven won; score, 6 to 0.
The Tammany leaders have been circulating the following to bolster up their cause:

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- An extraordinary case was brought to light in the police court yesterday through the arrest of a husband on complaint of his wife. The man gave the name of John McDonald, the wife that of Julia McDonald. Mrs. McDonald said she was born in New-York City and lived with her parents and sister there until her father died.

The attention of citizens and taxpayers is respectfully asked to the following correspondence, which deeply concerns them. Beyond and above all political considerations is the welfare of the people of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, and it is time that a fitting rebuke should be extended to city officials who are unmindful of their promises and who disregard the necessities of a community of eighty thousand souls.

One of the dullest and most uninteresting campaigns that Brooklyn politicians ever conducted practically ended last night. A little work will be done to-morrow, but it will probably have very slight influence on the voters. No more meetings are to be held, and the politicians say very few of those of the last two weeks did much good.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The details of an immense deal in real estate by the great packing firms of Armour Co., Swift Co., and Morris Co. are made public this morning. They have purchased 3,600 acres of land at the southern end of Lake Michigan, in Lake County, Ind., and will remove their immense plants to that point, where they will establish a vast manufacturing centre.

THE EXTINCTION OF THE BUFFALO. -- At one station we see four little snow-covered flower beds close to the track, bordered with buffalo horns, and I count the horns. Fifty to a bed -- two hundred in all; the relics of a herd of bison. There is not one buffalo now upon the Buffalo Plains; all have been murdered for their hides.

There ought not to be any question in the minds of intelligent citizens of the annexed district as to which of the two candidates for the office of Commissioner of Street Improvements they should support. The issue is in no sense a political one; in fact, politics ought to be the last thing thought of in connection with the work which the Commissioner will be called upon to do.

The lessees of the Essex Market building have suggested to Mayor Grant, through their counsel, Edward Swan, that the building could be used advantageously for school purposes. The property is worth $400,000, but brings in a rental of only $7,000, and, the lessees say, has become unfit for market purposes.

The season is rapidly approaching when it behooves those people who spend their Winters in pursuit of pleasant surroundings to decide upon the place where they will cast their lot for the next six months. The group in Washington of people who merely live there because they like it, and because there is no particular reason why they should live anywhere else, is becoming larger every year, and its most prominent members are New-Yorkers.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 1. -- The business portion of the town of Chillicothe was almost entirely destroyed by fire last night. The fire originated in Hancock's livery stable and spread rapidly in all directions. The Mayor of this city was appealed to for help, and in response a special train with fire engines was dispatched to the scene, but as there were no means of unloading the machines they could no be utilized.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- The commission on the tariff question, presided over by Herr von Boetticher, Minister of the Interior, has concluded its consideration of the proposed Austro-German customs union. The report of the commission has not been published pending the progress of negotiations with Austria, but its conclusions are known to disfavor both an extensive revision of the customs and combined action in the way of reprisals for the American and French tariffs.

Near the close of this volume the author says of his hero: "Had he kept silence he would have been made a peer; they would have buried him in St. Paul's or Westminster Abbey and put a grand monument over his grave." Charles Napier instead of a peerage got knighthood, and instead of a burial in the Abbey or St. Paul's was laid away in the garrison graveyard at Portsmouth.

For the present, at least, the curtain has been rung down on the Twenty-second Regiment troubles with the countermanding of the order for the disbandment of Company C, Capt. John G.R. Lilliendahl. There now remains the contention of Capt. John P. Leo to be disposed of, in the shape of a threatened suit for damages against the Adjutant General and the Commander in Chief.

At last the Amateur Athletic Union has taken steps to put an end to the practice of legalizing prize fights by having them under the protection of its rules. The Board of Managers has passed a rule to suspend men who engage in contests of more than four rounds. The Board of Managers could have gone further with this praiseworthy legislation, but this regulation will undoubtedly accomplish a great deal of good.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1. -- The football games on Jarvis Field this afternoon resulted in a most decisive victory for Harvard. At the end of the game against Cornell, Harvard had scored 77 to Cornell's 0. Newell, Lake, and Dean of Harvard did some of the best work. It was dark when the game ended. Harvard's score was the highest of the year at Cambridge.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The new steel cruiser Newark steamed up the Delaware to her moorings at Cramps', this afternoon, with colors flying and seemingly exultant over the satisfaction which she has given her contractors by the good record of her trip.

To the Dutchmen we have to look for the original of phantom-ship tales which form about the most familiar of sea legends. The famous phantom ship that remains off the Cape as the harbinger of wreck and woe is a Dutchman whose skipper dresses in yellow, wears a nightcap, smokes a short pipe, and is always kind enough to heave in sight when a vessel is going to founder or run ashore.

JEFFER'S LANDING, Nov. 1. -- The season for shooting deer, quail, rabbit, and pheasant began yesterday, and the hunters, with loaded cartridges and well-trained dogs, are ready for the sport. The game was never known to be so abundant as it is this season. The old sportsmen say that the woods throughout South Jersey are extraordinarily well filled with animal life.

At the banquet tendered Gen. Miles at the Auditorium a couple of weeks ago one of the speeches which rang in the ears of the auditors not only that night, but for days and days thereafter, was a little gem by Judge Gresham, which, by the kindness of a warm friend and admirer, was not permitted to perish like the other speeches of that evening. It is herewith presented in "the art preservative":

A public meeting of more than ordinary significance was held in the open air in Wall Street yesterday afternoon. For the first time in the history of this municipality an assemblage of people formed in front of the Sub-Treasury Building to listen to a discussion of matters pertaining to the City Government alone. It was one of the largest and most convincing of the many meetings held under the direction of the People's Municipal League.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- The Freshmen this year have developed a very strong team, having received a large number of men who played on their preparatory school teams. They are quite anxious to play the Yale Freshmen. J. Poe, a brother of Capt. Poe of the 'Varsity, is playing a brilliant game at half back for the Freshmen, and will undoubtedly develop into a 'Varsity player.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1. -- Theresa Blennerhassett, a woman fifty years old and well known in St. Louis, a daughter of Richard S. Blennerhassett, deceased, formerly a prominent member of the bar and the descendant of the historic family of Blennerhassett, possessor of all the records and relics of the family, filed a petition in court today that revealed one of the most sensational stories that real life has ever contributed to romance.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Several veterans of the war of the Rebellion were telling of their experiences here to-day. One related the following amusing incident:

Under the restrictions which now hold the Board of Aldermen in check there is very little for the City Fathers to do, and what the Tammany boards have done for the last few years has been done in a slipshod and careless manner. The men who have been placed in nomination for Aldermanic honors this year are about of the same stamp as the men who have been nominated for the Assembly.

Many contestants and an assemblage of 10,000 interested and enthusiastic lookers-on, good sport and lots of it, music by the full Seventh Regiment Band, generous encouragement of participating athletes, and the heartiest imaginable rejoicing over each victory won -- these were some of the features of the international joint athletic meeting of the Manhattan Athletic Club of this city and the Salford Harriers of Manchester, England, held in Madison Square Garden last night.

Senator Justin S. Morrill since his re-election to the United States Senate has been the recipient of numerous congratulatory letters and telegrams from prominent Republicans and Democrats throughout the country. The Hon. E.J. Phelps of this city, who received the Democratic vote for Senator, gracefully accepted the result of the election in a letter to his successful rival.

PANAMA, Oct. 25. -- The Panama Canal Company will be given an opportunity to pass its poorly-carried-on work over to a new company, under the provisions of the bill in reference to its affairs, which it is expected will soon become a law. In the bill the Government grants the representative of the company an extension of ten years in which to complete the canal and open it to traffic.

It was the Republicans' turn at ratification last night, and in the large hall of Cooper Union they put the finishing touches on this exceedingly lively campaign in a manner that left no doubt as to their sincerity in the support of the municipal ticket headed by Francis M. Scott.

With reference to the rapid-transit question, Mayor Grant declared yesterday that it had been his definite intention ever since the last commission expired by limitation of law to reappoint it some time before the convening of the next Legislature. This is the commission composed of August Belmont, John H. Starin, Orlando B. Potter, Woodbury Langdon, and William Steinway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $140,190,900. as follows: Currency sixes, $6,672,000; 4 12 per cents, $28,116,700; 4 per cents, $105,402,200.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Secretary Noble has not yet ordered the Census Office to compare its figures, for the first five wards of New-York, with those of the police enumerators, which were brought to Washington by Supervisor Kenny last night. He had the opportunity to do so early to-day, but he is still giving the matter his "careful consideration" before deciding what to do.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 1. -- The Newport Improvement Association has been this week engaged in circulating their petition to the City Council for the submission to the people of the proposition for the removal of the rails of the Street Railway Company from Bath Road to a new street to be laid out from Broadway along Easton's Pond to the bathing beach.

While this season's fabrics have been commented upon as showing remarkably fine effects in heavy grades, the lighter textures and richer, if no less weighty, materials, show such striking beauty of design and color as to elicit the most enthusiastic admiration.

The magnificent scores made by the gunners of the cruiser Philadelphia the other day when firing at a little target bobbing up and down on the waves and distant 1,000 yards from the ship is in strict keeping with the gunnery traditions of the American Navy. Out of 82 shots fired, 60 were lodged in a vertical line not over twenty feet in height.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- A dispatch from Youngstown, Ohio, says: "The announcement was made to-day that the leading iron manufacturing concerns in the Mahoning Valley have been sold to an English syndicate. Some time ago options were secured by a broker on the Warren Rolling Mill, Girard Rolling Mill, Youngstown Rolling Mill, Lowellville Furnace, Youngstown Steel Works, the Andrews Iron Works, and the Mahoning Valley Iron Works.

The speed of the sun slackens noticeably during November, there being only an increase of 7 in southerly declination for the month, 3 of which occur in the first ten days. The daylight is diminished by an hour, as it is ten and a half hours in length to-day and only nine and a half on the 30th. The sign of Sagittarius, or the Archer, in which the sun now travels, symbolizes the hunting season.

The stock market would have been dull the past week had it not been for Reading and Sugar. They made things lively at times. Apart from them not much has been done, and the tendency of prices has been toward improvement. One cause of this was the better state of affairs in London, where the settlement passed off with only one or two unimportant failures.

As history shows, Nicholas Bayard of New-York some time in 1686 was commissioned "Colonel of a Regiment of Foot." Gov. Dongan having encouraged improvement in the drill and discipline of the train bands, the two may be said to have first given something like shape to the New-York volunteersman.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 1. -- The Lenox season is at ast drawing to a close. Although many well-known society people have been here the past week, including the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough, they have not tarried long. The cold weather and the whitening of the hilltops indicate that nearly all of the cottages will soon be closed, and only the Winter residents will remain in Lenox.
THE CATECHISM OF VANITY FAIR. -- There has been an examination paper in "Pick-wick"; why not one in "Vanity Fair"?

Seven old canvases have been imported by Mr. William Schaus in one collection, which so far has remained unbroken. They consist of one specimen of each of the following masters: Rembrandt, Rubens, Van Goyen, Jacob Ruisdael, Frans Hals, Cuyp, and Cornelis Jansen. Considering the difficulty now found to obtain fine examples of the old masters of the Netherlands, it is no small triumph to secure seven pictures as worthy of admiration as these.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 1. -- The pastoral relationship in the Congregational churches of this State will not on the average exceed a period of five years, long pastorates being the exception in the denomination. It is not uncommon at present for the Congregational societies to call the pastors of other denominations. Within the past three months two cases of the kind have occurred in New-Haven County.

It is now the opinion of careful observers with a good opportunity for obtaining trustworthy information that, while the contest for the House is complex and desperate, the chances are in favor of a large reform majority. Some place this majority as high as fifty; others, who still do not deny the force of the evidence on which this estimate is based, from a sheer habit of moderation, put the figure at thirty.

Few men are better known in yachting circles than Niels Olsen, the Superintendent of the New-York Yacht Club. For nineteen years he has been on duty in the New-York Yacht Club's house, keeping the affairs of the club in ship-shape order generally, and to-day any man who does not know Superintendent Olsen may be put down as not being possessed with that useful part of the anatomy known in the yachtsman's phraseology as "sea legs."

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- If the theatrical critics of Paris avoid brain fever this week it is for no lack of stimulant. First came "Cleopatre" and the great success of Sarah Bernhardt. The grumblers say that Sardou cut the part to suit his heroine. No one, however, found the same words to say for Henri Meilhac, the author, and Mlle. Rejane, the actress, of "Cousine," at the Theatre des Varietes.

HARTFORD, Nov. 1. -- The political outlook at the close of the last week of the canvass in this State is unusually favorable for the Democrats. There is strong probability that Judge Morris of New-Haven will be elected Governor on the popular vote. The German Republicans have decided to support Nicholas Staub of New-Milford, the Democratic candidate for Controller, against ex-Senator Lyman S. Catlin of Stratford, the Republican nominee for the place.

THE SCHOOL OF ART IN FRANCE. -- In France the curriculum is a very trying one, and its superiority consists at once in the severity and thoroughness of the education to which pupils are subjected, and in their admirable opportunities for study in the ateliers of the best masters. The standard is the very highest.

Very little of the inside history of the famous Irish patriots' rescue from Australia has been told. The statement, however, of the political opponents of John W. Goff, the union candidate for District Attorney, that he did not hold the interests of the Irish people at heart has stirred up some of his friends to speak of the affair and of his connection with it.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- It seems that neither the Moulin Rouge nor the Elysee nor the Folies Bergeres quite fills the bill, for Paris can now boast of a very much more luxurious establishment than all these. The Casino de Paris, built in the central locality once known as a skating place in the Rue de Clichy and Rue Blanche, just behind Trinity Church, is a very stupendous place.

There has never been a municipal contest in this city in which the issue was so clearly defined and in which the character of the forces engaged and of the arguments employed was so strongly marked as that which is now drawing to a close, and it may be that the ordinary standard of judgment in what we have been wont to call "local politics" will be found at fault.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- The fashionable element of this city turned out to-day to see the football game between Princeton and the University of Virginia. There are Baltimore men on both teams, including Capt. Poe of the Princeton eleven, and every one took a friendly interest in the game.

We have frequently been entertained by the frankness of our Republican contemporary in Butte, Mon., the Inter Mountain, and we now find proof in its editorial columns that it does not shrink from handling boldly current questions relating to prices and the tariff. On the 20th ult. the Inter Mountain published this paragraph:

ROMANS AND OYSTERS. -- The Romans, like ourselves, were fond of eating a few oysters as a prelude to dinner. Athenaeus tells us that Dromeas the parasite was once asked whether the banquets in the city or at Chalcis were the best; he replied that the prelude to the banquet at Chalcis was superior to the whole entertainment in the city -- understanding by the prelude to the banquet the multitude of oysters served up.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- Senator Gorman's speech before Tammany last night is read here to-day with considerable amusement, and the large capital that the Tammany organs are trying to make out of his presence there seems, in the light of Senator Gorman's record in this city, to be a huge joke.

The entries for the Horse Show at Madison Square Garden are all in, and the list, as a whole, is the best ever known. In the thoroughbred class the gain is notable. There are no less than fourteen thoroughbred stallions, double the number ordinarily exhibited in this class.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 1. -- Chairman J.H. Manley of the Republican State Committee, who is supposed to have some idea as to the probable results of the coming elections, had the following to say to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day:

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 1. -- Chairman J.H. Manley of the Republican State Committee, who is supposed to have some idea as to the probable results of the coming elections, had the following to say to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day:

DIFFERENCE BETWEEN TAXATION AND ROBBERY. -- If individuals take away some of your property for purposes of their own, it is robbery; you lose your money and get nothing in return. But if the Government takes away some of your property in the shape of taxes, it is supposed to render to you an equivalent in the shape of good government, something without which our lives and property would not be safe.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Secretary Blaine received an ovation this afternoon when he appeared on the stage of the Academy of Music to address the Republican mass meeting. The building was crowded to the very doors, and hundreds were unable to gain entrance. Mr. Blaine thanked his audience for the old-fashioned, hearty Pennsylvania welcome they had given him, and then announced that the occasion was not an ordinary one or he should not be present.

The text is published of what purports to be the English proposal for settling the Behring Sea dispute. It contains little that is new, and advances the controversy not at all beyond formulating a scheme for discussion. Still, it marks a new point of departure in an international controversy of the first magnitude, and therefore cannot be neglected by any observer who wishes to keep track of such events.

The importance of up-town inter-communication cannot be exaggerated. I believe your correspondent yesterday, if anything, underestimated the importance of cross-town transit in Sixty-fifth Street, Seventy-eighth Street, and Eighty-fifth Street, and underestimated the indignation with which we regard Tammany Hall for refusing this necessity to all people living between Fifty-ninth Street and One Hundred and Tenth Street.

CARTHAGE AND LUBECK. -- The life by sea was the very life of Carthage. When the Romans before the last siege made it a condition of peace that Carthage should be forsaken and some point ten miles from the sea occupied instead, every Carthaginian felt it as a sentence of death. Athens could not be great without her fleet; but she could live without it.

Departing from Butte by its narrow exits through the mountain passes one feels very much like a visitor to the United States Treasury vaults -- impressed with the magnitude of the deposits, awed by their sombre surroundings, and exalted by some vague sense of being indirectly and personally involved in the deal. To the world's people, so called, it is always comforting to contemplate mammon.

Your running of the tax-rate buzz saw has resulted in the horrible mutilation of the editorial brains of the New-York Sun's staff; but please don't cut with this saw only one kind of timber. Let it cut into the Water Department, and expose, if possible, what power beyond that department works it and dictates its methods.

The annual financial statement of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad has been issued. It shows that for the year ended June 30, the gross earnings were $6,412,078, operating expenses $4,338,838, and net earnings $2,073,240 over the corresponding period of the previous year. Adding $52,687 income from other sources to the net earnings, the total income last year is found to have been $2,125,927.

Every effort has been made by those specially interested in to-morrow's election to make the voters of this city familiar with the provisions of the ballot law so far as the manner of voting is concerned. There will be no excuse for any one who goes to a polling place without knowing precisely what he will have to do when he gets there.

We have pointed out several examples of the contemptible trickery by which the makers of the new tariff law undertook to raise duties even beyond the higher rates specified in the schedules of the act. Mr. McKINLEY'S box trick for the benefit of the Window-Glass. Trust is one of these. Another has just been uncovered by a decision of the Appraisers.

The Tammany campaign did not stop Saturday night, but went on yesterday, without regard for the day of rest. There is no Sunday on the Tammany calendar. The leaders of that ancient moral organization opened their saloons at daybreak, and thither flocked the ward heelers, big and little, to talk over the political situation, to lay plans for to-morrow, to drink and gamble on the result, and, incidentally, to make as many converts as possible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Superintendent of the Census Porter seems to be having a hard time to satisfy himself as to just what figure he will finally settle upon as the official statement of the population of the United States.

TRENTON, Nov. 2. -- It is not impossible that the Democrats will gain two Congressmen in New-Jersey on Tuesday. The First and Second Districts are conceded to the Republicans; the Third, Fourth, and Seventh can be taken from the Democrats only by a revolution.
