The Fifth and Sixth Districts are fighting ground, and they are the two which the Democrats hope to rescue from the Republicans.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 2. -- The Quay-Delamater people of Allegheny City are very much exercised to-day over the alleged bad faith of Mayor Wyman of that city. When Senator Quay made his visit to this city some ten days ago on his "boodle" distributing trip the needs of Allegheny were considered. Pittsburg was conceded to Pattison, and it did not appear to offer sufficient inducement for the investment of any large amount of campaign funds.

The People's Municipal League has brought together in an address to the voters of the city a statement of some of the more serious effects of Tammany rule. It is significant that the consequences of its incapacity, neglect, and abuse of power fall with peculiar severity upon the poorer people among whom it claims to have its chief support.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 2. -- The campaign that will close at the polls Tuesday has been one of the most remarkable and hotly-contested ever known in this State. It began with the Republicans hopeful and aggressive, while the Democrats were threatened with the same factional dissensions that wrecked their chances of victory two years ago.

This is the cry which has been raised by well-known parties against the clergymen in this city who have used their pulpits to advocate municipal reforms, and who have brought all their power as individuals and their influence as professional men through the prestige of the pulpit to bear upon the proposed changes in the administration of the affairs of the city.

We hope that every rational friend of tariff reform in the Third (Brooklyn) District will to-morrow be sure and vote for Mr. COOMBS for the House of Representatives. He is emphatically the business men's candidate. His views regarding taxation are not those of a theorist or a partisan, but of a practical, clear-headed, experienced business man.

The present will be a lively week at the Elizabeth track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club, where racing will be resumed on Tuesday afternoon. In addition to the six races, which include one of heats at a mile, there will be run on that day a match race for $1,000 a side between E.H. Garrison's colt Text, by Kinglike-Maxim, and W.C. Daly's colt Charley Post, by Kinglike-Fan Fan.

When the Crescent Athletic Club's eleven is bunched for a scrimmage at the right side of the field one of their tricks is for Harry Beecher to make a long pass to Edwards, the left half back, who happens to be listlessly standing near the left boundary line. Edwards then bounds down the field and usually gains considerable ground.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- John Owens, a member of the notorious "Bridge Bandit Gang," at Newburg, was killed here by the cars last night. Owens and a companion named Elmer Sarvis were fugitives from justice, being wanted in Newburg for robbing a saloon there.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 2. -- All Saints' Day was observed more generally than ever to-day. The returns of the railway office show that 30,000 people went out to Metairie Saturday, and fully as many to-day. Twenty thousand dollars was expended in floral and other decorations for graves and tombs. There were several places in Metairie to which there was a constant procession all day.

It is in the presentation of subjects of a criminal character that Frenchmen are true artists. The mise en scene is always good. It is a kind of realism they delight in, and M. Mace's book, in a pictorial sense at least, cannot be looked at without a certain amount of emotion. As to the literary part of "Mon Musee Criminel" there have been many other books better written.

While Patrolman Thomas German of the Ninth Precinct was endeavoring last night to arrest a man who was acting in a disorderly manner at Hudson and Charlton Street he was set upon by a number of roughs, who knocked him down, wrenched his club from him, and beat him over the head with it, injuring him severely. The officer's assailants escaped.

MEADVILLE, Penn., Nov. 20. -- One of the boldest robberies perpetrated in this city for many years occurred at 10:30 o'clock last evening at the office of the Wells-Fargo Express Company. The agent, C.P. Moore, was alone in the office, which is situated the width of the street from the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Passenger station and in a locality where scores of people are continually passing.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Discount eased after the settlement, but became firm again on the report that the Bank of England was borrowing money. The quotations were 4 3/4 to 4. On the Stock Exchange during the week there was experienced a further shrinkage of prices, though the settlement passed off better than the most sanguine had expected. Only two small failures were announced, both dealers in the American department.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- Pere Hyacinthe to-day commenced a campaign against clericalism, in his own church, with a vigorous address. He said that the republic was firmly established, but that after leaning toward atheism there was now danger of its lapsing into clericalism.

It is of small consequence to the decent people of Pennsylvania whether the motives of the Democratic editors in bringing charges against DELAMATER be bad or good; it is of considerable consequence whether those charges be true or false. Mr. BLAINE says that the editors would not make these charges without some great purpose beyond, and that that purpose is to give blow to protection.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 2. -- The Democratic and Republican State Committees have given the final touches to the Iowa campaign. Chairman Fullen and Secretary Lee of the Democratic Committee left here for their homes last night, and Republican Chairman Mack and Secretary Chassell will go to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- Chief Supervisor Bond and United States Marshal Airey showed themselves more than a match for Peter Campbell and William S. Bryan, the counsel for the City Election Committee, in a conference recently held with reference to the instructions to the judges of election, and if they had not receded from the agreement made there would have been trouble at the polls on Tuesday.

The Brooklyn politicians talked about nothing yesterday but Internal Revenue Collector Ernst Nathan's brazen attempt to force the local liquor and cigar dealers to re-elect William C. Wallace to Congress from the Third District. The general opinion was that the Republican "boss" had made the greatest mistake of his life, and many thought that his action would be so forcibly rebuked as to defeat Wallace.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Little Violet Nevin, whose kidnapping by her uncle, J.U. Conolly, and journey to the United States and return have attracted so much attention on both sides of the Atlantic, is temporarily in charge of the Sisters at the Chelsea Convent, near this city, where she was placed by order of Judge Vaughan Williams when she was produced by her uncle in obedience to an order of the court.

One of the marvels of the municipal canvass has been that in the many speeches made by Mr. SCOTT, some of which have necessarily been hasty and offhand in a rush from one meeting to another, there has invariably been a readiness and an aptness to the occasion that studied effort could hardly have attained, and never an utterance that could be regarded as ill-judged or ill-timed or better avoided than expressed.

Four of the five leaders in the Irish home-rule movement arrived in this city yesterday on the French steamer La Champagne. John Dillon, M.P., and William O'Brien, M.P., who escaped from Dublin, were two of the arrivals. With them were T.D. Sullivan, M.P., the poet laureate of the Parnellites, and Timothy Harrington, M.P., Secretary of the National League.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2. -- A thirty-thousand-dollar-damage suit will be begun in the Circuit Court to-morrow by Helen S. Rumsey, the six-year-old daughter of Mrs. Mary P. Rumsey. She brings suit by her mother, as guardian, against Julius C. Strauss, the well-known photographer.

Active preparations are being made aboard the receiving ship Vermont at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to get in readiness the detail of 150 men to be sent overland this week to San Francisco. The sailors go by special train, and are to form part of the crew of the new cruiser San Francisco. The Independence, receiving ship at the Mare Island yard, is unable to supply the San Francisco with more than 200 men.

The system of public instruction, by means of which an education, however elementary, is within the reach of every child in our city, is rendered more effective and complete by the important share which the corporate schools have in carrying into execution this beneficent design.

Tammany's poverty in actual titles to esteem and confidence is so notorious that if its leaders had not gone into the business of manufacturing spurious claims to consideration they would have been destitute of campaign material. Here is one of the counterfeits taken from Mayor GRANT'S letter of acceptance:

A secret political club has put forward as its candidate for Mayor Hugh J. Grant, and it seeks to conceal itself behind the name of a great political party. Hugh J. Grant is not the candidate of the Democratic Party; he is the candidate of Tammany Hall.

The members of the Goethe Society and their friends filled the ballroom of the Hotel Brunswick last evening. It was the first meeting of the society this season. President A.M. Palmer said in his address of greeting that it would be the endeavor of the Executive Committee to make the programme during the coming Winter in every way as interesting as that of last year.

Still another controversy over the obscure and involved language of the McKinley Tariff act has been decided by the Republican customs officers of this port against the importers in favor of the American manufacturer, and as invariably happens in such cases, the consumer pays the damages. In this instance people will discover where the difference comes in when they go to buy their Winter underwear.

The sloop yacht Tyrant, having on board a party of duck shooters from this city, ran on Nigger Head lock, opposite Hell Gate, on Sunday night. Four men were rescued by crew that put out from Astoria and two of the party where drowned. The accident was due to the efforts of the Captain of the yacht to avoid collision with a sand schooner.

The Tammany bosses showed yesterday that their boast of confidence in the election of their ticket was the weakest kind of a "bluff." They hurried hither and thither in a wild scramble to pull victory out of defeat. Their tongues were so tuned to making ridiculous claims of big majorities for Grant that they talked on in the same mechanical fashion, while their actions gave the lie to their words.

The ducking season on the Susquehanna flats begins at 5 o'clock this morning. Every train yesterday took gunners to Havre de Grace from Baltimore, Philadelphia, New-York, and other places. These, with the local sportsmen and those whose business it is to shoot ducks for market, will make between 400 and 500 persons who will occupy the feeding grounds at daybreak to begin the slaughter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- Capt. John F. Allen of the schooner Cornelius Hargreaves, sunk in the collision off Barnegat, arrived in Philadelphia this morning, and gave his version of the accident. He said:
CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- The big packers themselves have confirmed the report that they have purchased about 4,000 acres of land in Lake County, Ind., for stock yard purposes.

The gunboat Concord will leave her berth at the yards of Roach Co., Chester, Penn., early this morning. She is expected to reach New-York about slack high water to-morrow afternoon. To-night the Concord will anchor inside of Delaware Breakwater.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Secretary Noble probably wishes there had never been such a thing as a New-York census while he was at the head of the Interior Department. New-York's persistent efforts to have her people fairly counted have made the Secretary very weary, and now he seems to find it hard to keep his temper as calm and unruffled as is becoming to a Cabinet officer.

The snake chosen by Sarah Bernhardt to serve as her executioner is of the "blind-worm" species, and is known in France as an orvet It is a pretty creature, which may be often found on the tops of old walls sunning itself. The back is dark green with metallic hues that are in ceruain lights iridescent. Sarah's snake is called by her Iris.

Broadway had a good old-fashioned blockade yesterday afternoon that tangled up trucks, wagons, backs, and street cars for almost a mile of the city's main thoroughfare, while smaller jams stretched back half a block or so in the side streets. The cause of all the trouble was a trifling one. It wasn't a big and heavily-loaded track that broke down right on the line of the street cars.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3. -- In the campaign now closing the dangers of the California Democracy may be expressed in two words -- money and Buckley. In all other respects the outlook is extremely favorable, but Senator Stanford is here overseeing the legislative fight in person, and the details of its management are in the hands of an able general, experienced in the financial persuasion of voters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The racing here to-day was run under discouraging weather conditions. The attendance was light and the sport evoked no enthusiasm. Details of the racing are as follows:

The Lyceum Theatre company ended its ten weeks Saturday night in Brooklyn, having played since August in Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia, and other important cities. The receipts of the tour are said to have been exceptionally large, and the reception of Mr. Frohman's company everywhere was of a most enthusiastic character.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Before President Harrison started for Indianapolis, where he is going to vote to-morrow, he designated Acting Fourth Auditor Whitaker to be also Acting Third Auditor of the Treasury Department, because the Third Auditor, the Deputy Third Auditor, and all other officers of the Third Auditor's office have gone home to vote. Mr. Whitaker is Acting Fourth Auditor because the Fourth Auditor is also absent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- "The big crops in Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho are likely to remain in warehouses several months before they can be hauled away," said James Albright, of Sprague, Washington, who has just arrived in this city.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 3. -- The football game between Amherst and Cornell to-day was marked by continual "kicking" on both sides. Two halves of thirty minutes each were played. In the first half neither side scored. The ball was in Cornell's territory the greater part of the time.

The real question before the country, which is in part to be settled to-day, is the question whether a political party can conduct the government of a republic, under universal suffrage, in defiance of public opinion. Mr. REED, Mr. QUAY, and a number of minor Republican machinists have staked their political future upon the proposition that this can be done.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- The Liliputians, who achieved such success at Niblo's and the Metropolitan Opera House in New-York, appeared in their spectacular play, "The Pupil in Magic," at the Hollis Street Theatre in this city for the first time to-night. The large house was packed to the doors. The audience, composed almost entirely of Americans, with hardly a German among them, was most enthusiastic and applauded the Liliputians again and again.

A remarkable feature of the Congressional campaign has been the deliberate and persistent lying of high-tariff journals about the requirements of the new tariff law and the effect of that law upon prices. Even the most respectable of these papers have yielded to the temptation and have thrown aside all regard for truth in dealing with these matters. And they have been supported by the official utterances of the Republican Campaign Committees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Telegraphic orders were sent to-day to Chief Engineer Loring, President of the board conducting the evaporation test of one of the boilers of the torpedo boat Cushing, directing him to give the boiler a supplementary test of one hour's duration at its fullest capacity, with the maximum coal consumption and with the blowers running at the highest possible speed.

There were not many changes of bill at the theatres last night, and none of them were very important. George Thatcher's newly-organized minstrel company had a demonstrative audience at the Bijou Theatre. In Part I. only the comic men had blackened faces. The others were dressed as Spanish toreadors, and, although the costume is not very appropriate it is certainly picturesque.

The application for the appointment of a receiver for the Sugar Trust was granted by Judge Pratt Saturday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. The opinion filed with the clerk is a very long one, and reviews in an exhaustive manner the history of the suits brought by Gleason and Cameron, and on which was based the demand for a receiver.

The Chicago Journal says that it has been practically settled that the Wabash Railroad Company will extend its line from Butler, Mich., to a connection with the Western Indiana, thereby rendering it independent of the Chicago and Erie for an entrance to Chicago, and that the Canadian Pacific will be given a Chicago line by the same route.

Just now great interest centres in the coming convention of amateur photographers. That it will be a success seems now to be beyond doubt, if the notices of amateurs of their intention to be present count for anything. From all parts of the country word has been received of delegations that are to come.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 3. -- The Governor General has received a petition from England praying that the sentence of death, recently passed upon Reginald Birchall, now in jail at Woodstock, Ontario, be commuted to imprisonment for life. Unless the Governor General intervenes, the prisoner will be hanged on Nov. 14. The English petition is signed by 2,000 persons, including Birchall's mother, Oswald Birchall, half-brother of the prisoner, and rector of Buscot, besides prominent clergymen.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Mr. Gladstone started on his return to Hawarden, from Scotland, to-day. When the train on which he was traveling reached Montrose a large number of his friends were in waiting, and they gave him an enthusiastic reception. This scene was repeated at Arbroath. At Dundee a number of his admirers presented him with a walking stick and a luncheon basket.

Ernst Nathan's secret intimidation circular is having such a disastrous effect in the Third Congressional District, Brooklyn, that Congressman Wallace, whom it was designed to help, yesterday repudiated it. Wallace reached his headquarters in the Arbuckle Building bright and early and found a letter from F.H. McArthur demanding to know all about the Nathan circular.

There is not much to choose, in point of dignity, between the Governor of the State of New-York and the Secretary of the Interior. We pointed out to the former functionary, when he sent in his protest against the refusal to recount the inhabitants of this city, that he was laying himself open to a severe retort when he allowed himself to bring partisanship into the question.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- M. Jules Lemaitre, the celebrated critic of the Debate, has once again entered the public arena. His first and only play, "The Revoltee," it will be remembered, met with considerable favor and considerable adverse criticism. It belonged to the so-called new dramatic school. The present venture of the author is still more modern, and more given to pure character study.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 3. -- Political affairs in Kansas are in a chaotic state, such as was never before seen. The Farmers' Alliance, organized first solely for self-protection and self-instruction, was, one year ago, not unlike the dozen other organizations in the State, small in numbers and without particular influence. It grew, however, like the fabulous pumpkin vine in Southern California, and threatened in a short time to entwine and choke all opposing parties.

Several public institutions in the city of Elizabeth will have their treasuries partly replenished to-day as a result of the racing at the Linden Park Blood Horse Association's track yesterday. The association itself gave $1,000 of its gate receipts, and a subscription among the bookmakers resulted in the collection of $620 more, of which latter amount Eugene Leigh, lately trainer for the Chicago Stable, gave $100.

The result of the election in Brooklyn was a most emphatic Democratic victory. That party elected its county and city ticket by large pluralities, that for Courtney for Sheriff in 505 of the 648 districts in the city running up to 14,000. Jackson for Controller and Weber for Auditor were also elected by substantial pluralities.

Mr. THOMAS B. REED was elected Speaker of the House in the present Congress by a majority of 7. When the House adjourned the Dictator had succeeded in making that majority 24. When the House meets in December, 1891, Mr. REED, if he is the candidate of his party for Speaker, will be defeated by a majority of at least 70.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Returns from all parts of the State show heavy Democratic gains. In Southern Maryland the new registration law cut the vote down nearly one third.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 4. -- Nebraska is the slowest State in the Union to count election returns, but all early indications foreshadow a remarkable Democratic triumph. This city has probably given James E. Boyd, Democratic candidate for Governor, 10,000 majority. Richards, the Republican candidate, was cut out and left by his own party. Early returns indicate that the same thing occurred in other large cities of the State.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- The friends of the new system of voting which has just had its first trial in this State have not been at all surprised or discouraged by the opposition it has encountered. They have never cherished the delusion that so radical a change in a matter touching so many people would be accepted without challenge or debate.

The once all-powerful, famous, and always popular racing stable of the Dwyer Brothers is now broken up. A great crowd was at the dissolution sale, which was held yesterday afternoon in the saddling paddocks of the New-Jersey Jockey Club's track. The stable has been very unfortunate this year, and no amount of coaxing would make fortune smile upon it.

The new Constitution of the State of Mississippi differs in the provision made for its adoption from most instruments of organic law now in force in the United States, though following precedents established in that State. It will not be submitted to the people. The Memphis Appeal of Sunday morning publishes the Constitution in full as adopted by the convention at 10 o'clock on Saturday night, Nov. 1.

Large fields and a good class of horses combine to make a card for to-day's races at Elizabeth which is far above the average, even in midsummer. As the opening race received twenty-two entries, it was divided so there will be seven contests on for decision, and those look as if they would give the eighty-three bookmakers all the business they care for. The entries and weights for the several events are as follows:

It became evident early in the day yesterday that the Hudson County ring had been up to its old tricks. In the first place nineteen of the Republican election officers failed to call upon City Clerk Scott in Jersey City for their official Republican ballots, and suspicion became strong that they had been bribed to stay away.

The number of votes cast in this city yesterday was a surprise to political observers of all parties. Little more than 214,000 ballots were polled on a registration of 245,164. Last year, with not as exciting or important a contest, nearly as many votes were cast on a registration of only 218,923. This year more than 30,000 citizens who were registered refrained from voting. This is unprecedented.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4. -- A crowd of about three thousand spectators watched Harvard defeat the famous Orange Athletic Club's eleven this afternoon. The Orange team was weakened by the absence of Gill, Corbin, and Bonvaird, the latter acting as referee. Cumnock played at his old position of left end for Harvard, but did not distinguish himself.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4. -- From the few returns received up to 10 o'clock, the indications are that the Democrats have made a clean sweep in Virginia and carried all ten Congressional districts.

The National Cross-Country Association succeeded in deciding its junior championship race at Morris Park yesterday. The race was postponed from last April, or rather was declared off, on account of the inability of the officials of the regular championship meeting to decide the winners of the junior event. To make the meeting yesterday more successful the association gave also an eight-mile open handicap, run over the championship course, a number of individual prizes being offered.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- The election in Ohio to-day was for Secretary of State, Supreme Court Judge, and member of the Board of Public Works. The Republican candidates were Daniel Ryan, Thaddeus A. Minshall, and Frank McCulloch. The Democratic candidates were Thaddeus E. Crumley, George B. Okey, and Leopold Kiefer.

Yesterday's experience demonstrated two things with reference to ballot reform. One is that, so far as the essential features of that reform as advocated by its real friends were embodied in the law of this State, the objects aimed at were fully attained. The other is, such complications and difficulties as were encountered were due wholly to the modifications of the orignal plan which were made to secure the approval of Gov. HILL.

ALBANY, NOV. 4. -- Gov. Hill received the news over the regular press wires and by special dispatches in the Executive Chamber. There were with him Judge I.H. Maynard, Col. McEwan, Col. Kopper of New-York, and T.C. Callicot, the ex-convict editor whose Albany newspaper is the Governor's personal organ. The Governor was in a gleeful mood and commented freely on the news.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 4. -- The election to-day turned entirely on local issues. The last Legislature passed an educational measure, compelling parents to give children between seven and fourteen years of age twelve weeks' schooling each year, in which reading and writing in English should be included.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 4. -- The vote polled in Iowa to-day is not as large as was expected, when the favorable weather is considered. The farmers seem to have preferred to labor in their cornfields rather than to go to the polls. This fact cost the Republican Party dearly, and it has probably lost them the State.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 4. -- The election passed off quietly throughout the State. A very small vote was polled -- not more than three-fourths of the registered voters. The negroes generally remained in the cotton fields and took no part in the election.

ELLENDALE, N.D., Nov. 4. -- The election in this State to-day exceeded in interest and importance any previous event of the kind. The most exciting pictures were the efforts to defeat legislative candidates favorable to the return of Senator Pierce, and to elect members pledged to a resubmission of the prohibition question.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 4. -- This State elected nothing but seven Congressmen to-day. The only districts where there was the least doubt were the Second, Third, and Sixth. In the remaining four there was no opposition. In the First and Fifth it was only a question as to what the Democratic majorities would be. The returns confirm this. In the Second District J.C. Kyle was the Democratic nominee, and George M. Buchanan the Republican.

Neology has flourished during the campaign just closed like the "green baize" tree. One editor -- and by the way the neologists have all of them been newspaper men -- has given us the verb "to McKinley," the definition of which will occur to any person of average intelligence, and another editor has introduced into his vocabulary the word "tomreedism," of equally obvious significance.

It is easy to foresee that the very first result of the re-election of Mayor GRANT will be an outcry from citizens of a virtuous disposition and a weak constitution for the resumption of the government of New-York from Albany. In fact, whoever appeared last night in the haunts of such citizens must have heard a good deal of talk tending in that direction.

CARMEL, N.Y., NOV. 4. -- The new ballot law worked successfully in Putnam County to-day, although in a few instances it was not carried out strictly to the letter. In giving out the ballots the clerks usually folded one, and then instructed the voter to do up the others in the same manner. The folding was frequently done in a very imperfect manner.

Tammany has elected twenty Assemblymen in this city, the only County Democrats chosen being BRADY in the Fourth District and DINKELSPIEL in the Twelfth, neither of them a credit to the organization, and the only Republicans are BRODSKY in the Eighth and HILDRETH in the Twenty-first, if, indeed, BRODSKY is still to be rated as a Republican.

Although, at the time of writing, the returns from Pennsylvania are still very incomplete, they indicate a majority of 10,000 for PATTISON. The extent to which QUAY has been "vindicated" must make Mr. BLAINE feel that he made a very poor bargain when he went down to Philadelphia last Saturday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- The returns in this city and State are being canvassed with extraordinary slowness. Only half the city precincts have been heard from on the vote for Sheriff, and at midnight no returns have been received at headquarters on the vote for the four Congressmen from this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The racing here to-day was witnessed by a small crowd, though the programme was an exceptionally good one. Stoval weighed out to ride St. John in the third race, but the betting becoming so suspicious, his price going back from 7 to 5 to 2 1/2 to 1, the judges substituted Higgs. Details of the racing are as follows:

It seems fitting that we should publish this morning in a little group certain assertions and expressions of opinion which indicate the attitude of Republican leaders and organs toward a marked increase of the cost of living. They are as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- This city gives about 25,000 majority for Delamater. The State is close, with chances in favor of Pattison.

The New-York Athletic Club and Boston Athletic Association began a series of annual football matches on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The Bostons won handily by a score of 34 to 0. Stickney secured five touch-dows and Beall one, and Beall kicked five goals from touch-downs. Capt. Peters of the Boston team and Schlesinger of the New-Yorks were injured.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 4. -- Reports received up to midnight show almost conclusively that the Democrats have won a victory. Morris and the entire State ticket are undoubtedly elected. There is a certain gain of two Congressmen, with a propability of three, and Senator O.H. Platt is possibly retired to private life by the election of a Democratic Legislature.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- Bright weather and the novelty of the Australian system brought out a very heavy vote for an off year all over Missouri. The election was for Supreme Judge, Railroad Commissioner, Superintendent of Schools, fourteen Congressmen, and the Legislature, which will choose a successor to George G. Vest in the United States Senate and rearrange the Congressional districts.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 4. -- Minnesota may still be classed as a Republican State, although the pluralities received by that party's nominees at to-day's election are nothing to brag of. W.R. Merriam is re-elected Governor by a plurality of about 8,500, against 24,000 two years ago. The remainder of the Republican ticket except Auditor is elected by greatly reduced pluralities Adolph Bierman (Dem. and Alliance) is elected Auditor by about 20,000 majority.

The Princeton College eleven won a game yesterday by a score of 85 to 0 from a team of Columbia College students. The game was played in the morning on the Berkeley Oval, and a crowd of nearly 3,000 persons turned out to watch the play of the orange-and-black kickers.

One of the few amenities of the late municipal campaign has been the sight of JUDAS and ANANIAS working together in harmony. Ever since JUDAS began to take away ANANIAS circulation, and Gov. CLEVELAND omitted to pay to ANANIAS'S opinion the deference that ANANIAS thought it deserved, ANANIAS'S politics have consisted in opposition to CLEVELAND and to JUDAS.

ABERDEEN, S.D., NOV. 4. -- Bitterness marked every feature of to-day's election in South Dakota. There were three tickets in the field -- Republican, Democratic, and Alliance -- and the fight centred on the legislative ticket, the Alliance and Democrats having fused in a large number of districts for the avowed purpose of electing men antagonistic to United States Senator Moody.

Herrmann's Theatre was closed last night, and the Minnie Palmer Comic Opera Company has probably collapsed. A slim audience had assembled in this place of amusement, when, a little after 8 o'clock. Acting Manager Morton appeared before the curtain and announced that, owing to the sudden and unexpected illness of Charles Dickson, an actor in the company, no performance would be given, and money paid for tickets would be refunded.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- The result of the election in Ohio yesterday has surprised both political managers and the rank and file of the parties. So far as the State ticket was concerned the Democrats on the outside were willing to concede the election of Ryan, Republican candidate for Secretary of State, by a plurality of 20,000.
I do not think the People's Municipal League need despair in their efforts for good government in the city of New York in consequence of the defeat of their ticket.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 5. -- The Republicans of Michigan have encountered in this election the worst defeat they have ever received in their history of thirty-six years. Both they and the Democrats are alike surprised at its extent and completeness.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 5. -- The recent visit of the English and German iron and steel manufacturers to Canada has attracted increased attention to the marvelous richness of the Sudbury district. Already the Standard Oil Company, the Dominion Company, and half a dozen other associations and corporations have commenced work there.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 5. -- William Arthur Lee of New-York was to-day married to Miss Catherine McLane in St. Paul's Church. The Rev. J.S.B. Hodges of officiated. The best man was Richard K. Sheldon of New-York, and the ushers were Messrs. George May, John McKim, Robert McLane, and Messrs. William Beekman, Frederick De Puyster Foster, Henry C. Demings, Philip H. Eill, and Stanley Dwight of New-York. There was a large attendance of society people.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Post, commenting on the American elections, thinks the Silver bill had a deal to do with the Republican disaster.

Prof. James Bryce addressed an audience of Armenians yesterday afternoon at the Grand Opera House Council Rooms, Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Before beginning his address he was presented with a memorial thanking him in warmest terms for his efforts on behalf of suffering Armenia.

A good crowd, big fields of horses, lively betting, and sharp contests were the features of yesterday's sport at the Elizabeth race track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club. Favorites and outsiders divided winning honors about equally, though, with the exception of Now or Never in the first race and the Brunette gelding in the last, all the winners were fairly well backed.

The large number of entries for the fifth race this afternoon has necessitated its division, so that visitors to the New-Jersey Jockey Club's track will see seven instead of six races run at the Elizabeth track. The entries for each of the races are numerous, so that there will be excellent sport for the enjoyment of the crowd that will certainly be on hand to see the contests.

HONESDALE, Penn., Nov. 5. -- L.A. Robinson, who was found dead in his bed in Brooklyn recently, was a retired millionaire tanner and made most of his great fortune five miles from this place, where he owned and conducted for many years what was at one time the largest tannery in the world, Wayne County, Penn., being then the leading county in the Union in the tanning industry.

The brother of the late Gov. Silas Wright was found dead at his home in Canton, St. Lawrence County, on Thursday morning, Oct. 16. Our correspondent in that town says: "Pliny Wright has been long a character in the truest sense. Credited with wealth varying all the way from $10,000 to $50,000, he has lived alone and in the most hermitlike manner for years.

One of the happiest men in New-York yesterday was Chairman Roswell P. Flower of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, Mr. Flower sat in his office all day and received congratulatory telegrams from Democrats all over the country and calls from New-Yorkers who wished to show their appreciation of his efforts to win Congress from the Republicans.

Now that the people have invited Tammany Hall to take complete charge of the City Government and do as it sees fit, there will be a number of offices for Mayer Grant to distribute among his faithful workers as rewards for their activity in his interests. The more important offices that are to be filled by the Mayor in the immediate future are as follows:

Ex-Mayor William R. Grace was at his office in Hanover Square yesterday, attending to business that had accumulated while his attention was monopolized by the local campaign. The ex-Mayor found no reason to be down-hearted over the result, although he had given the union ticket movement his heartiest support. When asked for his opinion on the result, he said:

The Forest Commission of the State of New-York devoted another long session yesterday to a consideration of the proposition for a State park in the Adirondack region. The commission is putting forth every effort to get information and opinions on the scheme, as it is desired to make a report to the next Legislature.

The additional returns received from the dilatory canvassers in Brooklyn up to 6 o'clock last night, when Police Commissioner Hayden's office was closed, indicate that William J. Coombs is, after all, elected to Congress over William C. Wallace in the Third District. With 8 out of 164 election districts missing, Mr. Coombs has a plurality of 163.

Signor Giovanni Succi, an Italian gentleman who has attained some fame as a professional faster, began last night what he declares will be a forty-five days' fast. Persons who would like to see how he fasts can find him in the small hall over Koster Bial's place of entertainment, in West Twenty-third Street, at any hour of the day or night.

In the results of the vote for city and county officers, Congressmen, and Assemblymen in New- York City, as published in the first edition of yesterday's TIMES, there are no changes to record. THE TIMES stated that the Tammany candidates for city and county officers, without exception, were elected. Yesterday's review of the returns shows this statement to have been correct.

Some attention has been paid by the public prints to a recent campaigning tour of Gov. DAVID B. HILL, and the impression has somehow found lodgment in many minds that the Governor's tariff-reform speeches contributed materially to the Democratic victory in the elections held on Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- Every additional return from the State of yesterday's election shows increased majorities for Pattison. At midnight special dispatches from every county in the State give him a majority of 16,889.

An Italian bark, the Leon Parcaldo, came in from Capetown after a sixty-five days' voyage late yesterday afternoon, and gave out a very meagre tale of a sea tragedy that it came across in its run up the coast. Her lookout sighted a big three-masted lumber schooner last Thursday morning about 300 miles off Hatteras tossing about with a signal of distress flying.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 5. -- Mrs. Birchall, overcome with emotion, made a final effort to-day in Ottawa to save her husband from the gallows. Unless Sir John Thompson, Minister of Justice, intervenes, Reginald Birchall will be hanged in Woodstock jail on the 14th inst. for the murder of his friend, Cenwell. Mrs. Birchall reached here this morning with her sister, Mrs. West Jones, and Lawyer Dugal McMurchy.

We do not know what private reasons Park Commissioner ROBB may have for resigning his office, but on public grounds it is greatly to be regretted. He was the one thoroughly efficient member of the board, and his recognized ability, integrity, and public spirit gave the public confidence that nothing could go far wrong in park management so long as he was concerned with it.

The new Board of Aldermen, a body to which respectable people nowadays seem to give very little attention, will contain nineteen Tammany men, three County Democrats, one Voorhis Democrat, and two Republicans. One of these Republicans CHARLES SMITH of the Eighth District, is not "regular," and is no better than a Tammany man in any possible particular.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 5. -- The launch of the steamship Howard Cassard was delayed to-day because the vessel became stuck on the ways. Several thousand people were present to see the event and were obliged to go away disappointed. Miss Alice Fryer, the daughter of the inventor, christened the boat. The Howard Cassard represents an attempt to revolutionize ocean travel.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Complete returns from this Congressional district give the following: Seneca, Rockwell 573 plurality, Schuyler, 202, making a total of 775 in both Democratic counties; Noyes, in Tompkins, 645 and in Schuyler 225, or a total of 870, giving Noyes a plurality of 95. In the face of this the Democratic leaders claim that Rockwell has a plurality of 26.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 5. -- Two weeks ago Senator Joseph Blackburn was badly injured by being thrown from his buggy, but to-night he was able to leave here for Washington City, where he goes to be present at the marriage of his daughter.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 5. -- Iowa went with the general landslide yesterday. Although the result in the State ticket is so close that the official count will be necessary to determine which is elected, there is a positive gain of five Democratic members of Congress, with one district still in doubt, and the next delegation from Iowa will be composed of a majority of Democrats for the first time since the war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -Provisions to-day yielded, along with everything else on the floor. Pork at night showed a decline from Monday of 10c, Lard and Ribs of 5c. Early there was renewed buying by Rosenbauma, Presse, and Dunham, the commission houses which from one source or other have had considerable orders of late on the buying slits of Pork. Their attitude maintained prices until toward the close.

ALBANY, Nov. 5. -- Now that the Democrats have obtained control of the Assembly, with the power of electing one of their party to the United States Senate, the thoughts of the politicians wander intuitively toward the chair of the Speaker of the Assembly and of that of Mr. W.M. Evarts. The first proposition is easy of solution.

Ninety-one Republicans, 240 Democrats in the House of Representatives! A majority against the Administration of 149! Was there ever such an overwhelming defeat of a party so powerful in appearance, so confident in spirit, so haughty and defiant in conduct! And when we regard the individual leaders.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- For the first time in its history, Illinois has gone Democratic, and by such a large majority as to make it seem probable that it will stay Democratic, at least until after the next Presidential election.

Undoubtedly the McKinley tariff was the chief issue in the elections of Tuesday, but not the professed principle of the bill nor even the extreme application of that principle. The real issue was the general policy of the Republican Party, of which the Tariff bill was the most conspicuous and the most important embodiment.

The funeral services of the late John G. Wright, a veteran of Company C., Seventh Regiment, N.Y.S.M., Colonel of the Fifty-first Regiment New-York Volunteers, and a member of Shepard Rifles, the Loyal Legion, and Ransom Post, G.A.R., Department of Missouri, who died at St. Luke's Hospital last Sunday night, took place from Grace Church yesterday at 2 P.M.

It is expected that there will be a conference in this city to-day between the members of the Trunk Lines Commission and representatives of railroads forming the Western connections of the trunk lines. The east-bound freight-rate question is becoming a very serious problem, and a majority of the trunk line Presidents are anxious to solve it as speedily as possible.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Cornell was defeated by Wesleyan in a well-played game this afternoon. Each team was on its mettle and it was only after a hard struggle that Wesleyan was able to win. Cornell's rush line was much heavier than Wesleyan's, but she lacked the skill and science which characterizes the playing of the Wesleyan men.

A recent number of the London Athenaeum contained a very perverted account of the relations of Messrs. HARPER BROTHERS with Mr. RUDYARD KIPLING, an account so perverted that it could scarcely have proceeded from Mr. KIPLING himself, Mr. KIPLING, however, returned the honorarium of 10 which the HARPERS sent him upon the publication of their collection of his stories, and thus seemed to give his support to the accusation against them of unfair dealing.

SAN FRANCISCO, NOV. 5. -- The new system of counting has so muddled the election officers that returns are in hopeless confusion. From 100 city precincts the returns were locked up, with the required bulletins sealed inside, and results cannot be known until they are opened for the official canvass next Monday. A recount of the entire city will be necessary.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 5. -- While the returns come in slowly, and are then incomplete, enough is known to prove that there has been a revolution in Kansas; that the farmers have awakened to their power and exercised it. The Alliance Committee claims the State by 15,000 to 20,000 plurality. The Republican Committee claims the election of its ticket by 10,000 plurality.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 5. -- In North Dakota the Republicans elected Congressman and State ticket by from 2,000 to 4,000.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 5. -- There is a possibility that when all the returns are in it will be found that Minnesota has joined in the revolt against Republicanism and elected a Democratic State administration.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The prettiest canvass in all of the State of New Jersey and one that will probably attract attention all over the country was that made by Dr. Thomas Dunn English, the Democratic candidate for Congress in Essex County, the Sixth District.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 5. -- The report telegraphed last night of a clean sweep in this State for the Democrats is fully confirmed by later returns. For the first time since the enfranchisement of the negroes the Democrats have elected a solid Congressional delegation in this State.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Thursday the Chicago Southwestern roads pledged themselves to sign an agreement adopted then which, if put into effect and honestly lived up to, would do much toward keeping tickets out of the hands of scalpers at Kansas City and maintain rates. But it seems to have been violated already, and a whole lot of new charges were in Chairman Finley's hands this morning.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- The remarkable and long-pending widow's pension claim made by Mrs. Margaret A. Jacoby of Port Jervis, Orange County, has at last been brought to a successful issue. Her husband, Sanford Jacoby, a respectable mechanic, enlisted in the Seventieth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, on April 20, 1861, and was honorably discharged in July, 1864.

The Democrats have scored a superb victory in the Congressional elections. They have secured a majority in the House of Representatives of the Fifty-second Congress of nearly 150, if not more than that unequaled figure. The Republicans will certainly have less than 100 members of the lower branch, so that the Democratic Speaker will be embarrassed in the work of making up the committees, as there will be scarely enough Republicans to "go round."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 5. -- It was not the tail end of the landslide which struck this State Tuesday. The Democrats elect seven and perhaps eight out of the nine Congressmen in this State. The Legislature is surely Democratic, and the majority on joint ballot is variously estimated at from 15 to 40.

Application was made to Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday for the appointment of James McHenry and Edward C. Perkins as Trustees under a trust made by McHenry and others in 1871, in place of S.L.M. Barlow and Charles Day, both deceased. McHenry and those associated with him are stockholders in the American Estates Company, formed to invest money in real estate in this country.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 5. -- The defeat of Quay, through his man Delamater, has been the theme of conversation among the politicians all day. Predictions are being freely made that this is the beginning of the end. His own county has rebuked him by reducing the Republican majority one-half. His promising son "Dick" has been elected to the Legislature by the barest majority.
To an Associated Press reporter, who asked for an expression of his opinions on the results of the elections, ex-President Cleveland yesterday said:

The principal business block in New-Rochelle went up in smoke yesterday. It was the biggest fire in the town since the same block burned down fourteen years ago. The fire started in the cellar of the four-story brick grocery and hardware store owned and occupied by George Ferguson, fronting on Main Street, and having a wing extending through to Centre Avenue.

The prospect is that when the Legislature of this State meets in January next there will be in the Assembly 67 Democrats and 61 Republicans -- a Democratic majority of 6. The Senate consists of 19 Republicans and 13 Democrats -- a Republican majority of 6. This indicates a tie in the joint convention, and as a United States Senator is to be elected to succeed Mr. EVARTS, this has unusual significance.

Luther H. Cary, the sprint runner of the Manhattan Athletic Club, made unsuccessful attempts to surpass several amateur records at the Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon. He did not try to run 100 yards in 9 1/2 seconds, as the Manhattans will not allow him to do this until the gust over his recent run at Princeton blows itself out, but he went for the 110-yard, 120-yard, and 125-yard records.

The announcement was made yesterday at all the headquarters of the Socialists and Anarchists of this city and Brooklyn that Herr John Most and Lucy Parsons would appear at the Labor Lyceum, Brooklyn, next Saturday night. Flaming posters were issued, the top sheet containing a large red flag, on which appeared, "Remember the 11th day of November, 1887."

The congratulations that have poured in upon Mayor GRANT upon his re-election are worth considering. Those from out of town always assume that his election is somehow a "Democratic victory," and are indeed based upon that assumption. The senders of these may easily be pardoned for not knowing what is the real significance of the event.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- The product sellers accomplished more in the Provision pit to-day than on Wednesday, and the signs were more auspicious for bear profits than for any day in a fortnight. January Pork opened at $12.10 and closed at $11.92. May Pork opened at $12.80 and closed at $12.70. January Lard opened at $6.50 and closed at $6.42. January Ribs opened at $5.87 and closed a $5.85.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 6. -- Miss Jessie Preston and George A. Draper were married to-night at the home of the bride's Parents on West Third Street. The ceremony was performed under a floral shell, composed of white and pink roses, back of which stood a screen, on which were the initials "D." and "P." in different colored roses. The Rev. E.H. Ward of the Episcopal church officiated.

Persons who are in the habit of drinking imported champagne, either because they like it or because they have been taught to believe that no good champagne can be made in this country, will have to pay more for their cheering tipple -- that is if they buy it at any of the big hotels of the city. Two dollars a pint and $4 a quart have been settled upon as the quotations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- It is now definitely known that Gen. John M. Palmer will succeed Charles B. Farwell in the United States Senate. On joint ballot the General Assembly of Illinois will stand 102 Democrats, 101 Republicans, and 1 Independent. In the House, exclusive of H.B. Moore of the Forty-fourth and James Cockerell of the Forty-third Districts, who have affiliated with farmers lately, the Democrats have 77 members and the Republicans 74.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The report of the Naval Board of Inspection on the cruiser Philadelphia shows that not only did three of her gun carriages fail on their recent trial, but her air pumps have not proved satisfactory. The same type of pumps has been used on most of the new ships, and the same trouble has been experienced, notably on the Yorktown.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6. -- One of the peculiar features of Tuesday's contest in Missouri was the election in Jasper County of Mrs. Annie Baxter to be County Clerk. W.H. Phelps of that county, member of the State Democratic Committee, thus tells how it happened:

A TIMES reporter met Mr. Smith M. Weed, the Democratic chieftain of Clinton County, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening. Mr. Weed had been in New-York but a few hours and had found himself overwhelmed with cards, telegrams, and letters congratulating him upon his bright prospects as the successor of William M. Evarts in the United States Senate. When asked about the alleged bribery in Clinton County, Mr. Weed said:

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Senator Collins believes that Gov. Hill will be a candidate for the United States Senate, and he said this evening that if Hill was a candidate he would be for him first, last, and all the time.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Speaking at Carlisle to-day, Mr. Gladstone said that, if the clause contained in the Licensing bill submitted to the House of Commons last Spring by the Government had become law, it would have cost the country 200,000,000 to purchase forfeited licenses from publicans. Parliament, he said, is now wearing out its life. The Government is avoiding dissolution as a man with a bad tooth avoided dentistry.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- This has been a great night for Boston Democrats. They have crowded both Music and Faneuil Halls and have sung hallelujahs over the triumph of constitutional liberty and free government economically administered, and the defeat of sectionalism, McKinleyism, Reedism, Quayism, and the law of force, as exemplified by Mr. Lodge and his little bill

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- One of the most encouraging results of Tuesday's elections to the Democrats is the remarkable gain made in the Democratic membership of the United States Senate. It is all the more gratifying because it was unexpected. The Democrats regard it as shortening by at least three years the period under which the country must suffer from the operations of the McKinley bill.

So close was the vote in the Third Congressional District in Brooklyn, that it looks as though only an official count can determine whether William J. Coombs or William O. Wallace was elected. From the temper of both candidates and their friends it is likely that either will contest in case the other is declared to have the majority of the votes.

BUFFALO, N.Y., NOV. 6. -- At 2 o'clock this morning fire was discovered in the O.J. Wells Elevator at the corner of Ohio and Indiana Streets. The flames started in the east tower of the elevator from an explosion, which was loud enough to wake up the hundreds of people who live in the boarding houses and tenements in the vicinity.

The International Brotherhood of Railway Employes was organized in Boston Wednesday night. It is founded by men who were formerly prominent in the Steam Railroad Men's Protective Union. Its object is primarily to secure legislation, and it is not intended to infringe upon the territory of the distinctively trades brotherhoods, such as engineers, firemen, and brakemen.

The only State in which the Democratic cyclone of Tuesday met with much resistance was Ohio. A year ago the Democrats elected their Governor by a plurality of a little less than 11,000 and secured a majority in both branches of the Legislature. This ought to have put the party in a position of great advantage, and would have done so if it had used its power with wisdom and moderation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- "Is the Republican Party dead?" mused Ben Butterworth this afternoon. "Has rigor mortis set in! It looks indeed as if it had. But it is a lovely corpse." And he stopped to shake his head as old men do at a wake, with one eye on the corpse and the other on the table in the next room.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- The cornerstone of the magnificent Masonic Temple to be erected at the corner of Randolph and State Streets was laid this afternoon with the solemn symbolism and impressive ceremonies of the Masonic Order. The presence of the Sublime Princes of the Oriental Consistory and of the members of the Scottish Rite in full regalia and uniform made the display an imposing sight.

A.H. Muller Son sold at public auction the three-story brick building, with lot 9.9 by irregular by 22.10 by 100, 68 Bayard St. north side, west of Elizabeth St. for $18,000, to Rachel Behrens, and four-story stone-front dwelling, with lease of lot 29 by 100.5, 64 West 49th St. south side, east of 6th Av, for $15,000, to James Berchett.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- The Democrats having obtained control of the House of Representatives at Washington, interest naturally centres upon the question of Speaker Reed's successor. Col. Levi Maish, the present member who represents the Nineteenth Pennsylvania District, which comprises the counties of York, Adams, and Cumberland, was to-day a visitor to this city, and was asked:

Five children, ranging in age from five to fifteen years, were rescued from a wretched hovel at 229 West Sixty-first Street yesterday morning by Agent King of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and the father, James Kelly, who was found in the hovel in a drunken condition, was arrested. In the Yorkville Court Kelly was held for trial and the children were committed to the Protectory.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Never in the history of the Republican Party in Onondaga County has there been such a factional feeling as to-day. Many of the office-holding party men have claimed all along during the campaign that the feeling was only on the surface, and the day of election would show an increased majority in the county.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 6. -- It is more than probable that the matter of the marked ballots in the Fifth Ward of this city will be heard from in the courts before it is settled, inasmuch as the election of the State ticket will probably defend upon the ultimate admission or rejection of these ballots, which were thrown out election day against the protest of the Republican counters.

Our cantankerous contemporary, the Sun, continues to fulfill the description given by Artemus Ward of his kangaroo as an "amoozin' but onprincipled little cuss." The fancied necessity of keeping one jealous eye on the prospects of Mr. CLEVELAND and the real necessity of keeping one prudent eye on its own receding subscription list has afflicted our contemporary with a political strabismus so violent that it is mostly impossible to tell what it is looking at.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The report of the Commissioner of Railroads contains full information in regard to the condition of the several railroad companies coming under the jurisdiction of his office for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1890. During the year prior to his last annual report the Commissioner had been unable to obtain statements showing the condition of several of the land-grant roads.

In refusing the second application of Mayor GRANT for a re-enumeration of the inhabitants of this city, Secretary NOBLE makes a curiously-labored and strangely-muddled reply, which confirms the impression first produced that there is no disposition at Washington to give the matter a fair examination and to ascertain what merit there may be in the complaint that the census is imperfect. There was no occasion whatever for all this controversy.

The Grolier Club finished its former season in the gravity of an exhibition of prints by Durer, Burgmair, Schauffelein, Holbein -- old masters in the antique art of wood engraving. It began its new season last evening in the gayety of an exhibition of prints by Cheret, Willette, Choubrac, Grasset, masters in the newest art -- that of bill posting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Major Gen. Sohofield, commanding the United States Army, has submitted to the Secretary of War his annual report upon the work done by the line of the army during the past year and its present condition. After paying a tribute to the memory of the late Gen. Crook, Gen. Sohofield speaks of the services rendered by the army in past years in subduing hostile Indians and protecting emigrants He says:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Secretary Noble to-day sent to Mayor Grant his decision upon the Mayor's second request for a recount of the population of New-York City. The decision is as follows:

Prince and Brutus, two promising young leonine actors, were given a chance to display their ability with the other members of Prof. Darling's troupe on the stage of Niblo's Garden yesterday afternoon. It was a private performance, but there was quite a good-sized party assembled to enjoy the debut of the two infant prodigies.

ALBANY, Nov. 6. -- Gov. Hill was tendered serenade to-night at the Executive Mansion by the Democratic organization of this city known as "the Buffalos." The Governor had a house full of guests during the evening, and he made them a speech in which he said:

The steamship Teutonic was made fast at the White Star Line's dock yesterday morning more than twelve hours after the arrival of her competitor in the race for rapid-passage honors -- the Inman Line steamship City of New-York. The lack of knowledge on the part of her officers as to any attempt to reach this port ahead of the City of New-York was surprising.

The Angelus painting will not go directly to the French Government, according to advices received from Paris. The sum of 750,000f. is given by an amateur standing in close relationship with persons who represent the Ministry of Fine Arts; but this picture, together with others hardly less noteworthy, will be presented to the national museums of France by their owner or left to them in his will.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Trading on the Stock Exchange to-day was limited and prices were weaker. There were some attempts at realizing by recent purchasers who got in on the last advance, but buyers generally were inclined to hold off. Part of the weakness was attributed to the low condition of the New-York stock market and part to the condition of the local money market, which was particularly close.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 7. -- This morning A.A. Nickerson, aged twenty-five, and his wife, twenty-nine years old, drove to Pushawa Lake, seven miles out, and, taking a canoe, paddled across to the vicinity of some deer yards. In a few hours Nickerson paddled back, and in great excitement ran to a hunting camp requesting the people to go to the canoe.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 7. -- If reports be true that drift in from all parts of the State, both parties, Republican and Democrat, are determined to take charge of the Legislature. The success of the Democrats in electing a majority of the lower house has simply prostrated the Republican leaders, who are practically at sea so far as having a policy to count in any of their defeated candidates is concerned.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Mr. Barttelot says that Stanley's account of his brother's death is completely at variance with Jameson's account and Sorga's confession. Lieut. Baert, one of the officers who tried Sorga, says that Stanley's assertion that an English jury would have acquitted him seems an impeachment of the court-martial's fairness.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- William F. Sheehan has no idea of being beaten out of the Speakership, which he thinks should be conceded to him. Said he, in answer to the remark that some of his friends would prefer to keep him on the floor of the House:

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- John Christie, the Republican member of Assembly-elect from Fulton and Hamilton Counties, has filed with the Secretary of State an itemized statement of all moneys contributed or expended by him, directly or indirectly, in aid of his election as member of the Assembly. The amount was $72.90, divided as follows:

There have been many curious remarks in the editorial columns of our high-tariff contemporaries since they began to realize the extent and meaning of the political revolution. The New-York Tribune explains that the party leaders have "emerged from a protracted period of legislative industry to find that the country has been confused and dazed by the boldness and comprehensiveness of their policy."
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 7. -- Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles, Commander of the Military Division of the Missouri, arrived in St. Paul yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- The Democratic city Executive Committee meets next Monday night, and at its meeting resolutions will be presented calling for the expulsion of Select Councilman Peter Monroe, member of that body from the Third Ward, and William McMullen, the member from the Fourth Ward.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- With one exception the favorites carried off the honors at Benning's Park this afternoon. Jockey Ray was the hero of the hour, he riding three winners and a place horse. The meeting, which has been a success both from a racing and a financial standpoint, will end to-morrow. The details of the racing to-day are as follows:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 7. -- Pat Malloy, the Woodburn stallion, died at the farm of his owner, A.J. Alexander, at Spring Station, Ky., yesterday. Pat Malloy was a son of Lexington and Gloriana, by American Eclipse, and was foaled in 1865 on the farm where he died. He was a splendidly-bred animal, tracing back to Diomed. winner of the first Derby in 1780.

Congressman John Henry McCarthy was Judge of a civil court before he went to Washington, and now that his Congressional career is over he is going to be a Judge again. This time he will wear the ermine in the City Court. The little Congressman's friends in the Eighth Congressional District did not like the idea of shelving him to make room for Tammany J. Campbell.

Information from a reliable source from the Isthmus of Panama received by the last steamer indicates a period of great unrest at that place. In fact, but for the presence of a heavy detachment of troops from the interior, the latter being Colombian Indians, one of the periodic revolutionary outbreaks would have happened before this time.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7. -- Senator George G. Vest, who will be elected at the coming session of the Missouri Legislature to succeed himself in the United States Senate, said this evening:

When, in December, 1887, Mr. CLEVELAND sent his now famous tariff-reform message to Congress, he outlined with great clearness the ground on which the great fight of this year has been fought and the victory won. It is not necessary now to call attention to the courage with which Mr. CLEVELAND performed what he believed to be an act of duty.

A noble work, carried on by noble men and women, was the impression left upon those who attended the reception at the Babies' Ward Department of the New-York. Post-Graduate Hospital at 224 and 226 East Twentieth Street, yesterday afternoon. Even to persons familiar with charitable work, this department, with its thorough equipment, its devoted attendants, and its splendid results, was a revelation.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 7. -- W.C.P. Breckinridge, Representative of the Ashland district in Congress, was to-day shown a newspaper paragraph in which his name was suggested as a candidate for Speaker of the next House, and was asked if he would become a candidate for that office.

Five men were at work in one of the casements of the lower Fort Wadsworth, on Staten Island, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon preparing cartridges for use on United States ships of war. Suddenly one of the cartridges exploded and ignited about thirty pounds of powder contained in an open barrel. The small stone chamber was immediately filled with flame and smoke.

The Philadelphia American on the 1st inst. said: "We presume the glass manufacturers read the text of the new law for the suppression of Trusts before they organized their big combine, and that they had good advice as to its application to their case. To an outsider it looks as though they were running their heads against that wall with more vigor than prudence."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- The Thirteenth Church Congress in the Protestant Episcopal Church will be held in this city next week, beginning Tuesday, in St. Stephen's Church, at 10:30 A.M., when Bishop Clark of Rhode Island will give the opening address, and lasting until Friday evening, the sessions being held in the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association.

DUBLIN, Nov. 7. -- Mr. Balfour left Gweedore at 6 A.M. to-day and arrived at Letterkeuny at 10 A.M. There he had a long interview with the Catholic Bishop and received deputations of prominent citizens asking for railway extensions. Mr. Balfour, in a speech, declared that the present Government's period of office would be looked back upon as an era of efficient public works in the poor districts of Ireland.

Contractor John D. Crimmins has had the larger part of Broadway in his own almost exclusive possession for the last four weeks, and numerous complaints have been sent to the Department of Public Works because of the interruptions to travel caused by the openings in the street and the piles of earth and paving material scattered about.

Some Interesting experiments with geblite were made yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the Forest and Stream Club, Claremont, N.J. They were conducted by Mr. Emmons, son of the inventor of the emmensite explosive. He succeeded in showing that geblite could be used with perfect safety in both a shotgun and rifle. Targets were erected and fired at to determine the relative penetrative power of geblite and the best grade of black powder.

Wall Street had an unhappy time yesterday. Stock quotations went all to pieces. There was what old habitues of the Street declared to be "worse than a panic." It was in its effects virtually a panic. There was little noise, and no running of wild and desperate men through the streets round about the Stock Exchange, nor were there any failures.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 7. -- On the marked ballots cast at Bridgeport hangs the election of a Governor of this State. It is certain that the Democratic Senate will not take a step toward a joint convention of the Legislature until the Bridgeport issue is determined by the court. The controversy, if the Republicans decide to press it, will involve the Legislature in the gravest responsibility that has fallen on that body in years.

The official returns will undoubtedly show that the Democrats are to have a majority of eight in the Assembly of this State, and this will give them a clear majority of two in the joint convention when it comes to choosing a United States Senator. This is much more satisfactory than the threatened "tic," which would subject the Democratic majority in the Assembly to the temptation of increasing their strength by unfair means.

The British Admiralty authorities have shown good sense in not ignoring or underrating the recent trial of armor plates at Annapolis. Realizing that compound armor, which is adopted for British ships, appeared to poor advantage in that test, and that nickel steel carried off the laurels, they have asked the war authorities to conduct a new trial at Shoeburyness.

For the use of the negro voters of the Second Arkansas District a greenback ticket was provided. It was a handsomely-lithographed greenback, its centre a vignette of the late Judge Benjamen, who was murdered in October, 1888, and is exploited by Arkansas Republicans as a martyr. The ticket bears upon its face the following: "Election, Tuesday, Nov. 4, 1890.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 7. -- A terrible accident has occurred at Tai-Ping-Fu, at which place are situated the Government mills for the manufacture of powder. While the workmen were employed about the mills an explosion occurred, which entirely demolished the building. The loss of life was enormous, 300 persons being killed.

One of the oddest things about the upset of the Republican Party on Tuesday is that nobody seems to have taken the trouble to ask the President of the United States what he thought about it. Mr. HARRISON is ex officio the leader of his party, and ought to be more responsible than anybody else for its policy.

In the last few days the ability of a considerable number of persons to "live up to" the new tariff -- in the words of Speaker REED -- has been injuriously affected by a reduction of wages. Here are three dispatches published on election day:

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The Board of Trade returns for October show that the imports decreased 490,000 and the exports increased 590,000 during the month as compared with those for the corresponding month last year.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 7. -- The conferences of the Executive Committees, candidates, and leaders of the two parties begun last night were continued till afternoon to-day, and the determination upon each side to contend for the organization of the House and the control of the Legislature on joint ballot remains fixed. Each of the candidates for Governor to-day expressed the belief that he will eventually secure the office.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 7. -- Prof. Saunders, Director of Dominion Experimental Farms, has prepared a report to the Dominion Government on the effect of the McKinley law upon the Canadian grain export trade with the United States. He found that in spite of the McKinley bill there have already been considerable shipments of six-rowed barley.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 7. -- Nearly all the county canvassing boards have been heard from. Their figures show the election of the Republican State ticket, with the exception of Attorney General, by a plurality of about 9,000. The real figures will exceed that number.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Ex-Boss Quay's promising son "Dick" does not appear to be content with the notoriety he achieved during the campaign and election in Pennsylvania, and he has succeeded in getting himself talked about in Washington.

Mr. Charles A. Dana, the editor and proprietor of the New-York Sun, was a passenger by the General Transatlantic Company's steamer La Champagne, from Havre for New-York. A representative of the Galignani Messenger greeted him as he stepped on board. Mr. Dana was gratified at this visit, and expressed himself in a complimentary manner on the enterprise and excellence of the Galignani Messenger.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- State organization for the promotion of the Columbian Exposition is what has absorbed most of the attention of the men at headquarters this week. Big appropriations are expected from the various States. Great interest is to be generated and Legislatures are to be put under strong pressure until large appropriations are forced.

HELLNA, Mon., Nov. 7. -- The election of Dixon Democrat to Congress and a Democratic majority in the State Senate is the direct result of the stealing of the State last year by the Republicans. The Democrats made an aggressive fight on the issue and hundreds of Republicans voted with them to release the methods of their own party.

The first meeting of the Quill Club will be held next Tuesday evening at Clark's. The question to be discussed is significant. "How much of a Socialist are You!" will first be answered by Marshal H. Bright of the Christian at Work, then by Cephas Brainerd, Sr., then by the Rev. Henry Van Dyke of the Brick Presbyterian Church, and then by any member of the club wishing to participate.

The Holland Society gave a very pleasant dinner last evening to Gen. P.J. Joubert, ex-President of the Transvaal Republic, who is at present in this city. The place chosen for the graceful compliment to the Dutch-African patriot was the Lawyers' Club and the occasion was most successful in every way.

Some disappointment has been felt by the candidates for brevet promotions based upon gallantry in Indian campaigning at the fact that the list was not sent to the Senate for confirmation during the late session. It is no doubt rather strange that since the act authorizing such brevets was passed, more than seven months ago, the practical enjoyment of its benefits should be so long delayed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- A great deal of curiosity is felt here as to what sort of spirit will be shown by the Republican Senators and Representatives during the coming short session of Congress. Many Republicans express the hope that the legislators may come back next month sufficiently chastened by Tuesday's defeat to be ready to act conservatively upon all measures.

A splendid card is offered to racegoers at Elizabeth by the New-Jersey Jockey Club this afternoon. Seven races are to be run, as the fifth, having received twenty-one entries, was divided, one-half the horses making up the sixth race. The entries are numerous, the horses are of a good class, and there should be excellent sport. The entries and weights are as follows:

I observe by THE TIMES'S interview of to-day with Mr. Henry M. Stanley that the explorer censures Troup, Bonny, Jamieson, and Ward for not having deprived Barttelot of his command, or at least protested officially against Barttelot's inhuman treatment of the natives. In conversing with an American officer Thursday evening, Mr. Stanley dwelt upon this same point, and declared that military men generally should be able to properly understand his censure.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- There was a meeting of Chicago beef and pork packers in the office of Attorneys Adams Hamilton to-day. The meeting was a private one, called to discuss the details of a scheme which has been carefully kept from the knowledge of the public. The plan is to form a combination of the packers to sell out to a syndicate of English capitalists.

The twenty-fifth annual week of prayer for young men, appointed by the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association, will begin to-morrow.
