Special meetings for young men will be held every evening in the week at the Twenty-third Street branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, beginning Monday as 8:30 o'clock.

The direct orders from Rome in regard to the transfer of the Rev. Dr. R.L. Burtsell from the Church of the Epiphany to St. Mary's Church at Rondout, Ulster County, have arrived, and to-morrow that clergyman will take charge of his new parish.

In one respect, at least, the conduct of the Republican majority in the United States Senate has not been less violently partisan for the last two years than that of the majority in the House, but, owing to the time and manner of electing Senators, the retribution is not so speedy and complete. By the admission of four new States last year the Republican majority in the Senate was increased from two to ten.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The football game between Cornell and Bucknell this afternoon was the dullest ever played here. Cornell played a substitute team, as a number of the best men were still in poor shape from their recent trip. The Bucknell team had a fairly strong rush line, and Allen, Captain and left half back, played its whole game back of the line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- According to the latest story in circulation among the politicians, the recent campaign developed a marked coolness between Secretary of the Interior Noble and ex-Assistant Postmaster General Clarkson.

In the first session of the next Congress Mr. THOMAS B. REED will be about the only survivor of the Republicans who have been conspicuous in the past session. He will owe his immunity to the fact that the election in his district came on before the voters of the country had come to understand what he had been doing.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8. -- Edwin Booth and Lawrence Barrett closed the first week of their engagement here to-night. The play was "Hamlet," Mr. Booth, of course, playing the title role. It was one of the two Washington nights of the week, and several hundred persons from that city came over on special trains.

The John J. O'Brien Association of the Eighth Assembly District held a curious festival at their Grand Street headquarters last evening. The O'Brienites are now rejoicing with exceeding great joy over the fact that they wiped out many old scores against their fellow-Republicans, "de reg'lars," by the nomination and election of John Brodsky to the Assembly and of "Silver-Dollar" Smith to the Board of Aldermen.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Chicago last night says: "Railroad managers claim that the formation of the Southwestern blind pool has done more to avert a serious panic than any other single step which has been taken since money commenced to be tight. The blind pool commenced operations Aug. 10.

Among all the variegated nomenciature of the States no name is more expressive than Montana. It is a liquid word, a fulsome and high-sounding word. Its very utterance fills the rotunda of the mouth like a reverberation of the rocks. It bespeaketh a new development. Montana! Domain of the Mountains!

Herve de Nervainville, Marquis de Saint-Laurent, was at once the biggest and smallest landlord of Calvados, the most important personage of that department and the most insignificant and powerless. Into his cradle the fairies had dropped all the gifts of fortune but those two without which the others taste as ashes -- love and happiness.

PICTOU, N.S., Nov. 8. -- A disastrous fire occurred here at 1:30 o'clock this morning. It originated in a cell in the police station occupied by a Dutch sailor belonging to the Norwegian bark Prima Donna, who was confined to prevent his deserting from the vessel. He was heard crying for help, but before any one could reach him the building was enveloped in flames and he perished.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8. -- The Yale football team easily defeated the eleven from Rutgers on the Yale field this afternoon, although playing with five substitutes. Capt. Rhodes went to Cambridge, expecting to see Harvard play, with Lafayette, and four other strong men of the Yale team were absent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- Eight thousand expectant faces greeted the appearance of the University of Pennsylvania's football team on the grounds of the college to-day at the match between this eleven and the representatives of Princeton. In anticipation of the immense crowd which it was expected would collect, railings had been put up along the southern side of the field, and back of this only were the spectators allowed to stand.
The political atmosphere was cleared yesterday by two important announcements touching the nominations for the United States Senatorship and for the Speakership of the Assembly.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 8. -- The political complexion of the Legislature will have an important bearing on the executive and legislative appointments that must be made during the approaching session. Should Gen. Merwin secure the Gubernatorial prize, his appointments as Governor will be obliged to run the gauntlet of a Democratic Senate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Col. John M. Wilson, Superintendent of West Point Military Academy, has submitted to the War Department his annual report. He says there are now 289 cadets at the Academy, 4 of whom were admitted Sept. 1. The number includes one cadet from Switzerland and one from Central America.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 8. -- The reports from the West published this morning controverting President Adams's recent statement as to the result of the boycott against the Union Pacific were shown to Mr. Adams to-day by a Traveller reporter. He said: "The statement I made to you the other day concerning the loss of traffic to the Union Pacific Road is absolutely correct, but I have no desire to discuss the matter any further.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- The Gas Trust was this morning fined $10 and costs in the suit of the people against the trust, and Judge McConnell entered a sweeping order forever disbarring the trust from holding any stock, even a minority, in any other gas company or electric light company. This was in accordance with his decision rendered some days ago.

HOME-RETURNING CHINAMEN. -- Forward, between decks, are more than a hundred Chinese steerage passengers, mostly reposing in their rude wooden bunks, since it is too cold and rough upon deck for them. Some chat, some sleep, many are smoking opium -- a few are gambling. At a low table covered with a bamboo mat the game of fantan is being played by the light of three candles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- An afternoon paper says: "Early in the coming session of Congress representatives of a syndicate composed of Chicago, Montreal, and London capitalists will present for consideration a gigantic scheme, which, according to the present plans, will place Chicago and the Northwest in direct connection with the Atlantic seaboard by means of a ship railway, which is designed to connect the lakes with the St. Lawrence River and the Atlantic Ocean.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 8. -- Mayor Grant and party, with one exception, of whom hereafter, left here this afternoon by the Short Line. They made their passage rapidly through the city and gave no word or evidence of having had any success whatever on their gunning trip on South River near Annapolis. They exhibited neither birds nor rabbits.

Mr. Jephson's book is the story of that part of the recent Stanley expedition across Africa in which he alone of Stanley's Lieutenants had a share. It makes its appearance at an opportune time. Publication here occurred only five days before the arrival of Mr. Stanley, with whom has also come Mr. Jephson.

An interesting feature in the history of local municipal affairs has been gradually assuming definite shape in the big towns across the river in New-Jersey. It concerns the matter of water supply, and offers an interesting story.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The following proclamation has been made by the President of the United States:

TOPEKA, Kan, Nov. 8. -- The corrected standing of the lower house is: Alliance, 88; Republicans, 27; Democrats, 10. There will be three Republicans unseated by contest, which will make the House stand: Alliance, 91: Republicans, 24; Democrats, 10. On joint ballot the Legislature stands: Total members, 165; necessary to elect, 83; Alliance, 92; Republicans, 62; Democrats, 11, giving the Alliance 9, more than enough to elect.

An instance of the difference in the method of dealing with crookedness on the running as compared with the trotting turf is furnished by the action in the case of Trainer William McGuigan, who got short shrift from the Kentucky Racing Association, and now stands in the unenviable position of being outlawed from both branches of turf sport.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 8. -- Quay has just two organs in this city, the Commercial Gazette and the Press. The latter says editorially to-night:

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- As a rule, I believe the critics have discovered that the Cleopatra of M. Sardou -- or of Messrs. Sardou and Moreau, to be quite correct -- closely resembles the heroine of Shakespeare. Sardou usually complains that the critics know far more about his business than he does himself.

There is a decided appearance of "bluff" in District Attorney FELLOWS'S demand upon the Rev. Dr. CROSBY that he appear before the Grand Jury with evidence to support the charge, which he is reported to have made, that a Police Captain in this city has made $70,000 in a year by blackmailing saloon keepers.

CIVILIZATION IN SICILY. -- In proportion as Sicily is less advanced in civilization than Italy, so is superstition here more obstinate and childish. One of the strangest beliefs of the peasantry is that the soul has its residence in the pit of the stomach, and that to its struggles to escape from imprisonment are due the prolonged agonies of the dying, especially in old age.

Changing leaves and the gradual decline of the thermometer are not surer signs of approaching cold weather than the coming of many letters of inquiry about Winter resorts and routes of travel southward. All of these letters, so far, I have answered by mail, but perhaps I can anticipate others by telling in print the things that most of the inquirers have desired to knew.

It is nearly thirty years since spectacular drama found its home at Niblo's, and since then every great spectacle that has been seen in this city has found its habitation on the great stage of that house. Early in the sixties, Jarrett Palmer produced "The Black Crook" at William Niblo's old playhouse on lower Broadway, then the heart of the metropolis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $140,097,900, as follows: Currency sixes, $6,692,000; 4 per cents, $29,934,200; 4 per cents, $105,471,700.

People directly interested in the welfare of the Twenty-second Regiment are disposed to indulge gloomy forebodings in respect of the future of that once flourishing National Guard organization. "The further this matter goes," remarked an active officer in the regiment, "the more it would seem to appear that the Adjutant General made a mistake in reversing his order of disbandment.

" Tammany all" was the cry of the braves last January. Tammany almost all it is. The original plans and purposes of Tammany when the year began were to make a fight to capture all departments of the City Government at the next election. This was then set forth clearly in THE TIMES, and the projects have been carried out with the single exception of the Controller's office.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Nov. 8. -- The appeal to Ottawa for a commutation of Birchall's sentence having failed, active preparations are now going forward for the execution on Friday next. The scaffold is in course of construction and will be put up in the western yard of the jail. An enterprising Toronto manufacturer has made the doomed man a present of a fine black silk shroud, with which Birchall seemed much pleased.

That much-debated topic, programme music, has come to the surface again of late, and the everlasting dispute as to the subjectivity or objectivity of music has been reopened. No one can deny the interest which is added to a composition for the average hearer by the application of a "programme." People love to have a peg on which to hang their imaginations.

So frequently has it been necessary to condemn the quality and workmanship of the ready-made garments, offered in more liberal quantities each season, that it is with pleasure the excellent character of some of this year's work is acknowledged.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- The Chicago packers of canned meats held an important meeting this afternoon. All the large packers were represented, the object being to consider some action to be taken in view of the increased duties on tin. The meeting was also for the purpose of discussing the possibility of moving the stock yards and plants of the various packing houses.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- The case of Morris Stein, a young Jew who had taken out a writ of habeas corpus against Mrs. Ann Eichert to recover the custody of his bride, Annie Stein, nee Eichert, came up before Judge Hare for a hearing this morning. The question at issue was purely one of religion and is the outcome of a Camden marriage between the two young people.

Wendell Baker of the Berkeley Athletic Club reduced the American Amateur two-hundred-yard record yesterday afternoon at the Berkeley Oval. He has been quietly practicing for the last five weeks at the two-hundred, three-hundred and one-thousand-yard distances. In practice he had several times run the 200 yards in 0:19 4-5, the watches being held by C.F. Mathewson of the Berkeley Club and John Conolly, his trainer.

Now that England, France, Germany, and Portugal have redrawn, more or less satisfactorily and with lines more or less exact, the map of the Dark Continent, what have they gained that they did not have before? Efforts to subject Africa to trade and civilization are no new thing, although the opinion prevails among many Englishmen that they are about to engage in an enterprise that has never been attempted.

SHOULD CHINA ADVANCE? -- We held with Lord Wolseley, who has seen the Chinese and seen them at war, that the Mongolian race is quite capable, under certain easily-conceivable circumstances, of overrunning Continental Europe, of stamping out our progressive civilization, and of establishing their own cast-iron, immovable polity in its stead.

There were reported at the Health Department last week 671 deaths, 713 births, and 345 marriages, showing an increase of 69 deaths over the preceding week, and 11 above the average for the corresponding week for the last five years. The annual death rate for the past week was 22.49, in an estimated population of 1,648,948, as against 19.06 the preceding week in an estimated population of 1,647,998.

Mr. E.J. Hale, ex-Consul of the United States at Manchester, England, has recently returned to America after a residence of five and a half years in Manchester. In that time he was brought into contact with all classes of Englishmen and made a close study of the British people and the trade relations existing between the United States and Great Britain.

Many happy recollections were revived and many pleasant things were said at a dinner given to Henry M. Stanley by Mr. Edward A. Quintard of this city at the Union League Club last evening. The event was commemorative of the organization of the Stanley Club in Paris in 1878, and the gentlemen who enjoyed the dinner were the original members of the club and about a dozen of Mr. Stanley's New-York friends.

In "Sidney" Mrs. Deland provokes the reader to overlook the story in impatience with her philosophy, its old errors and old truths, but it must not be denied that the story comes very near success. She has turned the kaleidoscope of human nature for our entertainment, and the scraps of colored glass with which we are familiar make a new figure that holds our attention.

With the multitude of voters who have now indignantly repudiated the high-handed manner of Republican methods, from the Speaker of the lower house of Congress down to our Supervisor of Elections in the city of New-York, I rejoice that not only Democrats but honest Republicans throughout our land have given a stunning blow to the stupendous effrontery of the Reeds, the McKinleys, the Rowells, and the Lodges of their own party.

A CRANBERRY BOG. -- The largest cultivated bog in existence lies about six miles north of Wareham. This bog is 160 acres in extent. Other bogs in the vicinity belong to the same management. These bogs are all as clean as the tidiest garden. The long and level stretches, like a carpet strewn with white and crimson beads, are a most pleasing and novel sight.

JOHN MILTON AS A MASTER OF FENCE. -- In taking thought for the brain and tongue Milton by no means neglected the hands and feet. He was a man of his hands in the strict sense, and the small number of modern Englishmen who cultivate swordsmanship may be proud to reckon him among their patrons.

We have from time to time given examples of the way in which the tariff has been "worked" by its beneficiaries in a spirit of trickery and deceit that should make every honest protectionist blush with shame. One of the meanest of the devices resorted to is the omission of an article from the regular schedules, leaving it to be caught in the drag net of the tax on "component materials."
Some time ago we published the following extract from a circular issued by a firm of hardware merchants in Grand Rapids, Mich.:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The meeting at Bennings Park was brought to a close this afternoon before a large attendance. The fields, though being comparatively small, were well classed, affording brisk speculation, and some close and exciting contests resulted. The favorites again carried off the honors, winning three of the six events, and as two strong second choices captured the remaining two, the bookies were hard hit.

New-York merchants interested in South American trade are very much concerned just now over the condition of business. It is not generally known outside of this trade that some of the South American countries have increased their duties just as this country increased its duties by the McKinley act. Ecuador, Brazil, and Nicaragua have all done so.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 8. -- The Rev. Charles M. Selleck was retired from the rectorship of St. Paul's Church, Norwalk, and the Rev. J.H. George of Salisbury has been elected Archdeacon of the Litchfield County Archdeaconry, filling the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Rev. H.M. Sherman, who has accepted the rectorship of St. Paul's, in Bridgeport.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 8. -- The remains of Abraham Lincoln, son of Robert T. Lincoln and grandson of Abraham Lincoln, were placed in the crypt in the Lincoln monument at 10 o'clock to-day. Mr. Lincoln arrived in a private car at 6 o'clock this morning. He was accompanied by Edgar P. Wells, but no member of his family was with him.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New-York yesterday sent an important document to Washington. It was addressed to the commission of the Treasury Department at present considering the question of establishing a governmental Marine Board, a Department of Commerce, or a Board of Commerce. This commission holds its last meeting next Tuesday, at the Treasury Department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- The theatres have done more than an average business this week, notwithstanding election night and the interest in politics. Francis Wilson has added another comfortable roll to his bank account, the receipts at the Chicago Opera House not having fallen off during the third week's run of "The Merry Monarch."

A wild and wasted life received a check when Samuel E. Sinclair was lodged in the Harlem Police Court Jail Friday morning to answer a charge of blackmailing. The charge was made by Mrs. Ada Rasines of 116 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, wife of Antonio Rasines, President of the Twelfth Ward Savings Bank and a well-known man in Harlem.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The terrible accusations brought in this morning's London Times, in the interview with Mr. Stanley, against the memory of Major Barttelot, and the still more fearful, fiendish, and inhuman crime with which he accuses Jameson, have sent a thrill of horror throughout England to-day.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 8. -- To-day the Supreme Court rendered a decision which will almost completely annihilate the business of the New-England Mortgage Security Company of Boston in this State. The company, together with the Corbin Banking Company, loaned one Banks, a farmer of this State, $1,000 upon real estate security at 8 per cent. interest.

ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Judge Earl, who was re-elected Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals on Tuesday, has filed with the Secretary of State a statement showing that he had not spent one cent in aid of his election.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 8. -- At the conference of leading Democrats of the State, including Charles H. Amsden, candidate for Governor; Congressman-elect Warren F. Daniell, Harry Bingham, Frank Jones, A.W. Sulloway, and John W. Sanborn of the State Executive Committee; H.W. Parker of Claremont, Col. Charles A. Sinclair of Portsmouth, John M. Mitchell of this city, and others, which was concluded here yesterday, the election returns were carefully revised and the situation was fully canvassed.

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- Chancellor von Caprivi, who has been visiting Milan, this morning received a deputation of German residents of the city, who waited upon him to present an address. In replying to the address, which was presented by the German Consul, the Chancellor spoke in terms of unofficial frankness of the objects and results of his meeting with the Italian Prime Minister.

In a closely-printed document of 142 pages, bearing the number 470, Mr. James G. Blaine, the Secretary of State, answers the question relative to "the enforcement of proscriptive edicts against the Jews in Russia" in compliance with the resolution of the House of Representatives of Aug. 20 of this year. On the 1st of October the President had the answer transmitted to the House.

By the referee's decision, and his decision usually "goes," the Orange Athletic Club defeated the Crescent Athletic Club at football yesterday afternoon at East Orange, N.J., by a score of 8 to 5. It would be hard to find a Crescent man to-day who will admit that his team was defeated, however, and when the facts are considered it appears that the Crescents have good grounds for their claim of victory.

Congratulatory telegrams and letters have been received by ex-President Cleveland since election day from every section of the country. They all evince an appreciation of the fact that the remarkable Democratic victories were won on the lines marked out by Mr. Cleveland in his famous tariff-reform message in 1888. Following are a few of the telegrams:

The first annual meeting of the corporation known as the "Isabella Heimath" was held at the home, One Hundred and Ninetieth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday. The Isabella Heimath, founded by Mr. Oswald Ottendorfer, is an institution for the maintenance and care of sick and aged persons, without regard to sex, creed, or nationality.

" Britannia rules the waves" is a national boast which was true a century ago and remains true to-day, thanks chiefly to an incurable habit of the American voter of choosing little men and dolts to make their laws and regulate their commerce. "Columbia rules the air" is a boast which American inventors have set before them as the ideal of the future.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 8. -- The annual football game between Phillips Andover and Phillips Exeter Academies took place this afternoon. It was a game in earnest from start to finish and was characterized by much "slugging" on both sides, which resulted in the ruling off of James of Exeter. Andover's play was sharp and quick, and "bucked the centre" from beginning to end, while Exeter played for the ends, using long passes.

Edward O. Hunt, twenty years of age, a student the Illinois Pharmaceutical College at Chicago, committed suicide Friday night by shooting himself in the head. Hunt's home was in Garnett, Kan., where his guardian, John R. Foster, is the President of the First National Bank. Disappointment in a love affair was the cause of the deed.

CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The village of Carmel consists for the most part of a long, shaded street. On the one side lie the waters of a peaceful lake and upon the other stretches a narrow valley. At the lower end of the long street rises a hill, upon the side of which is perched an imposing-looking castellated building.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- A few days ago the Rev. Charles Scadding, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, this city, received a communication from Bishop Henry C. Potter tendering him a nomination to the House of Bishops for the post of Bishop of Japan. The Rev. Mr. Scadding declined the proffered honor and will remain with Grace Church.

It is probable that the most interesting building in or about Wall Street is the Sub-Treasury, and it is just as probable that the most interesting gentleman within that establishment is its cashier, Maurice L. Muhleman, who has served an apprenticeship of eighteen years in the Treasury Department, and who may consequently be expected to know a thing or two about the financial bureaus of the Government.

The County Democracy is going to keep right on in business. Its leaders allege that an analysis of election returns shows that there are more than 40,000 Democrats in this city who are opposed to the rule of Tammany Hall, and they think that 40,000 men make a pretty good nucleus for an anti-Tammany Democratic organization.

Certificates of election expenses are beginning to be filed by persons who were candidates at the recent election in this State, as required by the new law in regard to corrupt practices, and it is noticeable that these expenses appear to be quite moderate compared to the amounts which candidates have heretofore been supposed to expend.

Austrian society has been greatly moved by the Prince of Wales journeying to Moravia to pass a week with Baron Hirsch. The Baron is the son of a banker in Bavaria. He is now worth above 20,000,000. The foundation of his fortune was a railway contract with the Turkish Government. The story goes that for each kilometer made he was to receive a certain sum.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8. -- Thomas P. Grasty of the Baltimore Manufacturers' Record was in Richmond to-day, and while here gave some inside facts about the Force bill. He said:

The suit of ex-Assistant United States District Attorney William P. Fiero against Sheriff-elect John J. Gorman, J. Woolsey Shepard, and Henry A. Bradley, as Trustees of the Hydro-Carbon Gas and Fuel Company, the company itself, and James Fitzpatrick for conspiracy and fraud came up yesterday before Justice Dykman of the Supreme Court at White Plains.

To see how their photographs would look and to enjoy the pleasure of a parade from the Casino in Central Park to the clubhouse at Jerome Park were the incentives that drew out eleven teams of the New-York Tandem Club yesterday morning. The plaza at the Casino was the meeting ground, and there each team was photographed as it arrived.

THE PRICE OF A STICK. -- In 1759 Foote visited Scotland, and thought traveling in the north very irksome. But he found quite a crowd of admirers in Edinburgh, and what pleased him as well, the results in cash were satisfactory. About this time he wrote some of his best plays, including "The Minor," and "The Liar."
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The Junior Promenade Committee has decided to hold the annual ball on Friday, Jan. 30, and it will be the society event of the Winter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- L.L. Polk, President of the National Farmers' Alliance, is very jubilant over the result of the elections. In the course of an interview to-day he said:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 8. -- Rose Coghlan, the actress, talked this evening in an exceedingly interesting manner on the troubles, disagreements, and alleged sensational charges following the divorce obtained from her by Mr. Clinton J. Edgerly of New-York in South Dakota about six weeks ago. She said she only consented to talk in self-defense and to set herself right.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 8. -- Rose Coghlan, the actress, talked this evening in an exceedingly interesting manner on the troubles, disagreements, and alleged sensational charges following the divorce obtained from her by Mr. Clinton J. Edgerly of New-York in South Dakota about six weeks ago. She said she only consented to talk in self-defense and to set herself right.

One of QUAY'S newspapers in Pittsburg, the Press, displays its knowledge in this way: "The high tariff of 4 cents a pound on tin was enacted at the last session of the present Congress for the purpose of enabling idle capital in this country to be used in the establishment of tin-plate works."

DUFFY of the "combine" continues to entertain the public with his peculiar ideas of the "business" in which he was engaged in 1884. He claims to have had a transaction with certain representatives of the Forty-second Street Railroad, in which an offer of "cash" was made to him for a six-thousand-dollar bond of that road, which he did not own, and which had no real existence.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9. -- United States Senator F.W. Cockrell consented to-day to an interview on the late elections. "It is not a hard matter to arrive at the causes of it," he said; "they have been often repeated since the election. The McKinley Tariff bill, the Force bill, and the obnoxious course of Speaker Reed all contributed to the interest of the Democratic Party.

TRENTON, Nov. 9. -- A print that circulates in New-Jersey asserted coincidently with the announcement of the Democratic victory in this State that the result indicated a great personal triumph for Gov. Abbett. A cartoon represented him as making a successful reach, with something that bore a close resemblance to a rag-picker's hook, for the Senatorial toga.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- All doubt as to the Rev. Dr. R.L. Burtsell submitting to the decrees of the Roman Catholic Church is now at an end, and the reverend gentleman is already the beloved pastor of St. Mary's Church here. The doctor came yesterday, and has already made many friends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Secretary of Agriculture has presented his annual report to the President. He expresses a hopeful view of agricultural affairs, indicating the obvious benefits to farmers of certain legislation which he specifies. By comparing prices at Chicago for Oct. 16 of 1890 and of 1889 he shows a marked increase in the values of agricultural products, especially of cereals.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Nov. 9. -- Last night as Joseph Handenshild, driver for Schmid's Brewery, was returning from a trip in the country he stopped at McDonald's saloon, four miles west of the city, and there fell in with three young men, who asked for a ride to the city. Two of them got into his wagon and the third jumped up on the seat with him.

Arsene Houssaye writes as he talks, as they talked in salons -- when there were salons -- and compliments, madrigals, epigrams, fine phrases for their mere beauty, were aimed like the hooplas wound in ribbons of a game of graces. He is alone in that faculty, now that it is the fashion to write as one thinks; the last of a generation which made its realities of the artificial and the ideal.

When the Revolutionary War broke out and the people of our State were summoned to arms, the old militia company at Hallowell was not found in a very belligerent condition. A return of 26 members showed but 15 guns, 2 cartridge boxes, 13 powder horns, 5 pounds of powder, possessed by 10 persons, with 15 spare flints and 107 bullets held by 7 persons, some of whom had no guns.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- Agnes Herndon, the well-known actress, left her company in this city this morning in the company of Emmet C. King, her leading man, and took the train for New-York. She left a crowd of exasperated actors and actresses without a single dollar to pay for the food they had eaten while here.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The Times this morning publishes a three-column signed seatement from Mr. Bonny. The writer opens by regreting that Barttelot's brother has forced the disclosure of a painful story. Bonny says that Stanley only heard of the poisoning suspicions from him on the 26th of October in the course of a conversation on Barttelot's book.

WINCHESTER, Ky., Nov. 9. -- The case of "Joe" Davidson, a party to the famous French-Eversole factional feud, in Perry County, was taken up here yesterday. The Court House was crowded, the local interest being great, and hundreds of people from Perry and adjoining counties being present.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Public interest in the murder of millionaire Amos J. Snell was revived yesterday by the publication of the following extraordinary letter in the Sunday Herald:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Superintendent of the Census Porter seems to have decided, as long ago as when Quay was trying to postpone action on the Force bill in the Senate, that the population of the United States would not exceed 63,000,000.

At St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, last night Mr. G. Edward Stubbs, M.A., made known to this public a notable contribution to the steadily growing volume of contemporary sacred musical composition. The occasion was the twenty-second of the choir festivals which are set forward in St. James's on the second Sunday evening of each month from November to April inclusive.
The Democrats elect all of their candidates for Congress in St. Louis, and reclaim their loss of two years ago. It will be safe to put old Missouri down for Cleveland and tariff reform in 1892.

The delay of Congress to authorize the purchase of additional land for the sites of the new gun and mortar batteries required for the harbor of New-York may prove costly. An appropriation was at length made at the recent session, but Secretary PROCTOR was staggered to find $2,000 an acre asked for some of the land desired.

TEXARKANA, Ark., Nov. 9. -- Last night and to-day's developments reveal the startling fact that this town has for five years had among its citizens one of the most dangerous and accomplished forgers in the country. The facts have come out gradually, and the general belief here now is that the story is not yet half told.

All Souls' Church was crowded yesterday morning. The Rev. E. Heber Newton's references to politics, however, were indirect, but he promised to say more in his Thanksgiving Day sermon, which he always devotes to public questions. His subject was "Heaven Is for Those Who Fail on Earth," and he said in part:

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- What, judging from appearances, is a murder mystery came to light this morning in the township of Livingston, about six miles from this city. Four young men were walking along Northfield Road, about 8 o'clock, when they saw a body partially submerged in a small brook which runs beneath a bridge.

According to the guide book, Halifax is the capital of Nova Scotia, has a population of about 40,000, and is, next to Bermuda, the principal British naval station in America. It was founded June 21, 1749, and was first called Chebucto, an Indian name, meaning "the chief haven," but afterward changed to Halifax, in compliment to the Earl of Halifax.

" School Boy." -- The McKinley bill was reported to the House from the Ways and Means Committee on April 16. The bill as agreed upon in conference committee was passed by the House on Sept. 28 and by the Senate on Sept. 30, being signed by the President the following day. Read the newspapers.

Referring to a report that the Sugar Trust has "sent orders to all its consignees in the interior to meet promptly all cuts on the price of refined by SPRECKELS," the Commercial Bulletin says: "Whether this covers the understanding that has been carried on between the Trust and other refiners at Philadelphia since June last is not known."

Our high-tariff friends are now beginning to admit that prices have been raised. Up to election day, almost without exception, they declared that there really had been no advance. The wicked Democrats had "conspired" to induce merchants to put up prices, but they had been unsuccessful.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Governor-elect Pattison spent a quiet day at his home in West Philadelphia to-day, where he was visited by several of his intimate friends. In spite of his having gained considerable in weight while making the tour of the State during the campaign just ended, Mr. Pattison is at this time suffering severely from the effects of his hard work during the closing weeks of the struggle.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 9. -- It now looks as if Col. William Elliott has been re-elected to Congress from the Seventh District, thus freezing out the Republicans and giving the Democrats the entire representation of this State. It was at first believed that Thomas E. Miller had carried the district, but it now appears that the ballots cast for him were defective in size and color.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 9. -- Seven desperate negroes made a daring escape from the county jail to-day. It is the custom of the prison officials to make their prisoners empty their slop buckets at 9 o'clock every morning. The prisoners are let out for this, cellsful at a time. Jailer Andy O'Hara was the guard delegated to the duty this morning.

Mr. NOBLE'S last denial of the claim of New-York to a recount is highly disgraceful to him personally. It does not appear what advantage he can now expect from it politically, for it was made after the elections that showed that the difference of one member of Congress or of one Elector from this State was likely to be a very small matter for some years to come.

The Brooklyn Ethical Association held its second Sunday evening meeting of the season last night at the Second Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, at Clinton and Congress Streets. Dr. Lewis G. Janes presided. A number of letters were read from corresponding members, and then Mr. Herbert Spencer's name was placed before the society for election, and the election was made unanimous.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- A contested will case that has just been brought to a conclusion in the Common Pleas Court here made public the vagaries of a most remarkable miser. No character creation of a novelist ever equaled the personality of this man, and the statements which follow and which were all made upon the witness stand under oath would, if incorporated in a story, pass for wild romancing.

Whoever sets out to visit the new war ships should not overlook the little Petrel. She is at present lying off Tompkinsville, S.I., and though in hull she may not be as attractive as her more graceful sister, the Dolphin, she sits the water as lightly and with as much jauntiness as a storm petrel riding a wave crest. The Petrel is the smallest vessel of the new navy in commission.

Many hundreds of New-Yorkers have received with sincere regret the announcement that Mr. THEODORE THOMAS had decided to remove to Chicago. A very considerable portion of these New-Yorkers must have received the announcement with some remorse in addition to their regret, for it was also announced that Mr. THOMAS'S removal was due to the fact that an arrangement had been concluded in Chicago more favorable to him than could be concluded in New-York.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 9. -- For talking politics to public school pupils Miss Emma Ash, principal of the girls' division in the E.A. Stevens School at Camden, finds herself in a kettle of the hottest kind of water. Miss Ash has always been a zealous Republican, and though she herself cannot exercise a voter's privilege she never loses an opportunity to inculcate the teachings of the party she espouses.

Our misguided neighbor, the New-York Tribune, in an editorial article entitled "Things to Think About," tells its unfortunate readers that "free hides would mean" the closing of establishments "now in operation." One of the things our neighbor should think about is the folly of making such blanders as this.

There was recently published in the Washington Post a report of an interview with Senator BLACKBURN of Kentucky, in which the Senator recounted an incident in the career of a very eminent hat -- a high hat in every sense of the word -- that is not without a certain interest quite apart from the truth of the story.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- The Irish leaders, John Dillon, William O'Brien, T.D. Sullivan, J.P. O'Connor, and Timothy Harrington, attended solemn high mass at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross this morning. This afternoon a reception was tendered them at the Boston Theatre, which was packed with people, fully 4,000 being present.
The professors of the Geological Survey do not take much stock in the coal discoveries of Idaho. Prof. Day, who makes the investigations of this kind, says:

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 9. -- Every Yale athlete of the last twenty years, and almost every student in that time, will remember the gray-bearded man of nervous disposition and active manner, who had been a constant attendant at all the college games, and who has long been acknowledged as an authority in football and baseball matters.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Nov. 9. -- Expert Hill, Marshal of the State Auditor's office, is still investigating the crooked work of Circuit Court Clerk Clouston, and it is believed a complete examination will show that the State has been robbed of over $100,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- The defeat of Major McKinley in the Sixteenth District makes him the logical candidate of the Republicans for Governor next year, and it is hardly probable any other candidate will be considered. In reducing the Democratic majority in the rock-ribbed counties that composed his district, Mr. McKinley was remarkably successful, but 2,998 was a very heavy contract to undertake with hopes of success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Some political blunderer or mischief maker has given the cause of Representative John Quinn of New-York, who is a candidate for Clerk of the Fifty-second Congress, a black eye at the outset of his canvass. He is presented as the candidate of Gov. Hill, and it is asserted here that Representatives Covert and "Tim" Campbell will push him as the choice of the Governor.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- Nathan Matthews, Jr., Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee, was to-night formally placed in nomination for Mayor by the Democrats in this city. The convention was short, harmonious, and enthusiastic.

A defective fine set fire to the farmhouse owned by George Lord, at Colt's Neck, N.J., Sunday night, and the building and contents wore completely destroyed. The house was built about twenty years ago at a cost of $12,000, and the total loss is $15,000.

In your issue of the 5th inst. you use the sub-head, "Floridians Disfranchised" and explain that it was "by reason of poll-tax requisites and the multiplicity of ballot boxes with illegible names upon them.' This is true so far as it goes, but it does not represent the worst phase of the matter. The arguments in favor of a poll-tax qualification, such as they are, are quite familiar.

Two additional mistakes in the canvassing of the votes cast in Brooklyn last week were discovered by the police accountants yesterday, and one of them elected Aspinall (Rep.) to the Assembly over Reinhard, (Dem.,) while the other reduced the plurality for Coombs (Dem.) for Congress to 24 votes.

The Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua, whose headquarters are at 44 Wall Street, in this city, has received from its agent at Nicarauga, the Hon. Henry C. Hall, the following gratifying cablegram in relation to the progress of work on the canal:...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The November returns to the Department of Agriculture of rates of yield per acre make the average for corn 19.9 bushels; potatoes, 57.5 bushels; buckwheat, 14.5 bushels; hay, 1.20 tons; tobacco, 718 pounds.

It can now make no difference about the census, but it is rather a good sign for Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER'S moral condition that he feels himself impelled to say something about the Federal enumeration of the inhabitants of this city. He says this something in the current number of Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper, and what he says, though somewhat remarkable, is less remarkable than what he omits to say.

BUFFALO, Nov. 10. -- W.F. Sheehan was asked by a Courier reporter to tell what, in his opinion, will be the result of the capture of the State Legislature by the Democrats, so far as it concerns the United States Senatorship. He was asked if he considered Smith M. Weed likely to be the man who would be elected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The synopsis of the annual report of "Uncle" Jerry Rusk, Secretary of Agriculture, sent to the country for publication, omits some of the interesting language of the full report, and particularly some of the phrases that would have been serviceable, at an earlier day, in enlarging the Democratic majority in Wisconsin.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- President Adams of the Union Pacific says there is no truth in the rumor that Traflio Manager Mellen will resign and be succeeded by W.H. Baldwin. He also says:" There is no foundation for any report that the Union Pacific-Northwestern alliance will be broken, at least while I am President."

The results of the late elections are peculiarly complicated in both Connecticut and New-Hampshire, in consequence of their retaining the unwise requirement that a candidate for Governor, in order to be elected, shall have a majority of all the votes, and, failing that, the Legislature shall choose one of the two candidates having the highest number of votes.

At high noon yesterday Miss Anne Heyward Cutting, daughter of the late Heyward Cutting, was married at her home, 101 Fifth Avenue, to Baron Raoul de Vriere, son of Baron de Vriere, Secretary of the Belgium Legation at Washington. Mgr. Preston officiated.

Success appears to be assured for the great horse show, which was opened yesterday morning in the new Madison Square Garden. This is the sixth annual exhibition given by the National Horse Show Association of America, and it promises to eclipse all previous efforts of this organization.

Candidates successful and unsuccessful sought the County Clerk's office yesterday with the statements of their campaign expenses, which the Corrupt Practices act requires them to file. In the course of the day about eighty statements were presented to Clerk Moss, who has charge of the business brought to the County Clerk's office by the election laws.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 10. -- Joe Jackson, the noted train robber and partner of the notorious Rube Burrows, committed suicide in the penitentiary here to-day by jumping from a flight of steps to a brick pavement fifty feet below. He was to have been arraigned to-day with Rube Smith, another of the gang, for robbing the malls at the Buckatunna train robbery a few months since.

Mr. Willard's triumph, on his first appearance in America at Palmer's Theatre last night, was emphatic and decisive. He is not only an extraordinarily good actor, but he will also be a favorite of this public. There is no doubt of the sincerity of the applause given to his work. No competent observer could doubt that his personal triumph was equal to his artistic success, and both were far out of the common.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Another hearing was had to-day in the matter of the contest over the probate of the will of Artist William H. Green, who died at Patchogue, L.I., Aug. 11. The witnesses sworn were Dr. L.S. Edwards, Sanford Weeks, and George Hulett, all of Patchogue. Weeks is owner of the Ocean House and Hulett is clerk at the Laurel House, where Green died.

A practical demonstration of the sympathy the Irish people of this city have for their brethren at home in their struggle for home rule was given in the reception tendered to the visiting members of Parliament, John Dillon, William O'Brien, T.D. Sullivan, T.P. O'Connor, Timothy Harrington, and T.P. Gill, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Those newspaper men who have been favored once a week during the campaign just ended with the chance to read the Politician, which called itself " a thoroughly good-natured weekly journal," missed that entertaining illustrated organ of the Republican Party last week, and it now appears that it had been regarded as superfluous to print it after Oct. 25, the last number of the Politician.

HARTFORD, Nov. 10. -- The official canvass of the vote for Governor and Lieutenant Governor will be made by the Secretary, Treasurer, and Controller, these officers meeting for that purpose at any time during the current month, probably this week. On the face of the returns, Judge Morris of New-Haven, the Democratic candidate, has a majority of less than 30.

We publish this morning a synopsis of a bill prepared some time ago by Prof. C.F. CHANDLER, providing for a system of street cleaning in this city, which shows how the work of cleaning the streets might be effectively done, if a proper system were once established and placed in efficient hands.

Lieut. Meigs estimates that there are never less than 500 seamen in and about New-York. At the present time there are nearly 2,500. He believes inestimable good would result should a rifle range be constructed at Sandy Hook or some other equally favorable locality. It would then be in order for every war ship arriving in New-York Harbor to send three or four times per week a detail of men for practice at Sandy Hook.

Some of our Republican contemporaries regard with a natural but exaggerated apprehension the part played by the Farmers' Alliance and kindred organizations in the recent elections. They say that it is the beginning of a Socialistic movement in the practical and actual politics of the United States which may go on until we shall have more serious trouble than even that which exists in Europe.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10. -- In view of the fact that the live stock inspection law became operative to-day the utterances of W.L. Lane of Cheyenne, Wyoming, are of special interest. Mr. Lane owns ranches in Wyoming and Colorado, and is largely interested in shipping cattle. He said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- At the Stock Exchange the week opened on a dull market to-day with declining prices. The weakness at New-York was the principal cause of the dullness in transactions, frightening out possible investors, and the offerings were also light. West Chicago Street Railroad opened at 127 1/2 and sold down to 126 in the forenoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The first of Mr. Thomas B. Reed's servile followers to reach Washington with an explanation of the Republican defeat is Col. T.M. Bayne, a member of the Ways and Means Committee, and the man on whose account Mr. Bynum was called to the bar of the House and decorated with the censure of the vindictive majority.

There was a panic there -- not the panic of rhetorical story, attended by tumult and confusion and fierce yells and wildly-dashing recklessness -- but none the less a panic. Quotations went all to pieces. Conspicuous stocks dropped as though they were ballast from an over-weighted balloon. Nothing escaped; not one quotation showed strength; everything was weak and sinking.

Says the Chicago Inter Ocean: "The campaign was within a few weeks of its close when the Tariff bill was finally passed. Lies travel so much faster than facts that the Democrats had a great advantage. All sorts of misrepresentations were made as to the provisions of the tariff on the assumption that there would not be time before election to correct them."

The Socialists held a mass meeting last evening at Cooper Institute to commemorate the execution of the Chicago Anarchists on Nov. 11, 1887. The hall was crowded and numerous red flags draped with crape decorated the platform. There was also a long red streamer, on which were inscribed the words, "Workingmen of all countries, unite!"

Only thirty miles from New-York there lives a happy family of nine men whose isolation is almost complete. Their nearest neighbors are several miles away, and the nearest railroad, which everywhere stands for civilization, is ten miles off in an almost inaccessible direction. These men make pilgrimages to New-York only at rare intervals, and even then they hurry back to their quarters as if their lives depended on it.

The faith of those patient and hopeful philosophers whom the defeat of Grover Cleveland on the tariff issue two years ago could not dishearten is amply justified by the election returns which the Eagle published this week. The much ridiculed and derided "educational campaign" at last demonstrates its power to educate.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- Mr. W.P. Balch, a well-known horseman, committed suicide early this afternoon by shooting himself with a revolver in his office, in the Commonwealth Building, corner of Water and Devonshire Streets.

MERCED, Cal., Nov. 11. -- A horrible murder was committed Sunday night near Merced Falls, a small village on the Merced River about twenty miles from this city. John L. Ivett, seventy years of age, and worth half a million and without an enemy, was the victim. Ivett lived at his ranch near Merced Falls with his wife, a young girl of twenty, to whom he had been married about two years.

At John A. Cameron's house in the rear of the station of the Hudson River Railroad at One Hundred and Fifty-second Street and the North River there is a broken sapling with pieces of wire rope wound around each end. It was taken to the house late Monday afternoon by Joseph Heaney and "Jack" Eaton, who are employed by Cameron.

Jay Gould has got control of the Union Pacific Railway Company; at least that is what he himself says. Interested with him in the deal which has led to the acquisition of this property -- to there-establishment of his power in it rather -- are, according to his own statement, William and John D. Rockefeller.

The Quill Club, a body of gentlemen with turns of mind more or less Socialistic, met last night at Clark's, and after a dinner proceeded to a discussion of their several views on the subject, "How Much of a Socialist Are You?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Secretary Windom said this afternoon that his latest information from Wall Street was that the situation was improving, with indications that the worst was over. He declined to say whether the Treasury Department would or would not do anything for the relief of the money market, but admitted that he was giving the matter serious consideration.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- There are now 625 boats in active service on the Delaware and Hudson Canal. As a rule, there are three persons on each boat, making in all 1,875 people. Each boat is towed by two horses or mules, or 1,250 mules and horses for the whole number of boats. The hours for locking now are from 6 o'clock A.M. to 10 P.M.

Bears are this year showing themselves in many places throughout Norway. They have been seen in the neighborhood of Kongsberg; first at Sandsvaer, where, it would appear, they have done no damage. Then Master Bruin paid a lengthy visit to Iondalen. Three weeks ago, according to the Kongsberg Addr, he carried off a couple of sheep, and a few days later killed a heifer.

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 11. -- The peculiar and unjust laws in this State regulating the election of the State ticket and the consequent muddle in regard to the Governorship are causing a great amount of comment on the secret ballot laws regulating the voting at elections.
BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- On the Boerse to-day prices were strong, especially in the case of foreign securities, which closed 38 to 1 1/4 per cent. higher.

There is trouble at the United States Watervliet Arsenal. William Sellers Co., machine toolmakers of Philadelphia, declare that the new gun lathes, being furnished the War Department, are not only defective but wholly unsuited for heavy ordnance work. The makers of the lathes are the Pond Tool Works of Plainfield, N.J.

The demoralization of the stock market resulted yesterday in a tremendous slump in values and the suspension of three firms, one of them, at least, being ranked among the leading houses of Wall Street. Besides three banks became embarrassed and secured relief only when the Clearing House Association had come to their aid by pledging the united resources of all its members to tide them over their difficulties.

Gen. A.W. Greely, Chief Signal Officer, has submitted to the Secretary of War his annual report of the operations of the corps during the last fiscal year. The Chief Signal Officer is gratified to report a decided improvement in the condition and efficiency of the army as regards signal practice. Gen. Greely, continuing, says:

The statements of election expenses thus far filed by candidates for office at the recent election in this State show that the act passed last Winter to amend the sections of the Penal Code relating to "crimes against the elective franchise," and generally known as the "Corrupt Practices Act," falls far short of accomplishing the purpose obviously intended in regard to such statements.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 11. -- Solomon Richardson, the negro porter of the Wells-Fargo Express Company of this city, was rearrested today and lodged in jail. Last Spring a box of the company containing $14,000 disappeared mysteriously and Richardson was arrested, charged with the theft, and kept in jail until two weeks ago, when he was released on the ground of insufficient evidence to convict.

The St. Paul Globe is of the opinion that if the Democratic House of the Fifty-second Congress should send the Republican Senate a "well-adjusted tariff-reform measure," to take the place of the "odious concoction which the country has so emphatically repudiated," enough Republican Senators would join with the Democratic Senators to pass the measure.

In spite of the forbidding weather yesterday the attendance at the horse show in Madison Square Garden was very much larger than it was on the opening day. This was especially the case in the afternoon, when the single seats were well filled.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- At the opening of the Stock Exchange to-day it appeared likely that the worst fears of dearer money and a difficult settlement would be realized. The deepest gloom and absolute stagnation prevailed during the first hour. It was rumored that contangoes on railroads would be 9 per cent., and that the loan rate to next account would on no securities be under 7.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction, in order to prevent the hospitals in their department from being common to the sick and injured of other States, directed Warden Fallon of Bellevue Hospital to be strict in keeping out what are known as "imported" cases, and he instructed the ambulance surgeons to be mindful of the rule.

The gravest element in the situation, of which the decline of prices in Wall Street and the failure of two considerable firms of brokers have been the signs, was the discovery yesterday that three banks, one large and two smaller, were in debt to the Clearing House some $1,400,000 beyond their immediate means to meet their obligations.

As soon as it became known how emphatic had been the Nation's protest against extortionate and corrupt taxation, an interesting discussion was begun on the Republican side about the tariff plank of the National Republican platform of 1888.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Columbus, Ohio, last night says: "For several months rumors have been current that irregularities on a huge scale were being unearthed by the officials of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway reflecting not only upon clerks in the passenger department, but on former officials of the road.

The two great republics of Europe and America are friends, of a surety, and such as they never were before; yet their friendship does not preclude rivalry; it seems only to add a zest to their bloodless wars. We have seen France struggle with the United States at the Hotel Drouot over the possession of a little canvas, seen the Yankee win and the Gaul obtain the prize after all.

Similarity of name between people who are united by no tie of relationship seldom-extends so far as the first and middle names and the trick of signature itself. Mr. William H. Crane, the well-known comedian, however, seems to be doomed to be continually running across individuals who distinguish themselves from other Cranes by the prefix of William H. to their surname.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 11. -- To-day was observed throughout Plainfield as a mid-week Sabbath. Stores and other places of business were closed, factories were shut down, a large number of commuters remained home from New-York, and the entire people, even at considerable personal sacrifice, united in giving the day up to Divine purposes.

The public reception given to Henry M. Stanley in the Metropolitan Opera House last night was one of which even that famous and much-lionized man may well feel proud. It was enthusiastic in character, and it was tendered by a brilliant assemblage of representative New-York people. All of the boxes and the orchestra chairs were occupied by ladies and gentlemen of social prominence, and many elaborate and handsome toilets were displayed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- Judges Gresham and Blodgett this morning took up an application for a preliminary injunction in the celebrated patent litigation brought by the Pullman Palace Car Company against W.S. Webb, President of the Wagner Palace Car Company, the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company, and the Michigan Central Railroad Company.

At the stated monthly meeting of the State Fish Commission yesterday Commissioner Lawrence D. Huntington of New-Rochelle, recently appointed by Gov. Hill, made his appearance, and was welcomed by President Blackford in behalf of the board. Mr. Huntington's special branch of the service is the cultivation and protection of salt-water fish and shellfish.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 11. -- It is probable that the Democratic County Committee of Essex County will shortly be called upon to investigate the cause of the defeat of Messrs. Barrett and Hamilton, the candidates for Assembly and Freeholder-ship in the Ninth Assembly District, of which this city is the centre. The district is Democratic and should give every Democratic nominee on the ticket a good majority.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 11. -- Over two hundred delegates to the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor were called to order to-day by Grand Master Workman T.V. Powderly, who, after a few remarks, read his annual address. At the conclusion of the address the assembly adjourned till to-morrow morning for the purpose of giving the Committee on Credentials time to prepare its report.

The dispute between Daniel Frohman as manager of the Kendals and Henry C. Miner as manager of the Fifth Avenue Theatre over the possession of the box office of the theatre was aired in court yesterday when ex-Judge A.J. Dittenhoefer made a motion before Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, for a permanent injunction to restrain Mr. Miner from keeping his employes in the box office during the rest of the Kendals' engagement.

It is announced that the McKinley bill has already caused the closing of many tobacco factories in Cuba. According to the reasoning of the supporters of the law, this injury to Cuba involves a corresponding benefit to the United States. What it does is to raise the price of all cigars, imported and domestic.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- In accordance with his statement that he desires neither material advantage nor pecuniary reward for his discovery of a method for the cure of consumption, Prof. Koch will, in two or three days, publish a full account of his researches in connection with the discovery.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Ever since the Adams Express Company and Tom Platt's United States Express Company began the conflict of extermination last Spring, residents along the line of the New-Jersey Central Railway have been anxiously awaiting the result. Up to the time Austin Corbin obtained control of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway the Adams Express Company controlled the business in this part of New-Jersey, and the service was prompt, cheap, and excellent.

The remarkable reception accorded to Mr. HENRY M. STANLEY at the Metropolitan Opera House last night on the occasion of his first public appearance in this country after his return from his latest African expedition was at once a personal tribute to the intrepid explorer and an indication of deep interest in his own account of his adventures.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- Major William M. McKinley arrived in Chicago this morning and is stopping on Lake Avenue with his sister, Mrs. McWilliams, where he will remain for a week. On being asked to what he ascribed the Republican defeat last Tuesday and what influence the McKinley bill had on the election he replied:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- The thirteenth church congress of the Protestant Episcopal Church opened here this morning. Bishop Whittaker of Pennsylvania, the Rev. S.D. McConnell, the Rev. Edwin Harwood of New-Haven, and the Rev. George D. Wilkes of Riverdale, N.Y., officiated at the celebration of the Holy Eucharist in historic St. Stephen's Church.

BOSTON, Nov. 11. -- The stock market opened booming this morning, the first figures being nominally from 1 to 3 per cent. above yesterday's closing. The rally, however, offered too much of a temptation to take profits, and the people who bought late yesterday were soon selling freely, and everything yielded under the pressure.

The crusade that was begun against the green goods men last August by the United States Post Office Inspectors has resulted in the discovery that not only were the swindlers doing a large amount of business, but that letter carriers were in league with them. The collusion was a surprise to the inspectors.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- William Spalding, Chairman and Treasurer of the Democratic County Committee of Niagara County, published the following statement in the Journal to-night:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Some day between the 15th and the 25th of this month a Brazilian squadron, consisting of the armored cruiser Aquidaban and the cruiser Guanabara, under command of Rear Admiral Balthazarda Silviera, is expected to arrive at New-York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- While temporarily insane from ill health, Michael J. Sullivan, the wealthy contractor, committed suicide to-day with a revolver. The deed was done during a few moments absence of his wife, the unfortunate man drawing up the coverings of his couch over his head and then blowing his brains out under the bedclothes.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 11. -- The first annual meeting of the Players' League of baseball clubs is confronted with the secession of the Pittsburg Club. Indications have been pointing toward a combination of the National and Players' clubs in this city, and to-night the climax was reached, when Col. McAlpin and H.B. Rae of Pittsburg arose in the meeting and formally tendered their resignation in the Players' League.

ST. Louis, Nov. 11. -- The New-Orleans mail that arrived in St. Louis this morning contained two letters from the Mafia. One was addressed, in a bold, round hand, "Joseph Gazzolo, 1,109 Vandeventer Avenue, St. Louis, Me.," and the other, "Antonio Capestro, 501 North Thirteenth Street, St. Louis, Mo." Both these men are wealthy and prominent Italians. Following is Capestro's letter:

One of the most notable weddings of the season took place yesterday at noon in St. Ignatius's Church, in Fortieth Street, when. Miss Mary Cambreleng, daughter of Major Churchill J. Cambreleng, was married to Mr. William M. Robertson, son of the late John David Robertson. Additional interest attached to the marriage because of the distinguished families of both bride and groom.

Health Officer Smith detected a case of scarlet fever in the steerage of the Hamburg-American Liner Russia, which arrived at Quarantine yesterday morning, and sent word ahead to the Barge Office to look out for it. The patient was caught at the landing and taken to the Marine Hospital, whence he was sent to North Brother Island.

John T. Walker, Son Co., importers of raw silk and teas, at 81 Pine Street and at 67 Greene Street, suspended yesterday, with liabilities of $1,100,000 and nominal assets of $1,300,000. The firm is composed of John T. Walker, Joseph Walker, and John W. Combs. They made an assignment to William T. Ryle, without preference.

The recent dispatch of a large number of men from the receiving ship Vermont, at the Brooklyn yard, clear across the continent by rail to the Pacific coast, for the new cruiser San Francisco, is suggestive. It shows that while that coast is capable of building great battle ships, fast unarmored vessels, and powerful harbor defenders, it cannot provide sailors enough to man the war ships it constructs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The interviews with prominent Republican politicians which are just now going the rounds of the press do not appear to be of very much value. About the only purpose they serve is to reveal the exceedingly disturbed condition of the Republican mind since Nov. 4 and the very great difficulty the managers have to determine just what it was that hit them.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12. -- The new system of voting in Maryland is pronounced a success. Opinions from all sections of the State have been received, and they are uniformly favorable. Even the opponents of the law, who thought it a needless expense, are now commending it.

When recently asked for his opinion as to the causes that had brought about the disaster of Nov. 4, Major MCKINLEY, the "Napoleon of the tariff," was clear that it was not the new tariff "law itself," though "the misunderstanding of its provisions among the people and the studied effort of the free traders at home and abroad to misrepresent it" may have helped.

The statement of Mayor Grant, "showing all moneys expended or contributed by him, directly or indirectly, by himself or through any other person, in aid of his election," was filed in the County Clerk's office late yesterday after noon. It shows his election expenses to have been $7,238,95, made up as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A question involving the rights and privileges of Canadian railroads in the transportation of American merchandise over American territory was the subject of a hearing at the Treasury Department] which lasted from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. to-day. The Treasury Department was represented by Secretary Windom, Assistant Secretary Spaulding, and Special Agent Tingle; the State Department by Secretary Blaine, and the Department of Justice by Solicitor Hepburn.

Next Monday evening the Board of Education will take up the course of free lectures to the people, begun two years ago, and which have since proved very successful. With a view to assuring the greatest possible advantage to all the committee in charge of the lectures, of which the Hon. McBrien is Chairman, has placed the contemplated course under the control and direction of Dr. Henry M. Leipziger, the well-known lecturer and educator.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The Duke of Edinburgh was attending a Patti concert at Plymouth when the news of the disaster reached that town. He was immediately informed of the calamity, and at once left the concert hall and hastened to the various newspaper offices in search of further details. After reading all the dispatches that had been received concerning the disaster, he went directly home without returning to the hall.

BUFFALO, Nov. 12. -- The talk since election connecting the name of Daniel N. Lockwood with the Speakership of the next House of Representatives has something back of it. In this Republican district he was elected this Fall by nearly 5,000 majority to succeed Major John M. Farquhar, who six years ago beat him by 165. The Major was denied a renomination.

ELIZABETH, Nov. 12. -- The trial of the indictment against the New-Jersey Jockey Club terminated to-day in the Union County Court, and the jury is still out, with no prospect of an agreement. Judge Van Syckel charged very strongly against the defense and practically gave the jurors to understand that it was their duty to convict.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Mrs. Dr. Frank B. Loring gave this afternoon one of the largest theatre parties which was ever seen in this city. Eight hundred seats in Albaugh's Opera House were filled with the guests, who witnessed the performance of "Prince Karl" by Mr. Richard Mansfield, who gave the theatre for the afternoon to Mrs. Loring.

Seven thousand Irishmen last night trudged up the high hill on which the Oakland Avenue Rink stands in Jersey City and yelled a tremendous welcome to William O'Brien and his fellow-Irish patriots. The meeting was scarcely inferior in size and enthusiasm to the gathering in this city Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

As considerable has been said lately through the American press regarding my experiments in what the newspapers call "flying machines," I think it would be well before I sail to Europe to say exactly what I am doing.

SPRINGFIELD, Nov. 12. -- Harvard defeated Amherst at football at Hampden Park this afternoon in two thirty-minute halves by a score of 64 to 0. Capt. Cumnock lined up the eleven best players in Harvard University, and the same men, with the exception of Shea, '92, perhaps, will be selected to meet Yale on the same ground a week from Saturday.

The ceremonies attending the marriage of Miss Lucy Elizabeth Low and William Allaire Shortt in Trinity Church yesterday were of impressive dignity. The bride is the daughter of Mr. Edward A. Low of 150 Montague Street, Brooklyn, and a niece of the Hon. Seth Low, President of Columbia College. The groom is a son or the Rev. William Shortt, a clergyman of the Church of England at London, Ontario.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Provisions at night showed a little all around advance over Tuesday. January Pork was up 10c, January Lard and Ribs 2 12c January Pork opened at $11.87 and closed at $11.95. May Pork opened at $12.67 and closed at $12.75. January Lard opened at $6.40 and closed at $6.42. January Ribs opened at $5.77 13 and closed at $5.80.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 12. -- John T. Haight, the newly-elected County Clerk, was sworn into office to-day. At the meeting of the Board of Freeholders this afternoon there were several candidates for the Collectorship, the position left vacant by Haight's election, among them being Jehu P. Cooper, John H. Heyer, and Assemblyman William S. Throckmorton. Throckmorton was elected. The Collector's salary is $2.000 per year.

The Baptist church at Sing Sing yesterday had a centennial celebration, it having been organized Nov. 12, 1790, principally through the efforts of Capt. Elijah Hunter. In 1783 he went from Stamford to Sing Sing and opened his own house for a place for worship. Through him the Rev. Ebenezer Ferris, pastor of the Baptist church at Stamford, of which Mr. Hunter was a member, went to Sing Sing to conduct the services.

KEYSER, West Va., Nov. 12. -- Deputy United States Marshal O.C. Miller arrived here a day or two ago having in charge a moonshiner named William Fansler, the prisoner being one of the most daring and desperate of that class in all West Virginia. The chase and capture of Fansler constitute one of the most remarkable episodes in the criminal annals of West Virginia.

It is the avowed purpose of the new Constitution of the State of Mississippi to establish such restrictions upon the suffrage as to insure the predominance of the white vote at the elections in the present condition of the people in regard to illiteracy. To avoid the possibility of an adverse vote upon the instrument itself under the present suffrage system, it is not to be submitted to the people for ratification.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- The Emperor opened the Diet of Prussia to-day. In the speech from the throne his Majesty said that, in view of the friendly relations of Prussia with all foreign States, which relations have been further strengthened this year, the country could look forward with confidence to the further preservation of peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Census Superintendent Porter has come down from his high position, and his employes are now at work getting out the names of the residents of the Second Ward of New-York, taken by the Federal enumerators, as called for by the Common Council of New-York. When Supervisor Kenny called upon Mr. Porter to-day with the resolution adopted by the Common Council, the Superintendent could think of no further excuse for delay.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 12. -- Capt. William McClelland, the Pennsylvania member of the Executive Committee of the National Council of Administration of the Grand Army, has just returned from a meeting of that body at Detroit. According to his report quite an amount of business was transacted. A committee of three was appointed to consider the propriety of erecting a memorial hall a Decatur, Ill., where the Grand Army was organized, April 6, 1866.

The Linden Park Blood Horse Association had an extremely bad day on which to begin the last half of their Fall meeting yesterday. Rain prevented many from making the trip to this the prettiest and coziest of all the New-Jersey race tracks, but still there were enough people on the grounds to make the grand stand look well filled and to give the eighty bookmakers a good bit of business.

As the great horse show in Madison Square Garden advances, the general interest in the exhibition increases. The attendance yesterday was the largest of the week, and she spectators were most enthusiastic. During the morning and afternoon there were many children present, and these little people clapped their hands and shouted with delight as they watched the manoeuvres of the various classes in the arena.

One by one the small insurance companies are being driven to the wall by the big English companies, with their great capital, low rates, and bold and radical methods of business. The latest to succumb is the Knickerbocker Fire Insurance Company, the Directors of which met on Tuesday afternoon and resolved to wind up the affairs of the concern and retire from the field.

The Congressional elections of Nov. 4 clearly illustrated again the unrepresentative character of the United States Senate. The Fifty-second Congress will legislate for forty-four States, only twelve of which will send to the lower house delegations in which the Republicans have a majority. Those twelve, with their estimated population, according to the Porter census, are:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12. -- While there were no failures at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange today, it was one of the hardest days of the present crisis, and when the brokers finally left their offices it was with a feeling of uncertainty as to what the morrow would bring forth. The tightness of money was more felt than for any other day this year.

The Cape Finisterre coast is known to seamen as the most dangerous on the west coast of Europe. It greatly resembles Cape Hatteras coast. In speaking of a coast, seamen allude to the nature of the water in the vicinity of the land. Cape Finisterre shore is bold and rocky. Cape Hatteras shore is low. In the case of each shoals extend seaward for a distance of twenty miles.
