It is evident that the Corrupt Practices act has not put an end to the corrupt practice of levying heavy assessments upon candidates for office. Several of the candidates upon the Tammany ticket at the late election, including Mayor GRANT, have filed statements in which items appear of $2,000 for printing paster ballots and $2,000 for hiring watchers and distributing paster ballots.

When the clouds of Tuesday's financial squall had partially blown away yesterday it was found that one bank and two small Stock Exchange firms had succumbed. Some larger institutions that had been laboring heavily when the squall was at its height had succeeded in weathering the storm, with every prospect of needing no further assistance.

Acting as a Board of Supervisors, the Aldermen yesterday began the official canvass of the votes cast at the last election. President Arnold acted as Chairman of the Supervisors, and County Clerk Scully as Secretary. John N. Outwater was, as usual, selected as the expert accountant. Alderman Oakley and Flynn had candidates for Sergeant at Arms. The former wanted Stephen Manning appointed, and Flynn wanted the place for William Crommy.

The Tribune, having discovered from the columns of its contemporaries the full extent of the Republican disaster, which its own typographical facilities were inadequate to portray, has recovered its composure, and demands that the McKinley bill be nailed to the mast, where the people can see it and learn to love it. But our pious friend of the Mail and Express still betrays considerable agitation.

Purchasers who have grown weary of the advance in prices owing to the new tariff will be agreeably interested in the fact that the eminent carpet firm of W. Sloane will continue to sell all goods at old prices for the next thirty days. The Messrs. Sloane are offering in their retail departments their full line of goods at the lowest prices at which they can be sold.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12. -- The game of football which was scheduled with the Manhattan Athletic Club to be played on the 'Varsity grounds to-day was canceled by the management on account of the crippled condition of the eleven, resulting from the rough game with the University of Pennsylvania last Saturday. Contrary to expectation, most of the men were in good condition and played a very strong game against the reserves.

The railroad situation in the West has reached a crisis. Holders of railroad stocks, who have suffered in pocket even though the volume of railroad business has swelled to larger proportions than ever before, feel that something must be done. The rolling stock of all the roads is taxed to its utmost capacity, and yet, owing to the warfare in rates, the earnings fall short of what the unprecedented business warrants.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Gen. S.V. Benet, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of War. On the subject of smokeless powder he says:

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- It takes something more than a landslide or a tidal wave to crush the spirits of A.L. Conger, the representative of Ohio upon the Republican National Committee. "Why, I see nothing in the last election to discourage the Republicans," he said to-day, "nothing at all. Inspection of the returns show that the voting strength of the Democratic Party has increased? Not at all.
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The British torpedo cruiser Serpent has foundered off the coast of Spain. Out of a total of 250 persons on board only 3 were saved.
Sir Morell Mackenzie, the imperial doctor and highest known authority on the throat and lungs, has just published pamphlet in which he gives advice to public speakers.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 12. -- The Southern Pacific steamship Gussie, which was reported lost during the storm off the Nicaraguan coast on the 31st of October, arrived at her moorings here to-day uninjured except for the loss of her smokestack, which was carried away by a ninety-mile wind. The main cable then parted, and the ship drifted over the Cape Gracios Bar and settled on the sand fiat inside.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 12. -- The will of Thomas Hollister of Bristol, an influential manufacturer of that place who died ten years ago, is a curious document in its way. Under it a fund, now amounting to $70,000, was established, the accumulations of which must remain inviolate for twenty years from the time that the will was probated, the principal not being accessible for forty years.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12. -- The gray weanling colt by C.F. Clay, dam Laura Wilkes, (sister to Dandy Jim, 2:19 1/2,) dam by Young Jim II., dam by Daniel Lambert, has been sold by Cecil Brothers of Danville, Ky., to Crit Davis of Harrodsburg, Ky., for $750.

FATHER POINT, Quebec, Nov. 12. -- Capt. Lindall, commander, and a quartermaster of the steamer Vancouver, which passed inward this morning from Liverpool, were washed overboard and drowned on Friday morning last. The steamship Vancouver left Liverpool with heavy sea running and a head wind. The wind increased until it developed into hurricane force and caused the ship's speed to average only about seven knots an hour instead of fifteen, her usual speed.

A slight oversight nearly forty years ago was the means of bringing into court yesterday the ante-nuptial agreement of William Astor and Caroline Webster Schermerhorn, now Mrs. William Astor. The agreement was an important one, but it was probably not contemplated at the time it was entered into that its provisions should ever be made public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- It is expected at the Census Office that, before the end of the week, the final population figures can be made public for all the towns and cities in the United States having 8,000 or more inhabitants. In some cases the count is already so nearly completed that figures can be given for all of the larger towns.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 13. -- Josephine Hymes, who gave damaging testimony in the Rosenbaum divorce case, had a hearing to-day on the charge of perjury. She had testified that Harry Cotterell, the co-respondent, visited Mrs. Rosenbaum at her house daily from June 26, 1889, to March, 1890. The stenographer's notes were put in as evidence against her, and then Mrs. Rosenbaum was called.

There was almost as much news in political circles in Brooklyn yesterday as there was before the recent election, and the gossips around the public buildings had plenty to talk about. The favorite subject of discussion was an article in the Democratic ring organ, the Citizen, evidently inspired, in which David B. Hill was boomed as the proper man for United States Senator.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 13. -- The disgraceful fight at the Michigan Military Academy at Ann Arbor last night between 1,000 students and a squad of the State militia has proved much more serious than was at first supposed. It has resulted in the killing of one student and the serious injury of a dozen more.

ELLENDALE, N.D., Nov. 13. -- The Republican leaders of this State are thoroughly alarmed at the political aspect, and are trying to call a halt in the factional wrangling that is fast disintegrating the party. M.N. Johnson, the Congressional candidate, would have been defeated by the bolting Republican newspapers and politicians had it not been for the specially earnest support given him by the Norwegians, to which nationality he belongs by birth.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Congressman John Sanford, who was the Republican candidate for re-election in the Twentieth Congressional District, has filed his statement of election expenses with the Secretary of State.

ELIZABETH, Nov. 13. -- One act in Pete De Lacy's farce, now being enacted in the Union County Court here, terminated this evening, when the jury in the New-Jersey Jockey Club's case, after having been locked up for thirty hours, came into court and informed Judge Van Syokel that it was utterly impossible for them to agree.
Mr. Gustav H. Schwab, Treasurer of the People's Municipal League, made public yesterday the following report of the receipts and disbursements of the league:

There were two topics of general conversation among the regular attendants at the horse show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. The first assumed the form of a unanimous protest against the length of time consumed in making the awards. A majority of the spectators come to the Garden with the express purpose of seeing the jumping.

The Aldermen, acting as a Board of Supervisors, proceeded yesterday with the official count of the votes cast at the last election. The canvass of the First, Second, Fifth, and Sixth Assembly Districts was completed, the Third and Fourth Districts having been counted on Wednesday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 13. -- Among the first to arrive to participate in the banquet to Judge Thurman were ex-President Cleveland and Col. Lamont, who reached here from New-York at 8:30 o'clock this morning in the private car of Senator Brice, who, owing to business engagements, found it impossible to accompany the party.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Nov. 13. -- This is a busy day about the Woodstock Jail. The Sheriff's officers were early astir this morning superintending the erection of the scaffold and arranging the other preliminaries for the execution of Birchall, which is to take place at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning. Thomas Ratley, who is to be the executioner, arrived in town from Toronto this afternoon.

The fact that Jay Gould and capitalists interested with him will soon assume control of the Union Pacific Railroad, as announced exclusively in THE TIMES of Wednesday, is now accepted without question by well-informed railroad and Wall Street men in spite of a few vague and evasive denials.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- At the annual meeting of the West End Street Railway Company to-day the old Board of Directors was re-elected, and the stockholders also approved plans for an elevated road. New stock will be issued for an elevated road to the amount of $1,500,000 next year and $500,000 the year following.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Soon after the death of Schuyler B. Steers, a wealthy and philanthropic resident of Cooperstown, an action was begun to obtain a judicial construction of certain clauses of his will -- more particularly those making bequests for educational, charitable, and religious purposes. Surrogate A.C. Tennant of Otsego County referred the case to W.H. Johnson for a hearing and report.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- The annual Fall meeting of the Board of Trustees of Princeton College, held to-day, proved to be a very important one. Dr. Patton presided, and in his report to the board referred to the exceedingly flourishing condition of the college, giving statistics which showed a great increase in the number of students over last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- The Protestant Episcopal Church Congress wrestled to-day with the problems of internal economy. This morning the question "Do We Need a Provincial System" was asked and answered in a variety of ways. The advocates of a provincial system were but two in number, the Rev. J.H. Egar, D.D., of Rome, N.Y., and the Rev. Joseph Carey of Saratoga, N.Y.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Thursday,Nov. 13.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- Association Hall was packed this evening with an audience gathered to hear Phillips Brooks of Boston and Bishop Coleman of Delaware discuss "Conditions of Growth in Missionary Lands." Liberal and Low Church views were most prominent in the discussion, although Bishops Coleman and Talbot won hearty applause for their strong churchly views.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 13. -- A Washington dispatch regarding the fraudulent Alliance men who secured their election as Representatives caused considerable stir here among Alliance leaders. Investigation reveals the fact that there is cause for this disturbance.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Congressman Tracey, who served in the Fiftieth and the Fifty-first Congress and has been re-elected by double the usual majority, says in the Argus:

The celebration of the seventy-seventh birthday of ALLEN G. THURMAN at Columbus, Ohio, yesterday was a somewhat notable occasion. It naturally assumed a certain political character and drew together a distinguished company of Democrats who gathered to pay their respects to the veteran statesman whom they are fond of calling "the old Roman," and at the same time to congratulate each other on the recent victory of their party.

A dispatch to the Evening Post reports Mr. WINDOM as intending to urge on Congress very strongly in his approaching report the policy of the Sherman bill with reference to the national banks This bill reduces the amount of bonds to be held by each bank as a condition of organization to $1,000, and permits the issue of circulating notes up to the par value of the bonds deposited with the Treasury as security.

There was an unexpectedly good track at Linden yesterday, and there was a big crowd on hand to enjoy the sport in spite of the fact that the card was a light one. The betting was lively, too, and the public left the course pretty well satisfied, for three favorites and two strong second choices were winners, Prince Edward being the only successful horse who was at anything like long odds.
CORUNNA, Nov. 13. -- The bodies of twenty-one sailors of the war ship Serpent have been washed ashore. No bodies of officers have yet been found.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- The second day's session of the seventy-second annual meeting of the General Missionary Committee of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church was opened to-day with devotional exercises conducted by the Rev. A.D. Vail of New-York. Bishop Merrill was in the chair. The matter of apportioning the appropriation decided upon yesterday among the various fields was the first business taken up.

Senator SPOONER of Wisconsin is quoted as expressing his "entire satisfaction with President HARRISON." He has been credited with aspiring to be a Judge of the Supreme Court in place of the late Mr. MILLER, and if he has aspirations that way he can hardly afford to be dissatisfied with the President just yet.

A curious struggle has been going on in the columns of the New-York Tribune between two theories as to the cause of the present condition of the stock market. One theory was that the decline was due to the defeat of the Republican Party in the elections, and the other took into account certain things that have engaged attention in the world of finance and speculation during the last few months.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 13. -- A saloon in Canfield Street, near William, in this city, was the scene of a double tragedy just before midnight Wednesday. The place is kept by Catharine Knable, a German widow. Among those who dropped in occasionally to purchase beer at her bar was Robert Kehr, an Orange grocery clerk and a man of family, who had not, however, lived with his wife and children for three years.

The twenty-seventh annual meeting of the New-York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled was held yesterday afternoon at the institution, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street. In the absence of President William H. Osborn, who is confined to his home by illness, there was no election for that office. Other offices were filled as follows:

BUFFALO, Nov. 13. -- Some of the Democrats of Western New-York, in discussing the question of what Democrat shall succeed William M. Evarts in the United States Senate, have suggested the name of Wilson S. Bissell of this city, formerly the law partner of Mr. Cleveland. When this suggestion was conveyed to Mr. Bissell he remarked:

The card for this afternoon shows the largest fields of the meeting, and there will certainly be a big crowd at the track, for the fields give promise of good contests in every event. The entries and weights for each race are as follows:

Speaker REED now joins Senator DOLPH in complaining about the ingratitude of the protected manufacturers who "helped to set the people in a panic about the McKinley bill after they had obtained just what they needed and wanted at the hands of the majority in Congress." This ingratitude consisted, we presume, in raising the prices of their goods, for Mr. REED says their action was taken "for the sake of a little temporary advantage."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- A peculiar phenomenon has been observed in this city to-day in the presence of an investigating committee of the Presbyterian Church, appointed at the General Assembly of 1890, investigating the truthfulness of the report of an investigating committee appointed by the General Assembly of 1889. This report was presented last May at Saratoga, the subject of investigation being the Board of Publication of the Presbyterian Church, with headquarters in this city.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The Times publishes the full text of Assad Farran's affidavit. After describing Barttelot's cruelties, it deals with the Jameson cannibal affair at Ribakiba.

More evidence is given in the statements filed yesterday that the system of assessing candidates for expenses flourished almost unchecked in the late municipal campaign. Controller MYERS was supposed to have been renominated by all parties on his merits, and he was elected practically without opposition.

A rush of candidates' statements of expenses is expected to-day at the County Clerk's office. There have been filed so far 235 statements. According to the provisions of the Corrupt Practices act the statements must be filed by to-night, and the candidates neglecting to comply with the law are guilty of a misdemeanor, and, if successful in the election, forfeit their offices.
LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Additional details regarding the loss of the British torpedo cruiser Serpent have been received here from Corunna.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- The Street looked better to-day than it has for several days. The whole day was a feverish one, but there was a general undertone that denoted strength. Had it not been for the bad break in North American the whole list would undoubtedly have closed in better shape.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13. -- It is believed by many that if the legality of the recent State election was questioned in court the entire proceedings would be set down as unconstitutional, and therefore void. The Cooper law has one clause which is believed especially to violate the Constitution of the State. It reads as follows:
Upon one subject -- a subject of the gravest importance to the Democratic Party -the speakers at the Thurman banquet last night united in giving sage counsel. Said Mr. CLEVELAND:
CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- A crisis was reached this week in the history of the World's Columbian Exposition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Particulars have just been received at the Navy Department of an important trial of American made armor piercing projectiles at the Annapolis proving grounds a few days ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- The Medical News of this city, issued to-day, contains a special cable dispatch from Berlin giving an exact translation of Prof. Koch's paper in the Deutsche Medicinische Wochenschrift of to-day. This, furnished exclusively to THE TIMES, is as follows:

LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- Three men were killed here this morning and four were severely injured by the explosion of twenty-five pounds of dynamite and the same amount of giant powder. The fatality occurred at Custer's stone quarry in the southwestern part of the town. The explosives were stored in a small shed on a ledge above the quarry, and two men were in the structure thawing out dynamite cartridges.

WILTON, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Augustus W. Merwin of this town is a man who is unwilling to take an office on a technicality. At the recent election Mr. Merwin was the Democratic candidate for Representative. When the ballots were counted it was found that on those cast for his Republican opponent the word "for" appeared before the word "Representative."

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Henry D. Minot, who was killed in the accident on the Pennsylvania Railroad near New-Florence yesterday morning, was a man of considerable prominence in the West, Southwest, and Northwest.

A reappraisment case of an unusually interesting character has just been decided by the Board of General Appraisers. It involved the fixing of the value for dutiable purposes upon several thousand unmounted pearls, fresh from the fisheries. There was more than a quart of the precious specimens of deep sea treasure, which were contained in several packages wrapped in jeweler's tissue paper and carried in two silk handkerchiefs.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- The Boston Pilot has been purchased by Patrick Donahue, editor of Donahue's Magazine, who owned the property a number of years ago. It passed out of Mr. Donahue's hands when he became financially embarrassed, owing to many poor people savings which had been left in his hands by small depositors.

The National League for the Protection of American Institutions, which is making strenuous efforts to bring about legislation to prevent national and State appropriations for sectarian purposes, met at the offices of the league, 140 Nassau Street, Thursday, elected officers for the coming year, and adopted a very interesting report of the General Secretary, summarizing the work of the league for the past six months.

Mr. Richard Anthony of the firm of E. H. Anthony, wholesale dealers in photographers' supplies at 591 Broadway, said to a TIMES reporter yesterday that the increased duty on albumenized paper has had no depressing effect on the demand from domestic consumers, although the price had been raised from $32 to $37 per ream.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- The long contest for the removal of the New-England Railroad tracks at Church Street was ended to-day by an agreement of counsel, under which the tracks are to be removed by Dec. 1 and suitable damages are to be awarded by the Asylum Street Bridge Commission. All legal proceedings are to be dropped, including those in the Federal courts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- "Is the Bible Infallible?" "Did Moses Write All of the Pentateuch?" Such were the radical questions in the course of the Church Congress debate on "Positive Gains of Biblical Criticism" this morning.

The publication of the circular inviting influential representatives of the Western and Southwestern railroads to a conference at the residence of J. Pierpont Morgan in this city has been deferred for a day or two out of deference to some of the managers of the railroads interested, who think that they can effect the necessary agreement and reforms without the intercession of New-York bankers.

ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- Edward Murphy, Jr., and Senator John J. Linson of Kingston, Ulster County, had a conference with Gov. Hill this afternoon. The Governor said it was of a private nature and Senator Linson refused to be interviewed. It is understood that both Assemblymen in Mr. Linson's district favor Smith M. Weed for United States Senator. It was to secure their opposition to Mr. Weed, it is reported, that the conference was held.

SPOKANE FALLS, Wash., Nov. 14. -- George Hazzard of Tacoma is in the city, and says arrangements have been concluded and capital raised by a syndicate of St. Petersburg (Russia) capitalists and some prominent New-York railroad magnates, among whom is mentioned Henry Villard, to build a railroad from Puget Sound to Alaska.

The Legislature of Alabama will be organized Nov. 18. The candidates for Speaker of the House are Col. N.N. Clements of Tuscaloosa, the Hon Francis L. Pettus of Selma, and the Hon. H.H. Brown of Birmingham. The leading candidates for the United States Senatorship are the present incumbent, Mr. Pugh, and Gov. Seay. Ex-Gov. Watts is also a candidate.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Intelligence has been received here that another person was saved from the wreck of the Serpent, in addition to the three who wore known to have reached the shore. These, as far as known, are he only survivors of the disaster. The survivors are unable to give any details of the disaster, except that the vessel was going ahead at full speed when she struck the rocks.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Nov. 14. -- Reginald Birchall was hanged in the jail yard here this morning. His wife spent the greater part of the night in the cell with him, but withdrew at an early hour in the morning after a most affecting farewell.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 14. -- A collision occurred on the Pennsylvania Railroad, near Florence, Penn., shortly before 7 o'clock this morning between the first and second sections of the Western express, killing two passengers and injuring eighteen others. Their names are:

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 14. -- Mrs. Benjamin Harrison has been greatly honored to-day. Two receptions were given to her as the President of the committee of ladies of the various cities to raise money for the great medical school to be established in connection with the Johns Hopkins University.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- The "black ballot" episode of 1882, which created considerable excitement at the time, cannot be treated as analogous to the secret ballot controversy now in progress in Bridgeport. Ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller headed the Democratic State ticket in 1882, running against Gen. William H. Bulkeley of this city, the regular Republican candidate.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- At a recent meeting of the Citizens' Association of this city, a committee was appointed to solicit funds for and super-intend the erection of a statue of Mrs. Emma Willard in Seminary Park. This committee has been incorporated under the name of the Emma Willard Statue Association, and is ready to receive subscriptions and transact all business connected with the erection of this statue.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- That Mr. Cleveland entirely captured the Ohio Democracy is now conceded on all sides.

The grand Horse Show which has been held at the Madison Square Amphitheatre the present week, has been the most wonderful exhibition ever given in this country, both as to the quality of the audiences and nature of the exhibits. Night after night thousands of the very best people of this country have been present, dressed in evening costume, and nearly all who attended were well bred, highly educated, and cultivated.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Mrs. Jameson writes to the papers that as the Emin Relief Committee appears to consider that the duty of refutation devolves upon her she asks the papers to insert a letter from her husband, who died a fortnight after writing it, and who, therefore, was unable to take the further steps which he intended to clear his character.

How fascinating the horse show is to many people is shown in the fact that many persons come early in the day, bring their luncheons with them, and remain until the night performance is over. These persons are known as "the campers," and for the most part they sit stolidly, looking at the arena, without any other manifestation of the satisfaction they must feel.

The leading slaughterers and provision merchants of Chicago, PHILIP D. ARMOUR and NELSON MORRIS, both Republicans, recently expressed their disapproval of the McKinley tariff law. Their action greatly displeased the unbending high-tariff organ in that city, the Inter Ocean, which spoke out in this way:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- That the Indians in Dakota are in a state of unrest and revolt so strong as to lead the officers of the Indian Office to fear a Winter outbreak is evidence enough of the extent of the agitation among them of the notion that an Indian Messiah is on the way, and that he is to make them independent of Government beef and contract blankets.

Mr. WILLIAM WALTER PHELPS is another Republican who has forgotten the Senate Tariff bill of 1888. In trying to explain the result of the election he says: "The Republicans were promised a revision of the tariff, and they expected that the revision was to be in the shape of a reduction, and a large reduction.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 14. -- One hundred and fifty carloads of wheat are leaving Manitoba daily, and soon the figures will run up to 200 carloads. This is the largest wheat movement yet. It indicates that the Manitoban farmer is collecting his earnings. Financial papers think the large wheat crops should not lead people into extravagances in the matter of wheat growing.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14. -- At the Bay District track to-day Sunol, in an attempt to lower her record of 2:10 1/2, made a mile in 2:11 1/4. The quarters were made in 0:32 1/2, 1:04, and 1:37 1/4.

The Congress at Philadelphia, which closed its meeting yesterday, was much the same in character as those held within the last five years at Louisville and Buffalo. The papers, with the exception of the two read yesterday on the new criticism, were inferior to the speaking on the same subjects, and did not carry great weight.

Anglers who are accustomed to troll in the Hell Gate waters have been very angry lately. They have had good reason for their indignation, for their favorite sport of working for the why striped bass was threatened with ruin. The trouble was all owing to the action of the Harlem Gas Company, a company that has bothered the fishermen on more than one previous occasion.

At a meeting of the granite cutters and sharpeners of Concord, N.H., yesterday a resolution was adopted not to return to work for the New-England Granite Company until their demand for semi-monthly payments on the company's time was complied with.

An exceptionally good card is offered for the races this afternoon, and the pretty Linden Park track will probably be crowded, for there will not only be a good track, but charming Indian Summer weather is probable, and thousands will take advantage of it for a delightful day's outing. The large fields will make good races and as good sport as was had at any time in midsummer.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 14. -- Probably among the happiest persons in Richmond to-day is an inmate of the almshouse. This is Amanda C. Ribble, an old maid of about sixty. She is one of six claimants for one of the handsomest farms around Norfolk City. The estate in question is the picturesque Ribble Farm, just over Smith's Creek and adjoining Ghent. It is now leased by Capt. Charles F. Spotswood.

The Chickasaws will no doubt become a very interesting tribe to many people now that gold has been discovered on their lands. Indeed it is said that seven companies have already been formed to work in the Arbuckle Mountains and their neighborhood, and that one of them secured from the Chickasaw Government a charter covering twenty-five square miles.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- New-York City, Jersey City, and Newark hunters who have been accustomed to male Sunday incursions into the populous coverts of Sussex County, N.J., in pursuit of game, are warned that in future they will run the risk of suffering severe penalties for Sabbath breaking and infractions of the game laws.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Secretary of the Navy to-day addressed the following order to Rear Admiral Gherardi, Commander in Chief of the United States naval force, North Atlantic Station, at Tompkinsville, N.Y.:

" Girls' feet! Well, it's a matter for me to discuss, maybe, but Lewiston and Auburn girls have awful little feet." "I suppose you want me to put your name in the paper now," suggests the newspaper. "Well, maybe it might attract trade," was the honest admission. "But, honestly, girls don't have half as big feet now as they used to.

FORT RENO, Indian Territory, Nov. 15. -- At various times during the last six months dispatches have appeared in the papers referring to the progress of the new religion which has within the past year sprung up among some of the Western Indian tribes. Nothing, however, has been printed which gives any history of this strange belief or any idea of its rapid spread.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Prof. Koch holds supreme sway over public interest. The publication of the professor's statement has intensified the excitement both here and abroad, and from every centre of Europe and America telegrams of inquiry are pouring in on Koch, Pfuhl, Cornet, Bergmann, and the other medical men who are known to be engaged in treating patients by the new method.

The great difficulty about any reorganization of the present Brooklyn Republican machine, according to one prominent member of that party, is that the very men who were so overwhelmingly defeated at the recent election, and on account of whose actions reorganization is necessary, are the men who must do the reorganizing.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- The Rev. Alfred B. Coats, for four years pastor of the First Baptist Church at Oneonta, N.Y., has tendered his resignation of the charge, to take effect Jan. 1, 1891. He has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Baptist church at Beverly, Mass.

A NOVEL METHOD OF TAXATION. -- Almost the first difficulty that besets a people trying to govern for themselves is the question of revenue. Where is the money to come from?. Taxes, the bugbear of all nations, also puzzle the Swiss. His method of raising them in some of the cantons is alike interesting and novel. No official assessment is made of property.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- The Episcopal Congress met here in 1875 for its second session. It returned last week to hold its thirteenth. It has been a gathering purely for the purpose of discussion, and twice a day Association Hall has been well filled and once to overflowing by intelligent and interested audiences.

HARRISBURG, Nov. 15. -- The Republican officials on the "Hill" who absented themselves to do work for Delamater have returned, and as a consequence of Pattison's election there is considerable speculation as to his policy when he again assumes the reins of government.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The great financial house referred to in this morning's Times as having been in peril for some days is that of Baring Brothers Co. They have been helped through by the Bank of England, the Rothschilds, and several London joint stock banks, who made large advances to the firm. The Baring Brothers' position is now believed to be secure.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15. -- Judge Thurman's deserved eulogy of Rufus P. Ranney, the eminent Cleveland jurist, at the banquet on Thursday night, adds significance to the fact that Ohio's present Democratic Senator, Henry B. Payne, did not appear in any feature of the festivities. The fact is that Thurman and Payne have never been yoked in brotherly love, and that in recent years especially the air has been rather frigid when the two have met.

BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- About three hundred of the leading Democrats of the State dined with the Bay State Club at the American House this afternoon celebrating the victory at the polls. Col. Charles H. Taylor of the Globe presided, and Alpheus B. Alger, prospective Mayor of Cambridge, was Secretary.

THE MAFIA. -- A recent trial elicited facts which show that spoliation and murder have been carried on in a genteel, unobtrusive way quite lately, and that the perpetrators of these misdeeds enjoyed immunity from "persecution"; for this is the term systematically employed by Vincenzo Einares, in his account of Antonio, the famous bandit.

" Some women look pretty in anything!" When a feminine voice utters that exclamation, with a vicious little accent on the "some," it is to be understood that the owner of the voice is in a state of supreme dissatisfaction with a new costume from which she has, perhaps, anticipated a more than usual degree of pleasure.

Our Vienna correspondent telegraphs: "I mentioned some time ago that Canova's famous marble group of Theseus and the Centaur was being transported from the Greek Temple,erected over it in the Volksgarten of that city, to the Museum of Art on the other side of the Ring. The Centaur was transposed without difficulty and is already on the pedestal which fills the recess of the first landing on the magnificent staircase of the museum.

The visit of the Brazilian vessels to the port of New-York, which is to occur during the present week, is interesting in several ways. As a return of the call made last June at Rio de Janeiro by Acting Rear Admiral WALKER'S squadron, it will be a fresh token of the friendship of two great republics of the New World.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 15. -- The Rev. A.H. Crosby of New-York has received a call to the pastorate of the Second Presbyterian Church in Thompsonville.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Most of the theatres have had very gratifying patronage this week. One new production was offered at the Auditorium -the Christmas pantomime, "Babes in the Wood," which was put on for a long run and with such wealth of spectacular effects as to make it successful, notwithstanding the poverty of the dialogue.

The funeral of the late Sir Richard Burton takes place at 11 o'clock to-morrow at Trieste. The remains of the distinguished traveler will, however, only be set aside temporarily here, as they are to be conveyed a few weeks hence to England, to be permanently interred there in the family vault. Lady Burton intends also henceforward to reside in England.

The smallest number of spectators seen at a football game this year was at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon to witness a game in the intercollegiate championship series between Princeton and Wesleyan. Only about a thousand persons were in attendance. Whether it was because football enthusiasts have not become accustomed to Eastern Park or because Yale men were at New-Haven and Princeton supporters at home, is a matter of conjecture.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The British gunboat Lapwing has taken on board the survivors of the Serpent disaster and will convey them to Corunna, where they will be tranferred to the troop ship Tyne, bound for England.

The young architects who are to compete at the sixth annual exhibition of the Architectural League have a little romance on which to base their drawings. They are asked to suppose that a citizen has brought from Greece a nine-foot statue of Zeus and presented it to the city. New-York's Aldermen have been so touched by this generosity that they have set aside a fine site for the building which shall display the classic antique.

DETROIT, Nov. 15. -- The football contest between the Cornell and University of Michigan teams took place this afternoon at the athletic grounds in this city, in the presence of 2,000 spectators. There was a slight drizzle throughout the afternoon, but not enough seriously to interfere with the game, which was really a fine one -- the best that has ever been seen in the West.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15. -- The football men of the University of Pennsylvania, which made such a good showing against Princeton a week ago, met with quite a different fate on the Yale field to-day. They might as well have rushed against a stone wall as to have tried to overcome the Yale team.

It will be a great pity to have the national census of 1890, containing statistics for the last decade of the first century of our existence as a Nation, discredited in advance by the fact that for the first time in our history partisan motives have been permitted to intervene in the purely administrative work of collecting statistics.
" How did you find your way here?" inquired the Brooklyn uncle in sleepy surprise, rubbing his eyes as the Chicago Boy walked into the room.

Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association has published a statement showing the precise rates on east-bound freight from Chicago, which are to go into effect one week from to-morrow. The figures are for the especial information of the managers and agents of the Western roads connected with the Eastern trunk lines.

Musical criticism is undoubtedly the most inexact Science in the world. Which assertion is easily translatable into another argument in support of the now familiar proposition that all music is subjective. However, this matter of subjectivity my be given fifty bars' rest, while we pursue the topic which suggested anew the fallibility of musical criticism.
WISE JAPAN AND QUACKERY. -- May not the plan adopted by the Central Sanitary Bureau of Japan offer some useful suggestions to the Legislature of this country

-- The World's Desire. A Novel. By H. Rider Haggard and Andrew Lang. New-York: Harper Brothers. 1890. -- Plenty of swing and go, incidents of more than human possibility, tall talk and symbolism make this a lively romance indeed! Collaboration between two writers like Messrs. Haggard and Lang presents a curious question, since there is a wider difference between them than commonly occurs under such circumstances.

LA LIBERTAD, Nov. 15, via Galveston. -- Advices have been received from Honduras that Gen. Sanchez has been captured by the forces under President Bogran, and that the revolution is probably at an end.

Chief Naval Constructor N.L. Mintonye, who has superintended the building of the cruiser Maine since her keel was laid in October, 1883, announced yesterday that the final details of the ceremony of launching the big war ship are completed, and that, barring mishaps, she will slide into the water next Tuesday, Nov. 18, at 11:57 A.M.

A modest young stock broker in Broad street whose views on economy have been more expansive than his business during the past year or two astonished some of his Stock Exchange friends Friday afternoon by marshaling them before the prescription desk of Delmonico's dispensary and insisting that each needed a tonic in the shape of something "sec."

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- It is rather an old story to tell again the intense passion of M. Porel for our poet Shakespeare; still he must always be a trifle more interesting to us on account of this pluck and courage. He showed taste and discernment in the selection and presentation of "Much Ado About Nothing," "A Midsummer Night's Dream," and "The Merchant of Venice."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15. -- About the latter part of May last, through the vigilance of the United States Secret Service officials only, President Harrison barely escaped assassination. The would-be assassin was a Southern crank, who claimed to be a sadly persecuted Republican whose life the Southern Democracy and thankless Republicans had made miserable.

WHEN IS A GLOVE NOT A GLOVE? -- The question is, What amount of leather and stuffing must a man have on his hand, when he is pummeling another man, in order not to commit a breach of the peace? If these stupid acts of Parliament did not always omit the most important details, the difficulty would never have arisen.

PARIS, Nov. 15. -- The last new comedy, "La Parisienne," has not been a success at the Comedie Francaise. This is owing, at least in a great measure, to the very inadequate interpretation. Mlle. Reichemberg was unwise in accepting a part entirely foreign to her nature and talent. Neither Feraudy nor Prudhon could help out the heroine.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Count Douglas, a Free Conservative, whose intimate relations with the Emperor and the Court are well known, will probably succeed Dr. Lucius as Minister of Agriculture. Count Douglas had an interview with the Emperor yesterday and a conference with Herr Miquel, Prussian Minister of Finance, to-day. Although Dr. Lucius has resigned, the Emperor to-day received verbal reports from him.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- The Street broke out again in a panic to-day, and only the early closing of the day's business saved disaster. Standard investment stocks that always are dividend earners went down to surprisingly low prices. The fall was conspicuous in Reading general fours, Northern Pacifics, and Pennsylvania.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 15. -- It took the Legislature just thirty minutes to fix upon ex-Delegate J.M. Carey as a United States Senator. His colleague will be chosen next week.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15. -- Signor Pasquale Corte, the Italian Consul in this city, has addressed a communication to the Grand Jury now investigating the murder of Chief of Police Hennessey, protesting against the ill- treatment of the Italian prisoners at present confined in the parish prison. Signor Corte was questioned about the contents of his letter to the Grand Jury.

" To-morrow," laughed a bright-faced matron, "will be my fortieth birthday, and I shall have to alter a long-established line of comparison. For twenty years and more I have used the phrase 'as if I was forty,' to indicate a condition far removed from my real one. Now, alas, the dreaded line is almost passed and I must adjust myself to my new future.

The story of the day and its developments may well cause the outside world to marvel at the crudeness of Wall Street's arrangements for getting news from London. It is generally understood among persons not engaged in the business of buying and selling stocks that trustworthy, prompt, and practically continuous information from the centre of the financial world is essential to the safe and convenient pursuit of that calling.

WHERE SIR WALTER RALEIGH SMOKED HIS PIPE. -- Sir Walter Raleigh, that most brilliant of adventurers, sometimes took a cup of wine and smoked a pipe of the new-found tobacco at the "Queen's Head," among the orchards and green fields of Islington. Sir John Suckling played bowls at the "Bear-at-the-Bridge-Foot," which stood at the Southwark end of old London Bridge, and was pulled down in 1761.

It is to guard against the depredations of such fast cruisers as the Baltimore, Philadelphia, San Francisco, and Charleston, and those of other nations that the British are pushing forward their cable connections. Work under the programme laid out by the Admiralty some months ago has already begun. The programme provides for the joining of Gibraltar with Sierra Leone direct, and not as now by way of St. Vincent in the Cape de Verde Islands.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 15. -- The Alpha Delta Phi lecture course for this year was opened Thursday evening by the Rev. Dr. McGlynn, who spoke on "Religion and Equal Rights." The remaining two speakers will be George Kennan and George W. Cable.

The page of history would probably be scanned in vain for the description of a more remarkable scene than that at the opening of the new Union League Club House, in Brooklyn, on Wednesday evening, when the Rev. S. MILLER HAGEMAN got up to recite his original and powerful poem, "Valhalla."

DUFFERS, SHARPERS, CRIMINALS, LONDON, 1790. -- We read of certain "sharpers who are known by the name of 'duffers,' who, among others knaveries, passed bad money." Oddly enough, in modern slang, it is the ingenu, or dupe, and not the knave, who is called a "duffer." It is stated also that elegantly-dressed "female sharpers" used even to go to Court at St. James's.

Now the book hunters return from those fabulous voyages to London, Munich, Paris, and Rome, bringing invaluable books that pay their expenses and a great profit besides. They have manuscripts, books printed in the fifteenth century, ancient woodcuts, masterpieces of bookbinding, and books from famous libraries. They make one jealous with their treasures.

They all thought he was a fool; but then they often make mistakes like that. Kangaroos can't jump like women when the women are jumping at conclusions. You see, the trouble was that Collis Beattie -- Collie they called him when they wanted to be funny -- did not have much to say. He used to lie about the hotel veranda in a big steamer chair and read novels.

" The science and practice of medicine and surgery," said an eminent physician of this city about a year ago, "are undergoing a revolution of such magnitude and importance that its limits can hardly be conceived." It was the revolution caused by the expansion of the new science of bacteriology -- the study of the infinitesimal organisms commonly called bacilli or microbes.

Before the market opened yesterday, the Street was flooded with abounding rumors intended to create distrust and accomplishing all that was intended. For a long time the Stock Exchange district has been flooded with tales of dire distress in high financial quarters. Not one house, but many, rumor has declared to be in difficulties threatening disaster.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 15. -- Mr. Charles Schiff, President of the Queen and Crescent system of railways, has forwarded to Samuel Thomas, President of the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway, his resignation of the office of First Vice President. Mr. Schiff retains his position as President of the other three roads forming the Queen and Crescent system.

A hundred years ago party lines -- as we understand them -- in our politics were yet unknown. They were in an embryonic state, however, in a short time to develop and to grow until such a climax in partisanship had been reached as has not been equaled since until our House of Representatives discovered a need of the country for such a measure as the Force bill.

There was little logic and less sense in the condition of Wall Street yesterday. The visible cause of the prevailing uneasiness was nothing more specific than a vague fear that something might happen to somebody and so precipitate a general disaster. Distrust of the strength of others rather than any consciousness of personal weakness was the basis of the apprehension that filled the minds of the frequenters of the Street.

" Society," says one of the definitions in Pierre Larousse's dictionary, is "an association of people who come together to converse, to enjoy themselves, to give themselves up to some common recreation," and it is in this sense that it must be understood in treating of society at the capital. People who stay at home are thus not society people.

Both the Brotherhood and League men held meetings yesterday, but little of importance was transacted. A.L. Johnson of Cleveland has come down from his lofty perch and publicly announced his desire to sell out. He said he would take $40,000 and leave a clear field in Cleveland for the League people, an announcement that caused much merriment in League ranks.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The unhappy controversy on the subject of the Stanley charges against the officers of Stanley's rear guard still continues, and it grows, if possible, in horrors as the revelations and rumors multiply. At present there exists only one opinion among sensible men. This is that the matter can only be satisfactorily settled in a court of law.

SEDAN. -- Every house in Bazeilles was destroyed, with the exception of three of the larger ones, belonging to well-to-do persons. Every poor little cottage was utterly abime, and the contents, furniture, clothing, valuables of humble kind, yet quite invaluable to the humble owners were absolutely done away with. Not that the Germans looted the village; the agency they employed was fire.

It is reported that the Post Office Department at Washington is seriously considering the advisability of a new General Post Office building in this city, located up town and constructed on the one-story plan. It is believed that the Postmaster General will make a recommendation to this effect in his annual report.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- The following statement has been issued officially by the University of Pennsylvania:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 15. -- John A. Judge of the Sunday Herald staff, this city, had an exciting adventure Thursday afternoon. He went to Greenfield Hill to interview Miss Agnes Murray, who was recently sued by S.W. Benjamin, a boarding-house keeper of Stratford, for a bill claimed to be due for her brother's board while she was hiding him from his young wife.

After a liquidation of extreme severity, which had brought prices so low that the instinct of the average man prompted him to buy, we are met by the announcement that the greatest mercantile and banking house in the world has been on the edge of insolvency. The house of Barings and the house of Rothschilds are known wherever civilized men trade.

Sixteen bright-eyed young girls stood in a row yesterday afternoon on the platform of the hall of the New-York College for the Training of Teachers, in University Place. They wore black silk jersey sailor waists and black jersey skirts, bordered with stripes of yellow gold braid. Each wore a bouquet and a silver badge of the Home and Happiness Club.

The completion and successful test of the first of our 4-inch rapid-fire guns for naval use has given assurance that a supply of this ordnance will be ready in due season for the vessels now under construction and designed to carry them. Yet the number of these guns of the 4-inch, 5-inch, and 6-inch calibres, already required under existing plans, is very great.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 15. -- At the beginning of the season the Yale outlook in football was not at all encouraging. Rhodes, Heffelfinger, Hartwell, and McClung were the only players of last year's team that could be counted on to play this Fall. One tackle, one guard, one end, and one half back did not seem to be a very large nucleus to build upon, and no one in New-Haven was at all sanguine.
In the November number of Murray's Magazine is an interesting description of "Brantwood, Coniston, John Ruskin's Home," from which the following extracts are taken:

The Lyric Ballad Company is to give a concert before the ball of the Mutual Benefit Association of Stern Brothers' employes Tuesday evening at Central Turn Verein Hall. Miss Margaret H. Elliot, Mrs. Adele Louis Baldwin, J.H. McKinley, and Carl E. Dufft will sing. Miss Bertha Behrens, violinist, and Mrs. J.H. McKinley, pianist, will furnish the instrumental solos, and Charles Roberts, the elocutionist, will appear.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Two men named Robert E. Wilson, both of Atlanta, Ga., are struggling for the same place, and the story of the struggle is interesting. One took the regular civil service departmental examination and the other the Post Office examination. Both succeeded in passing; the departmental man well, the other not so well.

The struggle between the brokers and the auctioneers for the control of the Real Estate Exchange is developing lively interest and animosities, which are hardly likely to be quieted with the close of the campaign next month, when the annual election will be held. This year the auctioneers have been in control because the illness of one Director elected by the brokers and the defection of another enabled them to capture the offices.

Just where the selvedge of the broad plains touches the surbase of the mountains, and the foothills drop down like the steps of a terrace, the mighty Missouri, already magnificent in volume, leaps forth from its rocky escarpment among the peaks in a series of wonderful falls, a third of a mile wide and 512 feet in depth. The water is emerald in color and clear as crystal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Major Gen. Schofield, ever since he assumed command of the army, has had in view the improvement of the efficiency of the heavy artillery, and he will at an early date promulgate an order outlining a scheme of competitive heavy-artillery practice for all the artillery regiments of the army. There will be three grades of competition: First, battery competition; second, regimental competition, and, third, general artillery competition.

Pierre Lorillard's jockey club does not seem to have a very promising future opening up before it, though another attempt to whip the club into shape is to be made some time next month. The whole scheme is looked upon as too exclusive to accomplish anything, even though the Coney Island Jockey Club has agreed to acknowledge the authority of this new club.

All inventors know the cold inattention of business men to some of the leading inventions of the age, which had to drag along helpless until they had nearly dragged their inventors into the poorhouse before they secured recognition and success. The various reaping, thrashing, sowing, and other devices for farm work were in this list. The inventions to facilitate and make safer the various operations in practical railroading underwent this experience.

John Jackson, the Texas Socialist, says: "The more we Socialists reflect on the causes that moved the avalanche the better we like it. The result is not mere change of parties in power; it is a revolution, and a revolution that is going to keep on until our millennium -- the confraternity of man -- is ushered in, and humanity need not be ashamed to look behind the curtain of civilization.

The contract for erecting the main building and boiler room of the Emigration Bureau on Ellis Island has been awarded to Sherwood Barns. The figure for the work is $116,205. The buildings must be finished by April 1, 1891.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Scotch banks will have a meeting to-day for the purpose of adding to the Barings' guarantee fund. The whole banking world has shown alacrity in subscribing, and when all the provincial and other subscriptions have arrived the total will be such a sum as will make the whole incident a brilliant triumph for the organizers of the fund.

CORUNNA, Nov. 16. -- The British gunboat Lapwing brought the Serpent's survivors to Corunna to-day. One of the survivors, named Burton, said that the Serpent struck a covered rock about 10:30 o'clock Monday night, the weather at the time being dirty, but not foggy. All hands were below, except the officers and six watchmen.

The business men of New-York have reason for pride and confidence in the financial system of this great city, and it is worth while to call attention to this fact at the moment that the country press is ringing with windy denunciations of the "New-York gamblers." We have undoubtedly been called upon to face a great financial crisis, one of those that are inherent in the conditions of modern commercial life.

Five steamships came into port yesterday with a large number of cabin and steerage passengers from England and the Continent. The Normannia of the Hamburg-American Packet Line brought among her cabin passengers the Hon. C. de Ceda Crantz, Chamberlain of the King of Sweden and Norway, who is on his way to Samoa to take the office of Chief Justice there, in accordance with the recent German English-American treaty.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16. -- Prof. Koch has a brother living in this city, Arnold Koch, President of the Redhoffer Koch Art Company.
Mr. SHERMAN has found an imitator in this city. The Tribune gravely announced yesterday morning:

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The crippling of Thomas C. Platt as a political factor in this State, the defeat of his favorite members of Assembly, the threatened revolt of several Senators who have heretofore been regarded as his subservient lieutenants, have started political speculators into figuring upon the future of the Republican Party in this State.

New-Yorkers who are fond of apples have doubtless noticed an absence from the fruit stores and the stands of street vendors of those varieties that in past years have been plentiful. Baldwins and Greenings, which for many years have been the principal apples in the market at this season of the year, are scarcely to be found this year.

In the maelstrom of Wall Street speculation another old and supposedly reliable firm of bankers and brokers has been wrecked. Mills, Robeson Smith, doing business at 96 Broadway, have gone under, not because of their inability to stand against the panic that last week swept through the market, but because of the confessed dishonesty of the junior partner, Albert H. Smith.

But three more days remain for racing over what are called the Summer race tracks, to distinguish them from the Guttenberg and Clifton courses, where Winter racing is made a specialty. Three days of sport will be had at the track of the Linden Park Blood Horse Association to-day, to-morrow, and Wednesday, and the entries for to-day's races show that there will be plenty of competitors for the eighteen races to be run.

A festival service of uncommon musical worth and interest was set out at All Souls' Church, Madison Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, last night under the direction of Mr. Richard Henry Warren. The occasion was the institution of the new organ with which the congregation of the Rev. Heber Newton has lately been supplied by the Messrs. J.H. C.S. Odell.

Any one who has had an opportunity to look at the editorial pages of the Republican papers of the West since election day, and to read also the utterances of the Republican organs in the East, must have been impressed by the indications that the party has been hopelessly divided by the tariff. We shall quote passages from these papers to show how strongly marked this division has already become.

In another column our readers will find a fair sample of the facts in regard to the spoils system under President HARRISON, as brought out by the investigations of the special committee, of which Mr. W. DUDLEY FOULKE is Chairman. This committee was appointed by the Civil Service Reform League. Of the five members Mr. FOULKE, the Chairman, and Messrs. BONAPARTE and SHERMAN S. ROGERS were Republican supporters of Mr. HARRISON.

It is natural that Secretary PROCTOR should dwell, in his annual report, upon the present year's important legislation for the army, and upon what is further needed to make the service attractive. A suggestive statement in the Adjutant General's report is that the enlisted strength of the army is now 1,600 below the authorized maximum, with the prospect of a still greater falling off.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The trouble between Mayor Rankin of this city and the Rev. Dr. Kempshall, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, which had its origin in the recent election, and has resulted in the Mayor leaving Dr. Kempshall's church, had another phase added to it to-day by a statement which the clergyman road to his congregation.

CHAMBERSBURG, Penn., Nov. 16. -- The Mormon propaganda in the rural districts of Pennsylvania seems to be a failure. Last Spring and Winter half a dozen Mormon missionaries made their appearance in various parts of Franklin, Fulion, and Adams Counties, and assiduously, but secretly, pursued the work of roselyting innocent farmers and their families to the Mormon faith. They intentionally chose the most secluded localities, those furthest distant from railroad stations and local commercial centres.

ELLENDALE, N.D., Nov. 10. -- The snow and frost have caused the Soo contractors to suspend operations. Nothing more will be done on the various North Dakota railway extensions until next Spring. The Soo management has adopted an aggressive policy with reference to North Dakota business, and will reach the State capital ahead of the Great Northern.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16. -- Last Sunday both night trains on the Georgia Road, between Augusta and Atlanta, were robbed of express matter. Last night's train from here for Atlanta met the same fate. Express Messenger Corput of Atlanta, who is in place of one of the messengers who were robbed, was in his car, unsuspecting.

The committee of the old Protestant Cemetery in Florence issued a notice to the effect that, as the municipality of Florence may possibly give directions for demolishing those tombs and monuments that are falling into decay through neglect, the committee are prepared to undertake the preservation and maintenance of any tomb on receipt of a capital sum of not less than 10.

A meeting in behalf of negro and Indian education was held in the Church of Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. In two of the front pews were four negroes and two Indiana from the Hampton Normal and Agrlcultr ural Institute, Hampton, Vm They wore the cadet uniform of the school, and showed interest in the meeting, which was held for the purpose of explaining and illustrating the xverk of the I school.

Persons who observed Mr. Jacobus at Central Park yesterday were aware that something had happened. His everyday look of cynical and blase indifference to peanuts and small boys had vanished, and in its place there was an aspect of concentrated pride and complacency such as might with propriety adorn the countenance of one who had suddenly climbed to the pinnacle of fame.

The idea suggested by Dr. Nagle of the Board of Health of this city, at a meeting of the Society of Amateur Photographers, that a collection of pictures be taken of all objects of interest in this city, as well as such artistic scenes as could be obtained of street life, has taken hold of the amateurs, and in a short time a fine collection will decorate the rooms of the society.

The great armored cruiser Maine will be launched to-day from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, rain or shine, at noon. Every preparation has been made for the reception of visitors, the commandant of the yard estimating that as many as 20,000 people will be on hand to witness the event. To look out for this crowd extraordinary precautions have been taken to avoid accident or disaster.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- At the banking house of Baring Brothers Co. this morning everything was quiet and there were no internal or external signs of disturbance. The members of the firm stated that all their acceptances and other liabilities would be met as they fell due. They also said that the position of the firm, with the Bank of England at its back, was stronger now than ever before.

Ex-Gov. John McEnery of Louisiana, who is an out-and-out Democrat, was until last week very much prejudiced against Grover Cleveland. He had never heard Mr. Cleveland talk and had gained the impression that he was far from being the statesman that other good Democrats declared him to be. Mr. McEnery went to Columbus last week to pay his respects to Allen G. Thurman and he heard Mr. Cleveland's famous speech at the banquet.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17. -- The little town of Mount Carmel, Ill., and all the country round about is terribly excited over the collapse of the private banking establishment of Cowling, Gowenlock Co. and the subsequent developments, which are of the most sensational character.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 17. -- Mr. E.B. Stahlman, Third Vice President of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, has resigned his position, and Judge W.J. Wood of Evansville, Ind., has been appointed his successor. Mr. Stahlman sent in his resignation several weeks ago, but it was not accepted. He again tendered his resignation, and it has been accepted and his successor appointed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- There can be no sort of doubt from many indications that Hill is determined to be responsible for something in national affairs, even if he is obliged to crowd himself in. The last report about him is not without sense, in that it shows his disposition to take up the most reasonable thing in sight in the hope of getting some credit for having made a discovery.

News was received on the Cotton Exchange yesterday morning of the mysterious death of William Bornemann, one of the best known and wealthiest representatives of the European cotton merchants in this country. When the details of his death became known they revealed a story in many ways resembling that of the sad fate of the late Charles Delmonico, whose body was found in the Orange Mountains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Speaker of the next House of Representatives will have to select a number of new men for membership on the Committee on Reform in the Civil Service. Six of the thirteen present members of that committee will not be able to accept a reappointment, for they will not be members of the House.

William F. Sheehan of Buffalo came to the city last evening and registered at the Hoffman House. Mr. Sheehan has begun active work to secure the Speakership. Yesterday he spent several hours with Gov. Hill in Albany, and last night was in consultation with a number of local politicians. He will remain in town several days.

It wasn't a particularly pleasant day at Linden Park yesterday, but the races were run off just the same, for in these days there is racing daily, rain or shine. Nothing except another blizzard or a cyclone which would sweep away the track would prevent a continuance of the sport. Three thousand regulars at least were at the track and kept the bookies busy.

The office of Mills, Robeson Smith, 96 Broadway, was visited by a great many anxious people yesterday, who wished to assure themselves of the facts in regard to the big stock certificate forgery reported in yesterday's papers. All those who called found that the news was only too true. The firm had gone down, and solely on account of the dishonest act of the junior partner, Albert H. Smith.

As a sample of the beneficence of the McKinley tariff, a little transaction in starch that is in progress just now is well worth considering. It is a transaction concerning three parties. The party of the first part is the National Starch Manufacturing Company, that company being identical with the institution commonly spoken of as the Starch Trust.

A notable Catholic ceremony took place in St. Ann's Church, in East Twelfth Street, yesterday morning, when the church dignitaries of the diocese, a hundred priests, scores of sisters of charity, and the parishioners of Mgr. Thomas S. Preston, in all about two thousand persons, gathered to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of his ordination.

Mr. and Mrs. Kendal were accepted and became prime favorites here more than a year ago, when they used Palgrave Simpson's "Englished" adaptation of Sardou's "Pattes de Mouche" as the medium of their first appearance in America. "A Scrap of Paper" was revived by them at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night, and the performance was received approvingly by an audience scarcely less noteworthy in numbers and quality than that which witnessed their debut.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- There is every prospect that the canal authorities will ask for a largely-increased appropriation next year. Extraordinary repairs will swell the amount into hundreds of thousands of dollars. State Engineer Bogart and Superintendent of Public Works Hannan have just completed their annual inspection of the State canals.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- A visitor to the consulting rooms of Dr. Cornet writes to the Vossische Zcitung as follows: "Imagine a dark corridor, scarcely four and a half feet wide, thronged by a motley assemblage of men and women, and in a small adjacent ante-room thirty persons coughing in a close atmosphere, anxiously awaiting their turn for examination and treatment.

The launch of the Maine, which is fixed for to-day, is an event of unusual interest in many ways. She is not only of larger displacement than any American war ship that has ever yet taken to the water, but she is the first armored cruiser of the new steel fleet and the first modern vessel to be built in one of the Government yards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The financial condition in 1890 of 858 cities and large towns is shown in Bulletin No. 14, issued to-day by the Census Office. Within a few days a supplemental bulletin will be issued, showing the same facts in relation to remaining cities of this size. This, with the one published to-day, will represent about 95 per cent. of the municipal debt of the United States.

There is a fair prospect that the result of the last election will destroy the arrogant control which THOMAS C. PLATT has exercised for some years over the Republican Party in this State. If "nothing succeeds like success," it is equally true that nothing fails like failure, and PLATT'S leadership has at last met with a very decided failure.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 17. -- While the candidates for the important local offices in New-York City have filed statements of election expenses ranging from $100 to $7,500, it remained for John Sanford, the Republican nominee for Congress in the Twentieth District, which includes the counties of Schenectady, Montgomery, Saratoga, and Fulton and Hamilton, to make known the banner statement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Another phase of the much-disputed worsted-woolen question was disposed of to-day in the Supreme Court.

Honduras, which at one time may have expected to take part in the war between Guatemala and Salvador, although relieved from that necessity, has had experience of a short and sharp insurrection in her own domains. An uprising of a portion of the troops of the capital, a few days ago, under Gen. SANCHEZ, proved so effective that President BOGRAN was glad remake his escape from the city.

Minnie Palmer's pretty face was as white as the pillows on which she lay when a reporter for THE TIMES saw her yesterday afternoon in the apartments of her mother at the Aberdeen Hotel. A slight cut disfigured one side of her nose, an ugly scratch marked her nether lip and the skin was torn from the palm of her left hand.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 17. -- Judge Howell E. Jackson of the United States Circuit Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, to-day decided a very important railroad bond case, in which Mr. Quinlin a New-York broker, was the plaintiff, and Lyons, County, Ky., the defendant. The suit, which has been pending in the Kentucky State courts and the United States courts in Kentucky for more than a decade, was decided in favor of Mr. Quinlin.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17. -- A crowd of long- haired Anarchists gathered in Judge Kirkpatrick's court to-day in anticipation of the trial of Lucy Parsons and the other Anarchists who had been arrested for attempted riot at a meeting commemorative of the executed Chicago Anarchists which Capt. Glori prevented ten days ago.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17. -- There is trouble among the spinners in the Clark O.N.T. spinning mills here and at Kearney, N.J., and should they strike, as they threaten to do, about four hundred and fifty men, boys, and girls will be out of work. Superintendent Herbert Walmsley and his assistant overseers are again blamed for the grievances of which the men complain.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 17. -- For $1,200, Dowling Foster of St. Paul, Minn., have bought the b.g. Consignee, 4 years, by Hyder Ali, dam America, by Alarm, of Sugar Grove Stable. For $1,000, J.E. Hittick of New-Orleans has bought the ch. m. Neva C., 4 years, by Springbok, dam Europa, by Hurrah, of J.M. Brown Co., Fort Worth, Texas.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 17. -- Kidder, Peabody Co. are in receipt of a cablegram from Baring Brothers stating that all matters are arranged satisfactorily and permanently, and authorizing Kidder, Peabody Co. to proceed with business as usual.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Gen. Nelson A. Miles, accompanied by Assistant Adjt. Gen. Corbin, returned from St. Louis this morning. Gen. Miles was in consultation with Secretary of War Proctor about the alleged Indian outbreak in the Northwest.

The Committee of Twenty-five appointed at the recent convention of the Prohibitionists of New-York County to organize an active campaign in behalf of the proposed prohibitional amendment to the State Constitution met yesterday at the temperance headquarters, 58 Reade Street. A Committee on Finance and a Committee on Public Meetings was appointed which shortly will report to the full committee as to the best plan of campaign to inaugurate.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The trial of the O'Shea divorce case was resumed in the Divorce Court this morning before Justice Butt and the special jury. The petitioner presented further testimony to prove the charges he makes against his wife and Mr. Parnell.

HARTFORD, Nov. 17. -- The views of Gov. Bulkeley concerning the possible election of his successor by the Legislature are of great consequence at this juncture in the Morris-Merwin controversy. The Republicans of the State maintain that there has been no election by the people and that the Legislature must elect under the Constitution.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 17. -- Senator George W. Delamater of Meadville was in this city to-day for the first time since his defeat for Governor. He met only a few intimate friends at his hotel, and left this evening for his home.

The proposal to use liquid fuel in our new torpedo boats derives interest and importance from the fact that so little has yet been done on this class of our vessels. With the Cushing, our only torpedo boat thus far, and scores, if not hundreds, likely to be built, the selection of their fuel is worthy of study, particularly in view of some remarkable results reached in foreign experiments.

Evidently the Republican leaders in New-Hampshire have not taken to heart the chief lesson of the late election. They are proposing to go on with precisely the same kind of methods for getting party advantage that has produced such a strong reaction in other States and throughout the country.

The demand that the Republicans of the present Congress shall at once retrace their steps by cutting down the high duties in the McKinley law at the coming short session is made, as we have shown, by several prominent Republican journals of the West. It is repeated, day after day, and undoubtedly it represents the wishes of a very large body of voters who have for many years been Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- In submitting his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy Commodore Farquhar, Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks, gives the estimates for the maintenance and improvement of the navy yards and docks as follows:

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Mr. Quilter, editor of the Universal Review, has an article in that publication on the Stanley controversy which has attracted much attention. Mr. Quilter says he is especially informed that Jameson's diary and private letters were placed in a box by Bonny after Jameson's death, and that the box, after being sealed up by Bonny, was confided to Stanley.

Miss Gladys Price, a very pretty young woman, organist of the Mariners' Temple, Madison and Catharine Streets, was shot in the back as she was leaving that place of worship after service last evening, about 8:30 o'clock, by an insane man named John T. Davis, who seems to have been laboring under an hallucination that the organist was his wife.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 18. -- The Navy Department is considering the advisability of adding to the list of small, swift vessels for chasing work. Bids are to be opened in February for a 750-ton torpedo cruiser. Great difficulty has been met with in the preparation of plans for this craft, nearly all of the available space being taken up with machinery.

A board of marine officers will shortly be ordered by Secretary Tracy to consider changes and improvements in the uniforms and accoutrements of the Marine Corps. The detail of such a board, judging from the expressions of many, will be hailed with delight by the progressive officers of the corps.

BOSTON, Nov. 18. -- Bishop William Taylor, who is here attending the conference of the Method 1st Missionary Committee and who is credited with knowing more about African matters than any other member of the committee, gave Stanley a good word on the latter'a arrival here today.

The New-Hampshire election was decisive as to the Congressional candidates, two Democrats being chosen to represent the State in the Fifty-second Congress, but it failed to determine which party should have control of the State Government for the two years beginning with the 1st of January, and it also failed to determine whether or not a Democrat would succeed Mr. BLAIR in the United States Senate.
LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The Pall Mall Gazette says:

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18. -- The Western Tobacco Journal has an interview with Senator John G. Carlisle on the subject of the omission of rebate on tobacco in the Tariff bill. Senator Carlisle was a member of the conference committee, and, as will be seen, does not agree with Senator Sherman's view of the matter. He says:...

Speaking of Jay Gould's purchases of Richmond Terminal stock, Mr. John H.
