Inman, President of that company, said yesterday that he had had some conferences with Mr. Gould recently, and was glad to welcome him into the Board of Directors. He understood that Mr. Gould owned about 100,000 shares. There are 700,000 shares, all told, of which the present management, including all of the Directors, control 150,000 shares.

NEWARK, Nov. 18. -- Monday morning the officials of the Howard Savings Institution in Newark observed that more depositors than usual were presenting themselves at the teller's counter to close their accounts. Yesterday morning when the bank doors were opened, a score or more of them awaited the arrival of the teller. The run increased as the day went along, and by the time the bank closed for the day $30,000 had been withdrawn.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 18. -- By defeating the eleven of the Grand Trunk Association here yesterday the Toronto University Club now holds the association football championship of Canada. The Toronto University Club has a record which is unequaled in the history of any Canadian association club. For two years its men have played the two seasons through from beginning to end and won every match in which they have played.

After spending twenty years of his life as an enthusiastic and devoted Republican, Gen. Alfred C. Barnes, the present head of the great publishing house, has become a Democrat. He lives in a big mansion on Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, and a few days ago he had himself enrolled as a member of the First Ward Democratic Club.

ELLENDALE, N.D., Nov. 18. -- The incoming Legislature will have a hard struggle on the prohibition question. This subject has, to some extent, been lost sight of in the excitement attending the Senatorial contest. A considerable number of the members of both houses were elected on that issue, and it is believed by the liquor element that a bill can be passed resubmitting the question of prohibition.

The practical crusade against the Anarchists begun in Elizabeth, N.J., last Tuesday, when Mayor RANKIN of that city forbade the holding of the meeting which LUCY PARSONS had been advertised to address and closed the hall against her, has been carried as far as Cincinnati. Herr MOST, the most disreputable of the gang of self-styled Socialists, was announced to deliver a speech in that city Monday evening, but his followers were disappointed.

In the accompanying map of the United State THE TIMES presents the results of the recent Congressional elections in a form more effective than tables, because the magnitude of the great ' victory for Tariff' Reform can be seen at a glance. The shaded parts of the map represent those portions of the country which emphatically resented tlie outrageous McKinley tariff law by voting for Democratic or, in a few instances, Alliance candidates for Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- When the first session of the present Congress ended, the unfinished business in the Senate was the House bill for the adjustment of accounts of laborers, workmen, and mechanics under the eight-hour law. It was the first of five labor bills in Mr. Blair's charge which had been given places on the programme of business arranged at a Republican caucus a few weeks before the adjournment.

The one hundred and twenty-second annual banquet of the Chamber of Commerce last evening was a notable occasion in several respects. Occurring as it did before the financial crisis had been fully and certainly ended, the speeches naturally abounded with references to that momentous event, or series of events.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- The new United States cruiser Concord reached here at 5 o'clock to-night. She is at present lying close in-shore her powerful electric lights illumining every nook and corner of the neighborhood. The display is evoking much admiration from those on the beach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- A Washington paper this afternoon contains an interview of some length with Representative John M. Wiley of New-York, in which he is allowed to say a good deal about the chances of Representative-elect Daniel M. Lockwood for the Speakership and something more about two candidates from the State of New-York for the Presidency.

Up to the very last day of the campaign the high-tariff papers asserted that there had actually been no advance of prices. Since the election some of them have admitted that prices were increased in the campaign as the result of a "Democratic conspiracy," but they now say that such prices as were raised have been lowered to the original level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The discovery made by Dr. Koch has been an attraction to the leading students of medicine at the national capital, and Dr. John L Billings, one of the most accomplished investigators in this country, has just expressed some opinions that are interesting as coming from a conservative man.

Will you permit me to indorse the sentiment your yesterday's editorial and will you also permit me to shift a responsibility which Mr. Frohman is seeking to place on me to just exactly where it belongs Your sense of justice, I am sure, will give me a hearing.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- The returns of the, late election have been received by the Secretary of State in numbers sufficient to varrant his callhg the State Board of Canvassers together the second week in December. Only seventeencoun. ties remain to be heard from. When their elec tion returns come to hand they will be added to the tabulation which is being prepared for the State canvassers.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18. -- The first step was taken last evening in an organized movement to oust Chauncey Ives Filley from his position of supreme manipulator of the Republican Party of Missouri.

CONCORD, Nov. 18. -- From the tone of the remarks of those who are closest to Senator Chandler, it is evident that he is weakening in his position upon the extra legislative session question. The trouble is that he is not clear in his mind as to the outcome.

The Archaeological Institute of America is in a condition of elation to-day over the assurance that it is to have the right and authority to excavate and explore the ruins of ancient Delphi. The guarantee fund of 400,000f. was completed last Saturday, and President Seth Low of Colombia College, who is President also of the Archaeological Institute, cabled the good news to Dr. Charles Waldstein at Cambidge, England.

A new source of uneasiness has arisen for the Republican managers; it is the menace to the country from the Farmers' Alliance and kindred associations or parties. This phenomenon does not affect the minds of all alike. They have not yet apparently had time to come to a view of it that shall be generally presented.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- There is a rumor that another prominent banking firm is in difficulties, owing to its inability to rediscount maturing bills. The financial News says it hopes the report is not true, but it is afraid that many weak spots have been made in the financial world by reckless underwriting, and that more than one house is tottering under a load of overwhelming unforeseen liabilities.

An operation which, if successful, will greatly advance the cause of orthopedic surgery and open wonderful possibilities in that direction was performed at the Charity Hospital, Blackwell's Island, Sunday.

This day promises to be one of critical importance in the history of the public school system of this city. Mayor Grant will, it is said, announce the names of the seven men who are to go into the Board of Education, three of them at once and the remaining four on the 1st of January, to hold office, all of them, until Jan. 1, 1894.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18. -- The Southwestern Railway and Steamship Association hold Its final meeting to. day. The only matters considered were those which interested calmthe members who remained over. The meeting a/iJourned sine (tie.

Secretary Windom's arrival in New-York yesterday was made the basis for a rumor that he had come from Washington to settle definitely the question of location of the Appraiser's Stores. This was a mistake. The Secretary said yesterday that he had only come to attend the Chamber of Commerce banquet. As to the Appraiser's Stores matter he could only say that it was approaching a stage when there might be something to say about it.

A review of this year's French naval manoeuvres shows that they must have rivaled in accidents what is generally considered a fair average score for a British set of evolutions. The torpedo boats and torpedo catchers or scouting vessels were particularly unfortunate. Two of them -- the Bombe and the Dague -- had trouble with their machinery and repeatedly had to be taken in tow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Treasurer James Huston has submitted to Secretary Windom the report on the operations and conditions of the Treasury for the fiscal year ended June 30.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 18. -- The adoption of an official ballot which shall be printed by the State will be earnestly demanded by the ballot reformers of Connecticut at the January session of the Legislature. The Bureau of Labor Statistics will advocate the measure, and the necessity for the law will be discussed at length in the Commissioner's report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Acting Indian Commissioner Belt has received no recent information fram South I)akot which justifies the evident alarm of the settlers in the neighborhood of the Pine Ridge Agency. That the Indiana are greatly excited there is no doubt, but lIr. Belt is of opinion tha, so long as the Indiana are not interfered with, no harm will be done cxcep to themselves.

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., Nov. 18. -- In the Criminal Court of Susquehanna County at Montrose to-day there was concluded one of the most singular cases in the legal history of the State. The case occupied four days. Olive Brown and her husband, Philander Brown, Spiritualists, secured through their peculiar doctrines and manifestations such control over Paul Hill, an aged man residing in Brooklyn Township, and formerly of Iowa, as to obtain from him nearly $3,000.

Victories by three outsiders, one second choice, and two favorites was the record of the day's racing at Linden Park yesterday. There was a good crowd on hand to see the sport, and there was good sport to be seen, even though the track was very muddy and heavy, thus necessitating a number of scratches, so that the fields of horses were small in all except the fourth and fifth events.

We have been reminded, in connection with the question of compulsory voting, that a bill was introduced in the Senate of this State at the last session of the Legislature entitled. "An act to make the exercise of the elective franchise compulsory." We do not find, however, that the provisions of the bill conform to the title.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 18. -- The third annual report of the Hon. Absalom Korner, Chairman of the Board of Agriculture, which is now in the hands of the printer, discusses the question of immigration at length, and makes pungent reading.
Prompted by your leading article in to-day's issue relative to managers of theatres and speculators, I beg to call your attention to my experience last Saturday night.

BERLIN, NOV. 19. -- To-morrow's number of the Gerta Medical lVeekly will contain an article strned by Drs. Bergmaun, Fracntzel, and WillIam Levy, and Staff Surgeon Koehl, In whtoh they declare that, after expertmsnts in many dLffereat eases, they are prepared to fully indorso Prof. Koch's statements rega!ding his remedy.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Mr. Balfour's speech at Grimsby last night is given a prominent place in all the Conservative newspapers and is strongly commended by them. The Irish Secretary met with an enthusiastic reception from the 7,000 persons present at the meeting.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- The civil marriage of Princess Victoria of Prussia, sister of Emperor William, and Prince Adolphus of Schaumburg-Lippe was celebrated at 4 o'clock this afternoon in the palace of Empress Frederick. Emperor William and Empress Augusta Victoria, Empress Frederick, and the parents of the bridegroom were present.

DUBLIN, Nov. 19. -- In the Judges' Court at Clonmel to-day a judgment of guilty was given against William O'Brien, John Dillon, Patrick O'Brien, all of whom are members of Parliament; John Cullinane, Thomas Walsh, Patrick Mockler, and Mr. Bolton, who were charged with conspiring to induce the tenants on the Smith-Barry estates not to pay rent.

Under a canopy of smilax, in the large banquet hall of the Hotel Normandie, which was profusely decorated with palms and chrysanthemums, Miss Ida Muller, daughter of Judge W.L. Muller of the Court of Claims, was wedded to Mr. W. Sutherland Hunter of Philadelphia, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The bride wore a dress of white satin chiffon, the skirt festooned with chiffon and ostrich tips, and a veil of tulle.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 19. -- The final papers of incorporation of the American Window-Glass Company have been filed and show the following stock subscriptions to the combination:

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19. -- Mr. Henry Fink, Second Vice President of the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway, came here to-day from New-York. He stated that he had not come to arrange for any sweeping changes of heads of departments. Whoever had been faithful and capable would not be disturbed. Mr. Miller, he said, would be Traffic Manager, and some other person would fill the place of First Vice President, resigned by Mr. Charles Schiff.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 19. -- The Western Turk Congress met at the Louisville Hotel to-day and remained in session with closed doors from noon until 6 o'clock. There were present Judge George E. Perkins, E.C. Hopper, and Judge Cleary of the Latonia Jockey Club, Gen. Robinson and Major B.G. Bruce of Lexington, Charles Green of St. Louis, Frank Shaw of St. Paul, and Col. M. Lewis Clark of Louisville.

" On Probation," a comic play written by Messrs. Brander Matthews and George H. Jessop, was acted by Mr. Crane and his company at the Star Theatre yesterday afternoon. The action passes partly in a Paris hotel and partly in Switzerland under the shadow of the Jungfrau. Of the eleven personages five are Americans, two Irish, one Russian, one Portuguese, one English, and one "cosmopolitan."

The downfall of Albert H. Smith and the failure of his firm, Mills, Robeson Smith, came ery near causing a loss of $4,500 to the Lucretia Mott Dispensary and Infirmary, at 13 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn. This is a charitable concern, managed by a Board of Trustees, of whom the Rev. S.H. Camp, pastor of the Third Unitarian Church, is President.

The Committee on Revision has completed its report to the Commission for the Proposal of Amendments to the Judiciary Article of the Constitution, and the report will be submitted to the commission at a meeting at the rooms of the Bar Association Tuesday, Dee. 2. James C. Carter, George F. Danforth, James C. Smith, C. Alonzo Kellogg, Homer A. Nelson, and William B. Hornblower constitute the committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Although the State of Michigan will be credited with three Republican and eight Democratic Representatives at the beginning of the first session of the Fifty-second Congress, it is confidently asserted by the politicians of that State that the figures will be two to nine before the close of the session.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The citizens of East Orange, West Orange, and this city are excited over the revelation that an attempt has been made to bribe the East Orange Township Committee to pass the ordinance granting permission to the Newark Passenger Railroad Company to run its cars through Main Street and to the Newark Rapid Transit Company to run cars through Central Avenue by means of the overhead system of electric propulsion.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 19. -- The Sabbath Association of Western Pennsylvania took occasion to discuss and criticise Postmaster General Wanamaker to-day. A resolution was under consideration which provides for the disciplining of church members who are in any way connected with Sunday newspapers, as well as those who advertise in Sunday publications.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18. -- Lee Webster shot and killed himself shortly after midnight this morning. The tragedy took place in the dining room of Mr. William Renshaw's residence, 1,201 North Charles Street, a fashionable quarter of the city.

The Mayor appointed two Park Commissioners yesterday, one in place of J. HAMPDEN ROBB, resigned, and the other to succeed M.C.D. BORDEN, whose term expired some time ago. Mr. GEORGE G. HAVEN, who is appointed for the remainder of Mr. ROBB'S term, has the advantage of being recommended by his predecessor.

Arrangements for the big flower show at Madison Square Garden next week are rapidly approaching completion. Its managers, Messrs. Pitcher and Manda, are confident that they will fill the floor space of the amphitheatre with their exhibits, and thus accomplish what the association of florists to whom the Garden was tendered for a show feared to undertake.

Wall Street had a season of calmness yesterday. The rumor mongers, recently so conspicuous, had suddenly and mysteriously disappeared. For days past insinuations, and even open charges, against the financial standing of prominent Stock Exchange houses have been abounding, but yesterday there was nothing of the kind.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- At 10 o'clock to-night an Associated Press reporter called on Gen. Miles to secure the very latest information relative to the Indian troubles. He was questioned in reference to a dispatch from the Rosebud Agency, which dispatch the General had carefully read.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- That capitalists believe that Cook County really is a good investment was shown last night in the Recorder's office, when a voluminous document, called the "Chicago Real Estate Agreement and Declaration of Trust," was put on record.

Mr. Caldwell will probably never again drop the starter's flag at the Linden Park track. Angered by the action of Mr. Appleby on Tuesday in paying the fines imposed on the jockeys, he yesterday failed to appear at the track and carry out his contract to start the racers during the meeting of the Linden Park Blood Horse Association.

The proposed cession of some British West African colony, probably Gambia, to France, in exchange for the abandonment of the French fishery rights on the Newfoundland coast, which is declared to be the basis of negotiations now pending, at least aims at decisively settling a dispute that has been going on ever since the treaty of Utrecht in 1713.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 19. -- Stephen Wood and Tuck Wood were to have been placed on trial to-day as accessories to the murder of Leander Pasco, but an important witness in the person of Sam Pasco, son of the murdered man, has disappeared. It is asserted that he has been got out of the way by the Woods, as his testimony would throw now light upon the case.

There seems to be no fault to be found with Mayor GRANT'S appointments for members of the Board of Education, and he says that he has no information regarding the politics of the new appointees. Three of the Commissioners whose terms were to expire with this year have been reappointed, viz., Messrs. DEVOE, HOLT, and PURDY, and they were among the more useful members of the board.

The discovery that ALBERT H. SMITH is a forger is much less startling than the fact that such a forgery is possible. That even the best of men will, when overtempted, commit even the worst or foolishest of crimes is so well established that, in this latest case, the considerable amount of the theft and the respectable position of the criminal are mere details, which will be forgotten next week.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The trial of the new cruiser Concord ended at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. The vessel made as high as 17.7 knots an hour, spurting at one time, it was estimated, to 18 knots, and maintaining an average for the trial of 17 knots per hour. This she did against a strong tidal current.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Elizabeth's charity ball, held to-night in aid of the City Hospital, was a brilliant affair. The leaders of society were present in force, and the decorations of the zouave armory, where the ball was held, have never been equaled here. Bernstein's orchestra of New-York furnished the music. The toilets of the ladies were magnificent.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Speaking of the sentence of himself and Mr. Dillon, this afternoon, Mr. O'Brien said:

The Committee on Revision of the commission appointed to frame amendments to the judiciary article of the Constitution of this State has submitted its report to that body, putting in form the amendments proposed substantially in accordance with conclusions already reached by the commission itself.

The strange excitement now prevailing among a dozen or more Indian tribes, notably among the Arapahoes of Wyoming, the Northern Cheyennes of Tongue River, and the Sioux of Pine Ridge and other agencies, is probably without a parallel in the history of the aborigines. The influence which has been exerted at times by the "Dreamers" is familiar, as also is the ordinary potency of their "Medicine Men."

In renewing his control of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company Mr. Gould accomplishes two things. He silences the men who have been disposed to boast of having "wrested the company from Jay Gould" and he secures the cooperation of a transportation line that will prove an important factor in Mr. Gould's transcontinental railroad scheme.
Mayor Grant announced the following appointments at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- To-morrow, if there be members enough of the House Committee on Appropriations in the city, that committee will meet to begin work upon the appropriation bills. The clerk of the committee, Mr. Courts, has been making preparations for the meeting, but this afternoon only four members of the committee had reported themselves as ready for duty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Although the Fifty-second Congress will not meet until a whole year has passed unless the Republicans in the Fifty-first Congress attempt to do more than there is absolute necessity for doing and force an extra session, the Republicans have begun their gratuitous work of selecting a Speaker for the majority.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 20. -- The steamer City of Dallas, Capt. Charles F. Hardie, of the Morgan Line arrived this morning from Port Cortez, bringing the latest intelligence of the revolt in Spanish Honduras. Capt. Hardie says:

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Gen. James W. Husted, the "Bald Eagle" of Westchester, has, to all intents and purposes, retired from politics. He will not be the leader of the next Assembly, as the Republicans of the State imagine.

The Republicans now in control of Congress and the Executive can do the country an immense service by repealing the Silver bill -- act of July 14 last. The welfare of the country calls loudly for the repeal of the act and for a halt in any further steps in that direction. The act and the policy embodied in it have had a full trial and have been found wanting.

The financial situation of the Argentine Republic wins new importance at present on account of the part played by Argentine securities is so nearly breaking down the BARINGS. It has been difficult to see until very recently the extent of the damage done Argentine credit by the political revolution of last Summer, and the events leading up to it, but now we have abundant means of measuring it.

Something of interest can always be looked for at the annual dinner of the New-York Jewelers' Association. That body sat down together last night at Delmonico's for the sixteenth time, and the occasion proved no exception to the rule. An elaborate dinner was enjoyed, and after it had culminated in a cup of coffee and a good cigar the gentlemen present listened to interesting addresses by ex-President Grover Cleveland and others.

ATCHISON, Kan., Nov. 20. -- J.W. Orr, assistant general attorney of the Missouri Pacific, who spent last week in the Seventh Congressional District, brings the information that the farmers are not satisfied with their recent victory at the polls, but will endeavor to strengthen their forces in the Legislature by the addition of nineteen votes.

The closing-out sale of the racing stable of the Hon. W.L. Scott, held at the old panorama building at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street yesterday, drew together a great crowd of racing men, horse owners, jockeys, bookmakers, and other followers of the sport. The sale was conducted by William Easton, manager of Tattersall's of New-York, and was a pronounced success, the thirty-one animals sold fetching a total of $93,465, an average of $3,015.

The leaders of the great subsidy movement of 1888 may well say with FALSTAFF that they have "led their ragamuffins where they have been well peppered." There is no regiment of the defeated and demoralized Republican forces that went into the fight with higher hopes or louder vaunting and have come out more completely used up.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 20. -- Surgeon General Hamilton has made a report to the Secretary of the Treasury, giving the results of visits paid by him to the principal foreign ports of embarkation of emigrants bound for the United States.

This year a determined effort has been made at the Fall exhibition of the Academy to suppress several hundred of the worst paintings which usually disfigure it. The jury of selection has felt that something must be done to redeem this minor exhibition, so they have rejected nearly twice as many pictures as now hang on the walls.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- The niece of Gen. Seliverskoff, who was found Tuesday with a bullet wound in his head in the Hotel Bade, and who died yesterday, has arrived here for the purpose of arranging the details of her uncle's funeral. At the request of the Russian Embassy no autopsy will be held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Republican members of Congress are apparently reluctant to return to Washington. They are coming so slowly that this morning, when the Committee on Appropriations should have met in response to the request made by Mr. Cannon at the close of the first session, there were but two Republicans in the committee room, and Mr. Cannon was not one of them.

The hopes of fur dealers that there would be a boom in their trade this year have not been realized thus far, and unless the thermometer goes down soon and remains down for some time at least the probabilities are that no fortunes will be made in furs this Winter.

The new United States cruiser Concord reached the docks of the Morgan Iron Works yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. She will remain in New-York until an understanding is reached between the Secretary of the Navy and President N.F. Palmer, Jr., when, in all probability, she will proceed up the Sound for another trial.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- At army headquarters this afternoon Gen. Miles received a letter dated Camp Poplar River, Montana, Nov. 17, 1890, which came from one of the army officers at that post, and contained considerable matter of interest with reference to the agitation among the Indians in the far Northwest concerning the new "Messiah." The army officer says:

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 20. -- Chandler is disgusted, desperate, and well-nigh foiled. He had Gov. Goodell in town to-day and several of the Councilors, and with his conspirators and subordinates he has been laboring to secure the approval of the majority of the latter for the extra-session scheme.
ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- The State Fish and Game Law Revision Commission met at 10 o'clock this morning in the Senate Chamber.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Mr. Bynum of Indiana, one of the candidates for the Speakership in the contest that is to take place a year from now has arrived here, and he has been talking to a Star reporter on the reasons for the Democratic victory, and suggesting what the course of the Democrats must be in that House.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- State Forest Commissioner Cox is very proud of the deer park which the State created in the Catskills, but it is not large enough to suit him. He urges that the entire township of Denning be added to the park. Of this territory the State and county own all but two or three small holdings, or about 64,000 acres.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- The day after election, Russell Co., manufacturers of agricultural implements, reduced the wages of thirty-five employes 33 per cent., with the avowed purpose of inducing them to resign. The firm was very active in the endeavor to elect McKinley to Congress. The employes whose wages were reduced were all Democrats and supporters of Warwick.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20. -- The calamity that befell the Longue Pointe Lunatic Asylum on the 6th of last May, whereby ninety-four inmates and four of the Sisters of Providence in charge lost their lives in the conflagration which consumed the buildings, is now yielding good results.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Chief Meiville of the Bureau of Steam Engineering in his report to the Secretary of the Navy, has this to say about the work done at the Brooklyn Navy Yard:

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20. -- The University Glee Club, together with the Banjo and Mandolin Clubs, will give their first concert of the season to-morrow evening in Queenstown Chapel, near Evelyn College. The young ladies of the college have secured an entire block of seats, and will attend en masse.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- There was considerable product bought by Dunham and by other commission houses to-day, apparently to reinstate holdings abandoned Wednesday. There appeared even to be some buying by Armour Co. The result was a strong opening and a further advance during the first hour of business. Provisions closed completely under the influence of all the depressing circumstances which developed toward the last and which closed all the other pits so weak.

ELLENDALE, N.D., Nov. 20. -- The Senatorial canvass in this State has become bitterly personal. Feeling runs so high between the hostile factions that there is no certainty of the Republican caucus settling the matter. The possibility of North Dakota sending a Democrat to the United States Senate is not so remote that it has escaped the attention of the national leaders, and hence the outside world is viewing the contest here with keen interest.

NEWYEAR-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 20. -- In the course of the last few weeks more than a dozen fires, most of them incendiary have occurred in this vicinity, and farmers arc becoming alarmed. Certain persons, said to be relatives, are suspected in two cases, one near Monmouth Junotion, and the other at Kingston. Some persons believe there is an organized gang at work.

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- Of the undoubted talent of M. Henri Fevre there can be no question; he has dramatic intensity, conciseness in his dialogue, and other remarkable qualities rare to find; but all these are allied to deplorable freedom of language. Such, indeed, was its frequent license that the murmur of revolt was very distinctly audible amid an audience fully prepared for crudity of subject and presentation.

The run on the Citizens' Savings Bank, corner of the Bowery and Canal Street, which is said to have been started on Wednesday by a paragraph in an east side Hebrew newspaper, continued all day yesterday, from the opening of the bank until the doors were closed, a little after 3 o'clock. In that time 290 depositors drew their money in sums varying from $5 to $3,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The Frank Courier states that the lymph used by Prof. Koch for the cure of tuberculosis is prepared in an incubating stove within a space that is hermetically sealed and sterilized, and thereby rendered free from fungus. The interior of the air-tight space is divided by an unglazed porcelain diaphragm into an upper and lower section.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 20. -- Congressman W.L. Wilson of West Virginia is at present in this city. He was asked to-day what Speaker Reed's position would be in the next House. He said:

In the Superior Court yesterday, before Judge Dugro and a jury, the old suit brought by Henry C. Miner against Michael B. Leavitt for breach of contract, which everybody thought was settled when the plaintiff obtained $1,000 damages sometime ago, was reopened by the defendant's attorney, ex-Judge Dittenhoefer. When Mr. Miner began to testify, ex-Judge Dittenhoefer objected on the ground that the last bill of particulars was incomplete.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. -- The members of Tong Yoong Co., one of the most extensive Chinese merchandising houses, and who are also labor contractors, have fled to China with $40,000, the wages of 240 Chinese fishermen who recently returned from Alaska. Geong Hen Ven and Haw Mee Sen comprise the firm, which was next to the Six Companies in importance.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 20. -- Attorney General Stone has filed cases in the District Court of Pottawatomie County against the Rock Island, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Chicago and Northwestern, and Sioux City and Pacific Railway Companies asking that a mandatory and perpetual injunction issue against them, compelling obedience to any compliance with the schedule of joint freight rates promulgated by the Iowa Railroad Commissioners in October and heretofore disregarded by the roads.

DUBLIN, Nov. 20. -- The Freeman's Journal, commenting on the attitude of Mr. Stead in regard to Mr. Parnell, says that he is a raging lion seeking to devour any one who disputes his argument that Mr. Parnell ought to be driven into eternal darkness. Mr. Stead, the Journal says, has called a meeting of the vigilance association to consider whether Mr. Parnell is a fit leader of the Irish Nationalists.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 20. -- The great contest by which the Independents hope to unseat Boyd, the Democratic Governor-elect, and the Republican members of the State ticket is begun. The papers were prepared to-day and will all be served before Saturday night.

The official canvass of the vote of this city at the recent election was completed yesterday. It shows that the Tammany candidates for Coroner, County Clerk, and President of the Board of Aldermen received a considerably larger vote than Mayor GRANT, while DE LANCEY NICOLL'S vote for District Attorney was about 5,500 less than GRANT'S, and GORMAN'S for Sheriff was nearly 8,500 below NICOLL'S.

The Indian Summer weather, which everybody has wished might last through the month, was ruthlessly attacked yesterday by a cold wave that was blown down from the lake region by a high and unpleasant wind. It wasn't at all the sort of a cold wave for an Indian Summer to battle with, and with its ally, the wind, it soon had possession of the field.

OMAHA, Neb., NOV. 20. -- A World-Heralv special from Rushville brings word that as soon as troops arrived there to-day couriers rushed with the news to Pine Ridge Agency. Word was received from this agency to-night that the bad Indians under Red Cloud and Little Wound deo{arc that they will meet the troops in battle tomorrow. Agent Royer was interviewed.

This has been a very unprofitable year alike for the wealthy stockholder and the much-advertised player in baseball circles. For some time past rumors have been prevalent to the effect that salaries remained unpaid in the Chicago and Buffalo Players' Clubs. It was learned yesterday, moreover, that some of the New-York men were in a similar fix.

The Rockford, (Ill.) Register, Republican, says "There is a short session left to the framers of the McKinley bill before they are driven out by the on-rush of a reverse majority, the greatest ever known in the history of the Government. The coming session should be proof of the fact that the Republican Party have heard the protest of the country and are willing to obey the imperious mandate of the people so emphatically expressed.

Will the Force bill be taken up seriously by the Senate at the approaching session? Senator DOLPH of Oregon says No, and he is probably right. The Senate has this dilemma presented to it: Either it must pass the Force bill as it came from the House, or it must amend it. If it do the former, the country will be profoundly shocked and the revolution against the Republican Party will be aggravated.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- There promises to be some legislation during the Winter that cannot fail to attract considerable attention in Ohio and other States.

The Republican majority in the House will not be able in the coming short session to dodge an appropriation for the pension payments required under the so-called Disability act. At the labor session, with a Congressional election impending, they made no provision for the expenditures under that law, and even their regular annual appropriation for pension payments fell short of the payments of the last fiscal year by about $8,000,000.

The Republican County Committee got together in the basement of Webster Hall last night, and as it was the first time it has met since the last election, it was an occasion of condolence. The committee's Executive Committee anticipated at its meeting on Wednesday night that last night's meeting would be as gloomy as a funeral unless something was done.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Financial circles were astonished and shocked when it was officially announced from the rostrum of the Stock Exchange at noon to-day that the old-established and hitherto invincible firm of Barker Brothers Co. was unable to meet its obligations and had suspended payments and made an assignment to Edward Mellor.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Mr. Parnell has sent to several of his colleagues a communication to the effect that as long as he is supported by his colleagues and the Irish people he will remain at the helm in politics. He says that he has never sought either office or reward of any kind from any English party, and he does not seek their assistance now.
In the article on the Starch Trust published in your issue of Nov. 18 there are some statements which are liable to create a misapprehension of the facts.

Senator CHANDLER has written a letter to the Tribune which, that paper says, contains a "faithful account" of the political situation in New-Hampshire. If by the phrase "faithful account" is meant a truthful statement, the phrase is a singularly inappropriate one by which to describe Mr. CHANDLER'S letter, for that letter is characteristically, willfully, and uniformly misrepresentative in all its statements concerning matters vital to the issue between the parties.

A paragraph in the Chicago Dry Goods Reporter affords ground for a suspicion that the protected manufacturers of buttons have joined that "vile Democratic conspiracy" to raise prices. The Reporter says:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Moses S. Marks, who, up to a year ago, was employed at the Flour City National Bank, in this city, telegraphed by the Western Union Telegraph Company's line to the National Bank of Commerce, the New-York correspondent of the Flour City Bank, to send immediately $25,000 in currency. He signed the name of the cashier of the bank, William A. Waters, to the dispatch.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20. -- The annual conference of officials and friends of the Law and Order Leagues of the United States and Canada opened in this city to-day. Judge C.C. Bonney of Chicago presiding. Delegates from fifteen States and provinces are in attendance.

Major W.H. Brawley of Charleston, Congressman-elect from the First South Carolina District, is staying at the University Club, of which he is a member. Major Brawley has been a member of the South Carolina Legislature for the past ten years and has served several terms as Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. He is the counsel of the Plant Railway System in South Carolina and is a prominent member of the bar in his State.
BERNE, Nov. 20. -- Dr. Turban of the Davos Sanatorium is treating patients with Prof. Koch's lymph.
WASHINGTON Nov. 20. -- Engineer in Chief George W. Melville has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy. He says:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 21. -- The International Law and Order League Conference to-day listened to letters from Judge Noah Davis, Senators Sherman of Ohio and Evarts of New-York, Secretary Windom, and Assistant Secretary Nettleton of the Treasury Department, and the Rev. Lyman Abbott, commending the work of the leagues and expressing regret at their absence.

The following authoritative Gould announcement was sent out by the Associated Press yesterday: "Mr. Gould was asked with reference to the report that he had got control of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad. Mr. Gould said that this report was erroneous, although he admitted that he owned a considerable portion of Atchison stock.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 21. -- The championship of the smaller New-England colleges, including Williams, Boston Technology, Amherst, Dartmouth, and Bowdoin was decided on the campus here to-day by Williams's victory over Dartmouth. It has been a stubborn and close contest, and Williams rejoices over the victory the more as it was hard won.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 21. -- The extra legislators session conspiracy which Chandler has been engineering for some time past still hangs fire. The Governor and Council have been in session all day, and met again at 7 o'clock this evening, but adjourned shortly after until 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21. -- Democrats in this city are very much amused over the interview with Phil Thompson, Jr., which appeared in yesterday's New-York Sun. As a factor in Kentucky politics Thompson's only influence lies with the whisky ring which employs him as a lobbyist in Washington.

P.S. Newell of Renshaw, Wis., was a passenger on the North German Lloyd steamship Lahn, which arrived yesterday. He declared that he was bringing in nothing dutiable. Attention was called to a small package that was protruding from his pocket. He became embarrassed, was searched, and $500 worth of diamond jewelry taken from him.

When the Committee on Appropriations was called together in Washington on Wednesday, to begin the usual preparation of bills for the session that opens in another fortnight, only four of the members responded. It is plain that the majority do not look forward with much pleasure to the work that is before them.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 21. -- It is the impression up this way that Gov. Hill will allow himself to be elected to the United States Senatorship.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- News from the scenes of Indian disturbances have been coming to Gen. Miles's headquarters all day.

Among the curious explanations of the rout of the high-tariff men is this from Senator MORRILL, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance: "Just preceding the passage of the bill its strong points were not brought out as fully in debate by the Republicans as they might have been. The Democrats, on the other hand, debated the bill incessantly for months.

A visit to Hall Gate any pleasant afternoon cannot fail to impress the casual observer with the fact that unusual interest is being taken in striped-bass fishing this Fall. There have not been so many anglers out in that famous old resort in years as there are this season, and the luck has not been so good in a long time as it is now found.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 21. -- Mrs. James A. Finley, wife of ex-Councilman Finley of this city, now Postmaster and post trader at Pine Ridge Agency, is in this city. Mrs. Finley left the agency a few days ago by direction of her husband, who sent her here for safety.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Chicago will soon have a private bank, or rather a trust company, backed by an immense amount of money. Mrs. Hetty Green, known widely as the richest woman in America, and her son, E.H.R. Green, will be at the head of the concern.

Mrs. Philip J. Joachimsen, President of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society at Grand Drive, Eleventh Avenue and One-hundred and Fifty-first Street, has presented an encouraging report of the past year's work done by that institution. Since the organization of the asylum, on Sept. 6, 1879, the society has not lost sight of the benevolent and religious aim to care for such Jewish children as are required by law to be placed in such an institution.

The suggestion that the rifle work of the Creedmoor Range might be profitably supplemented by an annual meeting of National Guard athletes seems worthy of consideration. The exercises which have been proposed would not only comprise many of those familiar in general athletic meetings, but also some which have a special bearing on the training of the soldier and his usefulness in campaigning.

Barnard College is now one year old, and when its Trustees met last night to look over the work of the year the evidences of satisfactory advance were apparent. But there was one problem that stared them in the face, and that was of a financial nature. Next year the expenditures will be double what they have been. and there is almost certain to be a deficit of $6,500.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The most important event in the way of progress made in the Exposition this week was a permanent selection of a site for the third time, together with such a specific apportionment of buildings that all further disputes on this vexed question are said to be rendered impossible.

ON WOUNDED KNEE CREEK, VIA PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., TO RUSHVILLE, Neb., Nov. 21. -- Accompanied by Buckskin Jack Russell, the scout; Major Burke, and a half breed named Half Eyes, a TIMES reporter has witnessed one of the famous ghost dances of the Sioux. Mounted on Cayuse ponies, the party started early last evening for the Wounded Knee.

The litigation over the estate of Maurice Hyland, who before his death, about two years ago, was a Republican politician of some local consequence and the keeper of a saloon at Park Row and Pearl Street, has been added to by a suit for $15,000 damages for ejectment brought against the Sheriff by M.J. Fleming and John Gleason.

A German paper professes to have discovered the composition of the lymph used by Prof. Koch in the treatment of tuberculosis and the process by which it is prepared. For certain reasons it does not seem probable that this paper has uncovered the secret. It is alleged that broth containing colonies of the tubercle bacilli is placed in the upper part of an incubating stove.

ALTON, Ill., Nov. 21. -- Reliable information received here makes it certain that the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy is preparing to bridge the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers opposite this city in order to effect an entrance into St. Louis at the north end, where they have lately been making heavy purchases of property for terminal stations anti yards. The charters have been secured, the route surveyed, and the plans accepted.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- In July, 1888, Assad Farran, the Syrian interpreter with Stanley's rear guard, wrote a letter to Mr. Camp, engineer of the Upper Congo steamer Henry Reed, the property of the American Baptist Foreign Missionary Society, describing events happening in the Stanley expedition, with special reference to the rear guard under Major Barttelot.

WINCHESTER, Ky., Nov. 21. -- The last and one of the worst participants in the Perry County feud has been released from prison on bail of $8,000, and it is believed now that the French-Eversole war is over. The man in question is Tom Smith.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 21. -- The Grand Jury returned into court just before midnight last night true bills against seventeen persons, nine as principals and eight as accessories before the fact, to the murder of the late Chief of Police, David Hennessy. The principals are John Matranga, alias Carribut; Peter Mutello, Louis Formeno, Salvador Sunzerio, Antonio Scafiro, Bastiano Incardona, Loretto Socareti, Antonio Bagnetto, and Pietro Monasterio.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The attempt to bribe the members of the East Orange Township Committee continues to be the chief topic of conversation in this city and East Orange. Interest had flagged in the matter, but last evening it was revived by the statement from Chairman Coyne that State Inspector of Factories and Child Labor Laurence T. Fell was the guilty man.

The North-German Lloyd had two steamships come up to Hoboken together yesterday morning, the Fulda and the Lahn. Both reported meeting head seas and heavy weather. The Fulda's passengers included Herbert S.E. Anderson, Dr. Hermann Ehrmann, Dr. Max Geiger, Dr. and Mrs. Karl Heitzman, William H. Libby, Otto Melford, the Baroness Marie von Schroter, Gustav Schmidt, and J. Kearney Warren.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Such information as was received to-day at the War Department from the scenes of Indian disturbances was not reassuring. The following telegram was received from Gen. Miles from his Chicago headquarters:

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- The savings bank at Stockbridge, Mass., had an injunction placed upon it this morning by Savings Banks Commissioner Chapin. The injunction was placed upon it owing to complications in reference to loans which have been made by the bank to the Trustee of the F.W. Adams Glendale Woolen Mill.

Senator CULLOM of Illinois does not lose his seat until March, 1895. Settled firmly in that comfortable place, reasonably certain of a couple of years' more enjoyment of the privilege of being counted with the majority, he is prepared to take a philosophic view of the future, and especially of the immediate future, leaving the remoter to take care of itself.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- About the last of December the term of office of Commissioner Augustus Schoonmaker of the Inter-State Commerce Commission will expire and the President have to name his successor. The law by which the commission was established provides that not more than three of the five Commissioners shall be of the same political party.

ST. Louis, Mo., Nov. 21. -- George Woodward, under arrest in London, England, for a big robbery, has a St. Louis record in connection with his crooked work all over the country. He is a shoplifter, confidence worker, diamond swallower, and general all-around crook of the first class.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Commodore Folger, in his report as Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, says that the department will manufacture no more 6-inch guns, 30 calibre, as the performance of the 35-calibre gun has been so successful that the latter gun will be furnished to all of the fast cruisers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Somebody at the White House appears to be a thrifty person. A notice on the front door of the Executive Mansion informs the public that visitors are not admitted after 2 P.M. A New-York gentleman who was "doing" Washington a few days ago escorted two ladies to the White House, but on reaching the door he was told that it was too late to see the house.

The United States war ships Dolphin and York-town will leave the navy yard to-day for the positions in the lower bay, where they will await the arrival of the Brazilian squadron. Admiral Gherardi, who will have charge of the reception, has hoisted his blue pennant on the Dolphin. This vessel will salute the visitors on their first appearance.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The municipal authorities have allotted temporarily to Prof. Koch five buildings in the Moabit suburb of Berlin, for the purpose or aiding him in carrying on his experiments looking to the discovery of a cure for infectious diseases, such as scarlet fever, measles, diphtheria, and typhus fever. Prof. Koch will also carry on his investigations into the nature and cure of cancer in these buildings.

The Directors of the Real Estate Exchange held a meeting yesterday afternoon and adopted the annual report which will be submitted to the stockholders at the beginning of next month. The report makes a very good showing in the matter of receipts, for the Real Estate Exchange has enjoyed larger revenues during the last year than in any year since its organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. --There were rumors on the Street this afternoon that a hitch had occurred in the arrangements for the formation of alpool by several financial houses and banks to assist the Finance Company of Pennsylvania, whoso dienculties were caused by the Barker failure, and that the money would not be subscribed.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Judge Conover has declared forfeited the bonds of the fourteen bookmakers who were indicted last month, on the complaint of Peter De Lacy, for making books at the Monmouth Park track.

Another one of those "S.B. Conover" letters, of which the Sun printed so many in the days when the Colorado carbonate ring was fighting against the Mexican fluxing ores, has recently appeared in the columns which are their habitat, the occasion being the desire of somebody to say something to offset certain statements of THE TIMES concerning the tin-bearing rock of the Harney Peak Mine.

YONKERS, Nov. 21. -- This city is without a Treasurer, and its prospect of getting one under the present peculiar circumstances, is very slim. For twenty years the office has been filled by R.P. Getty, one or the wealthiest and most prominent citizens. His term recently expired. Much to the surprise of everybody he was not renominated by Mayor Millward, but ex-Alderman Henry R. Hicks was named for the place.

It seems to be admitted that there is a deficiency in the pension appropriations for the current fiscal year of something like $40,000,000, which will have to be made up at the coming session of Congress in addition to the appropriation to be made for the next fiscal year. Of course, a deficiency was expected, for the regular appropriation was inadequate to the requirements of the bureau without taking into account the new disability law.

Not the slightest abatement occurred yesterday in the assault upon the tills of the Citizens' Savings Bank by the brigade of bewildered and frightened depositors. The motley line had formed by daybreak, scores of men and women, strangely possessed with the idea that their little hoards were somehow endangered, having spent the night on the sidewalk and in the neighboring cellar ways.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury has delivered judgment, against the Rev. Dr. Edward King, Bishop of Lincoln, who was charged with ritualistic practices, regarding the jurisdiction of the ecclesiastical court and his objections to obey the rubrical directions in the Prayer Book. The Archbishop suspended judgment in regard to the Bishop's rubrical irregularities.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 21. -- The Naval Institute met to-night at the Naval Academy, when a paper written by Lieut. W.F. Fullam, United States Navy, was read on "The System of Naval Training and Discipline Required to Promote Efficiency and Attract Americans." Lieut. Fullam says:

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Chicago thinks of having the great ocean steamers land passengers on the lake front without such passengers leaving the boats from the time they go on board at some European port. The only two methods feasible are by means of a ship railway or a canal such as the Wolland.

" I have to acknowledge," says Gen. Booth in the preface to his long-expected book, which was published in London a few weeks ago, and the American publishers of which are Funk Wagnalls, "valuable literary help from a friend of the poor, who, though not in any way connected with the Salvation Army, has the deepest sympathy with its aims and is to a large extent in harmony with its principles."

Officers who were cadets at West Point shortly after the close of the war will no doubt remember one of their number, whose Indian blood attracted the attention of all with whom he came into contact. He was not bright, but had a magnificent physique, and finally "scraped" through the different examinations until he was graduated and assigned to one of the colored regiments then serving in the Southwest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- One of the first things that President Harrison appears to be desirous of settling, in his determination to mark out for his party the way to victory in 1892, with himself as the candidate, is the status of Mr. Blaine as a possible rival.

THE HEIGHT OF WAVES. -- It is not uncommon in prose works to read of mountainous waves. Exact measurements seldom confirm first impressions. Scoresby found that 40 feet was the height from trough to crest of the largest waves measured by him in the North Atlantic and in a cyclonic storm, when bound for Australia in the Royal Charter.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 22. -- The excitement over the injunction put upon the Stockbridge Savings Bank and the closing of the Glendale Woolen Mills has rather increased than diminished to-day. Many of the depositors did not hear that the bank had been closed until to-day, and there is almost a panic among the depositors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Commodore Ramsay, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, recommends that vacancies in the lower grades of the Pay Corps shall be filled by graduates of the Naval Academy.

The latest ripple in Twenty-second Regiment affairs is the summary breaking up of the "six Captains" coterie through the unexpected change of residence of Capt. James Wells Finch commanding Company H. Capt. Finch is said to have started last week to make a home for himself in the wild West, leaving his resignation as an officer of the National Guard in the hands of his brother officer and intimate friend, Capt. George E.B. Hart.

BERLIN, Nov. 22. -- The bestowal, by Emperor William, of the grand cross of the Order of the Red Eagle upon Prof. Koch was gazetted tonight. This is the first time that this decoration has been bestowed upon any one who did not possess the preceding classes of the order.

-- House and Pet Dogs; Their Selection, Care and Training, with Portraits of Prize Winners, Specimens of all Principal Breeds. New-York: Forest and Stream Publishing Company. -- Of all intelligent dogs, the editor of this volume gives the highest order to the poodle, and after the poodle comes the collie. "Give a dog a bad name" and his fate is doomed, and so Newfoundlands and spitzes and Pomeranians have been blacklisted by many.

A propos of the showing in THE TIMES of a recent date that none of the vessels of the new navy, save the torpedo boat Cushing, is capable of passing through the Canadian canals on their mean displacement draught, it is of interest to know how many war ships Great Britain can pass into the great lakes in anticipation of trouble with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- This afternoon Secretaries Proctor and Noble had a consultation with the President respecting the threatened Indian outbreak in the Northwest. It was decided that two regiments of cavalry should be sent at once to the Pine Ridge Agency from Arizona and New-Mexico.

The dispute between the electric lighting companies and the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company over the rentals to be paid for the use of the subways was the cause of a seven hours' argument yesterday before Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court. The plaintiff companies have begun an action against the Subway Company, the object of which is to have the court fix a just rate of rental to be paid for the conduits.

The Workingman's School is especially intended to serve the needs of the children of the poor. Little ones from the tenement-house districts are admitted to its free kindergarten a three years of age. They go from the kindergarten at six into the school proper, which carries out Froebel's creative method on a higher plane and with a greater minuteness of detail.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- The Princeton Freshmen defeated the Crescent Reserves on the 'Varsity grounds this afternoon by a score of 34 to 0.

" A railroad rate should be like a postage stamp," said Mr. Chauncey M. Depew yesterday in commenting on the general railroad situation for the benefit of the readers of THE TIMES. "It should be as uniform and stable between common points of shipment as coin. Rate cutting is the worst evil with which the railroad business is afflicted.
The interesting interview of a reporter of the New-York Eagle Buzzard, which was unfortunately prematurely revealed in Constantinople, is well worth a place in the columns of THE TIMES.

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 22. -- The people of the village of Westport were treated to a most novel sight a few days ago. On Myrtle Avenue, Westport, lived Miss Ella P. Wheeler, a maiden lady, aged forty-three years. She lived with her sister, Mrs. Moses Wheeler. For nearly thirty years she had lived in the village, and by her kindness endeared to her a large circle of friends, who overlooked her eccentricities.

THE IRON DUKE AND THE TOAD. -- Le petit caporal was worshiped and feared, but men loved and adored the Iron Duke. Of the former, how few are the kindly human traits recorded! while of the other, to this day fresh proofs keep coming to light of simple sweetness dwelling long in the minds of men.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 22. -- The first act in Chandler's conspiracy against the people in this State has been accomplished. The Governor and Council this forenoon formally decided to call an extra session of the Legislature of 1889, to assemble on Tuesday, Dec. 2. The final vote in the Council was 4 to 1 in favor of the session, Merrill, the Democratic Councilor, alone voting against it.

There are few nations still existing as such which offer an example of sudden decline from greatness so remarkable as the history of Spain can show. Not only did she lose her grip on large and flourishing parts of Europe, not only did she forfeit many of her colonies, but what remained to her was struck with barrenness.

The experimental Free Theatre in Paris, upon which a great deal of ill-advised and thoughtless praise has been bestowed by persons who ought to know better, seems to have reached the lowest stage of intellectual and artistic degradation with the production of "L'Honneur," a "comedy" by HENRI FEVRE.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 22. -- The report that the Indians in the Canadian Northwest are preparing to go on the warpath is not confirmed by advices received to-day at militia headquarters. There is no doubt that an uneasy feeling prevails in certain quarters of that vast region. The Indians were recently paid their annuities, and have been doing considerable dancing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- The prosperity of the present dramatic season in Chicago has been the wonder and talk of the profession. Beginning with the preliminary season of the Lyceum company in "The Charity Ball" at Hooley's, it is noticeable that house has not had a poor week. Manager Hooley has had the satisfaction of playing to many thousands of dollars more this Fall than for a like period in any former year.

The more conservative Republicans of Brooklyn are studying the question of a "reorganization" of their party. A committee of which Mr. ROBERT D. BENEDICT is the Chairman is to hold conferences with committees from the Young Republicans, the Union League, the League of Republican Clubs, and a number of prominent Republicans to consider this question.

BOSTON, Nov. 22. -- The State Board of Massachusetts Electric Light Commissioners has rendered a decision in the case of the New-England Shoe and Leather Association and others against the Edison Illuminating Company, which is important both in itself and as a precedent. The Shoe and Leather buildings on Bedford and Kingston Streets each contain steam power and an electric-light plant with incandescent lamps.

What the future of the Business Men's Republican Organization will be has been a matter of interesting post-election speculation with many of the politicians. Some of them think it will have no future; others think that it will cut more of a figure in the future than it has in the past. It did not cut very much of a figure in the last campaign.

There are thirty-two women at least in New York City who desire to know all that it is possible to know about the workings of the Government of the United States. This number comprises the membership of the Society for Political Study, an organization of women which was perfected in 1886 through the efforts of Mrs. Thaddeus B. Wakeman.

APIA. Samoa, per Steamship Alameda to Associated Press, Nov. 22. -- Reports from several outlying districts indicate that the natives are becoming impressed with the idea that the Chief Justice appointed by the three powers under the Berlin treaty is not coming to Samoa, and are applying to redeem their firearms, which had been pledge to storekeepers after the war for food supplies.

There is a fight in the Tammany family in the Fourteenth Assembly District. It has not as yet assumed startling proportions, but even now it is big enough, some people say, to indicate the course of a movement within the Wigwam. This movement has to do with he eviction of all anti-Grant men from the organization and the establishment of the absolute control of the Grant clique.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Deer are quite numerous in Pike and Wayne Counties, Penn., this Fall, and as the open season prevails there hunters are having good sport. A Milford party, consisting of Prothonotary John C. Westbrook and three friends, killed four deer last week in the forests of Blooming Grove and Lackawaxen Townships.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- About 8 o'clock this morning fire was discovered in the engine room which adjoins the main building of the extensive silk mill of Bamford Brothers on Rip Van Winkle Avenue, in this city. An hour later the entire establishment was completely destroyed, 500 hands were thrown out of work, and loss to the amount of $400,000 had been inflicted on the firm.

Our usually sagacious contemporary, the Atlanta Constitution, advises Mr. Cleveland to "cut loose from the Mugwumps." This gives a wrong idea of the relationship. Mr. Cleveland has no absolute authority in the matter. It was not he who attached himself to the Mugwumps, but they who attached themselves to him. He hasn't the power to do what the Constitution asks except at the price of self-stultification.

The reorganization of the badly-demoralized Republican machine has been the interesting topic of the week in Brooklyn politics. Every day the possibility of a satisfactory solution of the problem grows less, owing to the continuation of the bitter opposition between the Nathan and Woodruff forces. This was shown very conclusively on Tuesday, when the Republicans held their first ward meetings since the election.

GREYTOWN, Nicaragua, Nov. 10. -- That tireless activity which is so large a trait of American character, and that capacity for conceiving and carrying out vast enterprises, which Prof. Bryce so often dwells upon in his "American Commonwealth," can in no place and in no circumstances be better exemplified than by a visit to this once pokey town and by viewing the works of the Nicaragua Canal.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22. -- Two students of Johns Hopkins University met early this morning in a grove near the country place of the late T. Harrison Garrett, just north of the city limits, to fight a duel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- The two old historic societies, Clio and Whig, which are now a century and a quarter old, are at present deprived of a suitable place in which to hold their meetings. The old halls having been torn down to give place to larger and handsomer ones, Clio is at present using the Old Chapel and Whig Examination Hall for their meetings.

SUSPENSION OF A HALF-DROWNED MAN BY THE HEELS. -- Reason and experience are agreed, I believe, as to the senselessness and mischievousness of this supposed remedy. But superstitions die hard. Not many weeks ago, in the course of a walk, I fell in with a fish hawker and walked most of the way home with him -- an old soldier

Since the publication of W.F. Apthorp's excellent volume on the "Art Life and Theories of Richard Wagner" this is the most convenient book on the Bairenth composer that has been written in English and made known to Americans. To say that it is convenient is not to place it above other books in point of excellence, but to accord it a high rank in respect of utility.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Chairman Finlay of the Western Passenger Association is now industriously calling the attention of his association to the fact that several lines are paying commissions to Thomas Cook Son of New-York in direct violation of the agreement. He says in a circular letter to the members that these commissions are paid on a 10 per cent. basis of the revenue received from the tickets sold by that firm.

CAMDEN, N.J., NOV. 22. -- Hog cholera is prevalent throughout the upper portion of Atlantic and the lower portion of Camden County. Scores of animals have already fallen a prey to this fatal disease in sections of Waterford, Winslow, and other townships, where nearly all the small-fruit farmers and truckers keep from one to four dozen porkers, both for their own Winter supply of bacon and for profit.

Senator CHANDLER and Congressman MOORE appear to have prevailed upon the Governor and Council of the Elate of New-Hampshire to call an extra session of the Legislature for the purpose of carrying out their scheme for stealing the next Legislature, together with the Governorship and the United States Senatorship.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- W.L. Prettyman, banker at 336 Division Street, closed his bank doors this morning and placed the following notice in the window:

The Retail Grocers' Union is at loggerheads with the wholesale dealers, jobbers, and receivers of fruit and vegetables, the commission merchants who handle California and Southern products, and the importers of foreign fruit. The burden of the difference is the advocacy by the union of the passage of an ordinance by the Board of Aldermen compelling the wholesale dealers to sell their perishable products by weight.

The United States Rolling Stock Company, which has been in operation for nineteen years, has been obliged to invoke a receivership. The suspension of the company was announced in this city yesterday noon, and the stringency of the money market was given as the cause. Mr. H. Hegewisch, President of the company, was appointed receiver in Illinois Friday.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- It may be rather late to go into much detail concerning Bernhardt's dresses as Cleopatra, but I could not refrain from joining in the infections merriment of the actress when I related to her the growing legend of the six meters of crepe required -- the only covering for her graceful, supple figure. "Men Dieu!" cried Sarah, "I should be nue in a quart d'heure."

One-half of the Republican Party of the city and State of New-York, through its leaders, went down the bay yesterday afternoon in the Starin steamer Sam Sloan to bid farewell to Gen. George S. Batcheller, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who was booked to sail on the French line steamer Normandie, to take his post as Minister to Portugal.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- The Cornell football team played its last home game to-day with the Columbia College eleven, and won easily by a score of 36 to 0. Cornell played the best game it ever played here, and with two exceptions did not make a misplay.

The wrangle over the site of the exposition to be hold in Chicago in 1893, to commemorate an event the anniversary of which comes in 1892, seems to have been settled at last. The site is to be the lake front and Jackson and Washington Parks, that is, it is to consist of two or three sites several miles apart.

Placards bearing the words "Cigarette smoking is forbidden in this office" have become quite common in the banking and brokerage houses down town. This prohibitory crusade against the cigarette is said to have been started by Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan, whose hatred of "paper cigars" is intense. As the story goes, Mr. Morgan stepped into a bank in Wall Street one morning to talk about some securities that his firm had been asked to handle.

The Judge sat within his private office composed, complacent, and comfortable. The Judicial day had ended, and between it and the next morning there remained a dinner and an evening at the club. The door opened and a woman entered. She was dressed in black, and her face was concealed by a heavy veil, but the outlines of her form indicated that she was young and comely.

The impending change in the control of the Union Pacific Railway system is said to be the result of an "amicable agreement" between CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS, FREDERICK L. AMES, and JAY GOULD. It is no longer denied that Mr. ADAMS is to retire from the Presidency and that the Gould interest is to take control.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- After a week of unparalleled anxiety, which on Tuesday developed into a money panic and which went near convulsing the whole financial world, the crisis is now neatly rounded off by the intimation that arrangements have been concluded for the continuance of the firm of Baring Brothers in the form, as newly constituted, of a limited liability company.
CHICAGO, NOV. 22. -- Aldaco F. Walker, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Railway Association, formerly a member of the Federal Commission, said to-day, in regard to the Interstate Commerce law:

HARTFORD, Nov. 22. -- The Rev. Dr. J.D. Herr of Milwaukee has received a unanimous call to the Central Baptist Church in Norwich, and has resigned his pastorate in the former city with the view of returning East. During the Presidential campaign in 1884 Dr. Herr was at the head of the Norwich church and supported the St. John ticket.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., Nov. 22. -- The greatest enthusiasm prevails at Swarthmore over the victory of Swarthmore over Haverford to-day. This is the great game of the season and though Centre Rush Mcllvain, the best man of the team was unjustly disqualified in the first part of the game, the score at the end was 30 to 14 in Swarthmore's favor.

The failure of the Concord to reach on her trial trip the average horse power guaranteed in her contract is the more to be regretted since the maximum speed that she showed was very gratifying. But her experience is far from being an unusual one, and the mishaps to her machinery severely handicapped her.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- The Rev. Frederick S. Griffin has been ordained in the priesthood of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and has been appointed by Bishop Doane to the rectorate of the lately-constituted parish of St. Paul's at Sidney, N.Y. The parish has bought a site for a new and larger house of worship.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, 8. D., via Rushville, Neb., Nov. 22. -- The Sioux and Cheyennes mean war. Early this morning Agent Rover received the last ultimatum he will get from the hostiles. It came by courier from the great camp of the ghost dancers now massed on the Medicine Root, and was written by Little Wound, the chief who, to all appearances, will lead the Ogallalas against the soldiers.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Robert P. Getty, Treasurer of the city of Yonkers, whom Mayor Millward has refused to renominate for that office, on the ground that he did not support the city ordinances, this afternoon addressed an open letter to the citizens, in which he says:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- The first case of undervaluation of imports under the new Customs Administration bill came up to-day before United States Commissioner Edmunds, when J. Henry Schmidt of 3,303 Arch Street, a prominent Front Street wool broker, was given a hearing on the charge of falsifying invoices so as to escape the payment of duty.

" It seems to be drawing to an end," said President Quintard of the Citizens' Savings Bank yesterday, addressing Secretary Hasler and referring to the run upon the bank. The Secretary said that he agreed with the President, and the appearance of things in and around the bank was an indorsement of this hopeful view.

Mr. Jefferson's rambling, easy-going story of his experiences reads better in book form than it did in the installments printed in the Century Magazine. It is a book worth having. The publishers have spared no pains with it, and the big quarto volume has covers of stamped vellum with gilt lettering, while the paper and type are of the best.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, NOV. 22. -- The students are diligent in their studies and everything is moving smoothly in the college. The last football game of the season was played yesterday. Field, '92, has been elected Captain of his class football team.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 22. -- The steamship Alameda arrived his morning from Sydney via Honolulu. King Kalakaua prorogued the Hawaiian Legislature Nov. 14. The session had lasted 129 days, one of the longest in Hawaiian annals. The King in his speech said the liberal appropriations which have been made were somewhat in excess of the estimated revenues of the country and would necessitate a careful and economical administration on the part of the Ministry.

The gunnery ship Alarm may be expected to go in commission in the course of a fortnight. Outside of the Navy Department it is not definitely known where she will first be sent. It is well understood, however, that she will proceed before long to the Washington Gun Foundry, receive on board her 6-inch breech-loading gun and secondary battery, and begin duty in connection with the instruction of seamen gunners.

The changes which have been arranged for the gunboat Bennington, if not radical enough to take her out of the Yorktown class, to which she belongs, are yet of a very notable character. According to a summary given of them they contemplate, not only the addition of a flush spar deck, but a change of her main battery throughout from six 6-inch guns to eight 5-inch.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Danny Richardson, speaking on the baseball situation, says:
BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Emperor William has sent a telegram of condolence to the Queen of Holland and has deputed Prince Albrecht to represent him at the funeral.

Mrs. Sarah F. Henssler, the widow of Prof. Frederick W. Henssler, committed suicide by shooting herself in the head yesterday morning at 8 o'clock at her residence, 873 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, while suffering from a sudden attack of religious mania.

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- James C. Carter, George F. Dauforth, James C. Smith, C. Alonzo Kellog, Homer A. Nelson, and William B. Hornblower, the Committee on Revision of the Constitutional Commission, have laid before the Commissioners their polished version of the amendments agreed upon at the last meeting of the commission in August.

Whatever the outcome of the Indian troubles at the West, they have already raised the question whether it would not be good policy for Congress to authorize a moderate increase of the army. It has been suggested, indeed, that the present excitement may have been purposely exaggerated in the reports with a view to securing such an increase.

The title chosen for this new biographical series will be made sufficiently elastic to embrace almost every class of eminent men who in any way have advanced the fame and fortunes of this country. As in the case of the Calverts and of Oglethorpe, these men will not from necessity be Americans either by birth or adoption.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 23. -- A Pioneer Press special from Bismarck, N.D., says: "Considerable excitement was caused last night by an assault committed by an Indian on Miss Dora Wright, a stenographer employed at the Capitol. While on her way home at 9 o'clock in the evening she was accosted by an Indian, and when she tried to evade him he struck her on the head with some blunt instrument and knocked her down.
