An event which is attracting general attention in Canada has been the remarkable revival of monasticism in the Dominion during the past few years. What with the Trappists, Sulpicians, Carthusians, and Jesuits, Protestant Ontario anticipates a return to the conventual system of the Middle Ages. This remarkable development is principally confined to the Province of Quebec, where monastic orders now possess property aggregating in value $1,000,000.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The monetary situation, under the judicious policy of the Bank of England Directors, assisted by the leading banks, has become unusually strong. A daily material addition to the bank stock of bullion is made. One and a half million pounds in Russian gold is due on Monday, a million more is on the way from Brazil, three-quarters of a million from Australia, and smaller amounts from European markets.

Frank W. Smith left his office at 27 School Street, Boston, on the morning of Nov. 8 without notifying any of his friends of his intentions and he has not been seen or heard from since. He was twenty-two years of age, slender, about 5 feet 7 inches in height, and of light hair and complexion. He boarded with his brother at 7 Asburton Place, and the two young men were unusually close companions.
The recent action of the manufacturers of carpets is mentioned as follows in the American Wool Reporter's review of the yarn market, published on the 20th:

To a reporter of the Dallas (Texas) News, who asked him who would be the Democratic candidate for President in 1892, Congressman Mills said: "The Nation has answered that question and answered it in no uncertain tone. I believe that Grover Cleveland will be the next President of the United States. He stands at the head of the tariff-reform movement.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- A rumor is current -- and is credited at the Carlton Club and other Conservative centres -- that Lord Salisbury, deeming the time opportune while the Parnell scandal is fresh in the minds of the people, has decided to dissolve Parliament in the Spring. Advice urging Conservative associations throughout the country to improve their local organizations immediately were issued yesterday from the central office of the Conservative Party.

COLUMBIA, Nov. 23. -- There is a serious race riot at Bishopville, Sumter County. Gov. Richardson to-day received a dispatch from the Sheriff, informing him that a mob of negroes had torn down the jail and released two prisoners. The dispatch stated that the trouble was serious, and that the people were unable to protect themselves and asked that troops from Sumter, ten miles distant, be sent to their rescue immediately.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 23. -- Naturally Capt. R.H. Pratt, Superintendent of the Government Indian Training School here, takes a deep interest in the Messiah craze in the Northwest. Many of the students under his charge are the children of the Indians affected by the craze, and the threatened uprising is a subject of serious thought and discussion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Secretary Proctor did not receive any information to-day from the seat of the threatened troubles with the Indians. He had a consultation, however, with Gen. Schofield respecting matters in that section in which the situation was talked over. The regiments of cavalry which it has been decided to send to the Pine Ridge Agency are the Seventh, now stationed at Fort Riley, Kan., and the Sixth, now in New-Mexico and Arizona.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23. -- There have been reports in circulation for some time that Congressman Niedringhaus and his brother intended erecting in St. Louis a tin plate mill, but they were not generally credited.

The statement from Ottawa that the seal-catching statistics of the Dominion show an increase in the numbers as well as in the aggregate value of the skins secured this year over last is rather surprising. There had previously been reports that the private schooners of Victoria suffered, like the new lessees of the Pribylov Islands, from a scarcity of the animals in Behring Sea.

-- Little, Brown Co. of Boston have made arrangements with John Murray for an American edition of the entirely new, revised, and greatly enlarged edition of Dr. William Smith's "Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities." The first volume of the work will be ready in December and the second in the Spring.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 23. -- A Bee special from Pine Ridge Agency says: "The first knowledge that the ghost dancers had commenced plotting to entrap the soldiers was brought to Indian Agent Royer last night by William D. McGaa, formerly an Indian scout and now a wealthy ranchman living in the vicinity of Buffalo Gap.

The grossest kind of neglect of duty on the part of certain members and employes of the Board of Coroners brought an undeserved measure of anxiety and suffering upon a bereaved family in this city about two weeks ago. The facts of the case have but just been made public.

Unlike some names of charitable societies, that of the "Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor" in this city is a strictly accurate one, and describes not only the purpose but the actual work of the organization. An abstract of the annual report will be found in another column, and we bespeak for it a careful reading.

Defects in the ballot law of this State. as revealed by the experience of the late election, are naturally the subject of careful consideration by those who are interested in the success of the new system of voting, and it will undoubtedly lead to propositions for the prompt amendment of the law when the Legislature meets in January.

Manning's Yacht Agency has sold for Mr. Horace Binney the cutter yacht Indra, 43 feet over all, 36 feet water line, 10 feet beam, and 7 feet draught, designed by George K. Boutelle of Waterville, Me., and built by George Lawley Son of Boston. It was launched in 1887. The yacht has been purchased by Mr. Seymour S. Hyde of this city, and will fly the flag of the Atlantic Yacht Club.

ABILENE, Kan., Nov. 23. -- A lady of this county, who left here a year ago to join the Topolobampa colony, on the western coast of Mexico, founded by A.K. Owen of New-York, has returned, and tells a narrowing tale of the sufferings of the colonists. After describing the troubles of the trip and the arrival in the harbor of Cinaloa, she says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Republicans who imagine that it will be an easy thing for the majority of the present Congress to pass the Force bill and the reapportionment scheme before the expiration of the session beginning one week from to-morrow might not feel so confident if they should study the record of the last Congress.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23. -- The Western Watchman, edited by the Rev. P.H. Phelan, and the recognized organ of Irish Catholics in this section, prints the following editorial repudiating Parnell:

Two boys who had been breathlessly hunting for a policeman suddenly ran into the arms of Officer Robert T. Claney at 1 o'clock yesterday morning as he was patrolling his beat on First Avenue, near East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, and told him that a drunken man had been lying for some time motionless, as though asleep, on the sidewalk in front of 443 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street.

The call from Republicans for a revision of the McKinley tariff law becomes stronger every day, and is made by a greater number of papers of good party standing. Some public men of the party, but not many, have given countenance to this demand. The expression of opinion in this sense is stronger than it is definite.
Sir Morell Mackenzie, the imperial doctor and highest known authority on the throat and lungs, has just published a pamphlet in which he gives advice to public speakers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Notwithstanding the fact that to-day was Sunday, Gen. Miles was at his desk early in the forenoon, as also were Gen. Williams, Col. Corbin, and other United States Army officers. It was after 2 o'clock this morning when the commanding General left the headquarters in the Pullman Building after he had kept the wires hot with orders to the commanding officers with the troops in the Northwest now among the Indians.

The testimony of visiting physicians concerning the efficacy of Prof. KOOCH'S remedy for tuberculosis substantially confirms the report made by the professor in his own published statement of the 14th inst, and it is well to bear in mind the assertions and suggestions which that statement contained.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 23. -- The King of Holland died at 6 o'clock this morning.

A correspondent writes: "The construction of this railway, which was first suggested in 1887, has now been sanctioned. Owing to financial reasons a continuous line of rail is for the present abandoned, but uninterrupted communication with the Pacific is to be established by a combination of railway and waterway in accordance with the plans prepared by the Russian Ministry of Communications.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 23. -- James S. Clarkson, wife, and son are in this city, stopping at the Battery Park Hotel, where they have been for three weeks.

When the Hedding Methodist Episcopal Church was built in Seventeenth Street, between First and Second Avenues, thirty-eight years ago, it was considered too far up town to assure it of success. But as it grew with that section of the city it attained financial strength, and has become one of the best properties in connection with the Methodist Church of this city.

Among the numerous echoes of the recent horse show none has been louder and more far-reaching than the controversy which has arisen in regard to the decision of the judges in what was known as the high-school class. It will be remembered that in this class, to compete for the prize of $150 offered by the New-York Riding Club, three horses were entered.

A question has arisen among naval critics as to the wisdom of the position chosen for the bridges on the new warships. On the Yorktown and Concord the bridges are built over the topgallant forecastle. On the Philadelphia and Baltimore the bridges are likewise jammed close up into the bows. The Chicago has two bridges, one well forward and a second well aft.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 24. -- At the meeting of the American Association held here to-day the Athletics of Philadelphia were dropped from the list of members, and in all probability the Players' League of Philadelphia will be admitted in their place. Efforts were made to drop the Rochester, Syracuse, and Toledo clubs, but as they are members in good standing their franchises will have to be purchased to make room for other Players' League clubs.

There seems to be considerable doubt whether "Boss" CHANDLER will be able to control the Legislature of New-Hampshire after he gets it together in extra session. The House of Representatives consists of 313 members, and a majority of the whole number elected, or 157, is necessary to a quorum for the transaction of business.

" A somewhat ominous opening of the week on Wall Street," was the expression of opinion heard at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning when the assignment of Edward Brandon of 2 Wall Street, a well-known stock broker, was announced. Mr. Brandon has been a member of the Stock Exchange since Sept. 8, 1852. He has at times served as a member of its Governing Committee.

Albert Griffin, a young man who is employed as a salesman in Alva Orcott's gentlemen's furnishing goods store, on Main Street, New-Rochelle, had a narrow escape from being burned to death early yesterday morning. At about 1:30 o'clock he was awakened from his sleep, as he lay on a sofa near the stove, by hearing a noise in the forward end of the store.

Another adjournment was taken yesterday in the cases of the Excise Commissioners who are under indictment for malfeasance of office in not deciding upon a large number of complaints against saloon keepers for keeping their places open near the polls on election day in 1889, made by members of the City Reform Club. This time no date has been fixed for the trials, but the lawyers agreed to arrange a time at their own convenience.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Col. John R. Baker, a well-known stock operator, is missing. He lived in handsome style at Devon, Penn., near this city, and is known to have been been quite heavily interested in Lehigh Navigation Company stock, which has depreciated in value during the past few weeks.

BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- Park Street Church to-night unanimously extended a call to the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Virgin of New-York to become its pastor, as the successor of Dr. Gregg, who goes to the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, in Brooklyn.

An ingenious, logical, cleverly written one-act play called "After Thoughts," by Augustus Thomas, whose "Man of the World" is so pleasantly remembered, was acted before "A Pair of Spectacles" at the Madison Square Theatre last evening. Nothing could be slighter in texture or less theatrical in quality than this piece, which lacks even the deference to popular sentiment that is shown in Bronson Howard's "Old Love Letters."

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 24. -- Mrs. Birchall and Mrs. West-Jones left Woodstock for their home in England this afternoon. The former looks very thin and worn. Interest in the case is somewhat revived here by a letter on the Birchall case published by Prof. Goldwin Smith in which he says: "It seems to be the fact, though strange, that many of our people believe Birchall to have been wrongly put to death.

Chicago, Nov. 24. -- A legal question of great importance was argued to-day before Judge Blodgett in the United States District Court. Upon its decision depends the question whether or not the inter-State Commerce Commission can enforce the inter-State law to the extent of punishing the railroads or shippers who violate its provisions.

ELMIRA, Nov. 24. -- Richardson, the wellknown second baseman of the Giants, says that he is sick and tired of the workings of the Players' League and he wants to get back with hie old employers. He thinks that the new organization is in poor shape. "It is true," he said, "that the club owes me for six weeko' services. I have not received any money since SepL 1.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- In dramatic developments the session of the World's Columbian Commissioners to-day went beyond those of any meeting since the commission was organized. John Boyd Thatcher made an earnest and dignified protest against James G. Blaine's Pan-American reciprocity arrangement, which was sprung on the commission.

The result of the re-enumeration of the inhabitants of Brooklyn taken by the Police Department was made publlo yesterday by Mayor Chapin. The total population, according to these figures, Is 853,04:5. The following shows the population of each ward:

The dispatch from Albany which we printed yesterday in regard to the work of the commission appointed to prepare amendments to the judiciary article of the State Constitution indicates that its work is likely to excite a good deal of criticism, and may be subject to considerable modification before the proposed amendments are finally submitted to a vote of the people.

August Belmont, the famous banker and turfman, died yesterday morning at 3 o'clock at his residence, 109 Fifth Avenue. The cause of Mr. Belmont's death was pneumonia, from which he had been suffering only three days. The beginning of the malady was a cold contracted at the recent horse show in Madison Square Garden.

The report of the Controller of the Currency has been completed. The condition of the national banks is shown in it to be, on the whole, extremely healthy, and the system has made steady progress during the past year. The net number of banks has increased in that time by 248 -- a larger advance than in any one year since 1865, or, practically, since the system was fairly established.
BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- Harvard's formal celebration of her triumph over Yale was held to-night with great show and cheering.
ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- The State Commission in Lunacy has adopted two orders which will be of much benefit to the welfare of the insane in the State insane hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day affirmed the judgment of the Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York, Judge Lacombe presiding, in the case of Shibuya Jugiro, the Japanese confined in Sing Sing Prison, New-York, unaer sentence oF death by means of electricity.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- It is stated this evening upon excellent authority that at the meeting of the Nationalist members of the House of Commons, to be held to-morrow before the opening of Parliament, Mr. Parnell will announce his retirement from the leadership of the Irish party. The Star, the leading home rule paper in England, reiterates this statement.

A good deal has been said lately in relation to the management of the Princeton-Yale football game to be played at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, Thursday afternoon, and the management has been subject to adverse criticism because a comparatively limited number of persons had been charged more for tickets than the advertised price of $1 for admission and $2 for a reserved seat.

The death of old King WILLIAM of Holland can hardly make even a ripple of disturbance in European politics, so thoroughly has its occurrence been provided for. More than once during the last two or three years a fatal termination of his maladies had seemed to be near at hand, and the whole method of procedure thereupon was determined.

In St. Stephen's Church in East Twenty-eighth Street there was a quiet wedding yesterday afternoon, when Miss Amelia Sarony-Lambert was married to Dr. Thomas A. King by the Rev. Father Colton. The guests were ushered into the church by Messrs. H.B. Henson, H.B. Besemer, M.M. Edmondson, and Frank McGovern.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 24. -- Senator John W. Daniel, in expressing his views on leading national questions to THE TIMES'S correspondent, said the recent victory means permanent Democratic ascendency if they improve their opportunity; not if they do not. Continuing, the Senator said:
LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The Queen's speech, which will be reed at the opening of Parliament to-morrow, was communicated at to-night's Ministerial dinners. It is of unusual brevity.

COLON, United States of Colombia, Nov. 13. -- The Enterprise arrived here last evening, thirteen days from New-York, relieving the Kearsarge, which sails to-day for Key West, there to await orders, having been in these waters two months.

Some of the Republican journals in regions where the editors seem to come closer to the people than do those of the Eastern organs are warning their party that if it do not abandon the extreme protectionist idea the fate of the old Whig Party, when it refused to abandon the "dough face" attitude toward slavery, awaits it.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- The eleven lea ves to morrow at noon for Chicago, where they will play the University Club on Thanksgiving Day. Thirteen men will be taken on the trip.

Until the new Park Comissioners appointed by Mayor GRANT last week shall have had time to gain some special knowledge of the work they have to do, of the needs of the parks, and of the policy and methods of their more experienced associates in the board, Messrs. GALLUP and HUTCHINS, there will be some apprehension in the public mind lest unwise measures be hastily and inconsiderately adopted.

" The Ironmaster," A.W. Pinero's very creditable adaptation of Georges Ohnet's" Le Maitre de Forges," was presented by the Kendals before a large and demonstrative audience at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last evening. This is the play in which they seemed to be best liked last year. There is probably a greater audience for Ohnet in this country than there is in France.

Up to the end of the campaign our high-tariff friends asserted that prices had not been raised. After the election they admitted that prices really were raised during the campaign as the result of a "vile Democratic conspiracy." Now they say that such prices a were raised have been lowered.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 24. -- A special to the Tribune from Pierre, S.D., says:

The advance in east-bound freight rates from Chicago which was ordered by the Trunk Lines Association a few weeks ago went into effect yesterday. The rates now go back to the basis of last May, which is an advance over the recent tariffs of an average of 25 per cent. on all classes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The Indian Messiah has been found. A letter received to-day by Gen. Miles from an army officer at Los Angeles, Cal., tells the particulars. The letter says:

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- State Engineer Bogart has recently returned from an extended inspection of the State canals, in company with Superintendent of Public Works Hannan. He found the general condition of the canals very good indeed; there has been plenty of water during the past season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The annual report of Mr. Lacey, the Controller of the Currency, gives the following information in reference to the affairs of national banks, and covers the operations of the bureau for the twelve months ended Oct. 31, 1890:

There was a crowd of lawyers interested in the Sugar Trust litigation in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, when Judge Pratt handed down a decision denying the motion to vacate the judgment entered over a week ago on the application of Duncan Cameron and John H. Gleason. The applicants were the Havemeyers and their associate Trustees of the defunct trust, and of them Judge Pratt says, in his opinion:

The New-York Retail Grocers' Union held a meeting last night at its headquarters, 213 East Twenty-third Street, which was largely devoted to replying to the numerous objections that the wholesale dealers in fruits and vegetables have put forward against the adoption of a city ordinance requiring all dealers, wholesale and retail, to sell by weight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Everybody about army headquarters to-day was busy. Telegrams were being constantly received from posts over the West, and Gen. Miles was sending replies and directing the movement of troops. A large force, larger than has been mustered in the West since 1876-7, will be in the region about Pine Ridge by Wednesday.

In view of the contemplated change in the dress of seamen in the United States Navy, it is of interest to note changes Just brought about in the British service. The new uniform regulations for petty officers, men, and boys of the British Navy bear date of Sept. 30. They have not been compulsory until within the last few weeks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 25. -- Gov. Campbell, Private Secretary Meeker, and Adjt. Gen. Hawkins are now in Cincinnati, having been summoned to testify before the legislative committee investigating the conduct of the defunct Board of Public Improvements of that city.

Jay Gould and Russell Sage went to Boston yesterday afternoon to attend the meeting of the Union Pacific Railroad stockholders which will be held there to-day. The Board of Directors will be pretty thoroughly reorganized at this meeting, and Jay Gould's influence will undoubtedly dominate the future policy of the company.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 25. -- The graduating exercises of the Medical Department in Dartmouth College occurred here this evening in the college church. Music was supplied by the church organ, with J.H. Proctor as organist. The programme of the evening was as follows: Prayer, by President S.C. Bartlett; address, George Cook, M.D.; music; oration, J.H. Egbert, A.B.; valedictory, E.P. Pitman, A.B.; music; address, President Bartlett; conferring degrees; music.
In your issue of to-day there appears a note under the head of "Playgrounds for Children," regarding the work of the Trustees of the New-York Society for Parks and Playgrounds for Children.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25. -- The Dominion Fishery Department is advised that the British sealing schooner Triumph has returned to Victoria, B.C., after an experimental sealing trip to Behring Sea during the Fall months. The voyage was very severe, the weather at times being inclement and the cold in Behring Sea intense. On the trip up heavy seas were shipped.

Bronson Howard has written a letter from London to Charles Frohman which is of more than ordinary interest at this time, when native American drama seems to be gaining a firm foothold in the land of its birth. Mr. Howard was one of the first to show that American subjects can be successfully treated for the stage, and his opinions on the English and American dramas are valuable.
BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- Benjamin F. Shillaber, so widely known as "Mrs. Partington," died at his residence in William Street, Chelsea, at 5:45 P.M. to-day, of diabetes and heart failure.

Harvard has during so many years been deprived of occasions for rejoicing over her annual football match with Yale that even her opponents will not grudge her the exuberant exultations in which she indulged on Monday night. We trust, however, that the remark of one professor on that occasion to the effect that "crimson and blue never harmonize unless the crimson is on top" is not to be accepted as literally true.

The Sioux Falls (S.D.) Press of Nov. 20 printed an interesting interview with Bishop Hare upon the Messiah craze. The Bishop had returned the day before from a protracted stay on the Sioux reservation. While there he had an excellent opportunity to view the condition of the Indians and examine into the craze. He has visited nearly all the agencies in the course of the year, and about Oct. 1 was at Standing Rock.

The flowers at the big show at Madison Square Garden were seen to much better advantage by yesterday's visitors than by those of the opening day. They had received overnight the magic touch of an artist, under which the crude arrangement of a hasty preparation was resolved into a well-ordered and symmetrical exhibition.

From an incident which occurred in the Special Term of the Superior Court yesterday morning it would appear that there is a firm in this city grinding out illegal divorces with perfect disregard for the law. In 1877 William Coppersmith, a jeweler doing business at 17 Maiden Lane, married. Until May, 1889, he and his wife, Mary, lived together, but in their twelve years of married life no children were born to them.

In the daily papers of the past week have appeared accounts of an operation performed at Charity Hospital on Sunday, Nov. 16, by Dr. A.M. Phelps. The operation was done upon the shortened leg of a boy of fourteen, and he is presumably to be benefited by the ingrafting of a piece of bone from the leg of a living dog.
PORTLAND, Oregon. Nov. 25. -- In the United States District Court to-day a decree was entered appointing Joseph Simon receiver of the Oregon Improvement Company. His bonds were fixed at $100,000.

Dr. Richard Kalish's paper on "The Resorption of Immature Cataract," read at the County Medical Society's meeting Monday night, provoked a lively and at times almost a bitter discussion. The treatment explained by Dr. Kalish (which he claims is his own discovery) leads to the conclusion that cases of immature uncomplicated cataract can be permanently benefited by a method of conjoined instillation and manipulation.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 25. -- The reorganization of the Oregon Improvement Company has been completed. Resident Manager McNeil has issued a circular announcing a number of changes in the heads of departments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Gen. Thomas Casey, Chief of the Corps of Engineers, has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of War, including estimates for continuing the present scheme of coast defense. He asks for next year nearly $3,000,000, to be expended at New-York, Boston, San Francisco, Hampton Roads, and Washington.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Lawrence T. Fell, the State Labor Inspector, found it necessary this evening to publish this card asking a suspension of public judgment as to the charges of attempts to purchase the votes of two East Orange Town Committeemen for the new rapid transit franchises that have been made against him:

An election campaign is regarded by a certain class of impecunious persons as harvest season. Candidates for office are looked upon as legitimate prey, and they are badgered, cajoled, coaxed, and intimidated in innumerable ways to part with their silver and their greenbacks. The name of the political "striker" is legion, and his ways are full of sinuosity and persistency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Live-Saving Service, according to the annual report of Mr. S.I. Kimball, General Superintendent, embraced, at the close of the last fiscal year, 233 stations, 176 being on the Atlantic, 46 on the lakes, 10 on the Pacific, and 1 at the Falls of the Ohio, Louisville, Ky.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 25. -- The General Assembly convened to-day, and no Legislature that ever sat in South Carolina has awakened a keener interest in the minds of the people or darker forebodings as to its outcome. Coming in on the great popular wave which has swept over the country and put the farmers in the lead, it is feared that it may undertake to reform some things that had better be let alone.

The ministers of all sects and creeds who advocated reform in municipal politics at the late election and lent their support to the movement for reform represented by the People's Municipal League have resolved to form a permanent organization for the study and discussion of civic problems and to hold stated meetings for that purpose during the Winter months.
DETROIT, Nov. 25. -- The Potts Salt and Lumber Company filed mortgages for $600,000 this morning at Oscoda, Iosco County, Mich.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- One of the hospitals in this city has already refused the applications of 400 physicians who have come here to study the Koch method of treatment on the ground that it is impracticable to instruct successfully the large number of those who desire to study the method.

It seems very difficult to get into the minds of business men -- at least of those whom admiring neighbors send to Congress -- the fact that the great mass of business in this country is done, not with money, but with credit based directly on commodities, or on securities which in their turn owe their origin to commodities.

The Brazilian squadron, consisting of the cruisers Aquidaban and Guanabara, was sighted close to the Highlands Light shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The fact was at once telegraphed to Sandy Hook and transmitted by signal from that point to the United States war vessels Dolphin and Yorktown, which were lying at anchor inside the Horseshoe.

Our readers will find described in another column a curious trick by which bribery seems to have been made possible in Columbia County in defiance of the secret ballot act. It is very simple. Votes were bought on time, to be paid for only when the buyer was convinced that they had been actually cast.
BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- "Brethren, let this defeat be to all of us a new lesson in constancy and courage."

WHEELING West Va., Nov. 25. -- Things took a sensational turn in the trial of Harry B. Seybold, charged with stealing $24,000 from the Bank of Wheeling. To-day the defendant went on the stand and swore that he did not take the money, but that it was taken by Harry W. List, a son of one of the partners and himself a large stockholder of the bank.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- The last sad rites to the memory of the Rev. M.J. McSwiggan, late pastor of St. Joachim's Church, in Matteawan, were celebrated to-day from that edifice. The chief mourners were an aged mother and two nieces. The attendance at the church was large, and a great number of priests were in attendance. The Archbishop was represented by his secretary, Mgr. McDonald.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 25. -- The Tribune's Standing Rock Agency (N.D.) special says the two Indian scouts sent out Saturday night by Col. Drum, commanding Fort Yates, with instructions to scour the country between here and Sitting Bull's camp and ascertain if any Indians were on the warpath and the state of affairs at Sitting Bull's camp, returned last evening and reported having seen no Indians on the warpath.

One of the prettiest wedding ceremonies celebrated this season took place yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock in St. Xavier's Church, in West Sixteenth Street, when Miss Aimee Marguerite Coudert, daughter of Charles Coudert, was married to McKenzie Semple, Assistant District Attorney. The Rev. Father George Kenny, S.J., came from Montreal to officiate.

Your editorial on "Pension Monstrosities" in to-day's issue is a matter well worth reading and deserving of consideration, especially by those who call themselves Republicans and who feel wedded to that party, and who seem unable to censure it for any fault, though always willing to excuse it for any error.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 25. -- There was considerable excitement in this city to-day over a telegram published in one of the morning papers from its Montgomery correspondent stating that ex-President Grover Cleveland would reach New-Orleans in the afternoon.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Parliament reassembled to-day. The Queen's speech opening the session was as follows:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25. -- The national bank of Shelbyville some months ago closed its doors, and J.M. Milton was appointed receiver. The liabilities of the bank were $180,000 and the cash assets about $16,000. The capital was $50,000. The greater part of the indebtedness was due other banks, most of the depositors having been paid in cash.

The Children's Aid Society held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the American Exchange National Bank, 128 Broadway. There were present William A. Booth, Robert J. Livingston, A.B. Stone, James R. Roosevelt, J. Kennedy Tod, Howard Potter, Charles E. Whitehead, William Church Osborn, Gustav E. Kissel, and George S. Coe.

NEW-HAEN, Nov. 25. -- Two wrecks occurred last evening on the New-York and New-Haven Railroad. At Coscob the freight train bound west dropped a brake beam while going at a good rate of speed, causing the rails to spread and throwing the train from the track. The cars were badly piled up. The train hands escaped by jumping.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Mrs. Eva Hamilton, after serving a little over thirteen months of her two-years' sentence, is free again. The Court of Pardons took up her case this afternoon and after only a brief consideration granted the pardon by a unanimous vote.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The report of Commissioner of Internal Revenue Mason upon the operations of that service during the past fiscal year shows that the total collections for the year were $142,594,696, or $11,700,262 more than the collections during the previous fiscal year. The total cost of collection was $4,095,-111, being $90,618 less than the cost for the preceding year.

I write to call your attention to a fact which I consider of great interest and importance relative to the present disturbances among the Sioux Indians. Should you view it from the same standpoint as my own, I trust that you may be inclined to bring the matter to the attention of your readers.

Here is an article I wrote about whist that I feel should be known by the public who indulge in this interesting game, and as there certainly must be thousands of such persons who are readers of your paper, I send it to you and hope you may agree with me.

CARLSBAD, Nov. 25. -- Yesterday's flood had its origin in the bursting of the dam inclosing Tepl Pond. When the dam gave way the river instantly rose to a fearful height and a volume of water ten feet deep poured through the Alto and Neue Wiese, Marienbader Street, the market place, and the Sprudelgasse. The gas and water works were completely ruined.

It is evident that Internal Revenue Commissioner MASON has no fancy for the task imposed upon him by the new tariff law of ascertaining what bounty the producers of sugar may be entitled to, and he suggests that it be shifted to the Department of Agriculture. The Internal Revenue Bureau is organized for the work merely of collecting certain taxes, and has no machinery for making disbursements.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25. -- Developments in connection with the famous Stillwell case add more mystery to the already mysterious affair. Amos J. Stillwell, a millionaire twice over, was murdered while asleep beside his wife at their home in Hannibal, Mo., on the night of Dec. 29, 1888. It was evident the crime was not committed for money.
DUBLIN, Nov. 26. -- The Freeman's Journal, in a leading article on Mr. Gladstone's letter, says:

WASHINGTON, NOV. 26. -- The Board of Visitors to the West Point Military Academy, of which Senator Hawley is President, says in its report that the buildings were found to be in very good condition, and, with the appropriations already made, the post will have all necessary buildings. The estimates for improvements ($201, 017) submitted by Superintendent Wilson are, says the board, undoubtedly necessary.

The Winter time table of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad will take effect Nov. 30. The Saratoga and Montreal express thereafter will leave Grand Central Station at 7:45 A.M., instead of 8:30, as at present. A new train, the fast mail and State express, will be scheduled at 9:10 A.M., taking passengers for Albany, Utica, Syracuse, Rochester, Batavia, and Buffalo only.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 26. -- The claim of Senator Ingalls that he will be United States Senator from Kansas to succeed himself appears to have good foundation, if his plans or the plans of his friends prevail. The preliminary steps have already been taken for a contest in the Senate, it being certain that the Alliance will command more than enough votes to elect.

The St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, was last night the proud protector of the two football teams upon whose muscles the result of today's game depend. Yale arrived in the afternoon and Princeton came later, to mingle the orange and black with the blue, and so survey the physical charms of their rivals with a solicitude that was close akin to bitter enmity.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- S. Frank Holsapple of Hudson has been appointed by Gov. Hill a manager of the House of Refuge for Women at Hudson, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Gen. Hoysradt.

The fact that the operatic institution of this city has acquired force and independence was adequately demonstrated last evening. A new season was begun at the Metropolitan Opera House with the performance of an opera never before heard in America by a company including three principal singers wholly unknown to this public, and of whom one -- a tenor -- sang the leading role in the opera for the first time in his life.

Mr. Jay Gould assumed control of the Union Pacific Railroad yesterday and made his trusted friend Sidney Dillon President in place of Charles Francis Adams. The Board of Directors met in Boston. The resignations of Mr. Adams, John P. Spaulding, James A. Rumrill, and Samuel Carr, Jr., as members of the board were promptly accepted, and Jay Gould, Russell Sage, Henry B. Hyde, and Alexander E. Orr were elected m their places.

The office of Gray Co. and Robert M. White, at 53 Broadway, "dealers in ready-made divorce decrees on easy payments and without any publicity," was not open for business yesterday. The subpoena which Judge Truax issued on Tuesday had had its effect. Even the young woman who had said that she was at the office for a short time each afternoon in the capacity of a secretary did not appear there yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 26. -- The famous Andersonville Prison stockade and grounds near Amerious, Ga., where thousands of Union soldiers were confined during the war of the rebellion, are now the property of E.S. Jones Post, G.A.R., of Macon. The land was under several mortgages, which were held by loan companies. Yesterday the last payment was sent to the Corbin Loan and Banking Company and Jones Post got the title to the property.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26. -- The officers of the Naval Academy gave to-night their opening hop of the season. The boathouse, where the hop was given, was decorated with flags. No one formally received.

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The German budget for the coming fiscal year makes the revenue and expenditures balance at 1,130,645,888 marks. The expenditures are divided into three groups, as follows: Permanent expenditures, 941,135, 067 marks; non-recurring ordinary, 90,720,452; non-recurring extraordinary, 98,790,369.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The marriage of Miss Emly Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hyde, to Mr. Barry Bulkley was celebrated at noon to-day in St. John's Church, Georgetown, the Rev. Mr. Register officiating. The ushers were Messrs. Gunnell, McCauley, Snowden, Pickering Dodge, Gaillard Hunt, Willis, and Trescott, and the maids of honor were Miss Sue Hyde, cousin of the bride, and Miss Bettie Knight of Baltimore.

ITHACA, Nov. 26. -- On Tuesday, Aug. 18, 1885, the citizens of this State were startled by the sudden announcement of the death of the Hon. E.K. Apgar, who was then Deputy State Treasurer. The grief felt at the death of the brilliant journalist and politician and the most distinguished son of Tompkins County was universal throughout the State.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 26. -Judge Robinson in the Superior Court in this city to-day admitted to bail A.R. Wilton, Secretary and Treasurer of the Shelton Comb Company, who was committed to jail without bonds on the charge of arson and murder. The bonds were fixed at $5,000 and were at once furnished, and the prisoner was released.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 26.--Speaker Reed will eat his Thanksgiving dinner in Washington, and he will no doubt feel duly thankful that Maine elected her Representatives in Congress before the people found out what the Republican Tariff bill really was. Like all the other Republican leaders, Mr. Reed is cultivating a large and expansive smile, and promptly puts it on when the slightest allusion is made to the disaster of Nov. 4.
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The Star (home rule) says:

When the Kings County Supervisors met yesterday the fight between William Watson and John Y. McKane, from which honest men expect to realize so much, was renewed. Watson had, at a previous meeting, prevailed upon the Democrats to reject the bills presented by the town of Gravesend for the fees of Justices and Constables.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 26. -- Trains going both north and south on the New-York Central and West Shore Railroads have been crowded to-day with Thanksgiving travel. Especially is this the case with the trains to-night. Among those who left this city to-day for their homes were 150 Vassar College pupils, the last of them departing this evening.

ALABANY, NOV. 26. -- Attorney General Tabor and State Engineer Bogart were recently appointed a committee by the Land Board to consider the application of the Standard Oil Company for a grant of land under water at Hunter's Point for the purposes of commerce. The committee has made a lengthy report detailing the hearings that were held and stating some facts relative to the land applied for.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Prof. H.R. Elliott of the Smithsonian Institution has prepared a report on the seal fur industry, in which he will recommend that the catch at the American rookeries be suspended for seven years. This period of inactivity he considers absolutely necessary for the preservation of the seals from utter annihilation.

The saddest thing about the Mayor's appointment of Mr. PAUL DANA as Park Commissioner is that it muzzles the New- York Sun in regard to park matters. The elder DANA is a gentleman of much experience and taste in the choice and disposition of trees, shrubs, and plants for the adornment of landscapes.

The conclusions reached in the competitive test of steel against compound plates at Annapolis last September have since been remarkably confirmed in similar trials held upon European proving grounds. The Annapolis contest showed, in the language of the official report which has just been published, that "the compound plate was perforated by all projectiles and its steel face was destroyed -- two of the shells passed completely through both plate and backing."

The editorial columns of the Tribune have not yet been able to convince the financial columns of the Tribune that the recent financial disturbance in all the world's markets was caused by the defeat of the Republican Party on Nov. 4. The editor of the financial columns continues to talk about the BARINGS, the Argentine securities, and the manipulation of the market in this country, without the slightest regard for the other theory.

Commissioner RAUM asks for a deficiency appropriation of $33,000,000 to straighten out his bureau up to the end of June next. As there has already been appropriated $97,000,000, this would bring the amount for the current year up to $130,000,000, in round figures. Next year he says that he (or his successor) will want a little over $133,000,000.

THE TIMES is pre-eminently the best paper published in New-York City. It doesn't oringe. It doesn't bow to a party's intrigue. It is a brave exponent of the people's rights. It doesn't cater to a promiscuous and cheap popularity at the expense of dignity and cleanliness. It is therefore not the paper of an unscrupulous and mindbefogged set. It caters to intelligence.

It is difficult to believe that the Republicans in Congress will seriously undertake the passage of the Lodge Elections bill, otherwise, and very justly, known as the Force bill. Senator GORMAN stated in an interview in Baltimore yesterday that he believed that the Republican Senators would "make a determined effort" in this direction.

The State Civil Service Commission recently made an excellent recommendation to the Governor, which we are glad to announce that he has approved. It was that the positions of Superintendents and assistant physicians in all the State hospitals, eight in number, shall be taken out of the non-competitive and placed in the competitive schedule.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- To-day's events have not believed the tension, but rather have accentuated the complications, of the Nationalist situaation. Mr. Gladstone's letter produced a strong impression upon the Nationalists last evening, and from the indications given at the hastily-summoned meeting it seemed that there was every reason to believe that to-day would bring forth new developments which would lead to an amicable arrangement of the trouble.

The big flower show at Madison Square Garden improves with age. Yesterday's visitors who had been there before and were tempted to return by haunting memories of the beautiful things they saw, were surprised by a display in every way superior to that of the earlier days of the week.

Capt. John Anderson, a prominent member of the New-York Marine Society and of the American Shipmasters' Association, and who enjoyed the distinction of having been master of the famous clipper ship Davy Crockett, the foremost of the celebrated "fliers" of the American merchant marine, died at his residence, 114 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, Tuesday, after an active life of over sixty-four years.

The Brazilian war ships Aquidaban and Guanabara, under the escort of the United States cruisers Dolphin and Yorktown, anchored at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in North River. The combined Brazilian and American fleets occupy the whole line of the river front stretching between West Fifteenth and West Fiftieth Streets. At the extreme lower end of the line lies the Guanabara.

ROCHESTER, NOV. 26. -- Democrats of influence in this part of the State believe that Gov. Hill is perfectly willing to be United States Senator, and that, all other considerations aside, he cannot afford to throw away an office which so big a man as Roscoe Conkling preferred to the Presidency. The Governor has unquestionably grown more reserved since election day.

So much of the contention over Africa is made by England, Germany, Portugal, and Italy that comparatively few people may know that France has a larger part of the Dark Continent under her control than any of these countries and than any other power. The figures given by a geographical authority are, in round numbers. 2,300,000 square miles for France, against 1,909,000 for Great Britain, 1,036,000 for Germany, and 775,000 for Portugal.

Within a bower of palms and growing plants which filled the north end of the drawing room in her parents' home, at 4 West Fortieth Street, Miss Mary Josephine Manice, daughter of William De Forest Manice, was married to Newbold Le Roy Edgar at 12:30 yesterday afternoon. The marriage was solemnized by the Rev. Dr. John W. Brown of St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- For some time the Cowles Electric Smelting and Aluminium Company of Lockport has been preparing to produce aluminium by a new process, which is claimed to be a successful solution of the problem of the cheap extraction of this metal from common clay. Eugene H. Cowles, President of the aluminium company, said to-day:
" What have we to be thankful for as a Nation and as a city?" This was the query that the Rev. R. Heber Newton put to his congregation yesterday for consideration. Answering it for them, he said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- At Army Headquarters, in the Pullman Building, Gen. Miles was at his desk early this morning. His first business was to send to the Governor of South Dakota a reply to the dispatch which was given publicity yesterday. Gov. Mellette was assured that nothing would be left undone to give every assistance for the protection of life and property in the Northwest, where the Indian excitement now exists.

There was a general interchange of calls yesterday among the Brazilian and American Navy officers in port. This was permissible for the first time since the arrival of the Brazilians, inasmuch as the custom of the services prohibits junior officers paying visits before all official courtesies have been disposed of. From the fact that Rear Admiral da Silveira did not leave the Aquidaban before 9:30 A.M., no calls were made earlier than that hour.

Down where the rippling waters of Jamaica Bay caress the soggy shore of Canarsie the Stony Lonesome banquet was held yesterday. Over the fishing huts of Denis Shea, Deputy Collector and Republican leader of the Second Assembly District, and John H. Gunner, Deputy Collector and Republican leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District, weird black flags with skull and crossbones on them were flapping and waving in the frosty wind.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 27. -- The navigation of the great chain of lakes at this season of the year is attended with more perils than is generally supposed. The list of disasters in Canada alone during the past ten years is simply appalling. Thanks to the efforts of the Dominion Marine Department, Georgian Bay, the vast expansion of Lake Huron, will soon present less dangers to the navigator.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27. -- The programme of Thanksgiving Day sports of the Athletic Association of the United States Naval Academy was successfully carried out to-day under the auspices of Commander Glass, Lieuts. Merriam and Underwood, and Naval Cadets Laws, Hartung, and Emrich as the committee, and Naval Cadets Hines, Macklin, and Potter as marshals.

Judging by the great crowd that gathered at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday to hear Prof. A.S. Bickmore's lecture on woods, the new scheme of the Trustees in affording free lectures on national holidays proves to be a great success. By this means the American Museum of Natural History is made -- what many of its sister institutions are not -- an educational force.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- The steamship Pennsylvania arrived at her dock to-day and reported that the British steamer Falcon, from New-York for Glasgow, with a cargo of staves, was abandoned on the 16th inst., in a sinking condition, with bow stove and bulwarks and sails gone. The Captain and crew were taken on board by the Pennsylvania and landed here.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- The New-York State Intercollegiate Football League has a rule that the referee in all games may be selected by the visiting club, and this has made much trouble this Fall, as the visiting club invariably selected its own manager or trainer. To-day at Culver Park in this city the Rochester University and Union College elevens played the last game of the season.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 27. -- The Riverside Gun Club opened its new grounds in Upper Broad Street to-day, there being a very large attendance. The shooting began in the morning and lasted until dark. American Association rules governed the shooting, which was at live and clay birds. A cold northwest wind blew, but, notwithstanding this and other unfavorable conditions, the shooting on an average was remarkably good.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 27. -- Trumbull, a town adjoining this city and having about 200 voters, now comes forward with a contested election case, and it is certain that before the matter is settled it will go to the Supreme Court of Errors. The town is strongly Democratic, but at the recent election, for the first time in fifty years, a Republican was declared elected First Selectman on the face of the returns.

A quiet church wedding was solemnized in Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when George Koelsch of this city and Miss Rita Markham, daughter of Mrs. L.M. Markham of Hastings-on-the-Hudson, and granddaughter of the late Samuel Longstreet, were married. The Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur, pastor of the church, officiated.
Yesterday at the close of a Thanksgiving Day sermon on "The Joy of Harvest," the rector of Grace Church said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Senator Gorman's opinion that the Republican Senators will try to push the Force bill through as quickly as possible after the Senate meets is generally regarded here as well founded only to the extent that the bill will be taken up very promptly.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27. -- Maryland Republicans are going to try to reorganize. Their present condition is sadly demoralized. They lost three Congressmen in the last election and elected only two of the twenty-two members of the First Branch of the Baltimore City Council. Their vote ran more than 20,000 behind their showing in 1888.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 27. -- The charge that the Republican residential ticket was sold out in the Second Connecticut District two years ago in the interest of Senator Platt's candidate for Congress, ex-Mayor H. Wales Lines of Meriden, has assumed a new lease of life and is likely to become an interesting factor in the contest over the United States Senatorship in January.

From a football standpoint the game was an inferior one on account of its one-sidedness, and serves to emphasize the superiority of the great match between Harvard and Yale at Springfield, Mass., last Saturday, when Harvard won by a score of 12 to 6.

There was a tingle in the atmosphere yesterday, but there was likewise sunshine, and the day was a fine one. A flurry of snow early in the forenoon gave it a slight wintry flavor. Persons who sought out-of-door amusements found a glorious invigorant in the clear, crisp air, and nobody failed to take home, at the proper time, a well-developed Thanksgiving appetite.

The account of new enterprises in the South published in the latest number of the Manufacturers' Record is particularly striking because of the recent difficulties in Wall Street that have given our own people the very natural impression that the whole country is affected by them. No one State in the South seems to have a monopoly of these enterprises.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 27. -- J.S. Allan, representing the Allan Line of steamships; David Torrance, representing the Dominion Line, and D. McNicoll, Passenger Superintendent of the Canadian Pacific Railway, had a long conference with the Hon. John Carling Wednesday with reference to a new plan in connection with immigration.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Chauncey Snyder, who lives on a road leading to the Overlook Mountain, for some time has missed sheep from his flock. After the recent fall of snow he saw the tracks of a large wildcat in one of his fields. That night, accompanied by his big bulldog and armed with a gun, Snyder lay in wait for the sheep killer.

It was a great day on the road and at Fleetwood yesterday. Hundreds of handsome turnouts, whose owners took advantage of the bright, clear afternoon, spun briskly up over the Macomb's Dam Bridge and off along Jerome Avenue. At Fleetwood a number of races had been arranged and a crowd of horse lovers assembled at noon to watch the sport.

A work of no little ambitiousness has been completed by the painter Richard Creifelds. It is an altar piece for St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, on Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street. St. Andrew is in the immediate foreground, conspicuous for his garments -- green and wine red: yet his back is turned so that one sees only a part of his face.

The Philadelphia American recently complained that a journal in the West was making assertions about the existence of combinations in certain industries without furnishing or being able to furnish any evidence in support of the same. At the close of its remarks the American said:

Casati, the friend and comrade for so many years of Emin Pasha, has been interviewed at his villa in Monza by Carl von Reinhardstottner, who gives in a Berlin paper a long account of the eventful life of the revolutionist, scientist, patriot, and African explorer. Casati was born at Lesmo in 1838, and studied mathematics at Milan and the University of Pavia.

One of the features that distinguish the latest of our large war ships from those which have already been completed is the provision made for supplying them with an elastic and buoyant material which, on being penetrated by projectiles, will very quickly close up the holes, and thus prevent the entrance of water into the vessel.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 27. -- Prof. Charles E. Gatchel of the Homeopathic Department pronounces mind-reading a "fake," and was in Chicago last Fall when P. Alexander Johnstone, the mind reader, did his feats. Prof. Gatchel studied the matter thoroughly, and finally concluded that he could do the same "tricks," as he calls them.

No degree of public censure and no penalty the law can visit upon the persons responsible for the disaster at the Brooklyn Eastern Park yesterday will surpass their just desert. The responsibility rests primarily upon the managers of the park, who, according to report, have left unused no device their greed could suggest to swell their profits from the Thanksgiving Day football match.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 27. -- Near Snohomish yesterday an Indian known as "Beaver" accused Jerry Gould, a rancher, of assaulting his squaw, and threatened to shoot him unless he put up $100. Gould refused, when the Indian opened fire. Gould returned the fire and shot Beaver dead. The other Indians took charge of Beaver's body with wild lamentations and swore vengeance. Gould has fled.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- The question as to whether Parnell should resign as leader of the Irish Party and the recent visit of the Irish envoys to this city have been the cause of war and dissensions among the leaders of Irish organizations here.

The Church of England has gained notoriety for its ecclesiastical judgments, but the decision just pronounced by the Archbishop of Canterbury on the ritual acts of the Bishop of Lincoln is more important than any which have ever proceeded from the Privy Council and marks an epoch in effort of the English Church to assert its spiritual authority against the decisions of the State courts in ecclesiastical and spiritual matters.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Mr. Davitt will publish in the Labor World to-morrow an appeal to the Irish race at home and abroad. In this he implores the people to rise and show themselves equal to the present emergency, and says that if Parnell remains at the head of the party there can be no hope of saving the cause of Ireland.

Yale's victory at Eastern Park yesterday ought to go far toward consoling her for last Saturday's defeat, especially in view of its remarkable score of 32 to 0 against such a college as Princeton. It is certainly an ample revenge for last year's triumph of the orange and black, which showed so much smaller a score.

While their punishment in this instance will be sufficient to deter the managers of the Eastern Park from putting human life in peril in their future speculative ventures, it cannot be urged in their behalf that there was any lack of warnings of the terrible consequences likely to result from their negligence. Disasters of this nature have been sufficiently frequent and numerous to remove every shadow of excuse for their recurrence.

Yale won. From the crimson field of Hampden Park she raised her trailing colors and rallied her beaten forces to sweep down upon Princeton yesterday with irresistible force. Her aggressive and ferocious play was not to be denied, and the orange bars sank beneath the dark blue banners not merely in defeat but in demolition.

The tribute paid by the rector of Grace Church yesterday to the memory of the late CHARLES L. BRACE was at once eloquent and deserved. There is no service to Christianity more precious than service to humanity in the name and inspired by the motives of Christianity, and this service was generously, patiently, wisely, and ably given by Mr. BRACE.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Hundreds upon hundreds of pretty ribbons floated in the nipping breezes that swept over the West Side Ball Park this afternoon, but the red and white, the colors of Cornell University, were the proudest of all. The occasion was the annual charity football game. Fully 5,000 people were on the ground when the ball was kicked off.

A game of Gaelic football was played yesterday afternoon upon the New-York Baseball Grounds. One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, under the management of the Irish-American Athletic Club. The contesting teams were the Irish-Americans of New-York and the Gaelics of Port Chester. Gaelic football is very much like the old American game, except that there is more scientific team work in it.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 27. -- Horace Johnson of Middle Haddam, on the Connecticut River, who prophesied the great blizzard, and so made more than local fame for himself as a far-seeing weather prophet, is out with his prognostications for the Winter now at hand. He has been so successful in his predictions of late that he is accepted by Middlesex County people as a better authority than even David A. Daboll, the Connecticut almanac maker.
The following letter, received by F.G. Barry last Friday, will be of general interest hereabout:

The new clubhouse of the Manhattan Athletic Club, at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, has already become a familiar landmark to persons who live in that aristocratic neighborhood, and, indeed, the outward appearance of the building is well known to the members of all the athletic clubs of prominence in the country.

The annual doll bazaar in the interest of the three day nurseries under the management of the Woman's Branch of the Board of City Missions, and which for the last four years has been held at the homo of Mrs. Arthur M. Dodge, was opened for the first time in a public place, at Sherry's pretty banquet room. 402 Fifth Avenue, at 2 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The forthcoming report of the Secretary of the Treasury will contain several tabulated statements showing as nearly as is possible the exact amounts of the various kinds of money in actual circulation among the people at several different periods from 1870 to the present time.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 28. -- The authoritative announcement of the resignation of George A. Dickey as Clerk of the House of Representatives in the New-Hampshire Legislature, made to-day, while not generally expected by the public at large, occasions very little surprise to those who are aware of the heavy pressure which the Chandler conspirators have been bringing to bear upon the unfortunate officer.

People of four generations will assemble to-day in the house over the branch Post Office in Grand Street near Norfolk Street to celebrate the hundredth birthday of the eldest of their number, Isaac Brandenstein. There will be present his remaining son, four grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren.

A special train will be run over the West Shore Road this morning for those desirous of witnessing the football game between the West Point and the Annapolis cadets. The train will leave New-York at 11:15. The game will be called at 2 P.M. The hotel on the grounds is still open, which will enable those going to the Point to obtain lunch before the game begins.

A number of scientists gathered yesterday in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, to attend the second annual convention of the American Folk-Lore Society. Dr. Daniel G. Brinton of the University of Pennsylvania presided, and Prof. W.W. Newell of Cambridge, Mass., recorded the proceedings. An informal address of welcome was delivered by the venerable Prof. John S. Newberry, D.D., LL.D., President of the New-York Academy of Sciences.

Something new in Biblical criticism has recently been written in the shape of a large octave volume entitled "A Wonderful Discovery in the Book of Job," which, briefly stated, declares that the entire modern steam plant, railway organization, boiler and engine practice, are treated of by the inspired writer.
Sir Morell Mackenzie, the imperial doctor and highest known authority on the throat and lungs, has just published a pamphlet in which he gives advice to public speakers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Postmaster General in his annual report reviews the legislation of Congress for the improvement of the Postal Service. He dwells at some length upon the changes for the better during the past year in the administrative methods of the department.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Dr. Bergmann in a lecture last night declared that the secret of the composition of Prof. Koch's curative lymph was the exclusive property of Prof. Koch. Dr. Bergmann illustrated the degrees of fever after each injection and explained the quantity of lymph required in the various cases.

A fire was discovered in the Metatoxet stables and laundry at Narragansett Pier last evening. The Fire Department succeeded in extinguishing the flames, but not until the building had been partly demolished. The horses and carriages were saved, but the laundry machinery was considerably damaged.

Angling has been rather cold work throughout a portion of the week. Tuesday a fine twelve-pound bass was successfully landed at Hell Gate after a vigorous effort on his part to get free from the hook. Other four and five pound fish a the same place have fallen to the lot of many a hook. The old grievance of the anglers has returned.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The most important events of the week in Columbian Exposition affairs were the concluding meetings of the National Commission and the board of lady managers. President Thomas W. Palmer has formally notified President Harrison that Chicago has furnished an acceptable site and has raised $10,000,000 for the Fair.

It was several hours after the conclusion of the great Yale-Princeton football game before any peculiar effect on the thermometers was noticed. The weather clerk had evidently put money up on Princeton, for when at last he learned the result of the game he felt very chilly, and the mercury in all outdoor thermometers began to drop.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28. -- King Kalakaua of the Sandwich Islands is expected to arrive here on the cruiser Charleston next Thursday. Last year the dusky monarch counted on a trip to the Paris Exposition, but a revolution in his domains prevented it. Now he proposes to remain several months on this coast and travel about incognito.

Their desire to insure the nomination of Mr. BLAINE in 1892 has led some of our Western Republican contemporaries into a curious error. Immediately after the election the St. Louis Globe-Democrat began to say that the nomination of BLAINE could not be avoided. On the 17th inst. it published more than two columns of matter as "special correspondence" from Washington under the head "A Letter from Mr. BLAINE Reviewing the Whole Question of Reciprocity."

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Judge Gresham's entire time was taken up to-day listening to arguments in the celebrated habeas corpus case of Charles Counselman, the Board of Trade man, committed to jail by Judge Blodgett for refusing to Answer before the Federal Grand Jury whether certain railroads have not by unjust discriminations violated the inter-State commerce law, the alleged discriminations being in Counselman's favor.

Each of the 25,000 persons who witnessed the Yale-Princeton football game on Thanksgiving Day realized the inefficiency of the management of Eastern Park to handle such a throng or to conduct a football match of any kind. In every action of this management one fact was made conspicuous -- its greed for gain. In its absorbing avarice it adopted the short-sighted and foolish policy of killing the goose that laid the golden egg.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The Rev. Dr. A.H. Lewis, pastor of the Plainfield Seventh-Day Baptist Church, a leader of his denomination, preached the sermon at the union services of all the local Protestant churches Thanksgiving Day. He spoke on "The Union of Protestant Christians as Related to the Future of Christianity in the United States."

The fourth annual reception of the Metropolitan Stenographers' Association occurred at Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, last evening. The march was led by President Edward F. Underhill. Robert E. Nicholls was Chairman of the Floor Committee, and he had as assistants G.W.P. Ramsey, D.H. Thomas, Peter Flint, William N. Hardy, William H. Hendee, Lloyd Roberts, and John R. Geary. The attendance was large.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 28. -- The Grand Jury of the parish of Orleans to-day filed in court their final report and were discharged. Their investigation of the Hennessy murder led to the disclosure of quite an amount of official mal-administration. With their report they present indictments against Gillighan, Captain of the yard, for assault and battery and robbing prisoners.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The silence that has surrounded the affairs of the missing speculator, John R. Baker, Jr., who disappeared one week ago last Thursday, was broken by a statement issued tonight, which shows that he has robbed the estate of his grandfather of about $1,000, 000. The statement is as follows:

The doubling in 1887 of the annual appropriations formerly made by Congress to the militia has been followed by a smaller ratio of gain in the numbers of the State troops than many had hoped to see. Still, Capt. D.M. TAYLOR of the Ordnance Department, who has charge of issuing militia supplies, figures out an increase of about 3,000 in the organized aggregate for the last year.

When Commissioner RAUM reported to the Committee on Appropriations last Wednesday that a deficiency appropriation of from $32,000,000 to $33,000,000 would be required for the pension expenses of the year ending on June 30 next, he explained that this estimate was based "on payments made in previous years, and on the amount paid out during the first quarter of the present fiscal year," being the months of July, August, and September.

An excavation at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, in the angle of the Park Tilford Building, has been made to such a depth as to arouse the wonderment of people who have seen it. Some inferred that the extraordinary depth of the excavation was an indication that a building of extraordinary height was to be put up on the site, and in this inference they were quite right.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 28. -- The schooner Mabel, from this port for Scatterie Island with a general cargo, has been wrecked on Eastern Rock at the latter place. The Mabel was of forty-three tons register, built at Canso in 1870, and owned by L.M. Smith of this city. There was no insurance on the vessel, but her cargo was insured for $10,000.

Ex-Alderman James G. McMurray and his partner in political misdoing, Charles A. Malloy, were expelled from the regular Republican organization in the Eleventh Assembly District last night for treachery to the party. They supported and worked for the election of Lawrence, the successful Democratic nominee for the Assembly in the Eleventh District over Hoag, Republican.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., Nov. 28. -- The Ninth Cavalry will probably leave at 10 o'clock to-night for the Big Village of the Rosebud Indians, which is supposed to be about twenty miles from the agency. It is the intention to reach the Indians at daybreak to-morrow.
LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Mr. Parnell has issued the following manifesto:

The investigations of the commission appointed by Secretary WINDOM to inquire into the expediency of establishing a Marine Board in the Treasury Department will bear fruit in a bill for the purpose, which is to be presented to Congress early in the coming session. In the conferences held by this commission with representatives of the commercial and shipping interests of the country the general sentiment in favor of such a Government board was manifest.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- John Daly, Isaac Thompson, John Thompson, Kelly, and Joseph Cotton, bookmakers at Monmouth Park, who were among those indicted by the Monmouth County Grand Jury last month, appeared in court at Freehold this afternoon and pleaded not guilty. They gave bonds to await trial Dec. 26.

Senator EDMUNDS of Vermont does not often come before the public in an interview, and it is understood that when he makes any statement for publication he takes measures to insure the appearance of an accurate report of what he says. Therefore it may be assumed that an interview with him published by the Tribune on the 26th inst. truthfully set forth what he had said to our neighbor's correspondent about sugar.
LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Post, referring to Mr. Parnell's manifesto, says:

It is plain that Mr. PARNELL has no intention of giving up the leadership unless he is forced to do so. That is a question hardly to be determined before the meeting of the party on Monday, if then. While it is clear enough that the retention of PARNELL as a leader will wreck the Irish cause for the present, it is by no means clear that his resignation would leave the Irish party united.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 28. -- Issac Bergmann, for ten years County Treasurer and Probate Judge, a prominent Mason, a pioneer, and owner of range cattle, made a most determined attempt to kill himself in his office this morning. He locked the doors and fired at his head five times. Four shots were from a pocket pistol of heavy calibre, and the last was from a regulation six-shooter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Blue Room in the White House was opened to-day for the first time since its redecoration, when Admiral Da Silveira and the other Brazilian naval officers accompanying him were received by President Harrison.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The official report of the series of evaporation tests conducted by board of naval engineers at the New-York Navy Yard with one of the Thornycroft boilers on the torpedo boat Cushing has reached the Navy Department. It is specially interesting to mechanical engineers, as it furnishes data for comparison with the Ward tubulo us boiler, the type recently adopted for the coast-defense vessel Monterey.

The Texas Pacific Railway has fallen behind in its earnings considerably during the past few weeks. The second week of this month alone shows a decrease of $24,210 as compared with the earnings in the corresponding week of last year. Officers of the Texas Pacific say that this diminution of income is due to the falling off in cotton shipments on account of tight money.

The tropical garden into which the Madison Square Garden has been transformed by the great flower show now in progress there was thronged yesterday afternoon and evening. The visitor asking for something new in the display is shown a new seedling chrysanthemum, which has just bloomed and has been christened Otero in honor of the Spanish dancer. The flower is a large bright yellow sphere, with double petals.

Although there was unquestionably much hasty passion in the feeling that produced the remarkable political revolution of this year, and though some of that passion was aroused by factional rivalry and resentment in the ranks of the Republican Party, there was one force that it will not do for the Republican leaders to underestimate, much less to ignore.

There is serious danger of pneumonia striking down half the men in the Brazilian fleet. The surgeons have already more work than they can attend to. Both officers and men are afflicted. The cause of the trouble is the cold. It has brought actual suffering to the fleet. Until yesterday the Brazilians were wholly unprovided with warm clothing.

The funeral services of August Belmont called a notable gathering of people to the Church of the Ascension, at Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, yesterday morning. It taxed the seating capacity of the spacious edifice and included statesmen and financiers, men eminent in the professions and in affairs, and a collection of personal friends whoso names are familiar in the social world.

LAKEWOOD, Nov. 29. -- The Thanksgiving Day arrivals this year exceeded those of any previous season. It is something so new in the experience of Lakewood to see a railroad train, made up of four parlor cars and five passenger coaches, draw up to the miserable little shanty erroneously called a station as to excite surprise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The Brazilian naval officers visited Mount Vernon to-day on the Despatch. Mr. S.A. Brown represented the State Department, Capt. Cowles and Lieut. Mason represented Secretary Tracy, and Lieut. Stanton Admiral Walker. The guests included Minister Valente of Brazil and his staff and a number of Federal officials with ladies.

A question having arisen as to the length of the coast line of the United Sates, the Coast and Geodetic Survey was recently called upon to furnish a statement of the length in statute miles of the general seacoast of the Atlantic, Gulf, Pacific, and Alaskan waters, and also the coast line in statute miles of the same coasts, including islands, bays, rivers, , to the head of tidewater.

MITCHELLS, S.D., Nov. 29. -- The State Farmers' Alliance in convention here this week chose delegates to the National Convention to be held in Florida Dec. 2. It also adopted a platform declaring fealty to the Alliance paramount to every party fealty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Speaker Reed will call to order at noon on Monday the second session of the Fifty-first Congress. At last, only a day before the event, the possibility of the attendance of something like a quorum begins to impress itself upon the observer. The streets are dotted to-day with newly-arrived members, most of whom have come, post haste, from their Thanksgiving Day dinners.
