The disposal of the Allen-Patteson controversy in the Seventh Regiment by means of a mutual agreement and aboard of inquiry makes it plain that scandals in the National Guard can be kept from publicity provided only that the parties thereto are amenable to reason and disposed to sacrifice personal interests to those of the regiment.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- West Point was the scene of a mighty battle to-day. The flower of the United States Navy invaded the classic precincts of the National Military Academy and captured the flower of the army.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- Mrs. Eva Hamilton arrived in this city to-day from New-York, where she had been to consult her lawyers relative to her contest next Tuesday of Robert Ray Hamilton's will. She was extremely reticent, and looked very pale and nervous as she walked down the platform at the Broad Street station.

S.C. Orr and Samuel Torrell, mining experts at work about six miles from Ely, Min., in trying to walk across Fall Lake Friday, broke through and were drowned. The bodies were recovered yesterday, Orr is thought to have gone to the rescue of his companion after he got in the water, and both went through and were lost.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 29. -- A special from Standing Rook Agency, N.D., to the Tribune says: Col. Cody and Dr. Powell had not been at the agency many hours today before the report spread through the agency and garrison that they had come for the specific purpose of arresting Sitting Bull and removing him from the reservation.

Persons who have invented flying machines that did not fly have attributed their failure in part to their inability to obtain a metal sufficiently light and strong with which to construct their apparatus. They said that when they could obtain such a metal, and obtain it cheaply, then they would perfect their flying machines.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Messrs. Healy and Sexton and a number of other opponents of Mr. Parnell held a conference to-day. Mr. Parnell's manifesto has stiffened their opposition, and they have resolved to issue a counter-manifesto forthwith. This manifesto, which will be prepared by Mr. Davitt, will bear a formidable list of signatures.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- Within the week just closed several notable weddings have taken place in this vicinity. At the residence of John G. Myers, in State Street, this city, on Tuesday, his daughter, Georgiana Seymour Myers, was married to Mr. Walter Launt Palmer, the well-known artist, and son of E.D. Palmer, the sculptor.

Telegraph operators form strong friendships over the wires. Metaphorically they shake hands cordially twice a day -- when they begin work and when they end it. And when business is dull they hold long conversations, with hundreds of miles -- perhaps thousands -- separating them, as two friends might do over a dinner table.

When the National Trotting Association was formed and its promoters began their important work of placing that class of racing on a better basis by defining what is legitimate and fair in light-harness sport, they found it necessary to uphold the enforcement of their laws by a special tribunal where the action of individual associations could be affirmed or set aside.

The bargain buying by the public, and the broken lot purchasing, have stopped. The rapid rise of prices from the low level which brought in the crowds of outsiders, has removed the inducement to further buying, and recent purchasers are now sellers, or waiting for further rallies to become such. The market is therefore again narrowing down to the professionals, and to their operations the activity of the past week must be mainly attributed.

The Republican machine managers in this city are in a novel position just now. They are trying to determine what to do with themselves. There was never a time in the political history of New-York when the Republican machine was as decrepit as it is now. The fact is that there is nothing now but the mere skeleton of a machine; the form is there, but the substance is not.

The great audience assembled in the lecture hall of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon was taken by Prof. A.S. Bickmore on a rapid panoramic survey of the Adirondacks, the Yosemite Valley, and intermediate points, including a passing glimpse of the coast of Ireland, and terminating on the banks of the Nile.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- John S. Mayhugh, until recently the Special Census Agent of Indians for Nevada, has written to the Indian Bureau upon the subject of the coming of the Indian Messiah. In his letter Mr. Mayhugh says:

Ever since W.J.K. Kenny, Supervisor of the City Record, returned from Washington with a copy of the Federal census of the Second Ward of this city he has been living in a maze of figures. He was instructed to get the Federal figures of this little ward by Mayor Grant because they were wanted as the basis of some future possible action in Congress in reference to the enumeration as yet undefined.

NYACK, Nov. 29. -- The icemen in this region feel hopeful of filling their icehouses this Winter, and they are preparing to begin harvesting at the earliest possible moment. Ice in various parts of Rockland County is thick enough to-day for skating.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 29. -- The city of Corry is in an unhappy predicament. A short time since the city authorities issued, executed, and signed $110,000 improvement bonds and intrusted them to B.K. Jamison Co. of Philadelphia to put on the market. The Corry officials took no security and have not a thing to show for the bonds.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 29. -- An interesting discovery of a "pot hole" has just been made in the red granite quarries at Stony Creek east of here. It furnishes other indisputable evidence that Connecticut was at one time the bed of a glacial stream, the whirlpools and currents of which left their imprint upon the rocky face of the old Nutmeg State by various borings or "pot holes," and by grooves and scratches.

NYACK, Nov. 29. -- James Bradner, a merchant in Brooklyn, accompanied by a clergyman of the Methodist denomination who preaches in a place in the suburbs of that city, "took a day off" yesterday and came up to Rockland County for a few hours' sport hunting for birds and rabbits. They had their hunt, but it was accompanied by an experience which they will not soon forget.

It is a well-known fact in this country that adults have no rights that children are bound to respect. It is true that in certain sections of society there is an elaborate fiction that children must be seen and not heard, and a studied simplicity, a complicated system of retirement, that keep Ethel and Jack out of the public view until one has "come out" and the other has had his twenty-first birthday party.

The first of the series of indoor baseball games for the championship of the Seventh Regiment was played at the armory last evening. There was a large-sized crowd in attendance, and no small amount of interest was manifested in the contest. Judging from the plaudits of the spectators, indoor baseball promises to be popular this Winter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The President to-day appointed M.D. Henry of Kansas to an be alternate Commissioner to the World's Columbian Exposition, vice J.F. Thompson, resigned.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- At a late session of the Clerical Union, a body composed of clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Central New-York, the Rev. Dr. William T. Gibson read an elaborate argument in favor of a division of the diocese. As now constituted, the Central Diocese comprises 14 counties, in which are 142 parishes and missions, 104 clergymen, and 15,314 communicants.

The Indian is not alone in his expectation of an early appearance of a new Messiah, as numerous instances are on record where, within the last two or three years, the more civilized and better-educated white men and black men of America have professed to have received revelations, and in some cases to be the Christ Himself.

H.B. Clover, in a letter to the Kansas City Times, says: "Every man elected on the people's of Alliance ticket (as some see fit to call it) is pledged against Ingalls and is elected on the principles outlined in the St. Louis demands, and the essence of those demands is 'purification in politics.' Every man elected by the people will be found true.
LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Star, (Home Rule,) commenting on Mr. Parnell's manifesto, says:
On the 1st of July, 1857, the Indian mutiny was at its height. For ten days the little British station at Sunda Gunge had been besieged by the insurgent sepoys.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- The Rev. C.C. Otis, for three years pastor of the Congregational Church at Norwich, N. Y., has accepted a call to the charge of the Congregational Church at Springfield, Ill. He will preach his farewell sermon to the Norwich congregation to-morrow, Nov. 30.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Thanksgiving week is looked forward to by managers with pleasurable anticipation It usually means for them a gratifying increase of receipts. The past week has been no exception to Thanksgivings in past years. It was rather better than the average. Without a dramatic novelty in the city, every theatre in Chicago has done well, some of them extraordinarily well, and several of them have turned people away.

The problem that now presents itself to the financial community, not only in this city but throughout the country, is the gradual retirement of the Clearing House certificates. We see no reason to doubt that this will he accomplished without any serious difficulty. But as their issue was entirely out of the ordinary course of business, they will disappear only as business resumes its regular course.

BRICK TEA. -- The genuine brick tea of the Chinese manufacturers is intended for the Thibetan market and for the Eastern Mongols. It is made of the whole leaf, stalk, flower, and all, as it is picked from the tea shrub, and is in shape and appearance not unlike a rather dirty ordinary brick.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- The Cleveland City football team, strengthened by Cowan and George of Princeton and the Germer brothers of the Boston Technology School, played a strong game at League Park against the celebrated Crescents of New-York this afternoon before a very large and fashionable audience.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Scranton, Penn., says: "General Master Workman Powderly arrived in the city to-day from the West, and left at a late hour to-night for the South to attend a Farmers' Alliance Convention which is to meet in Florida on Tuesday. To a reporter Mr. Powderly said:

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Superintendent Hannah of the Department of Public Works at noon to-day said that all the boats now due East on the Erie Canal would probably reach their destination, as he is doing all in his power to help them along. All of the ice breakers are plying along on Section 2, and Deputy Superintendent Simmons from Fultonville reports that the weather is moderating, although the ice is still very strong.

One of the main topics of conversation last week on the Produce Exchange, among shippers specially, wan the recent wholesale loss of cattle at sea. This subject has been discussed partly as affecting the underwriters and also because English newspapers are again agitating the question of a compulsory inspection of all cattle ships leaving this and other ports, claiming that such vessels should not be allowed to leave port without inspection and certification.

Never was royal maiden more regally clad than are our American princesses when wrapped in the great evening cloaks whose majestic magnificence, as they are offered for sale among wraps of less dignity, is almost awe-inspiring. Envy-inspiring they certainly are, for no woman ever yet gazed upon one without a fierce desire, hidden perhaps among her heart secrets, to possess and to wear it.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Nov. 29. -- The Hon. W.M. Fishback, who proposed to Senator J.K. Jones to have the people of Arkansas decide the United States Senatorship at a primary election, and who was replied to by Senator Jones in such severe terms, has written another open letter to the Senator. After reviewing their controversy at some length he says.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Such excitement as has to-day prevailed throughout the length and breadth of this country has never been experienced since the days when England was convulsed by the rumors of the advent of Napoleon's fleets.

TACOMA, Nov. 29. -- The wheat crop of Washington is the largest in its history, being estimated at 16,000,000 bushels. The elevators, warehouses, and box cars along the railways are filled and stacks of jacked wheat dot the fields. The inability of railroads to obtain motive power to move the enormous crop to market is exasperating the farmers, who are charging them with collusion with the warehousemen to lower the prices of wheat.

The smuggling of Chinamen is an industry which is evidently prosecuted with as much zeal on the Canadian as on the Mexican frontier. Indeed, while along the California and Arizona line several captures of Mongolians have been made this year, no such large hauls are reported from the British Columbia side.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- A local paper says: "The thrashing machine men of the United States have caught the infection from their brothers, the binders, and are busily engaged in forming a gigantic trust, which, it is thought, will rival in magnitude the recently-formed harvester company.

BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- Dr. von Gossler, Prussian Minister of Ecclesiastical Affairs, replying in the lower house of the Diet to-day to the interpretation of Herr Graf as to what measures the Government intended to take to promote the adoption of Prof. Koch's remedy, declared that the aspersions east upon certain physicians engaged in using the lymph had proved groundless.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- A disgraceful scene occurred in front of the Gazette office this morning. Royal R. Soper, manager of the Gazette, Gov. Hill's local organ, and ex-Assemblyman J.J. O'Connor were the participants. The parties mentioned had a war of words, ending in the complete discomfiture of Mr. Soper. During the melee O'Connor made remarks that have been a subject of discussion since.

Little Louis Norman, standing on the back veranda of his father's house at the foot of the Palisades, two miles from Englewood, Friday afternoon saw a man on the brink of the cliff, 175 feet above him. Something in the stranger's manner attracted his attention. He gazed out over the Hudson for a long time and then looked down upon the sharp-pointed rocks below him.

NEW-HAVEN, NOV. 29. -- South Middle College, in the famous old brick row at Yale, had a narrow escape from total destruction by fire at 10 o'clock to-night. The upper story and attic were burned out, and the entire Fire Department had hard work to save the rest of the structure.

There is good news in store for the hundreds of college graduates who have aspirations in the direction of the University Club, but have had but little hope of being able to reach that goal within the next decade or so. It is announced on trustworthy authority that a new university club will be organized in a few months, probably about Feb. 1. As everybody knows, the University Club has long been overcrowded.

Miss Marlowe has steadily and rapidly improved since Friday last, when she safely passed the crisis of her critical illness. The swelling has steadily decreased, and it is no longer doubtful that it can be controlled without resort to surgery. Her appetite is good, and she was yesterday strong enough to be propped up with pillows in bed and to take her food herself.

The German steamer Standard, Capt. Langen, that arrived yesterday, brought along the Captain and crew of thirteen men of the British bark Claudine, who were rescued in an exhausted condition from the waterlogged vessel.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- John Whitbeck, aged about fifty years, shot his boarding house keeper, Mrs. Augusta Vandekar, this evening in the head and then put a bullet in his own brain. The tragedy created great excitement. The shooting took place at the supper-table before a table full of boarders. Whitbeck was slightly enraged because Mrs. Vandekar had asked him for some back board he owed.

Joseph Wood, the negro murderer who was to have been killed by electricity at Sing Sing prison in the week beginning to-morrow, has secured another short lease of life. He has until the middle of February, at least.

A merchant who says he is "a Republican who voted the Democratic ticket at the last election" writes to the Dry Goods Economist about the knit goods trick in the new tariff law, and expresses surprise because the Appraisers have not been constrained by the "appalling defeat" of the party at the polls to "interpret the tariff in a conservative spirit."

Strange as it may seem, there are misguided men who believe or profess to believe that the duty on imported goods is not paid by the consumer who buys them. At last accounts Mr. EDMUNDS of Vermont was one of these. Certain other high-tariff men profess at times to hold this belief, but more commonly assume that the consumer pays.

Jay Gould is now credited with having acquired the largest salt plants in this country. The story comes from Kansas City, by Associated Press, that the New-York, the Diamond, and the Pennsylvania salt plants in Hutchinson, Kan., were conveyed to the Missouri Pacific Railroad last week for a consideration of $80,000. The purchase was made by General Manager S.H.H. Clark, acting for Mr. Gould.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 29. -- The death of Mr. August Belmont removes a man who has been good friend to Newport. He erected here many years ago in Toure Park a handsome bronze statue of Commodore Matthew C. Perry as a memorial to the father of Mrs. Belmont, and more recently built in the Island Cemetery a beautiful memorial chapel, which is an architectural delight.

Edward S. Willard off the stage is a prepossessing and interesting man. His manner is singularly free from affectation and vanity. He talks well, and his earnestness impresses one who meets him in every-day life as strongly as it impresses the spectator of his acting. He talked freely and well the other day about plays and the art of acting.

The political bacillus is the latest addition to the family of bacilli. He has been discovered by an Indiana Republican politician -- Gen. PACKARD by name. The General announced his discovery when he was recently called upon in a meeting of the Republican State Central Committee to state what, in his judgment, was the matter with the Republican Party of Indiana.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 29. -- Harvard added another to her list of victories by defeating Yale's '94 on Jarvis Field this afternoon in the presence of an immense crowd, with an unusually large proportion of ladies. It was a close rub, however, and men who had been giving odds of 5 to 1 on Harvard, '94, felt quite uneasy at the end of the first half, when the score was 4 to 0 for Yale.

SOMERSET, Penn, Nov. 29. -- Two years ago Herman Amberger, an aged farmer residing here, was murdered in the presence of his family and robbed of nearly $30,000. Joseph and David Nicely were tried and convicted of the murder and sentenced to death.

To have the courage of one's convictions is often difficult; to have the courage of one's emotions is to many persons even more so. It is a habit that seems to grow with our civilization, that of repressing expression of feeling. Sometimes it is a chilly habit which hurts our friends and makes us remorseful when the opportunity is irrevocably gone.
Those who are interested in the early history of piano music will note that last Sunday's article did not cover the whole of the early period.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, South Dakota, via Rushville, Neb., Nov. 29. -- Troopers of the Ninth Cavalry were under orders to march at a moment's notice last night. It had been reported that the Rosebud Indians and some of Little Wound's band were circling in a war dance and were prepared to fight. The defiant attitude of the Indians started a furious telegraphic correspondence between the military officers here and the authorities at Washington.

I have a friend who is a prophet. He must remain incognito, for of course he is without honor in his own country, and he is ashamed of the gift; but willy-nilly he dreams, and thus the future is revealed to him.

A trio of partisan tariff makers, about whom much was heard before the recent national Congressional elections, but who seem to have dropped voluntarily out of sight -- gone into hiding, as it were, since the returns from the elections were received -- were Columbus Delano, David H. Harpster, and ex-Judge Lawrence, all of Ohio, and upon whom the protective political faith of the wool growers of the country was founded.

The manifestations made in the newspapers by the friends and admirers of Mr. BLAINE have rather what our French friends would call a psychologic than a practical interest, but it cannot be denied that they are interesting. They afford about all the indications of life to be found in the Republican journals of the day.

In examining an interesting series of anthropometrical tables, carried out in an exhaustive manner by Miss Lucille Eaton Hill and Miss Anna Wood, the director and examiner, respectively, of the Wellesley College gymnasium, many curious facts are discoverable. The carefully- prepared chart shows the physical construction with the lung capacity of 1,100 women of from somewhat over eighteen to twenty-one years of age.

It requires a pilgrimage through the residence portions of the city to make the visitor appreciate November in New-Orleans. All along St. Charles Avenue, Esplanade Avenue, Prytania Street, Jackson Avenue, and throughout the garden district the lawns and gardens present an almost uninterrupted wilderness of flowers in full bloom.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 29, via Galveston. -- The Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railway Company has secured valuable privileges from the Government, and important news regarding the intentions of its managers will soon be made public. The freight and passenger traffic on this line is steadily growing.
" Swing the boat, father; I have struck a whale!" Sam exclaimed.

It is not clear to a good many persons why the United States Lighthouse Board is attached to the Treasury Department, and several times the board has been called on to show cause why it should not be transferred from the Treasury to some other department. Once it was proposed in Congress to transfer it to the Navy Department; still later, to the War Department, and finally, by the Forty-third Congress, to the Interior Department.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 29. -- The first move on the part of the defense, in what will be a tedious, involved, and long legal battle to save the lives of the Italians charged with murdering Chief of Police Hennessy, took place to-day.

The existence of a peculiar suit, in regard to which those who can give information insist on keeping a discreet silence, was brought to light yesterday when Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court granted an application to W. P. Kirk, the plaintiff in the action, for the appointment of commissions to take the testimony of various witnesses in Boston, Baltimore, Chicago, Philadelphia, Washington, and St. Paul.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- This city, since its first settlement by the Dutch, has furnished a market for the skins of animals killed and trapped by the hunters of Ulster, Greene, and Delaware Counties. R.E. Best has been a fur dealer here forty-one years. He has had a large experience in handling furs, and as he is an old hunter himself he has had an excellent opportunity to become acquainted with hunters and trappers.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 29. -- The cottagers enjoyed the line sleighing the early part of the week, but the snow now is nearly all gone. Among those who have enjoyed this little taste of Winter pleasures are Mr. and Mrs. David Lydig, Dr. and Mrs. Greenleaf, Miss Carey, Miss Rotch, Mr. and Mrs. Bacon, the Burdens, the Bullards, Henry A. Barclay and family, the Folsoms, the Higginsons, the Goodmans, F.A. Schermerhorn, the Gilmors, and others.

Thanksgiving week had little that was new this year to distinguish it from its predecessors in the social world. There was more or less merrymaking in the country and particularly in these Long Island, Staten Island, New-Jersey, and Westchester localities where the sets of people who devote their leisure hours to hunting and riding assemble at their cozy and comfortable clubhouses.

The Helena (Mont.) Independent remarks that while the wisest of Republican newspapers are promptly clearing out from the wreck caused by the cyclone of Nov. 4 there are still a few "pleiocene relics" who cling to the bed rock and profess to believe that the McKinley bill is the wisest and most statesmanlike measure that has over been passed by any Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The annual report of the Civil Service Commission, made public to-day, shows that the classified service has grown so as to include over thirty thousand people. The report says:

The suicide who took the fearful leap to death from the brink of the Palisades last Friday afternoon was yesterday identified by his nephew, Fred A. Howes, as John Townsend, a retired lawyer, with a half million dollars, who for many years had made his home in the handsome villa of his brother-in-law, E.L. Howes, in the northern section of the pretty village of Inwood, on the line of the New-York and Harlem Road.

The new Church of St. Andrew, at One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, was opened yesterday. All this week the celebration of its dedication will be continued with a festival of music. Though the new Church of St. Andrew is a very large edifice, covering 160x100 feet of ground, fully 1,000 people attended each of the services yesterday who were unable to get even standing room.

TRENTON, Nov. 30. -- Secretary of State Kelsey invited Gov. Abbett and several of the Senators to eat dinner with him and the State Committee at the Trenton House, and one day last week they all gathered around the banqueting board. The last time Mr. Kelsey gave a dinner -- it was at the Metropolitan Hotel in New-York some years ago -- it had an important bearing upon the subsequent political history of the State.

In appointing a committee to treat with the United States Commissioners for the sale of their surplus lands, the Cherokees have shown prudence. Congress is to meet to-day, and should it find the Commissioners reporting again no progress toward securing the Cherokee Outlet, it might take steps to open this tract without waiting for the action of the Cherokees.

INDIANOLA, Miss., Nov. 30. -- The express car on the west-bound train of the Georgia Pacific was robbed near here last night, and the robbers were captured at West Point this afternoon and placed in jail.

I read with much interest in my TIMES of Nov. 26 a letter from Mr. Samuel Untermyer criticising the utterances of Mr. Charles S. French and others, which declared that the rosy statements and prognostications of the Harney Peak Mining Company, of which Mr. Untermyer is President, were unfounded in fact.

A handsome young woman, dressed in a neat, close-fitting suit of half mourning, stepped off a train of the Suburban Elevated Railroad at the One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street station at 5:50 o'clock last night, and began nervously to fumble in the folds of her dress. A moment later she whipped out a revolver, and pointing it a little slantingly toward her left breast, she fired. She fell on the platform and lay there motionless.

The interest of amateur photographers is now almost wholly centred in the meeting of delegates from photographic societies and clubs all over the United States, which will begin at the rooms of the Society of Amateur Photographers, 113 West Thirty-eighth Street, on Thursday morning. Some of the objects of the convention have already been stated in THE TIMES.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 30. -- "I am through with sentiment," said "Al" Johnson to THE TIMES correspondent to-night. "I am not thirty years old yet. My brief experience with baseball has not crippled me financially. I need no sympathy, and deserve none, perhaps, but I'll wager $5,000 that before the League magnates are through with me they'll go down deep into their pockets a good many times.

A great match game of billiards will be played at Chickering Hall to-night between Jacob Schaefer and George F. Slosson. The game will be for a stake of $1,000, and a share of the receipts will go to the winner, besides a six-hundred-dollar championship trophy. The spectators will certainly be numerous, for every seat in the big hall has been sold.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Adding $141,295.12 to the salaries of 1,108 Federal officers, while cutting off $1,808.30 from the salaries of 8 officers, was only a small item in the record made by the last session of Congress in the line of providing for patronage.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- The view of the Irish envoys in America, excepting Timothy Harrington, was cabled to-night to London. Following is the document in full:

The Congress that meets to-day, after a bare two months' recess, will be composed of the same members, but, for all practical purposes, it will be a very different body from that which adjourned in the first week in October. Mr. REED, as he takes his seat, will hear the same names called over, but not so many will be responded to, and the faces on which he looks down will bear very different expressions.

The Quarterly Review contains an interesting critique on M. Renan, whom it describes as incomparably the greatest intellectual force in France at this moment. Indeed, "it would be difficult," adds the reviewer, "to mention any living man of letters whose influence in the civilized world is more diffused, more penetrating, and more effective."

The last Josephine volume in this series was published a few months ago and was devoted to the period when her title was the simple one of citizeness. Her husband was then fighting the first of his battles in Italy, those which were to give him his first pre-eminence, not only in France, but throughout Europe.

The recommendations of the Civil Service Commissioners are few, but important. They ask for a very modest increase of appropriation -- $21,000 -- to enable them to organize a central board of examiners to mark papers sent in from any part of the service, and also to employ, at small compensation, outsiders on the various local boards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- To-marrow, at noon, Congress will come together to complete, in some sort of fashion, the work which it began a year ago. Since it adjourned, in October, the people of the country, by a popular majority of probably not less than 800,000, have stamped with their disapproval the course which the Republicans, under the leadership of Harrison and Reed, marked out and declared should be followed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- In the first paragraph of his annual report Secretary Noble of the Interior Department says that it "exhibits to some degree the great responsibility resting upon the Secretary, and the almost increased labor required in supervising and directing the varied national affairs submitted * * * to his control," and declares that "it has been a year of much executive achievement in all the bureaus of this department."

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 30. -- The city was startled this morning when it was learned that T.A. Iler and Dr. W.E. Todd, two well and favorably known citizens, had engaged in a shooting affray in which the former was seriously and probably fatally shot.

DOVER, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The skeleton of Josef Barngarst, an infatuated German professor whose mad ambition was to discover a gold mine and to gain fabulous wealth with which to win back a fortune lost in the Fatherland, was found by a party of hunters in the mountains on Friday.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Mr. Parnell, by telegraph, invited those of his colleagues who were favorable to his retention in the leadership to meet him Saturday evening at the Westminster Palace Hotel. Twenty-four of those invited met Mr. Parnell, and together they discussed the situation. Mr. Parnell informed those present of the relations between himself and the Liberal leaders, and expressed a determination to fight to the last.

Mr. Carl Venth's seventh concert of the Brooklyn Orchestra was given yesterday evening before a large audience at the Saengerbund Hall. The orchestra, made up of sixty instrumentalists, was ably held in hand by Mr. Venth, and all the shades and colorings of the music were capably presented. Wagner was represented by the march from Tannhauser, and the "Prieslied" from "Der Meistersinger," and a former school by Rossini's overture to "William Tell."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Under the heading "What New-York Should Know," Col. McClure's newspaper, the Times, to-morrow will print the following leading editorial:

Seven years of trial have now been accorded to the civil service law of 1883. The report of the present Commissioners, Messrs. ROOSEVELT, LYMAN, and THOMPSON, of which an abstract will be found in our columns this morning, bears conclusive testimony not only to the fact that the law has stood the test well, but that it has steadily developed in usefulness.

Since March 4, 1889, nine new vessels, which were at that time in various stages of progress, the first two being practically out of the constructor's hands, have been completed and put in commission, as follows:

The large showrooms of Geo. C. Flint Co., at Nos. 104, 106, and 108 West 14th St., are crowded with specimens of some of the most artistic furniture ever offered for sale, ready made, in this city. Six floors are filled with sample pieces, no two of which are alike. It may be noted that each article is plainly marked with its price. The marked prices are never deviated from for anybody.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30. -- Dr. Julius R. Stiepel died early yesterday morning at his residence, 1,900 Lami Street. Thus is added a startling complication to an already mysterious case.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30. -- A floating church, the marine counterpart of Bishop Walker's church on wheels, built by the Pullmans, was launched here to-day. The vessel is built by the Free Will Baptists and is intended to carry the Gospel from St. Paul to New-Orleans along the Mississippi River. It is the idea of the Rev. M.A. Shepard, Free Will Baptist minister of Lebanon, Ill.

The most contemptible argument yet put forth by Mr. PARNELL'S few remaining supporters in favor of his continued leadership and in justification of their course is that the "independence" of the Irish party would be forfeited if its leader should retire at the demand of the English Liberals.

The condition of the officers and men aboard the Brazilian fleet has been much improved. Quantities of the very best clothing obtainable has been furnished the squadron by the Clothing and Equipment Department of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The price asked by the Government has been just sufficient to pay for the cloth and the making. The intercession of the United States naval authorities is deemed most timely.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Federation the special committee reported that arrangements had been made to hold a mass meeting Saturday evening to denounce Police Justice Welde for having held three bakers who were taken before him on charges of having boycotted an up-town baker.

Few persons outside of those immediately concerned, have any correct idea of the hurricane of red tape and permits which a first-class European steamship must battle through before she can land her cargo at this port. When one has examined the situation, he may understand that it is not astonishing that the steamship agents and others suggest that there is room for considerable reform in this direction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Mr. Lodge of Massachusetts will introduce to-morrow in the House a bill to regulate immigration. The first section of the bill excludes from the United States any person who is obnoxious in any way to the existing laws of the United States, including what is known as the "allen contract labor" law.

Mr. Samuel Untermyer, President of the Harney Peak Tin Mining, Milling, and Manufacturing Company, in a letter published in THE TIMES of Nov. 26, denied certain statements concerning his company and the company's property made in two articles published in THE TIMES, one on Nov. 10 and the other on Nov. 22. The statements to which Mr. Untermyer's letter was a reply were from various sources.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Hamilton, pastor of the Scotch Presbyterian Church of this city, will probably accept the call from the Warren Memorial Presbyterian Church of Louisville, Ky. No announcement of his acceptance was made from his pulpit yesterday, but it was generally understood among the members of the congregation that the announcement would be made within a short time.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 30. -- A special to the Times-Union from Punta Gorda says: "The report has just reached here of an outrage committed upon the Port Sanitary Inspector for this district, Morris Cochran, by a band of smugglers from Cuba. The affair happened far down the harbor, and the details are meagre. The report says that Cochran boarded a Spanish schooner near Lacosta Key and asked to see her papers.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 1. -- A Bee special from Pine Ridge Agency says:

Thirty-three years ago Mrs. A.M. Cannon took the Oregon trail across the plains with a party of pioneers and settled in Oregon. Twelve years ago he migrated to Washington Territory. Now he is President of the Columbia Railroad and Navigation Company, with headquarters in Spokane Falls, and crosses the continent in his own private car.

Since the middle of last June Pinkerton detectives have been scouring the country for Lyttleton Long, formerly the cashier and bookkeeper for the fruit importing firm of Nordlinger Son, 17 and 19 Bridge Street. Long is under indictment for a forgery and embezzlement from which he realized about $35,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- Deputy Attorney General Hogan, in response to a telegram from Warden Brush to Attorney General Tabor, met Warden Brush at Sing Sing Saturday afternoon when on his way to New-York on official business. Warden Brush wanted to see the Deputy Attorney General regarding the scope of the appeal from the decision against issuing a writ of habeas corpus in the Wood case.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1. -- The Government of Manitoba Province has gained the first victory in the fight for the abolition of the separate school system in that province. Through the various lower courts an appeal will be made to the Imperial Privy Council. The suit resulted from the legislation passed last session creating a uniform public school system, which the Roman Catholic population strenuously opposed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- The first issue of the Princetonian since last Thursday's defeat appeared this evening with two long editorials about the eleven and the game. The following is an interesting extract showing the spirit of Princeton men in defeat:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- The Hedding Methodist Episcopal Church of this city has recently been overhauled and greatly improved, and last week every night there were special services in the edifice, and about all the money needed for the improvement was raised. Now considerable trouble has arisen in the church because of the resignation of the entire choir, composed of twelve or fifteen ladies and gentlemen.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Sir Morrell McKenzie was seen this afternoon immediately after his first experiments with Koch's lymph in London. Although he had just returned from the experiment, he gave the following as the absolutely positive results:

NYACK, Dec. 1. -- The Rev. Dr. George R. Bristor, who a few months ago received more newspaper notoriety than generally falls to the lot of a clergyman, yesterday engaged in a continuation of the dedicatory services of his new Congregational church in Spring Valley, Rockland County. Dr. Bristor was originally a Methodist and acquired some reputation for his ability and eloquence as a speaker.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Mr. Parnell and his private secretary were the first to arrive at the place of meeting of the Nationalist Party this morning. After the members had all assembled Mr. Parnell took the chair and called the meeting to order. Telegrams from the delegates of the party now in the United States and from Archbishop Croke were read. An adjournment was then taken until 1 o'clock.

The hawk, supposed to be the one which has for some time made the top of the New-York tower of the Brooklyn Bridge its happy hunting ground, and which Officer Dooley of the bridge police force arrested Saturday night, as he said, "for chasing pigeons on the bridge premises without a license," turns out to be only a hawk impostor and to possess no claim whatever to the title of "The Bridge Hawk."

Through the English sporting papers which arrived in this country yesterday there was received the first reliable and complete information as to the much-discussed yachting trophy. "The Royal Victoria International Challenge Cup," and the conditions which are to govern races for it.

The project of a bridge across the Hudson River by which the railroads now intercepted at its west bank can be extended to the heart of the city and connected with those which reach it from the north and east is at once so important and so gigantic that it cannot fail to excite great interest, whatever may be thought of the proceedings that have attended its inception.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- As yet there has been no change in the position reached on Saturday in the question of Parnell's leadership, and, owing to the tactics employed by Parnell and his supporters, it is now unlikely that any decision can be arrived at tonight.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 1. -- Some new mining regulations by the Ontario Government announced to-day will have a material effect on the nickel mining interests at Sudbury. The Government has withdrawn from sale some of the most valuable mining deposits in the Nipissing and Algoma districts. No further sales will be made of mining locations within this territory.

Mr. Cornelius Vanderbilt, President Depew, Third Vice President Webb, and other officers of the New-York Central Railroad have returned from their tour of inspection of the Vanderbilt railroad properties in this State and are well satisfied with what they saw. They traveled in the private car of Mr. Vanderbilt and Mr. Depew inspecting the New-York Central Road on their westward trip and the West Shore on their eastbound trip.

There seems to be no doubt that the medical fraternity of this city will very soon have an opportunity of testing for itself the properties of Dr. Koch's wonderful lymph. Surprise has been expressed in many quarters that attempt had not been made before this to put into practical course of demonstration this mysterious remedy, it having been found possible in several countries besides Germany to get quantities of the lymph for purposes of experiment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Speaker Reed and his "business" majority have faced the music again and, with the beginning of the second session of the Fifty-first Congress, have prepared to take up the work remaining to be done before the control of the lower branch passes to the Democrats.

The Commissioners of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge voted yesterday to appropriate to their enterprise quite a slice of this town, beginning at Seventieth Street and the North River and extending from that point north and south.

The Trustees of Columbia College held their regular monthly meeting yesterday afternoon. Hamilton Fish presided, and those present included President Seth Low, W.C. Schermerhorn, Joseph Harper, the Rev. Dr. Marvin R. Vincent, Dr. W.H Draper, George L. Rives, United States District Attorney Edward Mitchell, and John B. Pine, who was elected clerk pro tem. in the absence of Mr. Beckman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- W.P. Thompson, President of the White Lead Trust and general adviser to members of allied industries, has summoned the lead and silver smelting concerns of the country to this city To-morrow morning they win "meet to confer," and if the anticipated spirit of harmony prevails at the conference there will be another trust added to the already long list of such combinations.

The reports of the several Executive Departments which will be laid before Congress in the usual course will exhibit in detail the operations of the Government for the last fiscal year. Only the more important incidents and results, and chiefly such as may be the foundation of the recommendations I shall submit, will be referred to in this annual message.

Jacob Schaefer is the champion billiard player of the world. The little Wizard won the title last night in Chickering Hall in the presence of 2,000 people, who gave him full vocal tribute as he scored the last point that made him the victor. George F. Blosson, his old-time eemgy, was Schaefer's opponent, but the fight he made was a weak one.

The President has forgotten little and learned nothing. He meets the Congress in which his party provoked defeat, on its reassembling, with a tediously urgent exhortation to remedy none of the mistakes already made, to press forward in the same line, and trust to that Providence which the French say watches over "Americans and fools."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Representative Wike of Illinois to-day introduced in the House a preamble and resolution on the subject of the tariff. The preamble recites that it is manifest the people of this country have at the recent election most emphatically repudiated the policy and principles of taxation and protection embraced in the McKinley law, and have, by he overwhelming majority a such election, umistakably demanded lower taxes and cheaper necessities of life.

At a recent meeting of the County Medical Society several physicians became involved in a discussion of overcoats. The substance of their verdict, in which all agreed, was that the use of thick and heavy overcoats is indirectly accountable for the very chills that they are intended to prevent.

A hot contest is going on between the East River, Central Park and North River Railroad Company and the opposing property owners. The contestants went before the Aldermen's Railroad Committee yesterday, and warred with words for over two hours. Alderman Rinckhoff presided, and the other Aldermen present were Gregory, Noonan, Dinkel, and Brown.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1. -- The discovery of gold-bearing quartz in the conglomerate rocks of Stewiacke Valley, Colchester County, N.S., and the reported discovery of a valuable nickel deposit in Queens County, in the same province, once more draw attention to the extraordinary mineral wealth of Nova Scotia, the development of which, with the exception of coal and gold, may almost be said to be in its infancy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The reports received at the War Department to-day from the locality of the threatened Indian hostilities are much less favorable than has been the case for several days past. The dispatches received to-day indicate that between one and two thousand of the Indians who have refused to come into the Rosebud Agency in response to the agent's orders have started westward toward what are known as the Bad Lands.

If Senator SHERMAN and the New-York Tribune expected that the President in his message would accept their explanation of the cause of the recent fall of values in the stock market their confidence was misplaced. Mr. HARRISON speaks of "surprising and very unfavorable monetary events which have recently taken place in England," and then says:

GLASGOW, Dec. 1. -- Much uneasiness is felt over the delay in the arrival of the Anchor Line steamer Ethiopia, Capt. Wilson, which left New-York Nov. 16 for this port. The British steamer Prussian, Capt. Calvert, from Boston Nov. 19, arrived in the Clyde this morning. She reports that she saw nothing of the missing vessel.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., Dec. 1. -- A very important meeting of the managers was held here today. When President Appleton accepted the position made vacant by President Magill's resignation, it was with the understanding that if a permanent President could be obtained within the year he must be relieved of his duties as President and return to his professional work.

The new people introduced by Mr. Tony Pastor last night were in the main merely foils to those prime favorites of the habitues of the cozy little theatre in Fourteenth Street -- the Irish-American Maggie Cline and the English importation, Bessie Bonehill. These two in their respective specialties, and Mr. Pastor with his familiar songs, abundantly entertained the friendly-disposed audience which filled the house.

There was a stormy meeting of the Trustees and of representatives of lot owners of Greenwood Cemetery at the office of that institution, 26 Broadway, yesterday afternoon. The meeting was called for the purpose of electing five Trustees to fill the vacancies caused by the expiration of the terms of Abiel A. Low, Benjamin D. Silliman, Samuel D. Babcock, Gerard Beekman, and Charles M. Perry, the latter being the Controller and Secretary of the cemetery.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- At the Grand Opera House to-night "Ship Ahoy," a comic opera by H. Grattan Donnelly and Frederick Miller, was given its first production.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Gen. Miles, who has been in Washington since last Saturday night in daily consultation with Secretary Proctor, Gen. Schofield, and Secretary Noble upon matters relating to the Indian situation in the Northwest, left for Chicago to-day. The General believes that danger is imminent. "The seriousness of the situation," he says, "has not been exaggerated.

There was an aroma of old times about yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen. The proposed resolution giving the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company the right to construct a tunnel under the East River from Long Island City and under Forty-second Street has been before the Committee on Bridges and Tunnels for nine months. There have been several hearings on it, but never a report.

The annual report of President Howell of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was made public yesterday. It shows that 40,898,484 people used the big structure during the year ending Dec. 1, 1890, of which number 30,676,411 were passengers on the railroad. This shows an increase in total traffic over the same period of last year of 374,820 and an increase in railroad passengers alone of 3,721,638.

Gayly-decorated booths, built and adorned to suggest the four seasons, and peopled by pretty girls who sold fancy articles and bric-a-brac, filled the pink room at Sherry's establishment, 402 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon and evening.

The suit brought by John Y. McKane, the Coney Island magnate, against John P. Adams, as Chairman of the Kings County Democratic General Committee, to force his (McKane's) reinstatement as a delegate to the committee, was passed upon by the Court of Appeals yesterday, the opinion being against McKane. This merely upholds the decision of the trial Judge and the General Term.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- At midnight, Parnell, facing certain defeat, is more subdued in his demeanor than yesterday. Courteous and dignified and to the last exhausting all the devices of obstruction, he announced the votes proclaiming the destruction of his leadership with as much calmness as if he were unconcerned. During the debates he resolutely and unfairly ruled all points in his own favor. Still, he conciliated his opponents with his politeness and gentlemanliness.

Perrin H. Sumner, a lawyer, who has an office at 198 Broadway and who lives at 402 St. Nicholas Avenue, was an involuntary guest of Chief Inspector Byrnes last night. He occupied a cell at Police Headquarters, having been arrested on a warrant issued by Justice White, sitting at the Tombs Police Court. He is charged with forgery and subornation of perjury.
LONDON, Dec. 2. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Balfour moved that the Irish Land Purchase bill pass its second reading.

AEsop wrote a fable founded on the truth that it is likely to prove embarrassing if one bites off more than he can chew. Many people have come to realize the truth of AEsop's observation, and among them are the proprietors of the Peoria Grape and Sugar Company of Peoria, Ill., the head and front of the late Glucose Trust.

The increase in the number of the Engineer Corps of the navy, which has been strongly urged by the head of the Bureau of Steam Engineering and is supported by Secretary TRACY, will probably be brought to the attention of Congress this Winter. Indeed, there is now a bill pending for the purpose, introduced by Senator BUTLER, which contemplates very large additions, while other measures content themselves with smaller ones.

OCALA, Fla., Dec. 2. -- The National Farmers' Alliance and Industrial Union met in the Opera House at noon to-day. Nearly every delegation has arrived, and the house was crowded with Alliance men and women.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Ordnance Bureau of the navy is still experimenting with the high explosive invented by Dr. Stephen H. Emmens and known as emmensite, and it is believed the results thus far obtained indicate that another most important offensive agency will soon be at the disposal of the navy.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec, 2. -- The officers of the Hedding Methodist Episcopal Church held a meeting at a late hour last night, at which the proffered resignations of the members of the choir were freely discussed, the result being that all the resignations were accepted. One of the members of the church who was at the meeting said to-day:

The departure of Dr. Fessenden N. Otis of this city for Europe in search of health is quickly followed by the sale of his collection of modern paintings and Japanese bronzes already announced. They will be sold at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries on the evenings of Thursday and Friday, Dec. 4 and 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Telegrams from San Francisco to the Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey announce the receipt of news from the two survey parties who have spent the last year on the Upper Yukon, in Alaska.

President Allen Manvel of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, who has been East for the past ten days -- spending part of the time in New-York and part in Boston -- left here yesterday for Chicago. Before departing he reiterated the statement previously made by him that he knew nothing of any meeting to be held by Western railroad men for the purpose of forming the great combination suggested by Mr. Gould.

Miss Mabel Stephenson, a young lady who imitates the notes of birds, and who also has a great deal of native humor, easily took the first place in the esteem of the not very numerous audience at Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre yesterday afternoon. Miss Stephenson carries you, in mind, to the woods on a June morning.

Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court signed an order yesterday requiring Benjamin C. Wetmore, a lawyer, to appear before a referee and submit to an examination in order to enable Charles Guillemot to frame his complaint in a suit begun against Mr. Wetmore last Monday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 2. -- The steamship Stillwater, which arrived at her wharf at daylight this morning from Puerto Cortez, brings the latest information of the recent revolt in Spanish Honduras. Most of the facts are covered by the following letter from the acting British Consol at Tegucigalpa:
A museum train of four cars, in which exhibitions are held en route, and which is illuminated by its own electric-light plant, is oue of the new developments of the "season" out West.

The Farmers' Alliance of Florida has got up a sort of agricultural fair at the town of Ocala, in that State, under the name of a Semi-Tropical Exposition, and it is accompanied by a convention of the National Farmers' Alliance, the second held by that organization. The chief question that seems to be agitating the assemblage is whether the Alliance is to take the form of a "third party" in politics.

The Brooklyn Aldermen were in such a hurry on Monday to increase the salary of the Auditor from $3,500 to $5,000 that they went ahead without endeavoring to ascertain whether they had the right to do so or not. They did not even consult Corporation Counsel Jenks, and yesterday that official had to call attention to Section 22 of the Laws of 1888, which, after giving the Aldermen power to fix certain salaries, says:
TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 2. -- Commenting on the President's message, the Globe (Liberal) says;

There was a hot and obstinate fight in the House yesterday over the International Copyright bill, resulting in a decided advantage for the friends of the measure. It was the intention of Mr. SIMONDS of the Committee on Patents to bring his bill up for a fair discussion, but its enemies were afraid to let him do that and straightway resorted to every form of "filibustering" possible under the rules.

All Souls' Unitarian Church, Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street, vas decorated with palms and growing plants last evening, and was well filled by those who came to witness the marriage of Miss Nannie W. Hudson, daughter of the late Woodbridge Hudson of this city and niece of Edmund Wetmore, to Samuel P. Moore, a young lawyer of Rochester, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore C. Williams, pastor of the church.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The Daily Telegraph says the indications at present are in favor of Parnell's leading a strong party in Parliament, although he will probably not have a majority of the Irish party at his back.

The extra session of the New-Hampshire Legislature may not be so brief as was expected. It has to decide upon the qualifications of its own members before undertaking to decide upon those of the members of the next Legislature, and there is a dispute as to whether those who were appointed census enumerators thereby forfeited their titles as members of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The first skirmish over the Force bill in the Senate has been fought out, and the Democratic Senators have no reason to feel proud of their part in it.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec.2. -- The scene is changed. Chandler is no longer on deck in New-Hampshire. Gallinger is in command of the Republican forces once more. He sat at the Speaker's elbow in the House of Representatives to-day ready to prompt him in any emergency that might arise, but, as it happened, no emergency arose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The annual report of the Secretary of the Treasury was sent to Congress to-day. It opens with the following table of receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year of 1890: The revenues of the Government from all sources for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1890, were:

In the Court of Appeals at Albany yesterday morning in the celebrated case of Campbell against Arbuckle for breach of promise the judgment of the lower court was affirmed. This judgment was that the plaintiff should receive $45,000 and an allowance of $1,000 for expenses.

Lieut. Col. W. Hope, V.C., of the British Army, arrived in New-York last evening, and will sail this morning on the Inman Line steamer City of Chicago for England. Lieut. Col. Hope has long been recognized by army and navy officers in this country as being one of the greatest living authorities on ordnance matters of the present day, and his opinions regarding the progress of American gun establishments are of much importance.
Yesterday was almost an ideally uncomfortable day, one of those which open with crisp air and snowstorm and end in a combination of fallen snow, soaking rain, and slush-covered streets.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The meeting of the Nationalist members of the House of Commons to further consider the question of the retention of Mr. Parnell in the leadership of the party, reassembled this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3. -- The marriage of Miss Camilla Ridgely, daughter of Andrew Ridgely, and Ensign Edward Simpson, United States Navy, son of Rear Admiral Edward Simpson, took place at noon to-day in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. J.S.B. Hodges, assisted by the Rev. S.P. Simpson, an uncle of the groom, officiated. The church was decorated with flowers and plants.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 3. -- A sensational lawsuit was filed here to-day, the parties to which have all of them more than a local fame. Albert Nicholas Robelot, a man of property, aged forty-six, through his attorneys, Charles F. Claiborne and Henry L. Lazarus, instituted suit against Anatole Brieugne, lawyer, and Aristide Gelpi, merchant, for $5,000, or fifty shares of the stock of the Merchants' Mutual Insurance Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Dillon, O'Brien, O'Connor, Gill, and Sullivan have decided to abandon their collecting tour through the United States. This change is the result of the stand taken by the various Irish public bodies that have met since Sunday on the question of leadership. The delegates were also influenced in making this decision by the strong Parnell sentiment shown by the great crowd at the Battery D meeting last Saturday night.

Aqueduct Commissioner Francis M. Scott introduced a resolution at yesterday's meeting of the board authorizing the chief engineer and Secretary to prepare a report of the work of the commission from Jan. 1, 1887, to Jan. 1, 1891. He said that as no report had been made in four years, and the work was so nearly completed, a report was now in order. The resolution was adopted.

Seventeen years in State prison is the punishment that was meted out to Albert H. Smith, the forger who raised stock certificates from smaller to larger amounts, in the aggregate representing $360,000, by Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. There was a very large crowd in court to see the forger sentenced, and the proceedings were watched with the closest interest.

Republican politicians in the National House of Representatives seem to have learned no lesson from the last elections in regard to the effect of trying to obtain partisan advantage by unfair means, although it is quite evident that such attempts produce a reaction upon the popular mind by which more is lost than there was any chance of gaining.

Lieut. Col. W. Hope, V.C., of the British Army, whose views on the superiority of American naval ordnance were published in yesterday's TIMES, sailed on the Inman liner City of Chicago for Liverpool yesterday. Before his steamer loft her pier he said that immediately on his return to England he would endeavor to demonstrate the necessity for Great Britain to raise the standard of its gunmaking to that adopted at the Washington Gun Foundry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- The lead and silver smelters concluded their deliberations to-day after adopting a plan for organizing an association which shall include all the lead and silver smelting plants in the United States. The question will be discussed by the respective companies, and some time in January another meeting will be held in Chicago and the organization perfected.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 3. -- The preliminary statement of the Union Pacific Railroad for October shows: Gross earnings, $4,306,692; increase, $5,264; net earnings, $1,482,595 decrease, $482,459. The expenses show an increase of $487,723.

Mayor Grant's special commission appointed for the purpose of considering the expediency of constructing a driveway from Seventy-seventh to Ninety-eighth Street, along the Hudson River, met again in the Mayor's office yesterday. In the absence of Chairman Samuel D. Babcock, Cyrus Clark presided. Corporation Counsel Clark asked for another week in which to answer the questions put to him by the commission at the last meeting.

The Fire Department was on its mettle between 10 and 11 o'clock last night, as dangerous fires broke out almost simultaneously at Arnstein Bonn's "White House" dry goods establishment, 924 to 928 Third Avenue, and in the three flat houses owned by E.L. Woolsey at 565, 567, and 569 Park Avenue.

The first performance of Meyerbeer's popular opera, "Les Huguenots," at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening revealed the fact that the weak spot in the company would be in the same place as it generally is. The difficulty of securing a really fine colorature soprano who can sing the leading bravura roles of what is known as the Italian repertoire with the German text is one that must not be underestimated.

The West Virginia General Railroad people will not let the case of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal rest. Appeals have been made, and the legal fight will go on for years. The Baltimore and Ohio is proceeding with its plans to put the old canal into operation again. It will spend altogether between $1,000,000 and $1,200,000 in the resuscitation.

There was a lively discussion in the Senate yesterday over a proposition to arm the citizens of the States near to and in danger from the hostile Indians. Mr. VOORHEES of Indiana made an impetuous, perhaps a rather extravagant, speech based on Gen. MILES'S statement that the Indians had been starved into fighting.

Mr. Charles S. Gleed of Topeka, one of the most prominent members of the Kansas bar, is staying at the Gilsey Hause. Mr. Gleed is a Republican, with a firm belief that the tariff is primarily a tax and that many tariff crimes against the people have been perpetrated in the name of protection.

The decision of the Court of Appeals that lot owners are not responsible to municipalities for damages secured against them by injured persons on account of defective sidewalks or highways, while it clashes with the pet theories of many learned Judges and lawyers, is grounded as firmly in common sense as it is in law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Mr. Hoar was unable to get the Force bill before the Senate to-day until 2 o'clock, when the morning hour expired, and it had the right of way under the rules. Only one speech had been made upon the measure, when the Senate adjourned, so that the progress made to-day was rather more satisfactory to the Democrats than to the Republicans.

If the New-Hampshire Legislature adjourns to-day, in accordance with the resolution adopted by the lower house yesterday, all that it will have accomplished beyond determining its own membership will be the election of a new Clerk of the House. Nothing will have been done to interfere with the rights of the new Legislature in passing upon the qualification and election of its own members.

The passage by the House yesterday of the international copyright law is something of which the whole people may well be proud, for it was the performance of an act of justice and honesty by representatives of the people who had through misunderstanding and ignorance, once taken action in the opposite sense.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The English political world is bubbling with wonder and excitement at to-day's result of the Irish meeting. The Liberals and Tories, until now the one delighted and the other aghast, to-night are both vowing that they are mystified by the Irish, who form the most extraordinary party ever constituted.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 3. -- The Republicans of New-Jersey gained a gain of comfort yesterday by electing their candidate for Mayor of Plainfield. The contest was spirited and good- natured. The Republicans nominated Mr. Alexander Gilbert, cashier of the Fulton Market Bank of New-York, who has made his home in Plainfield for the past twenty-five years; the Democrats rallied behind Joseph S. Cutter, a grocery dealer.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3. -- In the Common Pleas Court to-day Judge Pugh rendered a decision that will attract great attention, as the question involved has never before come up for decision.

Miss Carolina Cecilia Estevez, who was one of the bridesmaids at the Vanderbilt-Crawford-Talcott wedding a few days ago, was married yesterday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock to Thomas H. Terry of Brooklyn. The ceremony took place at St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, and was performed by the Rev. Henry Wilson, one of the assistant rectors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Provisions were weak to-day, Pork, at the close, showing a decline from Tuesday of 1712c, and Lard and Short Ribs of 5c. The closing prices were about the bottom ones. January Pork opened at $10.95, sold between $11 and $10.75, and closed at $11.77. May opened at $11.75, sold between $11.82 and $11.57, and closed at $11.60. January Lard opened at $6.02, sold between $6.05 and $5.97, and dosed at $6.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- Among the decisions of the Court of Appeals handed down yesterday is one which is of more than ordinary importance. Under this ruling a lot owner in a city or village is not liable for injuries persons may sustain by defects in the street or highway abutting.

BOSTON, Dec. 3. -- The marriage of Mr. Oliver Ames, second son of Mr. Frederick L. Ames and nephew of ex-Gov. Oliver Ames, whose name he bears, and Miss Elise Alger West, the daughter of Capt. Preston C.F. West of the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company, took place at noon to-day at the Arlington Street Church, which was filled with a notable assemblage.

According to the gentleman from Kansas whose remarks we quote elsewhere, that State is as rich in Senatorial timber as in any other kind of product, and can very easily dispense with the services of Mr. INGALLS. But for those engaged in the Senatorial contest with a view to the defeat of INGALLS there may be no advantage in such a plenitude of available candidates.

A resolution has been offered in the House that when the Senate bill for "placing the American merchant marine engaged in foreign trade on an equality with that of other nations" shall be reached on the House calendar, it shall be in order to offer as a substitute sections of the House bill providing for a naval militia.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Freight rates were tightened up again to-day by the executive officers of the Western roads, who were in session all day. Cattle rates from Missouri River points to Chicago were advanced from 22 cents a hundred pounds to 2312 cents. Rates from points between the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers to Chicago will be advanced in proportion, and there will be a slight increase from points west of the Missouri River.

ELIZABETH, N.J. Dec. 3. -- Complete returns from the charter election yesterday show a substantial Democratic victory. It was near morning when the court was finished in some of the wards, and it was found that the Democrats had made an unexpected gain in the Fifth, electing Jacob W. Sheppard Alderman by 7 majority. There was also a gain of a Democratic Alderman in the Third Ward.

OCALA, Fla., Dec. 3. -- At the morning season of the Alliance Convention the Committee on Credentials made a final report, but this does not affect the personnel of the body except in one or two instances, where representation from States was out down, owing to a decrease in membership on account of non-payment of dues.

The Memphis Appeal-Avalanche cautions the Democratic Party against following the lead of an extremist in any direction and particularly urges conservatism in handling tariff matters. It says: "The tariff must be reduced gradually and in a conservative manner, and not by extremists or one-idead men. It should be remembered that when the tariff is reduced its beneficial results will be the last felt.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Gen. Miles has decided to mount two regiments of infantry now at Pine Ridge Agency. Orders to This effect have been promulgated. The two regiments are the First, from California, and the Seventh, from Denver. The necessary horses and other supplies to carry out this order are being hastily provided. It is surmised in and about headquarters that Gen. Miles contemplates proceeding to the Indian country in person.
QUEBEC, Dec. 3. -- North Channel, between the island of Orleans and the north shore, is frozen hard, affording a solid passage to the Island.

The Fencers' Club entertained the officers of the Brazilian squadron last night at the club house, 8 West Twenty-eighth Street. Beside the Brazilian officers there were present the officers of the United States ships Chicago, Yorktown, and Dolphin, the dynamite cruiser Vesuvi us, and the torpedo boat Cushing, together with a large number of private citizens.

JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 3. -- One year ago the American Wheel Trust was given the use of the great shops vacated here by the Smith Purifier, rent free. The Wheel Trust of to-day was not a Wheel Trust then, and agreed to constantly employ 250 men. Not half that many are now at work. On the strength of being furnished wheels cheap several large concerns were started here.

In this mass of unverified reports about the Indian troubles there are certain known facts which, we believe, no one has attempted to deny, and which call for most emphatic condemnation. Two of the most critical points in the Indian country are the agencies at Pine Ridge and Cheyenne River.

Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision dismissing the complaint in the suit of Work, Strong Co. against Judge Miles Beach of the Court of Common Pleas. Judge Beach some years ago had two accounts with the brokers -- one personal and the other a joint account. There was a profit to him on the personal account, but on the joint account about $19,000 was due the firm.

Two of about twenty ejectment suits involving some of the most valuable property in the city were put on trial yesterday, before Judge Patterson, in the Supreme Court. The plaintiffs are Joseph C. Tucker and Gideon J. Tucker, grandsons of Gideon Tucker, who died in 1845, leaving an estate which included a large amount of real estate between the Bowery and Fifth Avenue, Tenth and Twelfth Streets.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 4. -- The cruiser Charleston, with King Kalakaua on board, entered the harbor at 11 o'clock this morning, receiving the salutes of the war ship Swatara and the forts. The officers of the Charleston reported a good trip from Honolulu until Tuesday, when a gale, which has raged along the coast, was encountered.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Mr. Parnell arrived at the House of Commons at 11:30 o'clock this morning. He at once proceeded to the library, where he busied himself attending to his correspondence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Dr. Jedediah H. Baxter, Surgeon General of the army, who was stricken with paralysis last Monday, died at 2 o'clock this morning. He regained consciousness after the attack only for an instant on Tuesday.

That part of President Harrison's message which announced the dismissal of the Guatemalan Minister, Mizner, was a genuine surprise to the Central Americans who are in this city. It was generally known that Mizner had been called upon for an explanation of the circumstances attending the killing of Gen. Barrundia, and of his own conduct at that time, but the announcement of his peremptory dismissal had not been made public.

ALBANY, Dec. 4. -- Attorney General Tabor gave a hearing this afternoon on the application of Harriet V. Truair and daughter, petitioning the Attorney General to bring an action in the name of the people of the State for the dissolution of the Syracuse Journal Company, and for the appointment of a receiver. C.G. Baldwin and Martin A. Knapp appeared for the petitioners, and F.A. Hiscock for the Syracuse Journal Company.

The Intercontinental Railway Commission, composed of representatives from the United States and other American republics, met for organization in the Diplomatic Chamber of the Department of State in Washington yesterday at noon. This commission was recommended by the International American Conference for the purpose of supervising a survey for a line to connect the railway systems of North America with those of South America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Secretary Tracy is urging upon the United States Senate the importance of immediately passing the Revenue Marine Transfer Bill. This bill has passed the House and is now pending in the Senate. It is deemed one of the most important and urgent military measures brought to the consideration of the Fifty-first Congress.

ALBANY, Dec. 4. -- The Kill von Kull Yacht Club has been incorporated with objects for recreation in yachting and other lawful sports, with principal office at Port Richmond. The Trustees are Richard H. Disosway, John J. Caughey, Cola M. Sterling, George H. Treadwell, George Ross, Charles A. Ingalls, Robert Schaikenbach, David J. Jones, and Edwin J. Van Pelt.

Speaking of the failure of the Rittenhouse Manufacturing Company, in which Mr. EDWARD H. AMMIDOWN, President of the American Protective Tariff League, appears to have been the controlling stockholder, the New-York Tribune says:

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- It is evident that Clancy's amendment yesterday was broached to give Parnell a chance to corner his opponents. It seems, however, to-night that they will corner Parnell instead. The question in the secret debate yesterday, when Parnell asked for twenty-four hours to consider, was, Would he accept the decision of the majority, whether Liberal assurances respecting land and the police were satisfactory or not?

The entertainment, dramatic, musical, saltatorial, and Spectacular, given at the Broadway Theater yesterday afternoon, under the management of Daniel Frohman and Frank W. Sanger, attracted a great crowd. The Theater was filled in all parts, and the assemblage included many distinguished persons. There were more men in the house than are usually seen at matinees of this sort.

The bedding and mattress factory of George Heyman, at 103 and 105 Mott Street, was wrecked by fire yesterday morning, involving a loss on the building and contents of $60,000. The fire was caused by the recklessness of Harry Weiser, a youth nineteen years old, employed in the factory, who, in violation of the rules, lighted the gas with matches and accidentally set fire to a large pile of exceisior used for stuffing.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Balfour made a motion that Parliament vote 5,000 for the purpose of providing seed potatoes for the distressed land cultivators in Ireland. The seed potatoes, Mr. Balfour said, were not to be given to the people gratis, but as a loan, and any one paying ready money would obtain 20 per cent. discount.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- There is hardly a doubt that all the packers at the stock yards except Armour, Morris, and Swift, will move their plants the town of Lyons, around the Stickney tract. This was practically decided upon at a conference held this afternoon between Mr. Stickney and the packers at the office of S.W. Allerton Co., in the Board of Trade Building.

A new scheme to divide the responsibility for subway construction and subway maintenance came to light yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control. Edward Lauterbach, President of the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company, announced that people interested in the various telegraph and telephone companies had organized a company under the title of the Empire City Subway Company, with the purpose of taking charge of all the low-tension subways in the city.

No surprise is caused in naval circles over Secretary Tracy's demands for more vessels of the Puritan type. The demand is a direct outcome of the delay in fortifying important seaports.
