Private establishment, it is found, are unprepared to undertake at once the fabrication of seacoast materiel of a kind commensurate with immediate demands.

The Ladies' Board of the New-York Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital for Spine and Hip Joint Diseases of Children held its twenty-third annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the institution, 126 East Fifty-ninth Street. The meeting was opened by the President of the board, Mr. Oscar E. Schmidt, who made an appeal for more funds to increase the efficiency of the work.

Among dry goods men yesterday the failure of the Rittenhouse Manufacturing Company of Passaic was a disagreeable and portentous piece of news. The company was capitalized at $200,000, and of this Edward H. Ammidown of Ammidown Smith, in Worth Street, was the owner to the extent of $160,000, and Edmund L. Gardiner, the general manager of the mills at Passaic, owned the remaining $40,000.

By an explosion of a tank in chemical works in the eastern part of Cincinnati yesterday morning three men were fatally injured and two slightly. The tank was 12 feet by 7, and was 3 feet deep. It was used for making yellow prussiate of potash. No one knows what caused the explosion. The fatally injured are Louis Schluss, John Printy, and James Fehl. Those slightly injured are John Wecker and Sidney Clover.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 4. -- The ceremonies incident to the inauguration of Gov. Tillman were held here at 1 o'clock this afternoon, in the presence of about 4,000 people. Residents of Columbia, who are generally opposed to the new administration, did not appear in great numbers. The officers of the outgoing administration, however, walked in the inaugural procession.

Benjamin R. Jewell, who has been for almost a quarter of a century Secretary of the Massachusetts Total Abstinence Society, tells a representative of the Springfield Republican that the reason of the falling off in the proportion of the no-license vote is that the temperance people get tired of the annual agitation. They want something settled, Mr. Jewell says.

The Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company, which has an exclusive contract for the construction and maintenance of subways for electrical conductors in this city, is once more applying to the Board of Electrical Control for the privilege of dividing its task with another corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Republican Senators were not saying much in public to-day about the action of the National Convention of the Farmers' Alliance, informally denouncing the Force bill. It is to be hoped they were thinking. It is not doubted that the verdict of the Farmers' Alliance has hurt the radical supporters of the bill just at a time when they need all the strength they can muster.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- There was a meeting of the managers of the lines between Chicago and the Northwest to-day to consider the reports of Chairman Finley of the Western Passenger Association, W.H. Newman, Third Vice President of the Chicago and Northwestern; E.P. Ripley, Third Vice President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, and W.J.C. Kenyon.
The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce took place yesterday, President Charles S. Smith in the chair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Assistant Secretary Spaulding of the Treasury Department has rendered a decision holding that the bondsmen of the famous painting "The Angelus" are liable for $16,500 duty on the painting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The annual report of Attorney General Miller was made public to-day, and gives a detailed statement of the business of the United States Supreme Court and the Court of Claims and of all the judicial proceedings during the past fiscal year in which the United States was a party, including criminal prosecutions in all parts of the country.

It has grown to be an annual custom with the Hon. Thomas L. James to gather some of his best friends about him at a round table in the Union League Club on each anniversary of his wedding. He has an old-fashioned theory that a good dinner stimulates geniality and that geniality should pervade the relationship between friends.

The American Protective Tariff League gives notice that it is now inclined to stand aside and wait for developments. It will climb up out of the political arena and look on, as it were, from the benches. "No extraordinary vision is needed," says the League in its Bulletin, "to perceive that the economic policy of the United States has reached a point of new departure.

Secretary NOBLE has been a long time getting up his indignation at the enormous tribute paid by old soldiers to the pension attorneys in Washington. He finds all of a sudden that these attorneys are collecting from $150,000 to $375,000 a week out of the money appropriated by the Government for the payment of pensions, and in many cases for alleged services that ought not to be required at all.

Norway's arctic expedition is, it appears, to have a rival in the undertaking of two Frenchmen, M. BESAC0N and M. HERMITE, who are to attack the north pole by balloon. Making their base at Spitzbergen, they will there fill their balloon with 45,000 cubic feet of hydrogen gas, and start when the wind blows the right way, with a good prospect of holding.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- There is a hand which is Italian and exceeding fine. It belongs to Mr. James G. Blaine, and, like Mary's sister Martha, it is busy about many things. By an act of Congress, this hand has an official connection with the World's Fair. By an act of James G. Blaine this hand would fain have a much closer and more personal connection with the World's Fair.

MEADVILLE, Penn, Dec. 5. -- No recent event has caused so much interest in this part of the State as the failure of Delamater Co., announced this morning by this card, displayed in the window of the establishment:...

Gen. J.L. Stackpole, one of the Republican members of the Board of General Appraisers appointed under the Customs Administration act, which went into operation Aug. 1 last, has resigned his position, and was yesterday notified by the President that his resignation had been accepted. Gen. Stackpole was appointed from Boston, where he had been engaged in the practice of the law.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Much progress has been made this week in shaping the details of the work of the Columbian Exposition. Nothing now remains to be done before President Harrison can issue his proclamation to foreign nations except to approve the rules and regulations for exhibitors. These rules were prepared by Director General Davis early in November.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Provisions were all day very weak. From the opening to the close there was a steady liquidation by all sorts of traders of the nearby months. December Pork sold as low as $8.25, and January dropped 95c under May. January Lard got to 60c under May and the spread in Ribs was 55c. Pork at one time showed a decline of over 20c, Lard of 10c, and Ribs of 1812c.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 5. -- The news of the failure of the banking firm of Delamater Co. of Meadville was read at the State Department with great surprise. State Treasurer Boyer was not here, but his cashier, Mr. Livsey, obtained early telegraphic information of the crash, which carried down with it $100,000 of the money of the State sinking fund.

The bill introduced in the House of Representatives by Judge Chipman of Michigan relative to the pension of Mrs. Gen. Custer provides for an increase to $1,200 annually, not $2,000, as was at first supposed. The latter figure is the amount paid to Mrs. Crook, Mrs. Kilpatrick, Mrs. Logan, Mrs. Blair, Mrs. Fremont, and several other widows of officers ranking near Custer.

The present exasperating condition of the public streets may result in an overthrow of the present management of the Street-Cleaning Department. The people are beginning to be heard from. The Mayor is receiving complaints right and left. Yesterday William B. Du Bois, a lumber merchant of 24 State Street, sent a letter to the Mayor asking many pertinent questions. Part of his letter is as follows:...

The Governing Board of Commissioners of the Vessel Owners and Captains' National Association, at a meeting held Thursday in the association's rooms in this city, resolved to recommend to the Secretary of the Treasury the establishment in his department of a marine board of an advisory character, to consist of the heads of each of the marine bureaus in the National Government, together with civilian representatives of foreign, coastwise, and internal navigation.

After having been closed for two months for repairs, the Thirty-seventh Street Methodist Episcopal Church will be reopened to-morrow with ceremonies of an unusually interesting character. The friends of this church will hardly recognize it in the transfiguration that has been made. When the building was closed two months ago it was almost dilapidated in appearance.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 5. -- The Chandler-Goodell extra session of the Legislature of 1889 came to an end at noon to-day after a four-days' sitting which will cost the State about $10,000. The only practical result of the session is getting rid of the old Clerk, who resigned only after the extra session had been summoned, and the election of another who is supposed to be a more complaisant tool of the Republican bosses.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5. -- Gen. Wesley Merritt, Commander of the Department of the Missouri, in the course of an interview concerning the situation and military movements in the Northwest, rather severely criticised the action that had been taken. Gen. Merritt is familiar with the country to which the troops have been sent, as he has himself done some very effective campaigning there.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Friday, Dec. 5:

The Bar Association of the City of New-York at its meeting next Tuesday will receive a report from Mr. B.F. Lee, Chairman the special committee on the bill to establish a Federal Court of Appeals, which, it is expected, will cause considerable discussion and probable action.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Messrs. Redmond, Sexton, Healy, Leamy, and the two whips, Power and Deasy, being, with the exception of Mr. Parnell, all the committee appointed at yesterday's meeting of the Irish members of Parliament to confer with Mr. Gladstone, drove to the residence of the Liberal leader at 12:40 o'clock today.

Some of our readers may remember that when Mr. HARRISON was nominated for the Presidency there was an audible sigh of relief on the part of a great number of excellent Republicans whose patience with their party had been tried to the point of breaking, or beyond it, by the task of supporting Mr. BLAINE four years before.

Perhaps the most important service in which the "Farmers' Alliance and Industrial Union," now in convention at Ocala, Fla., is engaged is that of breaking down the lines of sectionalism, and the effect of that service is likely to be permanent, whatever may come of the other purposes of the organization.

One of the largest and most conspicuous factory buildings on the west side, the Cohn Building, at 224 to 232 West Twenty-sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, opposite the Ninth Regiment Armory, was partially destroyed by fire last night, together with its valuable contents, involving a loss of over three-quarters of a million of dollars.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- Senator Delamater was in this city yesterday in consultation with some of his intimate friends in the financial centres, and it was then rumored that he was being hard pressed for cash. It is said that in the late campaign Mr. Delamater's personal notes were indorsed and discounted by Philadelphia business men who were his supporters, but that the loss to them is comparatively small.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 5. -- The sale of the Megibben thoroughbreds began here to-day at Tracy Wilson's stables, P.C. Kidd auctioneer. The attendance was large and the bidding spirited. Forty-one head were sold for $49,615, an average of $1,210. Palestine was sold to close partnership, Landeman having owned only a half interest. Bryon McClelland bid him in for Landsman, the contending bidder being Green Morris. Following is a list of the horses sold:

In the hearing yesterday before the House Census Committee upon the application for a re-enumeration of the inhabitants of this city, intimations were thrown out that an additional member of Congress might be allowed to this State without making a recount of the population of the city.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The Telegraph understands that Mr. Gladstone, in intimating through the party whips that a second interview with the Irish deputation was unnecessary, conveyed also the opinion that the question at issue was not one affecting the conditions under which home rule might be granted to Ireland, but related rather to the retention of Parnell in the leadership of the Nationalist Party or his dismissal therefrom.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5. -- The first definite results of the experiments by local scientists with Prof. Koch's lymph were observed to-day. The patient who was inoculated on Wednesday has progressed so much that the physicians have stronger hopes than they had before of a permanent cure. Dr. Francis Bacon has charge of this patient and, though conservative, he says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- It was not a very pleasant afternoon for the radical supporters of the Force bill in the Senate. Poor Mr. Hoar was driven from corner to corner by the Democrats, under Mr. Gray's lead, until he felt constrained to intimate that one of the most objectionable features of the bill appeared there by a mistake of the printer, and afterward to admit that, perhaps, the error was his own.

When the doors of the carnivora house in Central Park were opened yesterday morning to admit the public to the reception announced by Miss Murphy in honor of her young daughter, the draught was so strong that Superintendent Conklin, fearful for the health of this precious infant, closed the building until frames of glass could be placed around the cage containing the hippopotami.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- In response to the resolution adopted Sept. 24, last, the President to-day transmitted to the House of Representatives the correspondence growing out of the killing of Gen. Barrundia by Guatemalan officers on board the Pacific Mail steamer Acapulco, in the port of San Jose.

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- The action of Henrietta Woods against Erastus Wiman has been sent back by the Court of Appeals for a new trial. The action was for libel and grew out of certain statements in pamphlets submitted by Mr. Wiman to the Governor in urging the passage of the act of 1886, abolishing imprisonment for debt.

Our high-tariff contemporaries continue to tell their readers that "there is no more talk of rising prices on account of the McKinley act." These are the words of the Philadelphia Press. "The free-trade howl about higher prices has ceased," says the Cleveland Leader. "The cry of higher prices has subsided since election, showing that it was raised with little warrant and for political purposes only."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 5. -- The Liberty Street fire, which broke out in Maginn's cracker factory about 1 o'clock this morning, was not extinguished until four large business blocks had been consumed. The buildings were brick, seven stories high, and were occupied by E. Maginn, cracker house; R. Jenkinson, wholesale tobacco house; Crea, Graham Co., stove and hardware dealers; L.H. Harris Co., wholesale druggists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- When the Republican Party is ready, as it appears to be, to attack the pension sharks of the capital and the country, and to cut down the fees that they have been instrumental in allowing them for getting pensions, and for increasing the pensions that they have already been abundantly paid for getting, the suspicion may be justified that the Republican Party is "on the run."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- An unofficial meeting was held this afternoon at Camden Station by the Managers, Division Superintendents, Superintendents of Motive Power, engineers, telegraph Superintendents, and others to discuss matters of moment along the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Charles F. Mayer, President; Orland Smith, First Vice President; H.D. Buckley, expert accountant; Dr. S.R. Barr, Superintendent of the Relief Department, and C.O. Soull, General Passenger Agent, were present by special invitation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The returns canvassed to-day by the State Board of Canvassers show startling evidences of bribery on their face. The plan of causing bribed men to vote for fictitious names swelled the total number of "defective, blank and scattering" votes in the entire State to 28,965 out of a total vote of 1,003,533 for Judge of the Court of Appeals.

Now that international copyright is likely again to come before Congress, permit me to invoke your aid to prevent a serious wrong to authors threatened by the bill itself unless it differs from that offered last year.

The music of the bagpipes and the pungent aroma of the haggis pervaded Delmonico's large banquet hall last night on the occasion of the one hundred and thirty-fourth anniversary dinner of the St. Andrew's Society. Scotch songs were sung, Scotch stories were told, and Scotch prowess was extolled. It was a jovial night for Scotchmen, full of enthusiasm and cheers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- If New-York obtains in the new Congressional apportionment a number of representatives adequate to her population, as it is shown to be by the police enumeration, it will be about all she is likely to get from this Congress.
" This atmosphere is pretty rich for men of our class," said a railroad man of modest means as he shook hands with a friend in the cafe of the Windsor Hotel one night last week.

The recent organization of the Hamilton Trust Company, with such men as Col. Hester, William Berri, Silas B. Dutcher, Congressman Wallace, and Register of Arrears McGuire as Directors, calls attention to the fact that Brooklyn is enjoying a boom in this class of financial institutions. Five years ago there was one; now there are seven, representing, in the aggregate, a capital of over $4,000,000 and an aggregate paid-in surplus of half that amount.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Since the "Maitre de Forges" M. Ohnet has given only one play to the Gymnase, and the life of the "Comtesse Sarah" was not very brilliant. There are hundreds of people who always buy an Ohnet book, and there are just as many who would not miss a play by the same author. "Dernier Amour" was first written in serial form and published in the Figaro.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Census Superintendent Porter was heard this morning before the House Committee on the Eleventh Census in reply to the argument made yesterday in behalf of a new count for New-York by Mr. John F. Bowers, representing the Mayor and the city.

Mr. Francis Fussy was a wholesale dealer in cork. A married man was Fussy, with a family which indicated by its number the years of his matrimonial felicity. A devout man was Fussy. The ambition of his youth had been to win the title of deacon. For so long a time had he deservedly worn it that his smug features and demure whiskers constituted for many a type of that official.

It appears that Mr. J.A. Ancheta was elected by the Republicans in one of the southern districts of New-Mexico to the Territorial Council. The Aztec (N.M.) Index, a Republican paper, says it is now known that Mr. Ancheta has not reached the age required by law for eligibility for the position to which he was elected, and this, that paper states, invalidates his election and renders necessary a special election.

Imagine the sight! Eight hundred and fifty-two lively little youngsters, dressed in their best bib and tucker, sitting in graduated seats like those in a theatre! Their ages ranged from three years to eight. From the visitors' gallery they looked like an immense picture quilt, every baby picture of which had suddenly popped up alive, so regularly did the gay hoods and hats of the girls block out the shaved heads of the wiggling boys.

Several meetings have been held by the special committee of importers to which was referred the question of the constitutionality of the new tariff law, and after having received and considered at length the opinions of counsel upon the point involved the committeemen have reached a tacit if not expressed agreement upon the matter.
I notice an article in your issue of to-day in reference to overcoats and the conclusion reached by certain members of the County Medical Society.

It is a fine proof of the care with which the public business is done in Washington that two sections of the Elections bill authorizing house-to-house visits by Deputy Marshals were found in the bill after they had been stricken out by the Senate Committee. And it is not flattering to Mr. HOAR that his fellow-Senators seemed to find some difficulty in believing that this was, as he said, due to a printer's error.

The row over the Tammany leadership in the Fourteenth District goes merrily on. Percy Rockwell's friends are boastful that he will win ultimately, notwithstanding the fact that John Reilly, ex-Register, controls the District Committee almost to a man. The word has been quietly passed around that anybody who expects any patronage had better apply to Mr. Rockwell and that the Reillys cannot get any.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 6. -- A suit for $1,200,000 was begun in the Common Pleas Court this afternoon by Horace P. Weddell against Dr. Azarial Everett, President of the East Cleveland Railroad Company. This suit is the outgrowth of the failure of the banking house of Everett Weddell, which occurred in 1884, when an assignment was made to Attorney J.H. Webster.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 6. -- The third day of the experiments by Yale scientists and New-Haven physicians with Prof. Koch's lymph, for the cure of tuberculosis, has ended favorably, and there are strong indications that an effectual cure is being made in each of the three cases.

On Friday last First Lieut. Thomas A. Patteson, Jr., ceased to be a member of the Seventh Regiment and a commissioned officer of the National Guard through the action of General Headquarters in transmitting from Albany his discharge from the State service.
There is a germ of dissatisfaction in the police force that promises to develop into a healthy growth. The patrolmen and roundsmen want more pay.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- The new opera of "Benvenuto Cellini" by Diaz, son of the painter, produced at the Opera Comique, has been only moderately successful. The composer is an ardent lover of the ancient Italian methods and has a pronounced dislike of Wagner and the new school. Verdi -- the Verdi of the past -- is his idol.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 6. -- Bruce and Kidd offered the McCampbell string of horses to-day. There was a good crowd of bidders present and thirty-five head brought $28,715, an average of $820 each. In the afternoon Col. S.D. Bruce sold forty-one head of yearlings and others for $17,820, an average of $435 each. Lieut. T.J. Clay has decided to sell the two-year-old colt, Balgowan, next Monday.

Some years ago, when the poet Mr. A.C. SWINBURNE had rendered himself more remarkable than ever by entering the London Arts Club and making a Berserkir attack on the hats of his fellow-members, scattering them about the floor and dancing the wildest sort of rigadoon on them, a brother poet gave an excellent account of the affair in verse that rivaled the best of Mr. SWINBURNE'S imitations of the Greek manner in drama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- It is understood that the Republican members of the Census Committee have reached an agreement upon a reapportionment bill, based upon a representation of 356 members of the House. The present House consists of 332 members. This understanding has been arrived at after mature consideration and consultation with their party associates on the floor.

The Navy Department, it is reported, will shortly take up the subject of naval reorganization and give it serious consideration. Secretary Tracy, though crowded with work, is said to be fully alive to the recent discussions and thoroughly believes that the efficiency of the personnel demands as much attention as does materiel.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 6. -- All through this section of the country during the last campaign the people were told that the McKinley bill was all right; that it was in the interest of the wage earner, and that as soon as understood it would be favorably received by the masses. No one has been more persistent in this statement than that warm friend of McKinley, Congressman Boutelle, representing the Fourth District of this State.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- The Utica Pastors' Association is a body composed of ministers having charge of so-styled evangelical churches of that city, and which meets weekly for mutual counsel, aid, and encouragement in the work of spreading the light of the Gospel. At a late session of the association an application was made for admission to membership in behalf of the Rev. C.E. Rice, pastor of the Universalist Church of the Reconciliation.

M. Prieu, a merchant who carried on business for many years in Brazil, has brought an action against the Government of the French Republic for the respectable sum of 560,000, for damages he alleges to have sustained through the action of a French Consul. It seems that some thirty years ago M. Prieu felt aggrieved at the action of the Brazilian authorities at Itaque in overcharging him customs dues on merchandise passing through his hands.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Richard Mansfield came to Chicago with a record of having scored the greatest success of his life in the title role of "Beau Brummell." Its first production at the Columbia last Monday night fully justified all the good reports of Mr. Mansfield's artistic triumph, and Chicago added her indorsement to that of New-York and other Eastern cities.

The famous Nelson-Alcryon case, which has attracted the attention of the horse-racing world for more than a year, was decided yesterday by the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association, in session at the Murray Hill Hotel. Both Nelson and the stallion which bears his name were expelled from the Association.

ELEGY MONGERS. -- One of the items of expenditure which became fashionable after the Restoration was the payment of rhymsters to write funeral elegies. Quit a host of poetasters traded on this fashion, and the specimens which Mr. Maidment collected of their effusions show that the majority would have been dear at any price.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Dec. 6. -- The Legislature of the State of Idaho will convene at the Capitol in the city on Monday. It is generally thought that the first business to engage its attention will be the election of United States Senators. Of course they will both be Republicans, for of the thirty-six members of the House only five are Democrats, and there is the same number in the Senate, which has eighteen members.

In the course of my saunterings and cruisings this Summer, the names of islands along the Maine coast impressed me frequently with their significance. There are, for instance, several Brown Cows gazing on the ocean field, the islands bearing, especially at a distance, a resemblance to the esteemed contemporary which our milkmen are supposed to see daily.

OCALA, Fla., Dec. 6. -- The morning session of the Farmers' Alliance to-day was interesting. The afternoon session was highly exciting. In the morning, complaint was made by Col. Livingston of Georgia that the Government crop statistician relied too much upon information furnished by uninformed Congressmen. Frank Burkitt of Mississippi moved that a roster be furnished of all sub-Alliance secretaries, who will send to each Alliance all information in their possession bearing on statistics.

The Rev. Father M.J. Moran, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity at Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, will celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to-morrow. The celebration will really begin to-night, when the members of the congregation will meet in the Criterion Theatre on Fulton Street and present Father Moran with a purse containing $25,000.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 6. -- The Bee has received the following from its special correspondent:
A sportsman who has just returned from quail hunting in the neighborhood of Forked River, N.J., tells a very pretty and pathetic story.

Gen. Henry W. Slocum last evening delivered mother of his brilliantly graphic off-hand addresses, talking this time about "Sherman's March to the Sea." His was the fourth in the series of lectures upon war experiences by distinguished veterans being delivered for the benefit of the Reformed Episcopal Church of Reconciliation, at Nostrand and Jefferson Avenues.

Barton Wingfield made five circuits of his garden that June morning, whereas it was customary for him to make only four. He was in dressing gown, bareheaded, and tramped through the dew in his new russet leather slippers. Moreover, he was smoking a long, fragrant cigar, and this trespass on domestic discipline had not happened before for more than a year.

It is difficult to separate Henry Houssaye from Philoxene Beyer, his teacher, who was a universal library, a post in an age when mention of a tragedy in verse to a manager did not provoke a call for the police, a writer so classical that he might have given a Greek pattern for every phrase of his essays, Beyer died of old age at thirty-seven; Houssaye is Beyer continued, an excellent Hellenist and charmingly communicative.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6. -- The leaven of reform is working with such vigor in local Republican circles that great results will be shown next Monday evening, when the Republican City Central Committee will be reorganized. John McFall is now Chairman of the committee and Ford Smith Secretary. These two men are simply figureheads of Chauncey J. Filley, Chairman of the State Republican Committee and the great Republican boss.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 6. -- No official statement has yet been made regarding the failure of V. A. Meyer Co. yesterday, but it is learned that their assets will exceed $3,000,000, while their liabilities are very much less, approximating $2,000,000.

The career of Judge Maurice J. Power as leader of the County Democracy is practically at an end. His term of office as a Police Justice will close on Wednesday, and he will be seen no more upon the bench. He went to Washington yesterday with his wife, and his present plan is to spend most of the Winter in the South, and to go to Europe for an extended tour in the Spring.

It has been for us, of late years, a somewhat rare pleasure to agree with Senator EDMUNDS in regard to even the minor features of a partisan measure. We are bound to say that in his defense of what Mr. GRAY calls "domiciliary visits" under the Elections bill we think that the Vermont Senator showed more sense and courage than his fellow-Senators on the Republican side.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6. -- John J. Stoddard, as attorney for the Mercantile Trust Company of New-York, filed a bill in equity for $3,500,000 in the United States Court here to-day. This company holds the first mortgage bonds of the Zanesville, Wooster and Marion Railway Company, and asks for a foreclosure on the ground that the semi-annual interest due in July last has not been paid. But one section of the road has been built.

Lieut. L.K. Reynolds, who has recently been ordered to the command of the Coast Survey steamer Endeavor, served on board the United States frigate Constellation during the early part of the present decade. The Constellation was ordered to convey a draft of men to the European station. She proceeded on her mission without encountering heavy weather until off the coast of Spain.

Native literature in Bombay appears to be in a flourishing, and is certainly not in a lethargic, condition. During the past year there were published in the Presidency 365 books in the Mahratti and 445 in the Gujerati language. It is noted in Mr. Sathe's official report as a curious fact that while so much is heard of the awakening of India to political questions, these publications only include one which relates to politics.

Out on the plains of the West are a number of Indian schools where the little savages from the camps are brought together to receive some elementary instruction in English. Many of the best and brightest of these children are afterward sent East to schools like Hampton and Carlisle, and all are taught something of the industrial arts, and in so far fitted to become self-supporting.

The new Morgan Line steamer El Sol arrived in port Friday. She came directly from the yards of her builders, William Cramp Sons of Philadelphia, and began loading in the afternoon for her maiden outward-bound passage.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- So absorbing has been the interest in and the excitement created by the vital struggle waged between the advocates of the interests of Ireland and the supporters of Mr. Parnell that no person has had any time or attention to devote to Parliamentary occurrences which at an ordinary time would have made much stir.

The discussion over Dr. KOCH'S discoveries gives especial interest to any original contributions to the knowledge of microbes. Prof. FRANKLAND'S article in the English Illustrated Magazine is a popular account of some of his own investigations. He found, for instance, that KOCH'S Comma bacillus, which is probably the inducing cause of Asiatic cholera, had its power of growth entirely arrested by exposure for several days to an atmosphere of carbonic acid gas.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- The Reichsanzeiger gives in extenso passages that Emperor William himself selected from his recent speech on school reform. One point that the Emperor especially emphasizes is the time lost in the higher public schools in cramming youths with Latin and Greek, instead of the German language and German history, especially the growth of German institutions and the idea of national unity.

In last Sunday's Herald there appeared a number of letters from clergymen of this city explaining their views of the propriety of ministers engaging in political affairs, and more particularly of the conduct of the ministers who co-operated with the Municipal League in the late election. One of the most extraordinary of these letters appears over the engraved signature of the rector of Trinity Church.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- The general opinion seems to be that the big Poughkeepsie Bridge is of more benefit to Poughkeepsie than to the surrounding country. Produce and merchandise from the West, that was formerly distributed in the township of Lloyd, which includes the villages of Highland, Oakes, Centreville, and Chritondale, are now carried on to Poughkeepsie.

The efforts of the old County Democracy organization to rehabilitate itself are not very encouraging. If its aim is to be a political organization for local purposes it does not much matter whether it revives or not. We want less, not more, politics in local affairs, and organization with reference to their conduct should have no designs or relations with reference to State or national politics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Gen. Schofield, in a letter of Dec. 3 to the Secretary of War, says:

The Home Hotel Association has undertaken the benevolent work of providing for worthy persons in need who may have followed the various professions. It has secured the loan of a home at which during the year twenty-three persons have received care. Among the men thus helped were an artist, an opera tenor singer, a journalist, a lawyer, a professor of languages, and a school teacher.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 6. -- The Rev. E.F. Wilson of Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, has recently taken a prominent part in the organization of the Canadian Indian Research and Aid Society. He is associated with prominent Canadians who propose to promote the welfare of the Indians and preserve their history, traditions, and folklore, as well as diffuse information with a view to creating more general interest in both their spiritual and temporal progress.

OTTAWA, Dec. 6. -- A religious enthusiast named Dr. Jacques is creating something of a sensation in Montreal by establishing a semi-monastic residence in that city. He professes to have the approval of the Archbishop of Montreal. La Presse, a Montreal French paper, gives an interesting account of a scene witnessed on the premises in a recent visit.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 6. -- On Nov. 25 a well-dressed young man arrived in Denver and registered at the Broadway Hotel as George F. McLelland of San Francisco. He immediately asked if Mr. Edwin Price had arrived, explaining that Price was his secretary. Price was not on hand, and McLelland looked over the mail and finding a letter addressed to Price opened it.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 6. -- The Rev. J.C. McInerney of the Universalist church in New-Britain has resigned and will accept the pastorate of the church in Mount Vernon. His successor at New-Britain will be the Rev. Alonzo Chase of Granby.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 6. -- It appears from reports made to the Illinois Department of Agriculture that in the northern division of the State the average yield per acre of corn will not exceed 26 bushels. The area planted last Spring to corn in this division, as returned by the Assessors, was about 3,000,000 acres, giving a total estimated yield of 78,000,000 bushels, as against 105,000,000 bushels last year.

The twenty-first annual meeting of the National Board of Trade will begin at the St. Charles Hotel, New-Orleans, to-morrow. At this meeting many recommendations of the greatest interest to commercial bodies throughout the United States will be passed upon by their delegates.

The much-talked of meeting of railroad Presidents, which Jay Gould has striven so earnestly to bring about, will be held in this city one week from to-morrow, probably at the residence of J. Pierpont Morgan. The indications are that there will be a large attendance and some differences of opinion. Mr. C.P. Huntington, it is believed, will suggest some amendments to the plan outlined by Mr. Gould.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 6. -- The college has settled down till the Christmas recess, and there is much talk about the important events of the Fall term. The success of the football team has been commented on very favorably, both by Alumni and students, and never has more interest been shown in this sport. Candidates for the baseball team will begin practicing next term under Capt. Sullivan.

The old time-worn and generally threadbare subject of getting a street car on the tracks through Eighty-sixth Street has been revived in a letter written to THE TIMES by one of the anxious and abused taxpayer in that neighborhood. The tracks have been laid both east and west, and yet the Park Board permits month after month to pass without putting on the cars.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Railroad men and shippers have not yet recovered from the shock caused by the indictments of leading officials by the Federal Grand Jury. These indictments were the result of several weeks' of investigation, aided by two remarkably sharp attorneys, representing the Inter-State Commerce Commission.
The City and South London Railway was recently finished, and it is expected that in a few weeks the regular passenger traffic of the road will commence.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6. -- There is a tide in the sports of men as well as in their affairs, and at present the Winter sports of Canada have reached a very low ebb. It is not too much to say that this year will witness their extinction for a time. Not a single toboggan slide will be open in Montreal, where formerly there were six public and any number of private ones.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 6. -- Senator John B. Gordon is an Alliance man. He has at least accepted an invitation to join the order, and the ceremonies attendant upon his initiation will take place Tuesday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- Information from Delaware Breakwater is to the effect that the steamship Maryland, which put into the breakwater in distress this afternoon, encountered the terrible hurricane which swep tthe Atlantic coast on the 1st inst. with fearful results. On that date the Maryland at the height of the hurricane was washed by a terrific sea, which dashed those on the deck in all directions and swept everything movable overboard.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 6. -- With the close of the college football season the attention of Yale has been directed to boating. The assertion of Cambridge enthusiasts that Harvard's "luck" in athletics has turned may not be seriously entertained here, but either that or a feeling that the big football eleven which won the recent game at Springfield will contribute excellent material to the crimson crew has aroused Capt. Brewster and his men to early action.

The enlisted men of the Sixty-ninth Regiment assembled in mass meeting last night at 52 Union Square to protest against the methods of administration in vogue in the regiment, the effect of which has been sensibly detrimental to the interests of the organization. A large majority of the backbone of the regiment was in attendance.

The city has been given over, as far as its social side is concerned, during the last week to teas and receptions, and the up-town streets bordering on Fifth and Madison Avenues have been filled every afternoon from 3 to 7 P.M. with carriages bearing richly-attired women to and fro from this or that "day at home" or kettledrum.

Mrs. Mollie Ellen Saunders died at her home in this city last week after a brief illness. She was the youngest and only surviving child of Elle Ellen, an old resident of Truckee. Her death recalls a striking incident, which is related as taking place six or seven years ago. In 1883 Elle Ellen, a hale and hearty pioneer of nearly sixty years of age, was stricken with paralysis.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Mr. Gladstone, in his letter to the Nationalist meeting, acknowledges the receipt of the two resolutions adopted by the Irish caucus and says:

It is an unusual form of ambition, but there are some of Mr. HARRISON'S friends who declare that the one object of his efforts just now is to make the nomination in 1892 so nearly worthless that no one but himself will care, or dare, to take it. Men of ordinary shrewdness in politics will reject this story "on grounds," as the eminent subject of it would remark, "of repugnancy."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 6. -- In the Union County Court to-day Judge McCormick pronounced sentence ou the two Anarchists, Charles Klop and Emil Vogt, who were convicted of being active participants last August in a riot at a picnic, where the police were roughly handled and one of them, Officer Wind, was nearly killed by infuriated Anarchists.

" The conception of Aristotle, the father of modern science," said Prof. S. Blokmore in his lecture on "Limestones and Marbles" before the members of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday, "was that all things were divided into four elements, fire, earth, air, and water. He had an indistinct idea of a fifth element, a sort of ether.

Bitter complaint is heard from the medical profession regarding the severity of the unwritten law of professional etiquette. It is not that medical men are forbidden to advertise themselves; it is that they are constantly under suspicion of advertising themselves when they are really doing nothing of the sort.

The fourth annual convention of the Union of Societies for Ethical Culture of New-York, Philadelphia, Chicago, St. Louis, and London was resumed yesterday with a morning session at 10:30 o'clock at the Workingman's School, 109 West Fifty-fourth Street. William Stone presided, and the topic for discussion was "The Relation of the Ethical Societies to Political Reforms."

Admiral Luce declared at West Point a week ago that the cadets composing the football teams of Annapolis and West Point were his choice for officers when going into action. The Admiral inquired concerning the relative standing of the members of the two teams, and in almost the same breath added: "Never mind where they stand; those are the men I want in time of action.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The Irish envoys left here for New York at 5 o'clock this afternoon by the Michigan Central Railroad. A short time before their departure, Mr. Dillon, on behalf of himself and his fellow-envoys, made the following statement to an Associated Press reporter:

The bootblack in the County Court House appeared Friday morning at his usual hour for beginning work so changed that his oldest patrons hardly knew him. Tears had streaked his face, which had taken on a dusky hue through the practice of an absent-minded habit of wiping the back of his grimy hand across it after each shine and a general aversion to soap and water.

The depredations on the land of the nimble and ubiquitous sparrow find a counterpart in the sea in the porpoises. What the sparrow is to the gardener and the thrifty housewife the porpoise is to the fisherman.

The failure of the banking firm at Meadville, Penn., in which GEORGE W. DELAMATER, QUAY'S candidate for Governor in the late disastrous campaign in that State, is the principal figure, would not be a matter of special interest to the public but for the practice of QUAY and DELAMATER in mixing their politics and business to such an extent.

The Seventh Regiment Athletic Association is rapidly assuming a position in the athletic world equal to that which the Seventh Regiment itself occupies in the militia. The association held its eighteenth series of semi-annual games at the armory last evening. The competitors succeeded in lowering seven of the armory records and equaling one, and these records are such as any athletic association might be proud of.

The finals in the annual amateur boxing competition under the auspices of the West Side Athletic Club were held at Lenox Lyceum last night in the presence of about five hundred spectators. The officers were: Charles Coster, New-York Athletic Club, referee; Maxwell E. More and Dr. Guiteras, judges; William H. Struse, B. Williams, and M. Rush, weighers; R. Stoll and J.C. Spaith, timekeepers; Charles Harvey, announcer.

Some five months ago, in a cable dispatch from London to THE TIMES, the statement was made that a number of Mr. Parnell's Parliamentary colleagues were unable to account for his conduct upon any other theory than that of mental derangement. Public interest has been so absorbed by the recent spectacular series of catastrophes in Irish politics that it may be important briefly to recall the circumstances under which this statement was made.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- My messages have kept you informed throughout the week of the various vicissitudes of the great conflict which has been waged in Committee Room No. 15, at the guarded doors of which all the ears of Westminster have been ceaselessly straining. The matter is now settled, as it should have been settled a week ago.

The convention of the Farmers' Alliance adopted a platform on Friday, but it contained no reference to the "Sub-Treasury" scheme or to the advisability of undertaking a third-party movement. A declaration was, however, tacked upon it that no candidate for a national office shall receive the support of the Alliance unless he "indorses" its national platform in writing.
" New-York certainly has the prettiest children in the world!" exclaimed an enthusiastic. New-Yorker recently.

Adolpho Alves Maseira, a petty officer in the Brazilian Navy, yesterday morning cut down with a blow from a cutlass a seaman on board the man-of-war Aquidaban, now lying in the North River. The affair occurred shortly before 8 o'clock and in the presence of six Lieutenants of the flagship, who, to all appearances, entirely approved of the action taken.

The papers are publishing the politics opinions and reflections of one A.L. CONGER of Ohio. Col. CONGER says the people "misunderstood" the McKinley law, but the law "is a fixture for at least five years," and he is confident that everything will be satisfactory to the high-tariff men in 1892, when "the knotty points of the McKinley bill will have been unraveled by the people."

In October THE TIMES printed a dispatch from Chilton, Wis., concerning the discovery of pearl fields in that State. Later it published a brief interview with Mr. Kunz of Tiffany Co., in which that gentleman said that his firm had bought some of the pearls, and that they were remarkable for their beautiful colors. Some further facts concerning the Wisconsin pearls have come to light and will prove interesting.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Irvington was the quietest of the Newark suburbs to-day. A news store and a drug store were the only places of business that were opened. All the other business men had been directed to close, and there was a general compliance with the direction.

The young reformer is quite at the front in Massachusetts nowadays. One of his kind was lately elected Governor of the State and two or three were chosen as Representatives in the next Congress, and now another is candidate for Mayor of Boston, with almost certain assurance of being elected to-morrow. Whatever the political antecedents of the young reformer may have been, he is now constrained as a candidate to be of the Democratic faith.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Detective Gallagher of Camden has discovered the identity of the negro whose body was found in Johnson's Cemetery, and the county authorities are now convinced that the man was murdered, and have put both the county detectives on the case to search for the murderers. The body is supposed to be that of Isaiah Poke, who about two years ago worked on the farm of Henry Van Name at Moorestown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- It will be interesting to observe when the juncture has arrived at which the importance of attending to necessary legislation will lead the Senate to lay aside the Force bill as one that is abandoned from lack of time to perfect it rather than because it is a bad bill that ought not to pass.

DUBLIN, Dec. 7. -- A meeting of Nationalists was held to-day in Phoenix Park. The attendance was only moderate, owing to the bitterly cold weather. The Lord Mayor, who presided, moved a resolution that Mr. Parnell alone was fitted to lead the nation. He condemned the Healyites, whose independence and integrity, he said, had been sapped by English wire-pullers.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 7. -- The residents here were greatly surprised this morning to find copies of an Anarchist circular thrown into their yards or shoved under the doors of their houses. The pamphlet contains three columns of closely-printed matter, denouncing the authorities bitterly for prohibiting the Anarchist meetings and sending a couple of the lawbreakers to prison.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Col. A.J. Snider, a wealthy Kansas City cattleman, arrived in this city yesterday, and registered at the Grand Pacific Hotel. After a short conversation with some stock men, Col. Snider sent the follow message: A.B. Mayes, Chief Cherokee Nation, Tahlequah, Indian Territory:

A man in this vicinity who has an artificial trout pond recently took a friend to see his speckled beauties. To his horror he saw one of them floating on the top of the water dead Securing a boat he went out and found that the trout had tackled a red squirrel and been unable to master him, both of them having paid the penalty of fighting with their lives.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The conference of the McCarthy party was prolonged until after midnight last night, Mr. McCarthy presiding throughout the session. A committee consisting of Messrs. Murphy, Barry, Morrough, Healy, Sexton, and Power was appointed to draft a prospectus for a limited company, to establish a daily newspaper in Ireland, to be devoted to the interests of the Nationalist Party.

According to some of the business associates of Mr. Charles S. Higgins, the soap manufacturer, that gentleman's practical failure was caused by his heavy investments in articles which he expected to see advance materially in price under the influences of the McKinley bill. Others say that the tight-money market affected him, while others attribute his suspension to fierce rivalry in the trade.

It is not unnatural that the journals o Germany should resent the Emperor WILLIAM'S spiteful declaration that "journalists are high-school products run to seed." The tendency of an educated journalist to hesitation in accepting as indisputable every idea of the young ruler on any subject from political economy and foreign a policy to the proper costume for ladies and the cooking of dinners, is not necessarily the result of too much Latin and Greek.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- "The Washington girl" usually is not from Washington. The Washington society girl -- the girl typical of Washington social life -- is generally an exotic who has been transferred to this social hothouse from some far city and State. The mutations of political and official life bring debutantes from all portions of our continent, buds who bloom for a season and then drift away.

It is perhaps unavoidable, but it is certainly unfortunate, that the meetings of Congress are always, looked forward to with a good deal of uneasiness by business men who are in the habit of basing their calculations on large views of the situation. The unknown is, according to the proverb, magnificent, and it is apt in any case to be magnified, and nothing is more completely unknown than the action of Congress.

The Conference of Amateur Photographers in this city proved a success, and there is little doubt that the result will be of much benefit to the young photographers all over the country. Before the day of the convention terminated it was clearly evident that there is enough latent talent among amateurs and those scientifically inclined to complete an effective organization.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- During the past week discount was firm at 3 3/4 for three months and 3 1/4 for short. On the Stock Exchange business was dull. The recent rise was too rapid to last and has led to a reaction. Toward the close of the year there is a always a restriction of operations, but this year the movement has begun earlier and is more pronounced than usual.

The bronze tablet commemorative of the services held in St. Paul's chapel upon the one hundredth anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington was unveiled yesterday at the close of the regular morning services. There were no ceremonies connected with the unveiling, and there was no unusual attendance at the church except of such persons as had been connected in some way with the provision of the tablet.

The recent onslaught of Secretary NOBLE upon the pension attorneys at Washington seems to have aroused the ire of that prosperous fraternity. They propose not only to resent and to resist any effort to cut down the tribute paid to them by the pensioners of the Government, but to get the soldiers to join in their resentment and resistance.

MEADVILLE, Penn., Dec. 7. -- The failure of Delamater Co., bankers, is still on everybody's lips. The real extent of the disaster is becoming more apparent as the facts very slowly come to light. Every second man on the street carries a low chin. The effect of the failure upon business has been very depressing; all merchants and business men are complaining about the drop in trade.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 7. -- The Hon. Allen W. Thurman was called upon to-day for an expression of his views as to the effect the Farmers' Alliance would have upon the two dominant parties, now that it had touched upon political questions to an unexpected degree in the National Convention in Florida.

The Thirty-seventh Street Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been undergoing repairs, was reopened yesterday, and special services of an appropriate character were held, forenoon, afternoon, and evening. Popoular interest centred in the service of the afternoon, the feature of which was the dedication of the memorial windows, of which descriptions were given in THE TIMES of Saturday.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The annual harvest of poultry for the New-York and Boston markets is about over in this part of the State, and it has been a big one. Thousands of the finest and fattest turkeys in the land have already found their way from Northern New-York to the tables of people in the larger cities, and many more will get there during the coming holidays.

The Medico-Legal Society will hold its annual meeting Wednesday evening at the Hotel Buckingham at 8 o'clock. An election of officers for the coming year will be held and papers will be read by Dr. W.P. Spratling and Prof. John J. Elwell. The annual dinner of the society will be given at Delmonico's Friday evening. Dec. 19.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 7, via Galveston. -- An attempt has been made to assassinate Col. Carrascosa, the Governor of the State of Chiapas, at San Cristobal. The Governor, instead of being killed himself, shot the would-be assassin.

Home missions -- more particularly New-York city missions -- was the subject of Bishop Potter's sermon yesterday at All Souls' Church, Sixty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue. The church was very much crowded, and the music was especially fine. "The safety of the community in which you and I live," said the Bishop, "depends upon the homogeneity of the people, upon whose intelligence the foundations of our institutions rest.

A domestic misanthrope, Ernst Kettler, killed himself last night on the fourth floor of the flat house 303 East Seventy-sixth Street, after he had wounded his wife, Anna, and tried to kill either one of his children or a nephew. The tragedy was the culmination of years of intemperance. The wife is an Austrian of good family, and was reared in England.

The shaft to commemorate the landing of Leonard Calvert on the soil of Maryland, for which the Legislature of that State appropriated $2,000 last Summer, will stand on a small knoll near the old wharf at St. Mary's City. The mulberry tree under which, according to the legend, Calvert and his companions gathered was standing on this knoll until a few years ago.

We have published from time to time passages from the reports of well-known trade journals relating to the prices of goods, hoping that with these trustworthy and colorless statements before them certain prominent high-tariff newspapers would mend their ways. But they persist in their evil courses. Day after day they say that there is "no more talk about rising prices," and that the "vile Democratic conspiracy" to raise prices is no longer effective.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 7. -- The Bee has the following from its special correspondent:

To some of our high-tariff friends who are casting about for something new in the way of a policy we suggest that they take under consideration the expediency of openly supporting combinations in trade. It would at least relieve the high-tariff leaders of a heavy load of hypocrisy and inconsistency. From the beginning of public discussion as to the suppression of competition by Trusts and similar organizations they have fought at a disadvantage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the judgment of the Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York in the case of Clement A. Auffmordt and others, plaintiffs in error, against Edward L. Hedden, Collector of the Port of New-York.

The Commissioners of the State Reservation at Niagara met in this city yesterday at the office of Commissioner Green. Commissioner Bowers was the only absentee. The Treasurer presented his annual report, showing that his receipts, including balance on hand Oct. 1, 1889, amounted to $43,340.79, and that he had paid out $39,808.82. Bills to the amount of $4,053.71 were allowed, of which $1,241.75 was charged to permanent improvement ancl $2,81L96 to maintenance.

The announcement in Mr. HARRISON'S message that Congress will be asked to provide the means for participating in a prime meridian conference soon to be held possesses much interest. The invitation comes from the Government of Italy, which undertakes to manage all the preliminaries. Whether it has received any assurances or intimations that such a conference would meet with success does not yet appear.

The Presbytery of New-York, at its regular monthly meeting yesterday in the Scotch Presbyterian Church, the Rev. A.G. Harshaw, Moderator, presiding, voted to support the proposed overture sent down by the General Assembly providing that changes in the constitution of the Church, proposed in the General Assembly, might hereafter be made by a majority instead of a two-thirds vote of the Presbytery, as heretofore.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- All was peace to-day in Committee Room No. 15. The Nationalist majority met for further reorganization, but most of the proceedings were kept secret.

PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 8. -- Lieut. Gov. Fletcher, when asked regarding destitution among South Dakota farmers, said: "Yes, there is destitution in South Dakota, all reports to the contrary notwithstanding. And what is more, I can't see the wisdom of attempting to cover up these facts. And what is more, I can't see how by making these things publicly known anything but good can result.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Whether a new count of the population of New-York is recommended or refused by the Committee on the Eleventh Census the men from New-York, who have been presenting the case of the city, are returning tonight with the satisfaction of knowing that they have established by proof that Superintendent Porter has not been able to destroy their assertion that the Federal enumeration was a careless, incomplete, and unjust one.

Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan, in compliance with a request from several influential railroad men and capitalists, yesterday sent a telegraphic invitation to the Presidents of all railroads west of Chicago to meet at his house in Madison Avenue, this city, at 10:30 o'clock A.M. next Monday, for the purpose of discussing the situation.

The approach of Christmas is exerting a benevolent effect on the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge. At yesterday's monthly meeting they raised the salaries of the patrolmen, train conductors, and ticket choppers. The clerks, sweepers, and dispatchers are expecting to be cared for at the next meeting. Yesterday's wholesale elevation of wages aggregated about $25,000 per year.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 8. -- The next session of the General Assembly of Delaware will convene at Dover on Tuesday, Jan. 6 -- the "first Tuesday after the first Monday," the Constitution quaintly calls for, in order to avoid the possibility of being required to assemble on New Year's Day -- dud the patriots who aspire to the offices within the gift of the Legislature are anxiously awaiting the arrival of that date.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 8. -- Daniel B. Fayerweather's bequest of $300,000 to Yale University has elated the members of the Faculty, as the money is greatly needed at this time. Numerous improvements in the line of new buildings and the extension of various courses of study have rather crippled the college financially, and rigid economy would have soon become necessary but for the generosity of the New-York millionaire.

Four new Police Captains were appointed by the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday to fill vacancies, three of which have existed for some time, while the fourth was made by the recent retirement of Capt. Garland. The names of twelve Sergeants appeared on the eligible list sent to the Police Commissioners by the Civil Service Examining Board from which the selections were to be made.

There are now pending for consideration before the New-York Board of Customs Appraisers more than a hundred cases, in which the only question involved is the constitutional validity of the new Tariff act of Oct. 1, 1890, known as the McKinley tariff law.

The will of Daniel B. Fayerweather, the head of the firm of Fayerweather Ladew. leather merchants of this city, filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office for probate, contains public bequests amounting to over $2,000,000. There is, however, no danger of a contest, for Mrs. Fayerweather is perfectly in accord with her husband's disposition of his large estate, and she, with all the next of kin, signs the petition for the probate of the will.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Near Campbell Hall station, and about four miles from Goshen, lives John Lord, a well-to-do farmer. Up to Monday night of last week his family at home consisted of his wife, two young sons, and a daughter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Washington says: "There is very general denunciation of Senator Delamater among his political friends in this city. It is heard as yet only in smothered tones, but the fact can be no longer concealed that he has swindled his political and personal friends to the utmost of his opportunity.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 8. -- TO THE TIMES'S correspondent to-night Albert L. Johnson gave an outline of the method by which he hopes to thrust a thorn into the flesh of the League magnates.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 8. -- This was the day appointed for the drawing of the panels of struck jurors to try the Monmouth Park bookmakers. The lawyers in attendance entered vigorously into the contest. They were E.W. Arrowsmith, Judge Hoffman, who was prominent in the McDonald election case, and Frederick W. Parker.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8. -- The first of the series of contests for the Baird prizes in oratory, disputation, and poetry will take place on Wednesday evening. Music will be furnished by the Freshman Banjo Club. All members of the Senior Class are eligible, and between twenty and thirty men have signified their intention of contesting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- In the Special Term to-day Judge Rumsey vacated the stay of proceedings granted by Judge Mayham of Albany in the Noyes-Rockwell Congressional contest, and severely denounced the action of the latter magistrate in granting it. Counsel Thomas Raines moved for a postponement of the case in order to prepare his argument.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 8. -- A gentleman who has just returned from Washington, and who has long been a personal friend of the President, says that Harrison has never fully decided whether he will ask for a renomination, and it is now certain that his decision will depend upon the action of the present session of Congress.

Robert H. Silverman and Philip Trautwein, composing the firm of H.M. Silverman Co., dealers in hats, caps, and furs, at 12 East Eighteenth Street, made an assignment yesterday to John B. McGeorge, without preference. The business was established over thirty years ago by H.M. Silverman, who died in April, 1886.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 8. -- Charles Miller, the sixteen-year-old double murderer, the central figure of Cheyenne's celebrated box-car mystery, is on trial. Most of the evidence for the prosecution is in, and Miller will take the stand on his own behalf to-morrow.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8. -- A weird procession, such as was certainly never seen before in this city and probably not in any other city in the United States, took place between the hours of 2 and 5:30 o'clock this morning, the occasion being the celebration of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception by the Italians.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 8. -- The National Board of Trade met this afternoon in Parlor P, St. Charles Hotel. There were about seventy-five gentlemen present representing the Boards of Trade of Boston, Cincinnati, Buffalo, Indianapolis, Milwaukee, New-Orleans, Philadelphia, Portland, Oregon; Rochester, St. Louis, Scranton, Trenton, and New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 8. -- Efforts to secure a subsidy or guarantee fund for the New-Englander and Yale Review were made some months ago, it being proposed to secure subscriptions of $8,000 a year for three years. Assured of such support, it was declared, the New-Englander would be in a way to put itself on a firm basis.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- Gov. Hill has already begun to prepare his annual message, which will be submitted to the Legislature Jan. 6, 1891, and he does not find his task so congenial or so easy is his previous efforts.

The fifteenth annual report of the New-York Bible and Fruit Mission to our public hospitals was presented at a meeting of its officers in the mission house, 416 East Twenty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon. According to this report 256 young women, friendless and temporarily destitute, were given homes and employment during the year through the missionary, Miss Esther Gunderson.

DE LAND, Fla., Dec. 8. -- H.S. Thatcher of New-York, who has been cutting a wide swath here by giving forged checks on the Second National Bank of New-York, purporting to be signed by Charles N. Taintor, was arrested here yesterday. He arrived here in November and commenced having a good time, giving cheeks freely for his expenses.

DETROIT, Dec. 8. -- Some sixty delegates of the American Federation of Labor were assembled in Clawson's Hall this morning when President Gompers called the convention to order shortly, after 11 o'clock. The delegates were welcomed to the city by the President of the Board of Aldermen, in the absence of the Mayor, and President Gompers of the Federation responded for the delegates.

OCALA, Fla., Dec. 8. -- The National Farmers' Alliance assembled again this morning at 8:30. Early in the session the financial policy of the order came up for discussion under the report of the Committee on Legislation. This report as to the financial policy contained the following amended demands:

As we expectcc[, the controversy in the New-York Tribune's columns as to the cause of the recent and continuing depression of values in lho stock market has broken out agaim The editorial columns are again at war with the financial editor in his culumns.

The persons who throng the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Fifth Street, at the "authors' carnival," find bevies of pretty girls, handsome booths, and a general atmosphere of jollification and funmaking.

The State of Delaware's sons proved their devotion to the little Commonwealth by partaking of a bounteous repast at Delmonico's last evening and by thus launching fairly forth the Delaware Society which was organized last Spring. In spite of the diminutive proportions of their native State, there was no lack of Delawareans present.

Operagoers do not as a rule expect a very high degree of merit in translations of librettos, but I think we have some claims to protection against having palmed off on us so "literal" (not to put too fine a point on it) a translation as the one we are compelled to purchase at the Metropolitan Opera House as the "only correct and authorized" edition of the text book of "Asrael."

The Bar Association at its meeting last evening had a long discussion on the bills -- one of which has passed the House and the other the Senate -- making changes in the Federal judicial system. The matter was brought up by a report made by Prof. B.F. Lee, Chairman of a special committee appointed to consider the proposed establishment of a Federal Court of Appeals.

At last the consent of the Board of Aldermen has been given to the franchise for the construction of a tunnel whereby the Long Island Railroad may enter and cross the city from the depths of the East River. The struggle to get this franchise through the Board of Aldermen has been going on for three years and has been attended by many charges and suspicions of bribery.

Tokio was unusually quiet on Monday for an Emperor's birthday. The review of the troops in garrison, which generally constitutes the principal event of the day, had to be postponed on account of his Majesty's indisposition, and thus the city remained undisturbed until noon, when the boom of big guns rolled out from the saluting battery and the ships lying off Shinagawa.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9. -- There are now 800 of the 2,000 employes at the Clark Thread Works on the Passaic River out of employment, and three of the mills are closed. The idle employes are all men, but their inactivity will probably result, if the strike be continued, in throwing many hundreds of the female operators out of employment.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Nightingale Brothers Knight, silk manufacturers of this city, who failed recently, carrying with them Messrs. John T. Walker, Sons Co. of New-York, having failed to make a compromise with their creditors on the basis of 50 cents on the dollar, have made an assignment to ex-Judge John S. Barkalow of this city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -The Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua has filed with the Secretary of the Interior its annual report, covering the operations of the company during the year ended Dec. 1, 1890.

" Look at that," said a Sixth Avenue street car conductor as he settled back against the brake handle and held out a coin for the inspection of the passengers who were sharing the back platform with him. The coin was a five-cent piece, battered, worn, and bent. It was a ridiculous travesty of a nickel, and "counterfeit" seemed to stick out all over it.

Frederick Nauglo, the bookkeeper for Ransom Parker, Jr., who did business as the Commonwealth Ice Company, proved to Justice McMahon by his books in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon that the $116 he had obtained by indorsing a check payable to the company had been spent in paying the company's bills.

OGDEN, Utah, Dec. 9. -- About ten days ago the Union Pacific discharged three men from the night force of switchmen in the yard in this city. The result was a strike of the night men. Last Sunday a committee of the strikers visited General Manager Resseguie, but received no satisfaction, and yesterday the entire force of union and non-union men went out and not a wheel turned in the yards.

After a fight that had its beginning three years ago, the Board of Aldermen decided yesterday by the closest kind of a vote to grant the New York and Long Island Railroad Company a franchise under which it can construct a tunnel under Forty-second Street from river to river. The company's project includes the tunneling of the East River from Long Island City, thus connecting Long Island with the great Western trunk lines.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 9. -- The weather was cold and disagreeable here to-day, but the attendance at the sale of thoroughbreds was good and prices for well-bred and good individuals were very fair. The Nantura yearlings, thirteen in number, brought an average of $922, and the entire eighty-seven disposed of fetched $35,210, a grand average of $405. Details of the sales follow:

On Nov. 26, at the well-known London auction rooms of Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge, an interesting collection of the works of Charles Dickens, unpublished poems by Thackeray, Scotch books, , and a number of valuable autographs were sold. The London Times says the most notable lots were as follows:
HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 9. -- The steamer Miranda, which arrived this morning from St. John's, N.F., was saved from foundering on the voyage only by the use of oil. Capt. Leseman said:

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Dec. 9. -- Several weeks ago the Rev. Euclid B. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church in this city, was publicly vindicated from various serious charges preferred by persons in Franklin, Penn., where Mr. Rogers was pastor previous to his coming to Burlington. His vindication was telegraphed to Eastern newspapers, and finally reached the notice of the Franklin congregation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Gen. Grant's body will rest at Riverside, and, if reasonable diligence is shown in the construction of the monument that has been designed to mark his grave, it is probable that there will be a permanent suspension of the contemptuous references that have been made here ever since the death of the great soldier to the indifference of New-York to the responsibility it had assumed to care for his grave.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Senator Plumb to-day introduced, by request of William P. St. John, President of the Mercantile National Bank of New-York, a bill offered as an amendment, in the nature of a substitute, to Senator Sherman's bill to reduce the compulsory holding of bonds by national banks, The following is an abstract:

DUBLIN, Dec. 9. -- The priests on Achill Island have appealed to Mr. Balfour to aid 400 families who have been reduced to distress by the failure of the potato crop there. Owing to the lack of proper food they are compelled to eat diseased potatoes to keep from starvation.

Affectionate tributes to the memory of the lamented Charles Loring Brace were uttered last night by the lips of those who were his co-workers in his life-long philanthropic labors. A memorial meeting, under the direction of the Trustees of the Children's Aid Society, was held in the assembly room of the Newsboys' Lodging House, at the junction of William, Duane, and New Chambers Streets.

At the monthly meeting of the State Fish and Game Commission yesterday Commissioner William H. Bowman presided, President Eugene G. Blackford being confined to his bed with typhoid fever. The popular fish fancier has been dangerously ill, but yesterday was able to see one of his colleagues of the board, and his physician reported that the crisis was passed and Mr. Blackford was on the road to recovery.

A bill has been introduced into the House to appropriate $700,000 for the purchase of land and the erection of buildings for a military post at San Diego, in California. There is now a garrison at that place, consisting of a company of infantry, so that the present purpose is that of making it a more extensive military station.

The work of reorganizing what is left of the County Democracy was begun at a meeting of the County Committee held in the small meeting room of the Cooper Institute last night. Some of the old-time leaders were on hand to lend their aid to the effort, but some other old-timers were conspicuous by their absence.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 9. -- Balloting for a successor to Wade Hampton in the United States Senate began here to-day in the General Assembly. The issues generally stated are the Alliance against Senator Hampton. Last night a caucus of the General Assembly was held, at which two candidates, both members of the Alliance, were selected by the caucus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The President has approved the joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of War to issue 1,000 stand of arms to each of the States of North and South Dakota, Wyoming, Montana, and Nebraska.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 9. -- A morning paper says: "For some time a company composed of English and American capitalists known as the American Type Foundry Company has been negotiating for the purchase of all the type foundries in the United States. The fact became known yesterday through rumors of an attempted purchase of the type foundries in this city.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Concerning the report from Kansas City that English and American capitalists are endeavoring to purchase all the type foundries in the United States, T.H. Brewer, Treasurer of the Union Type Foundry of this city, said that he had heard nothing of such a syndicate. It was true, however, he said, that since the old Type Founders' Association had been, dissolved the business had been going to the dogs through disastrous competition.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 9. --The Federation of Labor assembled this morning at 9 o'clock.
