It was announced that the National Association of the Retail Clerks of the United States and the Waiters and Bartenders' Union had been organized. Among the resolutions submitted was one that each member of local, national, or international unions be assessed 10 cents per quarter to form a strike fund, from which all men on strike shall receive $2 a week.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- State Treasurer Boyer, in talking of the Delamater failure prior to his visit to Meadville, said: "I felt shaky about the Delamater deposit. It wasn't that I was afraid they were going to fail, but I didn't think it was wise to let them have the money without my bondsmen being fully protected.
The Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce has compiled a bit of personal statements of fruit growers, a few of which are given:

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 9. -- Eighteen months ago Halaway Wall married Miss Eva Haynes of Henrietta Mills, one of the most popular girls in the State, and belonging to one of the most widely-known families in the South. They moved West and lived together peaceably for eight or nine months, when domestic trouble caused them to part.
The Berlin correspondent of the London Economist said in his letter of Nov. 25:

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 9. -- Meyer Kleiner, a dry goods dealer who made a voluntary assignment two weeks ago, has been summoned to appear before the Probate Court next Monday for an examination under oath in regard to the disposal and condition of his property. Kleiner's liabilities are about $27,000.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 9. -- The press dispatches in relation to the destitution in Oklahoma did not tell half of the story of the suffering and want of the poor settlers in that cheerless region. Snow five inches deep covers the entire country, where hundreds of children are barefooted and only half clad. J.C. Strong, who lives near Kingfisher, came here to-day to solicit aid for his suffering neighbors.

There is matter enough for amusement and also for exasperation in the history of the Irish Parliamentary Party since the judgment against PARNELL was delivered, but the uppermost feeling, not only among the special friends of Ireland, but among all humane persons and believers in progress, must be one of profound melancholy.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Mr. Parnell started for Dublin this evening. A large crowd of Irishmen, residents of this city, had assembled at the railway station, and on the appearance of their leader cheered wildly. Mr. Parnell entered a car and from a window addressed his countrymen. He said:
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- On the motion to quash the indictment of the murderers of D.C. Hennessy, Judge Baker this morning delivered his opinion.

BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- Whitten, Burdett Young, clothing, in Winthrop Square, have made an assignment. Charles H. Allen, President of the Central National Bank, and Jonathan A. Lane of Allen, Lane Co. are the assignees.

What with fires and thefts, one of the most valuable items of the Nation's property, its timber, is fast disappearing, Seventy forest fires within a year in Yellowstone Park alone, making the most disastrous record in its history, give a clue to what is going on elsewhere, because there a Superintendent is stationed with a large force to prevent and to check fires.

The will of August Belmont, made June 24, 1889, with a codicil made Aug. 8, 1889, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday by Strong Cadwalader, and as all interested consented to its probate, the issuing of citations was waived, and it was at once probated. Mr. Belmont's partner, Waither Luttge, and his sons, Perry and August Belmont, qualified as executors.

The "Crucifix Carver of Ammergau" has been so popular that it has monopolized a large part of the stay of the Munich comedians. During this week, however, there is a chance to see at the Amberg Theatre Messrs. Hofpauer and Swoboda and the Misses Schonchen and Thaller in a series of plays intended to exhibit the habits and customs, the pleasures and trials, the loves and dislikes of Bavarian peasants and farm folk.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 9. -- After a fight in Council, which lasted from 3 P.M. till midnight, the report of the Railroad Committee giving the Baltimore and Ohio Company a route through the city which would come in conflict with the Wheeling Bridge and Terminal Company's belt line and union depot was turned down, and an ordinance, passed giving the Terminal Company the disputed route.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A report comes to-night from the Census Office that the Superintendent has taken steps to make a sort of recount of the enumeration already made of New-York City, and that the first thing done was the ordering on duty of the night force, which had been laid off because the work of the bureau had been so far completed that it was not necessary to work at night.
Sidney Dillon, President of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, who has removed the President's office from Boston to this city, yesterday issued the following order:

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- The National Board of Trade resumed its session at 10 o'clock this morning. After the transaction of routine business, James S. Stranahan of the New-York Chamber of Commerce and B.B. Waddill of the Helena (Ark) Chamber of Commerce were elected Vice Presidents.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The greater number of the most prominent members of both the Parnellite party and anti-Parnellite majority have now left London for Ireland, where exciting scenes are expected.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- To-day's deliberations of the American Sabbath Union have been sensational, saddening, and decisive. Together with the delegates sat very many of the clergy of the city.

Considerable comment was caused about Wall Street yesterday when it became known that the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company had issued a notice announcing that the practice of having its checks passed through the New-York Clearing House would be discontinued from and after the 1st of January, 1891.

We hope it has not escaped the attention of Mr. JOHN SHERMAN that the enactment of his so-called Anti-Trust law has greatly stimulated the Trust-making industry. Possibly this has not been overlooked by the high-tariff journals that pointed during the campaign to this law as proof that their party had "kept its pledges" and made ample provision for the overthrow of every "combine" in the land.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- When Dillon and O'Brien, the Irish envoys, were here all was happiness and harmony with the Irish Leaguers. It had been arranged among them that all the money raised should be sent by draft to Dr. Joseph E. Kenny, M.P., and Alfred Webb, M.P., the Treasurers of the Laud League funds. As is well known, the meetings in this city were very successful.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- A staff correspondent of the Philadelphia Times telegraphs from Meadville, Penn., as follows:

Ex-President Grover Cleveland and Mrs. Cleveland, with a party of friends, occupied a box at Daly's last night, and admired the wonderful performance of Ada Rehan and the rest of Mr. Daly's company in "The Last Word." This play is running well in line with the great Daly successes of the past. Special matinees are announced for Christmas and New Year's.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day rendered a decision in the matter of a complaint of the Commissioner and Overseer of Highways in the town of Dunkirk as to dangerous crossings over the tracks of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern, Western New-York and Pennsylvania, and New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroads where these railroads run through the town of Dunkirk.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- There was a notable gathering of autograph collectors, book lovers, and litterateurs in the auction room of Thomas Birch's Sons at 8 o'clock this evening, when Mr. S.V. Henkels, the noted book auctioneer, began the sale of the valuable collection of the effects of the great Washington and of his executor and nephew, Lawrence Lewis, and grand nephew, Lorenzo Lewis.

Senator SHERMAN tried yesterday to put the Vice President up to the trick of counting a quorum as present when it was not disclosed by the vote of the Senate. Mr. MORTON promptly rejected the bait and headed off what might have proved an exciting discussion upon the whole question of limiting debate by directing the roll-call to be proceeded with in accordance with the existing rules.

GUTHRIE, Dec. 10. -- To-day has been one of extraordinary liveliness in the Territorial Legislature. The women in a body visited the lower house, with a plea for woman suffrage. Their delegation consisted of some of the most prominent women of Oklahoma. They did good lobby work, as the consideration of the bill then pending was postponed.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The anti-Parnell members of the Irish Parliamentary party have issued their promised manifesto to the Irish people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Secretary Windom's action to-day indicates very plainly that he does not care to apply more than $8,000,000 of the surplus at present to the purchase of 4 per cont. bonds. The offerings to-day aggregated nearly $2,000,000, of which over $1,000,000 was at 123 12, the rate at which bonds were purchased yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- The different Irish organizations of this city are divided as to which of the two Irish Parliamentary parties should be the recipient of the funds raised here during the recent visit of the Irish envoys. Postmaster John Field is Treasurer of the fund, which amounts to nearly $13,000, which is deposited with Drexel Co.

The movement to establish more parks and playgrounds in this city for children received an impetus last night by the organization of a branch of the New-York Society for Parks and Playgrounds for Children, with Miss A.A. Chevallier as President. An earnest meeting of gentlemen and ladies interested in this project was held in Miss Chevallier's parlors, 574 Fifth Avenue, to discuss the best methods of arousing public sentiment.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 10. -- A dispatch was received here on Monday from Boston stating that the police of that city were anxious to ascertain the whereabouts of Marshall F. Gillon, alias A.C. Stewart, who is charged with fraudulently obtaining over $20,000 within the past year from Mrs. Mathias Mills, an aged widow of Needham, Mass.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10. -- A special to the Republic from Gainesville, Texas, says: A fatal duel took place last night in Paine's Valley, Indian Territory, between Senator Samuel Paul of the Chickasaw Legislature and his son, Joe Paul, in which Joe received a bullet wound in the back and one in the breast and the father received a dangerous wound in the thigh, made by a pistol ball fired by the son.
In response to Mr. Conway's letter in your paper of to-day it is necessary to say, briefly:

The annual meeting of the National Association of Trotting Horse Breeders was held yesterday afternoon in a parlor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel President H.W.T. Mali occupied the chair. J.C. Sibley, Franklin, Penn.; W.B. Dickerman, New-York; W.H. Wilson, Cynthiana, Ky.; S.A. Browne, Kalamazoo; S.H. Rundle, Danbury; Dr. J.W. Day, Waterloo, and C.E. Ford of New-York were among the prominent breeders present.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 10. -- The series of thoroughbred sales closed here to-day. The attendance was not so large as on former days, but the bidding was quite spirited, and $35,045 was realized for the sixty-three head sold, an average of $422 each.

QUEBEC, Canada, Dec. 10. -- A disgraceful scene was enacted in the Legislature to-day before the doors were opened. The Hon. Mr. Blanchet, leader of the opposition, reproached the Hon. Mr. Mercier, the Premier, the previous night in referring to a "round robin" drawn up by some of the members in 1888, asking that their indemnity be increased from $600 to $800 per annum.

An attractive wedding was solemnized in Grace Church, Broadway, near Eleventh Street, at 3 P.M. yesterday. Miss Margaret Helen Schieffelin, daughter of George R. Schieffelin, was married to Henry Graff Trevor, son of John B. Trevor of Yonkers, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington, assisted by the Rev. L.H. Schwab of St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, officiated.

There is strong evidence of a general onset upon Congress from different directions to secure some definite action regarding the currency. The opinion, of course, underlying this movement is that what the country needs is "more money," and that in some way the Government can and must furnish it.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Corporal Tanner made a brief stop in this city while on his way to Addison, where he filled a lecture engagement. In regard to whether President Harrison is seeking a renomination, Tanner said:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- To-night was the first time since her appearance in Philadelphia during her present engagement that Mrs. Kendal was anything like herself, so that those who saw her on Tuesday night, but more especially on Monday evening, saw only a woman acting who should have been in bed. All this time she has been under the doctor's treatment and hardly any nourishment but milk has passed her lips.

The Brazilian war ships Aquidaban and Guanabara, escorted by the United States cruiser Yorktown, left their anchorage in the North River at 1 P.M. yesterday. The three vessels proceeded in column down the North River, the Yorktown leading. It being slack high water, the war ships were able to regulate their speed by the engines alone.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 10. -- All the mills in the Clark thread works at Kearney and Newark shut down to-day, and 3,000 hands are out of employment. The lock-out is the outgrowth of the strike of the 120 spinners who went out last Thursday. Tuesday evening the employes of the works received order from their foreman to clean their machinery and tidy up their machines.

The Board of Electrical Control met in the Mayor's office yesterday with the intention of giving its consent to permitting the old Consolidated Subway Company to turn over its low tension, or telegraph and telephone subway, to the new Empire City Subway Company. A resolution granting this consent, with the necessary restrictions and reservations, was read by the Secretary.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 10. -- The one absorbing question in Kansas to-day is "Who will be the next United States Senator?" The Republicans confidently assert that they will re-elect Ingalls -- that is, some of them do, while others are fearful. The Alliance leaders, positive in their power, declare that no power on earth can return "the monster," they having the votes and the power to use those votes as they will.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 10. -- The National Board of Trade held its last sessions before adjourning sine die to-day. A resolution offered by Mr. Snow of New-York was adopted recommending the passage by the House of Representatives of the Shipping bill which has passed the Senate and is now pending before the House. The New-York Board of Trade and Transportation resolutions relative to United States Shipping Commissioners was laid over to the next annual session.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 10. -- A special from Clarksville, Tenn., says: "The Franklin Bank of this city suspended payment this morning. The failure was caused by the recent failure of Henry Seafert of New-York, a large tobacconist, with whom the Franklin Bank had been doing a large credit business. The Franklin Bank is a private bank; its capital stock is $50,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 10. -- A vigorous search is being made for John McClellan, the terror of the St. Lawrence tier of counties, on both sides of the river. This McClellan was recently traced to Alexandria, in Glengarry County, and various places on the track of the Canada Atlantic between Ottawa and the St. Lawrence, he generally keeping to the woods.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Wednesday, Dec. 10:

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The first contest among members of the present Senior Class for the Baird prizes in oratory and disputation was held in the old chapel this evening at 8 o'clock. These prizes, founded by Charles' O. Baird of New-York City, represent the income of $6,000, and are to be given to those members of the Senior Class who excel in oratory.

Edward H. Horner, a "banker" at 88 Wall Street, and also engaged in the embroidery business at 86 Walker Street, living at 124 East Eighty-fifth Street, was arrested yesterday at his "banking" office by Constable Werwick of Newtown, L.I., and taken to that village, where he was held in $500 bail by Justice Shappel for a hearing on Dec. 15 on the charge of obtaining money under false pretenses from Joseph Bernel.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 10. -- The wedding of Miss Fannie Nevis Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Thomas W. Johnson, to Mr. S. Powell Byrd, son of Richard C. Byrd of Virginia, took place to-day at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Graham officiated. The bride wore a traveling gown of blue, with hat to match, and carried a white German calf prayer book with a small bunch of white violets projecting from between the pages.

The first public concert of the Manuscript Society, given at Chickering Hall last evening, revealed the important fact that a new musical organization has come to life which has excellent reasons for existence and an abundance of vitality. The object of this society is to perform works by American composers which are still in manuscript, and limit has been set as to the kind of compositions to be given.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- Senator Quay arrived in this city to-day and personally took charge of the complications that have arisen out of the failure of Delamater Co. Here he met a host of other interested parties, by far the most important being V.M. Delamater, the cashier of the bankrupt firm and a brother of George Wallace Delamater.

The bill introduced in the Senate by Mr. PLUMB of Kansas, of which Mr. W.P. Sr. JOHN of this city is the author, is fully explained in another column. As an original plan of currency it would be impossible to approve of it. It involves views of the function of the Government and of the nature of "money" with which we cannot agree.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10. -- A.M. Hart of Sitka, Alaska, in the course of a long interview to-day at the Lindell Hotel, said he knew of several rivers in Alaska that were richer in gold deposits than the Feather River in California. In relating some of his own experiences he said:

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The Manufacturing Potters' Association, consisting of owners of potteries making sanitary ware in this city, Baltimore, and East Liverpool, held a meeting in this city on Tuesday and decided to reduce the wages of the operative pottery from 10 to 20 per cent, and as the pottery industry is a great one here, considerable excitement has been manifested as to whether the Potters' Union would order a strike or not.

TROY, N. Y., Dec. 10. -- The fight between Edward Murphy, Jr., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, and County Clerk Daniel E. Conway, the leader of the anti-Murphy faction, has assumed a new and interesting phase. Charges have been preferred to Gov. Hill accusing the County Clerk of misfeasance and malfeasance in office in converting to his own use public moneys.

There is one feature of the apportionment plan of Mr. FRANK of Missouri that deserves more consideration than it is likely to get from the majority leaders in Congress. It is the provision that each Congressional district shall not only be made up of "contiguous territory," but shall be so laid out that the opposite points on its boundaries shall be, as nearly as practicable, equally distant from the centre.

Mr. William P. St. John's bill, as introduced by Senator Plumb of Kansas, amends Senator Sherman's bill "to reduce the compulsory requirement of United States bonds by national banks," , by striking out all after the enacting clause and substituting the following:

Controller Theodore W. Myers and Tax Commissioner Michael Coleman worked long and hard yesterday in making a personal examination of the condition of the charity institutions on Blackwell's, Ward's, and Randall's Islands, and of Bellevue Hospital. This examination was prompted by the estimate of expense of the Department of Public Charities and Correction for the year 1891, and was made by Messrs.

The proposal of an enterprising association of cattle owners to buy for $10,000,000 the tract of land known as the Cherokee Outlet has been promptly followed by a "raise" of those figures to $20,000,000 from another association, which also professes to want it for grazing and speculation. This latter sum is to be paid in the proportion of $1,000,000 down and $19,000,000 within three months.

Two things were made evident yesterday about the experiments with Koch's lymph in New-York. In the first place, it was shown that there was rather more of the much-sought-for liquid in the city than anybody had supposed there was. In the second place, it was proved that the most freely-heralded tests are sometimes not the first to be made.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- A meeting of influential persons was held at the Guildhall to-day to consider the condition of the Jews in Russia and to take action to secure some alleviation of their distress.

Every precaution possible was taken to surround the formal opening of the Pulitzer Building last evening with large attractions of all sorts. A lack of precaution on the part of photographer who was given a point of vantage on top of the City Hall in order that the "largest flash-light picture ever taken" might be made, served to fill out the programme in an unexpected but remarkably successful manner.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Select Committee appointed to investigate certain charges against Gen. Raum, Commissioner of Pensions, met today.

The State Senate Committee on Finance met at the Hotel Metropole yesterday afternoon to consider what disposition should be made of the 121 acres of land on Ward's Island which belongs to the State and the control of which is now in the hands of the old State Board of Emigration Commissioners. Senator Sloane presided and the other Senators present were Saxton, Cantor, Jacobs, Sheard, and Erwin.

The assignee of the Chicago Safe and Lock Company, in which the missing millionaire, B.H. Campbell held a large interest, filed his inventory of the assets of the company yesterday, and the report was a surprise. It was represented at the time the assignee was appointed that the assets would amount to about $700,000. As it is, the total amount, including bills receivable, unfinished work in the factory, office furniture, , amounts to only $127,767.

The United Service Gazette, (British,) in its last issue, says: "Six 'young naval officers' from America are about to invade shipbuilding and marine engineering establishments in this country and in Europe, by order of the Secretary of the United States Navy, for a course of special instruction in naval architecture, preparatory to their appointment as assistant naval constructors.

It was announced yesterday that Reno Post, No. 44, G.A.R., had taken the initiative in what was announced to be a general appeal to President Harrison on the part of the New-York State Department of the Grand Army to "discipline" Collector Erhardt because he had not reappointed an old soldier, Thomas Martin, as engineer at the Barge Office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Mr. George was the only speaker on the Force bill in the Senate today, and, as has been the case with all the speakers, few of the Republican Senators remained in the chamber to hear him. Most of them were in the cloak rooms or committee rooms, earnestly talking over the situation, and trying to decide what they would do at the caucus to-night.

The results of the city elections in Boston for several years past shows the value of the separation of those contests from the general elections in which political considerations necessarily prevail. It is not certain but the Boston plan of having the city elections only a month after that at which State officers are chosen is a good one.

SWEET SPRINGS, Mo., Dec. 10. -- In 1778 Robert Edwards leased thirty-four acres of land situated in what is now the heart of New-York City, lying along both sides of Broadway, for a period of ninety-nine years. About the same time he placed a similar lease upon sixteen acres of land on which now stands Trinity Church. Edwards came from Wales. He was never married, and died about the commencement of the present century.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Mr. Parnell arrived at Kingstown at an early hour this morning. A bodyguard of 200 of his supporters, the Parnell Leadership Committee, and other deputations, who had traveled from Dublin on a special train, were on the pier to receive him. The deputations were headed by a band.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10. -- The Hon. Albert H. Walker of this city, who is now delivering a course of lectures on patent law at Cornell University, will be the Democratic leader in the Connecticut House of Representatives. The position will fall to him naturally, and the brunt of the battle in the House over the Governor's election will be his.
While the dishes clattered, the glasses clinked, and the busy cutlery rattled in the banquet hall of the Hotel Brunswick last night, enthusiastic Union College men sang,

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Mr. Gladstone upon arriving at Retford Station addressed a meeting of 2,000 persons. He said that he had anticipated that the Irish members of Parliament by their spontaneous action would settle the present difficulty in the Irish question. The continuance of Mr. Parnell in the leadership would be fatal to home rule in England, Scotland, and Wales.

Their are more signs of the weather noticed by hunters and fishermen than by any other class of persons who are out of doors a great deal, except the farmers. The examination of the game killed shows the hunter just what kind of a Winter is coming, while the trapper has simply to look at his fur-bearing specimens to tell the same thing.

The United States cruisers Philadelphia and Dolphin will start for the West Indies just as soon as it is possible to get the former vessel out of dry dock. This will be in the course of the coming week. After the departure of the above vessels all the ships of the North Atlantic squadron will be in southern waters.

The article in THE TIMES of Nov. 25 on ring rule in New-Rochelle excited much interest in that place, but affairs still go on in much the same sleepy fashion among the authorities, whose duty it is and who have the power to put a summary end to much of the breaking of the law.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- There was great excitement in this village this morning when the news was circulated that ex-Senator Frank Benedict Arnold had committed suicide at his home, in Unadilla, by shooting himself. The story of the deed, briefly told, is as follows:
BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- H.W. Greene of Hopkinton, N.H., makes this sharp reply to Senator Chandler's recent letter in the Concord Monitor charging a deal between the Democrats and certain Republicans:

I have heard of a woman who was very unhappy because directly in front of her work table there was a disfiguring crack in the wall. As she sat at her sewing her eyes would be drawn to the opening, which each day grew to her gaze larger and more exasperating. She had tried patching it, but she fancied that it looked ten times worse for her pains.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 11. -- The Iowa State Grange continued its session to-day. The committee on co-operative work reported a plan recommending that the Executive Committee of the Grange and the Farmers' Alliance confer, with a view of establishing a general supply house for the members of both orders, to contain everything needed for farmers, they which may get for cost and expense of transportation and delivery.

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down an opinion which ought to be interesting reading to New-Yorkers who have long been deprived of their rights to the sidewalks by merchants who seem to think that sidewalks are laid out especially for their use a stands for trucks and teams.

A large number of people in the Surrogate's Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, when the matter of the appointment of administrators for the estate of Loring A. Robertson came up, wore treated to a genuine surprise when an alleges widow of the deceased millionaire turned up and demanded that she be made the administratrix of the estate.

The Municipal Consolidation Inquiry Commission met yesterday noon at the office of the President, Mr. Andrew H. Green, 214, Broadway. All of the Commissioners except Mr. Catheart of this city and Mr. Greenfield of Richmond County were present. The Secretary informed the commission that a Commissioner had been appointed for Westchester and that he would probably be present at the next meeting.

Nicolas-Alexandrovitch, Czarowitch. Grand Duke hereditary, Ottoman of all the Cossacks, accompanied by his brother, George-Alexandrovitch, Grand Duke of the Russian Empire, is timed to arrive in New-York during the early Spring. The royal party is traveling toward the East by way of India. The route comprises Hong-Kong, Yokohoma, Tokio, and San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Court of Claims has given judgment in the celebrated case of the Berdan Firearms Manufacturing Company of New-York against the United States. This is a suit to recover about $400,000 for the use of plaintiff's patent in the manufacture of Springfield guns used by the Government. It has been pending for over twenty years, and has excited general interest.

The Irish envoys were extremely busy at the Hoffman House yesterday. They had decided to issue another manifesto "for the general information of all our friends," as Mr. O'Brien expressed it, and in consequence they were invisible to callers until late in the day. At 7 o'clock the following statement, signed by Messrs. Dillon, O'Brien, O'Connor, Sullivan, and Gill, was given to the press:

CORK, Dec. 11. -- At a meeting held here last night, over which the High Sheriff presided, a Parliamentary committee was appointed to oppose Mr. Parnell. The Chairman said he hoped hat the division in the Irish party would be brief, and announced that twenty-one Nationalist members of the Cork Municipal Council were opposed to Mr. Parnell's remaining at the head of the party.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 11. -- A great stir was made to-day in the circles of the Tillman administration, and in the State wherever it was telegraphed by the announcement that Attorney General Pope was arrested for violation of the statutes of his own State.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, Dr. Webb, C.F. Cox, and H.B. Ledyard arrived in the city last night after a tour of inspection of the Vanderbilt system of roads.

One of the liveliest business institutions in this city in these days is the Teachers' Bazaar in the Lenox Lyceum. The full-dress formalities attending the opening night, when teachers, booths, committee, and exhibit were by tacit understanding on dress parade, and people were not urged to purchase, disappeared with the opening night. Yesterday the bazaar had settled down.

It is significant of what Mr. HARRISON may be expected to do by his own party friends that it is currently reported in Washington that he is about to call Mr. CLARKSON, ex-Executioner of Fourth-Class Postmasters, to the Cabinet, vice NOBLE, made Attorney General, vice MILLLER, made Justice of the Supreme Court.
The Drawing-Room Club held a reunion reception at their clubrooms, 501 Fifth Avenue, last evening from 8:30 until 10 o'clock.

Judge Gresham, sitting in the United States District Court in Chicago, yesterday handed down his long-looked-for decision in the Counselman and Peasley habeas-corpus inter-State commerce cases, and in his ruling really passed upon the validity of the law itself. He denied the writ of habeas corpus in both cases and remanded both petitioners to the custody of the Marshal, where they were before their petitions were filed.

DUBLIN, Dec. 11. -- The large and enthusiastic meeting held in the rotunda last night and the speech then made by Mr. Parnell has already had the effect of influencing public opinion in favor of Mr. Parnell throughout Ireland, and the number of his adherents is growing rapidly. His supporter in Limerick are making preparations for great popular display in his honor upon his arrival there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Mr. Aldrich is not making very satisfactory progress in the canvass of Republican Senators directed by the caucus last night, in order to find out what sort of a rule to limit debate, if any, can be put through the Senate. He finds many of the Senators decidedly shy about committing themselves to anything likely to affect the chances of the Force bill one way or the other.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11, -- Prices were kept flying higher by book lovers and autograph collectors this afternoon and evening at the sale of the great collection of Washingtoniana. The attendance was almost as large as the previous evening and the bidding was most generous. Never before have such prices been received for relics of our first President.

A poorly-cooked breakfast or some other equally unpleasant thing had evidently ruffied the temper of Judge Charles H. Truax of the Superior Court yesterday morning. Judge Truax has never been noted for pleasant manners on the bench, but yesterday he fairly exceeded himself, and insisted on making a ruling such as it is doubtful if any other Judge in the County Court House could have been found willing to make.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 11. -- A year ago James Kelly, a British subject, was convicted in the District Court at Houston of theft and burglary, and on both counts was given eight years in the penitentiary. The British Consul resident at Galveston, W.T. Lyall, interested himself in Kelly's behalf and by letter begged Executive clemency of Gov. Ross, going so far as to ask for an unconditional pardon.

PEMBINA, N.D., Dec. 11. -- Senator Pierce, Congressman Hansbrough, and Colonel Ball of Fargo are the three leading candidates in the Senatorial contest in this State, but the fight promises to give birth to more competitors. Politicians here, for the most part, admit that John Lamoure, whose home is in this city, will have more to say and do on this question when the Legislature meets than any other individual in North Dakota.

At a meeting of the Actuarial Society, composed of actuaries of the leading life insurance companies in the country, held in the Senate Chamber of the Capitol in Hartford, Conn., in October, Sheppard Homans, President of the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society of this city, read a paper dealing with that class of risks called by insurance people "unsafe."

William Hamilton Gibson, the writer and artist, has just accepted charge of the Department of Illustration and Design in the New-York Institute for Artist-Artisans, in West Twenty-third Street. The institute has received several marked demonstrations of the approval in which it is held by men who are interested in the development of the industries of the country upon the lines of art, beauty, and usefulness.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Curtis G. Stoddard of New-York was arrested this afternoon on a warrant charging him with having embezzled bonds and stock of the Chicago and Arkansas Construction Company to the amount of $2,200,000, The warrant was sworn out by F.B. Modica, Secretary of the company, and Constable McInerny took the prisoner before Justice Prindiville, who released him on $6,000 bail.

Another hospital was added yesterday to the list of institutions in this city in which the Koch lymph is being tested in the treatment of various forms of tuberculosis. This was the German Hospital at Park Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, and there the operations were conducted by Dr. Jacobi, who also has had charge of the inoculations at Mount Sinai.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- One of the important inquiries that is being made by the Census Bureau is in regard to the statistics of religious bodies in this country, and a preliminary bulletin will be issued in a few days by the census office.

Henry Siebert, tobacco commission merchant at 76 and 78 Broad Street, has suspended. The first intimation the trade or his intimate friends received of any trouble was a dispatch from Clarksville, Tenn., saying that the Franklin Bank of that city had suspended on account of the failure of Mr. Siebert.

The monthly exhibition in the gallery of the Union League Club, which will remain open until Sunday, consists of illuminated books and manuscripts and a number of paintings by old masters, together with a number of canvases by modern hands. One of the glass cases is filled with rare illuminated volumes belonging to Mr. Brayton Ives.

One of the level-headed men of the Valuation Commission now in session at the State House in Augusta is Capt. David H. Ingraham of Rockland. Every one who knows the Captain has noticed that he almost invariably wears a silk hat. He was in business in Boston many years, and one day a young man entered his office and wanted to borrow $500 to buy out a small hat store.

It is announced from Washington that in a few days the Census Bureau will issue a preliminary bulletin giving the statistics of religious bodies in the United States. Of these it is announced that there are 140, "besides many independent congregations." Among the "bodies" as to which information is to be contained in the preliminary bulletin are the "Life and Advent Union," the "General-Six-Principle Baptists," the "Schwerkfeldians," and the "Theosophical Society."

Alfred Lister, a prominent citizen of Newark, sailed for the island of Hayti on the steamer Adirondack of the Atlas Line two weeks ago. He undertook the voyage in search of health, and he was accompanied by his physician, Dr. Cooper of Westfield, N.J. Yesterday it was announced that Mr. Lister was dead, and it is probable that he committed suicide.

Bradstreet's reports 341 failures in the United States in the course of the week, against 321 in the preceding week, and 370, 309, 253, and 292 in the corresponding weeks of 1889, 1888, 1887, and 1886, respectively. The Middle States had 72, New-England 34, Southern 76, Western 89, Northwestern 45, Pacific 23, Territories 2. Canada had 40, an increase of 13 over the previous week.

The degree of reliance placed upon Indian scouts during the present troubles at the West is sufficiently shown by the large increase made in their number. In some instances the recruiting seems to have been done among the Indian reservation police; and this in turn is a tribute to the fidelity of these employes. The reservation police are an armed constabulary who protect the agent and the Government's property, keep order, and arrest the unruly.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -- No freight trains were run on the Northampton Division of the Consolidated Railroad to-day because the brakemen of that division were out on a strike for shorter working days or pay for all the time they put in over ten hours a day. The strike was secretly planned, and was carried into effect without giving any notice to the company of the existing grievances or intended action.

The Brooklyn Bridge cable was stopped in the middle of the day yesterday to repair a weak strand, and the engines were put on to draw the trains to and fro. Over in the warm offices of the Bridge Trustees, in Washington Street, Brooklyn, it was said that the stoppage of the cable was for only forty minutes and that nobody was inconvenienced.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The exhibition which is to be held in Chicago in 1893 will be not so much a World's Fair as it will be a display of the peculiar ability of James G. Blaine to manipulate passing events for his own aggrandizement, unless some power greater than his steps in to prevent him from getting full control of the machinery of what is grandiosely termed the "World's Columbian Exposition."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 12. -- Some decidedly interesting revelations have just been made concerning the assassination of John M. Clayton, brother of Powell Clayton, at Plummerville. The Pinkertons sent Arthur Wood to Arkansas to work up the case. Wood died a few days ago in Chicago. From the Pinkertons now comes the revelation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 12. -- The Tribune's special from Pierre, S.D., says: "White Swan, head chief of the Minnekanju tribe of Sioux at Cheyenne Agency, came to this city to-day to secure counsel from the Government authorities as to the best way to disarm Big Foot's band of Cherry Creek hostiles, stating that his entire tribe. 900 strong, were ready to assist.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Senator Quay, who has been in consultation with the local Republican leaders for the past two days, had an hour's chat this morning with Chairman Andrews of the Republican State Committee relative to the organization of the party. The junior Senator, while accepting the defeat of his party as the result of the late State fight, is anxious to have the lines of battle, wherever weak, strengthened for future contests.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment began the work of arranging the final estimates for 1891 yesterday. A large number of city officials and politicians were present. Cyrus Clark, President of the West Side Taxpayers' Association, asked the board for an appropriation of $200,000 to build a retaining wall in Riverside Park north of Ninety-eighth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- About 3 o'clock this afternoon the same party of bibliophiles who for the last two days have been doing some rapid buying at the auction rooms of Thomas Birch's sons turned up again. Before the sale considerable excitement was manifested among them, as the first item on the catalogue was the celebrated letter of Washington written to Major Gen. Henry Lee regarding Arnold's treason.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- George F. Work, who was the master mind of the Work-MacFarlane-Pfeiffer-Dungan syndicate, which, it is alleged, wrecked the Bank of America and the American Life Insurance Company, was arrested on Thursday night on a warrant sworn out by District Attorney Graham, and at the hearing to-day, in default of $20,000 bail, was committed to Moyamensing Prison.

The report submitted by the three Commissioners who have undertaken to revise the building laws of the city of Boston is one that will be studied in many other cities, and it deserves the careful attention of all who are interested in legislation designed to prevent the destruction of property in large towns by fire and to promote the safety of tenants.

KINGSTON, Dec. 12. -- If action taken by a committee appointed by the bonded and non-bonded towns of Ulster County is ratified by the Common Council of this city, the sum of $92,250.29 will be raised on county bonds and refunded to those towns that are bonded in aid of railroads, to be used in paying interest and principal on the bonds. This is money which was diverted for county purposes.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 12. -- The bay yearling filly, Bridal Bell, by Bell Boy, 2:19 12, dam Trosseau, 2:28, by Nutwood, has been sold by Patterson Brothers of Lexington, Ky., to M.D. Petterson of Davenport, Iowa, for $5,000. The roan colt, two years old, by Eagle Bird, 2:21, dam Trosseau, has been sold by the same breeders to the same buyer, for $1,000.

Housewives are making a general complaint that the prices of fruit preserves, jellies, and canned fruits are higher now than they have been for many years. Inquiry at one of the leading wholesale grocery establishments of the city discloses the cause of this to be the failure of the fruit crop last season. The advance in prices of many kinds of preserves and canned fruits is remarkably large

It seemed but a day or two ago that the forcible appeals made by the opponents of PARNELL in the Irish Parliamentary Party to the sober second thought of the Irish people would not come to anything. There are not lacking those who maintain that such appeals are necessarily futile, because the thought of the Irish people is rarely sober and never second.

It is evident that the Republicans in the United States Senate have put themselves in a very awkward position, and are anxiously casting about for some way out of the predicament. They could easily have kept out of it, if they had given heed to the emphatic expression of popular sentiment at the November elections and allowed the Force bill to rest where it was.

The surveyors in the employ of the New-York Central Railroad have reached the village of Holland Patent, in this State, in their work of laying out the new line to Clayton. The new road will parallel the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg as it passes through Holland Patent. The work of surveying is proceeding slowly, partly because of the snow and partly because the men engaged in the work are not familiar with the country.

After the second day of the long-looked-forward-to midwinter meeting of the Staten Island Athletic Club at Madison Square Garden, the event must be recorded as a failure. This is primarily due to the fact that too much was attempted. The management made a great mistake in trying to combine track and light field athletics and heavy field games, such as football and lacrosse, in a single programme.

DUBLIN, Dec. 12. -- It coming to the knowledge of Mr. Leamy, who was appointed editor of United Ireland by Mr. Parnell, and other Parnellites that an anti-Parnell edition of the paper would be issued to-day from the office of the Nation, T.D. Sullivan's paper, steps were taken to secure an injunction against the Nation's publisher. The court granted the writ prayed for, restraining the publisher of the Nation from issuing the edition in question.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- Sumptuous bindings, illuminated manuscripts, engravings, historical miniatures, original drawings and water colors, were the attractions that served to draw a small but select company of buyers to the auction rooms of C.F. Libbie Co. to-day. A large part of this collection is from the library of the late Horatio Greenough, sculptor. The whole collection is a remarkable one, owing to the antiquity and rarity of many of the volumes.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Dec. 12. -- A hot and bitter fight is going on here and at Washington over the appointment of a Collector of this port, to succeed Mr. A.J. Pennypacker, who died a few months ago. When Mr. Pennypacker died many white Republicans in this city desired the appointment, to wit: D.L. Russell, W.H. Chadbourn, G.Z. French, F.W. Foster. C.P. Lockey, L.E. Rice, and S.H. Manning.

Since the extension of the Ninth Avenue elevated railroad train service to One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street there have been complaints from Harlem residents of long delays in reaching home between the hours of 5 o'clock and 8 o'clock at night. Under the old arrangement the Ninth Avenue trains went no further north than Fifty-ninth Street, and passengers were there transferred to the Sixth Avenue trains.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The Pall Mall Gazette today urges the members of the McCarthy section of the Irish Nationalists to take off their coats and fight the Parnellites.

The statement that Italy has received a set-back from England and even from Germany in her contemplated occupation of Tripoli recalls the recent designs upon the same country which were attributed to France. Those earlier reports caused an inquiry to be made by M. DEROULEDE in the Chamber of Deputies and a repudiation of any such purposes by the Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. RIBOT.

The Reapportionment bill favorably treated by the Ceases Committee of the House has one very evident fault to the support of which the Democratic members of the committee prudently refrained from committing themselves. It increases by thirty the membership of the House. There is not a member of that body who does not know that even now it is too numerous for any purpose of a legislative body.

The passage of the bill in the Reichstag for fortifying Heligoland will no doubt soon be followed by much activity in the little island. It has been treated with great consideration and favor ever since its acquisition, and as a sort of pet possession. It is expected, indeed, to serve a great variety of purposes besides that of an ocean outpost.

In order to make room for the new baseball nines that are to form the Eastern circuit of the American Association, President Thurman held a conference with George K. Frazer of the Syracuse team yesterday. Syracuse is one of the cities that will have to retire in order to make room for the proposed Boston Club. After the conference Mr. Frazer was anything but pleased with the result.

The chief event of the week among the gunners has been the disappearance of the ducks from the Great South Bay, where they usually remain till thick ice forms, and nearly all over the bay. Of course, not every duck has left for more sunny climes, but all the varieties that the sportsmen care for and those that are worth shooting, from a culinary point of view, have departed.

The pedestrians who have for years been suffering from the monopoly of the sidewalks in the lower part of the city by the large business houses who happen to need the public highway for storage and other purposes were overjoyed yesterday morning at reading of the decision by Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court in relation to this subject.

In looking over a copy of your paper, dated Nov. 30, I observe an item in reference to the Prison Association of New-York. I would like to tell you and your readers what that association has done for me. Last August I came out of the Kings County Penitentiary without a cent, after serving ten months. Owing to physical infirmity, (being lame,) on leaving that institution I asked for 5 cents for car fare.

" I can do any example in fractions, uncle," said Alan the other evening as he experimented with the cat to see if he could hold that patient animal near enough to the grate fire so that its hair would shrivel without any marked protest from pussy.

THE RUSSIAN THIRST. -- There is no outlet for Russia in the North to open water, the natural Atlantic harbor of the arctic provinces, Hammerfest, where the water never freezes, being still in Swedish hands, and on the South the Turk, though incompetent to rule his own dominions, and only propped on his tottering throne by foreign support, still holds the Russian gateway with a bared sword.

Prof. A.S. Bickmore concluded his course of lectures at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon. He will give two extra lectures, however, on Christmas and New Year's Days at 3:30 P.M. These extra lectures are free and do not require even the presentation of a card of admission. Any adult will be welcomed, but no children will be admitted.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The ice yachtsmen of the North Shrewsbury River are busily engaged in preparing their craft for the Winter's sport. Most of the club yachts are stored in the clubhouse, and these are being overhauled. Some are having new runner planks made, others will be titted with new keels and runners, while a large number of the yachts will sail with new canvas.

A SPANISH CALIFORNIA WEDDING. -- Nothing was more attractive than the wedding cavalcade on its way from the bride's house to the mission church. The horses were more richly caparisoned than for any other ceremony, and the bride's nearest relative or family representative carried her before him, she sitting on the saddle with her white satin shoe in a loop of golden or silver braid, while he sat on the bearskin-covered anquera behind.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 13. -- In the case of Thomas Duffy, charged with shooting Antonio Scaffidi, one of the alleged Hennessy assassins, his counsel in the Criminal Court this morning filed a motion to the effect that at the time of the commission of the offense the accused was suffering from homicidal insanity, and requesting that a committee of medical experts be appointed to examine into his mental condition.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 13. -- Natural gas was struck on the Exposition Society's grounds, in the First Ward, this morning. This means that Pittsburg may be situated immediately over an immense pocket of the valuable fuel. Other wells will be sunk within the city limits. Nothing has excited such general interest since the first strike of years ago.

Some excitement has been created in the village of Rockaway Beach, L.I., by the finding of a skeleton on the moor, near Rockaway Point, supposed by some to be that of S.S. Conant, the editor of Harper's Weekly, who disappeared in January, 1885, and has not been heard of since.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 13. -- The postponement of the opening of the Hotel Lakewood from Dec. 22 to Dec. 31 has been announced. The delay is not surprising. Work on a hotel designed to accommodate 800 guests comfortably and 1,000 when necessary naturally drags a little when approaching completion. But Superintendent Eizner and Col. Clements, who is to be the manager, are hard at work, and their combined efforts are having a visible effect.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The proposition of the State Fish Commission to stock the waters of Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River with muskallonge and other well-known varieties of game and food fishes is something in which all Northern New-Yorkers are deeply interested. All are pleased that these waters are to receive due attention.
The phagocyte is the enemy of the bacillus. The future of preventive medicine lies in the education of the phagocyte. So says Prof. RAY LANKESTER.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The Reichstag has adjourned for the Christmas recess. It will resume its sittings Jan. 12. Its debates, like those of the Landtag, are losing their bitterness and keen enmity toward the Government which were wont to characterize them during the Bismarck regime.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- The swallows have gone, but old Winter has not yet struck the three solemn raps for the ice curtain to rise on the frosty landscape where the golden wheat takes its, long shivering sleep. The leaves have all fallen, and they were even glad to go and get rid of the wet dripping of the constant rain.

Very many people familiar with the book-publishing business will recognize the force of what Mr. Moncure D. Conway says in his communication published in your columns this morning. A careful study of the provisions at the new Copyright bill shows that solicitude for justice to the lean and hungry author is to a great extent secondary to a regard for the fat and prosperous publisher.

At the present juncture, when, after so long a delay, an international copyright law seems likely to be enacted, it may not be deemed inopportune to recall the efforts made in its behalf some half century ago, when Henry Clay strenuously urged its claims, in which Washington Irving, Bancroft, Bryant, Longfellow, and most of the leaders of thought of that day co-operated.

OTTAWA, Dec 13. -- The Hon. Charles H. Tupper, Minister of Marine and Fisheries, is engaged in the election campaign in South Victoria County. He made an important speech at Napanee last night regarding the questions at present in dispute between Canada and the United States. He said the three questions that stand out to-day were Canada's attitude in regard to the Behring Sea, our treaty rights and commercial independence, and British connection.

As animated and interesting a spectacle as the city affords this week is the big Teachers' Bazaar in the Lenox Lyceum. Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. Yesterday was its fourth day and the attendance was larger than on any previous day. During the afternoon the visiting crowd consisted lagely of school children and their parents, who had come especially to inspect the imposing display of schoolroom and manual-training work.

How far the craze for "sensationalism" has gone in the race of certain papers to dish up "spicy" news for their patrons is shown by a "personal" which appeared in a New-York newspaper a few days ago. "Journalist," said this advertisement, "will pay cash for exclusive sensational news.

Another queer marriage, and even queerer comments, upon it, show what very hard work is made of what is, or at least is meant to be, the very simplest of all simple things. The intent of the laws of New-York is that no honest man or woman who means to marry shall miss doing so by informality. All other contracts are hedged about with precautions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- While the Republican Senators are trying to hit upon some sort of relief for the present unsatisfactory condition of affairs in the financial world to which the majority can give its support, Secretary of the Treasury Windom is consulting with bankers in New-York and the other members of the Cabinet are conferring with the President.

Secret Service Agent Harris returned to this city late Thursday evening, after an absence of about two weeks in Washington and Oregon, where he had been sent by the Treasury Department to look after a gang of counterfeiters who were flooding that part of the country with bad paper money. Mr. Harris was in Portland for several days locating the counterfeiters, who were raising five-dollar national bank bills to $20.

The cashier of a Woodward Avenue store had business at one of the banks the other day, but before he could transact it the teller gruffly informed him that he must be identified. "I've been with Blank Blank for five years," he replied, "Makes no difference." "There's my card." "Have to bring someone who knows you, Sir." It was done.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 13. -- In its issue of to-morrow the Times-Union will publish the following:

A pleasant social reunion was enjoyed by the Hon. Ashbel P. Fitch's Harlem friends last night. Around a beautifully-decorated table in Delmonico's half a hundred gentlemen sat in an atmosphere of geniality and enthusiasm and told each other of the respect and admiration that they felt for their Congressman.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 13. -- The situation in connection with the shoemakers' lockout grows more discouraging each day. When the State Board of Arbitration closed its investigation yesterday it recommended that each side appoint a conference committee to come together and endeavor to settle the points in dispute.

Notice is given by Capt. Fred L. Holmes, Corresponding Secretary, that the thirteenth annual convention of the National Guard Association of the State of New-York will be held in Albany Wednesday, Jan. 21, 1891, at 10 o'clock in the forenoon. The place of meeting has not been fixed, but it is hoped the sessions may be held in the new State Arsenal recently completed as an armory for the Tenth Battalion.

John M. Toucey, General Manager of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, New-York, writes us the following letter: "I was interested in your account of D.B. Fayerweather. As you did not mention an incident in his life which is an interesting one, and one, perhaps, you are not cognizant of, I take the liberty of giving it to you.

THE BIRD. -- A bird is one of the most wonderfully organized of all animals, and almost the whole of its organization is arranged to facilitate flight. The flights some birds will take, moreover, are extraordinary phenomena in themselves. A falcon belonging to Henry IV. of France is known to have flown from Fountainebleau to Malta, a distance of 1,350 miles, in one day.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Dec. 13. -- While on a fishing grip three miles out to sea from Boston Harbor last June W.J. Bogert of Westfield put his card, with the cards of other members of the party and the written request that the finder should communicate with him, into a bottle, which he scaled securely and threw overboard. To-day he received a letter, postmarked Halifax, N.S., Nov. 28, 1890, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- With the apparent certainty that the Force bill will be put out of the way in a very few days and left to die the death it so richly deserves, interest in the debate upon that measure in the Senate is growing less and less.
VANSEBURG, Ky., Dec. 13. -- For the murder of four negroes in August, 1868, John Blyew was to-day found guilty and sentenced to the penitentiary for life.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13. -- Considered from the standpoint of the society of most of the larger cities, and even of some of the smaller ones, society here would scarcely ever deserve to be termed gay, and even the fact that Lent will arrive this season early in February, and that an entertaining must therefore cease much sooner than commonly, has not thus far materially increased the amount of festivity.

One interesting feature of Mr. Fayerweather's will is that he has not fettered his benevolences with conditions that limit their efficiency. He has not prescribed ways or means of using his benefactions, but rightly leaves to the institutions which he has remembered the determination of the manner in which the gifts shall be employed.

SIR WALTER SCOTT'S LOVE FOR ANIMALS. -- Scott's horse, Brown Adam, was perfectly quiet with his master, but would not allow any one else to mount him, and broke the arm of one groom and the leg of another when they tried to do so. "Camp was at this time the constant parlor dog. He was very handsome, very intelligent, and naturally very fierce, but gentle as a lamb among the children.

Probably no man who has read of the munificent offers for the Cherokee Strip made by Col. "Andy" Snider of Kansas City and M.W. Levy of Wichita has enjoyed the joke more than Major John F. Lyons, now of California, but formerly attorney for the Cherokee Strip Live Stock Association.

TO SHAVE OR NOT TO SHAVE. -- For many years before the Crimean war the mustache in this country was the distinguishing badge of the cavalry: it was prohibited in the infantry, and as for the civilian who braved public opinion by sporting it he was looked on either as an artist, an eccentric, or as wishing to pass for a hussar.

The contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather, which is to be made by his widow, Mrs. Lucy Fayerweather, was placed in a new light yesterday by the statement on behalf of the three executors, Justus L. Bulkley, Thomas G. Ritch, and Henry B. Yaughan, that they are not to receive a dollar of personal benefit under the provision of the will by which they are to take absolutely the residue of the estate.

BOSTON, Dec. 13. -- Boston is fairly launched on the sea of intellectual frivolity, and is consequently as happy as it is in its nature to be. While the city contains a certain element that can be depended upon to sustain the ordinary run of amusements, the real heart of the "Hub" hungers for pabulum permeated by an intellectual essence.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 13. -- A special from Akron, Ohio, says: At a birthday celebration in the Buchtel College this evening thirty lady students were gathered in the society's library building. They were entertained by eight, who wore masks and loose, flowing garments, with high hats also covered with cotton.

By next Spring the works of William Cramp Sons, ship and engine builders, will be fabricating war material on a scale greater than has ever been known in the United States since the close of the war. Already the shops of this establishment give indication of prodigious work ahead, while the clearing away of numerous obstacles in the yard are unmistakable signs of coming activity.

If a tuning fork, when vibrating, is made to touch any part of a spider's web or the twigs or leaves by which the web is supported, the trembling of the web completely deceives the spider, so that, after rapidly finding which radial line is most disturbed, she runs along this one and attempts to secure the tuning fork, and struggles in vain to find a soft spot in the armor of her prey.

Mayor Grant received a letter yesterday from Mayor Manning of Albany asking the co-operation of the city officials and of citizens who may be interested in a hearing to be given by a board of army officers at Albany, beginning Jan. 6, in relation to the feasibility of widening and deepening the channel of the Hudson River between this city and Troy.

There is something exceedingly refreshing in the action of the Michigan Grangers in opposition to the plan indorsed by the National Grange for the loan of Government notes on real estate. No sounder or clearer statement of the facts regarding the mischievous proposition has come to our knowledge.

The unsuccessful effort made to reorganize the Republican machine in Brooklyn recalls irresistibly the period when that machine was at the height of its power, when the "Three Graces" ran it. This term was applied to a trio of men, now wealthy and prominent, who took absolute charge of local Republican affairs about 1870 and built up a machine that promised to convert Brooklyn into a Republican city.
Secretary Windom paid another visit to Wall Street yesterday and conferred with a number of prominent bankers and business men upon several important matters affecting the financial situation.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13. -- The carriage manufacturers of St. Louis have suddenly awakened to a knowledge of the fact that they are completely at the mercy of the Wheel Trust. Something less than a year ago the National Wheel Company was formed, with a capital of $3,000,000, the chief promoter being N.G. Olds of Fort Wayne, Ind. The declared object was to cheapen the cost of wheels by certain improved business methods.

One of the thousand things that prevent any well-informed or fastidious inhabitant of New-York from describing it as a civilized city has been the practice of using the public sidewalks as places of storage or delivery for goods, without any regard at all for the rights of foot passengers, for whom the sidewalks are constructed.

DUBLIN, Dec. 13. -- Valentine B. Dillon, Jr., Alderman of the Rotunda Ward of Dublin, has written a letter to the Freeman's Journal stating that Messrs. John Dillon and William O'Brien are still hopeful of effecting a compromise with Mr. Parnell.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- It has been repeatedly urged that Chicago has too many theatres. This is a matter of chief importance to the managers themselves. If any of them are indulging in the expensive luxury of running unprofitable houses that is their own business. Several new theatres are contemplated and two more will undoubtedly be opened in the near future.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 13. -- A courier from a camp on Small Creek to Rapid City, S.D., sends the following: "Two troops of the Sixth Cavalry, comprising 5 officers and 125 men and horses, under command of Major Perry, came into camp at Spring Creek during the day. Several parties of friendly Indians were seen, but no hostiles.

Considering the number of persons who wear them, one may justifiably affirm that wooden legs are quite fashionable in these times. A New-Yorker who deals in artificial limbs says that there are as many as 400,000 persons in this country each lacking at least one limb, and that of this number about 85 percent, are either one-legged or altogether short of nether extremities.
The character and result of the Yale-Princeton football game at Eastern Park Thanksgiving Day leads one to make the remark that upon that occasion Princeton was beaten by her own game.

We wish a committee of Michigan Grangers might get Senator SHERMAN and one or two other "financiers" in a quiet room for a few hours, and see if they could instill into their uncommon minds enough common sense to bring them to the doctrine -- the sound, wholesome, practical doctrine of the Michigan Grange.

That eminently respectable old plug hat that may be said to be almost a landmark to people who live in New-York and Washington, and that has such a world-wide celebrity, that glorious old tile of Senator Evarts, is, perhaps, the most famous hat in America to-day. It has been pertinently asked, where did he get it? The extraordinary thing about it is not that it looks old, but that it never looks new.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- This is to be a short season in society, but it will produce many debutantes. The list is already large, and there are, no doubt, many buds not yet announced that will seek the congenial capital as a place in which to have their first experiences as candidates for belleship.

A lawyer of sufficient standing to have been admitted to the bar and to be a member of a first-class club on Fifth Avenue met a gentleman upon some social occasion, and encountering him a few days afterward on the street, invited him into his club to partake of a "modest quencher." The gentleman, who was of French origin and a wealthy citizen of the metropolis, amiably accepted the invitation.

President Thurman of the American Association held another conference with George K. Frazer of the Syracuse Club, and the latter has agreed to give up his franchise when called upon by the Association. Frazer will be given a sum of money, and will be allowed the privilege of holding the territorial rights of his city and the players under contract with the club.

WORKINGWOMEN IN PARIS. -- What are the wages paid to female labor in Paris, and what is the cost of living? Three or four trades, or, more properly, professions, are well paid -- comparatively; but these, in fact, belong to the fine arts, and require natural talent, with careful and expensive training, so that they are open to few.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Mrs. Julia C. Lippincott, the alleged forger, who, with her husband, for many years kept the fashionable hotel Haddon Hall at Atlantic City, was to-night released from jail in Camden, where she had been confined for about five months. She was released by order of Wilson Jenkins, Prosecutor of the Pleas of Camden County, who has been trying for a long me to convict her without success.

It is reported from Washington that President HARRISON has in incubation, so to speak, a special message in regard to the currency, in which he will recommend to Congress some scheme of "relief" for the supposed need of the country. There is, we suppose, no particular form of ineptitude of which it would be safe to believe that the President is incapable.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- The Girard Life Insurance and Trust Company to-day filed in the office of the Prothonotary of the Courts the company's own bond for $200,000 as security for a trust resigned last week by Abraham Barker and Wharton Barker. The trust which it is claimed that the Barkers made was for the benefit of certain depositors with Barker Brothers Co.

ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- So many inquiries have been sent to the State Insurance Department regarding the rights in this State of assessment associations of other States that Superintendent Maxwell has issued a circular letter containing full and complete information on that subject. The department has been frequently asked what proceedings, if any, can be taken against persons acting as agents, solicitors, or collectors for associations not having authority to transact business in this State.

The number of inventors in this country, according to figures collected by Mr. E.P. Thompson of this city, and stated by him to the members of the New-York Electrical Society, is equal to the number of inhabitants in this city. That the women have had their go at procuring patents is shown by the reports from the Patent Office.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13. -- Capt. Clement M. Bellairs, now residing in St. Louis, was for ten years, from 1861 to 1871, an officer in the Royal Havre Artillery in India. He is a finished scholar, a great traveler, and a man of rare literary attainments. He was asked to-day for his views on the literary works of Rudyard Kipling. In the coarse of a long conversation on the subject Capt. Bellairs said:

It would be judicious for Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER to cease defending his census for this city, except before partisan committees of Congress which have decided in his favor beforehand. The case against him is altogether too clear to give his defense any chance of being accepted with a disinterested and fair-minded tribunal.

There are names predestined. Thus is Herisson to be the defender of Bazaine. doubter of the suicides of Abdul-Aziz, Louis II. of Bavaria, and Rudolph of Austria, author of this troubling, puzzling, enigmatic book about the victim of the Zulus. The surprise that charms or chills others finds him bristled up.

Col. "Sam" Scott of St. Louis and Kansas City, whose fame as a "boomer" has traveled across the continent, has been at the Hoffman House several days. When Kansas City was enjoying her wildest and most fascinating boom experience Col. Scott was the most noted real-estate operator of the thousands who sought fortunes in the elusive soil that made up her territory.

Three thousand dolls will be put on exhibition to-morrow night in the Judge Building, Fifth Avenue and Sixteenth Street, for sweet charity's sake. The exhibition will be the first of its kind ever given in America, and the prospect is that it will furnish delightful entertainment during the six nights and five days that it will be kept open for all who may patronize it, both old and young.

The commission appointed to inquire into the expediency of consolidating the cities of New-York and Brooklyn and the adjacent territory, including Staten Island, into one great municipality, will submit a favorable report at the coming session of the Legislature, together with a bill for carrying out the project.

The Essex County Toboggan Club of Orange, N.J., last night celebrated the opening of its slides for this season with a carnival, to participate in which a company of about 500 persons assembled, members of the club and guests. The night was a magnificent one for tobogganing, the slides were in absolutely perfect condition, and the arrangements for the carnival were complete, so that the opening was a great success.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, Dec. 13. -- The students of Rutgers College are getting up a course of lectures for the benefit of the athletic fund. The responses for money have been liberal.

If a collection could be made representing all the different styles of hats and bonnets in vogue in this Winter of 1890, what a source of inspiration it might prove to the milliner of posterity. The records of ancient styles, now so eagerly searched, suggest that it once required the genius of many generations to produce half the variety sprung upon a bewildered public in a single modern season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Pension Commissioner Raum would be quite excusable for not worrying very much about the verdict likely to be returned by the special committee of the House of Representatives, which is slowly "investigating" the patent refrigerator scandal and other matters connected with his administration.

Pedestrians who pass up Madison Avenue in the late afternoon and see the bright girls who come out of Barnard College are beginning to realize that the college has come to stay and is destined to become one of the city's features to be pointed to with pride. A brighter-looking company of girls cannot be found, and the work they are doing compares favorably with their intelligent countenances.

It is in some respects a new Ericsson that Col. Church brings before us in these two handsome volumes. The Ericsson of the Novelty locomotive, of the Princeton, the Monitor, and the Destroyer, of the calorie engine and the sun motor, we had partly known. Now we are made acquainted with the human side of the illustrious engineer, with his hopes, fears, and aims, his qualities and foibles, his habits and eccentricities.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 13. -- The annual Yale catalogue, which was issued yesterday, shows that the plan of lengthening the Summer vacation by one week has again been adopted, and the Easter recess and the Divinity School Commencement will come a week earlier than usual. Presentation day will, for the first time, come on Monday instead of Friday, in accordance with the long-expressed desire of the students.
A prominent Republican paper in the far Northwest, the Portland Oregonian, mournfully asserts that the Republican Party no longer has any great leaders. It says:

Count Papasogli, an Italian nobleman doing business as a junkman on the east side, pretty well up town, recently procured a donkey, and he uses the animal as a beast of burden, hanging baskets over her back, into which he loads the various things that he buys as he goes about on his routes.
But was her father a King? Was she in the smallest degree a Princess?

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 13. -- The exterior of the fine new Summer residence for Mr. Lorillard Spencer is about completed. The villa is on Halidon Hill, one of the finest sites in the city, "Sans Souci," formerly the property of Mr. Clement Ferguson. The old house, which was an old-fashioned, roomy mansion, was partly torn down and the remainder moved off.
" I swipes things," Hobo Jack said, in reply to my inquiry relative to the ways and means employed by him to live.

Naturally the fate of the two Nelsons, as the Maine breeder and his horse are designated, has caused considerable stir in turf circles. Whenever a trotter earns a championship for age or sex, the fame of the animal makes its future a matter of common interest, and, as with the human race, details that would be otherwise unheeded assume an import in keeping with the occasion.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 13. -- The Rev. C.H. McIntosh has resigned the pastorate of the Congregational church at Guilford and will immediately assume charge of the church at Plantsville. The Rev. A. McIntyre of the Congregational church at Stony Creek has resigned and will remove to Lake Grove, Suffolk County, N.Y.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 13. -- Yale University has been fortunate in acquiring from time to time, and especially the present term, various kinds of important apparatus for the interpretation of pure mathematics. Some of the models brought over from Germany are possessed probably by no other college in America, and other portions of the apparatus have come to Yale alone through the ingenuity of her own professors.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- Young Dechelly, a pupil of Delaunay's class at the Conservatoire, for whom so much was predicted at the last concourse, did not make a success in "L'Ecole des Femmes" of Moliere. He was all motion; his lack of repose, his rapid diction, his evident imitation of his master made up a most unfortunate ensemble, which, coming immediately after the debut of Jean Coquelin, was all the more noticeable.

HAVANA, Dec. 13. -- The amiable Manuel Garcia, the brigand, seems to be doing whatever pleases him, notwithstanding the reward published by the Government of $10,000 in gold for his head. His resent exploits locate him in the vicinity of the frequented highway between Havana and Batabano. All the Government troops have been stationed along and near this route.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- A long-breeding political explosion between rival factions in the Republican Party in this city has at length burst forth. The defeat of Congressman Flood for a renomination left a rankling feeling in his heart, but no unpleasant relations were manifested between him and friends to Senator Fassett, who, as is well known, defeated him for a third-term nomination.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14. -- At the meeting of the creditors of the Druid Mills Manufacturing Company the statement submitted showed the company to be solvent.
