The liabilities, including the mortgage on the mill property, are $450,000, while the assets are $716,000. The mills at Woodberry are carried on the books of the company at $600,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- While it is not at all certain that to-morrow night's caucus will end with a complete Silver bill, agreed upon by all the Republican Senators, some of the important features of such a bill will most likely be decided upon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Chicago will soon have the largest ten-cent lodging house in the world. The building will be seven stories high, will cost $85,000, and will be heated by steam and lighted by electricity. It will be built by the proprietors of the Liberty Bell, Chicago's celebrated ten-cent lodging house.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 14. -- The North Carolina Legislature meets on the second Wednesday of January next. There are only seven Senators and seventeen Representatives who are Republicans. This is the smallest representation the party has ever had in any Legislature in this State.

Among the first measures which the Legislature will be called upon to consider and pass this Winter will be a bill for a new rapid-transit law. There will be other measures affecting the interests of New-York City especially which will receive the sanction and support of the municipal authorities, but none of them will be of the general interest and importance of the rapid-transit law.

The members of the Brooklyn Ethical Association turned out in full force last night at the Second Unitarian Church, Clinton and Congress Streets, with the expectation of hearing from Prof. Huxley, who had been elected a member of the association at the last previous meeting. In this they were not disappointed. Dr. Lewis G. Janes, who presided, read a letter received from Prof. Huxley by Corresponding Secretary James A. Skilton accepting his election.

Hundreds of New-Yorkers will feel that they have lost an old friend when they read this morning of the death of "Papa" Sieghortner, the famous restaurateur of Lafayette Place. The old man was stricken with pneumonia about two weeks ago, but fought the disease wonderfully well for his age and was last Saturday morning considered so far on the road to recovery that his physicians told him he might sit up a while on Sunday.

There has been a good deal of discussion in recent years as to the capacity of the people of large cities to govern themselves, especially under the principles of representative government which have been established in this country, but the figures of each successive census suggest with increasing clearness the possibility of a time not very far off when cities may hold the ruling power of State and Nation.

Twice a year the thoughts of city folks turn longingly to the country -- first, in the Spring, when human nature is exhausted by the festivities of the preceding season, and again in the Fall, after the mental and physical drain at the hilarious Summer resort.

The horrors of the conventual life in two convents of Naples have recently formed the subject of animadversions by the anti-clerical journals in Naples, and some of the facts stated were several weeks ago printed in this newspaper. These reports coming to the knowledge of the Procuratore del Re have led to the determination to investigate the establishments in order to ascertain the foundation of the accusations.

In New-York, when we speak of the Erie Canal, it is as a waterway beginning at Buffalo and ending at Albany. In Ottawa, when they speak of the Canadian system of canals connecting the great lakes with tidewater, they consider the question as one involving the lakes themselves. In the last annual report of Sir John Macdonald, the Dominion Minister of Railways and Canals, appears this paragraph:

State Senator James W. Birkett, the Grand Mogul of the Republican organization of the Fourth Ward, Brooklyn, engaged in a wrangle late on Saturday night that resulted in an exchange of blows between him and George Cookran, one of the leaders of a faction that has been opposing the Senator in the party affairs of the ward.

Yawcoob Jacobus is one month old to-day, and Heinrich Jacobus is the proudest monkey in Central Park. As for Mrs. Jacobus, her homely but expressive face bears plain traces of the anxiety that consumes her mind. She watches Yawcoob's every movement with human solicitude, and exercises the maternal prerogative sternly whenever Yawcoob tries to walk across the narrow plank on which Mrs. Jacobus perches when crooning the lullaby at eventide.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Dec. 14. -- The Ramos mining district in the State of San Luis Potosi, one of the richest in Mexico, has been sold to an American syndicate headed by Mr. Kirkland of Milwaukee.

The addition of 2,340 square miles to the habitable and productive portion of Montana is an event that must not be measured by the average value of land in this portion of the Republic. The throwing open of this amount of the Crow Reservation carries much with it to this State. It means that nearly a million and a half acres of territory capable of development have been added to the area of the State.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 14. -- Mayor Gardner was suddenly called from his office Saturday morning to visit the bedside of a noted lawbreaker, who is at present very close to death's door.

In his "Paradise of Birds," a metrical protest in the nature of a satire is made by W.J. COURTHOPE against the wanton destruction of our feathered friends for the amusement of boys and pot-hunters of an older and less excusable sort, the adornment of hats, and the filling of collections made without scientific use and necessity.

The old question as to what constitutes the amateur photographer has come up again, and the young men and women who are fond of taking pictures are discussing the question with renewed interest. The Kodak and the new cameras of press-the-button order are now used generally by many who do nothing but touch the button.

At last the hungry subsidy seekers have wrested from the Committee on Rules an intimation that a day shall be given them for the consideration of their bills, known as the "Shipping bills." But we trust, for their peace of mind, that they will not be too much elated by the prospect, because there is great danger of their "day" being all that they will get.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 14. -- To people acquainted with the true situation of political affairs in this State the advocacy by the Kansas Democrat of Gov. Hill's Presidential boom is highly amusing. The editor of the Democrat is a former Republican named Tomlinson. The real owner of the paper is Cyrus K. Holliday, the nominal owner his son Charles.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14. -- Hebrew circles in St. Louis are shaken from centre to circumference by a recent publication in the Globe-Democrat and subsequent developments. The publication was a scandalous story reciting the shortcomings of a rabbi and his relations with a widow of his flock, but mentioning no names. The description, however, was such that people acquainted with the distinguished Jews in the city could readily understand what rabbi was meant.

Col. G.W. Thompson of this city, agent of the Diamond Mills Paper Company, at 44 Murray Street, was the man who got the duty on tissue paper raised from 25 per cent ad valorem to 8 cents a pound and 15 per cent ad valorem.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 14. -- In Republican political circles there is a strong disposition manifested to avoid the tariff issue, if such a thing is possible, in the next Gubernatorial campaign. It is urged that the nomination of Major McKinley would force that issue, and at the present time the party in Ohio is in no condition to make an aggressive contest with that as the only one.

Third week at the Autumn exhibition of the National Academy of Design closed on Saturday with sales of over fifty pictures, representing about $10,000. These figures surpass all previous sales in Autumn at the Academy, and, if they may be taken as an earnest of the Winter and Spring, should put courage into the impecunious artist and greater haughtiness into the bearing of those lucky ones who are sure of an income.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 14. -- Thousands of spectators flocked around the scene of Saturday's half-million-dollar fire to-day. Chief of Police Child ordered the circle of the ropes contracted to within safe distance of the tottering walls in order that the crowds might better survey the ruins. Trains coming into the city and the street-car service brought a multitude of spectators, who came and went till late this evening.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Frank C. O'Reilly and Philip J. Dwyer have resigned from the Board of Directors of the New-Jersey Jockey Club, their places being filled by P.H. Dalton and C. Cornehlson, Jr.

The high-tariff papers still cling to their old assertion that the "cry about higher prices" was only the work of Democratic conspirators who sought to deceive voters before the election. We have recently quoted the remarks of the Philadelphia Press, Cleveland Leader, Hartford Courant, and several other journals to that effect.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Dr. Frederic M. Warner of the charity hospital, New-York, and Dr. Thomas L. Shearer of Baltimore, who have been investigating the Koch treatment in Berlin, sailed to-day from Southampton in the steamer Spree.

Marcus Benyunes, the tobacco merchant who was found Wednesday morning at the bottom of an excavation in the basement of the Synagogue Zichron Ephraim, in East Sixty-seventh Street, near Third Avenue, with two scalp wounds, died Saturday night at Bellevue Hospital.

St. James's Episcopal Church, at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, held its customary large congregation at yesterday's evensong service. The occasion was the twenty-third of the choir festivals which, under the direction of G. Edward Stubbs, organist and choirmaster, have achieved for St. James considerably more than a merely local reputation.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14. -- At the annual meeting of the local division of the Order of Railway Conductors to-day some facts were learned of decided interest to the national organization and the railway world in general The national convention meets here in May, and already a movement has gained strong headway to have the permanent headquarters of the order located here. The headquarters are now at Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

TRENTON, Dec. 14. -- Assemblyman Perkins of Burlington, who is an enthusiastic supporter of Assemblyman-elect Bergen of Somerset for the Speakership of the House, made an attempt to commit the six South Jersey Democratic votes to that side of the Speakership contest one day last week. He succeeded in getting the six into a little conclave, but that was as far as he was able to go.

DUBLIN, Dec. 14. -- The anti-Parnell faction held a meeting to-day at Tipperary, at which about 2,000 persons were present. Telegrams were read from Messrs. Healy and Sexton, both of whom apologized for not attending the meeting on the ground that their presence was required elsewhere Mr. Davitt telegraphed: "Impossible to leave Kilkenny. The fate of home rule depends upon the struggle here."

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Gen. Nelson A. Miles, commanding the Division of the Missouri, accompanied by Capt. Marion P. Maus and the General's private secretary, Mr. Mizen, left Chicago for St. Paul to-night. Just before leaving, the General said he should remain at St. Paul a couple of days and go then to the Northwestern Indian country. He could not say how long he would be absent.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 14. -- This is the saddest day in the history of Buchtel College. It is, indeed, a house of mourning, and but few eyes there were closed in sleep last night. It is expected that the Faculty to-morrow morning will call a cessation of work for the rest of the year out of respect for the two ladies who now lie within the dormitory burned to death.

SCOTTSDALE, Penn., Dec. 14. -- A terrible riot took place near Jimtown, a mining hamlet, situated about three miles distance from this place, last night, in which several persons were badly hurt. A gang of Hungarians, nearly all of whom were fired up with whisky, were returning home, and about half way between Dawson and Jimtown they met two Americans named Watkins and Hunting.

The Republican Club met last night, and the Committee on Nominations posted the following list of officers to be elected at the annual meeting in January: President -- William Brookfield; Vice Presidents -- James A. Blanchard, John S. Smith, Lucius C. Ashley; Secretaries -- Charles Henry Phelps and Henry Melville; Chairman of the Executive Committee -- Cephas Brainerd; Treasurer -- Alfred B. Price.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 15. -- The Hon. E.P. Greer, editor of the Winfield Courier and half owner of the Daily Capital, published at Guthrie, is in the city and tells of the destitution existing among the people of Oklahoma, both in towns and country.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 15. -- The Republican politicians of this State will hold a meeting here this week to devise some plan of action for the Legislature in dealing with the Gubernatorial entanglement. No plan has not been offered, and the result of the proposed exchange of views will be awaited with considerable interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- When the eleven Republican Senators who have spent the past week wrestling with the financial legislation problem closed their sitting late this afternoon and walked out of the Finance Committee's room, their smiling faces showed plainly enough that something had been accomplished and that something definite would be reported by them to the caucus called for to-night.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 15. -- A report has been received here to the effect that Sitting Bull, the Sioux chief, has been killed. It is stated that the Indian police started out this morning to arrest him, and meeting him three miles from camp tried to effect his capture. A fight ensued in which Sitting Bull was killed.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15. -- A meeting of the various committees of Irish-American citizens of Baltimore who had arranged a public reception to the Irish envoys in this city Wednesday even-next was held to-night at the headquarters of the Celtic Club, and after a report from a special committee who went to New-York on Thursday last to have an interview with Messrs.

There was nothing new at the theatres last evening. Herrmann, at this pretty little house on Broadway, introduced in the middle of a clever and pleasing entertainment, that was enjoyed by a large company of spectators, his new illusion, which had already been seen by the newspaper reporters and others, and was fully described in this journal last Saturday.

There is published in the Iron Age a list of "the companies which will probably be taken into the deal" by the promoters of the projected combination of manufacturers of thrashing machines, and we are not surprised to find in this list "RUSSELL CO., Massillon, Ohio." The members of this firm were among the foremost supporters of MCKINLEY and advocates of a high tariff in the recent campaign.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Indian Commissioner Morgan this evening received from Indian Agent McLaughlin the following dispatch, dated Fort Yates, North Dakota, Dec. 15:

BOSTON, Dec. 15. -- Ex-Assistant Postmaster General Clarkson, who is in town on a visit to his two sons, who are at Harvard, in an interview on national topics, said he did not believe in talking much about the recent Republican defeat, but would rather look forward to the next victory. He did not ascribe to the big importers an extraordinarily large share in the general result.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 1. -- Another name has been added to the long list of royal and imperial personages in Europe who have become insane and have been placed under restraint. It is that of the Grand Duke Nicolas Nicolaiwitch, the eldest of the Czar's uncles and the senior in point of age of the reigning house of Russia.

The objections of Mrs. Lucy Fayerweather to the probate of the will of her husband, Daniel B. Fayerweather, were filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office by Mr. D. G. Holden. They were in the following form:

The application for the continuance of the injunction obtained by Edward Henry, as a taxpayer, restraining the Board of Electrical Control from modifying the contract with the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company and making a contract with the Empire Company, was argued before Judge Truax, in the Superior Court yesterday, from 11 o'clock until 4, when an adjournment was taken until to-day.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 15. -- The third-party movement which originated at the recent Farmers' Alliance Convention took definite form to-day, when the following call for a convention was issued:

A great many of the leaders among the Irish Nationalist of this city called on the Irish envoys at the Hoffman House yesterday. At a consultation in the afternoon the following manifesto was issued by Messrs. Dillon, Sullivan, and O'Connor:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- A very important State convention is to be held in this city, beginning to-morrow, by the flourishing fraternity known as the Knights of the Maccabees. The convention is called for the purpose of settling the question of a separate jurisdiction for this State. There are now 106 tents of the order in the State.

DUBLIN, Dec. 15. -- Mr. Parnell slept last night at Urlingford, whence he drove this morning to Rathdowney. Messrs. Davitt and Tanner also started for Rathdowney with the avowed intention of confronting Mr. Parnell publicly. Messrs. Harrison, O'Kelly, Edward Harrington, and Joseph Nolan, members of Parliament, joined Mr. Parnell at the Ossory Hotel.

In the recent campaign the high-tariff papers of the West were never weary of abusing the "rascally importers." Their vocabularies were ransacked for uncomplimentary adjectives that could be applied to the men who were guilty of the crime of bringing goods from foreign lands to this country for sale.

If we are to have free silver coinage, I know of no better or safer way of effecting such a result than in the policy I have embodied in the following bill. This policy would prevent any sudden contraction of the currency at any time through the retirement and exportation of gold, and I am confident that this combined "unit of value" would not depreciate in purchasing power.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 15. -- The war between the Chandler and anti-Chandler factions of the Republican Party in this State, or rather between Senator Chandler and would-be Senator Gallinger, is still in active progress, and engrosses the attention of the general public about as thoroughly as the question of the party control of the incoming Legislature.

From now until the end of the year the taxpayers will be more interested in the work of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment than ever, for that important body of city officials is now busy with the final arrangement of the city's budget for next year. The total of the budget passed last year for 1890 was $35,148,097.55, and the provisional estimate adopted last month for next year was $34,600,336.62.

The newspaper organs of DAVID B. HILL would have the public believe that the Mugwumps ardently desire his election to the United States Senate. We do not know how the Governor's friends obtained the knowledge they pretend to-possess of the wishes of the Mugwumps nor why they should particularly concern themselves about the views of persons they love so little.

A meeting was held in this city last week in behalf of the improvement of the State canals and of the relief of the water line of communication between the city and Lake Erie from some of the disadvantages from which it now suffers, and a committee was appointed to frame and to urge upon the Legislature measures necessary for this purpose.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15. -- There are nine patients at the Johns Hopkins Hospital inoculated with Koch's lymph. Owing to the fact that sufficient time has not yet elapsed, no effect is observed except the usual pain in the back and desire to cough. The subjects for the experiment were selected with great care, and are known as free patients.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The Daily News's correspondent at Kilkenny declares his belief that Parnell's cause is lost. He says: "It was a race between the Parnellites and the McCarthyites to reach Rathdowney, where it was announced Parnell would speak. The utmost enthusiasm was displayed for Davitt while there were hooting and groaning for Parnell.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- George E. Lemon, the pension attorney, was before the Raum investigating committee to-day. Mr. Lemon testified that he had never recommended to Commissioner Raum the appointment of any person in his employ. He did not recall in his whole career ever having recommended any person to any Commissioner of Pensions, save Mr. Whelpley, whom he recommended to Commissioner Tanner; but Whelpley was not appointed.

Brooklyn Republicans were busy yesterday getting ready for the primaries which take place to-day. The recent refusal of the General Committee to reorganize the party or to permit of any improvement in its present demoralized condition has encouraged the ward bosses to carry things with a high hand.

The Hon. John Sherman is characterized by the Philadelphia Record as one of those opportunist statesmen who float along with any passing current of popular opinion on questions of currency. In support of this characterization the Record says: "While opposed 'in principle' to the issue of more greenbacks, he has introduced a bill to make greenbacks the only paper currency of the future.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- There has been the most erratic conduct of late in New-York exchange rates. Exchange has closed some evenings at 70 cents to $1 discount, and opened the next morning at 25 cents premium, and vice versa.

BOSTON, Dec. 15. -- To-night was a great night for the Young Men's Democratic Club of Massachusetts. The third annual meeting and banquet were held at the Revere House. Democrats filled the corridors and the parlors, and when they filed into the banquet hall they were over three hundred strong.

The new departure in higher education, which is making a stir in England and arousing great interest in this county, was explained and its scope eloquently described last night at the First Baptist Church, in Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, by Prof. R.G. Moulton of the University of Cambridge Extension, England. The audience was composed of members of the Long Island Historical Society, the Brooklyn Institute, and many well-known educators. The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs presided.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The Times will say tomorrow that great interest is felt in O'Brien by that section of the Irish Parliamentary party led by Justin McCarthy. The members are anxiously discussing the possibility of his not coming into complete accord with them, or even arraying himself on the other side. This is shown by a conversation which occurred to-day with one of the most prominent members of the anti-Parnell division.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15. -- An Alaskan exploring expedition passed through here five months ago en route to the northwestern territory. The party included E.G. Glave, who was with Stanley in Africa; W.H. Wells, a Cincinnati journalist; a New-York newspaper man, and several others. Glave returned from the north a few weeks ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 15. -- The Tenth Battalion is holding a fair in its new armory to raise funds wherewith to furnish it. There have been offered as door prizes $2,500 in cash, a building lot, a silver tea service, and other articles. Within the fair is a "wheel of fortune."

The tenement population in the neighborhood of Fortieth Street and Ninth Avenue was very much frightened at about 10 o'clock last night by a brisk fire that destroyed the building used as a carpenter's shop at 328 and 330 West Fortieth Street. The alarm was first given by woman who ran screaming, "Fire!" down the street, toward Ninth Avenue.

It is a characteristic of political "bosses" of the type of QUAY and PLATT and CHANDLER that they never learn anything from the mistakes and disasters of one another. The overwhelming revulsion against QUAY in Pennsylvania and the total failure of PLATT'S tactics of dictation and coercion in this State have not deterred CHANDLER from pursuing similar methods in New-Hampshire.

The arrival of the Grand Dukes Nicholas Alexandrovitch, Czarowitch, and George Alexandrovitch in the United States need not be expected much before March 1, 1891. The two Dukes are traveling quietly and without ostentation. They are both young men, the Czarowitch being but twenty-two years of age and his brother, George, but nineteen years of age.

The sole indication, so far, that Mr. MCKINLEY and his friends have shown of a national appreciation of the effect of the tariff legislation of last session upon the business of the country is the action of the Ways and Means Committee in favor of reporting the postponement to July 1 of the payment of duties on importations made previous to the passage of the tariff of Oct. 1.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- At 9 o'clock to-night Assistant Adjt. Gen. Corbin of Gen. Miles's staff received an official dispatch from St. Paul saying that Sitting Bull, five of Sitting Bull's men, and seven of the Indian police have been killed. The thirteen casualties were the result of an attempt by the police to arrest Sitting Bull.

The railroad Presidents propose a new association, with an advisory board consisting of the President and one Director of each company, which shall have power "to establish and maintain uniform rates between competitive points, and decide all questions of common interest between the members of the association?"

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- The engagement of Lee and Robert Howard, trapeze performers, was brought to an abrupt and unpleasant close at Wonderland last evening. They performed the daring "Mexican ladder trapeze act." Upon the bar of the trapeze was a long ladder. At one end of it was a small trapeze upon which Robert performed while his brother, astride of the other end, acted as a balance.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- The Court of Appeals has ordered a new calendar to be made for a term of the court to be held Jan. 12. Attorneys and counselors have until Jan. 3 in which to file notices and returns in appeals.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- The report has been alternately made and denied that a protectionist professor in the University of Pennsylvania had been called to a professorship of political economy at Harvard, and a good deal of comment, both pro and con, has been uttered upon the educational and political significance of such step.

It seems to be agreed by all persons who are entitled to be regarded as experts in Indian affairs that the death of SITTING BULL will have important consequences on the course of events in the Indian country. Unfortunately no two of the experts seem to agree precisely upon what these consequences will be.

An application was made by certain philanthropic people last week to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for an appropriation to the Police Department to enable and require it to provide for the isolation of the sexes in the police stations and the care of female prisoners by police matrons, but it was avoided by the board upon the peculiar pretext that no requisition for the appropriation had been made by the Police Board.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Dec. 16. -- News reached here to-day that the United States troops had begun to remove all cattle belonging to non-citizens on leased pasturage on the Comanche and Kiowa nations across Red River into Wichita, Greer, and Wilbarger Counties. This ejectment is in compliance with the President's proclamation some time since regarding the removal of all such stock from the Cherokee strip and other tribal possessions in the Indian country.

Collector Joel B. Erhardt and Surveyor of the Port George W. Lyon do not speak as they pass by. This is but another evidence of the fraternal relations and harmony that exist between the Republicans of this city. The dissension between Messrs. Erhardt and Lyon is-not-at-all known except to their immediate friends. It has been generally supposed that the strongest bond, social and political, existed between them.

FORT YATES, N.D., Dec. 16. -- It is evident that there was, cruel as it may seem, a complete understanding, from commanding officer to the Indian police, that the slightest attempt to rescue Sitting Bull should be a signal to send the old medicine man to the happy hunting grounds.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Harvard shall not take part in the Mott Haven games next Spring, so the Athletic Committee has decreed. It must be consistent about the New-England rule this year, it says. Last year it relaxed the rule to the extent of allowing Harvard to share in the Mott Haven games and the Cricket Club to play its regular match at Haverford.

The dispatch of reinforcements from all parts of the country to the scene of the Indian troubles will give some of the troops a very vivid object lesson upon the large quantity and variety of climate possessed by the United States. The First Infantry, Col. SHAFTER'S regiment, exchanges the balmy breezes of Angel Island and Benicia, in California, for the blizzards of the Dakotas.

Several of the Western railroad Presidents went among their Wall Street and railroad friends in this city yesterday and told them what a good thing had been done in providing for an Advisory Board to control the rate question. With one exception, the members of Monday's conference in Mr. Morgan's house appear to be hopeful that the agreement there adopted will be put into successful operation.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 16. -- A special town meeting was held at the Music Hall this afternoon for the purpose of voting an appropriation of $10,000 for free text books in the public schools, a formality that was overlooked at the regular town meeting two weeks ago, when the petition of some of the Catholics for free books in the parochial schools was rejected.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- The trial of Michael Eyraud and Gabrielle Bompard for the murder of Toussaint Gouffe, a notary and process server, was begun to-day in the Assize Court. Great interest is manifested in the case and the court room was crowded with members of the upper classes. Among those who gathered to watch the proceedings were a number of ladies, members of the diplomatic corps, Senators, and members of the Chamber of Deputies.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- The progress of the law in the Hennessy assassination case is again stopped. The two indictments for murder and shooting, while lying in wait, against nineteen Italians had been quashed. The new Grand Jury returned two more bills. It was thought no objection would be urged against these, but the public demand for speedy justice in the case is again disappointed.

DUBLIN, Dec. 16. -- Mr. Davitt, accompanied by Father O'Halloran, was the first of the prominent speakers to arrive at the meeting in Balli-nakill to-day, and he took his stand in the higher part of the square, near the church. Cheers and counter-cheers and partisan shouts were vociferously indulged in by the assembled members of the two factions.

There was no vote reached on the Apportionment bill in the House yesterday, and it may be that there will be none to-day. The New-York City Democrats resisted the bill on the ground that it was based on a defective and inaccurate enumeration of the population here. That is perfectly true, and it ought to be conclusive with the rest of the Democrats in the House.

At 10:30 o'clock to-morrow morning, in the rooms of the Civil Service Board at the New-York Custom House, Capt. William E. Peirce, a member of that board, will be tried by a civil service court-martial. Civil Service Commissioner Theodore B. Roosevelt will preside, Gen. Floyd Clarkson will, it is understood, act as prosecutor, and Gen. McMahon, Judge Advocate, Grand Army of the Republic, will be part of the court.

When the counsel of the trio of returned "boodlers" asked Judge COWING yesterday either to set a day for their trial or dismiss the indictments, they apparently had no doubt that the indictments would be promptly dismissed, especially as Col. FELLOWS had kindly furnished the argument for them and expressed his judgment that the indictments should be "each and all dismissed."

DUBLIN, Dec. 16. -- Dublin, in contrast with Wednesday night's meeting with regard to the great leadership question, is now so calm that it is difficult to believe that the city was recently the scene of such transcendent Parnellite enthusiasm as was described by the press on the occasion of Parnell's reception.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- A short time ago a New-York lady and her fifteen-year-old son came here on a visit. Their names could not be obtained to-night, as the officers of the steamer D.S. Miller are the only ones who know them, and that boat has left for New-York. The boy returned to Yew-York on the Miller last Sunday night.

The coming investigation by a board of army officers of the feasibility of deepening and improving the Hudson River from New-York to Troy so that it may be navigated by steam vessels drawing twenty feet of water calls attention to a work upon which the State of New-York has been engaged for nearly one hundred years and upon which it has spent over $1,400,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- The whereabouts of ex-Senator John J. Macfarlane was discovered to-day. The fugitive figurehead of the picturesque combination that looted the American Life Insurance Company, the Bank of America, and their allied institutions is living in quiet luxury at Rio Janeiro, Brazil, the attractive centre of a coterie of American citizens and the honored guest of the United States Consul.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- An election to fill the vacancy in the House of Commons for the Basset-law Division of Nottinghamshire caused by the death of William Beckett, who was recently killed by a railway train, was held yesterday. It resulted in the return of Sir Frederick Milner, the Conservative candidate, who received 4,381 votes against 3,653 for Mr. Mellor, Liberal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The following order was issued from the War Department to-day:

The Manufacturer, which is published by Mr. DOLAN'S club of ultra-protectionists in Philadelphia, sharply attacks the Chicago Tribune for some things which it said the other day about wool and wool duties, and makes this remark:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The managers of the Clark Thread Company at Newark and East Newark extended an invitation to their locked-out hands to resume work to-day, and at 1 o'clock in the afternoon the mills were thrown open again to those who desired to enter. Not a single one of the 3,000 accepted the invitation, and the strike is assuming phases that but add to the difficulties attending an adjustment of differences.

Mr. Mansfield, whose engagement in Chicago ends with this week, has had no lack of encouragement during his unusually long stay in that city. Not only have his performances in "Beau Brummell" and other plays at the Columbia Theatre been attended by large and thoroughly-appreciative audiences, but the newspapers, without a noteworthy exception, have treated the work of the artist with understanding and sympathy.

The marriage of Miss Frances Walker, daughter of the late Francis T. Walker, to Mr. Henry de Berkeley Parsons, a well-known clubman of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. The Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee, rector of the church, performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Dr. John Hall of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church pronounced the blessing.

Certain persons and certain high-tariff journals still say that the result of the election was the cause of the recent financial stress and panic, and some of them even suggest that the fall of the BARINGS was due in large measure to the rejection of the McKinley idea by American voters. We are glad to see that our neighbor the Tribune continues to support two well-defined and inharmonious opinions as to this important matter.

HARTFORD, Dec. 16. -- The conference of Republican leaders and politicians here to-night has resulted in the employment of ex-Speaker William C. Case, the ablest criminal lawyer in the State, to defend Gen. Merwin's title to the Governorship. It has also been decided to hold the Republican members of the Legislature to the party plans that may be developed when the caucus is held on the night prior to the opening of the session.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- A special dispatch from Clearfield, Penn., announces the financial ruin of ex-United States Senator William A. Wallace, the leader of the political forces of David B. Hill in this State. The failure is an important one in a political sense, as it wipes out any chance the Hill people may have had to elect some of the delegates to the next national convention from this State.

The latest manifesto of the Irish delegates in this country is one of the strongest appeals yet made to the common sense of the Irish people. Celtic writers and publicists are not commonly supposed to be much impressed with the value of understatement, yet this manifesto must be all the more impressive to all sensible readers on account of its guarded and moderate tone.
SARATOGA, Dec. 16. -- If Saratoga is charming in midsummer, she is superb in midwinter, with her snow landscapes and her streets gay from curb to curb with flying sleighs.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16. -- On the face of things political in Pennsylvania, United States Senator Cameron has a clear field for re-election at the approaching session of the General Assembly. At the same time, it is true that if the great Keystone State contained a single Republican of merit with the pluck to make a fight against Cameron, the senior Senator would find it difficut to secure the return he so much desires.

Major Gen. Alfred Howe Terry died at 4 o'clock yesterday morning at his home in New-Haven, of heart failure, occasioned by Bright's disease, from which he had been suffering for two years. He was in his sixty-fourth year, having been born in Hartford Nov. 10, 1827.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Through warrants sworn out by Mayor William Cowie, Aldermen John McLennun and Charles E. Candee were arrested this afternoon on charges of bribery and forgery, respectively. The warrants were issued by Judge Kennedy of the Supreme Court.

Chinatown had a revel yesterday. It began at 4 o'clock, took a temporary adjournment at 6, at 11 o'clock was in full swing again, and at the hour when all good citizens will be having breakfast this morning 200 swarthy-skinned Mongolians will be in dreamland, sent thither either by Chinese wine or the more beloved opium.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 16. -- Mr. George Johnston, Dominion Statistician and Director of the Census Bureau, was seen to-night by THE TIMES'S correspondent regarding negotiations for preferential trade relations between Canada and the British West Indies and their probable effect upon American trade by the establishment of direct steam communication between Canada and the islands.

The Charity Doll Show yesterday was attended by about five hundred people, a large number of whom had come in from out of town to buy the pretty playthings on commissions from Santa Claus. They were much disappointed when told that they could not take their purchases home with them, because it would spoil the show if they did.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Congressional Apportionment bill was taken up in the House this afternoon and discussed until the hour of adjournment without reaching a vote. It was imagined when the bill was taken up that it would go through without much or prolonged opposition.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Dec. 17. -- Gov. Steele to-day vetoed House bill 49, which provides for the changing of the capital of Oklahoma from Guthrie to Kingfisher. In his message he administered a rebuke to the members of the combination which has existed in the Legislature from the day it convened. After dwelling at some length on different points of importance, the message continues as follows:

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- Harvard's annual catalogue will be published to-morrow. It shows large gains in all the Departments of the University. The total number of teachers now is 242, a gain of 25. The total number of students is 2,271, a gain of 192. Full details are given of the reorganization of the college and the strengthening of the graduate school.

The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Wednesday, Dec. 17: Richard V. Harnett Co. sold at public Auction the five-story brick building, with lot 25 by 100, 682 Water St., north side, 25 feet west of Jackson St., for $25,000, to H. Schmoll, and three lots, each 25 by 98.9, 535 to 537 West 84th St, north side, 400 feet west of 10th Av., for $33,000, to F.C. Weiler.
STANDING ROCK AGENCY, via courier to BISMARCK, Dec. 17. -- The following are the actual details of the fight in which Sitting Bull was killed:

KILKENNY, Dec. 17. -- A long tour through the several districts of the Kilkenny Division to-day has gone far to strengthen yesterday's impressions as to the growing sentiment of the populace on the question of Parnell's retention of the leadership. Every day weakens his hold on the people. This is for the simplest of all reasons -- that each day the populace is gaining a knowledge of the vital nature of the matter at issue.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Mr. Joseph Chamberlain made a remarkable speech at a private Unionist caucus in Birmingham to-night. Among other remarks, he said that within a week certain former friends in the Gladstonian party had reopened negotiations with him for reunion on the basis that, Mr. Parnell having rendered home rule impossible, they saw no reason why a Liberal reunion should not be formed.

Tammany has come into its own, and has thrown aside its mask. The cloak of respectability which was worn for a time and for a purpose, having served that purpose, has been cast aside, and the tiger of triangular countenance and vast appetite for spoils ranges undisguised. Mayor Grant, as chief dispenser of patronage, yesterday dealt out two rich political plums to two typical Tammany "touters."
Just look for a moment at these two horizontal lines and tell which is the longer:

New-York drew its bedraggled skirts about it yesterday and shuddered at the weather outlook. All day long the rain came down in varying quantities, from a few scattering drops to deluge, and all the while a strong northeast wind was eddying in the streets and squares of the city or was sweeping and roaring around some sharp corner to catch an unsuspecting pedestrian and rob him of his hat or umbrella.

C.P. Huntington, President of the Southern Pacific Railroad, said yesterday that he thought the action of the Western railroad Presidents last Monday would be productive of good results. "The plan to establish an Advisory Board to control the question of rates is good as far as it goes," he said. "I believe that all of the roads will act in harmony in giving it a fair trial.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- To-morrow's issue of the Medical Weekly will announce that Prof. Sonnenburg has commenced to apply surgical treatment to patients suffering from cavities in the lungs. Three operations have already been performed, Prof. Koch being present on each occasion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- The private banking house of S.A. Kean Co., one of the oldest in Chicago, will not open its doors to-morrow. Mr. Kean made a statement to-night announcing the suspension. He declined to estimate the assets or liabilities, but was of the opinion that every claim would be paid in full.

In addition to their action upon the silver job last evening, the Republican Senators determined to propose at some time not yet designated a form of previous question for the Senate. The professed object of this little arrangement is to get the Force bill through. We venture to predict that it will go but little further than the caucus.

A meeting of the creditors of Myron Nussbaum, doing business as M. Nussbaum Co., wholesale dealers in dry goods at Macon, Ga., was held yesterday at the office of Horwitz Hershfield, attorneys, in the Stewart Building. There were about one hundred and twenty-five creditors present, and Mr. Nussbaum made a full statement of his affairs, from which it appeared that his liabilities are $540,812 and assets $827,685, showing a surplus of $286,873.

The annual report of President Hendrix of the Brooklyn Board of Education was presented to Mayor Chapin yesterday. It fills a pamphlet of fifty-two pages and brings the record of the public schools down to Dec. 1. During the year ending with the month of November the total receipts for public school purposes were $2,982,093.65 and the total expenditures $2,254,358.83.

A fire in the building of the Kimball estate at Essex Street and Market Square, Salem, Mass., last night, damaged the building $500. Daniel Ladd, proprietor of a billiard hall in the second story, loses $1,000; Samuel Webb, dealer in hats, on the lower floor, is damaged by water $2,000, and the Union Pacific Tea Company's damage by water is $500. All are covered by insurance.

The appointment of "PADDY" DIVVER to be a Police Justice is without doubt the most grotesque travesty on popular government to which any Mayor of New-York has treated its inhabitants within the memory of living men. The only appointment that can be fairly likened to it at all was that of "Fatty" WALSH to be Warden of the Tombs, and this comparison is fallacious.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 17. -- The elegant home of United States Senator Gorman, near Laurel, in Howard County, was destroyed by fire early this morning. It was situated about three miles from the Laurel station of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Mrs. Gorman, the wife of the Senator, Miss Daisy Gorman, their daughter, and some servants were the occupants of the house last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- The second division of the contestants for the Baird prizes, representing the income of $6,000, delivered their orations in the old collage chapel this evening before a large audience. This completes the contest, which has been very spirited and close, as it consisted only of the best orators of the Senior Class.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 17. -- Dr. Joseph A. Blake of St. Luke's Hospital, New-York, and Miss Catharine, daughter of Landon Ketchum, the New-York banker, were married at the residence of the bride's father, at Saugatuck, to-day by the Rev. A.N. Lewis of New-Haven. The bride was attired in a robe of white faille francaise en train, which high neck and long sleeves.

The possibility of sharp competition some years hence between the Bell Telephone Company and the Western Union Telegraph Company engages the attention of the Washington Post, which points out that by means of its so-called long-distance wires the Bell Company is gradually but surely building up a first-class plant that can be used for telegraphing.

The board appointed by the Secretary of War to inquire into the subject of magazine rifles and smokeless powder met and organized at the Army Building in this city yesterday. The board is constituted as follows: Gen. Kautz, President, and Col. Hall of the Sixth Infantry, Major McKee of the Ordnance Department, Major Freeman of the Seventh Infantry, Capt. George S. Anderson of the Sixth Cavalry, and Capt. Blunt of the Ordnance Department.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Mrs. Bloomfield Moore of 510 South Broad Street to-day sent a letter to the Board of Directors of the Keely Motor Company. After expressing pleasure in the announcement that Mr. Keely's present position was such that the company has no further need of her assistance, she says:

While Mr. C.P. HUNTINGTON professes to believe that the Advisory Board plan for putting an end to rate wars on the Western railroads will be successful, he boldly declares himself in favor of consolidating all the competing lines into a single system owned and managed by one great corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- George F. Work, Louis E. Pfeiffer, and James S. Dungan were given a hearing this morning, at the Central Police Station, on the charge of wrecking the Bank of America and the American Life Insurance Company, and at its conclusion were held in $20,000 bail each to answer at court. Being unable to obtain this amount of bail they were remanded to prison.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- The correspondent of the Daily News at Kilkenny asserts that only bags of flour were thrown at Parnell and his companions at Castle Comer, and that Parnell's eye was injured by a stone which must have contained lime.

There is no other country in which popular elections are held in which anything like the scenes could be enacted that are reported from Ireland. The cruel outrage of attempting to blind PARNELL was the act, for all that appears, of a single ruffian, and it would be unfair to hold anybody else to account for it.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- The widow and two sons of the late Hon. David Wilber will erect a massive and fitting monument over his grave in Glenwood Cemetery, Oneonta. Mr. Wilber died in July last in the fullness of an honorable and useful career, and while representing the Twenty-fourth New-York District for a third term in Congress.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- Edward Atkinson advanced some new ideas in regard to financial questions before the meeting of the Boot and Shoe Club of this city to-night in an address intended to aid the solution of the pending problem of providing an elastic circulating medium.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 17. -- Over one hundred Farmers' Alliance men, masked, by force last night removed three loan company tenants from farms recently sold by the Sheriffs under foreclosure proceedings and put the original owners in possession. The farms are situated in Evans Township, Kingman County, thirty-five miles west.

The appear made by Matthiessen Weichers, sugar refiners, from the valuations placed upon their large factories in Jersey City by the ring Tax Board is the latest illustration of the false and deceptive system of finance by which the ring appeases public clamor with a low tax rate, but manages at the same time to plunge its arms to the elbows into the pockets of the taxpayers.

DUBLIN, Dec. 17. -- It is announced this afternoon that the surgeon attending Mr. Parnell fears that the injury to his eyes, which have become inflamed, may result in serious consequences. He has given orders that for the present his patient shall remain indoors, and he is kept in a darkened room.
HELENA, Mon., Dec. 17. -- The Helena Board of Trade has unanimously adopted resolutions favoring the free and unlimited coinage of all American silver.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 17. -- Over one hundred Farmers' Alliance men, masked, by force last night removed three loan company tenants from farms recently sold by the Sheriffs under foreclosure proceedings and put the original owners in possession. The farms are situated in Evans Township, Kingman County, thirty-five miles west.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 17. -- The Supreme Court this afternoon handed down one of the most important decisions of the whole term. It was the settlement of the celebrated swamp-land litigation, and it assured to the Duluth and Iron Range Road the title to between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 acres of land in the northern part of the State.
DENVER, Col., Dec. 17. -- A News courier from a camp near Daly's ranch brings the following from Rapid City, Dakota:

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 17. -- The Hon. Elliot F. Danforth, Treasurer of New-York State, is in this city. Mr. Danforth left Albany with the intention of going as far South as Charleston, where he has a grandfather buried, but the illness of a daughter who accompanied him necessitates their return.

PORT ROYAL, S.C., Dec. 18. -- The United States steamer Kearsarge is in quarantine at this port. Ten of her men are suffering from dengue, or what is sometimes called "breakbone fever." But matters are greatly improved on board the vessel compared with the state of things while she was at Key West, Fla., last week.

When the London meeting to protest against the Siberian atrocities was in agitation, Mr. GLADSTONE observed that Russia might not be very powerfully impressed with remonstrances upon the condition of Siberia from the nation responsible for the condition of Ireland. For this utterance he was sternly taken to task by the British press.

Among the answers received yesterday by the City Reform Club to their letter to legislators, asking whether they favor separate municipal elections for New-York City, and whether they would support a bill embodying these principles, is a characteristic letter from ex-Speaker Husted, in which he tersely answers: "Yes. Have always favored the proposition."

PARIS, Dec. 18. -- The trial of Michael Eyraud and Gabrielle Bompard for the murder of Toussaint Gouffe was continued to-day. The first witness called was Dr. Lacassagne, who performed the autopsy on the victim's body. He was asked by the President of the court whether the fracture of Gouffe's neck was due to hanging or to the pressure of hands.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18. -- The new revenue cutter Galveston was successfully launched this afternoon. The material used in her construction is iron seven-sixteenths to three-quarters of an inch thick. She is l86 feet between perpendiculars, 30 feet beam, and 12 feet depth of hold. Her displacement is 600 tons and she has double compound engines with cylinders 16 and 30 inches in diameter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Gen. Raum stated, when the Raum investigation committee began its session this morning, that he had made diligent search for the McGilley affidavit, but had been unable to find it.

One of the prettiest wrestling matches seen in this country for some years was the bout in the preliminaries of the 158-pound class Wednesday night. It was an early hour Thursday morning before a decision was reached. The contestants were J.H. Alward, the representative of the Boston Athletic Association, and J.J. Hughes, the crack wrestler of the Pastimes.

ALBANY, Dec. 18. -- The Democratic politicians are very much amused over the stories disseminated in the Republican papers charging that Mr. Smith M. Weed has threatened to make an issue with the Governor unless the latter throws his influence for the Plattsburg lawyer's candidacy as Senator. Mr. Weed is not indulging in threats, nor is he a man likely to do so.
The following extract from an editorial article in the Chicago Inter Ocean of the 14th inst. will serve to introduce some additional evidence as to the effect of the new tariff on prices:

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- The Orchestral Association, a corporation of Illinois "not for pecuniary profit," was granted letters of corporation Tuesday by the Secretary of State. It is composed of the following: N.K. Fairbank, E.B. McCagg, A.C. Bartlett, C.D. Hamill, and C.N. Fay, who constitute the first Board of Trustees.

KILKENNY, Dec. 18. -- To-day I again visited the rural districts, driving over thirty-five miles of country. A great change was noted from the mob of the city of Kilkenny, which latter does not vote. In the country I found the rural population to be under the leadership of priests and ardently anti-Parnellite.

QUEBEC, Dec. 18. -- The express train from Halifax on the Intercolonial Railway due at Levis at 11:40 o'clock met with a frightful accident about three miles from its destination. The scene of the wreck is an embankment at St. Josephs. The train was made up of a baggage and mail car, and one second-class car, one first-class car, and one sleeper.

Theodore Roosevelt told the members of the Nineteenth Century Club last night several things about "Americanism in Politics" which probably they had not thought of. He laid the foundation for his talk by remarking that a good healthy American spirit would not prevail until the prefixes were knocked off from the word American.

There is some confusion as to the programme laid out by the Republican Senators in caucus, or, at least, as to the attempt to enforce that programme. Two features are apparently most prominent in it -- one the speculators' Silver bill, the other the gag law, while the Force bill is supposed to hold a modest place in it.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 18. -- The present snowstorm that has been raging in this city for forty-eight hours is the most disastrous that this city has ever experienced. The total fall of snow will amount to about two and a half feet. The storm is about over. The telephone company of this city has lost thousands of dollars by the storm.

OTTAWA, Dec. 18. -- In regard to the Behring Sea question, Sir John Thompson, Minister of Justice, and the Hon. C.H. Tupper, Minister of Fisheries, who are more intimately acquainted with the subject than any of their colleagues, were interviewed by your correspondent to-day. The Minister of Justice does not appear to regard the situation as alarming.

ALBANY, Dec. 18. -- Upon information made by District Attorney Reilly, William W. Thompson, a lawyer, was arrested to-day, and is now awaiting bondsmen who must qualify in the sum of $8,000. The information of the District Attorney was that Mr. Thompson, about June 4, forged the will of James Denny, by which forgery all the interest in the property purported to be conveyed to Thomas Denny.

The big steamboat Providence of the Fall River Line found such a terrific sea off Point Judith when she started to round it on her way down to this city Wednesday night that she had to put back to Newport and stay in the harbor there till yesterday morning. The terrific northeaster that blew all Wednesday kicked up one of he worst seas off the Point that the officers of the Providence ever saw.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Commander and Mrs. N.H. Farquahar gave an enjoyable tea from 4 to 6 o'clock this afternoon to announce the debut of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Farquhar. The mantels of the parlor were banked with maidenhair fern and blush roses. Miss Farquhar stood by her mother, and was assisted by Miss Bertie Greer, daughter of Commander Greer; Miss Heideman, daughter of Dr. Heideman of Philadelphia, and Miss Meade.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the departmental estimates of the Park Department were taken up for consideration, and several items were gone over and severely criticised by Mayor Grant. Information which the Mayor wanted about them not being readily forthcoming, the whole matter was postponed until Monday, when President Gallup will try to come better prepared to defend his liberal requests for money.

HAVANA, via Key West, Dec. 18. -- Two of the five criminals, Valentine Sanchez Lopez and Guillermo Perez Cruz, under sentence of death, were executed at Santa Para Saturday morning. They were tried and convicted for the sequestration and assassination of Don Tomes Cacesis, in the Vega Enrique District of San Juan de la Remedios, March 8, 1885, nearly five years ago.

" The whole tariff question," said the Cleveland Leader on the 16th inst., "is virtually a question of wages." On the same day the Pottstown Iron Company of Pottstown, Penn., posted in its factories notices of a reduction of 25 cents per ton in the wages of puddlers and of a proportionate reduction in the wages of all workmen in its plate and puddling department.

Mayor Grant felt ill at ease yesterday over the criticisms which were visited upon his action in appointing ex-Alderman Patrick Divver to a Police Justiceship and took occasion to shoulder part of the responsibility off upon the persons who had recommended Divver's appointment. He showed to the reporters letters from several "distinguished" citizens recommending and indorsing Divver for the appointment.

The investigation of the Fire Department by the Senate committee has not proved very fruitful thus far, and the merits of the controversy in regard to the purchase of hose are not very clear. But it is proposed to take up the Street-Cleaning Department next week, and the people will be very much interested to learn what the matter is with that department.

DUBLIN, Dec. 18. -- Mr. Parnell started for the village of Goresbridge to-day despite the protests of his doctors. The physicians warned him that he ran the risk of increasing the inflammation of his eyes, which, they said, might result in the loss of his right eye. Mr. Parnell drove for twelve miles with his eyes bandaged and with a shawl wrapped about his head and shoulders to protect him from the bitter cold.

SEABRIGHT, Dec. 18. -- Fire which broke out in this town last night shortly after midnight did considerable damage, and for a time it looked as though the entire business portion of the town was doomed to destruction. The fire was discovered in the Seabright Inn Block, at the northeast corner of Ocean Avenue and the Rumson Road.

A new Berlin play, announced several weeks ahead, brought out an excellent audience last night, which filled the Amberg Theatre to overflowing. It is a realistic drama of modern German life by Ludwig Fulda, and may be classed among the hortatory or instructive plays which are expected to cure youth of its folly and age of its unwisdom.

An enlargement of the Luxembourg Palace is projected by Mr. Arago, the Director. His idea is to carry out a wing in the direction of the Rue Vaugirard so as to form a courtyard in-closed on three sides by the building. This courtyard can be utilized in time for the overflow of statuary.

Yesterday's hearing of the Senate Committee on Cities was all about the Fire Department and its adjunct, the Building Bureau. Senator Fassett is now more than ever the star of the committee. Senators Ahearn and Stewart were present during a portion of the time yesterday, but during most of the afternoon session Mr. Fassett was the only representative of the Senate present, and at 3:30 P.M. Mr. Fassett adjourned himself until 11 o'clock this morning.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Dec. 18. -- John A. Blair of Caldwell, Kan., Secretary of the Cherokee Live Stock Association, is in Fort Worth. His mission to Texas is to buy ranch property. To-day Blair received a telegram from Chief Mays of the Cherokee Nation asking him if his offer of $20,000,000 for the Cherokee Strip was made in good faith.

The Columbia College indoor championship games were held last evening in the gymnasium of the Berkeley Athletic Club. A large crowd of students and many ladies occupied seats around the room and cheered loudly at each event.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 18. -- A special to the Tribune from Pierre, S.D., says: "An Indian scout runner arrived at Fort Bennett last night bringing word that Sitting Bull's followers who escaped when their chief was killed, camped the night before at the mouth of Thunder Creek on the Morean River, being on their way to the Bad Lands.

The zeal with which pension agents in Washington have worked in behalf of pension legislation, using all their efforts and resources to stir up veterans and Grand Army men to demand it, is explained by the enormous amount of money which they make by pushing claims at the Pension Bureau, where meritorious claims ought to need no pushing.

Mr. A.B. Stickney, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Railroad, made the following statements to the Chicago correspondent of THE TIMES yesterday: "As I understand it. Mr. Gould's plan for a Western railway combination was laid aside and J. Pierpont Morgan's ideas were accepted. Gould desired a much stronger association and a closer agreement than the outlines of Mr. Morgan's plan would indicate.

There is no thinker in this country devoting his mind to business and finance who has a livelier sense of timeliness than Mr. EDWARD ATKINSON of Massachusetts, and none who is able to bring to the timely presentation of his ideas so wide, detailed, and practical knowledge and the power to apply to the question of the moment principles patiently worked out from and verified by facts.
BOSTON, Dec. 13. -- The Journal has an interview with Col. Frank C. Churchill, Chairman of the New-Hampshire Republican State Committee, in which he says of the extra session in that State:

Evidence of the greater caution which is being observed in treating patients with the Koch lymph was given yesterday, when two persons at Mount Sinai Hospital were inoculated with doses smaller by half a milligram than those which they had received at the preceding injection. In fact, the policy now is in favor of surrounding the operations with every safeguard against mistakes.

PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 18. -- In the case of the State against George Chapman and William Koeller, on a writ of error, the Supreme Court of South Dakota this afternoon handed down a decision, of which the following is a synopsis: "This was an action wherein the defendants were informed against for keeping a common nuisance by selling intoxicating liquors as a beverage.

There has been some desultory talk during the past week about an alleged conference at an up-town hotel at which certain Republican "leaders" met to consider the question of harmony in the party in this State. The lack of harmony does not appear to be so much in the party as between those leaders and certain other leaders, and the real question seems to be which set of leaders shall do the leading.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- At the holiday conference of the Associated Academic Principals of this State, to be held in Syracuse Dec. 30 and 31, the second proof of the Regents' studies and credentials will come up for final discussion. Principals are urged to submit criticisms and suggestions, as the final edition for use until 1895 will be printed immediately after the conference.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- A dispatch received in this city from Mr. Michael Davitt states that the injuries sustained by Mr. Parnell at Castle-comer were inflicted by women and girls, who pelted him with flour and mud. The story that lime was thrown in his face and eyes, the dispatch says, is Parnell's latest disgusting dodge to evoke sympathy and divert the people's mind from the real issue.

It is clear that the Irish have a large capacity for hating each other, which they seem to be employing to the full in the present contest. It does not appear ever to occur to either faction, in the warmth of its desire to injure the other, that it is injuring itself grievously, if not irretrievably, in the opinion of mankind.

Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street -- The music will be rendered by a quartet, consisting of Mrs. Elizabeth Northrop, soprano; Mrs. Carl Alves, contralto; Harry B. Moak, tenor, and John C. Dempsey, basso, assisted by a chorus. George F. Bristow is the organist. At the morning service the processional will be Nedham's "Gloria in Excelsis," and the chorus "Light Flashing Into the Darkness," by Bristow.

Bellevue Hospital physicians yesterday began a series of tests with the Koch lymph, making inoculations with the supply brought over from Germany by Dr. H.P. Loomis, who arrived here in the steamer Majestic on Thursday. The Post-Graduate Hospital expects to receive a consignment in time to begin a series of tests early in the coming week.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Dec. 19. -- Of the three United States Senators who were chosen here yesterday Fred T. Dubois will serve for the long term, which ends March 4, 1897, and George L. Shoupe and W.J. McConnell will draw lots for the two short terms, which end March 4, 1891, and March 4, 1893.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The Queen started for Osborne House, the royal residence on the Isle of Wight, to-day. A blinding snowstorm was prevailing when her Majesty left Windsor, but the weather was clear when the royal party crossed the Solent.

CORK, Dec. 19. -- Although at this juncture the eyes of the world are fixed on North Kilkenny, yet, being anxious to observe for myself the strength of the feelings of the people of other parts of the country, I have made careful inquiries throughout Cork with a view of ascertaining the attitude of the populace in regard to Parnell.

All the necessary papers were signed yesterday, and now the two New-York clubs are one. On Thursday last Col. McAlpin, E.B. Talcott, and Postmaster Van Cott, on behalf of the Brotherhood team, signed the necessary documents in Judge Bacon's office. The latter yesterday sent the papers to Lawyer Redding, who secured the signatures of John B. Day and J.W. Spalding, representing the interests of the League club.

Fire broke out last evening in the whitening loft of J.S. Crehore's split-leather factory, at Peabody, Mass, and in ten minutes totally destroyed the building and contents. The loss on building, owned by Augustus Harrington, is $2,000; insured for $1,500. Loss on stock belonging to W.W. Kellett Co. of Boston, $12,000; insurance, $13,000. J.S. Crehore's personal loss is $500; insurance, $350. J.A. Lord's vat buildings were slightly damaged; insured for $1,200.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 19. -- Shortly before 1 o'clock this morning flames broke out in the upper part of the small tenement house, 35 Drift Street. When the flames had been extinguished the charred remains of Mrs. Ann McGuire, an old woman of sixty, and of her five-year-old granddaughter, Anna Donovan, were found in the ruins. The cause of the fire is not known.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 19. -- To-day has been fruitful of phases in the Hennessy assassination case. The attorneys for the defendant Italians filed a motion for subpoenas summoning Foreman Walmsley and Mr. Hernsheim of the Grand Jury, and also members of the Committee of Fifty, and for Mayor Shakespeare and others concerned with the committee in the investigation of the Italian Mafia outrages.

The session of the Senate Committee on Cities yesterday, in Part II. of the Superior Court, was made interesting chiefly by the examination of Hans S. Beattie, Commissioner of Street Cleaning. Senators Fassett, Stewart, and Ahearn were present during most of the hearing, but Mr. Fassett left for home about noon, and Mr. Ahearn presided in his place.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 19. -- A large portion of the $800,000 bequeathed to charitable institutions by William Thaw is likely to be distributed in a very few days, and it is expected that the bequests will prove a very pleasant Christmas gift to the institutions anxiously awaiting their shares.

SHERBROOKE, Quebec, Dec. 19. -- Remi Lamontagne, the murderer of Napoleon Michel, his brother-in-law, was hanged in the yard of the Sherbrooke jail this morning. This morning's tragedy was a double one, for it involved the death of Sheriff Webb well. The Sheriff arrived at the jail a few minutes before 9 o'clock and was admitted to Jailer Road's private apartments.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19. -- The remains of Major Gen. Alfred Howe Terry were taken to their last resting place this afternoon. The services were held at the United Church on the Green. The Rev. Dr. Theodore T. Munger, pastor of the church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Newman Smith of the Centre Church, officiated. During the services minute guns were fired, and the fire alarm bell in the City Hall tower tolled.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 19. -- Dr. William G. Porter attended the late Henry Shaw in his last illness and after his death presented a bill aggregating $4,995. In this bill he charged $100 a day for a trip he made with Mr. Shaw and $10 a visit for going to Mr. Shaw's residence in the suburbs. The bill was rejected by the public administrator as exorbitant and Dr. Porter went to the Probate Court.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- A noble elk raised in Sullivan County will complete the collection of stuffed specimens of the elk tribe at the Central Park Museum of Natural History. This elk was raised at Glen Spey, the country estate of Mr. George R. McKenzie. In the ample deer park which forms part of the estate is a herd of elk, whose progenitors come from the Rocky Mountains.

Some days ago we published a carefully-prepared statement, taken from the Dry Goods Economist, showing how the cost in this market of certain imported worsted goods had been increased by the new duties of the McKinley law. Whereupon the Cleveland Leader, which is regarded as the representative of Mr. McKINLEY, said, on the 12th inst.:

The appointment of Naval Constructor THEODORE D. WILSON to another term as Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair and Chief Constructor of the Navy has not only set at rest rumors of a change but forms a merited tribute to the Chief Constructor's success during the last eight years in the building of the new fleet.

Cornelius Donnellon died on May 16 last at his home, 116 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, aged seventy-five years, leaving an estate of over $3,000,000, a widow, and nine or ten children. Just whether there are ten or only nine children is an issue which will be determined in the Brooklyn City Court when four ejectment suits, which were begun yesterday before Judge Clement by Mrs. Patrick Flannery of Cornwall-on-the-Hudson, come to trial.

A final decision in the Copper Trust cases has been made by the Court of Appeals in France. Several mining companies -- among them the Rio Tinto in Spain and the Tamarack in this country -- sought to obtain from SECRETAN'S company, the Societe des Metaux, damages for failure to abide by the terms of the ring contracts by which the great combination was formed.

The suits of Amos R. Eno against the elevated railroad company, in which United States District Attorney Edward Mitchell, Mr. Eno's attorney, declares that he is ready to waive the claim for damages and go to trial only on the question of an injunction, were again called before Justice Andrews, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday.

Sergius Stepniak, the Russian exile and leader of the Russian revolutionary party, sails to-day from Liverpool on the Umbria, and his first public appearance in this country will be at the Metropolitan Opera House, Jan. 8, 1891, when he will deliver a lecture. Mr. Stepniak's personal experience has furnished him with an ample fund of interesting information about the dark political and social systems of Russian.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Not since the Republican Senators began their champagne caucuses at the house of Mr. Sawyer and concluded at the house of Mr. Cameron have they been in such a hopeless tangle as they are to-night. The most clear-sighted of the band of partisans cannot see what is to be the outcome.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- It is reported that the new British protected cruiser Latona has gone ashore.

American Judges are, as a rule, so timid about expressing their views upon the conduct of litigants that the remarks of Judge ANDREWS, in a suit against the elevated railroads that came before him yesterday, are particularly refreshing. This is not one of the cases in which the corporation appears to the worst advantage. It was not a suit for damages, but an application for an injunction against the running of trains on the roads.

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 19. -- This city needs a new Post Office, and, moreover, its need is urgent. For fifteen years its postal facilities have been inadequate, and now that last Saturday's fire has made vacant a very eligible site upon its principal business thoroughfare the hops is generally expressed that action will be taken to secure the ground before it is again built upon.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 19. -- The New's special from the camp on Cheyenne River, by courier to Rapid City, says: About 2 o'clock P.M. a soldier was seen coming down the bluff, his horse at a full gallop. The rider crossed the river and reported to Gen. Carr that Capt. Stanton was in an engagement with the Indians. Gen. Carr gave orders for Lieut. Scott and Troop D to go to his assistance.

In the matter of the widening and the extension of Tremont Avenue from the old Macomb's Dam Avenue to the Boston Road, a proceeding which has been pending before the Board of Street Opening and Improvement since July, 1884, the board receded from its long-maintained position yesterday and adopted a resolution providing for its opening under the provisions of the Annexation act.

The lawyers for the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company have obtained from Judge Beach leave to serve a supplemental answer in the suit brought in the Supreme Court by the electric lighting companies to enjoin the subway company from cutting out their cables for failure to pay the rentals demanded for the use of the conduits, and to have a proper rate of rental fixed by the court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- For the first time in many years the public, which has been paying a good deal of money to Mr. John I. Davenport for his work as Chief Supervisor of Elections, is permitted to see what his labors have cost. At different times efforts have been made to secure these statements at the Treasury Department, but it has always been found difficult to get them.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Twenty-five prominent citizens of Bridgeport, Conn., including the Mayor, President of the Board of Trade, members of the Assembly, Senators, and editors arrived here to-day. They were the guests of the Rochester Railway Company, and their visit was for the purpose of inspecting the electric street-car plant of this city. The party left for home at midnight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- A bill will be introduced in the Illinois Legislature this Winter having for its object the legalizing of slave marriages. Two years ago a similar attempt was made, but so late in the season as to be ineffective. The thing that more than anything else brought out the original bill was the decision by Judge Tuley in 1888 in the case of Bond against Kilvery and others.

MISSOULA, Mon., Dec. 19. -- The most notable execution which ever took place in this section of the country occurred this morning, when La Laze and Pierre Paul, Antly, and Pascale, four Indian murderers, were hanged at the Court House here. All were cut down twenty minutes after the trap was sprung. Their necks were broken.

BERLIN, Dec 20. -- Prof. Koch. on his visit to William Walter Phelps, the American Minister, at the Legation, yesterday, passed through the anteroom, which was full of eager American doctors who were waiting to see the Minister, with the hope of procuring his good offices in securing for them interviews with the professor.

The beginning of one of Lord Beaconsfield's speeches upon the question of the housing of the London poor was particularly characteristic. As the speech must necessarily be largely of a statistical character, he exclaimed at the outset: "Gentlemen, I hate statistics!"

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Dec. 20. -- Laborers in this vicinity are delighted at the prospect of employment in the cutting of ice within the next few days. The Central Railroad of New-Jersey is filling all of its side tracks and branches with empty box cars to be loaded and sent forward to fill the icehouses of the "United Ice Lines" along the seashore resorts and the barges of many of the New-York City companies.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 20. -- The Journal's Rapid City (S.D.) special says:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20. -- The present working schedule proving unsatisfactory, railroad and steamboat officers interested have had a meeting to equalize the rates of the various water and rail lines connecting with New-York, Philadelphia, Norfolk, and Baltimore. The result of the meeting is that the Dispatch Line is thrown open for business to and from Baltimore to the Clyde Line.
