CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- There were no new attractions and few changes in the bills at the theatres this last week. Mansfield continued to draw large audiences to the Columbia with "Beau Brummell" during the last week of his engagement and one night played "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" to a packed house.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20. -- The Jersey Republican protectionist has continued to show the inconsistency of his theory this week. The strike in the big Clark Thread Works at Newark is not only still on, but it grows worse each day. It would be hard to imagine anything more deliberate than the cruelty practiced by the managers of the thread company upon the hundreds of employes.

The first annual report of the Isabella Heimath has just been issued, and shows the institution to be in flourishing condition. The Isabella Heimath comprises a home for indigent persons at least sixty years of age, hospital for the treatment of chronic invalids without means, and a convalescent ward in which convalescents in need of care and rest after an acute disease or a surgical operation are admitted for a limited time.

The Emperor was present a few weeks ago in Berlin at the first sitting of the School Reform Committee. An abstract of his remarks on that occasion has already been printed here, but further points are interesting. When the discussion was opened the Emperor expounded his own views on educational reform in a speech lasting more than half an hour.

The Executive Committee of the Harlem Republican Club has been engaged for several weeks investigating charges of conduct unbecoming a gentleman made against Herrmann M. Herzog by several members of the club. Three meetings were held, and a large number of witnesses were examined. The troubles of Mr. Herzog, who is a Prussian by birth, arose over a game of pool played in the clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Mrs. Harrison having successfully accomplished the task of dressing a handsome doll for the bazaar in New-York, has been giving her time and attention to the selection of presents for her immediate family, which includes, of course, her three grandchildren, as the preparation of the Christmas tree for the little ones is an all-important event in the White House.

The Rev. John Larkin, one of the irremovable rectors of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New-York, a member of the Archbishop's council, and for twenty-nine years pastor of the Church of the Holy Innocents, in West Thirty-seventh Street, died last evening of pneumonia, in the seventieth year of his age, after an illness of a few days. Father Larkin was born in Deer Park, County Galway, Ireland, and was graduated from Maynooth College in 1843.

A public address by Gen. Benjamin F. Butler, is a rarity nowadays. His lecture upon Wendell Phillips last night in Tremont Temple was an occasion of unusual interest. The General talked in his old-time style. His characteristic sly humor cropped out at frequent intervals. For the most part his delivery was quiet and suppressed.

Of the many New-Yorkers who enjoy those delicacies, turtle soup and turtle steak, few know where New-York obtains her supply of these clumsy marine reptiles, how they are captured, or anything about their habits. The turtle is essentially a warm-water reptile, and is rarely found north of Morehead City, N.C. To find him in perfection one must go to the tropical waters of Florida.
Christmas gifts of home manufacture are the popular fad this holiday season, and elaborate directions for their preparation multiply as the jingle of Kris Kringle's bells sounds nearer and clearer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,380,400, as follows: Currency 6s, $6,760,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $27,317,700, 4 per cents, $106,302,700.

Judge Richard O'Gorman was signally honored last night by his fellow-members of the Lotos Club, the club making him its guest upon the occasion of its second "Lotos dinner" of the current season, The desire of the club was to exhibit the high appreciation which its members have of the distinguished services which Judge O'Gorman rendered during the many years that he sat upon the bench from which he has just retired.

In the debatable region of "inference and conjecture" lies the question, "Are the effects of use and disuse inherited?" In the present volume this topic is discussed, and in opposition to Mr. Herbert Spencer, and even to Darwin, Mr. Ball argues against the inheritance of certain conditions in animal life as brought about by use or disuse. The selection of the fittest, however, the author does not for a moment question.

AMHERST, Dec. 20. -- The new catalogue appeared this week after a long delay. Among the new members of the Faculty are President Merrill Edward Gates, Ph. D., LL. D., L. H. D.; Henry Gibbons, M. A., Professor of Greek, and Frank M. Colby, M. A., Instructor in History. The summary shows a total of 5 Fellows and resident graduates, 84 Seniors, 90 Juniors, 100 Sophomores, and 73 Freshmen, a grand total of 352.

Nathaniel Niles, ex-President of the Tradesmen's National Bank, sat for over two hours in the Sheriff's office yesterday, in custody of Deputy Sheriff Terry, waiting for bail in order that he might not be obliged to go to Ludlow Street Jail. Mr. Niles had been arrested in a suit brought by Mme. Eliza Parret, to recover $73,000, representing money and chattels out of which she charges he defrauded her.

In a letter giving some information about the duties now imposed by Mexico upon live stock brought in from this country, the Mexican Minister at Washington writes to the editor of the Engineering and Mining Journal as follows concerning our new duties on silver-lead ores:

The daily life of paying teller in a city bank can scarcely be called exciting. And yet, he handles millions of money and has to face all sorts and conditions of men; youth, age, guilt, guiltlessness, honesty, and knavery, all framing themselves in his little wicket window during the hours from 10 to 3. The latter apparition, however, is comparatively infrequent, and months and even years glide by in unbroken routine.

The Society of American Artists, the Architectural League of New-York, and the Art Students' League, moved by the common purpose of securing a permanent home which would serve as a clubhouse for the members and fellows of the societies, as a place where instruction in the fine arts could be given, and where the work of artists could be exhibited, formed over a year ago an organization known as the American Fine Arts Society.

Count Herbert Bismarck, after spending five weeks with different friends in England, has arrived in Paris. Our correspondent there writes: "He has come chiefly in search of distractions,' which was also his object north of the Channel. Whether the search has been so far successful is more than doubtful, as he is looking a sad and depressed man, wearing the appearance of one from whom the tide has flowed.

A contest has begun in the Surrogate's Court over the will of Thomas Monaghan, who died Sept. 11 last, leaving an estate valued at about $500,000, and the matter will come up before Surrogate Ransom this week, when Mr. Charles H. Beckett of Boaraem, Hamilton Beckett will argue an application to have the decree admitting the will to probate set aside.

The Goethe Society of this city, founded fifteen years ago with the object of spreading and popularizing the thoughts of the great German poet, celebrated its anniversary with a banquet at the Hotel Brunswick last evening. About one hundred ladies and gentlemen were seated around a great flower-burdened table, spread in the Oriental dining room. An orchestra, under the direction of Frank Howson, served to make pass merrily the two hours devoted to the dinner.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20. -- The new college catalogue, which will be ready for distribution in a few days, is of special interest this year, as it shows the great advance made by the college during the past year. It announces a number of new courses open to Juniors and Seniors, the appointment of several new instructors, as well as additional prizes and scholarships.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad held in Boston yesterday the agreement approved by the Western railroad Presidents at J. Pierpont Morgan's house last Monday was unanimously adopted. President Manvel and Chairman George C. Magoun were appointed to represent the company in the proposed Advisory Board.

The detective camera is likely to play an important part in National Guard instruction hereafter, in the event of the undertaking set in motion by Major Heywood C. Broun, Inspector of Rifle Practice Twenty-third Regiment, proving the success it promises. Photography is proposed to be employed by Major Broun in perfecting the officers and non-commissioned officers first, and subsequently the rank and file of "Ours" in rifle practice.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 20. -- Pittsburg iron manufacturers are devoting much attention just now to the subject fuel for their furnaces and boilers. For almost a decade past natural gas has supplanted coal hereabout as a fuel for all classes of manufacture. Recently, however, there has been such a marked decrease in the supply of natural gas that there has been an enforced resort to coal or other fuel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Secretary Noble has withdrawn his order suspending the approval of the final adjustment of the land grants in favor of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway Company and the Wisconsin Central Railroad Company. These adjustments were approval on Feb. 12, 1890, but subsequently suspended because of pending legislation in Congress looking to the forfeiture of railroad lands where the roads were not completed within the time fixed by law.

One of the largest folios for the holiday season is a series of fac similes of water colors by eight artist, published in sumptuous binding and with bold letter press by the E.A. Stokes Company. "A Late Arrival" by W.T. Smedley opens the volume; it is scene from the Summer boarding house with a bashfull youth running the gantlet of a dozen critical pairs of eyes as he walks down the piazza.

A tale of roses and roguery is wafted from the last midsummer days. It was at a seaside resort, and a young man, a veritable Prince Charming before whom all women go down and who cannot help "practicing" when he is near a pretty girl, was at his usual occupation -- devoted to several of them at once. He counted, in fact, this time four victims to his attractions.

There are some distinctive features about this edition of Blackstone which are likely to commend themselves. Usually editors of the commentaries are a little too ambitious. They seek by means of their foot notes and other annotations to make a kind of legal digest of the work. American editors have been especially prone to do this.

There is nothing doing in the market and hasn't been for a week; which, however, is not wholly to be regretted. Perhaps it's about the best thing, like going slowly through a rocky channel in a fog. The railroad meeting fell awfully flat. Mr. Gould had not expected much public enthusiasm over it, but even he was surprised at the flatness with which it fell.

An attempt was made yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to sink the big double-turreted monitor Terror. The vessel is now lying in the new Simpson dry dock with thirty inches of water in her hold. Every attempt is being made rapidly to free her of water, but owing to the crude appliances at hand the work is necessarily slow.

An inquiry, made as carefully as the circumstances would permit, of the feeling entertained by the Irish-Americans in the principal cities which the delegates from Ireland have visited, on the subject of their support or non-support of Mr. Parnell, gives some interesting results. In New-York the feeling among the representative Irish organizations upon the question of Parnell's leadership seems to be evenly divided.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- Before the November election Mr. William F. Sheehan of Buffalo, who was confident that the Democrats would carry the next Assembly and that he would succeed Gen. Husted as Speaker, was quoted as saying that he believed in announcing the Assembly committees the day the Speaker was chosen, and thus abolishing the ten days' recess usually taken after the Assembly is organized to enable the Speaker to make up his committees.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 20. -- The Kansas delegation to the Ocala Convention has returned, and the various members have announced that they will devote the remainder of the time between now and the 27th of January to perfecting such an organization among Alliance members of the Legislature as will certainly defeat Senator Ingalls.

M. Gambetta, the father of the great French statesman, after suffering long from cancer in the stomach, says our Paris correspondent, died on Thursday in his seventy-sixth year. He was quite uneducated, but was shrewd and gentle-mannered, with much half-hidden fire and mother wit. He traveled a great deal as an itinerant dealer when he was young, and even pushed as far as Turkey and Egypt.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- The trial of Michael Eyraud and Gabrielle Bompard for the murder of Notary Gouffe was concluded in the Assize Court to-day. The crowd of spectators was the largest since the trial began. The physical and mental strain imposed by the trial is beginning to tell upon the prisoners, both of whom to-day plainly showed evidences of the fatigue and anxiety to which they have been subjected.

Messrs. D. Appleton Co. of this city would he very glad to know what persons are covered by the high-sounding business title, "The Evans Publishing and Engraving Company," for a book purporting to have issued from a house of that name contains forty illustrations reproduced by photographic process from illustrations contained in the Appletons' "New-York Illustrated."

The chances for early naval legislation during the present session of Congress are as yet uncertain. This is due to the preponderance of election and financial measures. At the same time it is recognized that Congress, in order to be consistent with the announced policy of the majority to continue the enhancement of the naval establishment, cannot long delay action.

From time to time there has arisen in France some one to protest against the abusive use of titles, the latest objector being M. Emile Moreau, who represents the Fifth Electoral District of Lille in the Chamber of Deputies M. Moreau is a civil engineer of some note, and was ever an uncompromising enemy of Gen. Benlanger. As a panacea he has proposed the levying of a tax on all titles.

KILKENNY, Dec. 20. -- To-day is practically the Parnellites' battle eve. To-morrow (Sunday) will be fatal to them, for it will be a field day for the priests, who are anti-Parnellite. The closing hours of the struggle are marked by great tension and nervous excitement on both sides, each feeling the tremendous weight of the issues of Monday's poll.

The spirit of the forefathers pervaded the beautifully-decorated banquet hall of the New-England Society of Brooklyn at the Art Assembly Rooms last night. Stanch Miles Standish was the hero of the hour, and the mention of his name only was necessary to elicit hearty outbursts of enthusiasm. Recollections of the Pilgrims were suggested in every device of the caterer.

The Canadian Government he apparently been taking some practical lessons from our own in regard to the enforcement of its tariff law. There is a duty on American potatoes imported into Canada, and several of the Dominion farmers are now having the existence of this tariff brought to their knowledge in a forcible and somewhat unpleasant manner.

The new clubhouse of the Alpha Delta Phi Club, at the corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, was thrown open to the members of the club last evening under the most agreeable conditions. Fully 350 members were present and took advantage of the occasion to renew old college associations. Every chapter of the society was represented.

A very serious problem confronts the management of the Metropolitan Opera House. Upon its wise solution depends the future of the institution. The problem is how to provide this public with something other than Wagner which will prove to be attractive. Up to the present time the financial exhibit of the current season is a striking argument against all opposition to Wagner.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- The decision of the New-York Board of Appraisal, which yesterday advanced the valuation of Passavant Co.'s importation of Suede gloves, was the topic of conversation to-day among Boston glove importers.

One of the most successful athletic entertainments given in this city was held at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, when the championships -- boxing and wrestling -- of the Amateur Athletic Union were decided. The crowd was fair and orderly and the sport was of a first-class character.

HAMrXX, H. S., Dec. 20. -- It is now behoved that nine men perishes in the disaster at Ounard's Wharf last night, caused by a section of the structure giving way under the weight of a large pile of coal, which had been unloaded from vessel. The bodies of two of the men, Brown and Dun, were recovered this afternoon.

A gentleman of an inquiring turn of mind asked Chauncey M. Depew some time ago how many railroad nicknames there were. The New-York Central's President blandly replied, "Just as many as you have a mind to make."

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 20. -- The Tribune's special from Pierre, S.D., says: "ranchman named Tom Hetlund, residing thirty-five miles up Bad River, arrived to-day, and what he tells creates a decided sensation, as he is a reliable witness. He says a peaceable, Christianized, and semi-civilized tribe of Two Kettle Sioux are now seized with sudden frenzy and are imitating the wildest orgies of the ghost dance indulged in by the hostiles.

The first game of indoor baseball for the championship of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association was played in the armory building last evening between the teams of Companies B and F, and resulted in a victory for the team of the latter company by a score of 33 to 6. From behind the netting which guarded the spectators, a large number of persons witnessed the rather one-sided contest.

BATON ROUGE, La. Dec. 20. -- Joseph Storey, a white man about forty years of age, was killed on the Greenwell Springs Road last night by William Tisdale, who reached Baton Rouge this evening and surrendered to the Sheriff. Tisdale was in town yesterday and left in wagon which also contained Emile Victor and Steven R. Verbois. Just out of town they met John L. Powers, who resides in their neighborhood.

Prof. James E. Keeler, who is connected with the Lick Observatory in California, gave an interesting lecture at the rooms of the Camera Club on Thursday evening upon astronomical photography as practiced at the observatory, and illustrated his remarks with some lantern slides which were excellent in their make, as well as giving some of the best specimens of star photography.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- Some circumstances of a peculiarly sad nature in connection with the recent suicide of ex-Senator Frank B. Arnold of Unadilla have just come to public knowledge. Mr. Arnold was born in County Clare, Ireland, in 1839, and came to this country as an orphan boy and under his proper family and baptismal name of Michael Edwards.

KILKENNY, Dec. 20. -- Mr. Parnell made another speech this evening. In the course of his remarks he said: "In 1875 God told me to put my hands to the plow, and I obeyed." He concluded his speech as follows:

It has been widely rumored during the past few days that the medical professors at the Pasteur Institute have been carrying on experiments in the cure of tuberculosis concurrently with Dr. Koch, and that the result of their researches has appeared to differ from that reached by the German savant. In order to discover whether this interesting report might be true, I called this morning at the Ecole Bacteriologique.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- Col. Richard M. Muckle, business manager of the Public Ledger, called upon Register of Wills Gratz to-day and handed over to him two letters which had been forwarded to Mr. George W. Childs. In presenting the letters to Register Gratz, Col. Muckle stated that Mr. Childs was in total ignorance as to who had sent them to him.

An uncommonly cordial greeting between two young men in Broadway, near Madison Square, a few days ago, attracted the attention of a few passersby. The young men were evidently warm friends and had not seen each other for a long time. After a few words had been exchanged one of the friends exclaimed: "By Jove, Tom, I am so glad to see you that we must go in and have a bottle of wine."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- For the simple reason that the Republican majority has not yet found but just how to let go of the Force bill, that discredited measure is still the "unfinished business" before the Senate.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The election at Bassetlaw, resulting in the return of the Conservative candidate, Sir Frederick Milner, by a majority of 723 votes, was an unpleasant surprise for the Liberals. The partisan press, as customary, has spared no effort on the one side to enhance the victory and on the other to extenuate its importance.

Many devious devices are adopted by impecunious stockjobbers who hang about the Bourse to influence the course of the markets to their own pecuniary advantage, but when they resort to the dissemination of false telegrams, the law steps in with a severe punishment. A broker named Arnould, and an individual who described himself as a "musician," were charged at the Assizes of the Department of the Neurthe et Moselle with an offense of this description.

The proposition of Mr. PLATT of Connecticut to appropriate $10,000 to enable the President to take action to obtain from the German Government a supply of the remedy discovered by Dr. KOOH and the formula for its manufacture is the latest and the most curious example of the tendency to paternalism in the minds of some of our statesmen.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 20. -- The approaching holiday season adds to the gayety and prosperity of Lakewood. The shops are made as attractive as those of a village suburb of New-York can be made, and the express wagons go heavily laden about the streets from morning to night. Presents come and presents go, and the smiles of the shopkeepers, the givers, and the recipients keep them pleasant company upon their gladsome pilgrimage.

The Philadelphia Telegraph thinks that Uncle Jere Rusk has been losing his grip upon his rural admirers ever since he left the "Wisconsin wilderness" to take a seat in the chief chair of the Agricultural Department. His latest blunder, the Telegraph says, was to invite some back-country friends to come up to dinner at 6 o'clock. Commenting on this invitation, the Telegraph remarks:

MONTREAL, Dec. 20. -- The cattle trade of Canada is in peril. Under the present arrangement Canadian cattle are permitted to be landed at English ports without any restrictions. They are then grazed in English pastures, and after they have recovered the weight lost by the hardships of the ocean voyage, and when the proper moment to suit the markets arrives, they are killed and offered for sale.

The Philadelphia Telegraph thinks that Uncle Jere Rusk has been losing his grip upon his rural admirers ever since he left the "Wisconsin wilderness" to take a seat in the chief chair of the Agricultural Department. His latest blunder, the Telegraph says, was to invite some back-country friends to come up to dinner at 6 o'clock. Commenting on this invitation, the Telegraph remarks:

Two of the largest of the colored churches of this city, the Second African Baptist and the Bryan Baptist, are having trouble of so serious a character that it is a question whether the congregation of each of them will not be broken up. And the trouble in each congregation grows out of differences relative to its minister. Savannah has been noted for a long time for the number of her colored churches.

A second article by "Adalet" on the harem appears in the new Nineteenth Century. "Adalet" is the first literary young lady whom the harem has produced. The editor vouches for it that her productions are absolutely genuine, and that the authoress has been for ten years the inmate of a harem. "Adalet" gives us the latest news from this famed region of mystery and romance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20. -- The steamship Mariposa arrived from Australia via Honolulu to-day.

Christmas at an army post in the far Southwest is somewhat different from Christmas in the cities of the Northern States. Let us look at one small garrison of Uncle Sam's small army. The buildings of sombre brown are quite unpretentious and stand, awkward and lonely, around the sides of a rectangle. One side is devoted to the officers' quarters -- that is, the line.

BERLIN, Dee. 20. -- The niunber of the American doctors who have been waiting here trying to get some of the Koch lymph is fast being dimlnisheck 8evoral of them u0oeeded in prooaring small upplies for use in their private practice before Prof. Koch issued his prohibition limiting the supply of lymph to hospitals or medical colleges. ho maJori have returned without the lymph, but weighted with expertene acqttired in studying eases.

While everybody has heard of the proposed viaduct at Washington Heights, there are probably only very few persons outside the circle of those directly concerned who have anything like an adequate conception of the magnitude and importance of this work. It is hardly enough to say of it that it will be the greatest piece of engineering of the kind in the world.

ROME, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- A successful test of the Justin dynamite shell, invented by Dr. Joel G. Justin of Syracuse, was made at Perryville Falls, Madison County, this afternoon. To-day's experiments have proved all that the inventor has claimed, and the result proves that dynamite can be safely fired in large quantities by the force of gunpowder.

The eyes of the politicians are now turned toward Albany and their ears are straining to catch such bits of information as they can as to the probabilities and the possibilities of the coming session of the Legislature. When they are not discussing the Senatorial question or the possible Chairmen of committees of the House, they speculate on the character of the proposed legislation for this city.

THE NOBLE TURKEY. -- The chroniclers and ballad-makers record many anecdotes of the geniality and readiness of adaptation to circumstances which made Henri Quatre so popular among his subjects. Not long before the great battle of Ivry, he was lodging in a country house in the character of an inferior officer.

The Board of Aldermen granted yesterday a surface-car franchise to run from the East to the North River through the transverse road of the Central Park at Eighty-fifth Street. This franchise the Controller was authorized to sell at public auction.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- Theodore Roosevelt of the Civil-Service Commission was the first of the special guests at the dinner of the Commercial Club in the house of the Algonquin Club tonight, and he talked to his hosts of civil-service reform.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- It is more than likely that no Finance bill will be passed at this session of Congress. Mr. Sherman is reported to have told his fellow-members of the Finance Committee that he would not press the remarkable "compromise" measure indorsed at the Republican Senatorial caucus Wednesday night.

There is little yellow fever yet in Rio, but the weather is exceedingly hot. Yesterday, after a regular scorcher, we went out to ride between 4 an 6 o'clock P.M., and within that less than two hours' time we saw eight funeral processions, and one uncoffined boby being carried to the cemetery on a curtained stretcher.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20. -- King Kalakaua is considerably cast down over the withdrawal of the Sherman resolution. He had fondly anticipated that through some favorable legislation he would be enabled to restore the credit of his kingdom and make a loan.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- The present Winter is proving highly satisfactory to the lumbermen who are engaged in denuding the Adirondack region of its choicest timber, and hundreds of men and teams now find employment in the lumber camps along all the large streams in Northern New-York. The snow in this part of the State is now nearly two feet in depth.

The annual Christmas festival given by the German Charity Society of Deaf-Mutes last night in the Beethoven Maennerchor Hall, in Fifth Street, was largely attended, and although in the nature of the case the tokens of approval were not vociferous, the faces of young and old were expressive of keen enjoyment from first to last. Although an unearthly quiet pervaded the hall, the scene was animated.

You should never judge a man by appearances. Because a human face is not like a signboard on a grocery store, put there to tell you what's inside. Very often it's more like a three-sheet poster in front of an east side theatre, all covered with promises that the management can't fulfill. Which is the moral of this tale.

Just now there is more than the usual activity in the clubs. It is the season of annual elections, and members who are candidates themselves or who have friends who desire official places may be seen at all hours about the particular club in which they are most interested. Qualifications of the many aspirants for club honors are discussed and arguments used to influence votes whenever there is a contest.

I met my friend Smith again the other evening at the club. He was stretched out in one of the easiest of the easy chairs of the smoking room. His cigar, though in hand, had gone out. His eyes were uprolled, as if studying the part-of his hair. He was thinking.

Under the new law providing for State care of the insane the Commission in Lunacy has been engaged since early in October in removing patients from the county poorhouses and so-called asylums to the State hospitals. The number of insane in the county institutions on the 1st of October was 2,050, and it has been reduced to 1,741.

-- The January volume of the Great Writers' Series will be a sketch of Thackeray. It was begun by Herman Merivale and completed by Frank T. Marzials. Use has been made of some unpublished material relating to Thackeray's early life.

It is not surprising to those who have a knowledge of Central American affairs that the recent complications between Guatemala and San Salvador were so soon followed by revolutionary disturbances in Honduras.

All of the patients in the hospitals who have been inoculated with the lymph did well yesterday. In some instances the improvement was marked. Those patients who are under treatment for lung trouble were in an especially satisfactory condition. They said that their coughs were less troublesome and their respiration was easier.

TUCSON, Arizona, Dec. 21. -The word contrast fails to convey any conception of the differences to be found between Arizona and anything in the East. Though smaller than New-Mexico by 5,000,000 acres, Arizona is still large enough to contain the States of New-York, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and Maryland combined, and one of its counties, Yavapal, is about as large as the State of Maine.

At the Washington Post Office there is collection of old envelopes and postal cards that would be entitled to a place in the most curious of old curiosity shops. The collection has been made by Mr. C.M. Merrill, head clerk of the city distributing case, who has secured the specimens after the persons for whom they were intended had read the communications.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 21. -- A fire bug got in some effective wore here Saturday night and Sunday morning, kindling two extensive fires. The first destroyed the lumber yard of Osborne Brothers at White and Canal Streets and six loaded freight cars on a siding of the Housatonic Road adjoining, and partly destroyed the Housatonic freight house.
What would a Virginia Christmas be without eggnog!

" Ganelon," William Young's play, in which Lawrence Barrett is to appear at the Broadway Theatre Jan. 5, is in four acts and five scenes. The first scene is laid in Colonna's palace, and the second in an audience chamber of the palace. Scene three shows the gates of the city, the fourth the camp of the Saracens, and the fifth a grand banquet hall.

Village tragedies are common enough in France, but that which lately occurred in the Commune of Saint Dorat, in Auvergne, was of so startling a character that it merits chronicling. A bride and bridegroom who were returning home after their wedding, accompanied by their friends in festive array, were shot dead, and their murderer has since committed suicide.

KILKENNY, Dec. 21. -- Mr. Parnell and Mr. Scully, the Parnellite candidate for Parliament, left here at noon to-day and drove in a closed carriage to Clare. They were accompanied by a long procession of cars filled with Parnell's supporters. Upon arriving at Clare, the Parnellites found a meeting proceeding, opposite the Catholic chapel, in support of Sir John Pope Hennessey.

What must be the state of mind of the Republican managers in Washington regarding the Force bill? They have thrown away the first third of the short session upon it and have not made one step toward disposing of it. It stands day by day a sort of legislative dog in the manager, unable to get anything for itself and crowding out every other measure.

Detective John Foley, who was recently transferred to Inspector Byrnes's bureau at the Central Office, will it is feared die at St. Vincent's Hospital of injuries inflicted at 10:30 o'clock last night by an Italian butcher, Antonio Bissolano, who cut Foley nearly down to the spine with a cleaver weighing five pounds.

According to the press reports from Washington there is to be no formal recess for the holidays such as has been usual with both houses. There will be an adjournment only from Wednesday to Monday, and the remainder of the time, probably for this week and next, will be filled up with such business as can be carried on without the presence of a quorum.

Even in a dry and formal decision of the Treasury Department concerning the tariff laws there may be found something that should not be overlooked by those who seek to promote the gayety of nations. The department publishes the following rebuke to a kind-hearted Collector of Customs who has incurred its displeasure by extending the hospitality of the Republic to the unfortunate offspring of American cows residing temporarily abroad:
BOONVILLE, Mo., Dec. 21. -- A sensation was produced here this morning by the discovery that John Oscar Turlington had again broken jail.

ATHOL, Mass., Dec. 21. -- The most disastrous fire ever known in Athol occurred to-day. The Masonic and Central blocks were completely destroyed, five merchants, the Post Office, Masonic rooms, , being burned out. A.C. Porter, George Burnham, L.C. Perry, and William Connor of Orange, firemen, were seriously injured by falling walls, Perry probably fatally.

There is no reason to doubt the statement that Tammany will endeavor to work sundry schemes for its own benefit through the Legislature at the coming session. It counts for success upon the rather narrow majority of Democrats in the Assembly and the expected defection of several Republican Senators from the Platt leadership.

There has been no instance in many years of more cruel and cowardly political persecution than that of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE of Arkansas by the Republican majority. We published recently a dispatch from Little Rock stating that a detective by the name of WOOD, who had been investigating the killing of CLAYTON, was believed to have discovered evidence that it was done by a gang of thieves.

The Central Labor Federation met yesterday and listened to a report of its delegate to the convention of the American Federation of Labor, who had been denied admittance because he also represented the Socialistic Labor Party. Samuel Gompers, he said, had been his principal opponent although that gentleman himself inclined toward Socialism.

The Navy Department is reported to be strongly considering the advisability of building the Ammen harbor-defense ram at the Boston Navy Yard. Bids for the construction of this new war ship were opened Saturday at the Navy Department, but none were deemed satisfactory. In consequence, the Secretary of the Navy must either advertise for new proposals or order the ship built at a navy yard.
LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Mr. Gladstone, in his letter to Sir Robert Peel's grandson, (Speaker Peel's son,) who is the home rule candidate in the Marylebone District, says:

Five hundred dapper gentlemen, in tight trousers and cutaway coats, gathered in the main audience chamber of Tammany Hall last evening and gazed earnestly at the bronze clock over the stage. Their locks were dark and curly, most of them wore toothpick mustaches and diamond rings, and there was about them that peculiar aspect of solicitude and affability which only a prosperous "boss" barber can assume.

The new edifice of the Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, was dedicated yesterday with appropriate services in the morning, afternoon, and evening. The first service of the day was the celebration of the sacrament of the Lord's Supper, which was administered by the pastor of the church, the Rev. James R. Day, D.D.

It is probable that substantial justice has been done by the verdict in the trial of EYRAUD and GABRIELLE BOMPARD, which ended in Paris Saturday. If ever a wretch was shown to be deserving of death by the guillotine EYRAUD was the man, and the sentence pronounced will arouse no sympathy for him.

Capt. Robert L. Meade, United States Marine Corps, has raised a storm of indignation among the seaman gunners stationed at the Washington Navy Yard. In all there are thirty-seven gunners undergoing an advanced course of instruction aboard the receiving ship Dale, and in an attempt to strengthen the conservative side of the naval reorganization argument Capt. Meade has denounced the seaman gunners as being wholly untrustworthy when freed from restraint.

Next to a horse, Senator Stanford loves a horse trade. The other day he was in his committee room and his private secretary, Mr. John B. McCarthy, was guarding the exterior of the door with characteristic vigilance, when a clerical-looking and venerable gentleman ascended the stairway and inquired of the secretary as to the whereabouts of the Senator.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- During the past week discount was not in demand. Money was plentiful. Discount rates were quoted at 3 34 for three months and 3 for short. The German drain of gold amounted during the week to 1,163,000. The withdrawals have now ceased, while the influx into the Bank of England from Brazil and Australia maintain a reserve of bullion sufficient to meet further demands.

Prof. Tessier of the medical faculty of Lyons has returned from Russia, whither he was sent last March to take evidence upon the course of influenza there and the various conditions of its evolution. I have had a conversation with him. Dr. Tessier began his sojourn at St. Petersburg, where he staid for some time. He also went to Moscow, Klev, and Warsaw. Scientists in all these cities readily gave him information.

The sympathetic influence of the London troubles touched New-York and there was a sharp calling in of resources. How much the restoration of confidence has been obstructed by the menace of unlimited silver coinage it is impossible to say, but the New-York flurry would be the occasion for the manifestation of any such obstruction.
The Indianapolis Journal, which represents the Administration at the President's home, asserts that "the Democratic organs have been lying about the advance in canned meats." and also says:

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Henry Christiansen, sixty-one years old, choked his aged wife to death in the bedroom of his home, at 7,109 Drexel Avenue, and cut his own throat some time during last night. The tragedy was seen by no one, and the exact time it occurred is unknown.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Robert H.S. Mitchell of New-York was arrested on Saturday at Jersey City by Officer Conlin of Elizabeth on a warrant issued by Justice Rogers of this place, at the instance of W. Phillips of New-York, who charges that Mitchell, J.G. Schull, W.H. Clough, and B.C. Peters, alleged officers of the Holland Building and Loan Association of New-York, conspired to swindle him out of a lot of money.

" What must be the frame of mind of a writer who has finished such a work as that which Mr. Lecky, after nineteen years of toll, has just brought to completion?" asks a writer in the Pall Mall Gazette. "He cannot be tormented by the artistic yearning for ideal perfection, for within its limits this product of unerring analysis and patient research is perfect.

-- The Sun Dial. A Poem by Austin Dobson. Drawings and Decorations by George Wharton Edwards. New-York: Dodd, Mead Co. 1890. -- In the metre and the manner of Gray's "Elegy," the pretty, dainty poem by Austin Dobson offers a good many themes to a decorator and illustrator who is gifted with as much fancy as Mr. Edwards.

HARTFORD, Dec. 21. -- A Tammany brave who hailed originally from this State recently startled a group of local politicians by the assertion that Connecticut was expected to send a solid delegation for David B. Hill to the next Democratic National Convention. This was coupled with the assertion that Indiana and New-York would do the same thing.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- There is nothing on the surface here to indicate which way the Senatorial contest will turn in the next week. The Hill forces are as dumb as oysters, but not particularly cheerful. Mark Eustace, the lieutenant whom Gov. Hill put into an examiner's place in the Bank Department, reached here from Elmira to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- A special to the Ledger from Delaware Breakwater says: For a Christmas present, William Cramp Sons of Philadelphia will hand to Uncle Sam the new cruiser Newark, which to-day successfully passed the ordeal of an official trial trip, and proved to the officers composing the Trial Board that an addition, had been made to the new navy of more than usual excellence.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Mrs. Ezra Holden, well known to people connected with philanthropic and charitable institutions, has prepared a new plan for the collection of the tax on liquors. The plan proposed involves a neat box securely locked by the excise officer and containing a coil of coupon tickets numbered consecutively from 1 up to 1,000; a self-numbering apparatus, dating device, self-registering dial, and a belt.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 22. -- The first definite action looking to the determination of important questions involving the organization of the House of Representatives in the next Legislature, upon which organization the political complexion of the State Government for the next two years largely depends, was taken today, and has occasioned no little surprise and some trepidation in Republican circles, to say the least.

The catalogue of Dartmouth College for 1890-91 has been issued and contains such information as is ordinarily given in a college catalogue. Two hundred and sixty-two students are listed in the catalogue. Two hundred and fifty-six of these are students in the college proper, 48 being Seniors, 55 Juniors, 69 Sophomores, and 84 Freshmen. The remainder is divided as follows: Chandler Scientific School, 63; Agricultural School, 36; Medical School, 98; Thayer School of Engineering, 9.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 22. -- The commission appointed by the Legislature three years ago to confer with a Rhode Island commission in regard to the adjustment of a disputed State boundary line, held a conference with the Rhode Island Commissioners at Willimantic Saturday, but no agreement was reached.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Miss Rebecca Dunson would not let the fact that she was supposed to be on her deathbed interfere with her nuptials, which had been set for to-day, so she was married this afternoon to James Palsley Long, who has been her accepted suitor from girlhood. Less than a week ago Miss Dunson received probably fatal injuries on the Jersey Central Railroad by leaping from a fast express train at Netherwood.

Your brilliant and versatile contemporary, the learned Chancellor of the University of the State of New-York, in his eloquent response for the Puritans at the dinner of the Brooklyn New-England Society on Saturday night, failed to give an accurate account of the epithet Puritan, although he fitted it very neatly to the men whom he meant to eulogize throughout all their generations, old and new, past, present, and to come.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- The Evanston Co-operative Housekeeping Association, upon which the eyes of thousands have been turned with keen interest, awaiting the outcome of the scheme to solve the servant girl problem, is already in trouble. During its brief experience of two weeks the books of the concern show a shortage of $2,000.

A young wife, Martha Lowitz, twenty years old, was murdered in a most cowardly manner in her mother's home, at 87 Division Street, yesterday afternoon about 1 o'clock by, her husband, Charles Lowitz, a shiftless ruffian, who was possessed with overpowering but apparently groundless jealousy.

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- When the Democratic State Committee meets on Jan. 8 to organize, Gen. A.P. Collins, who for the past seven years had been Chairman of the committee, will undoubtedly retire, and there is hardly less doubt that his successor will be Gen. John W. Corcoran.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 22. -- A News special from Hart's Ranch, near the Bad Lands, says: "Last night news was brought in that the Grangers on Coal Bow, near Battle Creek, killed an Indian while he, with others, was trying to set fire to a ranch belonging to a man named Thompson. This report was verified this morning.

Mr. Jay Gould's policy of railroad consolidation is being put in operation in the Missouri Pacific system. News from the West yesterday says that the Directors of five of the local Missouri Pacific companies was held in Atchison, Kan., yesterday and voted to formally consolidate with the parent system. Six other companies of the same system will meet at Wichita to-day and will be merged in it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22. -- The people of the town of Mansfield are making efforts to be transferred from the county of Tolland to Windham County on account of inconvenience in getting to the Tolland county seat, the town of Tolland. A petition for such a change is to be presented to the next Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Major Gen. Schofield has received a telegram from Gen. Miles, dated Rapid City, Dakota, Dec 22, as follows: "I believe all, or nearly all, of the followers of Sitting Bultnave been captured. Col. Sumner report to-day the capture of Big Foot's band of Sioux, numbering 150. He ha been one of the most defiant and threatening. The result so far has been satisfactory."
The board of United States Army officers ordered to report on a small-calibre rifle suitable for the army of the United States has adjourned until Jan. 20.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22. -- Juan C. Armijo, a young Mexican well known in West End society in this city, is made by the death of his father, Nicholas F. Armijo, at Albuquerque, one of the wealthiest young men in Mexico. Armijo is twenty-six years old, and has lived in St. Louis for the past four years, having come here to complete his education.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Board of Trade politics is growing more intense as the time for the election of a President -- Jan. 5 -- draws near. At present the indications put W. T. Baker, who is now President, against the field. The field is composed of Robert Lindblom, E. W. Bailey, George G. Parker, and others trailing along behind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Senator Hoar does not tire of playing the funny man with his Force bill. He was at it again to-day, and he succeeded in making a very amusing spectacle of himself and his party.
In a brief review of the condition of the paper trade, Bradstreet's said last Saturday:

Last July Mr. ELIJAH R. KENNEDY of Brooklyn made a journey to the Northwest, and immediately after his return he sent to the Tribune a letter which our high-tariff neighbor published under the title, "What a Wide-Awake Republican Observed in the West." Mr. KENNEDY said that he had had "excellent opportunities for conversing with representative Republicans."
At the Lotos Club dinner on Saturday night Judge O'Gorman is represented as having used the following language: "The poet says that in the case of a man arriving at old age his duty should be --

It was not to be expected that Tammany would consent long to confine its control of the parks to the appointment of unpaid Commissioners. The practical management of the parks has for some years remained in the hands of Mr. PARSONS, who is no politician at all, but an accomplished landscape architect and an industrious and vigilant Superintendent.

In a lecture delivered at Rosebank, Clifton, S.I., last evening, on the "Possibilities of Staten Island," Erastus Wiman criticised the location chosen for the new Appraiser's Stores. He thought that in the choice proper consideration had not been shown for the enormous commercial development that will occur in the course of the next decade along the shores of New-York Bay.

In the handsomest banquet hall that this city has ever possessed the members of the New-England Society of New-York last night enjoyed their eighty-fifth anniversary dinner. The occasion marked the opening to pubic uses of the well-planned concert and banquet hall in the new Madison Square Garden. About 500 men sat down to the tables and found themselves rather too closely packed together.

In your issue of Sunday, Nov. 30, the Rogers bell buoy was described in general as the best aid to navigation of its kind in the service of the lighthouse establishment. From information obtained at the lighthouse depot, Staten Island, it appears that precedence in efficiency is given to the Heap bell buoy.

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- That the chance to secure reciprocity with Newfoundland, presented by the overtures which the English Government has made to the United States, should not be allowed to escape was the sentiment which prevailed at the special meeting of the Boston Chamber of Commerce to-day.

A holiday display of the best work of those for whose benefit the New-York Exchange for Woman's Work was organized is on exhibition day and evening at the showrooms of the Exchange, 329 Fifth Avenue. The exhibit contains many articles of great beauty and excellent workmanship, being characterized by an individuality which cannot be found among the usual supplies of Christmas goods.

The action of ex-Mayor W.S. Pendleton of Fort Worth, Texas, in exposing the New-York law firm that procured him a bogus divorce in August, 1889, has brought to light a rotten condition of affairs on both sides of the question, and has unearthed some very discreditable methods of business followed by New-York lawyers. Pendleton was a lawyer of Fort Worth.

There are numerous indications that Gov HILL is in a quandary. While it is likely that he might compass his own election to the United States Senate if he were disposed to go there, it grows more and more doubtful whether he can dispose of the seat of Mr. EVARTS to whomsoever he will if he concludes that he does not want it himself.

TROY, Dec. 22. -- The south-bound express on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, which left Saratoga Springs at 12:25 o'clock and was due in this city at 1:45 o'clock this morning, collided with a freight train standing on a siding at Blue Mills, one mile north of Ballston Spa, owing to a misplaced switch. The engine was badly wrecked.

The steamship Spree of the North German Lloyd Line, which arrived yesterday morning from Bremen, not only brought over more of Prof. Koch's lymph, but had among her passengers a gentleman who was able to give the first comprehensive account of the properties and operations of the lymph. This person was Dr. Frederick M. Warner of the Charity Hospital.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- With the opening of the new year a number of newly-organized banking institutions will go into operation at points in the interior of the State. The First National Bank of Walton, Delaware County, will open its doors for business Jan. 2, with a capital of $50,000. The executive officers-elect are: George O. Mead, President; Samuel H. Fancher, Vice President; John Olmstead, Cashier.
KILKENNY, Dec. 22. -- The day has passed off quietly. There was no disturbance here, and no disorder worthy of mention is reported at any of the other towns in the district.

The new assembly room of the Madison Square Garden, in which the New-England dinner was given last night and the Reform League banquet is to be held this evening, was opened by the Directors of the Garden for a private inspection yesterday afternoon. Business Manager Morrissey has christened it "an emperor's throne room," and it is certainly as palatial an apartment as any Emperor might require for a coronation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Secretary Windom has sent to Senator Cameron. Chairman of the Senate Naval Committee, the following communication: Hon. J.D. Cameron, United States Senate:

DOVER, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Great suffering is threatened among the poor of Randolph Township, Morris County. The accounts of the poor fund, it has been discovered, have been loosely kept, and orders have been issued so promiscuously that the fund has been overdrawn several hundred dollars. Besides this there are a number of outstanding obligations, for settlement of which creditors, owing to the scarcity of money, are clamoring.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Jameson's diary will be published to-morrow. Mrs. Jameson and the dead man's brother, in a preface to the work, bitterly attack Mr. Stanley for making Jameson the scapegoat for all the troubles which occurred, and claiming that they were due to Stanley's own bad judgment and neglect. They also suggest that Messrs. Stanley and Bonny are not telling the truth.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- The Newark made fast to her dock at the Cramps' shipbuilding yard to-day at 2:30 P.M. As told in the dispatch of last night from the Breakwater, this cruiser has just finished one of the most successful trial trips the Cramps have ever had. The published accounts of the two previous trials of ten days ago gave the main engines 9,500 horse power, uncorrected for indicator errors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the name of District Judge Henry B. Brown of Michigan, to fill the vacancy on the bench of the United States Supreme Court, caused by the death of Justice Miller.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Great excitement was caused at the North Avenue station of the Jersey Central Railway this evening by the attempted suicide of George W. Bilyou, an artist of local reputation The young man was brooding over financial troubles. To-night, in a fit of madness, he rushed from his studio, crying, "I must die! I must die!"

CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 23. -- Another contribution to the literary controversy which is sharply agitating the Republican Party in this State, and in which the Democrats have no part, except that of decidedly interested readers and spectators, was furnished to-day in the shape of a ten-page pamphlet issued by the Hon. H. W. Greene of Hopkinton, the leader of the anti-Chandler forces in the last Legislature, and a member-elect of the next House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Republican Senators, having tried in vain to find some common ground upon which all could stand regarding the Force bill, the Finance bill, and the question of a gag rule, have at last given up the attempt and have concluded to settle the whole business in open Senate.

DETROIT, Dec. 23. -- Judge Henry Billings Brown, whose appointment to the Supreme Court is announced, is the present Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, and this is said to be the first instance, in the history of the country, where a district Judge has been advanced to the highest judicial position in the land.

KILKENNY, Dec. 23. -- The result of the election held yesterday to fill the seat for North Kilkenny in the House of Commons, made vacant by the death of Mr. Marum, was announced at noon to-day. The polling resulted in a victory for the anti-Parnellites, their candidate, Sir John Pope Hennessey, being returned by a vote of 2,527, against 1,956 for Scully: a majority for Hennessey of 1,171.

Nothing in the quaint and eccentric idea which Mr. W.S. Gilbert occasionally puts upon the stage seems so absurd to the London Daily Telegraph as the institution of "hereditary pawnbrokers," which, according to a recent decision of the Queen's Bench, actually exists in England. "Hereditary right has generally been associated with exalted functions.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The Daily News, referring to the election of Sir John Pope Hennessey, says:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23. -- William Duval, who swindled so many United States Senators and posed as the father of a numerous family of honorably-named and fictitious first-born babes, has disappeared. No one seems to know anything of his whereabouts. Inquiry at his home this morning developed the fact that he had not been seen since yesterday morning.

DUBLIN, Dec. 23 -- The first public meeting of the McCarthyite committee took place to-day. It is almost needless to add that everybody present was filled with enthusiasm over the result of the contest in North Kilkenny.

Patrolmen Thomas Reilly and John Madigan of the Eighteenth Precinct, Brooklyn, were in Peter Noonan's saloon at 19 Willoughby Street yesterday afternoon, when Patrolman John F. Holsworthy of the First Precinct entered by a side door. He was in full uniform, while Reilly and Madigan were in citizen's dress. According to Reilly, Holsworthy was drunk, and so Reilly went over and protested against his having any more liquor.

There is at present a good deal of internal commotion in the customs administration department of Appraiser Marvelle W. Cooper, which is likely to break forth within a short time with disastrous effect upon somebody. It has come about because the antagonisms engendered by the partisan tariff law which have set the commercial and manufacturing industries of the country at loggerheads have also involved many of the Government officials who are charged with its administration.
Kidder, Peabody Co. yesterday made their usual Christmas distribution among their clerks. The amount of money thus given by the firm exceeded $40,000.

There can be no doubt that the sentiments uttered by Dr. Frederick M. Warner of the Charity Hospital and by Dr. Shearer of Baltimore, on their arrival Monday from Germany, expressing strong opinions in favor of smaller and less frequent doses of Dr. Koch's lymph than those which have been usually administered in this city, have created a decided sensation, both in the ranks of physicians and laymen.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 23. -- Before the Gubernatorial contest in this State reaches the Legislature, the Supreme Court of Connecticut will have had an opportunity to decide a question that may be an important factor in that contest -- the legality of the ballots on which the word "for" was printed before the name of each office.

For many years a series of Sunday afternoon meetings for women has been held. First started by Dr. Harriet E. Clisby, in her home, they were the nucleus from which the now large and far-reaching Woman's Educational and industrial Union was formed. They are held now in the hall of She union rooms on Boylston Street.

Four of the Vanderbilt lines -- the New-York Central, the "Big Four," the Lake Shore, and the Michigan Central -- yesterday formally ratified the Advisory Council agreement, which was devised by Mr. H. McK. Twombly for the purpose of preserving harmony between the Eastern trunk lines and their connections. This agreement, which is similar to the one approved by the Western railroad Presidents, has been printed in THE TIMES.

The absurdity of the proposals made by the associated farmers in the Northwest is not nearly so comic as it is sad when it is remembered that they proceed from a very real distress. The fact that the farmers are wildly at a loss when they undertake to prescribe remedies for this distress does not at all discredit the reality of the distress itself.

Those charitable organizations that depend upon voluntary contributions labor under a double embarrassment this year. "Hard times" increase the needs of the poor and diminish the gifts of the rich. Charity is classed with the luxuries by many worthy persons, and it is in that class of expenditures that retrenchment begins when the pinch of a financial stringency is felt.
Concerning the forthcoming British naval exhibition the United Service Gazette (British) says:

Senator Fassett opened the proceedings of yesterday's session of the Senate Committee on Cities in Part II of the Superior Court, but about noon the joys of street-cleaning information began to pall upon him, and, awakening to the fact that it was getting pretty close to Christmas, he wished the other members of his committee and Mr. Ivins a merry yule-tide time, and started off for Elmira.

There is nothing prettier this Christmas than the repousse silver. It looks like the frostwork that King Winter has grown so stingy with. What nature refuses to do art is determined to accomplish, and though no snow may sparkle beneath the sunshine, the Christmas festivities will not lack the beauty of glistening, frosty radiance.

The McKinley papers in the West are still talking about goods that were imported just before the new tariff law went into effect and that are still held under bond in the Government warehouses. The Chicago Inter Ocean of the 22d inst. said:

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Michael Davitt's newspaper, the Labor World, to-day renews the onslaught recently made upon Mr. Parnell through its columns. During the course of a long attack opun the "uncrowned King," the Labor World says that if by any compromise Mr. Parnell remains leader of the Irish party a number of anti-Parnell members threaten to abandon public life, which would be disastrous to the party at large.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Representative Burton of Ohio to-day introduced in the House a bill to amend the Inter-State Commerce act by adding thereto a section relative to a railroad doing business partly in the United States and partly in adjacent foreign countries. It requires such a company to obtain from the Inter-State Commerce Commission a license or permit to engage in such business.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23. -- The recent political campaign, which resulted so disastrously to the Republicans in Missouri as elsewhere, has proved fruitful of heartburnings, and since the election the air has been heavy with charges and countercharges of responsibility for the disaster.

Yesterday Commissioner BEATTIE laid before the Senate committee a cheerful estimate that with an initial expenditure for "plant" of $266,537.50 the streets of this city could be thoroughly cleaned by the block system for $2,189,184 per year. If machine sweeping were retained in part, with a "plant" costing $271,254.25 to start with, the work might be done for $1,636,099.90.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- The hearing in the County Court touching the failure of the private bank of S.A. Kean Co. was continued to-day. According to the statement of Cashier Warne yesterday, John Culver is indebted to the bank on his note to the amount of $5,800. Mr. Culver, on the witness stand to-day, testified that he did not owe the bank anything; on the contrary, the bank owed him over $200.

The opinion that a more terrible tale of fierce jealousy than that unfolded by the evidence adduced in the course of the trial of Mary Eleanor Wheeler, alias Pearcey, who was convicted recently in London and sentenced to death for the murder of Phoebe Hogg and her infant daughter, Phoebe Hanslope, has never been revealed, is held by the London Daily Telegraph.

If as seems probable, the discussion of the Force bill is drawing to a close, the leaders of each party can review the general course of that discussion and draw some inferences as to the showing made by their respective followers. We confess that, on the whole, there has not been much in the innumerable speeches that have used up the first third of the session that is particularly creditable to either side.

The art of illustration has made enormous strides during late years, and during Christmastide we are apt to be impressed by the fact more vividly than at other time of the year. The quality of illustrations in books advances steadily when regarded broadly, though it might be held that it is a rise of the average rather than an appearance of books better illustrated, better printed, better bound than the best of former periods.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 23. -- Two years ago Mrs. Annice G. Barteau was happily married and had $300,000 in her own right. To-day she is divorced against her will and made penniless by a decree of the Supreme Court of Minnesota.

Enthusiasm surcharged the atmosphere of the banquet hall of the Madison Square Garden last night. The Reform Club of New-York was giving a grand banquet in honor of the sweeping political victory achieved by the Democratic Party last Fall, and there was an echo of triumph in every shout, a ring of confidence in every cheer.

Once in eight years the army of the United States deserts -- that is, the total number of desertions during eight years equals the number of soldiers receiving pay at any one time. In order to counteract this tendency to desert, orders have recently been issued by the War Department to all the recruiting stations throughout the United States, which will have the effect of improving the service to a marked degree.

GLASGOW, Dec. 23. -- In spite of all efforts to bring about a settlement of the matters in dispute between the railroad officials and the railroad employes, the strike continues to extend in many directions and has reached Edinburgh. Traffic is now hopelessly behind time everywhere along the lines of the roads affected.

Particular attention has for several years been paid to the subject of ocean currents, and various devices have been employed for ascertaining the set and drift of the great rivers of the ocean. The late Prince of Monaco was especially interested in the matter, and had a special kind of bottle prepared to be used by vessels all over the world where current observations were required.

The production of Sardou's "Cleopatra" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last evening came to a conclusion at ten minutes after midnight. It is, therefore, impossible to treat the presentation with such careful consideration as it deserves. A large audience witnessed the performance with apparent interest, which after some scenes was warmed into enthusiasm.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 24. -- A Christmas gift for farmers is the announcement this evening of the collapse of the Western Tobacco Association, which was a combine of Louisville and Cincinnati warehouses under one management, with a capital of $3,000,000.

The bold young Kaiser is about to continue his royal journeyings with a trip to Paris, on the way to Cannes and San Remo. It is hardly possible that he expects political results of value to the Fatherland to flow from his sojourn in the French capital. He is not to stop at the German Embassy, having a frugal regard for the windows of that mansion, and he is to preserve "a strict incognito."

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., Dec. 24. -- There was mounting in hot haste here to-day when the news came that 200 of the Sioux braves who surrendered to Col. Sumner had escaped and were on their way to the Bad Lands.

BOULOGNE, Dec. 24. -- In an interview to-day Justin McCarthy declared that his idea in coming here was to inform Mr. O'Brien fully in regard to recent events in Ireland. Mr. McCarthy said he believed that, in view of Mr. Parnell's declarations after the Kilkenny election, all idea of a reconciliation between the two factions of the Irish party must be abandoned.

President HARRISON'S invitation to "all the nations of the earth to take part in the commemoration of an event that is pre-eminent in human history," by sending representatives and articles for exhibition to the Chicago World's Fair in 1893, will be welcomed and responded to in various ways by the countries addressed.

No contention that has arisen under the new tariff and customs administration laws has awakened such general interest in Federal official and importing circles as the kid glove re-appraisement case of Passavant Co., now on trial before General Appraisers Tichenor, Somerville, and Sharpe, on appeal from the decision of General Appraiser Jewell.

Marcus Mayer, Miss Fanny Davenport's manager, with his counsel, ex-Judge Dittenhoefer, went to the Custom House yesterday morning to make arrangements for doing away with the guardianship over the "Cleopatra" costumes which two Treasury agents had exercised since the seizure of the goods on Tuesday, on a charge that they were liable to pay duty according to the specifications of the tariff.

The Grand Jury for December wished a "merry Christmas" to Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, and handed up, instead of presents, three presentments relative to needed reforms in the city. In regard to the police matrons and lodging houses the Grand Jury had this to say:

DES, MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 24. -- Some of the Justices and constables who have grown fat on the methods employed to enforce the prohibitory law in this (Polk) county have at last come to grief. The Grand Jury yesterday returned bills against a number of them. The charges are conspiracy to defraud the county, threats to extort money, blackmail, and making false returns of warrants.

ALBANY, Dec. 24. -- A sensational rumor was current about the State Department to-day that there were irregularities in the State Treasurer's office. It was intimated that they were not of a criminal nature, but were due to carelessness. Naturally the report created a good deal of excitement and was not generally credited.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Miss Mary Patrice Whitebeck, an actress, playing in "The Midnight Call" at one of the theatres here, is the plaintiff in a breach of promise suit for $20,000 begun to-day against A.P. Blakeslee, a young Board of Trade man, whose office is in the Royal Insurance Building and who is said to be wealthy.

Laggard shoppers were scurrying from shop to shop yesterday making their final Christmas purchases, but they were few in numbers as compared to the vast multitudes that have been thronging the streets for a fortnight. They represented chiefly that large class of persons who put off everything until the last moment and who then rush madly to its accomplishment.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- At an adjourned meeting of the creditors of G.W. Ingalls Co., boots and shoes, to-day the committee of creditors reported that they were satisfied that Mr. Ingalls had made a straightforward and correct statement of his affairs and they recommended an acceptance of the following proposition from Mr. Ingalls:

It is sincerely hoped in progressive naval circles that the appropriation of $25,000 for State naval militia will be passed by Congress. There are at present two State naval militia organizations, one in Boston and one in New-York. So far Congress has ignored these organizations. They are in need of small arms, accoutrements, in fact, in need of everything but what has been contributed by the individual members.

The most striking of recent suggestions for the management of reservation Indians is the one made by Mr. FREDERIC REMINGTON in Harper' Weekly. It is that the War Department should be authorized to "organize them into a semi-industrial military force, much after the fashion of the Cossacks, whose company chief is responsible for their operations in peace and their deeds in war.

Some of the leaders and oracles of the high-tariff party have shown a little anxiety, since the election, about the growth of the Trust-making industry and the political aspects of this movement. A Chicago paper publishes an interview with Secretary RUSK of the Department of Agriculture in which his anxiety is clearly disclosed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 24. -- Judge Acheson in the United States Court to-day handed down an opinion fixing $209,000 as the sum to be paid by the United States to the Monongahela Navigation Company for lock and dam No. 7, in the Monongahela River. This is an important step in the contest being made by shippers, consumers, and owners of river craft for free navigation of the waters of the United States.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24. -- Judge John M. Hall of the Superior Court, in giving judgment on a probate election contest, has rendered a decision which, if sustained by the Supreme Court of Errors, makes Judge Luzon B. Morris unquestionably entitled to the Governorship.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 24. -- Oystermen in this vicinity are happy over a newly-devised dredge for catching "stars," which is likely to prove of more value to the oyster business than any other discovery or invention of recent date. Thomas Thomas, a New-Haven oyster planter and dealer, is given credit for originating the device.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Mr. Aldrich's new gag rule is not yet before the Senate for consideration, but talk about it has already begun in the chamber. The Democrats in general, and Mr. Morgan in particular, do not propose to have a gag rule adopted without everybody knowing what is going on.

Mounted Officer Fanning was severely injured yesterday afternoon while attempting to capture a pair of runaway horses, attached to a victoria, belonging to Mrs. Ringier of 1,816 Madison Avenue. The horses were left standing at the Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue entrance to the Central Park, and taking fright at something, they dashed into the Park and along the East Drive.

The Grand Jury in a presentment yesterday gave a good deal of attention to a class of illegal divorces which often cause trouble to the ignorant persons who put their faith in them. Says the presentment:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The following proclamation has just been issued:

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24. -- The disgust aroused in this city by the nomination of City Solicitor Brinsmade for the vacant office of United States District Attorney is finding vent in other ways than expressions of individual feeling. The Franklin Club is an organization of radicals who call themselves Nationalists, but it is usually on the popular side in regard to local questions, and it often expresses the sentiments of almost the whole community.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 24. -- A notable incident of the decline of New-England farming is recorded in one of the most fertile parts of the East, the Connecticut Valley. Little City is in the town of Haddam and contains some fairly prosperous farms, but the decline referred to is there. On account of its depopulation, the village is having difficulty in maintaining its school, which once was flourishing.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- In the case of the Commonwealth against George Paul, (Philadelphia agent of Braun Fitts of Chicago, manufacturers of oleomargarine,) as to whom a special verdict by agreement of counsel was rendered for selling oleomargarine, Judge Reed to-day delivered a decision in which he holds that the State law forbidding the sale of oleomargarine in the packages as originally imported from another State is unconstitutional.

The expenses of the Sheriff's office for 1891 were considered yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in arranging the final budget. A larger amount than fixed upon in making the provisional estimate, and a larger amount than that originally asked for by Sheriff Sickles in his departmental estimate, was allowed.

Now that the treatment of incipient consumption with the Koch lymph is well under way in New-York, with favorable auspices, the medical profession is turning its attention to cancer, that other terrible disease of which humanity has long been an almost helpless victim, with the purpose of learning whether it, too, can be cured with the new remedy.

In appointing BRINSMADE to be District Attorney for the Northern District of Ohio, Mr. HARRISON and his Attorney General appear to have been moved by considerations like those which induced them to nominate Col. CLAYTON to be District Attorney for the Western District of Arkansas, and to stand by this nomination after the disgraceful history of the opening of Oklahoma had been laid before the country in the reports of two Republican officers.

Some of the German Catholic churches have been decorated more extensively this year than usual. In the Church of St. Nicholas, in Twelfth Street, between First Avenue and Avenue A, the sanctuary has been beautifully decorated with palms, cypress, and flowers. A new creche has been erected here. The stable overlooks a plain, while a rocky hill rises immediately behind.

Another effort was yesterday inaugurated to provide under the name of a coffee house a place where poor workingmen, not tramps, can get wholesome and sufficient food at a small cost, and at the same time be given such light, warmth, and opportunities for amusement as men in their circumstances now have to go to saloons or worse places to find.

The nomination of Surgeon CHARLES SUTHERLAND to be Surgeon General in the army is another instance of reversion on the President's part to the principle of seniority selection, as indeed the previous appointment to the same office had been. In several cases, however, he has chosen a junior to be the head of a staff department or corps.

Quite naturally, PARNELL and the Parnellites are now engaged in belittling their defeat at Kilkenny. It was a "preliminary skirmish" only and it was lost through "treachery" and the influence of the priesthood. But this line of explanation does not deceive anybody who is not anxious to be deceived. "Treachery" is by no means an unprecedented element in Irish or any other political contests.

The attacks made on Senator DON CAMERON in his own State by organs of his own party doubtless arise from motives purely personal or factional. They are interesting to outsiders only on account of their avowed basis, which is the Senator's opposition to the Force bill. That, in the opinion of impartial observers, is the most creditable incident in a career which, through long, has not been crowded with evidences of either sense or independence.

The ice at Van Cortlandt Lake is in firs-rate condition. That suburban skating resort has never possessed more attractions for skaters, and it is being appreciated by thousands of lovers of the sport. While easy of access by the New-York and Northern Railway, it is yet far enough from the city to avoid some of the disadvantages of a city skating ground, and is therefore especially popular.
