Reviewing the proceedings of a recent meeting of the Nebraska Farmers' Alliance, the Omaha Bee says: "There is a new force at work in the Farmers' Alliance. It is the spirit of wise conservatism, and it involves new leaders, new ideas, and a new and healthier impulse to the organization. This fact is apparent to every one who studies the course of the recent convention at Lincoln.

CHICAGO, Dec 24. -- It has been known for some time that Dr. Harper, President of the new Baptist University to be situated in this city, had made a rather startling educational proposition to the Trustees. The nature of it was not known until to-day, when the Rev. Dr. Goodspeed, one of the Trustees, outlined it.

The Board of Managers for 1891 of the New-York Institution for the Blind was chosen yesterday. These gentlemen were elected: Robert S. Hone, John Treat Irving, Smith Clift, William Whitewright, William C. Schermerhorn, Francis A. Stout, Frederick Augustus Schermerhorn, Peter Marie, Frederick W. Rhinelander, Frederick Sheldon, Chandler Robbins, Philip Schuyler, John I. Kane, Edward King, Edward Schell, Frederick Bronson, George A. Robbins, Gustav E. Kissel, John M. Bowers, and George L. Peabody, M.D.
DUBLIN, Dec. 25. -- In an interview to-day before his departure from this city, Mr. Parnell said:

The discriminating palate of a sybarite was necessary for a full appreciation of yesterday's Christmas dinner at most of the big hotels in this cosmopolitan town. The game preserves of distant lands had been ransacked for delicacies for the feast, and nothing rare and rich to the taste was seemingly overlooked.

Visitors to Naples during the next few years are advised by the London Globe to "take earnest note of the aspect of the city. In time to come they will have to regard themselves as privileged persons. The city is being reformed out of its old insanitary ways; it is being leveled to enable it to rise again as fair as modern builders subject to their own contract prices can afford to make it.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 25. -- A special to the Appeal-Avalanche from Carrollton, Miss., says: "A fatal tragedy occurred on the principal business street in this town to-day at 12 o'clock noon, in which John Prentiss Matthews, the Republican Postmaster at this place, was killed by young W.S. McBride, a wealthy and prominent young druggist here.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Some days ago representatives of the Industrial Benefit Association of Syracuse came here and took possession of the office of its agent, R.L. Embley, claiming that they were desirous of changing the agent. Mr. Embley claimed that he and not the company leased the office, and only a portion of the furniture in the office belonged to the company.

The most important object for the existence of the National Zoological Park here at Washington is to furnish a retreat for the breeding and restoration of animals indigenous to this country which threaten to become extinct. So says Prof. Langley, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, in his annual report about to be issued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The Bureau of American Republics has received information of an organization of a corporation in Brazil under the name of the "Companhia Nova Era Rural do Brazil" with a capital of $25,000,000, a large part of which has been furnished by bankers and merchants of Europe, and the remainder by local investors.

Caricaturists continue to give a considerable deal of trouble to Parisian magistrates, and a few eccentric strokes of the pencil frequently evoke long legal disquisitions which are not altogether devoid of entertainment. Thus, an illustrated newspaper which maintains a fair artistic reputation has been engaging magisterial attention again by reason of the pictorial vagaries of one of its staff of sketchers.
Shanghai Dispatch to the London Standard.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 25. -- The examination of old papers and letters frequently brings to light many interesting incidents in the life of some of the best known of public men. The life of Judge Creighton is now being written and among his old letters is the following, which Mr. Creighton received while a member of Congress, from the father of Judge Allen G. Thurman:

Under the regulations now put into operation for the new summary courts recently authorized by Congress the court-martial work of the army will be simplified. The system provides for the trial of the minor offenses of enlisted men by the officer second in rank at a post instead of by the cumbrous machinery of a full garrison or regimental court.

Short-weight gold coins are becoming annoyingly common. Bankers and others are frequently coming across light pieces. The discovery a few days since of nearly $300 in light two-and-half-dollar gold pieces tendered in payment of custom duties by a prominent importer has led to the detection of numerous pieces short in weight, showing that there is in operation a systematic scheme for robbing the Government by stealing metal from coins.

If by the time you read this weather tale this morning the snow is not flying thick and fast before your windows, it will be flying in the above-mentioned manner a few hours later, according to the infallible Weather Bureau, so do not be ashamed to go down town wearing rubber boots, ear muffs, snow spectacles, wristlets, and the rest of your left-over "blizzard" paraphernalia.

" My idea of economy is to live within your income," remarked a wealthy manufacturer the other day. "What a world this would be if everybody hoarded his money, and tried to accumulate as much as possible! It is the money a man spends that he gets the good of. And it is the part of his fortune that benefits the community most, too. Keeping money in circulation makes good times."

To be present at any of our Western Indian Agencies on "issue day" is worth many miles of travel. The selection of the day of the week on which rations are distributed rests entirely with the agent, but for years in the Southwest the day has been Friday. At San Carlos, for instance, where about 5,000 Indians are fed and cared for, a just distribution of the weekly allowance is no easy task.

A deadly fight took place yesterday afternoon in the stable of Michael J. Gallivan, at 191 West Forty-fifth Street, and in less than five minutes James Cummings, a hack driver, had been shot dead with a revolver in the hands of Gallivan, a bullet had been put through the cheek of Edward Hurley, another driver, and Gallivan himself had been beaten almost insensible, his nose and a rib broken, and several teeth knocked out.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Dec. 25. -- Money is easy and there is little demand for loans. There have been remarkably few failures during the year, and a small proportion of them were bad ones. THE TIMES'S correspondent has interviewed the leading bankers of the city, who say, in substance, that the country, on the whole, is prosperous. Government revenues are keeping up well and railway receipts are excellent.

The Manufacturers' Club of Philadelphia publishes, "under the immediate direction" of a committee of the organization, a journal called the Manufacturer, and Mr. THOMAS DOLAN, President of the club, is a member of this committee. A few weeks ago the Manufacturer undertook to explain why the McKinley act was not sustained at the recent election, and this was a part of the explanation:

GLASGOW, Dec. 25. -- It is now estimated that about 9,000 men are out on strike on the various railways in Scotland. Traffic on the North British Railway has almost ceased. The company will suspend the operations of its steamers on Loch Lomond and the Clyde in order to obtain employes to work on the railway.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 25. -- A few years more will witness the completion of the Winnipeg and Hudson's Bay Railway, which, in conjunction with a line of ocean steamships, will provide a new and direct outlet to the European markets. Hugh Sutherland of Winnipeg, the leading promoter of the scheme, has overcome public opposition, and has at last convinced the Canadian authorities of the wisdom of his vast undertaking.

The Boston Saturday Evening Gazette has received from Capt. Nathan Appleton the following relating to the famous Saturday Club of Boston, of which no records were kept, and to which allusion is made in Mr. Adams's "Life of Richard H. Dana," just published:

The festival of Christmas drove lugubrious thoughts from the minds of the lymph patients in the hospitals yesterday, and holiday dinners and the like kept the doctors from talking much about the progress of the Koch cures. There were nine reinoculations and no new cases at Mt. Sinai. One of the persons reinoculated at the Polyclinic Hospital on Saturday developed a subnormal temperature on the reaction.
You report Mr. Depew as saying in his speech on Dec. 22:

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 25. -- The Riverside Gun Club had an all-day shoot to-day at live and inanimate targets. The morning was devoted to blue rock shooting and the afternoon to live birds. The events were governed by national rules. A summary of the events follows;

The suggestion of the Albany Evening Times that Gov. HILL should decline to be "shelved" in the United States Senate, and "boldly go before the people of this State next year as the Democratic candidate for Governor for a third time" is variously interpreted by the press of the State.

In the course of the recent tribute to the memory of the late Samuel J. Randall, Speaker Reed referred to a scene in the House never to be forgotten by those present. It was in the closing hours of Congress, in March, 1885. The hands of the clock were fast approaching the hour of 12, and there was the rush of business and furor of excitement incident to the close of the session.

The Young Men's Association of Holy Cross Church will give an entertainment and reception at the Lexington Avenue Opera House Friday evening, Jan. 9. "Little Mother," a comedy in two acts, and "Peace and Quiet," a one-act farce, will be pesented.

Mr. and Mrs. Littledale's adventurous journey across the Pamir and the Hindu Kush into India will bear fruit in a volume of travels which should be one of considerable interest. The travelers left Odessa in the early Summer, and, crossing the Caspian, reached Osh, in the heart of Central Asia, in May. They were accompanied by a Russian and a Persian interpreter, and six or seven followers.

The most hopeful sign for the future prosperity of the republic of Brazil that has appeared since the deposition of Dom PEDRO is to be found in the incorporation of the "Companhia Nova Era Rural do Brazil," which is just announced. This company, which has a capital of $25,000,000, contributed by European and Brazilian capitalists, proposes to establish twenty agricultural settlements on the public land of the new republic.

MITCHELL, S.D., Dec. 25. -- Indefensible though they may be when looked upon as combinations, brought into being for the purpose of advancing prices of articles which in moderate quantities it is necessary for persons engaged in farming to possess, the several farm machinery trusts which are now in various stages of organization may prove instrumentalities of great good to the people of the Western States.

One of the most instructive an oftentimes most amusing features of a court in operation is the way in which the presiding Judge keeps order. The natural tendency when the wheels of justice are going around is toward noise. The lawyers, of course, feel that they must do something to make their clients believe they are earning their fees, and occasionally the Judge adds his voice.

The most dangerous counterfeit ever known in the history of the coinage of this Government has been found by the authorities of the Mint in this city. It is a five-dollar gold piece designed and executed with such remarkable skill that few of the experts can distinguish the spurious coins from the genuine. In general appearance, color, weight, and design the counterfeit is perfect.

The Geological Society of America will hold a meeting in Washington next week, which, it is expected, will last from Monday morning until Wednesday night. Prof. Alexander Winchell will preside, Mr. Dana, the President of the society, being too ill to undertake the journey to Washington. The list of offered papers contains about fifty titles, and the indications are that the meeting will be largely attended and full of interest.

M. de Freycinet was elected a few weeks ago a member of the Academie Francaise, in succession to Emile Augier. There were nine candidates, only four of whom were serious -- namely, the Prime Minister, M. Thureau Dangin, the Orleanist historian of Louis Philippe's reign; Brunetiere, and M. Emile Zola. At the first ballot M. de Freycinet polled thirteen votes, M. Brunetiere seven, M. Thureau Dangin twelve, and M. Zola three.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26. -- A meeting of the bankers and business men of this city who had loaned George Westinghouse $500,000 lately was held to-day. An advisory board of five was selected to act with Mr. Westing house in placing the half million and managing the affairs of the companies requiring the loan.

The Albany Argus reminds Senators Evarts and Hiscock that if they have any pride whatever in the State which they assume to represent they will do all in their power to increase the membership of the House of Representatives, under the new apportionment, to 359, thus giving New-York State the additional member of Congress that every fair-minded man believes we are entitled to.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- United States Senators R.F. Pettigrew and G.C. Moody of South Dakota arrived from Washington yesterday on their way to Pierre, where the Legislature will meet Jan. 6. As to Moody's chances for re-election, Mr. Pettigrew said:

This is story Marcus R. Mayer tells about himself: Mr. Flayer is the director of Miss Fanny Davenport's tour in "Cleopatra," and was therefore deeply interested in the preparations for the production of Sardou's play New-York last Tuesday evening. On Monday evening the final dress rehearsal of "Cleopatra" was given at the Fifth Avenue. Mr. Mayer was on hand early.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- An evening session of the Court of Sessions was held to-night and the proceedings were quite sensational. John Reed, on trial on a charge of train-wrecking near Greenbush last September, was sworn in his own behalf. He told a most remarkable story. He declared that he had nothing whatever to do at any time with wrecking trains or misplacing switches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Capt. James Carroll of Sitka, Alaska, is in the city. He was chosen by the Territorial Convention, held at Juneau, in October last, to represent the Territory as a Delegate in Congress, provided that body should see fit to grant it the right of representation.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 26. -- The Congregational Club of Connecticut has refused to cooperate with the Congregational clubs throughout the country in the project to erect a monument at Delfshaven as a remembrance of Holland's hospitality to the Pilgrims, who, before they sailed from Dolfshaven on the voyage which was completed at Plymouth Rock, resided for twelve years in Amsterdam and Leyden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The fourth annual meeting of the American Economic Association was begun this afternoon in the hall of the Columbian University. In the absence of the President, Gen. Francis A. Walker, the meeting was called to order by Prof. J.R. Clark.

The future of the Koch lymph as a panacea for tuberculous diseases is a matter about which there has been some modification of opinion among New-York surgeons who have experimented with it. The general opinion now is that it will effect at least a temporary cure of lupus, and will retard the progress of what is commonly called consumption in its incipient stages.

It is a curious story that comes from Washington as to the latest chapter in the Huston-Harrison story. It is well known that Treasurer HUSTON nearly six months since offered his resignation to the President, and it was said at the time that he was discontented with the treatment he had received and wanted to go back to Indiana and work off his discontent in "fixing" that State against the denomination of the President.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The President to-day, made the following appointments:

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered the estimates for the Department of Charities and Correction yesterday in arranging the final budget for 1891. Commissioners Simmons and Porter and Dr. Macdonald were on hand to explain the necessities of the department in the way of money.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 26. -- The insurance on the Masonic Temple Building, which was almost totally destroyed by fire yesterday, is as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Charles B. Farwell means to be re-elected to the United States Senate if he and "Long" Jones can, by hook or by crook, bring it about. Jones is Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee. He secured that office this year because of his record in the past as an unscrupulous wire-puller. The Republicans feared defeat unless heroic measures were resorted to, and Jones was a heroic dose.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 26. -- There passed through this city to-day a family that is certainly remarkable. The name of the family is Forsse, and the parents are natives of Sweden. They have been married a little over ten years, and have spent that time in Manitoba on a farm. The ministering angel was exceedingly kind to them, and sent a bright little son the first year, and kept following it up each year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The immediate effect of the issuance by President Harrison of his proclamation inviting foreign countries to take part in the World's Columbian Exposition will be to hasten work in every department. For almost two weeks little has been accomplished at either local or national headquarters.

The Sun denounces as "a Mugwump plan," and therefore abominable, the proposition that the elections for Now-York city and county officers shall be separated from State and national elections and held in the Spring. "The proposition has long been a favorite one with the Mugwumps and the Jibooses," says the Sun.

Ex-Senator Thomas F. Grady and ex-Senator Thomas C.E. Ecclesine have been hard at work for some time past trying to get appointed to one of the places that De Lancey Nicoll will have at his disposal as District Attorney after Jan. 1. The two ex-Senators were among the leading Tammany "spell binders" in the last campaign, and their friends have been pushing their claims with so much assiduity that the rivalry became exciting.

In its general features, the storm which struck New-York yesterday morning more closely resembled the great blizzard of 1888 than any weather disturbance that has happened in this locality since that memorable occasion. In a less degree there were the same indications -- tempestuous winds bearing a downfall of fine, cutting snow, a low temperature, and a general discomfort to man and beast, whether indoors or out.

Senator ALDRICH of Rhode Island seems to think that he can manage his reputation on the principle of the Sibylline books, the smallest remnant being worth as much as the original stock. When he entered the Senate and for some time afterward, he was looked upon as a man of intelligence, fairness, and a decided tendency to conservative views and behavior.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- By the burning of a cottage about 5 o'clock this morning a woman and three children lost their lives. The victims were Mrs. John Dietrich of Orchard Street and three of her children -- Libbie, aged six years; Jacob, aged three years, and Louisa, aged eleven months. How the fire originated is a mystery.

The hospital collection returns now being made to Mr. Charles Lanier, the Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, 17 Nassau Street, exceed in amount those of any previous year at the same date, and there is a good prospect that the collection of 1890 will be the largest in the history of the movement. Following are the returns:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Andrew Cauldwell, the special agent of the General Land Office appointed to make an investigation as to the location, condition, number, , of giant (Sequoia gigantia) trees in the Stockton and Visalia land districts in California, has made his report to the Commissioner of the General Land Office.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 26. -- Gen. Palmer received a telegram this morning from the Chairman of the Madison County Democratic Central Committee with the query: "What is the latest date a contest can be filed against a member of the Legislature!"

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- The Temps announces that, after the meeting between Parnell and O'Brien, a formal conference of the Irish leaders will be held. Among those who will take part in the deliberations will be Messrs. McCarthy, Power, Redmond, O'Kelly, Sexton, Kenny, and Arthur O'Connor. The aim of the conference will be a reunion of the two sections of the Irish party, based on the temporary retirement of Mr. Parnell from the leadership.

The Navy Appropriation bill, at least in its present form, feels the effects of the pension prodigality and other lavishness in which Congress indulged during its first session. The House Naval Committee has contented itself with providing for only one new vessel, a duplicate of Cruiser No. 12, now under construction.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- After a long discussion this afternoon, the Board of Trustees of the new Chicago University accepted the scheme of organization in which Dr. Harper's plans are embodied. The work of the university will be arranged under three general divisions -- the university proper, the university extension work, and the university publication work.

The Executive Committee of the Illinois Tariff-Reform League has arranged for a dinner at the Grand Pacific Hotel on Tuesday evening, Dec. 30. The principal object will be to celebrate the recent victories of the cause. Wayne MacVeagh of Pennsylvania, J. Sterling Morton of Nebraska, and John M. Palmer of Illinois will be among the bright lights in the assemblage.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- The fall of snow has been steady all day. Luckily, there was no wind to speak of, and the temperature was but 15 below freezing. Railroad travel has been delayed all day, Western trains being several hours behindhand. The electric-motor street cars had to suspend trips on some roads late in the day, and on others were kept running with difficulty.

CALCUTTA, Dec. 26. -- The National Indian Congress was opened in this city to-day. One thousand delegates were present, and there were 5,000 persons in the audience which listened to the deliberations of the meeting. Among those who attended were Charles Schwann and William Caine, members of the British House of Commons; several Rajahs and Mohammedan nobles, and a number of high-caste native ladies.

The civil courts are full of accident cases, claims for damages for injuries accidentally received. These suits are principally against mill owners, contractors, and railroad companies. The Penn sylvania Railroad Company, the Reading, and the Traction Company come in for a large share of such claims, and the verdicts are generally adverse to the defendants.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26. -- A conspiracy to flood the United States with counterfeit silver dollars has been unearthed here. Nineteen persons are already under arrest, and $1,100 in spurious coin is in the hands of the police. The money was brought from a central depot in New-York City to Pittsburg by a gang of Italians employed to pass it.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 26. -- The Democratic members of the Senate will hold a meeting next week to decide on the course to be adopted in the Senate relative to the Governorship contest. The Hon. E.S. Cleveland of this city will decline the Senate Presidency, the party considering his services on the floor of more consequence than in the President's chair.

Judge Henry Bischoff, Jr., in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday granted a motion made on behalf of Thomas B. Musgrave to have opened the default taken against him in the suit of Miss Lutie V. Smith for $50,000 damages for defamation of character. Mr. Musgrave's counsel urged that the case had been improperly advanced on the calendar and that his client was entitled to his day in court.

MADRID, Dec. 26. -- Two persons suffering from leprosy have been inoculated with lymph according to the method of Dr. Koch. The doctors of the hospital where the lepers are being treated report that the patients have apparently been rapidly improving since the new remedy was applied.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26. -- While the Knights of St. Patrick of St. Louis deeply lament the present dissension among their countrymen at home, they have no tears to shed over the defeat of Mr. Parnell. When he visited St. Louis several years ago the Knights paid him every consideration possible, and invested him with the insignia of their order.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The Rock Island express train due in Chicago at 10:50 o'clock this morning was an hour late. The engineer had a dispute with a farmer about the right of way, and an hour passed before the argument was finished. There was some strategy used by the trainmen, for they chased the farmer into the city, and then had him arrested for obstructing the railroad.

The system of post schools in our army is far from satisfactory, and if Congress can do anything to improve it the men will be the gainers. The trouble, according to Inspector General BRECKINRIDGE, is that "no adequate and definite work is made the special duty of the commissioned officers connected with the schools, and there are no special officers at department headquarters to supervise this work."

METZ RUINED. -- The trade of Metz I found ruined, and Metz was a thriving town once. "The old Messing," said a commercial traveler from German Rhineland to me -- under the shadow of that cathedral which Quicherat places in the same category with St. Ouen -- "hate us. And they are right. I say it as a German.

Dr. Heinrich Schliemann, the archaeologist, whose death was announced yesterday, has been known the world over as the "Discoverer of Troy," and, although it is by no means certain that he has a right to the title, it is universally admitted that the great work which he has performed as an explorer of ancient cities has placed archaeologists under great obligations to him.

An unusually largely-attended meeting of the Manhattan Club was held last evening to formally protest against the passage of Congressman Lodge's co-called Force bill. Frederic R. Coudert, President of the club, presided and made an earnest and well-considered speech against the measure fathered by Mr. Lodge, President Harrison, and other men prominent in the councils of the Republican Party.

FRENCH COOKERY, 1578. -- "The French," writes the Venetian Ambassador in 1578, "never spend money so willingly as when they are purchasing food, and making what they term bonne chere. This is the reason why butchers, restaurateurs, pastrycooks, and tavernkeepers abound. There is not a street in which you do not find them.

The sale of the horses of the late August Belmont's racing stable took place yesterday at the farm at Babylon, L.I. A hundred horsemen and about the same number of curiosity-seekers went to the farm to see the disposal of one of the most famous racing stables in America. Although the twenty-eight horses sold for $123,600, an average of $4,414, it would be useless to claim that the sale was a success.

Dr. Nansen has made a voluminous record of an exploring expedition in itself essentially very simple. We do not mean that this simplicity relates in any way to the quality of the endurance and fortitude required. It is intended rather to apply to the uniform nature of the experience he and his companions had to undergo.

As it is the fashion to take cognizance of the centennials of prominent events, it is apropos to note the fact that the coming year will be the centennial of the naming and describing of the dahlia, and that last year was the centennial of its first flowering in Europe after its introduction from Mexico, its native country.

Gov. Tillman's veto of the Railroad Commission act was one of the most novel proceedings of this "record-breaking year." His objections to the act were twofold: First, because it did not give the election of the Commissioners to the people direct; and, second, because the right of appeal to the courts from the decisions of the Commissioners would render nugatory the power of the Commissioners.

CHIMNEY POTS. -- When we reflect with satisfaction how far we have emancipated ourselves from the restraints of fashion in the matter of beards, does it not seem marvelous that we still endure the oppressive, though unwritten, law which constitutes the chimney-pot hat to be the only decorous headdress for well-to-do male humanity?

WINES. -- The vine is, in one respect, out of the many that could be mentioned, a particularly remarkable plant. It might be called a climatometer -- a measurer or indicator of climate. In cold, temperate regions it survives all but the severest Winters, grows vigorously, and clothes itself with healthy and luxuriant foliage; but the fruit which it may perchance produce cannot ripen into an eatable condition.

The steamship Elbruz, which arrived yesterday from Flushing, Belgium, brought the crew of a Gloucester fisherman, the Gracie C, Young, which had undergone a severe experience during the raging December gale of the last few days.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 27. -- It has been learned that for several weeks several chemists have been engaged at the torpedo station in the manufacture of a new smokeless powder according to a formula conceived by Prof. Charles E. Munroe, the regular chemist of the station. Several experiments have already been made with it which indicate a superiority over other smokeless powders, and this in two particulars.

SIR WALTER SCOTT'S LITERARY VENTURES. -- Before marriage he had written verses; but little had proceeded from his pen that was markedly superior to the rhymes of the day. A translation of Burger's "Leonore" caused Miss Cranstoun to remark: "Upon my word, Walter Scott is going to turn out a poet -- something of a cross, I think, between Burns and Gray."
A pretty story of Christmas peace and goodwill is left over from last year, but, like the holly and mistletoe, will fit any 25th of December.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The Socialist leaders issued a manifesto to-night. The document affirms the determination of the Socialist Party to rally the peasants around the flag of socialistic reforms. It says that the life of the agricultural laborers is scarcely human, and that they are serfs in all but name. They are exposed to the tyranny of capital quite as much as are the Russian factory hands.

I have received a very curious circular from the Tribune office, addressed "To Union Veterans." It says at the commencement that "the Republican defeat in the Congressional elections was due, primarily, to free-trade lying about the tariff," and then follows with a long diatribe regarding pensions, pension legislation,

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 27. -- The income from the railroad tax in this State for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1890, was $822,766, being a gain of $150,946, as compared with the previous year. The savings banks paid a tax of $246,799 into the State Treasury, while the mutual insurance companies paid $241,439. The increase for the year from ordinary sources of taxation was $201,980.

THE FIRST WRITER ON POLITICAL ECONOMY. -- Political economy, the dismal science, is generally supposed to be the creation of Adam Smith and the writers of the present century. It is, therefore, not without surprise that we find not only a treatise on the subject but the very name itself appearing in France as long ago as 1615.

UNDERGRADUATE PERVERSITY. -- It owed its existence to a passage in "Charles O'Malley," in which Mr. Frank Webb disguised himself as an itinerant organist and went about the streets of Dublin playing on a hurdy-gurdy and collecting coppers. The Government ought to have dealt very generously with our novelists, for few men have sent so many into the army as Charles Lever, or so many into the navy as Capt. Marryat.

The undertaking of a grand National Guard tournament at Creedmoor, with a view to constituting the enterprise an annual event, a scheme which has the sanction and approval of the Adjutant General and the earnest support of Gen. George W. Wingate, to whose persistency and energy the country is indebted for the present exalted status in rifle practice of the volunteer and regular military forces, has assumed a new phase.

Mr. Hans S. Beattie, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, is not happy. He says that he worked all the available forces of his department throughout Friday night and scarcely made an impression on the snow that shrouded the city. Mr. Beattie unquestionably carted off some snow, although it was scarcely apparent to an uninitiated observer just where he took it from.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 27. -- The recommendations of the committee of bankers who examined the affairs of the eight Westinghouse corporations are made public this evening. The recommendations are made to the two score subscribers (including seventeen banks) of the guarantee fund of $520,000 with which Mr. Westinghouse will tide over the money stringency.

The vow of his youth had been kept in his age. For five and twenty years Mr. Strange had shunned the demon rum. Total abstinence had had no more brightly shining example. In a quarter of a century no black bottle or portly demijohn or seductive flask had found its way into his household. His cook's sauces had been innocent of wine, and her mince pies had known not alcohol.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 27. -- The Rev. Edward G. Fullerton of Worcester, Mass., has been called to the pastorate of the Park Street Congregational Church in Bridgeport, succeeding the Rev. Dr. H.C. Hovey, and will begin his work there on Jan. 1. The Rev. James W. Moulton will be installed pastor of the Congregational church at Middle Haddam on Dec. 30, and the Rev. Charles H. Mcintosh will be installed at Plantsville on Jan. 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- Among the last items of business agreed upon by the Legislature before adjournment two years ago, was the appointment of a State Commission for the purpose of inquiry and investigation into the various systems of management governing the charitable and penal institutions of Pennsylvania, where State aid is part of the support.

THE DEPRAVATION OF WORDS. -- It is in the manufacture of new and unnecessary verbs, by the mangling or twisting of innocent substantives that some writers do most offend. A contributor to Bentley's Miscellany, nearly thirty years ago, wrote of some one whom, "as men said, the Nonconformists ambitioned to send into Parliament."

" F.H." -- If you wish a star atlas with which merely to determine the different constellations, Prof. Young's Uranography, published by Jinn Co., Boston, in pamphlet form, price 50 cents is the best for your purpose. If you employ this it would be advisable for the sake of conference to cut out the star maps and paste them upon cardboard. Besides the maps this pamphlet contains information about the stars.

UN BLAGUEUR ANGLAIS. -- We shall never adopt their system of shaving, nor they ours. I frequent for the purpose a showy little shop with a large "English spoken" across the front. I asked the attendant how much of the language of Shakespeare he knew. He knew "Yes," "'ow do you do?" "mees," "plum-puddeeng." "Goddam."

GABRIELLE BOMPARD'S plea of hypnotic suggestion lends interest to an article on the "Dangers of Hypnotism in the new Westminster Review. The author, Dr. ST. CLAIR THOMSON, besides pointing out the opportunities for crime which hypnotism offers, throws doubt upon the good results to be obtained from it, and in general belittles the importance of the recent investigations.

Grover Cleveland has a special fight to rejoice over the success which has been achieved thus far in the "campaign of education." He may rejoice frankly and openly, as he does, without immodesty. Of the events of the campaign he is justified in saying "Quorum magus pars fui." Frankness and boldness are parts of his character, and for these traits the American people admire him.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- According to charges made in court to-day, the P.E. Stanley-Winston Company, a well-known real estate corporation, has been wrecked by the speculations of the President, P.E. Stanley. Bertram M. Winston, the Treasurer, to-day applied for the appointment of a receiver for the concern and that the affairs of the corporation be wound up. Mr. Stanley is charged with misappropriating $70,000.

The Boston Post considers it probable that the decision of Judge Reed upon the constitutionality of the Pennsylvania oleomargarine law, as applied to trade in that article imported from other States in original packages, will be sustained by the higher court. The Post regards the decision as a sound one, and is of the opinion that the principle on which it is based applies also to the sale of liquors.

At a meeting of the creditors of Ambrose Eastman of Boston yesterday Mr. Eastman made a statement of his liabilities and assets. The liabilities, partly secured, he placed at about $30,000, the greater part of which was for indorsements of the paper of corporations which have recently failed. The assets consisted of his law library, book accounts to the value of a few hundred dollars, and shares of stock of various corporations.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- The November bulletin of the Stats Board of Health, issued today, contains these remarks:

WHAT IS THE TRUE TEXT? -- If a history of churches and church councils (which have aimed at oracularity) fail to present to us in any period of Christendom an infallible oracle, still greater is the failure to find such an oracle in the Bible, which is but one among many utterances of the Word of God, and does not pretend to prescribe definite code for the regulation of life.

The announcement that a special gun is under construction at the Washington Ordnance Yard for the purpose of using shells charged with emmensite sufficiently indicates the hopes that are entertained by the Navy Ordnance Bureau of this new high explosive. The system of armor for our ships is now practically settled; so is that of our heavy guns; while even the question of projectiles is also far advanced toward solution.

The presentment of the Grand Jury upon the care of "casuals" and upon the appointment of police matrons should receive the early attention of the incoming Legislature. Obviously the care of persons who find themselves at night in the city without the means of paying for even the shelter of the cheapest lodging houses is not the proper business of the police.
DENVER, Col., Dec. 27. -- A News special from Creston, S.D., via Rapid City, S.D., by courier, says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- At the meeting of the American Economic Association to-day a paper was read by Prof. F. W. Taussig of Harvard University entitled, "Contribution to the Theory of Railroad Rates."

THE EYES OF DEEP-SEA FISH. -- The queerest thing about deep-sea creatures is their arrangements for vision. Fish that live at very great depths have either no eyes at all or enormously big ones. Indeed, there are two ways you may get on in these gloomy abysses -- by delicate touch organs, or by sight that collects the few rays of light due to phosphorescence or other accidental sources.

The return of our Summer birds, after Winter has passed, is quite generally noted. But it is doubtful if nearly as many people ever note down the dates on which our birds leave in the Autumn. If they did, very possibly we would have predictions of cold or of mild Winters, based on their early or late departures, as well as by the advent of northern birds, such as the arctic owl.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 27. -- Lakewood's Christmas was homelike, social, and merry. The New-York trains of Wednesday brought large additions to the number of guests at the hotels and cottages, every one of which was crowded. The decorations at the Laurel House were elaborate and tasteful in holly and evergreen, and the cottages were made attractive with the same materials.

Christmas tide has brought for the first time in some years seasonable weather, and the social world has made merry in town and country all the more in consequence. While the snow delayed its advent just a few hours too long to make Thursday other than a "green Christmas," its coming was too surely foretold to allow of any croakings or depression on the part of even the most superstitious.

HOW SPIDERS KILL. -- Spiders kill their prey by the agency of a poisonous fluid, which is secreted in a gland, and which flows at will to the extremity of one of the fauces or jaws. Some writers have denied the existence of this poisonous substances but the effects which a spider's bite have been known to have upon a human being prove undoubtedly that it is present.

THE HISTORIC SCROLL OF EGYPT. -- The chronicles of Egypt are written on a scroll of such vast proportions that we often fail to realize them as a continuous record. Egypt is referred to as Ptolemaic, Roman, Arab, , as if the racial characteristics changed with the various dynasties. But the ancient race, the veritable descendants of the builders of the pyramids, still exists.

BOSTON, Dec. 27. -- Boston has had a book boom. Doubtless holiday goods generally have found ready sale, but the characteristic Boston trade has centred to an unusual extent upon books. The sales at the leading bookstores have been phenomenal, exceeding those of years more financially prosperous. Art gift books have not been the popular choice; for reasons not easy to define the current has set suddenly against them.

MOOR BATHS. -- The moor baths, of which much is now heard, and which are provided at many Austrian and German health resorts, were first used at Franzensbad. In 1823, Dr. Poschmann, a physician there, believed that he had found in them a new curative medium, and they have since become popular. Some physicians still question their efficacy, while others in Austria and Germany rely upon them to render good service in many maladies.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- It is announced that Chief Secretary Balfour has changed his mind and that he will not carry out the programme, previously mapped out by himself, of delivering a series of speeches in January through the Province of Ulster.

INSCRIPTIONS ON OLD STAINED GLASS. -- Most of the fragments of ancient stained glass handed down to us have inscriptions and dates introduced either on scrolls in the hands of the personages depicted or in some other manner. In the east window of the chapel in Haddon Hall, Derbyshire, for instance, we may read: "Orate proai'abus Ricardi Vernon et Jenette uxoris ejus qui fecerunt ano dni milesimo CCCCXXVII."

SIAMESE GIBBONS. -- I only once saw a specimen of the siamang in captivity at the house of a Malay chief at Sirdang. It was about three feet high, but the stretch of its arms was over five feet. A sad-looking, depressed creature it seemed as it moved awkwardly about the floor, tripping itself up with its own arms; but once among the rafters of the roof it moved with the agility of a spider.

The private secretary of a railroad man who is supposed to be worth $10,000,000 remarked yesterday that, if "the very rich" millionaires got as many begging letters prior to Christmas as did his employer, there was an unprecedented amount of begging done through the mails this year. "Persons who beg by letter," said he, "almost invariably name the amount of money that they desire to have sent to them.

Book collectors occasionally make lucky finds. No more than three weeks ago Mr. George P. Philes, the eminent authority upon Americans, and especially New-York and Philadelphia imprints, quite unexpectedly, while glancing over the books upon the ten-cent stand of an old book store of this city, come upon the first American edition of the "Vicar of Wakefield," printed in Philadelphia for William Mentz, and sold by most of the booksellers in America, 1772.

Once every year the local political organizations undergo a process of reorganization and rehabilitation through the medium of the primary election. The reorganization thus brought about differs in extent according to the needs of the party. The primaries this year will be particularly interesting in the Republican camp. The last election left the Republican local machine in a sadly damaged condition, whereas it left Tammany in practically better shape than ever.

THE LITERATURE OF THIBET. -- Thibetan literature to chiefly Buddhistic, but not wholly so. The capital of Thibet Lhasa, ("the seat of the gods,") is indeed the Rome of Buddhism, and in no other country does that religion attract higher patronage, and nowhere else is its philosophy more ardently studied.

MARX'S DOCTRINE. -- Marx's doctrine of the production of relative surplus value necessarily implies that as capital grows strong labor grows weak; that as the wealth of the capitalist accumulates the poverty of the laborer increases. Almost all modern Socialists have come to the same conclusion.

Many rivers flow through forest-clad Western Washington, flow from the eternal snow banks of the Cascade Range to Puget Sound or to the heaving water of the Pacific Ocean. Hundreds, yes, thousands, of smaller rivers, brooks, and creaks flow; some slowly as become streams of size, up which enormous salmon ascend to spawn; others with roars as of laughter rush in foam through boulder-strewn gorges to tumble down sloping falls

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- The announcement made in the newspapers of this city that the formal conference between the Irish leaders will take place on Monday next is officially stated to be premature. Mr. O'Brien has not yet seen Mr. Parnell.

The approaching marriage of that old Mormon, Father Time, with another New Year is announced, and the notice bears in bold, firm lettering the legend, "No cards." Since holiday cards first appeared there has never been such a dearth of thein as now. Booklets there are in plenty, and many of them quite pretty, but the genuine card is not among them.

The laws concerning the holding and government of slaves in the early days of the American colonies present some curious features and contain provisions little known to the reading public of these days. In Virginia, for instance, Indians as well as Africans could be held as slaves under statutory law between 1679 and 1691.

In the Passavant glove reappraisement case pending before the Board of General Appraisers, Special Agents Tingle and Wilbur of the Treasury Department, Examiner Leseur, and Appraiser Cooper gave further evidence in the case yesterday. Passavant Co. received a large consignment from Trefousse Co., dated July 30, which was divided into two shipments, one of which was dispatched by the La Champagne and the other by the City of New-York.

BURTON A MANY-SIDED MAN. -- He and I were only visitors, and had no official connection with the congress: the Royal Geographical Society, if I mistake not, was represented by its President, Lord Aberdare, who chanced to be passing by that way; but all the geographical societies of foreign nations had sent strong deputations, and men of science of all kinds had assembled from far and wide.

The bill introduced into the House of Representatives last session by Mr. Turner of Kansas and into the Senate by Mr. Walcott of Colorado to impose a special tax upon and to regulate the manufacture, sale, and importation of adulterated malt liquors is again before the Ways and Means Committee of the House, and the malsters on one side and the brewers on the other are preparing for a vigorous contest over it.

Incur Washington dispatches yesterday morning there was an explanation of Senator ALDRICH'S extraordinary move in regard to shutting off debate in the Senate that, whether correct or erroneous, is extremely significant. It was that the Senator from Rhode Island had introduced his proposition for closure in the most offensive form possible in order to provoke a prolonged debate and prevent any action in regard to silver legislation at the present session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,435,650, as follows: Currency 6s, $6,760,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $27,258,950; 4 per cents, $106,416,700.

AFTER ORCHIDS.--M. Charles Andre given an account of his experiences when on a botanical expedition by the shores of the River Amboan, which, though interesting to read when safe at home, gives a good idea of the unexpectod dangers often incurred by botanical collectors. M. Andre was in search of Cxlogyne asperata and happened to be in a Dyak hut when the natives were sorting rice preparatory to sowing it.

The figure of the Speaker of the House of Representatives is so familiar that it hardly warrants description. A tall man, of large and clumsy proportions, with a round, plump face and a cool, bold eye, carelessly clothed and unconcerned in his movements -- such, in brief, is Thomas B. Reed. His predecessor, Carlisle, now Senator from Kentucky, is as unlike him in appearance as it is possible for him to be.

The Secret Service Bureau in this city is not a widely-advertised place and the methods used in detecting the counterfeit money men are kept as close as the name of the bureau would imply. Outside of the office itself there is probably not any one who knows how many men are employed in running down those who make and sell the base coin or counterfeit the bills.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- Notwithstanding the protests made by Mr. Ribot, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and M. Roche, Minister of Commerce, against the Tariff Committee's augmentation of the tariff duties proposed in the Government bill, the committee continued, until adjournment, to raise the tariffs to a prohibitive pitch.
" What is the hottest city in the world, uncle?" asked Alan, looking up from his geography.

There is scarcely any form of property bought for pleasure that of late years has returned to its possessor in this city so small a return in pleasure upon his investment as a sleigh. Last Winter and the Winter before the sleighs of the metropolis industriously gathered mold in their lofts. Yesterday, for the first time in three Winters, there was what could fairly be called sleighing.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 27. -- The Angelita, a ship flying the Spanish flag, has been captured off the west coast of Florida by the United States revenue steamer McLane. The Angelita has just been brought into part by an armed prize crew under the command of Lieut. P.H. Uberroth of the McLane, and is now in the hands of the United States authorities at Key West.

The mammoth brewing establishment of Mr. George Ehret will be gayly decorated with flags and bunting from sub-cellar to turret all day to-morrow in honor of the marriage of Mr. Ehret's eldest daughter, Miss Anna Magdalena Ehret, to Carl Baron von Zedlitz-Leipe of Prinsnig, Silesia, Germany. The wedding will take place at Goerbersdorf, Silesia.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- Advices from Rome state that the Pope has finished the draught of his encyclical upon the social question. His Holiness has been working upon the subject for over a year, and at his request the most competent economists and Bishops of different countries, including America, have furnished memoranda.

The immediate occasion of this query is the recent remark of an esteemed contemporary. Just what that remark was does not matter at this time. It was not at all sour or discourteous, but it revealed a tendency to look upon those who disagreed with it as Wagnerites; and a Wagnerite, dear reader, is more to be dreaded than a Hittite or a Jebusite or a Canaanite or oven a Harlemite.

President MICHAEL COLEMAN'S letter to the Deputy Tax Commissioners reproves in temperate language the perpetrators of a gross public abuse. The reports of the various Deputies show that they have made what Mr. COLEMAN calls a "marked increase" in the assessed value of real estate for 1891 in all parts of the city.

The broad inclosure in Aberdeen whose massive gates bore the inscription "The Williams Steel Works" contained a curious and yet not unpleasing combination of the past and the present. In the rear stretched the furnaces, the foundries, the engine houses, and the warerooms, begirt by masses of ore and slag and veiled by viscid smoke and cloudy steam -- the exemplification of progress.

An English gentleman who has lived many years in India tells some queer stories about the sacred monkeys that are a great nuisance in some parts of that country. No one is allowed to molest them. They run about the streets, help themselves to whatever they please at the shops, rob orchards and gardens, and play havoc generally.

GLASSGOW, Dec. 27. -- There is a slight change for the better in connection with the railroad strike. Even the strikers admit that the railroad companies are making improvements in the train services. The number, regularity, and punctuality of the trains are increasing, and with this improvement the hopes of success for the strikers get smaller and smaller.

Two more Western railroad companies have ratified the agreement approved by the meeting of railroad Presidents held at J. Pierpont Morgan's house in this city on the 15th inst. This makes ten of the sixteen roads represented at the meeting. The Directors of the Southern Pacific Road met in San Francisco yesterday, and, after unanimously approving the plan, appointed President C.P. Huntington and Vice President J.C. Stubbs to represent the company in the Advisory Board.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The labor organizations of this city and State are about to commence a crusade agaainst the system of convict labor. The Granite Cutters, Marble Cutters, and Marble Polishers' Unions have decided to take decisive action, and will send a delegation to Harrisburg during the next session to petition the Legislature against the further employment of convict labor in the manufacture of any goods not required by the prisons.

Will you permit one who has had twenty-five years' practical experience as a bank officer in this city to offer a few remarks upon Mr. Atkinson's recent address? Are his premises correct? He says: "It is a time of profound peace." Is this true, in the sense his words convey? A true peace implies the happy mud contented condition of the plain people. Was there ever so much unrest and discontent?

The all-absorbing topic at the Union League Club is the election of club officers which will be held at the January meeting. There have been rumors that Mr. Depew wished to retire from the Presidency, and that his name will not appear on the ticket. The contrary is the case. Mr. Depew is a candidate and his name will head the regular ticket.
A brief examination in the way of a trial balance, to show how much there is to discourage and how much to encourage the friend of revenue reform in this important State, may be worth the making.

No duty under the United States Government is at ones so arduous and full of danger as that which usually falls to the lot of the revenue cutter officer. The revenue cutters seldom exceed 400 tons in displacement. They are either single-screw or twin-screw ships. On a few of the stations they are side-wheel craft. The batteries for these vessels range between two and four guns.

The sun rises on New Year's Day about 7:15 and sets about 4:30, which makes the day almost nine and a quarter hours in length. The increase in the length of the day for the month will be fifty minutes, and at the month's close we shall have almost an hour of daylight added to the shortest day of the year at the Winter solstice.

Old Japan, with its feudal chivalry, its ceremonious etiquette, its bloody hara-kiri, and all the brilliant color of its ancient life is gone forever. The story of the past is only partly known to the world as yet, but in the romantic history of the olden time are embalmed examples of honor and loyalty, tales of courageous deeds, and legends of the doings of the mythical heroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Congress and the copyright law have made a library large to overflowing for its present quarters. It is in the Capitol, and so is near the Congress. Sometimes it seems regrettable that the Congress is not better acquainted with the library. It is chiefly Congressional because the Congress has to provide for it.

ENGLISH CAVALRYMAN IN BARRACKS. -His duty is monotonous in the extreme -the same place -- the same work -- the same comrades. He lives, works, moves in a perpetual groove. In the ordinary course of each week he has no holiday except a Sunday half holiday. On Saturday his so-called half holiday drill simply gives place to fatigue duty.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 28. -- The question of ballot reform is engaging the attention of the intelligent people of Maine just now, and the belief is almost general that the Republican members of the Legislature chosen last September will be forced by public opinion to join with the few Democrats who will sit with them in the passage of a secret-ballot law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Promotions have been very slow in both the army and navy during the year just ending, and the outlook for 1891 will not be much more cheerful unless Congress passes some of the personnel bills now pending. During the present year the staff corps of the army has fared comparatively well, the Paymaster General, Commissary General, Quartermaster General, and Surgeon General all retiring for age.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28. -- The following is printed in a morning paper here:

The J.W. Dann Manufacturing Company Carriage and Wagon Works, Columbus, Ohio, burned at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. The fire originated in the drying kiln and spread through the building by way of the elevator. It was beyond control when the department arrived. The total damage was $48,000, the estimated value being: Five-story building, $20,000; machinery, $22,000, and stock, $6,000.

Senator EDMUNDS is not ingenuous. When he represents the Aldrich rule for shutting off debate as being simply a measure to enable the majority definitely to dispose of a bill after every Senator has had an opportunity to express his opinion, he is guilty of that form of misrepresentation known as suppressio veri.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 28. -- The Hebrews of the Court Street Synagogue, composing the leading and wealthiest congregation of that faith in this city, are engaged in a movement to change their day of worship from Saturday to Sunday, with the idea of making the change national. This is regarded here as the most progressive undertaking of the Hebrews in this age, and is favored by all except some of the most orthodox believers.
Superintendent Martin of the Brooklyn Bridge was asked yesterday how much he expected would be realized from the study which the commission of experts has given to the bridge problem.

The progress made in building up the new navy has been more marked in the year 1890 than in any other twelve months since the beginning of the rehabilitation. This progress has been due to the constantly increasing efficiency of the shipbuilding establishments, and warrants the belief that the United States Navy is now relatively stronger in comparison with European navies than at any time since the close of the civil war.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 28. -- The Bijou Theatre of this city, one of the most prosperous popular-priced houses in the entire West, was burned at 7 o'clock this morning, involving a loss of from $30,000 to $40,000. The building was on Washington, near Hennepin Avenue, was owned by Lambert Hayes of this city and leased by Jacob Litt, who has also theatres in Milwaukee, St. Paul, and Chicago.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- During the past week discount was firm and in good demand. There was the usual inquiry for accommodation observable toward the end of the year. Discount was quoted at 4 for three months and 3 for short. There was nothing doing on the Stock Exchange. The settlement was commenced yesterday, but as the bulk of the arrangements had been made on Wednesday there was a thin attendance.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Dec. 28. -- The news to-day indicates that the Indian troubles are about to be brought to a close without the sacrifice of any more lives. Gen. Miles's advices of last evening that hostiles in the Bad Lands had listened to the logic and persuasion of Gen. Brooke's Ogalalla and Brule peace commissioners and were moving in toward Pine Ridge, were confirmed by Gen. Brooke's dispatches today.

The British Admiralty is putting in practice some of the methods of the United States Naval Intelligence Office. An officer is now detailed on each British cruiser as a representative of the British Naval Intelligence Office. A "confidential" book is kept as aboard American cruisers. This latter fact is not generally known to the British. Surprise was recently evinced by several British officers on being informed of the American practice.

If life in some eon yet to come is to be but one long water party on the Thames, and occupation but the cutting of grass in the meadows, then Mr. Morris describes that utopian age. "Looking Backwards" finds simply another treatment by the author of "The Earthly Paradise," and it is the aesthetic or sentimental side of future socialism which, in a measure, entrances him.

The joys of the Christmas festival held in Tony Pastors Theatre and Tammany Hall, last night will be long remembered by the 400 children who participated in and were benefited by it. The entertainment included a varied theatrical performance by the children of the stage, a sumptuous feast, a distribution of toys, and a dance.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 28. -- The Secretary of State is required to publish a report of criminal statistics biennially. One was published last year, and the next is due in 1891. The County Clerks, however, make their reports to the Secretary of State annually, so that here are now in his office the returns from every country in Iowa for the year ending June 30, 1890.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28. -- The conflict which has for two years been going on between the Rev. Father A.M.J. Hynes, pastor of St. Patrick's Church at Pierce City, Lawrence County, Mo., and the Right Rev. B.J. Hogan, Bishop of the Diocese of Kansas City, has again broken out with renewed vigor. It is without precedent in this country.

Yesterday was "Hospital Sunday," and collections were taken up in the following churches at the morning service: Broadway Tabernacle Incarnation, Holy Trinity, West Presbyterian, St. Bartholomew's, Heavenly Rest, All Souls' Fifth Avenue, and Grace. At the latter the collection amounted to $1,429.61, at the Heavenly Rest it was $714, and at Dr. Hall's church, the Fifth Avenue, $100 was given to the fund and $5,000 to the Presbyterian Hospital.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Within a radius of a few miles in this section there are a great many instances of longevity. In this city there are several persons nearly one hundred years old and in the surrounding country are many more.

The American girl is to the fore again, the Marquis de Breteuil being engaged to Miss Garner, first cousin of Lady Vernon. She is one of three sisters, all ambitious of being in the front rank of European society. Their father and mother were drowned at sea, yachting. The former was President of the New-York Yachting Club, an the latter was a member of the wealthy Lawrence family of that city.

In December, 1886, a number of young society men, then undergraduates of Columbia College, organized the now celebrated Columbia College Dramatic Club, probably the strongest club of amateur actors in existence to-day in the United States.

Private advices received here from Russia represent the persecuting measures against the Jews to be by no means prompted exclusively by religious intolerance. It is pointed out that in a country where there are a thousand different religious sects, and where nearly half the population is schismatic, the Jews would hardly be persecuted on account of their faith.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 28. -- About 2 o'clock last night a fire broke out in what is known as the new roundhouse of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad Company, which is used for the purpose of housing to locomotives of the Seaboard Railway system. The house was a half moon, built of brick, with an iron roof supported by native pine wood, and cost $20,000.

On New Year's Night the Liliputians will present a new operetta at the Park Theatre entitled "The Dwarf Wedding at the Court of Peter I.," which they have presented successfully in Berlin, Hamburg, and St. Petersburg. The story deals with the dwarf colony which Peter I. established for his own amusement, and the operetta is said to be full of taking melodies.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- A specia United States Fisheries Commission car from the Government hatcheries in Illinois completed its work of distributing fish fry in the upper waters of the Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers adjacent to the Erie Railroad just before these streams were closed by ice. The distribution was made under the supervision of Mr. H.C. Ford, President of the Pennsylvania State Fish Commission.
We published on the 26th inst. the following dispatch relating to the intentions of the manufacturers of plate glass:

-- The Cherokees in Pre-Columbia Times. By Prof. Cyrus Thomas. New-York: N.D.C. Hodges. -- This treatise is a valuable contribution to the question, Who were the mound builders? Prof. Thomas, who has published many monographs on the Indians of North and Central America, examines the mound-building habits of the ancestors of the Cherokees and tries to unravel the tangle of their migrations during the centuries preceding the advent of the whites.

The present week is to owners of thoroughbred horses one of the most important of the year, as on Thursday the stakes for the Brooklyn Jockey Club's Spring meeting will close, those for the Coney Island and New-York Clubs closing on the following day. The stakes for a half dozen Western racing associations do not close until Jan. 15.

If the Senators who are vexing their souls over the kind of finance bill that can be agreed upon in Washington would take the trouble to consult a few intelligent New-York business men they would discover very promptly that no bill is needed, none is wanted, and none can be passed that would not do more harm than good.

That very impertinent woman, Mme, Novikoff, whose face was verbally slapped, so to speak, by the Duchess of Sutherland some years ago, again showed her boldness and invited further smitings, on the occasion of the meeting held lately at the Guildhall, in London, with the object of expressing "public opinion upon the renewed persecutions to which millions of the Jewish race are subjected in Russia under the yoke of severe and exceptional edicts and disabilities."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The following letter from George R. Davis, Director General of the Columbian Exposition, was received by President Harrison Saturday:

TRENTON, Dec. 28. -- The Hudson Assemblymen appointed by the local caucus to make a canvass of the Assemblymen on behalf of Assemblyman Mullone's candidacy for the Speakership have within the last week been all over the Fourth Congressional District. It is in this district that the county of Somerset, which Mr. Bergen, who is Mr. Mullone's competitor in the Speakership contest, represents, lies.

In the arguments for and against the reorganization of the navy personnel, as urged by Lieut. Fullam in a paper recently read before the Naval Institute, the marine has had some able defenders. His side of the controversy has been no more strongly presented than is the following extracts from a letter written to a friend by a well-known officer now on duty in the department at Washington.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- Having been advised that he cannot bring an action for libel with hopes of success, Capt. O'Shea has published a letter to disprove the truth of Timothy Healy's taunt that he bartered his wife's honor to gain a seat in Parliament. The letter is dated "Stalbridge, Dec. 24, 1890." The writer says:

By his will, which bears the date March 20, 1885, the late Mr. Charles Edward Mudie of 31 Maresfield Gardens, formerly of The Limes, Muswell Hill, who died on Oct. 28 last, aged seventy-two years, leaving personalty valued at 59,347 11s. 1d., bequeaths to his wife 2,000 (to be paid within three months) and his pictures, books, plate, and furniture.
" There was a time when cotton was worth $1,000 a bale; now it is only worth about $50," sighed a veteran cotton broker recently, as he sauntered around the "pit" of the New-York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Some of the Republican Senators who have been reading what Mr. Edmunds had to say about the necessity for a gag rule in the Senate to pass the Force bill detect in his conversation the evidence of an alliance between the Vermont Senator and the President against Mr. Blaine.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- In the course of a long interview concerning the work of the Farmers' Alliance Convention recently held in Florida,. U.S. Hall, President of the Missouri Alliance, was asked: "What do you think of your organization becoming a separate political party and nominating a ticket in 1892?"

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- The fourteenth annual meeting of the New-York State Bar Association will be held in this city Jan. 20 and 21, 1891. The Hon. Mathew Hale, President of the association, will deliver the opening address. The annual address will be delivered by the Hon. John S. Wise of Virginia, his subject being "New Sources of Litigation," under which he will discuss the character of controversies which have arisen between electrical enterprises.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Official dispatches from Gen. Miles dated Rapid City, S.D., were received to-night by Gen. Schofield telling of the fight in the Bad Lands to-day between the Indian hostiles and the white troops. The dispatches were first sent by Gen. Brooke to Gen. Miles. The first was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Secretary Tracy issued a circular to-day, prescribing very minutely the course to be followed in surveys and repairs of vessels in commission, and definitely fixing the responsibility for the work in its various stages.

One of the worthiest of modern English plays was worthily produced at Palmer's Theatre last evening. "Judah," by Henry Arthur Jones, was acted with rare skill and sympathy, in a setting of unusual beauty, and was received with the closest attention and rewarded with perfectly honest applause by a distinguished audience. There are not many such nights in the routine of the habitual playgoer.

THE Board of Police Justices held their annual meeting last night in one of the rooms of the Jefferson Market Court, and all of the fifteen were there except Justice Murray. The following assignments were made for the ensuing year:

The three political shepherds of Ohio -- DELANO, HARPSTER, and LAWRENCE -- have been very quiet since the election. But while they are not thrusting themselves before the public, we can believe that they are chuckling in some obscure retreat over the tricks in the new wool tariff that are coming to light, and are heartily enjoying the decisions of the Treasury Department-which make those tricks successful.

The collar of Mr. Jay Gould and the neck of Mr. Park Commissioner Paul Dana were presented in conjunction to the admiring gaze of mutual friends at yesterday's meeting of the Park Commissioners. It seemed to be a very snug and comfortable fit, and was evidently much enjoyed by the young Commissioner, in spite of the tight leash that held it.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 29. -- A dispatch to the Bee from Pine Ridge says:
CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- The following was received at Army Headquarters to-night at a late hour:

Athletic games were given last evening by Company E, Ninth Regiment, and the Star Athletic Club of Long Island City, in the Ninth Regiment Armory, 219 West Twenty-sixth Street. Several hundred persons witnessed the contests, and after they were over, the armory floor was cleared for dancing. B.C. Williams of the New-York Athletic Club was referee of the games, and C.J. Harvey of the Star Athletic Club was the official announcer.

We presume that some persons have recently scanned the pages of the pension attorneys' newspaper for some expression of opinion concerning the pending bills for a reduction of the pension attorneys' fees. Perhaps they expected to find there also some protest against the demands of many prominent Republican papers for such a reduction, and the very uncomplimentary remarks in the same journals about the pension attorneys themselves.

Senator Hendricks presided at yesterday's session of the Senate Committee on Cities investigation in Part II, of the Superior Court. Senator Fassett was detained in Elmira by business. Senator Hendricks has not appeared before at the meetings of the committee for several weeks. Mr. Ivins continued his inquiry into the Street-Cleaning Department and incidentally directed it into the rather remarkable official career of Michael Whelan, the Superintendent of the department.

The eighty-first birthday of Mr. GLADSTONE is an event considerably more momentous to Irish as well as to English politics than the conference of PARNELL and O'BRIEN. The Parnellites are placarding Ireland with an absurd appeal to Irishmen against "lowering the flag of independence on the vague promises of English statesmen."
Mayor Grant received from William Steinway yesterday the following letter accepting his appointment as Rapid-Transit Commissioner:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- At the close of Saturday night's performance Mr. Arthur Dacre, the handsome English actor, who is Mrs. Leslie Carter's leading support, will sever his connection with the "Ugly Duckling" Company, the trouble between him and E.D. Price, the manager of Mrs. Carter, having resulted in Mr. Dacre's receiving a two weeks' notice to that effect.

Young George Work, son of Frank Work, drove up the road yesterday afternoon in a light Portland sleigh, drawn by a small iron-gray mustang colt. With him was John McCahill, one of the grooms of the Work stable. The colt had been in George Work's possession about a year, and several efforts had been made, it is said, to trade it off for a more tractable piece of horse flesh.

The substance of Prof. CHANDLER'S plan for street cleaning is simply that the force of the department should be organized upon a permanent business basis and made independent of politics. The detail as to assigning a certain number of men to a certain limited district and holding them responsible for its condition would suggest itself to any man who was at liberty to apply natural methods.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The members of the Civil Service Commission have sent to the President a letter in reply to certain statements made by Postmaster General Wanamaker on pages 4, 37, 38, and 39 of his last annual report.

The Baptist pastors yesterday listened to an interesting paper on "The Missionary Spirit' by the Rev. Dr. Edward Judson, pastor of the Berean Baptist Church. The debate following the reading of the paper was participated in by the Rev. Dr. Mason, the Rev. Dr. Samson, the Rev. Dr. McBride, the Rev. Leighton Williams, and the Rev. Dr. N.E. Wood.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- About six months ago a man named Hallenbake opened a dry goods store in East Main Street here, and after a few months was succeeded by William J. Mills, who, in turn, made an assignment last week. One of the principal creditors in the Hallenbake failure was Mrs. Flora J. Orr, who runs "The Fair" In Brooklyn.

The question of providing an adequate system of rapid transit for this city will be an urgent topic of discussion with the people until it has been solved. The appointment of a new commission and the approach of a new session of the Legislature give it special prominence just now. Mr. JAY GOULD has seized the occasion to put in a plea for the extension of the privileges of the present elevated railroads.

The Jewelry trade of this city has again been victimized. Albert Jahn, who kept a jewelry store at 389 Eighth Avenue, put all of his portable stock in two big valises on Christmas Eve, and is now in parts unknown. A half dozen wholesale firms, which sold him goods on one-third credit in spite of warnings from the Jewelers' Board of Trade, mourn their flight.

The opinion of the Berlin expert, reported in our cable dispatches, as to the operation of the new tariff on German exports is instructive. He is said to believe that there are two disadvantages under which American competitors with German manufacturers labor, and which, taken together, will prevent any serious injury to the German export trade.
PARIS, Dec. 29. -- Mr. O'Brien received an Associated Press correspondent to-day at the residence of M. Raffolovitch, his father-in-law.

The Cherokees have at last come within hailing distance in their negotiations for the sale of the Outlet. They want $2 an acre for it and the Government's offer is $1.25. As about 6,000,000 acres are involved, the bidding and asking prices are about $4,500,000 apart. That is a large sum, but it is probably capable of being scaled down.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 29. -- The stranded schooner Yale lies high and dry on the beach near the foot of Deal Lake. Capt. Simpson and his crew have left Life-Saving Station No. 6 and again taken up their quarters on the vessel. The steamer Rescue of the Merritt Coast Wrecking Company of New-York lies anchored abreast of the stranded vessel and has attached two heavy steel hawsers to her bow.

ONAMA, Neb., Dec. 29. -- Attempts were made this morning by the Milwaukee and Rock Island Railroads to run trains across the Union Pacific Bridge, but the switches remained locked and the trains were obliged to return the Council Bluffs transfer. S.H.H. Clark, General Manager of the Union Pacific, was seen by a reporter and said that the Union Pacific proposed to do its own business.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Jesse James's wildest exploits at frontier settlements were outdone in Chicago to-day by three stock-yard toughs. The Chicago bandits are undoubtedly the same that a fortnight ago coolly robbed the office of the Allerton Packing House within a few feet of hundreds of Allerton's butchers armed with cleavers and knives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Ex-Surgeon General and Mrs. Moore gave a handsome dinner, followed by a reception, to-night, in honor of Cardinal Gibbons. The guests were Gen. and Mrs. Butterfield, who came from New-York for this occasion; Senator and Mrs. Manderson, Chief Justice and Mrs. Fuller, Dr. and Mrs. William A. Hammond, and Mrs. Gen. Miles. Mrs. Moore wore a gown of black lace.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- At Hawarden Castle to-day the eighty-first birthday of William Ewart Gladstone is being celebrated with quiet rejoicings. Telegrams of congratulation and large numbers of presents arrived during the early part of the day from all parts of Great Britain, and there were also received several congratulatory cable messages from the United States.

If ever sea Captain bad occasion to use all his wit and efforts to reach New-York Harbor on a given date, Capt. Sproul of the fine four-masted ship Walter H. Wilson has at this present moment.
