It means $3,000 in solid cash to his owners if he gets up to Quarantine by tomorrow midnight; but he seems to be having a sort of Flying Dutchman's luck in his endeavors to make his port.

Historical lessons do not impress the practical politicians of our country much more than they do the lighter-minded of our journalists. The latter disparage them with cheerful modernness as "back numbers" and the former look with wonder not unmingled with contempt at any other politician who ventures to cite them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A paper was read before the American Economic Association to-day by T.G. Shearman of New-York, entitled "Crooked Taxation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The skirmish lines of the Force bill advocates, the gag-rule supporters, the free-coinage adherents, and the opponents of each were moved a little nearer each other to-day. There was a little manoeuvring for position and a little progress toward the grand charge, which is awaited with so much interest by all concerned, and by so much doubt as to the result by a good many of those who will take part.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 29. -- The opinion of the court filed at Towson to-day stating that the bondsmen of Stevenson Archer are liable for his defalcation as Treasurer of the State, is the first point scored in the very remarkable contest and it is accepted as an indication that the State will get the money, although the case is only in the preliminary stage and is not before a jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- The American Chemical Society, a national organization, comprising in its membership the most noted and best-known analysts and chemists in the United States, met in first semi-annual session for the year 1890 at Newport, R.I., last July, and tomorrow morning the second meeting takes place in one of the halls of the University of Pennsylvania.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 30. -- More than a thousand delegates to the Minnesota Farmers' Alliance State Convention assembled at the Newmarket Theatre this morning at 10:45 o'clock and held three sessions, the last not ending until nearly midnight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The American Window Glass Company will commence active business operations after the first of the new year. This decision was reached at a meeting of glass manufacturers held to-day at the Auditorium Hotel. The glass men were in session all day long and it was late this evening before the final touches were given to the big combination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- There was an unexpected little skirmish to-day between the factions of the Republican majority. It amounted to nothing as to results, but it was very entertaining to the spectators, especially the Democrats, and it served to show very plainly the torn-up condition of affairs within the Republican ranks.

A letter from Washington was received by Collector Erhardt yesterday, which conveyed an order that is going to again direct public attention to the famous litigation in the hat ribbon cases which so long occupied the attention of the courts and of the business public. The Supreme Court's decision, it will be remembered, was in favor of the importers and against the Government.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- The statement in THE TIMES of Dec. 21 that Robert Shaw Oliver of this city would succeed Gen. Amasa J. Parker as Brigadier General of the Third Brigade was verified this evening when Gov. Hill gave out the information that he had accepted Gen. Parker's resignation and appointed Gen. Oliver in his stead.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- An extraordinary outrage was perpetrated last Saturday night at Hurleyville, a station on the Ontario and Western Railroad, thirty miles north of here. Mrs. Parker, a widow, is housekeeper for John Knapp, a merchant there. Mrs. Parker has a comely daughter named Gertrude, who is understood to be affianced to Roswelt Vernoy, a young farmer in the neighborhood.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, Dec. 30. -- Early this morning another bloody battle took place between the Indians in Two Strikes' band and soldiers near this agency. A number of soldiers were killed and wounded and thirty-three of Two Strikes' band were killed.

A move toward paying off the liabilities of the North River Bank was made yesterday by Francis Higgins, the receiver, who applied through his attorneys, Doherty, Durnin Hendrick, for an order for the publication of notice to the bank's debtors and creditors. Judge Beach of the Supreme Court, to whom the application was made, signed the order.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Star this evening says that Senator George of Mississippi has received a number of letters relating to the killing of Postmaster Matthews, who was in charge of the office at Carrollon, Senator George's home. The following epistle, given to a Star reporter by the Senator this afternoon, is from the Baptist minister in that town:

In the Century for January is printed the first installment of selections from the so-long-expected Talleyrand "Memoirs," made by arrangement with the publishers of the complete work in advance of its appearance. A brief introduction by the American Minister to France enumerates some of the striking points in Talleyrand's career, and quotes opinions of Talleyrand that have been expressed by many French and other writers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The pilot chart of the North Atlantic Ocean, for the month of January, 1891, will be issued by the Hydrographic Office of the Navy Department to-morrow, and will be of more than usual interest.

The controversy between the Union Pacific Railroad and the Rock Island and St. Paul Railroads over the Union Pacific's Omaha bridge is just now the chief topic of interest among railroad men both East and West. Its effect on the new President's agreement is a matter of much concern.

The speech of Mr. WOLCOTT, Senator from Colorado, against the Force bill, made yesterday, adds one more to the Republican opponents of that measure. The list now embraces Senators CAMERON and QUAY of Pennsylvania, STEWART of Nevada, WOLCOTT of Colorado in open opposition. Senators PLUMB and TELLER in scarcely-concealed opposition, and Senator CULLOM in ill-concealed opposition.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- A fire broke out in the vicinity of Queen Victoria and Thames Streets, near Blackfriar's Bridge, just before 2 o'clock this afternoon, which, before it was under control, at 6 o'clock, had laid in ruins four large blocks, with a loss estimated at $2,000,000.

COLUMBUS, Dec. 30. -- President Thurman of the American Baseball Association arrived home to-day from his visit to Toledo, where he went, accompanied by President Van Der Ahe of St. Louis, for the purpose of buying the franchise of the Toledo Club. He made an offer of $7,000, but the club officials would not listen to the proposition.

It is perfectly natural that physicians in good standing, who have spent time and money in the acquirement of a skill that makes their services of value to the community, should object to being placed on the level of unskilled laborers when the question of their compensation is being discussed.

Dozens of city officials have occupied the witness chair before the Senate Committee on Cities, but none of them have enjoyed the position quite as much as has President H.H. Porter of the Department of Charities and Correction. He is so completely satisfied with the management of his department that he is all the while bubbling over with praises of it and of the men who have the various institutions in charge.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30. -- It was learned here to-day that the first official act of the American Harvester Company of Illinois, a consolidation of the eighteen harvester companies of the United States, with headquarters in Chicago, will discharge about 10,000 employes, whose services are rendered unnecessary by the consolidation of eighteen separate and distinct companies into one monopoly.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- Secretary of State Rico said to-night that the designation of the paper to publish the public notices, otherwise known as the State paper, would be announced to-morrow. This has hung fire for some time.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- When William F. Sheehan visited New-York soon after the late election, he told the newspaper men who met him at the Hoffman House that under no circumstances would he favor the unseating by the Democratic Legislature this Winter of Republican members who had been honestly elected. Of course this was pure buncomb.

William Ziegler, who, as a taxpayer of Brooklyn, obtained the injunction restraining the purchase of the Long Island Water Supply Company by the city for $1,250,000, denied yesterday that he had ever been a stockholder and had been frozen out, or had ever wanted to get into the deal and been refused.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 30. -- The Senate Chamber, at the State House, where the Supreme Court holds its sittings in full bench when the Legislature is not in session, was crowded at 3 o'clock this afternoon with representative leaders and politicians of the two parties, including many lawyers outside the counsel engaged on the respective sides in the hearing on the petitions for injunction and mandamus against Clerk Jewett of the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Vice President and Mrs. Morton will give their first dinner of the season Jan. 9 in honor of the President. This will be followed by a reception. Baron von Kossman is at present their guest. Miss Rachel Sherman will arrive to-night from New-York for a visit to them, and will assist Mrs. Morton in receiving on New Year's Day.

With an earnestness and enthusiasm characteristic of their efforts at the polls, the members of the Harlem Democratic Club celebrated last night the recent national Democratic victory, and four members of the Congressional delegation from this city co-operated with them in doing honor to the triumphant cause. It was a joyous banquet that enlivened the Harlem Democratic Club house in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.

Commissioner BEATTIE undertook to demonstrate to the Board of Estimate and Appointment yesterday that he could clean the streets of this city during the coming year with the sum of $1,787,774.81, of which $274,000 was to be put into covered carts and other equipment, and not with a cent less.

Bateman Co., bankers at 57 Broadway, drew up an assignment for the benefit of their creditors yesterday afternoon, too late to be filed in the office of the County Clerk. At the same time the senior member of the firm, Commodore Arthur E. Bateman, prepared a personal assignment. For both the firm and Mr. Bateman the assignee is John A. Garver of Sherman Sterling, lawyers. The papers will be filed this morning.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 30. -- An ingenious Minneapolis man has invented and placed on sale what he calls a "spirit level," and with it he proposes to stamp out prohibition in Iowa and the Dakotas.

When General Appraisers Tichenor, Somerville, and Sharpe began their investigation of the Passavant kid-glove reappraisement case they struck a mine of information showing several veins of exceeding richness. A Congressional investigating committee, with power to send for persons and papers, and a purpose to get at the truth and the whole truth, could follow one of these veins with great profit to the tariff-ridden people of the country.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The permanent residents and Summer cottagers of the town of Long Branch, which also includes Elberon, West End, Hollywood, Norwood Park, and North Long Branch, will have a big New Year's gift. It is a statement from the Board of Commissioners showing that the town is entirely free from floating indebtedness.

Here is another illustration, if any were needed, of the arbitrary and mischievous influence of high-tariff legislation upon business. Under the law of 1888, which was much more carefully prepared and compiled than the law of 1890, it happened that there was confusion as to the duties on hat trimmings.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- The annual report of the Superintendent of State Prisons, Mr. Austin Lathrop, is devoted largely to the operations of the present convict labor law, and for that reason it is unusually interesting. Superintendent Lathrop defines the aims of the law as follows:

It would be an abuse of language to describe as a battle the encounter that took place on Monday between United States troops and hostile Indians. The Indians were captives and were surrounded by four times their number of armed white soldiers. They themselves were armed and it was the order to give up their arms that brought on the conflict.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- John J. Reed, who was indicted with Cain and Buett for misplacing the "cabbage" switch on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad near Greenbush during the big strike, and who made a confession before the Grand Jury, was sentenced this morning in the Court of Sessions by Judge Griffith to seven years' imprisonment in Clinton Prison at Dannemora.

The pantomime produced at Niblo's last night ought to please the frequenters of that big playhouse for a long while. It is a beautiful stage exhibition, and pictorially it far surpasses any of the recent shows of the eminent Kiralfys. As "The Babes in the Wood, Robin Hood and His Merry, Merry Men, and Harlequin, Who Killed Cook Robin?" is a real "English pantomime," it is of course not a pantomime at all, properly speaking.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Democracy triumphant feasted to-night at the Grand Pacific Hotel. The banquet was given by the Illinois Tariff-Reform League, and 200 Democrats, all wearing an air of satisfaction over the late victory, sat around the tables.

The interest manifested by the public in the experiments now being so extensively made in the city hospitals with Dr. Koch's lymph has had the effect of stimulating the medical fraternity to scientific investigation that may yet result in many valuable medical discoveries. Many physicians believe that the practice of medicine, in so far as tuberculosis, cancer, and kindred malignant diseases are concerned, will be revolutionized in the near future.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- The schooner A.D. Samson arrived here to-day from Savannah and had on board Charles Nollenberg, a seaman of the wrecked schooner Lucinda A. Potter, who is the only survivor of the officers and crew, eight men in all. Nollenberg related the following story of the wreck of the vessel and the suffering he endured, with the Captain, who died shortly after being rescued:

The Window-Glass Trust has at last completed its plans for taking full advantage of the high duties and the tricks that were inserted in the new tariff law for its benefit as a result of the labors of Mr. MCKINLEY. At the meeting held in Chicago yesterday all obstacles were removed by the accession of two manufacturers who had been standing aloof, and, with the assistance of ex-Gov. FOSTER of Ohio, the scheme was perfected.

BOSTON, Dec. 30. -- Miss Ada Dare, one of the leading members of the company now playing at the Park Theatre, had a narrow escape last evening from serious injury at the hands of a young man named John Morton.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Dec. 31. -- The Republicans had everything their own way in Gov. Fifer's special election, held to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of W.C. Collins. Collins is the Republican who received the highest number of votes last November as Representative from the Twenty-first District in the Legislature.

ELIZABETH, Dec. 31. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day surprised the residents here by putting a gang of 200 men to work on Railroad Avenue laying the company's fourth track. This street has been in dispute for nearly two years between the city and the Pennsylvania Company, the latter wanting the right of way for its track, which the City Council absolutely refuse to give.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- It is rumored that the Treasury Department is preparing to augment the revenue cutter fleet in Behring Sea for the coming Spring by seven vessels. It is not known as yet from where the seven vessels will be obtained. It is inferred, however, that the seven vessels will be made up of chartered steam whalers and small coastwise steamers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- An accident occurred near the village of Stafford, four miles west of Leroy, Genesee County, this afternoon, by which four men were instantly killed, four other men received injuries which will probably result fatally, and a foreman was seriously hurt.

Wagner has the preference at the Metropolitan Opera House this week. On Monday evening "Tannhauser" was given, and last night the opera was "The Flying Dutchman," which is to be repeated at Saturday's matinee. Several things pointed to the conclusion that the patrons of the Opera House desired to hear the Wagnerian list.

The wintry cheerlessness of the Pavilion Hotel, at New-Brighton, S. I., was last evening for a few hours dispelled by the ball of the Richmond County Country Club. In the main room, which had been selected as the scene of the dance, the club's colors, red, green, and white were conspicuous everywhere. Folds of red and white gauze were interlaced with and hung suspended from ropes of evergreen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Senators Chandler, Hale, and Power, and Representative Owen were the only members of the joint Congressional Committee on Immigration present this morning when the investigation into the purchase of American industries by foreign capital was begun, with C.A. Pillsbury, the Minnesota miller, in the witness chair.

PARIS, Dec. 31. -- Messrs. O'Brien and Gill returned here to-day from Boulogne. They have warned their friends not to accept as true any statement they may read or hear as to the results of the conference with Mr. Parnell yesterday.

We have no doubt that Secretary TRACY, in the letter to Lieut. Commander REITER as to the Barrundia affair, will make a clear statement of the law governing naval officers in such matters. That is one of the advantages of having an able lawyer at the head of the department, though by no means the only one when the lawyer happens to be a man of as much practical sagacity and energy as Mr. TRACY.

It was inevitable that the "conference" between PARNELL and O'BRIEN should give rise to a great deal of rumor and gossip, but it is not credible that it should amount to anything. Mr. O'BRIEN has committed himself publicly to the position that every Irishman who is at once patriotic and sensible must take, that it is necessary to the Irish cause that PARNELL should give up its leadership.

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- The Albany Argues was designated the State paper to-day by the unanimous vote of the board, composed of Secretary of State Rice, Controller Wemple, and State Treasurer Danforth. The selection would have been made several weeks ago, but there has been a decided difference of opinion concerning the paper on which the rich pium should be bestowed.
BOSTON, Dec. 31. -- The American Wool Reporter, in its annual review of the wool trade of the United States, will say to-morrow:

The financial estimates of the city for the year 1891 show only a moderate advance upon the expenses of the year just past. There has been an evident effort on the part of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to keep them down, even to the sacrifice in some cases of really needed expenses.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, Dec. 31. -- The Seventh Cavalry had just reached camp yesterday morning, after repulsing the attack made on their supply train by Two Strikes' band, when a courier arrived with word that the Catholic mission was on fire and the teachers and pupils were being massacred. In twenty minutes the hungry and almost exhausted cavalry were once more in motion.

While the news of the failure of Bateman Co. came as something of a surprise yesterday to a large share of the Wall Street public, it failed to produce any particular effect upon the stock market. The announcement in the morning newspapers that assignments would be filed in the County Clerk's office in the name of the firm and of its senior partner was read by the brokers long before they reached their offices.

If any demonstration of the necessity for improved rapid-transit facilities for New-York City were required beyond what is apparent to the eyes of every clear-headed observer of the trend of population, it might be found in some carefully-compiled statistical statements of the building operations in the district above Fifty-ninth Street, and especially on the west side, published in an elaborately-illustrated edition of the Record and Guide of last week.

Cadets have been appointed as follows to the Military Academy: Clarence M. Butler, of Rootstown, Nineteenth Ohio; Charles E. Stadter, Nelson, Nineteenth Ohio (alternate;) Ernest P. O'Sullivan, New-York City, Twelfth New-York; Oscar P. Osthelder, Sheboygan Falls, Eighth Wisconsin, with James E. Collins, of Sheboygan, as alternate; Conway H. Arnold, New-York City, Ninth New-York, with Horace I. Lawrence, as alternate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The following call for a national convention of Railroad Commissioners was issued this afternoon:

Several of the city departments made informal reports yesterday as to the amount of business done during the year 1890. The Public Works and Street-Cleaning Departments were not ready with their figures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Not a particle of real progress toward disposing of the Force bill was made in the Senate to day, and. as Friday's sitting will be held merely to meet the constitutional provision against adjourning over three days, nothing more will be done this week.

According to the report of the Board of General Appraisers, the Customs Service in this city coming under their immediate observation is in a very bad state. They say: "The temptation to fraud in high tariff rates, as well as the vast business of the New-York office, renders imperative an exact system and a supervision both comprehensive and minute."

The Board of Trustees of the New-York Free Circulating Library have presented their eleventh annual report for the year ending Sept. 30, 1890. The libraries are situated at 49 Bond Street, 135 Second Avenue, 226 West Forty-second Street, and 251 West Thirteenth Street. The work of the past year was begun under discouraging circumstances, but the libraries are now in satisfactory condition.

It is evident that ballot reform is to be the most important question before the Legislature of Pennsylvania at the coming session, and it was one of the issues that aided in the political overturn of that State last Fall. Unfortunately, it is necessary to amend the Constitution of the State in order to get a satisfactory law into operation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Nearly the entire telegraph system of the United States was in a comatose state to-night. Throughout the West and Southwest a gigantic wet blanket of mist, hundreds of miles in extent, almost shifted every throb of electricity, and the wires stretching from city to city were literally sudden and lifeless. To the west a blizzard was overturning poles and snapping the metal cords holding far-separated communities together.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Under the head of Economic History, the following papers were read before the American Historical Association this morning: "Historical Development of the Budget in the United States," by Ephraim D. Adams, University of Michigan; "Yazoo Land Companies," by Dr. Charles H. Haskins, University of Wisconsin; "State Activities and Politics," by W.F. Willoughby, United States Department of Labor; "Slavery in the District of Columbia," by Mary Tremain.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 31. -- The progress of work on the Georgia, Carolina and Northern Railroad is very great. Through trains will soon be the result. Trains will be running to Athens by March 1. Trains already come to the Savannah River, and the roadbed is very nearly all graded from the river to Athens, ready for the tracks.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment, made up of Mayor Grant, Tammany; President Arnold of the Board of Aldermen, and President Coleman of the Tax Department, Independent Democrat, yesterday approved, by the necessary unanimous vote, the city's financial budget for 1891.
District Attorney-elect Nicoll yesterday announced the names of the assistants who will comprise his staff.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31. -- Gen. Francis E. Spinner, ex-Treasurer of the United States, died at 8:30 o'clock to-night at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. James M. Schumacher, in Brooklyn Suburb, on the west bank of the St. John's River.

The new District Attorney, Mr. DE LANCEY NICOLL, has announced his appointment of a staff of assistants for his work as the prosecuting officer of this county, and it appears on the whole to be made up of a very capable body of men, and to have only a comparatively slight flavor of Tammany politics.

The exposure in yesterday's TIMES of the work done by a combination of glove importers, with the assistance of Col. W.W. Dudley, in arranging the glove schedule under the McKinley bill and its bearing on the now-famous Passavant kid-glove reappraisement case now being investigated, was read with a great deal of interest in customs circles.

Mr. Mansfield's Beau Brummell is doubtless one of the most distinct triumphs of the modern stage. Such a dainty creature is this bean, with his supreme regard for that which is "quite correct" and his horror of that which is "bad form," so abhorrent of wrinkles, so indifferent to creditors, so interested in his boots, his coat, his cravat, his finger nails, and so imperturbable.

" Yes," said Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa yesterday, "my term of banishment from Great Britain and Ireland has about expired. Twenty years ago come the second of January I was escorted from Chatham Prison by the Deputy Governor and two jailers. The Deputy Governor saw me aboard a ship bound for America at Liverpool and left me.

It is saddening to consider the state of mind of a person who expresses joy upon a day of general thanksgiving or at the opening of a new year by blowing on an untunable tin horn. It may be assumed that the person who thus gives cacophonous vent to his sentiments is young. Children, as has been remarked by various anthropologists, are everywhere addicted to noise for the sake of noise.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 31. -- A dispatch from Saratoga, Carbon County, tells of a rich silver strike in the Gold Hill district, at the head of Brush Creek. Samples brought in are of beautiful native silver, taken from a twelve-foot vein. It was opened yesterday. Prospectors show large nuggets of almost pure silver flocked with gold.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- When shown the St. Louis item this morning regarding the discharge of 10,000 men by the American Harvester Company and the confirmation of the story by Assistant Manager Kelso of the St. Louis agency of the D.M. Osborne Company, President Thomas M. Osborne said: "Mr. Kelso knows no more about the intentions of the American Harvester Company than one of our office boys.

Thomas Mulrey of Jersey City is of the opinion that he has laid the foundations upon which he may build a great fortune. He has invented a locomotive engine for use upon ice fields and has just completed the first working model, and will make an exhibition of it within few days upon some lake in or near New-York.

According to semi-annual statistics compiled in the Health Department yesterday there were in 1890 39,250 births, 14,992 marriages, and 40,230 deaths. The death rate was 24.66. In 1889 there were recorded 37,531 births, 14,400 marriages, and 39,583 deaths, and the death rate was 25. In 1890 the mortality among children under five was 16,249 and in 1889 17,051.

BOSTON, Dec. 31. -- Governor-elect Russell, in his inaugural address, is likely to advocate the abolition of the property clause of qualification for the office of Governor. He will do this because of the fact that, before this last campaign, he has not had that qualification, which, in accordance with Article II. of the chapter in the State Constitution devoted to the Executive power is as follows:

The gossip about the Papal succession is quite inevitable, considering the age of the present Pontiff, and his state of health. It is to be noted, however, that it affects only ecclesiastical circles, and this fact indicates the wisdom of the Italians in taking away the temporal power of the Papacy. There is nothing in this disestablishment of itself to diminish the reverence in which Roman Catholics hold the head of the Church.

PLAINFIELD, N. J. Dec. 31. -- The handsome new home of the Union County Country Club was thrown open to the members and their friends to-night. Dedicatory exercises were begun in the casino, the theatrical wing of the clubhouse, at 9:30 o'clock, when Rowland Cox, representing the Building Committee, delivered to the keeping of Harry M. Stockton of the House Committee the keys of the structure, which were linked together with gold.

The Mugwump is not the grim and austere person that the fancy of his enemies paints him. Like the Puritan of old, he is an earnest and stern man when he takes his seat in the council or goes forth to battle, but, unlike the Puritan, he enjoys mightily the fun and humor of this world. Just now he is getting a great deal of amusement out of Gov. DAVID B. HILL.

With what little remained of the antiquated Knickerbocker custom of New Year's calling yesterday's storm wrought havoc. Strangely enough, the intensely disagreeable atmospheric conditions worked disruption after a double fashion. Not only did they deter many who would otherwise have paid visits to their friends from so doing, but it put an effectual damper upon what seemingly promised to prove a revival of the custom of receiving.

The new year will be doubly welcome if it shall bring rapid transit to New-York. It is no longer the need but the means of rapid transit that should be discussed. In regard to the need opinion long since became desperately unanimous. Some diversities still exist as to the means, but experience has been instructive and the process of elimination has been at work.

" There is no more talk of rising prices on account of the McKinley act or anything else," said the Philadelphia Press not long ago. On the 26th ult. the Press published a news article entitled "Blessings of Protection," containing interviews with certain manufacturers doing business in or near Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- Ever since the passage of the Silver bill by Congress at its last session there has been talk of a silver pool in which members of the National Legislature were said to be interested. In one instance mention was made by a New-York newspaper the other day of the name of Senator Farwell in connection with the supposed silver pool.

An interesting bit of 1890 statistics is that of arrivals of vessels at this port from foreign countries, made up by Boarding Officer Jmes 0. Ellery from the Government books at the Barge Office. His figures show in the first place that 5,758 vessels of all kinds, from steamships down to schooners, came in here in 1890, against 5,570 for 1889, a gain of nearly 200 for last year.

Canada's latest suggestion for settling the Behring Sea controversy is worthy of the season and of her climate. Some of her Government papers are proposing the purchase of Alaska. How much they intend to give for it is not clear; nor is it stated how much of the right to the open-sea seal fisheries they propose to have go with the bargain.

DUBLIN, Jan. 1. -- It is understood here that Mr. William O'Brien, M.P., has cabled Mr. John Dillon, M.P., now in New-York, that Mr. Parnell consents to retire if Mr. O'Brien is made leader of the Irish party. It is further understood that the Boulogne conference was adjourned in order to await Mr. Dillon's reply to this cable message.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 1. -- The State Farmers' Alliance spent most of the afternoon and evening sessions wrangling over the new constitution. The Committee on Resolutions sat up all night, and at the morning session presented its report in the shape of a declaration of principles in twenty-five parts, covering everything from the tariff to the Australian ballot system. The most important of the resolutions are as follows:

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 1. -- A special to the Bee from Pine Ridge Agency says: Gen. Miles has assumed command of the forces here, relieving Gen. Brooke, who started this morning into the field with the Second Infantry, going by way of Oelrichs to a point some five miles north of here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- A fog that appeared with early morn and thickened as the day grew older enveloped the White House to-day like a gray sheet. At intervals all day long this fog was sprinkled with showers, and, as the streets were slushy from the softening snow that fell a week ago, travel was disagreeable either on foot or in carriages.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- At 2 o'clock this morning word reached this village that Clinton Prison, sixteen miles from here, was on fire. A TIMES representative at once started for the scene, reaching there at 5 A.M., and learned the following facts: The fire was discovered about 11:20 last night in the hospital kitchen, which is situated midway between what is known as the old and new prisons.

A woman who rides over the Brooklyn Bridge a great deal said yesterday: "I consider that I have a right to complain of the treatment which women receive from men at the bridge stations. The men behave brutishly, I think.

Along the Appalachian range of mountains, from Alabama to the Adirondacks, and thence across to Niagara Falls. Such was the interesting journey made yesterday by a large gathering at the American Museum of Natural History, in Central Park annex, under the guidance of Prof. Albert S. Bickmore.

CORK, Jan. 1. -- The feud existing between the Irish Bishops and the Parnellites, which has been smoldering since the election in North Kilkenny, again burst forth fiercely to-day, and the most bitter-feeling prevails on both sides.

A warm wave from the Gulf of Mexico was traveling through Colorado day before yesterday, when it met a blustering cold wave from the far Northwest. The cold wave grabbed the warm wave by the collar of its linen duster and made a sudden effort to efface it from the landscape. The effort did not meet with a large measure of success.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1. -- The new Church of Corpus Christi, the memorial of the Jenkins family to their parents, was solemnly consecrated today by his Eminence Cardinal Gibbons. Bishop Foley of Detroit was the celebrant of the pontifical mass and Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia preached the sermon. The congregation was made up of Baltimore's very best people in social rank, commercial station, and literary eminence.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 1. -- The Democratic State Senators-elect held a meeting in this city this week and departed from custom in making their nominations a week before the opening session of the Legislature. This plan was adopted so that the Senators might devote their entire time to the Gubernatorial contest next week. Chairman Clinton B. Davis of the State Central Committee was absent, but all of the Democratic Senators, seventeen in number, were on hand.

To-day there will be a formal meeting of the Senate to take a recess to Monday, that being the longest period for which either house can adjourn without the consent of the other. When the Senators come together again on Monday or Tuesday it is probable that some definite issue will be sought from the vexed and complicated situation in which the majority have involved themselves.

The machinery for the big armored cruiser Maine is fast being assembled. The work is in progress at the shops of the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company of this city. When contracted for, the Maine's machinery was the most powerful ever undertaken to be built by an American establishment. It is, however, exceeded by more recent war-ship contracts issued to the Union Iron Works of San Francisco and William Cramp Sons of Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1. -- A New Year's event which has caused not a little commotion among the usually placid and quiet Society of Friends, the marriage of Miss Mary Elkinton, the accomplished daughter of Joseph S. Elkinton, a prominent member of the society, to Inazo Nitobe, a young Japanese, took place this morning at the Friends' meeting house, Fourth and Arch Streets.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- The work on Cruiser No. 11, building at Harrison Loring's yard, is reported as progressing more favorably than was the case a month ago. Considerable difficulty was experienced in getting started. This difficulty was due to failure to receive hull material promptly. The major portion of No. 11 material is now awaiting assembling. The work is being pushed rapidly along.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Although the Legislature will meet on Tuesday for the one hundred and fourteenth session, no members outside of those residing here have yet arrived. William F. Sheehan of Buffalo, the next Speaker, is due to-morrow, and several Tammany Hall representatives, and Edward Murphy of Troy, are expected to drop in about the same time for the purpose of discussing the composition of the Assembly committees.

What proved to be an extremely hard fire to handle was discovered in the Trenkmann Building, 241 and 243 Centre Street, last evening at about 8 o'clock. Watchman William McGurran, while making his rounds at that time, noticed smoke issuing from the third-story windows of the building and immediately gave the alarm at the house of Engine Company No. 55, nearby.

A correspondent at Salonics writes that on Dec. 5 a serious accident happened on board the British battle ship Inflexible by which one of her large boilers was rendered useless. By some means at present unexplained the water in the boiler was allowed to run low, with the result that the steam pipes got red hot, burning the "lagging" off as far as the upper deck.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 1. -- Col. Mercer Slaughter, Commissioner of the Southern Passenger Association, makes the declaration that the Southern roads are more conservative than those situated in the Northwest, West, and Southwest.

All discussion of rapid transit in this city is sure to revert sooner or later to Broadway as in nearly all respects the ideal route for a main line, if an underground road is to be adopted. Just now there are several circumstances which direct attention more forcibly than ever to that thoroughfare. In the first place, Broadway is destined to be torn up in the next year for two purposes.

BERLIN, Jan. 1. -- Dr. Koch, who had left Berlin for a short vacation, suddenly returned to the city to-day. He was summoned back to attend a patient to whom, by accident, an overdose of the lymph had been administered. Dr. Koch administered to the patient strong anti-febrilles, which subdued his alarming symptoms, and now there are evidences of marked improvement in his condition.

Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN seems to consider Mr. GLADSTONE'S difficulties as his opportunities. He has betrayed that opinion several times, but it has not thus far been justified by events. He has just been endeavoring, in a speech at Birmingham, to extract something to his advantage from the Irish situation, and has in effect invited the Gladstonians to join the Unionists.

The Cleveland Leader's defense of the new Mower and Reaper Trust has not yet struck a responsive chord in any of its contemporaries. Speaking of this combination and another recently planned, the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette says that there would not be so many of these Trusts "if business-men would be less savagely ambitious, less grasping, less malevolent toward their neighbors, and would be satisfied with the fair and decent earnings of their endeavors."

Wherever the agents of Gov. HILL travel upon political errands outside of this State they meet with nothing but discouragement. Treasurer DANFORTH has been in North Carolina looking around for Hill sentiment, but finding none, although there appear to be all sorts of politics in that State. The fact is that there is no such thing as Hill sentiment, and sentiment is a thing that cannot be manufactured to order.

PARIS, Jam 1. -- President Carnot's New Year's reception was au unsually brilliant affair. Mgr. Rotell, the Papal Nuncio, who introduced the members of the Diplomatlc Corps, expressed in the name of all hearty good wishes for the prosperity of France. President Carnot, in his reply, expressed equally good wishes for the welfare of the couutries represented.

A bitter fight is imminent in North Carolina between the railroads and the Farmers' Alliance members of the Legislature. A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Raleigh says: "The flat has gone forth that an iron-clad Railroad Commission must be established with authority to fix passenger fares and freight rates.

It looks as if Vice President MORTON had distinguished himself, an event that was hardly expected by his most intimate friends. In the course of the proceedings on Wednesday in the Senate, Mr. MORTON being in the chair, exercising the modest functions attributed by the Constitution to the Vice President, made a decision on a point of order which was appealed from.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 2. -- St. Paul was full of swearing farmers to-day. Last night, at 11 o'clock, after two-thirds of the delegates had gone to their hotels, the new constitution, which has been the subject of a wrangle for many hours and defeated by a decisive vote, was again called upon and railroaded through the convention.

The newly-elected officials of Queens County took the oath of office and were duly qualified to act by filing their bonds with the Board of Supervisors in Long Island City yesterday. The new officials are County Treasurer Joseph E. Dykes of Flushing, District Attorney John Fleming of Jamaica, re-elected, and Coroners Meiner, Cory, and Schenck.

Italy, which keeps in the front rank in naval construction and appliances, is credited with being so well satisfied with her recent experiments in the use of petroleum for the fuel of war vessels as to propose introducing it very largely into her fleet. If its advantages are so great, Russia and America, with their oil resources, ought not to be distanced in its application by Italy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The session of the Senate to-day lasted only long enough for the Chaplain to pray and the Secretary to read the Journal of the last sitting. The adjournment was until Monday, so that the New Year's lull in the Force bill debate will last two days longer. Beginning Monday, however, there are not likely to be many more dull days in the Senate for the remaining two months of the session.

Little James Halloran, who was only nine years old, lives with his parents at 222 First Street, Hoboken. He went out with two companions to make New Year's calls on Thursday and returned in the evening so intoxicated that he fell on the floor half unconscious. His mother and little sister put him to bed and then went out to spend the afternoon. When they came back, lafe in the evening, they found James ead.

One more change in the affairs of Uganda has taken place. The Arabs have been routed in battle, the Christians have the upper hand again, and they have joyfully opened a new church and baptized many of the natives. The kingdom must have had a surfeit of war during the last two or three years from foes without and foes within.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 2. -- The trial of the Dodge County conspirators for the murder of Capt Forsyth, in the United States District Court, Judge Speer, is now closed, so far as the evidence is concerned, and will be given to the jury, probably to-morrow, or as soon as the lawyers get through with their arguments.

The fog which yesterday enveloped the city in its dripping mantle for fourteen mortal hours, with its consequent and accompanying stifling atmosphere, stalled trains, and universal mud, was calculated to play havoc with many a laudable resolution of the day before. Although dubbed by the Weather Bureau as "local," it extended its depressing influence over nearly one thousand square miles of territory.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 2. -- Boone County, Mo., is just now in the throes of an immense sensation, which has forced its way to the surface in spite of most heroic efforts to suppress it, owing to the fact that the politics of the State will be agitated by the discovery, and the carefully-laid plans of well-known and ambitions men will be seriously disarranged by the developments.

At the twenty-fourth National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, held in Boston in August last, a resolution was adopted recommending the removal of the body of Gen. U.S. Grant to the National Cemetery at Arlington, Va., near Washington, D.C. A resolution of a similar nature was introduced in Congress at its last session, but has been voted down in the House of Representatives this last month.

Against most varieties of injurious weather civilization has provided more or less effective defenses, but it seems to be still quite helpless against fog. London has more than once suffered an absolute embargo of traffic and even of movement, which, if it had lasted two or three times as long, might have resulted in the deaths from starvation of people abundantly supplied with money in a city abundantly supplied with food.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2. -- The Democratic State Central Committee in this city to-day re-elected Clinton B. Davis Chairman. The second and decisive ballot resulted: Davis, 13; W.H. Talmadge of Stamford, 9.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 2. -- More important legislation will be submitted to the Kansas Legislature this month than ever before in any one session in the history of the State, and it will be of a character that will command the widest attention. All bills originating with the Alliance are to be thoroughly discussed in that organization and will have its approval before being introduced.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 2. -- The river to-night is twenty-two feet and rising slowly. Several ice gorges have passed down, but everything in the city is quiet, with the exception of Allegheny River men, who are drawing boats and flats nearer shore and making all taut. The Pittsburg and Western tracks are covered, but it is thought the cold snap stopped the flood in time to save damage here at least.

Thirty-eight young men from Harvard College descended on the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, arriving in time for breakfast. But for once the presence of a college crowd was not a synonym for noise, and the fact that such a crowd of unbridled youngsters vas in the hotel vas unknown to the other guests, unless they looked at the register.

GOLCONDA, Ill., Jan. 2. -- John Fields, brother of Mrs. Juliet Raum, wife of Pension Commissioner Green B. Raum, acting for his sister and himself, has begun suit against Golconda for property amounting to over $200,000.
Just fifteen minutes after the audience had left the Fifth Avenue Theatre last evening the watchman of the house, in making his usual rounds, discovered a small fire under the stage.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- The Daily Telegraph (Conservative), in its issue of to-day, invites the followers of Mr. Gladstone to recognize manfully the distasteful fact that home rule for Ireland is defunct. The present policy of the Liberal party, the Telegraph thinks, is certain to give way to a different programme, while the party itself will at the same time have to make new combinations. The paper says:

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Messrs. Armour, Morris, and Swift, of the big packing firms, declare that the statement in a dispatch from St. Louis to the effect that they were about to purchase the Union Stock Yards at that city and the National Stock Yards at East St. Louis is untrue.
Bids for the new torpedo-gunboat cruiser will be opened at the Navy Department Feb. 11. The new vessel is designed to have 750 tons normal displacement. The speed requirement is 23 knots an hour.

The first step in what promises to be a general reform in the matter of land transfer was taken in the Register's office yesterday under the Block Indexing act of 1889. Register Fitzgerald is enthusiastic concerning the new system, and says that if it had been in vogue for the last fifty years any layman would now be able to make his own search, if not his own transfer, without assistance.
BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- Senator Wardwell of the Republican State Committee says of the proposed new State Republican Club:

Twenty members of the Casque and Gauntlet Fraternity, a Senior Class Society at Dartmouth College, held a reunion at Mazettl's, Sixth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, last evening. Among those who responded to toasts after the banquet were Henry P. Blair, J.C. Ross, and F.E. Wheat of Washington; Ozara S. Davis of White River Junction, Vt.; F.J. Hazen of Whitefield, N.H.; C.M. Smith and G.S. Mills of Hanover, N.H., and George Hiram Hitchcock of this city.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 2. -- The wholesale dry goods firm of Allan Sheldon Co., founded nearly half a century ago by Zachariah Chandler, yesterday ceased to exist, having been dissolved by mutual consent. It was in 1883 that Mr. Chandler laid the foundation of the firm, which has flourished through many stages of commercial life to eventually die a natural death by the mutual consent of the partners.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 2. -- A genuine sensation in baseball news is to be sprung upon the public within a day or two. The Players' League people contemplate organizing a circuit of clubs composed of Philadelphia, Brooklyn, New-York, and Boston in the East, and Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati, and St. Louis in the West, to play Sunday ball at 25 cents per game.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 2. -- The Bee has the following from its staff correspondent:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 2. -- James H. Van Ness, a milkman, drove his two horses into an alley leading from East Mechanic to Ferry Street this morning. Of a sudden both horses fell to the ground. Van Ness leaped from his wagon, and, under the impression that the horses had slipped on the ice, proceeded to unharness them. The moment he touched the iron traces he received an electric shook that almost paralyzed him.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 2. -When the injunction case of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul vs. the Union Pacific, to restrain the defendant from interfering with the running of plaintiff's trains over the Union Pacific bridge, was called for a hearing in court this morning, the petition for removal to the Federal court was granted and the hearing was set for Monday next.
A few additional remarks about prices may be introduced by the following extracts from representative high-tariff journals:

HURON, S.D., Jan. 2. -- The joint conference of independent and Democratic members of the Legislature this afternoon failed to come to any definite conclusion concerning the United States Senatorship. They agreed to stand together in the organization of the House, but this may not be carried out, as the independents want all the best offices and the Chairmen of most of the important committees.

DUBLIN, Jan. 2. -- Mr. Parnell has arrived in this city, and has held a long conference with Timothy D. Harrington and Dr. Joseph Kenny. The interview took place in the offices of the National League. Subsequently Mr. Parnell held a private reception in Dr. Kenny's house. This evening Mr. Parnell started for Avondale, whence he will go, Monday, to Boulogne.

THE DANGERS OF HYPNOTISM. -- At Nancy I have seen a young woman return on three consecutive mornings to be hypnotized for a headache! After each seance she expressed herself as feeling quite relieved. Now, if the hypnotic cure of a headache has to be repeated three consecutive mornings, it has nothing to boast of over simpler remedies, whereas it may, as I have shown, be but substituting a dangerous neurosis for a headache.

Mr. A.C. Welles of South Dakota, who has lived for many years in the Indian country, and who is a grandnephew of President Lincoln's Secretary of the Navy, says that the present Indian troubles are such as would not have occurred had the army officers been left to deal with the redskins as they alone can deal with them.

Since Sept. 4 last there has been in existence at Washington a United States Board of Geographic Names, the work of which promises to be of great value, not only to the various departments of the Government for whose benefit it was planned, but to the makers of text books, scientific works, and those generally interested in geography, history, and kindred studies.

CHILD LIFE INSURANCE. -- It is miserable to a patriot to think how these collectors of premiums upon child death policies openly, week by week, call at doors within which, the neighbors believe, a child is being slowly neglected to death -- a fact, by the way, with which the canvasser has no concern. His one and sole duty is to get business, and getting it, to keep it.

If M. Henri Welschinger is one of the most fortunate searchers in the national archives it is not only because of his activity -- others as active find nothing startling -- but because of his independence. He has no prejudices, no partialities, no masters to serve.
" Hy'ar, y'ar! hy'ar, y'ar! 'Er cent er piece. Hy'ar, y'ar! Yer can throw 'em at der old man, and it won't cost yer but 'er cent 'er piece!"

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 3. -- The one hundred and third annual communication of the Grand Masonic Lodge of Connecticut will be held at New-Haven Jan. 21 and 22. The annual address will be delivered by Grand Master Clark Buckingham of that city. The total membership of the subordinate lodges in the State will exceed 16,000.

The movement which was begun at Albany last Friday, having for its object the raising of the prices of straw wrapping paper, is not an absolute novelty. A number of times in the last ten years the paper manufacturers of New-York and neighboring States have undertaken to accomplish the very thing which they now are aiming at.

BOSTON, Jan. 3. -- To-day the Boston and Maine's "Supplement No. 6 and Tariff No. 66" went into effect, making still another drop of 75 cents in second-class passenger fare from Boston to Chicago, and a proportionate reduction to other points West. The Boston and Maine still adhere to their old position that they are entitled to $1.25 differential over the Fitchburg on the second-class passenger business which they send West via Montreal or Norwood.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3. -- To-day Judge Harley B. Morse and George G. Merrick of Denver, Col., called at the United States Mint in this city with a brick of silver weighing 514.18 ounces fine, presented it to the weighing clerk, and demanded that it be coined into money for them. Upon their demand being refused they waited upon Col. Bosbyshell, Superintendent of the Mint, and made the same demand verbally of him.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 3. -- The Rev. J.V. Garton of the First Baptist Church in Meriden has been called to the oldest Baptist pastorate in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. E.W. Husted of New-London, who has accepted the pastoral charge of the Main Street Baptist Church in Meriden, succeeding the Rev. I.R. Wheelock, will begin his work in that city to-morrow.

Familiarity with those nationalities, Dutch or Celtic, which first peopled the Mohawk Valley would not have alone sufficed in drawing the remarkable picture Mr. Harold Frederic presents. A high literary sentiment was a necessity. Douw Mauverensen, in whose veins there runs the Van Hoorn blood, shows his Frisian origin, some little tempered by new surroundings.

" Her Point of View," the admirable melange of feminine gossip which THE NEW-YORK TIMES prints each Sunday, recently quotes a lawyer who had employed women stenographers and typewriters as saying: "I find it hard to get them to come down to solid business and avoid nonsense. They are liable to become offended because people coming in on business are not nice in their manners.

Mr. Anstey in an amusing manner constructs a series of little comedies taken from modern social life, as the "Pastoral Play," when the Brandesbury Brown's at their villa in North Kensington present "The Tempest" of a rainy day. The fun is very light and always proper. But English fun is not American.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Old-timers who have been present at the assembling of every Legislature since the palmy days of Thurlow Weed, fall to recall an occasion where every peg was firmly adjusted, and so little was known of it. Four, perhaps five men understand the situation, know how the committees are arranged, and how the plums and biscuits are to be parceled out.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Social gayeties began somewhat earlier than usual in Albany this Winter. Perhaps the continued cold weather -- the temperature during December was below the normal -- and the bountiful supply of snow had their influence.

Engineers generally are discussing the Broadway project for a common subway for pipes and a railway tunnel. The views of Chief Engineer Birdsall, as expressed yesterday in THE TIMES, have confirmed the impressions of many of them, however, that the undertaking as a whole is to be criticised chiefly because of the expense which it would involve.

The election at the Union League will be held next Thursday evening. The ticket selected by the Nominating Committee is announced as being a compromise one, arranged to satisfy the demands of the members who desire to make the social life in the club of more importance than the political features. As a matter of fact, the new ticket is almost identical with that of last year, and the changes are very slight and unimportant.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan 3. -- The new year didn't come in very happily for the thousands of employes in the highly-protected Jersey manufactories. The assurance that the miseries of Christmas week would not be repeated this week, which the Republican organs so confidently gave, proved as false as most of the predictions of the protectionists.

The conflagration which threatened to destroy two blocks on Broadway in the dark hours of yesterday morning proved, in the daylight to have been less disastrous than it then appeared. Between 1 and 2 o'clock A.M it looked as though both the Fifth Avenue Theatre and Herrmann's Theatre would be totally destroyed, and the Sturtevant House on the opposite side of Broadway would be do damaged as to prevent occupancy.

The affairs of the Berkeley Athletic Club are in a very unsettled state. In fact, over since the organization was started by a stock company, known at first as the Berkeley Lyceum Association, the athletic club has been resting on a rather weak foundation, owing to the manner in which it has been governed.

LONDON, Jan 3. -- Mr. Parnell sent no congratulatory message to Mr. Gladstone on his birthday at the close of the old year, and Prince Bismarck exchanged no greetings with the Kaiser upon the advent of the new year. These two facts sum up all that Europe finds distinctive about this freshly-arrived 1891.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The United States Treasurey now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,523,150, as follows: Currency 6s, $6,772,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $27,258,950; 4 per cents, $106,492,200.

CRESSETS AND LAMPS IN CHURCHES. -- Among the legends of the early Celtic saints nothing is more common than the story of the saint being sent to borrow fire, and carrying it in his lap without the fire injuring his garment.
The Brooklyn Board of Estimate yesterday announced the apportionment of $100,000 from the excise moneys to the various charitable institutions of the city as follows:

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- Prof. Koch's first step on returning here yesterday was to seek a conference with Dr. von Gossler, Minister of Medicinal Affairs, , on the agitation of the medical societies against the continued secrecy regarding the nature of the lymph and the present method of its distribution.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Superintendent Andrew S. Draper of the State Department of Public Instruction, in his annual report for the year 1890, says in brief:

ENGLISH PATENTS. -- The immense increase in the number of patents granted is partly due to the increased facilities afforded by recent legislation. But, down to 1852, the old, absurd method which provoked the satire of Dickens in his "History of a Patent" was allowed to continue in full force.

" French soirees" are a recent London fad. As their name indicates, they are evenings of French with programmes which include French conversation, recitations, and readings, with music, tea, and coffee. The fashion might be introduced in New-York society with the really profitable result of improving many social amateurs in the French language.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3. -- The bal poudre on Wednesday evening was a brilliant affair and undoubtedly the great event of the Winter. Most of the subscription entertainments which are given through the season are of a rather unsatisfactory kind and are, in fact, nothing more than dances in the confined sense of the word, at which no suppers or refreshments are served, with the exception of ices and cake.

A SONG IN JAPANESE. -- From many a house as we pass, especially at evening, is heard the tinkling samisen, or the thrum of the stronger-voiced koto. Every house seems to contain a samisen, the three-stringed guitar of Japan, having a long, black neck, unprovided with frets, and a square sounding body covered by stretched catskin.

One of the liveliest conferences in the history of amateur athletic sports occurred yesterday afternoon at the Lawyers' Club, and was continued last evening at the Astor House. At midnight the conference committees of the Amateur Athletic Union and League of American Wheelmen were still in session at the Astor House, discussing the question of the payment of the expenses of athletes to games, which question has agitated these two organizations for so long.

The short time intervening between New Year's Day and Ash Wednesday this year will make necessary a rapid succession of entertainments if all the elegant toilets prepared are to be displayed. A beautiful dinner dress, which its owner is not likely to neglect, is of gold and white brocade, and the richest of green velvet, both materials being wisely permitted to fall in unbroken folds.

The Webster's Unabridged with which we are familiar was a sufficiently useful book and a dictionary so full and up to the times that a revised edition was hardly expected. But the edition of 1884 was not out before the plans were laid for another issue which should surpass that one, excellent as it was.

The Sun has been engaged for a long time past in abusing Mr. Cleveland and in booming Mr. Hill. Its frantic efforts are worthy of a paper which has never had the political confidence of Democrats. Heretofore it has been an assistant of our political enemies. It was treacherous toward Hancock. It supported Butler in 1884, and in 1888 it did its best, in an underhanded and deceitful way, to defeat Cleveland.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 3. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day, on motion of District Attorney Grant, fifty-five informations pending against the late M.A. Dauphin were dismissed. They were all for violating the section relative to lottery tickets and circulars in the mails. One test case was tried in 1884, when all the informations were filed, and as an acquittal resulted no further effort at prosecution was made.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Unless all signs fail, next week's session of the Senate is going to be one of the liveliest and most interesting it has had in recent years.

ASSOCIATIONS OF WILD HORSES. -- Life in societies is again the rule with the large family of horses, which includes the wild horses and donkeys of Asia, the zebras, the mustangs, the cimarrones of the Pampas, and the half-wild horses of Mongolia and Siberia. They all live in numerous associations made up of many studs, each of which consists of a number of mares under the leadership of a male.

LAKEWOOD, Jan. 3. -- Good sleighing and skating added materially to the pleasures of the Lakewood season during the first three days of this week. These facilities for enjoyment were not included in last year's programme. There was then hardly more than a glimpse of snow and scarcely a skimming of ice on the lakes. Sleighing parties and skating parties from the hotels and cottages made the most of their brief opportunity this season.

Much curiosity was manifested in naval circles yesterday concerning the department's intention regarding the United States steamer Yantic, now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. This vessel was detached from Rear Admiral Gherardi's squadron last Summer, and since then has been undergoing extensive repairs and alterations necessary to fit the vessel for service as an apprentice training ship.

The news of the death at Berlin of Dr. Henry Schliemann, the great Grecian archaeologist, recalled to many of the older German residents of this city that he at one time lived here. "Oh, yes," replied Mr. Herman Lieber, when asked if he remembered Dr. Schliemann. "I met him a number of times while he was here. He was not then recognized as a great person.

Mr. J.A. Riis has had the fullest experience in regard to the subject he treats, for he has devoted many years to the study of New-York. The title explains itself, for it is true "that one-half of the world does not know how the other half lives." The question is, Does it care?

An incident occurred at the City Hall station of the elevated railroad yesterday that within the space of fifteen minutes made enthusiastic converts of at least 3,000 persons to any system of rapid transit that could be built. It was at about 4:45 o'clock, and there had been a delay of trains up town somewhere, so that for fully a quarter of an hour no trains had arrived at the City Hall station.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 3. -- For the past twenty years or longer the oyster question has attracted the attention of the lawmakers of Virginia. Hardly a legislative session during that period has passed at which this subject has not been discussed. At the last session a bill was passed providing for leasing the State's oyster ground for a period of years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Gen. Schofield this morning received the following telegram from Gen. Miles, dated Pine Ridge, Jan. 2:

The sensation of the week in Brooklyn has of course been the water scandal, which was precipitated by the action of William Ziegler, a heavy property holder, in resorting to the courts to prevent Mayor Chapin, Controller Jackson, and City Auditor Rutan from buying the Long Island Water Supply Company with $1,250,000 belonging to other people.

Mr. C.S. Staley of New-Albany, Ind., recently told a reporter of the Kansas City Times how the trouble between Gresham and Harrison originated. He said: "The first trouble that I ever heard of occurred when Gresham was the presiding Judge and Harrison was the attorney for a railroad in Southwestern Indiana. Harrison, as the attorney for the road, had been delaying matters until Gresham became tired of the obstructionist methods adopted.

The opening chapters of this volume give a promise of excellence which is utterly belied by what follows. The American part of the story is as good as the African part is bad -- a phenomenon which may be best accounted for by supposing that the author knows the one continent and does not know the other.

Such biographical notices of Langfranchi as have been printed, though correct in the main, are wanting in details. In his naturalization papers taken out in New-York, 1893, he declared that he was born in Pisa, Italy, and was twenty-nine years old. Americans, prone to give foreigners nicknames, had dubbed him "Lanky Franky," supposably on account of his Quixotic mien.

There is music in the air as the Smeaton Tower bowls smoothly along toward Porto Rico. Capt. Godfree is fond of music, and he has four instruments in the cabin -- a violin, a guitar, a concertina, and a flute-harmonicum, the latter a curious French instrument with a bellows at the back like an accordion and a row of kevs in front like a piano.

The Babylonian Exploration Party, which left New-York in the Summer of 1888, in charge of Prof. J.T. Peters of the University of Pennsylvania, has returned, after having made two exploring trips. Dr. Peters reached Beyrout in November, 1889, and then, leaving his family there, started into the interior. He was accompanied by Prof. Robert F. Harper of Yale College.

It is a fact of some significance that half a dozen Presidents of colleges assembled the other day to hear a graduate of Cambridge University explain the system by which in England the advantages of a college education are extended to those who are unable to attend college. There seemed to be a general agreement that the system could not be applied in this country.

When Dr. George F. Shrady visited the New-York Cancer Hospital yesterday to observe the progress of his experiments with the Koch lymph, he found, much to his surprise, that the inoculations had been followed by local as well as constitutional reactions. So much astonished was he that he at once resolved to continue the injections.

The Park Board voted yesterday to lesse the Mount St. Vincent Restaurant in Central Park to Gabe Case, and thereby hangs a tale. The award was made in executive session, which was an unusual thing. The Commissioners present were President Gallup, Waldo Hutollins, and Paul Dana. Mr. Straus was not in the city.

The shipbuilding programme at the royal dockyard, Devonport, England, for the ensuing financial year has now been decided upon. The second-class cruisers Phoebe and Philomel are to be completed, and the first-class cruiser Edgar is to be pushed forward as far as possible. The Bonaventure, only recently laid down, will be continued, as also the cruisers AEolus and Astrea.

STANDING ROCK AGENCY, N.D., Jan. 3. -- On the issue of rations to-day it was discovered that a large number of the bucks who received their supplies here had disappeared, and on close questioning of the friendly Indians the fact came out that they had gathered together what rations they could conveniently carry on their ponies and moved southward toward the several hostile bands, making a stand in the Bad Lands.

BOSTON, Jan. 3. -- A conference was held today of the men interested in the formation of the Republican State Club. The leaders in the movement now include, not only those who attended the Tremont House conference a week ago, but also some of the young Republicans who nine months ago were at work for the formation of a club with a similar object in view.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 3. -- A joint stock company of Connecticut capitalists, with Capt. Isaac S. Brown, formerly of this city, at its head, has gone into the oyster-growing industry at Brunswick, Ga., with prospects of success that indicate strong competition for the Connecticut and Maryland growers. The company has a capital of $50,000 and controls some valuable grounds at Brunswick.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 3. -- The Bee has the following from its staff correspondent:

During the past week there were heavy falls of snow in numerous sections of this country, and doubtless many sportsmen are concerned as to the welfare of the game birds. The favorite Bob White need considerable attention at the present time, and it behooves sportsmen to immediately attend to feeding them. This suggestion is particularly pertinent to those who have recently introduced these birds.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- The Rev. George T. Price, late pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church at Milford, N.Y., has accepted a call to the charge of Bethany Methodist Episcopal Church at Baltimore, Md., and will enter on his new pastorate on March 1.

A subject much discussed in England at present and of more general interest than most matters purely English is that of child insurance. A clergyman has lately attacked this institution in the Contemporary Review with a passion to which philanthropists are not wholly strangers. The current Fortnightly Review has an article on the other side which is fully as energetic.

The withdrawal of Col. William H. Beard from the Empire Warehouse Company led to a report yesterday, which got into several Brooklyn papers, to the effect that Franklin Woodruff, another extensive owner of warehouse property, had also withdrawn. This Mr. Woodruff denied absolutely when a TIMES reporter called on him. He had not thought of getting out, didn't want to get out, and only wished he was in deeper.

The advantage in all recently-designed wardrooms aboard British war ships is the separation of the dining from the sleeping apartments. This separation can be appreciated more thoroughly by officers who have quartered in open wardrooms. The tendency to separate the dining and sleeping apartments is showing itself in some of the latest American-designed ships.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8. -- During the Christmas vacation at Yale the college society has interested itself in preparations for the production, which has already been announced for about April 1, of the 'Antigone of Sophocles." The Greek play has never before been attempted here, but if the anticipated success is realized there will be further endeavors in the same line.

Character is a thing which surprises us by its permanence, not so much from father to son as from father to grandson, and grandmother to great-grand-daughter. It is, therefore, historically interesting to find the same spirit that animated the Pilgrims while in Holland rising up in their descendants of Connecticut to put things in their proper places and arrange history according to the eternal verities.

Under date of Dec. 19, Mr. Louis Windmuller of this city wrote an open letter to Senator Plumb, which was printed in THE TIMES of Dec. 21, commending Mr. Plumb's attitude on the tariff, but expressing the belief that the Senator's position on the silver question was wrong. In due time Mr. Windmuller received from Senator Plumb the following reply:
DUNNELLON, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Jim Ota, a life convict, is at large. He escaped from Phosphate Camp here last night, under circumstances that add another chapter to a strangely eventful career.

WHY NOT LET THEM ALONE? -- To the ethics of Christ the Buddhists had no objection; to the dogmas of Christianity, which are altogether a different and, indeed, a hostile thing, they were averse; and those who carefully consider the morits of the two creeds as a defense against the troubles of this life and a solution of the difficulties of the next will be very slow to condemn them.

With the advent of the new year up go the prices of cigars of every class and grade. Domestic Havanas and seed and Havanas suffer alike with the imported goods, so dear to the people who smoke the two stamps on the imported box rather than the actual cigars, as far as discrimination as to their merits or demerits is in question.

Yesterday there was a slight improvement in prices in Wall Street, due mainly to the favorable bank statement, but, had any member of Congress been within hearing distance of the talk of business men in that region, he would have learned that, in good part, the more cheerful view of the future taken there was due to the hope that Congress would do nothing in regard to finance at this session.

One of the most interesting and suggestive of our contemporaries, the Musical Courier, publishes an article on the present condition of musical productiveness all over the world and sees little that is encouraging. Germany is absolutely barren of ideas; her composers are prolix and wearisome. Russia shows some evidence of ability, and in Italy there is only Verdi, sole exponent of the art of which he is without doubt the greatest living master.

Passengers on the elevated roads are frequently amazed at the recklessness with which conductors give the signal to go ahead while persons are crowding through the train gates from the station platform. Of course on such occasions only patrons of the road suffer. They are pushed and banged about while the gleeful trainmen chuckle and hurl darts of profane sarcasm at them.

The very interesting and convincing experiments of KLEIN and POWER in London concerning the source of infection in certain epidemics of scarlet fever and diphtheria and the transmission of these diseases from animals to man are recalled by another series of experiments recently made in Berlin by BEHRING and KITASATO, two bacteriologists who have been working in Prof. KOCH'S laboratory.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The week has been one of more than usual profit to theatrical managers and of enjoyment and profit to the patrons of theatres.

One of the most interesting and suggestive of our contemporaries, the Musical Courier, publishes an article on the present condition of musical productiveness all over the world and sees little that is encouraging. Germany is absolutely barren of ideas; her composers are prolix and wearisome. Russia shows some evidence of ability, and in Italy there is only Verdi, sole exponent of the art of which he is without doubt the greatest living master.

Passengers on the elevated roads are frequently amazed at the recklessness with which conductors give the signal to go ahead while persons are crowding through the train gates from the station platform. Of course on such occasions only patrons of the road suffer. They are pushed and banged about while the gleeful trainmen chuckle and hurl darts of profane sarcasm at them.

The old saying which in effect is that that which is everybody's business to attend to gets sadly neglected was never so brilliantly illustrated as by the people of the State of New-York who own the great Erie Canal. Between exorbitant elevator charges which are controlled by railroad companies, and excessive wharfage rates in the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, coupled with railroad discrimination, the peoples' transportation route is completely handicapped.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The week has been one of more than usual profit to theatrical managers and of enjoyment and profit to the patrons of theatres.

" The best of all financial measures," says the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, one of the most prominent Republican journals of the country, "would be a bill to correct the McKinley tariff law in accordance with the wishes of the people as expressed at the November election." The Globe-Democrat does not agree with the party leaders at Washington and the subsidized McKinley papers in regarding the people as fools.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Camden's military was in a state of great excitement over the reception of an order from Gen. W.J. Sewell, commanding the Second Brigade, directing every man to report at the armory, Fifth Street and the railroad, for duty. The men of Companies B, C, and D of the Sixth Regiment were called on at their homes by a corporal's guard and were marched to the armory.

We are glad to announce that the foremost of the McKinley papers in the West at last admits that it has peristently sought to deceive the people as to prices, and makes the admission in the most comprehensive and positive manner. Not content with confession, it seeks to make reparation by trying to counteract in almost every branch of industry the effect of its false teaching.

People who are anxious to see an adequate system of rapid transit for New-York City, and who are working toward that end, are united in the conviction that the viaduct system would be the nearest approach to the ideal.
