Some of them, however, who have recently expressed their views upon the general subject have believed that, with an exception heretofore stated in THE TIMES, a viaduct system was rendered impossible by its tremendous expense.
PARIS, Jan. 4. -- Leon Say, in an article in the Journal des Debats, severely criticises the McKinley tariff law and the American Farmers' Alliance.

BRIDGEPORT, Jan. 4. -- One of the old and original patentees in the Norwalk (Conn.) settlement was a family by the name of Kellogg. Among the records of the family are a number of deeds and patents from the Indians which are very interesting. An Indian deed to Roger Ludlowe is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Force-bill advocates and gag-rule supporters are apparently very confident that the Senatorial caucus, to be held at Mr. Stockbridge's house to-morrow night, will adopt the scheme of holding the continuous session in the interest of the two discredited measures. If this is done, it is the purpose of the Republicans to begin the fight Tuesday.

Xavier Scharwenka, a distinguished composer and piano virtuoso, arrived in New-York yesterday on the Saale. He is to give a series of concerts here under the management of Behr Brothers. Sharwenka is forty-one years old, having been born in 1850 in Samter, in the Prussian Province of Posen. He was educated in the capital of Posen and in Berlin.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- The Civil Service Commissioners and Secretary of State Pierce, who is presently to be succeeded by Col. William M. Olin, have disagreed over a question of appointments. The commission holds that the Secretary has not the right to a non-competitive examination for his appointee for the office of archives clerk.

The third appearance at the Lyceum concerts of Campanini was the most striking feature, perhaps, of the concert last night. His selections were such as to show that he is by no means confined to Italian music, and that his perfect vocal culture is available for music of which the characteristic is dramatic expression as well as for that which aims only at melodious sweetness.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- The only interest manifested in Albany to-day was over the threatened outbreak between the Platt and anti-Platt forces over the leadership of the minority. A corporal's guard of Platt's followers have been endeavoring to persuade Gen. Husted that it was his duty to jump into the breach and save his party.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 4. -- There is but little less excitement here to-night than a year ago, when the famous fight for two seats in the United States Senate was made, resulting in the seating of Messrs. Sanders and Romer by the throwing out of the Silver Bow Precinct, (Thirty-fourth,) and the members of both legislative bodies are nearly all here.

The "rumor" brought by the schooner W.F. Beebe to San Francisco that Germany had "seized the Marshall Islands" in the Pacific and had compelled all the chiefs but one to sign a petition for a German protectorate may be taken with less qualification than rumors sometimes require. The protectorate in question was announced years ago, when the dispute about the Carolines was decided by Pope LEO in favor of Spain.

Secretary McIntyre of the Brooklyn Jockey Club has issued a partial list of the entries to the Brooklyn Handicap, the first of the great Spring handicaps. Sixty-six were received up to Saturday evening. This is the same number us that of last year, but there are several distant points to be heard from, and it is thought that when these returns are in, the list will he largely increased.

FRANKFORT, Jan. 4. -- During the week past business on the Boerse was dull. Prices showed a tendency to weakness. The final quotations of yesterday include: Hungarian gold rente, 91.80; Russian 4s, 98.10; Spanish 4s, 75.50; Austrian credit, 274; Austrian silver rente, 70.70; Italian 5s, 93.20; short exchange on London, 20.34; private discount, 4 3/8.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4. -- Comment is aroused among navy officers over the series of orders emanating from the Navy Department, within the past few weeks, directing the commissioning of war ships at San Francisco and the ordering of various other cruisers to Pacific waters.

The results of the canvass made by Farm and Home of Springfield, Mass., with the aid of the New-England Homestead, to ascertain the preferences of the farmer of the United States as to Presidential candidates in 1892, have been tabulated by States and make an interesting showing. The question upon which the answers were based was:

The extreme modesty of Mr. Fletcher's preface does not prepare us for the excellent work he has produced. He says distinctly that he makes no pretension to originality of research, that he has not read all the authorities on the subject, that he reads the Swedish language only with the help of a dictionary, that he knows nothing of the meaning of military terms and nothing of the exact effect of manoeuvres.

DUBLIN, Jan. 4. -- The Earl of Zetland, Viceroy of Ireland, and Chief Secretary Balfour sign a declaration which has been issued on the condition of the poor in the western part of Ireland. The declaration says:
CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- Assistant Adjt. Gen. Corbin, upon telegraph orders from Gen., Miles, left for the Indian country at 6 o'clock to-night over the Chicago and Northwestern Road.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 4. -- A gentleman recently returned from Central America, in commenting upon matters in that section, mentions a growing belief in Guatemala that Barillos will soon be superseded in the Presidency of Guatemala by Gen. Cayetano Sanchez. Sanchez, it is said, has pretty thoroughly terrorized Guatemala. Complaints against his lawless and brutal conduct are almost daily laid before the President, but fear prevents Barillos from remonstrating with him.

" Isaac," so well known to visitors to the Tenderloin Club house, has been immortalized upon a photographic plate, and will now be exhibited all over the country by means of the optical lantern. The members of the club, who have now moved from the ramshackle old building in West Thirtieth Street to more commodious quarters, were desirous to have some souvenir of the old home to keep in the new building.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 4. -- Carlton Cable, mate of the Pittsburg steamer Annie Roberts, on which five men were killed and mangled by an explosion at Portsmouth, Ohio, on Friday returned to the city yesterday and gave an account of the affair. He said: "I was in the pilot house and watches had just been changed. The furnaces had been cleared out of clinkers.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4. -- The young gentleman who is to marry the fifth daughter of Chief Justice Fuller on Monday is Hugh Campbell Wallace, who was born and raised at Lexington, Mo., where his parents reside to-day. Mr. Wallace's father was an appointee under Grant, and had an important claim pending here for many years for damages incurred to his property during the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Those persons who are interested in the Bering Sea controversy, and who have been impatiently waiting for the President to send in the correspondence on that subject, have read with some concern the dispatches from Europe that represent the British Foreign Office as occupying a serene disposition about the menace that is implied in the preparations of Mr. Blaine to assert the right of search next season.

A monetary conference will meet at Washington on Wednesday, and the delegates, who are to be from the American States, will be welcomed in a speech by the Secretary of State. It seems to be expected in some quarters that this conference will have some definite influence upon the solution of the silver problem.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4. -- Late advices from the Caroline Islands state that an era of insurrection and bloodshed has set in among the natives and Spanish troops quartered in the group.

The official acts of no city officer who took charge with the new year will be watched with closer public interest than those of De Lancey Nicoll, District Attorney. Mr. Nicoll has said that he has a future to look out for, and that he will have this fact in mind while he is in office. His views on the administration of the excise laws are therefore of interest.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The First Presbyterian Church of Newark celebrated the centennial anniversary of its dedication to-day by exercises of special interest. The old brownstone church on the east side of Broad Street, near Market, was handsomely decorated in the interior with palms and potted plants, the gallery being hung with the old-fashioned portraits of former ministers and church members.

BUTTE, Mon., Jan 4. -- The District Court will to-morrow consider an application for the appointment of Commissioners to take the testimony of twenty-two witnesses residing at Eldon, Iowa, in the interest of Henry A. Root of New-York and others, who claim a large share of the $10,000,000 left by the late Judge Andrew J. Davis.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- The General Term recently handed down an opinion affirming a judgment below, which holds that actions for penalties for violating the game laws of the State must be brought in the county where the cause of action arises, and when not so brought the Supreme Court can change the venue. Judge Landon, writing the opinion, says:

Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Abbey returned from Europe yesterday on the Saale after an absence of three months, and Mr. Abbey reports that Sarah Bernhardt will certainly come to America this month, notwithstanding the numerous reports to the contrary.

The fiery cross has been sent out to all quarters of the Union by the Republican chiefs in Washington, and it is hoped that by this evening enough of the absent Senators will have returned to make possible a council of war. At this council there will be an effort to decide upon both the strategy and the tactics for the remainder of the session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Navy Department has been notified by N. F. Palmer, Jr., Co. that the gunboat Bennington is ready for her official trial. Her sister boat, the Concord, has already been out on a trial trip, which failed on account of the bursting of a small steam pipe. It is probable that both boats will be tried and accepted within the next two months.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 4. -- At 3 o'clock this morning Adjt. Gen. Stryker was aroused by a telegram from Toms River, Ocean County, signed by Lieut. Edward S. Farrow of the Twenty-first Infantry, United States Army, asking that troops be sent at once to Barnegat Park to quell a riot.

The eyes of thousands of Brooklyn taxpayers will be fixed on Judge Cullen's part of the Supreme Court to-day, and their ears will be strained to hear what reason Mayor Alfred C. Chapin has to give why he and his associates in the Municipal Government should not be restrained forever from purchasing the stock of the Long Island Water Supply Company.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 4. -- Bank Commissioners Charles Griswold of Guilford and Stephen Goodrich of Hartford have issued their report of the condition of the banks in the State on Oct. 1, 1890. The number of banks in Connecticut, as stated by the Commissioners, is eighty-six -- the same number as last year. The total amount of deposits on Oct. 1 was $116,406,675.39, showing an increase during the year of $6,035,713.09.

The Democratic leaders of New-Jersey are reported to be exceedingly anxious that the Legislature, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, shall make no mistakes that will imperil the strong position now held by the party in that State for the first time in many years. The leaders recognize the fact that they and their party are now on probation, and that everything depends upon the action of the Legislature which the people have voted into power.

The funeral of the late Queen Dowager and Regent of Corea appears to have been celebrated with great pomp and ceremony. Five months were consumed in preparations, and from the day of the interment every Corean citizen is bound to exchange his black hat for a white one for the space of three years. He must also wear white shoes and avoid parti-colored clothing.
RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 4. -- The Republican leaders of this State are a fighting lot. When not fighting Democrats, like the army worm they fight and eat up each other.

The genius of George Eliot has made Savonarola a real and living personality to thousands with whom he had till then been a mere name. But a careful compilation like the present volume has its own value nevertheless, supplementing the matchless portrait in "Romola" as an exact photograph might supplement a masterly painting.

Executions were issued to the Sheriff yesterday aggregating $5,900 against the Standard Fashion Company, paper patterns, at 59 West Fourteenth Street and in Chicago. The company was incorporated May 16, 1887, with a capital stock of $25,000, which was afterward increased to $50,000 in August, 1889. Frank Koewing was President and George A. Walton Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Navy Department authorities do not admit that the naval preparations now being pushed at San Francisco with so much vigor have anything to do with the Bering Sea controversy. It is still said that the San Francisco will leave for the China station as soon as completely fitted out, and will become the flagship of the squadron in those waters.

Capt. Reilly yesterday learned that the poolrooms in his precinct were doing a lively business, and he detailed officers to make arrests. James Lawrence of 114 West Thirty-third Street, Bernard Ford of the "White Elephant," 1,245 Broadway, and Bookmaker James McNulty were arrested. Detective Taylor of the Twentieth Precinct arrested James Smith of 200 West Forty-second Street.

Mr. Henry C. Miner stated positively and emphatically yesterday that he had made an arrangement with the representatives of the Gilsey estate to rebuild the Fifth Avenue Theatre at once. He had gone so far as to have plans drawn for the building, and the only thing remaining to be done before commencing operations was the approval of Mr. Miner's plans by the Gilsey estate.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 5. -- Work on the machinery for the new battle ship Texas is advancing favorably. The construction is being carried on by the Richmond Locomotive and Machine Works of this place. So far all the cylinders and liners have been successfully cast. The high and intermediate pressure cylinders are practically compinted.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 5. -- Episcopal clergymen from all over the country are registering at the various hotels to-night in order to be in attendance at the trial on Wednesday morning of the Rev. Howard MacQueary of Canton on the charge of heresy. The case has excited intense interest throughout the country, and the trial will be conducted before a large number of men high up in the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Nobody who is interested in the parks of the city can read without a shudder the paragraph of the Mayor's message that is devoted to them. The most discouraging fact about the paragraph is its showing that the Mayor himself takes a personal interest in the parks and has his own views about them.

I have the honor herewith to submit a statement, prepared by the Controller, of the financial condition of the city, pursuant to the provisions of law which require such statement to be made each year by the Mayor to the Common Council:

Mayor Chapin and his associates in the Brooklyn Municipal Government, Controller Jackson and ex-Auditor Rutan, had their day in court yesterday to show cause why they should not be enjoined from purchasing the Long Island Water Supply Company, but they did nothing more than present affidavits in refutation of the allegations made by Mr. William Ziegler.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 5. -- Judge Leake of the Richmond Chancery Court to-day rendered a decision which will make Bettie Thomas Lewis the richest colored person in Virginia. This case has been pending for more than two years, and in many features is the most remarkable ever before a Virginia court. Two years ago W.A. Thomas, a retired dry goods merchant, died, leaving an estate worth about $225,000.

It is of a piece with everything that the Administration has done respecting Indian affairs that it should now be dispatching to Gen. MILES urgent telegrams exhorting him to avoid further bloodshed. There is a pathetic old song in which a girl is moved by the conscription of her lover to express the wish that "those who make the quarrel" should "be the only ones to fight."

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 5. -- At 11 o'clock this morning, the hour set for the coming in of the Supreme Court in the injunction and mandamus proceedings against Clerk of the House Jewett, the court room was crowded with counsel and spectators. Both the Republican United States Senators, Gov. Goodell and would-be Gov. Tuttle, were there, as well as Dr. Gallinger and other Republican leaders, with many active Democrats.

Several Western railroad Presidents are on their way to this city to attend the first meeting of the new Advisory Board called by Temporary President Roswell Miller. It will be held in the Windsor Hotel on Thursday, beginning at 10:30 o'clock A.M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Mrs. Brown, wife of Justice Brown of Michigan, the newly-appointed Associate Justice, held her first reception this afternoon in her parlors at the Arlington Hotel, where she had many callers, notwithstanding the fact that her presence in the city was not generally known. Mrs. Brown has many friends in Washington, made during her former visits here as the guest of Senator and Mrs. Palmer.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- The new City Government was inaugurated to-day, Mayor Nathan Matthews (Democrat) being sworn in by Chief Justice Walbridge A. Field of the Supreme Court. Alderman Herbert S. Carruth was chosen President of the Board of Aldermen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Nothing has been received at the War Department about the rumor that Gen. Miles had been killed by Indians, and the report is discredited.

The annual message of Mayor Chapin was presented to the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday and referred by them to a committee with the usual perfunctory order to have it printed and distributed. The document would fill about five columns of THE TIMES and is almost entirely devoted to pointing out how the city has been growing in the past and in designating the lines along which its future greatness must be built.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 5. -- To-day was the date set for the meeting of the State Legislature, and three bodies of men met in as many different places and organized three branches of the Montana Legislature.

Delmonico's ballroom was once more brilliant with sparkling jewels, radiant faces, and rich apparel last evening on the occasion of the second Patriarchs' ball. The invitation list was somewhat more exclusive than at the first of the series, and not more than three hundred guests were present, but there was no sparing of good taste or expense to make the affair the most successful of the season.
The following additional sums are reported from the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collections by Mr. Charles Lanier, General Treasurer, 17 Nassau Street:

It was a great surprise to Mr. HOAR yesterday when, on the very eve of the caucus called to arrange for the passage of the Force bill, that bill was calmly voted out of the way and the Finance bill was taken up in its place. This was the result of a suddenly-developed, but probably well-matured, coalition between the Democrats and the silver Republicans, and it was accomplished with a touch of theatrical effect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The fashionable world congregated to-night at St. John's Church to witness the marriage of Miss Mildred Fuller, daughter of Chief Justice Fuller, to Mr. Hugh Campbell Wallace of Tacoma. The chancel was decorated with fine palms. At each of the entrances to the chancel were jardinieres of roses, behind which, intermingled with the palms, were poinsetta blossoms.
As one interested in ballot reform in Pennsylvania, I fear your editorial of Thursday last may produce a wrong impression concerning the movement in this State.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 5. -- Governor-elect Luzon B. Morris and Lieut. Gov. Samuel E. Merwin will both go to Hartford on Wednesday to attend the opening of the Legislature. That they will have to remain at the capital from one to three weeks before the title of either to the Governorship can be disproved is the opinion of the leaders in both parties.

It is not only by imposing a duty of 300 per cent. on common goat hair, which has heretofore been admitted free, that the Treasury Department has sought to increase the cost of carpets. A decision as to the manner in which the dutiable value of carpet wool imported from Russia shall be fixed has had the effect of increasing still further the cost of the carpet manufacturers' raw material.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The contest over rapid transit will open with the legislative session. Tammany Hall will introduce its bill to-morrow, Senator Eugene S. Ives handling it in the Senate and Assemblyman John Connelly in the House. Mr. Thomas C. Platt will also introduce a Rapid Transit bill in the interest of the mob that is all that remains of the faction which he so proudly led before the election.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The clash between the partisans of the Force bill and its opponents came to-day. Although it had been threatened for weeks, it came at last suddenly. The Republican opponents of the measure had kept their programme so quietly to themselves that when they finally moved it was with a brilliancy of effect and with a decisive result.

The conference of Baptist pastors held its quarterly election yesterday morning at the Baptist Tabernacle, and the Rev. Dr. J.C. Grimmell of the First German Baptist Church Brooklyn was chosen Moderator of the conference for the ensuing three months. He was cordially welcomed to the chair by the Rev. Dr. Maul of Staten Island, the retiring Moderator.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 5. -- Within the shadow of the Mormon Tabernacle and within a stone's throw of where Brigham Young lived and died, Emma Abbott breathed her last at 8 o'clock this morning.

Charles S. Ehrlich's saloon at 590 River Street, Troy, N.Y., was destroyed by fire yesterday morning. Before the River Street blaze was extinguished the Fire Department was called to Stephen Mayhew's grocery and saloon on Federal Street. The fire had gained considerable headway before the engines arrived. The River Street building is owned by Mrs. Theodore Vaine.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 5. -- The Bee correspondent telegraphs as follows:

In the new Grammar School No. 7, at Hester and Chrystie Streets, it is proposed, according to the plans provided by George W. Debevoise, Superintendent of School Buildings, to prepare the two lower floors for the primary department and the two upper floors, with some class rooms, covering half the roof area above the fourth floor, and really constituting a fifth story, for the grammar department.

The new Rapid-Transit bill, which has the approval of the city authorities, and which will probably be the first bill introduced in both the Senate and Assembly to-day, is in its main features the Fassett bill of last year. Some changes have been introduced in the details of the measure, notably the provision authorizing the Rapid-Transit Commission to provide space for pipes, wires, , in connection with any roads to be constructed.
LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The Foreign Office this evening has issued the following communication to the press in regard to the Bering Sea dispute:

It looks very much as if the Government had been so much occupied in getting Indian lands by cession and purchase during the last year or two as to have unduly neglected one or two minor matters, such as properly feeding the red men. Documents laid before Congress show that over 20,000,000 acres have been thus acquired within two years, and nine-tenths of it within about a year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- The Ohio Legislature convened in adjourned session at 4 P. M. and listened to the reading of the Governor's message. The second paragraph in Gov. Campbell's message is devoted to municipal reform, and the subject is presented in the Governor's characteristic style. The enormous amount of special legislation annually enacted for cities shows, he says, the need of a radical change in the system of Municipal Government.

Miss Rosina Vokes, who has hitherto come to New-York with the strawberries, has now chosen to fill a midwinter engagement in the metropolis and to enter boldly into competition with the stock companies -- excepting Mr. Palmer's, whom she has temporarily dispossessed -- and all the "stars." She is fortunate in having the Madison Square Theatre for her experiment.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 6. -- Unless some unknown power intervenes between now and next Friday in Nebraska politics, this State is likely to have at least two Governors and two sets of State officers.

The unpublished chapter of our diplomatic history which the Senate gave out yesterday has been long and carefully kept from the public view, though some information of its contents had transpired in President ARTHUR'S last message and through the mysterious channels by which the executive secrets of the Senate usually reach the outside world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- President and Mrs. Harrison gave the first state dinner of the season to-night in honor of Vice President and Mrs. Morton and the Cabinet.

Mr. TELLER of Colorado yesterday undertook to define the position of the Republican silver Senators. He denied, with more warmth than seemed to be called for, the intimation that there had been any coalition between himself and friends and the minority Senators to lay aside the Force bill and take up the Finance bill.

There were three rapid-transit bills introduced in the Legislature yesterday. That which was sent to Albany with a flourish of trumpets by the local authorities was introduced in the Senate by Mr. IVES and in the Assembly by Mr. CONNELLY, and Mr. STEWART introduced one in the Senate which is regarded as embodying "TOM" PLATT'S ideas of rapid transit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Some influence appears to be at work to prevent the investigation asked for by Mr. Dockery to ascertain who were the Senators and Representatives who made money by the passage of the Silver bill by being in a "pool."
In his annual message submitted to the Legislature yesterday Gov. David B. Hill said: "There should be devised a comprehensive plan for the creation of a State park in the Adirondacks."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- The developments thus far in petitions for relief by depositors in the suspended bank of S.A. Kean Co. had shown that widespread and diversified interests were involved, but it remained for Ross Taylor of Evanston, in a petition filed in the County Court this morning, to show that the savages of the far-off Congo have both a temporal and eternal interest in the collapse.

In entering upon the seventh and last year of my service as Chief Executive of the State, I will not affect to conceal my gratification at the fact that fort the first time during the past seven years the popular branch of the Legislature is in political accord with the Executive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- It will not be very strange if Senators who a day or two ago were bitterly denouncing the opponents of the Force bill and gag rule as obstructionists are soon found playing exactly the same role. Some of the most earnest advocates of the Force bill are very strongly opposed to the free coinage of silver.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 6. -- The biennial session of the Pennsylvania Legislature began at noon to-day. Caleb B. Thompson of Warren County, the caucus nominee of the Republicans, Was duly elected Speaker of the House, receiving 125 votes. George W. Skinner of Fulton County received 78 Democratic votes. Senator Boies Penrose of Philadelphia was chosen President pro tem. of the Senate.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 6. -- It is probable that by to-morrow evening the Republican State stealers will be in possession of the New-Hampshire Legislature and in a position to grasp the Governorship, the United States Senatorship, and everything else which goes with the control of the legislative branch of the State Government.

The second Board of Experts has finished its labors. For two months it has been engaged on the problem of increasing the terminal facilities of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge -- a problem second only in difficulty and importance to that of rapid transit. The plan for increasing the terminal facilities has been adopted and only its details remain to be elaborated.

ROME, Jan. 6. -- The Ecumenical Council has pronounced in favor of the validity of the marriage of Count Ursel of France and Marie D. Ursel, nee Davis, of New-York. The marriage took place in 1868, and in 1878 the Countess eloped with a Frenchman named Say, subsequently contracting a civil marriage in Switzerland.
We published yesterday a paragraph from a letter sent to the London Lancet by Sir JOSEPH LISTER, in which he spoke of his recent visit to the Hygienic Institute of Prof. KOCH in Berlin, and said:

HELENA, Mont., Jan. 6. -- Gov. Toole made a new departure to-day in the matter of transmitting his annual message to the Legislature. He read it himself in the presence of the Senate and the Democratic House in the hall of the former body. The Republican House had taken a recess at the time till 3 o'clock, though a majority of the Senate had no intention of inviting that organization to attend the joint session.

The argument on the motion of William Ziegler to continue an injunction obtained by him restraining the Mayor, Controller, and Auditor of Brooklyn from carrying out the purchase of the Long Island Water Supply Company pending a suit to nullify such purchase was continued in the Supreme Court, before Judge Bartlett, yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- In June last on application of Dr. Nathan A. Mossman of 350 Madison Avenue, New-York, Judge Dykman of the New-York Supreme Court appointed Congressman-elect Henry Bacon of Goshen a Commissioner to investigate the pecuniary affairs of Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Carroll, a supposed lunatic under treatment at the Middletown State Homeopathic Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Mexican Legation was crowded this afternoon upon the occasion of Mme. Romero's first reception, which, like its predecessors of last year, was in every respect highly enjoyable. The gown worn by the hostess was of black velvet, brocaded in pink, with deep ferns of pink satin in the skirt, and trimmings of jet passamenterie.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The Press Association of this city announces that Lord Salisbury is engaged in the consideration of the forty-page dispatch received from Mr. Blaine Dec. 30, the latest dispatch received from Washington. It does not contain s definite acceptance of Lord Salisbury's proposals for arbitration on the main question, that of the right of the British sealers to catch seals in Bering Sea.

A temporary injunction which will, for the present, put a stop to any consolidation of the Brooklyn League and the Brooklyn Players' League Baseball Clubs, was obtained yesterday from Judge Cullen of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, by Edward F. Linton, one of the Directors in the Brooklyn Players' League.

The reported combination of Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica in a request to our Government to send them each a separate Minister, allowing Minister PACHECO to remain accredited to Guatemala, is rather singular. It does not appear to be exactly a "round robin" affair, but a movement in which all join, each on its own responsibility.

MADRID, Jan. 6. -- Gen. E. Burd Grubb, the new United States Minister here, has indicated the desire of his Government to negotiate a reciprocity treaty with Spain on the understanding that the treatment granted to American imports in the Spanish West Indies should not be extended to imports from other countries, and that the United States in exchange would partly exempt Cuban sugars and tobaccos from the imposts of the McKinley tariff.

A petition signed by nearly 500 seamen gunners, petty officers, able seamen, and apprentices aboard the war ships Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, Yorktown, Yantic, Minnesota, and Vermont, now at New-York, has been forwarded to the Secretary of the Navy. The petition has also been signed by men aboard the receiving ship Dale at Washington and the cruiser Atlanta at Norfolk.

BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- The express business centring in Boston has been given a severe shaking up by a movement of the Adams and American Express Companies to play into one another's hands. The New-England territory, as covered by the two companies, is divided in a rough way by the line of the Boston and Albany Railroad, the territory north of it being covered by the American, and the Adams serving the southern district.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Gov. Hill will not be a candidate for Governor next Fall. At least the opening and closing paragraphs of his message issued to-day convey that idea, and the men who are closest to him reaffirm the declaration.

FARGO, N.D., Jan. 6. -- Farmers of North Dakota have formed a combination to fight the Harvester Trust. The news of the formation of the American Harvester Company, with headquarters in Chicago, was received in this city with considerable distrust. The statement made by its managers that prices would not be advanced quieted all apprehensions.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 6. -- The Picayune's Havana special says: The sensation of the hour is the death of Sixto Valera, the brigand, the first officer of Manuel Garcia's band, which resulted from an encounter with the troops of the Government about 8 o'clock on the night of Dec. 31, on the farm called the "Santa Rosalia," owned by Don Enrique Perez Castaneda, in the district of Bataban.

Prominent railroad men from the West are arriving in town by almost every train from that section of the country for the purpose of at tending the meeting to-morrow. President Roswell Miller of the St. Paul and President R.I. Cable of the Rock Island reached here night before last, and spent the greater part of yesterday in the vicinity of Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- THE TIMES'S dispatches setting forth the strength of the naval forces on the Pacific station have starved to draw considerable attention to the condition of the American squadron in those water. The Pacific station has within the past few years furnished more real work for the navy than all the other stations combined, and this condition of affairs is apt to continue for some time to come.

The annual charity ball given for the benefit of the Nursery and Child's Hospital of this city was held last night at the Metropolitan Opera House and was a brilliant success socially and financially. The parlors, corridors, and grand stairways were brilliant with promenaders from early evening until early morn, and no end of charming toilets were displayed by the ladies.

Victory perched on the banners of the administration party in the contest for control of the Fidelity and Casualty Company yesterday. There was a heavy vote, 2,376 shares being voted out of a total of 2,500. The opposition controlled 903 shares, while the administration party put in 1,473 votes. It had more which could have been brought forward if it had been necessary.
PINE RIDGE, Jan. 6. -- Information from the camp near Wounded Knee Creek, South Dakota, to-day, says:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 6. -- The Bering Sea dispute continues to engross public attention in Canada. Here, at the Dominion capital, there is a political element which regards the situation as really alarming.

The theme given out by Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN at Birmingham the other day has been repeated by the London Telegraph, with variations in the Telegraph's florid manner. The theme was the advisability of the dropping of the Irish question by the Gladstonians, and their addiction to something that the Telegraph calls "a common faith in rational progress, tempered by loyalty toward order, good government, and legislative honesty."

The very quiet and skillful manner in which eight of the Western silver Senators on Monday overthrew the whole plan of campaign of the leaders of the majority shows that the stroke was as deliberately arranged as it was resolutely and effectually carried out. The amazement and confusion with which the result was received by the leaders, on the other hand, show a singular blindness to the real situation.

There is every prospect that a long and bitter legal battle will be fought over the late Daniel B. Fayerweather's millions. The case comes up for trial on the 28th of this month. Mrs. Fayerweather, the contestant, who has made application to have the codicil of Nov. 15 set aside as illegal, declares that the codicil was signed while her late husband was of unsound mind and on the verge of death.

The Long Island Water Supply Company will not be saddled upon the taxpayers of Brooklyn just yet. Judge Bartlett yesterday continued the injunction granted by Judge Cullen in the suit brought by Mr. William Ziegler, suing as a taxpayer, to have the contract entered into by the Mayor, Controller, and City Auditor to buy the company for $1,250,000 declared null and void.

The Young Men's Democratic Association of Philadelphia will celebrate "Jackson's Day" with a grand Democratic ratification meeting, so to speak, and banquet. The most prominent speaker on the occasion will be Grover Cleveland, as he would be the most prominent speaker in any assemblage of American citizens.

The Board of Experts on increasing the terminal facilities of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge met yesterday and revised the proof sheets of their report. The report will be made officially public on Friday or Saturday.

There is a sentimental disease prevalent in many parts of the United States that makes it seem ungracious to condemn an act of executive clemency, such as the pardon by Mr. HARRISON of the embezzler GOULD. The facts in the case are set forth briefly but clearly in our Washington dispatches this morning.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 7. -- The crisis is over, the trouble is ended, the conspirators have triumphed, and the Government of the State of New-Hampshire has passed from the control of the people into the possession of the gang of thieves of which "Statesman" Chandler is the managing director. The man Jewett has done precisely what it was expected that he would do.

The Board of General Appraisers, Col. Tichenor, Gen. Sharpe, and Judge Somerville acting, decided the Passavant kid-glove case yesterday adversely to the importers. The decision was a divided one, Col. Tichenor and Judge Somerville siding with Col. Jewell in his reappraisement and Gen. Sharpe declaring in favor of Passavant Co.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7. -- President Baker of the Franklin Bank in a report to the stockholders says that the bank has met with reverses on account of the incapacity and untrustworthiness of the cashier to the extent of $119,000. H. Webster Crowl had been allowed to overdraw his account without his (the President's) knowledge and entirely unknown to the Board of Directors.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- In the safe of Clerk De Freest of the Assembly are three big bundles of legal cap containing the evidence in the contested Assembly election cases of William B. Howard against Nevada W. Stranahan of the First Oswego District, John F. Dwyer against W.B. Dunlap of Montgomery, and Robert O. Davis against C.R. Sheffer of the First Saratoga District.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The War Department has been unsuccessful in its first attempt to have heavy guns built by contract. Bids were opened in the ordnance office on Monday for the construction of fifty guns of eight, ten, and twelve inch calibres under the provisions of the Fortifications act of Aug. 16, 1890.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 7. -- The Republicans organized the upper house of the Legislature to-day and the Democrats the lower house. Interest was centred in the lower house, in which the three Alliance men, who hold the balance of power, are seated. Clayton E. Crafts was elected Speaker by one majority, the vote standing: Crafts, 77; R.N. Ramsey, Republican, 73; H.H. Moore, Democrat, 3.

" Prince Karl" was presented by Mr. Mansfield and his company at the Garden Theatre yesterday afternoon. The audience was numerous for a midweek matinee, and the play, which is now one of the most entertaining in Mr. Mansfield's repertory, was followed with delight. This performance is all in the spirit of burlesque, but is controlled by the nicest artistic taste, and thoroughly finished in every detail.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 7. -- Postmaster Tichenor's term of office is rapidly approaching its end, and as he was appointed under the Cleveland Administration, all good Republicans look for his dismissal. When President Harrison first took his seat an effort was made to have Mr. Tichenor removed, but public feeling was so great that the effort was abandoned.

The marriage of Miss E. Louise Garrison, the adopted daughter of Mr. W.D. Garrison, manager of the Grand Union Hotel, to Dr. J.V.D. Young was celebrated at St. Bartholomew's Church, Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. At 4 o'clock the bridal party entered, headed by the ushers, Dr. C.W. Cutler, Dr. E.K. Losee, Dr. T.H. Meyers, Dr. L.F. Bishop, Mr. J.W. Garrison, and Mr. Herbert Marshall.

Another lease of life has been granted to Jugigo, the Japanese murderer, owing to the intricacies of the United States statutes. His case will again go before the United States Supreme Court on new points raised by Lawyer Roger M. Sherman and his appeal from the denial of a writ of habeas corpus by Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court.

We should say that the lesson administered to Mayor ALFRED C. CHAPIN yesterday would make an impression that will not be effaced during the remainder of his political life. It is the lesson of an act of unwisdom, of a plain and palpable error, coming up to plague him who committed it at a most awkward and unfortunate moment.

BOSTON, Jan. 7. -- The Legislature of 1891 was easily reorganized this morning, Speaker Barrett and President Sprague of the Senate being harmoniously re-elected. The Republican House caucus lasted six minutes and agreed to support all the present officials of the House. The most important political development of the day was in the House Democratic caucus, which passed this resolution:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- During the Administration of President Hayes it was the practice of the President to invite all representatives of the press to the White House receptions by card, just as Senators and Representatives in Congress were invited.

The Committee on Construction of the Aqueduct Commission has reported in favor of constructing the new Croton dam in accordance with the recommendations of Chief Engineer FTELEY made in his able report of last October. The committee has made careful investigation and given public hearings and has reached the conclusion without hesitation that the new dam should be built.

Those would-be bosses of the Republican Party in Brooklyn who are opposed to Franklin Woodruff's domination in the machine, met in caucus at the Clarendon Hotel last night, to decide upon a candidate for Chairman of the Kings County Republican General Committee, which meets to elect such an officer Tuesday night. About fifty gentlemen were present and found Senator James W. Birkett in control.

If the Rapid-Transit bill introduced in the Assembly on Tuesday by HAMILTON FISH, Jr., is in substance and effect the same as that passed by the Assembly last year, as it is generally stated to be in the Albany dispatches, and if, as is also stated, there are six or eight Republican Senators who are prepared to support it, we see no reason why it should not be enacted without any prolonged controversy or delay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Gen. V.D. Groner of Norfolk, Va., Chairman of the Committee on Transportation for the Columbian Exposition, is in Washington to-night, on his way to Norfolk. He reports that he has made substantial progress in securing assurances of favorable rates and arrangements for the conveyance of persons and exhibits to the fair at Chicago.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 7. -- Five clergymen, none of them especially versed in Scriptural or ecclesiastical lore, began to sit as an ecclesiastical court in this city this morning, and their decision will settle the clerical standing of the Rev. Howard MacQueary, formerly rector of St. Paul's Church. Canton, Ohio, and will put the Diocese of Ohio on record on theological questions that men are disputing about the world over.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Justice Hamburger decided to-day that however unpleasant the duty, he believed there was probable cause for the supposition that S.A. Kean knew he was insolvent when he received Royer's money, and he would therefore be compelled to hold the banker to the Grand Jury in bonds of $3,000. The banker promptly furnished the required bail and was released.

The most remarkable thing about the project for assorting the mails at sea is that it should now be brought forward for the first time. It appears that letters for Europe are habitually retained for distribution in the New-York Post Office, and the delay thus entailed often suffices to cause them to miss the first steamer that sails after they arrive.

It is impossible to read the account of the proceedings of the Senate on Monday without being more or less sorry for Mr. GEORGE F. HOAR. That venerable scholar in politics has been the sponsor and spokesman of the Force bill in the Senate even as the juvenile scholar in politics, Mr. CABOT LODGE, has been its sponsor and spokesman in the House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- If the silver men have their way in the Senate the Finance bill will be acted upon within a week. Mr. Stewart proposed this morning that voting on the bill and its amendments should begin Friday. Later in the day he suggested that the discussion should end Saturday.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- Advices received in this city from Boulogne-sur-Mer state that Mr. O'Brien, at his own request, was empowered to ask Justin McCarthy to retire from the Chairmanship of the anti-Parnell section of the Irish party in favor of John Dillon; or, it is understood, the conference agreed that if Mr. O'Brien preferred to do so , he (Mr. O'Brien) could serve as Chairman.

The time of the House of Representatives was chiefly spent yesterday in a discussion of the Subsidy bill, which proposes to pay several million dollars a year, collected from the people at large, to the owners of vessels to enable them to overcome the restrictions and disadvantages imposed upon shipping by our own laws.

W.T. Moore, President of the United Electric Light and Power Company, advances a comparatively new scheme for relieving the overcrowded condition of our business districts by rapid transit. Mr. Moore thinks that the people who are trying to solve this vexed question have made the mistake of beginning at the wrong end of the line.

There is something akin to a row under way in the American Society of Civil Engineers. The trouble will come to a head at the annual election for officers, which takes place on Jan. 21. Meanwhile an earnest and in some respects a bitter campaign is being conducted by the leaders of the opposing factions, known respectively as the Wellingtonians and the anti-Wellingtonians.

NEW-YORK, Jan. 3. -- Recent cable dispatches from Carlsbad more than confirm the impression already received by those familiar with the subject that the disastrous floods which devastated that most famous of German watering places a short time ago are likely to prove a serious matter to the people of this country.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- One result of the recent election on the Chicago Board of Trade has been to precipitate a fight between the board and the traffic departments of all the railroads entering Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Secretary of the Navy Tracy made public to-day his letter to Commander George C. Reiter, who was removed from the command of the Ranger on account of his failure to interfere and prevent the killing of Gen. Barrundia on board the American ship Acapulco, in the harbor of San Jose, Guatemala, Aug. 29.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 7. -- A letter from Congressman E.J. Turner of the Sixth District was made public to-day, which has caused much bad blood and may result in a permanent split in Alliance ranks. The letter was in the possession of Judge Peffer, one of the Alliance candidates for Senator, and McLellan, editor of the Alliance organ, and held until McGrath, President of the State Alliance, to whom it was addressed, threatened personal violence.

Gen. H.L. Abbot, Gen. C.B. Comstock, and Col. G.L. Gillespie, forming the United States Board of Engineers, held their first public meeting at the Army Building yesterday on the plan of the North River Bridge Company to throw a single span across the river from Broomfield and Twelfth Streets, Jersey City, to Twenty-third Street, this city.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan 8. -- President Frank McGrath of the State Alliance responds in the following letter to the charges that he has "sold out" the Alliance by entering into a contract with Congressman Turner:

In his speech to the Young Men's Democratic Association at Philadelphia last evening, on the anniversary of the battle of New-Orleans. Mr. CLEVELAND showed himself in some respects at his best. Mr. CLEVELAND'S conception of "the principles of true Democracy" is clear, broad, just, and practical, and his vision is penetrating enough to see the actual bearing of what he accepts as Democratic principles upon the requirements of the present.

Sergius Stepniak, the Russian revolutionary leader and exile, lectured before a large audience in the Metropolitan Opera House last evening for the benefit of the Society to Befriend Working Girls. His subject had been announced as "Count Tolstoi as a Novelist and as a Social Reformer," but Mr. Stepniak deemed it expedient to speak on "Nihilism; or, the Revolutionary Movement in Russia," instead.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- The Hon. William E. Russell, Massachusetts's third Democratic Governor since the war, and the youngest save one in her history, was inaugurated to-day. The State House was crowded. A detail of the city police and a contingent of the State force kept the crowd in order. The ladies were present in great numbers, and they thronged into the galleries of the House as soon as the doors were open.

HARTFORD, Jan. 8. -- When the Connecticut Legislature closed its business this afternoon, Morgan G. Bulkeley, the present Governor of the State, concluded to hang out a sign, "Business will be resumed at the old stand and continued for two years under the same auspices." This was done under the advice of his counsel, Charles J. Cole of this city.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 8. -- There was war at the State Capitol to-day and soldiers filled the corridors. It was all due to the attempt of the Alliance to keep the State office by force and prevent Governor-elect Boyd from taking his seat. The outcome of this the most disgraceful wrangle ever seen at the Capitol was the counting of the votes and the declaration that Boyd (Dem.) was elected Governor.

On the suggestion of Senator INGALLS acceded to by Senator GORMAN, the Senate has by unanimous consent agreed that general debate on the Finance bill shall close with the adjournment on Tuesday next; that on Wednesday debate on the amendments shall be limited to ten minutes for each Senator, and that the vote shall be taken before adjournment on that day.

The twelfth exhibition of works of art at the Union League Club is likely to be the last for some time to come. The Committee of Seven feels that it has labored hard for the pleasure of the members and their friends and has pretty well exhausted the collections of its immediate acquaintances while obtaining material for twelve loan exhibitions.

From the time of Mr. GLADSTONE'S notification that he could not co-operate with the Irish Parliamentary Party so long as Mr. PARNELL remained in the lead of it, the leader thus invited to depose himself seemed to have lost his head entirely. No man has gone further to illustrate the saying that whom the gods wish to destroy they first make mad.

Harmony was the watchword among the influential Western railroad men who attended the first meeting of the new Advisory Board at the Windsor Hotel, in this city, yesterday. Although the meeting was uneventful beyond the designating of a committee to draft a constitution and by-laws, there were convincing evidences that the unanimous sentiment of the members of the board was for peace and harmony.

Gov. RUSSELL of Massachusetts departs from the useless custom of making a summary of official reports in his first message to the Legislature and devotes himself mainly to recommending reforms. He is strongly in favor of abolishing the poll tax as a qualification upon the suffrage.

The Ingalls theory of politics as warfare, in which the Decalogue and the Golden Rule have no place, and in which every advantage is to be taken of the enemy without regard to moral principle, has so far prevailed in times past as to beget among violent partisans a remarkable callousness as to moral distinctions where public office is to be gained or lost.

The suggestions of Gov. HILL about the improvement of the highways of the State are at least so far commendable as they tend to arouse public interest in the subject. Gov. BEAVER of Pennsylvania is entitled to the credit of being the first Chief Magistrate of a State to call attention to a topic the importance of which cannot well be overestimated.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 8. -- Both branches of the State Legislature met in joint convention at 11:10 A.M. to-day. The oath of office was administered to Gov. Burleigh by the President of the Senate, and the Governor immediately proceeded to read his inaugural address.

It now appears to be very well settled that Patrick Keenan, for so long the County Democracy leader in the Twelfth Assembly District, will be a member of Tammany's General Committee in that district after the primary election on Jan. 16. This means a loss to the County Democracy of one of its strongest leaders. The move has been discounted for some time by the politicians.

CONCORD, N.H, Jan. 8. -- If in some manner there could have been held here this morning a convention of those wise and sententious fellows, the old sawmakers, for the purpose of selecting an appropriate motto for this, New-Hampshire's inauguration day, the decision would have been speedily and unanimously given that there was nothing which would answer so well as that particular old saw which affirms that the receiver is as bad as the thief.

The report of the Railroad Commissioners of Connecticut shows that the law enacted two years ago in that State concerning the abolition of railroad crossings at grade has scarcely any value. Under its provisions only four companies could be compelled to make any changes, and if the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Company, which controls several lines, had separated grades at only six crossings it would have complied with the statute.

The officers and managers of the Nursery and Child's Hospital held their annual meeting yesterday at the hospital building. Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Mrs. F.N. Goddard, the Treasurer, reported that on Jan. 1, 1890, there was a balance of $12,537.43 in the treasury, and that the total receipts for the year were $133,045.80.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 8. -- Charles L. Jewett of New-Albany has been secured as counsel for a life insurance company in a case that is to be tried at the present term of the Scott Circuit Court. Several years ago Abraham Cline, who held a five-thousand-dollar policy on his life with the company, disappeared from his home at Scottsburg.

For the first time the handsome new ballroom at the Madison Square Garden felt the step of the dancer last evening, when the first ladies' assembly of the season was given. The ballroom glowed beneath the soft electric lights imbedded in its ceiling and about its walls. Long festoons of laurel hung from the balconies, while the orchestral platform was a mass of palms and pine.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- The new calendar for the Court of Appeals for 1891 has been made up in the quickest time on record and it is now being printed. It will be ready for distribution early next week. It contains a total of 911 causes. Of these, 644 are on the general calendar, two are criminal, and 252 preferred. There are also fifteen appeals from orders.

We are apt to consider "an old-fashioned Winter" in New-York an unmitigated nuisance, and it is comforting to dwell upon its mitigations, such as they are. One of them is that the patient owners of sleighs and cutters have had something like a week's sleighing, and the Weather Bureau appears to promise them more.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The only subject of conversation in the Navy Department to-day was Secretary Tracy's reprimand of Commander Reiter. It has been many years since a naval officer has been so severely censured by the head of the department, and officers naturally express considerable sympathy for Commander Reiter.

It is difficult to see the way out of the Connecticut muddle. The legislative session is practically suspended until the 20th, when action will have to be taken on the election of a United States Senator. The Democratic Senate has declared Mr. MORRIS and the other Democratic candidates for State offices duly elected, but that declaration is of no effect unless made by both houses.

The bill introduced by Assemblyman Hamilton Fish, Jr., on Tuesday, is declared by its author to be a practical reproduction of the Fassett bill of last year. By the limitation to cities of over a million population, which is common to all the bills, it is made applicable exclusively to New-York City. By sections, its provisions are substantially as follows:

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 9. -- The report of the committee which was appointed under authority of the Legislature of 1889 to investigate the condition of the poor insane in the State and recommend measures for their relief is about ready. The statistics concerning the situation have been accumulated by ex-Senator Lyman S. Catlin of Stratford.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 9. -- Lieut. William Henn, who is en route to Florida, was seen this morning on board the Clyde steamer Yemassce by a TIMES representative in regard to the chances for a race for the America's cup.

All the officials connected with the Brooklyn water scandal were extremely reticent yesterday, and although Mayor Chapin and Corporation Counsel Jenks were in conference nearly all day they declined to talk for publication. It was given out, however, that they had practically decided not to appeal from Judge Bartlett's decision, but to go to trial of the Ziegler case at the earliest possible time, which will be in February.

Charitable and educational institutions come in for a generous proportion of the large fortune of Mrs. Elizabeth Perkins Fogg, who died in this city last week. Over $600,000 is disposed of in this manner under the will, which will be offered for probate as soon as a complete list of the relatives can be obtained for purposes of citation.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners are proceeding with their preliminary work just as if their existence as well as their powers did not depend upon legislative action yet to be taken, and they have already decided that additional provision for rapid transit is needed in this city. They will go on and consider the question of routes, and they have appointed a public hearing to be held on Thursday next, at which suggestions will be listened to.

ASBURY PARK, Jan. 9. -- The Rev. S. Edward Young, the pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church of this place, takes a great deal of interest in the life savers who patrol the Jersey coast on the lookout for wrecks. Mr. Young has organized a band of Christian workers, and religious services are now held regularly every Sunday at the different life-saving stations in this county.

The daring exploits of New-Jersey's Revolutionary fiotilla men in New-York's waters were related last night by Philip R. Voorhees at the Berkeley Lyceum before the members of the New-York Genealogical and Biographical Society. Chief among these bold and successful skirmishers were Elias Dayton, Adam Huyler, and William Mariner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Events in World's Fair work this week were the selection of architects to prepare plans for the main exposition buildings, the determination of the Directory to increase the popular subscriptions to $10,000,000, and the proposed solution of the question of transportation between the lake front and Jackson Park.

Although much was accomplished yesterday toward framing a plan of organization for the new association of Western railroads, much yet remains to be done before the work shall have been completed. The agreement which is to serve as the basis of the authority of the Advisory Board has not assumed any definite form.

MEADVILLE, Penn., Jan. 9. -- This morning a warrant was issued by William A. Dougan, Justice of the Peace of the Third Ward, for the arrest of G.B. Delamater, G.W. Delamater, and T.A. Delamater, members of the late banking firm. The information was made by Messrs. Marley, Bailey, and Lindsey, the County Commissioners who retired from office last Monday.

The opposition to the continued leadership of Police Justice Solon B. Smith in the Twentieth, Assembly District took definite shape at the meeting of the district Republican organization in Brevoort Hall, Fifty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, last night. The meeting was called for the purpose of receiving the report of a committee appointed to make up a ticket for the January election, to be held next Tuesday.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., via Rushville, Neb., Jan. 9. -- Hostiles began their devilment this morning by burning the cabins four miles north of the agency. Three columns of dense smoke in the north show where the fires are raging. There is pandemonium in the great village of the hostiles. The assassination of Lieut. Casey has caused a panic, which has not yet been quelled.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 9. -- The American Manufacturer, in to-morrow's issue, explains the causes which have compelled the shut-down of twenty-three blast furnaces in the Shenango and Mahoning Valleys of Pennsylvania and Ohio, throwing nearly ten thousand men out of work.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- It is now the seventh week of the prevalence of frost throughout the United Kingdom, with no signs of abatement of the severity of the weather. From John O'Groat's House to Land's End the country is wrapped in snow and canals and streams are icebound. Even a number of tidal rivers are frozen fast.

The selection of Point Turner, at Port Orchard, in Puget Sound, as the site for the new dry dock on the Pacific coast, ought to be followed by a prompt appropriation for its construction. The place chosen by the commission, whose report is now before Congress, is exactly the same that had been recommended the previous year by a commission of naval officers.

It is announced that Senator PLATT of Connecticut, upon whom the charge of the Copyright bill has been devolved, will endeavor to call that measure up for consideration on Monday. If the attempt succeeds, there ought to be no doubt of the passage of the measure, which means its enactment.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 9. -- Fifty-four Alliance members of the Legislature met this afternoon and investigated the charges of corruption made against President McGrath of the State Alliance in connection with the Turner letter. Resolutions were passed exonerating him and charging that the letter was a part of a systematic scheme in Topeka and Washington to disrupt the Alliance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- A week from next Sunday at the Emergency Hospital a remarkable scene will be witnessed. This will be the cutting off of portions or the skin from the bodies of seventy-five or one hundred members of St. Bernard Commandery, Knights Templar, and the grafting of the severed pieces of cuticle upon the naked flesh of a brother Mason, John Oscar Dickerson.

Mr. HARRISON is not put in a more attractive light by the latest accounts of the order which he issued at the instance of Gen. MILES and revoked at the instance of Secretary NOBLE. An army officer is now exercising the functions of the agent at Pine Ridge, who was dismissed, not by the President, but by the Secretary of the Interior.

An indifference, which is probably to a large extent assumed, may be noticed nowadays among amateurs with regard to a collection that has been for sale in Paris ever since the death of the connoisseur who passed his life bringing it together. The Spitzer collection is a private undertaking beside which museums subsidized by national moneys pale.

Those old and tricky political shepherds in Ohio -- DELANO, HARPSTER, and LAWRENCE -- will mourn because the Treasury Department intends to withdraw its instructions about the assessment of duties upon goods brought from countries where the currency is paper of much lower value than the coins of the same denomination.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Fire broke out in the office of the Crawford House, at Brattle Street and Scolly Square, at 3:15 A.M., and the office was gutted, causing a loss of several thousand dollars. The alarm was given to the guests almost instantly, and all escaped in a partially-dressed condition. One man jumped through a second-story window on the Brattle Street side and was severely injured.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 9. -- Another restraining order was issued from the District Court to-day en joining the Union Pacific Railroad Company and the Omaha and Republican Valley Railroad Company from interfering with traffic of the Rock Island Company between Council Bluffs, Omaha, South Omaha Lincoln, Beatrice, and all intervening points. Application for the order was made yesterday.

A large part of the Chicago Inter Ocean's confession of the falsity and wickedness of its recent assertions that "prices have not gone up on account of the McKinley bill or on account of anything else," and that "prices are lower, rather than higher, than a year ago," is taken up with accounts of the work of Trusts and similar combinations and of advances in prices made by these rings.

The abdication of King CHARLES I. of Roumania, which is spoken of in Bucharest as likely to occur very soon, would not now cause the anxiety and excitement that might have attended it a few years ago, since the prolonged Balkan troubles have gradually dropped into the background, and the succession to the throne has also been fully settled.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Rigor mortis has seized the American Harvester Company. It was organized one month ago with a capital of $35,000, 000, and was in point of fact a reorganization of all the harvester manufacturers in the country into one company, which was in effect a trust or monopoly. By purchasing the plants of the various companies outright it was thought all legal obstacles had been avoided.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 9. -- The charge of theft brought against the Republicans of New-Hampshire is not mere declamation made by men of another party which they have defeated in a fair contest, but it is actually a true charge. No softer word than theft would adequately describe the proceeding to which it has been applied.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- Ex-President Cleveland, who came to Philadelphia expressly to take part in the celebration of Jackson Day by the Young Men's Democratic Association, was preceded here by Mrs. Cleveland, and to-day was compelled to leave in advance of her and return to New-York by an early afternoon train.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 9. -- Steps were taken to-day looking to ending the deadlock in the Montana Legislature. In the Republican House a resolution was adopted to appoint a committee of five to formulate and report on a plan of settlement of the existing difficulties. This action was taken in response to the expressed wish of the Republican caucus.

Secretary Babcock of the Board of Civil Service Examiners at the Custom House has received a letter from Commissioner Lyman giving the reasons for canceling the examination in July last for damage examiners at the Appraiser's Stores. It was the dispute over this examination and the position taken by Capt. W.E. Peirce that led to the resignation of three members of the Examining Board, Messrs. Riker, Walden, and Birdsall.

Here is a snub for the amateur editors of the Tribune. Says the Daily Saratogian of Jan. 7: "The New-York Tribune yesterday advised the Republican press of the country to print the names of the eight Republican Senators who voted against the Elections bill prominently and in bold type, the object being to expose them as traitors to their party and renegades.

SPIDER SILK. -- Dr. Walsh recounts that in his travels through Brazil he came across a spider which he named Arena maculata, and is admirably adapted for silk producing purposes. Far from devouring one another, after the voracious manner of their European relatives, these spiders live in little communities apparently on the best of terms.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The scheme which has lain some years in abeyance for constructing a section of railroad sixty miles long, connecting the Ontario and Western Road at Norwich with the Elmira, Cortland and Northern Road at Cortland, is revived. As originally planned in 1866, the section was to form part of what was to be known as the Auburn Branch of the New-York and Oswego Midland Railroad.

ALSACE-LORRAINE, 1890. -- The German gendarmes make traveling rather a troublesome process. The whole country seems under police surveillance. It literally bristles with spiked helmets. There are policemen everywhere. You come upon them at every turn, armed as if for war with a rifle on their shoulders and a bullet in the barrel -- fierce of aspect, and ready to bully you as only German gendarmes can bully.

PERM. -- The town of Perm, though far inferior in dignity of aspect, commercial importance, and natural beauty to Nijni-Novgorod, Kasan, and other towns on the Volga, is not altogether devoid of life and interest. Situated on the elevated left bank of the "mother river." as the peasants call her, it commands a homely but pleasant prospect, extending over fifteen versts of the ancient land, "Biarmy," with its old-fashioned churches and houses.

Two matters which will occupy the attention of the National Guard Association at the coming convention in Albany are of individual and collective interest. The first of these is a proposition advanced by Col. William Seward, commanding Ninth Regiment, to amend the Military Code so as to make the provisions of the law bearing upon company or field musicians more elastic.

The 'Varsity crew and tug-of-war teams will go into hard training to-morrow. Capt. Metcalf of the crew is confident that his men will be quite as speedy as any crew found at New-London next Summer. Some of the old oarsmen in college, who have rowed on the 'Varsity or their class crews, are Metcalf, Robertson, Norrie, Beekman, Mellen, Chrystie, E.P. Smith, Prince, McKee, and Tuttle.

Snowshoe men have been enjoying the Winter in a manner that has not been vouchsafed to them in several years. For the past two weeks they have been tripping over the snow-covered meadows and mountain sides of New-Jersey. The members of the Oritani Snowshoe Club have especially improved the opportunities for walking over real snow, and almost all of them have been out during the last few days.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The Rev. Philip W. Mosher, formerly rector of Grace Episcopal Church at Ellenville, N.Y., and now assistant rector of St. Paul's Church at Troy, has accepted a call to the rectorate of St. Paul's Church at Muskegon, Mich., and will enter on his new duties Feb. 1.

BISMARCK, N.D., Jan. 10. -- Gov. Burke to-day received a number of telegrams from citizens of Devil's Lake, Bottineau, Willow City, and other places in the northern part of the State, urgently appealing for arms and ammunition as a means of protection against the Indians. It seems that the movements of several small bands of Indians in the Turtle Mountains and vicinity have greatly alarmed the settlers.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- Ninety-eight Republicans gathered at the residence of Frank Morison, in Chestnut, Street this afternoon in response to the call sent out a week ago to take definite action regarding the projected Republican Club of Massachusetts. The club was organized with Roger Wolcott of Boston as President, E.B. Hayes of Lynn as Secretary, and C. Lithgow Devens as Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- In the House to-day Representative Anderson of Kansas presented for printing in the Record a resolution calling on the Inter-State Commerce Commission for the following information:

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Bishop Samuel Fallows, for the last fifteen years rector of St. Paul's Reformed Episcopal Church, is suffering from nervous prostration, and has taken refuge in a private sanitarium at Lawndale, a suburb of this city.

The Indian uprising has induced certain Republican papers to indulge in a little criticism of the manner in which the Indian service is conducted, but this criticism stops short of the point to which it ought to be carried. Some of it is very good so far as it goes, but our Republican friends are restrained from applying it directly to the persons who are responsible.

There is a pleasant discussion upon the subject of the education of clever and famous people in the current English Illustrated Magazine. This discourse, which is by Mr. JAMES SULLY, runs over the various phases of the theme, such as family education and school and college education. The writer appears to agree with GALTON in the belief that men of genius owe more to their fathers than their mothers.

The Congressional Record is being inequitably conducted just now. The other day at least twice or three times in the House did members say something which resulted in laughter, and the Record announced the cacninnatory fact. In the Senate things happened which were more humorous than any of the occurrences in the House, but the manifestations of the tickled multitude have not been made apparent in the Government newspaper.

The Pastime Athletic Club, an organization which has done a great deal in the way of the development of athletes, especially boxers, began its annual boxing tournament last evening at the Lenox Lyceum. The boxing entertainments of this club have always been well attended and last night's exhibition was in accord with previous ones.

MOUNTAIN CLIMBING AND HUMAN ENDURANCE. -- We occupied an entire day in passing from the lower to the upper station of Cotopaxi. The labor was not severe, and the effects could only be attributed to our inability to accommodate ourselves to reduction in atmospheric pressure to as low a point as 16,500 inches.

BUFFALO, Jan. 10. -- At last the location of the new Canadian Pacific Bridge across the river has been practically decided upon. The party of survey who were at work just beyond the mills in the village of Suspension bridge, it appears, were here for the purpose of staking out the line of the new River Bridge Railroad Company, which will be the railroad feeder of the new bridge.

The new home of the Democratic Club, at 617 Fifth Avenue, was properly "warmed" last evening. Grover Cleveland was there and Lieut. Gov. Jones stood beside him as he shook hands with the thousand or more gentlemen who pressed forward to exchange a word with him. Gov. Hill might have had the honor of receiving with the ex-President had he not seen fit to decline an invitation to be present.

BUFFALO, Jan. 10 -- At a meeting of the Erie County Democracy, which is largely a Cleveland organization, there was a good deal of criticism visited on the offending heads of Speaker Sheehan, Congressman Wiley, and Moses Shire, Chairman of the late County Convention, by a resolution fathered by one of the members of the Cleveland Democracy and passed by the County Convention.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The annual report of the Board of Civil Service Commissioners submitted to the Governor shows that during 1890 999 persons were examined in competitive and non-competitive schedules, of which 861 passed and 138 failed. The number examined was classified as follows: In competitive examinations, 285; non-competitive, 714.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- To-day the cause of home rule for Ireland seems to be in a more hopelessly wretched condition than it has been before since the news of the Phoenix Park murders spread over astonnded England. John Dillon, they say, leaves New-York to-day for Europe. The pity is that he did not sail a month ago, and leave William O'Brien behind him.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Flaming dodgers are being circulated about the city to-night which state that an Albany paper will to-morrow give a full account of the attempted assassination of Edward Murphy, Jr., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee and the bosom friend of Gov. Hill.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 10. -- The anthracite industry of Pennsylvania presents a tragic record for the year 1890. The official reports of the mine inspectors show hat within the year 1,066 persons were injured in the mines, and 275 killed outright. As a result of the fatal mining accidents of the year there are 147 widows and 513 orphans.

The official trials of the Spanish iron-clad Pelayo have recently been completed. The Vavasseur-Canet gun carriages stood the heavy tests without developing a flaw. The mountings for the smaller guns were tested at the Hoe Polygon, near Havre, and, after having been fixed on board the Pelayo, three more rounds were fired from them, the guns being trained horizontally and at positive and negative angles.
LONDON, Jan. 10. -- Mr. Gladstone has written a letter to Mr. Furness, the Liberal candidate for Hartlepools to succeed the late Thomas Richardson, in which he says:

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 10. -- Gen. O.O. Howard, United States Army, commanding the military Division of the Atlantic, will have a two-column interview in the Times-Union of to-morrow morning regarding his Indian experiences and his views on recent events in the West. The General has studied the Indian question fully, and his long experience entitles his views to consideration.

Under date of Dec. 30 last Mr. Louis Windmuller of this city wrote Senator Plumb of Kansas a second letter criticising Mr. Plumb's position on the silver question. To that letter Mr. Windmuller received the following reply:

" What are you going to do with that cost?" asked a Brooklyn husband of a Brooklyn wife a few days ago. They were leaving the house together, he for his office, she for a trip to Jersey City, and over her arm hung an outgrown overcoat that had belonged to her young son.

A case of skin granting by wholesale is among the operations to be performed at Bellevue Hospital. The story has been told of how Minnie Emma Wilck met with a terrible accident the day after Christmas in the Co-operative Laundry, at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Her husband, Herman Wilck, was foreman there, and she had gone to call on him.
