CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- After Emma Abbott's remains had been laid in the vault yesterday her opera company disbanded, and its members left last evening for their several homes. About forty of them went to New-York, while Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Washington were the destinations of others.

Speaking of a recent difference of opinion about wages in Mr. CARNEGIE'S mills, the Indianapolis Journal says: "It is sufficient answer to say that the Edgar Thomson Works produce steel rails, and that the tariff law reduces the duty on rails from $17 to $12 per ton -- a reduction of nearly one-third of the duty.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 10. -- President Harrison has at all times practically ignored the Republicans of Kansas. At least such is their belief when the golden apples do not all fall their way. Those who helped roll up that wonderful 82,000 Republican majority promptly applied for office, office of any kind, as a reward for their partisan patriotism.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 10. -- The preliminary hearing of the forty-six Hungarians who were prominent participants in the riot at the Edgar Thomson Steel Rail Mill, which is owned by Andrew Carnegie, took place in the town Council Hall at Braddock this afternoon. The hall was densely packed with Carnegie's workmen, and outside there was an immense crowd trying to gain entrance.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 10. -- A syndicate is being formed to control and operate all the big marl beds on the James and Pamunkey Rivers in this State. Among those interested in this project are a prominent railroad magnate and politician of national note and New-York capitalists. The richest of these beds are probably those near the Pamunkey River, prominent among which are those on the splendid estate of Washington Bassett; Hampstead, Newburg, and New-Castle.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- Among the letters received at the Mission Rooms here concerning the destruction by Spaniards of our mission buildings in Ponapi, one of the Caroline Islands, is one from Miss J.E. Fletcher, who says, in reference to the assertion of the Spaniards that the missionaries had incited the natives to revolt:

There would have been a fine scandal in Pennsylvania if GEORGE W. DELAMATER had been elected Governor of the State, and had afterward been arrested for embezzling county funds intrusted to his broken bank. Of course the charge remains to be proved, but the disclosures made in the proceeding at Meadville are of a kind that can hardly be cleared away to the vindication of DELAMATER'S character.

MARRIED LIFE IN THIBET. -- Among the Thibetans a man marries only one wife, whom he purchases from her parents, a belle often costing as much as ten ponies and thirty yaks. The price to be paid for the wife is arranged by a relative or a friend, who acts as go-between, and the only marriage ceremony is a grand spree, lasting as long as the bridegroom can afford to keep it up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Mrs. Harrison's first public reception, held this afternoon, was in every respect highly enjoyable. The plan adopted by Mrs. Harrison of doing away with a formidable line of a half dozen or more ladies, and only asking as her assistants the wife of the Chief Justice and of Associate Justice Brown, was a very welcome innovation to the public.

PIERRE, S.D., Jan. 10. -- The House Committee on Elections to-day resolved to report in favor of unseating the eight Republican members from Brown County, whose election is contested by the independents. They were elected by throwing out one precinct in Greenfield Township, from which the returns were not certified.

We must think that "A Boy's Town," as far as its little hero goes, is autobiographical. Whether it will serve the purpose for which we suppose it was written, the edification and amusement of young people, we are doubtful about. It is a very old book in the sense that it will be understandable only by persons of mature age, who must possess a certain amount of judgment.

HOPS. -- Are we not told that hops "are employed to communicate to beer its aromatic bitter"? So, at least, it should be. It is rather a suggestive fact, however, that though the consumption of beer and ale is rather on the increase than otherwise, the area of land under hops and the annual yield are on the decrease.

It is a notable fact that the people of New-Orleans take great delight in their seasons of French opera, and give them generous support. In addition to that, the newspapers of the city accord to the enterprise their best consideration, and have no hesitation about uttering candid opinions. The New-Orleans Times-Democrat took occasion at the opening of the year to review the work done up to that time. Its remarks are as follows:
CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- It has been a most successful week for theatrical people. At every house the receipts have been unusually large. The attractions have also been of more than usual merit.

A good many readers of newspapers must have been reminded by the trial for heresy that has been going on in Cleveland of a remark of the learned Dr. JOHNSON. He was defending the expulsion from Oxford of some of the disciples of WESLEY, when his interlocutor reported his information that the expelled students were "good beings."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10. -- Capt. Elizur Thompson, the keeper of the old white lighthouse at the entrance to New-Haven Harbor, is now in his eight-first year, but with the preservation of his physical strength to a remarkable degree and with mind and memory yet undimmed, he is interesting and entertaining.

With ice blocking the ferry slips, snow mountains forming in the streets, skating in the parks, and Jack Frost in the air, New-Yorkers might imagine it was Winter if there were not such visible evidence to the contrary in the elaborate displays of Spring goods tempting their admiration.

A HINDU GIRL. -- A Hindu baby girl is an unwelcome addition to the family; her birth is supposed to be no blessing, but a curse and a sign of divine wrath. Rukhmabai says that when the new-born baby is a girl "the father gnashes his teeth and stamps his feet. The mother is sorely disappointed, and although her tenderness may bring its sure wealth of love, she curses both herself and the child.

The Sugar Trust dropped out of the financial world yesterday, and the American Sugar Refining Company rose up in its stead. The receivers of the trust were relieved from further duty, the books and papers they have been inspecting were returned to their old owners, and the litigation which has been keeping the Brooklyn courts busy was ended.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Before midnight last night five safe blowers, while robbing the safe of Diamond Broker Murray, on the fifth floor of the building 161 La Salle Street, were captured by the police. Lieuts. Kipley and Clark, with six officers, had followed the thieves. They went up stairs, each with drawn revolver in hand. When the fifth floor was reached a noise was heard in Room 81.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10. -- The Grand Jury, in its report to-day, says: "The attention of the jury has been particularly called to violations of the now or high-license law, and if the presentments have been few, it has certainly not been from want of attention or careful examination, but rather has arisen from defects in the law itself.

In the parlor of the Victoria Hotel last night, from 7 o'clock to 7:30, a tall, lank, middle-aged man was fidgeting about in an alleged easy chair, tying his legs into bowknots and doing everything with his hands that the hands of a naturally awkward man ever did do when he was in a state of nervousness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The estimates of the products of corn, wheat, and oats of 1890, as completed by the statistician of the Department of Agriculture, make corn aggregate 1,489,970,000 bushels; wheat, 399,262,000 bushels; oats, 523,621,000 bushels.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The remedial virtues of the national game of baseball in the treatment of mental disorders are dwelt upon with considerable emphasis by Dr. Selden H. Talcott, the Medical Superintendent of the Middletown State Homeopathic Hospital for the Insane, in his annual report for 1890 to the State Legislature.

The scenes about the Ministry of Finance in Paris yesterday morning were very curious. Subscriptions were to be received at the opening of the offices for the loan of some $170,000,000 offered by the Government. Before daylight the crowd of applicants began to gather. They were of all classes, from the great capitalist's agent to the workmen in blouses and the work-women with braziers hugged in their arms to keep them warm.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10. -- A staff correspondent of the Post-Dispatch at Rushville, Neb., telegraphs that paper as follows under to-day's date:

The scheme exploited by Mr. Benjamin S. Henning of shooting people under and across the East River through a tunnel with sharp inclines at either end by the force of gravity and the assistance of a cable clutch has been expanded by the projector into the Henning Rapid Transit Company, with the object of filling the long-felt want of quick communication between the lower end of Manhattan Island and Westchester County.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 10. -- New-Jersey is still the Gretna Green of the Union. The annual report of the State Bureau of Vital Statistics, recently issued, proves this fact. The license laws of other States in this part of the Nation send hundreds of couples to Jersey, where the matrimonial knot is tied with neatness and dispatch by some clergymen or one of a few Justices of the Peace who make a specialty of marriages.

Gen. Pacheco, the Mexican Minister of Public Works, has recently submitted to the Mexican Congress a report on the proposed changes in the coinage, with a bill to carry them into effect. The report says that the design on the Mexican dollar should be much better as a precaution against counterfeiting. The present design was adopted in 1823, and an unsuccessful attempt was mad2 to improve it in 1867.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The filing of a certificate of incorporation in the Secretary of State's office yesterday marked the organization of a new labor body in opposition to the Knights of Labor and the State's Trades Assembly. The articles of incorporation recite that the new organization is to be called the New-York State Workingman's Alliance.

The week which close last night brought compensation and consolation to the society world of the metropolis for the dullness and depression of the preceding fortnight. Every night was filled with entertainments, and the days each and all had marked features. The seasonable and beautiful weather which has prevailed had much to do with the general atmosphere of gayety.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10. -- The only parallel of the dead-lock now existing in the Connecticut General Assembly must be found in the antiquated journals and records stowed away in the Capitol loft. Up to 1840 the legislative journals were kept with pen and ink, and no great amount of care had been bestowed upon them.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10. -- It is reported at the Treasury Department in Washington that fully twenty vacancies exist in the grade of Third Lieutenant in the Revenue Marine Service. It is feared that unless some measure is soon taken to fill these vacancies the service will be seriously handicapped for want of officers.

REELFOOT LAKE, Tenn., Jan. 10. -- Here is a veritable sportsman's paradise, a woodcraftsman's dream, a wonderland, full of fascination and mystery, where the hunter or angler may revel to his heart's content, and yet situated only a comparatively short distance from the settlements of civilization. Reelfoot Lake is the central feature of this unique region, and surrounding it stretches an extended territory completely given up to wild game and nature.

The opening of the new home of the Century Club, in West Forty-third Street, near Sixth Avenue, was signalized last evening by the holding of the annual meeting and election of officers of the association. The attendance of members was the largest in the history of the club, the gathering numbering close upon 700.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 10. -- A Russian gentleman, whose name is not given by the authorities, who, for some reason or another, say that it must be kept secret, blew his brains out with a revolver last night. He left a letter saying that as he had lost 800,000 rubles at the gambling tables and was utterly ruined, there was nothing left for him to do but to take his own life.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10. -- The party skirmishes for the Summer convention and the Fall campaign have commenced, and the indications are that the competition will be brisk and the fight hot and vigorous. The prizes are the United Sates Senatorship and the Governorship, with most of the other State and general offices for secondary consideration.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The Senatorial question is apparently no nearer final settlement to-day than it was a month ago. The Governor maintains his policy of secrecy and mystery, and his reasons for doing so are becoming understood. The Governor is unquestionably groping through the State for a wealthy, characterless man who will do his bidding, contribute to his campaigns, and protect his interests in every possible way.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Cornell University resumed its session for the Winter term on Monday, and only a few students were missing. The number dropped from the university this year was decidedly small, including two Juniors, three Sophomores, fourteen Freshmen, and two Seniors in the Law School. The number of Freshmen dropped is only about a third of the number dropped last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Mr. Sherman has reported to the Senate to-day from the Committee on Foreign Affairs a bill authorizing the issue of bonds, guaranteed by the United States, for the building of the Nicaragua Ship Canal. It is accompanied by a long report. It was placed on the calendar.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 10. -- The first race of the season of the North Shrewsbury River Ice Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon. The river was literally alive with skaters and iceboats. The weather was warm and the ice was quite soft in spots where the snow had remained. Another drawback to a good race was the light wind, which blew from the southwest.

NOT A ST. PREUX. -- Consciously or unconsciously, our forefathers held that plain straightforward language purified immoral incidents of half their danger. Vice never moved through their pages with the mince and the simper of simulated virtue. Novels depend on the same breaches of the decalogue.

This book is really an autobiography. The first volume contains a biography of himself, written by Cardinal Newman in the third person and committed by him to the care of his niece, Miss Anne Mozley, who is the editor of this work. Newman had long been of the opinion that in whatever was published of him after his death the Protestant part must be kept separate from the Catholic part.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Corcoran Art Gallery stands next in importance among American collections of art to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New-York. But the distance between these two institutions is considerable. Local pride and the rich gifts of its open-handed citizens have contributed to make the Metropolitan Museum superior.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The following letter has been addressed to the Secretary of the Navy by Commander Reiter, United States Navy, who was severely censured by the Secretary for his conduct in the Barrundia affair:

The Board of Experts, consisting of Samuel Spencer, Prof. George W. Plympton, and C.W. Buchholz, appointed to devise some method of improving the terminal facilities of the Brooklyn Bridge, presented their report to the committee of Bridge Trustees yesterday. It is a lengthy document, containing elaborately-drawn plans of tracks and terminal stations, and in it the experts review the present unsatisfactory state of affairs at great length.

The Western railroad Presidents completed their agreement yesterday and unanimously subscribed to it, making the Western Traffic Association an established fact. The Advisory Board met early in the day in their parlor at the Windsor Hotel and received the report of the Committee on Detail, which had previously adopted the report of the Sub-Committee on Territorial Divisions.

The once wicked Gibbs's effort to bring about harmony among the Republican factions in the Thirteenth District has had no results. Last Saturday night Gibbs had the regular organization appoint a committee of five to see if harmony could be secured. Last night the regular organization met again in the rooms of the Union Republican Club in the Grand Opera House Building.

A strange discovery was made a short time ago in the city of London. Workmen while, engaged in the destruction of old houses in Knight-rider Street (not far from Blackfriars Bridge) came across some fragments of black stone containing inscriptions in cuneiform characters. The British Museum succeeded in acquiring the stones, three in number, which turn out to be bits of monuments dating from the time of the oldest Babylonian kingdoms as yet known.

British war vessels measuring less than 2,000 tons displacement have rarely more than three watch officers. The executive and navigating officers are included in this number. American war vessels of the same tonnage displacement carry a far greater number of officers. This is seen by the following comparison:
LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 10. -- Victor Vifquain, the new Democratic Adjutant General, took possession of his office this morning, and on his orders the militia company marched out of the Capitol building.

CLINTON, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Besides Hamilton College, which opened on Thursday after the customary holiday vacation of tree weeks, Clinton's other institutions of learning, the Grammar School, Kirkland Hall, and Houghton and Cottage Seminaries, have taken up the work of another term under circumstances which betoken increased prosperity.

Postmaster Van Cott has received from the heads of departments in the Post Office their annual reports, showing in detail the business transacted in each department during the year ended Dec. 31, 1890. There were delivered through lock boxes and by carriers 343,497,329 pieces of ordinary mail matter, divided as follows: Letters, through boxes, 57,146,060; by carriers, 170,118,702; postal cards, through boxes, 6,660,856; by carriers, 35,070,828; other mail matter, through boxes, 34,114,940; by carriers, 40,385,943.

A very singular fact is noted by the American Architect with regard to its traveling scholarship, of which the second holder, Albert Kahn, has just left for Europe. It appears that only one competitor has ever appeared for the two architect scholarships of Boston in a given year. It is true that the idea is a novel one and has hardly time to have spread far, even among architects, who, presumably, read this able periodical.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. -- The Landtag resumed business yesterday without a sign of any alleviation of the conflict between the Conservative majority and the Government, and, practically, legislation is in a state of suspense. The Communal Reform bill is still in the hands of the commission. Discussion of the measure in plenary sitting has been postponed until it shall have had a second reading.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett's portrayal of Benedick has long been highly esteemed in other cities than New-York, but, like Mr. Booth's performance of the same role, it has not been often seen here in recent years. It is worth seeing, for Mr. Barrett plays comedy with a light touch, with a keen perception of humor, and with notable executive skill.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10. -- An interesting study in regard to the emigration of people from the East to the newer portions of the country, is contained in statistics of the ancestry of the academic Freshmen at Yale. These statistics were completed last evening by Dr. Jay W. Seaver, the college physician, who obtained the information in taking the class measurements.

There is probably no substantial difference of opinion among the people of this city as to the advisability of allowing any further encroachment by the elevated railroads upon the little park at the Battery. Any encroachment at all is a public outrage that ought never to have been permitted, and any extension of it by public authority would be universally condemned.

LIMERICK, Jan. 11. -- Fully twenty thousand persons assembled hero to-day to greet Mr. Parnell, thousands coming from all the adjoining counties. In response to addresses, Mr. Parnell made a long speech. He held that Mr. Gladstone had caused the present trouble by issuing a mandatory letter demanding that the Irish members depose their leader.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- The rain has interrupted the play of skating, except at the aristocratic Jockey Club pond on the Bois, where the necessary form of an invitation first and a twenty-franc subsequent fee rather limit the paying guests. Queerly enough, here the best skaters come from the southern climes; there are ten Brazilians, Argentines, , pretty South Americans in general, to one French girl.

The bark Antwerp, which came in yesterday after a tempestuous voyage of seventy-one days from London, reported that one of her crew, John Simpson, a Scotch sailor, forty-three years of age, fell overboard from the foretopsail yard Jan. 1 and was lost.
The annual report of the Attorney General of the United States, dated Dec. 1, 1890, contains the following paragraph:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Hon. Roswell P. Flower is a hospitable gentleman, and it has been the custom with him during his service in the House frequently to give dinners to as many of his personal and political friends as his dining room can comfortably hold. It has sometimes happened that more than one of his admirable dinners would be given in one week.

The recent action of the Treasury Department with respect to the duty on common goat hair has caused dismay among the high-tariff men of Philadelphia. The unforeseen imposition of a duty of 300 per cent. upon raw material that has hitherto been admitted free gives a chill to some of the manufacturers who contributed large sums to the great fund raised by WANAMAKER in the last days of the Harrison campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The naval ordnance factory in the Washington Navy Yard was inspected yesterday by members of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs and Coast Defenses, who were shown through the shops by Commodore Folger, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, and the officers on duty in the shops, and were afterward entertained at lunch by the commandant, Commodore Skerrett.

The American missionaries in the Caroline Islands seem to have ground for their complaint of ill treatment by the Spanish authorities there. The Madrid Government on assuming active control of the group has undertaken to leave them free to prosecute the religious and educational work in which they have been engaged for so long a time.

Services in many of the churches yesterday afternoon and evening had special reference to the work of the Young Men's Christian Association. The anniversary of the Twenty-third Street Branch occurs to-day, and on the Sunday previous to this event it is always customary to present the work of the association in the churches. At each church where they were held a layman and the pastor made addresses.

Mr. J. Theodore Bent, a member of the Council of the Royal Geographical Society, well known for his explorations among the ancient cities of Asia Minor, has undertaken the investigation of the celebrated ruins of Zimbabeye, in "the Land of Ophir," of which some account was recently given in the Pall Mall Gazette.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- The striking spinners at the Clark Thread Works say that the men whom the company has smuggled into the mills are not new hands brought to Newark to take their places, but Fuller Agency detectives. They are armed, the men allege, and have been brought to Newark to create a false impression in the public mind that the attitude of the spinners in a menacing one.

Excellent racing is promised for the Spring meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club. Of the two-year-old stakes the Great American Stakes, at five furlongs, has 181 entries; the Clover Stakes, for fillies, at five furlongs, 55 entries; the Bedford Stakes, five and a half furlongs, 78 entries; the May Stakes, six furlongs, 54 entries; the Seaside Stakes, five furlongs, 61 entries.

The very accident which people have been predicting would again happen on the elevated road and on the possibility of which there is almost constant speculation occurred yesterday morning. A switch engine plunged to the street from the down-town side of the Third Avenue structure at a point between One Hundred and Eighteenth and One Hundred and Nineteenth Streets, and was smashed into small pieces. Fortunately it was only a switch engine.
TRENTON, Jan. 11. -- Gov. Abbett has concluded the preparation of his annual message to be presented to the Legislature at the opening on Tuesday, and everything is ready for the caucuses.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 11. -- There will scarcely be enough Republicans in the next Wisconsin Legislature which convenes on Wednesday next to make a fair "political situation." Out of the 100 Assemblymen elected in November, sixty-six are Democrats, one is a Labor Party man, and the remaining thirty-three are accredited to the Republican Party.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11. -- The present favorable condition in which the Ohio Democracy finds itself, due in part to the blunders of the Republicans, has already caused the managers of the latter party seriously to consider the best and most available way of again assuming the offensive. The party in Ohio that does not do this is beaten before the election.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11. -- The death of Emma Abbott has revived the general interest in anything connected with her career. A newspaper correspondent signing his name "Carlfrield" and dating his letter New-York, Feb. 10, 1872, had the following to say about Miss Abbott:

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions has just sent some important documents to Secretary of State Blaine, asking, or rather demanding, that the American missionaries in the Caroline Islands, who have too long suffered wrongs and privations at the hands of the Spanish authorities, be rehabilitated and guaranteed the rights of American citizens.

In the mutations of fame and fortune which African campaigning and adventure so often cause, EMIN Pasha, who lately appeared to be threatened with disgrace for disobedience of orders, already finds defenders, while Baron WISSMAN, whose renown eclipsed that of all other German leaders in Africa after his successful operations in Zanzibar, now seems himself to be a little under a cloud.

An important but well-considered and justifiable departure from the usual practice and policy of our Federal Government was recommended to the Senate on Saturday by the Committee on Foreign Affairs in the bill and the accompanying report providing for a Government guarantee of the interest on the bonds issued for the construction of the Nicaragua Canal.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11. -- A controversy in the Probate Court concerning the great Pratt estate, valued at about $750,000, has developed a queer story. Samuel N. Holiday was the trustee for Charles R. and Thomas H. Pratt, and in making settlement with the young men, who have just come of age, he makes certain claims.

Fire broke out at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the engine room of the Annex ferryboat No. 1 while she was tied up to the bridge dock near the Fulton Ferry on the Brooklyn side, and the boat was damaged to the extent of $25,000 before the flames were controlled. She is insured for $20,000, principally in the London and Liverpool and Globe Insurance Company.

Some weeks ago we directed attention to the action taken by the combination of German rolling mills. A meeting was held at which "it was stated that the prices for rolled iron had sunk below the price of imported rolled iron, duty paid," and "the result of the deliberations was an advance of the prices for rolled iron to 130 marks per ton."

We recalled yesterday to the attention of those who have become deeply interested in the causes of the Indian war the manner in which the reports of Special Agents MCBRIDE and PICKLER concerning the Oklahoma jobbery were treated by Secretary NOBLE and President HARRISON, and mentioned in connection with that affair the earnest warning addressed to Secretary NOBLE last April by Indian Inspector ARMSTRONG.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- It is the pleasantest thing in this world -- at least, for a theatrical manager -- to have at one's easy call and bidding a genuine, popular actor, whose very name is dear to the public, and whose simple appearance behind the footlights causes a ripple of laughter to blend in one common, infectious joy from parquet to gallery.

The proposition now pending in the Senate in the form of an amendment to the Finance bill, as reported from the committee, must in reality be regarded as a substitute for the portion of the bill relating to silver, and if the former be adopted the latter would be stricken out. The proposition was submitted by Mr. STEWART of Nevada, one of the most active of the silver Senators.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 11. -- The political see in North Carolina has been disturbed for the past six months by the Alliance men's opposition to Mr. Vance's return to the Senate, and now, since this opposition has abated and Vance's hopes have been inspired by the unity in the ranks of the hayseed Legislature for him, another obstruction has fallen in the way of the onward march of this farmer delegation.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11. -- The detectives have been at work on the mysterious robbery of the residence of Banker James Campbell and have found some very queer developments.

National prudence and national self-respect alike constrain us to retain in our own hands the control of this canal, connecting our Atlantic and Pacific coasts, or at least to forbid its passing into the hands of any European Government. The guarantee of the bonds of the company at 3 per cent. and the holding by the Treasury of $70,000,000 of the $100,000,000 of its stock secures this control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The British Government has taken Mr. Blaine by surprise, although Mr. Blaine denies it, by appealing to the Supreme Court of the United States, to decide many of the most important points in the controversy in the Bering Sea dispute. It was not expected by anybody at the State Department, or by any member of the Senate or House Committees on Foreign Affairs.

By the designation of territorial divisions and the election of a Commissioner for each division, with an extra Commissioner to be Chairman of the board, the new Western Traffic Association completed its work in this city yesterday. The members of the association assembled in Parlor 22, Windsor Hotel, at 10 o'clock A.M. There was a full attendance, all of the Western railroad men having remained in town over Sunday.
ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- Great improvements have been made in the Capitol since the Legislature of 1890 adjourned. That body made an appropriation of $365,000 and classified the work in this way:

Apropos of the reception given to Mr. Cleveland at the Philadelphia banquet, the Ledger says: "Wherever Mr. Cleveland goes, in whatsoever place his name is spoken, the enthusiasm with which it is received, the tumults of applause that come like echoes upon the mention of his name, testify to the strength, the sincerity of the feeling of the people for him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The report of the House Ballot-Box Frauds Committee, which last session made an extensive investigation into Ohio political affairs in connection with alleged subscriptions by members of Congress for stock in a patent ballot box, was to-day presented to the House by Mr. Mason of Illinois, the Chairman of the investigating committee of five.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The Legislature is to convens again to morrow evening, but up to 9 o'clock this evening Speaker Sheehan declared that he had not finished his committees. "Indeed," he observed to a caller, "I have not began to assign the Republicans to places, for I have not yet disposed of the democrats."

The experts chosen to improve the terminal facilities of the Brooklyn Bridge have recommended a system substantially like the present regarding the railway, but with additional platforms for the accommodation of an increased number of trains. The calculation is that twice as many passengers can be accommodated as are carried now, and the experts think that before the traffic reaches that figure it will be advisable to build another bridge.
PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., Jan. 12. -- To-night it looks as though the Indian troubles would be ended to-morrow, and that without further bloodshed.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12. -- The Johns Hopkins Hospital of this city is besieged with applications for treatment by the Koch method. The applicants are from all parts of the country, but they are not encouraged. If accepted, they are taken on the distinct understanding that the success of the treatment is problematical. The physicians do not care to treat consumption until the lymph is more thoroughly tested.
PARIS, Jan. 12. -- The Customs Committee has agreed to the Government's proposal to exempt undressed hides from duty.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 12. -- The athletes at Yale University took up the regular Winter work in the gymnasium on Saturday afternoon and from now until the Spring and Summer contests there will be no cessation of active training. Dr. Seaver has charge of the preliminary work and he has divided the men into classes for instruction each afternoon and evening.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 12, via Galveston. -- A large business is being done in this country in the sale of lottery bonds, issued in Europe. The principal sales are said to be among large farmers in the interior States. Since attention has been drawn to this business in the United States the sale of the bonds has become a matter of interest here.

While Mr. HARRISON and his serviceable friends at Washington were expressing deep solicitude concerning the preservation of "purity in elections" last week, a little incident at the President's home in Indiana served to refresh the memories of critical persons as to the manipulation of "blocks of five" and the methods of QUAY and DUDLEY.

The new Western Traffic Association has practically completed its organization and the general plan of its operations by the adoption of by-laws, the election of officers, of a Finance Committee, and of a Board of Commissioners, and by the division of the territory which it covers into five districts, corresponding to those already existing under the several associations heretofore formed.

More than 350 years ago the cutting of a canal across the isthmus that connects North and South America was proposed and discussed as a feasible and necessary undertaking. For 65 years the building of such a canal has been looked upon by the United States Government as a work which it ought to promote with its favor or its funds.

The "Bureau of the American Republics" at Washington publishes the news that "since the passage of the McKinley bill" a company organized in New-Jersey, with a a capital of $4,000,000, the greater part of which was obtained in this city, has undertaken the erection of large smelting works at San Luis Potosi, in Mexico.
The following additional sums on account of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection are reported by the General Treasurer, Mr. Charles Lanier, 17 Nassau Street:

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- The new United States cruiser Concord anchored off City Island at 4 this afternoon. She left the docks of the Morgan Iron Works at 11 this morning, steamed rapidly through Hell Gate, past Willett's Point, and was sent bowling down the Sound on a preliminary speed run. The engines were fairly opened out abreast of City Island.

The Committee on Legislation of the Real Estate Exchange held its first meeting of the year yesterday afternoon, when President George R. Read addressed the members on the subjects they would probably have to consider while in office.
BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- In the lower house of the Prussian Diet, Herr Miguel, Minister of Finance, announces that the secret of Prof. Koch's lymph would soon be published.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 12. -- There is now no longer room to doubt that there in a deficit in the State Treasury of at least $100,000. Major W.C. Woodruff will go out next Thursday, when his successor, Col. Morrow, will take charge.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The following summary shows the aggregate of resources and liabilities of the 160 banks of discount and four individual banks of the State of New-York on the morning of Saturday, Dec. 20, 1890, as exhibited by their reports to the Superintendent of the Banking Department:

HANTFORD, Jan 12. -- Gov. Bulkeley said here this afternoon that he is not in the counsel of the Republican managers in the Legislature, and that he is not aware what course will be pursued by them in the contest for the Governorship. It was commented on at the time Speaker Paige appointed the investigating committee last week that not a single one of Gov. Bulkeley's political friends or associates was selected.

At a special meeting yesterday called to consider practically all the propositions before the Congress relating to silver, or connected with it, the Chamber of Commerce of New-York passed a resolution condemning free coinage until a common ratio between gold and silver is adopted by the commercial nations of Europe and by the United Sates.

The streets on the lower east side of the city have been particularly dirty of late, because while the snow and ice were upon them the sweepers could not be used. Yesterday Hans S. Beattie, Street Cleaning Commissioner, sent extra gangs of men to clear away the accumulation of refuse. In the Eighth Street cleaning district there were 100 extra men at work, with 65 extra carts. The extra expense is about $450.

Patrick J. MacKeon, dealer in men's furnishing goods and shirt manufacturer at 210 and 212 Sixth Avenue, corner of Fourteenth Street, made an assignment yesterday to James Duane Squires, giving preferences for $2,974 -- to Earl Wilson, for merchandise, $1,808; to Sarah J. Wyckoff, for rent, $1,166. Mr. MacKeon began business in 1871 and gradually increased it until his sales, it is said, averaged over $150,000 a year.

HARTFORD, Jan. 12. -- It appears from the report of the Connecticut School Fund Commissioner for 1890, that the department has not yet learned that a new town was incorporated in the State eighteen months ago. Discovery of this fact by the members of the Legislature will doubtless lead to a renewal of the clamor for new and younger blood in the school fund office.

Cigarmakers employed at 214 and 216 East Fifty-second Street, who have been on a strike for some time, met last night at John Wenz's saloon, 187 East Seventy-sixth Street, to arrange to go to work to-day. Among those present was Vaclan Bozdich, who went out with Fromer's hands, but who is now employed in a factory in East Sixty-third Street.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- A dispatch was sent to Mr. Gladstone to-day in regard to Mr. Parnell's statement in his Limerick speech that Mr. McCarthy communicated to the ex-Premier the substance of Mr. Parnell's manifesto before it was published. In reply to this Mr. Gladstone telegraphs as follows:

Mrs. Elizabeth M. Delabarre of 44 West Twenty-second Street has brought an action against Louis Silverman of 359 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, to recover the value of furniture taken from her house by Silverman on Dec. 27 last. She has also called the attention of the District Attorneys of New-York and Brooklyn to Silverman's transactions.

The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries has recommended the passage of the bill to create a marine board in the Treasury Department. This measure is the fruit of conferences held during the interval between the two sessions before a commission appointed by Secretary WINDOM.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- The British Minister at Buenos Ayres, the Hon. Francis J. Pakenham, has informed the Foreign office here that heavy taxes, in the shape of licenses, have been imposed upon foreign companies doing business in the Argentine Republic. Only companies which hold concessions from the Argentine Government are excepted from the new tax.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Pennsylvania's Senators are not losing opportunity after the nomination of Cameron, in spite of the opposition of the Administration, to indicate to the President how little the Senators care whether the President is pleased or not with the course which they think they ought to pursue.

The will of Emma Abbott Wetherell was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday afternoon. It had been drawn and executed in this city at the Hotel Marlborough May 8, 1890, in the presence of W.F. Dunning. Miss Abbott's lawyer; A.J.A. Callaghan, and Samuel J. Hare. Lawyer Dunning, Vas Houghton of Brooklyn, formerly a business partner of Mr. Wetherell, and James L. Mitchell of Indianapolis were named in it as executors.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 12. -- Hudson never before turned such a delegation loose upon a Speakership contest as that which she sent down here this evening to make Mullone the presiding officer of the House. Allan McDermott and the rest of the State House statesmen have, on the other hand, promised the State House away to make votes for Bergen.

The opportunity of hearing so eminent a Russian as Sergius Stepniak talk on such a fruitful subject as "Tolstoi as a Novelist and Social Reformer" attracted a large audience last night to the First Baptist Church, on Clinton and Pierrepont Streets, Brooklyn, which had been secured for the occasion by the Long Island Historical Society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- For some reasons it may be regrettable that the President is known to be determined to veto any bill that provides for the free coinage of silver. There is a streak of perversity, apparent to the most imperfect political vision, that leads one to suspect that if the President's wishes were not opposed to the desires of the free-coinage men the Silver bill would not be so persistently and warmly advocated.

The season of fashionable private entertainment opened last night with a ball at the residence of Mrs. Ogden Mill, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-ninth Street. The large house was splendidly decorated, and supper was spread for 300 guests Every room on the first two floors was thrown open. After supper came the English cotillion, Mrs. Mills leading with Mr. William K. Vanderbilt.
Very few agents or companies offer their policies to-day solely as a protection to the family, or dwell upon their adaptation to that purpose, or urge them for that motive.

A.L. Johnson of Cleveland, J.M. Ward and Wendell Goodwin of Brooklyn, and J.E. Wagner of Philadelphia, representing the defunct Players' League, held a meeting in the St. James Hotel for the purpose of settling the difficulty that has arisen in the Cincinnati Club. The latter organization was purchased by Brotherhood capitalists to weaken the League, and is to-day a white elephant.

The Republican primaries were held in all the Assembly districts in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards yesterday. In three of the districts -- the Fifth, Thirteenth, and Twentieth -- there were lively contests, and in each case the faction already in power won the fight. In the fifth an effort was made to depose Stephen B. French, and in the Twentieth the fight was against Police Justice Solon B. Smith.

The speech of Senator SHERMAN in opposition to the Stewart amendment to the Finance bill yesterday was powerful. It was marked by even more than Mr. SHERMAN'S usual moderation of tone and courtesy in form, but it was relentless in its exposure of the real purpose of the silver scheme, and as compact and telling as it was merciless.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- After the first surprise of the State Department at the appearance of the Bering Sea controversy in the Supreme Court was over, Mr. Blaine's friends are taking courage at finding, as they believe, that it will not be possible for the case to get on the docket or receive any attention from the court.

The Republican machine in Kings County was organized for 1891 last night, and Internal Revenue Collector Ernst Nathan was on hand to boss the job. He succeeded too. The Athenaeum, on Atlantic Avenue, where the General Committee met, was packed to the doors, and Nathan's lieutenants were all over. They included David A. Baldwin, George F. Elliott, W.H.N. Cadmus, James C. Fuller, ex-Assemblyman Taylor, and a number of others.

Every three years the Society of French Artists elects a managing body composed of 50 painters, 20 sculptors, 10 architects, and 10 engravers. This committee has been renewed. The painters who voted were 1,075 in number and cast 947 ballots, the largest vote, for Bonnat, followed by Robert Fleury, Lefebvre, Benjamin Constant, Laurens, Cormon, Pelouse, Jules Breton, Bouguerean stood fourteenth, with 878 ballots.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- President John M. Egan of the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City and a number of other railway officials whose headquarters are in St. Paul were in the city to-day. It developed, on inquiry, that the Federal Grand Jury at St. Paul, on complaint the special agent of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, has begun an investigation into alleged violations of the inter-State commerce law.

The snug assembly room in the Railroad Men's Building, 361 Madison Avenue, was crowded to overflowing last night on the occasion of the celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the railroad branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. On the platform and in the audience were Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, the Hon. Abram S. Hewitt, the Rev. David H. Greer, Cyrus W. Field, H. Walter Webb, John M. Toucey, and Col. F.K. Hain.

The report of the Superintendent of Public Works shows that the aggregate freight movement on the canals of the State was less last season than in 1889, though the season of navigation was three days longer. There was a falling off as compared with the previous year of 369,625 tons on the Erie, 132,719 on the Cayuga and Seneca, and 11,500 on the Black River.

The talk at Washington regarding a possible extra session has become rather more definite within the week, and it looks as if there were some of the Republican managers who really imagine that such an outcome of the Fifty-first Congress would be politically an advantage to the party. We do not, we confess, quite see how they can figure that out.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Speaker Sheehan to-night when the Assembly convened announced the following standing committees of the Assembly:

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- The Post will announce tomorrow that another large New-England industry is almost in the hands of an English syndicate. This time it is the business of manufacturing spools, bobbins, and shuttles upon which the shrewd eye of the prudent Englishmen has turned. These goods are used in cotton, silk, woolen, and linen mills, and the industry is a lucrative one in all cases where carried on a large scale.

The Harlem Republican Club installed its officers for the coming year at a meeting held last evening. The incoming officers are: President -- Washington Winsor; First Vice President -- H.C. Robinson; Second Vice President -- Henry T. Peirce; Corresponding Secretary -- Headley M. Greene; Recording Secretary -- Frank L. Norris; Treasurer -- Thomas Wright.

The judgment of conviction found in March last against James A. Flack and William L. Flack for conspiracy was reversed yesterday at Albany by the Court of Appeals and a new trial was ordered. The opinion of the Court of Appeals is written by Justice Andrews, Justices Earl and Gray dissenting.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Elliot Danforth, the State Treasurer, has transmitted to the Legislature the annual report of his department for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1890. During the fiscal year the receipts of the different funds under the supervision of the State Treasurer were:

Roswell Miller, President of the newly-organized Western Traffic Association, has sent out a telegraphic notice from this city calling a meeting of the traffic managers of the lines embraced in the Presidents' agreement to be held in Chicago next Friday. The purpose of the meeting is to arrange the territorial divisions of the association and carry out the details of the plan with respect to joint rates and divisions.

HARTFORD, Jan. 13. -- The Woman's Board of Missions will begin its twenty-third annual session here to-morrow under the direction of Mrs. Judson Smith of Boston, wife of the Secretary of the American Board of Foreign Missions. The session, which will last two days, will be held in the Rev. Dr. George L. Walker's church, and will be attended by delegates from all sections of the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- By far the most interesting discussion of the silver question had in the Senate since the Finance bill was taken up was that of to-day, and its feature was the very earnest effort of John Sherman to stem the tide which is flowing so steadily toward free coinage.

The Parnell business has reached that most dismal stage of political controversies at which they degenerate into "issues of veracity." It was almost inevitable that this would be the result when Mr. PARNELL committed the monstrous breach of decorum involved in making public his account of a confidential conversation with Mr. GLADSTONE on Irish affairs.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 13. -- Because of the mad demands of the Alliance, Kansas is to-day blessed with a somewhat unenviable reputation. The farmers of Kansas are sensible people. They want something, and know, apparently, only that there must be some change in order to bring much-needed relief. A drought comes upon the country, and they seek as a remedy a change in political government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Census Bureau has issued a preliminary bulletin on education. In Louisiana in 1880 there were 8.62 schollars to each 100 persons, and in 1890 there were 11.11 scholars to each 100 persons, or a gain of 28.8 per cent. In the Louisiana public schools for the year ended Dec. 31, 1890, 71 per cent. of the teachers were white, while 29 per cent. were colored.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- State Railroad Commissioners William E. Rogers, Isaac V. Baker, Jr., and Michael Rickard have transmitted their annual report to the Legislature.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The Senatorial atmosphere has begun to clear slightly, but the choice of the Democratic Party to succeed Mr. Evarte has not as yet appeared in tangible shape.

Some weeks ago Mr. CARNEGIE silenced the troublesome competition of a formidable steel-rail factory in the Pittsburg district by purchasing the entire plant. There had been a dispute in the "association" of steel-rail manufacturers about the "allotment" and other details, and it seemed to be expedient to reduce the number of owners.

Immediately after the overwhelming defeat of the Republican Party in the recent elections, influential newspapers, representing as we believe the opinions of a majority of the Republicans of the West, sharply and repeatedly demanded that all the additional duties in the McKinley law should be repealed.

The Bar Association held its annual meeting last evening in its building, 7 West Twenty-ninth Street, and found, after the numerous annual reports had been read, that it had been exceedingly prosperous in the last year. The report of the Executive Committee, read by Clifford A. Hand, showed a membership of 1,123, and the Treasurer's report, read by Secretary Brownell, a total of $26,158.80 cash on hand.

Baseball men of all calibres thronged the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. There were present ordinary substitutes, gilt-edged managers, much-advertised stars, anxious stockholders, good, bad, and indifferent umpires, healthy-looking Presidents, irrepressible cranks, and, in fact, every class of men connected with the diamond-field sport.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 18. -- The trial of the new United States cruiser Concord is a complete success. Conservative calculations place the vessel's horse-power development at 8,500. Many members of the Engineers' Board believe that 3,600 horse power has been obtained. In the latter event the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company is entitled to a bonus of $20,000 over and above the contract price.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 13. -- The Republican House waited four hours for a quorum to-day in order to receive the report of the committee appointed to draft a proposition for compromising existing difficulties. The committee reported this afternoon.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 13. -- The Supreme Court this morning in the quo warranto proceeding instituted by the Republican ex-Governor, John M. Thayer, vs. the Democratic Governor, James E. Boyd, to deprive him of his office, the court gave the ex-Governor a black eye by tersely insinuating that the best thing he could do was to recognize Boyd and get out.

HARTFORD, Jan. 13. -- This State now revels in two sets of State officers just as it used to glory in two capitals. Gov. Morgan G. Bulkeley and his Republican associates, whose successors were elected last November, constitute one set, and Judge Luzon B. Morris and his Democratic associates who were elected such successors, make up the other.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Provisions opened weak, but closed strong. They were undoubtedly influenced considerably Grain. The weak opening was on the news from the stock yards. Packers led the selling. The Chicago Packing Company attracted some attention by its sales of January Pork. John Cudahy was a very free seller of Pork Lard, and Ribs. The Cudahy concern of Milwaukee was credited with covering a considerable line.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 14. -- The Republicans had their turn in the game for the possession of the Gubernatorial chair here to-day and played one of their highest cards. The Select Committee on the Canvass of Votes for State Officers appointed by the House met in the State Capitol in the morning, all the members being present at that time.

It was perfectly characteristic of Senator HOAR that when a request was made on Tuesday that the Finance bill should be allowed another day of discussion he snappishly refused. His avowed purpose was to bring up the Force bill and try once more to lash the Republican Senators into line in its support.

We are not sure that the present session of the Legislature of this State is to be a favorable occasion for efforts in the direction of reform of any kind. The Assembly is in the control of the Democrats, and they have been so long submissive to the tutelage of Gov. HILL that it is doubtful whether the spirit of reform is in them.

The Court of Appeals has just handed down a decision sustaining Judge McAdam in a case that attracted considerable notice while it was in the City Court. Horace B. Wellman kept a so-called matrimonial agency in this city. Mrs. Emily Guion, a wealthy widow, applied to him for a husband, entered into the customary contract with him and paid him $50.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 14. -- Don M. Dickinson and Col. Richardson of Tennessee opened the case of R.M. King, the Adventist, taken up ex parte in the Federal court this morning. The indictment on which King was arrested in 1889 charges the offense of plowing on Sunday, the repetition of which, under common law, made of it the offense known as a common nuisance.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- It is announced that several British army officers, a number of whom are said to be personal friends of the Hon. William P. Cody, (Buffalo Bill,) have started from England for the Pine Ridge Agency, with the intention of offering their services to Col. Cody in fighting the hostile Indians of that section of the United States.

The Atlas steamship Alvo, which arrived yesterday from Kingston and other West Indian ports, had among her passengers Miss Edith Annis, whose thrilling experience on the fever-stricken barkentine James H. Hamlin has been reported before. Miss Annis is only eighteen, and has shown herself to be not lacking in the qualities that make up the heroine.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 14. -- State Railroad Commissioner Rich in his annual report says there is an increase of 836 miles of track over the previous year. The total mileage operated in Michigan is 7,019. There are several hundred miles operated by private parties, logging railroads, , which escape taxation and ignore police regulations, being incorporated under the Train Road act.

The Medico-Legal Society of New-York met in the parlors of the Buckingham Hotel last evening and listened to the inaugural address of Mr. Clark Bell, President of the society, and to the reports of several committees. Mr. Bell said in his address that the society had a membership of 862, a gain of 119 over last year. Eight active and fifteen corresponding members were elected last evening.

When the delegates to the baseball conference in the Fifth Avenue Hotel arrived here they felt certain that the differences would be patched up, and that peace would reign once more among the backers of the various teams. But in this they were mistaken. Instead of arranging matters to the satisfaction of everybody, the baseball situation is to-day in a chaotic state, and there are rumors of war on every side.

Dr. Hammond of the New-York Athletic Club, who was recently elected a member of the Athletic Committee in the place of W. Rathborne, resigned, was interviewed last evening at the clubhouse, 104 West Fifty-fifth Street, in regard to the alleged dissatisfaction of some of the members of the club with the expenditure of money by the Committee for Athletics.

A foot race which promises to attract the attention of the sporting fraternity of this and other cities was arranged yesterday between L.E. Myers of this city, the American champion, and Harry Darrin of Shetiield, England, the champion of Great Britain. Considerable rivalry exists between the two men. Darrin, as an amateur and professional, has defeated every pedestrian of note in England, while Myers is acknowledged the premier foot racer of America.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14. -- In the recent reorganization of the Republican Central Committee Secretary Ford Smith and Treasurer Thomas C. Martin, the lieutenants of Chauncey I. Filley, were deposed, and the silk stocking element gained control. At the time it was rumored that sensational developments might be expected regarding the disposition of the $30,000 contributed by them.

A most savage onslaught has been made by the American Economist, which is the organ of the Protective Tariff League, upon a poor little paper published in the City of Mexico called the Mexican Financier. The cause of the onslaught is as follows:

The hearing at Albany last week before the Government commission appointed to consider the subject of deepening the Hudson River from Coxsackie to Albany or Troy, so that ocean-going vessels may reach those cities, brought out a great many interesting facts concerning the commerce of the river and of the lakes and canals of which it is the outlet.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 14. -- The first meeting of the candidates for the intercollegiate track athletic team was called to-night by order of Capt. Black. Nearly seventy men handed in their names as applicants for a position on the team. Only two men of last year's team were absent -- Dohm and Janeway. The old members present who scored points in last year's contest were Cary, Roddy, Vredenburg, Borcherling, Woodbridge, Jefferson, and Turner.

Richard Pendleton, a salesman at the store of the Gotham Manufacturing, Company, 889 Broadway, and George Williams and James Russell, two of his friends, pleaded guilty in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon to a charge of robbing the company of $3,000 worth or goods in the last year. They were held in $5,000 bail each for trial.

The Medical News of Philadelphia yesterday published the following important cable as to the injurious effects found by Prof. Virchow in a number of post-mortem examinations of patients treated by the Koch method:

Although the decision of the Board of General Appraisers in the kid glove reappraisement case of Passavant Co. is held by the board to be final and conclusive, the firm did not propose to accept it as such nor to rest under the imputation cast upon it by the decision. Preparatory to further steps in the matter, Passavant Co. on Monday wrote to the board as follows:

It is not surprising, and on the whole it is not to be regretted, that, if the Senate was determined on free coinage, it should have passed a free coinage bill pure and simple as a substitute for all the proposed legislation. There was certainly nothing consistent between free coinage and any of the provisions of the Finance Committee's bill that related to silver.

The steamship Ciudad Condal, which arrived last night from Havana, brought the crew of the schooner Helen A. Chase, which left Pensacola Dec. 31, bound for this port. Capt. Southard of the schooner was also on board, and was loud in his praise of the Condal's officers for the rescue of himself and his men from a terrible death.

The new United States cruiser Concord reached New-York at 4 P.M. yesterday. She anchored for the night off Twenty-sixth Street, East River. The Concord got under way at New-London at 8:30 yesterday morning. Before starting, brooms were lashed to the funnel and jury foremast. The Concord made the run to New-York at an average speed of fifteen knots per hour.

The fire at 194 West Street, which began about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, required the attention of the firemen nearly all day yesterday, and caused an aggregate loss of probably $90,000. Beatty Votteler, lithographers, suffered substantially a total loss of presses and other working material. The presses fell through several floors, carrying beams as well as flooring with them, and were good only as junk afterward.

The amended petitioner of the elevated railroad company for the appointment of Commissioners to condemn about thirty parcels of property was passed on yesterday by Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court, who decided that the petition should be granted except as to seven parcels. In the cases in which the proceedings are dismissed, the company maintains stations or other unauthorized structures in front of the property it seeks to condemn.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Ritchie Brothers, brokers, suspended business this afternoon. The failure is attributed to the extensive and losing operations of the senior member of the firm. The firm consists of John C. Ritchie, George S. Ritchie, and James B. Ritchie. The failure caused scarcely a ripple in the Stock Exchange. John C. Ritchie is the most active member of the firm, and he has been a prominent bear for some years.
The lew-York Society of he Arclneological Institute of America has arranged for a course of Six free lectures to be .given in HamlltQn Hall, Columbia College,

PINE RIDGE, S.D., Jan. 14, via Rushville, Neb. -- This morning Little Wound, Little Hawk, Crow Dog, and Old Calico came in from the hostiles to talk with Gen. Miles under the escort of Young-Man-Afraid-of-His-Horses. This council progressed satisfactorily. Col. Corbin, Assistant Adjutant General, announces that the chiefs have assented to the surrender of their arms, and that the latter will probably be brought in to-night or to-morrow and be tagged.

The contest over the will of Robert Ray Hamilton was resumed yesterday morning in the Surrogate's Court. The public interest in the proceedings was so great that the court room was crowded to the doors by a heterogeneous rabble. The centre of observation was the woman claiming to be the widow of the unfortunate Hamilton.

It is evident that a number of the Republican Senators at Albany have concluded that it is not expedient any longer to make factious opposition to such a rapid-transit measure as will be acceptable to the people and authorities of this city, and that they will refuse to be controlled in this matter by the wishes of TOM PLATT.

Advocates of such excise reform as will lead to a proper restriction of the liquor traffic have taken a step which will centralize their efforts in that direction. The movement consists of the formation of the Excise Reform Association. It will take the place of the Citizens' Committee on High License, the Church Temperance Society, and the Society for the Prevention of Crime in the work in the field of excise reform.

A.B. Stickney, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Railroad, reached Chicago yesterday on his return from New-York. Concerning the Presidents' agreement, he said: "There is nothing in it that was not in the former Presidents' agreement, and we all know what came of that. What is the use of thrashing over old straw?

There are indications that Gov. HILL is getting "rattled" in his effort to play bigger politics than he has been accustomed to. A month ago it was assumed that he would do as he pleased with the Democratic majority in the Legislature, but now it looks very much as though he would not be able to handle it just as he pleases.

More musical people than could be comfortably accommodated crowded the parlors of Mason Hamlin, in Fifth Avenue, last night, on the occasion of the ninth meeting of the Manuscript Society of New-York. The influence upon local musical culture of the society was indicated not alone by the extent and character of the attendance, but in the admirable quality of the original compositions submitted for critical approval.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Realizing that he is imperiling his status as boss by his policy and threatening his party with a scandal that may seriously impair the Democracy's chances next Fall, Gov. Hill has begun to put out new lines on the Senatorial question, which proves that he himself has grown anxious regarding the result, and that he is aware of his inability to hold the Democratic aggregation for any candidate other than himself.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The pressing need of more ships on the Pacific station bids fair to result in the increase of Admiral Brown's squadron by at least one ship, and that one the splendid new cruiser San Francisco, now fitting out at the Mare Island Yard, and heretofore intended to be sent to China to become Admiral Belknap's flagship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Just six months ago to-day President Harrison approved the Silver bill of 1890, which, although a compromise between the views of the extreme silver men and their opponents, was declared to be a long step toward the goal of free coinage of silver which the silver men have been so determined to reach.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Dispatches were received to-night by Gen. Schofield from Gen. Miles announcing the end of the Indian troubles in the West. Gen. Miles says:

The Free-Coinage bill was sent over to the House yesterday from the Senate in the ordinary course of business, and was promptly referred by the Speaker to the Committee on Coinage. The chances of the bill in the committee and in the House are fully discussed in our Washington dispatches. Meanwhile we may state that the substance of the bill is not materially different from the amendment submitted by Mr. STEWART.

Mr. Winslow Homer exhibits at the Reichard Gallery, opposite the Hotel Brunswick, four canvases which indicate greater powers than have yet appeared in his work, always original and delightful to connoisseurs as it has been in the past. At his studio, near Portland, Me., he has been studying the play of light on the ocean by dayshine and moonshine, and now presents a quartet of sea views that surpass all former efforts.

Mr. E.M. Reed, Vice President of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, yesterday denied emphatically the report that that road and the New-York and New-England were to be consolidated. He declared that such a scheme had never been brought to the attention of the Directors of his road, and that, so far as he knew, no petition for power to consolidate will be presented to the Legislatures of this State, of Massachusetts, or of Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- By the grace of Vice President Morton the Force bill is once more before the Senate. It was almost exactly midnight last night when, the Silver bill having been passed, Mr. Hoar made his motion to take up the Force bill, and the sixty-six Senators present entitled to vote divided equally on the question.

It seems now that JAY GOULD is regarded as the chief obstacle to rapid-transit legislation, but it is scarcely possible that the Legislature will put itself in the position of appearing to serve the interests of the elevated railroad monopoly, especially when there can be no explanation for it except the corrupt influence of GOULD.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 15. -- Pittsburg coke operators headed by H. Clay Frick, Carnegie's partner, are seriously considering a proposition to buy out the plant in the Connellsville region owned by W.J. Rainey of Cleveland for $1,000,000. Mr. Rainey is of an independent turn, and operates his plant without the interference of labor unions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 15. -- The estimate of expenditures by the State of Connecticut for the two years ending June 30, 1893, which is to be submitted to the Legislature by the State Treasurer, is now completed, the total being $3,697,221. The estimate for the Board of Education is $619,372, of this amount $491,872 being for the common schools and $80,000 for the normal schools at New-Britain and Willimantic.

BRIDGEPORT, Jan. 15. -- The agreement entered into by the American Graphophone Company of this city and the Edison Phonograph Company of Newark, N.J., some time ago, it seems, does not appear to be satisfactory. Up to six months ago the Graphophone Company occupied the old Howe sewing-machine factory in this city. They seemed to be doing a large business, and employed a large number of skilled workmen.

The decision which seems to have been practically reached not to attempt to pass a general River and Harbor bill at the present session may disturb the friends of some pet dredging projects, but will hardly injure public interests. The Fiftieth Congress, in like manner, did not pass a River and Harbor bill at its second session.

The new Republican County Committee met in Clarendon Hall last night, but failed to perfect organization because protests were made against seating the Gibbs delegation from the Thirteenth District and the French delegation from the Fifth. Clarendon Hall was not big enough to hold the committee. Col. S.V.R. Cruger called the meeting to order and then Charles H. Murray, loader of the Third District, nominated Col. W.C. Church for temporary Chairman.

The Chicago Club is trying to secure the services of "Mike" Kelly. He will play in Chicago if the Boston Club does not give him the management and Captaincy of the team. Directors Billings and Conant are in favor of placing the nine in Kelly's charge, but the old warrior, Soden, does not like the idea. Both Boston and Chicago have offered Kelly $5,000 for next season.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 15. -- The legislative situation in Montana is as much muddled as ever and grave doubts exist as to any compromise being effected by which laws can be passe about which there will be no question. The members of the Republican House held a caucus this morning. The refusal of the Democrats to accept the Republican plan of compromise was considered for two hours.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 15. -- The Hon. David Mills, a high authority on international law, In an interview rezardin Sir John Thomason's action in bring a portion of the Bering Sea question before the Supreme Court of the United States, says:

The Brooklyn Union League Club held a very largely attended meeting last night and, after electing ninety-one new members, started in to discuss a proposition to establish a cafe and to permit the sale of liquor in the club on Sunday. President Francis H. Wilson, in stating the case, declined to express an opinion, but urged the 300 members present to regard the honor of the club rather than to consult their own desires.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Private cable dispatches received from Iquiqne contain the information that the blockade extends to Coquimbo. The Chilean war ships Almirante Cochrane and Magell are engaged in the work of operating the blockade. All the telegraph wires to the north of Valparaiso have been out.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 15. -- The Republican caucus to nominate a United States Senator to succeed Senator Blair was held to-night in the Opera House, there being many spectators present in the galleries. Representative C.H. Bell presided. Nominating speeches were dispensed with, and the caucus at once proceeded to ballot with the following result: First ballot -- Whole number of votes, 193; necessary to a choice, 97.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- President and Mrs. Harrison were the guests of honor to-night at a dinner given by Senator and Mrs. Leland Stanford. The other guests were Vice President and Mrs. Morton, Chief Justice Fuller, Gen. Schofield, Mrs. McKee, Mrs. Logan, Senator and Mrs. Edmunds, Senator and Mrs. Sherman, Senator and Mrs. Frye, and Minister and Mme. Romero.

The Tammany primaries will be held to-night and as a result the already powerful Wigwam will be strengthened in several points. There will be no contests; Tammany is too strong for that just now. There is a dispute, to be sure, in the Fourteenth Assembly District, between the Reilly and Rockwell-Creamer factions, but that will be settled later and no primary will be held in the district to-night.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- The report of the examination made by Chief Examiner Michael Shannon and James A. Horan into the condition and affairs of the Fidelity and Casualty Company has been made to the State Superintendent of Insurance. It is dated Jan. 6, and is as follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The death of the American Harvester Company, the infant trust organized in November by half a dozen manufacturers of harvesting machinery, leaves Col. A.L. Conger of Akron, Ohio, in an unpleasant predicament and incidentally puts the McCormick company, the head of the trust, in possession of a mass of information of almost incalcuable value.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- At the Congress of the Knights of Labor to-day, the Graham Assembly bill of 1886, providing for county care of convicts, was indorsed and a resolution was adopted calling for a more stringent enforcement of the Fassett prison labor law.

In the hearing accorded to the general public by the Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday, at Steinway Hall, there was such a resurrection of impossible schemes as nearly to swamp the one or two practicable and feasible schemes presented. The meeting was decided upon as something of all experiment. An invitation was extended to the general public to appear and present its various schemes, and the results were not generally encouraging.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The following official communication from the Union Pacific Railway Company signed by Vice President W.P. Helcomb was received by President Cable of the Rock Island to-day: To the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company:

KEY WEST, Jan, 15. -- Several of the great lights on the Florida Reefs have recently had a narrow escape from running out of oil. Owing to the severe "northers" of late in the Gulf, the Government lighthouse steamer Laurel has been unable to visit Key West for over a fortnight. During the past week news reached Key West that several of the Florida Reef lights were getting short of oil.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Senator Morgan, Democrat, of Alabama, introduced in the Senate to-day a resolution criticising the action of Great Britain in placing the question of the seizure by the United States of British sealing vessels before the United States Supreme Court. The resolution is as follows:

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 15. -- The Macon Construction Company and the Georgia Southern Road expect to pull apart, and the road will be operated independently of the company. General Manager Lane of the Georgia Southern will leave the road and devote all of his time to the general management of the affairs of the Macon Construction Company and the Macon and Savannah Construction Company.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- The only obstacle to rapid transit, as THE TIMES has said from the first, is Mr. Jay Gould. Among the legislators who have the interests of New-York rather than the welfare of their own pocket at heart but one sentiment is heard, namely, to give the metropolis a bill desired by the local authorities in conformity with home rule, whether it is agreeable to the Republican leaders or not.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 15. -- The chaotic state of the lower house of the Legislature has at last been the cause of loss of life. Harley McCoy, a Deputy Sergeant at Arms, shot Charles Hawley, Captain of Police, twice at an early hour this morning. The wounds resulted in the victim's death. Officer Morris rushed to Capt. Hawley's rescue and was shot by a Deputy Sheriff named Anderson.

Postmaster Van Cott has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship Oceanic arrived at that port Wednesday with mails from China, Japan, , of the following dates: Shanghai, Dec. 19; Hongkong, Dec. 19; Yokohama, Dec. 27; Honolulu. Jan. 7; due to arrive in New-York the morning of Monday, Jan. 19.

The nature and composition of Prof. KOCH'S curative lymph have at last been disclosed, so far as they can be made known, but it is noticeable that even the discoverer himself is still very much in the dark as to the substance obtained by his researches. The lymph is not an attenuated culture of the bacillus of tuberculosis.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 15, via Galveston. -Three earthquakes occurred to-day at Parral, in the State of Chihuahua. The gallery at the Convent of the Sacred Heart gave way, killing six persons and wounding nine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The dispatch recently printed in THE TIMES relative to the pneumatic gun carriage going into the "scrap heap" is correct despite the recently-published letter from President Creecy. The statement was based on an interview with the chief of the Bureau of Ordnance of the Navy Department, Commodore Folger.

The Postmaster at Larchmont is in a quandary. The tariff, a silk handkerchief, and a burglar have combined to bring about the present situation, and although the amount of money involved is not great, the question at issue is a nice one. This correspondence tells its own story, the first letter being sent to the Postmaster by the customs officers in this city and the second being the reply thereto:

The railroad strike in Scotland is exceptional for the length of time that it has continued without giving a decisive advantage to either party. Of course, such a condition cripples the railroads and prevents them from giving the public full service. Furthermore, it exasperates the strikers, the strain upon whose tempers is increased by every day of unpaid idleness.

The announcement that the Directors of the Metropolitan Opera House had voted for a season of Italian opera at their institution next Winter was undoubtedly a great surprise to readers of THE TIMES yesterday morning.
