It was absolutely unknown to almost every person employed in the Opera House that any movement toward such a change was on foot, and the employes of the establishment fairly rubbed their eyes when they read yesterday morning's news.
BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- The long-talked-of secret of the ingredients entering into the composition of Prof. Koch's famous lymph is given to-day to the world at large. Prof. Koch says:

The Federal statute regulating the election of United States Senators will make it necessary for the two branches of the Connecticut Legislature to be in session next Tuesday, when each will have to vote for a successor to Senator PLATT, and on Wednesday the two houses must meet in joint convention and elect the Senator.

ERIE, Penn., Jan. 15. -- The Pennsylvania Farmers' Alliance completed its deliberations' here to-day, and adjourned for a year. Before adjourning National Organizer Ashby of Des Moines, Iowa, installed George D. Brown of Lawrenceville, Penn., President; Secretary -- Clinton Shaddock of Harbor Creek; State Organizer -- H.H. Chaffey of Wellsburg, and Charles Morgan of Hornby delegate to the Northwestern Alliance Convention in Omaha this month.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Special Agent Chance of the Customs Service made an important discovery a few days ago which gave evidence of the existence of a conspiracy to defraud the Government out of legitimate revenue. By the merest accident he was made aware of the fact that there was a lowering of the sugar entries of W. Ford Thomas, representing the Claus Spreckels Sugar Refinery.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- The announcement in the dispatches to-day that Assemblyman Frank P. Demarest of Rockland County is a self-confessed forger and embezzler has caused a good deal of consternation in Democratic circles. The Democratic margin of safety on joint ballot is slight enough at best, but if Mr. Demarest fails to appear when the election of United States Senator takes place next Wednesday it will be exceedingly fragile.

Property owners along the river front in Yonkers are very much excited just at present over an accidental discovery to the effect that the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company claims the title to all the Hudson River front from Spuyten Duyvil to Albany. In 1846 the company laid out a strip of land for its tracks 66 feet in width and laid them.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard was a scene of energy and excitement yesterday. Besides the clamor of the redoubled forces of hammers at work on "No. 7" and on the-smaller craft, there was a great hurrying here and there in the neighborhood, of the long stone docks, where the two flagships Chicago and Philadelphia were making final preparations for sea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- There seemed to be a general expectation on the part of the public that the proceedings of the Senate on the Force bill would be very entertaining to-day, and when the Senators were called to order at noon the galleries were all filled, except a small portion of the ladies' gallery.

CATTELLSBURG, Ky., Jan. 16. -- News comes from McDowell County, West Va., of the murder of "Joe" Black by John James, who afterward married his victim's widow, who had urged him to commit his crime. James came from Virginia, and fell in love with Black's wife, whom he urged to elope with him. Fearing her husband, she refused, and made James promise to kill Black on condition that she would marry him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Secretary Tracy has written a reply to Commander Reiter's letter, complaining of his recent reprimand and asking for trial by court martial for his conduct in the Barrundia affair. Not only is a trial denied, but a second public reprimand is added to the first.

The victories of the French at Niora and Youri are likely to strengthen their hold on the Western Soudan. Sultan AHMADU has long been the most determined enemy of French progress in that region. About ten years ago he consented to make a treaty of peace and protection, but when the French attempted to visit his capital, Segu-Sikoro, he quickly showed that his notion of peace was that of being left alone.

The Tammany primary elections were held last night in all the Assembly districts but the Fourteenth. The call for the primary in the latter district was omitted by Tammany's Committee on Organization, because there is a fight going on there between the Reilly and the Rockwell-Creamer factions. The primaries passed off without contests, and, as already indicated in THE TIMES, the Wigwam has acquired through the primaries additions from the County Democracy.

The following article upon the new political party in the United States, from the pen of M. Leon Say, will be published in the Journal des Debats to-morrow morning. M. Say is rarely a contributor to the newspapers under his own signature, and his views upon the latest political move in America must interest all nations where the same elements exist:

The President and the Secretary of the Interior are the two men who ought to feel most relieved and most grateful that Gen. MILES has succeeded in averting the general Indian war that has been so long and so seriously threatened. For these two are the men immediately responsible for the threat, and upon them would have rested the frightful responsibility for the great battle that a week ago everybody expected to be fought.

Mayor Chapin, Controller Jackson, and ex- Auditor Rutan of Brooklyn filed their answer yesterday in the suit brought by Mr. William Ziegler to prevent them from buying the Long Island Water Supply Company at the alleged exorbitant price of $1,250,000, and the case come up for trial at the February term of the Supreme Court.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 16. -- The recent reorganization of the City Republican Committee, by which Boss Filley was practically shorn of his power in Missouri, will in all probability lead to a Grand Jury investigation and proceedings against Secretary Ford Smith and Treasurer Thomas C. Martin of the old committee to force a detailed statement of the handling of funds in the Fall campaign.

Voluminous affidavits were submitted to Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on an application made in a suit brought by Charles E. Coon against Albert J. Wright and James L. Gladwin, to restrain the defendants from disposing of any of the assets of the firm of A.J. Wright Co. of Buffalo. Mr. Coon is a special partner in the firm, and his suit is for the purpose of having the partnership dissolved.

School Commissioner John B. Merrill of Queens Counter, who is also a lawyer and a Past Grand Master of the Order of Odd Fellows, and William Dykes, a member of the Board of Education and also a Past Grand Master of the same order, fought with their tongues and fists on a street of Jamaica, L.L. yesterday, and caused more excitement than the quiet old town has known for a long time.

Seventy sons of Dartmouth College were seated at the twenty-seventh annual banquet of the Dartmouth College Association of New-York, at Sherry's last evening. The affair was in every sense of the word a jolly reunion.

Father Ignatius will start for Florida next Monday to get some rest after his arduous labors of the last six weeks. Requests to preach in all parts of the country have been flowing in upon him in constantly-increasing numbers, and his friends say that his time would be taken up for the next four or five months if he merely complied with the invitations from this vicinity.

Three banks of this city have taken to themselves new Presidents. They are the Bank of North America, the Third National, and the Mechanics and Traders'. Mr. William Dowd, who was for seventeen years President of the Bank of North America, voluntarily retired from the Presidency of that institution last Thursday, and Mr. Warner Vannorden was elected to fill the vacancy.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 16. -- The House had its first real battle to-day, when it reached the resolutions of Mr. Josiah Quincy in favor of the maintenance of the bi-metallic standard of value and against the debasement of the currency through the free coinage of silver. Mr. Wardwell of Haverhill offered substitute resolutions in favor of honest money.

Detectives have for several weeks been attempting to find the person who took valuables worth $8,000 from William Simpson's pawnshop at 91 Park Row. They finally fixed on Patrick Forrestell, a discharged employe of the pawnbroker, as the thief. A few nights ago they saw him leave a salson with two professional thieves, who went with him to the pawnshop.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 16. -- It became known late to-night that on Wednesday evening Henry S. Ives visited here and had a secret interview with William Mckeen, President of the Vandalia line. He returned to New-York late the same night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Commissioner of Indian Affairs has received from Elaine Goodale, Supervisor of Education, a letter dated Pine Ridge, Jan. 12, giving a report of the battle at Wounded Knee. Among other things it says:
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 16. -- Matthew Stanley Quay will probably surprise the Senate and the country to-morrow by repeating the performance of Conkling and Platt in 1881.

Business went on as usual yesterday at the office of the Fidelity and Casualty Company in spite of the report made to the Insurance Department by Examiner Shannon that the capital of the company had been impaired. There was no meeting of Directors, and the officers said that none would be held before the regular session next Wednesday.

Not the least gratifying result of the November elections has been the retirement from the Senate, and presumably from politics in general, of Mr. HENRY W. BLAIR. It has been supposed, though the supposition was not very creditable to New-Hampshire, that the eccentric statesman had great popular strength in that State, but it appears to have lain chiefly among the women and children, who approved his various schemes of high-handed benevolence.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Robert Lindblom and F. G. Kammerer have resigned from the committee appointed by President Baker to forward the plan of building a telegraph line between the different commercial Exchanges of the country. Mr. Lindblom said to-night:...

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 16. -- A famous landmark is about to vanish before the onward march of improvement, in the removal of the tall tower which Llewellyn Haskell built at his country seat at Kearney in 1843. The tower is to make way for a public street that is to run through the once handsome grounds. Its height is ninety feet.

A woman's grace and beauty, as well as her wit and eloquence, were again made manifest last night at the twenty-second annual dinner of Sorosis at Delmonico's. The men were there, too, as guests, robbed of their usual inspiration of wine and cigars, and they made a gallant showing. Mrs. Ella Dietz Clymer presided, and nearly all of the more prominent members of Sorosis were present.

The committee of Wabash employee and the officials of that road had another conference yesterday at St. Louis, and a satisfactory settlement of the matters under consideration was reached. The schedule prepared by the committee was submitted to General Manager Hayes. It provides for an equalization of wages and hours of labor all over the Wabash system.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 16. -- The monthly live-bird shoot of the Riverside Gun Club took place this afternoon. The conditions were favorable and the birds were strong and swift fliers. The opening event was a club shoot at seven birds, handicap rises, $2.50 entrance. Henry C. White, Edward Cooper, James Cooper, and John Cooper killed six each, and in the shoot-off John Cooper won on the fourth bird.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- In accordance with the call sent out by President Miller from New-York, traffic managers of the lines embraced in the Presidents' agreement met here to-day to arrange the territorial division of the Western Traffic Association. It was expected at the beginning that this work could be completed in a day, but the proceedings were blocked by the non-appearance of a representative of the Great Northern Road.

It is announced that Senator QUAY, who has so long remained silent under charges affecting his official honesty, because those charges were susceptible of easy proof and could not be refuted, is to seek "vindication" by resigning his seat in the Senate and being sent back to it with great alacrity by the Legislature of Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- E.H. Horner, the man arrested in New-York yesterday for disposing of bogus bonds, had an office here. The receipts of his Chicago office, opened only ten months ago, exceeded $4,000 a month, and were rapidly increasing. As nearly as can be determined, the total number of customers in and around Chicago exceeds 3,000.

The pestilence now ravaging a great part of Asiatic Russia bears that name of "Black Death," so familiar for centuries as describing one of the most fearful of those plagues which, appearing at irregular intervals, have devastated the globe. Presumably it was this same form of scourge that, starting also from Asia, spread over that continent and Europe about the middle of the fourteenth century, and is reputed to have had millions of victims.

In its new quarters, 49 West Twenty-second Street, the Salmagundi Club held a joyous meeting last night, proud in the consciousness that it has at last solved the problem of establishing a club of artists. About 150 members of the profession are on the rolls. The first floor of the building contains a lounging room, prettily fitted up, and a gallery with a reception room between.

The suit at the city against the Manhattan Railway Company for an accounting as to moneys alleged to be due, representing 5 per cent. yearly payments on the net income from passenger traffic of the New-York Elevated Railway Company to which the city alleges that it is entitled, was partly tried by Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, permission being given to have the arguments on law points take place later.

Peace reigns supreme in baseball circles. The war is over and the anxious capitalists, the-gilt-edged player, and the overworked manager have buried the hatchet and are now smoking the pipe of peace. This state of affairs was brought about yesterday when the League club of Boston decided to share its territory with an American Association nine.

The renewal of the modus vivendi between Great Britain and France has caused an outburst of indignation in Newfoundland. Some of the current talk there may recall that which the mother country heard from certain other colonists on this side of the Atlantic about six score years ago. In those earlier days the particular subject of grievance was tea; now it is lobsters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Prof. Egleston of Columbia College, delegate from the American Society of Civil Engineers, called on Senator Evarts and Representative Flower to-day and presented the memorial of the society urging legislation by Congress to legalize the adoption of standard time throughout the United States. Later in the day a bill for this purpose was introduced in Congress.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- M. Daudet -- whose son is to wed Mlle. Jeanne Hugo before the New Year chimes cease to ring in the frosty air -- has enjoyed two triumphs this week, and his friends say that the one given by M. de Goncourt's "Fille Elisa" was the one dearest to his heart. The long and faithful friendship existing between these two literary celebrities is legendary.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 17. -- John Stewart of Columbia owns a clucking hen that is carefully nursing a trio of sparrows, fully grown and able-bodied. Charles Starbaugh of Hanover has a hen that is brooding in a most affectionate way over a pair of kittens.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 17. -- The offer made by the American Government to the Canadian authorities for closer trade relations between the two counties is attracting widespread attention in Canada. The Hon. George E. Foster, Minister of Finance, informed THE TIMES'S correspondent to-night that negotiations are still in progress, and may probably result in a conference at an early date.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 17. -- The meeting of the Iowa State Agricultural Society here this week, with the several organizations that are auxiliary to it, has brought into the city a large number of farmers from all parts of the State and several politicians, chiefly of the Republican persuasion, who come to make a little political hay under a January sun, and to repair their fences in spots where they seem to be weakest.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 17. -- Gayety may at last be said to prevail in this city, and as the past week has been fraught with much excitement for the social world, so the succeeding weeks until the close of the season will doubtless bring much of uncommon interest. On Thursday next the first of the series of four dinner dances referred to some time ago will be given at the Lyceum Theatre.

Near the close of those handsome and instructive volumes, the author writes, under date of Nov. 3, 1812: "I am now arranging my manuscripts for the press. They will prove that if I have mistaken my own interests through life, I have been perfectly correct as to those of my country." To understand this declaration it is necessary to know what were the main lines in Mr. Miles's career.

" Yes, it was a plucky thing, certainly, but I can't help thinking that the motive was not altogether an unmixed one. You see, Westminster Bridge is one of the best-known places in the world, and when a man jumps over its parapet to save a fellow-creature who is struggling in the tideway below he is tolerably certain to be well repaid for his exertion.

ENGLISH PLAYERS IN FRANCE. -- English playgoers of sixty years ago had reason to feel thankful for the visit which Fanny Kelly made to Paris during the Autumn of 1819. Much against the wishes of her father, the Captain, this young girl of sixteen had taken to the boards at Cheltenham in the June previous.

This is a question which is being constantly asked. It is put to the geologist, the physical geographer, the astronomer, the meteorologist, and "the oldest inhabitant," and each one, except the last, when pinned down to the matter of the data on which he bases his answer, has been obliged to confess that he knows of no thorough investigation of the subject from the various possible points of view.

Notwithstanding the almost total failure of the peach crop of last season, an exceedingly short apple crop, and a general disaster to the fruit crop grown within five or six hundred miles of this city, our market is far from being fruitless. The great abundance of the California fruit crop enabled canners to pack an unusual quantity last season in State.

As a constant reader of your paper I ask for a little space in your news columns in which to discuss the question of rapid transit. I should like to have you head this article as follows: "Rapid Transit as Far Away To-day as it was Ten Years Ago." This heading may seem strange to a great many of your readers, but nevertheless I sincerely believe that this expresses a fact.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The coming week the White House will be three times open for entertainments in the course of the seven days. The State dinner to the Diplomatic Corps on Tuesday evening will be followed on Friday evening by a reception from 9 to 11 to the Congress and judiciary, and on Saturday afternoon, from 3 to 5 o'clock, Mrs. Harrison will hold her second public reception.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 17. -- Of the series of annual meetings which will be held here next week that of the Connecticut Humane Society will be the most interesting from a popular point of view. This society was organized eleven years ago, principally through the efforts of the Rev. Dr. Burton, and was incorporated by the Legislature in 1881.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Prof. Koch will return to Berlin in March, after he makes a tour of Italy and Egypt. Upon his return the Koch Institute will be formally opened. Yesterday was the twenty-fifth anniversary of his receiving his diploma as a doctor, and he was the recipient of a large number of congratulatory letters and messages.

Hindus are very skillful in taming wild animals and snakes, and an incident was related the other day by an Indian traveler of how an Indian fakir tamed in a few minutes a refractory horse that no one else could manage.

Cardinal MANNING excited much surprise in his own Church as well as in the Church of England and the dissenting bodies when he appeared publicly as the friend and counselor of the London dockmen in their famous and successful strike. That strike was not marked by many or flagrant excesses, and of course the Cardinal would not have counseled any violent or disorderly proceedings.

NEW-ORLEANS, La, Jan. 17. -- A Key West special to the Picayune says that a vessel that has just arrived from Tortugas reports that the American barkentine Joseph Baker of Bangor, Me., bound from New-Orleans for Baltimore, with a cargo of molasses and rice, went ashore on Jan. 13 on North Key Flats, five miles east of Fort Jefferson, Tortugas.

The annual meeting last night of that prosperous organization, the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn, was largely attended. An election of Governors was hold resulting in the selection, for three years, of E.W. Bigelow, R.R. Vernon, William H. Ford, Thomas E. Stillman, W.F. Smith, Carl H. De Silver; for two years, Alexander Barrie; for one year, Alexander Cameron.

The castle smiled benignantly upon us from a hilltop on the east, as the Smeaton Tower steamed slowly into the harbor of San Juan. On the west, and some distance within the mouth of the harbor, there rose up out of the water a square, turreted little stone water battery, a Lilliputian fort. oddly picturesque, but practically insignificant.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Snow has again fallen in East Prussia, South Germany, and Austria-Hungary. The severity of the frost and the wideness of the area affected are greater than ever before chronicled. Railroad traffic is greatly delayed. Over one thousand men are employed in clearing the streets of Berlin.

What is undoubtedly the largest collection of antique French painted fans ever seen in this country has just been placed on exhibition at Tiffany's. It embraces eighty specimens from the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and is valued at between $10,000 and $12,000. In the lot are fans from nearly all the best known European collections, including those of Walker, de Lancy, Pelonze, Speyer, Stephani, Riviere, Boas, Mallet, Aullier, Bienaime, Gunckel, and Fabien.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 17. -- At the meeting of the Newark Saloon Keepers' Protective Association Friday night Secretary Kleine announced that three bills are to be presented to the Legislature this week. One is for the reduction of the license fee, a second invests the Governor with the power of appointing Excise Commissioners, and the third is to modify the Sunday restrictions on liquor selling.

Isaac Goldman, editor and proprietor of the Plattdeutsche Post and head of a large printing office in New Chambers Street, has been at law to collect a bill of $320.67 from a company whose capital is said to be $1,500,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 17. -- The meeting of creditors of the Westinghouse Electric Company this afternoon was attended by thirty persons, or one-fourth of the known creditors. The committee appointed to examine the books reported they found $175,000 due Pittsburg creditors and $300,000 to outside creditors in New-York, Chicago, and other large cities.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- American pork has been the subject of much discussion in the Tariff Committee of the Chamber of Deputies. It seems to be generally understood that the committee will recommend the abrogation of the decree prohibiting the importation of American pork. If this is adopted American pork will be placed upon the same footing as the product of other countries.

It is strange that after the first successful adaptation of steam to war vessels the ram bow did not suggest itself to naval men. In the faraway days of triremes and quinquiremes, when Carthage was mistress of the seas, the prow was the most redoubtable weapon. It disappeared with the advent and success of sailing ships, only to be reintroduced after the modern armored ship was an accomplished fact.

APIA, Samoa, per steamer Zealandia, Jan. 17. -- The long-expected Chief Justice of Samoa, Mr. Sedarkranz, arrived on the steamship Alameda, which anchored off the islands Dec. 30. The Chief Justice landed through a misunderstanding at another wharf than the one at which he was expected, and passed the night at the house of Hr. Hettzler, a countryman of his.

Mr. JAY GOULD takes advantage of the ready hospitality of the Sun for anything he may desire to promulgate to express the opinion that no rapid-transit legislation is necessary at Albany. All that is needed, he says, "is that the city should grant the elevated road a few more privileges, such as a loop at Battery Park." This expression of opinion follows a statement of what the elevated roads are doing to increase their facilities.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 17. -- Capt. Francis S. Bullock died to-day, aged sixty-five years Capt. Bullock belonged to Rockland, Me., but came to Baltimore in 1866, where he had since lived. During his sojourn here he sailed in the South American trade, but afterward became connected with the firm of Loud, Claridge Co., ship chandlers and vessel brokers, from which he retired about three years ago.

The futility of all efforts hitherto made to create a permanent navigable channel and to prevent overflow of the levees raises this question, Does the Mississippi River Commission, as at present constituted, present the best attainable agent for effecting the great object it was created to deal with? and if not, how can it be reorganized so as to increase its efficiency?

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17. -- Commercial circles are agitated by rumors concerning the Lead Trust. Two representatives of the great concern are now here, Second Vice President Rookwell of New-York and Hugh McBurney. Both of these gentlemen arrived this morning and were on 'Change during the forenoon. Mr. Alex Euston who, it is said, has an indirect influence in Lead Trust affairs, is also expected before Monday.

TARSUS, PAST AND PRESENT. -- When Cleopatra came to Tarsus to pay her celebrated visit to Antony, she was able to sail right up the river Cydnos in her galley, and landed near those pretty falls which were then in the centre of the city, but which now form a pleasant object for an idle stroll about a mile to the east of the present town.

THE ABUSE OF MEN'S FRIENDS. -- Men seem to forgot that from dogs kept for sporting purposes we exact an amount of violent exercise which tells upon them exactly as it does upon ourselves. A dog who comes home overtired, unless supplied with tempting food and a warm, clean, and comfortable bed, would break down as certainly as a man would.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- With a crash heard for a mile and smashing plate-glass windows for a radius of three blocks, a sewer manhole exploded this evening at the intersection of Jackson Street and Wabash Avenue, when both thoroughfares were crowded with shoppers and work people. Dozens of persons were thrown from their feet by the terrific force of the explosion, and a wild panic ensued among those left unhurt.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- Every one is waiting now for the premier of Sardou's "Thermidor" at the Comedie Francaise. The management has been obliged to decline the further opening of letters asking for seats. Were the auditorium twice the size it is it would not be equal to the demand for seats for first nights.
Copyright, 1891, by the New York Times.

The innovation of having the bridesmaids go down from the chancel to meet the bride at the church threshold, which Miss Robbins introduced at her wedding on Wednesday, is likely to become a popular one. Bridesmaids have always suffered, no matter how charming they may be, because they usually precede the bride and are lost in the halo of her interesting brilliancy.

William B. Norman, an auctioneer, sued Solomon Johnson in the Superior Court for breach of contract. Johnson had imported a fine lot of paintingz valued at from $20,000 to $25,000, and in November, 1889, employed Norman as auctioneer to sell them off at auction, upon the understanding that he was to have 5 per cent. commission upon the proceeds of the sale.

The New-York State Forestry Association is engaged in the earnest and intelligent promotion of a work of great public interest and importance. Some of the most prominent citizens of the State are associated with it, such men as Grover Cleveland, Morris K. Jesup, George William Curtis, Seth Low, Warner Miller, Ellis H. Roberts, Carl Schurz, the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs, William Potts, and Edward M. Shepard.

Charles S. Keene, the well-known Punch artist, who died at Hammersmith, near London, recently, had been in failing health for three years past. His last drawing for Punch appeared on May 3, 1889, a drawing which appeared in August last having been done in the previous year. One who knew Keene writes of him as follows in the Pall Mall Gazette:

Surprises have been coming out of Egypt ever since outside barbarians picked up intelligence enough to recognize that which was odd when they saw it. Even down to this day the Nile country has continued to send forth strange things, and every-day things put to unusual uses, and curious things to be used for most prosaic purposes.

People who take an interest in politics have three things conspicuously before their minds at the present time -- free coinage of silver, Mr. Hoar's "Force bill," and the possibility of the adoption of a cloture measure in the Senate. Of the last-named, it may be said that there is no good reason why the word cloture should b used to express the idea of stoppage of debate instead of the English word closure.

The wives who found in their Christmas stockings valuable scraps from their husband's check books appropriated them with varied emotions of gratitude for the liberality or disgust for the laziness of the gift according to the balance of practicality or sentiment in their composition, but they all agree in seeking the fur stores for the expenditure of the windfall.

Walk-in-the-Water was a chief of the Wyandottes, who lived with his band on the Detroit River. He was a very brave Indian, when he could feel the hard earth under his moccasins, with a path behind him for retreat when too hard pressed by the foe, but war upon the decks of a vessel was something he could not comprehend.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- The loss on the fire at John James Dobson's carpet mills last night will be about $1,500,000 and the insurance will reach about $1,000,000, and is distributed among nearly all companies doing business in Philadelphia and many in England. No one company will be disastrously affected by the heavy loss, $10,000 being about the largest policy held by the Messrs.

One after another the tricks and jobs put into the new tariff law are coming to light, and in some cases the makers of these hidden traps are beginning to boast of their smartness. Of course we are not speaking of the open increases of duty, but of the unforeseen increases that were concealed in apparently innocent changes of words and phrases and that have recently been revealed by decisions of the Treasury Department.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 17. -- The instantaneous killing of a horse by a live electric wire here this afternoon almost caused a panic among the people in Miner's Newark Theatre. The horse was attached to the theatrical express truck and was standing in Beaver Street, near the theatre, where the Stuart Robson company was playing.

It is not generally known that education in the army is compulsory, and that the determined opposition to it from the enlisted men, whom it is supposed to benefit arises from this reason. They are enlisted as soldiers, and must be twenty-one years of age at least, except in certain specified cases, such as musicians.

The National Academy of Design and the Society of American Artists will hold their several exhibitions for Spring in April and May, the younger organization three weeks later than the other. The Academy varnishing days are Thursday and Friday, April 2 and 3, the press being admitted after 12 o'clock. As usual, the galleries will not be open to the public till Monday the 6th.

The British Government takes every possible precaution to prevent the people of India from having arms to indulge in a second mutiny. As it cannot very well disarm the troops of the semi-independent Princes that are under British protection and at whose courts there are Ministers Resident, some English statesmen have hit upon a novel and presumably successful method of preventing any prolonged hostilities on the part of those Princes.

A marked characteristic of the American people from the earliest days of our national existence has been an apparent indifference to impending danger until facts become so convincing and startling as to cause a thorough arousing, when vigorous action has always followed. It is not necessary to cite facts at length to show this.

A biographer may rarely tell the entire truth about his subject, and Mr. Reid has not quite told the whole truth about Lord Houghton. By this we mean that certain eccentricities, which to an unfriendly eye might seem absurdities, do not come out. Lord Houghton's manners were often rather brusque -- indeed, we have heard people say that he had no manners.

The traffic managers of the roads in the Western Traffic Association have, after a two days' struggle with the subject, failed in the task of establishing the territorial divisions of the association. They were in session for three hours in Chicago yesterday and got no further than an informal discussion of the subject. The excuse given on Friday for not accomplishing the work was that the Great Northern Road was not represented.

The Department of Docks is next on the list of the Senate committee. It is expected that investigation will proceed at once to this department next Friday, when the committee will meet here again. The subject is a large one, for its ramifications have extended to almost every branch of the City Government, and have occupied no small amount of attention in the courts

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- At noon yesterday the Senate began a session which Mr. Hoar had announced should not be interrupted, until the Force bill was finally acted upon. At 6 o'clock to-night, just thirty hours later, Mr. Hoar moved that the Senate adjourn until 11 o'clock Monday, and the Force bill is still the pending business before the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The House Silver Pool Investigation Committee began its inquiry this morning. W.B. Stevens, the principal Washington correspondent of the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, which paper first printed the charge of a Congressional silver pool, was called to the stand as the first witness. He identified the article in the Globe-Democrat as having been prepared by himself from statements made to him by others.

In a speech at a council of Sioux Indians near Pine Ridge on Friday Lieut. TAYLOR told them, as an inducement to obey the orders of Gen. MILES, that if they did so some of them would be allowed to go to Washington "to see the Great Father and state their grievances." It would be imprudent to carry out a promise of that kind.

The American Association held a meeting yesterday and finished up business for the present. From the state of affairs it appears that the baseball war has had a tendency to teach the financial backers a lesson and they are now on the fair road to make the game a paying investment. Petty jealousies have been cast aside and baseball in the future will be run on business principles.

" There has been a great deal written about a woman's No," said my friend Smith one evening at the club, as we were smoking away the remembrance of a disastrous rubber; "but, like eternity, words fail to describe its awful potentialities."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The House Silver Pool Investigation Committee began its inquiry this morning. W.B. Stevens, the principal Washington correspondent of the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, which paper first printed the charge of a Congressional silver pool, was called to the stand as the first witness. He identified the article in the Globe-Democrat as having been prepared by himself from statements made to him by others.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Forty hours before the time called for the caucus to decide the Senatorial question half a dozen legislators are not to be found in Albany. Mr. George S. Weed and John B. Riley of Plattsburg are holding forth in Smith M. Weed's headquarters at the Delavan, and outside of their rooms the Senatorial problem is not discussed in Albany to any extent.

THE FRENCH LOUVERIE. -- Sometimes after a grande chasse the trophies of the day may number some half a dozen dead wolves, and these ugly corpses are heaped on one of the primitive Breton carts, and are thus triumphantly dragged through the streets of some town or village, amid the acclamations of the people, suggesting to the unaccustomed stranger a dream of the Middle Ages.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Jan. 17. -- An aged colored woman sat crooning to-day over the straw mattress on which lay the body of "Irish Bob" McDonald. Up in the defiles of the Ramapo Mountains two constables from Hackensack tramped through the snow and rain, hunting in vain for Philip Mann, the " Jackson-white" who beat Irish Bob two nights previous to his death.

During the second session of the present academic year at Columbia College, extending from February to May, three courses of instruction in aesthetics will be given, in accordance with the following plan:

The Weather Bureau has for a long, time been losing the public confidence, which it formerly enjoyed and deserved under a different management. Its recent eccentricities in prediction must have startled even those who trusted it least, and profoundly disgusted those who regulated their plans and movements according to its prophecies.

About every meteorological condition in the almanac was experienced in this city yesterday. The weather was full of idiosyncracies, and this in spite of the fact that the Signal Service Bureau predicted "fine weather." It is not an infrequent thing for old Boreas to refuse to conform his programme to the opinions of the Signal Service officers, but it is seldom that he takes so much pains to prove contrary as he did yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17. -- Many people here and people who live along the line of the Omaha and St. Louis Road from Pattonsburg, Mo., to Council Bluffs, Iowa, and whose memory extends back twelve or thirteen years, remember Daniel H. Solomon, a lawyer of Glenwood, Iowa, who was Secretary and Treasurer of the Council Bluffs and St. Louis Road, as the line was called during the construction period.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oklahoma, Jan. 17. -- Intense excitement was created here late last night by wild reports that the Cheyennes and Arapahoes had gone on the warpath. Nearly three hundred settlers from exposed sections came flocking into town. Couriers sent out brought information that the report was based on a charivari party. This shows the feeling of insecurity that prevails.

M. LEON SAY is among the most respected of the modern survivors of the old school of economists in France, the men who received their first impulse toward the study of political economy from the Manchester school in England, and who, through good report and evil report, through prosperity under the empire and confusion and reverses under the republic, have held to the doctrines of their teachers.

THE TWO GREAT ENGLISH POETS. -- Tennyson's earlier lyrics have a melodious tone that lingers on the ear like notes of music, and no modern poet has given to the language so many touching and graceful expressions which have passed unconsciously into the familiar speech of our people.

VANITAS VANITATUM, OMNIA VANITAS. -- The evening of the parson's working day comes at last, and he commonly finds only then the warm sympathy and the kindly regard in which his parishioners hold him. Englishmen are not demonstrative, but affection will break out at times, and a parson's death frequently arouses feelings in the heart of a parish which are an honor to human nature.

After a comparative lull in matters matrimonial, there has been a revival during the last week with the large and beautiful wedding of Harry McVickar and Miss Maud Robbins on Wednesday, several announced engagements, and the coming weddings of Mr. Schieffelin and Miss Shepherd, of Oliver Harriman and Hiss Carley, of N.L. McCready and Miss Borrowe, and of George Parsons and Miss Webb.

PINE RIDGE, S.D., Jan. 17, via Rushville, Neb. -- The council between the friendly and the hostile Indians has tended to revive the anxiety of many white people and assure the Indians that their fear of being massacred by the soldiers was without foundation. Everybody to-day seems to feel that the trouble has been brought to a close.

For the growth and extension of reform methods in popular education there is no more devoted or faithful advocate than Mrs. Mary Hargrove Simpson, publisher of the Teacher, Her journal plants progressive ideas just where they are most needed and are likely to produce the best results -- among the school teachers and educators of the country.

People, generally, are unaware that they are in danger, constant danger, of losing their liberty. But they are. Everybody is. There are degrees of this danger, of course. Persons of a certain class are in very great danger. Persons of another class are in comparatively little danger. And these people are not of the criminal class.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 17. -- Considerable interest is being manifested in political circles in Ohio, as well as among the farmers themselves, regarding the probable action of the Farmers' Alliance at its State Convention to be held at Galion next Tuesday, Jan. 20. This arises from the circumstances under which the convention will meet as well as from the past action of the farmers of the State.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Jan. 18. -- About 1 o'clock this afternoon, while the guests of the Hotel Marvin were congregated in the office and parlor waiting to be called to dinner, a tremendous explosion occurred in the dining room, which wrecked one whole side of the building, breaking every window in the house, and killing and wounding a half score of employes.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton was at his best yesterday, and his sermon, "The Theology of Music," was the most powerful of the series which he has been devoting to music and religion. The third and last will be preached at some time to be announced within a month.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18. -- E.H. Horner, the dealer in so-called European bonds of Wall Street, New-York, who was recently arrested, has been operating very extensively through agents in this section. From a gentleman whose home is in Vienna, Austria, and who has made a thorough investigation of Horner's scheme, details of the gigantic fraud are obtained.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Henry A. Allen, District Master Workman of the Knights of Labor of Michigan; Joseph D. Manlion of Troy, N.Y., Master Workman of District Assembly No. 68, and T.T. Drury of Rutland, Vt., Master Workman of District Assembly No. 200, arrived here to-day, and will begin an investigation of the accounts and financial conditions of the order generally, at the headquarters of the order, 814 North Broad Street, on Wednesday next.

The Board of Walking Delegates yesterday received a letter from the Sheldon Marble Company stating that it had not given Contractor Volkening the job for the marble work in the new Turkish baths at Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, where a strike had been ordered under a misapprehension that Mr. Volkening had the contract. The delegates said that Contractor Kilpatrick of the Edison Building had told them that Volkening had the contract.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Drs. Bertin and Picq of Nantes have recently made an interesting experiment in the treatment of consumption. Acting on the fact that goats are not subject to consumption, the doctors, after experimenting on rabbits, injected the blood of a goat into the veins of two consumptive patients, one a boy of seventeen and the other a woman of forty-seven years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- One of the most unique surgical operations on record was performed in this city to-day, and 100 Knights Templar gave to the world a notable example of fraternal love and heroic self-sacrifice, made in order that a sick brother might be restored to health. These Knights each suffered the loss of a piece of cuticle which was transferred to Sir Knight John Dickerson.

There is no truth in the sensational stories about a quarrel between Prince Bismarck and the Emperor William respecting the memoirs which the ex-Chancellor proposes presently to publish. The fact is that Prince Bismarck has scarcely completed the arrangement of his vast accumulation of papers of all sorts and descriptions, so that he has not yet commenced to write (or dictate) his contemplated work.

-- The Table. How to Buy Food, How to Cook It, and How to Serve It. By Alessandro Filippini. New-York: Charles L. Webster Co. -- This is the magnum opus of cook books. We have been educated, and in our turn we have given encouragement to culinary artists, and so we have really become past perfect.

NYACK, Jan. 18. -- Newspaper men from this place, and others representing metropolitan journals, scoured Clarkstown, the home of Assemblyman Demarest, last evening in search of the "Little Giant," for the purpose of an interview with him, but he was not there and information reached this place last night that the Assemblyman was then on his way to Albany, where he would be secure under the protecting wing of Gov. Hill.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- E.B. Hemmingway of Whitney's Point, N.Y., who fled in December 1889, was arrested at Cortland, N.Y., late Saturday night, and will be brought to this city to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18. -- Sufficient progress has been made with the movement for the reformation and purification of the Republican Party affairs to develop what it really means. It is a well-known fact that for years Chauncey I. Filley has controlled the party machine and has run it on the rule-or-ruin policy. It is also well known that the Globe-Democrat has bitterly fought Filley and incidentally opposed the work and methods of his committee.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 18. -- The usual affidavits from stool pigeons of the lottery company stating that they held certain tickets and won the larger prizes of $300,000 and $100,000 will not appear this month, as the prizes were scaled, and only one-fourth of each ticket was sold.

Those interested in Egyptian archaeology will be glad to know that a movement has been set on foot to make an archaeological survey of Egypt, that a fund for the purpose has been started, and that work has already begun.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- There is to be a most rigorous protest against free silver by the business and other interests in Boston this week. Yesterday afternoon Mayor Matthews issued a call for a conference at the Mayor's office at noon to-morrow to consider the advisability of holding a public meeting to protest against the free coinage of silver.

The programme of the Thomas concert last night was especially attractive to musical students by the juxtaposition of Schubert, in his "B minor March," Mendelssohn in the "Meoresstitle" overture, and Beethoven in the delicious larghetto of the "Second Symphony." All these were admirably played.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Post prints the following: "Secretary Noble talked freely yesterday of the Indian situation, and, now that the trouble is practically over, what policy should be pursued by the Government in its treatment of the Indians in the future. First of all, he believed the Indians had no legitimate use for firearms, and, therefore, should be required to dispose of them.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 18. -- Dr. Jacob H. Gallinger, having received a unanimous nomination for the United States Senatorship by the Republican caucus held last Thursday, will probably be elected day after to-morrow to represent New-Hampshire in the United States Senate for a term of six years, beginning March 4, 1891.

In a recent number of the Nineteenth Century the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, member of Parliament, asks what must be to patriotic, conservative, precedent-loving Britishers a startling, if not, indeed, an impertinent and wholly unnecessary question, to wit: "Shall we Americanize our institutions?"

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 18. -- At 1 o'clock to-day Judge James A. Warder, late Republican candidate for State Supreme Judge and now City Attorney of Chattanooga, shot and killed his son-in-law. S.M. Fugette, cashier of the South Chattanooga Savings Bank, seriously wounded his daughter, Mrs. Fugette, and was fatally wounded by Fugette.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The army and navy officers who have been detailed as Special Commissioners to carry the invitations from the Government of the United States to the other American republics and the West Indian colonies to participate in the Columbian Exposition have received their letters of credence and instructions from the Department of State and will start on their missions at once.

FLEMINGTON, N.J. Jan. 18. -- Yesterday's severe rainstorm caused high water at many places in this section. Beaver Brook, coursing through Clinton, overflowed its banks this morning and flooded the lower streets of the village, filling cellars with debris and ruining carpets and furniture. The south branch of the Baritan rose to a height not reached before in five years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Before the end of the present month, the President will be called upon to devote his attention to the selection of a new Colonel Commandant of the Marine Corps, as Col. Charles G. McCawley, the present head of the corps, will retire Jan. 29. For some time Col. McCawley has not been able to attend to the duties of the office, and Col. C.D. Hebb has been the Acting Commandant.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Reports of "limited" corporations are being filed with the Secretary of State. The following have made statements:

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Jan. 18. -- A convention of prominent squaw men of the Chickasaw Nation was held in Purcell a few days ago for the purpose of formulating a plan to get rid of the newspaper, published in that nation, which have been advocating the allotment of lands in severalty and Statehood for the Indian nation.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Reports of snowstorms and increasing cold weather come from various parts of the Continent. In France the Gironde is covered with ice floes, and heavy snowstorms are reported in various sections of the country. Communication between Lyons and Savoy is completely cut off, all the roads being blocked by snow.

The home of the Hapsburgs -- a gray hill castle in a poor Swiss lordship, so Carlyle described it -- is almost in the market. Three efforts have been made to secure it for the heirs of its first owner. They have all failed, but the record of them is honorable. First, the officers of the Austro-Hungarian army wished to present the property to their King.

The sending back of a large part of the troops at Pine Ridge to their stations and the simultaneous return of some of the Sioux and Cheyennes to their own agencies show that the Winter campaign in Dakota is believed to be over. Alarms may still occasionally be sounded among the excited frontiersmen, especially among those who profit by the presence of a large number of troops

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 18. -- A negro barber named Monday McFarland was arrested yesterday on a charge of being the murderer of John Sheedy, a wealthy gambler, who was assassinated last week. McFarland, while entering his residence to-day, confessed the crime, stating that he was hired by Mrs. Sheedy to commit the deed. He was to be paid $20,000.

HARTFORD, Jan. 18. -- The Republican attempt to capture the State offices will be resumed here on Tuesday with the presentation by the House Select Committee on the Canvass of Votes for State Officers of a report that, after the examination of matters extrinsic to and explanatory of the official returns, they find that there is no election of State officers by the people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- It is difficult for an outside observer to see any justification for Republican boasting over the result of the thirty hours' struggle upon the Force bill which ended last night.

Members of the New-York Jockey Club may congratulate themselves that their new clubhouse at Morris Park will be completed and ready for occupancy May 1. Mr. Alfred Hennin Morris, of the firm of J.A. A.H. Morris, and Mr. Frank M. Pirsson, Chairman of the Athletic Committee of the New-York Jockey Club, entertained a score of gentlemen at luncheon in the new clubhouse yesterday, and subsequently gave their guests an opportunity of inspecting the structure.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 18. -- Senator John B. Gordon returned to Atlanta yesterday, and at once authorized the statement that he was going to join the Farmers' Alliance and intended to champion the cause of that order in the United States Senate.

A report made public by the Reform Club of this city states that in January, 1890, the club began its systematic canvass by tariff reform discussions held in the villages and hamlets of such rural counties of the State as it considered most in need of such treatment -- that is, of those which were apparently the most thoroughly wedded to protection.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- For some time prior to Nov. 23, 1883, Nathan Klein conducted a large collar and shirt factory in this city. In the preceding February his manufactory, then in the Burdett Building, on River Street, was destroyed by fire. Heavy losses were sustained according to the proofs filed with the insurance companies, and they settled, although they had some doubts about the origin of the fire.

TRALEE, Jan. 18. -- Mr. Parnell was received here with mingled groans and cheers. Replying to addresses presented to him, he said that he had done his part toward the solution of the Irish problem, when he had the conferences with Mr. O'Brien, and the subsequent delay in arriving at a settlement of the difficulty was entirely the fault of others.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 18. -- Col. W.C. Jones, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who has been in this city for the past week studying the Senatorial situation, says that he believes there is a good chance for the election of a Democrat to succeed Ingalls.

A regular monthly meeting of the Alumna Association of Rutgers Female College will be held at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the college parlors, 56 West Fifty-fifth Street. A full attendance is requested, as important business is come before the meeting. At 3 o'clock Mrs. Fannie M.C. Harris of Brooklyn will make an address upon "The Fads of the Day; How to Get Good Out of Them."

Miss Olive Schreiner's volume of "Dreams," in which Mr. Fisher Unwin has collected some of her allegories, is dated from Matjesfontein, Cape Colony. Miss Schreiner's home is in one of the beautiful suburbs of Capetown. But Matjesfontien is a strange little oasis in the desert karoo, through which the railway runs from the Cape to Kimberley.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- A determined effort will be made this Winter to amend the ballot-reform law. So far the attempt is confined to the Republicans. If there is Democratic opposition to the bill in its present form it has not yet manifested itself. Of course the proposed changes cannot be effected without the aid of the Democrats.

The proposal to equip Alaska with a full Territorial Government, including a Legislature and a more extensive judicial system, will perhaps find favor in Congress, now that the census report credits her with 38,000 people. There are drawbacks, however, to ambitions of this sort, in the imposition of taxes, from which she has thus far been free.

We published yesterday a very full statement of the condition of things in the New-York Board of Education and the probabilities of any reform in the immediate future. Briefly, it may be said that the hope of reform for the present lies with the President, Mr. HUNT. He has the appointment of the standing committees of the board.

Lieut. C.P. Terret, United States Army, has completed his arrangements for establishing the rendezvous post here. There is a belief among some people that Uncle Sam's army is composed of the riff-raff of the earth and of tough characters generally. Lieut Terret is frequently accosted with some such remark as this by prominent citizens: "With our large floating population, you ought to get a large number of recruits in Savannah.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY. Jan. 18, via Rushville. -- This morning about a dozen more arms were turned in to Capt. Pierce by the hostiles. They informed him that a systematic search was being made in their tepees for weapons, and those found would be turned over to-morrow. The exact number of guns surrendered cannot be ascertained from the custodian, though the latter places the number at about five hundred.

Nearly all the amendments to the Ballot Registration and Corrupt Practices acts which have been submitted in the Senate at Albany, a summary of which is printed in another column, are intended to improve the law in various details in accordance with suggestions afforded by the experience of the last election.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 18. -- As Spring approaches, the interest in the trotter is growing rapidly. Breeders have nearly all made arrangements for breeding the coming season, and the books of many of the leading stallions in the country are already full. Never before in the history of trotting horse breeding has there been such an array of stallions offered for public service as there is this year.

-- Charles E. Merrill Co. have ready the first two volumes of the authorized American edition of Ruskin's works, which comes from the press of George Allen, Mr. Ruskin's publisher. These volumes are "The Seven Lamps of Architecture" and "The Two Paths." To each work Prof. Charles Eliot Norton contributes an introduction.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 18. -- The visit of State Treasurer Elliot F. Danforth of Albany, N.Y., to North Carolina to work up a" Hill boom" has already been told in THE TIMES. Another agent of Gov. Hill has also made visits to the Tar Heel State for the purpose, probably, of verifying an impression which the Governor may have received as to the feelings of the Democracy of this State generally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Mr. Bancroft's funeral will take place to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock at St. John's Church, its rector, the Rev. Dr. Douglass, conducting the services. In accordance with Mr. Bancroft's wish there will be no military services in connection with the funeral, but the Secretary of the Navy and other officers of the department will be present in a body.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day handed down an opinion affirming the judgment of the Circuit Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Virginia, directing that a writ of habeas corpus be granted to William Rebman, convicted in Norfolk of violation of the State meat inspection law.

Austin Corbin has a rapid-transit scheme. He sent yesterday to the Rapid-Transit Commissioners a pamphlet, with maps descriptive of the plan, which provides for an underground road, the level of the first section of which has been fixed at 110 feet below the surface. Mr. Corbin also filed articles of incorporation in Albany yesterday for an organization for the construction of a tunnel from Whitehall Street in this city to Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn.

A motley gathering of bookmakers, horse owners, jockeys, trainers, and sporting men in the Chambers Street ferry house yesterday forenoon gazed intently at the following placard posted in a conspicuous place: "There will be no racing at Clifton to-day." The ferrymaster said the notice was posted at the request of George Engeman, the proprietor of the race track.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- The Merchants' National Bank, one of the strongest in the city, was the correspondent of the American National of Kansas City. Inquiries at the bank this afternoon elicited the information that the Merchants' will lose nothing by the failure.
DENVER, Col., Jan. 19. -- Henry L. Teller was unanimously chosen in the Republican caucus to-day for United States Senator.

Some two hundred and fifty guests attended the ball given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at their home, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, last night. A heavy tapestry curtain separated the entrance vestibule from the central hallway, and rose as each guest entered. This hallway, the drawing room, and the library were given over to the dancers. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Mr. Jacob Ridgway Moore led the cotillion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- "L'Africaine," an operetta not by Meyerbeer, was performed to-night at the Lincoln Music Hall by a company of ladies and gentlemen unused to the stage, who appeared in costumes prepared under the supervision of the Misses Hunt, daughters of the late William M. Hunt. The performance was given for the benefit of the Home for Incurables.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- The Democratic members of the Legislature of the State of New-York, in caucus assembled, nominated this afternoon Gov. David B. Hill as United States Senator, to succeed William Maxwell Evarts, Republican, whose term of office will expire on March 4 next. Within half an hour thereafter the Republican members of the Legislature renominated Mr. Evarts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The United States Supreme Court, through Justice Blatchford, to-day rendered an opinion confirming the Judgment of the Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, in the suit for an injunction brought by the city of St. Louis and the St. Louis, Kansas City and Colorado Railroad Company against the Wabash Pacific Railroad Company.

The serious character of the Chilean insurrection is no longer a matter of question, in spite of the denials at first made. The fact is that political troubles have been going on in that republic more than a year, as the scenes in the Chilean Congress last January showed. Riots have since then occurred in departments where the General Government was accused of interfering with and controlling elections.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., Jan. 19, via Rushville, Neb. -- There is increasing nervousness noticeable among the Indians, occasioned by the difficulty the Indians experienced in agreeing upon the question of turning over their arms, submitting to the degradation of the several tribes, and the manner in which they are to be treated by the Government.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 19. -- The American National Bank of this city was taken charge of this morning by F.E. Marshal, National Bank Examiner for the State of Missouri. The capital stock of the bank is $1,250,000. No statement of the liabilities or assets can be obtained. To the Associated Press correspondent Examiner Marshal said this morning: "There is absolutely nothing to say, except that the bank is in my charge."
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19. -- Speaker Bergen announced his committees to-night, and Hudson County is hard hit. The list of standing committees is as follows:

ELIZABETH, Jan. 19. -- Judge Van Syckel today, in the Union County Court, sentenced the New-Jersey Jockey Club and Linden Park Association to each pay a fine of $500 and costs for keeping a disorderly house by allowing bookmaking on the tracks. The Judge spoke in strong terms, and said if the defendants did not take warning from this the law would impose a more salutary punishment.

It is not to be supposed that the Irish Parliamentary Party will accept any compromise by which PARNELL will retire from the leadership on a condition of being allowed to name his successor. A particular objection has been raised against Mr. DILLON because he is liable at any time to arrest and imprisonment.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- The insurances on the burned carpet mills of John and James Dobson aggregate nearly $725,000, and the policies are divided among the following companies:

Southern reminiscences, Southern music, Southern cordiality, and a loyal Union sentiment were the controlling elements of an enthusiastic banquet given in the New-York Hotel last night by the Veteran Confederate Camp of this city. Nearly 150 ex-Confederates sat down to the handsomely-decorated tables in the large dining room of the hotel, and as their guests there were several distinguished Union soldiers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- A report reached here at 1 o'clock this morning to the effect that a constable from Rockland County had come to Albany and arrested Assemblyman Frank P. Demarest on a new charge. At the Stanwix, where Demarest has been registered since last night, it was said he had surrendered his room. Up to 1:30 o'clock Demarest had not been brought to Police Headquarters, and nothing was known of him there.

Two or three private dispatches were received in Wall Street from Chicago yesterday saying that the Chicago and Alton Railroad and the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Railroad had abandoned their attitude of hostility to the new Western Traffic Association and would probably join the organization. Such dispatches were commonly regarded as expressing more of hope than of fact.

The experience of one election under the new ballot law of this State has revealed a number of points in which it can be improved, and already several amendments have been introduced in the Senate. There is no reason why there should be any party division on the question of making the law simpler in its operation and more effective for the purpose of protecting the secrecy and the purity of the ballot.

When we noticed the long and very interesting confession of the Chicago Inter Ocean as to the falsity of its repeated assertion that "prices have not gone up on account of the McKinley bill or on account of anything else" -- a confession that covered several columns of our repentant contemporary on Jan. 1 -- we expressed a hope that nothing would induce the Inter Ocean to backslide.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 19. -- The 19th of January being the birthday of Gen. Robert E. Lee, is now a legal holiday in Georgia. To-day not only were all the banks and business houses here closed, but the Post Office, by order of Gen. Lewis, a one-armed Union veteran, who is Postmaster, observed holiday hours. From all parts of the State come reports of similar observances.

MONTREAL, Jan. 19. -- The wholesale dry goods firm of McLachlan Brothers is financially embarrassed, and if it goes into liquidation the amount involved will be between $600,000 and $700,000. It is by no means certain that the firm will be obliged to take this extreme step, but if it does the assets are so considerable that the creditors will be well covered.
LONDON, Jan. 19. -- The latest advices received here from Chile show that there is no improvement in the state of affairs.

For the forthcoming annual report of the Chamber of Commerce Mr. George Wilson, Secretary of the Chamber, has prepared some interesting statistics bearing on the foreign commerce of the port of New-York for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1890. A very large increase in the trade is shown, particularly in the imports.

PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 19. -- In the celebration of the birthday of Gen. Robert E. Lee the people of Petersburg to-day paid a noble tribute to the memory of the great Confederate Captain. It was here that Gen. Lee had his headquarters during the memorable siege that ended in the capture of the city, and the people knew and loved him.

The recently-formed Hanover Club of Brooklyn celebrated the opening of its new clubhouse on Bedford Avenue and Rodney Street last night. The new clubhouse, formerly the Hawley mansion, is a substantial building of brick trimmed with brownstone. It was bought for $27,500 and is excellently adapted to club purposes. An extension has been constructed in which the billiard room and main reception room are situated.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 19. -- When Calvin S. Brice made a speech here at the Democratic State Convention, he made every effort to hear John H. Thomas's sores over the result of the Senatorial fight, and alluded to him as "my distinguished friend, the Hon. John H. Thomas, whose democracy is as broad as his hospitality, and that is saying a great deal."

The second annual exhibition of the Poultry and Pigeon Association, which is to begin at Madison Square Garden Feb. 4, promises many new and interesting features which the officers of the association hope will prove an incentive to a wider appreciation of poultry culture in this vicinity. A meeting of the Committee of Arrangements was held yesterday at Madison Square Garden, and the plans for the exhibition were thoroughly discussed.

How careless church people habitually are in regard to fire in church buildings is demonstrated by the report of the Survey Bureau of the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters, which charges that there are sixty-six churches in this city, Brooklyn, and Jersey City that have defective heating apparatus and are otherwise so equipped as to increase the danger of conflagration.

At the Grand Opera House an audience which about two-thirds filled the theatre gave close upon three hours' undivided attention to the "story of New-York police life," which Mr. Will R. Wilson, the author of the melodrama, has entitled" The Inspector." The majority of the spectators were seemingly impressed with the supposition that they recognized the "life-like" portraitures of the play, and the applause was frequently vociferous.

It is one of the curiosities of current politics that when Gov. HILL takes his seat in the United States Senate, he will be forced, by circumstances entirely beyond his control, immediately to assume a position on at least one of the committees in which his peculiar capacity will hardly fit him to shine.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- Rumors are rife in this part of Rockland County concerning Assemblyman Demarest's mad career, and it is reported that large deficiencies have been discovered in his accounts.

Mr. AUSTIN CORBIN has a rapid-transit plan which is a sort of obverse to that suggested by Mr. DAVID H. KING, except that he proposes to connect it with Brooklyn and Jersey City by tunnels under the rivers. Mr. KING does not believe in underground tunnels, but suggests viaduct lines near the two rivers and a central line near Broadway.

TRENTON, Jan. 20. -- Both houses sat for a little time this morning and then brought the sitting to an end for the week. The net result of their week's work was the creation of five new doorkeepers for the Assembly Chamber, and it is said that there are now three men to hang to every doorknob.

The one matter of any importance in Congress at present seems to be the Force bill. It not only occupies the time and attention of the Senate, but while there is any chance of its passage in that body the Democrats of the House are bound to block business there in order that there may be as much trouble as possible in getting it through the lower branch.

Controller WEMPLE in his annual report joins in the ignorant cry about personal property not bearing "its equitable and fair share of taxation" and real estate being "overburdened," and argues like others of his kind as though owners of real estate and of personal property were two separate and distinct classes of persons and taxes were paid only by those from whom they are collected by public officers.

DUBLIN, Jan. 20. -- Mr. Timothy D. Healy, M.P., delivered a lecture yesterday evening at Mullingar, and a riotous scene was the result. A strong force of sympathizers with Mr. Parnell gathered outside the hall during the course of the lecture, and threats of violence toward Mr. Healy were freely uttered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The funeral of George Bancroft took place this morning at 11 o'clock at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, opposite Lafayette Square, and was attended by a large gathering.

Fighting was the order of the closing hours of the French ball in the Madison Square Garden yesterday morning. Pugilism was rampant, and between 2:30 and 4:30 o'clock there were at least a dozen personal encounters. Neither the managers nor the members of the Cercle Francais de l'Harmonie were responsible for these reprehensible exhibitions of rowdyism. All the trouble was caused by outsiders fighting among themselves.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 20. -- The statistics of the Grand Masonic Lodge of this State, which will hold its annual conclave at New-Haven to-morrow, will show a larger death rate in the order during the past year than has been known before in the history of Connecticut Freemasonry. The total number of deaths was 254, being at least 100 in excess of the usual figures.

Some days ago it was reported that the Window-Glass Trust had been dissolved, owing to some difficulty about the payment of the sums assessed upon the several manufacturers. This was the combination which was formed while MCKINLEY was making his Tariff bill, and for the benefit of which he caused to be inserted in the new law at almost the last moment a proviso requiring importers to use small packing boxes.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The annual report of Controller Wemple, transmitted to the Legislature to-day, shows that in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 last there was received into the Treasury from all sources the sum of $18,219,399.49, and paid therefrom in the same period $17,416,854.70. For the current year the State tax is $8,619,748.17, the rate being 2.34 mills, and the valuation of property $3,683,653,062, the tax to be devoted as follows:

There is by no means so much confidence in the passage of a Free-Coinage bill by this Congress as there was a week ago. Indeed, the most active of the free-coinage advocates are beginning to talk of getting an amended bill through the House. The amendment they contemplate is one limiting coinage to American silver by one contrivance or another.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20. -- Kalakaua, King of the Hawaiian Islands, died at the Palace Hotel in this city at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon. There had been no hope of the King's recovery since Sunday, though his alarming condition was not generally known until last evening, when the attending physicians announced that his malady was Bright's disease of the kidneys and urmia.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 20. -- The Republican Senatorial voters made a poor showing at the session called this afternoon for the election of a United States Senator. The result was a great disappointment to Representative Taggart, who seemed hopeful a few days ago of defeating the re-election of Cameron. He then spoke of a probable Republican defection of thirty-three votes, which would have been more than enough to accomplish his purpose.

" The School for Scandal" never had a handsomer dress than that given to it by Mr. Daly in the revival now on view. It is not possible in this necessarily short notice to give an adequate idea of the ingenuity and beauty of the stage pictures, which lack nothing that good taste and a wise and generous expenditure of money could provide.

That the theology of the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs is acceptable to the students of Union Theological Seminary was apparent at his inauguration as the Edward Robinson Professor of Biblical Theology in the chapel of the institution, 700 Park Avenue, last night. They applauded long and loudly when the professor arose to make his address, and continued their marks of approval during his speech.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The Democratic politicians in town are very nervous to-night. The absence to-day of three Democratic members from the formal balloting in each house -- the joint and decisive convention occurs to-morrow -- has created the greatest uneasiness, and the fear that the Republicans may practice a trick which will prevent the election of David B. Hill as Mr. Evarts's successor is not concealed.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20. -- Amateurs from New-York, Philadelphia, Washington, and Boston gave "L'Africaine" this afternoon at the Academy of Music. The theatre was crowded to its limit. All Baltimore society was there, the audience numbering 2,500. The performance went much more smoothly than the usual efforts of amateurs, and applause was loud and frequent. The orchestra was led by Marquis Imperially, Secretary of the Italian Legation, and Mr. Van Rennselaer played second violin.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 20. -- A special to the Star from Atchison, Kan., says: "The Bank of Downs, at Downs, Mitchell County, Kan., closed its doors this morning. It was connected with the American National Bank of Kansas City, which failed yesterday. The liabilities and assets cannot be ascertained."

Senator QUAY is said to have abandoned his purpose to resign his place in the Senate and seek some more "vindication" at the hands of the Legislature of Pennsylvania. The exposure of his little scheme in our Harrisburg dispatches has disturbed his plans, and there seems to be some doubt whether the "pipe" he had laid so carefully would be found in working order.

The seventeenth annual public meeting of the New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice was held last night in Association Hall, at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. An unusual feature of the meeting was the presence of a large number of ladies, it being the first time that they have been invited to the public meetings of this society.

Secretary Windom's manifest determination to remove the Custom House to the so-called Bowling Green site still encounters the united opposition of all the principal banks and banking houses in and near Wall Street. The argument of the bankers is that the removal of the Custom House to Bowling Green would naturally be followed by the removal of the Sub-Treasury and Assay Office to the same location.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 20. -- Governor-elect Robert J. Reynolds was inaugurated at Dover to-day in the presence of as many people as could crowd into the Court House Hall, where the ceremonies were held. The inauguration was preceded by a parade of the First Regiment, the Governor-elect and members of the Legislature heading the line in carriages. By reason of sickness Gov. Biggs was unable to be present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The second State dinner at the White House was given this evening at 7:30 o'clock to the diplomatic corps. At each plate were five wine glasses. The dinner to-night was marked by the absence of boutonnieres or bouquets for the guests. President Harrison escorted Mrs. Blaine, who sat at his right, Mme. Romero occupying the place at his left.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- All the train dispatchers and operators employed by the Chicago and Erie Road, formerly the Chicago and Atlantic, struck at 10 o'clock to-night. The places of the dispatchers were promptly filled by officers of the road, who will dispatch trains until new men can be secured. It is expected by the management that a number of trainmen will also strike.

W.T. Bowman, formerly a traveling salesman for the Eyelet Button Hole Machine Company, Union Square, was yesterday held for trial by Justice Ford on a charge of larceny.
