Last August Bowman was furnished with a bag of samples and $100 for expenses, He started on a tour for the company, and he was not again heard of until yesterday, when he was arrested in the Ashland House by Detective Kemp.
The annual meeting of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company was held at the office of the company in Philadelphia yesterday. The annual report of President Wilbur was submitted and ratified.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 20. -- The Junior promenade, the great social event of the year at Yale, took place to-night in the Second Regiment Armory, which was handsomely decorated with silk, plush, lace, and bunting. The predominating color was dark-red, relieved by gold medalions on a blue background. The windows were concealed by lace curtains of the Eygptian style, surmounted with the Eygptian shields.

Against the remonstrance and to the great confusion of the plans of the editor of the Sun, Gov. HILL decides to go to the United States Senate, and the Sun promptly throws him overboard. Every just and sympathetic man will say, "served him right." For in truth, the treatment of this DANA by this HILL has been ungrateful and inhuman.
The sixth annual Ihpetonga ball was held last night in the art and assembly rooms of the Academy of Music in Brooklyn, about 300 persons being present.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 20. -- The two houses or the legislature voted for United States Senator to-day. George Graham Vest was reelected. The Republicans voted for Samuel M. Headlee of Greene County.

GALION, Ohio, Jan. 20. -- One thousand farmers and about five hundred Knights of Labor are gathered in this town discussing the financial problem and trying to devise a plan whereby the laboring classes of the United States may be placed upon an equal footing with the capitalists in the matter of taxation and citizenship. The two organizations meet separately, but a very friendly feeling exists.

Important action was taken yesterday afternoon at the special meeting of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees toward reducing the friction of travel between the two cities. The meeting, which was held at the Trustees' regular headquarters, Washington and Nassau Streets, Brooklyn, was a large one, but three Trustees being absent. The business on hand was the report of the Board of Experts appointed to devise means of increasing the facilities.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Fully 1,000 persons attended the shooting tournament at Freehold to-day between the Riverside Gun Club of Red Bank and the Freehold, Dayton, and New-Brunswick Gun Clubs. The Red Bank Club won. Although a valuable silver pitcher and a half dozen cups were offered as a prize, the contest virtually decided the championship of Eastern New-Jersey.

The shareholders of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad held their annual meeting at the offices of the company, 16 Exchange Place, yesterday. More than 400,000 shares of stock were represented and Directors were elected as follows: Thomas P. Fowler, Joseph Price, Samuel Barton, Francis R. Culbert, John Greenough, Richard Irvin, William H. Paulding, H. Pearson, Albert S. Roe, Charles J. Russell, E.K. Sibley, Charles S, Whelan, and John B. Kerr.
BOSTON, Jan. 21. -- Erastus Wiman of New-York attended the banquet of the Boot and Shoe Club this evening and spoke on reciprocity, the new hope of New-England. He said in part:

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 21. -- James S. Hogg, who was inaugurated Governor of Texas yesterday, sent his first message to the Legislature to-day. As Mr. Hogg was nominated on the Railway Commission issue, what he has to say about the railroads is already well known. Suffice it to say, Texas will have a commission patterned closely after the Georgia commission.

The House yesterday was enlivened by one of those animated discussions between the Chair and the floor that would not have been possible a year ago when Mr. REED was laboring under the delusion that he was a kind of Cromwell, with a divine mission for suppressing impertinent "deliberative bodies."

To-day the Chief of Ordnance of the Army, Brig. Gen. STEPHEN V. BENET, retires from active service, having reached the age limit of sixty-four years. A native of Florida, and a graduate of the Military Academy in 1849, where he stood third in his class, he at once joined the Ordnance Corps and has ever since remained in it.

Wells, Fargo Co.'s "Annual Report of Precious Metals" for the year 1890 shows production during the year in the States and Territories west of the Missouri River, including British Columbia, as follows: Gold, $32,156,916; silver, $62,930,831; copper, $20,569,092; lead, $11,509,571; total, $127,166,410. In making the estimates of the values of the several metals silver has been rated at $1.04 per ounce, copper at 14 cents per pound, and lead at $4.30 per hundredweight.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- The thirteenth annual meeting of the National Guard Association took place to-day. The Rev. Dr. Newland Maynard opened with prayer and Col. Samuel L. Welch followed with the President's address. Col. Welch sharply criticised the so-called Veteran Reserve bill.

The Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday declared unanimously and with great emphasis in favor of the construction of the new Croton dam recommended by Chief Engineer FTELEY and the retention of the present Aqueduct Commission unchanged until its important task shall have been completed.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 21. -- The General Assembly of Tennessee to-day put itself on record concerning the Election bill now pending in the United States Senate and the question of the State's representation at the World's Fair in the city of Chicago. Among the resolutions presented in the Senate this morning was the following, bearing the signature of Senator McCorkle:

Manager H.C. Miner has received a letter from David Belasco closing an agreement for the services of that playwright for the new Fifth Avenue Theatre, when it is constructed. Mr. Belasco will supervise all productions at the new house and all his plays will be presented there.

Our "business Congress" continues to show a singular lack of business qualities. The sessions of both houses yesterday were marked by that "sweet do-nothing" to which we called attention two or three days ago. The opening hour of the Senate was consumed by a powerful debate, mainly between Mr. GORMAN and Mr. ALDRICH, on the question whether the Journal for the previous day was correct.
The following additional amounts on account of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection were reported yesterday by Mr. Charles Lanier, General Treasurer, 17 Nassau Street:

The Senate was held in continuous session yesterday for fourteen weary hours in a vain attempt by the Republicans to get a quorum to do the business that had been laid out for them. The Democrats were ready and anxious to attend to any of the legitimate measures before the Senate, but they steadily refused to make a quorum to enable the Republicans to adopt the gag rule.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21. -- The body of the late King Kalakaua was embalmed last night, and today the remains were placed in a metal casket, hermetically sealed, and conveyed to the mortuary chapel of Trinity Church, where they are guarded by a detail from the United States Army forces here. The remains will not lie in state and will not be exhibited to the public.
Here is a significant passage from the brief but telling speech of EDWARD ATKINSON in Faneuil Hall on Tuesday afternoon:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The ordering of Assistant Adjt. Gen. McKeever to duty in Chicago as Adjutant General on the staff of Gen. Miles has excited some comment in the War Department to-day. There would be nothing unusual in the ordering of an officer of Gen. McKeever's rank to this post were it not for the peculiar circumstances under which the order was issued and the chain of events that led up to it.

The meeting of the Board of Education yesterday was attended by a larger number of spectators than has been seen in the hall of the board for many a day. The Board of Trustees of the Tenth Ward schools sent in the nomination of Nathan S. Levy to be Trustee in place of Joseph Bellows. Action upon it was deferred.

Had the bright electric lights in Delmonico's banquet hall suddenly become extinguished last night the room would not have been darkened, for the flashing gems worn by 200 members of the New-York Jewelers' Board of Trade would have made the illumination as bright as was Col. Ingersoll's wit.

There is on foot among New-York artists a movement of great importance. It is nothing less than the establishment in this country, with headquarters in this city, of a National Salon of Art, similar to the Royal Academy of England and the Paris Salon of France, which shall bring together once in every three years the best works of American art in a national exhibition, to be given in the Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Speaker Reed mounted his high horse again to-day, and after the fashion that he made unpopular last Summer he undertook to prove that the House is no place for deliberation. He attempted to drive through the District of Columbia Appropriation bill under a rule from the Committee on Rules to shut off debate and compel a vote at 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

There was a time when love made the world go around; soon it will be electricity. Recently THE TIMES described a simple electric apparatus by which housewife, without getting out of bed, could awaken the cook in the morning and tell her just what to cook for breakfast and how to cook it, said cook being in bed in a remote part of the house.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 21. -- The tenth annual convention of the National Association of General Baggage Agents met here this afternoon. There were about one hundred delegates present. The meetings will be held with closed doors. Officers will be elected for the ensuing year and the following matters discussed:

Before Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday there was put on trial a suit which has been dragging along in the course for several years, and is one of several complicated actions which followed the death of Mlle. Russell of the millinery firm of Moschowitz Russell of this city and Paris, which did a large business prior to 1880.

It was predicted in these columns when the players of baseball undertook to be their own managers that their experiment would come to be a disastrous failure, and that its worst consequences would fall upon themselves. The prediction was not one upon the fulfillment of which anybody could be entitled to plume himself.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Secretary and Mrs. Rask gave a Cabinet dinner this evening at which the guests were President and Mrs. Harrison, Attorney General and Mrs. Miller, Postmaster General and Mrs. Wanamaker, Secretary of Interior and Mrs. Noble, Senator and Mrs. Frye, Senator and Mrs. Spooner, Senator Sawyer, and Mrs. Howard G. White.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Lord Salisbury delivered a political address at Cambridge to-day. In the course of his remarks he said that his Parliamentary opponents had furnished him a merry Christmas. They executed transformation scenes with great versatility, but the importance of events in which they participated had been exaggerated.

Sensational as have been the developments all through the now famous contest over the will of Robert Ray Hamilton carried on by Evangeline L. Steele, or Parsons, or Mann, or Brill, who wrecked the brilliant young Assemblyman's life and claims to be his widow, the proceedings yesterday were so startling as fairly to dumfound even those who have been listening to the case throughout.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Mr. Thomas C. Platt, who took particular pains to promulgate through one of his official papers a week ago the fact that the Republicans would never surrender on the rapid-transit question, must have changed his mind, for to-day his friends in the Senate abdicated and left the field to the New-York City authorities.

The tactics employed by Gov. HILL to secure the unanimous vote of the Democratic members of the Legislature for the United States Senatorship have been in accord with the tricky methods that have characterized his entire political career. There can be little doubt now that he had made up his mind to go to the Senate long before the present session of the Legislature began.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The first official information received by this Government of the death of King Kalakaua was conveyed in the following note from the Hawaiian Minister to the Secretary of State:

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 21. -- Senator Orville H. Platt was re-elected for his third term in the United States Senate at the joint assembly of the Legislature here to-day, the vote being a strictly party one. Ex-Congressman Carlos French received the votes of all the Democratic members, the figures being 141 votes for Platt and 134 for French.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- At 11:30 o'clock this morning the Assembly Chamber presented a curious scene. It was within half an hour of the time set by law for the election of a United States Senator. The great chamber was packed as it never was before. Ladies were crowded and jostled and pushed in their efforts to get through the gate at the rear, and were forced to stand after all.

Mr. Daly's production of his revised version of "The School for Scandal" was submitted to the Judgment of the ladies yesterday afternoon, and the verdict was prompt and unanimous. Every new play at Daly's may be said to have two first performances, the first on the Tuesday evening of its production and the second at the matinee on Wednesday, and the matinee is a fair test of the success of the piece.

If variety were always spice, nothing could be more spicy than the ignorance displayed in the comments of English papers upon American affairs. It is most noteworthy just now in connection with the recent Indian troubles. The only incident in these that seems to have attracted attention is the fight at Wounded Knee, which is almost uniformly treated as a bloodthirsty and wanton massacre.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 21. -- William E. Chandler met his second great reverse of the season to-day, when, in joint legislative convention, after the election of Dr. Gallinger, his hated rival, as United States Senator for six years from the 4th of March next was duly proclaimed and the election of State officers was proceeded with, his candidate for State Printer was defeated by combination of Democrats and bolting Republicans.
DOVER, Del., Jan. 21. -- Gov. Reynolds this morning commissioned Garrett J. Hart of Wilmington Adjutant General of State Militia, to succeed Gen. R.D. Kenny of Dover.

BOSTON, Jan. 22. -- The Republican Club of Massachusetts, it is said, recently considered the advisability of adopting resolutions favoring the retention of Postmaster Corse in his present office, and such a course would probably have been pursued but for the disinclination of the organization to establish the precedent. Curtis Guild, Jr., Chairman of the Membership Committee of the organization, says regarding the matter:

The proposal that a troop of cavalry shall take station in the Yosemite National Park, to perform duties similar to those now incumbent on the cavalry in the Yellowstone Park, is very sensible. This new pleasure ground, which was established during the closing days of the first session of the present Congress, has an area of more than a million acres, and completely surrounds the old reservation of the Yosemite Valley.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- A severe southeast rainstorm commenced last night and has prevailed all day, creating considerable damage, as all the streams are rising rapidly. On the New-York and Massachusetts Railroad a bridge east of Pine Plains has been swept away and another at McIntyre has been moved and cannot be crossed to-night, consequently the inwardbound passenger train cannot get through.

Mr. ACKER has introduced a bill in the Assembly appropriating $500,000 to carry out the objects of the law passed last year for the State care of the insane, and a hearing is to be given upon it next Wednesday before the Committee on Public Institutions. The law having passed establishing the State-care system and defining the manner of giving it effect, the necessary appropriation should be made as a matter of course.

Owing to the fatigue of a long journey from San Francisco M. de Pachmann was unable to play at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. The recital was postponed till Monday. Tickets sold for yesterday will be good, or may be exchanged, or the money will be refunded.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Provisions were weak early There was considerable covering of sbort lines bj speculators, and the prices of product at the cloat were about where they started, in the morning and about where they left off Wednesday night. There was gelling of Pork by Stovers, DuBham, Orr. Oudahy, and Pardrldge. The baying was led by Allerton, Roloson, Kyan, and Walker Wrenn.

Nearly two hundred of the members of the American Society of Civil Engineers yesterday combined the pleasure of an extended all-day excursion with a practical inspection of some recent engineering achievements about NewYork. In spite of the pouring rain and muddy streets the trip was a great success.

For the first time in this session, which has been worse than wasted by the majority in the Senate, Mr. ALDRICH, as the leader of that majority, undertook yesterday to defend on its merits the rule for the suppression of debate which he has brought in. He declared that it was necessary to enable the majority to do business, for which the country held them responsible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- In brazen violation of the rules of the Senate, in open defiance of the precedents of that body for a hundred years, and in contemptuous disregard of the rights of the minority, the proposal to make a gag law a part of the code of its rules is now under consideration in the Senate, while the Journal of Tuesday's proceedings is still uncorrected and unapproved.

A dinner was tendered to ex-Judge Richard O'Gorman last evening at Delmonico's by members of the bar of this city. The tables were tastefully decorated with flowers and a large basket of roses adorned the centre of the speakers' table, at which sat Judge Brady, the presiding officer of the banquet, with the guest of the evening on his right and Judge J.J. Freedman on his left.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 22. -- The lottery question has now assumed a "personal phase" and it is more pronounced than in ordinary campaigns. In this country political differences are personal. To differ from a man is to invite his personal indifference or animosity. This is even more so than usual in the present lottery campaign, which promises to be more lively than the memorable one in which the White Leaguers overturned the reconstruction carpetbag Government.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from St. Paul says: "That the Grangers in the Minnesota Legislature propose to lead the railways of the State a merry dance is shown by the introduction of drastic joint resolutions in both houses to-day. That introduced in the Senate by Mr. Mayo was made a special order for next Thursday at 11 o'clock and is a sweeping blow at all the railways of the State.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 22. -- South Carolina, after years of apathy, has just awoke to the importance of immigration. During the past three weeks the State has been thoroughly organized under the auspices of the Southern Inter-State Immigration Association, and bureaus have been located, with a full corps of active and pushing officials, in the following towns and cities: Charleston, Columbia, Sumter, Florence, Darlington, Georgetown, Aiken, Anderson, Barnwell, Spartanburg, Marion, and Cheraw.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- The Republicans seem bent upon playing good politics this year. Their policy to give the New-York local authorities all that is desired on the all-absorbing question of rapid transit has unmasked Tammany's true position and lent color to the suspicion that Tammany either does not desire rapid transit or is distrustful of the commission which Mayor Grant appointed with such a hurrah a few weeks ago.

HAVANA, Jan. 17. -- The sum of $1,000,000, needed by the Territorial Hipothecary Bank to commence operations, has already been subscribed for, and the Directors of the Spanish Bank are contemplating an increase to $4,000,000 or $5,000,000 of their issue of gold bank notes. This action will be taken for the purpose of rendering to those engaged in commerce, especially sugar producers, much better facilities than they have heretofore enjoyed.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 22. -- The Pyramus and Thisbe Dramatic Club gave the first of two performances for sweet charity to-night in the pretty little Casino of the Union County Country Club. The placing of the tickets for the entertainment was the work of the fifty patronesses, and this naturally made it one of the social events of the season.

There is nothing which so forcibly accentuates the progress of Mexico as the fact that its people are becomingfond of beer. Breweries arc springing up in every city of importance. This is a phase of development whose importance should not be overlooked The beer-drlnkintr nation is a thinking nation. In a beer-drlnkAng nation revolution is an impossibility.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 22. -- William F. Vilas was this afternoon formally placed in nomination by the Democratic caucus of the Wisconsin Legislature for the office of United States Senator, to succeed John C. Spooner, a Republican. The nomination was unanimous, every member of both houses present on roll call voting for him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The reception given by Mr. and Mrs. George Bloomer to-day was in the nature of a housewarming. The hostess received in the large parlor, which was transformed into a conservatory by a profusion of flowers and growing plants. Mrs. Bloomer's gown was a beautiful one of torquois blue silk, veiled in tulle, with a deep border of forget-me-nots about the lower part.

It is hard to see why, if men of all parties at Albany are so anxious to pass a rapid transit bill as they pretend to be, such a discussion should spring up as that which occurred in the Senate yesterday over the section that empowers the commission to grant an extension of facilities to the existing elevated roads.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Senator Stewart this morning appeared before the Silver Pool Investigation Committee for the purpose of making a brief statement, he having been mentioned as making statements rather confirmatory of the existence of a silver pool.

The decision of the Surrogate in the Hamilton will case is a matter for congratulation. One of the chief motives of adventuresses like the contestant in this case for inveigling unwary or infatuated rich men into disgraceful marriages is the chance of coming into the estates of the rich men when they die.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22. -- The Hon. N.S. Hall, President of the Missouri Farmers' Alliance, describing the Kansas Senatorial situation, said:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22. -- The last honors were paid in San Francisco to the late King Kalakaua this afternoon. Last night the body of the dead King lay in state in the mortuary chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church, where the King had several times attended the services. A guard of regular soldiers from Presidio kept watch over the coffin throughout the night.

The annual report of Brig. Gen. Thomas H. Barber, Inspector General State of New-York, has been made public. The document deals exhaustively with the work of the National Guard for the year ending Nov. 14, 1890. Gen. Barber finds, as the result of the annual inspection and muster, that a large number of the organizations into which the 13,426 members of the military force are divided have reached a high state of efficiency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The House was as orderly to-day as if it had a Speaker the personification of impartiality. There was an opening brush or two, in which the leaders on both sides took part, but no turbulence whatever and very little rude characterization of the Speaker.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 22. -- The Rev. James S. White, D.D., pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church at Rockhill, S.C., during a fit of aberration of mind, committed suicide early this morning by drowning himself. Yesterday, on account of ill health, he resigned his pastorate, but the church refused to accept his resignation and gave him a year's vacation.

Archibald Clavering Gunter, the author of "Mr. Potter of Texas," which is to receive its first metropolitan presentation Monday night Feb. 2, at the Star Theatre, conceived rather a novel idea in connection with the production, the consummation of which would have begun a new era in theatricals in America; it smacks somewhat of the Chinese, if one wishes to trace the inspiration to a possible source.
BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- In the Reichstag to-day, Herr Barth, a member of the Deutsche Freisinnige Party, moved to repeal the prohibitions on American pork and bacon imports.

J.J. Kalbach, a merchant of 18 Broadway, living at 82 East Ninetieth Street, met with a terrible death yesterday. He intended to make a trip to North Carolina to purchase lumber, and, having missed the moaning train on the Pennsylvania Road, crossed over to Jersey City early in the afternoon to take the next train.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- The Forest Commission has transmitted to the Legislature a special report on the establishment of an Adirondack State Park. The report reviews the history of the movement on behalf of preserving the forests of the Adirondack wilderness, referring to the fact that there have been efforts in this direction ever since colonial times.

After much discussion the Aqueduct Commissioners decided yesterday to build a great Croton dam at Cornell's, a site nearly three miles below the old dam, one and a quarter miles above the proposed Quaker Bridge site, and about one and three-quarter miles below the site recommended by Chief Engineer Fteley, known as "Location 2." The dam will cost about $5,000,000, and about six years will be needed to complete it.

Still another day of the session now so near its end was wasted by the Senate yesterday over the absurd and yet outrageous scheme for suppressing debate on the Force bill. The rule of closure proposed by Mr. ALDRICH was finally got before the Senate but nothing was done with it, the Republicans being steadily baffled by the skill and persistence of the Democrats.

There was a meeting of the American Exhibition Company, the proprietors of the New-York League Baseball Club, yesterday. The Directors present were James E. Sullivan, John B. Day, J. Walter Spalding, and C.T. Dillingham. A committee composed of Day and Spalding was selected to confer with a committee that is to be appointed by the Players' League to-day. The latter will probably be E.B. Talcott and Col. McAlpin.

In the course of the experiments which led to the discovery of the remedy now commonly called Prof. KOCH'S lymph the professor succeeded in making guinea pigs proof against tubercular disease. This fact he made known in that address before the International Medical Congress which excited so much curiosity as to the final result of his labors.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 23. -- A Washington special dispatch to the Times says: "There is no longer an attempt to conceal the effort to remove United States District Attorney John R. Read of Philadelphia. The movement has been quietly organized for some time, and Dolan, the big woolen manufacturer and close friend of Postmaster General Wanamaker is understood as inspiring it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Both Republican and Democratic Senators have felt the intense strain under which the proceedings of the Senate have been conducted for the last fortnight, and to each side it was a great relief to-day when the sitting turned out to be one without an unusual incident and given up entirely to routine speech making.

Mirth, music, and Chauncey M. Depew prevailed at Delmonico's last night. Nearly two hundred sons of Yale ate, drank, and made merry in honor of their Alma Mater, and incidentally glorified the distinguished President of their Alumni association. Mr. Depew was in fine spirits, and entertained his fellow-Alumni with a speech which was witty, thoughtful, and eloquent.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The commission appointed by an act of the Legislature of 1890 to revise the judiciary article of the State Constitution and to formulate amendments to be presented to the Legislature completed its work to-day and adjourned without day. The meeting, which was brief, was held in the Assembly parlor.

A Striking example of the interest that people in small towns take in the discussion of economic questions was given at Montclair, N.J., last evening. In the big hall of the Montclair Club, which will seat about 1,500 people, there was a debate on the silver question. Every seat in the hall was occupied and many stood up.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 23. -- About 15 minutes after midnight of May 5, 1890, at the corner of Esplanade and Clayborne, two wide avenues thickly studded with trees, a wagon containing seven Italian stevedores was fired upon by some men in ambush. "Tony" Matranga, Vincent Caruso, and Salvador Sunzeri were badly wounded, but ultimately recovered.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 23. -- Prince Baudouin, nephew of King Leopold, died in this city at 1:45 o'clock this morning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The returns from the flooded districts throughout Dutchess County to-night revealed additional damage. The main freshets, inundations, wash-outs, and destruction of bridges were along Wappinger's and Fishkill Creeks. At Rochdale and Titusville, both manufacturing places, bridges were destroyed and mills stopped.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 23. -- On the Saturday preceding Christmas large tracts of valuable pine lands were thrown open to settlers by the Government. A line of claimants stood in the cold for forty-eight hours and had their meals brought to them, while they postponed sleep, in order to secure titles. The militia was called out to preserve order.

Joseph F. Donoghue, the champion skater of the world, arrived home yesterday on the White Star steamer Germanic. He had carried the cherry diamond emblem of the Manhattan Athletic Club to victory everywhere over the ice of Northern Europe, where skating is an art fairly bred in the bone of the people, and he was accordingly the particular lion of the Manhattan Athletic Club last evening.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 23. -- The Democrats finally won the point they have been striving for since last Wednesday, and to-day, instead of only one ballot being taken in the joint session, there were eight. The balloting might have gone on until nightfall had not Senator Charles Fuller, the Republican leader, demanded an adjournment, which was acquiesced in by the Republicans and Speaker Crafts.

BISMARCK, N.D., Jan. 23. -- Congressman H.C. Hansbrough was elected United States Senator to succeed Gilbert A. Pierce on the seventeenth ballot this afternoon. Hansbrough reached 32 votes on the fourteenth ballot and 42 on the sixteenth. Most of the Democrats went to him on the seventeenth, and his vote reached 67.

Henry Wilson, one of the oldest members of the New-York Exempt Fireman's Association, and for many years a resident of the Ninth Ward, died Thursday at his residence, Seventh Avenue and Fortieth Street, of peritonitis.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- All the New-York Senators and Lieut. Gov. Jones were absent this morning, and Senator Jacobs called the Senate to order. The Old Guard ball was responsible for the many vacant seats. Senator Robertson, who does not attend balls, wore a very virtuous look as he arose in his place and remarked:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- That heavy armor plates for naval vessels can be made in the United States equal to the best made in Europe is now settled. The first test plate made by the Bethlehem Iron Works at South Bethlehem, Penn., was tested at the Annapolis proving ground this week for the makers. It was eleven and a half inches thick, representing the armor of the after barbette of the coast defense vessel Monterey.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan 28. -- The Hon. Isaac Montgomery, the distinguished colored member of the late Constitutional Convention, has received the following letter from ex-President Cleveland:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The new and handsome building of Warner Brothers, at Terrace and Pearl Streets, was almost completely ruined by fire to-night. Within a week of the destruction of the Walbridge Building more than another quarter of a million dollars has gone up in smoke. The building was erected about a year and a half ago.

The ability of Mrs. Beatrice Roberts to furnish infants with their natural food of a quality calculated to keep them in thriving health was put at issue yesterday before Judge Van Wyck and a jury in the City Court, when Hrs. Roberts's suit against Florian Hendricks was put on trial. Mr. Hendricks, who is a wine merchant living at 348 West Fifty-first Street, engaged Mrs. Roberts's services when his little daughter was born.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 23. -- One of the first bills that will be introduced in the House on Tuesday will provide for a Constitutional Convention to be held in this city one year from now, the members to be elected in November. The measure has been prepared and will be offered by Representative Albert H. Walker of this city.
DUBLIN, Jan 23. -- William O'Brien telegraphs from Boulogne-sur-Mer to the publishers of the recently-established Insuppressible of this city as follows:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 23. -- Ex-Congressman E.H. Gillette and wife of this city have separated, and the intimate friends of each feel pretty certain that Chester Turney has been the chief cause of their trouble. Chester Turney was convicted of larceny several years ago, and was sentenced to a long term in State prison. There were about fourteen different counts, and a conviction and sentence on each one.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Several of the difficulties which the World's Fair Directors have met have been removed this week, and considerable progress has been made in shaping the work. The Michigan Avenue property holders withdrew them objections to the placing of buildings on the lake front, and the plan prepared by the late John W. Root for the arrangement of the structures along the lake front has been adopted.

The Trolley system of electric traction for street railroads came up before the Board of Electrical Control yesterday at the Mayor's office upon the application of the Harlem Bridge, Morrisiania and Fordham Railway Company for leave to construct poles in the streets through which its line, familiarly known as the "Huckleberry Road," now runs.

For some days there has been a belief among many of the physicians of this city that a lymph famine would shortly occur. There is really no ground for this belief, for within the past three days a considerable supply has been received in New-York and an equally large amount is on the way here.

There was never a better supply of fish in the markets for this season of the year than is displayed this Winter, and if lovers of food fish go hungry it is their own fault. Pompano and redfish are so abundant that the fish dealers have been compelled to send word to shippers to curtail the amount of their shipments. These fish come from Florida, and are sent up by steamer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The conference of the different labor organizations, begun yesterday, was resumed this morning, the delegates having under consideration some plan of agreement by which all the organizations can unite on some satisfactory platform and form a close confederation of the State organizations for both offense and defense.

With every day of useless squabbling at Washington over the Force bill and the gag rule, an extra session is made more nearly inevitable. Some of the Republican leaders seem to think that the political disadvantages of such a session would fall wholly on the Democrats, but we are sure that they are in error.

" Some time ago," says the Cleveland Leader, an industrious defender of McKinleyism, Reedism, and the Force bill, "the Leader called attention to the fact that the only Republican journals in the country opposing the Federal Elections bill were the alleged Republican journals that are tarred with the free-trade stick, and that all of them were doing it."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The ball given to-night by the Spanish Minister and Mme. Suarez in honor of the fifth birthday, or, more properly speaking, the Saint's Day, of the young King Alphonse XIII., was a brilliant gathering of distinguished guests, prominent in diplomatic, official, and social circles.

The prospect of reviving the grade of Lieutenant General has hardly been much improved by the tinkering done on the pending bill in committee. As the measure now stands this grade would be re-established for the benefit of the officer now commanding the army, and yet expressly withheld from the enjoyment of any successor in that command.

Director Linton of the Brooklyn Players' League has gained his point. His colleagues have bought out his interest in the team, the injunction suit will be discontinued, and the consolidation of the two Brooklyn nines will take place next Saturday. The stockholders in the club refuse to state how much they paid the obstinate Director, but Linton is happy, and that alone is sufficient ground for believing that he got the price asked -- $9,000.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- Since the debauched and epileptic Rudolph of Austria made such a weird ending of himself, two years ago this month, no dynastic event has stirred Europe so much as the unexpected death of young Baldwin of Belgium, who, to all intents and purposes, was the Crown Prince of that tight little kingdom.

Much interest has been taken in the newspaper comments on the coming change of policy at the Metropolitan Opera House. The general attitude of our esteemed contemporaries, with the exception of the Herald, is based on an assumption that the Directors of the Opera House are flying in the face of public demand. This seems a little severe.

The question that interests the members of the Republican County Committee just now is, "Who is to be the next County Committee Chairman?" The committee will meet to perfect organization as soon as the Committee on Contested Seats is ready to report on the disputes in the Fifth and Thirteenth Assembly Districts.

Rear Admiral D.L. Braine, commanding the Brooklyn Navy Yard, will be sixty-two years old and will be placed on the retired list May 2. There is no little curiosity manifested in navy circles as to his successor. It has been frequently stated that Admiral Gherardi, who now commands the North Atlantic squadron, would be given the place.

It is a source of satisfaction that a work of this novel character -- "the first book of the kind ever published in any language," the author believes -- should have come from an American artillerist. Capt. Ingalls, a native of Vermont, enlisted in the Sixteenth Infantry at the opening of the year 1864, and served as private and non-commissioned officer until the close of the civil war, May, 1865, when he obtained a commission.

The proposed new armory for the Thirteenth Regiment has been productive of more bickerings among the men interested in it than any other public undertaking in Brooklyn for several years. From all accounts there have been several narrow escapes from a scandal, too, in connection with the purchase of the site in Classon Avenue at the rather exorbitant price of $146,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The subject has been discussed more generally, or with more interest, at the Capitol to-day than the attitude of the States that have declared, in their Legislatures an intention to postpone appropriations for the Columbian Exposition at Chicago until the fate of the Force bill has been decided.

Wall Street is not often reverent. As proof -- or refutation -- of this assertion may be cited the remark made by one of the Street's "kings" when asked to cease his attacks on a certain stock. The man who urged the request gave as an argument the fact that the "king's" oldest friend had invested heavily in the stock and was on the verge of bankruptcy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Lyman J. Gage will retire from the Presidency of the World's Columbian Exposition in April. Under no circumstances will he accept the office for another term. Within a few weeks Mr. Gage will succeed S.M. Nickerson as President of the First National Bank. He does so on condition that all of his time be devoted to that institution.

Mayor Grant has tackled the street-cleaning problem again, this time from a new quarter. He yesterday addressed to Messrs. Morris K. Jesup, Thatcher M. Adams, Charles F. Chandler, David H. King, Jr., and F.V. Greene copies of a letter, as follows:

BISMARCK, N.D., Jan. 24. -- There have been some racy developments to-day in connection with the Senatorial canvass. The information comes from reliable sources that Hansbrough was compelled to make written pledges of the most extraordinary character to secure his election.

An arrangement was completed yesterday by which P.S. Gilmore will occupy the Madison Square Garden for five weeks from May 30 to July 3, inclusive. Mr. Gilmore will exploit a band of musicians numbering 100. This is larger than any instrumental musical organization which has yet appeared in the new Madison Square Garden.

A writer in the Nineteenth Century gives his reasons for believing that animals have a future existence. His argument is not addressed to those who do not believe in the immortality of the human soul. Persons who hold any kind of life to be merely a specialized product of matter may believe, of course, that the body and mind of an animal die with its physical destruction.

The contest for the position of boxing instructor of the Manhattan Athletic Club took place in the clubhouse yesterday afternoon. "Prof." Doherty of Boston was there to try conclusions with Edward Smith of Denver and Dominick McCaffrey of this city. Smith withdrew, which left only McCaffrey and Doherty in the heavy-weight class.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 24. -- The number of applicants for places on the baseball team is already nearly fifty. After the examinations are over there will be many more. Buchanan Schley of Hagerstown, Md., who was centre field last session, has been elected Captain of the team by the Baseball Committee. Among the games definitely arranged is one with Yale, to be played here March 30.

Even the babies are snuggled up in furs now, the tiny capes and muffs being wonderfully cute and pretty. From these diminutive specimens there are sets of many sizes up to the full-grown ones, for children of all ages have mamma's and papa's fur garments duplicated for their wear. The krimmer, with large, flat curl, liberally tufted with white, makes, perhaps, the prettiest furs for children.

After a week of dullness with sagging prices, the market broke yesterday when the bank statement appeared showing an increase in the surplus reserve of $5,000,000, which brings the aggregate up to $24,000,000. Last week, there was a temporary strengthening of prices on a bank statement not so good as this. The decline yesterday shows that the bullish influence of increasing case in money is exhausted.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- The firemen injured in last night's fire are all doing well and will recover. Public subscriptions have been started for the families of the two firemen who were killed. The list of insurances held by Marcus Son on their stock is as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- State Factory Inspector James Connolly has made public his annual report. It makes 157 pages of printed matter which, introduced with a burst of rhetoric, exalts the importance of the Factory Inspector and his subordinates, advises manufacturers not to use linseed oil on belts, declares that iron rope is better than steel for elevators, and winds up with these recommendations:

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- There were changes in the bills at most of the theatres this week, and at all the houses the audiences have been large. The most successful play produced from an artistic standpoint was "The Maister of Woodbarrow" at Hooley's. Mr. Sothern made an instantaneous hit in Jerome K. Jerome's play, and has had the satisfaction of receiving the approbation of all the people that she theatre would hold nightly.

BUFFALO, Jan. 24. -- An important meeting of independent oil refiners and producers, representing the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, and Ohio, was held at Oil City this week. Mr. C.B. Matthews of this city presided at the meeting. An organization was effected and the following officers were elected for 1891: President -- John Teagle, Cleveland; Vice President -- C.D. Ramage, Reno, Penn.; Secretary -- C.D. Chamberlain, Ohio; Treasurer -- D.E. Byles, Oil City.
He was scarcely ten years old when he was first arrested as a vagabond.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 24. -- The approaching carnival festival will be one of the best Now-Orleans has ever had, both in the excellence of its display and in the numbers that will be in attendance. The programme of attractions which will delight visitors and home folks too is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The silver-pool investigation was resumed this morning. Representative George W. Dorsey of Nebraska, who is also a banker, testified that he had no knowledge of any Congressman or other Government officers being interested in any silver pool or silver speculation.

A letter has been received in this city from the Vienna Camera Club concerning the lantern slides sent over from this city by the American Lantern Slide Interchange to the effect that the slides arrived in good condition and were considered of a high character by those who had seen them. The method of packing them was considered most excellent and the best device known for safe transportation of the fragile pieces of glass.

Whenever a combination of manufacturers is dissolved or becomes embarrassed, and whenever the projectors of such an organization are induced to give up their plans, certain McKinley papers cry out that these changes are caused by Mr. SHERMAN'S so-called anti-Trust law. They profess to have much more confidence in the effectiveness of this act than the author of it had.

There is a great deal of very interesting matter in the forty-sixth annual report of the Women's Prison Association of New-York and its adjunct, the Isaac T. Harper Home. The report is made by Dr. A.S Daniels, the physician in charge. The most interesting part of the document is the statement of Dr. Daniels's observations in regard to the New-York station houses and prisons and his recommendations thereon.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 24. -- It was developed to-ay that ex-Adjt. Gen. Bonham, whose shortage to the State amounted to $5,500, although not indicted, has been kept under surveillance of the Sheriff by Gov. Tillman. As Bonham throughout the State is regarded as a man of honor and a representative of the old regime, the action of the Governor is denounced roundly by friends of Bonham.

The tests prescribed by Gen. KAUTZ'S board for the competition between magazine guns which may be offered for introduction into our army are certainly of an exhaustive character. They will thoroughly try rapidity of fire, accuracy, endurance, and safety, besides ease of manipulation and the time of taking apart and putting together the breech and magazine systems.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- The Collectorship of the port of Cape Vincent is a bone of contention among the politicians just now. H.E. Morse, the Democratic Collector, who has been holding over under the Republican Administration, when, as many of the politicians think, he should have been summarily removed, will have to get out in a few weeks.

A dozen surveyors and engineers were at work in Long Island City yesterday surveying the proposed line of the East River tunnel. Mr. E.H. Barnes, the engineer in charge, said that, while the survey was only preliminary, the line would probably be the one accepted by the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company. There would, he said, be three branches, or arms.

" Organized labor" is very apt to halloo before it is hurt, but it has not heretofore exhibited so much of what the lawyers call "abundant caution" as has been shown by the men employed on the cable roads of Chicago. It appears that the Superintendent of the system on which these men are employed has lately been discharged.

Comparatively few people understand the functions of the Naval Officer of the port of New-York, and of those who are brought in contact with that official not many know the valuable work that is done under his direction, both in the matter of saving time to the merchants of New-York and in the saving of money to the Government.

NEW-CITY, Jan. 24. -- At this little hamlet, the county seat of Rockland County, strange and unpleasant rumors are afloat concerning the Demarest forgery matter, which is to be presented before the Grand Jury next Tuesday. Some of the disgraced Assemblyman's friends say he will not be prosecuted for forgery, and, when asked how they know, they reply that "the evidence against him either has disappeared or will disappear before Tuesday next."

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Since Trainer George Goldie of the New-York Athletic Association resigned as the instructor of gymnastics at Princeton, Mr. Turner, the present instructor, has labored earnestly in the face of a great many difficulties. Immediately after Mr. Goldie left there was a year or two in which Princeton was left without a professional gymnastic trainer and in the meantime all the best gymnasts were graduated.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 24. -- Major J.W. Burst of Sycamore, Ill., Inspector General of the Grand Army of the Republic, left here to-day, after a pleasant visit of over a week. His mission was to heal the differences in the Grand Army ranks in Louisiana. Commander Alger authorized the installation of colored posts, the Grand Encampment approved the alteration, but the Department Commander elected by the white posts was recognized.

The present widespread interest in the navy, naval construction, naval training and personnel demands a field of action and material for growth. The safety of the Nation in time of war, in so far as concerns the land forces, rests on the militia system. The regular army is a highly trained nucleus about which the volunteers will rally.
There was once a man who received a telegram which said: "Cog hog alonce gether is bad." He didn't know what to make of it. He puzzled over it for two hours. Then he took it to the telegraph office.

BRUNSWICK, Jan. 24. -- At the annual meeting of the athletic association the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President -- Pugsley, '92; Vice President -- Clifford, '93; Secretary and Treasurer -- Hussey, '93. Directors -- Merriman, '92; Machan, Frost, '93; Chapman, Bagely, '94. Master of Ceremonies -- Downes, '92. The regular exhibition will take place March 20 in Town Hall.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Until this evening the understanding that has prevailed at Albany concerning the report of the Constitutional Commission had been that the commission recommended the continuance of the Second Division of the Court of Appeals. Upon the authority of Mr. W.B. Hornblower it may be stated that the commission recommended that the Second Division of the Court of Appeals be discontinued.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 24. -- The Picayune's Havana special says:

There is one queer notion that our English friends must get rid of if they hope to arrive at any just conception of the policy of the United States toward Canada, if, indeed, the United States be said to have any policy with reference to her northern neighbor -- that is, the notion that this country has any "efficient" desire to annex Canada.

Dr. Koch having published his process of lymph manufacture, the interest in the subject of a remedy to be used for tuberculosis has not diminished but is rather on the increase. In the January number of the Contemporary Review Sir Morel Mackenzie's paper entitled "Koch's Treatment of Tuberculosis" is so fair, honest, and clear as to present an understandable view of this recent discovery with its efects upon a particular class of diseases.

In an ethnological and archaeological sense Mr. Bandelier's work as a study of the Pueblo Indians of the long past is a remarkable one. The author believes that by clothing the sober facts with the garb of romance he can draw attention to the subject, for it is true that those reading scientific books on the possible ways of the early Indians are but few.

The charm of a collection of book plates was its utter inutility. It had the superb indifference of the lily, and as for value in gold coin, it had none. It was the only collection which one could form, with the ideal pleasure of Baudelaire in rhyming. for nothing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Traders on the Board think "Ed" Pardridge is becoming scared at the way the market is going. Pardridge was out on the curb last night. Nobody escaped his inquiry, "What do you think of wheat?" Big men and little men, rotund commission men and obsequious have-been plungers and office boys were all interrogated by the man who is just now plunging in the market as nobody before him ever traded.

Jersey City was last night the scene of one of the most remarkable series of fire fatalities in her history. The culmination of an afternoon and evening of fire excitements was the death, while in the discharge of his duties, of Henry E. Farrier, the Chief of the city's Fire Department, and one of the bravest, as he was one of the oldest, firemen in the State.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 24. -- The Improvement Association-street railway conflict was enlivened this week by the counsel for the former asking the Highway Committee of the City Council to give a public hearing on the petition of the association for the summary removal of the rails of the company from Bath Road. The committee has agreed to do so. The hearing will be held next Saturday evening, and more fun may be expected then.

The East Orange (N.J.) people call their newly-organized Citizens' Protective Association their Vigilance Committee. Its organization is the outcome of the efforts of Hamilton Wallis, a New-York lawyer who lives in one of the handsomest of the villas on Prospect Street, and seems, from all accounts, to have been prompted by the fear that the exclusive little settlement was in danger of invasion by the common herd from the outside.

At a pink dinner on costume given last week to twelve ladies of social prominence one of the guests wore the actual toilet in which she appeared at a reception thirty years ago. It was the height of the fashion at that time. The dress was a magnificent one of heavy, old rose silk with trimmings of Honiton lace. It was out away in the neck with voluminous sleeves, full gathered skirt, and immense hoops.

HARTFORD, Jan. 24. -- The representatives of the three medical schools in this State will meet here on Tuesday to complete the Medical Practice act, which is to be presented to the General Assembly for adoption during the current session. The bill has been under consideration for months and is the result of compromises and concessions from the different schools of practitioners in the State.

There is one social organization in this city which is a club in everything except in name, and about which very little is known despite the fact that half a hundred, more or less, of the Four Hundred are members of it. This club, in fact if not in name, is known as the New-York Farmers. It was organized several years age the owners of several famous "fancy" farms, and now has nearly fourscore members.

The idea of a certain pomp and dignity about Tycho Brahe is necessary for the appreciation of him, for he was no common or underbred man, but a Danish nobleman of ancient lineage, and wont to hold his head with the highest and to associate with Kings and great people. His temperament was choleric, not without a certain independence, and he had a high opinion of his own inabilities.

A dinner can have but one object, the entertainment of all present; but it is at once a necessity and a pleasure, and the time devoted to it is profitable to man physically and mentally. It is the dividing line between the day of work and worry and strife and the evening of ease and quiet and friendly intercourse. It is a time of relaxation, when the past is forgotten and the future ignored.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Lyman D. Davis, a nephew of Gov. Hill of New-York, died here this morning. He was an electrician and was twenty-six years of age. Gov. Hill visited him yesterday, and this morning the Governor telegraphed to have the body sent on to Elmira.

Henry F. Dimock, ex-Dock Commissioner, occupied the witness chair before the Senate Committee on Cities for the greater portion of yesterday's hearing in Part IV, of the Superior Court, Senators Fassett and Stewart were the only members of the committee present. A.B. Boardman, who, in Mr. Ivins's absence, conducts the examination, proceeded with the work of bringing out the manifold difficulties met with in the Dock Department.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 24. -- "Do you know why we Democrats of the West support Grover Cleveland?" asked a well-known member of that party of a group of friends in the Boody House last evening. "We naturally have several reasons, but the one that first captured us, and holds as good to-day as it did in the beginning, is this: He was a New-York Democrat who had never been mentioned in connection with Tammany Hall.

It costs money to fly the flag of one's country or one's private banner, If it has to be run up every day, rain or shine. A storm is terribly wearing on flags, and any faulty work in the making is very quickly brought to light by a peering rain or a half gale. When the two come together it is a very trying time for cloth and cord.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 24. -- Williams looks forward with much interest to the convention of the New-England Young Men's Christian Association, which is to be held here next February. Accommodations are being provided in the dormitories and society houses for 110 delegates. The session will begin Feb. 6 and last until the following Monday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- A bill has been filed by James B. Smith and others involving the Traders' Safe and Trust Company and alleging conspiracy among some of the Directors against the stockholders. The company was organized by Frederick S. Eames, J. Foster Rhodes, and E.W. Shirk for the purpose of leasing property and building.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 24. -- The lack of uniformity in the Pennsylvania poor laws has long been a fruitful source of annoyance to those charged with the care of the indigent in the various districts of the State, and it would be comprehensive mind that could grasp successfully the many complexities of the numerous systems in vogue for the relief of the destitute.

In painting, mechanical dexterity is quite a minor matter, and the painter is comparatively free from any but artistic considerations In sculpture, on the other hand, though the same application of artistic principles is exacted and necessary, a large proportion of purely mechanical work falls to the share of the artist, necessitating unusual care and skill.

Athletic clubs all over the country are planning for the reorganization of the Amateur Athletic Union, to go into effect in March. According to the books of the union's Secretary, James E. Sullivan, the organization at present contains 110 clubs, ranging in membership from the Manhattan Athletic Club, which now has nearly 2,700 members, down to smaller organizations, whose membership is scarcely a hundred.

BOSTON, Jan. 24. -- The formal announcement of the centennial celebration of the formation of the Massachusetts Historical Society was rung from the chimes in the tower of the Arlington Street Church this morning at 11:30 o'clock. Before noon a large congregation had assembled, not only of members of the society, but also delegates from other associations of a similar nature.

There is nothing surprising in the incredulity with which the official account of the death of the heir to the Belgian throne has been received by the Belgian public. At least, there is nothing surprising in the general suspicion that a true account of the Prince's end would reveal a disgraceful scandal.

EtOOR PoNxms. -- Sir Frederick Knight's ponies have now acquired a wide reputation, and deservedly so, for sweeter animals are not to be found. The original Exmoor is a tiny creature, seldom more than eleven, or at most twelve hands high, but wonderfully strong and hardy, and surefooted as a goat. The best specimens of the original breed are in the possessions of the Acland family.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- The Rev. William H. Scudder has accepted a call to the pastorate of the First Congregational Church at Norwich, N.Y., and will enter on his new charge to-morrow, Jan 25. He is the son of the Rev. Dr. Scudder, long a missionary in India and an Alumnus of Rutgers College. He has filled pastorates at San Francisco and at Boston.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 24. -- It is well understood to-night that the Dominion elections will be held on Thursday, March 5. Though no date is officially given in the Government organs, Le Canada, controlled by a Cabinet Minister, announces the early dissolution of Parliament.

If earnestness, intense enthusiasm, and unanimity of sentiment count for anything in any popular movement, then the people of Harlem are in a far way of getting rapid transit. Their meeting last night at the Harlem Democratic Club headquarters brought together the representative men of Harlem, irrespective of party, in movement to which it will be well for all interested politicians to give respectful attention.

The indoor game of baseball in the Seventh Regiment Armory last night attracted a large crowd. Companies D and C were the contestants. From the outset the contest abounded in brilliant plays. The men have improved wonderfully in their work, and gave a clever exhibition of the diamond field sport. In last night's game some pretty stops, good catches, and accurate throws were made.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 24. -- The oyster beds of Eastern North Carolina are becoming very valuable. They have all been plotted and surveyed during the past five years, and opened to entry and occupation. Nearly all these lands, or water, as the case may be, have been entered and grants taken from the State, and the owners have commenced oyster farming.
An old traveler who has been over half the world showed a reporter a handsome uncut ruby the other day. "This," he said, "is from India, and was given me by a friend who found it while out shooting."

My attention has been called to an editorial in your issue of Jan. 18, under the above heading. Will you allow me, as one of the members of the last congress at Stockholm, to correct what appears to be a false impression? The disagreement which has led to the calling of two congresses instead of one was not due, in the first place, to any friction between German and French scholars.

Sales of pictures and prints at Christie's during 1890 were productive of 470,000, or, if we reckon the ceramics and art furniture, of over 500,000. Following a plan which is indorsed by the experience of other seasons and reckoning all other fine arts sales of "old masters" and deceased artists as equal to what was disposed of at the St. James's Street galleries, we have over 1,000,000 spent in this way during the past year.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Assemblyman Keeler has introduced in the Legislature a bill which directs the Regents of the University to have compiled and to publish, for sale at cost to the schools of the State, text books in reading, spelling, arithmetic, geography, grammar, United States history, civil government, physiology, and physical geography.
Sir Edwin Arnold, under date of Nov. 29, writes from Tokio to the London Daily Telegraph as follows on the birth of the first Parliament on Asiatic soil:

The taxpayers and citizens of Brooklyn view with interest amounting to alarm the effort of the Democratic gang to got more money from the Legislature to squander on so-called granite pavements. A bill has been introduced at the present session providing for the issue of $1,000,000 in bonds, the proceeds to be spent in developing Mayor Chapin's comprehensive scheme of public improvement.

It was announced Saturday that the Rev. Dr. B.F. De Costa, rector of the Church of St. John the Evangelist, would preach yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Church, in West Forty-sixth Street, upon the subject, "Strengthening versus Extinguishing of Parishes." The parishioners of St. Stephen's, knowing that Dr. De Costa would touch on the consolidation controversy with Holy Trinity of Harlem, braved the storm only to be disappointed at his nonappearance.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Early last evening rain began to fall, but at midnight the rain gave place to snow, and a blinding storm continued till after daybreak. The wet snow clung in great masses to everything, and, added to the force of the wind, soon caused serious damage. Trees were unable to stand the strain and lost branch after branch or were wholly uprooted.

The Sunday afternoon service at the Young Men's Christian Association Building, Twenty third Street and Fourth Avenue, yesterday was a memorial meeting in honor of Henry H. Webster, who, for the past ten years has been connected with the Young Men's Christian Association, and who recently presided at the meetings of the Twenty-third Street branch. Mr. Webster had also accomplished much in personal work with young men.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 25. -- Senator Ingalls was right when he remarked in his speech last night that the battle was on. No truce was declared over Sunday. The Farmers' Alliance was busy all day, no member going home for Sunday. Every man was needed at the caucus, and each was on hand.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25. -- If the Standard Oil Company could have trained a Gatling gun on the gathering of independent oil refiners and producers held at Oil City last week, and set it in operation for a few busy moments, the head and front of the opposition to monopoly in oil would have been blown from the face of the earth.

It is in the power of those Republican members of Congress who know that the bill for the free coinage of silver is a mischievous measure to do their party, as well as the country, a service by resisting popular clamor and voting against it. Free coinage in this Congress can be defeated if every Republican who believes it bad policy takes counsel of his courage and votes against it.

Mr. Alfred Hennin Morris of the racing firm of J.A. A.H. Morris is very enthusiastic over a scheme of breeding thoroughbreds which his father and he are now carrying out. This scheme is to send the best bred and the best individual American mares to England, where they will be bred to the best English sires. The produce of this union will be brought to America as yearlings and trained and raced here.

Since our last notice of this colossal work four volumes have made their appearance. The same promptness that has become familiar to all observers heretofore has characterized them. For good reasons we may confidently look forward to a continuance of it, but years must pass before the work is all completed. It is six years since the first volume was issued. This means that about four volumes have come out each year.

Miss Mary Howe and Mr. Bendix were the soloists at the Lenox Lyceum last evening, but it can hardly be attributable to either or both of them that the ample hall was packed, but rather to the natural growth of these admirable concerts. Miss Howe selected the "Caro nome" for her first solo, and in this her powerful voice, especially good in its middle notes, and her thorough training were shown to excellent advantage.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25. -- A very important decision was rendered yesterday by the Supreme Court of Illinois, at Mount Vernon, which came up from St. Clair County and which affects large interests. The case was originally brought by James D. Baker, Collector of St. Clair County, against the Consolidated Coal Company of St. Louis, on application of Assessor Stookey of St. Clair Township.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 25. -- The recent purchase of the Allegheny Bessemer Steel Works by the Carnegies and of the Scranton Steel Works by the Lackawanna Coal and Iron Company have directed attention to the fact that steel rail manufacturing is slowly but surely becoming a monopoly.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- In the course of a conversation with Mr. N.C. Moak to-day by a representative of THE TIMES as to the present status of affairs in the commission and the Court of Appeals since the commission has met and finally adjourned and the new Second Division has been organized and set in motion, Mr. Moak said:

We can pick up this collection of articles from "The Bookworm" anywhere, read a paragraph or a chapter, put it down again, and be interested, for the amusement found in books themselves is only secondary to the pleasure derived from reading about them. You need not then exhaust this "literary treasury," but take the gold or the silver or copper in it by driblets.

The census which has just been taken in Vienna reckons the population of the capital, excluding the suburbs, at 809,443, which makes an increase of 104,687 since 1880. The garrison of 22,000 men is not computed in this total.

READING, Penn., Jan. 25. -- Dr. C.F.G. Bergen of this city has three patients under treatment who have been bitten by mad dogs. One is Ammon Stitzer, aged thirty, and the two others are young sons of Frank Hahn, all of this county. They are doing well so far, and hopes are entertained that they will escape hydrophobia and recover.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25. -- There is a very pretty little row going on in Republican circles here over the appointment of a Postmaster, and whichever way it results it is almost certain to provoke animosities that will result in the Democrats carrying the city elections in the Spring.

TRENTON, Jan. 25. -- Having made Mr. Bergen Speaker of the House of Assembly, State Committee Chairman Allan L. McDermott seems to feel himself bound to defend all that Bergen does, and he resents the insinuation that Bergen has punished Hudson for her contumely by excluding her Representatives in the Assembly from the desirable committees.

There are very few Republican leaders left who advocate the kind of party policy that was named "Thorough" by STRAFFORD two hundred and fifty years ago. The original "Thorough" policy cost its author and his royal backer their heads, whereas the Republican imitation of it has thus far merely cost the party only the control of Congress.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Jan. 25. -- At a banquet here last night Mr. Chapleau, Secretary of State, in a speech said he was sure there was no better friend of Canada than Mr. Blaine -- perhaps Mr. Blaine loved us a little too much. Some people were nervous because they thought Canada's cousin across the line was altogether too much interested in her.

Another job may now be added to the list of those which have been disclosed in the new tariff by the decisions of the Treasury Department since the law went into effect. The Collector at Boston has been instructed by the department that sago flour is dutiable at the rate of 2 cents a pound, which is equivalent to an ad valorem rate of about 100 per cent.

The Chickasaws, in sending a messenger to Washington to ask the Government to expel intruders and squatters from their domains, are following the example of the Cherokees, who made a like request about a year ago. As the latter tribe or nation has not shown itself particularly ready to forward the desire expressed by Congress to purchase the Cherokee Outlet, naturally there has been no haste to aid them in this matter.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 25. -- The snowstorm of last night and this morning did unprecedented damage here to the telegraph and telephone service, and to-day the city is completely cut off from all communication by wire with the outside world. During the big blizzard there was one telegraph wire in operation between here and New-York, and one telephone wire, but now everything is down.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 25. -- A lively church war which has been waging for eighteen months among the Amish-Mennonite brethren at the east end of this county, over a trilling detail of church furniture, has reached a climax, and now the law is to be invoked by the combatants, not withstanding the well-known scruples of this peculiar sect against litigation.

There are two causes that interfere very plainly with the healthy progress of business which every one expected would be resumed when the temporary stringency of December had passed away, as it now has. One is the fear of silver legislation, the other is the fear of the Force bill. In one sense these two causes are one -- the fear of Congressional interference with the course of business.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- Admiral Latorre of the Chilean Navy, who is noted as the capturer of the Peruvian iron-clad Huascar in the war between Chile and Peru, has been sent by President Balmaceda to Europe to supervise the building of war ships for Chile.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26. -- The conflicts between the organization of the brewery workmen and the Anheuser-Busch and Lemp Breweries is becoming widespread, and has already involved all the principal labor organizations in the country. The boycott is being pushed with redoubled vigor, and the loyal organizations of brewery workmen are daily receiving indorsement of their action from the most distant places.

Senator Leland Stanford of California arrived in this city from Washington Sunday night with Mrs. Stanford. Yesterday morning he left the Windsor Hotel with his private secretary, J.B. McCarthy, to go to the American Institute Building in Third Avenue, near Sixty-third Street, to see the Senator's horses, which are to be sold there to-day, to-morrow, and Thursday.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 26. -- The havoc wrought by the storm among the telephone and telegraph lines throughout Central New-Jersey will cripple for many days the service of the Western Union Telegraph Company, the New-Jersey Postal Telegraph Company, and the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company. Not only are the smaller and cheaper side lines rendered useless, but the total annihilation of the main trunk service of these companies has been accomplished.

The count of the pennies, dimes, and dollars in the boxes which were scattered all over the city for the reception of popular contributions to the Hospital Satarday and Sunday Association's fund has been completed and the total box collection is found to amount to $2,126. This with the amounts already acknowledged from other sources brings the total figures of the collections for this year up to $47,310.

If shortly after March 3 or before that day Mr. HARRISON should call upon Congress to convene again, the session would in every sense of the word be an extraordinary one. The very occasion for it would make it so. We do not know what Mr. HARRISON'S own feeling on the matter might be. It will be affected by the fate of the Force bill.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 26. -- William J. Baldwin, who was arrested for having an official ballot in his possession outside of the voting inclosure and was fined $300 this morning in the Third District Court, withdrew his appeal from his sentence, and the judgment was affirmed. Unless the fine is paid Baldwin will have to serve three months in jail.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- News has been received here from Buenos Ayres that the British Minister to Chile, J.G. Kennedy, is acting as mediator between the Chilean Government and the insurgents. It is added that President Balmaceda offers to resign.

The drug trade section of the Board of Trade and Transportation was formally organized in the rooms of the board yesterday at noon. Among the firms represented were Dodge Olcott, Tarrant Co., H.J. Baker Brother, Lehn Fink, Seabury Johnson, Fairchild Brothers Foster, Fraser Co., Schoelikopf, Hartfut Maclagan, (Limited,) Theodore Ricksecker, Rogers Pyatt, R.W. Robinson Son, and Williams, Steiger Co.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 26. -- The fact that George Gray of Newark has decided to accept the State Treasurership was proved to-night by his appearance among "the boys." He opened rooms at the Trenton House, and kept whisky on tap and handed around a box of cigars. He was in the best of humor, as well he might be, and had a genial smile for all who waited upon him.

Judge TRUAX of the Superior Court has decided that the Board of Electrical Control cannot make contracts to suit itself for the construction of subways. It is bound to have the work done by the Consolidated Company unless the contract with that company, which was specifically ratified and sanctioned by act of the Legislature, shall have become ineffectual and inoperative.

One of the most brilliant and fashionable balls of the season was given by Mrs. Astor last night at her home, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The floral decorations were most elaborate. The hall was transformed into a corridor of tropical plants, orange trees in fruit, palms, and rare cut flowers. The Louis XIV room was decorated with orchids.

After enjoying a sociable dinner at Morello's last evening the members of the Commonwealth Club listened to a discussion of "The Practical Working of the New-York and Massachusetts Ballot-Reform Acts." Mr. William J. Coombs, President of the club, presided over the meeting, and among the listeners to the discussion were the Hon. Carl Schurz, Everett P. Wheeler, Dorman B. Eaton, Prof. Van Amringe, Silas W. Burt, Herbert P. Turner, Walter S. Logan, and Henry Hentz.

At the first meeting of the Directors of the Harlem Free Kindergarten Association, held yesterday at 1,905 Madison Avenue, the following officers were elected: President -- M.D. Rothschild; Vice Presidents -- Ezra A. Tuttle and A. Oppenheimer; Secretary -- Thomas McAdam; Treasurer -- James Klaber. The membership fee was fixed at $2, the patrons' fee at $5, and a life membership may be secured on the payment of $50.
It is historically true that the United States Senate is a stepping stone toward the Presidency.

The name of the third victim of Brooklyn's human hair robber was entered on the blotter of the Tenth Precinct Station House, corner of Sixth Avenue and Bergen Street, Brooklyn, early this morning as Gertrude Breast. She is the seventeen-year-old daughter of Thomas S. Breast, who lives at 363 St. Mark's Place, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, and is employed in the Arbuckle Coffee Mills, foot of Jay Street.

Taxpayer Edward Henry's application for an injunction to restrain the Board of Electrical Control from making any contract with the Empire City Subway Company, Limited, for the construction of subways, and from taking any action toward relieving the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company from any of its obligations under its contract until the same should have become ineffectual, was granted yesterday by Judge Truax of the Superior Court.
