It is a striking fact that after the lapse of over two thousand years a Roman Catholic Bishop of Carthage should resume the work of reclaiming part of the great Sahara Desert, abandoned when Carthage fell beneath the power of Rome. Cardinal LAVIGERIE, whose general field is Algeria, but who is also "Bishop of Carthage," is well known for his zealous efforts to suppress the slave trade in Northern Africa.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Federal politics monopolized the time of the Assembly this evening. The Democrats attacked the Harrison Administration, and two resolutions denunciatory of the Force bill and threatening the withholding by the Assembly of the bill to appropriate $250,000 for the World's Fair were introduced and referred, after a somewhat acrimonious and stupid debate, in which the Democrats were conspicuously prominent, to the Census Committee.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 26. -- The Fisheries Department is advised that the Commissioners of Fisheries for the State of New-York have arranged a plan to place in the waters of Lake Ontario next Spring 13,000,000 whitefish, 4,000,000 ciscos, and from 8,000,000 to 10,000,000 wall-eyed pike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- In the silver pool investigation to-day John R. Tanner of Louisville, Ill., who was the first witness, said he knew nothing of silver pools or transactions, except one dealing of his own. His transaction consisted of the purchase of 100,000 ounces of silver, for which he put up a margin of $5,000. It was in the shape of certificates, purchased through S.V. White Co. of New-York.

It is strange that there should be any manner of doubt that the Farmers' Alliance members of the Kansas Legislature will elect a successor to Senator INGALLS. It is a mere question of holding together, for they have a majority of twenty on a joint ballot, and each individual is said to be bound by oath to vote against INGALLS and for the caucus candidate of the Alliance.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- Representative J.H. Mellen of Worcester this afternoon introduced in the House of Representratives at the request of the International Brotherhood of Railway Employes a bill providing for the election by the people in November of each year of three Railroad Commissioners, to serve for one year from Jan. 1 following, the Governor to fill by appointment any vacancy that may occur on the board.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- "The snow was like a thick fog and it drove so hard that it cut the skin," was the report of the storm from Pennsylvania Railroad men who came through it into Camden early yesterday morning. So dense was it that the railroad could not be discerned ten feet ahead of the locomotive, and the headlights were so deadened by ice coatings on the glass that little light penetrated.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The following is from the Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26. -- Lansing B. Mizner, ex-Minister to Guatemala, has decided to make public his official defense in the Barrundia case. He justifies this on the ground that Mr. Blaine's letter dismissing him was given to the press three weeks before it reached him and two weeks before Congress met.

The peace patched up last Summer between Guatemala and Salvador seems to have been a hollow one, and from all sides come doubts whether it will last even a twelvemonth. Yet there is no proper cause of quarrel between the two republics. The question of the legality of President EZETA'S title, which was considered as at stake before, is so no longer, Quatemala having joined the other republics in conceding it.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 26. -- To-night the Alliance has gone into a Senatorial caucus with the determination to settle upon a candidate if it takes till morning. Every candidate has been required to give his pledge to abide the result of to-night's meeting, and each Alliance member of the Legislature has taken an oath to vote for the caucus nominee.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- The storm in this city yesterday completely demoralized the fire-alarm telegraph, and the entire force of firemen was patrolling the city all night. Telephone, telegraph, and electric light companies also suffered more or less damage. On Bridge Street, East Cambridge, four large poles carrying over one hundred wires, belonging to the Long-Distance Telephone Company, were prostrated.

The war of the Bishops, which made the year 1890 memorable in the annals of the Evangelical Association of the United States, and which culminated in deposing all three of the contending Bishops, DUBBS, BOWMAN, and ESHER, has been promptly renewed this year in the courts of Illinois. The result of the legal proceedings just held in that State was a decision that ESHER had been legally deposed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- The heavy snow and sleet storm of Sunday morning prevailed at all points on the Hudson. The snow hung on trees, lay in big coils on telegraph, telephone, and electric-light wires, and made clotheslines look as big as a ship's hawser. The storm raged with great severity for nearly seven hours, and over half a foot of snow fell.

The trunk line General Passenger Agents met at 346 Broadway yesterday and disposed of two matters of interest. A resolution was passed providing that the railroads in the association shall discontinue the sale of circuitous route tickets and shall retire all such tickets outstanding as rapidly as possible.

CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- A terrific explosion of blasting powder took place this morning on the site of the annex dam of the Carmel storage reservoir and resulted in the death of Con Connelly, the foreman employed by Coleman Co. of New-York, the contractors having the work in charge. Connelly, who had had considerable experience in handling explosives, went, shortly before 8 o'clock, to the powder box, which contained twelve cases of powder.

The recent action of Congress has increased from 50 to 75 the number of army officers who may be detailed to schools and colleges as instructors in military science and tactics, so that the aggregate both of army and navy officers who can hereafter be so assigned will become 85. There are indications from applications already filed that places for many of the additional number authorized will soon be found.

The change of taste in paintings among Americans toward the middle of the present century is shown in nothing more than in the dispersal of the galleries of old masters that used to be the pride of well-to-do persons in our large cities and the accumulation of modern works by later collectors. A reaction was inevitable; a recognition of the value of old masters set in some years ago.

The tenth annual dinner of the superior officers of the Police Department was eaten last night at Delmonico's. Superintendent Murray was not there, but a letter from him explained that he obeyed the orders of his physicians. Chief Inspector Byrnes did the honors of the occasion ably. All the Inspectors were present, and the only Captain who was absent was McElwain of the Seventh Precinct, who is ill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- The six Commissioners of the Western Traffic Association resumed their meeting at Chairman Walker's office to-day, devoting the entire session to a discussion of territorial divisions. Contrary to expectation, the settlement of this question has proved to be no easy task. The most formidable stumbling block that has been encountered is a dispute as to whether Lake Superior business shall be subject to the provisions of the agreement.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27. -- The continued interruption of telegraph facilities has called a halt almost to business on the Exchanges. The little doing is for the supply of immediate wants and at prices unchanged from yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- There was a big smash-up on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad at Peekskill about 4 o'clock this afternoon. The Peekskill work train was crossing the main tracks when a heavy freight train came along at full speed and smashed into it. Both locomotives were badly wrecked, and the up and down tracks were strewn with broken and derailed cars.

The telegraph, telephone, and electric lighting companies yesterday did their best to unravel the tangle into which their wires were thrown by the storm of Sunday morning. The full extent of the damage done was hardly appreciated until this work of repair was fairly entered upon, but now it can safely be said that the devastation wrought among the wires was very much greater than that occasioned by the memorable blizzard.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- The New-York Citizens' Alliance, a humbug crowd, whose avowed object is to give greater liberty to the citizens of New-York who wish to drink beer, ale, or other spirituous beverages on Sunday without molestation by the authorities, came to Albany to-day in the person of John W. Kehoe with a bill embodying its plans.
LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Charles Bradlaugh, who was reported yesterday to be improving, has suffered a relapse. It was reported to-night that he was in an exhausted condition and suffering from insomnia.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 27. -- A special from Scottdale, Penn., says: By an explosion of fire-damp in the Mammoth shaft of the H.C. Frick Coke Company 110 sturdy miners were hurled into eternity and a number seriously injured.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- A rapid-transit bill will be favorably reported to the Senate by the Railroads Committee of that body to-morrow morning. It will bear Senator Stewart's name, but will be practically the Ives bill, with the addition of the amendments proposed by Senator Robertson last week.

PIERRE, S.D., Jan. 27. -- Senator Moody has released the Republican caucus from further obligations to him as its nominee, in view of the utter hopelessness of his cause. His most valiant worker, Senator Pettigrew, together with a large number of smaller politicians who have remained here in his interests, departed to-day, giving up the fight.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 27. -- The stalwart Republican Pittsburg Times, owned by C.L. Magee, for many years one of Senator Cameron's stanchest friends, will say to-morrow:

A brilliant and fashionable wedding was celebrated in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, in Fifth Avenue, at 8:30 o'clock last night, when Miss Marion Abbot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Abbot, was married to Mr. Abbott Treadwell, son of the late Col. Thomas J. Treadwell, United States Army. The Rev. D. Parker Morgan officiated.

BOSTON, Jan. 27. -- The residence of ex-Gov. Oliver Ames, on Commonwealth Avenue and Westchester Park, was the scene of a charming home wedding at early noon to-day. The bride was his daughter, Miss Anna Lee Ames, the groom Mr. George M. Nowell of Commonwealth Avenue.

The Elkhorn Coal and Land Company organized at 2 Wall Street yesterday, electing these Directors: Edmund Smith, Calvin S. Brice, Constant A. Andrews, Russell Sturgis, and Clarence Andrews. Constant A. Andrews was made President, Russell Sturgis Secretary, and Clarence Andrews Treasurer. The company's property is on the Elkhorn River, in West Virginia, on the line of the Norfolk and Western Railroad.

There is reported to be some talk at Topeka about the refusal of the Kansas Senate to meet the House in joint convention to-day for the election of a United States Senator, but the Republicans who control the upper branch of the Legislature will hardly go to the length of preventing an election by such a desperate device in the face of the positive requirements of the Federal statute.

BUFFALO, Jan. 27. -- From reports which have recently come to this city from Albany, friends of Speaker Sheehan are beginning to be fearful that he is going to have a difficult task in managing things this year so that the Democratic majority in the Assembly can come out of the session of 1891 without producing one or more big scandals.

It is a little too soon to be sure of the failure of the Silver bill. It is undoubtedly deeply discredited. The sentiment of conservative men in opposition has made itself felt The malodor from the investigating committee's room offends some and frightens others of those who might have supported the bill.

The Driveway Commission appointed by Mayor Grant to consider the project of constructing a driveway on the Hudson River water front from Seventy-second to Ninety-sixth Street and making other great improvements in the vicinity, as recommended by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, met in the Mayor's office yesterday afternooon.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Provisions during the day were exceedingly weak, that, too, without a very heavy trade. The announcement that the stock of Ribs Feb. 1 would probably be the largest on record had possibly something to do with the selling spirit. Of late the offerings have come from the manufacturers. To-day this was not the case. It was liquidation by outside holders, a slaughter of the innocents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Attorney General Miller presented his answer in the Supreme Court this afternoon to the motion for leave to file a petition for a writ of prohibition to amend the proceedings of the Sitka (Alaska) court in the case of the schooner Sayward, seized by the Rush in the Summer of 1887 for catching seals in Alaskan waters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Senator Hearst has been reported as dying in nearly every paper that has been issued for a week, and he is still in what his physicians regard as a dangerous condition. His serious illness was, until the disposition of Senator Stanford toward the Force bill and the closure resolution was known, a matter of grave concern to the opponents of the gag rule.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Dispatches received in this city from Chile, via Buenos Ayres, say that the rebel Chilean war vessels occupied the roadstead at Porto Coquimbo on a day not specified, but supposed to be about four or five days ago. The war vessels also fired shots into the town, probably at the troops defending the coal depots.

Senator Leland Stanford sold the first consignment of his Palo Alto bred trotting stock yesterday at the American Institute Building. This consignment included the get of the famous Electioneer, Ansel, Fallis, Benefit, Norval, Piedmont, Alban, Nephew, Clay, Liberty, and Whips. Of these stallions Norval, Clay, Whips, Ansel, and Fallis are sons of Electioneer, and several of the get of the other stallions were out of mares by Electioneer.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 27. -- The Board of Trade of this city this morning entered a unanimous protest against the passage of the Silver bill by the adoption of a comprehensive series of resolutions.

The disorder that has been brought about in Paris by the production of SARDOU'S "Thermidor" at least shows how much closer the drama is to the actual life of the people in France than in any other country, except, possibly, Italy. It is impossible to imagine a mob collected in New-York to hoot the dispersing spectators of a play in which objectionable political sentiments are inculcated.

The McKinley act and the Dingley act were aired in the United States Circuit Court yesterday before Judge Lacombe, and their constitutionality was discussed. A suit was brought by Herrman, Sternback Co. for a review of the action of the Board of General Appraisers in regard to the classification of importations of certain cotton and flax goods.

The authorities of the New-York Stock Exchange are in a dilemma. Mr. Jay Gould is responsible for their unhappiness. They will hold an official session to-night. They will try to solve their difficulties. They are likely to meet with some rather corpulent obstacles.

The well-known Wall street house of H.K. Enos Co. is to go out of business Feb. 1, after an existence of eleven years. The firm is made up of H.K. Enos and Thomas C. Buck. Both of these men are members of the Stock Exchange, Mr. Enos having been admitted on May 11, 1878, and Mr. Buck on Oct. 9, 1879. Their handsome quarters are at 45 Wall Street.

TRENTON, Jan. 27. -- Hudson kicked her heels up high at noon to-day. The State House bosses had issued a sudden and unexpected call for a joint caucus, and the Hudson men made up their minds that the time was ripe for that little revolt which they had been talking about for a fortnight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The steel jacket was successfully put on the first twelve-inch, built-up, breech-loading rifle for the navy at the Washington Ordnance Factory this afternoon. The operation to-day was interesting, as the gun is the largest yet in course of construction in the United States.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 27. -- Grace Protestant Episcopal Church was crowded to-night with people well-known in society and literary circles to witness the marriage of Miss Hester Crawford Dorsey to Mr. Albert L. Richardson of New-York. The bride is a successful writer and the founder of the Woman's Literary Club of Baltimore. The groom was for a long time connected with journalism in this city.

Mr. J.H. Biles, an eminent English engineer and a member of the Council of Naval Architects, who has recently received the rare honor of an appointment as a member of Lloyds Committee, has been in this country for ten days, most of his time here having been spent as the guest of Mr. C.C. Griscom of Philadelphia, President of the Inman and International Steamship Company.

An entertainment consisting of readings and music for the benefit of the Training School for Nurses connected with the Post-Graduate Hospital was given yesterday at 12 o'clock at the Plaza Hotel The company which assembled to enjoy it more than filled the large room which had generously been placed at the disposal of the managers by the proprietor of the hotel, Mr. F.A. Hammond. The net proceeds exceeded $500.

The financial question played but a minor part in the recent Italian elections out of which CRISPI came so triumphantly. The burden of his own speechifying was denunciation of Irredentism, and harping on the vast increase of national dignity and importance which had come with the triple alliance and the reappearance of Italy as a factor in European politics.

The building planned by Capt. R.W. MEADE for the Navy Department exhibit in 1893 will lend a welcome nautical aspect to the Chicago fair. As a certain memorable ocean voyage is nominally the event to be celebrated by "the World's Columbian Exposition," it has several times occurred to the managers that something in the guise of a vessel would not be out of place.

The Young People's Christian Association of New-York City, a union of young people's societies connected with the evangelical churches, held its fifth annual convention yesterday in the Madison Avenue Reformed Church, corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue. At the afternoon session 75 of the 234 societies comprising the association were represented.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 27. -- The particulars of the collision between a passenger train and the special bearing the troops from Pine Ridge, which occurred last evening on the Union Pacific Railroad at Florence, a small station near Irwing, Ken., have been received here. The special was carrying about 400 soldiers, part of the Seventh Cavalry and Battery E, Light Artillery, bound for Fort Riley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The storm which did so much damage to telegraph wires in and about New-York was also responsible for the little outbreak of ill temper which marked the vote in the Senate yesterday which set aside the gag rule.

The report of the State Commissioners in Lunacy, which has just been submitted to the Legislature, contains a number of important suggestions and recommendations for improving the administration of the hospitals for the insane, showing the importance of a comprehensive and harmonious system.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 27. -- The long contest is practically ended, and W.A. Peffer, editor of the Kansas Farmer, will succeed Ingalls as United States Senator, receiving 98 votes. Ingalls received 58 votes, and 8 went around scattered by men who did not have the nerve to place them where they most desired.
The following business was transacted at the Ex-change and Auction Room yesterday, Tuesday Jan. 97.

Apparently nothing can prevent the bill allowing the sale of wine, ale, and beer at balls after 1 o'clock at night from passing the Assembly precisely as it came from the Senate, which is likely to impress the responsible majority in the latter body with the fact that it is well to give more careful consideration to measures that somebody is in a hurry to get through.

Lawyer Charles F. Mathewson of the Berkeley Athletic Club said yesterday than an agreement had been practically reached whereby the Berkeley Athletic Club will lease the clubhouse at 19 West Forty-fourth Street of the Berkeley Athletic Association, the corporation owning it, as well as the Berkeley Oval at Morris Dock, and the boathouse on the Harlem River at that point.

TORONTO, Jan. 28. -- Sir John Macdonald left here for Ottawa to-night. He was entertained at a banquet last night by Toronto supporters, to whom he made an address touching on the policy his Government intended to pursue in regard to trade relations with the United States. Their opponents, reformers in Canada, had, he said, as many aliases for their policy as a thief has excuses for his wrongdoings.

The more closely the little speculation of Senator CAMERON in silver is examined, the less flattering is the result to that gentleman. He has himself admitted that he bought silver on a margin, and voted for the Free-Coinage bill that was to make that silver legal tender, at his option, for 25 per cent. more than he paid for it.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- The marriage of Miss Haller Horwitz, daughter of Mrs. Horwitz of Baltimore, to Mr. Claude Ponsonby, son of the Hon. Ashley Ponsonby and cousin of Sir Henry Ponsonby, Equerry to the Queen, took place to-day at Ascot, near Windsor.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28. -- A controversy over the estate of the late Noah Walker has been begun in the courts. Noah Walker died on Feb. 8, 1874, leaving an estate estimated at $1,500,000. Samuel Hamilton Caughy and Noah Walker Caughy were named in the will as sole trustees of the whole estate, and no bond was required of them. The sum of $25,000 was bequeathed to each of the trustees.

The milk business is hardly profitable to the farmers this Winter and the prospects for an improvement in the trade in the Spring are not very bright. The prices of feed for the cows are high, and so are the freight rates on the railroads, while the abundant supply of milk keeps the prices down. The milk farmer is not a person to be envied this Winter.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Upon the invitation of the State Board of Agriculture, Mr. Chauncey B. Ripley delivered an address before that body to-day at the State House in favor of improved roads. The subject is one upon which Mr. Ripley speaks with authority, for he has been foremost in awakening interest in it -- not in New-Jersey alone, but in other States.

There is every prospect now of the speedy enactment of a satisfactory rapid transit law applicable to this city alone. The Senate yesterday passed the modified Stewart bill unanimously, after refusing, by a vote of 23 to 7, to strike out the section referring to extensions of the privileges of the existing elevated railroads, and after adopting an amendment prohibiting any such extension in Battery Park.

The Michigan Masonic Home at Grand Rapids, Mich., for aged and infirm Master Masons, their widows and orphans, was dedicated Tuesday with appropriate ceremonies by the Grand Lodge of Michigan. Hugh McCurdy, Deputy Grand Commander of the Grand Commandery of Knights Templar of the United States, delivered the address. The home is a magnificent structure of white brick, costing $80,000, situated on the shore of Reed's Lake, three miles east from Grand Rapids.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28. -- Some weeks ago Mr. Hale Parker, Principal of the Alexandre Dumas (Colored) School, made formal application to President Harrison for an appointment on the World's Fair Commission as Commissioner at Large, representing the colored race. Principal Parker's application was indorsed by letters from prominent citizens strongly recommending him for the position.

ANTIGO, Wis., Jan. 28. -- The committee appointed by the County Board to examine the accounts of C.H. Larseclere, County Treasurer, has made a report that his accounts are short $9,282. Notwithstanding his re-election last Fall, he has been unable so far to secure bonds, and the board will declare the office vacant and put in a new man.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 28. -- The lottery managers evidently wish to cover some of their tracks. Last Saturday suspicions were aroused among the stockholders, when in collecting their dividends they were required to sign a resolution heading the receipt book indorsing all expenditures by the lessees authorizing the destruction of all vouchers for moneys expended and approving the management of the concern.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 28. -- The Hon. J.F. Chaplean, the Dominion Secretary of State, is in arms against the proposal of his English-speaking colleagues to allow the bill passed by the Manitoba Legislature abolishing separate schools and French as an official language in that Province to go into effect. In an address at Kingston Friday night he raised the loyalty cry and spoke as follows:

Since the unfortunate mishap to the Serpent, the following order has been issued to commanding officers of her Majesty's ships: "One Lieutenant or sub-Lieutenant and (in ships bearing them) one midshipman shall be directed to take the requisite observations, work the reckoning, and determine the error of the standard compass daily when at sea, independently of the navigating officer.

Brisk bidding and better prices ruled yesterday at the sale of Senator Leland Stanford's California-bred trotting horses in the American Institute Building. Yesterday was the second day of the sale, and forty-five horses were disposed of for a total of $49,420, an average of $1,098.22. This was an improvement compared with Tuesday, when the sale of forty-three horses brought a total of $41,745.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- It was an instructive sight in the Senate to-day, when eleven Senators, all Republicans, all allied with Thomas C. Platt, voted with Jay Gould and against the Sheard amendment to exempt Battery Park from the operations of the Stewart Rapid Transit bill. Nothing could have been more clever than this amendment, this flank movement of Senator Sheard.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The annual report of the State Assessors will be submitted to the Legislature to-morrow.

GENTLEMEN: The labor of another year is completed. The results covering our work for the first decade in our history are before you. Our books containing the record of the work accomplished during the tenth year of our labor are closed, and we enter upon the first year of the second decade of our history under more favorable auspices than has existed at any time since the organization of the association.

The Red "D" Line steamship Philadelphia, in from La Guayra yesterday morning, spoke the bark Montreal in latitude 33, longitude 72, last Monday flying distress signals. The bark, which was seventy-one days out from Windsor, N.S., on her way to St. Simon, Ga., had been doing little except fighting gales and hurricanes since leaving port, and she had lost most of her sails and received damage about decks.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The commission appointed to codify the fish and game laws of this State, consisting of Gen. R.U. Sherman, Robert B. Roosevelt, and Edward G. Whitaker, will submit its report to the Legislature to-morrow, accompanied by a long bill as a result of their labors. The report says in brief:

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The Rev. M. Van Auken, a Lutheran minister from Utica, was taken from this city last night to the insane asylum. Mr. Van Auken's wife was buried on the 17th inst. Last Saturday he came here to see his nephew, President Kellogg of the Elmira Bridge Company. Sunday he became insane from brooding over the death of his wife, and Sunday night disappeared.

YOUNGWOOD, Penn., Jan. 28. -- One hundred and ten bodies had been taken from the ill-fated mine of Frick Co., at Mammoth up to 2 o'clock this afternoon. It is estimated that the remains of at least seventeen more victims of yesterday's explosion are still in the pit, but it is thought that all will be out in a few hours.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Joseph H. Choate today concluded the argument begun by him yesterday in behalf of the petitioners in the Bering Sea case. He submitted that, if the court reached the point that it had the right to grant the application, it did not matter whether it was a political or a judicial question in the present aspect of the case.

Controller MYERS has written a letter to the Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Public Institutions protesting against the appropriation for carrying out the law which provides for State care of the insane on the ground that it will impose a burden upon this city for an object from which it will derive no direct benefit.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 28. -- The passage of an act by the recent Legislature providing for a commission to take charge of the phosphate mining industry in South Carolina has caused something of a flutter in commercial circles in the State. The act, which will go into effect March 1, embodies the ideas on this subject advanced by Gov. Tillman during the recent campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- When the attempt by the Senate to apply the previous question, or the gag rule, to that body was defeated on Monday by the motion of Mr. Wolcott of Colorado to proceed to the consideration of the Apportionment bill, the Senate did something more than decide that it was inexpedient to insist upon getting at the Force bill with a rule that would enable its supporters to pass it.

BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- What is generally believed to be the oldest house standing in Boston has been transferred from one estate to another for the first time in over 200 years. The property is known as the Wells mansion and is situated at 119 Salem Street. The sale was to Mr. Ratchesky, the Hebrew millionaire, who has been making so many investments in the north end recently.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 28. -- A wedding in which eight clergymen participated took place at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at 7 o'clock this evening, when Miss Caroline Elizabeth Lowrie, daughter of Dr. H.H. Lowrie, was married to the Rev. Cornelius Gardner Bristol, rector of the St. Alban's Episcopal Church at Danielsonville, Conn.

Great progress has been made by the telegraph, telephone, and electric lighting companies in restoring the service over the wires wrecked by the recent storm. Nearly all evidence of the devastation has been removed from the streets of this city. The electric lighting companies yesterday announced that their circuits had all been cleared again and that the Board of Electrical Control had granted permits for the entire resumption of business.

According to his will, suitable mausoleum is to be erected in the highest part of the Athenian cemetery for himself, his Greek wife, and the two children born of his marriage with her. The will was accompanied by a plan of the mausoleum, (drawn by an architect named Ziller,) the interior of which is decorated after the fashion of Orchomenus and Pompeii. The cost is put at 50,000 drachmas.

The gentlemen who are suggesting an amendment to the Copyright bill providing that copyright shall be granted to designs by foreign artists or designers only when the object in which the design is embodied is manufactured exclusively in this country can hardly have realized the precise nature of the condition proposed by them, or its necessary results.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 28. -- In this town of great industrial enterprises and huge speculations, George Westinghouse, Jr., has for ten years past been a figure of interest. He first attracted attention by the versatility of his inventive genius, then by the boldness and scope of his business undertakings, and now all eyes are turned upon him in his heroic efforts to avert disaster.

ROME, Jan. 28. -- Signor Grimaldi presented the annual financial statement to the Chamber of Deputies to-day. It shows a deficit for 1891 of 60, 000,000f. Deficits of 40,000,000f, yearly are expected for the next three years. Increased duties are proposed on oil seeds and mineral oils, as well as various economies, chiefly in the military and public works budgets.

The alarm started in Northern Minnesota among the settlements bordering on the Chippewa reservations is entirely natural, considering the recent events in Dakota, but there is good ground for trusting that no trouble will occur. The Chippewas of that region, it appears, are engaged in a series of dances.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- A great surprise came this afternoon to the officers of the Clifton race track in the form of a speedy conviction on the indictments charging them with keeping a disorderly house. The first indictments taken up were against George H. Engeman, William A. Engeman, John J. Engeman, A. H. Battersby, and C. V. Sass. Judge Dixon and Judge Inglis occupied the bench.

It must be a source of unqualified gratification to the Vice President that the gag rule never got any further than it did, and that he will probably for the remainder of his term be allowed to exercise in tranquillity the legitimate functions of his office or to abstain from exercising them a all.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 28. -- Ex-Gov. William Pitt Kellogg who has just returned from West Louisiana, where he has recently made some investments, has repeatedly prophesied the defeat of the Force bill.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 28. -- Out of the singular provision governing Congressional elections in Rhode Island which renders this State peculiar in requiring a majority of votes to elect upon first trial has grown a disgraceful struggle for partisan advantage which yesterday culminated in an all-day squabble in the Grand Committee, as the joint assembly of the Senate and House of Representatives is termed.

Miss Sophy Sturge of Birmingham, England, a daughter of the late eminent Quaker philanthropist Joseph Sturge, whose statue the city preserves, and of whom Whittier has written so beautifully, moved with sympathy for the suffering poor of Ireland, has made her home at Letterfrack, Galway, and devotes herself to teaching the women and children the art of fancy basket making, the baskets finding a ready market in England.

The tenth annual meeting of the members of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of New-York was held yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, at the offices of the company in the Potter Building, this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Secretary of the Navy has finally decided to change the batteries of the cruisers Cincinnati and Raleigh, the two 3,000-ton cruisers building in the New-York and Norfolk Navy Yards, respectively, and cruisers Nos. 9, 10, and 11, the three 2,000-ton cruisers, of which the first two are building in Baltimore and the latter in Boston.

The decision of the Collector at Burlington, Vt., that a duty of 12 cents a pound -- which is more than 300 per cent. -- must be paid, under the McKinley law, on common goat hair, which has heretofore been imported free of duty, has been affirmed by the Board of General Appraisers.

While a restless Hungarian band played waltzes, polkas, and gavottes, and while a dozen or more elaborate mechanical toys played amusing pranks on the banquet tables, the members of the Association of the Alumni of the University of the City of New-York, enjoyed their annual dinner at the Hotel Brunswick last night. The company included many distinguished New-Yorkers and the occasion was a very merry one.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 9. -- C.M. Bell, a Washington (D.C.) photographer, recently sued the Henderson Krebs Lithographic Company for $34,000 damages for infringing on his copyright of a picture of Mrs. Cleveland. The bottom of the affair fell out to-day.

Mayor Chapin made public his new Brooklyn Bridge bill yesterday, and sent it to Albany last night. The first section authorizes the Trustees to improve the terminal facilities, and the second provides that the new structure shall extend only over the sidewalks, and shall not extend "north of the southerly side of Park Row," in this city, nor south of the northerly side of Tillary Street, in Brooklyn.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 29. -- The action of the several medical societies in this State which have taken steps to have a bill presented to the General Assembly to prevent the practice of medicine by quacks has aroused the dentists, and this year an effort will be made to secure the passage of a bill to regulate the practice of dentistry.

The importers of this city are greatly pleased over the decision just rendered by the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the proceeding brought by the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation against all the transcontinental railroad lines and their connections engaged in the transportation of goods from the seaboard. Atlantic and Pacific, and from the Gulf of Mexico to interior points.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29. -- When W.A. Peffer was elected United States Senator on joint ballot yesterday, he responded to a call of the House and expressed himself as follows:

The report of the committee of the Connecticut House of Representatives on the canvass of votes is not in the least likely to contribute to clearing up the muddle in the Legislature over the election of State officers, but it shows the mischief of any attempt to go behind the regular official returns of a popular election in declaring the result.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 29. -- The trial of the Rev. Dr. William Mitchell, formerly of Boston, Mass., and for two years past pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church of Fort Worth, was finished in the District Court to-day. Dr. Mitchell was arrested last Summer for forging the name of Martin Case, an intimate friend, to a number of notes, amounting to $5,000.
BUENOS AYRES, Jan. 29. -- Advices received here from Chile show that the insurgents are steadily gaining ground.

The linseed oil men finished their conference at 1 Broadway yesterday and adjourned, having accomplished the objects for which they came together. One of these objects was an advance in the price of their product, and, as a result of the meeting, a new scale of rates was adopted, to take effect immediately. It involves an advance of about 1 cent per gallon.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 29. -- Perhaps the most remarkable scene in the history of the State Legislature was presented to-day. It was that of the representatives of two parties, who met as two houses, for ninety days last Winter and for over three weeks this year, meeting together as one house in the hall where the Republicans have been holding sessions. It was a genuine love feast.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Joseph Nolan, member for North Louth, asked that the Government, in common with the Governments of other nations, should join in a movement which should result in conferring upon Prof. Koch a pecuniary reward for the services he has rendered to humanity.

When Shoverling, Daly Gales imported some gun stocks a little while ago they were charged the duty levied upon sporting guns. They claimed that they should pay the duty on the articles as "manufactures of which metal was the component part," and appealed from the decision of the Board of Appraisers to the United States Circuit Court. Judge Lacombe heard the argument yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 29. -- The suit of the National Tradesmen's Bank of this city against W. Whittemore of Meriden, Conn., involving the ownership of the greater part of the Blue Mountain in the Adirondacks -- including about two-thirds of a township -- after a varied career in the court of New-York State, stands where it was when the litigation was begun six years ago.

ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 29. -- Arkansas City has been filled with men from the surrounding country and towns, eager by their presence and eloquence to add some weight to the opening of the Cherokee outlet. The convention was called to order at the Opera House. There was an immense throng present.

As a mere piece of party tactics, and judging it by its effect upon partisans only, the little game now going on among the Republicans of the House of Representatives does not seem very promising. The friends of the Force bill are seeking to defeat the Free-Coinage bill in revenge for the course of the silver men in defeating the Force bill.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 29. -- Brussels was truly a city of mourning to-day, the day of Prince Baudouin's funeral, black bunting, draped flags, and crape being seen on all sides. The humblest houses vied with the richest mansions in exhibiting outward sings of sorrow at the death of the popular Prince Baudouin.

WASHNGTON, Jan. 29. -- The news of the death of Secretary Windom reached here late to-night, but spread with great rapidity, causing general astonishment and profound regret. To the President, who was at dinner at the house of the Postmaster General, the announcement was painfully shocking, and the information fell upon all of the social entertainments of the evening like a pall.

When the late Mr. ENG learned of the death of his twin brother CHANG, to whom he was much attached, a sickening fear seized upon him, a mortal chill ran through all his veins, and presently he himself died. The New-York Sun is affected in much the same way by the news of the political death and burial of Senator INGALLS.

Hans S. Beattie, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, has increased the salary of his deputy, William Dalton, leader of Tammany in the Fifteenth District, from $3,000 to $3,500 per annum. The salary of the Superintendent, a place that is now being filled by Assistant Superintendent Robbins, was decreased from $2,800 to $2,500, and the salary of the Assistant Superintendent was increased from $2,000 to $2,200.

The funeral of Prince BAUDOUIN was the most memorable pageant that Brussels has witnessed for many years. It testified in a striking way to the existence and the political influence, even in the most modern communities, of what we are apt to regard as the obsolete sentiment of personal loyalty.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- The strike of the employes of the United Shirt and Collar Company has ended in a victory for the strikers, although the latter made some concessions. settlement was reached this afternoon. The United Shirt and Collar Company is composed of manufacturers who formerly comprised five firms. A month ago they arranged a new schedule of prices so as to make a uniform rate to be paid in all their factories.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Commissioner Roosevelt and Superintendent Porter of the Census Bureau were in attendance at this morning's meeting of the House committee on reform in the civil service. Mr. Porter had made some statements at a previous meeting which Mr. Roosevelt had construed into an attack upon the Civil Service Commission's methods, and he was armed with a typewritten statement in reply. Mr. Porter sat by to prepare himself for the rebuttal.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- Last night's performance at the Theatre Francais was quiet enough, for the police promptly suppressed demonstrations upon the part of an element of the audience that wanted to call for "Thermidor." The members of the theatre are again discussing the idea of abandoning its charter and of forming a free organization with a new theatre to be called the Theatre Affranchi. It is said that 4.000,000f, are promised toward this scheme.

The manning of the navy has become a question of no little concern for the Bureau of Navigation, which has charge of the subject. The sending to sea of a large part of the cruisers lately in home ports, including Admiral WALKER'S squadron of evolution, has pretty nearly drained the receiving ships of men.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 30. -- Another strong complaint is being made at this point against the manipulation east-bound rates through routing freight by the longer lines. The trouble arises from shipments of packing-house products east from Kansas City. It is assured that the bulk of the meat shipments east are going over the Indiana, Illinois and Iowa Road. The line is 119 miles in length and runs from Streator to North Judson and Knox.

Anglers who are always either recalling encounters with large fish or looking forward to a coming season on the stream or pond are already beginning to speculate as to next season. Some of the wise fishermen profess to foretell the luck of the Spring fishermen by the kind of Winter that has been experienced. A mild, open Winter is always construed as favorable to the fish and a severe one as the contrary.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 30. -- There are no new developments in the financial situation of the Winona Company at Holyoke. Local bankers view the situation hopefully. The following additional attachments were served on the company to-day: Attlebury Brothers of Brooklyn, N.Y., $8,000; Goddard Machine Company of Holyoke, $3,000; Williams Sons of Easton, Penn., $2,000, and H.E. Gaylord, coal dealer, of Holyoke, $1,000.

The Controller of the Currency yesterday gave his formal assent to the reduction of the capital stock of the Third National Bank from $1,000,000 to $750,000, and he likewise assented to the subscription of $250,000, which latter was necessary, because of the impairment of capital and surplus through the recent "kiting" operations and loans to Simmons and his associates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The monthly pilot chart for the North Atlantic Ocean for February will be issued by the Hydrographic Office tomorrow, and will present the usual information of interest to mariners. The weather forecast for the month will say:

It is tolerably well known now that, while the makers of the new tariff law openly increased the duties on many kinds of goods, they at the same time increased duties on a considerable number of products surreptitiously, by tricks and devices of one kind or another. In these instances they sought to conceal the advances by apparently unimportant changes of phraseology, or by the omission of certain words, or in other ways.

The transfer of the custody of the official election returns of Connecticut from the Legislature to the Governor, who has properly no concern with them, would not be a matter of much consequence, apart from its utterly unlawful character, but for the suspicion that there is some crooked design in it.

The auction sale of the De Haas paintings at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries was continued and concluded last evening. The attendance was even larger than on the first night's sale, and as the breezy marine views appeared, they were greeted with a brisk, spirited bidding that showed the interest and appreciation of the audience.

MEADVILLE, Jan. 30. -- The Delamaters are again under arrest. This evening a complaint was made before Justice Dougan by G.W. Willer of this city and a warrant was issued for the arrest of G.B. Delamater, G.W. Delamater, T.A. Delamater, and V.M. Delamater. The first three composed the late banking firm of Delamater Co., and the last named was cashier.
We commend to the Democratic leaders in Congress the following petition, signed by bankers and business men of Louisville, Ky. It is very brief, but it is very pregnant:

ELIZABETH, Jan. 30. -- A big struggle is on hand between this city and the Central Railroad Company over the proposed opening of Third and Front Streets, the two chief arteries that pass through the manufacturing portion of the city from east to west.

The next United States Senate will consist of 88 Senators, and the roll now lacks but 3 names to make it complete. The names of 46 Republicans are upon the list. Of the remaining 39 names 37 are those of "straight" Democrats; the other 2 belong to the Farmers' Alliance men elected from South Carolina and Kansas.

Tammany's new General Committee met in the Wigwam last night and organized for 1891. The body of the big hall was packed with office holders, would-be office holders, and men who have already made their fortunes out of holding office and getting offices for others to hold. Sweet recollections of boodle days were called up by the presence of ex-Alderman Patrick Farley of the Sixth District, who was a member of the board of 1884.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Six men began work this week on a building for the World's Columbian Exposition Company. The building, a small frame affair, is situated on the lake front at the foot of Harrison Street. It is to be used by the construction department and by the force of superintendents that will soon be working on the big exposition buildings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The silver' hearings were continued by the House Coinage Committee to-day. Director Leech of the Mint said that the exchange value of silver had been kept equal to that of gold because the Government would exchange silver for gold. A refusal to do this would injure the credit of the Government. He did not believe gold and silver would circulate together if bimetallism were established here.

It is not very creditable to the New-York City delegation in the Assembly that thirteen of its twenty-four members were absent from their seats when the Rapid-Transit bill made its appearance in the chamber yesterday morning. Here was the most important measure of the session, so far as this city is concerned, and the one in which its people take a greater interest than in all others combined.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30. -- Monks Mound, the oldest and most imposing landmark in the Great American Bottom, and which is so graphically described by Charles Dickens in his "American Notes" as the greatest of all Indian mounds, is, so it is reported, to be leveled to the natural surface and hauled away to fill a portion of East St. Louis to grade.

The contest was resumed before Surrogate Coffin at White Plains yesterday over the will of the late William L. Wallace, the millionaire candy manufacturer of this city, who resided at Tarrytown. The contest is by his daughter, Kate, who eloped with a young man named H.H. Wood of Sing Sing, for doing which the father disinherited her.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- Railroad employes should be pensioned in case they receive any injuries while in performance of any service for a railroad corporation. Soldiers, policemen, and sailors in the navy are pensioned in case they are disabled or incapacitated from labor while in the performance of their duties. The services of a railroad employe are as necessary to the welfare of the country as are the labors of the navy, militia, or police.

Corporation Counsel Jenks of Brooklyn served his answer yesterday to the amended complaint in the suit of William Ziegler to prevent the consummation of the sale of the Long Island Water Supply Company to the city at the exorbitant price of $1,250,000. The answer is very lengthy and is identical with the original one, except in that it takes up the new allegations contained in the amended complaint, and denies them in toto.

The Hon. Hugh S. [sic] Grant, Mayor of the city of New-York, arrived in Charleston, via the Atlantic Coast Line early yesterday morning, in his own special car, the Mayflower, on an extended trip South, through the States along the Atlantic.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- In St. James's Hall to-night, Gen. Booth of the Salvation Army began the carrying into effect of the scheme of social regeneration set forth in his book, "In Darkest England and the Way Out." In connection with the exercises, he affixed his signature to the deed of trust drawn up in the interest of the subscribers to the fund for carrying on the work.

" Our Navy" was to have been the subject of Secretary Tracy's speech at the Board of Trade dinner Thursday night, when the sudden death of Mr. Windom brought the programme to an unexpected close. There were a good many interesting statements in the Secretary's manuscript, and, had it been read aloud, many of those present would have learned some important practical lessons of the new navy.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Mr. Charles Bradlaugh, member of Parliament for Northampton, who had been critically ill for some time past, died at 6 o'clock this morning. Mr. Bradlaugh's end was quiet and peaceful. He was insensible when he died, and seemed to suffer no pain. The immediate cause of his death was uraemin. The funeral will take place Tuesday. There will be no funeral procession, no show of mourning, and no religious service.

There was a notable gathering of persons prominent in the theatrical and social world at the home of Mr. and Mrs. A.M. Palmer, 25 East Sixty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon to meet Mr. E.S. Willard, the English actor. Mrs. Palmer received the guests in the large drawing room. She wore a dress of yellow silk trimmed with white lace and pearl ornaments, and she was assisted by Mrs. Lyman Fiske and Mrs. A.M. Dickenson.

A great crowd was present in the Court of General Sessions yesterday to see what would become of the fraudulent divorce lawyers, William H. Buttner and William D. Hughes. Both men, when called to the bar to receive sentence, made speeches.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The Rockaway Park Improvement Company, Limited, petitioned the Governor last October for relief from the offensive and dangerous nuisances which emanate from certain factories on Barren Island, asking that he direct the abatement of the nuisances complained of. The matter was referred to the State Board of Health.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 30. -- The social event of the Winter in Richmond society, and, indeed, in Virginia society, was the Association Ball to-night. This was given under the auspices and for the benefit of the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities, an organization which came into existence at Williamsburg, the colonial capital of Virginia, two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Representative Dockery of Missouri appeared before the Silver Pool Investigation Committee to-day and said that inasmuch as he had, when last on the stand, given his testimony hastily and without sufficient deliberation, he desired briefly to restate the reasons why he did not wish to testify until the day after the Senatorial election in Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- While many persons in Washington heard last night of the sudden death of Secretary Windom in New-York, by far the larger number of officials and private citizens learned of it from the morning papers, and dwelt upon the melancholy topic all day long. The regret at his death was shared by everybody.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Already, before the office of Secretary of the Treasury has been vacant twenty-four hours, speculation is active about his successor. The President was so shocked by the suddenness of the Secretary's death and has been so occupied with business that demanded immediate consideration, that he has not had opportunity to consider the matter of the appointment of his successor.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Mr. Shaw-Lefevre (Liberal) moved in the House of Commons to-day that the Government use its influence in favor of the settlement by arbitration of the remaining disputes between tenants and landlords in Ireland arising from the plan of campaign. He said that there were now only twenty estates upon which differences exist.

The death of CHARLES BRADLAUGH removes from English politics a striking and interesting figure at an age when, as the lives of English statesmen go, he could not be called an old and was commonly regarded as a "rising" man. But his personality, individual as it was, was not so interesting or so instructive as the persecution to which he was subjected.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 30. -- The contents of a mail box were found yesterday in Holmes Co.'s lumber yard, at Tenth and Spruce Streets, and Superintendent Dice and his railway inspectors are trying to solve the mystery of the robbery, for there is no doubt that a robbery, and a pretty big one, has been committed.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 30. -- The Democrats were compelled to speak to empty Republican benches in the House this afternon in discussing the investigating committee's report, but before abandoning the Capitol the Republicans adopted a resolution guarding against any advantage that might be taken by the Democrats, who outnumbered their opponents three to one in the House most of the afternoon.

It is generally stated by all who were familiar with the official life of the late Secretary of the Treasury that he was literally worn out by the exacting nature of his duties. Though a strong man, with unusual executive capacity, familiar with the work of the office, methodical in his business habits, his strength was overtaxed as was that of Mr. FOLGER and Mr. MANNING before him.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 30. -- Resolutions of respect to the memory of Secretary Windom were adopted in the State Legislature.

The American Water-Color Society is nearly a quarter of a century old, and has the good fortune never to have suffered the ups and downs which usually attend associations of artists who make yearly exhibitions of their work. This result is largely due to the popularity of water colors, but good sense in the management of the society has played its part.

ITHACA, Jan. 30. -- The Class of '92, Cornell, gave its Junior ball to-night in the armory. The ball was the greatest social event ever held in Ithaca, the attendance far surpassing that of any previous ball. The armory was decorated in accordance with special designs. The ceiling was hidden by heavy gray moss, the walls were decorated with flags, class colors, and lace curtains.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Both branches of the Legislature took appropriate action to-day in memory of the dead Secretary of the Treasury. In the Senate as soon as the regular order of business had been disposed of Senator Robertson made a motion, which was unanimously adopted, that the Senate adjourn as a mark of respect to the memory of the late Secretary Windom.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 30. -- A notable event of each social year in the Oranges is the ball of the Orange Athletic Club. This ball, which is always considered the close of the social season, took place last night. The entire clubhouse was prettily decorated. In the reception room there were banks of palms and ferns in the corners and rich Oriental rugs were draped about the walls.
PARIS, Jan. 31. -- Jean Louis Ernest Meissonier, the painter, who has been ill for several days, died in this city to-day.

NEWPORT, R. I., Jan. 31. -- The Newport Street Railway Company held its annual meeting this week and showed its finances to be in an excellent condition. The stockholders unanimously approved the action of the Directors in declining to enter into any arrangements looking to a change of route or the removal of the rails of the company.

The political protege of Gov. Hill, Frank P. Demarest, representative of Rockland County, who was recently arrested for forgery, is boss of the dominant faction of the Democracy of that county and represents the worst element of its local politics. A large part of his support has been derived from the Republicans in each of the three terms he has been elected to the Assembly.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 31. -- The annual day of prayer at Yale University was observed to an even greater degree on Thursday than in any preceding year, and there is no doubt that now the students would object as strongly as anybody to the abandonment of the religious custom which calls for these special services. All recitations except those at 8:30 o'clock in the morning, were omitted, and the entire day was given up to prayer.

The bill drawn up by Mayor Chapin and John A. Quintard, counsel to the Kings County Charities Commissioners, which provides for the transfer of the care of the St. Johnland County Farm from the Board of Supervisors to the Charities Commissioners, has aroused expressions of dissatisfaction from more than one source. Supervisor at Large Kretzschmar doesn't like it at all, and he has not hesitated about saying so.

Recently I took a turn through the Cuban cigar factory in this city and saw eighteen Cubans or Spaniards who can't speak any English working for dear life. All of them have been brought here within the past few weeks. I was struck with the handsome appearance of two young dark-eyed, swarthy cigarmakers who sat back to back working merrily at different tables.

Although it is now more than a week since the notice was posted in the Produce Exchange that the members would be allowed to vote on the proposition to buy in seats next Tuesday, the discussion of the proposition continues with unabated vigor. It is safe to say that no matter has come before the Exchange for years which has stirred up so much feeling and caused such an amount of debate among the members.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31. -- "Indian Dave," a half-breed hunter, trapper, and fisherman who for fifty years has lived in a little cabin a few rods north of the Shore Line Railroad station at Old Saybrook, has been taken in charge by the Selectmen of that town and placed with a family in Essex, where he will receive proper care and attention during his declining years.

PINE RIDGE AGENCY, S.D., Jan. 31. -- For many months before the outbreak of the recent Indian troubles there was a persistent demand for troops all along the Cheyenne River in the vicinity of the lands given up from the reservation by the Sioux under the agreement made between them and the commission of which Gen. Crook was President.

RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES. -- When Disraeli delivered his memorable maiden speech, Milnes, who was sitting next him, said, "Yes, old fellow, so it will," in response to the famous words, "The time will come when you will hear me." On the following night, Milnes made his own first essay in Parliamentary oratory with distinct success.

In his recent message Mayor Grant of this city declares that the question of widening and improving the drives in Central Park is one which demands immediate attention. There is nothing novel in this suggestion. The necessity of widening and straightening and leveling the roads of the Park has often been urged by persons who assume that these roads were made primarily for pleasure driving.

Ten times as many persons carry hand bags east of Broadway and south of Thirteenth Street as in other parts of the city. The usual type is of yellow leather, large enough to hold a good-sized book, with numerous smaller articles, and it is not apt to be new. It holds surgical instruments if carried by an old man, notebook and the latest edition of Strumfell or Flint if by a young one.

The bill of Senator SANDERS of Montana imposing penalties for selling arms to Indians, except those of the civilized tribes, or under official permission and regulations, is of course called out by the recent troubles in Dakota. The difficulty both in disarming the Indians and in keeping them disarmed was fully explained by Gen. SCHOFIELD before the attempt which resulted in the disastrous affair on Porcupine Creek.
BOSTON, Jan. 31. -- Ex-Gov. Ames being asked to-day whether or not, in the event of Elijah Morse's candidacy for a third term in Congress, he should also be a candidate, said:
CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Although four new plays were presented in Chicago during the week, none of them proved of sufficient strength to arouse much enthusiasm.
HOW TO REVIEW SHELLEY'S "SKYLARK." -- If Shelley were unknown, were alive, and were to publish his "Skylark" to-day, one can well imagine how it would be reviewed.
A BAVARIAN COTILLION. -- It was intended to represent the ascent of the great mountain of the neighborhood, the Zugspitz, which is, in fact, the highest mountain in Germany, being 9,600 feet high.

RUSSIA TRYING TO WRECK FINLAND. -- There is no room to doubt that the Orthodox Greek Church is a stalking horse from behind which deadly aim is being taken against Finnish liberties. The Roman maxim, Divide et impera, has also been frequently applied of late, but with pitiful results.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 31. -- Marie Hubert Frohman and her company produced "The Witch" in the Opera House last Monday night. In the audience was Harry Jones, a ten-year-old son of E. Jones of Newman Springs. Young Jones was enthusiastic over the play, and yesterday he and a seven-year-old sister decided to reproduce the hanging scene.

There are no obligations of the Jesuits to the Dominicans so profound as to make indiscreet the remark that Father Clair's "Ignace de Loyola" is, passively, tacitly, an admirable criticism of Father Didon's "Jesus Christ."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The house of the late Secretary Windom was closed to visitors to-day. A few intimate friends were admitted, however, and were permitted to gaze upon the well-known face of the dead financier. It was shaved this morning, and presented more natural appearance than it did yesterday.

THE FARM IN FINLAND. -- One of the most instructive sights of the country is an ordinary Finnish farm in the interior, say in Satakunta or Savolaks, or in Ostrobothnia on the verge of the dreary country of the Lapps, which is in truth -

WAS THE HORSE DRIVEN BEFORE IT WAS RIDDEN? -- Canon Taylor, in that most interesting book. "The Origin of the Aryans," has raised once more a question which has often attracted the attention of scholars, especially those interested in the Homeric poems. Why is it that in the earliest records of the Greeks, Egyptians, Assyrians, Indians, and Celts we find the horse used for drawing chariots, but not yet for riding?

New-York is to have another new and large hotel. It is to be erected as soon as possible at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street. The area that it is to occupy is 63.3 feet by 113.4 feet. This property was transferred on Friday last from William S. Cooper to M.L. Sire for $275,000. The latter gentleman said yesterday:

Ground has been broken at last in Chicago as a first step toward the construction of buildings for the "World's Columbian Exposition" in 1893. Considerable progress has been made in the work of organization and in preparing plans for the departments and buildings for the great show, and we can begin to see in dim outline the grand fair that is to be held on the shores of Lake Michigan.

THE ROSE OF SHARON NOT A ROSE. -- The Anemone coronaria commonly grows wild about Smyrna and in Asia Minor, spreading far and wide as the most beautiful of Spring blossoms, growing on chalk soil along the edges of shrubbery. We cannot wonder that it was already in ancient times a favorite of the inhabitants and excited in poetic minds sensations such as can only be excited by surprising beauty.

Louis Cyr, who has beaten the world at heavyweight lifting, is to receive a magnificent championship belt at the Queen's Hall to-night, presented by appreciative citizens. Cyr is a French Canadian. He was born in St. Johns, Quebec, twenty-seven years ago. He is a large man, lacking but an inch and a half of six feet, and weighing 318 pounds.

Members of the Manhattan Athletic Club enjoyed another love feast last night. Ever since the club took possession of its new clubhouse, at Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, the members have been keeping up festivities in one way or another, scarcely a night passing without some entertainment being provided, and this last demonstration was the club's annual dinner. Covers were laid in the theatre for 450 persons. There were few empty places.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 31. -- Rowing matters at Harvard have not progressed very rapidly during the last two weeks. The question of a coach is not yet decided, and with this important matter still in an unsettled state, one can easily imagine how things are going.

" The sweet little cherub that sat up aloft" can no longer perch or hover on or over the topmast. He has flown, driven off by smoke from the funnels. The Deadeye of comic opera, and Tom Bowling, and Pipes, and Checks, and Hatchway, together with Poll and Black-Eyed Susan, belong to the limbo of the past, and are as shades, past resurrection.

Judge John H. Lippincott rendered an interesting blue-law decision in a case in the Hudson County Common Pleas yesterday. John Dillworth of Henderson Street, Jersey City, borrowed John P. Van Doren's carriage one Sunday three years ago and went riding. The horse became fractious and broke the carriage and threw Mrs. Dillworth out. Van Doren sued for damages to the borrowed equipage.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 31. -- The Rev. Melville K. Bailey of Branford has accepted the rectorship of Trinity Church at Torrington, succeeding the Rev. H.M. Sherman, who has recently become the rector of the Bridgeport church. Mr. Bailey is the Secretary of the Diocesan Convention of this State.

LAKEWOOD, Jan. 31. -- The weather of the week has not been auspicious for the promotion of out-door society pleasures at this resort. Guests at the hotels and cottages appear to be waiting for some of the regular made Lakewood sunshine. There is no falling off in numbers, but most of the guests are kept indoors by the regularity with which snow and rain and freeze and thaw follow upon the heels of each other.

The charm of a private dinner is simply that it is private. Why, then, allow its charm and sacredness to be destroyed by anything so obviously brought into existence by the people and for the people as the menu? A menu is a "bill of fare." The use of the French word is an affectation; that language, however, lends, itself to the cause of cooks, as well as it does to that of Courts.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Jan. 31. -- The country hereabouts, ambitiously termed "the land of the sky" on account of its elevation, almost perpetual sunshine, and salubrious climate, has been growing in popularity with seekers after health and pleasure for several years. Recently persons suffering from lung disease find a new attraction in this city in the fact that a supply of Prof. Koch's lymph has been secured.

SYMPATHETIC VIBRATION. -- The well-known phrase of Dr. Chalmers, "The power of littles," is strikingly illustrated in the physical world by the phenomena we are about to study. Little forces acting in the same direction and recurring at rapid and regular intervals of time will, if accumulated, soon add up to a single force of gigantic magnitude.

BIRDS WHICH HAVE DISAPPEARED. -- A very interesting bird, once an inhabitant of Britain, but now everywhere utterly extinct, is known as the great auk. It was about the size of a goose, but, having very small wings, was quite unable to fly. Being a powerful bird, with a strong bill, and a most accomplished diver, it would have continued to live on in full security but for man's reckless destruction.

Commissioner of Public Works Thomas F. Gilroy has sent his annual report for 1890 to the Mayor's office. The total expenditures in his department were $6,004,189.58. Four hundred and thirty-seven contracts at a total cost of $3,855,416.33 were entered into, and 387 were completed at a total cost of $3,130,768.22. The total number of gallons of water now received daily in the city is 145,000,000.

" Any valuable reforms in the public-school system of this city will have to be instituted through special committees. It will be idle to expect reform from the standing committees." This declaration was made by a School Commissioner after he had heard the standing committees for the current year announced by President John L.N. Hunt of the Board of Education at its last meeting.

The new apportionment, which is to take effect in 1893, will not affect the Electoral vote of 1892. The admission of six new States in the last two years has increased the number of Representatives from 325 to 332 and the number of Senators from 76 to 88, which will make the number of Electoral votes next year 420.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 31. -- The romance has been stamped out of the coal valleys of Pennsylvania by the anthracite industry, whose grimy trail is on the green hillsides, in the faces of the people, in the black heaps of culm that rise at regular intervals on the landscape, like the pyramids of Egypt, and in the inky streams into which the sulphurous mine water is pumped.

The popular demand for etchings has so stimulated the trade that cheapness has been sought and obtained, to the present detriment of the art. It is an open secret that the Etching Club has felt severely the rivalry of cheap etchings (not to speak of process prints) which appear to those who are not specialists as fine as the best etcher's proofs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- J.M. Donald, cashier of the Hanover National Bank of New-York, appeared before the silver pool investigating committee this morning and testified that he had paid Owenby $250 for information with regard to the progress of silver legislation last session, but that Owenby had not furnished any earlier information than was published in the newspapers.

LONDON FOGS. -- It is not every city in the world that, having usurped some hundred square miles of the earth's surface for its foundations, could actually create for itself an atmosphere of its own; and yet that is what London succeeds in doing, though, indeed, the feat is hardly a matter for boasting or congratulation on the part of its citizens.

The General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines returned from Buffalo yesterday very well satisfied with their work on Friday in reorganizing the Buffalo Railway Passenger Committee. They were assisted in that work by Leslie P. Farmer, Chairman of the passenger department of the Trunk Lines Association, and F.C. Donald, Vice Chairman of the Central Traffic Association.

LISBON, Jan. 31. -- News of the revolt in Oporto of a portion of the garrison of that place caused no uprising here. The city remained perfectly quiet. The mutiny is said to be the result of a movement in favor of the establishment of a republican form of government in Portugal.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31. -- Mr. Alfred Russell Wallace, the distinguished English naturalist, in a letter recently written to Prof. R.F. Ely of Johns Hopkins University, called forth by reading, the latter's "Political Economy," said:

There is a report from Hartford about the Republicans offering a basis of settlement for the Governorship dispute in which a proposition for a Constitutional Convention is the chief point. It is difficult to see what logical connection such a proposition has with the settlement of a dispute over the result of the election last November.

BOSTON, Jan. 31. -- The case of Walter Potter of the Potter-Lovell Company, charged with the embezzlement of notes drawn by Slingluff, Disney Co. of Baltimore, and placed with the company for negotiation, came up by continuance this morning in the Municipal Court, before Judge Hardy.

If anything is wanted to sustain interest in African exploration, the Pall Mall Gazette thinks, "Dr. Hans Meyer's luxurious volume, 'Across East African Glaciers,' ought to do it. The book is translated by E.H.S. Calder, and published by Messrs. George Philip Son. Its numerous illustrations and maps are beyond praise.

If there is any one international principle thoroughly established among the civilized States of the world, by treaty, by custom, usage, and precedent, it is that no political refugee may be surrendered to his enemies. There is a line of unbroken precedents on this subject in the navy reaching as far back as 1842, if not further. All civilized Governments, even those of Russia and Turkey, acquiesce in this principle and admit it in practice.

Really, our French friends who enjoy -- and enjoy greatly -- a reputation for logic do not expend it recklessly on their current phrases. The joyous M. Prudhomme, with whom HENRY MONNIER enriched French literature some sixty years ago, is a personage very much delighted in still by the present generation of French writers, who seem to see in his characteristics something so exceptional that they can afford to laugh at him without reserve.

BOSTON, Jan. 31. -- "I do not believe very much in civil service reform," said Dr. J.H. Gallinger, United States Senator-elect from New-Hampshire, at the dinner of the Middlesex Club at Young's this afternoon. "In New-Hampshire," he said, "party lines were closely drawn; the Republican party fought to win, and when it did win it intended to get the fruits of victory every time."

OPORTO, Jan. 31. -- Great excitement has been caused here by an attempted revolution against the authority of the Government. Three regiments of infantry, comprising a portion of the garrison, openly revolted to-day. The remainder of the garrison, including the Municipal Guard, remained loyal to the Government. The population of Oporto held aloof from the movement. The avowed object of the mutineers was to establish a Portuguese Republic.
ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The Rapid-Transit bill became a law this afternoon. Not content with signing the bill and letting it speak for itself, the Governor delivered himself of the following memorandum:

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 31. -- Congressman Quackenbush's counsel this afternoon served upon Senator Collins his answer to the petition of the latter to be awarded the seat as Representative from the Eighteenth New-York District in the Fifty-second Congress, for which Quackenbush holds the certificate of election. It is a very long document, covering 107 pages of typewritten legal cap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The body of Secretary Windom lies in its coffin in the stricken home, on Massachusetts Avenue, and will not be buried until Monday, yet the principal thing talked about by the Senators and Representatives and other politicians at the capital is the probable selection the President will make to fill the vacant place as the head of the Treasury Department.

MASON CITY, Iowa, Jan. 31. -- Lieut. Schwatka was not as well to-night as during the forenoon. His physician says that he is suffering from a severe contusion of the muscles of the back. He cannot be lifted or even turned over in bed, and it is impossible yet to tell the extent of his injuries. It is certain that he is injured internally, and from this the worst is feared.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31. -- The marked opposition shown by the practical machine politicians of Hamilton County to Gov. Campbell, with a view of forcing his retirement as a political factor, is not, so far as surface indications show, meeting with the sympathy and hearty good-will anticipated by the promoters and backers of the movement.
BUENOS AYRES, Jan. 31. -- War news continues to filter from Chile into this republic, but the information received seems to come in the main from sources favorable to the insurgents.

Mr. Chauncey M. Depew, in an address at a Manhattan Athletic Club dinner given recently at Delmonico's, declared that it was never the intention of the Almighty that there should be gymnasiums. Mr. Depew was telling the Manhattan Athletic Club men what he does not know about modern athletics, and in speaking of physical exercise he told of the health found in following the plow all day long.

The retirement of Col. CHARLES G. MCCAWLEY removes from the active list an officer who for upward of fourteen years has been Commandant of the Marine Corps and for nearly thirty years longer a member of that corps. His first service dates back to the Mexican war, where, as a Second Lieutenant, he was brevetted for gallantry in the storming of Chapultepee and the occupation of the city of Mexico.
