DUBLIN, Jan. 31. -- The Gazette announces that the Government puts the crimes act in force in the town of Carlow, in Leinster, and revokes it in portions of Sligo County.

BOSTON, Jan. 31. -- Designer William Fife of Fairlie, Scotland, has sent the design of a forty-six-foot cutter, to be built in this country. As was to be expected, the "canny Scot" hedged his plans about with all manner of secrecy. Builder Lawley has been obliged to sign a cast-iron contract which forbids his giving the slightest inkling of the new cutter's dimensions or outlines.

Courbevoie is at all times a depressing suburb, and an assassination which was discovered this morning would tend to show that it is becoming a dangerous one as well. Mine. Dussaigne, eighty-two years of age, lived in a detached cottage alone, the woman who acted as servant to her during the day being in the habit of sleeping in her own room in another part of the town.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- The resignation of Count von Waldersee from his position as Chief of the General Staff is not associated, as was reported, with his appointment as commander of the Ninth Army Corps, which was made vacant by the withdrawal of Gen. Leczynski. Like the latter, Count von Waldersee retires from his position as Chief of Staff through his inability to agree with the Emperor.

To continue last week's article is demanded by the season's promiscuous use of fur. It is employed in a variety of ways unthought of before last year, and only hinted at then. The notion of applying fur to other than the legitimate purposes of wraps and robes, once accepted, has developed almost alarmingly.

In one of the wards of the Babies' Hospital, at 657 Lexington Avenue, a baby, born prematurely, is thriving in an incubator. The expectation is that the child will emerge from the incubator in about two weeks about as well equipped to enter upon the struggle for existence as is the ordinary weakly infant.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 31. -- Notice of appeal has been given by the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad from the decision of the United States District Court in the Union Pacific bridge injunction case. The Supreme Court will be asked to define distinctly the right of the Union Pacific to make contracts without Congressional sanction.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- The Government has extracted a vote of confidence from the "Thermidor" episode, but the incident leaves a bad taste in the mouth. It is not pleasant to contemplate the spectacle of a Ministry thus deferring to the noisy violence of a little group of loafers whom the police could easily have taken care of.

ROME, Jan. 31. -- In the debate to-day in the Chamber of Deputies on the Spirit Taxes bill, Signor Crispi, the Prime Minister, urged that the taxes proposed by the Government were imperatively necessary to prevent Italy from falling again to the servile condition she was in, as regards foreign powers, in 1874.

The New-York Press Club held its annual banquet at Delmonico's last night, and incidentally entertained Henry M. Stanley as the honored guest of the occasion. Prior to sitting at the tables Mr. Stanley held an informal reception in the parlors adjoining the banquet hall, and went through the ordeal of shaking hands with at least 250 men.

There were three elevated railroad accidents yesterday. A collision occurred at 11:15 in the morning at One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Third Avenue between a passenger train and a train composed of ash cars. Nobody was injured. There were three versions of the way the accident occurred. It was actually due to a failure on the part of Engineer Tucker of the passenger train to obey a signal.

BAVARIAN AMUSEMENTS. -- As to amusement, you may trust a Bavarian not to be behind in that. The men meet almost nightly in the different inns and beerhouses, according to their status in the local society, where they have talk, singing, music, cards, , the large glass mugs of beer at their side being constantly replenished.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 31. -- James A. Smith, Sr., formerly one of the heaviest local ice dealers, was arrested to-day upon an indictment charging him with swindling Millionaire Charles P. Choteau out of $31,250 and embezzling $30,000 from the J.A. Smith Ice and Fuel Company. Mr. Choteau's attorney tells this story:

It is a trite saying that history repeats itself. Since this is so, however, there seems to be no good reason why comment on these repeated historical events should not be reiterated. Last season, when Mr. Abbey came forward with his Italian company at the close of the series of German opera performances, some remarks were printed in this column bearing an the conquest of Teutonic harmony by the mellifluous jingle of Italy.

Mr. JAMES BRYCE has published in the Contemporary Review the address which he delivered in Brooklyn in November on "The Age of Discontent." The address, as might be supposed, is full of knowledge and philosophical reflection, and will well repay a leisurely perusal. Mr. BRYCE'S remarks apply to the state of mind of Christendom, but Americans whose memory goes back thirty years will readily agree that they are true as regards this country.

In the dressing room of a happy married woman who lives in a Madison Avenue mansion there stands in a conspicuous corner a small ebony casket with silver trimmings. It is locked and has not been opened for ten years. Few know its history, which is one full of romance and also of food for reflection for those on whom the marriage yoke bears heavily.

The Board of Managers of the Amateur Athletic Union held a meeting yesterday at the Astor House, and as a result of the deliberations all of the athletes who took part in the lacrosse tournament in Madison Square Garden Jan. 9 and 10 are suspended from competition under union rules. The Madison Square meeting was not approved by the board, the management going on without consulting the union in any way.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Jan. 31. -- The late Mrs. Lombard of Springfield, in a codicil added to her will Jan. 9, named this college as one of six residuary legatees. Five thousand dollars or more will probably be received, and another $5,000, came recently as a bequest from Mrs. Williston, mother of A.L. Williston, one of the Trustees.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- The severity of the temperature and the snow may afford some clue to the sympathy of the French for Russians, but the 5 o'clock caviar and Moscovite salad was quite sufficiently suggestive of this craze without the dirty white mantle dear to poets and to small boys, but horribly provoking to pedestrians here and everywhere else.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 31. -- A great sensation has been created in political circles by Secretary Blaine's denial of Sir John Macdonald's statement that negotiations were on foot for a reciprocity treaty between Canada and the United States. The Canadian Premier is placed in an awkward position, especially as a few weeks more will see the election campaign fully opened.

The Turkish Ambassador at Vienna, Sadullah Pasha, had the habit of assembling the staff of the Embassy at 1 o'clock for what is called "la lecture," when the dispatches were read and commented upon and orders given. "On Wednesday, Jan. 14," says the London Daily News's correspondent, "Councilor Nasri Bey and the Secretaries, Subhi Bey, Mehemet Bey, and Nusret-Sadullah Bey, were assembled, and waited much beyond the usual time to be called by his Excellency.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31. -- The protected pottery manufacturer in this city heard something drop this week. Despite his studied silence and his attempt at dignified reserve, he was badly shaken up. This was particularly true of the twenty manufacturers controlling the seven sanitary-ware potteries out of which 300 employes, men and women, have been locked.

When Prof. HUXLEY wrote his famous essay on protoplasm, or the physical basis of life, a great many people, and notably Mr. JAMES STIRLING, were seriously disturbed by it and began to tremble for the goodly frame of spiritualism, that much-abused word being taken in its philosophical and not in its popular sense.

AN ESTIMATE OF "DIZZY," 1855. -- "As to the secession," Elliot said, of "Herbert and Gladstone, it is a great blow to the future Government and a prodigious accession to the Tories. But I am not sure that it is a loss to the country. If Gladstone had remained he could only have made a loan and raised the income tax to 10 per cent.

One day recently a New-York doctor prescribed beer for a patient. "Take it with your meals," he said, "and I reckon that it will do you lots of good." Then he chatted a few minutes with the patient's wife and at length started for the door.

Among the many services which that truly great man, Capt. Kidd, rendered to society by adopting the profession of a pirate must be reckoned the furnishing of material to unimaginative authors by his singular and uncontrollable mania fur burying his hard-won treasures so carefully that neither he nor any one else has ever been able to find them since.
Dr. Paul Henry Knaupf knew even as much as the lumps on his protuberant forehead predicated; and this is extravagant praise, for it always looked as though it had just returned from an Irish picnic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- When the House went into Committee of the Whole to-day on the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill, Mr. McCreary of Kentucky, after inveighing against the Committee on Rules for its refusal to allow the Committee on Foreign Affairs a day for the consideration of bills reported by it, took up the Barrundia case and the Bering Sea controversy.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31. -- The amendment recently passed by Congress and approved Jan. 13, 1891, to the statute concerning details of officers of the army and navy to educational institutions, has an important effect upon Yale University. The Sheffield Scientific School has had for the last two years a course of military instruction under the direction of Lieut. A.L. Totten of the regular army.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 31. -- A contest in the courts over the estate of the late Job Male is probable. The octogenarian philanthropist and millionaire left the making of his will until too late. When he lay on his deathbed, Thursday evening, he made an effort to dispose of his possessions in legal form, but died before the will was signed.

The Peruvian war and its great prize, consisting of the rich provinces of Tarapaca and Antofagasta, have made Chile wealthy, proud, and hateful to all her neighbors. In a way the Chileans are the Prussians of South America, overweening talkers, arrogating to themselves the first place in war and in peace among the republics of the southern hemisphere, and taking measures to make their pretensions a reality.

THE DECAY OF THE MYTH. -- When the Germans and Dr. Arnold disposed of Romulus and Remus and their nurse, who was a more genial form of Red Ridinghood's grandmother, all fairyland was in danger, and since then the whole realm of poetic story has been invaded. Hawthorne's "Wonder Book" would now have to be rewritten, for its wonders have been reduced from poetry to prose.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 31. -- New-Jersey Athletic Club marksmen turned out in force this afternoon to shoot at clay pigeons on the club grounds here. Thirteen useful prizes were offered in four scheduled matches. The principal event was a team match for silver cups. George S. Virden and Edward L. Vredenburgh carried off the honors as a team. Each was rewarded with a cup.

In the amiable preface which he has written for the catalogue of the richest, most curious, and most original collection of books ever formed Mr. Brayton Ives says modestly: "It is not claimed that the books described in this catalogue form a library. They are only a collection. Nearly twenty years ago I began a tolerably comprehensive course of historical reading.

The fourth concert of the Symphony Society, which was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was one of the most interesting of a season which has not been barren of musical fruit. Some of the interest, it must be admitted, was of a factitious nature, for on purely artistic grounds the performance in concert of any scene from a Wagner music-drama is indefensible.

POISONOUS FISH. -- I have known two kinds of poisonous fish in the Cape waters, one of them small and the other large. The latter kind is known by the local name of "keeler," and is, as a rule, good to eat, although the oil is the most profitable use it can be put to. Only at certain times is it poisonous.

How OLD IS PUNCH? -- On landing at one of the sugar factories, we found that there was a fair going on under an avenue of tamarisks close by. The dealers sat under the trees with their wares before them, fruit and vegetables in one quarter, cotton and calicoes in another, native woollen stutis, robes, rugs, cloth, , in a third; there was also a cattle fair, sheep, buffaloes, camels, and donkeys.

Of the numerous gatherings of aggressive religious workers, one of the most notable is the New-York State Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association, which will be held this year at Lockport, N.Y., Feb. 19-22. In the past there has usually been between 600 and 700 delegates in attendance.

BOSTON, Feb. 1. -- A visitor in Boston during the last week would have had an exceptional opportunity to study the traditional Boston woman. Boston women delight, above all things else, in convening, and a chosen few, informed with purpose, and eloquent in its elucidation, may be depended upon at all times to address them.
PARIS, Feb. 1. -- The Journal des Debats, commenting on the Ministerial crisis in Italy, says:

The decision of Judge SOMERVILLE for the Board of General Appraisers in the knit-goods case will sorely disappoint the tricksters who believed they had provided for a transfer of imported underwear and hosiery from the old paragraph relating to the duty on such goods to the paragraph relating to wearing apparel.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Feb. 1. -- The Randall Chambers Dry Goods Company made a general assignment last night to H.C. Edrington. The liabilities are $59,000, well scattered over the country.

The Argentine Republic has recently added to its navy six first-class torpedo boats of almost identically the same type and size as the Cushing. One of these, the Bathurst, recently completed her trial trips, making an average speed of 24.458 knots over a continuous six-mile run. The chief point of interest in the Bathurst is the introduction of quadruple expansion engines, which have four inverted cylinders acting on four cranks on one shaft.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Discount rates were firm during the past week at 11 3/4 to 1 1/4. The cheapness of money led to an increase of the foreign drain of bullion which was barely balanced by the return of currency from the provinces and the distribution of dividends. Signs of a reduction of bankers' balances, combined with shortening supplies of floating capital in the markets, render a further drop of money rates impossible.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 1. -- From a newspaper compositor the following story is obtained of the earlier career of Henry Hansbrough, recently elected United States Senator from North Dakota:

A collection of objects used in their worship by Hebrews of the thirteenth, fourteenth, and fifteenth centuries has been arranged in one of the rooms of the Hotel Cluny at Paris. These articles were collected by Isaac Strauss, who was conductor at the Opera balls during the reign of Napoleon III. They were bought at the sale of his effects by the Baroness Nathaniel de Rothschild, and that lady presented them to the Cluny Museum.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- The advocates of State control of the manufacture and distribution of school text books will make a determined effort this Winter to secure the enactment of a law requiring that all text books to be used in the public schools shall be issued under the direction of the State itself. Two bills calculated to bring about this situation have already been introduced, and they will be vigorously pushed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- All the arrangements for the funeral of the late Secretary Windom have now been completed. The private services will take place at the house at 11 o'clock. The members of the family, the relatives, the President and his Cabinet, and the servants of the family will attend the services. They will be brief, and at their conclusion the entire party will proceed to the church.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 1. -- Reports were current here yesterday of an attack by white men, at Galloway mines, on negroes who had been put to work during the recent strike. Efforts made by telegraph to secure a confirmation of the reports proved futile. The only answer obtainable was that a negro had been killed by a white man in self-defense and that the reports were incorrect.

It is not surprising that after so vigorous and so successful a campaign of education as that which was made last Fall by the young men of the Democratic Party in Massachusetts, some of their puzzled opponents should be looking for new issues or for something to divert public attention from the old ones.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- The annual report of the New-Jersey State Board of Agriculture, recently prepared, gives a very interesting summary of the agricultural situation in one of the most fertile farming regions of the Middle States. The report shows that the farming industry is in a much better condition than it was in 1889.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 1. -- John W. Chalfant, the millionaire steel manufacturer of this city, and one of the largest individual stockholders of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad Company, to-night confirmed the report that that corporation had passed into the control of the Baltimore and Ohio.

Writing of the late Duke of Bedford, the London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian, who may be regarded as specially well informed on the subject, says: "I am not sure that substantial justice has been done to one of his most marked qualities -- his munificence. Having begun life as a very poor man, he had contracted the habit of close attention to details of expenditure, and this habit passed with superficial observers for stinginess.

The revolt in the garrison at Oporto on Saturday, which was suppressed within a few hours after it broke out, seems to have been hopeless from the start, having been attempted without suitable preparation or assurances of support. Possibly, however, further investigation may reveal a more widespread disaffection, of which this was a premature demonstration; and indeed, no doubt Portugal is always liable, during its present restless condition, to uprisings against the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The report on the recent survey of the Despatch has not yet been completed, but it is expected that it will show that to repair her would cost more than the 20 per cent. limit fixed by law, and consequently she will probably be condemned at an early day and sold.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 1. -- War has been announced between the farmers in Indiana and the Postal Telegraph Company. A dispatch from Brazil, Ind., says:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 1. -- Auditor C.W. Pavey, when informed of the statement of the officers of the Consolidated Mutual Fire Insurance Company that the failure was due to his arbitrary and unwarranted rulings, said such charges were nonsensical. When an examination was made, as required by law, and the company's assets were found to be impaired, he had given it forty days in which to make good the assets by special assessment.

The latest addition to the long list of persons "spoken of" for the Treasury Department is Mr. PALMER of Michigan, known to the country only as an intimate friend of Mr. HARRISON, whose disappointment at not being appointed to the Department of Agriculture was assuaged by an appointment as Minister to Spain.

The new act for the protection and preservation of birds, fish, and game which has been prepared by the Commission to Codify the Game Laws is far more extensive than was expected by the anglers and those interested in fish culture or by the hunters.

It is not very clear why a committee of Congress should now be engaged in investigating the business of landing immigrants at this port. The whole matter of immigration has lately been made the subject of a much more thorough investigation at the hands of Congress than this committee can possibly make in the time at its disposal.

A reception will be given at the New-York Trade Schools, First Avenue, Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets next Monday afternoon at 2 o'clock, to the delegates to the fifth annual convention of the master builders of the United States. An address will be delivered by the Right Rev. Henry C. Potter.

TRENTON, Feb. 1. -- Delay is the object the Hudson delegation in the Senate and Assembly will play for at the reassembling of the Democratic joint caucus to-morrow evening. But it is doubtful if they will be able to give the State House managers a second surprise party. Delay can do the disaffected element no good.

Lady Dufferin seems to have followed her husband, the Viceroy, (she calls him D. for short,) wherever he went, and besides that made excursions on her own account. Whether at a durbar receiving Punjab chiefs, Rajahs, or Dukes and Princes at her receptions, or shooting a tiger or founding hospital, attending a steeplechase, playing tennis, or doing charitable work, or taking photographs, her ladyship never tired.

Miss Florence Birch, an estimable resident of Bay Shore, L.I., has during the last ten days been subjected to a series of cruel and criminal persecutions which have aroused in the citizens of her town great indignation. She is a milliner and has kept a store in Smith's Block, on Main Street.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 1. -- A concise statement of Bayonne's financial condition is clearly shown by the State Controller's annual report for the year 1890. Mayor John Newman certified to the correctness of this report.

The Portland (Oregon) Morning Oregonian expresses its opinion free coinage in vigorous language. It says: "Free silver coinage, like the greenback inflation, would cause the price of commodities to advance, and, while this would transiently help the debtor farmer, how would the millions of wage workers feel with their wages paid in docked dollars?

The impression of his recent visit to Washington, given in another column by Mr. EDWARD ATKINSON, should be considered by our own business men. Mr. ATKINSON was one of a delegation of Boston men who went to the capital to protest the passage of the Free-Coinage bill. He reports that the majority of the House Committee on Coinage and of the Congressmen met by his delegation were anxious for light.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The Senate is shaping up its business with a firm determination to adjourn March 1 without leaving behind it the necessity for an extra session. To this end the "Steering" Committee of the Republican majority has already arranged a programme that would of itself occupy the attention of the Senate for two weeks.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- A local paper prints the following developments in affairs of the World's Columbian Exposition:

OPORTO, Feb. 1. -- Perfect quiet reigned in this city to-day. Government reinforcements have arrived from all parts of the country. Three hundred civilians and soldiers were arrested to-day. All of the republican clubs have been closed, and all of the republican newspapers have been seized by the Government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 1. -- The action taken by the officials of the Miners' Union in demanding that at the expiration of the present contract all coal mined in Ohio should be weighed before passing through the screens, is calculated to discourage the operators, who claim that they cannot and will not make further concessions to the miners.

The swords of our heroes are coming into the market, and it is sometimes a little difficult to put a price on them. A sword of WASHINGTON, won by him when he resigned his commission as commander of the army at Annapolis in 1783 under memorable circumstances, has just been offered to the Massachusetts Legislature, the request of the owner being simply that a committee shall be appointed to negotiate with him for its purchase.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- The Industrial Senate of New-Jersey, which is composed of delegates from the district and local assemblies of the Knights of Labor, the Farmers' Alliance, and the open trade unions, met here to-day for the purpose of advocating the passage of labor bills by the Legislature, the election of new officers for the coming year, and the adoption of a platform.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A warm debate was had in the Senate to-day on an amendment to the Fortifications bill, reported by the Committee on Appropriations, reducing the appropriation for the gun and mortar batteries for the defense of the harbors of New-York, Boston, San Francisco, Hampton Roads, and Washington from $1,000,000 to $750,000.

The proposed rearming and manning of Fort Taylor and the water batteries at Key West, and possibly, also, of Fort Jefferson, at the Dry Tortugas, will presumably depend much on the question whether the regular artillery is increased by two regiments, as is contemplated in a bill which has already passed the House and is pending in the Senate.

While the carbonate ring of Colorado was trying to induce the Treasury Department to reverse the old ruling as to the admission of silver-lead fluxing ores from Mexico, and afterward, while the same ring was procuring the imposition of a high duty on such ores in the McKinley bill, we pointed out that the owners of American mines producing refractory ores would be affected injuriously by the proposed changes.

Mr. J.H. Young of 230 West Thirty-eighth Street does not favor the project of building a new drive on the margin of the Hudson River north of Seventy-second Street. He says: "It is folly, in my view of the matter, to attempt to lay out a road for fast horses close to a railroad track.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- There is trouble in the Third Regiment, National Guard, over the peculiar financial methods of Col. W.B. Smith, who was impeached when he was Mayor of this city for operations very similar to those with which he is charged in handling the funds of the regiment of which he was chosen Colonel about one year ago.

There will be held in this city next week a convention which promises to be of exceptional interest and importance to the architects and builders of the country. It is the fifth annual convention of the National Association of Builders. It will convene on Monday at Masonic Hall, at Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, and will continue through the week.

The body of Miss Helen Potts, the nineteen-year-old pupil at Miss Lydia Day's school, 32 West Fortieth Street, who died suddenly Sunday morning after taking quinine and morphine pills prescribed for her by young Carlyle W. Harris, a student at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, was yesterday taken to Miss Potts's late home, in Ocean Grove, N.J., for interment.

Many of the contractors who did work on the new aqueduct under sub-contracts with O'Brien Clark have brought suits against the city to have the liens which they have filed against the money in the hands of the Controller, to the credit of O'Brien Clark, declared valid, and to have the city adjudged to pay their claims out of it.

It is evident that the French Government, as now constituted, thinks the political advantage of protection so great as to make it worth while to try the experiment of a pretty high tariff. It counts on the active support of a few favored interests to overcome any general opposition. But we are confident that, as a mere matter of policy, this is short-sighted.

The sixteenth annual report of that worthy charity, the Hospital Book and Newspaper Society, has just been issued. The work of the society is to distribute reading matter to the unfortunates in all public institutions. During the year 1890 there were fifty-nine such institutions under the society's patronage, and among these were distributed 4,940 books, 14,870 magazines, 39,811 weekly papers, and 131,993 daily papers.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Trustees of Columbia College, yesterday, the resignation of the warden of the Law School, Prof. Theodore William Dwight, LL.D., was received, together with the request that he be placed on the emeritus list under the conditions of the resolution passed by the Trustees in December.

A well-dressed woman, with two children, walked out on the pier at the foot of Dover Street last night, and acted so suspiciously that a citizen called the attention of Policeman Bretts to her movements. He rushed after her and caught the woman as she was about to jump from the stringpiece of the pier.

The authorities in naval and marine matters, in setting about correcting the false impressions prevalent as to the meaning of a "knot," have, if they are correctly reported, not made very good work of their task. They announce, according to the reports, that a "knot" is simply a unit for measuring speed at sea, and has nothing to do with distance which is measured by the nautical mile of 6,080 feet.

In matters of principle in legislation, compromises, like curses and chickens, come home to roost. This is a commonplace of politics, which is as well established by experience as it is generally ignored. There are sundry financial statesmen still extant, who were influential in Congress or the Cabinet in 1878, who, after a dozen years, may recall with chagrin, and also with profit, the finance bills of that year and apply to them this truth.

The Baptist pastors yesterday listened to an interesting discourse on "Sunday-School Missionary Work in Minnesota" by Boston W. Smith of Minneapolis, State Sunday-School Missionary of the American Baptist Publication Society. Mr. Smith took charge of his work in Minnesota in June, 1880, and when he went there there were 154 Baptist churches and only 66 regular working Baptist Sunday schools and 30 union Sunday schools.

Mr. Jay Gould's trip South to inspect the Richmond Terminal properties is exciting much interest in railroad and Wall Street circles. That the trip is regarded as significant and important by the Richmond Terminal people is clearly indicated in the personnel of the party which is to be Mr. Gould's escort. Besides President John H. Inman, there will be Gen. Samuel Thomas, Senator C.S. Brice, C.M. McGhee, and Lawyer Patrick Calhoun.

The Legislature at Albany appears to have started off to make a notable record of extravagance. The annual expenditures of the State Government are ordinarily in the neighborhood of $10,000,000, but although the Legislature was in actual session only fourteen days during the month of January, appropriation bills were introduced aggregating in amount nearly $14,000,000, while the General Appropriation bill and the Supply bill are yet to be heard from.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The passage by the House to-day of the bill giving the President thirty days in which to fill such a vacancy as that caused by the death of Secretary Windom and the expected prompt concurrence of the Senate in the measure will probably extend for several days the time in which the politicians can speculate upon the chances of the numerous persons brought forward for the Secretaryship.

Josiah G. Willetts, a tall, thin man about fifty years old, a copyist in a lawyer's office at 111 Broadway, lives with his unmarried daughter, Emma, a beautiful woman of twenty-five years, at 275 President Street. His wife died about two weeks ago, and since then Mr. Willetts's friends have noticed that he has been acting queerly.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2. -- Judge Snyder of the Illinois Circuit Court at Belleville to-day dealt the American Live Stock Commission a black eye by dissolving the Robinson injunction.

Mme. Sarah Bernhardt is in New-York once more. She arrived on the Champagne yesterday and is now domiciled at the Gilsey House. She is in excellent health and capital spirits in spite of a long and remarkably rough voyage. Whenever this voyage is referred to by Mme. Bernhardt she makes the wryest faces and gesticulates wildly in disgust.

If there are no organized gangs of rowdies in the Sixteenth Precinct, on the west side, near the river, and Capt Grant, the commander there, is authority for the assertion that his precinct has long ceased to be the habitat of such gangs, those who are not organized are capable of a good deal of mischief.

The death of the patient who was the first subject of the Koch treatment in this country will attract much attention because of the reports concerning the effect of the inoculations in his case. As to this the testimony is conflicting. The press dispatches indicate that his general condition became much worse after the beginning of the treatment, but this may have been due to the natural progress of the disease.

Quite naturally the Tory and Unionist press in England take the side of PARNELL in the quarrel among the Irish members of Parliament, and it is astonishing that any sensible Irishman should fail to perceive what this championship means. The Standard goes so far as to interpret PARNELL'S speech at Ennis to mean that "DILLON and O'BRIEN have consented to unite with him in extorting guarantees from the Gladstonians."

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 2. -- George M. Bradley, who was the first patient in this country to receive the lymph inoculation, died to-day, and the son of Prof. Blake, another lymph patient, who has been under treatment for nearly two months, is at the point of death.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The special House committee investigating the alleged silver pool met at 2 o'clock to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- The new steel cruiser Newark formally went into commission to-day at the Cramps' shipyard as a man-of-war of the United States Government. Capt. Silas Casey, her commander, in the presence of the entire crew of the vessel, read the order from the Secretary of the Navy ordering the Newark into commission.

The amount of interest taken by members of the Produce Exchange in the vote to-day on the proposition to buy in membership certificates with the net revenues of the Exchange was shown in several ways yesterday. One of them was the display of a cartoon, in which the friends of the scheme appeared supplied with very long ears. Another was the circulation of documents bearing on the case.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 2. -- The Veteran Zouaves of this city, commanded by Gen. J. Madison Drake, will, at 5 P.M. to-morrow, start on a trip which is to embrace sixteen States in the South and West, with receptions at ten of the leading cities, Cincinnati, Chattanooga, Birmingham, Ala.; New-Orleans, Mobile, Atlanta, Augusta, Charleston, Richmond, and Washington.

The New-York College of Dentistry is soon to move from its cramped and antiquated quarters at Second Avenue and Twenty-third Street into a new building at 205 and 207 East Twenty-third Street, near Madison Avenue. For eighteen years the college has occupied the two upper floors over the De Milt Dispensary, and it has entirely outgrown the room at its disposal.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Cardinal Lavigerie, the Archbishop of Algiers, has addressed a remarkable circular letter to the clergy of the Diocese of Algiers. In this letter, while advocating adherence to the French Republic, he pleads for the formation of a purely Cathotic party, distinct from monarchical and imperial elements, with which, he says, religion has hitherto been identified.

With unexpected promptness the Supreme Court at Washington has determined to grant leave to file a petition for a writ of prohibition to prevent the District Court of Alaska from carrying out the decree of forfeiture in the case of the British schooner Sayward, seized in Bering Sea in 1887 for capturing seals in the "waters of Alaska."

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2. -- The Princeton Alumni Association of Maryland held its sixth annual reunion this evening in the dining hall of the Lyceum Theatre. The guest of the evening was ex-President McCosh, who was given a hearty welcome. Among the guests were President Patton, Prof. Woodrow Wilson, James W. Alexander, President of the New-York Princeton Club; President Gilman of Johns Hopkins, and Dr. Richard Gundry of Baltimore, President of the Maryland Harvard Club.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- The first nomination of the session was made to-night, when Gov. Abbott renominated Allan L. McDermott to be Clerk in Chancery. Among the bills ordered to second reading were those for Saturday half-holiday, for the appointment of a State Inspector of Weights and Measures, and for the consolidation of Milburn and Springfield Townships.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 3. -- Politicians to-night are watching with keen interest the members of the Executive Committee of the Confederation of Farmers and Laborers of the State, all of whom are in the city and holding frequent and secret consultations. Not a member of the committee can be led to say anything concerning the Senatorial situation or to acknowledge that the meeting at this time has any bearing upon the question.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 3. -- Mr. M.G. Menocal of the engineer corps of the Nicaragua Canal Company is in this city. He gives good accounts of the progress being made on the canal. The surveys across the country are completed, and the engineering work is being prosecuted on the eastern portion. The boring and dredging have been commenced, using the machinery purchased from the Panama Company at a low cost.

Miss Annie A.S. Lydon, formerly a member of the Third Order of St. Francis, has obtained permission from Archbishop Corrigan to establish a new sisterhood on the rules of the Third Order, but differing from that religious community in several essential particulars. Miss Lydon became dissatisfied, and severed her relations with the order, but continued to wear her religious habit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Witness Owenby, who was yesterday before the bar of the House to explain why he had not come to Washington to testify in the silver pool investigation, was on the stand for several hours to-day, and was pretty well "pumped" by the members, who have developed a great deal of curiosity to learn from men who do not appear to know anything.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Harrisburg, received this morning, said that the 1889 headquarters warrant issued to the Third Regiment of the National Guard was indorsed by Col. Bounaffon, that the headquarters warrant for 1890 was indorsed by Col. W.B. Smith, but that both were paid to Col. Smith after he assumed command of the regiment.

The amusing hodge-podge of contradictions and evasions that was suggested last week by Speaker BARRETT of the Massachusetts Legislature as a new and saving policy for the Republican Party excites some interest in his State and out of it because he is a prominent member of the new Young Republicans Club and the editor of the leading organ of the party in Boston.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 3. -- The greatest anxiety has been aroused throughout the city as to the fate of Lelia L. Highsmith, who for several months had made her home at the residence of Elmore D. Moffett, Councilman of Plainfield and Chief Deputy County Clerk at Elizabeth, on Orchard Place. Miss Highsmith has been mysteriously missing ever since last week Friday.

The funeral of Baby Johnson, the three-pound infant which resisted the efforts of the physicians at the Baby Hospital, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth street, to prolong its life with the assistance of an incubator, will take place to-day from the father's home, 22 West Sixtieth street. The baby was born on Dec. 21 and was a mite of humanity.
PARIS, Feb. 3. -- Michael Eyraud, the murderer of Gouffe, was executed at 7:20 o'clock this morning on the Place de la Roquette. He met his fate with fortitude or sullen resignation.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 3. -- As intimated in THE TIMES two months ago, Sir John Macdonald has dissolved Parliament. The elections will be held on March 5. Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner in England, and the Hon. C.C. Colby, President of the Privy Council, are due in New-York to-morrow from England. They will take part in the campaign, which will be inaugurated by a Conservative demonstration in Toronto next week.

The practical work of harbor defense is, after-all, slowly progressing, and soon it will be impossible to say longer, as it has been said hitherto, that we possess no modern appliances for this purpose. The new fortifications at Sandy Hook are advancing, and will be supplied with heavy mortars of the most effective sort, supplemented in due time by heavy guns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- It does not take very long to pass a bill through Congress when both Senators and Representatives are disposed to hasten legislation. The House received yesterday President Harrison's message recommending an extension of the time within which such a vacancy as that caused by the death of Secretary Windom must be filled.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 3. -- Sir John Macdonald has received an important communication from the Hon. Audley Coate, M.L.C., of Sydney, N.S.W., regarding the projected transpacific cable. Mr. Coate, among other things, says:

PANAMA, Jan. 26. -- Advices from Lima, Valparaiso, and Santiago show the feverish feeling regarding the political troubles of Chile which prevailed before the revolution broke out. It is evident that trouble had been brewing for sometime and a feeling of hostility on the part of the populace against Balmaceda and the militarists who are urging him on was with difficulty kept under control.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Johannes Gelert has just finished his statue of Gen. Grant, and will exhibit it to-morrow at his studio. It is about eight feet high, and is completed in the clay, but the bronze reproduction will not be finished for several months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Corean Legation was open to callers this afternoon for the first time in several years, Mrs. Ye Cha Yan, wife of the Charge d'Affaires, haying decided to hold receptions on the first two Tuesdays in February. The bright-faced little hostess stood alone to receive her callers, and accorded to each a cordial greeting in English, spoken with the slightest possible accent, which lent a decided charm to her conversation.

Many people of both sexes braved the inclement weather yesterday to see the annual display of the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique in Madison Square Garden. They were repaid for their trouble. The display, which is the twenty-fifth annual exhibition given by the society, is one of the finest in the history of the institution. It discloses wonderful cleverness on the part of the chefs both in the variety and the finish of the exhibits.

For the forthcoming fifth annual convention of the National Association of Builders, which will hold possession of the Masonic Hall during all of next week, the Entertainment Committee is busy with the making of many preparations. Mr. Stephen M. Wright, Secretary of the Mechanics and Traders' Exchange, is Chairman of the committee.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 3. -- A very peculiar trial is in progress here. In October, 1889, Richard D. Young, a wealthy dealer in perfumes in New-York City, arranged with Melano C. Reichardt, an employe of his, to drive from Montolair to Paterson with Mrs. Young, stop at the Hamilton House, and try to get Mrs. Young into such a compromising position that Mr. Young would have cause for a divorce.

There is something rather diverting in the calm and matter-of-fact way in which the Supreme Court has assumed jurisdiction in the Sayward case so far as to grant leave to file a petition for a writ of prohibition to prevent the Alaska court from executing its decree, after the organs of the Administration had been protesting that it could not with propriety do anything of the sort.

The Electrical World will this week offer some very pertinent suggestions regarding the telephone monopoly. Last December the fundamental patent on the speaking telephone, granted in England to Alexander Graham Bell, expired, and the Britishers are already congratulating themselves on relief from what, there as here, has proved to be a very obnoxious monopoly. Telephone rates have already been reduced through the natural agency of competition.

Mme. Minnie Hauk was installed in luxurious quarters at the Hotel Normandie yesterday. Although landed from the steamship Traave only few hours previous to receiving THE TIMES'S representative, Mme. Hauk gave no evidence of having undergone a long and especially trying voyage.

The Plan and Scope Committee of the movement that has been projected under the designation of the Pan-Republic Congress met yesterday at the Hoffman House and discussed more or less informally for several hours suggestions in regard to the best way to formulate the purposes of the organization. Champion S. Chase of Omaha presided.

Newberry D. Lawton, owner of the forty-foot yacht Chispa, has consented to be a candidate for re-election to the office of Commodore of the Atlantic Yacht Club. At first Commodore Lawton refused to allow his name to be used, but he finally consented, and he will undoubtedly be unanimously re-ected Commodore at the annual meeting of the club, to be held next Monday evening at the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn.

Of course a Judge is not entitled to any thanks for declaring what the law is in a case that is properly brought before him, and it is almost an impertinence to offer him any thanks for such a declaration. Nevertheless, we take leave to say that Judge WALLACE'S decision in the case of the "Peale reprint" of the Encyclopaedia Britannica is a matter for public congratulation.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- The Republican Senators who voted for Senator Stadler's "Public Ball" Liquor bill under the impression that it was identical with the measure he introduced last year, and discovered later that it contained several outrageous provisions which they had utterly failed to notice when it was before them, succeeded to-day in adopting a resolution to recall the bill from the Assembly.

A three-story frame building at the junction of St. Paul's Avenue and the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad. Jersey City, used b the railroad company as telegraph station and storehouse was burned last night. Loss about $8,000.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 4. -- It seems that there is an interesting piece of political intrigue behind the resignation of State Geologist Spencer. By law the State House officers are appointed a Geological Commission, to which the State Geologist must report. They forced upon Dr. Spencer, who is a capable geologist, a young man of indifferent calibre named Whatley.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4. -- The Newark Presbytery entered into a heated discussion to-day over questions connected with the liquor traffic. A committee had been appointed to investigate certain charges made against the First German Presbyterian Church and report to the Presbytery. The Rev. J.G. Hammer read the report and embodied in it some references to the liquor question.

The schedule for the Acme Hall Bowling tournament, which is to begin next Monday at Acme Hall, Brooklyn, has been completed. The clubs to contest on the first night are the Lincoln Council, Prospect Hill, and the Acme. There will be five bowlers in each team.

The members of the Sub-Committee on Plan and Scope of the Pan-Republic Congress were in session all day yesterday and evolved a report, which was submitted late in the afternoon to the full committee and was adopted. The report was framed by Champion S. Chase of Omaha, John Clark Ridpath of Greencastle, Ind.; Dr. Persifor Frazer of Philadelphia, Col. Ethan Allen of this city, and William O. McDowell of Newark.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- The Assembly Committee on Public Lands and Forestry met tonight for the purpose of beginning the investigation of the Forestry Commission, ordered by a recent Assembly resolution. Three Commissioners -- Cox, Knevals, and Basselin -- with their counsel, J. Newton Fiero and Albert Hessburg, were present.

About two years ago residents of Flatbush, L.I., organized the Midwood Club. It rapidly grew in popularity, its membership in a few months increasing to 500, and it soon became the leading club of that suburban town. The secret of its popularity lay in the fact that the ladies of Flatbush were allowed the privileges of the clubrooms on Monday of each week.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 4. -- The following is a copy of a dispatch from the Governor General to the Secretary of State for the Colonies showing the nature of the Canadian Government's proposals to the United States, and indicating the desire of the Administration for the development of trade between the United States and Canada:

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- It leaked out to-day that E.P. Davis, who has been for a year or more employed by the Inter-State Commerce Commission to obtain evidence against the railroads by which they might be prosecuted for violations of the law, has been discharged. Davis was formerly in the service of the Central Traffic Association, employed in the inspection department, which is presided over by Chief Inspector Paul P. Rainor.

Arguments for and against the trolley system as a motive power for the cars of the Harlem Bridge, Morrisania and Fordham Railway were heard by the State Railroad Commissioners in the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. Commissioners Rogers, Baker, and Rickard were present, as was also a large number of interested persons.

Judge DYKMAN seems to have performed the remarkable feat of putting the lawyers and the laymen upon a footing of perfect equality in regard to a legal proceeding. Neither the lawyers nor the laymen understand or can make even a good working guess why he conditionally dissolved the injunction restraining the Mayor, Controller, and Auditor of Brooklyn from carrying out their scandalous bargain for the purchase of the Long Island Water Supply Company's plant.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- Work is going on rapidly on the new building for the "Fair," a department store on the corner of Adams and Dearborn Streets. The idea of erecting a sixteen-story building in sections while business is going on in the old edifice is unique in this city, though it is only following the example of THE NEW-YORK TIMES in the construction of its present building.

William H. Powell, lately in the butter business with Ferris C. Lockwood, in Chambers Street, called at Duffy's undertaking establishment yesterday afternoon with A.E. Sumner, son of Perrin H. Sumner, and identified the body of the Astor House suicide as that of George H. Edgar, nephew of James H. Edgar and of George R. Edgar, who, according to an affidavit signed by James H. Edgar and published last Saturday, is the Yonkers suicide.

There has not been so lively a meeting of the Board of Education in a long time as that of yesterday. Reform, that has been such a bugaboo in the board rooms for several years, permeated the atmosphere. Commissioners who until recently have been indifferent to the demand for reform fairly scrambled for identification with some one of the several movements under consideration.

Strong language was used at yesterday's adjourned meeting of the Directors of the Utica Belt Line Street Railroad Company, held at the office of I.B. Newcombe Co., 54 Wall Street. An unsuccessful effort was made to untangle the finances of the company, and the local Directors on hand from Utica said some unpleasant things about ex-President Lathrop R. Bacon.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 4. -- The first step toward breaking the dead-lock in the Legislature was ordered this afternoon, both houses deciding to appoint a committee of conference concerning the issues at stake. The plan was originated by the House, and contemplated a conference relative to the report of the investigating committee which was adopted yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- The Assembly accomplished a much-needed reform this morning. Heretofore it has been the custom for canal appropriation bills to be introduced by members who were governed by selfish and political motives. On Friday last the Canal Committee reported favorably five measures aggregating $37,600. As a matter of fact, that committee was not entitled to consider any one of these measures, as they unquestionably belonged to the Ways and Means Committee.

Judge Jackson O. Dykman journeyed down from White Plains to Brooklyn yesterday and took a hand in the suit brought by Mr. William Ziegler to prevent Mayor Chapin, Controller Jackson, and ex-Auditor Rutan from loading the Long Island Water Supply Company upon the broad backs of the taxpayers of that city. In doing so he took upon himself the task of playing the part of the savior of the ring.

The latest number of L'Economiste Francais contains an important and interesting article by M. PAUL LEROY-BEAULIEU on "Gold and Silver; The American Scheme of Unlimited Silver Coinage and Its Probable Consequences." The article was written before the action of the Senate, but a note attached mentions that action, based on an erroneous statement in the cable dispatches that the Senate bill limited coinage to silver of American production.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Gov. Abbett has brought about a novel and interesting legal situation in regard to the borough election at High Bridge, in Hunterdon County, held yesterday. It was with the view of heading off that election that the repeal of the Borough act of last year was rushed through both houses and into the Governor's hands yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4. -- Reports from Virginia City declare that there is great excitement on the Comstock over the decision to drain the lower levels of all the large mines and to begin prospecting and keep on mining, which has been practically abandoned for over six years.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 4. -- The bribery and corruption surrounding the election of Senator Washburn will not down. It came up in a very lurid way in the Senate this morning, over a bill to prevent corruption in elections. Ignatius Donnelly made a fierce onslaught on Washburn, first charging him with having watered the stock of the Soo Road $7,000,000, for which infamy he was rewarded by being sent to the Senate.

The conjugal infelicities of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Finch bid fair to be thoroughly discussed in court. They have two children, who are at present in the custody of Mrs. Finch, at 136 West Eighty-second Street. Mr. Finch, who lives with his father, has procured a writ of habeas corpus in the Supreme Court to gain possession of the children, charging that his wife will not let him see them.

The hearing in the contest of the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather was again taken up yesterday in the Surrogate's Court, before Surrogate Ransom. Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, one of the partners in the firm of Arnoux, Ritch Woodford, Mr. Fayerweather's legal advisers, whose cross-examination was begun at the first hearing Monday, took the stand and when court adjourned at 4 o'clock was still there.

If we may judge from the tone of the Tribune yesterday morning, Mr. BLAINE has already made up his mind to aggravate the difficulties of Sir JOHN MACDONALD in the approaching elections as much as he can. He is reported to have declared that no schedule of articles can be formed as to which the United States will consent to reciprocity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The army and navy were well represented at the tea given this afternoon by Mrs. Avery Delano Andrews at the residence of her father, Gen. Schofield. The hostess wore a gown of gray camel's hair and silk, and boa of gray ostrich feathers thrown across her shoulders. Miss Kilbourne of Iowa, the guest of the house, wore a pale blue bengaline.

Shareholders of the National Lead Trust held their annual meeting at 1 Broadway yesterday. They elected F.W. Rockwell, W.H. Thompson, and R.R. Colgate to be Trustees for three years and L.A. Cole to serve out the term of S.R. Bradley. About 500,000 shares were represented.

The curious inability of manufacturers to resist temptation when they are engaged in promoting "harmony" and in reducing the cost of their goods is shown very clearly by recent events that have excited much interest in the carriage and wagon trade. Everybody has heard, of course, that the purpose of those who make Trusts is to reduce the price of goods to the consumer.

The two houses of the Connecticut Legislature have joined in appointing a committee of conference to devise some means of breaking the existing dead-lock. The Democratic Senate properly enough consented to this, but it made its own position very clear by the resolution which it adopted in response to the House report in regard to the canvass of votes.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 4. -- A terrible mine accident occurred at Janesville, this county, shortly before noon to-day. Nearly 100 men were at work at the Janesville Mine, operated by the Spring Water Coal Company, when all at once, and with hardly a moment's warning, the noise of rushing water was heard. In seven minutes after the first report the whole mine was flooded with millions of gallons of water.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 4. -- The most elaborate event in the history of Rutgers College occurred to-day when Dr. Austin Scott was inaugurated as President in the Opera House. The Legislature of the State and Gov. Abbott were present. The former were entertained at luncheon at Winant's Hall, and the latter reviewed the college cadets on the campus.
LONDON, Feb. 4. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gladstone moved the second reading of the bill to remove religious disability, and during the course of his remarks he said:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Leila Highsmith, the seventeen-year-old protege of Councilman and Mrs. Elmore D. Moffatt, who mysteriously disappeared from her home on Orchard Place last Friday, was found late this afternoon. She had wandered away while almost crazy from a blinding headache and while possessed of the fancy that the Moffatts wanted to get rid of her.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 4. -- Jay Gould and party arrived here to-day at 2 o'clock by a special train of private cars from Washington, D.C. The party consisted of Jay Gould, Miss Gould, Miss McCall, Sidney Dillon, John P. Munn, John H. Inman, Mr. and Mrs. P. Calhoun, Gen. and Mrs. Samuel Thomas, Miss Carpenter, and Samuel M. Felton.

That perennial nuisance, the Gibbs-Cowie faction fight in the Thirteenth Assembly District, is again claiming its share of public attention. Last night the Committee on Contested Seats appointed by Col. William C. Church, temporary Chairman of the Republican County Committee, met in the headquarters of the Eleventh District Republican organization, Broadway and Thirty-Fourth Street, to hear the report of the Cowie-Sprague faction against the sitting Gibbs delegation to the County Committee.

Major Calvin De Witt, Surgeon, has been relieved from duty at Fort Hancock, Texas, and ordered to report to the commanding officer, Fort Sam Houston, Texas, for duty; Lieut. Col. Joseph P. Farley, Ordinance Department, to proceed from Governors Island to the steel works at Spuyten Dnyvil, and at Cold Springs, N.Y., on official business in connection with the inspection of steel projectiles and pneumatic dynamite guns.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Symphony Society held at Mr. Andrew Carnegie's residence yesterday afternoon, Mr. Walter Damrosch announced that he had obtained a guarantee fund of over $50,000 a year for the establishment of a permanent orchestra in New-York. It was resolved to organize the orchestra at once and to secure the best material that can be obtained here and in Europe.

Civility is cheap. Incivility often is very expensive. The following little story illustrating the truth of these observations is respectfully dedicated to Mr. Jay Gould and the other magnates of the Western Union Telegraph Company:

It is evident that Mayor Grant's purpose in neglecting to sign the new civil-service classification of employes under Commissioner Heintz of the annexed district, before going away, is part and parcel of the Tammany scheme to harass and annoy the new Commissioner, either with the purpose of driving him into Tammany with his patronage or making his office as uncomfortable as possible.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 5. -- There has probably been no incident of the Senatorial campaign that has aroused such a feeling of antagonism and anger on the one hand and of loyalty on the other as William R. Morrison's letter published to-day, in which the Illinois member of the Inter-State Commission expresses the opinion that Gen.

The Administration is to be congratulated on the arrangement for reciprocal trade that it has made with the United States of Brazil. In substance and effect, it will be noticed that this arrangement consists of a very valuable series of concessions made to the commerce of the United States of America.

To the strains of Wagner's music, the second annual exhibition of the New-York Poultry and Pigeon Association opened yesterday in the new Madison Square Garden. When the hand began to play, 4,000 fowls began to sing, and the people streamed into the immense amphitheatre and listened in awe to the mighty chorus of blended voices. All sang but the ostriches.

" Mr." Cal McCarthy of Jersey City, a smooth-faced boy with broad shoulders and ponderous flats, and "Mr." George Dixon of Boston, a sleepy-looking colored youth, signed an agreement some time ago to bruise each other's faces in the Puritan Club, in Long Island City, last night. But they failed to carry out their agreement.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The report of the State Board of Health, containing the bulletin for the month of December, 1890, and a summary of the mortality of the State for the year 1890, contains some interesting details. The total reported mortality for December is about 1,000 greater than in November, which is always the month in which the greatest health is enjoyed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- In the action of the people against Henry L. Gregg and Thomas F. Hannon, the judgment of the Court of Sessions convicting defendants of misdemeanor is reversed and judgment given for the defendants on demurrer. The opinion is by Judge Mayham. The defendants are the Mayor and an Alderman of Hudson.

The disclosure of the tricks and jobs by which the agents of the Wool Growers' Association sought to increase surreptitiously the high duties openly required in the wool schedule of the new tariff has aroused the righteous indignation of many manufacturers, and their anger and disgust give a sharp emphasis to what they say in the address of the Wool Consumers' Association.

The annual report of the Directors of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey was issued yesterday. It stated that the net surplus revenues of the company over all operating expenses, taxes, extraordinary repairs, and fixed charges during the year 1890 amounted to $2,507,370. Following is a summary of the earnings and expenses, including the new-York and Long Branch Division:

The proceedings in the contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather became more interesting to the audience which has crowded the Surrogate's Court at each hearing in the case when the execution of the fourth codicil was taken up yesterday afternoon. This is the codicil which Mr. Fayerweather signed the day of his death, Nov. 15 last.

Treasurer Horace L. Hotchkiss of the Grant Monument Association has received the following additional subscriptions: By B.F. Onderdonk, Winfield Scott Post, No. 257, G.A.R., W.H. Schieffelin, $25; A.J. Onderdonk, $5: by Commander George Chappell, Vanderbilt Post, No. 136; by Department Commander Floyd Clarkson, John A.C. Gray, $100; by Commander Smith of John E. Bendix Post, No. 402, cash, $2.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 5. -- Judge Gresham of the United States Circuit Court rendered a decision to-day in the case of Marshall Ayers and others against Michael Manning and others Ayres was the assignee of Sawyer, Wallace Co., produce commission merchants of New-York, who failed. Among the assets of the insolvent firm were certain valuable lands in Franklin and Williamson Counties, in this State.

HAZLETON, Penn., Feb. 5. -- The flooded mine at Jeansville has been surrounded to-day by great crowds. It is now certain that the seventeen missing men are all dead, and that most of them were drowned in their chambers. The water in the pitch of the slope has risen 200 yards, which is a higher point than any of the breasts reached, and those who were not drowned must have died from suffocation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Edward J. Davis, Special Agent of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, has been discharged. Davis was formerly employed by Paul P. Rainer, Chief Inspector of the Joint Rate Committee of the Trunk Line Central Traffic and Western Freight Associations. He was discharged by Chief Inspector Rainer for dissipation.

The opposition to the appropriation for carrying out the law for the State care of the insane, which was made at the committee hearing at Albany yesterday, was only a tedious repetition of the representations made before the law was passed. All the questions raised on behalf of county Supervisors and Superintendents were the old ones that have been repeatedly answered by investigations and reports.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- George Johnson, engineer of the Watkins Gas Company, and Mrs. Cobe Barton of the same place, eloped yesterday, their departure creating a lively stir in the village. Johnson took away about $100 of the company's money and left several creditors to mourn his absence. He also left a heartbroken wife, and the Barton woman left a husband. The couple were traced to illiamsport, Penn.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5. -- The Junior promenade, which has long had the reputation of being the most brilliant social affair of the year in Princeton, took place this evening, and was fully equal to any of its predecessors. University Hall, where it was held, was very tastefully decorated in pink, green, and gold.
" It is doubtful if Mr. Palmer or any other prominent American manager would regard very favorably a play in manuscript by an unknown American dramatist treating a similar theme in a similar manner."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 5. -- A meeting of the creditors of the Winona Paper Company of Holyoke was held in this city this yesterday. People were present from Boston, New-York, Providence, and Worcester, and about 75 per cent. of the indebtedness was represented. T.M. Brown of this city presided and W.A. Castle was Secretary. B.O. Hosford, the Treasurer, made a statement confirming the condition of the mill and the cause of the present embarrassment.
ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The twenty-fourth annual report of the New-York State Board of Charities has just been made public.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- Chancellor von Caprivi, in the Reichstag to-day, in defending the African policy of the Government, said that it had allowed the lines laid down by Prince Bismarck, who once declared that Lord Salisbury's friendship was worth more than the entire coast north of Witu. Emin Pasha and Major Wissmann, he added, can remain in the service of Germany if they so desire.

A novel experiment to be tried in connection with the New-York Homeopathic Medical College and Hospital, and one having a counterpart only at the University of Strasburg, is the establishment of a laboratory for the purpose of analyzing drugs and testing their effects upon human beings. The originator of the plan is Dr. T.F. Allen, Director of the Laboratory of Experimental Pharmacology at the college.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The President makes known to-day by proclamation a convention with Brazil by which trade relations believed by him and by the Secretary of State to be beneficial to both countries have been entered into between the United States and Brazil, authorized under the the tariff legislation of the last session of Congress.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 5. -- The conference between the two houses, from which an adjustment of the issues now in dispute in the Legislature was expected, was blocked under Gardner Greene's direction in the House at the opening of this morning's session, and nothing in the way of settlement has been accomplished to-day.

HELENA, Mon., Feb. 5. -- The sensation of the hour is the resignation of Lawrence A. Brown, State Senator from Beaver Head County, who not only gives up his seat but cuts loose from his party. His resignation was accepted by the votes of the Democratic Senators, the Republicans voting no.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Representative Bishop W. Perkins of Kansas, who was on the stand some days ago, was recalled to-day by the silver pool investigating committee, and testified that he had never endeavored to have the present investigation suppressed. He declared that he had never in any manner sought to prevent an investigation. He had absolutely no knowledge respecting silver speculation and had never been approached by any persons interested in pools.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Feb. 5. -- From all over Vermont come reports that this is the most prosperous Winter for many years. Snow is an important factor in the business prosperity of the State, and this Winter there has been plenty of it. A fall of snow such as would paralyze traffic in New-York brings joy to the heart of the true Vermonter.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- The ice-yacht race for the Poughkeepsie challenge pennant was sailed this afternoon, the start being made at a stake off Roosevelt's Point. The course was twelve miles long, wish several turns in it. The wind was fresh from west-southwest, and the surface of the ice was in good condition.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The Supervisors of the different counties throughout the State and the Superintendents of the Poor gathered in Albany this afternoon to oppose the appropriation of $454,000 to carry out the provisions of the pauper insane law passed last year. The hearing on this was set down for this afternoon before Sulzer's House Committee on Public Institutions.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 5. -- A Post-Dispatch special from Fort Smith, Ark., says: "Passenger train No. 63 on the Little Rock and Fort Smith Railway, which left here this morning, was ditched near Alma, Ark., every coach being wrecked. As far as known only three passengers were injured. Spreading of the rails was the cause."
BARCELONA, Feb. 5. -- The revolutionary spirit smoldering throughout Spain nearly burst into flame in this city to-day.

The Mayor's Advisory Committee on Street Cleaning has given Commissioner BEATTIE his first lesson. It is in the form of an experimental plan for cleaning the section of the city between Twenty-eighth and Fortieth Streets from river to river, and it is such a plan as a competent head of the department, if untrammeled by political interference, might have adopted for himself at any time.

The first services ever held in the new Memorial Baptist Church, at Thompson and West Fourth Streets, took place last evening. The church itself has not yet been completed, but regular Friday evening prayer meetings and Sunday services will be held meanwhile in the lecture room, which occupies the greater part of the ground floor.

A number of bills have been introduced in the Legislature of this State amending the laws relating to taxation. Two or three of these provide for what is known as the "listing system" and for the deduction of ordinary debts from the amount of personal property and mortgage indebtedness from the value of real estate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Representative Morrill, Chairman of the special House committee that investigated the charges against Green B. Raum, Commissioner of Pensions, has completed the report of the result of the inquiry. There will be a minority report submitted by the Democratic members of the committee.

The proceedings for the widening and extension of College Place are rapidly approaching a conclusion. The taking of testimony, which began in April last, was concluded two weeks ago, and the Commissioners of Estimate, Messrs. Eugene L. Bushe, James O. Janeway, and Thomas F. Hayes, are now engaged in making up their report of awards for damages to property taken.

LITTLE FALLS, Feb. 6. -- In the last Presidential campaign one of the most bitter detractors of Grover Cleveland was Charles King, proprietor of the Saxony Knitting Mill in this village. He used the "pay-envelope" device to frighten his employes into voting the Republican ticket, telling them that a Democratic victory would result in either throwing them out of employment or reducing their wages.

CALEDONIA, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Almost the entire business portion of his village was destroyed by fire early this morning. The fire broke out about 4 o'clock in the building occupied as a saloon by Thomas Reid on Main Street. It was discovered by George Outturson, who lived in the house, and it was with difficulty that himself, wife, and son got out of the building.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The Star says the Prince of Wales will soon appear as a witness in a court of law.

The continued reduction of wages perceptibly disturbs our high-tariff contemporaries, and some of them are constrained to offer feeble explanations. Unfortunately for them, the people who were too stupid to "understand" the new tariff in the recent campaign have not forgotten their assertions and promises, and know inconsistency when they see it.

Probably no order of a court was ever before brought into a state of such unstable equilibrium as the injunction in the Long Island Water Supply grab case has been left in by the singular action of Judge DYKMAN. An injunction had been granted by one Judge to restrain the city authorities from effecting a wasteful, and possibly fraudulent, purchase which they had agreed to make.

It may be recollected that at the beginning of the season THE TIMES expressed the opinion that Edmund C. Stanton had got together for the present season, at the Metropolitan Opera House, one of the best all-around companies ever assembled here for German opera. Last night's performance was one of the finest demonstrations yet given of the justice of this opinion.

The plant and oas of the Danville Electric Street Car Company at Danville, Vs., were destroyed by fire yesterday, and he city is without street car service. Tile loss on building, cars, and machinery is estimated at $29.000: insurance, $12.000. in tha lollowing companies: Fire As,,ciatlon, Philadelphia, $t,000 Hambmrg. lremen, $2.600: London Assurance, $L950; Liverpool ancl London and Globe, $2,500; Imperial, $1,100; zEtna, $2,000.

The statement made on Thursday in the Reichstag by Gen. VON CAPRIVI indicates, so far as it goes, that the colonial policy projected and introduced by Prince BISMARCK is to be abandoned by Germany. The present Chancellor was careful to explain that such measures as had been taken by the Government, or were in contemplation, with reference to negotiations in Africa, had been, or would be, taken after consultation and in concert with Great Britain.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- There was much rejoicing among Republican politicians this morning when the news came that President Harrison had at last nominated William A. Hopson to be Postmaster. When President Cleveland came into office he let Postmaster Conklin, an earnest Republican, hold on until his term had expired, which was two years after Cleveland was elected.

Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH'S lucid exposition of the issues upon which the Canadian Parliamentary election will be contested, which we publish this morning, will amaze many American readers by its showing of the extent to which Sir JOHN MACDONALD has carried the process of assimilating Dominion politics to our own.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- President Palmer has called a meeting of the Board of Reference and Control of the World's Columbian Exposition for Monday, Feb. 16. In his announcement of the meeting the President said it was to review the changes made in the arrangement of buildings at Jackson Park, particularly those in the Agricultural Department.

The proposed Game and Fish bill which has been presented to the Legislature by the commission to codify game laws is giving general satisfaction to the fishermen in this city, if the comments heard in the tackle stores and haunts of the angling fraternity count for anything. The fish laws regarding Long Island are not to be changed to any extent, and local fishermen are not affected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Minister Mendoca makes no secret of his belief that the new reciprocity convention is quite as much of a good bargain for Brazil as for the United States. He is also very frank to say that the feature of special importance to his country, and the one for which she is most to be congratulated, is the free admission of sugar from Brazil into the United States.

Ohio is the greatest State in the Union; at least, that was the prevailing sentiment, if not the prevailing belief, at Delmonico's last night, where the Ohio Society of New-York held its sixth annual banquet. Everything was done in the way of preparation, as well as in the way of speeches, to remind the company of Ohio and to awaken enthusiasm on behalf of that State.

Americans, especially those who are interested in trade relations, may wish to know the meaning of the election contest in Canada, to understand the conditions under which it takes place, and to be prepared for estimating the significance of the result. I am so far qualified to inform them that I have never belonged to either of the party organizations, and am thus unbiased by the mere struggle for power.

PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 6. -- The lobbies of the House of Representatives were packed this morning as never before at the hour for taking the joint ballot for Senator, the impression of nearly everybody being that the long fight was about to end. There was, however, another hitch in the programme, and the first ballot resulted: Campbell, 53; Melville, 48; Tripp, 26; Moody, 18; Mellette, 7.

More like a debating society at work than an investigation was the hearing of the Senate Committee on Cities in Part III. of the Superior Court yesterday. The Dock Department was the subject under discussion, but it was not "investigated"; it was debated. Most of the talking was done by A. B. Boardman, counsel to the committee, and ex-Corporation Counsel Henry R. Beekman.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 6. -- The Auditorium was packed to-night with citizens listening to the addresses of the Dominion Ministers, who arrived here to-day to open up the political campaign. The Hon. Mackenzie Bowell, Minister of Customs, was the first speaker. He devoted his remarks to proving that trade relations with Great Britain had increased under the national policy, while there was a corresponding decrease in trade with the United States.

Tammany's Committee on Organization for 1891 organized for business last night. Police Commissioner James J. Martin called the meeting to order and nominated Commissioner of Public Works Thomas F. Gilroy for temporary Chairman. A Committee on Permanent Organization was appointed, and on its report Mr. Gilroy was made permanent Chairman and Judge McQuade Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- J.M.
