Donald, cashier of the Hanover National Bank, who testified heretofore before the Silver Pool Investigating Committee that he had no knowledge with regard to Congressional silver speculations, again appeared before the committee to-day for the purpose of replying to statements made by the witness Owenby that he (Donald) was his chief informant in the matters of which he (Owenby) testified.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- At no time since the Presidents of the Western railroads formulated their agreement has there appeared so little prospect of a successful launching of the Western Traffic Association as to-day. Men who have heretofore argued that the movement would be pushed to a successful issue now say that in view of the obstacles that have been thrown in the way they do not see how the scheme can be carried out.

The Senate Committee on Cities appears to have finished its inquiries into the Dock Department yesterday, but it can hardly claim to have investigated the administration of that department. Yesterday's proceedings were practically a debate upon the policy of dock management, turning chiefly on the question of public and private ownership of the water front.

Three thousand persons visited MadisonI Square Garden yesterday, and the Poultry and Pigeon Show is booming. The fowls are not yet accustomed to the music of the band in the little peep-be gallery away up under the roof. When[ ever the band begins to play, the curious hens m and pullets poke their heads out of their cages and nearly tie knots in their necks in an endeavor to locate the plealng sounds.

The mass meeting called by the Reform Club at the Cooper Institute for Wednesday evening next to protest against the enactment of the Free Coinage bill will speak out with emphasis against the silver delusion, we may be sure, and its utterances should have peculiar weight and authority in the West, where the free silver sentiment is strongest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Railroad rates on Western lines are being closely maintained. Roswell Miller, President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul and President of the Advisory Board of the Western Traffic Association, said to-day:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 6. -- The conference of Presidents, Managers, and General Freight Agents of the Southern railroads was concluded this evening. An agreement as to a contract between all lines that are at present outside of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association, south of the Ohio and Mississippi, has been drawn up, and will be presented for signatures.

JUNCTION CITY, Ky., Feb. 6. -- The wildest excitement was created here this morning about 8 o'clock by a battle between ten or twelve negro raftsmen from the mountains and Marshal George Wells and a posse of this place. Marshal Wells was seriously wounded, being shot in the right shoulder, and J.W. Sampson, his brother-in-law, was shot twice in the shoulder and arm.

A determined effort has been made by the Section of Public Health of the New-York Academy of Medicine to awaken such a healthy public sentiment as will demand that the public schools shall be put in a condition consistent with sanitary and hygienic laws. Last evening the Section held a meeting at the Academy building on West Forty-third Street, chosing as a topic for discussion "The Hygienic Condition of the Primary Schools."

Annie Bradley, whose father, Michael Bradley, was on trial in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for assault, created a scene by refusing to testify against him, and in consequence she was committed to Raymond Street Jail. Her father knocked her down, kicked her, and then cut her with a clasp knife.

It is now more than two months since, in an open letter to your paper, I asked, in "the name of humanity and fairness," for honest and frank answers to a series of questions upon the "boy-and-dog" experiment performed at the Charity Hospital, Nov. 16, by Dr. Phelps. No answers have been forthcoming; on the contrary, every effort has been made to keep the results a secret.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- "Maid Marian," an operetta by Reginald De Koven of Chicago, which has been performed in the present season in America by the Barnabee-Macdonald-Karl Company, has just been produced at the Prince of Wales's Theatre here, and has not only won high praise from all the critics, but is evidently going to have a long and remunerative popular success.

BRIDGEPORT, Feb. 7. -- Many residents of East Bridgeport, and especially the parishioners of the East Washington Avenue Baptist Church, are at present much disturbed at the sudden disappearance of Ralph Gay. Gay came to this city about a year and a half ago, and since that time has been in the employ of the City Steam Printing Company. He was about fifty years of age.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7. -- Sighs of regret are now beginning to be heard on all sides at the interposition of Lent, which will so abruptly put an end to festivities. Doubtless, however, as in former seasons, many card clubs, reading classes, and other mild little associations will quickly spring up whereby what is regarded by a part of society as an unbearably stupid period will be rendered just tolerable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The views of the minority of the Raum investigating committee, which were formally presented to the House this morning by Messrs. Lewis and Goodnight, the Democratic members of the committee, are the same as those drawn up by them at the end of the last session of Congress and publishes at that time.

Something has happened to the hardshell Democratic politicians who represent Gov. Hill in Kings County, and they have suddenly been given to understand that the wily David will not be the party candidate in 1892. Where the tip came from outsiders do not know, but it is asserted that Senator John C. Jacobs was the medium employed for its dissemination.

If the fifth annual convention of the National Association of Builders, which convenes at the Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning, does not prove memorable in a special sense to the delegates it will not be the fault of the Building Trades Club of this city.

By the consolidation of the College of Physicians and Surgeons with Columbia College President Seth Low has crowned the policy to which he has persistently adhered since the beginning of his energetic administration. With a medical department an integral part of its university system, Columbia becomes in scope and equipment a complete university.

The agreement of several gentlemen of wealth and refinement to contribute $5,000 each per year for the maintenance of a permanent orchestra in this city is an accomplished fact upon which this public should congratulate itself. A permanent orchestra is something which New-York does not at the present time possess, strange as that may seem to those who do not look beneath the surface of musical affairs.

Although the action of the Committee on Coinage in resolving to give hearings on the Free-Coinage bill will certainly prevent that bill from being reported to the House in time for passage, and although the House by its vote on Friday showed no inclination to force a vote on the bill, yet the situation is by no means a secure one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- There is some expectation in army circles that there will be an important court-martial growing out of the recent transfer of Gen. McKeever to a position closer to Gen. Miles than the War Department building. The Star, without mentioning names, anticipates this court-martial in a paragraph that has been inspired, doubtless, by some one who knows more than he cares to tell. This story says:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7. -- The Treasury Department is asking of Congress an appropriation of $80,000 with which to rebuild the revenue cutter Ewing. An appropriation is also called for to build a new vessel to replace the revenue cutter Johnson, stationed at Milwaukee, Wis.

CLINTON, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The Juniors organized a whist club early in the season, and its last meeting was held Monday evening at the Theta Delta Chi House, on Sophomore Hill, when the championship of the class was decided. The greatest strife was between the Delta Upsilon and Delta Kappa Epsilon representatives for first place and between the Theta Delta Chi and Alpha Delta Phi members for the last place.

In the name of all that is pure and worthy in life insurance permit me to protest, through your columns, against the proposed nomination and confirmation of James F. Pierce as Superintendent of the Insurance Department of the State of New-York.

In the course of the last days of the discussion in the Senate of the proposed rule for closure of debate an interesting colloquy took place between Senator Gray and Senator Edmunds on the subject of the Speaker of the British House of Commons. Mr. Gray characterized the English Speaker as a non-partisan officer and was promptly taken up by Mr. Edmunds.

The great American tin-plate liar is at present doing business up in Harlem, having established a connection with that beneficent institution known as the Harlem Republican Club. At his instigation, along with the notices of the February meeting of the Harlem Republican Club, which were mailed last Thursday, bits of tin plate were inclosed, attached to each of which was a label upon which appeared the following:

The marriage of Miss Isabella D. Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A.C. Armstrong, to Dr. John E.L. Davis of Nyack-on-the-Hudson and 612 Fifth Avenue, took place yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock at the residence of the bride's parents, 4 East Sixty-third Street.

The work of building up a bull market goes on slowly, but considering the obstacles in the way the progress made is reasonably good. Destruction is often rapid enough, but since the time of Aladdin and his lamp construction has generally been slow work; and to make a bull market now is work of that kind. We shall get there, however.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The more the legislative record of ex-Senator James F. Pierce is examined the more its utter lack of redeeming points becomes apparent. If he ever did anything for the public good the Senate Journal fails to reveal it. If he ever made any speeches in support of any worthy measure the Senate Clerks were strangely remiss in not causing them to be printed.

The women of Southold, L.I., scored what is deemed another substantial victory on Friday in their vigorous crusade against the illicit rum-sellers by the conviction of Manuel Claudio. The trial took place at Orient, L.I., before Justice Glover, and lasted from 9 o'clock in the morning until after midnight.

Tammany has found a way to crawl out of the ugly position in which Mayor Grant left it by going off on a pleasure trip without approving of the new civil-service classification of men employed by Commissioner Heintz of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards. Because of Mayor Grant's neglect, the pay of more than sixty men was withheld in the Controller's office.

The Oxford and Cambridge crews will soon be in the full swing of preparation for their annual match on the Thames at Putney, and after the exciting race of last year, when Oxford won by one boat's length only, the interest in the coming contest is likely to be even greater than usual. There have been forty-seven races between the two universities since the first one took place at Henley in 1829.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Secretary Noble to-day issued instructions to the Commissioner of the General Land Office under the recent railroad land grant forfeiture act in the case of the Mobile and Girard Railroad Company of Alabama. The Secretary holds that the company is entitled only to a quantity of land equal to that earned by the line from Girard to Troy, being eighty-four miles in length.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- From a musical standpoint the week just ended has been more than usually interesting; dramatically it has bean one of the dullest weeks of the season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The indefinite postponement of official entertainments will, singularly enough, do away with the Presidential reception to the general public planned for the evening of Feb. 10. Last season the public reception was omitted because of a similar suspension of gayeties as a mark of respect to the family of Secretary Tracy.

The parade of the Seventh Regiment Thursday evening for the presentation of marksman's badges is the chief event of the current week. It is announced that the review of Col. Appleton's command on this occasion will be taken by the Commander in Chief, Gov. Hill. Cards for the reception are in active request, and the crush on Thursday night is expected to fully equal that attending the opening of the new armory.

LAKEWOOD, Feb. 7. -- The Lakewood of this week has been more like the Lakewood of a year ago than at any time this season. A large list of new arrivals at both of the leading hotels included many young persons, and there have been entertainments and amusements in plenty, quite after the old fashion.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 7. -- This has been a day of preparation but not so much of results. At daylight to-morrow, however, the three ships of the white squadron will be due in the stream in front of this city, while by different routes the visiting military companies will be received by the local companies and escorted to their rendezvous.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 7. -- Col. M. L. Dempsey, member of the Ohio State Board of Equalization, and one of the most active men in the country, died at his home in Warrensville, Ohio, Friday night, of a bronchial trouble. Col. Dempsey served throughout the war in the Union Army, and was confined for four months in Libby Prison.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 7. -- The action of the Amateur Athletic Union in expelling Yates Pennington, Thomas Symington, H.P.C. Wilson, Jr., and Thomas D. Penniman, four members of the Druid Lacrosse team, for playing against professionals at the Madison Square Garden exhibition games last month, did not become known here until yesterday, and it has produced a decided sensation.

Gov. Hill's scheme to bolster up his reapportionment demagogism was begun in Part III, of the Superior Court yesterday. The Special Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Reapportionment came down to begin its work. The committee is made up as follows: Wright Holcomb, Chairman, Tammany, New-York City; Percival Farquhar, Tammany, New-York City; Charles W. Sutherland, Democrat, Kings County; D. Morgan Hildreth, Republican, New-York City; Wilbur H. Selleck, Republican, Oswego.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- As the time approaches for opening bids for torpedo cruiser No. 1, at the Navy Department, next Wednesday, it becomes more doubtful whether any bids will be submitted, and it is regarded as almost certain that there will be none within the limit of $350,000 fixed by Congress.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- In an interview to-day with M. Marie Albert Viger, one of the Deputies from Orleans and reporter of the Tariff Committee of the Chamber, M. Vigor said that he was satisfied that the Chamber would adopt the tax of 12f. per 100 kilos on American pork, which the committee recommends instead of a ten-francs tax, as urged by United States Minister Reid.
Mgr. McDonnell, Archbishop Corrigan's private secretary, has issued the following circular, which will be read in all the Catholic churches of this city to-day by order of the Archbishop:

Five thousand dollars will be spent for plants and flowers in decorating Madison Square Garden for the big masquerade ball of the Arion Society, Feb. 20. From 900 to 1,000 picturesquely-arrayed characters will be grouped on the numerous floats which will form the pageant with which the ball will be opened. The artists having the affair in charge promise that in brilliancy it will far surpass any similar event ever given in this city.

Two women riding from Fiftieth Street to Twenty-third the other day were enlivening the trip for themselves and others by an animated discussion -- perhaps it would be as well to be accurate and say dispute -- as to the most approved style of evening sleeves. One contended for the long and half-long sleeve, the other for the sleeveless bodice.

The twenty-eighth annual report of the New-York Catholic Protectory, submitted to the Legislature of the State and to the Common Council of the city of New-York in pamphlet form, the product of the handiwork of the pupils of the protectory, is a really creditable piece of typography.

The ludicrous farce in the way of a distorted conference between the Amateur Athletic Union and the League of American Wheelmen has at last ended, and the proceedings of the two committees which conferred have been made public. It is so difficult to treat this recent conference or conferences in a serious light that one hardly knows where to begin thinking about it and where to let the subject drop.

An able editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 4 discussed the subject of knots and miles, but more should be written about the matter to make the question clear to the "landlubber," and even to some of those who are "old salts."
They were talking of dreams and several persons had told dream stories more or less interesting. Finally somebody called on Mr. Jarvis to tell his dream story.

The reason assigned in a brief preface for an English translation of this work is a peculiarly English reason. We are told that the royal translator has been prompted to the work by the hope that it will interest Englishmen "who have passed any time on the Island of Malta." Now, the Malta part of this story, standing apart from what followed the Count's stay on that island, is of only the slightest human interest.

This has been a season of revolutions in the musical world. Theodore Thomas is going to Chicago because he cannot find sufficient support in New-York, and Walter Damrosch is to have a fund of $50,000 a year to establish a permanent orchestra. Mr. Damrosch's good fortune is largely due to his own enterprise and judgment.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 7. -- Sir Charles Tupper was seen by THE TIMES'S correspondent this morning respecting the suit brought against him by Mrs. Josephine Bailey in New-York. "I really am unable to say," explained the High Commissioner, "what it means. I recall that the plaintiff, who is said to be the widow of a sculptor, was employed by the Dominion Government at Washington during the Fishery negotiations of 1888.

The Lisbon Correspondent of the London Times telegraphs that a boatman named Joaquin Lopez," remarkable for his bravery in saving a great many Lives, has died in the ninety-third year of his age, in his cottage at Cascaes, near Lisbon. This brave Portuguese fisherman must be well known to Englishmen, many of whom are indebted to him for being rescued from certain death.

Most people would say that the condition of our worst tenement houses was bad enough for children in attendance on our public schools. Yet, according to Dr. CHAPIN in his address on Friday evening, the smallest quantity of air space allowed by law in tenement houses is four times as great as the largest required by law in the public schools.

Pilot Frank Kelley of Pilotboat No. 12, the Ambrose Snow, came into port yesterday morning in charge of the ship Genista, from Calcutta, and made a report that causes it to seem very probable that the Norwegian fruit steamer Simon Dumois, which left here for Matanzas last Wednesday, is at the bottom of the sea.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- All four of the races of the National Skating Association were held on the river here this morning -- quarter mile, five miles, one mile, and ten miles. The ice was in good condition, the sky clouded, and there was no wind of consequence during the first three events. The course was half a mile in circumference

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Feb. 7. -- Judge Albright of this city has been in Easton for the last four days, and is engaged in trying the contest of the will of Jesse Lines of that city. The latter died several months ago at the advanced age of eighty years, leaving a widow of about the same age, but no children except a natural son.

In this period, when there are more misstatements to the square inch being made than ever before relative to American-made tin plates and the possibilities of our producing in the near future a sufficient quantity to supply the home demand, kindly permit your humble servant, who subscribes his name hereto, to submit a statement of facts which may be of interest to you and your readers.

At the request of Baron Maurice de Hirsch of Paris several well-known Hebrew residents of this city have undertaken the management of a philanthropic scheme of great practical utility. They have consented to act under a deed of trust, by which Baron Hirsch places in their control the sum of $2,400,000 to be used in improving the condition of the poor Hebrew immigrants that are continually coming here from Russia and Roumania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- A defalcation has been discovered in the pay department of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, and, as a result, one of the clerks to Mr. Parsons, the disbursing officer, has been discharged. The Treasury Department has been investigating the affair for about a week.

MONT MOOR, Feb. 7. -- This is not a charge against Assemblyman Frank P. Demarest, but a remarkably interesting story of how a large estate when successfully manipulated may be affected by the laws of contraction so that more than $20,000 will melt away into about $1,000, and even that amount be doubtful. The story, stranger by far than fiction, is as follows:

CHESTERFIELD'S LEANING TOWARD THE FnEcH. -- Chesterfielhl is of all English writers, if we except perhaps I-lorace Valpole, the most essentially un-English. Nothing pleased him so much as a compliment paid to him when a very young man by a French gentleman at Paris: "Monsieur, vous 6tos tout comme nous," and it was simple truth.

The prison pen at Atlanta was a good type of all the other pens in the South, though, as it was used as a place of temporary detention, it was small compared with Macon, Columbia, or Andersonville, but it was quite up with them in its unfitness for man or beast.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 7. -- The new Weekly Payment bill, which was introduced in the House Thursday, was drafted in accordance with the ideas of the Central Labor Union of the State, and will be baked by the organized labor representatives. The bill regulating the matter in question which the Republicans passed proved to be a dead letter, and the labor interests now demand a measure that will prove effective.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The conference between Secretary Noble and the Sioux Indian delegation was begun this morning at the Interior Department. The Secretary of War, Mrs. Proctor, and Miss Proctor were present, and also the wife of Secretary Noble and Miss Halstead. Miss Dawes, Miss Kate Foote, Miss Alice Fletcher, and others prominent in the work for the Indians were interested spectators.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 7. -- Escaped convict J.A., alias "Spanks" Waggoner, who, with his brother "Link," has been terrorizing the parishes of Claiborne, Webster, and Bossier for the past six months, has been recaptured after a hard fight and safely landed in the penitentiary.

PARIS, Jan. 21. -- The "Hotel Godelot" is not a new play. It was given many years ago at the Gymnase, and then signed by M. Crisafulli alone. Sardon was known to have had a finger in the pie, and upon this occasion he signs the bright play. There is very little, if any, common sense in the plot, but there is considerable fun, and that is becoming a very hard thing to find.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- A storm in every respect similar to that which paralyzed New-York's telegraphic and telephonic communication began here at sundown. A heavy wet snow fell, and by 8 o'clock telegraph and telephone poles all over the city were down. The Hudson River Telephone Company thus far is the greatest sufferer. Cable boxes high up on telephone poles burned up with pretty effect, and wires coming together threw off bright flashes of light.

Before this week is over the plans for a combination of the County Democracy and the Voorhis Democracy may nave developed sufficiently to indicate what sort of an anti-Tammany Democratic organization there is to be in this city in the near future. Despite the denials of certain County Democrats, it is pretty well settled that advances toward such a union have been made by the Counties as well as by the Voorhis people.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7. -- The annual report which President Eliot of Harvard University has just submitted to the Board of Overseers again brings into prominence two subjects which have long engaged the attention of leading educators, and which are of supreme importance to the general public as well as to college men. These are the proposed shortening of the college course and Harvard's new position with regard to advanced study and special research.

Before this week is over the plans for a combination of the County Democracy and the Voorhis Democracy may nave developed sufficiently to indicate what sort of an anti-Tammany Democratic organization there is to be in this city in the near future. Despite the denials of certain County Democrats, it is pretty well settled that advances toward such a union have been made by the Counties as well as by the Voorhis people.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Mr. Parnell's betrayal of his country and its friends is at last complete. All hope of a compromise is abandoned. Rumors and speculations about a settlement may fill the air for the next few days, but they will have no basis in fact. This may be taken as absolutely certain.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 7. -- Chairman Smith issued a call this morning for a special meeting of the General Managers and General Passenger Agents of the lines in the Trans-Missouri Association, to be held in Chicago next Thursday, for the purpose of taking any formal action that may be necessary for the reorganization of the Trans-Missouri Passenger Association.

The litigation over the will of the late Daniel B. Fayerweather has aroused such general interest that a resume of the testimony thus far adduced in the attempt to break the will is interesting. The chief objective point of the contestants seems to be the residuary estate as disposed by the last codicil. Here it is charged that Henry B. Vaughan was added to the residuary legatees by the exercise of undue influence.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- Official assurances from Rome that the Marquis di Rudini will personally guide Italy's foreign policy, assuming Signor Crispi's engagements, including strengthened armaments, have removed much disquiet here. Emperor William had a communication from King Humbert at the earliest period of the Cabinet crisis, intimating his determination to agree to no Ministry that would imperil the Dreibund; but the Kaiser desired further assurances.

The completion of those plans for "harmony" in the steel-rail trade to which we recently directed attention has been delayed for some weeks by slight differences of opinion as to unimportant details, but now the end of discussion has been reached and a final settlement has been made. The resultant condition was thus described in the Commercial Bulletin's market report of yesterday:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7. -- The Yale students have at last become actually enthusiastic over the new gymnasium which is being erected on Elm Street, and they are now devising means to raise the remaining $35,000 that is needed for the completion of the work. The committee has appealed to the Alumni, but the latter do not seem to appreciate the importance of the petition, for the desired funds have not been received.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 8, via Galveston. -- The mall steamer Arequipa brings the following news up to Jan. 27 from Valparaiso:

The lottery snake is hard to kill. We have now an extremely rigorous Federal law forbidding the advertisement of lottery plans or drawings of whatever description, and the disappearance of such announcements from the newspapers is practically complete. But a curious advertisement has recently been published upon the programmes of certain New-York theatres that seems to be clearly within the inhibition of the statute.

The congregation which filled St. James's Episcopal Church last night was treated to a sacred concert, the chief feature of which consisted in the production of the greater part, for the first time in this country, of a cantata by George Garrett, organist of St. John's College, Cambridge, England, entitled "The Shunammite."

This work is a happy medium between the vague rhapsodies of some tourists over "stately palm trees" and "gorgeous sunsets" and the wearisome egoism with which others chronicle every dinner, every cigar, and every headache. It is, in fact, a concise little guide book for those who go to Honduras to settle, and the information that fills it is of a thoroughly practical kind.

Since the proposed increase of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company's capital stock was announced, early in January, there has been a perceptible advance in the price of stock, the quotations rising from 265 to 270, and the managers of the road assert that the advance has resulted from the anticipated greater capitalization.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8. -- At the Convent of the Good Shepherd to-day took place the most elaborate religious ceremony that has occurred here for years. There was an immense throng of spectators, and hundreds who could not get into the building owing to the crowd filled the grounds and the streets in the vicinity. Nearly half the Catholic clergy in the city and several priests from abroad assisted.

Patrolman Lincoln Gray of the Thirty-Second Precinct late Saturday night found Ernest Parburry, sixteen years old, and James Killian, thirteen years old, wandering about in the storm, in the neighborhood of One Hundred and Eighty-first Street and King's Bridge Road. They had made their escape from the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, at Lafayette Place and Great Jones Street.
ROME, Feb. 8. -- The following Cabinet will be officially announced to-morrow, with the probable addition of Signor Villari as Minister of Education:

UNITED STATES STEAMSHIP PHILADELPHIA, PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 26. -- After a six days' passage the flagship Philadelphia arrived here from New-York. At different times she evinced her great swiftness, easily keeping up a speed of thirteen knots for hours in a moderate sea with no attempt to push her, and this on half-boiler power, at the rate of thirty-six tons of coal a day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Now that Mr. Blaine has found the way, by reciprocity, to extend the commerce of the United States with other countries, there is every prospect that the statistics furnished in abundance by the bureau of the Government established for that purpose will become a fascinating study to all persons who are inclined to think that in one direction Mr. Blaine is likely to be something better than a "dead beat."

The revolts against the Spanish Government have of late years arisen mainly in the form of military mutinies. The Government of an infant King, under the regency of a Queen mother, of course affords the most encouraging environment possible to plots of all kinds. But it is significant that the recent plots in Spain have been not at all dynastic, but avowedly republican, in their origin and purpose.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The report that Gen. McKeever will probably be tried by court-martial on account of his criticism of Gen. Miles has been the general topic of discussion in army circles to-day.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The Republican Senators who are credited with having entered into a "deal" with Gov. Hill whereby they will vote to confirm Tweed's old ally, James F. Pierce, for Superintendent of Insurance can offer no good excuse for their action in view of the strong light thrown on the record of the ex-Senator by THE TIMES.

James MacMahon of the Australian theatrical firm of Charles James MacMahon, and his brother, Joseph S., have been in New-York for several weeks arranging to secure attractions for their Melbourne theatre and the circuit which they control. The MacMahons and the firm of which J.C. Williamson is the head practically divide all Australia between them, so far as the management of theatres is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The test of a compound armor plate on board the British proving vessel Nettle, Friday, which has been exploited as a great victory for compound armor, will not shake the faith of the American Naval Ordnance authorities in their decision to arm the new ships of the navy with homogeneous plates of all steel or nickel steel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8. -- Several delegates to the World's Theosophical Convention at Madras, India, have arrived here on their way to their homes in America and Europe. The annual meeting of the theosophists has closed at Adgar, near Madras, with great enthusiasm. Delegates were present from sixteen countries.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- Discount was in moderate demand during the week; rates quoted were 1 3/4 for three months and 1 1/4 for short. The Bank of England will pay back to the Bank of France, at the end of the present month, the three millions of bullion borrowed during the Baring crisis. It will be returned as received, a it has never been unpacked since it was shipped to London.

That liking for paintings by the old masters that has become so pronounced of late differs in many ways from the fashion that obtained in the United States half a century ago. But it is a fashion now as it was then. The question remains whether it will have permanent value or prove as sterile as the weaker flood that ran before.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 8. -- At the African Methodist Conference at Tangipahoa yesterday Bishop Grant made a severe attack on Bishop Newman of the Methodist Episcopal Church, who recently gave publicity to the charge that great immorality existed among the colored clergy. Bishop Grant pronounced the charge unfounded, and denounced Newman for bearing false witness.

The meeting called by the Reform Club for Wednesday evening to protest against the free coinage of silver will undoubtedly have a very decided influence, not merely upon the present Congress, but upon public opinion throughout the country. The one thing to be remembered by all classes of the community in connection with free coinage is that no one can foretell the extent of the effect from it.

The details of what is known in Paris as the "Tragedy of Ville d'Avray" have recently been slowly unfolded in the Assize Court of Versailles. Peter Wladimiroff figures as the chief actor. The young Russian stands accused, on his own confession, of having shot Mme. Dida, a fair and wealthy widow whom he pursued with his attentions until she became helpless in his hands. The victim was well known in Paris.

Yesterday was the Chinaman's New Year's Day, the first day of the year 5781, reckoning from the time when the Mongolian conqueror, Ju by name, after having successfully invaded the Flowery Kingdom, founded the present Chinese Empire. The celebration of the day began at 1 o'clock yesterday morning in Mott Street, is still in progress, and will attain its largest dimensions some time to-night.
The year 1890 completed forty-five years of service by this company to its constituency. How great that service has been and how great an one is still in progress, may be seen from this summary:
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 8. -- All the town is laughing over the clever, although rather impertinent manner in which the Grand Army men borrowed the eloquence of Mr. Depew.

WA KEENEY, Kan., Feb. 8. -- Judge Osborne of the Twenty-third Judicial District has rendered a decision which will affect nearly every mortgage claim in Western Kansas, and, if sustained by the Supreme Court, will make thousands of dollars for Eastern investors. He has decided that a mortgage given by a settler on a United States claim before filing final papers is valid.
CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 8, via Galveston. -- It is reported here that a secret alliance has been signed between Guatemala and Honduras against San Salvador.

To-day Senator PLATT of Connecticut will try to get a vote upon the International Copyright bill, which was crowded out on Saturday by the long discussion upon the eight-hour back-pay scheme. So far as we can see, the opposition to the bill has been diminishing, and the movement of the chromo people has not developed any real strength.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 8. -- It is safe to say that no one can form a deception of "a mountain town" that does not in some respects resemble Asheville. It answers that description in every respect. Situated in the heart of the mountain region of Western North Carolina, near where the Blue Ridge and Appalachian Ranges meet, the dweller in it sees mountains wherever he looks.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 8. -- H.M. Rogers, a young insurance agent who came here from Chicago last week, attempted to commit suicide after writing a letter to the United States Mutual Life Insurance of New-York confessing that he murdered his sweetheart last Summer near Mercer, Penn. He did not mention names, but admits that he assumed the name by which he was known.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The present House of Representatives has made a record in the line of raising committees to investigate the acts of its own members, but there is a fair chance that it will be asked to appoint at least one more investigating committee before it goes out of existence.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 8. -- At daybreak this morning two squads of police officers made simultaneous visits to the residences of James W. Phenix and Henry Williams, near Pond Avenue. Both parties were armed with search and arrest warrants, but it was only at the Phenix place that the squad under Capt. Garnett met with satisfactory results.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 8. -- Democratic members of the Arkansas Legislature while they make a great puff and blow about investigating and punishing crookedness in the State Treasury, to hide their real efforts to shield the criminals and conceal the crime, are confronted with the exceedingly disagreeable fact that there is no money in the State Treasury to pay the legislators their wages.

TRENTON, Feb. 8. -- The whirl of New-Jersey legislative politics for the next week or two, and probably longer, will be around the race track. The veto of the bill legalizing bookmaking and pool selling which the Legislature of last year passed was a severe disappointment to sports of high and low degree, and the action of the courts in some parts of the State has helped to give it a keen edge.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Albany is picturesque in her scenes of wreck and wealth of snow. Telephone and telegraph poles, with their wires resembling hawsers, are broken in every part of the city, and the wires hang in fantastical forms or lie upon the ground.

There seems to be good ground for the belief that owing to the mysterious disappearance from the County Clerk's office in Brooklyn of certain important documents bearing upon the now notorious "water deal," in which Mayor Chapin, Commissioner Adams, and the Long Island Water Supply Company are concerned, Mr. William Ziegler's counsel, William G. Gaynor, will be deprived of some very valuable evidence as to the actual value of the water company's plant.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 8. -- Jacob N. McCullough, First Vice President of the Pennsylvania Company, which controls the leased lines of the Pennsylvania Railroad west of Pittsburg, died at 9:30 o'clock this morning.

The rumors which have been flying about at Albany during the last few days touching the Insurance Superintendency are well calculated to produce uneasiness in insurance circles and among the holders of insurance policies. For if these rumors are correct an outrageous deal is being concocted, having for its object the annexation of the Insurance Department -- "for revenue only" -- to Gov. Hill's political boom.

ATCHISON, Kan., Feb. 9. -- The depositors' committee of the People's Savings Bank of this city has found that when the bank went into the hands of the receivers recently the nominal assets were $141,999.16, but only $616.40 was cash. The remainder consisted of bonds, notes, mortgages, and other securities. The liabilities were $108,688.16.

The annual meeting of the corporation of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was held yesterday in the Museum building, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street. Messrs. Rutherfurd Stuyvesant, William E. Dodge, and Joseph H. Choate were unanimously recommended by the Board of Trustees for election as Trustees to serve for the term ending Dec. 31, 1898, and the recommendation was ratified without a dissenting voice.

There was a little friction at the meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence, in the new Academy of Medicine building, last night, caused by some proposed amendments to the by-laws. Judge David McAdam, the recently-elected President of the society, was in the chair. The Secretary read the suggested amendments which had been printed on the postal card notices of the meeting.

The third and last Patriarchs' Ball of the Winter was given last night at Delmonico's. In every respect it was a most successful conclusion of ante-Lenten gayeties. The number of guests was limited to 400, and many who wished to attend were unable to get tickets, Mr. Ward McAllister made every effort to have the occasion a fitting cap to the climax of the social season, and the opinion was general that he had succeeded.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- It looks to-night as if James F. Pierce's chances had been ruined as the successor of Robert A. Maxwell, State Superintendent of Insurance. In the face of the expose of THE NEW-YORK TIMES and of the hostile criticism that has been engendered all over the State it is doubtful whether Gov. Hill will dare to send Pierce's nomination to the Senate to morrow, as he originally proposed to do.

Jacob Baiz of 102 Front Street, the Guatemalan Consul General, yesterday received two dispatches from Central America denying the existence of political troubles there. President Barillas of Guatemala sent this message:

The indication that one of the wrecked vessels off Absecom may have had a hole stove in her hull by running upon the projecting masts of a wreck already there reinforces the argument for a methodical policing of the coast for the clearing away of such dangerous obstructions. The Yantic performed a valuable service week before last in blowing away the masts of the Spanish steamer Vizcaya and the schooner Cornelius Hargreaves off Barnegat Light.

The General Term room in the Brooklyn Court House was not big enough to hold the crowd of lawyers and politicians who went there yesterday morning to hear the argument on the appeal taken by Mayor Chapin, Controller Jackson, and ex-Auditor Rutan from the decision of Judge Bartlett continuing the injunction in the suit brought by William Ziegler to prevent these officials from buying the Long Island Water-Supply Company at the exorbitant price of $1,250,000.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- Several collisions between steamers occurred last night at Gravesend. The steamer Caroline, from Grangemouth for London, was in collision with the steamer Lambeth. The Caroline sank soon afterward.

Acting under the advice of Corporation Counsel Wllliam H. Clark, Controller Myers signed the warrants yesterday for the January pay of the employes under Commissioner Heintz of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards. Their pay was vithheld because Mayor Grant had neglected to ign the new civil service classification before going South to enjoy himself in the land of oranges and alligators.

Yesterday was the first day of the fifth annual convention of the National Association of Builders of the United States, and there were about 300 delegates in attendance in the large hall of the Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, about half the number composing the convention; the others will probably be in the hall this morning. The convention was opened with an organ recital by Prof. Goodale.

It is a great pity that the Copyright bill should have been saddled with the amendment, in the supposed interests of certain lithographers that the Senate put upon it yesterday. It is impossible to admit that the majority of the Senate, who thus put the bill in jeopardy for the sake of this amendment, were really in favor of international copyright even though they may have been sincerely in favor of the amendment itself.

There seems to be a persistent notion in Canada that a sentiment prevails more or less strongly in the United States in favor of the annexation of the British provinces to our domain. This notion distorts the view of many Canadians on the fisheries controversy and on all questions of trade between the two countries, and it helps to foster the policy of commercial and political isolation for Canada.
ROME, Feb. 9. -- The Marquis di Rudini, the new Italian Premier, was granted an audience by King Humbert to-day. The King approved of the new Cabinet formed by the Marquis.

Discussion of the resolution offered by Richard Deeves for a petition to Congress and the State Legislature for the enactment of a law to close the Harlem River and thus make the city area unbroken in that section occupied a greater part of yesterday's session of the Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange, and made the meeting by far the most interesting of the year.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 9. -- The work of constructing the new fifteen-hundred-thousand-dollar "west" breakwater in the New-Haven Harbor was begun to-day. Capt. Thomas Beebe of New-London has the contract of transporting the stone from Stony Creek quarries, and for the next month he will deliver 400 tons per day; after that the rate of the work will be increased. Henry B. Gorham of West Haven, a Government Inspector of Breakwaters, is the supervisor.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 9. -- Robert Bonner was in Pittsburg to-day, en route to Col. J.W. Echols's stock farm at Athens, Ga. Talking of his famous trotters, Mr. Bonner said that Maud S. would never again be speeded, but would be allowed to rest with her record of 2:08 3/4. During the coming season she will be bred for the first time, to what stallion had not yet been decided.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 9. -- The strike of the 16,000 employes of the coke regions for an increase of 12 1/2 per cent. in wages, a reduction of working hours of day men from nine hours to eight, the placing of scales for weighing the coal on all tipples, and against a counter demand of the operators for a general reduction in wages of 10 per cent., was begun to-day.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Feb. 9. -- Last Summer the Times printed along account of an extraordinary case at Amboy, Ill., in which a young lady fell into a sleep or a trance about the 1st of April and had been sleeping for eight or nine weeks. The publication aroused public attention, and the matter of pretty Grace Gridley's phenomenal sleep became heralded far and wide.

The delegates to the National Convention of Master Builders, now in session in this city, yesterday visited the Trades Schools founded by Col. AUCHMUTY. We are confi dent that they must have learned there much of permanent interest and value not only to their own association, but to the entire community.

A notable social event at Staten Island last evening was the sixteenth annual charity ball at the German Club Rooms, Stapleton, S.I., for the benefit of the S.R. Smith Infirmary. The rooms were prettily decorated in Louis XVI. style with white and gold hangings. The stage showed a landscape scene, and was filled in with masses of palms and shrubs, through whose green depths calla lilies lifted their white, graceful heads.

In the several articles that have appeared in your columns lately apropos of the meaning of the nautical term "knot," no mention has been made of the reason for selecting 28 and 14 seconds as the intervals to be marked by the sand glass, instead of the more simple half and quarter minute -- an oversight which, in my opinion, leaves the discussion still in much obscurity.

The prevalence of typhoid fever in Albany since the beginning of the year has attracted the attention of those who are acquainted with the conditions under which the people of that city are supplied with water. It is stated that 203 cases of the fever were reported in January, and that with very few exceptions these cases were found in that part of the city which procures water from the Hudson River.

A correspondent, who is evidently in the habit of looking at both sides of a question before he makes up his mind, writes to THE TIMES, asking "Is reciprocity a good thing?" We print the letter in which he states his case:

The second performance of "Die Walkure" at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening drew an unusually large house for Monday, which is the light night of the week. The weather seems to be an element which does not count with devotees of Wagner. It would probably occur to an anti-Wagnerite that the aforesaid devotees have learned to suffer and be strong.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 9. -- To-day saw the formal inauguration of the Carnival. For a week past the city has been in holiday attire, and flags, draperies, and colored lights have adorned each business house. Crowds thronged the streets, and superb mask balls and big society events have characterized each evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The friends of the Copyright bill were a good deal disappointed to-day over the success of the proposal to make its provisions apply to maps, charts, dramatic or musical compositions, engravings, cuts, prints, chromos, and lithographs.

Gov. HILL is bold in evil doing so long as he has effective support. When his supporting squadrons quit the field he is a veritable coward. He likes company in his infamies, and plenty of it. If the responsibility for an official misdemeanor narrows down until it includes only him and a few like him, his heart weakens within him and the executive pen falls from his nerveless fingers.

The poultry show at Madison Square Garden closed last night. There was a large crowd in attendance. No prizes were awarded yesterday. Some of the prize fowls were sold and good prices realized. In a financial light the show was a failure.

Gen. W.T. Sherman's friends were startled yesterday to learn that he was seriously ill and had been dangerously low. On Monday his condition was so alarming that his married daughters and his brother, Senator John Sherman, were summoned to his home, at 75 West Seventy-first Street, in this city. Callers at the house last evening were informed that the General was much better, although still suffering severely from erysipelas.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10. -- A gigantic mining deal has just been carried through, in which St. Louis, Chicago, and New-York capital is invested.

Mr. James Redpath died yesterday morning at 9 o'clock at St. Luke's Hospital from the effects of injuries received last Thursday afternoon, when, as has already been told in THE TIMES, he was run over by a Madison Avenue horse car.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The consummation of the most disgraceful deal that has marked the regime of David Bennett Hill as Governor of New-York promises to be accomplished to-morrow, when the Governor, in defiance of the public sentiment and of the protests of the press, will send to the Senate the nomination of James F. Pierce for Superintendent of Insurance in place of Robert A. Maxwell.

Any one who visits the art museums may be struck with the fact that the feet of all the ancient statues seem very large. They do seem so, but it will be found that for symmetrical perfection these feet could not be better, and yet the feet of the average man or woman to-day are much smaller than in ancient times.

An application was made by the One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street Railway Company to the Board of Aldermen yesterday for permission to construct a street railroad from One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, through One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, Lenox Avenue. One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, Seventh Avenue, and One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, to the ball grounds at Eighth Avenue.

PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 10. -- A report reached Pierre to-day from Chicago that there was a deal on foot between the Democratic and the independent members of the Illinois and South Dakota Legislatures by which the Illinois contingent was expected to co-operate in choosing a Democratic Senator, and the South Dakota fusionists were to get a farmer to succeed Moody in return.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 10. -- Prof. Elroy M. Avery achieved a signal victory over his old companion in arms and present arch enemy, C. Spaulding of Dundee, Mich., to-day. When the case against Avery, who was arrested on a charge of stealing a watch from Spaulding during the war was called, Spaulding did not appear in person, though his attorneys were present.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 10. -- When Rex appeared on the streets yesterday, the thermometer stood at 79. Signal Observer Hunt volunteered the prediction that the temperature would fall 30 in the ensuing twenty-four hours. He was mistaken, it fell only 29, and when the parade passed the newspaper offices this afternoon the thermometer registered 50.

A source of considerable anxiety to the local managers of the convention of the National Association of Builders lest the convention should not prove a success was happily removed by the time the convention came to order yesterday, when the sun came out, dispelling the rain and mists of the previous days and bringing a bright, clear, bracing atmosphere.

The exposure of Mr. James F. Pierce's record in connection with irregularities in the Insurance Department of this State under Mr. Superintendent Miller has served to call the attention of the Senate at Albany to the wrong to insurance interests at large which would be likely to result from Mr. Pierce's incumbency and has strengthened the hands of Messrs. Fassett, Saxton, Sheard, Robertson, and Sloan in their efforts to defeat the nomination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- When the House took up the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill to-day Mr. Dalzell of Pennsylvania brought up the Barrundia case, and attacked the course of Secretary Tracy in his treatment of Commander Reiter.

SHENANDOAH, Feb. 10. -- It is now well known that a secret Polish society, organized for the purpose of defending their people and avenging their wrongs, has existed in this valley for the past two years. The police officers of this place have made the discovery, which in details are as sensational as anything connected with the Mollie Maguire troubles.

According to the news from Chicago yesterday the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago (Monon) Road is to pass into the control of the Richmond Terminal. A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Chicago late last night says: "On Monday evening United States Senator Calvin S. Brice arrived in Chicago and met President William L. Breyfogle of the Monon here, and it is believed that the purchase of the Monon by Brice was then consummated.

The case of Acting Sergeant Enoch A. Goodell of the Grand Central Station, who was found by Inspector Williams asleep on a lounge behind the desk, with the lights turned low and the door barred, was before the Police Commissioners yesterday for decision.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- When the Assembly Committee on Public Lands and Forestry met to-night it found one corner of the Assembly parlor occupied by a great map, 15 feet high and 10 feet wide, whereon was depicted the forest preserve in the Adirondacks and the boundaries of the proposed park. The land owned by the State was colored red, and the amount of red on the map was surprisingly small.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Mrs. Oates, wife of Representative Oates of Alabama, gave a violet tea this afternoon, which was largely attended by persons prominent in Senatorial, army, and navy circles. The hostess wore a Worth costume of cloth of gold brocade on white satin, the front draperies of crepe de chine caught at the left side with a garniture of white satin fuchsias.

" The investigation of GREEN B. RAUM has terminated," says the Cleveland Leader, "and has not left even the slightest stain upon the character of that very efficient and honest officer." Such are the outgivings of those blind partisans who believe that a great political party can best be sustained and enlarged by defending all the unworthy men who have been put into high offices by its influence.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 10. -- Miss Anne May Farnam, daughter of Charles H. Farnam of this city, was married at Trinity Church this evening to Frank Lincoln Woodward of Denver, Col. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Chauncey B. Brewster of Grace Church, Brooklyn, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Edwin Harwood of Trinity Church, this city.

Some of our contemporaries appear to have been misled as to the relation of the National Lead Trust to the white-lead industry. At the recent annual meeting of this Trust a few explanatory remarks were made by the President, W.P. THOMPSON, a gentleman who became familiar with Trust methods through his large interest in the Standard Oil Trust.

TRENTON, Feb. 10. -- The houses had busy sessions to-day. The main thing done was the passage in both chambers of the act which takes the control of the Insurance Department out of the hands of the Secretary of State. Mr. Kelsey, the Secretary, himself suggested the change. The new act authorizes Gov. Abbett to appoint an Insurance Commissioner at a salary of $4,000 per year.

A reciprocity agreement similar to that made with Brazil is said to have been effected with the Republic of Venezuela, and proclamation thereof is expected as soon as the official documents now on the way have been received. While the foreign trade of Venezuela is much smaller than that of Brazil, we have had a larger proportionate share in it.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- It is believed here that Senator Hendricks has made a deal with Gov. Hill, one of the objects of which is to secure the appointment and confirmation of a Superintendent of the Onondaga salt springs in place of P.J. Brumelkamp, appointed by Cleveland. Brumelkamp has held over Several years because Hendricks would not consent to the confirmation of any successor that might be appointed by Hill.

The most novel feature of the long entertainment given in Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon for the benefit of Annie Russell was the last act of "Aunt Jack," comprising the trial of the now famous breach of promise case, presented by members of Mr. Palmer's Madison Square Theatre company, with the assistance of nearly one0 hundred ladies and gentlemen of the stage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Hydrographic Office reports have for several months past shown an unusual number of wrecks and sunken vessels forming dangerous obstructions to navigation off the Atlantic coast, and masters of coasting vessels and other navigators have had to keep a sharp lookout to avoid running into some of them.

Up-town select poker circles are greatly agitated over an occurrence in the Hoffman House the other evening at the card table, and which has cast a cloud over the reputations of two men, who have lately been winning large sums of money at the favorite American short-card game.

The notice given by Mr. BLUMENTHAL in the Assembly yesterday that he should move a call of the House this morning is construed as indicating that he expects to rally a sufficient number of votes for the Stadler "dance-house bill" to secure its passage. The men who are showing so much zeal in behalf of this measure ought carefully to count the cost to their own reputations of its passage.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Senator Sheard's concurrent resolution calling upon the State Representatives in Congress to vote against the passage of the Free-Coinage bill was passed by the Senate to-day after a sharp political debate.

The Brooklyn water scandal, which occupied the attention of the General Term of the Supreme Court on Monday, got back into the Special Term yesterday, when William J. Gaynor, on behalf of Plaintiff Ziegler, took his first step toward having the case tried by a jury. In order to do this he had to frame issues to be so tried, and he got together fifty questions based on the complaint of Mr. Ziegler.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Unusual interest will attach to the campaign in Chicago this Spring, owing to the fact that it is to be made the basis for the national contest in Illinois in 1892. The Democratic leaders will make every effort to carry the city by a larger majority than ever before.

HARTFORD, Feb. 10. -- The House withdrew from the position this afternoon that prevented the conference proceedings last Friday, and the committees from both houses attempted an adjustment of the troubles to-night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- The general Cattle market was without much change to-day. The better grades, suitable for exporters, sold in some instances 5 a 10c higher, but, on the other hand, common grades shaded lower. The supply was rather light, and a good clearance was made. The quality was rather poor, there being no real choice Cattle on sale. The highest price reported-was $5.15.

For several years past the sessions of the Legislature of this State have lasted until the middle of May or later, but there seems to be no good reason why the present session should not end at least a month earlier. Last year a good deal of time was taken up with the World's Fair, ballot reform, and rapid transit, but there is nothing now that is likely to lead to any such prolonged controversy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The marriage of Miss Susan Carberry Lay, daughter of the Consul General to Ottawa, to the Hon. William F. Wharton, Assistant Secretary of State, took place this afternoon at the residence of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Hobson, 1,820 N Street. The Rev. Dr. McKim of Epiphany Church officiated.

An old Republican politician -- a man who knows pretty well all the fine points in political moves in this State -- said last night in speaking of Gov. Hill's project to make ex-Senator Pierce Superintendent of Insurance:
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 10. -- At a meeting of the Jefferson Club last night the following letter was received and read in response to an invitation to attend the annual banquet in April:
TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 10. -- The Globe (Liberal) says:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- It is understood that the President has ready for announcement a proclamation of reciprocity with Venezuela similar in terms to the agreement just reached with Brazil. This agreement has been reached by the exercise of the powers conferred by the legislation of the last session of Congress, and will take effect, according to report, about the same time as the agreement with Brazil.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 10. -- The Sun will have the following in Wednesday's issue:

The committee that appeared before the Coinage Committee of the House yesterday from St. Louis had one striking peculiarity in its composition. Though it represented capital amounting to $100,000,000, there was not among its members, or among those who signed the St. Louis protest, a single banker or capitalist. All were either merchants or manufacturers.

The Fish Commissioners were forcibly reminded when they assembled yesterday for their monthly meeting that this is the time of year to arrange for the distribution of fish. They found 866 applications awaiting them from various parts of the State, calling in the aggregate for 22,165,075 fish. Reports from five hatcheries showed that 21,790,000 fish are on hand.

The Ash Wednesday services in Trinity Church Yesterday were peculiarly solemn and impressive. Every seat in the church was occupied and many persons were compelled to stand. The preacher was the Rev. J. Nevett Steele, D.D., assistant minister of Trinity. His subject was "Fasting as a Duty." He spoke in substance as follows:

The National Association of Builders, when it came together yesterday, took up the report of the Committee on Arbitration. In harmony with the views of the committee a form of agreement was adopted to secure the establishment of arbitration committees and a plan of organization for the use of associations or employers and associations of workmen in all branches of the building trade.

The appointment of JAMES F. PIERCE for Superintendent of Insurance reflects the deepest disgrace upon every man concerned in it, and will deprive an important branch of the State Administration of public confidence. The brazen pretense of Senator VEDDER that it was only a question of retaining a Cleveland Democrat in office or displacing him with one who is not a Cleveland man will blind no one to the true motive of the transaction.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 11. -- Toronto this morning for the first time in its history saw a black flag carried by unemployed men, bearing the motto. "Work or bread." An evening paper yesterday contained an innocent-looking paragraph inviting all laborers out of work to meet at 9:30 o'clock this morning at St. Andrew's Square.

The Rev. J.H. Twichell writes as follows to Mr. Hersey, Secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association, as to the benefits of the gymnasium connected with the proposed new building of the association:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Sioux Indian conference was concluded to-day and the Indians will to-morrow or Friday start for home, going by way or Philadelphia and Carlisle. The feature of to-day's meeting was the story of the fight at Wounded Knee, which was told by Turning Hawk and American Horse.

Bandmaster Patrick S. Gilmore's Twenty-second Regiment Band is to give a series of promenade concerts in the armory, Sixty-eighth Street and the West Boulevard, alternate Saturday nights, beginning this week. A commodious stage and sounding board has been erected, and accommodations for seating 5,000 people will be made, space being left for a promenade around the entire armory floor.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 11. -- Ex-State Treasurer Noland, who went out of office under a cloud, is awaiting trial for stealing nearly $40,000 of the State's funds. It is an open secret that Noland lost the money at poker, and it is generally believed that the money, or a large portion of it, was won by men who are prominent in political circles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The committee representing the New-York Chamber of Commerce made its formal protest against free coinage of silver before the Committee on Coinage this evening.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 11. -- The election campaign in the Maritime Provinces has been embittered by the partisan action of his Grace Archbishop O'Brien of Halifax in issuing a letter on the subject of the position of the Church, its prelates and its priests, during a political struggle. The Archbishop is coming in for a great deal or criticism from Roman Catholic Liberals.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11. -- This was the opening day of the extraordinary sale of the John R. Baker, Sr., collection of Washingtonian and rare American literary and historical curiosities, and a large number of eager purchasers were attracted in consequence, both afternoon and evening, to the auction rooms of Thomas Birch's Sons.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- United States Minister Lincoln had his first interview to-day with Lord Salisbury since the former's return to this country. The interview lasted a long time, and gave rise to the rumor that the main subjects discussed were those bearing upon the Bering Sea question.

An opinion, handed down by Justice Ingraham of the Supreme Court, yesterday, created a great deal of excitement among lawyers, and copies of it were in demand. It was rendered upon the application of James M. Lyddy, counsel in the suit of Susan M. Laytin against Thomas Cunningham, Sons Co., to have the order referring the case to Middleton S. Burrill set aside.

Shortly after midnight the lights in Gen. Sherman's room were turned down, and it was said that his condition was unchanged. Dr. Alexander was with him, but the members of the family had retired to get needed rest.

The Italian Alpine soldier has no easy life of it in winter, buried in small forts on the high Alps, and being obliged to march in storm and snow, the new military orders enforcing never-interrupted communication between the fortified places, whatever may be the state of the weather. A Turin correspondent gives the particulars of the late accident, when Lieut. Zanzucchi and four of his six companions met with their death.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- In an interview to-day Mr. Parnell declared that he would not recede from his position, which he said was consistent. He would not submit, he said, to the dictation of Mr. Gladstone and the priests. He believed that the general election would not be held for two years yet.

AYER, Mass., Feb. 11. -- The First National and the North Middlesex Savings Banks closed their doors to-day and ugly rumors are afloat concerning them. H.E. Spaulding, cashier of both institutions, has been missing from town since Monday evening. Where he has gone no one here knows. Commissioner of Savings Banks Warren E. Locke, who arrived this afternoon, said that from a superficial examination he thought that the savings bank is all right.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- This was the date fixed by the Navy Department for opening bids for the construction of torpedo cruiser No. 1, but 12 o'clock, the hour for opening, came and passed and not a bid had been received. As has been anticipated by the department, no shipbuilders are prepared to undertake this work within the limit of cost fixed by Congress and at the same time guarantee the results required.

The Fish Commissioners spent several hours yesterday over the Spring allotment of trout. When the work was finished the requisitions for 14,000,000 of brook and brown trout had been scaled to 4,100,000, leaving about 570,000 of the supply at the hatcheries unallotted. Some of the allotments may be further reduced in order that the hatcheries may not suffer from shortage.

The opinion expressed by the London News in its comments on the Nicaragua Canal guarantee, that "the Americans seem about to triumph by sheer persistency," and that "if one-half of Mr. MENOCAL'S anticipation is realized he will rank among the world's greatest engineers," is pleasant compliment and possibly something more.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- If the story told by the agents of the National Treasury Department now in this city is true, one of the most diabolical of dynamite plots, involving great loss of life and property, has been discovered and its consummation prevented just on the eve of putting it into effect.

My attention has been directed to a movement now on foot for aiding American art students. It is not my desire to write a single word calculated to interfere with the commendable intentions of the gentle men who have originated the movement, but I do desire to point out the absolute inadequacy of the scheme (so far as yet outlined) to meet oven partially the needs of American art students.

Jay Gould's purpose in visiting the South was to inspect railroad properties essential to the formation of a Southern transcontinental system. So says Mr. John H. Inman, President of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Company. Mr. Inman left Mr. Gould's party at Savannah, Ga., and reached this city yesterday morning. He talked frankly about the trip, and said that the inspecting party found the Richmond Terminal system in even better condition than they expected.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 11. -- The Republican majority in the House has been placed on the defensive by the proposition from the Senate conference committee for a judicial determination of Gov. Morris's title to the Governorship. On the recommendation of this committee a bill was passed to-day by the Senate providing that the Superior Court in Hartford County shall have power to determine the issues involved, subject to appeal to the Supreme Court.

WASHINTON, Feb. 11. -- The Democratic side of the House is very proud to-night of the performance to-day of Representative McAdoo of New-Jersey, whose speech this afternoon during the debate on the pending Appropriation bill, but really against the Subsidy bill, that is not under consideration, is pronounced to be the most vigorous and effective attack upon the subsidy measure that has been made at this session or for many years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 11. -- Richard Stahl, author of the comic operas "Said Pasha" and "The Sea King," is in the custody of the Chief of Police of Portland, Oregon, awaiting a requisition from Gov. Markham of California.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- By a combination with the worst element that misrepresents the Republican Party in the State Senate, Gov. Hill succeeded to-day in removing from the position of Superintendent of Insurance Robert A. Maxwell, a man whoso offense consisted in his devotion to the public welfare, and in his refusal to convert his office into banking office for Gov. Hill and his friends of the Democratic State Committee.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11. -- Cardinal Gibbons has sent the first remittance out of the proceeds of the Irish relief fund, amounting to $1,000, to Archbishop McCormack of Galway. Others will follow in the near future.
Edward S. Holden, Director of the Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton, in speaking of the prominence which the institution has gained in the scientific world, said:

A great mass meeting, called in behalf of New-York business men by the Reform Club, was held at Cooper Union last evening to protest against the free coinage of silver in the United States. The protest was uttered in clarion tones by men of national reputation, and their words were applauded to the echo by nearly two thousand people.

A discussion on hypnotism was the chief feature of the meeting of the Medico-Legal Society in the Hotel Buckingham last night. A report on that subject, submitted by a committee of the society a month ago, was the basis of the discussion. That report suggested several questions to be considered, such as: Is hypnosis a disease? Is hypnotism attended with danger to the subject?

About twenty-five breeders of Ayrshire cattle, every one an enthusiastic supporter of the merits of that famous stock, were at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon to attend the annual meeting of the Ayrshire Breeders' Association.

AMPERSAND, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- This month has opened under the most auspicious circumstances and the season is now at its height. It has been an ideal Winter, and there has been continuous sleighing since Dec. 3. The weather has not been so cold as in some Winters past. The thermometer has averaged about 25 above, and ice 20 inches thick is now being cut from the lakes and ponds.

BROCKTON, Mass., Feb. 11. -- The Brockton Enterprise this afternoon prints a two-column letter addressed to the local public from Charles W. Robinson, the clerk of the police court and partner of F.S. Howard and Emerson Goldthwaite in the stock brokerage business, who disappeared on Oct. 24 last, being a forger to the amount of $150,000. The letter is postmarked Middletown, Conn.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 11. -- Led by Frederick E. Bach, private secretary to Senator Higgins and an employe of the Senate folding room at Washington, the Republicans of Wilmington are now engaged in a fierce fight for the possession of the crumbs of local patronage gained by them when they elected a majority of the Levy Court last November.

The discussion on the naval militia in the Senate the other day indicated that some members of that body had not kept the run of the important movement which has been going on of late in this direction. A Senator from Kentucky, which shares with Bohemia the inability to have a seacoast, confessed that the subject was wholly new to him.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 11. -- The weather was cool to-day but pleasant, and there was an increased attendance at W.R. Brasfield Co.'s sale of trotting horses. There was considerable poor stock offered, but the best bred ones continued to sell well. Sixty head brought $44,695; average, $647. Lots bringing $800 and over follow:
ALTON, Ill., Feb. 11. -- The murderers of Senator Daniel B. Gillham have been arrested, and two of them are now in the jail at Edwardsville.

Fletcher R. Short, an unmarried man of twenty-eight years, who for the last three years has been bookkeeper and confidential business manager for John F. McHugh, manufacturer of awnings at 1,263 Broadway, blew out his brains early yesterday morning in his room at the home of his brother-in-law, John Thompson, with whom he boarded at 235 McDonough Street, near Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- In the opinion of the best posted politicians in Syracuse, Gov. Hill has begun very promptly to get on good terms with the man who is to be his colleague in the United States Senate for the next two years. Nobody but Senator Hiscock, they believe, could have induced Mr. Hendricks to give his support to such a nomination as that of Pierce for Insurance Superintendent.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- The Executive Committee of the World's Fair Directory to-day decided that the departments to be organized by Director General Davis shall be subject to the closest scrutiny of the committees of the Directory. The committees may be instructed to exercise supervisory power over the departments.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill, Feb. 11. -- The Republicans in the Legislature are apparently in a hole of their own digging to-night, and the chances of their getting out are no very promising.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Earle S. Youmans of Winona, Minn., brings to Washington some interesting information about the political prospects in his State.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11. -- Allen M. Murphy, a typical Westerner, who runs a large grain farm at Borga, Mich., was swindled out of $380 in this city to-day by the old green-goods game, worked by three unknown confidence men. The farmer is now confined behind the bars at the Central Station, and will be given a hearing by the United States Commissioner this morning on a charge of attempting to purchase counterfeit money.

PLAINFIELD, K.J., Feb. 12. -- By reason of working night and day in the coal business to retrieve the fortunes of his family and by assisting in the music on Sundays in the First Baptist Church of this place, Abram Staats had little time t ospend at home. Mrs. Staats became accustomed to attending religious meetings with Edward Wilson, a tailor, and gossips connected their names, apparently with good cause.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- When the Coinage Committee met this morning Mr. Frederick Fraley of Philadelphia, President of the National Board of Trade, was given an opportunity to present his views. All international business settlements, he said, were based upon the standard of Great Britian because of its permanent character.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Cleveland and his alver letter to the Cooper Union meeting was the subject of conversation in Washington today. The talk about the Watterson letter, which had been a most exciting and diverting topic, ceased to concern anybody, the superior importance of the latter totally eclipsing both Hill and Watterson.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 12. -- The Tennessee River at this point has passed the danger line -- thirty-three feet -- and is still rising steadily, and will in all probability pass the forty-foot mark. Although no serious consequences will follow, thousands of logs have drifted past all day from the wreck of the boom at London, entailing a loss of more than $40.000.
