That most adventurous of women travelers, who is known to the reading public as Miss Isabella Bird, and to her friends as Mrs. Bishop, says a London correspondent of the Leeds Mercury, "has just returned to England after safely accomplishing a most difficult and dangerous journey, a records of which will shortly be published by Mr. John Murray.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Feb. 12. -- Judge Wilson Lewis of Harlan County, the man who made himself famous as the leader of the law and order faction, has been killed. On Tuesday night he was murdered by his son, Sidney Lewis, and the latter succeeded in making good his escape, and is still at large.

Once more the holders of what have been so long known as the French spoliation claims are urging upon Congress the payment of the amounts which have been adjudged as clearly due by the Court of Claims. There is nothing more discreditable in the entire history of our national legislation than the failure to provide for the payment of these claims, which the Government voluntarily assumed more than ninety years ago.

The public has a short memory, but it ought not to forget that DAVID B. HILL and six Republican Senators by a corrupt agreement and understanding have established the office of Superintendent of Insurance upon a blackmailing basis. They have made arrangements to restore the office to the scandalous condition in which it was put and kept by GEORGE W. MILLER and JOHN F. SMYTHE.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 12. -- This, Lincoln's birthday, was chosen as the date for the fourth annual convention of the Ohio League of Republican Clubs. The officers-elect for the ensuing year are: President -- W.L. Squires, Toledo, and four Vice Presidents; Secretary -- John J. Chester, Columbus; Treasurer -- B.L. McElroy, Mount Vernon.
FOLKESTONE, Feb. 12. -- Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien, upon their arrival at this place from Boulogne-sur-Mer, voluntarily surrendered themselves to the police authorities here.

The so-called debtor class unquestionably has considerable influence in Congress, perhaps because a certain number of members of Congress belong to it, and certainly because a much larger number of politicians, on whom the Congressmen are dependent, belong to it. If we were to believe the orators who advocate cheap money in the interest of this class, we might suppose that it embraced by far the larger number of voters in the United States.

QUEBEC, Feb. 12. -- About 9:45 o'clock this morning a boiler in the Quebec Worsted Company's factory at Hare Point exploded completely demolishing the engine house and a part of the factory. A large number of the employes were buried in the ruins, and over twenty persons have been killed, among them being Mr. Styles, the chief engineer.

At the regular meeting of the Union League Club last evening an unusually large number of members came together to listen to the reading of the resolutions concerning the death of Secretary Windom. They were introduced by Charles Watrous at the beginning of the meeting, the rules being suspended by Vice President Le Grand B. Cannon (who presided in Mr. Depew's absence) for that purpose.

BOSTON, Feb. 12. -- In the cellar of a Harrison Avenue hotel devoted to the Celestial art dramatic was a curious combination of two civilizations to-day. The Boston branch of the Folk Lore Society had engaged the Chinese theatre and the players for the occasion. The play was "The Celebration of the Birthday of the Great Emperor."

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- The long-talked-of meeting of the anti-Parnellite members of the House of Commons was held to-day in Committee Room 15 of the House. The meeting was called to order at 1 o'clock by Mr. Justin McCarthy, who presided. When Mr. McCarthy entered the room he was warmly cheered by his supporters.

Charles Koenigsberger of 188 East Houston Street and William Langeheim, an unemployed waiter of 430 East Sixteenth Street, amused themselves at noon yesterday by baiting an old Jew glazier, Jacob Goldschmidt of 282 East Houston Street, but their sport ended when a pistol that was not loaded and which was produced to scare she old man "went off" and killed him.

Two Winters ago a cultivated and enterprising woman looked about for an opportunity of exercising her pretty talents with profitable results. With almost the inspiration of genius she concluded to hold classes in conversation. On first thought her friends were greatly amused, and yet, when her explanation was made, they began seriously to wonder how society had moved along satisfactorily without the aid of lessons in conversation.

A meeting of most of the leading representatives of American life insurance companies was held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday morning and took action which will doubtless prove of great importance to the business throughout the country. There has been a sentiment prevailing among insurers of the better class for some time that something should be done to prevent the increasing competition among companies for the services of agents.

The Lenox Lyceum held a larger congregation of builders last night than has ever before been brought together in this country. The occasion was the annual banquet of the National Association of Builders of the United States, which has been in convention in the city during the week.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 12. -- A special from St. Augustine to the Times-Union says: "Jay Gould was taken suddenly ill this morning, and by advice of his physician started for New-York in his private car at 11:55. He is accompanied by Dr. Munn, Miss Helen Gould, and Miss McCall.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Charles J. Gibson, the Secretary of the Whisky Trust, who was arrested here yesterday, left for Cleveland last night. In an interview before leaving he said regarding the charges against him:

A document presented as the last will of the late Barnum B. Peet of the firm of Peet Smith has been refused admission to the Probate Court by Judge Beardsley on the ground that it was not drawn in compliance with the law. Following is the text of the instrument:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The Secretary of War to-day made public the report of the investigation into the battle at Wounded Knee Creek, S.D., Dec. 29 last, particularly with reference to Col. Forsyth's conduct on that occasion. The official order for the investigation is dated Jan. 4 and is signed by Lieut. Maus as aide de camp. It is as follows:

The resignation of Ex Norton as President of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad was a surprise to railroad men, and it caused considerable comment in Wall Street yesterday. The general impression prevailed that Mr. Norton retired because of a difference of opinion between himself and the owners of a majority of the stock. Following is Mr. Norton's letter of resignation:

Gov. HILL is right -- Mr. WATTERSON'S letter was an insulting and impertinent communication. But the convicted criminals who come before the Judges of our Court of Sessions always resent the severity of the language used by the court in pronouncing their sentences. And Judge KIRBY BENEDICT of the Supreme Court of New-Mexico in pronouncing a death sentence once addressed the prisoner as follows:

Modestly peering out from among the brilliant roses that nod their queenly heads in the florists' windows in Baltimore, little clusters of pink and white blossoms with beautiful green foliage have attracted the attention of passers by the last few days, since the plant has bloomed plentifully. It is the Primula obcornica, technically called, and is a variety of primrose.
What are Gov. Hill's views on the free coinage of silver?

BELLEVUE, La., Feb. 12. -- The Supreme Court will in a few days decide whether a proposed constitutional amendment shall be submitted to the people providing for an extension of the Louisiana Lottery charter for twenty-five years. The people in the country are very determined in the matter, and should the decision be favorable to the lottery there will no doubt be organized resistance at the polls.

At 1:30 o'clock this morning Gen. Sherman was resting quietly and no symptoms of cedema had made their appearance. Dr. Alexander, Miss Rachel E. Sherman, and Private Secretary Barrett, were in attendance at the bedside. Dr. Alexander in a bulletin announced that the outlook was hopeful. He was strengthened in the belief that if the General could maintain this condition during the next twenty-four hours there would be a good chance for his ultimate recovery.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Gen. Miles, when asked to-day whether he had anything to say in regard to Col. Forsyth's reinstatement, said: "I know nothing about the action taken at Washington. I do not care to make any statement in regard to it, nor do I care to review the case.

HARTFORD, Feb. 12. -- Nicholas Staub of New-Milford was declared elected Controller by the House this afternoon, but is still out of office through the unexpected stand taken by Gov. Bulkeley. On the first day of the session (Jan. 7) Staub, whose majority at the polls exceeded 1,600, was declared elected by the Senate, and on Jan. 13 was sworn in by that body.

Deputy Sheriff Tracy yesterday took possession of the New-York Smelting and Refining Company's works at 506 Water Street. On Nov. 12, 1888, the company made its note payable on demand for $47,400, and on Nov. 14, 1888, another note payable on demand for $32,000, which notes were indorsed by L. Lissberger Co., metal merchants of 46 Cliff Street.

Mr. BLUMENTHAL failed yesterday in his strenuous effort to get the Stadler "dance-house" bill through the Assembly. It received but sixty-three votes, only one of which was cast by a Republican. JOHN E. BRODSKY, whose Republicanism is of a very dubious sort, was naturally in favor of giving the dance houses of the Eighth District a chance to sell beer all night.

A more admirable hall for an art sale than the Assembly Rooms of the new Madison Square Garden would be hard to find. The decorations of the walls are artistic in themselves and pleasing, while the view from all parts of the house to the stage is open and unobstructed. Last night at the sale of the second installment of the George I. Seney collection, the rooms were crowded.

These are busy times for those officials of the elevated railroad whose duty it is to investigate causes of death of employes. Last year there were six people killed on the elevated, according to the company's official report, three of whom were passengers and three employes. Already, this year, four of the road's men have lost their lives, and the year has just fairly got under way.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- The Times (Ind.) tomorrow under the caption "A Man of Courage" will say:

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- The Senate wasted the day from 11 o'clock this morning to 9 o'clock tonight in filibustering on an amendment to the rules. It was one of those childish exhibitions for which the Senate has become renowned, and it exemplified the old adage that many men are but little removed from boys.

A curious story has just leaked out concerning what seems suspiciously like an attempt to bribe the Russian Minister of the Interior. The well-known Jewish banker Baron Ginzburg waited the other day upon the Minister in question, (writes the St. Petersburg correspondent of an English provincial press syndicate,) and, so runs the story, said to him, speaking in the name of the Jewish community:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 12. -The following letter is given out to-night:

The hearing in the contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather was resumed yesterday before Surrogate Ransom. The morning session was taken up with the examination of Miss Elizabeth R. Joyce, the niece of Mrs. Lucy Fayerweather, who was one of the witnesses to the last codicil, made on the day of Mr. Fayerweather's death.

No more fitting memorial to the late CHARLES L. BRACE could be devised than an endowment fund for the maintenance of the wise and fruitful and noble work to which he gave the best energies of his life for nearly forty years. This is the Form in which the Trustees of the Children's Aid Society have determined to lay before the public the memorial project.

The venerable Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, Vice President when Abraham Lincoln was President, and the only surviving representative of that Administration, was the honored guest at the banquet of the Republican Club of the City of New-York, held at Delmonico's last evening in honor of the eighty-second anniversary of Lincoln's birth.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Timothy M. Healy, member for North Longford, greeted the reappearance of Chief Secretary Balfour, "because," he said, "the Irish are anxious to know when any portion of the relief fund will be paid cash down."

There is more trouble in store for the Brooklyn baseball managers. George W. Chauncey, who was largely interested in the Players' League Club, but who is also President of the company from which that club leased its grounds at Eastern Park, applied to Justice Walsh yesterday for a warrant on which to dispossess the club for non-payment of rent.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Congressman Quackenbush attended the Republican Club banquet to-night, where it is believed the appointee to succeed the late Postmaster Ashley was decided upon. It is believed John Consalus or A.E. Bonestol will be named, although Mrs. Ashley may be named as a compromise.

St. Valentine's Night will be observed to-morrow at the Lenox Lyceum by the Directors of the Aguilar Free Library Society and their friends. At 8 o'clock there will be addresses by the Hon. Carl Schurz and Mr. Brander Matthews and at 8:30 the Valentine bazaar will be opened. A messenger service will be at the disposal of the guests for the prompt delivery of valentines.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Crowds of young men and women loitered around the besieged thread mill of the Clarks, on the Kearney side of the Passaic River to-day. They began to gather early in the morning. They belonged to the class of working people who are in the habit of getting up early. But they were not early enough to catch Walmesley, the hated Superintendent of the works, and his handful of imported spinners.

Five months ago District Superintendent J.J. Morrison of the Street-Cleaning Department preferred charges against V.F. Flanagan, a foreman, for neglect of duty. Flanagan was dismissed. He filed an affidavit with Commissioner Beattie charging that John J. Morrison received money from him under the threat that if it was not paid things would be made unpleasant for him.

The American Loan and Trust Company is assailed again. Its accounts are being overhauled by State Bank Examiners. Wall Street gossip, based on charges made by an ex-clerk of the institution, have led to this. But the investigation under way was asked for by the trust company itself. The officers insist that its affairs have been misrepresented and that the examination in progress will amply vindicate them.

A more successful picture sale than that of the collection of George I. Seney, which for the last three evenings has been going on in the Assembly Rooms of the Madison Square Garden, has not been had in this city for several years. The sale was closed in a blaze of glory, a crowd being present that occupied all the seats.

The Republican papers in the West that opposed any increase of duties before the McKinley bill was passed and that have since called for a repeal of the additional rates are beginning to see that the followers of MCKINLEY insist upon a new definition of protection and a protective tariff.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 13. -- The jury in the case of Henry Kimberly, Robert Snyder, C. M. Eggleston, and William Carr returned a verdict of guilty to-day as to all of the defendants, but recommending Snyder to the extreme mercy of the court. The accused were agents of the Granite State Provident Building and Loan Association, and were charged with conspiracy to defraud.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13. -- Regarding Mr. Cleveland's anti-free coinage letter the St. Louis Republic (Stalwart Dem.) will say editorially to-morrow: "This is, of course, merely the expression of his view as a single private citizen. Far from attempting to speak as a party leader or to control the party, Mr. Cleveland has waited until the attitude of the party became pronounced and unmistakable, and has then declared his private opinion.

Some time ago the Attorney General of Ohio brought suit against the Standard Oil Company of that State, a corporation which is a part of the Standard Oil Trust, alleging that it had forfeited its charter for reasons like those which the courts in this State declared to be sufficient in the similar proceeding of Attorney General TABOR against one of the corporations in the Sugar Trust.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13. -- Major Gen. Herbert, commander of the Canadian militia, has left here for the West on his first official tour of inspection. It is well understood in military circles that the General, who is an officer in the imperial army, will make a study of the whole question of the proposed imperial defenses on the Pacific coast in British Columbia.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 13. -- The rumor that George J. Gibson, Secretary of the Whiskey Trust, is in Cleveland, seems to be without foundation. If he has arrived here he has certainly not made his presence known to his relations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- Work at Jackson Park in preparation for the World's Fair came to a standstill this morning. All of the Italians employed by McArthur Brothers refused to go on digging trenches, and the contractors say they will not resume until police protection has been furnished. The suspension of the operations is due to the threatening attitude of American laborers, who swarm into the park and terrorize the Italians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Admiral David D. Potter died suddenly at 8:15 o'clock this morning at his residence, 1,714 H Street. Death resulted from fatty degeneration of the heart. The disease showed itself at Newport, R.I., last Summer, when, contrary to the persistent advice of his physician, he overtaxed his strength by taking violent exercise and was stricken down.

Some remarks by the Rev. H. Price Collier at the December meeting of the New-York Universalist Club put me on the line of the following calculations as to the wastefulness of church methods in my own city of Newark.
The highest in rank of our naval officers -- the only American sailor, indeed, except PARRAGUT, who was ever raised to the full grade of Admiral passes away in the death of DAVID DIXON PORTER.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Even those Democrats who are moss directly concerned in Gov. Hill's future unhesitatingly admit that in his treatment of Col. Watterson and of the Watterson letter he has made a grievous error.

Gov. Hill's featherweights in the Special Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Reapportionment resumed their amusing labors yesterday. Chief Featherweight Wright Holcomb was in charge and the funny little committee, with the aid of its lawyer, Franklin Bartlett, went amusingly along with the self-arrogated work, quite regardless of any right to exist.

The letter of Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER to one of his subordinates respecting the investigation of the census taken last June under Mr. PORTER'S supervision is calculated to do its author much harm. He instructed his subordinate in effect that he did not need to answer any questions about the method of taking the census, and that he must not answer any questions about his own official work.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 13. -- Beautiful weather, good attendance, and rather low prices marked the fifth day of the Brasfield sale. Seventy-five head changed hands for $33,840, an average of $451. John Donovan of St. Joseph, Mo., bought privately of John E. Madden of this city the bay horse Clark Street, five years, by Red Wilkes, dam Lapunta, by Jim Monroe, for $3,000. The following horses sold for $800 and over:

Central Office detectives yesterday arrested a family of Russian Poles named Prachumowsky. They were Morris Prachumowsky, aged forty-eight, his wife, Leah, and Samuel and Abraham, their sons, aged respectively twenty-four and fourteen. The parents have stolen and cheated all their lives, and the sons were early taught also to steal and cheat. The father has many of the characteristics of a Fagin. The mother is an expert pickpocket.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Senator Vedder has in contemplation a scheme that will necessitate the construction of a new Capitol. He will introduce a concurrent resolution next Tuesday, so he says, asking for the submission to the people of an amendment to the Constitution which shall call for an enumeration of the inhabitants of the State in 1895, under the supervision of the Legislature.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13. -- The Democrats of Missouri are greatly agitated over the letter written by Mr. Cleveland on the silver-coinage subject. The lower house of the State Legislature at Jefferson City spent over two hours discussing the subject this morning and the debate was at times very hot.

Miss Margaret Dupignac was taken from the Flatbush Insane Asylum yesterday to the City Court of Brooklyn on a writ of habeas corpus sued out by her brother, Dr. Edward A. Dupignac, a dentist living at 73 Fleet Place. Miss Dupignac was incarcerated in May, 1887, on petition of her sister, Mrs. Almyra Van Buskirk, who was appointed a committee of her estate.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 13. -- Immediately after the reading of the Governor's speech at the opening of the Legislature to-day, Colonial Secretary Bond proposed resolutions reciting certain statements regarding the reciprocity negotiations which will cause a stir in Canada, the United States, and England. The resolutions were discussed with closed doors.

The New-York City Association of ex-Union Prisoners of War held its monthly meeting last evening in Company D room, Seventy-first Regiment Armory, and did little outside of routine work but accept the invitation of the Union ex-Prisoners of War National Memorial Association to attend its entertainment at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday evening, March 5.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Michael Brennan, aged 22, of this city, was arrested to-day for a second attempt to kill Harvey C. Ellis, the head of the order department in the Singer Sewing Machine Works. Over a year ago Brennan, who was a clerk under Mr. Ellis, conceived the idea that his chief was opposed to his advancement, and brooded over it till his naturally weak mind gave way.

Yesterday was reception day among the animals belonging to Barnum Bailey's Greatest Show on Earth at their Winter headquarters in Bridgeport, Conn. According to a prearranged programme a party of New-York newspaper men and others interested in the way in which the captive beasts of various kinds manage to while away the long and barren hours of the Winter season, visited the place and was very hospitably entertained by Mr. Barnum's pets.

Mr. GILROY has done one excellent piece of work, for which he deserves public credit, in following out the suggestion made in these columns with reference to the disposition of vehicles left in the public streets. He has ordered them to be impounded in the yard owned by the city at the foot of East Twenty-fourth Street.
LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The News this morning says: "It is reported in Ministerial circles that the Bering Sea negotiations promise a favorable conclusion."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Since the death of John L. Dockworth, two weeks ago, a bitter struggle for the possession of his three orphan children has been in progress. Duckworth was a Protestant, but his wife was a Roman Catholic. After Mrs. Duckworth's death, two years ago, her sister, Mrs. James Keating of Elizabeth, tried to persuade the widower to let her have the children.

At 1:30 o'clock this morning Gen. Sherman's condition was such as to preclude hope of ultimate recovery, without raising apprehension of immediate death. The swelling of the face and neck had subsided and the erysipelas was under control. The danger is of another kind. With the subsidence of the enlarging symptoms of erysipelas came the development of lung trouble, complicated with a return of the long-standing asthma.

Capt. George G. Cochran of Company I, Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, is enthusiastic over what he considers a revolution in the mode of military signaling. Flags and lights have been used, but the Captain has already demonstrated that this work can be done by electricity he having introduced and adopted a code of flash lights.

All organic creations of nature that belong to the highest order take a long time to attain perfection. This period of development, until the attainment of maturity, takes up nearly one-third of the entire length of its existence. It is only an exception to this rule when a single subject passes through this period in shorter time. And what is true in the physical world is likewise true in the spiritual and moral.

Gen. Sherman's first appearance here in 1850 was when he was married in the house now occupied by Montgomery Blair, opposite the War Department, then occupied by his father-in-law, the Hon. Thomas Ewing, Secretary of the Interior. The General did not come to the city to reside until he was nominated by President Grant to succeed him as General of the army, in 1869.

RICHMOND, Mo., Feb. 14 -- The new "Church of Christ," which THE TIMES introduced to the world a short time ago, is gradually getting into shape for missionary labors. Viewed from a philosophic standpoint, it presents a new problem in the history of the Mormon Church which students of religious history will be interested in seeing worked out.

A part of WALTER DAMROSCH'S plan for the operations of his permanent orchestra next year is the presentation of scenes from operas with chorus, principals, and orchestra in the English language, with a view to the development of a company capable of giving grand operas in the tongue of the American people.

At a meeting of Boston merchants engaged in the glass trade one of them explained, two or three days ago, the plans of the new Glassware Trust as they had been described to him by the projectors of the combination while he was in Pittsburg. "The main purpose is to raise the price of staple table ware and control the output."

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 14. -- The Freshman Class will hold its class supper next Friday evening at the Eagle Hotel in Concord, N.H. The Sophomores will have a banquet the same evening in Claremont, N.H., at the Belmont. The toastmaster of the occasion is G.C. Smith.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 14. -- A series of bold and daring robberies has so alarmed the people of Rutherford within the past ten days that half the population lie awake every night in order to protect their personal property from the onslaught of the thieves.

One might fancy that "a system of psychology" or "a problem of evil" philosophically considered would present something easier to lay hold of than a "Philosophy of Fiction." Ordinary common standards for literary work there are requiring little explanation, because self-evident, but beyond these, even when they are presented by such an able essayist as is Mr. Thompson, all the other rules are apt to be eluding.

Two weeks ago a family of two persons -- husband and wife -- rented a small apartment up town and proceeded to furnish it. The carpets were supplied and laid, by a reputable house. Something about one of them was unsatisfactory, and a man was sent to investigate. The wife -- Mrs. L. -- was on her way out of the building to post a letter when she encountered him.

An interesting seance with the phonograph was held at the rooms of the Messrs. MacMahon, the Australian theatrical managers, at the Westminster Hotel the other evening. A number of professional and other people were present and were entertained by some unique and interesting records from cylinders in the possession of Mr. MacMahon.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 14. -- Prof. John Fiske of Cambridge, Mass., inspected the historical department library early in the week and was introduced to the students by Prof. Adams.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- The story is told here this evening that the Republican Senators will attempt next week to bring the filibustering Democrats to terms by adjourning the Senate whenever the Democrats resort to dilatory methods to prevent the passage of the Sloan resolution, which caused the dead-lock last Thursday.

The Census Office has recently announced the statistics of population for the city of Washington. Of the total population of 230,392 persons 75.927 are colored. In 1880 there were 118,006 whites and 55,596 colored; 1870,88,728 whites and 43,404 colored, and in 1860 60,763 whites and 14,316 colored. The white population in the last ten years has, the figures show, increased 30.80 per cent., whereas the colored population has increased only 27.40 per cent.
SWARTHMORE, Penn., Feb. 14. -- The midyear elections are about over and matters have settled back into their usual order. The officers of the several classes are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The news of the death of Gen. Sherman was early conveyed to the President. He was very much shocked at the intelligence, as he and Gen. Sherman had been near and dear friends for many years. The President served under Gen. Sherman in his famous march to the sea, and the friendship begun at that time has been strengthened by their close association ever since.

Considering the great difficulties under which the project of the World's Fair is laboring, there seems to be a particular reason why harmony should prevail in its own counsels. Perhaps, however, it is the difficulties that make the discord which the persons concerned cannot even keep to themselves.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- State Entomologist J.A. Lintner believes that the wanton destruction of our wild birds largely aids the excessive ravages of insect pests, which have rapidly increased each succeeding year of late, and it is essential that every bird which is of benefit to the agriculturist be protected. It is possible to declare definitely what particular birds are beneficial, what are of negative importance, and what are injurious.

The Manhattan Athletic Club sent out a notice yesterday of a resolution which its delegate, George W. Carr, was to introduce at a meeting of the Board of Managers of the Amateur Athletic Union at Boston last night. The meeting was postponed until to-day, when the resolution will probably be introduced. It is as follows:

To talk and theorize is one thing, but to act is quite another. The Manhattan Athletic Club may, as it says it did, have talked in favor of abandoning questionable practices in arranging boxing entertainments, hut the New-York Athletic Club has been the first of the two to take action in this direction. The New-York Athletic Club, therefore, deserves all praise for its present stand.

At the monthly meeting of the New-York Genealogical and Biographical Society, held in the Berkeley Lyceum Friday evening, Gen. James Grant Wilson in the chair, Dr. George Stewart, F.R.G.S., President of the Literary and Historical Society of Quebec, and editor of the chronicle of that city, read a most interesting paper on the first administration of Louis de Buade, Count Frontenac.

" Raconteur" of the Musical Courier desires to see a musicians' club formed in New-York. He hungers for a place where professionals and amateurs may assemble to talk about their art over their steins and grow wise like gods. The dream is very lovely. It has a roseate, Walhalla-in-the-golden-age tint about it, and one would naturally expect to enter such a club over a rainbow bridge of bright tone-colors.

There is something almost touching in the attitude of many of our Republican friends regarding the subject which they vaguely designate as "reciprocity." Heaven only knows what that term, ordinarily simple enough, connotes to their minds. To some of them, undoubtedly, of the Thurber variety, it means subsidies.

Eight months have now elapsed since Prof. Masson saw completed the first half of this important edition of De Quincey, and now the final volume, with an index to the whole fourteen, is before us. Criticisms of the plan after which he has chosen to arrange the matter have been many and free, especially in England.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- A consultation between President Greenhut of the Whisky Trust, Director Woolner of Peoria, Director McNulty, and other officials was held here to-day in regard to sensational developments in connection with the alleged dynamite conspiracy of Secretary Gibson. Mr. Greenhut announced at the outset that Gibson had resigned pending an investigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- To-day was appropriately celebrated by a St. Valentine's luncheon given by Mrs. N.S. Lincoln. The decorations were in pink and gold. On a pink silk square covered with church lace rested a large white swan filled with maidenhair fern, above which poised a big heart of pink carnations pierced with a golden arrow.

Gen. Sherman died yesterday afternoon at 1:50 o'clock. So gently and peacefully did the spirit of the great soldier depart that the sorrowing relatives at his bedside could scarcely realize at the time that death had completed its work. The dying man was surrounded by all of the members of his family except his eldest son, the Rev. T.E. Sherman, who is now on the Atlantic homeward bound.

The article in your issue of the 9th inst. under the head of "Polluted Water Supply" quotes many valuable statistics from a report of Mr. H.F. Mills, Chairman of the Committee on Water Supply of the Massachusetts State Board of Health. There is one omission which, if you will allow me, I would like to quote and make a few comments with respect to it, viz.:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The Rev. William M. Howie, for six years pastor of the United Presbyterian Church at Walton, N.Y., has tendered his resignation of the charge, to take effect April 1. As editor of the Walton Standard, an ardent Prohibition organ, Mr. Howie has played a conspicuous part in the politics of Delaware County.

Accident insurance men held a meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last Thursday to discuss the question of combining to advance rates, secure a uniform style of policy, and in other ways get their business into more comfortable shape.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 14. -- In many ways the recent sessions here of the New-England College Young Men's Christian Association has left its impression the college. Religious meetings are being held almost every evening under the leadership of S.M. Sayford, the college evangelist whose success due partly to the influence of the convention, but mainly to his own enthusiasm and ability.

The big Post Office building in this city was seriously threatened with destruction by fire last night. For an hour flames raged in the engine rooms on the Mail Street side and only the most arduous efforts of the Fire Department prevented them from spreading throughout the building.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The failure of a prominent wine merchant, whose name is withheld, was made public to-day. The liabilities will be about 5,000,000f, the loss falling mostly upon Spanish houses. The merchant in question failed several years ago, and was never discharged from the Bankruptcy Court. He, however, started in business again under his wife's name, and obtained an enormous credit.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Feb. 14. -- William Andrews was arrested here yesterday for stealing two books. Half an hour afterward he was on his way to the County Convict Camp. He is a first cousin of Gen. Lew Wallace, and was educated at Trinity College, Dublin. While at college he visited Gen. Wallace at Constantinople and spent two months with him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- There is a general out-cry on the part of society entertainers at the manner in which they are imposed upon by the adventurers and aspirants for social honors who annually come to the surface. The majority of the latter class are harmless enough, except in the pretension which induces them to leave cards, on which their address is wrongly given, in some fashionable locality.

ROME, Feb. 14. -- Upon the assembling of the Chamber of Deputies to-day, the Marquis di Rudini, the new Italian Premier, declared that the Cabinet would fight under the standard of economy, and that it proposed to equalize the budget by a reduction of all estimates, including the war and naval estimates.

The pictures in Mr. Aaron Healy's collection of modern paintings were sold at auction last night in Chickering Hall by Robert Somerville. There was a large attendance, the body of the hall being well filled, and enough bidders were present to make the contests lively for some of the choicest bits in the collection.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 14. -- The Lenten season has a marked effect at Yale, both on account of the lessened social celebration in the college and the comparative lack of society events around the city. The students naturally have an important place in New-Haven society, and when they are temporarily out off from that by this religious season the result is widely felt.

The astounding success of Mr. Seney in his sale of paintings will be sure to confirm him in the view he is said to take of his own usefulness as a collector and distributor of works of art. It launches him as an art dealer; for hereafter he will have to think, even more than he has hitherto, of the prospective value of what he buys, rather than the pleasure his purchases will give him.

I have read in your issue of Feb. 1 an article headed "Tyranny at the Sailors' Snug Harbor" and signed "American Shipmaster." Evidently "American Shipmaster" is well informed as to the management of the Harbor. I can corroborate all he says, and fully agree with him that a merchant sea Captain is not a proper man for the Governor of the Sailors' Snug Harbor.

HARTFORD, Feb. 14. -- Official instructions have been received at the Controller's office at the Capitol from the Republican occupant, John B. Wright of Clinton, to transfer the possession of the office, with the books, records, files, and the property of the State, to the Democratic Controller, Nicholas Staub of New-Milford, who was declared elected by the House Thursday afternoon.

I wish to enter a protest on behalf of the evening school teachers against an evil obtaining in the administration of the evening schools and practiced upon the victims of the system. The evening school teachers are a set of hard-worked and underpaid public servants. These men are required to mold the toughest material imaginable into intelligent youths or into men creditable to our civilization.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- Mr. Hutchinson's operations in the speculative markets on the Board of Trade are amazing everybody. There was a time shortly after the first of the year when he took very little part in the trade and avowedly did nothing save execute commission orders. The last four weeks he has been the prominent figure in all the pits.

The bill introduced by Senator James W. Birkett providing for two additional bridges to span the East River has aroused great interest among residents of Brooklyn. The magnitude of the thing took Brooklyn people by surprise. The provision for $24,000,000 capital has been more talked about in the cars and on the streets the last week than the water scandal.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Feb. 14. -- Parties from the southeast portion of Montague County to-day report considerable excitement over a gold and silver find. The vein is six feet wide, and assays $400 to the ton. Coal is found under the ledge of silver, the vein being thirty-seven inches thick, underlaid with nickel and gold and magnetic iron ore.

It is a hopeful sign that New-Hampshire seems to be recognizing the commercial value of her mountain forests, and the movement in favor of establishing a permanent Forestry Commission, with a view to the preservation of the natural beauties of Crawford, Dixville, Franconia, and other mountain notches, is one which ought to succeed.

In conversation the other day with the clerk who has charge of the wheels and axles used by one of our Western railroads, the writer learned a great deal about them and found the subjects an interesting one. Persons who never have any business with a railroad except to ride on its cars occasionally have an idea that paper car wheels are entirely made of that substance.

I was glad to see in THE TIMES of Sunday an account of the result of the "boy and dog" experiment. It was well to publish the facts, although, of course, everybody knew what the result would be. The whole performance was a piece of shallow empiricism and brutal stupidity. The Medical Record attempted to conceal its true character by calling it a "therapeutic" experiment.

BRUNSWICK, Feb. 14. -- Whether Bowdoin will race with the Boston Athletic Association this Spring is as yet undecided. The Boston Athletic Association crew will be considerably stronger than last year, but her defeat on the Charles River last Spring has made the association somewhat adverse to another race with Bowdoin. However, negotiations are being carried on and Commodore Cilley hopes to make satisfactory arrangements for a race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- There is a vast deal of difference between the feeling of the friends of the Copyright bill to-night and what they were twenty-four hours ago. Last night the prospect of securing an international copyright law was practically hopeless. Now the outlook is extremely encouraging. Indeed, those who gave up all hope yesterday are to-night full of confidence that the bill will go to the President next week.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 14. -- The fight between the high-tariff manufacturers and labor in this State has been very interesting this week. Here in Trenton the pottery situation has undergone another change. The looked-out laborers issued a reply to the public statement published by the sanitary ware manufacturers last week.

I am but a common man, with next to no book learnin' -- certainly nothin' like as much as is wantin' to make anything proper to put in print. Nevertheless, I'm goin' to do my best to tell a story of summat that happened to me, and which beyond all doubt was more than a little bit out of the common run of things.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14. -- The following telegram was forwarded this evening:

MONTREAL, Feb. 14. -- The city of Montreal has paid off the Barings and arranged a loan with the National Bank of Scotland at 3 1/2 per cent., and has sold exchange to the amount of $1,000,000 to the Bank of Montreal.
PARIS, Feb. 14. -- The Duo de Chartres, upon hearing of the dangerous illness of Gen. Sherman, expressed deep-felt grief over the news, saying:

Beautiful oil paintings of the three former Judges were presented to the United States Court yesterday. They were the pictures of Thomas Hopkinson, his son, Francis Hopkinson, and his grandson, Joseph Hopkinson, and were presented by the Hopkinson family. Thomas Hopkinson was the Judge of the Court of Admiralty of Pennsylvania, and was appointed in 1741.

The bill introduced into the Senate for the establishment of a Department of Commerce, to be presided, over by a Cabinet officer, is liable to a general objection founded on the creation of new departments and the enlargement of the Cabinet. All that is really essential could probably be attained by the organization of a Marine Board in the Treasury Department, which was the moderate form first taken by the movement.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 14. -- The Rev. Dr. J.V. Garton of the Baptist church in Meriden will complete his pastoral work in that city March 1 and will remove to Cambridge, Mass., where he has accepted an important pastorate.

There was a pleasant gathering In the ue quarters of Blelnan, Heidelberg Co.. Broadway and Bleecker Street, yesterday afternoon. The removal of the firm of specialty elothin manufacturers was celebrate(! by an invitation dinner, at which the 100 cutters and about 50 women and girls employed by the firm, wet the guests.

The Trustees of the Wllliamson Free School of the M Mechanical Trades met at the office in the Forrest Building to-day and adopted rules governing the admission of applicants for scholarships. According to the rules, preference is given, where other things are equal, to applicants as follows: 1. Those born in Philadelphia. 2. In Bucks County. 3. In Montgomery and Delaware. 4. Elsewhere In Pennsylvania. 5. In New-Jersey. 6. Elsewhere in the United States.

The bill which Mr. STADLER succeeded in hurrying through the State Senate near the beginning of the session by falsely representing that it was substantially the same as that introduced last year, and only intended to give the German musical societies and other reputable organizations the opportunity of continuing the sale of wine at their balls after 1 o'clock, is by no means dead.

It is an interesting coincidence that the two great Union soldiers who first successively rose to the full rank of General were born in the same State of Ohio, and that there also Sheridan, the third and only other Union soldier who reached that exalted grade, passed all his boyhood from infancy, his home being only a few miles distant from the birthplace of Sherman.

[Every effort ma de to down Cleveland in his own party simply results in making him more prominent. Unless the West shall produce free-silver champion it does not now appear that anythin can provelat Cleveland's being the nominee of his party in 1892.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 14. -- Gov. Pattison has sent this message to P.F. Sherman: "I desire to express the sincere sympathy of the people of Pennsylvania for the family of Gen. Sherman, of whose death I have just been advised. His patriotic, faithful, and invaluable services to his country will ever be gratefully remembered."

The Legislatures of Illinois and South Dakota have gone over to another week without succeeding in the prolonged effort to elect United States Senators, and there are rumors of a "combine" of a kind hitherto unheard of in our variegated politics. It is well known that in Illinois three Farmers' Mutual Benefit Association members hold the balance of power between the Democrats and Republicans.

LAKEWOOD, Feb. 14. -- Ex-President Cleveland returned to New-York Monday morning. Mrs. Cleveland following him Tuesday afternoon. On Monday evening Col. Clement, with the assistance of Prof. Latham, gave to Mrs. Cleveland a very pleasant surprise. A series of illustrated lectures has been a feature of the Lakewood since its opening.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 14. -- Representatives of Yale and Harvard met at the Crocker House in New-London this afternoon, and for two hours discussed the conditions under which the race between the crews of the two universities will be rowed on the Thames River next June if it is decided to row there this year. President Lawrence Brooks.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 14. -- The Brasfield sale of trotters closed here to-day with the sale of seventy-one horses for $12,195; average, $171. During the six days 427 horses changed hands for $227,640, with the remarkable average of $533.

Importers of leather have been very much annoyed of late by the ruling of the appraisers that skins which may be received from abroad having hair upon them must pay a duty on account of the hair. The special application of this ruling to goatskins is the particular grievance against which complaints are leveled. It was supposed when the new Tariff bill was passed that raw hides would be admitted free without question.

The ten-year-old son of Mrs. Rouse, a widow at Leavenworth, Kan., shot and killed his brother, aged nineteen, at their house yesterday. The younger son was playfully snapping a revolver in which, unknown to him there was a solitary cartridge. There was an explosion, and the elder boy, who was reading a book, fell from his chair to the floor with a bullet hole over his right eye. His death was instantaneous.

A unique entertainment, christened a "St. Valentine's Night," was given at the Lenox Lyceum last evening for the benefit of the Aguilar Free Library. The affair was social in character and was a great success. Over one thousand persons were present. A goodly fund was realized for the library by the sale of tickets and by a few little devices introduced by the ladies having the arrangements in charge.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 14. -- Ex-President Cleveland's letter on the silver question continues a leading topic of conversation among the senators and Representatives of the Assembly. The Assembly is almost a unit for free and unrestricted coinage, and for that reason there is much dissatisfaction and regret among the Democratic members that the ex-President should come out so squarely for the Eastern view on the silver question.

Grover Cleveland seems to be an unfeeling sort of a man. Every once in a while he has a habit of sending a cold chill down the spines of his party's practical politicians. His latest essay in this direction has to do with free silver coinage. Somehow or other he declines to look upon the sliver question as a matter to be determined merely by the gauge and rule of petty political caucuses.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 14. -- The American Casualty Insurance and Security Company of Baltimore, of which William E. Midgely of New-York is President and which is largely owned by New-York men, has filed a protest with Insurance Commissioner Talbot against the issuing of a license to the Fidelity and Casualty of New-York.

LITTLE FALLS, Feb. 14 -- Since the publication of dispatch from this village a week ago in THE TIMES announcing a reduction in the wages of employes of the Saxony Mill, several contradictions have been printed in Republican organs. Fuller investigation, however, confirms the entire truth of the statements first published.

The events chronicled in these volumes would generally be accepted as very ancient history. Of that OEcumenical Council which, in the years 1869 and 1870, aroused the close attention of millions of Christians speaking many tongues, scarcely more is now thought than of those eighteen other great councils held at lung intervals since the Church of Rome began to make its history.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 14. -- Rigid simplicity is the rule of life at the White House. Republicans declare with pride to Democrats that it is even simpler simplicity than was the simplicity of Jefferson. Democrats analyze the claim. Courteously they respond that Jefferson's simplicity was stern and austere; that Harrison's is artless and obtains not in official but only in domestic life.

Upon the side of the Union, the last "hero of he civil war" is gone. There are hundreds of men left who have done "gallant and meritorious service," not merely in the ranks, but in command of regiments and brigades and divisions and army corps. There are a few who have led armies and held independent commands.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 14. -- The Chamber of Commerce was in session when the announcement of Gen. Sherman's death was received. On motion of Mr. Theodore Cook, the President was authorized to appoint a committee of fifteen to prepare a suitable memorial to be spread on the records of the Chamber.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Baltimore says: President Charles F. Mayer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad returned from his Western trip this afternoon. To all newspaper men who assembled at the Central Building to question him on recent rumors he sent this response: "I have not seen the reports of any option on Baltimore and Ohio having been secured by certain parties, but I have heard of these reports.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 14. -- The Commercial Union Club of Toronto has issued an address to the people of Canada. The address is signed by Prof. Goldwin Smith and Mr. G. Mercer Adam. It deals with the platform adopted by both political parties and says that unrestricted reciprocity is its first choice. It points out that two bugbears are employed in support of trade restriction.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- London papers print to-day the details of Parnell's perfidy, which were published in these dispatches a week ago. It was not until Wednesday that even the rank and file of the English members of Parliament learned what New-York knew last Sunday, that the so-called negotiations were completely broken down.

If any one wishes to have a clear notion as to what the Republican politicians hoped from Mr. CLEVELAND on the unlimited free coinage of silver lot him read the following remarks by that most ingenuous of organs the Philadelphia Press. The first was published on Wednesday last, the morning of the day on which the Reform Club meeting was held and Mr. CLEVELAND'S letter was read:

A short time ago Prof. Billroth, in one of his public lectures, held out the hope that a cure for cancer might be found. Prof. von Mosetig, another medical celebrity, lecturing at the Vienna Physicians' Association, has just stated positively that medical science is already on the high road to that all-important discovery. The professor himself has been working at it for the last ten years.

A streamer of crape fluttered yesterday from the entrance of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman's late residence, 75 West Seventy-first Street, mutely telling of a family's irreparable loss and a nation's great bereavement. Black-bordered flags floated from the windows of the houses on both sides of the street. From early morning until late at night thousands passed the dead General's dwelling and looked with sorrow at the drawn blinds and the crape on the door.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The London newspapers this morning all contain long obituary articles eulogistic of Gen. Sherman.

When the three political shepherds of Ohio so arranged the wool schedule of the new tariff that a duty of 300 per cent. must be imposed, to the great surprise of manufacturers of carpets, on common goat hair, which had been imported free of duty, they well knew that this would not be the end of the job.

Yesterday in the Lord Mayor's Court the case of Marks vs. Flower came on for trial before the Recorder, Sir T. Chambers, Q.C., and a special jury. The plaintiff, Mr. Thomas Marks, sued the defendant, who carries on business as a colonial broker at 40 Mincing Lane under the style of Thomas Cook Co., to recover 1,920 alleged to be due for arrears of salary, and for damages for alleged misrepresentation.

A caucus of the Republican members of the House of Representatives will be held this evening. The announced purpose is to discuss and determine the policy of the party with regard to the measures now pending in the House and remaining unacted on. But there is only one measure of importance sufficient to require a caucus -- the Free-Coinage bill.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15. -- President Eliot of Harvard University will arrive here on Saturday morning, March 7, and remain until Wednesday, the 11th. This will be the first visit the chief executive of the oldest and largest American University has made here, and the occasion will be a notable one, both in educational and social circles.

HONOLULU, Hawaii, Feb. 15, via steamer to San Francisco. -- Workmen were busily engaged in preparation for welcoming King Kalakaua, who was expected to return from the United States improved in health, when the Charleston was sighted early Tuesday morning, Jan. 29. Decorations and arches of welcome have been torn down or turned into emblems of mourning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Unusual interest will be manifested on the production, in the House, of the impeachment resolutions about to be made by the Judiciary Committee against Judge Boarman of Louisiana. The sub-committee that made the recommendation was thoroughly convinced of the necessity for proceeding to the extremity of impeachment in this case, as the facts set forth were flagrant and notorious.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- If the Penal Code is not amended this Winter it will not be through lack of effort on the part of a dozen or more legislators. Already quite a large grist of bills designed to affect the code have been introduced, and the number will probably equal that of any previous year before the session closes.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- That amateur athletic sports are becoming exceedingly popular in this city was made clear last night at the annual indoor games given by the Boston Athletic Association, aided by the First Regiment Athletic Association, in the latter's armory. The seating capacity of the armory was entirely taken up, among the enthusiastic spectators being Gov. Russell and staff and many of Boston's "400."

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 15. -- The Times to-morrow will say that President Nettleton of the Kansas City, Fort Scott and Memphis Railway has, within the past few days, determined to carry out plans which have been under consideration by him for some time past.

Another curious side light on the English theory of divorce was thrown by the case heard before Mr. Justice Jeune yesterday. A young man and young woman -- a boy and girl, rather -- agreed by their own account to go through a sham marriage. The bans were put up and the ceremony gone through under a pseudonym, with the additional circumstance that the rites were Protestant rites and the bridegroom a Catholic.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- The Jewish Alliance of America, with its object the alleviation of the existing distress among the Hebrews, especially those now suffering under the ban of the Czar of Russia, by the formation and maintenance of Jewish farm colonies in the West, was organized to-day.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- The patrol of Jersey City police established yesterday afternoon in front of the Clark Thread Mills was kept up to-day. Passaic Avenue between the railroad bridge and the Clay Street bridge was guarded at either and by platoons of police and deputies. Senator McDonald was on hand at intervals to see that everything was all right.

The estimate of $2,000,000 as the cost of the recent Pine Ridge campaign, which has been derived from figures recently laid before Congress, is made somewhat prematurely. The outlay of about $1,300,000 by the Quartermaster's department refers to military expenses proper, and chiefly those of transportation for the many troops concentrated in Dakota and for the supplies of clothing, rations, horses, and so on.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 15. -- In reply to a telegram sent by Gov. Campbell to Gen. Thomas Ewing, to the effect that Ohio claimed the remains of Gen. Sherman, the following has been received by the Governor:

A meeting of the associate Commanders and Quartermasters of the posts of the Grand Army of the Republic of this city was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of Hans Powell Post, No. 638, in the Essex Market Building, for the purpose of taking action in regard to the proposed amendment to the bill passed in 1888 by the Legislature, concerning State appropriations for the families of needy veterans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A large number of prominent people called at the Porter mansion to-day to offer their condolences to the bereaved family. They included the President and Mrs. McKee, who remained at the house some time; Vice President Morton, and several members of the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The President has transmitted to Congress the report of Carroll D. Wright, the Commissioner of Labor, on the cost of production of steel and steel rails. The report is the result of several years' careful investigation in this country and Europe, based upon an examination of the books of leading manufacturers by expert agents.

A great many persons have had their attention attracted recently, in passing the brick building in course of construction at 152, 154, and 156 Wooster Street, to the apparently dangerous condition of the wall at the northern side of the structure, which abuts on the lot at 158, owned by William W. Horton, a lumber dealer.

The act transferring from the limited disability list to the unlimited age list of the army all retired officers of the former who have reached or may reach the age of sixty-four years is the most important measure for increasing the flow of promotions which has been enacted by Congress during many years.

The police have been asked to look for Frank Waite, a clerk twenty-six years old, who on Thursday disappeared from Perth Amboy. He is described as 5 feet 10 inches in height, medium build, dark complexion, black hair and eyes, black mustache, and wore a dark-blue overcoat, an undercoat of dark mixed stuff, dark trousers with a stripe, and a brown derby hat.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15. -- Democratic politicians are considerably agitated over the problem of redistricting the State in accordance with the new apportionment which gives the State an additional Congressman. It was at first proposed to allow the districts to remain as they are and elect the new member at large. This plan has been abandoned, as it would deprive the State of an additional vote in the Electoral College.

The letter of ex-President Grover Cleveland, completing his excellent record on the silver question, is a brave, timely, and important contribution to the debate on the subject. It is in line with his letter of 1885, before his inauguration as President, in opposition to the silver measures of that time, and it shows the earnestness and honesty of his convictions on the most important financial question before the country.

There is hope, strong hope, almost a feeling of confidence, that the International Copyright bill will pass the Senate unchanged and go to the President. The Senate's action on Saturday effected this change in the prospects of the bill, and that action was as unusual as it was gratifying. Senator PLATT is a zealous friend of international copyright, and an experienced parliamentarian.

HARTFORD, Feb. 15. -- Controller Staub arrived here last night from his home in New-Milford and has been in consultation this afternoon with his attorney, the Hon. William Hamersley, concerning the course to be adopted in obtaining possession of the Controller's office to-morrow morning under the instructions received yesterday from the retiring Republican Controller, John B. Wright, of Clinton.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 15. -- Sir John Macdonald, the Tory Premier, is fighting his last political battle with the desperate energy of despair. As a last resort his supporters from sea to sea have raised the loyalty cry, and throughout the land the air is filled with doleful predictions of the fate which awaits the Dominion should the Liberals gain the victory.

The daily Lenten services this year in the Episcopal churches of the city are more largely attended than those of last year. The reason for this is that the rectors of the larger churches have made the services unusually interesting.

TRENTON, Feb. 15. -- This week will probably see a new series of movements in the political game in the Legislature. Little has been said lately about the scheme for the reorganization of the Senate by the division of some counties and the consolidation of others, but it has been brought to the front afresh by a bill which some one introduced last week for Speaker Bergen.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 15. -- In an interview in a Sunday paper here to-day Mr. Watterson is quoted as saying regarding the Hill matter:

A turbulent crowd, made up of the parishioners and ex-parishioners of Father Yodyzsius, the Lithuanian priest, assembled yesterday afternoon in Palace Hall, on Grand Street, Williamsburg. The meeting was called by the faction of Yodyzsius's congregation who are shocked at the recent revelations in regard to the priest's character, and who wish to oust him from the church he owns, but which they claim he swindled them out of.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- From Rouff comes the fashionable light this week, and his hints and novelties show that tact and discretion which have made the repute and elegance of his dictates. Rouff says that skirts will continue to be long and plain and the basques even longer; that their materials and softer Spring and Summer goods may show more caprice in draping.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- There never has been, either in the army or the navy, any fixed and uniform code of punishments but with the exception of a few offenses, the penalty for which is fixed by law, the degree of punishment has been left entirely to the discretion of the court-martial trying the case, subject to revision by the reviewing authority.
BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- Gov. Russell has written the following letter to ex-President Cleveland:

The Cleveland Leader (Rep.) says that if it were not for the humiliation of the thing the meeting of the next House could be anticipated with as much pleasure as a circus. It is certainly a big "if" which stands between the Leader and the power serenely to contemplate the prospective surrender of the House to the party of the people.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15. -- Hundreds of people visited Calvary Cemetery to-day to see the grave of Mrs. Sherman and the place for the interment of the General. Private vehicles, hired rigs, and street ear service were used by the crowds visiting the cemetery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Mr. Quay has at last made his long-expected reply to the criticisms which have been so freely made upon his record, but he seems to have given up the decision to resign his seat and rely upon his Legislature to "vindicate" him by promptly sending him back.

The Brooklyn police think they have, in Thomas Marshall, the man who has committed the petty burglaries in Bayonne, N.J. They captured him late Saturday night while he was leaving Edward Karcher's house at 157 Graham Street, Brooklyn. His pockets were full of jewelry and trinkets of various kinds, but of little value, most of which were identified by Karcher, and a fine set of burglar's tools was also found.

In the text of Moreau and Sardou's drama of "Cleopatre" the Queen of Egypt is often called a sorceress, and in one scene she actually pretends to be a magician and confounds Demetrius and other Romans by pretending that a windstorm, the coming of which she had foreseen while the skies were still blue and cloudless, works devastation at her bidding.
The following question from an inquiring correspondent and the accompanying answer were published on the 9th inst. in the Cleveland Leader, a journal which directly represents Mr. MCKINLEY:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Senator McConnell of Idaho, whose term will expire next month, after less than three months' service, does not propose to retire without letting the Senate and the country know something of what he thinks should be done with the Pacific Railroad. A month ago he introduced a bill containing his ideas on the subject, and to-day he elaborated those ideas in a speech which his colleagues found both interesting and entertaining.

Insurance and shipping men have been examining with care the revised edition of the Subsidy Shipping bill as it now awaits the action of the lower branch of Congress to discover the purpose of the House Committee on Commerce in substituting for the bill which passed the Senate a bill with an entirely new phraseology.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- The Manufacturers' Club of this city had for its special guest this evening Erastus Wiman. Mr. Wiman spoke of the impending struggle for reciprocal freedom in Canada, and said, among other things:
PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 16. -- James H. Kyle was chosen United States Senator on the fortieth ballot to-day, the vote standing: Kyle, 75; Sterling, 55; Tripp, 8; Campbell, 1, with 30 paired.

The resolutions of the Farmers and Laborers' Union of the First Congressional District of Missouri, which were presented to the Senate yesterday, constitute, we believe, the first direct notification to Congress of the demands of the Farmers' Alliance. There is nothing at all bashful about these demands.

The information that Gov. Hill would to-day send the name of Dr. Seneca D. Powell to the Senate for confirmation as Health Officer of this port, to succeed Health Officer Smith, was furnished last night by a man who is usually well posted on important political moves.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- A semi-official resume of Gen. Butler's forthcoming autobiography was printed here to-day. The book will contain thirty chapters, and the General's career as a struggling scholar earning the money to pay for his tuition by seating chairs; as a lawyer, as a soldier, and as a statesman, and his campaign for the Governorship, will all be related.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Another American-made armor plate was tested at the Annapolis Naval Ordnance proving ground Saturday, with results that may be very far-reaching in the development of armor.

We see no indication that the country has been much impressed by the first shallow criticisms of Mr. CLEVELAND'S letter upon silver coinage. It would have been surprising if these hasty opinions had made an impression, for they came for the most part from men who are unaccustomed and unauthorized to do the country's thinking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- "Do nothing." That was the advice given this afternoon to the Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures by Mr. Henry Hentz, speaking for the Reform Club of New-York. His speech was the last of a series of protests against the passage of a Free-Coinage bill made by representative business men of the metropolis.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- A fifteen-minute squall enlivened the proceedings in the Senate this evening, and for a while affairs looked threatening. The Democratic Senators labored in a heavy seaway, while the Republicans were laying to in tranquil waters calmly observing the plight of their opponents.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- From the time of the arrest of Sadler, charged with the murder of "Carroty Nell," great excitement has prevailed in and about Whitechapel. The Stepney police station, in Arbour Square, where the prisoner was detained, was surrounded by a crowd of people, mostly women, eager for a sight of the prisoner. Threats of lynching and tearing the prisoner to pieces were uttered by the most excited of these women.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A decided sensation has been caused in this city to-day by a daring robbery, committed in broad daylight, at the National Provincial Bank of England, 112 Bishopgate Within.

TRENTON, Feb. 16. -- The race men were down in full feather to-night, when the Legislature resumed its session for the week. There was evidently something in the wind, but they would not tell what it was. The Winter track men were especially active. They are trying to save themselves, it is said, from the attack which the proprietors of the bigger race courses contemplate making upon them.
ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Gov. Hill sent to both branches of the Legislature this evening the following official announcement of the death of Gen. Sherman:

The Chicago Herald Building is expected to add another to the great monuments to the progress of American journalism which ornament nearly every large city in the country. Upon the walls of the business office alone $30,000 will be expended in illustrating in oil the origin, rise, and success of the newspaper press.

Silver fell yesterday a trifle below a dollar an ounce, touching the lowest point it has reached since last July, except for a little while during the semi-panic in November. The dealers are inclined to explain this occurrence by the general belief that there will be no silver legislation this session.

Some of our high-tariff contemporaries are greatly annoyed when attention is directed to admissions they have made in unguarded moments. A few days ago we quoted passages from an article in the Chicago Inter Ocean relating to the so-called Cartridge Trust, in which it was asserted that the combined manufacturers of cartridges sold their goods in foreign countries at prices 25 per cent. lower than the prices exacted from buyers at home.

In the legal fight between Pauline Hall and her former managers, Marcus R. Mayer and Benjamin Sterne. Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday gave a decision against Miss Hall. She applied for an injunction to restrain Messrs. Mayer and Sterne from beginning any suits on account of the contract with them which she broke except in this State.

HARTFORD, Feb. 16. -- The Controller's office was surrendered this afternoon to its rightful occupant by Chief Clerk Moore under instructions from ex-Controller Wright of Clinton. The Governor addressed an official communication to the Chief Clerk prior to the transfer of the office to Controller Staub, in which he said:

UTICA, Feb. 16. -- The third, final, and overwhelmingly decisive victory won by The friends of State care for the insane in the Assembly last Thursday unquestionably settles the question in its present shape for practically what may be said all time to come, for public sentiment is now aroused to that degree that it will never tolerate a return to the methods formerly in vogue.

Yesterday the brave General who marched to the sea slept in dreamless peace in the shrouded chamber of his home. To-day his body will be clothed again and for the last time in the full uniform of the exalted rank of a General, and on Thursday, surrounded by the bereaved family and his old comrades, his body will be transported to its final resting place in St. Louis.

The route of the New-York Central's new line to the Thousand Islands has been definitely determined and the work of construction will begin in two or three weeks. The engineers have completed the laying out of the line, which will be built and operated by a recently-formed corporation bearing the title of the Mohawk and St. Lawrence Railroad Company.

The Rapid-Transit Commission at its stated session yesterday ordered that on Friday next, at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, a public meeting should be held at 22 William Street, at which schemes, plans, and suggestions having for their object the furnishing of quick and reliable communication between points in New-York should be received and considered.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. John Morley moved that the House adopt a vote censuring the Irish executive for its action in the Tipperary prosecutions. Mr. Morley's motion declared that such action on the part of the Irish executive was calculated to bring the law into contempt, and was a violation of the rights of citizens.

BISMARCK, N.D., Feb. 16. -- A remarkable occurrence was witnessed in the Senate this afternoon. The Missouri slope members, who are all resubmissionists, formed a combination with the Prohibitionists. By the terms of their compact Bismarck was to retain the capital and the action resubmitting the liquor question was to be reconsidered.

The Brooklyn Union League Club, which is desirous of being recognized as a strictly Republican organization, is to hold a special meeting on Thursday night to take steps toward supporting Assemblyman Aspinall in his effort to retain his seat in the Legislature. A committee from the Assembly is to meet in Brooklyn in a few days and inquire into the circumstances surrounding Aspinall's election and to investigate Reinhard's claim to the seat.

SEATTLE, Washington, Feb. 16. -- A New-Westminster special to the Post-Intelligencer says: "This city was yesterday visited by a conflagration which destroyed in the neighborhood of $500,000 worth of property and caused the death of John McCannon, a member of the Volunteer Fire Brigade. The fire started in the premises occupied by F. Stiersky, watchmaker and jeweler, on Columbia Street.

TORONTO, Feb. 17. -- Sir John Macdonald spoke to a large audience to-night in the Academy of Music. There was a good deal of bluster in his speech. He threatened that if the United States dared to lay a finger on Canada she would have to answer for it to Great Britain.

HAVANA, Feb. 17. -- THE TIMES'S correspondent has been waiting for the excitement occasioned by the killing of the five bandits, who came to Havana with the intention of leaving the island by the Spanish steamer Baldomero Yglesias on the 6th inst., to subside in order to give a true account of the affair.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- McKinley's tariff law is on trial in the United States Circuit Court before Judge Blodgett. The validity of the measure is called in question in the appeal of Marshall Field Co. from the decision of the Board of Appraisers at New-York.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 17. -- In the House this morning resolutions of regret at the death of Gen. Sherman were unanimously adopted.

The ladies and gentlemen of the Nineteenth Century Club comfortably filled the Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House last night and listened to discussion of the topic, "Modern Finance: Its Evolution and Its Vagaries." Mr. Simon Sterne road a thoughtful paper on that subject and deftly and forcefully punctured a good many bubbles.

There is open war between Mayor Gleason and the School Trustees of the Fourth Ward of Long Island City. The Gleason Board of Education recently ordered that more seats be placed in the main school building in the ward. The Trustees say the school is overcrowded now, and Chairman Whitcomb told Janitor Hayes, it is alleged, to stop any one who attempted to enter the building.

WHEELING, West Va., Feb. 17. -- The river at 7 P.M. was 34 feet 2 inches, having risen 712 inches during the past hour. It looks as if 42 feet would be the extreme limit of the flood, although the streets are filled with excited rumors of 45 feet and more.

Protracted but harmonious meetings of the Directors and stockholders of the American Loan and Trust Company were held yesterday afternoon and evening, first at the office of Russell Sage and then up town, at which a reorganization of the company was decided upon. The reorganization will, of course, be acompanied by a change in the management, President P.D, Baldwin and his associates having tendered their resignations.

By the new tariff the duties on glassware wore largely increased. The duty on common pressed ware, of flint or lime glass, was raised from 40 to 60 per cent. in the McKinley act, and the requirements of the Administrative act add about 10 per cent. more. The old duty of 40 per cent. was so high that the value of "plain molded or pressed flint or lime glassware" imported in 1889 was only $68,285.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The Copyright bill is having a hard time in its passage through the Senate. Its course has been one of ups and downs, and its ultimate fate in this Congress is still uncertain. The action of the Senate last week in rejecting all the amendments which had been put into the bill led to the hope that the measure would pass without change as it came from the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Whatever the legislative outcome may be of the agitation of free coinage, there can be no doubt that the protest against it made by the representatives of the New-York Reform Club must have a restraining effect.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 17. -- Mr. Erastus Wiman has declined the Liberal nomination to represent the county of Algoma in the Dominion Parliament.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17. -- If there has ever been any doubt about the body of Gen. Sherman being laid to rest beside that of his wife in Calvary Cemetery, the Roman Catholic cemetery of this city, it no longer has any reason for existence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- With martial honors and with all the ceremony due to his high rank and distinguished services, the body of David D. Porter, Admiral of the navy, who died at his residence in this city last Friday, was this afternoon laid to rest in historic Arlington. Not since the burial of Sheridan has Washington witnessed so imposing a funeral.
