ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The calendar that the Court of Appeals proper directed the Clerk to prepare for it has been finished and is now in the hands of the printer. It contains 189 causes, 166 of which are appeals from judgments and 23 from orders. Of the cases about 60 were carried over from the unfinished part of the previous calendar that the court, or "old court" as it is termed, assumed.

A dispatch from Milwaukee, published in the Chicago Tribune of the 15th inst., reports the sale of certain iron mines in Northern Michigan to the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Company by FERDINAND SCHLESINGER, acting as the representative of a syndicate. The dispatch says:

Members of Dr. Watson L. Savage's gymnasium at 308 West Fifty-ninth Street gave their first gymnastic entertainment last evening. The spacious gymnasium was well filled. About fifty well-built young men participated in the exercises, and inasmuch as the majority of them began work only about two months ago, their ability to handle themselves well in the various movements and feats spoke well for the system taught them.

Thousands of people yesterday were afforded an opportunity to gaze upon the face of the dead hero of the march to the sea. Contrary to all expectation, the Seventy-first Street residence was thrown open, and whoever desired to do so was permitted to pass by the bier of the great General

CINCINNATI, Feb. 17. -- It was after 7 o'clock to-night when the steamer Sherlock of the Cincinnati and New-Orleans line, under command of Capt. McIntyre, backed out from her wharf and started down the river on her last trip. She had aboard from thirty to thirty-five passengers and a crew of fifty to sixty men.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 17. -- The sale of trotters by W.T. Woodward was largely attended to-day and the prices ruled higher than yesterday. Sixty-one head brought $35,605, an average of $585. The following horses brought $800 or over:

In the course of an article in regard to the forthcoming reorganization of the Amateur Athletic Union, in your issue of to-day, it is stated that "there is strong feeling in the East that there is only one man for President and that that man is A.G. Mills of the New York Athletic Club." Furthermore, it is intimated that "many prominent men" propose to elect certain gentlemen (including myself) to certain positions.

A writ of habeas corpus was issued yesterday by Judge Brady in the Court of Oyer and Ter miner in the case of Charles Webster, the actor, whose conviction of manslaughter for killing Robert McNeil was last week set aside by the General Term of the Supreme Court Webster's release on ball will be asked for.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- After midnight last night the Common Council passed a resolution which has a direct bearing on the war being waged between the local Directory of the World's Fair and Director General Davis.

The argument of Mr. A.J. WARNER, ex-member of the House from Ohio, on the silver question yesterday was far more intelligent and less absurd than most of those in favor of free coinage. It was also, we believe, the argument of a perfectly sincere man, with no personal interest in this scheme.

The maintenance and improvement of the canals of this State is a matter of much importance, but the recklessness with which appropriations are proposed under the guise of benefiting the canals is calculated to injure the cause of legitimate improvement. Bills are now pending in the Legislature which provide for the expenditure of more than $3,000,000 in connection with the canals, including $300,000 for the dam at Troy.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- The Gaulois to-day publishes a dispatch from Buenos Ayres, which announces that the Chilean Government troops have been defeated at Coquimbo and Quillota, that the insurgent forces are rapidly increasing in numbers, and that they are advancing upon the capital, Santiago de Chile.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 17. -- The Republicans held a caucus to-night to try to settle the Senatorial question, but found themselves as much at sea after hours of wrangling as when they began. "Long" Jones's lieutenant made a valiant effort to get all the Republicans to pledge themselves to vote for Streeter, the Alliance candidate, tomorrow, but only eighty-seven agreed to do so.

Mr. Watterson has decidedly the advantage of Gov. Hill in the letter episode. Mr. Hill exhibited an unreasonable amount of temper when the communication was made public, and his denunciation of Mr. Watterson was coarse and uncalled for. It cannot fail to offend the South and the Democracy, whose champion Mr. Watterson has been before the public knew of the existence of such an individual as D.B. Hill.

There is to be a meeting of the General Committee of the People's Municipal League at Scottish Rite Hall, corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, this evening, for the purpose of carrying out the plan of reorganization which has been prepared. Mr. GEORGE L. RIVES will preside, and the constitution and by-laws framed by the sub-committee appointed for that purpose will be adopted.

Gen. Sherman's son, Thomas Ewing Sherman, who has been studying at a monastery on the Island of Jersey, arrived on the steamship Majestic last night. Although all the steamships arriving since Saturday have made fast passages and reported good weather, the Majestic, which was generally expected to come up the bay yesterday morning, was not reported from Fire Island till 8:50 o'clock last evening, and it was 11:35 o'clock when she arrived at quarantine.

Says the Boston Herald: "The member of the New-York Senate who voted to confirm Gov. Hill's nominee for Insurance Commissioner on the ground that the nominee's father, who was a physician, assisted in bringing him into the world deserves the prize chromo." It is hardly necessary to say to readers of THE TIMES that the Herald's remark refers to that strikingly handsome gentleman who represents St. Lawrence County in the Senate, Mr. George Z. Erwin.

Charles Demetri, an Italian who collected paper stock for a Reade Street firm, went to the Judge Building in Fifth Avenue yesterday to get waste paper from the press room. He started the sidewalk elevator platform. It went down so rapidly that he lost his wits and reversed gearing, and, as the platform was ascending, he attempted to jump out, but was caught between the platform and the sidewalk and killed.

There is nowhere in history, and scarcely anywhere in fiction, to be found a more melancholy spectacle than that presented to all Europe by Prince BISMARCK. The passion of revenge is essentially a mean and ignoble passion, the manifestations of which escape contempt only when they become tragical. When they are less than tragical the passion itself appears merely as spitefulness.

There is a general impression that the South and Northwest are strongly in favor of the free coinage of silver. This comes in part from the fact that the most active advocates of free coinage have been from these sections. The Northwest, however, has not furnished very many outside of the "mining-camp" States.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 18. -- The National Transportation Association to-day adopted resolutions calling upon Congress to take measures to compel carriers to furnish all shippers a uniform bill of lading in which the common law liability of the carriers shall be expressed. The adoption of a uniform classification is urged. Congress is requested to accord to the shipping interests a hearing on these subjects.

For three hours and a half yesterday the American Loan and Trust Company of 115 Broadway stood the strain to which it had been subjected since last Friday. Then it gave up the fight, closed its doors, and passed into the charge of the Superintendent of the Banking Department of the State, which now figures that it has a deficiency of nearly $657,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- At a meeting of the General Committee of the Natural Bridge University, or Summer Art School, held to-day in the rooms of Mrs. J. M. Sweat, President of the Organization Committee, Col. H.C. Parsons reported that a charter had been obtained under the laws of Virginia, and that in a few days might be expected a certificate which would secure the powers necessary to the establishment of a university.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- The forestry inquiry was continued this afternoon by the Assembly investigating committee. Commissioner Basselin was again called. He testified at great length and with minuteness as to the efforts the Forest Commission had made to protect the forests. In relation to the Hurd proposition for an exchange of land there were several considerations that guided the commission in refusing it.

Patrolmen William McHugh and John A. Morrison of the King's Bridge police station were on trial yesterday before Commissioner Martin, charged with improperly conducting themselves in the house of John Prochatka, an iron molder, living at Spuyten Duyvil. Witnesses testified that the two policemen, who were on patrol duty, were in Prochatka's house from 9 to 11:30 o'clock Saturday night, Jan. 25, drinking, singing, dancing, and in other ways misbehaving.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- "You may rest assured that if Gov. Hill commits himself to this free-coinage-of-silver business he will take a position directly opposite to that of Mr. Cleveland's, and he will straddle it."

The People's Municipal League organized itself as a permanent political body last evening by adopting the constitution which had been prepared by a committee. The organization took place at a meeting of the General Committee held in the Scottish Rite Hall, Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. Wheeler H. Peckham called the meeting to order and introduced George L. Rives, who presided.
TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 18. -- The Globe, commenting on the Conservative meeting of last night, says:

It appears that it is to Mr. GALLUP of the Park Commission that the up-town public owes it that there is now a public conveyance between Fifty-ninth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets across the Park. There was an outrageous delay in laying the rails, and they have been laid for months without bringing us apparently any nearer to the result for which they were laid.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday a letter was received from Mayor Grant transmitting resolutions adopted by the House Owners' and Real Estate Association of the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards, stating that many non-residents are employed as teachers in the public schools, and that they annually receive salaries which aggregate about $500,000, and protesting against their employment to the exclusion of residents.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The Post this morning says: "Nobody denies the right of Canadians to advocate annexation, but this policy must emanate from themselves and not be forced upon them by intrigues with a foreign power. Mr. Edward Farrer appears to be obliged to admit the truth of Sir John Macdonald's terrible exposure of his opponents' tactics.

The recent act of Congress, which has now become a law, providing for the enlargement of the military post at Plattsburg, is one of an important series of measures having for their avowed purpose the protection of our northern frontier. It has already been followed by the introduction of a bill to establish a new military post in Northern Vermont.

The North German Lloyd steamship Havel, a sister of the Spree, and the latest addition to the fleet, began her first trip to Bremen yesterday afternoon by running down and sinking a bark and drowning two of its crew. The new Italian bark Mascote, which had just finished her maiden trip to this port, was the unfortunate vessel, and her two boys, Giovanni Garossa and Adolfi Bancalari, were the victims of the accident.
ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Saxton offered the following, which was adopted:

The last one of the fifteen witnesses to the will and four codicils of Daniel B. Fayerweather was examined at yesterday's session before Surrogate Ransom, in the attempt of Mrs. Fayerweather and the next of kin of Mr. Fayerweather to prove that the leaving of the residuary estate to the three executors absolutey was obtained by fraud and deception.

Henry S. Ives, who used to make things lively in the railroad world, expressed mild surprise yesterday when he was asked about the reports telegraphed from Chicago of charges that he was trying to wreck the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Road. The story must refer to somebody else, Mr. Ives said. President W.L. Breyfogle, who, it was charged, was interested with him in the deal, he said he knew only very slightly.

At a meeting of the American Association yesterday it was decided to break away from the national agreement. This means that the sport-loving public is to be afflicted with another baseball war, the result of what the Association people claim unfair treatment at the hands of the League. When the war was raging last Summer the League people showed a tendency to make all sorts of concessions in the interest of peace and harmony.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 18. -- The Etna Coal Company, one of the strongest companies in this section of the country, made an assignment to-day. Its liabilities are placed at $90,000 and its assets at $300,000. David B. Pillsbury of Whiteside, Tenn., was named as assignee.

WHERLING, West Va., Feb. 18. -- George Hess of Fulton was mistaken for a burglar by his two brothers-in-law, named Ball, at Pleasant Valley, at 1 o'clock this morning, and shot. He died almost instantly.

The Democratic Party will read with the liveliest interest what Senator GORMAN of Maryland through his friend Mr. RUSK of the Third District will have to say on the political situation created by Mr. CLEVELAND'S letter. The Senator probably has more experience and is credited with greater sagacity in politics than any other man in his party.

ST LOUIS, Feb. 18. -- The display at the funeral of Gen. W.T. Sherman on Saturday next will be one of the most magnificent ever seen in this country. The contingent of troops from neighboring States is much larger than had been expected, and the number of those who will participate in rendering the last honors to the departed soldier is being constantly increased.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- The appointment list for the Senior Class of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University was announced to-day. There are ninety men in the class, and of this number thirty-six receive appointments to prepare theses for the anniversary exercises in June. From this number the Faculty will select ten or twelve to read papers at Commencement.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- The Regents of the University of the State of New-York, after two years' careful consideration of the subject, and after conference with and at the urgency of representatives of the leading colleges and universities in this State, have decided to extend their work upon lines calculated to more widely offer and carry to the people at large opportunities and facilities for education.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Copyright bill has passed the Senate at last, but in a form that bears little resemblance to the measure that the House of Representatives sent over to the upper house.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 18. -- Two prisoners, a white man and a negro, were taken from the county jail in Gainesville, Alachua County, late last night and hanged. They had been arrested ten hours before for complicity in numerous assaults committed in the neighborhood during the past two weeks.

The Crescent Athletic Club's famous football players never lined up for a livelier scrimmage or were cheered more enthusiastically by their friends than they were last evening when they were given a complimentary dinner by members of the club at the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn. The dinner was an acknowledgment of the many victories won by the football team last Fall.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 18. -- "One of the most interesting matters that will come up before the General Assembly of the Church at Detroit will be the approval or disapproval of Dr. Charles A. Briggs's appointment to the Chair of Biblical Theology by the Board of Directors of the Union Theological Seminary of New-York," said Dr. T.R. Monfort of the Herald and Presbyter today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- The twenty-eighth annual report of the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company was given out to-day. It shows that the gross earnings from traffic and interest on temporary investments of surplus in the year 1890 were $7,339,250. The total disbursements in the same period for operating expenses, taxes, rent of leased lines, interest on bonds and dividends were $7,258,133, leaving a balance of $81,117.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 18. -- The frauds upon the pension list of the State of Georgia have become so pronounced that strict scrutiny has lately been employed to prevent it. Georgia was one of the first States in the South to make an appropriation for the benefit of wounded and maimed ex-Confederates. The benefit was in the shape of artificial arms, legs, eyes, , renewable at stated periods.

At the annual meeting of the Larchmont Yacht Club, held at Delmonico's last night, the following officers were elected: Girard C.W. Lowrey, Commodore; Joseph H. Sterling, Vice Commodore; David Irwin Jackson, Rear Commodore; Charles A. Singer, Secretary; William Murray, Treasurer; Augustin Monroe and Eugene L. Bushe, Trustees, to serve three years.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 18. -- The works of the Enterprise Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of fishing tackle and self-luminous bait, were almost entirely destroyed by fire this afternoon. Miss Nettie Cruse, a forewoman, was fatally burned. The fire originated on the second floor. The forewoman was pouring alcohol into a pan of melted wax, when the alcohol caught fire, enveloping her in a sheet of flame.

HARTFORD, Feb. 18. -- The House was the scene of proceedings this afternoon that will be regarded with shame throughout the State when the facts are known. An attempt was made by the Republican majority to discipline the Democratic Representatives from this city for using language assumed to be derogatory to Gov. Bulkeley.

Honest Americans may hold their heads a trifle higher to-day and feel a little more respect for themselves. The principle of international copyright has been recognized as right and just and necessary by a majority of both houses of Congress. House bill 10,881 passed the Senate yesterday by a vote of 36 to 14.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 18. -- This was another successful day at the W.T. Woodard horse sale. The weather was cold and disagreeable, but nearly 2,000 persons attended and prices were satisfactory. Forty-eight head brought $41,000. The average was $854. The following sold for $800 and over:

Acting Superintendent Robbins of the Street-Cleaning Department made a report yesterday on the result of the first day's experiment in cleaning the streets between Twenty-eighth and Fortieth Streets and the North and East Rivers, under the plan of the Advisory Committee. It favors the method of sweeping by hand, followed in Section A, which is the more expensive.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- The annual inspection and muster of the organizations named below will take place in the evening of the respective dates, as follows:

Another insidious attempt to undermine the work of the Civil Service Commission appears in Senator PLUMB'S proposed amendment of the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill allowing a lot of clerical and other employes of the Census Bureau to be transferred to other branches of the public service when they get through with the special work for which they were appointed.

Philip A. White, who died Tuesday at his residence at 312 Claremont Avenue, Brooklyn, was one of the best-known colored men in this city, and for many years he enjoyed also the esteem of a wide acquaintance outside of his own race. Mr. White carried on the business of druggist and chemist at Frankfort and Gold Streets for nearly forty-seven years.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Feb. 19. -- An Odd Fellows' encampment was organized here last night. The name of the new society is Highlands Encampment, No. 26. The organizing and instituting officers were Grand Patriarch A.J. Doane of Jersey City. Grand High Priest James C. Robbins of Hamilton Square, Grand Senior Warden Ewan Dairymple of Clinton, Grand Junior Warden William H. Biddle of Atlantic City.

The prospects of reorganizing the American Loan and Trust Company seemed to grow brighter yesterday, and, as on the preceding day, there were many conferences of those interested in the project. In a good many of them Russell Sage was a central figure. He saw stockholders, Directors, and Bank Superintendent Preston, and before he left his office for the day he was inclined to look upon the prospects of re-establishing the company as very favorable.

We are not willing to credit the story, current among the sliver men in Washington, that Representative WALKER of Massachusetts has been delaying action on the Free-Coinage bill in order that it may reach the President late enough to "die on his hands" if he should not care to approve or disapprove of it.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -- The train bearing the body of Gen. Sherman left Jersey City at precisely 6:48 o'clock this evening. It moved slowly across the meadows between Jersey City and Newark. No stop was made there, but as the train passed the station those on board could see a crowd numbering thousands gathered there to see the train pass.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- Following is the summary of results at the athletic games given at the Seventy-fourth Regiment armory tonight, in which several Canadian and State athletes contested:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- The Grand Opera House, a variety theatre owned by ex-Secretary of State Frederick Cook and Jacob Darling and managed by John D. Hopkins, and the Windsor Hotel were destroyed by fire this morning. An explosion in the Opera House was the cause of the fire. It occurred about 4 o'clock. In a few moments the building was in flames from top to bottom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The Census Bureau to-day announced the population of the State of New-York by counties, as follows:

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19. -- The recent description by a TIMES correspondent of the overhead electric street railway system in Boston dealt in unmistakable truths, as every citizen of this city of 205,000 souls can testify. For about two years a so-called system of rapid transit by the use of electric motors has been attempted in Cleveland. It is anything but a marked success.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 19. -- The famous old Sea-Fence bill has at last become a law, ready to go into force. Readers of THE TIMES have been made familiar with this measure in years past, and it was this correspondence that first drew attention to the bill when it was originally introduced.

Three of yesterday's incoming fleet of steamships, the Bayonne, the Veendam, and the Elise Marie, met a terrific snowstorm and a freezing gale off the Banks last Monday. Each one reported being completely iced up by the bitter storm. Vincent Brandan, a German steerage passenger on the Veendam, died Wednesday and was buried at sea.

The Dallas (Texas) News thinks that Mr. Cleveland's letter intimating his belief that the greatest perils would be initiated by the adoption of the Silver-Coinage bill now before Congress, and characterizing free, unlimited, and independent silver coinage as a dangerous and reckless experiment, should entirely satisfy those Republican newspapers which have been asking for an expression of opinion on that subject by the ex-President.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- A lunch was given to W.H. Crane, the comedian, at 1 o'clock this afternoon in the Naval Committee rooms in the Capitol, by the Hon. Charles B. Reade, Assistant Sergeant at Arms of the Senate. There were present among others Senators Blackburn, Carlisle, Gray, Hale, McConnell, McMillan, Pettigrew, Plumb, Sanders, and Squire and a number of members of the House of Representatives.

Mr. JAMES F. PIERCE took possession of the office of Superintendent of Insurance yesterday, and there is a very general expectation of a "shake-up" in the department. Nobody doubts that it is to be turned over to the service of the Hill machine, and the efficient deputy, Judge RUGLES, will probably have to go as soon as Mr. PIERCE gets things well in hand.

DUBLIN, Feb. 19. -- Mr. William O'Brien and Mr. John Dillon, who recently surrendered to the police at Folkestone, England, and who were taken to Clonmel Jail in order to undergo their terms of imprisonment, were transferred to Galway Jail at daylight this morning. The prisoners were taken from Clonmel in a saloon carriage.

The statement that the Prince of WALES has been engaged in gambling with sharpers is a more formidable menace to the British Constitution than the announcement that the Lord Mayor of London has been plagiarizing. Still, this latter assertion, of the correctness of which there seems to be no doubt, is calculated to cast a gloom over conservative Britons, and to cause them to inquire what the country is coming to.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 19. -- Mr. Frank Von Phul, formerly of New-Orleans, now of Greytown, Nicaragua, arrived on the steamship Morgan Sunday night. He gives a very satisfactory account of the work on the Nicaragua Canal and the harbor improvements. Mr. Von Phul says that the sensation in Nicaragua at present is the success of several gold mines.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 19. -- Dispatches received here to-night indicate that the League will not put a club in this city, but will transfer the franchise to Indianapolis. Local interest in baseball is almost dead, owing to the long delay in settling the Cincinnati muddle and the belief that Johnson had the best claim on the franchise.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- Following is a statement of the condition of the American Loan and Trust Company of New-York on Dec. 31. This report was sworn to before Henry Remsen Ritch, notary public, on Jan. 19, and was signed by President O.D. Baldwin and Secretary J.S. Thurston. The report was filed in the State Banking Department on Jan. 20:

Once before New-York has seen a military pageant, arranged upon a like occasion, that was even more deeply impressive than the funeral procession of Gen. SHERMAN, which yesterday passed slowly through streets packed on either side with people. Another pageant of the same kind equal to it the present generation of New-Yorkers are not likely to see.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- At 10:30 o'clock this morning ex-Senator James F. Pierce walked into Controller Wemple's office. "I wish to file my bond as Superintendent of Insurance," he said. The bond -- $25,000 -- was signed by William H. Hazzard and Augustus Storrs of Brooklyn, who qualified for double the amount.

The People's Municipal League is to be organized upon a permanent basis, and it is only by permanent organization and continuous effort that its objects can be accomplished. Its fundamental principles and the conditions of membership are laid down in the brief constitution adopted at the meeting on Wednesday night, and a large committee was appointed to carry out the work of organization in the several Assembly districts of the city.

The effort led by Senator PLUMB of Kansas to establish in the civil service some thousand clerks who are now in the Census Bureau, without complying with the law regulating appointments to the departments at Washington, strikes us as indicating that the spoilsmen have reached their last ditch.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 19. -- Next to the Gubernatorial question, the Cleveland letter on free coinage is the most generally-discussed subject hereabout. This section is against free coinage; therefore Mr. Cleveland has greatly strengthened his position by his frank avowal of his views, and has increased the admiration which many Republicans have always felt for his courage and honesty and the soundness of his financial policy.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19. -- It is now considered a practical certainty that the United States Grand Jury will this Spring find sweeping indictments against a number of local officials and representatives of various railroad companies. It can be said positively that the District Attorney is at work preparing the cases, but when he was asked for information this evening he declined either to deny or to confirm the report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The young officers recently ordered to duty under the Hydrographic Office of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey have been assigned as follows: Ensign W.G. Milier, United States Navy; Ensign W.L. G. Howard, United States Navy, and Ensign F.L. Chapin, United States Navy, to the steamer Patterson; Ensign W.B. Hoggatt, United States Navy, to the steamer Bache; Ensign Benjamin Wright, United States Navy, to the steamer Blake.

Mr. H.L. Priddy, an old-time Memphis journalist, is one of the men who regret the death of Gen. Sherman. He and D.A. Brower, now editor of the Little Rock Gazette, were publishing the Argus in Memphis during the time that Gen. Sherman was in command there, and they had several rather exciting experiences with him.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- The Fiske-McGraw estate, which has attained considerable fame on account of the lawsuit concerning it between the heirs and Cornell University, to which institution it was given by Mrs. Jennie McGraw-Fiske upon her death ten years ago, was sold a auction to-day. The property consists of thirty acres of land on the slope of East Hill, overlooking the city and just below the university grounds.

There seems to be no longer any room for doubt that the steam lifeboat Norton has been lost at sea, and that its Captain, F.L. Norton, with his wife, his niece, Chief Engineer W.H. Crawford, and a crew of six men have perished.

HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- The sequel to last week's gossip arising from the recalling of the invitations for the marriage of Fred Dubois Stott, son of Charles H. Stott, the millionaire woolen goods manufacturer of Stottville, N.Y., to Miss Caroline Havilnd, eldest daughter of W. Carroll Haviland, cashier of the Farmers' National Bank of this city, came to light to-day.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 19. -- The warm, moist weather of the past few days has so swollen the buds on the peach trees in this State that some trees in Sussex County are nearly ready to bloom. A continuance of such weather would so forward the buds that cold snap would work irreparable injury.

A decision made last Monday by Judge WALTER LLOYD SMITH of the New-York Supreme Court in a case relating to a Trust combination deserves attention in all parts of the country for several reasons, one of which is that the existence of the combination affected by it has been known to only a small number of persons.

MEXICO, via Galveston, Feb. 19. -- No official communications between this Government and Washington on the subject of reciprocity arrangements have yet been exchanged, but the Mexican Government expects when Congress adjourns in Washington to hear something from Mr. Blaine, and although there is strong feeling here against special trade treaties, it is likely that Mexico will come to some understanding with the United States.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Mr. Leslie Fraser Duncan, late editor of the Matrimonial News, has paid Miss Gladys Knowles the reduced amount of damages, 6,500, with costs, awarded to her as a result of her suit against him for breach of promise of marriage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Representative Walker of Massachusetts continued his examination of Mr. Newlands in the silver hearing to-day, the inquiry being chiefly on correlative subjects rather than on the direct issue involved in the silver question. Mr. Walker wanted to know there was anything in this world with which man had to do which was not subject occasionally to disturbance.

The first annual report of the New-York Kindergarten Association, covering a period ending Dec. 31, 1890, has just been issued. The association came into existence Nov. 22, 1889, owing its origin to the conviction in the minds of its projectors that the public school system did not extend far enough and that children in their earliest years should have the benefit of kindergarten training.

The man who was shot by Ella Nelson, in the flat jointly occupied by them at 100 West Twenty-eighth Street, on Wednesday night was Samuel L.M. Post, who has been employed as cashier by Owens Phillips at 32 Liberty Street. He is a married man, but has been separated from his wife for a number of years and has been living with the woman Nelson for nearly five years.

The veterinary department of the University of Pennsylvania has undertaken to test the value of KOCH'S tuberculin by experiments upon milch cows. A commission of eight veterinary surgeons has been appointed, and these gentlemen will seek to discover the value of the so-called lymph as an agent for diagnosing tuberculosis in dairy herds and as a remedy in cases where the disease is clearly exhibited.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 19. -- At 9:30 o'clock the train started from Mantua to make the run of 103 miles to Harrisburg, the next stop. About 10 o'clock the members of the Sherman family and nearly all the others on the train retired for the night. Lancaster was reached at 11:20, no stop was made, but the train ran through the station at a reduced rate of speed.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19. -- The special joint committee of the Legislature that has been investigating the affairs of the Treasury submitted its report to the House Tuesday. It was quite long and contained many sensational features.

The letters we print this morning from Congressman-elect HARTER of the Fifteenth Ohio District and from two correspondents in the South reinforce other testimony we have printed in disproof of the extravagant assertions of the advocates of free coinage as to prevalence of the of the silver delusion in the West and South.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19. -- The third annual convention of the American Inter-Seminary Missionary Alliance was held to-day in Princeton, and the meetings will continue throughout to-morrow. Ministers and theological students from different parts of the United States and other countries, including several missionaries, came on the morning trains, and assembled in the seminary chapel, where an informal reception of the delegates was held.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- The report published in New-York yesterday that the demand for the payment of a large draft by the Monroe County Savings Bank precipitated the suspension of the American Loan and Trust Company was shown to the bank's attorney, Oscar Craig to-day, on his return from New-York. He said the statement was incomplete.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- The Boerse was agitated to-day owing to canards announcing that Emperor William was ill. These reports, it is said, were circulated for the purpose of influencing subscriptions for the new loan. The authorities have decided to take action in the matter and are trying to trace the fabrications to their authors.

The Republican leaders of Now-Hampshire say that they propose to give the people ballot reform this year. But it is safe to say that they will not do it if the pending bill, which undertakes to gerrymander the Councilor and the Senatorial districts, fails to become a law. Exactly what this bill undertakes to do appears from an abstract of it printed in the Manchester Mirror, Republican.

As a first step toward reorganizing the American Loan and Trust Company the proceedings for the appointment of a receiver and the dissolution of the corporation, brought by the Attorney General, were adjourned yesterday morning when they came up before Judge Ingraham in Supreme Court Chambers. Deputy Attorney General Lardner appeared for the State and ex-Judge Granville P. Hawes for the company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The bill for the free coinage of silver is on the House calendar and at the foot of that calendar, and nothing but the order of the Committee on Rules, or a favorable vote of the House, can get it up for a vote at this session.

The Brooklyn politicians will sit down to a so-called Police Captains' dinner to-night in the Assembly Rooms of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Captains will have about as much to do with it as any of the other men present, and no more. They have been taxed $20 each, but the other "guests," with the exception of ten or twelve, have had to pay $15 each.

The preparations for the fifth annual orchid exhibition, to be held in the Madison Square Garden from March 3 to 11, have been completed. These annual shows have presented for public inspection the most valuable collection of rare and wonderful exotics in New-York, but greater efforts than ever have been made to have the coming show the largest and most important exhibition of rare flowers and orchids yet held in the United States.

A squad of counsel and retainers of the Trolley Motor Company presented themselves before the Railroad Commissioners yesterday determined evidently to make a bold break for the recognition and approval by that authority of their scheme to string overhead wires in the upper wards of the city. Judge Ingraham had declined to continue the temporary injunction against their filing the consents of property owners to their scheme.

It was to be expected that the "cranks" would appear at an early stage to impress their views upon the managers of the World's Fair. A convention just held at Washington has resolved, first, that the fair should not be opened on Sunday, and secondly, that no liquor should be sold in the buildings or on the grounds.

It is perfectly safe to assume that the story started in Washington about ex-President CLEVELAND'S determination not to allow his name to be presented to the Democratic National Convention next year as a candidate for the Presidency is without any authority whatever emanating from the subject of the elaborate tale.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 20. -- The sensation in horse circles here to-day was the sale of Anteeo by S.A. Brown to H.S. Henry, Morrisville, Penn., for $60,000, an advance of $5,000 on the price paid for him yesterday at auction. The weather to-day was balmy, and another large crowd attended the Woodward sale. Bidding was far from weak, and good prices were obtained.

Col. John E. Marshall of this city, who was attached to Gen. Sherman's headquarters during the famous campaign which included the fight at Atlanta, the march through Georgia, and the surrender of Gen. Joe Johnston with his entire army at Raleigh, N.C., has in his possession the original draft of the order Sherman issued to his army announcing the surrender of Lee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Ex-Secretary Whitney came here a few days ago to attend the funeral of Admiral Porter. He has been about town among his friends, and there has been some political talk in the company in which he moved. All sorts of sayings are attributed to him, and a story ascribed to him on the subject of Mr. Cleveland's probable candidacy in 1892 appeared in the Post this morning.

DENNISON, Ohio, Feb. 20. -- The departure from Pittsburg was at 7:10, Central time. The only additions to the party at this point were Assistant Superintendent Turner of the Pennsylvania Railroad and Division Superintendent Bradley of the Western Union Company. Breakfast was served as soon as the train had got outside of the city limits on its way westward.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 20. -- At Dennison a large crowd was gathered at the station, and the comrades of Welch Post of Ulrichsville, Ohio, were there also. The door of the funeral car was opened and they were allowed to take a look at the casket. After a short stop here the train resumed its westward journey.

The Harvard Club of New-York sat down to its twenty-fifth annual banquet at Delmonico's last night two hundred strong. The spirit of the occasion which yearly brings together this representative gathering was of that distinctive character which, engendered by hosts of recollections, is peculiar to reunions of college men.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 20. -- The commission appointed two years ago to inquire into the feasibility of a ship canal from Lake Erie to the Ohio River, will make its report to the Pennsylvania Legislature next week. The route recommended is from Lake Erie to Conneaut Lake, thence through the Shenango Valley of Western Pennsylvania, a distance (to Pittsburg) of 128 34 miles.

Frederick Allers, who keeps a saloon at 345 Court Street, Brooklyn, and lives in a flat over it, took his wife to the theatre Thursday night, leaving Charles Schmidt in charge of the saloon and Tillie Hahn, a nineteen-year-old servant, in charge of the flat. He returned about midnight to find Tillie lying on the floor of the kitchen bound, gagged, and unconscious.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- A dispatch from Easton, Penn., says: "H.H. Kingston of this city has been appointed receiver of the Pennsylvania, Poughkeepsie and Boston Railroad. This road runs from Slatington, Lehigh County, Penn., to Campbell Hall, N.Y."

The public meeting of the Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners was largely attended yesterday afternoon. Arguments were heard in support of several schemes of rapid transit submitted to the commission for consideration.

The decision of the House Committee on Coinage, by a vote of 8 to 4 to report the Senate bill for the free coinage of silver adversely, with a recommendation that it do not pass, may be safely taken as indicating that no silver bill will be passed at the present session of Congress. It is not probable that the bill can be got before the house for final action before the session closes.

The present disturbance in Belgium is distinctly due to the political aspect of the labor question. That the labor question should be very troublesome in such a country is a foregone conclusion. It is the most densely populated country in Europe, and for that reason it is the country in which labor is cheapest and the struggle for life among the laboring population most exhausting.

The investigation into the affairs of the Sugar Trust, or, under the recent form of organization, The American Sugar Refineries Company, by the Senatorial Committee on General Laws, took a more interesting turn yesterday. Little direct evidence to show what an inflated organization the trust is was brought out, but the very failure to elicit satisfactory answers to direct questions was significant.

WHEELING, West Va., Feb. 20. -- At 7 o'clock to-night the water at Parkersburg was 44 feet 8 inches, and is still rising. The steady rise all last night and to-day is astounding to the oldest inhabitants. It has now exceeded the highest limit predicted by the most reckless, and the destruction will be great. It is described as "awful," and the tawny waters continue to creep up.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- The storm of last night was the most serious in its effects on telegraphic communication that has been experienced for many years. This morning nearly every train dispatcher's office in the city was silent, and trains in every direction were making their way through the fog as best they could without running orders.

Next to insanity itself, the saddest thing in the world is the way in which the public regard it. The grossest ignorance still prevails concerning mental disease, for superstitions concerning the more complex and finer things are the last to be given up. While the idea of demoniac possession has in a measure departed, the notion of disgrace attendant on such possession still remains.

Sir JOHN MACDONALD must be taken to know the temper and intelligence of his constituents. Sir JOHN is now hotly denouncing the "treason" of his opponents, whose policy he is trying to steal, and devoting his talk to topics which he wishes the people would vote on. Does he think they are fools?

Opponents of the separation of Church and State in France have frequently declaimed against the absence of ceremonial pomp in civil marriages. They pointed with pride to the splendor, or at least the stateliness, with which the Roman, Jewish, and even Protestant rites surrounded hymeneal unions, and they scouted as absurd and grotesque the efforts of M. le Maire and his acolytes to make official weddings successful from an aesthetic point of view.

The last British consular report from Sicily remarks that there are dark shades in the Sicilian character which contrast with the simplicity by which one might imagine the people to be wholly possessed. They can be deceitful, reticent, malicious, and vindictive; petty thefts and robberies are not uncommon; it is said also that in gratitude they are sometimes wholly deficient.

A mass meeting of lithographic artists, engravers, and designers was held at Turn Hall, East Fourth Street, last night. The hall was comfortably filled. The meeting had for its object the creation of interest in the association of members of the artistic departments of the lithographing establishments. Application blanks were distributed and a number of them were filled out.

Charles Lovitz, indicted for murder in the first degree, in killing his wife, Martha Lovitz, was yesterday found guilty of murder in the second degree by a jury in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Brady. Lovitz shot his wife Dec. 22, 1890, at the home of her parents, 87 Division Street, where she had gone to live, having left him.
LUNENBURG, N.S., Feb. 20. -- Sir John Thompson, in the course of a speech to a thousand fishermen, referring to the negotiations for a treaty between Newfoundland and the United States, said:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 20. -- While a change of engines was being made here for the Sherman funeral train this morning, Lieut. Thackara, the General's son-in-law, explained why no general demonstration was permitted along the route from New-York to St. Louis, and disclosed some facts of interest.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 20. -- When the funeral train left Harrisburg last night at 11:30 o'clock, a cold rain was falling. This continued all night, and when the train arrived in Pittsburg it was still raining. The run during the night was devoid of incident. Altoona was reached at 4:05. The Rev. S.P. Kelley of Pittsburg, representing the local committee at that place, boarded the train here.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- With the approach of March interest in Gov. Hill's decision as to his future personal course is stimulated, and the important question Will he get out of Albany or stay in it? is heard more frequently. It is no secret that the Governor is bending every effort to force the Legislature out of Albany at a date as early as possible consistent with the settlement of the public business.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 20. -- There was a big blaze here to-night. The old Peters Row, on Third Avenue and John Street, was totally destroyed. The fire started in the cellar of a grocery in the row kept by Jacob Blum, the owner of the building, which was inhabited by twenty families -- a mixture of Germans, negroes, Italians, and Polish Jews, chiefly the latter.

AN IRISH ELECTIONEERING BILL -- During the time of a contested election in Meath some sixty-five years ago, Sir Mark Somerville sent orders to the proprietor of the hotel in Trim to board and lodge all persons who should vote for him. In due course he received the following bill, which he had framed and preserved in Somerville House, County Meath.

CAMBRIDGE, Feb. 21. -- Most of last year's intercollegiate team are in training and are working every day. Among the old men are J.P. Lee, '91, who holds the intercollegiate record for 220 yards' hurdle; Moen, '91; Lowell, '92; Batchelder, '92; Carrs, Cook, Wells, Hale, Rothschild, Priest, White, and Fearing, runners; Davis and Greenleaf, bicycle riders; Finlay, Shea, and Evins, shot; Allen, hammer; with a host of other aspirants for places.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 21. -- The Essex County Circuit Court was the scene of an exciting encounter between two litigants this morning. Carl Peiper, a New-York musician, parted from his wife some time ago, leaving one of their two sons with her and taking the other with him. At his wife's death the child she had in her care was taken by her sister, Miss Attila Drenier, of Montclair.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21. -- Little has transpired in the way of amusement in the last few days to gladden the social heart. Some talk has been heard of forming card clubs and matinee clubs, but the most that has thus far been done to brighten the usual Lenten dullness is to organize a so-called literary club, to meet four times before Easter, at the homes of four of the members.

The collections of rare books and bindings, of Japanese lacquers and knife handles, of swords and sword-guards, of Chinese jades, agates and crystals, and of Chinese porcelains belonging to Mr. Brayton Ives are now to be seen at the American Art Galleries, where they will remain on exhibition until the sale, about two weeks hence.

I am an architect, and a few years ago was charged with the erection of a building in Boston, in the construction of which I used considerable quantity of granite. I bought some of the stone of a Down East woman, whom I knew as Widow Haley. One day I called my assistant, Mr. Benjamin Barker, into my room and said: "Look here, Barker, you've got to go down to Widow Haley's.

In 1884 the Legislature of this State passed an act requiring all corporations owning or controlling "telegraph, telephonic, and electric light wires" in this city to place the same under ground and remove all their poles, wires, cables, and other appurtenances from the surface of all streets and avenues by the 1st of November, 1885.

By yesterday's bank statement, the surplus reserve is reduced to $15,300,000. The loss for the week was a little over $3,000,000, which seems to be due mainly to a large reduction in specie. Assuming that the movement of the money currents will be about the same this year as last, it is likely the surplus will be further reduced in the next two or three weeks and may get down to about $10,000,000, possibly less.

If Mr. Jay Gould had observed the proprieties of the occasion he should, on his arrival in Atlanta, have paid his respects to Gov. Northen. This was his plain duty. The Chief Magistrate of Georgia was entitled to this courtesy at his hands.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- While the country is absorbed in the topic of free silver and its possible effect upon Presidential candidates, Lieut. Gov. Jones is pulling every wire in his reach that he thinks will forward his ambition to succeed Hill as Governor. Of late several opportunities to make addresses have offered, and he has eagerly embraced them. A week or so ago he made a speech to the Grangers assembled at Elmira.

It is not cheering, after an experience of the planet Egyptian darkness which prevailed in London yesterday morning and during the earlier hours of Saturday, to read the statistics of the atmospheric dirt of London just contributed by the correspondent of a scientific journey. He calculates that during a more than mainly dense fog something like ten tons of rain suspended over the metropolis.

Celts, Latins, Slavs, Anglo-Saxons force their way into a new country and govern an aboriginal race according to Celtic, Latin, Slav, or Anglo-Saxon methods. There may be varying accidents befalling the new-comers, but the civilization of the alien race finally predominates. We, as inheriting Anglo-Saxon ideas, believe that the laws and regulations we may have forced the native population to adopt are the best.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., Feb. 21. -- As Spring advances, outdoor work in athletics begins to be noticeable. There has been a good practice game of baseball nearly every day during the past week, with very encouraging results. The track men are also getting good preliminary training from cross-country runs, which are taken almost every day.

A great many complaints have been made this Winter by trustworthy shipmasters that several of the fog signals along the Atlantic coast, particularly between this city and ports to the north and northeast, have not been sounding properly in bad weather. Instances have been reported where very narrow escapes were had, and others where disasters actually occurred, owing to the failure of these aids to navigation to sound their warning signals.

Apparently the military critics have not yet discarded the method of classifying merit that the literary critics have abolished, for Gen. Thoumas, an excellent military critic, places Turenne above Conde, and an excellent literary critic does not place Corneille above Racine or the reverse. It must be with army commanders as with poets.

Mr. HARRISON has nominated Mr. CHARLES FOSTER of Ohio to be Secretary of the Treasury. The friends of an honest currency can, we believe, accept this nomination with satisfaction. For some time Mr. FOSTER has not been prominent in public life, and we do not know that he has had occasion to express his views in regard to the free coinage of silver since it has become an urgent question.

A few hours before the final passage of the Tariff bill Mr. MCKINLEY procured, at the suggestion of the Window-Glass Trust, the insertion of a proviso requiring importers of window glass to use boxes of the smallest size known to the trade. The members of the Trust, who were then holding a meeting in Chicago, had decided to discontinue the use of such boxes and thus to reduce largely the cost of packing.

HOW THE WOLF WAS MADE -- AN ESTHONIAN LEGEND. -- When Allfather had created the world and all the beasts, he asked the devil: "Don't you admire my work! Or do you think there is any important plant, or any useful animal a wanting! or that the hills are not high enough, or the seas not deep enough?"

BRUNSWICK, Feb. 21. -- A bill has just been passed by the Maine Legislature permitting Bowdoin's endowment fund to be increased indefinitely. In accordance with its charter as granted by the laws of the State it was previously obliged to limit the amount of its endowment fund to a sum already nearly reached. It is now allowed by law to accept any increase whatsoever in its fund.

The Lenten search for novelties is again at its height. The new and the beautiful are being sought with quite as much fervor and devoutness in the stores as the "good, the true, and the beautiful" in the churches. The many new designs in the black nets and laces indicate renewed popularity for this line of goods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- When society is exhausted by the pleasures of the world, it is glad to turn to religion for rest. Therefore it is fashionable to keep Lent, and Washington's gay contingent walks soberly to church on Ash Wednesday, almost too tired to pray to be forgiven for the sins of the season that is past.

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 21. -- Springhill, one of the most important coal mining districts of Nova Scotia, has been thrown into mourning by a terrible explosion that occurred in what is known as Slope No. 4, about 2 o'clock to-day. This part of the mine was opened a few days ago by a committee appointed by the workmen, who reported it to be in excellent condition.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 21. -- Prof. William R. Harper has forwarded to the Trustees of the National University of Chicago a letter in which he formally accepts the Presidency of the new institution. Thursday he started for Ann Arbor, Mich., where he will conduct the Winter session of the Institute of Sacred Literature, which is to begin to-day. Instead of going to Chautauqua, as usual, next Summer Prof. Harper will go to Europe.

The Chicago World's Fair Directory has decided to get rid of all the trouble and dispute which the lake-front portion of the site for the fair has begotten by abandoning it altogether and putting all the structures upon the Jackson Park site, in the southern part of the city, several miles from most of the railroad stations and hotels.

Many persons suppose that the quaint and musical Indian names in American geographical nomenclature are wholly unlike anything else in human language. There is a belief also that the aboriginal titles of our waters are the coinage and application of the rude savages discovered here in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. Both these ideas are erroneous.

Australians may consider themselves happy that, either because of the remoteness of their colonies or of their thoroughly practical trend of mind, they have not been worried with the irritating phrase fin de siecle, which appears to be the latest "gag" that has become fashionable in the dilettante circles of Paris and London.

The Erie Railway's handsome new steel ferryboat John G. McCullough took a small party of railroad men and others a short distance down the bay and up the Hudson yesterday afternoon. The boat was in command of Capt. T.A. Egbert, Superintendent of the Erie's ferries, and ample social courtesies were extended by Mr. W.C. Rinearson, the General Passenger Agent, assisted by other officers of the Erie.

We give in another column the resolutions recently adopted by the Chamber of Commerce of Portland, Oregon, on the question, "silver money" or "free coinage." They were unanimously adopted. It will be seen that, like the large number of similar expressions from all parts of the country, these resolutions are directed against "continued discussion in Congress" upon this subject.

The expression of cordial sympathy on the part of Londoners and Englishmen generally for the millions of suffering Jews in Russia has as yet had only the effect of aggravating their hard lot, which at the time seemed so wretched that it could not possibly be worse; and yet what seemed impossible six months ago is an accomplished fact to-day, writes the St. Petersburg correspondent of the London Telegraph.

The Berlin correspondent of a syndicate of provincial papers has had an interview with Dr. Kitasato of Tokio, a Japanese doctor now studying at the hygienic institute there, who professes to have discovered a method for the cure of lock-jaw. This cure is based on a principle somewhat similar to that of Mr. Hankin's cure for anthrax.

The Rev. Henry Y. Satterlee, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, in an open letter to the Board of Trustees of the proposed Cathedral of St. John the Divine, expresses the conviction that the impending intention, according to common report, of the board to make definite and final selection of architectural plans for the cathedral will be premature.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 21. -- The "burst boom" of Los Angeles has become proverbial. The boom was unparalleled in its inflation; its collapse was overwhelming. For months men and enterprises sank, tottered, or led a precarious existence. There were persons who predicted that the City of the Angels had received a death blow.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21. -- A discovery has been made in the manufacturing line by a concern doing business at Woodbury in this State that is worthy of notice. For years glassblowers have predicted that bottles could not be made by machinery. The American Bottle Company, incorporated a few months ago, with works at Woodbury, has demonstrated and is demonstrating that the glassblowers are wrong.

We arrived at Harper's Ferry by rail from Baltimore on Monday, May 26, 1862, a few days after Stonewall Jackson had driven Gen. Banks's little command out of the Shenandoah Valley into Maryland. Disembarking our battery near the ruins of the old gun shops whore John Brown's body had made its last stand, we marched up through the steep and picturesque streets of the old town and out to a commanding hill called Bolivar Heights.

The Catholic clergymen of this city are up in arms against the Stadler bill, now pending in the Legislature, permitting the sale of liquor at entertainments after 1 o'clock. They are taking such aggressive steps to defeat it that the Tammany leaders who want it passed are unhappy. Yesterday the work of circulating the following petition among the Catholic priests was begun:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- An enthusiastic celebration of Washington's Birthday took place at the Lyceum Theatre to-day. Three years ago George H. Thomas Post, G.A.R., presented a beautiful flag to each of the Rochester schools, and each year, on Washington's Birthday, the schools holding them present them to their successors.

Now that a modern kind of interest is attached to the name of Talleyrand by the publication of his memoirs, much literature dealing with the episcopal diplomatist is being launched in Paris. The time has been well chosen by M. Pallain, whose "Ambassade de Talleyrand a Londres.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- If Inter-State Commerce Commissioner Cooley had resigned his office at this time, as some of his friends, knowing his delicate state of health, believed he would, the President might have responded favorably to the request that he reappoint the Hon. Augustus Schoonmaker, whose term expired a short time ago.

COVINGTON, Ky., Feb. 21. -- In the Chancery Court here to-day, in the famous case of the Beall heirs against the Wickliffe heirs, Judge O'Hara, one of the attorneys, related a startling story. It was corroborated by Judge Humphreys of Louisville, Judge Tompkins of Lexington, and four other attorneys.

WHO ORIGINATED THE UPAS TREE! -- Perhaps the deftest artist in this department of fabrication was George Steevens, the Shakespearean commentator. Animated by an impish spirit of trickery, to which jealousy of rival antiquaries may have lent a spice of malice, he industriously devised cunning snares for their feet.

Handwriting is often an index of character, though it does not follow that a graceful penmanship necessarily betokens a graceful life or that an uncouth scrawl denotes a disagreeable disposition. Perhaps no class of persons handle their pens more characteristically than composers of music, and it may be interesting to note the penmanship of some of America's musical geniuses.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 21. -- At the residence of Prof. George J. Brush this afternoon Miss Anita Trumbull was married to Frederick Van Lennep of New-York. President Dwight of Yale University officiated, using the service of the Dutch Reformed Church. Prof. Brush gave away the bride, and his daughters, Miss Sarah and Miss Elizabeth, acted as bridesmaids.

Last week there appeared a statement in THE TIMES to the effect that there is a growing sentiment among delegates to the Amateur Athletic Union in favor of A.G. Mills for the new President, to be elected March 18, when the reorganization of the union arranged by Mr. Mills will go into effect. Mr. Mills wrote a letter to THE TIMES stating that he had no knowledge of this fact. It is nevertheless true.

It is well to be famous for something: so my friends often told me, and then they added that I was famous for my paper knife. This gave rise to a question which produced considerable controversy at the time: "Is a fact like that conclusive proof of the paper knife being extraordinary, or may it mean that the owner is insignificant?"

Mr. GLADSTONE'S speech on Friday fairly brings the disestablishment of the English Church in Wales into the category of living political questions. The retort to his remarks that will be made by the Tory speakers is one that could be made about his position on many other issues. It is that he has changed his mind.

AFAFITE, Egypt, via Suakin, Feb. 21. -- A severe engagement was fought at Tokar on Feb. 19 between the Egyptian troops who recently left El Teb and Osman Digna's forces. Nearly one thousand lives wore lost in the battle which followed the appearance of the Egyptians at Tokar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Representative Wickham of Ohio, Chairman of the House Committee on Coinage, to-day submitted to the House, by authority of the majority of the committee, an adverse report on the Senate bill for the free coinage of silver. The report says:

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- The squabble among the lines operating between Chicago and St. Louis in regard to passenger rates was settled today. A meeting of the lines in interest was held at Chairman Finley's office, and President Manvel gave it out that unless the Jacksonville Southeastern maintained rates in future the Atchison would cancel its contract with that road.

Beneath a cloud of smoke that rose from over a hundred of the most fragrant Havanas the members of the Legal Protective Association of Cigar Manufacturers of the City of New-York and National Inquiry System last evening sat at Delmonico's, aiding the digestion of a superb banquet by the enjoyment of witty after-dinner speeches.

The great banquet hall of the Madison Square Garden presented a beautiful picture last night on the occasion of the annual dinner of the New-York Southern Society. There was a reminder of Southern climes in the hundreds of palms and ferns that were set off so prettily by the decorations of gold and white of the banquet hall itself.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21. -- The inconsistency of the pottery manufacturers of this city cropped out conspicuously again this week. They absolutely refused to treat with the locked-out employes, after the latter had been invited to a conference and had attended in the hope of a speedy settlement of existing troubles.

BUENOS AYRES, Feb. 21. -- A dispatch received here from Valparaiso says that a Government steamer has arrived there from Aric, a maritime town in the province of Tarapaca, where she landed troops. The steamer reports being pursued by the rebel ships Hussoar and Esmeralda, and had a narrow escape from being captured.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 21. -- A scheme which the New-Haven Yacht Club has on hand and will endeavor to carry out is to induce the New-York Yacht Club to join with the local organization in building a magnificent clubhouse at Morris Cove, a portion of New-Haven Harbor. The matter was thoroughly discussed at a recent meeting of the club, and Commodore Harris was delegated to extend an invitation, based on that plan, to the New-York yachtsmen.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 21. -- Another meeting of the General Grievance Committee of employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the highest officers representing all the organizations of the train service was held to-day. A.P. Arthur, Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, was present, as was also Grand Chief Conductor Clark, representing the organization of conductors; P.H. Morrisey, Past Grand Master of the brakemen, and Grand Master Sargeant of the firemen.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Feb. 21. -- Another premature invasion of the Cherokee strip was begun here to-day with every prospect of its continuing unless it is stopped either by Executive order or by United States troops. More than 200 families crossed the line here to-day, and dispatches have been received from South Haven, Caldwell, and Kiowa which state that the invasion seems to be general all along the border.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- Crowded and fashionable houses have been the rule at the down-town theatres this week. At the Chicago Opera House the Bostonians achieved another marked hit by their production of De Koven and Smith's opera, "Robin Hood." This is the opera running in London under the title "Maid Marion." Very likely what the London critics objected to is the basis of the opera's success with the Chicago public.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Senator Plumb's particularly ugly and mischievous attempt to destroy the civil service system by permitting the transfer of clerks from the Census Office to the classified service without further examinations is not to be permitted to go through the Senate before the Committee on Appropriations has learned what the effect will be of the adoption of the amendment to the Sundry Civil bill proposed by the Kansas Senator.

Six lives were lost last night in a fire which started about 8 o'clock, and which destroyed the two upper floors of the four-story brick tenement 129 Sands Street, Brooklyn. It was the second time within eight weeks and the third time within four months that the building had been on fire. One of the former tires was of supposed incendiary origin.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The triple alliance, after a nominal duration of eight years, but an actual existence of eighteen, is apparently going to pieces. The treaties still exist, though they have not a great while to run, and all three huge armies back of them are still stern facts, but the loosening of ties has become at last so palpable that the whole world can see it.

FOSTORIA, Ohio, Feb. 21. -- The appointment of ex-Gov. Charles Foster to the office of Secretary of the Treasury is naturally accepted by the people of this part of Ohio as only one move in the natural order of things, as he has been for so long the central figure in the world of Fostoria that her citizens do not see why he should not be a central figure in the world at large.

THE PAINTINGS OF POMPEII. -- Of all the remarkable things found at Pompeii none are more important than the pictures, on account of the light they throw on ancient painting. While many masterpieces of Greek sculpture and architecture have come down to us, the Greek paintings, from the fragility of their nature, have perished, and it is chiefly in the Roman ruins that we find some tradition of them left.

SPRINGFIELD, Feb. 21. -- In 1887, when Gen. Keifer delivered the address at the dedication of the Garfield Monument in Washington, Gen. Sherman, at the close of the oration, asked Gen. Keifer if he would deliver an oration on him when he died, Gen. Keifer promised to do so, and kept his word to-night, when he delivered a tribute to the career and genius of his friend.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- Representative James J. Belden made no mistake in recommending Martin A. Knapp of this city to President Harrison for the appointment as Inter-State Commerce Commissioner to succeed Judge Schoonmaker, in the minds of prominent Republicans here. Mr. Knapp is one of the most able and prominent lawyers in Central New-York.

The State of California in one respect is wonderfully like great bisected funnel. Nowhere on earth is there just such a system of water-flow and outlet to the sea. All the run of her waters is ultimately westward and through one single channel, the pipe or spout of the funnel. The upper portion of the funnel has a long and curious narrow rim -- in other words, its gathering bowl is strangely steep and shallow.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The Prince and Princess of Wales and a distinguished party of notables honored with their presence Charles Halle's orchestral concert given last night at the special request of the Prince of Wales, after Halle had decided to terminate this celebrated series of concerts by his Manchester orchestra owing to the paucity of support received from the music-loving portion of London's population.

Though the harness racers are still enjoying their annual vacation, the driving park associations have arranged the plan of campaign for the coming season. As in 1890, the most important of the regular Spring circuits begins on the Atlantic side of the continent, the success of what was known as the Southeastern Circuit last year, warranting its members in continuing that series.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 21. -- General Manager Tuttle, Superintendent Shepard, and the other officials of the Consolidated Road insist that the burning of the wrecked car in the tunnel Friday morning was not due to the overturning of a stove or heater. The cars are heated by hot water forced through pipes under the seats from a patent heater.

VESTAL VIRGINS. -- Ovid tells us that the first temple of Vesta at Rome was constructed of wattled walls and roofed with thatch like the primitive huts of the inhabitants. It was little other than a circular, covered fireplace, and was tended by the unmarried girls of the infant community.

The principle of Senator SHERMAN'S amendment to the Copyright bill has received considerable support from the feeling that a free-born American should have the right to fill his library with editions of his own choosing; that if he prefers fine and costly English editions his preference ought not to be obstructed by the law.

The first full week of Lent has passed and brought with it enough of incident and interest to make the fact that the penitential season has arrived almost forgotten. The wedding of young John Jacob Astor and Miss Willing in Philadelphia Tuesday was as interesting and novel as had been anticipated and will furnish food for gossip and reminiscence for many a day to come.

An Italian newspaper correspondent in Buenos Ayres, being on the point of publishing a comic journal in Spanish and Italian, advertised it in the following manner: "The President of the Society of Merrymen has declared that he will be assassinated by ennui if the periodical El Coco be not published on such and such a date." The words "The President" "will be assassinated" and the date were printed in large characters.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 21. -- The appointment of ex-Gov. Charles Foster as Secretary of the Treasury has been anticipated in Ohio by all parties, both Democrats and Republicans,but the marked disposition of Mr. Harrison to ignore Ohio and bestow favors upon his Hoosier neighbors led many to believe that the same policy would be adhered to in the future.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 21. -- Mr. Eugene Levering of Baltimore, who presented Levering Hall to the university to be used as a Young Men's Christian Association building, has offered to continue for five years the lectureship on Christianity which was started last year by the Rev. Dr. John A. Broadus of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary of Louisville, Ky.

The inquiry to be made by the Corner's jury concerning the collision in the tunnel will be an unusually important and interesting one, because the elaborate block-signal system used in the tunnel will be on trial, and because the New-Haven Company will be required to defend its almost inexplicable course with respect to the use of coal stoves.

VISITORS TO TILACKERAY. -- It happily does not always follow that one cares for an author in exact proportion to the sale of his books, or even to the degree of their merit; otherwise some of us might be overpowered by friends and others remain solitary all our lives long. It also does not always follow that people who write books are those who see most of one another.

John Crowley of Boston, the Secretary of the Clothing Operatives' National Union, has just got through investigating the sweating system in the clothing business in this city. His investigation followed one by officers from Massachusetts, who came here for the purpose of presenting a report upon the subject to the Legislature of that State.

Two letters bearing on interesting musical topics of the day have reached THE TIMES in the last few days. The first one treats of opera in English. The writer of it has read some of the remarks of this journal on that topic, and, while he is with us in the spirit, does not see whence the necessary forces are to come. He says:

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 21. -- The remains of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman were laid to rest in Calvary Cemetery to-day with imposing ceremonies, combining severe simplicity and military grandeur in a manner that gave to St. Louisians and the thousands of strangers who came to participate or see the solemn show a spectacle that has rarely, if ever, been equaled in the West.

The best account of Switzerland, historically considered, is given by Coolidge in his "History of the Swiss Confederation." "Swiss history teaches us all the way through that Swiss liberty has been won by a close union of many small States." It must be stated at once that the study of this country is interwoven with such meshes of difficulties that sometimes the tangle of it is hard to straighten out.

The strange custom in America of appointing men to offices without any regard to their previous career or occupation frequently leads to the most extraordinary incidents, which to English readers unacquainted with transatlantic life would appear extravagant even if they witnessed them on the stage of some theatre devoted to opera bottle.

The investigation into the affairs of the Sugar Trust by the Senate Committee on General Laws was continued yesterday at the Metropole Hotel. It dragged very wearily, the testimony being on precisely the same line as on Friday. Only Senators Irwin, Van Gorder, Coggeshall, and Chase were present.

TORONTO, Feb. 21. -- The Farrar incident is still the talk of both parties, and interest in it was revived to-day by the renewed attempt of the Empire, the chief Tory organ, to implicate Goldwin Smith in the case.

The first census over taken of the co-operative building, loan, and savings associations of this State has just been concluded by Superintendent Preston of the Banking Department. The results are interesting in showing the size, growth, and extension of the system of co-operative banking, which, notwithstanding its large proportions, has been until recently uncared for by the State authorities.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 21. -- The Minnesota Mutual Live Stock Insurance Company of Fergus Falls has sued a number of farmers in Norman County for assessments due which the farmers had refused to pay.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Superintendent Pierce of the State Insurance Department will to-morrow evening transmit to the Legislature the annual report (Part 1) of the Insurance Department, showing the condition on Dec. 31, 1890, of the various fire and fire-marine insurance companies authorized to transact business in New-York at the close of last year.
ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The investigation of the charges against the Forest Commission will be continued this week by the Assembly Committee on Public Lands and Forestry.

The United States man-of-war Charleston, which left this port on the afternoon of Jan. 22 with the dead body of King Kalakaua aboard, steamed into the harbor at Honolulu early on the morning of the 29th. The Charleston's yards were cockbilled, and the flag of Hawaii floated at half-mast.

HAZLETON, Penn., Feb. 22. -- Four more bodies were to-day taken from the mine at Jeansville. They were those of Mike Smith, Harry Ball, Lawrence Reed, and John Bullock. The position in which they were found and the circumstances surrounding them gave unmistakable evidence of their having escaped death by the flood which precipitated the terrible catastrophe only to meet it in a more tortuous manner by starvation or suffocation.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 22. -- Vice President E.M. Reed of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, speaking of the accident that occurred in the tunnel in New-York last Friday, says:

A proposition has been made by the owners of a granite quarry near Petersburg to furnish the Confederate Sailors and Soldiers' Monument Association of Richmond a mammoth monolith for the shaft of the Libby Hill Monument, which is to be dedicated to the private soldiers and sailors of the Confederacy. The memorial will be surmounted by a bronze figure of a Confederate soldier.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 22. -- The Dominion election campaign grows hotter as election day draws near. Sir John's fate will be decided on March 5. There are unmistakable signs of alarm and dismay in the Tory camp. All the "shoutings of the Captains" and the desperate whistling to keep up the spirits of the rank and file cannot conceal this palpable fact.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Feb. 22. -- A mob of 150 masked men lynched two negroes last night at Dont's Swamp, about five miles from Brunswick. The negroes were Wesley Lewis and Henry Jackson. They had been tried in the morning at Sterling, on the East Tennessee Railroad, for the murder of C. Jordan and had been found guilty.
