We described a few weeks ago the experiments by which two bacteriologists working in Prof. KOCH'S laboratory, Drs. BEHRING and KITASATO, had discovered, as they believed, a method of making animals proof against lockjaw and diphtheria. These experiments seemed to show conclusively that the blood-serum or an animal which had been made proof or "immune" against these diseases can be used as a curative lymph on other animals in which tetanus or diphtheria is manifested.

There were none but partisan reasons for depriving the Inter-State Commerce Commission of the benefit of the experience which Mr. SCHOONMAKER has acquired by his four years' service. The duties of the commission are in effect judicial, and the knowledge and experience acquired by its members are of such value that no change ought to be made except for reasons that have no connection with politics.

BOSTON, Feb. 22. -- Investigation indicates that the story told by Jacob F. Goss, a Lynn shoemaker, about "the extreme hardship and rough usage" the men and girls who lately went from Lynn to Caracas, Venezuela, to work in a new shoe factory there have been subjected to, may be a veritable cock-and-bull yarn. Arthur Fuller of the Boston firm of Swain, Fuller Co. characterizes Goss's statements as evidently false from beginning to end.

Dupuy's two-story frame building at the corner of Ames and Park Avenues, Rutherford, N.J., took fire last night, it is supposed through a defective flue, and in an hour was consumed. Dupuy lost $8,000 on the building and $2,000 on a dry goods stock. Luther Shafer, a lawyer, and the banking office of the State Trust and Safe Deposit Company lost $1,000, covered by insurance. John Bogle, shoe dealer, lost $1,500; no insurance.

All the indications point to an unusual year in railroad combination and extension in the South. While Gould and Inman and their associates have been talking of big things, the small roads have been reaching out.

HARTFORD, Feb. 22. -- It has been definitely settled by the Democrats that no public legislation shall be introduced by the party or engaged in in either house of the General Assembly until the election of the Democratic State officers is declared by the Republicans in the lower branch. The idea that the Senate will yield is wholly untenable.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Senator Evarts was honored Saturday evening at a dinner given by Senator Hiscock to observe the departure of his colleague from the Senate.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- The public is already informed that Luther R. Marsh, formerly a distinguished member of the New-York Bar, but of late devoting his entire attention to the alleged phenomena of Spiritualism, is now a resident of this city. The attractions which keep him here are the pretended spirit revelations of Mrs. Clarissa J. Huyler, a so-called trance medium.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 22. -- Probably five thousand people visited Calvary Cemetery to-day to look upon the spot where rest the remains of Gen. William T. Sherman. As early as 9 o'clock in the morning Florriscent Avenue, leading to the cemetery, was crowded with vehicles of various kinds, and all day long the stream of carriages was so steady as to look like one continuous procession.

TOLEDO, Feb. 22. -- From the dispatches from New-York of the last few days, and especially of the twenty-four hours previous to the appointment of ex-Gov. Foster as Secretary of the Treasury, it appears that the question of his relation with the Standard Oil Company came up only to be cast aside as of little account.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Superintendent Porter of the Census Bureau has prepared an introduction to the bulletin on private indebtedness of individuals and corporations of the United States. In it Mr. Porter says:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The United States Naval Institute has just issued an extra number of its proceedings, giving in full the official report of the Annapolis armor test of last September, illustrated by thirty-two full-page reproductions of photographs of the plates and projectiles. An introduction is contributed by Lieut. Edward W. Very, and the whole forms the most valuable publication of the kind that has been issued for some time.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 22. -- The Administration, and especially the Post Office Department, is being scandalized in this city and State by the conduct of a man whom ex-Postmaster General Gresham once summarily discharged from the Postal Service and who has done more to corrupt the politics of Nebraska than any other one man.

Our London dispatches yesterday morning reported the impression that prevails among observers of European politics that the tie binding the members of the triple alliance is so far loosened that it may be regarded as practically severed, and that the three great powers of Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy are seriously considering a general reduction of armaments.

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 22. -- The first shock of yesterday's fearful disaster at Spring Hill Mines, which dazed and bewildered the people by its startling magnitude, has given place to-day to grief, despair, and gloom. The enormity of the disaster is beginning to be realized. The loss of life exceeds that in any other mining disaster in Canada. It is placed at 117 men and boys.

One of the chief grounds of opposition to the bill reported in the Senate by the Foreign Affairs Committee in relation to the Nicaragua Canal seems to be the fear that in some way it may bring us into collision with Great Britain on account of the stipulations of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty of 1850.

The one hundred and fifty-ninth anniversary of the birth of George Washington was observed yesterday afternoon by the Society of the Sons of the Revolution with a special service at St. Bartholomew's Church, Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. St. Bartholomew's Church is noted for the large crowds it has held on various occasions, but few times in its history has it contained so many people as assembled there yesterday afternoon.

Great crowds yesterday visited the scene of Saturday night's fire in the double brick tenement house 129 and 131 Sands Street, Brooklyn, by which six lives were lost. The front of the building, with the exception of the blackened upper story with its charred and empty window frames, presented slight evidence of a conflagration.

The attendance was small at the temperance, meeting held last night in the Friends' Meeting House, Fifteenth Street and Rutherford Place, but the speakers were earnest and their arguments in behalf of prohibition were listened to with close attention. The meeting was in the interest of the prohibition amendment to the State Constitution, which is to be voted on in April.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 22. -C.S. Bushnell of this city, Vice President of the Ericsson Coast Defense Company, which has just had the old Destroyer taken out of the Brooklyn Navy Yard and hauled up on Simpson's dry dock, at South Brooklyn, for repairs, says, in regard to the fitting up of the vessel for the trial of a newly-invented gun:

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Private advises from Washington verify the reports that have been circulating for the past year that Gen. Harrison is a candidate for renomination. The information is interesting to New-Yorkers only to the extent of its effect upon Republican politicians who are attempting to control the party.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 22. -- The great question with Democrats at the present time seems to be: 'What should the Democratic Party do about silver coinage?" This question is not a new one to Illinois politicians. The same question was a leading one in 1878, when the demand was making for the remonetization of silver.

A case of police brutality that the Commissioners might look into with benefit to the city was brought to light yesterday afternoon in the Essex Market Police Court, Justice Murray was surprised to see the court officer bring before him a most respectable-looking old lady, Mrs. Eliza Alter of 8 Montgomery Street, and her two sons, Nathan, aged eighteen, and Mark, a lawyer at 111 Broadway.

George William Curtis stood beneath the fluttering folds of American flags in Association Hall, Brooklyn, last night and told in eloquent phrases of Charles Sumner's heroic battle against slavery. An audience fairly representative of the most cultured people in Brooklyn listened, enjoyed, and applauded his scholarly tribute.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 23. -- Senator Craig this afternoon introduced the Minnesota Congressional Reapportionment bill which the Democrats and all the Alliance men of both houses have agreed upon. It makes seven districts of the five which now constitute the State's apportionment, and slices them in such a way as to give the Republicans the least possible advantage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Mr. Plumb's proposal to undermine the merit system by attaching to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill an amendment shoving into the permanent departmental service the army of clerks now employed in the Census Bureau without the competitive examinations required by the civil-service law is not the only blow aimed at civil service reform by United States Senators.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 23. -- Two men were killed and several wounded in a fusillade of pistol shots early this afternoon. The affair was the outgrowth of a newspaper feud which has been raging for several weeks between the publishers of the Sunday World and Sunday Capitol of this city. Col. W.J. Elliott, editor of the Capitol, shot and instantly killed Albert Osborne, city editor of the World.

The annual report of the Railroad Commissioners of Massachusetts was submitted to the Legislature of that State a few days before the recent collision in the Fourth Avenue tunnel, and it contained a statement as to the progress made by the railroad companies doing business in Massachusetts with respect to the substitution of steam heat for stove heat in passenger cars.

The interesting account of the City and South London Railway, which is given by our London correspondent and published in another part of this paper, indicates that the inventions of the Greathead system of tunneling may be the practical solution of the rapid-transit problem for large cities. It is evidently so regarded in London.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- Late nineteenth-century civilization lays many heavy burdens on its men of science from mere whimsical wantonness of mind. But it also has sternly urgent problems for them to work at. In armed Europe the greatest of these problems is to discover superior new methods of killing men. In unarmed America the most pressing question is how to transport busy people most rapidly from point to point.

The first of the illustrated lectures of John L. Stoddard, constituting the first of the Lenten matinees at Daly's, was delivered yesterday morning to an audience which packed the theatre from gallery to orchestra, and which would have been larger had the capacity of the house been adequate to meet the demands made upon it.

A dispatch from Chicago yesterday announced the death of John O. Dickerson, the Knight Templar upon whose body skin taken from the arms of his brother Knights of St. Bernard Commandery was ingrafted three weeks ago. His case recalled among the physicians at Bellevue Hospital that of Mrs. Wilok, which attracted attention in the latter part of January.

On the general theory that men who are holding over in office awaiting the appointment of their successors do not make as good public servants as men who are serving their regular terms, it would appear that Mayor Grant is deliberately neglecting his duty to the people in not appointing Police Justices to succeed Justices Murray and Smith, whose terms expired Nov. 4. That the delay is simply a makeshift apparently goes without saying.

Although the report of the majority of the Coinage Committee on the Free-Comage bill is logically reasoned with reference to the immediate situation, it betrays marks of the curious confusion of mind prevailing in this country as to the currency. As we have already remarked, the silver-mine owners themselves ought to find the arguments of the report conclusive, since they are in fact addressed chiefly to them.

The testimonial for the benefit of the widow and infant son of County Clerk Edward F. Reilly will take place at the Star Theatre next Sunday evening. Mayor Grant will preside, and among the speakers will be Lieut. Gov. Jones, Speaker Sheehan, Senator Cantor, and Thomas C. O'Sullivan, while an attractive musical and dramatic programme has been prepared.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 23. -- The Arthur Kull Rowing Association took possession this afternoon of its handsome new clubhouse in this city, and celebrated the event by a house-warming. The house is on First Avenue, and is what formerly was known as the Doyle mansion It was purchased by the club and renovated.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23. -- A letter from Senator Blackburn to Col. John C. Noble of Paducah, Ky., under date of Washington, is made public. The letter says:

It is inevitable that the politics of Canada should appear to us on this side of the border as somewhat Pedlingtonian. It is not only that Canada is a much smaller country than the United States. It is also that Canada's relations with us are managed not by Canada herself, but by Great Britain, and that the declarations of Canadian statesman upon international affairs have a happy irresponsibility.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The Batavia Daily News this afternoon publishes the following: "The Hon. Robert A. Maxwell, ex-Superintendent of the Insurance Department, who returned to his home in Batavia on Saturday, was asked by a reporter this morning if he had anything to say to the News about the department over which he had presided for several years.

Efforts to reorganize the Amateur Athletic Union were made yesterday at the Astor House in this city, at Philadelphia, and at Detroit. To-day at Boston efforts to this end will be continued, and it is hoped, especially by the smaller athletic clubs throughout the East, that soon this great organization will comprise associations of clubs instead of the clubs themselves.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- An ingenious scheme has been devised, under which racing is to be resumed immediately at Clifton, and prosecuted vigorously until the opening of the Sheepshead track at least. On Saturday the Engeman's transferred the Clifton track to Charles H. Ford for $115,000. Ford is described in the deed as being of Acquackanonk, in which township the track lies, but his identity appears to be unknown to everybody around here.

The new Secretary of the Treasury -- we assume that he will be confirmed -- may be set down as a hopeful international bimetallist. He has very sensibly gratified the desire of the business community to learn his views. They are briefly stated in his reply to questions put by representatives of the newspapers:

ELIZABETH, Feb. 23. -- The police of this city are searching for Samuel Plumb, Jr., who boarded at Mrs. Moffet's, in Second Street. Plumb is a young man respectably connected, whose father is agent for a New-York soap and soapine firm. Young Plumb worked as machinist at the Singer machine works. Joseph Butler, an employe of the New Jersey Extract Works, also boards at Mrs. Moffet's.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 23. -- Dr. W.E. Moore, Secretary of the Presbyterian General Assembly's Committee on the Revision of the Confession of Faith, which held its second session at Washington, D.C., Feb. 4 to 16, furnishes the following:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The House Committee on the Census held a meeting this morning and adopted the report prepared by Representative Sherman of New-York, adverse to the claims of New-York City for a recount of the population of that city, and ordered the resolution introduced by Representative Flower providing for a recount to be reported to the House with a recommendation that it do not pass.

Two foremen in the Street-Cleaning Department have charged a District Superintendent with demanding money from them, and he has retorted by charging them with neglect of duty. All three have been suspended while a secret investigation of the charges has been made by Deputy Commissioner DALTON.

Our Washington dispatches report this morning a practically perfunctory debate on the defects and faults of the Government printing system. It is a little ridiculous to call that a system which has no adequate rules, no responsible administrator, and no fixed purpose. The number and character of publications are determined haphazard by the whim of Congress or by influences that cannot be traced.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 23. -- The ill feeling that has been increasing almost hourly over the developments in connection with the Treasury deficit has become so intensified that, despite party interest, State pride, and family influence, a sensational scene was enacted to-day closely bordering on a riot in the House of Representatives.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23. -- All the athletic clubs except three in the Atlantic division were represented at a convention held at the clubhouse of the Athletic Club of the Schuylkill Navy in Arch Street this afternoon and evening. The purpose of the convention was to form a permanent organization and to elect officers.

A New-York chapter of the new organization, the Daughters of the Revolution, was formed yesterday at Sherry's. The central body of the association was organized at Washington last October, and Mrs. Benjamin Harrison was made President General. Since that time efforts have been made to start chapters in different parts of the Union, and with great success.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 23. -- The New-Jersey Athletic Club's clay-pigeon shooting tournament was held to-day. Mr. W.R. Hobart of Newark captured more prizes than any competitor. A slight wind prevailed. The attendance of spectators was large.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The news comes from Syracuse this evening that Senator Frank Hendricks has officially served notice upon the Onondaga organization that under no circumstances will he accept a renomination. And to-night's Syracuse Journal, the official organ of Senator Frank Hiscock, announces that Assemblyman Howard White will get a foreign appointment from President Harrison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- A report went around the Senate corridors immediately after the executive session to-day that the nomination of Mr. Charles Foster to be Secretary of the Treasury had been confirmed. It did not take long to ascertain that this report was incorrect, and that instead of being confirmed the nomination had been referred to committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The feature of this morning's session of the First Triennial Council of the Women of the United States was the address of Miss Frances E. Willard, the President of the council. Albaugh's Opera House was filled in every part by a highly-enthusiastic audience, which was largely composed of representative women from all parts of the country.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 23. -- Zach Phelps, ex-President of the Association, says of the present complications in the baseball world:

During the last six months the State of Jalisco, Mexico, has been the field of operation for that unscrupulous bandit, Demetrio Jauregui. The authorities have made many efforts to put a stop to the robberies and murders which Jauregui and his band have been committing, but in spite of these efforts burglaries, abductions, and murders by the score were committed by the daring desperado, according to the Mexican newspapers.

The red and yellow roses which looked down smilingly from their evergreen bowers the other night on the gay dancers at he Arion ball yesterday curled their petals in dismay at a far different scene. Below them a legion of men in blouses were engaged in setting up long lines of stout wire cages, into which other workmen were stuffing straw.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- The customary Sophomore-Freshman escapades on Washington's Birthday have been indulged in. Class feeling between the Sophomores and Freshmen, which had been almost lost sight of for three months, was resurrected on Saturday night, when some daring Freshmen climbed the water tower to the height of about 150 feet and hung therefrom an orange and black banner and painted '94 on the tower in the college colors.

Mr. C. Mortimer Wiske gave what he was pleased to call an American concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. How any human being with knowledge enough to discern the difference between B flat and a North River sloop could dare to produce some of the compositions which figured on Mr. Wiske's programme must forever remain as deep and insoluble a mystery as the political confidence of Gov. Hill or the Gutermuth murder.

Some unexpected opposition was made yesterday to the prompt confirmation of Mr. FOSTER as Secretary of the Treasury. It came from Senator CAMERON of Pennsylvania. What the grounds for it are does not seem to be clearly known. They can hardly relate to Mr. FOSTER'S views on the silver question, for CAMERON will not fight the Administration on that point.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 23. -- The body of the missing Prof. Bancroft was found early this morning in Dyer's Pond, Cranston.

We wonder if there is any depth of impudent and cynical defiance of honest public sentiment to which the spoilsman in the Senate, whether of one party or the other, will not dive when he gets the chance. Mr. GORMAN of Maryland took a new plunge yesterday, and the Senate, with only a score of members, followed him.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Mr. Louis Danzig of New-York died of apoplexy at the Casino at Monte Carlo. His widow, who was staying at Nice, has claimed the remains, which will be taken to the United States for burial.

Joseph C. Biglin, Assistant Appraiser, is at work determining the value of a consignment of plush machinery brought over by Hind Harrison, a firm which has been doing business in Bradford, England. The machinery is worth about $6,000. It has to pay duty at the rate of 45 per cent.

ASHLAND, Penn., Feb. 24. -- A wreck occurred on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad near this city to-night, causing a loss of $150,000. A freight engine drawing five oil tanks, containing 60,000 gallons each, and forty box cars loaded with produce, crashed into three locomotives and sixteen coal cars.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24. -- Indications for the past week point to a Liberal majority of 15 or 20 for the entire Dominion. The Conservatives are working themselves into a frenzy over the alleged treason of the Liberals, and to-day's disclosures by Sir John with respect to the correspondence between Congressman Hilt and Mr. Edward Farrer, editor of the Toronto Globe, and Mr. Erastus Wiman show the extremities to which the Government have been reduced.

Gen. Robert McAllister died Monday night at his home in Belvidere, N.J. The pause of death was Brlght's disease. He was seventy-eights years old. When the rebellion broke out, Gen. McAllister was engaged in a business enterprise of moment at Oxford Furnace, N.J. He was no longer a young man, hut his patriotism was so strong that he gave up his business interests and his comfort without hesiation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The board of naval officers detailed to witness the official trial of the gunboat Bennington has been ordered to report on board that vessel to-morrow, and the trial will take place as soon as the preliminary inspection of the vessel is completed if the weather is favorable.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Further particulars from St. Petersburg in regard to the fire which broke out during the afternoon of Feb. 18 in the apartments of the Empress at the Anitchkoff Palace show that the Czar was alone in his study when he smelled something burning and saw smoke issuing from the portion of the palace in which the Empress's suite of rooms is situated.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 24. -- Even before Gen. Sherman was dead a movement web begun for erecting in St. Louis a handsome memorial statue in his honor. It will be remembered that while other cities were talking about the matter St. Louis erected a monument to Gen. Grant. It is hoped that the Sherman movement will be equally successful.

The bill for the revision of the excise laws of this State which has been prepared in the interest of the liquor dealers was introduced in the Assembly yesterday. The principal regulations and the fees for licenses do not differ materially from those of the existing law, but there are certain new features for the sake of which the whole scheme seems to have been devised.

TRENTON, Feb. 24. -- The Tax bill came-up for second reading in the Assembly this afternoon, Speaker Bergen and Assemblyman Puster of Hudson at once attacked it with great vehemence. When three or four sections had been read and considered the House laid the bill over for further consideration to-morrow morning.

The bill for refunding the direct tax collected by the Government in the several States during the war was passed by the House of Representatives yesterday and goes to a conference committee on account of the amendment incorporated in it by the Judiciary Committee. A similar bill was vetoed by President CLEVELAND in 1889 on very conclusive grounds.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Interest in the contest over John Guy Vassar's two-million-dollar estate increases. An important meeting of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of Vassar College, composed of James M. Taylor, President; H.M. King of Albany, D.D. Parmly of New-York, Henry L. Young of Poughkeepsie, F.F. Thompson of New-York, R.E. Taylor of Poughkeepsie, and Allen W. Evarts of New-York, was held in New-York City to-day at Marquand Co.'s offices.

SUAKIN, Feb. 24. -- Further particulars of the recent fight at Tokar have just been received. Col. Slith, on learning that Osman Digna was preparing an attack on the flank while the Egyptians were marching from El Teb, hastened his advance to Tokar. The cavalry drove in the enemy's mounted scouts, but the enemy advanced rapidly in a semicircle through the thick brushwood.

BOSTON, Feb. 24. -- A meeting to organize the New-England branch of the Amateur Athletic Union was held in the Boston Athletic Association clubhouse to-night. George B. Morison of the National Board of Managers presided and Lawrence Tucker of the Boston Athletic Association was Secretary. The draft of a constitution submitted by the board was adopted with a few slight amendments.

The fourth and last concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Chickering Hall last evening was undoubtedly a disappointment to the judicious in the audience, though it seemed to tickle the ears of those groundlings who go wherever the crowd goes, and are prepared to applaud anything now, from a Nibelung pianist to a balloon ascension.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The investigation into the conduct of the Forestry Commission was resumed to-night before the Assembly Committee on Public Lands and Forestry. The three Commissioners were present with their counsel, Judges Hensberg of Albany and Anable of Amsterdam, while Mr. Adams of Utica, counsel for the committee, made the life of Samuel F. Garmon, the Warden, miserable temporarily.

Ever since last Fall negotiations have been going on between the representatives of St. Luke's Hospital and the House of Rest for Consumptives at 1,831 Anthony Avenue with a view to a final consolidation of the two institutions. Monday night such action was taken by the Trustees of St. Luke's Hospital that to bring about consolidation there is now only necessary favorable action by the Trustees of the House of Rest.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 24. -- The case of S.B. Cowles, President of the Pacific Bank of this city, charged with murdering his wife at Clark's, Neb., was called in the District Court of Merrit County this morning and he was discharged without a hearing. He demanded a hearing to vindicate himself, but the Judge said it was not necessary; he was not guilty.

The bench show of dogs is one of the most interesting and popular yearly events of New-York. It is as interesting as the horse show to a lover of animals, and it is much more truly popular. The owners of horses are necessarily a minority of the community, but a dog is within reach of the humblest.

SHREVEPORT, La., Feb. 24. -- Judge Alexander Boarman, Judge of the United States District Court of North Louisiana, and now under impeachment and probably soon to be tried by the United States Senate, is a native of Mississippi, but was reared from infancy in Shreveport, La. Being left an orphan when quite a youth his elder brother and brother-in-law gave him a liberal education.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 14. -- Were it not for the constant presence of the United States naval squadron on this coast and for the ever-changing crop of rumors arising therefrom, Haiti would sink back into the merited obscurity from which it emerged two years ago, when Uncle Sam condescended to take an interest in a so-called revolution which was really only a local squabble for plunder.

The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, one of the most influential Republican papers of the West, has been looking at Commissioner WRIGHT'S report as to the cost of labor in the manufacture of steel rails here and abroad, and is led by the Commissioner's figures to make the following remarks about the new duty of $13.44 per ton and some other features of the tariff:

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- The Dowager Empress Frederick to-day inspected the German Governesses' Home and called upon a number of artists at their studios. The Empress was also present at a banquet at the German Embassy, which was followed by a musical soiree which was attended by many members of the diplomatic corps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Mr. Charles Foster can snap his fingers at Mr. Don Cameron, Mr. Teller, and any other Senator who may have wished the Senate to reject his nomination to be Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Foster was confirmed this afternoon on a viva vace vote, in which, it is asserted, not a negative response was heard.

Greensburg, Decatur County, Ind., is now bathed in that fierce light which the census casts upon the centre of population of the United States, thus dethroning Cincinnati from its ten-year-old rivalry with Boston for the hubship of the Nation, and leaving the Queen City to the consolation of beer and pork alone.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Secretary Blaine to-day received a cable message from United States Minister Egan at Santiago, Chile, saying that the Pensacola arrived at Talcuhuano Feb. 20, and that Rear Admiral McCann reports some fighting at Iquique and that the rest of the country is tranquil. It is said at the Navy Department that the Pensacola is on her way to Valparaiso and stopped at Talcuhuano for coal.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 24. -- Sir Donald Smith has declined the Conservative nomination for Winnipeg, having accepted one for Montreal West, and Hugh John Macdonald, son of the Dominion Premier, has been chosen in his place. He has accepted.

Judge Ingraham in Supreme Court, Chambers granted another adjournment yesterday of the hearing on the Attorney General's application for a receiver for the American Loan and Trust Company and the dissolution of the corporation Deputy Attorney General Lardner explained that Banking Superintendent Preston had told him that if the proceedings were adjourned tip Friday the company would probably be on its feet by that time.

The gunboat Bennington, which has long been under construction, is at last ready for trial. Like her sister ships, the Yorktown and the Concord, she is of about 1,700 tons displacement, and happily combines an adequate speed and battery power for ordinary station service with moderate cost of building and maintenance.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The will of Mrs. Woods, aunt of Mrs. O'Shea, bequeathed to Mrs. O'Shea a large fortune, of which the divorced expected to obtain possession, but frequent public allusions to Mr. Parnell's probable interest in the fortune have induced her brothers to bring an action to have the will declared invalid, on the ground that undue influence was used and that Mrs. Woods was incapable of making a will.

UNITED STATES STEAMER BOSTON, KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 21. -- An incident of the trip of the Boston to this point was the falling in with the Atlanta at sea. The Boston, it will be remembered, left the Hook on the 13th. The greater part of the first day was occupied in swinging ship for compass deviation. This work finished, a course was laid to clear Hatteras.

HARTFORD, Feb. 24. -- The Senate this afternoon peremptorily refused to receive Executive nominations from Morgan G. Bulkeley. In affirming this position Senator Pierce said: "The majority of the Senate holds itself responsible for its acts. It has been determined not to recognize communications from Mr. Bulkeley, who is acting as a usurper."

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Gov. Hill's personal friend, George G. Campbell of Syracuse, President of the State Liquor Dealers' Association; Morris Tekulsky of New-York, Chairman of the Excise Committee of that association, and William Padian of New-York, President of the Central Liquor Dealers' Association, appeared on the floor of the Assembly Chamber to-day, and were seen in close consultation with Mr. Schaaff of Brooklyn.

Without other ceremony than a mighty chorus of barking, without even a band, the fifteenth annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club opened yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The experiment of a band was tried last year and it was such a failure that it was then and there resolved never to attempt to combine Wagner music or any other kind of music with a dog show.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday authorized Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy to expend the third million of the $3,000,000 set apart for repaving the streets of this city by the Legislature. Mr. Gilroy submitted a list of the streets to be paved, the kind of pavements to be laid, and the estimated cost.

It is difficult to decide whether the opposition to civil service reform that breaks out now in one party and now in the other, in the Senate and House, is more foolish than it is wrong, or vice versa. We have already referred to the two latest manifestations of this hostility, one led by Senator PLUMB on the Republican side and one by Senator GORMAN on the Democratic side.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Major Gen. Schofield issued two general orders to-day, publishing to the army the names of officers and enlisted men who during the years 1888 and 1889 distinguished themselves by specially meritorious conduct in services. The acts for which this honor is bestowed are not all strictly in the line of military duty, but include all acts worthy of special mention.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- At this morning's session of the Department of Superintendence of the National Educational Association, Dr. James MacAlister, ex-Superintendent of the Public Schools in this city, and now President of the Drexel Institute, made a most interesting address. Dr. MacAlister took for his subject "Art Education in the Public Schools." The next essay was by Frank Aborn of Cleveland, whose subject was "The Highest Office of Drawing."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 25. -- A special to the Sentinel from Hagertown, a village sixteen miles west of this city on the Logansport Division of the Pan Handle, says the village was this afternoon the scene of a frightful wreck, resulting in the death of four persons, two more being probaby fatally injured and twenty others more or less severely hurt: The killed are:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25. -- The successorship to Senator Wilson is being discussed to-day in political circles. Senator Wilson was re-elected by the Legislature of 1890. His only opponent was Gov. Jackson, who fought vigorously but vainly, and who was obliged to withdraw his name before it was submitted to the Democratic caucus. Gov. Jackson is a millionaire and is ambitious politically.
PARIS, Feb. 25. -- Empress Frederick to-day visited the Louvre, and afterward dined at the German Embassy. The Papal Nuncio was present.

Letters from Peru reached this city yesterday bringing many details of the hostilities in Chile which have not been sent here in the cable messages. Correspondence from Lima dated Jan. 31 gives an idea of the state of things reported by vessels just arrived from the south.

There could be no more striking illustration of the evil effects of the system under which our Congress goes on with legislation for a full session after its conduct has been condemned by the people, and after a new House of Representatives has been chosen, than is afforded by the reckless and defiant conduct of the majority at the present session.

With less than seven days of the session remaining, Sunday included, and with half a dozen important appropriation bills still pending, to say nothing of other measures of much consequence, chief among which is that concerning the Nicaragua Canal enterprise, the Senate adjourned yesterday out of respect for the memory of Senator WILSON of Maryland, who died the night before.

The need of some judicial method of deciding contested election cases was illustrated in the Assembly yesterday by the unseating of DUNLAP of Montgomery County and the seating of DWYER, the contestant. It may be that unlawful methods were employed in the election of DUNLAP, and that he was not fairly entitled to his seat, but nobody knows whether that was the case or not.

The Herkimer, Newport and Poland Railroad was bought last Tuesday by Dr. W. Soward Webb in the interest of the New-York Central Railroad. Negotiations to this end had been under way for several weeks. The purchased road is narrow gauge and runs from Herkimer to Poland, in this State, a distance of not quite seventeen miles.

IQUIQUE, Feb. 25, via Galveston. -- A battle was fought Feb. 15 on the Pampa at Dolores. The Government was defeated with the loss of about 500 men. On the 16th, Iquique surrendered to the fleet. A riot the same night, caused by an incendiary mob, was quelled by the fleet and the foreign residents. One hundred and seventy-five of the mob were killed and wounded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The silver pool investigating committee made its report to the House this evening. The report, which is unanimous, gives the history of the investigation, alluding to the more important testimony, but not reviewing it in detail. It dismisses the testimony of Mr. Owenby as the product of a "romancer," whose imagination is not restrained by the limitations of truth. The report says:

For every proved or suspected participant in the operations of the Congressional "silver pool," save Senator CAMERON, the investigating committee provides a decent coat of whitewash. ABNER TAYLOR, the Republican member from the First Illinois District, bought and sold his silver subsequent to the passage of the bill. According to the present standard of official morals at the capital, that was a matter of no consequence.

OTTAWA, Feb. 25. -- The Dominion election campaign is now at its height. It will prove the hottest political fight in the history of Canada. Every day sees fresh accessions to the Liberal ranks. The country is overrun with politicians and cartoons adorn the walls of every city, town, and village in the land. The Liberals feel jubilant over their enormous gains in the rural districts.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Mr. W. Barlow Dunlap, Republican, of Montgomery County, is no longer a member of Assembly. He was unseated to-day in accordance with the plan long ago arranged by Gov. Hill, and John F. Dwyer, his Democratic competitor, was declared his successor.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 25. -- Probably what will prove to be the severest blizzard of the season is raging in Kansas to-night. It commenced late this afternoon, when the cold wave of yesterday became intensified. The thermometer dropped to 10 above zero, and a high wind came up from the northwest. At 7 o'clock it began to snow, and the storm developed into a blinding blizzard.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- Only the House was in session to-day, and before evening its members had followed the example of the Senators and gone home for the week. They did not go, however, till they had accomplished some interesting and important legislation. Mullone's bill creating the State police and authorizing the Governor to recruit his force from the police departments of cities in times of public excitement provoked a party debate.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25. -- The Trustees of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal bondholders of 1844 will begin to repair the canal as soon as possible. It is said that the attorneys of the Washington and Cumberland Railroad will attack their operations and try to prevent the restoration of the canal by beginning proceedings to condemn the bed of the canal from Washington to Cumberland for the use of the railroad.

Judge Pryor, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday handed down an opinion in a suit brought by the De Witt Wire-Cloth Company against the New-Jersey Wire-Cloth Company to recover for goods sold and delivered. Both companies were members of the Wire-Cloth Trust. The New-Jersey company had deposited $2,000 with a trust company, to be forfeited to the other companies in the trust in case it should violate the trust agreement.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 25. -- Citizens of Minnesota will not vote upon the question of prohibition in 1892. The matter was settled in the House this morning. The advocates of submission had labored with due diligence to carry their point, but the majority was clearly against them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Commissioner Douglass of the District of Columbia held a reception last night, when a large number of his friends met the members of the committees of the Senate and House that have had charge of the interests of the District for two years.

A general meeting of stockholders of the American Loan and Trust Company will be held to-day, when the reorganizers expect to do something definite. Last night the consent of more than the requisite two-thirds of the stockholders had been obtained to the proposed scheme.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Gov. Hill's churlish exhibition of himself in the Charles Fardon requisition case has created a feeling of the greatest indignation among the better class of people here. The Governor's refusal to honor Gov. Bulkeley's demand was purely demagogic. It was an advertisement for himself, a proclamation of partisanship that is certain in the end to injure more than it will benefit him.
DEFIANCE, Ohio, Feb. 25. -- Business was largely suspended here to-day, and to-night the streets are alive with excited people. The schools are completely demoralized.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Kansas women do not forget that, some years ago, Mr. Ingalls, in speaking of the woman suffrage advocates, described them as "the unsexed of both sexes, the capons and the epicenes of society," and now they are claiming a share of the credit of having beaten him as a candidate for re-election to the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- A sensation was caused in the Court of Common Pleas this afternoon by Louis E. Pfeiffer, President of the Bank of America, withdrawing his plea of not guilty and entering a plea of guilty as indicted.

The breaking out of a fire in the Imperial Palace at St. Petersburg gave occasion for a curious demonstration of the weakness of the Czar's Government. An investigation after the fire had been put out showed that it was purely accidental. It might have broken out in any other house in Europe without exciting any alarm except on its own account.

So many complaints have been received by Controller Myers regarding the poor service to patrons of the Hoboken Ferry Company that he has written to the President of the company, E.A. Stevens, demanding that improvement be made. In 1889 the Controller insisted on a reform in the management of this ferry, and some improvement resulted.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- There are 1,300 veterans here attending the State Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, which began this morning. Before the beginning of the parade the vicinity of Powers Hotel was thronged with veterans. Flags were displayed from public and private buildings, and store windows were handsomely decorated with flags and bunting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- By an almost strictly party vote the Republicans of the House this morning passed a special rule, reported by the Committee on Rules, setting aside to-morrow and Friday for the consideration of the Subsidy bill, and ordering that a vote be taken at 5 o'clock on Friday.

ROME, Feb. 25. -- The Pope has informed the Propaganda that he is exceedingly displeased with the last nominations for Bishops made in the United States and sent here for the approval of his Holiness.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 25. -- There are three measures now before the Legislature of a mischievous nature and calculated to damage railroad and mining interests in this State, should they pass. One of these measures is said to provide against the employment of inexperienced conductors, another to establish a Board of Examiners of Employes, including telegraph operators, and to prescribe their duties and powers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- A rumor has been several times put in circulation here to the effect that the employes of the Eastern system of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company would co-operate with their fellow-employes on the Western system in their demand for higher wages and the adjustment of other matters of complaint. A prominent officer of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company when questioned regarding the rumor to-day said:

George Gunton, President of the Institute of Social Economics, at 126 East Twenty-third Street, last evening delivered an interesting lecture on "Cities and City Government." The professor said that cities were not only the centres of population, but were also the centres of manufactures, trade, hygiene, improvement, and social development. Men must accept them, not as necessary evils, but as necessary to progress.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 25. -- A special from Jeffersonville, Ind., to the News says: A tornado passed over here at midnight. No damage was done in the city except the blowing down of the seventy-five-foot bell tower at Howard's Ship Yard. Houses rocked like cradles. The fertilizer factory of Yachem Willunger, two miles north of here, and miles of fencing and entire orchards were blown down.

With that fine disregard for the proprieties which has always characterized it and ever will, the weather yesterday tried to keep folks away from the dog show. It threatened rain during the afternoon, and as night came on the clouds poured down their burden, but the throng of visitors at Madison Square Garden, instead of being diminished, was larger than on the opening day.

The three executors of the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather -- Thomas G. Ritch, Justus L. Bulkley, and Henry B. Vaughan -- have signed away all claim to any benefit from Mr. Fayerweather's estate as residuary legatees. That fact became known at the close of the examination of Henry B. Vaughan at yesterday's hearing in the will contest before Surrogate Ransom.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Final arrangements for the funeral of Sentor Wilson of Maryland were made this afternoon, and it was decided that brief services will be held to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock at the Hamilton House, where he died, by the Rev. Dr. Bartlett, pastor of the New-York Avenue Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Butler, the Chaplain of the Senate.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- In has been decided to call in the services of an auctioneer in the distribution of the Bernhardt tickets, instead of going on the first-come-first-served plan, which induced the posting of agents a full week in advance of the opening of the box office sale. This change of policy is the result of mature consideration on the part of Messrs. Abbey and Schoeffel, which was only finally fixed upon this morning.

A tall, well-dressed old gentleman was walking down Broadway yesterday afternoon in the vicinity of City Hall Park. He was apparently in deep thought. A young man stepped up to him and said, "Excuse me, Sir; your watch chain is hanging down." He quickly discovered that his watch was gone. At that moment a dapper-looking young fellow, whose face is well known to the police, started on a hard run down the street.

No appeal more deserving of prompt and generous response has ever been made to the lovers and patrons of the fine arts in this city than the request of the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum that funds be contributed to extend and complete the museum's collection of casts from the world's masterpieces of sculpture and architecture.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- An increased feeling of anxiety, lest a sudden disturbance should occur here before the Empress Frederick leaves Paris, prevails here and is reflected in Berlin. The Bourse has been weak, owing to reports that articles unfavorable to France, arising from the feeling here over the visit of the Empress Frederick, have been printed in the Cologne Gazette and other German newspapers.

Rain, hail, and snow, driven by the wind, came down all day yesterday and made it uncomfortable for those who had to be out of doors. In the morning it was warm and the wind was gentle. At noon it had begun to grow cooler and the wind blew harder. At 1 o'clock sleet pelted down and the wind was still more wintry.

This was a notable event in the modern history of the British Navy. It is so seldom now that her Majesty takes part in any public function that when she does so the event is endowed with exceptional lustre, and a very large proportion of the aristocracy, talent, and wealth of the United Kingdom always gathers within the precincts of Portsmouth Dock Yard on this occasion.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Feb. 26. -- The disruption in the Evangelical Association of Eastern Pennsylvania reached a climax to-day by the refusal of the anti-Bowmanites to allow Bishop Bowman to enter Ebenezer Church to preside over the conference. Presiding Elder Hell acted as spokesman of the anti-Bowmanites and informed Bishop Bowman, when the latter presented himself at the door, that he refused him admission by authority of the trustees.

The examination of Thomas G. Ritch was resumed yesterday before Surrogate Ransom in the matter of the contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather. The deed in which Mr. Ritch had joined with his fellow-executors, which divested him and them of all interest in the residuary estate, did not figure in the proceedings, except that it was called for by Mr. Rollins, and a copy of it put in evidence.

Following its monthly banquet, the Electric Club last night undertook the consideration of the subject of "Rapid Transit in Cities." The facilities of the clubhouse were taxed, covers being laid for close upon 150 members and their guests.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 26. -- The Pennsylvania Company's employee to-day received an answer from the railroad officials. The reply adjusts local grievances cited by the men and presented to the company early in January, and is the result of a conference of the past three days between General Manager Wood, General Superintendent Watts of the Northwestern system, General Superintendent Miller of the Southwestern system, and all Division Superintendents.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26. -- Collinsville is a suburban town in Illinois, across the river from the extreme north end of St. Louis. The Town Marshal of Collinsville, assisted by eight citizens, last night caged and caught six burglars in a store kept by Thomas Robinson, and have thereby broken up a band of lawless characters regularly organized with a Captain and a rendezvous in the most approved dime-novel style.

The dead-lock in the Connecticut Legislature has gone over to another week with little improvement in the outlook. The Democratic proposition to have the title of the State officers tested before the courts in regular proceedings has been thus far evaded by the Republicans, and the proportion of the latter for merely taking the advice of the Supreme Court is scorned by the Democrats.

The altitude of the Sioux when Spring opens will be awaited with some anxiety. That the chiefs who visited Washington were dissatisfied and disgusted became evident even before they left the wigwam of the Great Father. They came East with a story of grievances, and were told to cut it short even before they had begun it.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 26. -- At 1 o'clock this morning fire started in the five-story brick block owned by Sol Smith Russell, the actor, and destroyed his building, besides damaging a four-story brick block owned by J. M. Roberts. The fire caught in the fifth floor of the Lumber Exchange, one of the most magnificent blocks in the country.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 26. -- The citizens of Martinsburg, West Va., are much exercised about the removal of the Martinsburg Division of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to Cumberland. For the purpose of protesting against this change, F. Vernon Aleer, on behalf of the Merchants' Protective Union of that town, had an interview with General Manager Odell.

There was no change in the control of the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad yesterday. The annual meeting of the stockholders was held in Jersey City and resulted in the re-election of the old Board of Directors with two exceptions. An authoritative statement was made that the negotiations for the sale of the road were off for the present.
Energetic steps are being taken by the indefatigable promoters of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences to forward the plan to erect public museums of art and science in that city.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- If Speaker Sheehan had any claims for the nomination for Lieutenant Governor next Fall he has ruined them during the past two days by his arbitrary action in suppressing the petition of the Catholic priests of New-York City against the Stadler dance-house bill. A more outrageous decision, for partisanship and shortsightedness, and a more complete repudiation of the right of appeal have seldom been seen in a legislative body.

The annual meeting of the Grant Monument Association was not held yesterday because no quorum was present. Ex-Mayor Grace, the President of the association, is away; C.H.T. Collis, Chairman of the Executive Committee, was confined to his house by sickness; Cornelius Vanderbilt, Justice Taintor, and other members did not make their appearance. The Treasurer's report showed that there was $145,506.01 in the fund.

The proposed appropriation of $250,000 for the expenses of the Government in entertaining its foreign guests and taking care of their ships at the great naval review of 1893 has been postponed until next Winter on the suggestion that this will still give ample time for making such a provision.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Edward O. Leech, the Director of the Mint, has submitted to Congress a report on the production of the precious metals for the calendar year 1890.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Since the funeral of Charles Honeywell, who committed suicide at Norwich, interesting and sensational facts have come to light regarding the cause of the act. The young man was disappointed in love, and the fact of his former intended being in Norwich to purchase her wedding outfit and the interview he had with her was too much for him to bear. Honeywell left this note:

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Queen Victoria, accompanied by Prince Henry of Battenberg and Princess Beatrice, his wife, and a large suite, left Windsor at 10:30 this morning for Portsmouth in order to be present at the launching of the new line of battle ships. The weather was very pleasant, of the kind generally known as "royal weather."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The twenty-third annual convention of the National American Woman Suffrage Association was begun this morning at Albaugh's Opera House. The convention was opened by music and a prayer by the Rev. Olympia Brown. After an address of welcome by Mrs. Ella M.S. Marble, President of the District of Columbia Woman Suffrage Association, Miss Susan B. Anthony read the address of the President, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, who is now in England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Civil Engineer Robert E. Peavy of the navy has made preparations to start on the 1st of May to lead an arctic expedition through the heart of Greenland, and has been granted leave of absence for eighteen months from that date. He believes that if he does not reach the pole itself, he will at least reach the highest latitude yet attained by any arctic expedition.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 26. -- There is not a little comment among Pittsburg Republicans concerning the fact that President Harrison has been giving all the offices lately, hereabout, to candidates indorsed by Christopher L. Magee, the Allegheny County Republican leader. Until the November election, when there were any honors to be had, they went to the friends of Senator Quay, between whom and Mr. Magee there is an impassable gulf.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Late to-night the report reached this city from Chicago that Mrs. James G. Blaine wad seriously ill. Upon inquiry at the home of Mrs. Blaine it was stated by Mr. James G. Blaine, Jr., that Mrs. Blaine was not ill, that she had not been, and that all the members of the family were quite well.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Gov. Hill received by this morning's mail the buffoon letter from Morgan G. Bulkeley in answer to the former's refusal to honor the Fardon requisition. The Governor laughed grimly. To a reporter who called about, that time he said:

The bill to refund to the States $15,000,000 collected under the direct tax law of 1861 has gone to the Senate with the House amendment. One of President CLEVELAND'S last official acts was the vetoing of a bill for this purpose. He described the proposed repayment as a "gift," a "sheer, bald gratuity," and his objections to it, based on constitutional grounds and on equity, were absolutely unanswerable.

The Jury which, under Coroner Levy, is investigating the accident in the Grand Central Station tunnel last Friday, continued its work yesterday. Three important points were brought out. The first was that the block system of signaling in vogue in the tunnel is not infallible. The second was that the liability of accidents, in consequence of the imperfect operation of the signals, would be greatly lessened if the tunnel was properly lighted.

Senator IVES made himself rather ridiculous yesterday by insisting that the Asylum for Juvenile Delinquents should not be allowed to apprentice children outside of the State until it permitted the children within its walls to have the benefits of worship according to the forms of the Roman Catholic Church.

Col. Thomas Wentworth Higginson made the Drawing-Room Club's reception at 501 Filth Avenue last night one of rare interest, delivering an entertaining address, the title of which was "How to study History." His address was replete with suggestions based upon years of experience and observation, and it was enlivened by a wealth of characteristic anecdote and illustration.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 26. -- Gov. Turtle yesterday signed the bill providing that if the existing Board of Trustees is willing the number of Trustees of Dartmouth College shall be increased by the election of five additional ones by graduate of five years' standing of the college, the Chandler Scientific School, and the School of Civil Engineering.

The Purim Association held the thirtieth of its annual charity balls at the Metropolitan Opera House last night and netted a good round sum -- over $15,000 -- for the sick and impoverished Hebrews of the city. The societies through which this money will be distributed are the United Hebrew Charities and the women's societies of the various tabernacles.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 26. -- Excitement over the Dominion election campaign reached fever heat to-day when the nominations of candidates took place throughout Canada. Three Liberals and two Conservatives were declared elected by acclamation. The list includes the Hon. W. Laurier, leader of the Opposition, whose strength in Quebec East prevented the Tories bringing out an opponent.

The full Board of Engineers, United States Army, held an adjourned public hearing at the Army Building yesterday in the matter of the proposed bridge across the Hudson River, from Bloomfield and Twelfth Streets, Jersey City, to Twenty-third Street and Tenth Avenue, this city. Gen. Henry L. Abbot presided, and with him were Gen. C.B. Comstock, Col. George L. Gillespie, and Col. D.C. Houston.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 27. -- A brief dispatch sent out from Omaha, Neb., announces that Mrs. Thomas P. Caffrey, wife of a plumber of that city, has fallen heir to an immense fortune by the death of her father, a many times millionaire, of Bradford, England. Her husband has relatives in St. Louis, and from them has been obtained the young woman's romantic story.

The Grand Jury for February, before being discharged yesterday, had a presentment to hand up to the court. Foreman Fosdick read it, and remarks were made by Judge Cowing concerning its recommendations. The presentment, referring to excise matters, is as follows:

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 27. -- The twelfth juror in the Hennessy case was accepted and sworn to-day. The jury consists of two jewelers, one real estate dealer, one drummer, three clerks, two grocers, one molder, a machinist, and one bookkeeper. All of them are young men. Twelve days were consumed in selecting the jury. There were 780 persons examined.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 27. -- "I have one man under sentence of death for smuggling arms across the lines and I hope Mr. Lincoln will approve it." This sentence was contained in the letter from Gen. Sherman to his brother John sherman, written from Memphis, Tenn., under date of Aug. 13, 1862, and published since the General's death.

A Bureau of Information will be opened Monday morning in the Broadway lobby on the ground floor of the Post Office Building, at which clerks will be stationed to answer any inquiries by the public concerning postage rates, both foreign and domestic, the postal laws and regulations, the hours of closing and arriving of mails, and all other postal matters.

PASADENA, Cal., Feb. 27. -- All the local railway trains are again running, but there are no prospects of any overland mails for several days yet. Over two miles of track on the Santa Fe in Cajon Pass are either washed out or covered with landslides.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The trial of the wreckers of the Bank of America resulted today in a verdict of guilty against George F. Work and James S. Dungan, and against Louis E. Pfeiffer, the President of the wrecked bank, as guilty according to his own confession and plea. Sentence has not yet been passed upon the convicted men by reason of an application made by counsel for Work and Dungan for a new trial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Job of jobs, the pet of the lobby, the "big steal of the session," the companion of the McKinley bill, which had been under discussion in the committee of the whole of the House, came to a vote to-night after it had been praised as the cure-all by its friends and the waste-all by its opponents.

DES MOINES, Feb. 27. -- The great issue in Iowa in the coming campaign will be the repeal of the prohibitory liquor law. The people here are now living in the seventh year of the reign of prohibition. At first the friends of the measure insisted that it should have a fair trial. Seven years ought to be long enough in this enlightened age to test the merits of any statute.

The project of holding an annual contest of National Guard athletes at Creedmoor is for the moment not making much headway, but the idea on which it is based, that of encouraging physical training, is too useful to be dropped. NAPOLEON'S reliance upon celerity of marches is familiar, and STONEWALL JACKSON'S "foot cavalry" won victories by their legs as well as their guns.

President McMillan of the Amateur Athletic Union is being ridiculed for the course taken in the organization of the Atlantic Athletic Association at Philadelphia Monday. Mr. McMillan did not know that his association had no power to adopt by-laws or to elect members of the Board of Governors of the Amateur Athletic Union. The athletic world may soon awaken to the fact that Mr. McMillan knows very little about framing or carrying out athletic laws.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 27. -- Twenty-eight thousand men in Western Pennsylvania who are usually steady workmen earning good wages are idle. Twenty seven thousand of these are in conflict with their employers. The other thousand await the result of a war between capitalists.

Miss Jane Meade Welch told a large audience in Berkeley Lyceum yesterday many instructive and entertaining things about John Quincy Adams and Andrew Jackson. She described and contrasted the personal characteristics and public acts of the two men in a way that filled her hearers with an agreeable sense of having learned something.

DANVILLE, Penn., Feb. 27. -- Miss Anna E. Dickinson, lecturer, author, and actress, is now an inmate of the hospital for the insane here. Her case is regarded as a very doubtful if not a hopeless one. A visit was paid to the institution to-day and something was learned as to her condition from Dr. Shultz, the head physician of the asylum.

The testimony taken by the Coroner's jury concerning the recent collision shows how difficult it is at times to see the signals which are displayed in the tunnel. This difficulty was not overlooked when to the visual signals was added the gong alarm by the side of the track. It does not appear that this gong alarm was heard by any one on the New-Haven train, but it may have been in operation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The monthly pilot chart of the North Atlantic Ocean for March will be issued from the Hydrographic Office of the Navy Department to-morrow, and in addition to the data given on the chart proper an interesting feature will be the publication of a large number of reports recently received from mariners, giving their experience with the use of oil in heavy weather at sea to moderate the violence of the waves.

The Senate yesterday corrected the silly action of the House regarding the force of the Civil Service Commission. The nature of that action is described in our Washington dispatches. The debate in the Senate was marked by some spirited and pertinent remarks from ,Senator WOLCOTT, who in many ways is demonstrating a wholesome independence of the traditions and prejudices of the venerable body of which he is a member.

It is rather early in the season to be reading of floods and freshets, especially as the Winter is still obviously with us and there are scarcely any signs of the coming of the Spring. Manifestly the floods in the Mohawk Valley and along the Hudson River have been unusually serious, and have greatly hampered the operation of the New-York Central system.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 27. -- At Quebec last night Sir Charles Tupper announced the determination on the part of the Canadian Government to establish a great ocean line of fast steamers between Great Britain and Canada. The sum of 100,000 a year had been voted for the purpose, but owing to the largely-increased cost of building ships it was found that this was not enough.

The investigation of the contest in the Thirteenth Assembly District by the Republican County Committee's Committee on Contested Seats came near breaking up last night in a row. As it was a little blood was spilled. It was not a Gibbs man who lost the fluid.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- Empress Frederick of Germany left Paris this morning. No unpleasant incident marked her departure. Acting under advice from high quarters, she changed the line of her route for fear of being insulted by that portion of the populace which had gradually worked itself into a fever heat of rage over the presence of the imperial visitor in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- While considerable ignorance of the methods of the Civil Service Commission was displayed by one or two men in the Senate to-day, the body, as a whole, took an eminently practical and intelligent view of the needs of the commission, and gave it the number of clerks it had asked for for the coming fiscal year.

One of our neighbors, the Press, in the following remarks concerning Judge PRYOR'S decision with respect to the Wire Cloth Trust, gives publicity to an erroneous opinion, now held by many persons, as to the danger to which such combinations are exposed under the common law:

Franklin Bartlett, counsel for Gov. Hill's featherweights of the special Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Reapportionment, at yesterday's session of the committee in Part II. of the Superior Court called United States Commissioner John A. Shields as his first witness. Mr. Shields testified that the only warrant issued for the arrest of an enumerator was the one issued for Thieme.

Piscatorial prophets are finding many signs of an early angling season, but their judgment is based upon observations similar to those which may be made almost every season. The fact that flounders have been seen in the bays which they are accustomed to haunt and that a few of them have been so rash as to eat worms lined with hooks does not necessarily mean an early fishing season.

The investigation into the disaster of a week ago in the big tunnel leading out of the Grand Central Station was continued yesterday by Coroner Levy and his jury. As the investigation goes on it becomes more and more evident that there is nothing to occasion surprise in the fact that such an accident occurred under the existing conditions. It is only surprising that there have not been many more of them.

Chauncey M. Depew, President of the New-York Central Railroad, was asked yesterday if he knew of any perfectly satisfactory system of heating railroad cars. He replied: "I do not. A car can be heated more comfortably by the stove than by any other means, because with a stove you can regulate the heat. But the element of danger in the stove bars that absolutely.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The Central Railroad Company has bought the river front property formerly owned by the Improvement Company, Charles L. Walters and David B. Keeler, Jr. The property between the station and river will be graded and improved in many ways.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- The appointment of Henry M. Hard of Lyndonville, Orleans County, to be Consul at Clifton, Ontario, yesterday by the President has caused no little surprise and criticism among the Republicans at Niagara Falls, where it was generally understood that Charles E. Cromley of that town would be the favored one. Mr. Hard will succeed Amos A. Brown of Lockport, who was appointed by President Cleveland.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Speaker Sheehan has grown so accustomed to riding rough shod over the minority that there was very little surprise manifested this morning when he made another of his outrageous rulings. An hour later he reversed the ruling, which he knew from the first was contrary to precedent.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 27. -- The case of the United States against George W. Dupre, in which the defendant is charged with sending through the mails a newspaper containing a lottery advertisement and also a letter containing lottery matter, was called for trial this morning before Judges Don A. Pardee and Edward C. Billings in the United States Circuit Court on the special plea filed by the defendant to the indictments found against him.

The contest in Canada is taking pretty much the course which, when I last wrote to you, it seemed likely to take. The dissolution of Parliament before the regular time, and with the electoral roll imperfect, was justified, you will remember, on the ground that the Government was about to make commercial overtures to the United States, and required the sanction of a freshly-elected Parliament for that purpose.

The crippled Board of Electrical Control managed to hold a meeting yesterday. The three resolutions proposed by Mayor Grant Thursday came up. The first requires all electric light and power companies maintaining housetop wires in districts where there are subways to have them in the subways within thirty days. Expert Electrician S.S. Whecler submitted a map of the portion of the city below Canal Street showing the location of the wires that must be removed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 27. -- Plans for the buildings of the World's Columbian Exposition have been approved this week both by the Grounds and Buildings Committee and by the commission's Board of Control. The Board of Architects met on Monday and submitted designs that insure the finest buildings ever dedicated to exposition purposes.

Gov. HILL is reported as having admitted that his refusal to recognize BULKELEY as the Governor of Connecticut is not right -- or was a "mistake," as the report has it -- but as claiming that it was "good Democratic politics." No "rabid" Republican could make a more cynical insinuation as to the kind of politics that is considered "good" by Democrats.

The Anchor Line steamship Belgravia which sails to-day for Gibraltar and Naples, will carry out the Rev. Dr. H.M. Wharton, editor of the Baltimore Baptist and a party of thirty-four ladies and gentlemen, who are going to make a trip to Palestine with him under the management of Henry Gaze Son. The round journey will take four months, which includes one month of camping out in Palestine.

Mr. James Mortimer's dog show at Madison Square Garden stopped at 10 o'clock last night At 9:55 the potato salad in the so-called "press" room gave out, and at 9:59 the fat man at the door reluctantly quit selling catalogues at 25 cents apiece. The lights went out while he was making change for the last customer.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- To-night the freshet in the Hudson is two feet lower than it was last night.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The passage across the channel was unmarked by incident. Count Von Hatzfeldt, the German Minister, met the party in London. The Prince and Princess Henry of Battenberg greeted the party of the Empress on their arrival at Windsor, where a guard of honor was drawn up. The streets of the town were thronged with people.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 27. -- Some interesting facts have been learned as to the cause of the recall of J.O. Kirby, a former Pittsburg newspaper man, from the post of Consul to Para. It appears that he went to Brazil with the unconcealed purpose of subordinating his official position to newspaper syndicate work. He wrote letters with a free pen as if he were not connected with the United States Government.

The second performance of "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was attended by a comparatively small audience. Those who do not like Wagnerian music may possibly explain this by saying that it was because the public cannot stand this music-drama. But it will hardly do to assume that it is possible to crowd a house with the dramas of the Nibelang cycle and empty it with "Tristan."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27. -- The United States flagship Charleston, which arrived this afternoon from Honolulu after a passage of ten days, brings word that the Hawaiian Ministry refused to resign and that Queen Liliukaloni has appealed to the Supreme Court of Hawaii to oust them. Affairs otherwise are progressing quietly.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 27. -- The Citizens' Industrial Alliance, which sprang into existence in Kansas just before the opening of the Fall campaign to work as an auxiliary to the Farmers' Alliance, has an agent quietly and actively at work in this city. So far one lodge has been organized.

The Kings County Grand Jury which has been investigating the St. Johnland County Farm handed a presentment to Judge Moore in the Sessions Court. Brooklyn, yesterday, and in it the so-called improvements at the farm are characterized as "a fraud and an outrage," and a demand is made for the instant removal of Supervising Architect R.B. Eastman and Supervising Engineer James Carey.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 27. -- The great contest has been narrowed down to-day. The nominations are over, and less than a week will tell the tale. Dispatches from all over the Dominion show that the Liberals did their part well yesterday. The news from every Province is such as to encourage all the sister Provinces. The fire of enthusiasm burns in the hearts of Liberals everywhere.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- John McCarthy, Master workman of N.T.A., No. 216, and the official head of the Morocco Dressers' Assembly and leader of the looked-out workmen and strikers in Lynn, was served with a warrant this forenoon charging him with conspiring against John T. Moulton and John Donallan, morocco manufacturers, to unlawfully molest their workmen.

PARIS, Feb. 14. -- Paris is astonishingly dull. Not a ripple has disturbed the calm waters since the fall of "Thermidor." The undercurrent in the political world, is said to be strong, however, but the general sentiment is equally as distinct in its desire for peace to-day, peace to-morrow, even if the deluge comes in the future.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 28. -- The taking of the testimony in the Mafia-Hennessy assassination case was begun this afternoon. The court room was crowded with spectators, but the big place had an unnatural stillness when Dr. Paul Archinard, the Deputy Coroner, was called as the first witness. He described the wounds on the body as it appeared one hour after death, at 10 o'clock on the morning of Oct. 16.

THE ART OF PRIMITIVE MEN: -- Whoever has examined the handicraft of savage peoples knows well that from a very early age two totally distinct types of art arise spontaneously among uncultured races. One is imitative, the other decorative. Paleolithic men, for example, the cave-dwellers of prehistoric Europe before the Glacial epoch -- had an art of their own of a purely imitative and pictorial character.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28. -- The annual apportionment of the school fund income for the support of public schools throughout the State was made this afternoon by Controller Staub, the sum of 75 cents per capita on the basis of the school enumeration in October being allowed. This is the amount that has been paid from the school fund annually for a number of years.

THE PLACE TO SMUGGLE CHINESE. -- Looking on the map one may see that the northwest corner of the State of Washington is torn off and the space that is left is filled with water, dotted with an archipelago. The island of Vancouver fits partially into the gaping corner as if it had been torn out by some gigantic convulsion.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- In the face of the present mid-Lenten stimulus to theatregoing, "Puritanic" Boston must protest her piety somewhat less. Never were the playhouses more crowded, nor, apparently, the audiences more appreciative. The Kendals have been the great attraction since their appearance at the Hollis Street Theatre, and the house is sold out far in advance of each performance.

Five out of six of the Democrats of this State are in favor of the renomination of Cleveland. A contrary statement has, however, recently been made by ex-Senator Eaton. The principal general and special agent of Gov. Hill in this State is "Judge" Birdsall. The Sun will please take notice of this.

LANCES. -- During the Afghan wars many of our foes would throw themselves on the ground out of reach of sabre cuts, and when our horsemen had swept past, rise to deliver a fatal shot from behind, or mortally wound men or horses with their razor-edged swords and knives as they galloped over them.
