Mrs. Edge lives on one floor of an apartment house on Third Street, Jersey City. Her downstairs neighbor is Mrs. Edward F. Gill. With Mrs. Edge live George and Edward Kessler, her two brothers, who so closely resemble one another that either would easily be mistaken for the other, even by those who know them well.

There has been a great demand lately upon the time of Controller Myers by property owners on account of a notice of sale of lands and buildings in this city for unpaid assessments. The sale was announced to take place at the Court House to-morrow. It includes, according to the notice, 4,820 pieces of property, the owners of which failed to pay assessments for street improvements levied against their property.

LENOX, Mass., Feb. 28. -- The Lenox cottagers are beginning to anticipate the coming season. Among those who have recently been up to look over their places are William D. Sloane, D.W. Bishop, Col. Auchmuty, Henry A. Barclay, the Bacons, and members of the Frelinghuysen family.

Mr. Prudencio Lazcano, the Chilean Minister at Washington has at last consented to present the Government side of the Chilean controversy. In an interview yesterday Mr. Lazcano spoke as follows: "The American press has been publishing comments emanating from different and sometimes conflicting sources on the political situation of Chile, to which comments the cablegrams lately received in regard to the revolt of some ships of the Chilean Navy have attached a special interest.

THE GREAT PORTRAIT PAINTER. -- The most important painting executed by Velasquez toward the end of his career, and by some considered his masterpiece, was the large group at Madrid known as "The Maids of Honor." Into this painting Velasquez introduced a portrait of himself working at an easel.

The new gunboat Bennington succeeded yesterday in completing the trial of her horse power, much to the satisfaction of the board of naval experts in charge of her. She arrived at about 7 o'clock last night off Whitestone Landing, L.I., where she dropped anchor for the night.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 28. -- The high water matter is again assuming importance in Louisiana, and while the river is rapidly rising, an inspection of the levees around New-Orleans shows that the protection is not at all adequate. In the upper portions of the city the levee is low, but is able to hold three feet more water. At the head of Seventh Street the levee is caving, but the inside revetment is holding.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- M.C. Bernard, a mining engineer, who has just returned from Mexico, says that a young American, named Graham, is in prison at Guanajuate under a sentence of twenty years on an unjust conviction of murder. Graham was attacked on the streets of Lagas by a Mexican and a German, who were drunk, and he shot the German in self-defense.

A POLYNESIANS LEGEND. -- Tura, coming from over seas, found himself in a land named Otea, and leaving his canoe, journeyed inland. Traveling through the dense forest, he saw fairies sitting in the flowers of the climbing plants and swinging on the llianas which trailed from the high boughs across the vistas of the wood.

THE MOST HONEST PEOPLE IN THE WORLD. -- It might be rash, perhapS, to assert that among the criteria of a nation's civilization security of life and property deserves a prominent place, but it is certainly quite safe to affirm that in no other European state, not even in Sweden and Norway, is life and property so secure as in Finland.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28. -- The political situation in St. Louis is all tangled up. The Republicans, the Democrats, and the citizens are preparing for the Spring election, when the new Municipal Assembly is to be chosen. The fight will be a very bitter one. Under the city charter the Mayor makes all his appointments in the middle of his term.

It would be unfair to pass judgment upon the reorganization of the Amateur Athletic Union before one has had an opportunity to see the practical workings of the organization in its new form. This opportunity will not be offered until after March 18, when the reorganization goes into effect, and it will be some time before the new plan of government has had a fair trial.

A glittering array of rass buttons, gold badges, and gold braid on a background of blue greeted the Special Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Reapportionment when it resumed, its census investigation farce in Part II. of the Superior Court yesterday. In response to a general alarm sent out by Inspector Byrnes, at Mr. Bartlett's request, more than a dozen Police Captains had presented themselves to be witnesses before the committee.

RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 28. -- The Democrats of Shrewsbury Township held their primary at the Globe Hotel last night. Martin M. Drohan called the meeting to order and was elected Chairman. David A. Bell was elected Secretary. A committee was appointed to prepare a ticket, and they made the following nominations:

There is great need for reform in the method of locating and building schoolhouses in this city, and residents of the Twenty-third Ward know this quite as well as the residents of any other ward in the city. There is also need of reform in the methods which obtain in the appointment of teachers and in other school matters. An investigation, properly conducted, would thoroughly exhibit this need.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- The Rev. Mrs. Amanda Deyo, for three years pastor of the Universalist Church at Oxford, N.Y., has resigned that charge and accepted a call to the pastorate of the Universalist Church at Scranton, Penn.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- Prof. William Libbey, Jr., of the department of Histology and Physical Geography has recently returned from a four and one-half months' scientific expedition in connection with the Mexican Exploration party, and brings a very favorable report as to the results obtained by the explorers. Their object is to seek traces of the Mexican Aztecs, and it possible to discover proof of their connection with the tribes of New-Mexico and Arizona.

The protests of the Massachusetts Homeopathic Medical Society against the use of arsenic in the manufacture of wall paper, textile fabrics, and other articles commonly found in the sleeping and living rooms of dwelling houses have led the Massachusetts Legislature's Committee on Public Health to take testimony concerning this matter.
PARIS, Feb. 28. -- It is no exaggeration to say that this has been one of the most critical weeks for France and Germany both since the outbreak of the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71.

In the Summer of 1862 Gen Sigel's little army was advancing up the Shenandoah Valley, Stonewall Jackson having kindly retired from its front. For some weeks in that fair garden of fertility, where the rabbits jumped into the arms of the soldiers in their bewilderment, we had been drilling courageously in the wheat fields, and growing fierce as the ears of ripened grain tapped our stirrups and the fences crackled under our camp kettles.

AMHERST, Feb. 28. -- The following men have presented themselves as candidates for the Springfield and Berkeley Oval teams: Dashes -- Boardman, Shattuck, '92; Raley, Woodworth, '93; Tucker, '94. Runs -- Wells, '91; H.L. Clark, Coyle, Griswold, Jackson, Pettingill, Shattuck, '92; Beekman, Russell, H.C. Wood, '93; Munson, Seymour, '94. Weights -- Allen, '91; Alexander, Burbank, E.P. Smith, '92; Edgell, Sanderson, Turner, '93; Munson, Pellet, '94.

The New-York Athletic Club was to have given another "scrapping" entertainment last night, but it didn't. The "scrappers" have no use for that club any more. Its Board of Governors having passed a rule that its prizes shall not exceed $20 in value, and no extra inducements being offered, the alleged amateur boxers of the down-town region did not send in their entries, so the club abandoned entirely the idea of having a boxing show.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- The Emperor's wrath at the failure of the visit of Empress Frederick to Paris to establish, in some sort, good feeling between Germany and France, has fallen upon both Chancellor von Caprivi and Count von Munster, the German Ambassador at Paris; upon the former for advising the trying of the experiment and upon the latter for assenting to the Empress's prolonged stay and to her fatally indiscreet visit to Versailles.

The topic broached in our columns last Sunday under the above title has troubled those who speculate on the migrations of men about the globe ever since the discovery of America. It was common in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries to fix on Hebrew as the language which offered so many analogies with one or other of the tongues spoken by American Indians that their descent from the Lost Tribes was a certainty.

THE SCOTCH BEADLE. -- Of course he was fond of his snuff, and made free with the "mull," as the Scot terms his snuff-box, right and left. An old beadle himself tells of having got a sharp reproof from the pulpit because of his too devoted attention in this particular. "When the minister was preaching," says he, "a neighbor asked a snuff, and I gave him my box.

The second monthly educational conference of the New-York Society of Friends was held yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Committee on Education of the society in the library parlor of the Meeting House. Sixteenth Street and Rutherfurd Place. The theme for discussion was "Manual Training." The conference was opened at 2 o'clock with an address by Mr. Charles H. Ham, formerly of the Manual Training School at Chicago, Ill.

A rather curious comedy of errors was played over on Sixth Avenue last week. It had three sets, the scene of the first two being a big shoe store, and the third taking place in an indefinitely distant somewhere whose location is as yet unknown.

Heart-easing Mirth, the goddess fair and free, in heav'n yolep'd Euphrosyne, rules in this hour on the stage. Therefore, why not pay homage to Jenny Hill? She is an artist, though her stanchest admirers do spell that much-abused word with an "h." She has natural gifts of a certain sort, and knows how to use them perfectly well.

It is difficult to see where the farmer is going to get any benefit out of the kind of reciprocity, Mr. Blaine is trying to bring about, and the farmer knows it. The agriculturist's distrust of townspeople is deep-seated and centuries old. Feasting together, the farmer has always gotten the bones and the other feasters the meat. Naturally, they are suspicious and alert to get advantage when they can.

Since the last of these volumes were in press the Nestor of American historians has disappeared, leaving a field, which he left practically open for a long time before his death, quite without a representative of his own style of work.

Methodical statesmen and prosy old constitutional lawyers will be startled by the attempt of the Kansas Legislature to amend the United States statutes. Congress, in its wisdom, has declared, by the act of June 9, 1879, that our subsidiary silver coins -- that is, the half-dollars, quarters, and dimes -- shall be a legal tender to the amount of $10.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Only a week ago Europe was luxuriating in an unaccustomed and most welcome relief from a long nightmare of suspicions and armed vigilance. To recall a figure used then, she had taken off the cuirass and helmet and was stretching out her limbs in the sunlight, too happy for words.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Feb. 28. -- This little town, way up in the New-Hampshire hills, was greatly excited to-day when the news was brought into it by the Boston papers that Blair had been appointed Minister to China. The first man to discover the news was an old gentleman who sat on a cracker barrel in one of the grocery stores reading his morning Journal.

We have already made such specific comments as the case seemed to call for upon the disturbing incidents of the visit of the Empress Dowager of Germany to Paris. Of course no Government and no people can be held accountable for the behavior of the rowdies who infest every capital in greater or less numbers.

CHARLOTTEVILLE, Va., Feb. 28. -- Many years ago the Rev. Otis A. Glazebrook, now of Elizabeth, N.J., who was then chaplain to the university, started a fund for the building of a chapel on the university grounds. By him the work was pushed slowly but surely, and last June he was invited down to dedicate the building, which, owing mainly to his efforts, had been erected at a cost of $30,000.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 28. -- The season at this resort reached its height at the close of last week. The trains of Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning brought down more people than have arrived at any time since the beginning of Lent a year ago. The Laurel House, the Lakewood, and the Palmer are fully crowded, and the cottages have without exception full complements of guests.

SILVER PADLOCKS FOR BLACKS AND DOGS -- In the London Gazette for March, 1685, there is an advertisement to the effect that a black boy of about fifteen years of age, named John White, ran away from Col. Kirke on the 15th inst. "He has a silver collar about his neck, upon which is the Colonel's coat of arms and cipher; he has upon his throat a great scar,"

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 28. -- The Mayor's permit under which the Royal Street concert halls have run all night expires at midnight, and the Mayor to-day announced publicly that he would refuse to renew it. He has issued orders to the police to close at once all establishments found open after midnight without a permit, and expresses his firm determination of breaking up, so far as it in his power, this business.

The amateur professor and I were sitting together smoking in the club the other night, and the conversation happened to turn on the experiment now under way in this city in which a cat and a dog have been made to exchange cerebellums, and for the results of which the doctors of a Spitzka turn of mind are now all anxiously on the lookout.

After the 1st of January, 1864, life in Libby became a daily torture and a nightly horror. In order to force the Government at Washington to exchange prisoners the Confederate authorities refused to receive any more supplies under flag of truce, a decision that compelled us to live -- it forced many to die -- on the insufficient and innutritious prison rations

ITHACA, Feb. 28. -- The loss of the control of the Tompkins County Legislature by the Democracy this week was due to dissensions in its own ranks, and not to any revolution of political sentiment. In point of fact, Tompkins County made large Democratic gains in Republican strongholds, and the loss in leading officers was duo to dissension within the party in the towns of Ithaca and Enfield.

BIRDS AND ANIMALS IN TENNYSON. -- Among birds which occur most frequently may be mentioned the cock, the dove, the swan, "in among the stars," or "fluting a wild carol ere her death"; the hawk, and the eagle. The latter is, as usual in poetry, employed to symbolize dominion and lofty aims, and we do not know that there is anything special in the poet's treatment of the king of birds.

Judge Wallace has rendered a decision in the United States Circuit Court in regard to the powers of the Collector of the Port and Superintendent of Immigration, respectively, in passing upon the cases of immigrants held as contract laborers. The case before the court came up on habeas proceedings against twenty-three Italians who recently came over and were detained under the Contract Labor act.

WHAT WAS PAINTING IN THE TIME OF PHIDIAS? -- We vainly try to imagine what painting was in the days of Phidias, when Polygnotus covered the walls of the Lesche at Delphi with those great compositions which were newer equaled for elevation of thought, though the technique was still in its infancy; or at a later period when Zeuxis and Apelles brought the art of painting to its highest development in Greece.

THE INTELLIGENCE OF ELEPHANTS. -- In instituting a comparison between the intelligence of a dog and an elephant, Sir S. Baker decides in favor of the former, "who, when the day's work is over, lies down and sleeps before the fire at his master's feet and dreams of the dangers and exploits of the hunt."

Next Wednesday Congress adjourns, and the stock market would appear to be waiting for that event to get up and do something. It has done little the past week. There has been activity in spots, with higher prices in one place and lower in another; as in Burlington, which dropped; and Pacific Mail, which went up rapidly and came down again.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 28. -- In accordance with the plan presented in THE TIMES of last Sunday, Heffelfinger, '91, has gone to Philadelphia for a special course of training for the crew under the direction of Robert J. Cook, and with him has gone Ralph D. Paine, '94, a newly-acquired Freshman of 184 pounds and muscular build, from whom great work is expected.

Mr. Belton is somewhat apologetical in his preface, and he fears that the exact raison d'etre for his manual may not be understood. He wishes to present in this volume only those quotations "which have a distinct literary flavor" He excludes all legal maxims, and selects those which give him the opportunity to show how maxims have been used by contemporaneous English, American, French, and German authors.

At the present moment the country is so relieved at the prospect of getting rid of the Republican majority in the Fifty-first Congress without further damage than it managed to do in the fist session that there is a disposition not to inquire too closely into its course in the second or short session.

The warfare which has existed many years between the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey and the City Government of Bayonne, N.J., has reached a climax which promises a partial settlement of vexed questions at an early date. The railroad people want favors from the Mayor and Council of Bayonne, and must capitulate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The Senate was not in so great a hurry to appoint conferrees on the Shipping bill to-day. Mr. Frye wanted no delay and received some sympathy from Mr. Washburn, but the Senate conferrees are not yet selected. When the bill was received from the House of Representatives this afternoon Mr. Frye promptly moved to agree to the conference asked for by the House.

The investigation into the affairs of the Sugar Trust that was -- the American Sugar Refineries Company that is -- was continued yesterday by the Senate Committee on General Laws at the Hotel Metropole. What Senator Erwin and his associate committeemen know about the trust now that they did not know before they entered upon the present tedious inquiry would not fill very many large volumes.

WHAT PEEL DID NOT KNOW. -- Peel regarded all light litterateurs as triflers, and poets with their unprofitable pursuits as the butterflies of the human species. Carlyle had prompted Milnes to press Tennyson's claims for a pension. The rival claimant was Sheridan Knowles, the popular dramatist.

When Winfield S. Davis went to his printing office in Nassau Street yesterday morning he found awaiting him three anonymous letters and a box wrapped in brown paper. The letters threatened him with bodily injury unless he kept to himself for the future his skeptical ideas about modern Spiritualism. He opened the box and found what was intended to pass for an infernal machine.
About 1,500 people attended the first indoor athletic meeting of the Seventy-first Regiment, held at the armory, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, last night. The results of the games were as follows:

BREACH OF PRIVILEGE. -- In both houses a standing order exists which declares that "it is a breach of privilege for any person whatsoever to print, or publish in print, anything relating to the proceedings of either house." Practically these orders have long since fallen into disuse, and it is only when debates are reported "mala fide" that the question of "breach of privilege" is raised.

New Friday Robert Somerville will sell at auction in the Fifth Avenue Galleries about seventy paintings and pastels by William M. Chase, the President of the Society of American Artists. Mr. Chase's style and methods are too well known to those who frequent the exhibitions of the National Academy of Design, of which he is also a member, that for them extended statement should be necessary.

ALL FEATHERS. -- The biggest of all really powerful flying birds are, I believe, the wandering albatross and the South American condor -- for the roc I reject outright as worthy only of the most restricted Arabian and nocturnal ornithology. Seen on the wing, or even with the wings expanded, merely, both these great existing birds have a most majestic and colossal appearance.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 28. -- Bowdoin's hopes of being admitted to the three-cornered eight-oared race this year have been blasted. It was announced some time ago that if the race should be rowed at some other place than New-London or Springfield, Bowdoin would be admitted. At these two places the courses are not wide enough to admit of four crews.

" At a dance the other evening," said a young woman, "a man whom I have been meeting out all Winter stared at me curiously for a moment, then passed on without bowing or speaking. Later he came to me with an explanation: Do you know, Miss Z.,' he said, 'I didn't recognize you this evening when I first saw you! I have never until to-night seen you without your bonnet.'

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 28. -- Sir Richard, Cartwright addressed a crowded meeting to-night, and in the course of his speech ran foul of Mr. Van Horne, President of the Canadian Pacific Railroad, whose two manifestoes in favor of the present protectionist Government and against reciprocity with the United States have attracted such general attention.

BISMARCK, N.D., Feb. 28. -- A prominent politician who has just returnee from St. Paul is treating his friends to some choice gossip regarding Alexander McKenzie, George E. Spencer of Louisiana Lottery fame, and other notables who aid in the manipulation of North Dakota politics. In responce to an inquiry he said:

The calendar Winter months that closed at midnight show rather unusual fluctuations of temperature and a high degree of precipitation, particularly for February. There were very few really bitterly cold days, although December was a cold month, and gave everybody the idea that we were in for a season of low temperatures to make up for the mild weather of the two previous years.

The sculptor, William H. Rhinehart, left $40,000 at the time of his death (1874) in the hands of William T. Walters and Benjamin F. Newcomer of Baltimore for use in the encouragement of art in that city. The fund now amounts to $95,000, and the trustees have offered it to the Peabody Institute in order that an art department may be established.

The new code of penalties which has at last been completed for the army will, with its formal promulgation, mark an important change in our system of military justice. The substitution of fixed maximum punishments for the discretion of the court-martial will secure, as far as is practicable, that uniformity which must be the basis of any equitable administration of law in the army, and it ought also to remove some causes of complaint.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28. -- The Johns Hopkins House of Commons was re-established Tuesday evening and promises to regain its old position as a popular and educating factor in university life. Mr. Vernon Cook was elected Speaker.

The Brooklyn Police Captains were an indignant set of men when THE TIMES exposed the little political deal back of their recent dinner at the Academy of Music. They were particularly incensed at the statement that they had forced assessments from politicians and office holders, and several of the men who hold high places on the force denounced this allegation as false.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28. -- The Chronicle's Honolulu letter, dated Feb. 13, says:

Discussion of Mr. Chanler's admirable scheme for founding an annual prize scholarship for the benefit of American art students wishing to pursue or "finish'' their studies in Paris has brought to my mind the necessity of beginning the charity much nearer home

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 28. -- The Executive Committee of the Western States Commercial Congress, to be held in Kansas City, commencing April 15, held its first meeting to-day and organized by selecting Senator H.B. Kelley of McPherson, Kan., as Chairman, and A.G. Stacey of Topeka, Kan., as Secretary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Senator George Hearst of California died here at 9:10 o'clock to-night, after a long illness.

In the affidavit in which Mayor CHAPIN of Brooklyn attempted to justify his agreement to buy the plant of the Long Island Water Supply Company he stated that he was a lawyer, familiar with statutes and their interpretation. Controller JACKSON, who was associated with the Mayor in the transaction, swore also that he was a lawyer, and both these officials had at their command the large legal learning of Corporation Counsel JENKS.

The recent ruling of Secretary PROCTOR that enlisted men must attend the post schools as a military duty, and that Congress in the establishment of these schools required such attendance, will presumably have the effect of materially increasing the numbers of those who are thus instructed. The institutions have never hitherto been on a wholly satisfactory footing.

LONDON, March 1. -- There was an active demand for discount during the past week. Money was scarcer. Discount houses were obliged to seek assistance to the amount of over 1,000,000 from the Bank of England, and raised their rates to about the Bank's minimum. The quotations were 3 per cent for three months, and 2 3/4 per cent for short.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 1. -- The largest pulp mill of the Remington Paper Company, about two miles below this city, was almost totally destroyed late last night by the high water, causing damages requiring about $50,000 to repair and killing John Murphy, an employe, aged sixty-eight. Eleven pulp grinders, the wheel, and various other machinery were carried down the river.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 1. -- Concerning the condition of the levees and the uneasy feeling produced along the Lower Mississippi by the continued rising of the water, the following information has been received.

ST. LOUIS, March 1. -- Brief dispatches from Montreal, Quebec, have announced the mysterious suicide there of a man going by the name of Lake, which was known to be an assumed name. Three years ago he landed in Montreal and immediately sought the companionship of dissolute characters. He drank and gambled a great deal and spent money freely.

The New-York City Association of Union ex-Prisoners of War will attend a public meeting at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday night, to be held under the auspices of the Union Prisoners of War National Memorial Association. They will meet at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at 7:15 o'clock and march to the Opera-House.

Mr. Jackson S. Schultz died yesterday afternoon at 2:15 o'clock at his residence, 303 East Seventeenth Street. The funeral services will be held Thursday morning at 10:30 o'clock at All Souls' Church, Madison Avenue, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1. -- The appointment of the Hon. Charles Foster as Secretary of the Treasury has without question removed any doubt that might have existed of the nomination of Major McKinley for Governor of Ohio. In the advocacy of his eligibility and the wisdom of forcing the tariff issue in the next Gubernatorial contest, no man in Ohio has outdone the ex-Governor in urging Mr. McKinley to the front.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- At the final business session of the Board of the National Council of Women there were present the five general officers and the representatives of the twelve associations now duly entered in the council lists. The board considered unfinished business and passed resolutions to the following effect:

A commission of eight physicians connected with the veterinary department of the University of Pennsylvania began last Saturday a series of experiments designed to show the effect of KOCH'S tuberculin upon consumptive cows. "It is estimated," said the Chairman, Dr. ZUILL, before the first injections were made, "that 50 percent, of the cases of consumption originate from the use of dairy products.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 1. -- To-day, Sunday, saw no cessation of the great political fight. Meetings were held only in Quebec, the French-Canadian province, but throughout the English provinces both parties continued the canvass for votes. Now that the campaign has narrowed down to three days, redoubled efforts are being put forth, as the fate of both parties still hangs in the balance.

A mass meeting of the taxpayers in conjunction with the School Trustees of the Fourth and Fifth Wards of Long Island City was held in the Fourth Ward Grammar School, in Astoria, on Saturday night, to protest against Mayor Gleason's interference in school matters and to condemn his Board of Education for assuming powers that did not belong to it.

The death of John Wesley occurred 100 years ago to-day, and the centennial will be fittingly observe almost throughout the world. Yesterday, in churches of all denominations, reference was made to his life and work, and in Methodist churches generally special services were held in his honor.

For nearly a year the leading musicians of this city have had in contemplation the formation of a club to be composed of professional and amateur musicians and lovers of music, and which, in its scope, would be similar to the Actors' Club or the Painters' Club. Among the promoters were Rudolph Archson, Jesse Williams, Alexander Lambert, J. Travis Quigg, and Americo Gori.

NEW-HAVEN, March 1. -- The refusal of Gov. David B. Hill of New-York State to grant a requisition in the case of Charles E. Fardon, the alleged thief, wanted in Connecticut for trial, is having a strong reaction on even the minds of the small class of Hill-admiring politicians in this State, and the general opinion now is that the Presidential aspirant instead of gaining in popularity made a serious mistake.

Charles E. Fardon, alleged burglar and friend of Gov. David B. Hill, walked out of the dingy little Essex Market Prison yesterday afternoon. Mr. Fardon has attained some notoriety from the fact that Gov. Hill refused to grant a requisition from Gov. Morgan G. Bulkeley of Connecticut for his return to that State, where a charge against him of burglary exists.

Walter Damrosch and his Metropolitan Opera House Orchestra gave yesterday in the big stone ampitheatre in Cooper Union the first of a series of free concerts for the people similar to those given at the same place last year with such great success. Mr. Damrosch gives his services and some generous friends of his and of Dr. Felix Adler pay all the expenses of the entertainments.

TRENTON, March 1. -- Marsh of Union is not the only statesman who is willing to take anything and everything that happens along his way. The two houses are full of Executive appointees, present and prospective. President Adrain is the real Prosecutor of Middlesex County, but he is not under appointment. He is merely designated by the court to act as Prosecutor pro tem.

The reported inclination of Senator BLAIR to decline the Chinese mission will rather be strengthened when he reads the history of ex-Senator PLATT'S excursion to Washington in regard to that office. It will confirm any suspicion that may have taken root in his mind that the appointment is equivalent to being "kicked up stairs" when he learns that the wily New-York "boss" tried hard to get rid of Mr. ERHARDT by that process.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 1. -- An enthusiastic mass meeting of Plainfield citizens was held in the Opera House this afternoon at 4 o'clock to protest against the three proposed laws to legalize pool selling and race-track gambling throughout the State, to give up to liquor saloons one-half of Sundays, and to reduce the license fee of saloons to a uniform figure of $100 in the various cities of New-Jersey.

The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix spoke plainly to his parishioners yesterday of the responsibility resting upon the congregation of Trinity Church to care for the poor and needy in the lower wards of New-York and of the charity which begins at home and confines itself to its legitimate field as respects church work in general He said:

YUMA, Arizona, March 1. -- Yuma is a camp of distress. Out of 150 houses composing the town only 50 remain. The second high water of the Gila River on Thursday was more disastrous than that of Sunday. The canals have been washed out, the ranches destroyed, and the railroads are under water. The loss in Yuma is half a million.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 1. -- Hermon, St. Lawrence County, a village of about six hundred inhabitants, six miles from De Kalb Junction, was visited this morning by a terrible conflagration. About midnight fire appeared in the business part of the town in a store owned by J.H. Phelps. It spread with irresistible force and lightning speed until it had lapped up about twenty buildings and entailed a loss of upward of $70,000.

A close approximation of the results obtained by the Bennington in her trial Saturday shows that she compares very favorably throughout with both the Yorktown and Concord. The figures are interesting as showing that a marked progress is being made in the quality of work done on the latest ships, and that, at the same time, the same specifications may bring forth vessels of varying capacity and ability.

It is a sign not without encouragement for the friends of honest methods in the Government service that the Civil Service Reform Committee of the House has presented to that body a report recommending changes in the law that have for their obvious purpose the strengthening of the reform system and a more logical and effective application of the principles of the reform.

The dedication of the new Sands Street Methodist Episcopal Church of Brooklyn, at the corner of Clark and Henry Streets, occurred yesterday. The ceremony took the nature of a memorial, and services were held morning, afternoon, and evening. At every service the ample seating capacity was taxed. That of the morning, at 10:30 o'clock, opened with a voluntary by A.L. Shultz, organist of the church, and was followed by Gounod's anthem, "Praise Ye the Father."

This translation of one of the most minute and painstaking of the many lives of Columbus has appeared very opportunely, at a time when the four hundredth anniversary of the great discoverer's crowning exploit is so near at hand. Though evidently written by a warm admirer of the famous Genoese, the work is happily free from that extravagant and unreasoning adulation with which Johnson was bedaubed by Boswell, and Frederick the Great by Carlyle.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 1. -- A destructive Winter thunder storm, accompanied by lightning, visited this city about 9 o'clock last night. In the city proper not much damage was done, but in South Dartmouth, Dartmouth, Westport, and Mattapoisett the lightning played havoc, destroying no less than six buildings and causing serious injury to two churches.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 1. -- Several of the statesmen in Congress are claiming to be the originators of the so-called "Sub-Treasury bill." While there is no credit in being the author of such a scheme, it may be as well to give its origin and its evil effects when first put into operation.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 1. -- THE TIMES'S correspondent called to-day on Judge George F. Danforth, Chairman of the Commission on Constitutional Revision, and asked him what recommendations had been agreed upon for submission to the Legislature. The Judge stated that the report of the commission would be presented to the Legislature early this week.

The Postal Subsidy bill as it passed the House was yesterday accepted by the Senate and is pretty certain to receive the President's approval. Its fate is likely to be different from that of a somewhat similar measure passed just before President CLEVELAND went into office, Postmaster General VILAS having refused to exercise the authority given him to pay a subsidy for carrying the foreign mails.

ROME, March 2. -- The Pope to-day is receiving congratulations upon the occasion of the eighty-first anniversary of his birthday. He was born March 2, 1810, and was elected to the Papacy upon the death of Pope Pius IX., being crowned March 3, 1878.
PORTLAND, Me., March 2. -- Following are results in municipal elections in this State to-day:

McPHERSON, Kan., March 2. -- The Second National Bank of this city closed its doors at 11 o'clock to-day. Some time last night Augustus Hegglund, President of the bank, was shot and now lies at the point of death. So much mystery enshrouds the affair that a great deal of excitement prevails here and in the surrounding country, where the customers of the bank reside.

The greater part of the time at the hearing yesterday before Surrogate Ransom in the contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather was taken up with an attempt on the part of the contestants to prove, by further questioning of Thomas G. Ritch, one of the executors and a residuary legatee, that the residuary legatees were to receive the residuary estate under a secret trust.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 2. -- John Tucker, one of the best-known and most popular young men of this city, is a prisoner to-night at the Elizabeth Police Headquarters, charged with embezzling money from the Singer Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A great many persons have come to Washington to see the Fifty-first Congress die. The hotels are full of them, and all day long they have streamed through the halls of the Capitol, a crowd of eager and interested men and women, who enter the galleries and depart from them without having gained the slightest idea of how legislation is carried on.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 2. -- A very brief account of a whisky war in the mountains of Johnson County has reached here. It comes in such a way as to make the story absolutely reliable. Several months ago the notorious Wright and Potter gangs of Kentucky emigrated from that State to Johnson County, and soon became involved in trouble with the inhabitants.

The proceedings that have been taken in Paris since the departure of the ex-Empress of Germany cannot be very full of encouragement to adult Frenchmen. It seems that the object of the whole demonstration, so far as it was organized, was to galvanize Boulangism into some resemblance to life, and put the "hero of the concert saloons" into a position where he could be made available at the next turn of the political wheel.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 2. -- At a meeting of the Louisville Ministerial Association to-day the question of admitting Catholic priests, Jewish rabbis, and Unitarian ministers provoked a warm debate.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Judge Thomas Wilson of Minnesota was here to-day. He lacked a few votes of being elected Governor of Minnesota, and he is hopeful of the success of the Democratic ticket in the State in 1892.

HARTFORD, March 2. -- Up to the time for closing the Executive Department offices this afternoon Gov. Bulkeley had not seen the officers from Danbury, who were expected to come here for requisition papers to bring back to Connecticut Colbert, the horse thief, traced by Danbury officials to Carmel, a town in New-York State.

VIENNA, March 2. -- Elections for members o the lower house of the Reichsrath have commenced in the rural districts. Lower Austria has returned seven anti-Semitics and one Clerical, the Liberals losing four seats.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Senate has agreed to the Postal Subsidy bill, sent to it by the House of Representatives as a substitute for the Shipping bill, and the subsidy hunters must be contented with half a loaf instead of the whole lump they have been seeking.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 2. -- The Hennessy case took a very sensational turn this morning in the undoubted confession of one of the nine Italians now on trial. His statement was taken in Chambers and was not made public.

Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa learned yesterday with interest that Mrs. Yseult Dudley, who shot him in the back in Chambers Street and tried to kill him in 1885, was at Liverpool en route to Broadmoor Asylum, England.

For a year past there has been much discussion in the public-school circles of the Twenty-third Ward over the erection by the Board of Education of two immense schools a few blocks apart and what seemed to be a great deal of favoritism in the appointment of Principals for them.

Another gentleman who must be told by the Philadelphia Press that the price of carpets has not been increased is Mr. ARTHUR T. LYMAN, Treasurer of the Lowell Carpet Company and Vice President of the American Carpet Manufacturers' Association. As a member and representative of the Executive Committee of the Wool Consumers' Association, Mr. LYMAN published the following on the 28th ult.:

An official announcement from Washington declares that the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, under its authority to construct railroad approaches to the bridge, will proceed at once to solve the rapid-transit problem. These cheering tidings come from an authority no less reliable than Charles H. Swan, who must be conceded to know more about the purposes of the above-named corporation than has ever appeared in print.

At the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Monday 2, by order of the Superior Court, in auctioneer, sold three lots, each 25 by 100.7, on East 136th St, northside, 104 feet east of Southern Boulevard for $24.000, to Frederick C. McCormack, confror. Esq.,

Citizen William Ziegler and Attorney William J. Gaynor held a reception in the Special Term room of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Lawyers and politicians, both Republican and Democratic, crowded about them and congratulated them on their victory over the forces that had tried so hard to compel the taxpayers to buy the Long Island Water Supply Company's plant at the exorbitant price of $1,250,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- New-York and Pennsylvania indulged in a "kissing match" in the House to-day. The Philadelphia people have been anxious to secure an appropriation for a new building for the United States Mint. The New-York delegation has been equally anxious to get authority to build a new Custom House. Mr. Bingham, for Philadelphia, and Mr. Flower, for New-York, were the respective managers of the two bills for the purposes indicated.

Citizen William Ziegler and Attorney William J. Gaynor held a reception in the Special Term room of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Lawyers and politicians, both Republican and Democratic, crowded about them and congratulated them on their victory over the forces that had tried so hard to compel the taxpayers to buy the Long Island Water Supply Company's plant at the exorbitant price of $1,250,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- New-York and Pennsylvania indulged in a "kissing match" in the House to-day. The Philadelphia people have been anxious to secure an appropriation for a new building for the United States Mint. The New-York delegation has been equally anxious to get authority to build a new Custom House. Mr. Bingham, for Philadelphia, and Mr. Flower, for New-York, were the respective managers of the two bills for the purposes indicated.

PITTSBURG, March 2. -- Mrs. Fitch, wife of Lieut. T.W. Fitch, nee Sherman, gave some interesting details to-day concerning the proposed sale of the famous Khedive jewels, presented to her by the Egyptian ruler upon her marriage fifteen years ago.

The shallowness of Gov. HILL'S bit of partisan clap-trap in refusing to honor Gov. BULKELEY'S requisition for the surrender of a Connecticut criminal because it would be a recognition of his title to office is effectually exposed by the proof that he had already recognized BULKELEY more than once since Judge MORRIS was declared by the Senate at Hartford to have been elected and went through the form of taking the oath of office.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 2. -- The little State of Delaware is in the midst of one of the biggest sensations that it has enjoyed for years. Ex-State Treasurer William Herbert, one of its most trusted citizens, it is charged, is short in his accounts about $34,417.75, and the State securities which were intrusted in his hands for safe keeping, valued at about $70,000, are missing.

The attempt to naturalize American trotters in England is one of the most innocent enterprises in which the Duke of MARLBOROUGH has been engaged. That nobleman has bought in Kentucky five very well-bred mares with the intention of forming a stud. It is not likely that he will succeed.

Among the numerous bills pending in the Legislature which relate to the subject of taxation is one introduced in the Assembly by the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, upon which a hearing was given at Albany yesterday. It is intended to establish in this State what is generally known as the "listing system," though that term is avoided in the bill, a tacit recognition of the odium with which it is regarded.

HARTFORD, March 3. -- There is a decided prospect that the dead-look in the Legislature will be broken during the week. The two parties have exchanged propositions with the view of adjusting the controversy, and on the strength of the Republican offer the Senate ordered an adjournment within ten minutes after being called to order this afternoon.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 3. -- The discovery made public yesterday that certain gilt-edge securities of the State of Delaware supposed to have been in the custody of ex-State Treasurer William Herbert were missing has disclosed the remarkable fact that Mr. Herbert and at least three of his immediate predecessors never saw any of these securities and merely took it for granted that they were in existence.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 3. -- It became known here to-day that the remains of Emma Abbott, the opera singer, were cremated in Pittsburg two weeks ago yesterday. The dead singer's mother, even, is not yet aware of the cremation. For three weeks the reporters of Chicago, New-York, Detroit, and Pittsburg have been waiting patiently for the announcement of the day of the cremation.

There is a prospect that the Supreme Court of Connecticut may be called upon to settle the election dispute which has kept the Legislature of that State in a deadlock for nearly two months. There have been three propositions made, having in view an appeal to the judiciary, and it now looks as though the two houses might come to an agreement before the present week is over.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- The reception this evening given by Mr. Cassatt to his colleagues of the Inter-Continental Railway Commission at his residence on West Rittenhouse Square was one of the most notable affairs of its kind ever given in this city. Over 700 invitations had been sent out and over 500 gentlemen, representing nearly every walk of life, were present.

The Republicans in the Senate will have an opportunity before noon to-day to save their party from a disgrace with which Mr. HARRISON and Mr. WANAMAKER threaten it. The President has asked the advice and consent of the Senate for the appointment of the notorious WILLIAM R. LEEDS of Philadelphia to be Marshal of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

The investigation by Coroner Levy and his jury of representative citizens into the fatal collision that occurred in the Grand Central tunnel on Feb. 20 was resumed yesterday, after a three-days' rest. All the jurors were present except John D. Crimmins.

What looks like a row of large dimensions seems to be on at Columbia College, and threatens to destroy the Law School of that institution. The resignation of Prof. George Chase and Prof. Robert D. Petty Monday, as was noted in THE TIMES yesterday, following the resignation of Prof. Theodore W. Dwight, the veteran Warden of the Law School, confirmed fears that serious dissensions have occurred. Columbia men talked of little else yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., March. 3. -- The race-course bills attracted to the Assembly Chamber this afternoon one of the most notable gatherings of women that ever graced the hall. There were probably fifty of them, all told, and ten counties of the State were represented. Mrs. J.H. Knowles, wife of the Rev. Dr. Knowles, Mrs. Charles E. Hill, Mrs. Polhemus, Mrs. Plume, Mrs. Roff, and Mrs. Dennis were conspicuous in the fashionably-attired throng.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 3. -- Representatives of the Harvard and Yale Boat Clubs met the representatives of the New-London Board of Trade at the Crocker House, New-London, yesterday, and drew up a set of stipulations under which these colleges agree to row on the Thames course for five years more.

ST. LOUIS, March 3. -- A new phase was added to the baseball war to-day when the President of the St. Louis Club tried to have Mark Baldwin arrested. Mr. Von Der Ahe, his attorney Walter McEntire, his Secretary George Munson, and Al Spink called upon Assistant Prosecuting Attorney Thomas Estep to swear out a warrant, charging conspiracy against Mark Baldwin, manager of the Pittsburg Baseball Club.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- There was a whirl of excitement at the Capitol to-day, but it was principally in the lobby. The closing hours of a Congress are commonly exciting, but during ten years of Congress there has never been a time at the end of the second session when the lobbyists were so thick and so desperately active.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 3. -- Detective Bedford of Atlanta this morning arrested S.E. Barton, President of the Electric Mutual Insurance Company and agent of the Royal Insurance Company of Liverpool, the Germania of London, and the Pennsylvania of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- President Harrison has waited until the last night of the session to make a nomination that will disgust every decent citizen of Pennsylvania in general and of Philadelphia in particular. Late this afternoon he sent to the Senate the nomination of the notorious William R. Leeds of Philadelphia to be Marshal of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

According to the terms of the bill authorizing the erection of a new Custom House on the Bow ling Green site, the proceeds of the sale of the present Custom House are to be used in paying for the new one, and the Secretary of the Treasury is directed to sell the Wall Street property "for not less than $4,000,000."

NEW-ORLEANS, March 3. -- This was the sixteenth day of the Hennessy trial. The evidence is gathering thicker around the accused, and the prospects look very blue for them. Nothing more about the confession of the man Manuel Politz was disclosed to-day, but there was damaging evidence introduced against him.

Philip A. Smyth, Secretary of the Real Estate Exchange, was voted out of office by the Directors of that institution yesterday afternoon and James E. Leviness was elected to the place. The change thus made was a move in the struggle which is going on between the Board of Directors and the auctioneers.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The first session of the second annual convention of State Railroad Commissioners, accounting officers, and others similarly interested in railroad matters was to-day held in the rooms of the Inner-State Commerce Commission.

There was a christening in Central Park yesterday afternoon. Nine days ago yesterday the second baby of the season arrived in the family of sacred cows, and Keeper Phil Holmes decided that it was time to name the infant, which, by the way, is a lively little heifer, pretty and perfectly healthy.

Assembly Tax bill No. 614 has met with the opposition of President Coleman of the Tax Department. He sent a letter to the Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment yesterday, in which he said that the bill as now drawn would be injurious to both city and State. He added:

Armand Behic, whose death in Paris is announced, was the Director of the Messageries Maritimes, and it is to him that is due the efficiency of the commercial service between France and her colonies. Holding his office under the Government, he occupied in fact, if not in name, the situation of colonial merchant navy minister. His entire life had fitted him for it.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 3. -- Gen. Russell A. Alger passed through Birmingham Saturday last, and it was given out that the was on his way to Florida. He was met at the station here by Col. Noble A. Smithson, a leading Republican, by special appointment, and they had a long conference.

It is interesting to watch the helpless twistings and turnings of a man like Senator PLUMB when he undertakes to attack in public the reform of the civil service. As a politician of not too high grade Mr. PLUMB hates the reform system. He dislikes to give up the power over patronage, of which it deprives him, and of which weaker or better men are glad to be rid.

A number of exporters of this city have been receiving letters from West Africa, especially from Cape Coast Castle, lately, on which they have had to pay from 15 to 20 cents unpaid postage. As these letters are mainly requests for price lists and circulars, they are growing tired of expending their money and sent a complaint to the Post Office yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 3. -- The municipal election here to-day closed an exciting canvass. The city offices to be filled were those of one member of the Executive Board, City Treasurer, and Aldermen in about half of the wards.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 3. -- The Duke of Marlborough, England, has bought of A.J. Alexander, Spring Station, Ky., the following trotting stock:

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Transito Hurtarte, widow of Gen. Barrundia, in her own name, as the representative of her six minor daughters, and Ramon Beugoechea, as the representative of his wife, Teresa Barrundia de Beugoechea, have filed with the Secretary of State a claim against the United States for $1,000,000 for having surrendered Gen. Barrundia to the Guatemalan authorities, at whose hands he lost his life.

There were few developments in the Brooklyn water scandal yesterday. Corporation Counsel Jenks had gone to Albany to appear before an Assembly committee in reference to certain local bills, and his successful opponent, William J. Gaynor, had gone to the same city to argue a case before the Court of Appeals. Mayor Chapin might as well have gone away, for he refused to talk to reporters or to disseminate any information if he had any.

PARIS, March 3. -- The Marquis de Breteuil and Miss Lita Garner were married to-day at Pau. All the nobility of the Basque provinces were present at the wedding. The civil ceremony was performed in the Town Hall. At the conclusion of the marriage the Mayor congratulated the happy couple, and in the course of his remarks he said that the Marquis had opponents, but no enemies.

Irvington-on-the-Hudson was taken possession of yesterday afternoon by a wedding party which left this city on a special train to be present at the marriage of Miss Marion Langdon and Royal Phelps Carroll at the old Alexander Hamilton homestead. Miss Langdon is the daughter of the late Eugene Langdon, and stepdaughter of Philip Schuyler.

ALBANY, March 3. -- To persons acquainted with the methods of David B. Hill there was no question but that in the course of time Judge William B. Ruggles, who had been the legal mainstay of the Insurance Department for the past five years, would have to succumb to the demands of a party organization that had no regard for merit and was looking only for blackmail.

All the shining lights in the baseball world were present at the meeting of the League held in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. It was like all gatherings of baseball men of late -- anything but harmonious. Early in the day the delegates began to squabble, and they continued until it was time for all respectable citizens to be abed.

Cornwall Brothers of Louisville, Ky., soap manufacturers, made an assignment last night. A statement of the liabilities cannot be obtained to-night but they are estimated at $500,000. William Cornwall, Sr., William Cornwall, Jr., and Aaron Cornwall each made an individual assignment, which were precipitated by the filing of several suits against them by local banks.

LONDON, March 3. -- The Right Hon. James Stanfield, member for Halifax, in moving that the House amend the electoral law by enacting that nobody can vote in more than one electoral area, that the term qualifying a person to vote be reduced to three months, and that the act of registration be simplified, argued that the present system is entirely out of date.

Let us analyze the presentment of the February Grand Jury in regard to violations of the excise law into its constituent elements and try to ascertain the method and purpose of the compounders of the mixture.

ALBANY, March 3. -- A bill that ought to be killed before it is a day older was ordered to third reading in the Senate to-day. It is an innocent looking measure -- for that matter all vicious measures are innocent enough looking. It was introduced Feb. 11 by Judge Robertson, and its two first lines read, "Subdivision 7 of Section 594 of the Penal Code is hereby repealed."
The jury which under the direction of Coroner Levy has been investigating the recent collision in the Fourth Avenue tunnel yesterday practically finished its work.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 4. -- When David B. Hill awoke this morning he heard something drop. The news from the various towns in the State which held elections yesterday was not encouraging to the Democratic Senator, who, after the terrific tidal wave of last Fall that was looked upon as having wrecked the Republican Party irretrievably, believed that the Democrats would sweep the State in the Spring.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- While the bill to provide for international copyright, which has finally become a law, is not entirely satisfactory to any of the friends of such a copyright, and is particularly unsatisfactory to its opponents, all of its advocates feel that a most gratifying victory has been gained in securing from the American Congress an indorsement of the principle of international copyright.

ALBANY, March 4. -- That Senator Stewart is becoming expert in the methods of legislation was proved to-day. He had a subway bill, which he bunched with several others, and which, in his most demure and quiet tones, he requested to be ordered to third reading.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 4. -- The action of Gov. Bulkeley in sending the name of Dr. Joseph W. Alsop of Middletown, who was elected by the Democrats as Lieutenant Governor in November, to the Senate this afternoon for confirmation as member of the State Board of Agriculture for four years from July next, was not calculated to advance the efforts now in progress for a settlement of the legislative controversy.

It has been proved over and over again that "prohibition does not prohibit" -- that is to say, that intoxicating liquors are extensively sold and drank in States where the sale of them is forbidden by law. The brewers in this city, however, have just supplied the Prohibitionists with a piece of evidence that prohibition at least diminishes the consumption of intoxicating drinks.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Fifty-first Congress expired to-day at noon, according to law, promptly as to Mr. Reed's end of it, and therefore with a sort of consistency to his boasted "business" policy, and with some delay and the customary setting back of the clock on the part of the more deliberate Senate. In the Senate the end came with decorum and without picturesqueness.
NYACK, N.Y., March 4. -- At the town elections in Rockland County yesterday the Democrats elected two. This is the first time in many years that two Republican Supervisors have been chosen.

When Mr. ROBESON was Secretary of the Navy it used to be said that the function of an American man-of-war was to serve as "a basis for repairs." One is inclined to apply that expression to the Copyright bill as it passed Congress and went to the President for his signature. The application is not wholly just, because the bill has one very great and positive merit.

ST. LOUIS, March 4. -- Isador Frauenthal of this city, who committed suicide at Cincinnati this morning, together with Ernst Sallinger of Philadelphia, was eighteen years of age. His parents reside at 1,512 Lafayette Avenue. He had been attending the Union Hebrew Seminary of Theology at Cincinnati since Sept. 1. The boy was widely known in St. Louis, and was considered to have exceptional intelligence and learning for one of his age.
TORONTO, Ontario, March 4. -- Oarsman William O'Connor offers to row John Teemer for from $1,000 to $5,000 a side in June or July, if a course can be mutually agreed upon.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Senator Saxton's concurrent resolution proposing an amendment to Section 10, Article III, of the Constitution, in these words, "The election, return, and qualifications of any member of either house of the Legislature, when disputed or contested, shall be determined by the courts in such manner as the Legislature shall prescribe, and such determination, when made, shall be conclusive upon the Legislature," has passed the Senate -- 17 to 8.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- A great crowd turned out here last night to hear Senators-elect Peffer and Kyle and Representative-elect Jerry Simpson address the Citizens' Alliance in Grand Army Hall. Peffer and Kyle surprised everybody by displaying more than ordinary oratorical ability, and Mr. Simpson created great enthusiasm by his vigorous eloquence, that was attractive, although unconventional.

OTTAWA, March 4. -- The future fiscal policy of Canada will be determined at the polls to-morrow. Never since confederation has a political struggle been waged with such vigor and acrimony as the present campaign. A blinding snow storm raged throughout Central Canada all day. The roads in the country are almost impassable, and as a result the vote which will be polled in Ontario and Quebec will probably not be heavy.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 4. -- The Democratic and Alliance State Senators are in high feather to-night over the fact that they have secured the publication of the evidence of corruption in the famous Washburn-Sabin contest, the greatest campaign card of the year. The evidence is of the most damaging character, and, after reading it, one cannot get away from the belief that at least $10,000 was used in the Senatorial contest.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4. -- Capt. Dana announced this evening the result of the month's practice of the baseball men in the choice of sixteen men who are to constitute the nine and substitutes. Brokaw, '92; Woods, '92, and Humphrey, '94, will be the catchers. Young, Bergen, Woodcock, and Drake are the pitchers, Capt. Dana first base, Durell second, Knickerbocker short stop, King third.

In marked contrast with the attitude and remarks of Mr. REED was the modest and dignified farewell with which Vice President MORTON acknowledged the deserved tribute of gratitude and esteem offered him by the Senate. The Speaker was defiant to the last, and intimated to the members of both parties that his conduct, arbitrary and rude as it had often been, was no more than the majority desired and the minority deserved.

LONDON, March 4. -- Mr. Leonard W. Jerome of New-York, who was recently removed from London to Brighton, in the hope that his health, which had been in a precarious state for some time, might be improved, died last night. Mr. Jerome's wife and daughters were present at his bedside when he passed away.
Madison Square Garden put on the appearance of Summer yesterday when the vast interior became redolent with perfume and bright with color in honor of the opening of the orchid show.

The suit of James M. Bloomfield against his wife, Martha S. Bloomfield, for absolute divorce, on the statutory grounds, was continued in the Court House at White Plains, yesterday, before Justice J.O. Dykman and a jury. The plaintiff is a jeweler, being a member of the firm of Oliver Bloomfield of John Street, this city. He was married in Brooklyn Nov. 22, 1882, to Martha S. Oliver, a daughter of his partner.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 4. -- The Board of Trustees of Vassar College met in the institution to-day, President Edward Lathrop, D.D., of New-York in the chair. Out of the twenty-nine members of the board only eight were absent. The proposition made by the next-of-kin heirs of John Guy Vassar not to contest the will so far as Vassar College is concerned if paid $146,200 was considered by the board.

It is a disgrace that such a measure as the rumsellers' excise bill should even have to be seriously opposed before a legislative committee. There ought to be no occasion for the supporters of salutary restriction upon the liquor traffic to go to Albany to point out the objections to a measure so infamous.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 5. -- Sir John Macdonald and his Tory Government are probably sustained by a slight majority. Incomplete returns give the Conservatives 101 and the Liberals 89 seats respectively. When the back counties are heard from, if the Liberal gains continue, the Premier's majority of 51 when Parliament was dissolved will be still further reduced.

Our Washington dispatches describe a trick of the Republican leaders to avoid a part of the responsibility for expenditures made necessary by their action. A new mint building was authorized at a cost of at least $2,000,000, but the money was not appropriated, and beyond the preparation of the plans in the Supervising Architect's office nothing can be done until the next Congress provides the funds.

VIENNA, March 5. -- The Austrian elections were concluded to-day. The returns thus far received show the election of 58 German Liberals, 7 German Nationals, 28 Young Czechs, 9 Old Czechs, 4 Independent Czechs, 15 Catholic Conservatives, 13 Slavonians, 31 Poles, 8 Ruthenians, 2 Roumanians, (Anti-Semitics,) and 8 not classed in any party. Eight supplementary ballots are necessary.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 5, via Galveston, Texas. -- The concessionaires of the Torolobampo Railroad have deposited the forfeit required by law, and there is every probability that this road soon be built, as the Government is very anxious to have the line completed and has granted it liberal concesions.

The officers of the Children's Aid Society are daily having brought to their attention by the Principals of their industrial schools distressing cases of destitution and suffering. These schools are situated in the poorest neighborhoods of the city, and their teachers are brought into the closest contact with poverty under all conditions and in its most aggravated forms.

Everything has been arranged to start the baseball season of 1891 as far as the League is concerned. The Cincinnati Club has been admitted to membership, a committee has been appointed to look after the club's interests, and the schedule of games has been adopted. Unless Old Probabilities interferes, practice games will begin in the latter part of this month and the regular struggle for championship laurels will start on April 22.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 5. -- The drawing for the long and short terms occurred in the Senate this afternoon, and was witnessed by an immense crowd. There was great excitement, and an effort was made by the men from odd-numbered districts to postpone the lottery. Arnold said that the even-district men all looked so confident and smiling that he feared a "job had been put up."

That part of the verdict concerning the tunnel collision which relates to the car stove is sufficiently positive and clear. The New-Haven Company is held "immediately responsible for the deaths by suffocation and burning of JOHN MURRAY and JAMES B. FLYNN," which were caused, it is stated, by the upsetting of the stove in one of the wrecked cars.

The Hartford and New-York Transportation Company's sidewheel steamer City of Richmond was burned yesterday afternoon in the north slip of Pier 24 East River. One man, a negro waiter, was suffocated to death, and another man and a boy, also waiters, are missing. The loss is within $100,000.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5. -- The striking spinners at the Clark Thread Mills have been watching for the return of Treasurer Clark from his European trip with solicitude. They had heard that the purpose of Mr. Clark's foreign tour was to find employment elsewhere for Walmesley, the detested Mill Superintendent, and so eliminate him from the discussions between the hands and their employers on this side of the ocean.

CLEVELAND, March 5. -- "The Administration has put its foot into it again" was the way in which a stalwart Republican to-day referred to the appointment of A.T. Anderson as Postmaster. In a recent issue THE TIMES contained a dispatch describing the fight between the Anderson and Avery factions in this city. The feeling was bitter, though outwardly the candidates professed the highest regard for each other.

" Senator Quay is advised to take a rest. The advice comes from a Democratic contemporary." It is fair to remind the Philadelphia Press, from which the above is taken, that the same advice which it refers to has been given by such good Republican papers as the New-Haven Palladium, the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, and even by the Boston Journal.

We hope our high-tariff friends will not overlook a letter written by Mr. A.B. FARQUHAR and read by Col. McCLURE of Philadelphia at Kennett Square, Penn., on the 2d inst., in the course of a debate concerning tariff duties. Mr. FARQUHAR is the Chairman of the A.B. Farquhar Company, Limited, whose great factories are at York, Penn. -- one of the largest corporations engaged in manufacturing agricultural implements.

Having committed the blunder of refusing to recognize BULKELEY as "the Executive" of the State of Connecticut in the case of the requisition for the burglar FARDON, after having previously recognized him in making requisitions for fugitives from justice in Connecticut, Gov. HILL could not honor the requisition for the horse thief COLBERT without putting himself in a ridiculous plight.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 5. -- Niagara Falls has a sensation of no small magnitude in the arrest recently of Walter Jones, President of the Niagara Wood Paper Company of that village, on the charge of publishing in the Niagara Falls Gazette a statement concerning the liabilities of the company vhich he knew to be false and untrue.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 5. -- Gov. Hill refused again to-day to recognize Morgan G. Bulkeley as Governor of Connecticut. A requisition was presented for John T. Colbert, who is wanted in Danbury for alleged horse stealing, and who is now in the Putnam County Jail, at Carmel, on a twenty-day sentence as a fugitive from justice.

" The new Tariff bill," says the Tribune, "was a magnificent result of the Fifty-first Congress. It is yet to be fully appreciated by the people. With great wisdom, Speaker REED declared in his admirable closing address that time and distance were needed to ripen judgment regarding the action of Congress, and that the verdict of history, the only verdict worth recording, had not yet been recorded."

The Indian Appropriation bill has among its provisions an item for the so-called "Courts of Indian Offenses." The Judges in these tribunals are Indians exclusively, and in some cases there are other court officers who also are Indians. It may surprise many people to learn that these courts are in operation at nearly thirty agencies and that there are nearly one hundred Indian Judges regularly employed.

The responsibility for the fatal collision that occurred in the Grand Central Depot tunnel on the morning of Feb. 20, in which six lives were lost, has been placed by twelve representative citizens of this city who for two days past have been sitting as a Coroner's jury on the case upon the shoulders of the officers and Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.

The motion for a receiver in the suit brought by the Attorney General for the dissolution of the American Loan and Trust Company will be called before Judge Beach, in Supreme Court, Chambers, this morning. Unless a plan of reorganization shall have been agreed on by the persons interested in reorganizing the company, who will hold a meeting earlier in the morning, the motion will probably be argued.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Three communications, sent to Congress in the last hours of the session, from the Secretary of the Navy, attracted no attention at the time, and almost escaped notice altogether. They were the long-delayed replies to the resolutions of inquiry concerning steel, adopted by the Senate and House of Representatives last September.

ALBANY, March. 5. -- There has been a good deal said of late concerning the failure of the American Casualty Insurance and Security Company of Baltimore to secure a certificate of authority to do business in New-York State. About all the criticism of the administration of Superintendent of Insurance Maxwell was based on his continued refusal to admit this company.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 5. -- The Republicans left the Capitol this afternoon without having advanced a step toward the ending of the deadlock. The bill which the party proposed last Tuesday should be submitted for carrying the controversy into the courts was not completed this afternoon, when a recess was ordered until March 10, on account of the absence of a quorum.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The opponents of the whisky bill which David B. Hill is trying to force through the Legislature had a brief hearing today before the Assembly Committee on Excise. It seems to be the policy of the Senator and his friends of the Liquor Dealers' Association to give those who recognize the dangerous provisions of the bill as little time as possible to point them out.

The etchings of William Strang, one of the most successful pupils of Prof. Alphonse Legros of London, have already appeared with Herman Wunderlich, and now the master's work is shown by Frederick Keppel in the little gallery in East Sixteenth Street. Specimens of his crayon work and painting in oils are added to the mezzotints, dry points, and etchings for which he is best known.

The Senate at Albany is wasting its time in a rather trivial contest for which there is no reason that in any way affects the interests of the public. The Constitution requires the Senate to "choose a temporary President, when the Lieutenant Governor shall not attend as President or shall act as Governor."

NEW-ORLEANS, March 5. -- The Hennessy case continues to furnish sensational testimony. This morning the court room was jammed, and it remained so as long as the court was in session. This morning Amos Scott, a colored boy, told how the fourteen-year-old boy, Aspeeri Marchesi, met him in the Pogras market three days after the shooting.

The Conservative Party and Sir JOHN MACDONALD met with a serious reverse in the Dominion elections yesterday, and although there will probably be a Conservative majority it will be too small for effective Parliamentary work. At the dissolution Sir JOHN had a majority of 51, the Conservatives having 132 seats and the Liberals 81.

The answer of Lawyers James M. and William M. Lyddy to the order requiring them to show cause why they should not be disbarred for professional misconduct, was submitted to the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday. The Lyddys requested until Monday to put in an additional affidavit, and the request was granted.

The monthly meeting and dinner of the Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island, which occurred last night at Clark's, in West Twenty-third Street, was rendered notable by reason of the fact that it was made the occasion for the first unfoldment of the plan and scope of the great Baptist University of Chicago about which there has been so much interest and speculation in educational as well as religious and denominational circles.

Those who are fond of entertainment of song are numerous in this music-loving town, if any, judgmnent may be based on the large number of persons present at two concerts yesterday. In the afternoon an audience which nearly filled the roomy auditorium of Chikering Hall assembled to listen to Miss Lena Little sing German, French, and English songs, with two intermissions in which Alexander Lambert played the plano.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 5. -- There is great indignation expressed here on account of a petition, now being circulated by those interested in the advancement of the Standard Oil Company, asking the President to appoint Judge John H. Doyle to the position of United States Circuit Judge under the act recently passed by Congress. There is a strong probability of his appointment.

The inability of ex-State Treasurer WILLIAM HERBERT of Delaware to explain satisfactorily what has become of $34,417.75 in cash and $70,000 in securities belonging to the State and lately in his care as Treasurer moves the Hartford Courant to ask, "What is the matter with the Democratic State Treasurers?" and it recalls several instances in which trust has been betrayed and public funds squandered by Treasurers belonging to that party.

The sale of the collection of valuable books formed by Mr. Brayton Ives was begun at the American Art Association's Rooms in Madison Square yesterday. In two sessions of three hours each there were sold 445 lots, realizing $40,366.75 in one session and about $20,000 in the other.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Indian Commissioner Morgan has discovered once more that he is not a bigger man than the Secretary of the Interior. Somebody started the story last Fall that the Indians who had been taken abroad by Col. William F. Cody to take part in the "Wild West" had been badly treated and were surrounded by degrading influences.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 6. -- The Times-Democrat's Austin (Texas) special says: "The House today passed the Railway Commission bill, known as the Terrell substitute, with the Gresham amendment. The amendment, in effect, provides that the commission may authorize the railroads to charge more for short than long hauls where it may be necessary to prevent manifest public injury; providing, also, that no manifest injustice shall be imposed upon any citizen at any intermediate point.

" Under the guise of a compliment to our President, ex-Judge William H. Arnoux, we have met here to welcome the leaders who fought our fights and won our victories in the last Congress. We welcome Reed, we welcome Lodge, and we regret that McKinley is not with us."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 6. -- Prof. Howard Osgood of the Rochester Theological Seminary has taken up the cudgels in defense of the Rev. Mr. Anderson's position in the controversy over the Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor and the eligibility of Universalists to become members. The Herald to-morrow morning will contain a communication over his name on the subject.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- An order will be issued soon announcing the apportionment that has been made of army and navy officers among the States as professors of military science and tactics in educational institutions under the new law, which increases the number allowed to be detailed from fifty to eighty-five, of whom seventy-five shall be army officers and ten navy officers.
