BOSTON, March 6. -- Archbishop Williams was asked to-day about the cable dispatch from Rome denying that he was to be made a Cardinal and stating that the Archbishop had written a letter to the Pope requesting him not to place that honor upon him.

M. HERBETTE, the French Minister at Berlin, is one of many persons who have been very well abused concerning the "incident'' of the visit of the Empress Dowager to Paris, which he was said to have advised. He now declares that he not only did not advise it, but that he knew nothing about it until it was too late for his advice to have any effect.

SIR: When I wrote you last the opinion of the best and most neutral judges with regard to our Canadian election was that the chances were in favor of the Liberals. This opinion was founded mainly on the feeling in favor of reciprocity, manifested by the farmers of Ontario, which it was supposed would turn the day in twenty or twenty-five counties carried last time for the Government by small majorities.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 6. -- The Assembly Forestry Commission resumed its investigation this morning. B.L. Turner of Plattsburg testified that he claimed a certain tract of land near Plattsburg and was told by Warden Garman that he would aid him in getting it if he would pay $15,000 for it. He found purchasers for it, and $11,000 was paid to the State for taxes due on the tract.

Cornelius's merry little opera "The Barber of Bagdad" and the nondescript ballet "Dresden China" were the attractions at the Metropolitan Conversation House last night. The performance of the opera was exceedingly uncertain, owing to the fact that for some inexplicable reason the tenor, Dippel, seemed to have forgotten his part.

This is the season of year when the prudent angler overhauls his tackle to see in just what condition the left-over material of last year remains and to ascertain what repairs are necessary. There is nothing like having the tackle in prime condition the minute the angling season opens. A month from now the Spring exodus to Long Island of anglers hankering after the fat trout of the tidewater streams will begin.

The inquiry concerning the recent collision has shown conclusively that the block-signal system used in the tunnel should be improved. On an open road and under ordinary conditions this system is doubtless a very good one. Certain experts say it is the best that has been devised. But in this crowded tunnel it is not sufficient for the control of trains.

HALIFAX, N.S., March 6. -- The address in reply to the Governor's Speech at the opening of the Newfoundland Assembly contains the following allusions to the reciprocity treaty with the United States and the French shore difficulty:

An officer at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday said that few people had as little to thank the Fifty-first Congress for as the officers of the navy. "While various sums," he said, "have been appropriated for the building of new vessels which will be completed several years hence, absolutely nothing has been done to relieve the stifled condition of the personnel, a relief demanded at once.

A big cat yesterday escaped from what the members of the Fire Department supposed to be a very securely-fastened bag. Perhaps the members of the department are to be congratulated upon its escape. The public, however, may extend its sympathies to the galaxy of legislators at Albany who are always on the lookout for plums.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- In the closing hours of Congress the appropriation for the use of the National Commission and the lady managers of the World's Columbian Exposition was restored to a reasonable amount. The sum agreed upon in the joint conference of House and Senate committees was $95,500. Of this, $36,000 is set apart for the lady managers, leaving $59,500 for the commission.

President Charles P. Clark and Directors Chauncey M. Depew and Joseph Park of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad surrendered themselves at the Coroners' office yesterday and gave heavy bail to await the action of the Grand Jury upon the verdict of the Coroner's jury fixing on the officers and Directors of the road the blame for the Fourth Avenue tunnel collision.

In this week's Medical Record Dr. A. Jacobi sums up the results of his extended experiments with Koch lymph, which he calls "tuberculin," in Mount Sinai, the German, the Foundling, and the Skin and Cancer Hospitals. A great variety of symptoms were observed, says Dr. Jacobi. After the inoculation of tuberculous patients the temperature would rise in from two to twenty-eight hours.

In his speech at the Federal Club dinner last night Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT began by claiming credit, which is fairly his due, for his efforts in maintaining a nonpartisan administration of the civil service law during the last two years. Then he proceeded to show that during those two years, or perhaps a longer time, he has been developing within himself a spirit of partisanship which did not characterize his earlier career in politics.

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 6. -- An English detective named Partridge secured possession of the famous English letters of Charles Hammond, but was a few days ago robbed of them by a man named Tyrrel. Officers have arrived here in hot pursuit and expect to have Tyrrel under arrest in a few hours.

Charles McElvaine, whose conviction of the murder of Grocer Luca was recently affirmed by the Court of Appeals, was sentenced to death yesterday by Judge Moore in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn. His lawyer made a speech, but merely said that the trial was fair and just. McElvaine was then sentenced to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing during the week beginning April 20.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- While nobody except ex-Speaker Reed will pretend that there were many features of the last House of Representatives which could be commended to the imitation of the Senate next Winter, everybody who has had occasion to refer to the Congressional Record this week will agree that, in the work of its official reporters of debate, the House set an example which the Senate may well follow.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 6. -- Yesterday the extraordinary spectacle was presented of the Speaker of the House descending to the floor to advocate the passage of a measure which the Democratic leader, Charles P. McClelland, had denounced in unmeasured terms. It was the notorious bill appropriating $60,000 for the dredging of Black Rock Harbor.
CINCINNATI, March 6. -- Announcement is made of the following baseball matters:

Most people consider ailments, like hoarseness, cough, sore throat, , not worth their while to look after. This neglect is very often the cause of severe and protracted sickness. Use Soden Pastilles in time. Dr. Moreau B. Brown writes: "I have used the Soden Pastilles, and find the results very satisfactory for diseases of the throat, chest, and lungs." Each box must have the testimonial of Sir Morell Mackenzie with each box.

PARIS, March 6. -- The XIXme Siecle to-day publishes an interview with M. Herbette, the French Ambassador to Berlin, in which the Ambassador said that he thought that the French artists, in refusing to exhibit at the Berlin exhibition, obeyed the orders of a few blusterers. It was llogical for the artists to exhibit at Munich and Stuttgart and object to exhibiting in Berlin.

William Ryan and Henry Mason, alleged professional till-tappers, whose pictures have been in the Rogues' Gallery for eighteen years, were yesterday remanded at Jefferson Market Police Court for robbing the money drawers of Henry Dlabola, 1,484 First Avenue, and Henry Koch, 204 Forsyth Street, of $45 and $43 respectively.

Among the important bills on which work will have to be begun almost from the beginning on account of the incapacity of the Senate is the Bankruptcy bill This passed the House after careful consideration and a reasonable discussion It was found to command the approval of a larger number of the various classes interested in its operation than any previous plan, and it excited almost no opposition that could be called sectional.

J. Alexander Lindquist, editor of Tariff Reform, stood in the hall of the Eleventh Congressional District Tariff Reform Club, 502 West Thirty-eighth Street, last night, and dissected that part of the McKinley Tariff bill whi ch affects articles used in making pianos. Many of those who listened were employee in piano factories.

At the time of the Assembly Chamber ceiling scandal Mr. SHEEHAN, now Speaker of the Assembly and then a member of the committee that had charge of the construction of the sham ceiling, showed considerable sensitiveness regarding his reputation and official honor, but it looks now as though he were involved in a transaction quite as discreditable, for which he cannot escape the responsibility.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 6. -- The prisoner Manuel Politz in the Hennessy case created another sensation to-day. To all appearances he has become temporarily insane. The defense was to have placed its first witness on the stand to-day. There was a long delay pending the attachment of absent witnesses. Politz, since his supposed confession on Monday, has been kept in the Sheriff's office away from the other prisoners, of whom he was in mortal dread.

Lieut. Gov. JONES'S way of getting the nomination for the Governorship is the way of a hungry man with his dinner. Frankly and without any thought of indirection concealment he proceeds to the table and in distinct tones asks for what he wants. The late Mr. TILDEN would have opened seven different and circuitous avenues of approach to the coveted repast, and at least four of them would have been subterranean.

In spite of all the talk about "issues," well founded though that talk may be, the interest of the Canadian election is mainly personal, and centres in the picturesque and now venerable figure of Sir JOHN MACDONALD. He is really the only Canadian politician whose personality has made a distinct impression beyond the limits of the Dominion.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Franklin MacVeagh, the leading wholesale grocer of Chicago, worth $5,000,000, was nominated for Mayor of this city to-night by the Columbian League. This is the outcome of the citizens' movement for pure government started two weeks ago. The League is composed of the leading citizens irrespective of party. It has held two or three meetings, but nothing was done until to-night.

Between 1,500 and 1,600 shares of stock were bought in under the rules on the Consolidated Exchange yesterday for the account of A.E. Nichols, a broker of 60 Broadway. The principal items on the list were lots of Richmond Terminal, North American, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Northern Pacific preferred stock. Mr. Nichols says his troubles are due to customers failing to pay up.

NEW-HAVEN, March 7. -- Prof. Charles A.L. Totten of Yale University made a statement today regarding the project of restoring Palestine to the Jews, which project was set forth in a memorial to President Harrison Thursday, and which is advocated by prominent men of the leading American cities. The memorial, as explained to the President by William E. Blackstone of Chicago, is the result of a conference of Jews recently held in Chicago.

The Sherman Monument Committee at its last meeting adopted a resolution offered by President Smith of the Chamber of Commerce to the effect that any surplus of subscriptions received for the erection of the statue be transferred to the family of the General. This action was the result of a letter from Mr. Amos R. Eno, which was submitted to the committee and which was unanimously approved by its members.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7. -- The system of training recently instituted by Capt. J.S. Roddy of the track athletic team for the better efficiency in the training of applicants for the intercollegiate team has already shown its merits and affords candidates the individual attention of a trainer in each specific event, besides the general attention of McMaster, the college trainer.

Messrs. Wilson G. Hunt, William Rockefeller, and William D. Bishop, Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, yesterday gave bail in $25,000 each before Coroner Levy to answer any indictment the Grand Jury may find against them growing out of the tunnel accident. The first to appear was Mr. Hunt, who went to the Coroner's office accompanied by his bondsman, Alexander T. Van Nest, a hardware merchant of 122 Chambers Street.

A ROMAN EMPEROR. -- Augustus was a reasonable man, and did not like being taken for god -- at least, no more than was advisable for political reasons. Addressed by a petitioner with the title of Dominus, he rebuked him sharply, saying that he was either a fool or guilty of gross impiety.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7. -- The candidates for the intercollegiate team are working in the gymnasium every day, and, as all the men are now in training, it may be well to make a forecast of Harvard's prospects for maintaining her position of leader in track athletics. At the games last year her team won the intercollegiate cup with a score of four firsts, two seconds, and eight thirds, making a total of 32 points.

Amateur photographers are anxiously awaiting a bit of warm Spring weather to go out in search of photographic game. There have been so much rain and chilly weather recently that few have mustered courage to do outdoor work. The Society of Amateurs in this city has much work to accomplish this Spring in making a photographic survey of the city.

Now that the long controversy over the New-York monument at Gettysburg is at last settled, there may be leisure to consider what shall be done to honor the soldiers of the State who took part in the battles around Chattanooga. Congress has established on the field of Chickamauga and the approaches thereto a national military park which is to be to the West what the Gettysburg military park is to the East.

Argument was had before Judge Wallace in the United States Circuit Court yesterday in regard to the site for the new Custom House on Bowling Green which the Government has condemned and to which proceeding property owners do most strenuously object. District Attorney Edward Mitchell and Assistant District Attorney Maxwell Evarts represented the Government.

The short duration of the Winter season has had the effect of filling the early Lenten days with more of incident and interest than is usually the case. Despite the many departures for Europe and the Southern resorts, which have had the effect of thinning out to some extent even the clubs, there has been considerable of interest going on from day to day and night to night.

It is the opinion of nearly all Brooklyn lawyers who will talk at all that the Ziegler water case has kicked its last kick. Over twenty of them talked to a TIMES reporter about the suit on condition that their identity should not be disclosed, and each one thought that the suit would not only never be tried, but that there was great doubt about its ever being argued before the Court of Appeals.

Diplomacy is supposed to be nothing when it is not a fine art, but the fine arts are seldom used for diplomacy. RUBENS, it is true, and several other painters of name and fame were employed as ambassadors, and in the magical epoch of once-upon-a-time the portrait painter figured as a necessary agent between the Prince and that Princess for whom the former nearly died of love -- all because he had seen her picture.

AMHERST, March 7. -- Final preparations are being made for the Western tour of the Glee and Banjo Clubs at Easter in a special car. An entirely new programme has been arranged, and concerts will be given in New-York, Pittsburg, Rockford, Joliet, and Chicago, Ill.; Cleveland and Cincinnati, Ohio; Syracuse and Troy, N.Y. Other concerts will also be given. This month the clubs play in Holyoke, Springfield, Boston, Laselle, and Northampton.

There was excitement in the little town of Westchester last evening. A town meeting that was full of lively incident and confusion was called to settle a momentous matter. The subject over which discussion had been aroused was of apparently trifling origin, and probably would not have become generally known had it not been for the lively political condition that exists at present.

Why is it that club restaurants do not pay expenses, no matter how well patronized they may be? Hundreds of club men and club officers have tackled this conundrum in the last decade, and the answer is not yet. It is easy enough to figure out, theoretically, that the restaurant, at the prices that prevail, should be a source of income rather than a loss.

Col. Fellows has drawn down upon himself the wrath of many of the Southern papers by his statement at a recent banquet that "although no had oeen an officer in the Confederate axuy he had always felt that he was a traitor to his country, who deserved to be hanged, if captured, and that he vas not hanged was duo mainly to the mercy of God,"

CLEVELAND, March 7. -- There was a time in Ohio when the onion was not only recognized upon its own merits, but men banded themselves together in its honor. The eminent Abolition leader, Joshua R. Giddings, was proud to be a member of the Onion Society that flourished upon the Reserve in those days when men ate according to their likings and cultivated what they ate.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Men who come here from the cities on the Canadian border, notably Buffalo and Oswego, bring discouraging reports of the effect of the McKinley tariff law upon the maltsters and importers of Canadian barley. This barley contains properties not found in the grain grown south or west of Lake Ontario, and is peculiarly adapted to the manufacture of beer.

Mr. Keary is favorably known for work at the British Museum and for volumes like "Outlines of Primitive Belief," whose titles sufficiently show the direction of his studies. Training in the study of the earliest civilizations is in some ways excellent for preparing a writer to treat of times near at hand, yet not abundantly supplied with materials for history.

The simple fact of the earth's being round has called into existence a scheme which, if it could be put into effect, would revolutionize the carrying trade between the Old and the New World, because it would bring the centre of the American continent as near to European ports as is the seaboard according to the present routes.

The investigation into the affairs of the Sugar Trust by the Senate Committee on General Laws was continued yesterday at the Hotel Metropole Judging by the progress that is being made, it will continue to be continued for many weeks to come. A dozen sessions have already been held. Bookkeepers and clerks of the old trust have been examined without stint.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., March 7. -- The baseball team will go into the hands of a trainer next week. F.R. Coates, '90, is manager of the team, and C.W. Throckmorton, '93, is Captain. The following rules have been adopted for the government of the baseball team: 1. All men will report at the gymnasium on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays at 4:30 P.M. 2. The batteries will practice in the cage on Thursdays and Saturdays.

LONDON, March 7. -- While the acute anxiety concerning the general European situation has passed away, there are still enough elements of uncertainty and misunderstanding drifting about to make it probable that we shall hear more rumors of trouble during the month. The main question between Berlin and Paris arising over the affronts to the Empress Frederick has undoubtedly been smoothed over.

Two outbreaks of outraged virtue in different parts of our country seem to call for the attention of the observer of current events. Several matrons of Philadelphia have entered an indignant and public protest against the "flagrant indelicacy" of several pictures now on exhibition at the Academy of Fine Arts in that city, the flagrant indelicacy consisting, so far as appears, in the introduction of nude figures.

EAST AFRICA. -- From a European standpoint, Dr. Meyer declares the commercial value of the products of Kilimanjaro to be so far -- nil. In this opinion he is diametrically opposed to Mr. H.H. Johnston, who gave glowing reports of the region. Dr. Meyer says the timber is worthless, the india rubber is scarce, the orchilia weeds not common, and minerals almost absent.

SPORTSMEN NEVER GET ILL. -- As a rule a sportsman may take great liberties with himself without being much the worse. No man was ever harmed by wet feet on a moor, though if he comes home and contemplates them for an hour over a gunroom fire he may be reminded of the indiscretion. A deerstalker has to put up with great exposure and temporary discomfort, but he is rarely the worse for it.

BLACKBEARD. -- He was a beau ideal pirate, possessed with a mania for getting married. During his first sojourn at North Carolina his friend the Governor married him to his fifteenth wife, a young girl of sixteen, whom he treated most brutally. Unlike the French Bluebeard, however, he did not, so far at least as our knowledge goes, kill any of his wives.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 7. -- Leonard Kuhn, the ex-cashier of the First National Bank of Dansville, the institution owned and wrecked by the Faulkners, entered to-day upon his term of one year in the Monroe County Penitentiary and this completes the last act in the drama of the Faulkner family. The offense for which Kuhn will suffer is the receipt by him of deposits after he had become aware that the bank was insolvent.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- When President Harrison nominated James H. Beatty of Idaho to be United States District Judge for the new State he did so in spite of the most earnest protests by the Idaho Senators. Their opposition was so strong that the President was told the selection of Beatty would be taken by them as a personal affront.

Permit me to call the attention of the readers of your valuable paper to the system pursued at the quarantine station, at Staten Island, with regard to the visit of the doctor to the incoming steamers from Europe. According to existing regulations such visits are only provided for between gun fire at sunrise and the same signal at sunset.

With the next public hearing, on Thursday, the Board of Rapid-Transit Railroad Commissioners expect to exhaust the presentation of such schemes as have thus far been unfolded to the public, and so far as information governing the choice of systems is concerned it will be in possession of all that is contained in reports upon existing systems, and, in addition, all that the promoters of all other schemes have been able to adduce.

The club projected by numerous wealthy men who think that there is room in that part of the city north of Fifty-ninth Street for a club that shall give all clubs now established in the city a hard tussle for supremacy, and which has been known, for want of any name given it by its promoters, as the "Millionaires' Club," yesterday took a long stride toward tangibility. It was given a name.

BOSTON, March 7. -- The latest and most interesting topic of conversation among the members of the new Republican Club of Massachusetts is the programme for the meeting and dinner of the organization in Music Hall Wednesday evening, April 8.

The reports from Washington indicate that President HARRISON'S present notion is that it is not necessary to convene the Senate in special session for the purpose of confirming the appointment of new Judges, which must be made in time for the organization of the Circuit Courts of Appeal on the 16th of June.

The Ives sale of books was finished in one long session yesterday afternoon. The total amount realize is $124,375.25. The sale financially is a success. Its fault is that it will not serve to illustrate a diatribe against bibliomania.

Two men wearing broad-brimmed slouch hats, with long hair falling down upon their shoulders, with fierce mustaches, and well-trimmed imperials, met and exchanged cordial greetings in the corridor of the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon. One was Buffalo Bill Cody, chief of the scour of the United Sates Army; the other was J.T. Bell, for many years chief of the Secret Service at Washington.

The movement for the establishment of a botanical garden in this city, begun several months ago, has received fresh impetus by the introduction of a bill in the Legislature to authorize the city to construct the necessary buildings at Bronx Park and to make the other needful preparations preliminary to the management of the enterprise by private subscription.

Stationed in that portion of the Brooklyn Navy Yard known as the Cob Dock is the old line-of-battle ship Vermont. This vessel is better known to naval people as the "New-York Guards," or receiving ship, and on board this relic is where recruits for the naval service are enlisted.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 7. -- There is still considerable diversity of opinion as to the actual majority the Government obtained in the recent elections. The Mail (independent) places the Government majority at 29, with Cariboo, Algoma, and Huntingdon to hear from. The World (Conservative) places the Government majority at 35, while 27 is the most the Globe (Liberal) can make it. Impartial authorities place the Government's majority at about 30.

ST. LOUIS, March 7. -- Religious and political circles are greatly agitated over a secret meeting of Protestant ministers of the city that was held last Monday in the Second Baptist Church, of which the Rev. J.H. Ford is pastor. The object was to devise some way to make the influence of the Protestant Church felt in politics and resist the encroachments of Catholicism.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Of the many dramatic and musical attractions in Chicago during the week just ended but two were novelties to the amusement public. The principal one, in point of novelty at least, is that remarkable organization known as the Liliputians. "The Pupil in Magic" affords abundant opportunity for the introduction of singing and dancing by the little folk and some prettily-costumed ballets.

The manner in which the protest sent to the Assembly by the Catholic clergy of this city against the Stadler bill was received by Speaker Sheehan has stirred up the Catholic laity of this city. The breach between Tammany and the Catholic clergy occasioned by Tammany's advocacy of the Staler bill is now wider than ever.

The people living along the line of the various branches of the Union Elevated Railroad Company in Brooklyn have been puzzled for a long time to know why engines keep thundering up and down the road until 3 and 4 o'clock in the morning. The general supposition has been that the engines went from station to station to collect the money taken in during the day, but that is an error.

ALLANTA, Ga., March 7. -- For over sixty days rain has fallen almost continuously over the cotton States. The effect on the preparations of the farmers for the crops of the coming season is expressed in the declaration of State Agricultural Commissioner Nesbit of Georgia that "the prospect has not been so bad in forty years."

NYACK, N.Y., March 7. -- Interesting proceedings have occupied the attention of the Town Board of Orangetown, Rockland County, all this afternoon. The cause was a contest over one of the results of last Tuesday's election, and it may yet be necessary for the Supreme Court to settle the matter.

Mr. J.W. Carroll yesterday exhibited to newspaper representatives at his office, 78 Duane Street, what he claimed to be the "third largest diamond in the world." He said that it was worth $70,000, and he called it the "orange stone." It is asserted that this stone weighs 115 carats, that it was found in the African mines in 1884, and that its original weight was 200 carats.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 7. -- The jury in the case of Sarah McMullen, the seventeen-year-old girl who was charged with murder in the first degree in pushing a child named Ella May Connors off a bridge at Akron, Erie County, causing her death, in November last, came into court shortly before noon to-day with a verdict of not guilty on the ground that Sarah was insane at the time she committed the act.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 7. -- The Hon. F.J. Thompson of Fargo, one of the attorneys employed by the resubmission element, has given to THE TIMES'S correspondent his views of the liquor contest which is now agitating the people of North Dakota. He said: "An appeal has already been taken from the Supreme Court of this State to the Supreme Court of the United States in the Frazier original-package case.

PARIS, March 7. -- Every one here is delighted at the more than probable reappointment of M. Carvalho as Director of the Opera Comique. When the old opera house was destroyed by fire a victim was needed to be made suddenly responsible. Carvalho stood like a man and endured the general vituperation without a murmur.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Perhaps the only tolerably complete set of portraits of the more prominent editors and proprietors of newspapers in the United States is to be seen in the lobby of the press gallery of the House of Representatives at Washington, D.C. Prior to two years ago there were no portraits in the room, except those of Grant and Lincoln.

BOSTON, March 7. -- The Massachusetts Club at its dinner to-day had for its topic of discussion "The Present Condition of the Republican Party in Massachusetts; Its Immediate Needs and Its Future Prospects." Its guests were ex-Mayor Hart, W.W. Doherty, who have just been appointed Postmaster and United States Marshal, respectively, and the Chairmen of three or four of the Republican Committees of the larger cities of the State.

Among the most fascinating of the Spring goods are the fine wools and those silken mixtures which bear such close relationship to the wools that they are never far apart in the displays. This class of fabrics grows more delicately lovely each year. Texture, coloring, and design find their highest expression in these dainty weavings. Happy will be the girl who has her wardrobe full of them.

EIGHT THOUSAND STUDIES OF PASSION. -Dr. Johnson defines the novel as a tale "usually of love," and there is no doubt that most novels, since the Greek romances, have been very full of this passion. In his English novel, during the time of Shakespeare, M. Jusserand gives some statistics as to the preponderance of fiction in modern English literature.

WHEELING, West Va., March 7. -- Dr. George Baird, member of the City Water Board and one of the most prominent physicians of the city, was shot and almost instantly killed this morning by Dr. George I. Garrison, ex-City Health Officer and a physician of high standing. The tragedy occurred on Eleventh Street, just in front of the plumbing shop of Rose Hamilton.

SING SING, N.Y., March 7. -- Two convicts in the prison made an attempt to escape about 3 o'clock this morning, but they were caught by the guards just in time. One was James Russell, sentenced March 18, 1890, for twenty years for burglary in the first degree in New-York, and the other was John Quigley, sentenced March 18, 1884, for fifteen years for robbery in the first degree from Queens County.

LONDON, March 7. -- Mr. Irving's revival of "Charles I." has drawn crowded houses because of the exquisite beauty of the poetic settings and the admirable acting. Its reception affords a curious contrast to the ferment in Paris over "Thermidor," which, at worst, only attacked Robespierre and Marat.

HARTFORD, March 7. -- The Rev. Sidney K. Smith of the Methodist church in Naugatuck will retire from the pastorate in that place in April, and will remove to Marlborough, Mass. Mr. Smith graduated from Wesleyan University in 1865, and has held important appointments in this State. He is a native of Huntington, L.I.

The Canadian election naturally agitated the whole Dominion, and if it made very little stir outside, the failure was not the fault of the high contending parties. It is interesting, whether or not it be gratifying, to note that all the modern improvements from this side of the border were imported into Canadian politics, with additions that are of native production.
The sensational reports published of Miss Dickinson's insanity can be turned to her benefit if used as the basis of a public appeal in her behalf.

BALTIMORE, March 7. -- Not since the early Fall has a week passed so quietly for society. Entertaining seems indeed to have at last completely given way to at least a semblance of orthodox Lenten observance. With the exception of two musicales, one given by Mrs. Robert Garrett and the other by Mrs. Tyson, on Monday evening, nothing disturbed the torpor into which gayety has temporarily fallen.

In last week's article it was said that the market appeared to be waiting for Congress to adjourn to get up and do something. The prevalent expectation was that the something would be an advance. Congress did adjourn at noon Wednesday last, and the announcement was received with cheers on the floor of the Exchange.

ORANGE, N.J., March 7. -- A meeting of the Essex County Branch of the New-Jersey State Charities Aid Society was held in this city this evening. Mrs. Williamson, General Secretary of the State Association, spoke on the work of the association. A "mi-careme" cotillion was given at the clubhouse of the South Orange Field Club, Monday night and was largely attended.

LAKEWOOD, March 7. -- Saturday and Sunday are the great days for arrivals at Lakewood. Over 2,000 guests were here on those days last week, and the number to-day and to-morrow will be about the same. New-Yorkers find it convenient to run down for a day of rest, and nineteen parlor cars, with the usual number of regular coaches, were required to bring the people from that city here last Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $141,010,650, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,074,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $25,806,450; 4 per cents, $108,130,200.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., March 7. -- The last Congress is well represented at Old Point Comfort. After adjournment Wednesday a large contingent of Representatives came down here to rest and to enjoy the general delightfulness of the sleepy bit of Virginia beach. Washington society has given its full quota to the small army of guests through the season.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 7. -- The Duke of Marlborough's recent purchase of six highly-bred trotters at Woodburn is being discussed by trotters horse men everywhere. When John Splan returned from England a year ago he said that English people would eventually become the best buyers of our trotters; that, while they are critical purchasers, there would be no difficulty in selling them really good trotters at remunerative prices.

In testifying before the Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Apportionment yesterday on the subject of census taking, Gen. FRANCIS A. WALKER, who was Superintendent of the Census in 1870 and 1880, recalled the difference in the way complaints of incorrect and incomplete enumeration were treated in 1870 and in 1890.

LONDON, March 7. -- Owing to the presence of the Court in London and to the "drawing room" just held and the Prince of Wales's levee, which is to be held on Monday, this has been a truly "royal week" for the theatres of the metropolis. The boxes nightly have been graced with the presence of more or less important royalties or other people of rank and title.

PROSPER MERIMEE. -- Merimee, a literary artist, was not a man who used two words where one would do better, and shines especially in those brief compositions which, like a minute intaglio, reveal at a glance his wonderful faculty of design and proportion in the treatment of his work, in which there is not a touch but counts.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 7. -- The following Commencement officers have been elected by the Senior Class: For Class Day -- President -- Bayard L. Peck, Hudson: Orator -- Philip Ward, Clinton; Poet -- William H. Kelley, East Weymouth, Mass.; Historian -Thomas L. Coventry, Deerfield; Prophet -- Samuel H. Adams, Rochester; Presentation Committee -Thomas E. Hayden, Rudeston; Frank B. Hathaway, Rochelle, Ill.; James W. Fowler, Andes.

The brewers here and elsewhere in the State are secretly laying plans to defeat the proposed prohibition amendment to the Constitution, which is to be submitted to a popular vote either next month or in November. Their campaign will be a campaign of money, and a big sum is to be raised.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 7. -- The defense in the Hennessy case was to have begun its testimony yesterday, but the apparent insanity of Manuel Politz, one of the nine accused, compelled a continuance until to-day. Politz resisted desperately this morning when brought by the Deputy Sheriffs from the parish prison to the prison van, and fought until overpowered.

There are breakers ahead for John H. Wallace, once the dictator of the National Association of Trotting Horse Breeders, and till recently the official Registrar of that body. Fifteen years ago this organization accepted the plan for fixing the standard of breeding for trotters which the ex-preacher submitted to them by advice of Peter C. Kellogg, though he did not himself have much confidence in the success of his scheme.

In writing my reminiscences of Southern war prisons, I have given the incidents in something like chronological order. But, before going on to describe the building of and the escape through the famous Libby tunnel, it may be well to state certain facts about which I have often been questioned by friends who learned of my imprisonment.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, March 7. -- Considerable expense has been incurred by the authorities of Rutgers College in presenting the course of ninety lectures this Winter by the Agricultural Department for the benefit of agriculture and the mechanical arts, and much disappointment is felt because of the meagre attendance of farmers, though this may be due to the horrible condition of the roads leading to this city.

BOSTON, March 7. -- The Rev. Edward Everett Hale, D.D., was announced to lecture in Channing Hall this afternoon, but as he was absent on a trip in the West he deputed the Rev. Edward Hale to read the paper he had written. The subject was "The Great Schism in the Congregational Churches." The lecture was made especially interesting by a number of reminiscences of the more important crises of the transition.

The Food and Health Explosion, which opens formally to-morrow evening at the Lenox Lyceum, promises to encourage the pure-food movement in a substantial way. Mr. Depew will deliver the opening address at 8:30 o'clock, and there will be liberal attractions offered on each succeeding day of the exposition, which will continue until March 28.

Our esteemed contemporary, the Evening Post, makes unsympathetically merry over the division in the Democratic Party of this State touching the controversy whether Mr. HILL can properly retain the seat of the Governor of New-York in the Capitol at Albany while at the same time there is a seat in the Senate Chamber at Washington which may be said to be yawning for him.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 7. -- The Sophomore Class has voted to hold a cotillion during the Spring term in place of the annual banquet. The following committee has been appointed to take charge of the affair: w.S. Gilbert, E.I. White, G.H. Marx, F.C. Pond, G.V. Fowler, S.C. MacNider, G.A. Rumsey, A.T. Baldwin, E.M. McGonigal. It is probable that the cotillion will take place June 15, the night before the Senior ball.

SPECTACLE GLASSES. -- Although many opticians are in the habit of recommending various descriptions of glass for spectacles, there are in reality only two kinds -- native glass or rock or mountain crystal, usually called pebble, and artificial glass. They also advise users of spectacles to have them of pebbles, as more beneficial to the eyesight, artificial glass being decried as heating and wearying the eye.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 7. -- Three large crates containing English pheasants arrived at Shelburne Farms, the estate of Dr. W. Seward Webb, yesterday. Dr. Webb intends to stock his estate with these birds. He has signed game leases of many of the farms adjoining his, will employ several gamekeepers, and proposes to enjoy hunting in real English style.

The bill introduced at Albany last week for the construction by the city of common subways for the reception of pipes, wires, and all underground connections has received already more attention from property owners than any legislation projected for a long time. It has been felt of late years that such an improvement had become an absolute necessity in this city.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- The wreckers of the Bank of America and the American Life Insurance Company were sentenced this morning by Judge Arnold. George F. Work is condemned to four years in the Eastern Penitentiary, James S. Dungan to three years, and Louis E. Pfeiffer to two years' imprisonment. Only a few persons were in the court room, probably because no one expected that sentence would be passed so soon.

All sorts of rumors are afloat regarding the baseball situation. The latest is that Claimant Johnson has been dickering to sell out his interests in the Cincinnati Club, and he has even gone so far as to name a figure. Another is to the effect that Chris Von Der Ahe is going to desert the Association and join hands with the League.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 7. -- There is talk of a new Summer Episcopal church here for the cottagers. There is already one church in this denomination which is open only in the Summer and is attended almost exclusively by the Summer residents, and there are two other Episcopal churches which are quite largely attended by cottagers during the season, but which are open the entire year.

" Nine carats ef it's a blessed one." "Scale'im, and ye'll find he's a half better. Christmas puddings! What a bit o' glass! Clear es a bottle o' gin, an' flawless es the Pope! Tommy Dartmoor, ye're in luck, s'welp me never ef ye ain't, an' that's a brilliant yer can show the polis and not get time fer."

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The need of a naval proving ground, fitted with all the best appli ances for handling and testing modern guns, armor, and projectiles, and at the same time easily accessible from the Washington ordnance shops, has been fully met in the new proving ground at Indian Head, Md., on the left bank of the Potomac, twenty-six miles below Washington.

TRENTON, March 8. -- Gov. Abbett is taking steps to "hedge" on the tax question. The bill prepared by the Tax Commission under his instructions, and which his indiscreet friends tried to smuggle through the Assembly before the protests it was sure to arouse could be heard, has been finally abandoned. It will be loudly claimed that the Governor was not in accord with its onerous and ruinous provisions.

The fourth anniversary of the death of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher was yesterday, observed by a memorial service in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, by the Sunday school. The exercises began at 3 o'clock P.M. On an easel on a table in front of the communion rail was a large crayon portrait of the dead pastor, entwined with wild ferns, among which were a few wild roses.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 8. -- After almost an entire week of dissipation and idleness, during which the members visited Washington to witness the death of the Fifty-first Congress, and then very appropriately wound up with a visit of inspection to the State Insane Asylum, the Legislature will reassemble at Dover to-morrow.

ALBANY, March 8. -- A disturbance is threatened in the Assembly. It is the old story, a quarrel over patronage. The Speaker and Clerk of the lower house are allowed by law the appointment of sixty officers. Contrary to precedent, when the announcements of appointments were read from the desk two months ago, the residences of the fortunate officers were not given. A good reason existed for this, as developments have shown.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 8. -- The look-out of 400 clothing cutters in this city, which took place yesterday, is likely to prove a pretty serious matter unless a settlement is reached soon. If long continued, the idleness of the cutters will have the effect of paralyzing the entire clothing industry of the city and throw something like 20,000 persons out of employment.

There will be two "Poor Jonathan" celebrations this evening. The one hundred and fiftieth performance of the opera will be given in the Casino, and in the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, the one hundredth performance will be given by Rudolph Aronson's company. The souvenirs to be presented to the audience in both theatres are handsomely-bound books, containing the musical gems of the opera and two of Lillian Russell's solos arranged for the pianoforte.

Col. Malleson was well prepared to write an authoritative book on that great native uprising which more than thirty years ago threatened with destruction England's empire in the East. He was already known as the author of works of considerable value on the decisive battles of India, on the French operations in that land, and on the career of Clive.

Seventy-one years ago the first movement was made in this city for the establishment of savings banks. The idea took shape as an outgrowth of Thomas Eddy's scheme for the prevention of pauperism, which had been embodied in a society for that purpose. One day Eddy posted up on the crowded bulletin board of the "City Hotel" a call for a meeting of all persons interested in the founding of an institution for savings.

BALTIMORE, March 8. -- One of the sensational divorce suits of the past year was decided yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Milton M, Wheat of Kentucky came to Baltimore a few years ago and entered the city's fashionable society. The filing of Mrs. Wheat's bill for absolute divorce last September created a sensation. The husband filed a cross bill, charging infidelity.

MONTE CARLO, March 8. -- Several instances of the futility of trying to "beat the bank" are recorded here this week. The first is that of the Englishman who, a week ago, by an extraordinary run of luck, won the sum of 7,000 at the gaming tables. Not satisfied with his success, the winner continued to tempt fortune, and the result was that he lost not only all that he had won, but 15,000 besides.

Chairman William W. Goodrich of the Kings County Republican General Committee is working very hard to bring about a condition of harmony in the ranks of local Republicans. With this idea in view he has carefully selected the members of a new Committee on Municipal Affairs, whose names he will announce at the meeting of the General Committee to-morrow night.

JACKSONVILLE, Ill., March 8. -- A terrible railroad wreck occurred this morning on the Jacksonville Southeastern, which resulted in the total destruction of all the cars by fire, the smashing of the engine, the loss of one life outright, and the serious injury of several persons, one or two of whom lie in a precarious condition.

CONCORD, N.H., March 8. -- The Now-Hampshire Nuisance act, which is being talked about all over the country, provides that upon complaint of a specified number of residents a person may be cited before a Justice of the Supreme Court and made to answer to a charge of selling intoxicants contrary to the law regulating the sale of such liquids.

Among the laws of New-York was one which provided for the inspection of all kinds of merchandise consumed in cities. This system of compulsory inspection gave a large amount of patronage to the Governor. The inspections included leather, hides, flour, beef, tobacco, pork, wood, and even hoop poles. Not less than 175 men were employed in the Seventh Ward in the inspection of tobacco alone.

The grotesque ignorance of our language, laws, and institutions shown by many applicants for naturalization is amusing in a sense, but when we consider the sure consequences it is rather a dismal joke. In our news columns this morning is described the case of a would-be citizen, between whom and the Judge of the Court of Common Pleas the following colloquy took place: Judge: "Who makes the laws?"

Gen. WALKER'S testimony before the Assembly Committee on Enumeration recalls the history of the census of 1870 in this city and puts in striking contrast an enumeration made with honesty and competence and one made without either for partisan uses. Gen. WALKER was the Superintendent of the Ninth Census.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Senators Jacobs and Robertson, to whose arbitration the Senate dispute was left last Friday, have had but one conference since the adjournment. Senator Robertson has now gone home. Senator Jacobs said tonight that he had received a proposition signed by Mr. Robertson, which the latter said was the only one he would agree to.

NYACK, N.Y., March 8. -- Mrs. Bridget Armstrong, a middle-aged Irishwoman, lies in bed in her little home on Piermont Avenue, to-day, in a pitiable condition. Her neck is terribly wounded, her face is covered with blood, and she is suffering much pain from two kicks in the side, administered by her assailant. With feeble voice she told her sad story to THE TIMES'S correspondent.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- If Pension Commissioner Raum is still at the head of the Pension Office when the Fifty-second Congress meets, in December, he will have another opportunity to explain to a Congressional committee the methods he employs in managing his important office. There are some persons who still think President Harrison will invite Gen. Raum to retire before the end of the Summer, but their number is not large.

It is not easy to say how much foundation there is for the rumors circulated both here and in the foreign money centres as to new financial difficulties growing out of the Argentine troubles. The fact that very little effect has been produced in London, and even less in Paris, would indicate that there is little to fear.

LONDON, March 8. -- During the week past money was more plentiful, owing to lessened revenue collections, large Treasury disbursements, and the reflux of cash recently sent to the provinces as railway dividends. The gold demand for the Continent ceased, with no prospect of dearer money and a growing scarcity of bills. Discount was weak, being quoted at 2 1/2 for three months and 2 for short.

MONTREAL, March 8. -- THE TIMES'S correspondent has learned on the best authority that Sir John Macdonald will lose no time in filling up the vacancies in the Cabinet caused by the defeat at the polls of John Carling, Minister of Agriculture, and C.C. Colby, President of the Privy Council. It is to come about in this way:

BOSTON, March 8. -- The Massachusetts Civil-Service Reform League has entered a strong protest against President Harrison's settlement of the Boston Postmastership contest. After reciting Harrison's and the party's professions for reform, the league says:

NEWARK, N.J., March 8. -- James Ryan, one of the spinners who returned to work a few weeks ago, has been living in Clark's barracks since and made his first visit home this afternoon. While going along the street under the influence of liquor Ryan was approached by a couple of strikers, who struck him on the head with a brick. A policeman came to Ryan's assistance, and a big crowd collected.

The recent decision of Judge PARDEE of the United States Circuit Court in the case of the American Biscuit and Manufacturing Company against BERNARD KLOTZ and others should not be overlooked by persons interested in the attitude of courts toward combinations of manufacturers. The complainant, commonly called the Cracker Trust, asked for the appointment of a receiver.

The most tiresome duty that the Judges of the Superior and Common Pleas Courts have to perform is the naturalization of the thousands of foreigners that wish to become invested with the rights and privileges of American citizenship -- especially just before election time. When naturalization is going on the court room is turned into a school room.

ALBANY, March 8. -- One of the echoes of the appointment of ex-Senator James F. Pierce as Superintendent of Insurance is that just previous to the time his nomination was sent to the Senate he had been a stockholder in an insurance company. The law controlling this department expressly prohibits the chief from being interested directly or indirectly in any company as an agent or a stockholder.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 8. -- Attention was called Wednesday last by the Constitution to the fact that no steps had been taken by The citizens of Atlanta to show their appreciation of the honor conferred on the city in having one of the best cruisers in the navy named for Atlanta, and it was suggested that $1,000 be raised to secure a suitable present for the vessel.

ORANGE, N.Y., March 8. -- The annual charter election takes place in this city on Tuesday next, and the nominations have all been made. There will be lively fights in the Second and Third Wards, where the situation is doubtful. In the First and Fifth the Republicans have everything their own way, although the Democrats have a fighting chance in the First.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Speaker Sheehan is greatly disturbed over the criticisms that have been made of his course in relation to the Black Rook Harbor Dredging bill, and he declares that he will make a statement to the House to-morrow night which will conclusively prove that he has no personal interest in the bill. He says there are votes enough to pass it and that it will undoubtedly go through.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 8. -- This week the State Conventions will be held and candidates for the April elections will be designated. The contest, of course, is between the Republican and Democratic Parties, and upon the nominees for Governor the comparative vigor of the canvass will depend. The Prohibitory Party will make its nominations, but, as usual, will poll hardly a twentieth of the total vote.

LONDON, March 8. -- Further facts have come to light regarding the murder of Dr. Leidermann, whose body was found in a ravine near San Remo, and who was at first supposed either to have committed suicide or to have fallen by accident down the ravine.

SQUADRON OF EVOLUTION, OFF PENSACOLA, Fla., March 5. -- Notwithstanding the fact that the daily papers of Feb. 26 reported the completion of the squadron by the arrival of the Boston and Atlanta, the former did not reach here until March 2 and the latter is not expected until to-day. The Boston's run from Key West was made in forty-eight hours, under one-half to five-eighths boiler power, at an average speed of ten knots.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 8. -- Six months ago to-day the convention to form a new Constitution for Kentucky assembled in this city. Its 100 delegates were selected from among the men who, it was supposed, would know the needs of the people. Among them were a Governor, two ex-Governors, Justices o the Court of Appeals, and lawyers and business men of more than local reputation.

The latest defense of the extravagance of the Republican majority in the Fifty-first Congress may be found in the editorial columns of the New-York Tribune, where it is pointed out with some expressions of satisfaction that by spending so much money the Republicans have put the Democrats of the Fifty-second Congress "in a hole," as certain politicians at Albany would say.

Mrs. Emelie A. West, eighty-seven years of age, died suddenly at her home, 34, East Sixtyfourth Street, yesterday. Mrs. West had been in constant attendance upon her invalid husband, Joseph I. West, a retired merchant, eighty-three years old, and her strength had been greatly overtaxed, it is thought. Yesterday morning, while about her household duties Mrs. West was stricken with apoplexy, and died before medical aid arrived.

BUENOS AYRES, March 8. -- The panic in financial circles is over and business will be resumed to-morrow. The feeling in the gold market is more quiet and confidence is restored. A number of prominent merchants and bankers met at the Government House and appointed a committee to decide upon the question whether it would be more advisable for the Government to issue gold notes or a loan.

PARIS, March 8. -- Owing to heavy rains the race course at Auteuil early in the day was almost deserted. In the afternoon a few hundred onlookers were present, chiefly engaged in watching the movements of the large force of police on the ground. Only a few racing men were present at the weighing in. A number of bookmakers entered bets without being interfered with by the police.

This evening, at the Grand Union Hotel, will be held the annual meeting of the Middle States Regatta Association. It will be an important meeting in the eyes of oarsmen in this vicinity, for it is expected to reveal whether the majority of boating clubs in and around New-York City are in favor of antagonizing the boating men of Philadelphia.

LYNN, Mass., March 9. -- All of the printers heretofore employed as "piece hands" on the Lynn Daily Press were to-day locked out of the establishment by the new manager, Robert Leon. Leon assumed control Saturday, and submitted that he had a right to make all employes "office hands" and pay them $15 per week, as called for by the scale, which expires March 29.

Yesterday's session of the Ives sale at the galleries of the American Art Association in Madison Square was the least attended, but it was the most attractive of all its sessions. Instead of books, usually ugly, and to be enthusiastic about which one absolutely needed to be a bibliomaniac, there were white and blue porcelain vases, cups, and plates of fabulous colors, masterpieces of an art unknown to the moderns and therefore valuable.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Very little stock is taken here in the story, started once a day since Congress adjourned, to the effect that the President will soon call the Fifty-second Congress together in extraordinary session.

I suggested that Mr. Watterson's fearless and energetic style was well revealed in a letter he had recently written to an eminent New-York politician, and this led to one of the most interesting phases of our conversation.

PARIS, March 9. -- A terrible scene by which a well-known lion tamer will lose his life was witnessed at the Hippodrome in this city to-day. The spectacle of "Nero" is being prepared at the Hippodrome, one of the features of the show, as proposed, being an attack by a number of lions upon wooden figures so arranged in the arena as to represent human beings.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 9. -- The fourth week of the Hennessy trial was begun to-day, the testimony of the defense being resumed. Before any witnesses were called, Lawyer John Flynn, counsel for Politz, asked for a continuance until to-morrow to give him time to confer with his client. Up to this time since his appointment Saturday he had not had the confidence of the prisoner.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 9. -- Representative W. T. Ellis of the Second Kentucky District and Representative Asher G. Caruth of the Fifth (Louisville) District, in Congress, signalized their return from Washington by rushing into print and denouncing Mr. Cleveland. Mr. Ellis went so far as to say that Cleveland's silver letter had killed him, and that he would not carry two counties in Kentucky, should he receive the Presidential nomination.

One of the friends of the late Secretary Windom says in regard to the movement to make some expression to Secretary Windom's family of the high esteem he was held in among his personal friends: "The amount contemplated has been raised and it is probable that it will be invested in a suitable residence at Washington if the family shall determine to make that city its home.

TRENTON, March 9. -- The Elections Committee of the Assembly held along sitting this afternoon to hear the contest between McAdams, Democrat, and Engard, the sitting Republican member, for one of the seats in the House belonging to Camden County. It is said that the House has about made up its mind to unseat Engard. It is a question, however, whether McAdams will be admitted.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 9. -- This city is Sunday headquarters for a large number of commercial travelers. They come from all places within a radius of fifty or more miles to spend the day, especially in the Summer. Yesterday afternoon, A. Ellis made the suggestion that an association should be established for caring for the worn-out commercial travelers of the country.

Another of the outrages with which the striking Polish cloakmakers have been occupying their leisure time of late was committed in Jamaica, L.I., early yesterday morning, and as a result of it a little for-year-old boy is now lying in bed suffering from vitriol burns that will disfigure him for life. A gang of twenty-seven men took part in the affair in broad daylight within six miles of Brooklyn. Only one of them was caught.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 9. -- The Evening Journal prints a letter written by Gen. Sherman in 1888 to the Hon. Edgar Angier, the latter having solicited Sherman's influence with President-elect Harrison in favor of Gen. Longstreet. After declining to embarrass the President-elect by asking favors of him, Gen. Sherman writes:...

ST. LOUIS, March 9. -- A great deal of comment has been caused by a short address, delivered on the floor of the Merchants' Exchange this afternoon, by President C.W. Eliot of Harvard College. Some portions of the speech had a decidedly queer sound to Western ears; so much so that one evening paper so far forgets the laws of hospitality as to denounce the city's distinguished visitor as a" snob."

Mr. Willard made a stronger impression upon his audience at Palmer's Theatre last evening by his portrayal of Matthew Ruddock in "Wealth" than he had previously made on any "first night" since his American engagement began. To tell the truth, not much was expected of the play itself, reports having come from London that it was continuously gloomy, and not over strong.

Mr. John S. Kennedy, the philanthropic and public-spirited banker, sent letters yesterday to the four principal charitable organizations in this city announcing his intention to build a United Charities Building on the site now occupied by St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. The congregation of that church will soon remove to another locality, and Mr. Kennedy has arranged to purchase the church property, including the parsonage in Twenty-second Street.

Even if it shall appear that Prof. KOCH'S tuberculin has very little value either as a trustworthy agent for disclosing the presence of tuberculosis or as a remedy for that disease, the interest excited throughout the world by the experiments of physicians must be of great service to mankind, because it directs attention forcibly to the fact that tuberculosis is an infectious malady.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, one of the bosses of which (Michael J. Coffey) owns a lot of real estate along the line of the projected extension of Second Avenue, Brooklyn, adopted resolution yesterday indorsing Assemblyman Byrnes's bill providing for that extension.

The New-York Presbytery, at its monthly session yesterday, planted itself squarely and unmistakably against the proposed introduction of the Order of Deaconesses into the Presbyterian Church. For months the debate has been going on over this subject, and it has been sent from Presbytery to committee and back again more than once, like a shuttlecock between two battledores.

Members of the middle class of the Columbia College Law School last night gave a full airing to their side of the present troubles in the institution. Incidentally, the whole situation was discussed, including the resignations of Profs. Dwight, Chase, and Petty, and the ideas of President Low were stated as the students of this branch of the university understand them.

The officers of the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Street Railroad Company explain that the reason why that road was not put in operation nearly a year ago, when it was substantially completed, is "because of their inability to make any arrangement for the use of the tracks of an existing railroad company whose cars are run in Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets, between First and Second Avenues."

MONTREAL, March 9. -- The outcome of the recent elections has had a most unexpected result upon the more honest followers of Sir John Macdonald. These men, while they could not conscientiously support the Liberals in a policy which they thought would lead to annexation, are disgusted with the corruption and carelessness with which so much of the policy of Sir John's Government has been associated.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Another illustration of the dangers of the trolley system of propelling street cars by electricity was given to-night. A heavy rain fell all the evening and the atmosphere was densely charged with moisture. About 10:30 o'clock a telephone wire fell across the trolley wires at the corner of Broadway and State Street.

The Commercial and Financial Chronicle in its latest issue gives some facts that throw a curious and instructive light on the effect produced by the operations of the Treasury upon the business of the country. During the month of February, according to the Treasury statement of March 1, the cash holdings increased by about nine and a quarter millions of dollars.

It is to be hoped that the one man who was caught by the police at Jamaica yesterday morning may turn out to be the wretch who deliberately poured vitriol upon a child in the interest of "organized labor." The crime was so particularly cowardly and detestable that the administration of justice in such a case ought to be not less a pleasure than a duty.

There was a meeting of the Special Committee on Legislation of the Board of Education, of which Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer is the Chairman, recently, the usual dull routine of which was relieved by an inquiry into one of the most audacious bills ever introduced at Albany. It was Assemblyman Martin's bill to amend the law relating to the election and tenure of office of the New-York City Superintendent of Schools and his assistants.

Gov. HILL indulged in a little of his familiar buncombe yesterday by sending a special message to the Legislature congratulating that body on adopting his suggestion in regard to referring contested elections to the courts, and repeating his recommendations for an extension of the provisions of the Corrupt Practices act.

The contest over the will of Daniel B. Fayerweather has been withdrawn, and the millions belonging to his estate will be distributed according to his wishes as expressed in the will and the four codicils, supplemented by the deed of gift by which the executors divested themselves of the residue, which they were to take as residuary legatees.

We fear that it requires a mind trained in the subtleties of the Roman theological school to understand exactly how the school question as "the principal Catholic question in America" is "burningly delicate," as it is described by the Moniteur de Rome. But that journal is quite justified in thinking that a "Kulturkampf is impossible in the United States."

CONSTANTINE B. KILGORE, he of the door-compelling foot, writes to the Galveston News that he is unable to discover among the Democrats of Texas any liking for Senator HILL of New-York. If Senator HILL'S remarks about a "proper international ratio" between gold and silver meant anything, which Mr. KILGORE doubts, they meant that the Senator "was opposed to the free coinage of silver."

John Braun, a demented barber, made a desperate effort to commit suicide yesterday. He has been wandering about this city and Brooklyn for about three years without a home and without friends. He was once in comfortable circumstances, and had a happy family. Financial troubles overtook him, his wife and children died, and he became a victim to chronic catarrh of the stomach. These misfortunes caused melancholia and insanity.

The Sub-Committee on Rapid Transit of the Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange reported yesterday in favor of the new scheme to give Jay Gould's elevated road four tracks in Battery Park, and the report was accepted. The sub-committee remarked that it had heard arguments of C.H. Butler in favor of the plan and had received a letter from Charles Collins opposing it. In his letter Mr. Collins says:

Yachtsmen are continually being hampered by the Government authorities, and it appears that this next season they are to undergo an unusual amount of red tape unless they can induce the Government to refrain from enforcing the orders already sent out. By the present laws yachts of five tons or over must take out papers, and must have their names marked on their sterns and on each bow in letters of at least four inches.

The millionaires who decided Saturday to organize under the title of the Metropolitan Club are probably above venting spite upon Postmaster Van Cott's letter carriers, but that industrious body of men is likely to pay the penalty of that selection if it should be finally confirmed. There is already a Metropolitan Club, which for some years has occupied quarters in the neighborhood in which the millionaires think of building.

F.W. Janssen of the Staten Island Athletic Club has a plan on foot to consolidate five of the athletic clubs of Staten Island, making one organization with a capital of $250,000 and a membership of 2,500. It is proposed to erect a clubhouse costing $80,000, and provided with 150 sleeping rooms, a large gymnasium, and a theatre on the plan of the one in the clubhouse of the Manhattan Athletic Club.

The apparently interminable investigation into the affairs of the Sugar Trust by the Senate committee was continued at the Hotel Metropole yesterday morning. The session was productive of but one practical result. Sidney Harris, counsel for the committee, declared that he expected that the committee would support him in insisting that the books of the constituent corporations of the old trust should be produced.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 9. -- The freshet in the Cumberland has submerged all the lower districts of the city. The gauge now registers within six feet of the record of 1882. Dispatches from Burnside report continued rainfall and a rise that threatens to lower the high-water mark here. River men hold that the fall will begin here in time to relieve the gorge of water from Burnside.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9. -- Never before were matters political in so chaotic a state on the eve of a Republican State Convention as to-night. Senator Aldrich is here, and rumors of all kinds of deals are current.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Chattanooga excursion party left Wahington this afternoon on a special train of vestibule sleepers over the Richmond and Danville line. This trip is given for the purpose of showing Secretary Proctor and a number of Congressmen over the battle fields of Chattanooga and Chickamauga, where a park is to be established by the government, for which apppropriations have been made.

The manufacturers of table glassware are completing their project for taking full advantage of the increased duties on such ware that were imposed by the McKinley act. The Boston Commercial Bulletin of the 7th inst. publishes the following information:

NEW-HAVEN, March 9. -- Since it became known that the New-York Yacht Club would not accept the invitation of the New-Haven yachtsmen to join in establishing a joint clubhouse at Morris Cove, the local association will proceed with the movement of its own accord. The club will ask the Government for the use of the land at old Fort Hale, in return for which privilege the yachtsman will improve the property.

The Cleveland Leader, which publishes on its editorial page every month several columns of answers to inquiring subscribers, told one of its correspondents a few weeks ago that the price of potatoes would have been at that time "much lower" but for the increased duty in the McKinley act.

The liveliest kind of a club campaign is the result of the contest now going on in the Manhattan Club over the election of managers. The election does not take place until Thursday evening, March 19, but the fight has been raging for several days.

In his reply to Mr. BLAINE'S letter of Dec. 17 Lord SALISBURY maintains his advantage in the argument of the Alaska sealing question and deprives our Secretary of State of some valuable materials he has hitherto freely used by showing that he has not correctly apprehended their bearing upon the case.

One of the stockholders of the Morton Naval Construction and Shipbuilding Company is a Spiritualist, but, while believing in mediums, does not believe in having his name mentioned. He has consulted a medium in relation to the fate of Capt. Francis L. Norton, who sailed from New-London for Toulon 107 days ago in his miniature craft, and who is supposed to have been lost at sea.

Speaker SHEEHAN secured the passage of the Black Rock Harbor job in the Assembly yesterday, virtually by an appeal for the vindication of his own motives in supporting it, which motives had been wickedly impugned. That is a very poor ground for supporting a bad bill, but there is no doubt that many of the votes were cast because the Speaker pleaded for them as a vindication of himself.

PEORIA, Ill., March 10. -- The starch house and sugar refinery of the Peoria Grape Sugar Company burned to-night. The loss is $100,000; fully insured. One employe was fatally burned. The owners of the plant were A.M. Drake, St. Paul; Levi Mayer, Chicago; B.H. Rhodohamel and Adolph Woolner, Peoria.

The Bar Association at its meeting last night elected the following members: Lew Wallace, Jr., Julian Gerard Buckley, Charles M. Cannon, George F. Danforth, William H. Page, Jr., George Cromwell, Eugene Stevenson, William Seton Gordon, Elihu B. Frost, Osgood Smith, Everett Masten, Benjamin Darker, Jr., Elisha K. Camp, William Manice, John W. Goff, Charles Fox, and Robert P. Getty, Jr.

An impression that the new County Committee of the County Democracy was to organize at the Cooper Institute last night drew a number of people to that place, but word was sent down from the New-Amsterdam Club that no meeting had been called and that none would be held until next week. The conference at the New-Amsterdam Club disclosed the fact that the new County Committee is not yet ready for organization.

Negotiations between representatives of holders of Virginia bonds and representatives of the State have reached such a stage that there is a prospect of an early and mutually satisfactory settlement of the long-pending financial difficulties under which Virginia has labored. It is the only one of all the States that were in rebellion whose ante-war debt still remains unpaid.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 10. -- Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner to England, now that the elections are over, has commenced boasting about Thursday's victory. In a speech delivered at Amherst, N.S., last night he overhauled the Grand Trunk Railway management for its alleged partisanship in the recent contest.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., March 10. -- Harmony and enthusiasm, to a degree unlooked for and unwarranted, if the preliminary canvass may furnish indications, marked the action of the Republican State Convention to-day, and the ticket nominated, with perhaps a single exception, may be considered one of the strongest that could be put up.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The statistical returns of the Department of Agriculture for March are estimates of the corn and wheat in the hands of farmers, the proportion and present value of merchantable corn, the weight of wheat per measured bushel, and other points in the commercial distribution of grain.

BUFFALO, March 10. -- Local officers of lake vessels to-day formed an organization, with the following officers: President -- Capt. Frank Perew; Vice President -- Capt. Maytham; Secretary -- E.H. Keep; Treasurer -- James Ash.

ALBANY, March 10. -- When a Speaker of the Assembly is forced to descend from his rostrum to explain, support, advocate, and force a measure, it is certainly in a bad way or deserves to be beaten. Last week a bill of Mr. Gallagher's, of Buffalo, to appropriate $60,000 to dredge Black Rock Harbor was declared to be passed in the Assembly.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 10. -- Henry Clay King, one of the brightest lawyers at the Tennessee Bar, is pacing a cell in the county jail, his hands still wet with the blood of a fellow-attorney, whom he murdered to-day in the open street in the presence of scores of people, and he knows that only the strong walls and iron framework of the prison save him from the summary vengeance of the victim's friends.

WASHINGTON, MARCH 10. -- The Bering Sea negotiations have taken a most favorable turn, and the Governments of the United States and Great Britain appear to have, at length, reached a basis upon which to settle their difficulties, as is shown by the following communication from Lord Salisbury to Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Minister here, which was laid before Secretary Blaine and was made public by him to-night:

The Police Commissioners were informed yesterday that the Board of Aldermen had approved of the proposed purchase of the lots 177 and 179 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, near Third Avenue, for a new police station and prison. The price of the lots is $20,000.

A delegation of Northport oyster growers came to the city yesterday to see how they were to come out in the allotment of something over seven hundred acres of land under water for oyster planting. Bids were invited from them for the land. The Fish Commissioners appointed yesterday as the time for opening the bids. Owing to the absence of three Commissioners the opening had to be postponed until to-morrow.

HCAGO, March 10. -- Amerlcan' sleeping cars roll over Australian railroads In fear months. The cabs.will lle built at pullman in sections and gliippel to Melbourne, vhere a oolony of workmen from Pullman wt put them together. George .

HARTFORD, March 10. -- The bill which the Republican majority of the House was expected to present this afternoon for the removal of the legislative dead-lock which has lasted since Jan. 7 went over under a caucus order until Wednesday. While the Republican managers insist on strict secrecy in regard to the bill, it is known to be based on the Brandegee resolutions.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 10. -- One of the heaviest storms of the season is now in progress throughout this region. Snow has fallen for twenty-four hours. Railway travel is somewhat impeded. The heavy fall of snow is satisfactory to the farmers, who now have the prospect of starting the crop season with plenty of moisture.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10. -- The little band of Democrats in the Legislature held a caucus last night and agreed to vote on the first day's balloting for D.A. Ostrom for United States Senator, on the second day for G.G. Goncher, and on the third day for J.V. Coleman. Ostrom and Goncher represent farming constituencies in the State Senate.

The expected radical change in the course of instruction at the Columbia College School of Law was made public in detail yesterday by the issue of the prospectus for 1891-2. President Low authorized the following summary of the differences between the new course and the old:
