The Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment yesterday reported favorably, by a vote of 6 to 5, one of the Tax-Revision bills, that introduced by Mr. KEELER of St. Lawrence County, but it was attacked with so much vigor by Gen. HUSTED and others that it was recommitted.

It appears that President ELIOT of Harvard has made a speech on the floor of the Merchants' Exchange in St. Louis which did not meet the views of his auditors, and which still more emphatically failed to command the assent of some of the public journals of that town. The objectionable remarks, as might perhaps have been expected, were made about silver.

The General Passenger Agents of the Trunk Line Association discussed the proposed abolition of unlimited tickets yesterday, and voted to withdrawal such tickets west of Chicago on April 1. The sentiment of the meeting was in favor of abolishing unlimited tickets altogether, and a resolution was passed looking to a conference of representatives of all the roads in the country, with that end in view.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 10. -- The Meriwether matter develops new and sensational features every day. To-day's developments took the form of a bitter attack in the State Senate on the ex-Labor Commissioner and on Col. Charles H. Jones, editor of the St. Louis Republic. The Senators who made the attack are political lieutenants of Gov. Francis.

Recent remarks of Mr. CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW concerning the heating of passenger cars by steam have greatly surprised certain persons who have tolerably good memories. But if these persons will only bear in mind that with respect to this question he appears in two characters, because of his official connection with two companies, the puzzle is solved.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- Theodore Thomas is under engagement to give a week of orchestral concerts in Chicago, beginning March 23. He is trying to engage a number of musicians from the membership of the Chicago Musical Society, and they will not play for him.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 10. -- The House of Representatives was the scene of a disgraceful and sensational exhibition about 11 o'clock this morning, the actors being E.C. Mitchell of Boone County and H.C. Head of Little River County.

Town and city elections ought to turn upon questions of local administration and the character of candidates for local offices and to have no political significance, but so long as the nominations are made by political parties and these contend with each other for the control of local affairs, this will not be the case.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 11. -- The Herald will say to-morrow morning: "The Herald is confident that among the rank and file of Republicans, disappointed as they may be, that a man of their own faith could not be elected, there will be sincere rejoicing that Palmer has been chosen. There is much in his triumph that transcends party lines and trenches upon the realm of true patriotism.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The four days' contest in the Senate over the amendment to the rules to abridge the Lieutenant Governor's powers was brought to a satisfactory end at 3:40 o'clock this morning, after a session lasting nearly seventeen hours. Twenty-three Senators were in at the death, and up to within five minutes of adjournment the Senate continued under the operation of a close call of the house.

In his entertaining seal fisheries letter of Dec. 17 Mr. BLAINE thrusts under the nose of Lord SALISBURY a list of 105 "of the most authentic maps published during the ninety years prior to 1825 in Great Britain, in the United States, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Germany, and Russia, on every one of which the body of water now known as Bering Sea was plainly distinguished by a name separate from the Pacific Ocean."

TORONTO, Ontario, March 11. -- The attack of Sir Charles Tupper on the Grand Trunk Railway for the part it took in opposing the re-election of Sir John Macdonald's Government is exciting much interest in Canada just now. It is a remarkable fact that each of the great railway concerns in Canada has its own party, and the reason for this is apparent.

Gen. PALMER, who was yesterday elected United States Senator from Illinois, was undoubtedly the choice of a large plurality, and probably of a majority, of the people of the State, but his election was reached only after a long and tedious struggle. The choice, so long as the Republicans and the Democrats remained faithful to their party candidates, lay with the three members of the Farmers' Mutual Benefit Association.

RED BANK, N.J., March 11. -- The Republicans of Shrewsbury Township elected their entire ticket yesterday with the exception of A. Holmes Borden, the candidate for Overseer of the Poor, who was defeated by Daniel S. Borden by a majority of 72, and J. Frank Patterson, Constable. The average majority for the successful ticket was 150.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Mrs. Mary E. Reynolds, residing in Aurora, Ill., and Ernest M. Dickey applied to-day for letters of administration on the estate of the late Joseph Reynolds, widely known as "Diamond Jo." Deceased left $2,500,000 of personal property and no realty. The only heir at law is the widow, and she receives the entire property, as no will has been discovered.

On the suggestion of ex-Mayor HEWITT the Board of Trade and Transportation adopted resolutions yesterday not only protesting against the bills now pending in the Legislature of this State on the subject of taxation, but favoring the appointment of a commission to revise the tax laws.

ADAMS, Mass., March 11. -- The financial complications of Levi L. Brown increase daily. A large number of attachments have been placed upon his various manufacturing interests in Adams and North Adams. Lawyer M.E. Couch of North Adams has placed attachments upon his interests in the L.L. Brown Paper Company, the Freeman Print Works, on his stock in the Renfrew Manufacturing Company, his interest in the Zylonite Company, and also upon his other attachable property.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 11. -- Pittsburg brokers and investors to-day talked of nothing save the astonishing manner in which Asaph T. Rowand and other whilom friends of George Westinghouse, Jr., turned Mr. Westinghouse and his Directors out of the management of the Union Switch and Signal Company.

LONDON, March 11. -- When Lord Shrewsbury, annoyed at the receipt of a telegram from Lord Lonsdale, upbraiding him for failing to appear for the novel driving match, about which so much has been said, withdrew entirely from the contest, Lord Lonsdale decided to drive over the course alone. He did so to-day, and covered the twenty miles in 56:55 4-5.

Now and then Wall Street gets a story of Cupid's pranks to rejoice in. It has one now in an ingenuous tale of how two young people met at Lake Hopatcong, and there, in joke, plighted their troth in a way that puzzles them now to tell whether it was binding or not.

At the new salesroom of Tattersall's yesterday William Easton sold at auction a consignment of twenty-six head of horses from the Pleasanton Stock Farm at Pleasanton, Cal. There was a much larger attendance than on Tuesday, and the bidding was very much livelier, the offerings being in more fashionably-bred lines.

We can hardly share the alarm that seems to have seized on some of our contemporaries as to the secrecy of the organization by which a certain number of farmers -- many of whom would not know a pig sty from a corn crib -- are seeking ends of their own. So far as the ends of the Farmers' Alliance are good, they can only be served by open action.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 11. -- While it is now generally conceded that Major McKinley will be the Republican candidate for Governor, it is apparent that in certain localities the opinion prevails that some Republican not so closely identified with the burdensome protective tariff would poll a heavier vote.

The story that the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company had obtained control of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Road was revived yesterday only to receive the most emphatic denials from the principal officers of the first named company, including President Depew. President Parsons of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Road also said that there was nothing in the story.

Organized opposition to the idiotic bill passed by the Assembly, providing for the roofing over of the old Forty-second Street Reservoir and the construction thereon of a public beer and botanical garden, was last evening accomplished at the Murray Hill Hotel. The opposition there organized will join hands with the opposition of the Real Estate Exchange in attempting to convince the Senate what a ridiculous step the Assembly has taken.

The Trustees of Rutgers Female College, in West Fifty-fifth Street, have brought suit in the Supreme Court against Jacob B. Tallman to recover $100,000, alleged to have been obtained by him while a Trustee of the college by wrongfully causing to be foreclosed a mortgage on the college buildings when they were situated in Fifth Avenue, near Forty-second Street.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 11. -- The bill devised by the Republicans for settling the controversy over the State election was reported in the House this afternoon and made the order of the day for Thursday morning.

CATLETTSBURG, Ky., March 11. -- A dance of death was that at Kilgore, a small mining town near here, Tuesday night. There was a ball there and when it broke up six men were carried out with bullets in vital parts of their bodies. Exactly what led to the battle no one seems to know. A quarrel arose between two of the dancers over a young woman present.

There is a bill pending in the Legislature the ostensible purpose of which is the old familiar one of securing "freedom of worship" in public institutions, but the real object of which, like that of its predecessors, is to gain entrance for the Roman Catholic Church into the House of Refuge on Randall's Island, which is and always has been conducted upon strictly unsectarian principles.

PATERSON, N.J., March 11. -- On Monday last Foreman Walter Todd of Ashley Bailey's silk mill in this city discharged Benjamin Harrison, one of the twisters employed in the mill. When the other men learned of this they held a meeting and resolved that Todd should be discharged, on the ground that he was not a "union" man, and that Harrison should be reinstated.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- During the last two or three years the people of Washington have been taking a constantly-increasing interest in the District militia. The result has been, of course, a marked improvement in drill discipline and everything that goes to make up an efficient National Guard, until Washingtonians have come to take a good deal of pride in their citizen soldiers.

Harlem is to have a new music hall. The Columbus Market, in Seventh Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-fourth and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, has not proved a success as a market, and so the recently-organized Harlem Amusement Company is going to change it into a great hall for musical purposes. Nathan Schwab, who is Treasurer of the Columbus Market Company, is President of the new amusement company, and he controls the market site.

Republican editors are beginning to force themselves up to their work again, and are now quite generally publishing thoroughgoing party papers. For a time after the November election they were in various conditions of collapse, and it seemed almost a probability that the most of them were past bracing up; but it was not so, for as a rule they are now as chipper as they were before election.

The first fruits of that broad-minded charity which Mr. D.O. Mills established two years ago under the name of the Bellevue College Hospital Training School for Male Nurses were shown last evening in the graduation of the first class of pupils from the institution. The exercises were held in the hall of the school, 431 East Twenty-sixth Street, and consisted of awards of diplomas and speeches by ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and Chauncey M. Depew.

" Guilty of the first count of the indictment" was a portion of the verdict of the jury that has been trying James A. Simmons in the United States Circuit Court for the wrecking of the Sixth National Bank. It was 11:15 last night when the words that meant so much to the contractor were uttered.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- A large number of the leading athletic undergraduates of the University of Pennsylvania, with the Board of Directors of the Athletic Association of the University, met Monday evening at the University Club to discuss the feasibility and advisability of making a radical change in the manner of conducting athletic sports.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 11. -- Representative Jerry Simpson this afternoon interrupted the proceedings of the Farmers' Alliance and State Grange Convention in session here for the purpose of making a personal statement. The Baltimore reporters had sent a note to him at his hotel asking him to give an official answer to the question, "Do you wear socks?"

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 11. -- At Clyde, Wayne County, the village election resulted in the choice of three Democratic and two Republican candidates for Trustees. B.F. Westfall, Democrat, was elected Treasurer. It was decided by 76 majority to have electric lights.

In his professedly gratuitous efforts to secure for the use of the elevated railroad company another slice of Battery Park, Mr. C.H. Butler has been exhibiting a map, said to be drawn to a scale, illustrating by black lines the existing structure in the park and by red lines the proposed widening. An inspection of the road yesterday showed that the map is false and misleading.

The Twenty-second Regiment Veteran Club has been incorporated for social, patriotic, and literary purposes, and to preserve and continue recollection of services of the Twenty-second Regiment. The managers are: Josiah Porter, George W. Wingate, Joseph G. Congdon, S. Ellis Briggs, George W. Pearce, Marvin R. Pearsall, Sherlock H. Byron, A. Judson Stone, James G. McMurray, Frederick M. Robinson, Joseph P. Jardine, James O'Neill, Abraham B. De Frece, Henry C. Piercy, and Frederick W. Seybel.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Charles E. Cook, formerly an officer of the defunct Park National Bank of this city and part owner in two Wisconsin banks that failed when the Park National went under, was arrested to-day here on a requisition from Wisconsin. The charge against Cook is illegal banking. The complainant is George W. Morse, Clerk of the Circuit Court of Dodge County, Wis., one of Cook's alleged many victims.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 11. -- The Republic will say to-morrow: "The great Democratic victory deserved and won in Illinois after an unprecedented struggle will be forever memorable in the history of the United States and of popular government. It is, first of all, a triumph of the West in the remarkable movement of Western Democracy for the re-establishment of popular supremacy in government.

LITTLE FALLS, March 11. -- A few weeks ago a dispatch to THE TIMES from this village chronicled a reduction of between 15 and 20 per cent in the wages of the employes of the Saxony Knitting Mill, and predicted that this was but an entering wedge for a gradual and far-reaching reduction of wages by the protected manufacturers here.

ROME, March 11. -- The Marquis di Rudini, the new Italian Premier, has made overtures to the Vatican, with the view to bringing about an entente cordiale, based on concessions to be made to Catholics.

An exhibition was afforded in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night of a nature at once humiliating to and without precedent in the National Guard. This was the presence in the building of a squad of police, summoned to preserve the peace at a civil meeting of one of the companies of the regiment.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 11. -- Gen. John M. Palmer was elected United States Senator from Illinois, in joint assembly of the Legislature, at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon, after eight weeks of balloting, during which 101 Democratic members stood shoulder to shoulder, without faltering in their loyalty to the veteran. The 154th roll call for Senator drew to them the support of Cockrell and Moore, the Farmers' Mutual Benefit Association representatives, and closed the contest.

The storm in the south of England is comparable to nothing in the way of weather that we have experienced excepting the blizzard of March, 1888. It has been really more destructive and more of a public nuisance than the blizzard, because the usual rigors of our Winter climate enforce precautions that are not taken in the South of England, and are not needed there once in a generation.
Mayor Grant received the following letter yesterday from Hermann Oelrichs:

ROME, March 11. -- The Duke of Aosta, while hunting to-day, was thrown from his horse and painfully injured, his shoulder being dislocated. Although suffering intensely, the Duke was able to return to this city.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The announcement that the Government of Great Britain is willing to submit to arbitration the matters in dispute between the two countries, relative to jurisdiction in the Bering Sea is received with a great deal of satisfaction by those who are especially interested in the preservation of the seals.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12. -- If anything were needed to show the necessity for the Sheard amendment to the Rapid-Transit bill, to prevent Battery Park from falling into the hands of Jay Gould and his elevated railway system, it was furnished to-day, when Assemblyman McClelland of Westchester, the Democratic leader in the Assembly, introduced the bill which THE TIMES yesterday morning said had been sent to him by C.H. Butler of New-York, who drew it.

It leaked out yesterday that nearly all of the 500 diamonds stolen from Lewisohn Co., 41 Maiden Lane, two months ago, by William C. Duncan, their eighteen-year-old clerk, had been recovered by Inspector Byrnes and were in the custody of the Property Clerk at Police Headquarters. When Duncan decamped he had $28,500 worth of unset diamonds in tissue paper packages in his inside pocket.

BOSTON, March 12. -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the elevation to the Episcopacy of the Roman Catholic Church of Archbishop John J. Williams was begun this forenoon at 10:15 o'clock by the celebration in the cathedral of pontifical high mass before an immense audience. The Bishops and clergy formed in the sacristy in the rear of the cathedral and joined the procession into the cathedral.

A man went into a large cutlery establishment in Nassau Street yesterday to buy a pocket knife. He was shown a pearl-handled knife, with a variety of useful blades and fixings, of German manufacture. He was told that the price was $2. He asked to see something similar of domestic manufacture, and was shown a knife almost the counterpart of the other one, but having one less of the "fixings."

Warner Miller, President of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company, will sail for Nicaragua to-morrow on the steamship Aguan with a large party to inspect the work going on there. About seventy gentlemen who are interested in the canal project gave him a farewell dinner at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening. Hiram Hitchcock, who is President of the Nicaragua Maritime Company, the parent of the Canal Construction Company, presided.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 12. -- The decision of the Supreme Court to-day declaring the act of the special session of the Legislature unconstitutional was made because the bonds of the new members of the Cincinnati Board of Public Improvement were made approvable by the Superior Court, thus bringing the law under the head of special legislation.

Concerning the Lehigh Valley accident, we have knowledge of the facts. What Mr. Depew said is true in the letter and absolutely untrue in the spirit. The case was the dreadful Mud Run disaster of 1888. The steam which did the damage was from a locomotive which telescoped the car. There was no steam in the heating pipes, as the accident was early in October and the trains were not heated.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 12. -- A banquet was given this evening at the Read House to celebrate the commencement of the manufacture of basic steel in this city. Among those present were Senators Manderson, Frye, Hawley, Butler, Sanders, and Carey; Representatives McKinley, Cogswell, Cannon, Wheeler, Hooker, McMillin, Allen of Michigan, Post, Henderson of Illinois, Osborne, Clements, and Baker.

There are brighter days in store for the Naval Reserve of this State. Never since its organization has the State and National Government stood by it so squarely. The Fifty-first Congress passed an appropriation giving the reserve $25,000, and a bill is now before the Legislature, introduced by Senator Cantor, providing for the enrollment of its several companies with thirty-five men, instead of eighty-five, as was originally provided in its incorporation.

The days of pranks with high police officials are over. None of the present Commissioners is to be trifled with, and Superintendent Murray and the Inspectors do not relish practical jokes. But in the times of Oliver Charlick, Gen. Duryee, George W. Matsell, and Superintendent Walling there did not pass a week without a bit of outrageous pleasantry or horseplay being recorded.

Miss Claire Coudert, daughter of Charles Coudert, was married yesterday morning at 11:30 o'clock to Marquis de Choiseul of France, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, by Archbishop Michael A. Corrigan. Owing to its being a Lenten wedding, the services were brief. About 1,500 invitations had been sent out, and most of them were responded to personally. By request of Archbishop Corrigan only those were admitted to the cathedral who had cards.

AUGUSTA, Me., March 12. -- The Australian Ballot bill is practically dead. It was killed in the House yesterday by a vote of 74 to 71. Seventy-four Republicans voted against the bill and the forty Democrats and thirty-one Republicans voted for it. The bill will come up in the Senate to-morrow, and will probably meet the same fate.

CINCINNATI, March 12. -- The American Baseball Association completed the following schedule of games at 9 o'clock to-night. It is believed that in only two or three instances the dates clash with those of the League:

Since the publication of the remarkable interview in which Mr. CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW, laying aside the character of Dr. Jekyll and assuming that of Mr. Hyde, sought to explain Mr. Hyde's affection for the car stove by telling a harrowing story about an accident on the Lehigh Valley Road, much curiosity as to the date and peculiar features of that accident has been shown.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12. -- Judge Caldwell of the United States Circuit Court has signed the decree of foreclosure in the case of the Rock Island Road against the Chicago, Kansas and Nebraska, and the later line is now to be disposed of at public sale to satisfy the Rock Island's mortgage of $28,000,000. The date of sale has not yet been fixed. The case has been hotly contested for over a year.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- The course of municipal legislation in Select and Common Councils was rudely interrupted to-day by a personal encounter between two of the city fathers. The difficulty occurred between Select Councilman Peter Monroe of the Third Ward and Common Councilman George W. Allen of the same bailiwick, who, though formerly fast friends and political associates, have lately been at daggers' points personally and deadly foes politically.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 12. -- The members of the Pharmaceutical Association of this county are outspoken in their denunciation of the Alcohol Trust. The companies in the trust include all the large distilleries in the United States except two, one of which is situated at Chicago and owned by M. Schufeldt.

Mr. Alexander's pictures were barely discernible against the walls of the Aldine Club rooms in Lafayette Place last night because of the volumes of smoke that curled upward from the long clay pipes of the club men and their guests, who had met informally to hear a number of "Stage Talks." It was the second very interesting and unique reception held by the club this Winter.

LONDON, March 12. -- A foreign steamship, the name of which is unknown, was wrecked off Start Point, near Dartmouth, Devonshire, England, during the recent blizzard. All the crew and passengers were drowned.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 12. -- It was all harmony and unanimity on the old ticket with the Democratic State Convention to-day. The caucuses had shown a general movement to Davis, in spite of his letter withdrawing in favor of Mayor Pond of Woonsocket, and the matter was clinched by the introduction of the informal ballot. Both conventions have resorted to the informal vote this Spring for the first time.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 12. -- Ignatz Zeisler of Chicago is in the city. He is a son of Edward Zeisler, who up to a short time ago was the Chicago representative of E.H. Horner, the dealer in foreign bonds. His father has had a dispute with Horner and has attached the Chicago office on a judgment for salary and commissions.

The Shoe and Leather Reporter, of which Isaac H. Bailey, an intimate friend of the deceased Daniel B. Fayerweather, is editor, comments on the compromise effected in the Fayerweather will contest in a manner that is anything but creditable to the executors. In regard to the settlement with Mrs. Fayerweather, the editorial says:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 12. -- An Associated Press representative found Mr. Watterson confined to his house to-day with an attack of la grippe.

A dead man lies in the Morgue at Tottenville, S.I., and the doctor who examined his body, the Coroner, and the police say he was murdered. Samuel Morton, mate of the schooner Emily S. Baymore, noticed the body lying in the water off Elliott's wharf day before yesterday afternoon and fished it out. The unknown man had been bound and a gag made of a pocket handkerchief driven down his throat with a stick.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The reports of the trial of the Bennington, which were given out as soon as the trial was over, will not be borne out by the official report, which will probably reach Washington to-morrow. It is learned that this report will give the vessel 3,313 horse power, which is 87 short of the requirement of 3,400, instead of the excess that was claimed just after the trial.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Secretary Tracy proposes to push the construction of the 7,400-ton protected cruiser authorized by the Naval Appropriation bill approved March 2. This vessel is to be known as Protected Cruiser No. 13 until a name is selected for her. The appropriation will not be available until July 1, but the Secretary has issued an advertisement calling for bids to be opened June 1.

The City Reform Club is actively engaged in circulating throughout the State copies of the proposed amendment introduced in the State Senate by Senator Laughlin, which have in view the taking of the administration of local affairs out of the field of State and national politics. A hearing will be held on the amendments by the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate Tuesday, March 24.
CHICAGO, March 12. -- In the "Monon" litigation Judge Tuley has allowed the Fort Wayne, Terre Haute and Southwestern Railroad Company to become a party defendant.

Mme. Ann O'Delia Diss Debar paid a visit to the Superior Court yesterday, and when she found that Judge McAdam had handed down a decision against her on her application for an injunction to restrain her manager from compelling her to appear in tights and from posting bills representing her as Cupid attired in them, she made believe that she was much put out.

The suggestion of sundry residents of Chicago formerly in the naval service that instead of putting the Navy Department exhibit at the World's Fair in a building resembling the hull of a battle ship a real vessel should be built for it, which should afterward take the place of the old Michigan for lake service, has much to recommend it.

The City Reform Club has taken up the support of the proposed constitutional amendments introduced in the State Senate by Senator LAUGHLIN early in the present session, the purpose of which is to separate local and general elections, and a hearing is to be given upon them before the Judiciary Committee of the Senate at Albany on the 24th inst.

Mr. Easton yesterday began the sale of J.B. Haggin's trotting-bred stock in the old Panorama Building, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Fifty-five animals were disposed of during the afternoon for a total of $33,885, an average of a few cents over $616 a head. As a majority of the offerings were yearlings, the average is therefore a very fair one.

The Committee on Ways and Means of the Assembly yesterday reported the Blumenthal bill forbidding the payment of State money "to or for any incorporated institution, society, or association" unless the "free exercise and enjoyment of religious profession and worship" is in good faith allowed to "all inmates of such institution or beneficiaries of such society or association."

Eternal vigilance seems to be the price of almost everything worth having as well as of liberty. Everybody has known for some time that there was a scheme before the Legislature to floor over the reservoir at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue and convert the flooring into an "air garden," as if every garden were not an air garden.

TRENTON, N.J., March 13. -- The Assembly held its first Friday session to-day. Father "Tom" Smith, the clerical looking liquor dealer, who represents one of the Newark districts, invoked the Divine blessing, and then Jackson of Essex sprang to his feet to say that the printed minutes of yesterday's proceedings showed that the clerks at the desk had recorded him incorrectly on some pending measures.

The new County Committee of the New-York or Voorhis Democracy organized in Webster Hall last night. Nearly six hundred delegates and about as many spectators were present. Police Commissioner Voorhis made a speech of course, and ex-Congressman John Quinn acted as Chairman until ex-Assemblyman John Martin was made permanent Chairman and D.N. Carvalaho, George Stetson, and E.J. Howell were chosen Secretaries.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13. -- The managers of both political parties are greatly surprised and annoyed at the discovery that the various farmer organizations of the State have been quietly at work during the Winter with a view of taking a leading position in the politics of the State. In the southern tier of counties bordering on the Ohio River active work was begun directly after the elections in November.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The official report of the gunboat Bennington was received at the Navy Department to-day. As already stated in these dispatches, it shows that instead of developing 3,400 horse power, as required by the contract, her engines made only 3,312.69 as the average for the four hours' trial.

The concluding sale of the J.B. Haggin lot of trotting horses was held at the Cyclorama Building, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon, a large number of buyers and speculators being present. Breeders were noticeably absent, as the offerings were geldings, which are of no use to them and available only for driving or track purposes.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, March 13. -- The heir of Lord Leicester of London has been discovered here in the person of his granddaughter, Mrs. Henry C. Klise, wife of a well-to-do contractor of this city. She has been in correspondence with Lord Leicester for some time and has established her identity. He will arrive here in April.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Affairs of the World's Columbian Exposition are now in a satisfactory condition. A feeling of confidence and enthusiasm prevails on all sides. The first Board of Directors, chosen by stockholders, will retire in two weeks. By that time most of the preliminary work will have been performed and little will be left for members of the new board to do but to carry out the plans laid down by its predecessor.

The auctioneers who had been at odds with the management of the Real Estate Exchange ever since the Directors ordered an increased scale of fees on auction sales to go into effect on Jan. 1, have secured a new auction room outside the Exchange.

The Board of Ordnance and Fortification has of late been contemplating a trial of leading rapid-fire guns of foreign manufacture against two American types, the Hotchkiss and Driggs-Schroeder, already contracted for. Accordingly it has made an allotment for the purchase of one Armstrong 6-inch rapid-fire gun and one 3.94-inch Canet gun, and the Ordnance Department will carry that provision into effect.

ALBANY, March 13. -- The McClelland bill, which gives the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company a valuable slice of Battery Park, was referred by Speaker Sheehan to the Cities Committee this morning. The Speaker informed the House that he was in doubt as to which committee should handle it, and several members volunteered to aid him.

Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER'S defense of his census of this city before the special Assembly committee was rather a pitiful performance. He threw the responsibility for the failure to consider the just demands of New-York upon the shoulders of his official superior, and his whole attitude was precisely what it has been ever since the accuracy of his work was brought in question.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 13. -- John F. Kilgour, the largest producer and shipper of bluestone in the Delaware River Valley, is said to be insolvent and a fugitive. He owned or operated under lease thirty quarries situated along the Erie Railroad or Delaware and Hudson Canal, and on the New-York or Pennsylvania shores of the Delaware, between Port Jervis and Deposit.

A meeting of the Fourth Ward Long Island City School Trustees and taxpayers, who are making a vigorous fight against Mayor Gleason and his puppet Board of Education, held a meeting last night in the school building, into which the Mayor sent a squad of police Wednesday to guard carpenters whom he had ordered to put in a lot of extra benches against the will of the Trustees.

Competition for the favors of the Rapid-Transit Commission is growing intense. The value of the franchise that the commission is called upon under the law to dispose of to somebody is beginning to be appreciated. No better evidence could be given of this than is contained in the elaborate prospectuses of the various schemes which have been and are being offered for the consideration of the Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The trials and tribulations of the Census Office are not all at an end. The chief of the division which is engaged in collecting statistics of fish and fisheries is Prof. Charles W. Smiley, who, after putting at work a number of special agents in various parts of the country, went to California to collect statistics.

Mr. John D. Rockefeller has added one more contribution to his long list of charitable bequests by giving another $100,000 to the American Baptist Education Society. The communication from Mr. Rockefeller in which this pledge was made was received at the last meeting of the Executive Board of the society, held at 5 Beekman Street. The letter is as follows:

The Inter-State Commerce Commission, in an opinion by Commissioner Morrison issued in Washington yesterday, decided the case of Coxe Brothers Co. against the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company. The points decided are briefly as follows:

LONDON, March 13. -- The Queen's second drawing room, held to-day, was of special interest, owing to the large number of Americans present. A wonderful display of roses was a marked feature of the day. The demand for roses was unprecedented, and florists imported great quantities from Italy and the south of France.

Theoretically the members of the State Legislature are representatives of the people, chosen to promote and to guard their public interests. Practically they have to be jealously watched to prevent them from betraying the interests of the people and using the power intrusted to them for the benefit of private schemes at the expense of the public.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 13. -- Bishop Leonard was visited this evening at his apartments in the Stillman and asked whether the court in the Macqueary trial had as yet reached a verdict. He replied very briefly that it had not and that any reports and rumors to the contrary were without foundation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 13. -- Convention time is four months away, but the political pot in Ohio is beginning to bubble in a most interesting way. The Republicans are outwardly confident of carrying the State against Gov. Campbell or any other Democrat who may be named, but in private they have visions of disaster that much belie their seeming confidence.

LONDON, March 13. -- Mr. Parnell issued to-day from the House of Commons a manifesto addressed to the "Irish People of America," complimenting them on their support of him in the past, and calling on them to extend financial aid to his cause through the Parnell delegates now on their way to the United States.

The dense fog which yesterday hung over the bay and rivers made the day a fruitful one in marine disaster. Traffic by water was seriously interfered with, and at times almost suspended. While cautiously groping their way through the almost impenetrable mist, ferryboats and other river craft frequently bumped into each other. Fortunately, none of the numerous collisions reported was attended with any great damage, but there were many narrow escapes from serious accident.

Secretary NOBLE'S recent issue of a permit to Gen. W.F. CODY, better known as Buffalo Bill, to engage one hundred reser vation Sioux for his Wild West Show is the more remarkable since only about seven months ago the Secretary expressly prohibited the issue of any more such permits.

The thirteenth annual report of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, which has just been issued, shows what came last year from diligent and well-directed efforts for the correction and abatement of the liquor traffic and kindred evils in this city.

Robert P. Porter, Superintendent of the Eleventh Census, appeared as a witness before the Special Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Reapportionment, known as the Featherweight Committee, yesterday. After answering the usual preliminary questions concerning his occupation and residence, Mr. Porter said that he was connected with Gen. Walker when he made the census in 1880.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 13. -- The Direct-Tax act is already stirring up a lively row in Ohio. The Buckeye State's share of the money which the late unlamented Republican Congress distributed among the States amounts to $1,300,000. State Auditor E.W. Poe, who has a Gubernatorial boomlet to foster, has devised a plan that will put a share of the spoil in Republican hands, and every Republican politician in the State is applauding Poe's scheme.

LONDON, March 13. -- While throughout the London district a thaw has set in and is causing much inconvenience to travelers, there are no signs of a moderation in the severity of the weather in the southwest of England. A heavy snowstorm prevailed throughout the past night in Devonshire and Cornwall, considerably adding to the sufferings of the farmers and still further impeding the resumption of traffic on the railroads.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 13. -- The report already published in THE TIMES that Lyman B. Goff, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, was not aware of his intended nomination, and might not accept it, is now borne out by his declination of the honor. Mr. Goff's son at Pawtucket received this morning a telegram from his father in which he said he should decline the nomination.

The campaign opened in Rhode Island by the Democratic nominations bids fair to be very interesting. There is no very pressing State issue, and the canvass will be made mainly on the question of revenue reform. The Democrats have taken a perfectly definite and candid position in favor of tax reduction and economy, the former to be carried to the point where the Federal taxes will be, as they should be, for revenue only.

The future home of the Catholic Club of this city is nearly ready for occupancy. It is a building which, in exterior appearance and interior arrangements and furnishings, would commend itself to any club in the city, and in location it is certainly equal, if not superior, to any other clubhouse here.

In view of the petition that is now being gotten up by the down-town merchants who deal with the New-York Steam Company and the Edison Electric Illuminating Company asking the Legislature at Albany for relief from extortionate charges, the following letter may be read with interest:...

LONDON, March 13. -- Mr. Parnell's absence from the House of Commons Thursday during Mr. Balfour's graphic narration of the distress in Ireland and the relief measures adopted by the Government has caused intense surprise in Ireland. Mr. Parnell mysteriously vanished on Wednesday.

Mr. PARNELL'S tours of this country apparently have not had the effect of impressing him very deeply with the intelligence of its inhabitants, either American or Irish-American. If they had had this effect he would scarcely have ventured to issue "to the Irish People of America" the address that is transmitted by the cable.

The recent issue of an injunction by the United States court against the Board of Phosphate Commissioners in South Carolina will perhaps bring to a head the mining troubles of that State. The injunction is granted in favor of the Coosaw Mining Company, which had found the State Commissioners giving or preparing to give licenses to others for dredging in the Coosaw River on territory which it claimed as its own.

The work and aims of the Charity Organization and the evils of indiscriminate almsgiving were discussed informally in the parlors of Dr. Lucien C. Warner's residence, 2,042 Fifth Avenue, last evening, by gentlemen who understand and appreciate the value of organized charity.

Should Joseph Barondess, the leader of the vitriol-throwing cloakmakers, be to-day admitted to bail in Jamaica, where he is in jail, he will be arrested by Inspector Byrnes's men and brought to this city to answer to charges of extortion.

The Hon. Honore Mercier, Prime Minister of the Province of Quebec, accompanied by a distinguished party from that province, arrived in New-York last night. The Prime Minister is on his way to Europe, where he will negotiate a loan of $10,000,000 to be expended in building railroads, bridges, and public institutions at home.

Ex-Congressman John M. Farquhar of Buffalo, the mover and general manager on the floor of the late House of Representatives of the Subsidy bill, was in New-York yesterday conferring with steamship officials who are interested in the bill. Before he left Washington he had long interviews with Postmaster General Wanamaker on the subsidy questions, and he will report to Mr. Wanamaker what impressions he received in his interviews with the companies.

At yesterday's session of the Ives sale the voices hushed in the enthusiasm of Thursday whispered that the Metropolitan Museum of Art might have bought the Ives daggers, swords, swordguards, and collections of knife handles in cabinets if the amount of $15,000 contributed by Mr. W.T. Walters, Mr. Brayton Ives, and others had not been used for the purchase in one lot, privately and without competition, of only the unsold daggers and swords.

LONDON, March 13. -- The Hamburg-American Line steamship Suevia, from New-York Feb. 26, for Hamburg, which was reported yesterday as being in a disabled condition sixty miles off the Lizard, is, as this dispatch is sent, still breasting the Channel seas, without anything definite being known as to her exact condition.

Speaking of the forthcoming report of the Advisory Board with reference to street cleaning, the Evening Post says: "What the report will not, and cannot, touch on is the moral or political side, (of the work of cleaning the streets,) which is also very important, in fact we might say the most important."

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Provisions -- Traders went home of the opinion that this latest surprising bull movement had culminated. It turned out a rather exciting day. At the outset prices looked very strong; the close was at a very sharp decline all around. May Pork opened at $11.15, sold between $11.25 and $11.75, and closed at $10.77; July opened at $11.50, touched $10.60, and closed at $11.15.
BOSTON, March 13. -- A Traveller reporter propounded twelve questions to ex-Senator Ingalls to-day, and the net result was a column of views "On National Men and Issues."

The form in which the so-called Freedom of Worship bill appears in the Legislature this year shows that its supporters feel the necessity of disguising its character and purpose. The demand for this kind of legislation has come invariably and solely from the priesthood of the Roman Catholic Church.

The London Telegraph states that Prof. von Mosetig of Vienna is confident a cure for cancer will be obtained, because it has been ascertained that cancerous tissue has much less vitality than healthy tissue, and can, therefore, be dealt with separately.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Not even the accompaniment of almost continual bad weather was sufficient to destroy the enjoyment of the trip to Chattanooga, Tenn., made by a party invited by the Secretary of War, Representative H. Clay Evans of Tennessee, and Gen. H.V. Boynton, historian of the Chickamauga Park Association.

Fairies, gnomes, elves, hobgoblins lurk in the mysterious creations called hats this Spring and resent any attempt to reduce the elfin designs to reasonable and sober discussion. "Aha!" say they, "here we are; look at us, study us, analyze us, 'get us down fine,' will you, O, presumptuous mortal? Better give it up, it's no use." And echo answers, "Give it up -- no use!"

LONDON, March 14. -- An enterprising young Dutchman, a correspondent of several Continental newspapers in London, named Jack I. Grein, has been for a long time at work trying to establish here a Theatre Libre on the lines of Antoine's famous Parisian experiment, and by a natural alliance with the Ibsenites last night he succeeded in getting one presentation through without the Lord Chamberlain's interference.

BERLIN, March 14. -- A deputation, consisting of members of the Alsace-Lorraine Parliament, had an audience with Emperor William today. His Majesty received the deputation in full state. He was seated upon a throne and was attired in the full uniform of a General of the Garde Corps. He wore the insignia of the Order of the Black Eagle.

Of the half million passengers who daily ride on the elevated railways of New-York, how many ever reflect that their personal discomfort is an ill omen for the city of which we are all so proud! In the "rush" hours no more passengers ride over this sole practicable route of quick passage from home to business, and from business home again, simply because, as every New-Yorker knows, more cannot get on the cars.

Notwithstanding the fact that a sub-committee of the Municipal Building Commission reported to the full commission nearly a year ago, recommending a site for the proposed building, no steps have since been taken by the commission either to accept or reject that report or to do anything toward carrying out the provisions of the act under which it was authorized to construct the building.

The Chicago Tribune believes that political careers should begin early in life or not at all. This it said referring to the candidacy of Gen. Palmer for the Senatorship. By way of illustration it discussed the career of Mr. Evarts, saying: "Senator Evarts was never a business man nor a politician, but always a lawyer and almost a statesman.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- To prepare a correct list of the multitudinous "classes" which monopolize the attention of society during Lent would be a fit task for a census expert. The week is ushered in with metaphysics by the meeting of the Cabinet Club at the Richmond, where in the apartments of the President, Mrs. Sweat, the "twelve spiders" read exhaustive papers upon erudite subjects.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- The Theatre Libre is very late this year in giving its representations. Spring is about here, and we have just now listened to the fourth one of eight. This is owing to the success of the recent public representations of the Porte St. Martin and to the Brussels season, which begins this week.

Three or four patrons of a popular chop house up town, a night or two ago, fell to discussing the question of a suitable name for the recently-organized millionaire's club. "I see that their chosen title, 'The Metropolitan,' belongs to another club," remarked one gentleman.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 14. -- Senator Manderson was to-day asked his views on Presidential probabilities. He said that in his opinion Blaine, though a possibility, is not a probability, and continued:

The butchering of the acquitted Italian murderers in New-Orleans shows how thin and fragile is the wall so laboriously built up between civilized methods and those of primitive barbarism. When no forms of law are provided for the punishment of crime the people of a community are apt to attend to the business of inflicting penalties without forms of law.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 14. -- In the death of Mrs. W.H. Stoddard of Northampton, Mount Holyoke loses the last teacher associated with Miss Lyon. Mrs. Stoddard (Miss Hazen)was Associate Principal several years after Miss Lyon's death. After six years as a missionary in Persia Mrs. Stoddard returned to this country in 1857, and in 1864 was appointed Acting Principal, filling the place two years.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 14. -- President and Mrs. B.P. Raymond gave a reception to the Faculty and members of the Senior Class on Thursday evening.

The vessel which was reported as having gone ashore on Romer Shoal Friday morning turns out to be the Italian bark Umberto Primo from Rosario with a cargo of hides consigned to Funch, Edye Co. of this city. The bark lost all of her spars soon after grounding, and the heavy seas careened her to an alarming angle.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 14. -- Two fires which occurred in this city this morning destroyed thirteen blocks, ten of which were in West Fayette and Franklin Streets. Over one hundred families, who occupied flats above the stores, were burned out, and four residences were destroyed by the first fire. Fortunately there was no loss of life.

Ever since the General Term handed down that sweeping decision prohibiting the purchase of the Long Island Water Supply Company on the sole ground that the authorities had no right to enter into a contract to buy it, the politicians who, of necessity, look ahead and not behind, have been asking: "Where does this leave Alfred C. Chapin?"

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 14. -- This morning the Central Insane Asylum, situated seven miles from this city, is almost a mass of ruins, and beneath it are the charred bodies of half a dozen of the unfortunate inmates. At 10:15 last night Watchman Fitzhugh discovered an ugly tongue of flame breaking through the roof of the western main wing of the building.

Those who think that amateur photographers make a plaything of their fad would soon have that idea dispelled if they attended one of the meetings of either the Society of Amateur Photographers or the Camera Club of this city. At these meetings there is invariably some new apparatus to be shown, an improvement upon a camera, plate, or method of developing the latter.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14. -- Aristotle's "Treatise on the Constitution of Athens," which was recently discovered and of which the British Museum secured the original and has had several copies struck off, is just now a topic of interest at Harvard. Two of these copies have been received by Harvard. Prof. William Watson Goodwin has given several talks on the nature and value of this manuscript, which show it to be a most important discovery.

CHICAGO, March 14. -- The novelties of the last week in theatrical circles were Marie Tempest in "Dorothy," and Rosina Vokes's company in "Barbara" and "Frederic Lemaitre." Miss Marie Tempest appeared to advantage in "Dorothy" at the Grand. The production by the Duff company was more satisfactory than was that of "The Red Hussar." The Vokes company added to its laurels and profits at Hooley's.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, March 14. -- The Senior Class, department of mechanical engineering, accompanied by Instructor L.P. Breckenridge, was in New-York for four days this week, inspecting various manufactories.

HANOVER, March 14. -- The regular Spring trip of the 'Varsity baseball team has been arranged as follows: April 2 at New-Haven, April 3 and 4 at Philadelphia, 6 and 7 at Baltimore, 8 and 9 at Charlottesville, Va., and on the 10th the team plays the New Yorks.

AMHERST, March 14. -- This season's lecture course has been most prosperous, notwithstanding the existence of a town lecture course. Every concert and entertainment has been of the highest order, and, although the scheduled course was completed at the last concert by Mary Howe, the managers intend to give two more entertainments.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, March 14. -- There were several competitors for the Quick prize, which was awarded to John H. Thompson of this city. The latter banqueted the defeated aspirants on Wednesday night.

A disagreement between District Attorney Nicoll and the four Judges of the Court of General Sessions over the necessity of a fourth part of the court is apparent from the following letter from the Judges. The District Attorney has, however, gone ahead with his bill and introduced it in the Legislature:

Large crowds have been gathering nightly at the Coliseum Rink in Harlem to witness the fancy exhibitions and races on roller skates. The toboggan slide, however, has attracted the most attention. During this week Thomas D. Phillips, Miss Jessie Brunsfield, and Master Robert Wood will do some fancy skating, and there will be races between representatives of well-know amateur athletic clubs of this city and Brooklyn.

Until recently the neglect of the art of the sword in the army and navy of the United States has been a natural consequence of the conditions under which both branches of the service have existed. Nothing is more common than to hear army and navy men repeat that arms of precision have destroyed whatever good there once was in expertness with the sword.

At Pariseus Groove, on the beach of Raritan Bay, two hundred yards from the railroad station at South Amboy, Phineas Munday, professional fishermen, has erected an oblong stockade of substantial hemlock planks and embarked in the dime museum business. Showman Munday's stock in trade, his "curiosity," as it were, is a whale, which is yet not a whale, being unquestionably a narwhal, but nevertheless an undoubted curiosity.

It was rather surprising to learn recently from good authority that a custom prevails more or less nowadays of acknowledging wedding presents verbally. "Brides wait," it was asserted, "until the giver is encountered in person to express pleasure over the gift," which would seem a very unfair arrangement. Intimate friends would thus learn promptly of the appreciation of their offerings, while casual acquaintances and strangers would stand a chance of considerable delay in so doing.

Between fifty and sixty pool rooms were in full blast in this city yesterday afternoon, and all of them were doing a lively business on the so-called races being run at Guttenberg and Gloucester. Policemen in uniform paraded back and forth before the doors leading to these gambling rooms, but made no attempt to interfere with the business which was being transacted.

" Diamond Joe" is dead. The news comes to New-York in a telegram announcing application for administration of an estate valued at $2,500,000 in personalty. One item is a half interest in the Crown Point Mine at Leadville the co-tenant being J.D. Morrissey. Another item is a railway, probably the only existing one owned exclusively by a woman.

ALBANY, March 14. -- A resolution calling for the final adjournment of the Legislature not later than April 30 will probably be introduced in the House next week. It is possible that April 23 will be the date fixed upon by the Democrats, who are desirous of winding up the session sooner than the Republicans did last year, in order to make a little political capital.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 14. -- All last week, both here and at Albany, the greatest effort was made by attorneys to compromise with Vassar College, so that the next of kin of John Guy Vassar would not contest that portion of his will which gives the college $650,000, it being claimed by the next of kin that the bequest was illegal because Vassar cannot have an income of over $40,000 per annum.

I was pleased to see in your paper that the druggists of Binghamton had at last taken some action against that arrogant monopoly, the Whisky Trust, the late doings of which are incurring disgust and condemnation among druggists, manufacturers who use alcohol largely, as well as liquor dealers.

WICHITA, Kan., March 14. -- From New-York City to Wichita, through a score of States and Territories, a journey occupying six weeks has just proved a fruitless errand, and Mr. Delhomme and Henry Crisp of New-York City find themselves foiled after having had every assurance that to-day would restore to them the little child they were in search of.

BRUNSWICK, March 14. -- The all-absorbing subject of the organization of a general athletic committee has at last been settled. Wednesday the whole body of students met in Memorial Hall to take action on another constitution brought in by the appointed committee. After being thoroughly discussed and slightly amended it was unanimously accepted.

Gov. HILL is the first Governor in the Union to make a requisition upon the United States Treasury for the money to be paid to the States under the Direct Tax Refunding law. This law is thoroughly bad in its origin, purpose, and history. It is uncalled for, unjustifiable, and probably unconstitutional.

Mr. COCKRELL is one of the Farmers' Alliance members of the Illinois Assembly who aided in the election of Gen. PALMER to the Senate. In a speech at a Democratic dinner in Chicago on Friday evening he is reported to have said: "On behalf of 4,000,000 farmers I wish to warn you that you cannot make GROVER CLEVELAND the next President of the United States."

District Attorney Fitzgerald of Richmond County, S.I., who is trying to solve the mystery of the murder of Carl E. Ruttinger, is anxious to learn where William Wright is. Wright was the brother-in-law of the dead man, an Englishman, and the close friend and companion of Ruttinger. He has shown no interest in Ruttinger since the murder.

The Supreme Court has affirmed the judgment of the Superior Court of San Diego County in the case of William C. Nagle against the California Southern Railroad Company -- a suit for damages for personal injuries alleged to have been sustained by Nagle.

" I can tell you a little story about Charlie Foster's father that illustrates the fact that there is nothing obtuse or dense about the Foster family," Mr. Mahlon Chance said the other day as, with a group of well-known men, he was talking of the new Secretary of the Treasury.

Papers were submitted to Judge Beach, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday for and against the acceptance of the American Surety Company's bond on an appeal in the suit of Rachel B. Pollock against the Brooklyn Cross-town Railroad Company. When the defendant proposed, on its appeal, to offer the surety company's bond as security, Mr. David Tim examined one of the company's officers and declared that he was not willing to accept the security.

HARTFORD, March 14. -- The Rev. D.L.R. Libby, State Missionary of the Universalist denomination in Connecticut, has received a unanimous call to the pastorate of the First Universalist Church in Putnam and will be located there permanently for the future. Mr. Libby has been connected with State mission work for years and has been a successful representative of the denomination.

Yesterday's session of the Ives sale was the last, the prettiest, and the most brilliant. The pedestal for vases that the solemn black man -- in black, red, yellow, and gold, and with a chrysanthemum on each shoulder -- attends had been recovered with velvet of Peruvian gold color. The auction room was crowded. There were many women.

The glass factory of the Lippincott Lamp Chimney Company at Findlay, Ohio, was destroyed by fire yesterday morning, together with a large stock of manufactured goods in the warerooms and six carloads of goods on a side track. The loss is estimated at $40,000; fully covered by insurance.

The contrast between the various trials of armor plates and projectiles conducted of late on the ordnance proving grounds at Annapolis, and some of those that have been going on in England gives a fresh indication that our navy, having at last gained a creditable position in the manufacture both of guns and armor, means to hold it.

Naturally the public sales that have been held in the metropolis almost continuously since early in February have brought together trotting turfmen from all quarters. No more democratic assembly could be found anywhere than that which gathers at these events, from the man who reckons his wealth by tens of millions to the one who calculates closely whether he can spare the few hundreds that will secure what looks like a bargain.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,969,150, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,074,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $25,436,200; 4 per cents, $108,458,950.

COPENHAGEN, March 14. -- Philipsen, the soap manufacturer, who was arrested in April, 1890, for participation in insurance frauds, and who confessed that he had strangled a clerk named Meyer, who had been missing since Jan. 7, 1890, and had sent his body to New-York in a lime cask, has been condemned to death.

It is remarkable, considering the amount of annual recognition and honor which is paid to the memory of St. Patrick and the place he holds in the hearts of an entire people, that so little should be known concerning him which is not open to doubt, discussion, and even contradiction. Volumes and treatises in plenty have been written, but the evidence they offer is meagre and unsatisfactory.

Wall Street is feeling better than it did ten days ago, when the adjournment of Congress was followed by another slump in the market. It felt blue enough then. Things wore a very doleful aspect. But it has recovered a little, and begins to hope again. Prices have improved in the past few days, except for the anthracite coal stocks, which were depressed by the decision in the famous Coxe suit before the Inter-State Commission.

Carnivorous man is forbidden to eat the flesh of the ruminating beasts for forty "fast days of precept," as the Archbishop calls the season of Lent, yet he need not go hungry nor unsatisfied. Beef and veal, mutton and lamb, pork and fowl are banished absolutely for two days each week of Lent; the remaining days of the week such food is allowed conditionally.

BOSTON, March 14. -- The Bernhardt engagement being over, society people are preparing to flee the town. Life in Boston is voted barely endurable by these unregenerate minds while the highly flavored social courses are served, but when the annual literature-and-water period sets in they feel called to move on.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 14. -- A death which, it is possible, resulted from violence was discovered in this city at about 7 o'clock this evening by ex-Assemblyman James S. Beckwith, one of the proprietors of the Ocean House. A private cottage at 108 South Connecticut Avenue, just opposite the Ocean House, has been occupied since December by a middle-aged maiden lady named Laura Purnell and a year-old baby.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 14. -- The Rev. Dr. R.W. Van Schoick, Presiding Elder of the Wyoming District of the Methodist Episcopal Church, has accepted the appointment of pastor of the First Methodist Church of Albion, Mich. Dr. Van Schoick formerly served in the itineracy as pastor of Methodist churches at Norwich and New-Berlin and other points in Central New-York.

Bonfires were blazing in various parts of Sing Sing long after midnight Friday night in celebration of the victory won at the primary meeting by the Young Democracy of the town under the lead of Francis Larkin, Jr., over the bossism and Czarism of ex-State Senator Henry C. Nelson, who now appears to have got to the end of his rope.

This volume will rank fairly well with others that have gone before it in the same series. But the reader must judge it with full recognition of the fact that the materials extant for a biography of Thackeray are very meagre. Trollope's unsatisfactory sketch has heretofore been the only approach made to a work of biography.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14. -- There has been but one subject discussed by the trotting-horse men of Kentucky during the last week, and that is the proposed new National Breeders' Association. Judge Irving Halsey ("Iconoclast") was asked yesterday if he thought the breeders ought to control registration.

It is morally certain that before many years have passed there will be a revolution in the University Club and that the revolutionary element now termed "the opposition" will manage to secure a voice in the management of the club. As it is, the club is controlled by a certain clique, principally Yale and Harvard men, and the men from the little colleges have precious little to say about how it shall be run.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 14. -- This resort has lost none of its former popularity in the Lenten season. Many of the guests who were here last year are here again this Winter, many of them making their homes at the Laurel House, as has been their custom. The Lakewood became popular at once, and every Saturday and Sunday finds from five to seven hundred guests there.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 14. -- In every paper in the city this morning appeared the following call:

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., March 14. -- The United States steamship Galena and the United States steam tug Nina went ashore at 10:15 last night one mile South of Gay Head Lighthouse, during a strong southerly wind and dense fog. The Galena was being towed from New-York to Portsmouth by the Nina.

The explorer, when speculating on the possibilities of the colonization of a newly-discovered land, must first consult his thermometer, next his rain gauge. There may be the likelihood of future greatness in a land when he mercury stands during the year at such a given height, and no chances at all when it either ascends or descends above or below a certain mark.
BERLIN, March 14. -- Dr. Ludgwig Windthorst, the Parliamentary leader of the Catholic party in Prussia, who had been dangerously ill for some days past, died at 8:15 o'clock this morning.

" They'll have a ghost dance in the Cabinet whenever the Indian policy comes up," said a man just from Washington yesterday. "There will be a three-cornered row, and Ben Harrison will have hard work to keep the peace. They have had no end of trouble over the question of dealing with the Sioux, and Charlie Foster's appointment to be Secretary of the Treasury will make more.

ROXBURY, N.Y., March 14. -- The oldest white man probably in the United States, whose age can be clearly authenticated, is Eri Grey, whore-sides at Roxbury, Delaware County, N.Y. The records in the Town Clerk's office at Weston, Fairfield County, Conn., attest the fact that Mr. Gray was born in that town on Dec. 16, 1785, and while yet a youth removed to this State.

The Special Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Reapportionment practically ended its work yesterday. The committee has spent much valuable time and no little money in what appears to be a wholly useless enterprise. It will undoubtedly recommend to the Legislature that an enumeration of the inhabitants of this State should be ordered this year, but this it could have done just as well after holding a five-minute session in Albany.

ADAM SMITH AND THE CHANGES. -- Throughout "The Wealth of Nations" Adam Smith constantly dwells on the disadvantage which mere distance imposes on the trader. The home trade is preferable to the Continental trade, and the Continental trade to the American trade, because the returns in each case are quicker.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 14 -- The Allegheny County License Court will open next Monday. Judges White and Magee will be on the bench. The Indications are that the court will not permit the interference of any one or ask the assistance of any one. Judge White has indicated his policy in the License Court in his recent charge to the Grand Jury.

The business men of New-York have a good deal of work on hand between now and next December, if they hope to prevent, at the next session of Congress, action that may seriously compromise their interests, and that may beyond that affect injuriously the interests and the honor of the whole country for a long time to come.

The twelve striking cloakmakers charged with wrecking Billet Greenbaum's cloakmaking establishment in Jamaica, L.I., and Joseph Barondess, the leader, charged with inciting and planning the riot, were arraigned for examination before Justice Hendrickson in the Jamaica Town Hall yesterday. The room was packed with friends of the prisoners and townspeople.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Marchh 15. -- A desperate effort is being made to swing West Virginia into line for David B. Hill. AS early as last September this matter was talked over among the adherents of the Governor-Senator, and when the campaign came on, Thomas F. Grady was sent to Ohio and West Virginia to see what could be done.

WASHINGTON, March. 14. -- A sumptuous volume has just been sent out from the Bureau of the American Republics, of which Mr. William Eleroy Curtis is the Manager, as Bulletin No. 1 of a series that is to about exhaust every subject of interest concerning the countries in Latin America with which, by the help of reciprocity, Mr. Blaine and Mr. Curtis are promising to build up an immense trade.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 15. -- A Sabbath quiet rests over the city to-day, but public spirit is still heated over yesterday's occurrences. The action of the Vigilantes meets with the approval of all. The New Delta, a leading Democratic daily, thus concisely summarizes the sentiment of the city:

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 15. -- Fred W. Hall of Cleveland, Ohio, and Miss Katie Warren of this city were married here Friday night. They had become acquainted while the young lady was visiting her brother in Cleveland. After the ceremony the bride and groom and invited guests sat down to a wedding supper in the house of the bride's father.

The most favorable reports are being received in this city from all portions of the fruit-growing regions of this country as to the probable crop of the coming season. The rainfall over the United States east of the Mississippi last season during the period when new wood was forming on the fruit trees was all that the most enthusiastic fruit grower could desire.

The amendment of the law providing for a tax upon inheritances which is proposed by the bill introduced at Albany by Senator VEDDER applies a principle entirely different from that upon which the original law is based. The act of 1885 provided for taxing "collateral" inheritances, that is, the estate of a deceased person which does not go to direct heirs.

ALBANY, March 15. -- To say that Hill stock has declined in the past ten days is putting it mildly indeed. Quotations on the boss political hog are most disheartening to his friends, and the market shows every sign of a further disastrous slump.

The seventh payment has just been made on the Maine's boilers and engines, which shows that those very important parts of the big battle ship are seven-tenths completed. They are being rapidly put together at the Quintard Iron Works in this city. The new steel columns for the engines, which were forged at Bethlehem, have arrived, and they will take the place of the old and imperfect ones this week.

We learn with satisfaction that the Wholesale Grocers' Association of St. Louis has taken steps to renew the agitation in favor of the Torrey Bankruptcy bill, which passed the House in the late Congress and failed, as was said, for lack of time in the Senate. There were several unpleasant features about the facts which this vague explanations intended to cover.

ALBANY, March 15. -- THE TIMES'S correspondent called to-day upon an eminent lawyer of this city and asked his opinion upon Senator Vedder's bill to enlarge, the inheritance tax so as to include all estates of over $5,000 by taxing inheritances, by father, mother, husband, wife, child, brother, sister, daughter-in-law, son-in-law, or adopted child, not now subject to such taxation.

PITTSBURG, March 15. -- William Slicker, until recently President of the International Association of Window-Glass Workers, who was charged with having aided in the importation of contract labor to the window-glass plant of Chambers McKee of Jeannette, Penn., has been suspended from Local Assembly No. 300, Knights of Labor, for three years.

By holding out false inducements and by making promises which they will never be able to fulfill, the joint agents of the elevated railroad company and of a number of owners of suburban property in Yonkers and beyond have procured the indorsement by two organizations of real estate dealers and owners of the scheme to give to the elevated railroads the use of an additional slice of Battery Park.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Secretary Rusk was asked this evening what he thought of the statement said to have been made by Dr. von Boetticher, in the Roichstag, on behalf of the German Government, to the effect that the new sanitary measures adopted in the United States were inadequate, and therefore that the Government did not intend to rescind the prohibition placed upon the importation of American hog products.

TACOMA, Washington, March 15. -- Larry Kelly, one of the most desperate and successful smugglers on the coast, was arrested last night on board a train for Portland. It happened that on the train were Mr. Mulky, special agent of the Treasury Department, and Inspector Fox. In passing through the smoking car Mr. Mulky's eyes happened to light upon Kelly, whom he recognized at once, sitting in a seat with another man.

Getting the jury is one of the most tedious proceedings of a criminal trial, and often in cases which are not even commented upon in the newspapers a couple of hundred talesmen are examined before the twelve satisfactory men are obtained. All sorts of things operate to make men if not ineligible, at least unsatisfactory.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 15. -- There was considerable excitement here to-day in Italian quarters. Large numbers of Italians gathered during the day at the office of the Italian Consul, where they had translated to them the newspaper accounts of the New-Orleans tragedy. They were bitter in their denunciation of the affair.
HALIFAX, N.S., March 15. -- A semi-official statement of the grievances of Newfoundland with reference to the imperial Government has been issued, which in substance is as follows:

The residence of Gen. Edward B. Fowler, a two-and-a-half-story brownstone house at 532 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, was on fire yesterday morning, and the General's son William, aged twenty-one years, lost his life. The other members of the family escaped without injury.

The publication in yesterday's TIMES of a description of the flourishing condition in which the business of pool selling is in this city at present evidently caused much commotion in the ranks not only of the lawbreakers themselves, but among those who, although in authority, allow the lawbreaking to go on under their very noses.

There is a surprising public demand for bridges across the East River. The tendency of the people of Brooklyn to want a thing badly when they want it at all is famous. Just now the fad is for bridges. Neighborhoods are clamoring for them as children cry for toys. They must have bridges, and nothing but bridges will satisfy them.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Treasury Department and the Government of the United States are in the way of being hampered by the assurance and obstinacy of the Knights of Labor, who control the operations of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- A large representative meeting of Italians was held here this evening to take action in regard to the occurrence of yesterday at New-Orleans. Dr. Volino presided, and in opening the meeting delivered an impassioned address. Among other things, he said: "Our countrymen have been vilely slain by a mob of assassins; shot down and murdered by a lawless and barbarous mob in the city of New-Orleans.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., March 15. -- The news of the wreck of the Galena was received with sorrow by several hundred workmen employed in the navy yard here, as the vessel was on her way there, where nearly $100,000 was to have been spent in repairs to be made upon her.

Ten or fifteen individuals and corporations have practically taken possession of over a score of streets in Brooklyn and have coolly erected fences and gates at the foot of such thoroughfares, thereby preventing the ordinary citizen from reaching the water front.
MONTREAL, March 15. -- This city and vicinity have been visited during the last twenty-four hours by a terrific hurricane and blizzard, and great damage has been done to the city by the wind.

Our readers will find in our columns this morning the facts forwarded by our London correspondent regarding the men whom PARNELL has sent to this country to try to wheedle money from Irish-Americans. We have no fear that they will get much, but we cannot refrain from calling attention to the fact, which ought to be obvious enough, that every dollar given them will prove a contribution to the defeat of home rule.

ST. LOUIS, March 15. -- Several people in St. Louis have just discovered that they have been duped by a woman who once held a good social position. Her name is Mrs. Jennie Livingstone. She is a rather handsome blonde, somewhat faded, but with large, innocent-looking gray eyes. She is, or was, the wife of a man formerly connected with the largest wholesale dry goods house in the city.

ST. LOUIS, March 15. -- The local political situation is decidedly mixed and gets more so every day. A ticket of six candidates for the City Council has been put in the field by the certificate plan under the Australian ballot law. These candidates are representative citizens, all of wealth and high social and business standing. Three of them are known to be Democrats and three Republicans.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 15. -- At 5 o'clock this morning, before the firemen had left the scene of the disasters of the previous day, fire broke out in the St. James Episcopal Church, in Look Street, near James, in this city and, having destroyed the structure, spread to the McLennan flats, next adjoining, owned by Peter B. McLennan.
