The threads of it, almost imperceptible, fall on the blade, appear in the daylight like a spider's web dipped in dew under the morning sun. Suddenly one said: "Mr. Sutton must have had two Morgan vases." And he told the mystery of the peachblow vase.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Several attempts have been made to-night to see Secretary Tracy and Assistant Secretary Soley to ascertain from them the necessity for the costly experiment of towing the Galena from New-York to Kittery Navy Yard. Mr. Tracy was reported to be out. At the house of Mr. Soley he was reported to be with the Secretary at the house of the latter.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 15. -- The anti-Campbell Democrats have been in clover since the decision of the Supreme Court last week which returned to power the old Board of Public Works ousted by a special act of the Legislature.

The Moniteur de Rome is kind enough to devote a leader to the school question in the United States, which, it remarks, is "burningly delicate," but it adds that it does not expect a conflict between the Catholics and the civil authorities. It believes that the Catholics are too wise and the "American civil powers" are too just and tolerant to permit the breaking out of a Kulturkampf in the United States.

The lynching of a pair of murderers or horse thieves in the West or Southwest is not an event of such uncommon occurrence as to attract much attention. But the New-Orleans mob shot to death eleven victims. Two or three others upon whom it sought to carry out its notions of justice could not be found.

While the tests of the Mefford-Zalinski pneumatic gun at Shoeburyness are conducted by the British ordnance authorities with such precautions against publicity as to give rise to contradictory reports about the results, the weight of evidence seems to be that in accuracy of fire it has surpassed all expectations.

WASHINGTON, March 15.- The Italian Legation in this city has mysteriously disappeared, at a time when it would be interesting, if not important, to get an opinion form the Minister or the Secretary of Legation as to what course they may be expected to pursue to secure from the Government of the United States proper notice of the killing of the Sicilians in New Orleans.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 7, (Special correspondence TIMES.) -- California has just passed through a protracted period of heavy rain. Three weeks ago the ranchers of Middle and Southern California, and for that matter the entire business community as well, for everything here depends upon the crops, were praying for rain.
PARIS, March 15. -- President and Mme. Carnot, together with the Ministers of the Cabinet and many other notable people, to-night attended a dress rehearsal of Massenet's opera "Le Mage."

The Senate Committee on General Laws apparently pins its faith to its Chairman, Senator Vedder, for during the past three sessions of the investigation into the affairs of the Sugar Trust, from which he has been absent owing to the death of his father-in-law, the course of the committee has been aimless.

There will be two parades to-day in honor of the natal day of Ireland's patron saint. One will take in the upper and the other the lower part of the city, so that every New-Yorker will have an excellent chance to view the demonstration.

There are several Republican lawyers in Brooklyn who hope to profit by the power given to President Harrison to appoint a new Circuit Judge of the United States Supreme Court, whose district shall include New-York, Vermont, and Connecticut. They have begun to lay pipes already, and the most mileage is claimed by two well-known gentlemen, William W. Goodrich and Jesse Johnson.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The triple loss of the Galena, the Nina, and the Triana, at Gay Head and Cuttyhunk, may prove to be not only a national but a political disaster.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Mr. Gould's Battery Park grab bill is quietly slumbering in the Cities Committee of the Assembly under the paternal care of Chairman Blumenthal. The conviction has forced itself on many people here in Albany that the Tammany organization is committed to this measure in return for past favors from the Wall Street Wizard.

Judge John Riker Brady of the Supreme Court died yesterday morning at his residence, 2 East Fifteenth Street, after an illness of only eleven hours. Although nearly seventy years old, and beginning recently to show the effects of advancing age in a less firm stop and somewhat feebler bearing, his general health was apparently good, and there appeared every reason for supposing that he still had years of active, life before him.

RUTLAND, Vt., March 16. -- Some years ago N.T. Sprague, President of the Sprague National Bank of Brooklyn, was one of a company which tried to run a hotel in Brandon, in this State, without a bar. The attempt was a signal failure financially. Since then hotels in Brandon, as in other parts of the State, have sold liquor, with only occasional fines which amount to about the same as a license would cost.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 14. -- John P. Richardson, who owns the biggest dry goods house in New-Orleans, besides thousands of dollars' worth of other property there, and who is famous as the largest cotton planter in the world, is in Chattanooga. In an interview to-night about the New-Orleans tragedy, he said:

Bright and early yesterday morning the proprietors of the fifty-eight city poolrooms, which are credited with being under police protection, opened their places for business. Customers began to drift in about 9 o'clock, and they found in each of their favorite resorts the blackboards bearing the names of the horses entered to start in the several races at Guttenberg and Gloucester all ready for business.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 16. -- The Episcopal Court which heard the charge of heresy against the Rev. Howard MacQueary of Canton, Ohio, held three long sessions at Trinity Cathedral to-day and adjourned at 10 o'clock to-night. It will probably convene to-morrow and finish its work. The Rev. Mr. MacQueary was found guilty as charged by a vote of three to two.

Hearings are to be given, beginning with to-day, before the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment at Albany on the principal taxation bills now pending. A large number of commercial and industrial bodies have provided for representation at these hearings, and if the time is judiciously divided and effectively employed it ought to be possible to give our legislators some greatly-needed enlightenment regarding the effect of the proposed "listing system."

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- "Baby" McKee had a birthday anniversary party at the White House to-day to celebrate the beginning of his fourth year of existence. For the first time this conspicuous grandson put on knickerbockers. The knickerbockers and jacket were of black velvet, the collar and cuffs very broad, and there were abundant ruffles of lace upon "Baby's" shirt front.

The Italian population of New-Orleans is apparently larger, in proportion, than that of any other city in the United States.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 16. -- The revenue euVcers Dexter of Newport and Gallatin of Boston arrived in this harbor at 11 o'clock this morning. The Dexter had on board the officers and ew of the TeXans, wrecked at Cuttyhunk,

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 16. -- What will probably be a long and bitter fight has opened between the city of Plainfield and the Plainfield Water Supply Company. The company has no franchise from the city to lay water pipes through the streets, but claims authority from a charter granted to it twenty years ago.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- This is the day on which the Jacksonville Southeastern agreed to furnish the Alton Road with a complete statement of all the tickets of every description it has outstanding. The statement was not forthcoming, and this evening General Passenger Agent Charlton of the Alton notined the office of Chairman Finley that he should expect an immediate ruling on his application for authority to make a two-cent rate on mileage tickets.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16. -- Secretary John R. Fanshawe of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company make the following statement concerning the decision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the Coxe suit that is of interest: "In the absence of our President, Mr. Wilbur, I cannot say positively what will be done. I know his views, however, sufficiently well, I think, to state what he will be likely to do.

Judge Wallace of the United States Circuit Court yesterday denied the application for Commissioners to condemn the Bowling Green site for a Custom House.

It has been announced that Dr. ROYER is in Washington seeking a reappointment to the Indian Agency at Pine Ridge, his incumbency of which was one of the main causes of the uprising of the Indians, and his removal from which, at the request of the military authorities, was made necessary by his scandalous incompetency.

Already the "Alliance" movement is developing those differences of opinion and of interest that are stimulated rather than repressed by a secret organization. In the first stages of the movement it was naturally the rallying point of many different kinds of discontent, but so soon as the combination of these has given it a certain amount of tangible power, the internal quarrels begin as to what use shall be made of that power.

RED BANK, N.J., March 16. -- Grace Methodist Episcopal Church is a split from the First Methodist Episcopal Church. The separation occurred several years ago when the Rev. Charles W. Heisley was pastor of the church. Grace Church has had a large number of pastors, but the relations between the pastors and people have been at times quite unpleasant because of the numerous social classes represented in the congregation.

A remarkably strong and impressive performance of an interesting and well-contrived new play was given by Mr. Palmer's company at the Madison Square Theatre last evening. Compared with the mawkish and insipid "Sunlight and Shadow," which has just passed into oblivion, "The Pharisee" seems to be a noble work of art.

Smith Morehouse is a rugged old farmer of sixty years, who lives near Pine Island, Orange County, N.Y. About a mile away, in Vernon Township, Sussex County, N.J., just across the border, lives William Owen, also about sixty years old, and a close friend of Morehouse. The two men have always accompanied each other to town.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., March 16. -- The banking house of F.R. Weed Co. failed to open its doors this morning, and a single placard on the door announced that the bank had closed. The institution was the oldest private bank in the city, having conducted business successfully for over twenty years.

A large number of the regular passengers -- most of them New-York business men -- who patronize the branch of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad between this city and Montclair, N.J., complain that the train service allowed them is very poor in point of promptitude. One of these gentlemen said yesterday to a TIMES reporter that the Montclair trains are almost invariably late anywhere from a quarter of an hour to forty-five minutes.

Representative HOLMAN of Indiana, who has always been a champion of economy in public expenditures, has many reasons for regarding the Fifty-first Congress as the worst in the history of the country, but he seems to regard its extravagance as its worst offense. He rightly deplores the influence of the precedent which it set upon the standard of national expenditures, which it is difficult to retrench after the bad precedent has been established.

ROME, March 16. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Marquis di Rudini, the Italian Premier, said that President Harrison had recognized the right of Italians in the United States to protection from the authorities, and that he had expressed profound regret at the occurrence and had charged the Governor of Louisiana to guard the Italian residents of New-Orleans and to bring the assassins to justice.

An address delivered at the Chattanooga basic steel banquet last Thursday by Mr. Frederic Taylor of this city attracted a great deal of attention. Mr. Taylor, in responding to the toast "Our Country," said, in substance:

The acquisition by the New-York Central of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad has given rise to much talk and speculation regarding the future movements of the Canadian Pacific and the New-York, Ontario and Western. The Canadian Pacific is supposed to be desirous of coming to New-York without going to the expense of building any net lines of its own. It is in the market for an advantageous dicker with some other road.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 16. -- The fourth and final hearing before Commissioner Henry Bacon and a Sheriff's jury in the matter of the alleged lunacy of Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Carroll was held at the Court House at Goshen to-day. Mrs. Carroll has been an inmate of the Middletown Homeopathic Insane Hospital since May, 1885. Her husband, George D. Carroll, is a stationer of East Fourteenth Street, New-York.

The discursive mind of District Attorney NICOLL has been somewhat abruptly turned from his self-assumed task of creating a fourth part of the Court of General Sessions to a consideration of the unsatis factory state of his own official business. This was done with the utmost neatness and courtesy by Judges SMYTH, COWING, MARTINE, and FITZGERALD of the court in question in the letter published in THE TIMES of Sunday.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 16. -- The Judson bill vill be the first thing to be considered by the House when it reassembles te-morrow afternoom There is a general feeling that it will not pass in its presen form, he Republicans themselves having abandoned it when under debate last Thursday, desertin the floor of the House ' in order to escape voting on its adoption.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- No further action will he taken by the Federal authorities at Washington in regard to the shooting of Italians at New-Orleans until after the receipt of Gov. Nicholls's reply to Secretary Blaine's telegram.

The efforts of the Mayor and other Tammany officials to annoy and embarrass Commissioner HEINTZ of the annexed district are not merely a particularly small and mean business, but they are a distinct violation of public duty and an injury to the interests of an important section of the city.

LONDON, March 16. -- The Slur this evening la of the opinion that "the impressive feature of the Nev-Orleans affair was the lerfeo orderliness maintained throughout The proceedings. Here, champions of law and order stand aghas at such proceedings. The American Democracy has sounder notions as to what law and orde really mean."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16. -- For some time past a number of Republican organs of the State have strongly urged that the candidate for United States Senator be named by the delegates to the State Convention, and in the event of the success of this plan there would be no doubt as to who the next Senator would be.

The judgment that has been announced in the case of the Rev. HOWARD MACQUERY is hardly a square verdict, though three out of the five judges of the ecclesiastical court believe that he ought to be condemned. Two are for his expulsion from the ministry, one is for his suspension from office, and the other two hold that no penalty is demanded.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 17. -- The Rev. W.J. Holland, D.D. Ph. D., was to-day unanimously elected Chancellor of the Western University, the foremost educational institution in Western Pennsylvania. He succeeds Milton B. Goff, who died recently. It is understood that Dr. Holland will accept the place and resign the pastorate of the Bellefield Presbyterian Church, this city.

ALBANY, March 17. -- The charges made by Lieut. Moriarty of Company D, Sixty-ninth Regiment, against Col. Cavanagh of that command have been received at General Headquarters. The former charges his commandant with having on Feb. 19 at the armory addressed him in these words: "You -- scoundrel, you are the cause of all this.

A number of well-known music lovers of this city are trying to induce Herr Scharwenka, founder of the Berlin Conservatorium, to establish a counterpart of that institution in this city. It is intended to raise a guarantee fund of $200,000. Three-fourths of this sum have already been subscribed. This would enable Herr Scharwenka to devote his entire attention for three years to the work.

St. Patrick's popularity seems to run in inverse proportion to the weather. When the day is rainy, as usually happens, the processions and the crowds are both large, but when a pleasant day, such as yesterday, comes along there is a noticeable falling off. The crisp breeze swayed hundreds of green flags about town.

At the exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Tuesday, March 17, Smith and Ryan, auctioneers sold two three-story brick stores, with plot of land 40.2 by 80, 705 and 707 3d Av, east side, 20 feet north of 44th St for $28,200, to David Cohen.

Barnes Compton, Congressman from the Fifth District of Maryland, said yesterday that he wanted a Congressional committee appointed to investigate and make public the frauds in the election of Thomas B. Reed in Maine last Fall. Mr. Compton was at the St. James Hotel. He came to New-York to see his son, who is an officer in the Military Academy at West Point.

There were meetings of the Boards of Trustees of the Normal College and College of the City of New-York yesterday. For the Normal College, President Thomas Hunter presented a resolution for a suspension of the by-law requiring candidates for admission to pass examinations in, among other studies, history and geography, and accepting, in lieu of the same, the certificate of the student's proficiency in these studies from teachers of the first grammar grade

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 17. -- The latest news from the wreck of the Triana on Schooner Ledge, gleaned by a Standard representative, who went to Cuttyhunk this morning on a special tug, is that that vessel is lying in about the same position as when she struck. The heavy seas of yesterday and last night did not materially damage the hull, although the deck houses were washed away.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- When Mr. Bayard was Secretary of State there were not a few representatives of newspapers here who complained that he was exclusive and that he very reluctantly consented to see and converse with newspaper men about the business of the State Department.

BOSTON, March 17. -- President Eliot of Harvard, who has just returned from a six weeks' absence in the West, said to-day that the growth which the West had made in educational matter, in the last few years was marvelous. "I was particularly impressed," said he, "with the rapid strides which all the State universities have made.

Of course, a formal remonstrance from the Italian Government against the lawless and irregular killing of certain Italians in New-Orleans is to be expected, and the remonstrance may be coupled with a demand for indemnity. The answer of our Government is perfectly plain, and is furnished by an unbroken series of precedents.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 17. -- The fire at Highland Village last night broke out in the Tillson Building. In a short time the entire block of buildings, including the large Maynard Building, was in flames. Word was dispatched to the Poughkeepsie Fire Department for aid. Chief Engineer Caldwell of that department immediately secured transportation for Steamer No. 4 on the bridge railroad and reached the scene of conflagration in time to do excellent service.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 17. -- Elias Young, residing in Jackson Township, was brought here this afternoon charged with the killing of Lieut. J. Stewart Robinson on Aug. 3, 1864. This was during the war, when Solomon Taylor, a United States officer, called upon Robinson and others to assist him in capturing deserters.

CONCORD, N.H., March 17. -- It is settled, most persons think, that the New-Hampshire Legislature will not enact a secret ballot law this year. The reason why it has been so settled is that the Republicans are afraid to institute any system under the operation of which the people might hold honest elections. New-Hampshire Republicans thoroughly believe that when honest elections come in their party must go out.

ROME, March 17. -- Since Crispi's fall a certain relaxation is noticeable in the relations between the Vatican and the Quirinal. The present Cabinet, with the support of the Court, is hopeful that the Pope may ere long be induced to allow Catholics to vote and take part in Italian politics. But there is a strong feeling against this.
ELMIRA, N.Y., March 17. -- Ex-Gov. Lucius Robinson is better to-day and hopes are entertained of his recovery.

On a sunlit hill in the Methodist Cemetery at Tottenville, S.I., in the presence of a large gathering of villagers, the black casket containing the body of the man found in the mud near Ellis Dock, opposite Perth Amboy, a week ago, was yesterday lowered into its final resting place. On the lid of the casket was the inscription:

An understanding between the officers of the New-York Central and the officers of the New-York, Ontario and Western has been reached by which the last-named road will continue its close relations with the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad. Presidents Depew and Fowler have conferred on the subject, and there will be no change in the status of the Ontario and Western, at least for the present.
ROME, March 17. -- Prince Napoleon is dead. The end came about 7 o'clock this evening.

Minden's poolrooms were crowded from 2 o'clock until 5 yesterday afternoon, and the men who were at work there had all the business they could attend to. The place has two entrances, one at 33 West Twenty-ninth Street and one at 1,213 Broadway. Police Commissioners, officers, private citizens, in fact anybody may go there.
PARIS, March 17. -- The Princesse Marianne Bonaparte, a grandniece of Napoleon I., died to-day at Ajaccio, Corsica.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 17. -- The river at this city is rapidly rising to the highest point yet known. In several places the water is flowing over the levees, but the overflow was prevented from doing any damage by the rear levees built for protection against last year's waters. At 6 o'clock the gauge marked 16.8 feet, the highest yet reached, but it fluctuated considerably.

COLUMBUS, March 17. -- The lobbies and corridors of the House wore filled to-day by the delegation from Cincinnati, who had come to Columbus to aid in the passage of the bill providing for a new charter for that city. Another delegation, headed by Lew Bernard, Dan Dalton, and Buck Brady, are also present for the avowed purpose of defeating the bill and of continuing the present Board of Public Works.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17. -- The Senatorial bomb has exploded. It was filled with mud, and every one of the leading candidates has been spattered. Last night De Young withdrew from the fight in favor of Felton, for the avowed reason that Stanford's agents were buying votes for Estee at $2,000 each.

BALTIMORE, March 17. -- The city has had a sensation to-day. Early in the morning the rumor began to spread that William A. Wisong, Treasurer of the Association for the Improvement of the Poor, was $11,000 short in his accounts and that he had disappeared. No man in the city had a stronger reputation and none was better known.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 17. -- The city remains very quiet. The Mafia warning received by Mr. W.S. Parkerson, who led the citizens movement on Saturday, does not make him feel uneasy, although there may be some foundation for it. Mr. Parkerson treats the letter lightly. He knows that if a hair of his head is touched it result in a terrible punishment of the Italians and Sicilians.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 17. -- The State Board of Mediation and Arbitration to-day began its investigation into the existing lock-out of clothing cutters in this city. Chairman Purcell and Commissioners Donovan and Robertson were present. The following statement was made on behalf of the manufacturers by Attorney William T. Cogswell:

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The first annual dog show of the Washington City Kennel Club opened this morning under the most favorable auspices. The show is being held in the Riding Academy and the collection embraces 500 dogs, among them being the celebrated dog Graven Image from Yale, noted chiefly for his homeliness.

A legal effort has been made to break the power of the great Standard Oil Trust by securing a forfeiture of the charter of the Standard Oil Company of New-York, its constituent company in this State. The decisions against the legality of the Sugar Trust which resulted in its being driven from the State furnishes the ground for hope that success may attend this movement against the oil monopoly.

Both the Stadler and the Hildreth bills for allowing wine to be sold at balls after 1 o'clock in the morning were defeated in the Assembly yesterday. Curiously enough, the fate even of the Stadler bill is attributed to the liquor dealers, who desired to have no favors extended to keepers of halls and assembly rooms for the sale of wine and beer that could not be shared in by the trade generally.

The Tribune of yesterday published a letter from its Washington correspondent who has been engaged all Winter in fanning the dull embers of party interest in the personality of Mr. BLAINE. The letter is in purpose and substance an announcement by Messrs. HARRISON and BLAINE that the former is a candidate for renomination and that the latter promises (whatever his own intention may be) to support him.

TRENTON, March 17. -- Gov. Abbett sent in a batch of nominations for State officers to-day. The name of his candidate for State Prison Keeper was conspicuous by its absence. Everybody knows that it is to be John H. Patterson of Monmouth, and everybody knows also that the Senator from Monmouth is prepared to oppose his confirmation.

Fires were many in this city last night. The first of the series was the greatest, and it was the most destructive blaze New-York has seen in many a day. Even before it was at its height two other fires in the same district were reported and added greatly to the difficulties the firemen had to meet. And at 11:30 o'clock a fourth fire was burning fiercely on the west side.

Two European dispatches from different points show the curious confusion that has fallen upon the relations of Germany and France apropos of the recent visit of the Emperor's mother to Paris. On the one hand, the London papers, on the authority of correspondents in Paris and Vienna, state that the French Ministry has decided to recall M. HERBETTE, the French Ambassador at Berlin.

We are perhaps entitled to a little national self-congratulation when we consider the difference between American and foreign crowds. The departure of Mr. GLADSTONE from London is not so rare an event, one would suppose, as to endanger the public peace. But his departure yesterday was the occasion of the assemblage of a crowd, and of a consequent "rush" in which several men were seriously injured.

Several matters of moment to the National Guard were discussed at the meeting of commanding officers of the First and Second Brigades at the residence of Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, on Monday evening. The conference began at 8 o'clock, and broke up shortly after 1 in the morning.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Fourteen letter carriers in the Washington service have been suspended for fifteen days each and three have been dismissed, under direction of the free delivery service of the Post Office Department. The offenders were watched by detectives and were charged with loitering, skipping boxes, drinking while on duty and in uniform, and using car tickets for other than official purposes.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Baron Fava, the Italian Minister, to-day received the first reports from the Italian Consul at New-Orleans in relation to the killing of the Italians there last Saturday. These reports, it is said, sustain the position taken by Baron Fava in his protest to Mr. Blaine of March 15 with relation to the inaction of the authorities of New-Orleans before and during the shooting.

Everybody who was of a speculative turn of mind and wanted to wager money during the heated political campaign of 1884 remembers the place 15 West Twenty-eighth Street. It was then operated by Kelly Bliss. Large sums of money were handled there during that campaign, and especially during the week succeeding the election, when the Blaine tonters professed to believe the result was in doubt and were bluffing prodigiously.

Out of the frozen black mud of that desolate and low-lying marsh on Hart's Island, called by name Potter's Field, the pine box containing the body of "Fred Evans," the Astor House suicide, was yesterday dug with pickaxes. No tombstone marked the spot and it was located only with the aid of the map of that delectable region. On this map it appeared as coffin 85 in plot 169.

The last meeting of the old Amateur Athletic Union was held last evening in the gymnasium of the clubhouse of the New-York Athletic Club, Fifty-fifth Street and Sixth Avenue. It was called a "schedule meeting," but inasmuch as the union is now divided into associations, it was deemed advisable to allow the several associations to arrange schedules of games for the coming season.

Of course the "ovation" that Mr. GLADSTONE received on Tuesday, when he went to Hastings, was in great part a tribute to his character and his career, and nothing can fairly be concluded from it about the popularity of the cause he advocated. It is none the less noteworthy that the Irish cause was the staple of his speeches.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- A new chapter in the troubles of the Snell family was unfolded to-day which may rival the mysteriousness of the murder of Millionaire Snell and the disappearance of Tascott. A few days ago Hattie Juerst, a nurse girl employed in the family of Albert J. Snell, was arrested charged by her employer with larceny.

LANSING, Mich., March 18. -- The present Legislature, which is composed largely of Patrons of Industry, from the time of its assembling in January has been outspoken against appropriating $50,000 to aid Detroit in entertaining the Grand Army of the Republic at its National Encampment next August. Representative Minier of Detroit has introduced a bill having this end in view.

PORTLAND, Me., March 18. -- The Republicans of Portland are so happy that they would build bonfires at every street corner if they dared to. They are rejoicing at the defeat of the Secret-Ballot bill in the Maine Legislature, and it is because they know that they ought to be ashamed of themselves to be jubilant over such an event that they are a little shy of making public demonstrations of their joy.

TRENTON, March 18. -- Gov. Abbett to-day sent in the name of John H. Patterson to succeed himself as keeper of the State prison. He also nominated Assemblyman Daley of Hoboken to be a District Court Judge in Hoboken, Assemblyman Puster of Jersey City to be a District Court Judge in Jersey City, and Assemblyman Kerr of Paterson to be a District Court Judge in Paterson.

About Wall Street considerable comment was heard yesterday in regard to the application of Roger A. Pryor, Jr., to the Attorney General, in behalf of certain independent oil refiners, for the institution of legal proceedings against the Standard Oil Company of New-York for the annulment of its charter on the ground that it had violated the laws of the State by transferring all its rights, possessions, and privileges to the great Standard Oil Trust.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Owing to the untiring efforts of United States Minister Phelps, Chancellor von Caprivi has removed the embargo place upon American cattle landed at Hamburg, and it is likely that Mr. Phelps will be able to obtain the removal of the restrictions placed upon the importation of the American hog.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 18. -- The sixth annual meeting of the Holstein-Friesien Cattle Association of America was held here to-day. President David H. Burrell of Little Falls made an address which treated of the depression in agriculture, which he attributed to the combination of manufacturers and capitalists against the farmers.

Although the Treasury put every legitimate obstacle in the way of the two firms that applied to the Assay Office on Tuesday for $1,000,000 in gold bars for shipment to Europe, it was unable to prevent the shipment. The gold was exported aboard the Havel yesterday, not in bars, but in coin.

The last of the disastrous fires that kept the department busy in the lower part of the town Tuesday night had scarcely been extinguished when, at 3:30 yesterday morning, the five-story tenement at Hester and Allen Streets was found to be in flames. Officer Rogers first saw the fire in the narrow stairway on the Allen Street side, which is the only stairway in the building.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- There is enough chivalry in the Navy Department to take from Senator Chandler's shoulders the burden of the responsibility for the issue of the order to send the Galena from New-York to the Portsmouth Navy Yard.
LONDON, March 18. -- The Times to-day strongly defends the New-Orleans citizens for the action taken in the case of the Mafia conspirators. In its editorial it says:

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Feb. 23. -- The Hon. Paul Neumann, Attorney General of the Hawaiian Government, who arrived in Yokohama in December last, has just finished negotiating a treaty with the Emperor of Japan for the unrestricted immigration of Japanese subjects into the Hawaiian kingdom.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 18. -- The works of the Elizapethport Cordage Company, comprising several brick structures covering fifteen acres of ground, were destroyed by fire this afternoon. The flames started in the laying ground from an overheated shaft. All the buildings of the company save one storage house, together with machinery and stock, were consumed.

GIBRALTAR, March 18. -- Of the 880 persons, passengers and crew, on the steamship Utopia, which was sunk here yesterday, 311 have been saved, leaving 569 as drowned or missing. In addition to this, two of the rescuing party were drowned, making the probable loss of life by the accident 571.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 18. -- This may with perfect propriety be termed boodle week in the Legislature. That money is already here with promises of more is shown by the actions of the various committees and the conduct of the highwaymen in both houses. To-day boodle was openly talked of in both houses. In the Assembly it was talked of in connection with the new Cable bill fathered by Mr. Mase of Dutchess.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 18. -- Both houses of the General Assembly abandoned the Capitol this afternoon for one week, without any change being effected in the dead-lock that has now lasted two months and a half.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 18. -- At the investigation of the clothing cutters' lock-out here by the State Board of Arbitration the scheme by which money is extorted from firms by the Clothing Cutters' National Union was shown by voluminous correspondence between manufacturers in this city and Walter S. Westbrook, Secretary of the Cutters' Union, and James Hughes, Chairman of the Executive Board of the union.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Feb. 15. -- The American bark W.W. Crapo, Capt. Hardy, arrived here yesterday, 197 days from New-York. On Jan. 1 she touched at Onalan or Strong's Island, of the Caroline group, where, in November last, the Alliance had taken the American missionaries to await the cessation of the war now in progress between the Spanish troops and natives of the island of Ponapi.

The State Legislature having appropriated funds for the maintenance of Prof. Albert S. Bickmore's Saturday lectures, in compliance with a request made by 5,000 persons who had been disappointed by the announcement that the lectures were to be discontinued, the announcement is now made that the lectures will be given regularly hereafter for at least four years.

Senator ALLISON and Representative CANNON, Chairmen of the Appropriations Committees of the Senate and House, respectively, were authorized before the adjournment of Congress to prepare statements for publication in the Congressional Record showing the amounts appropriated by the last Congress in comparison with those appropriated by the Fiftieth Congress.

Peter J. Claassen was sentenced to six years in the Erie County Penitentiary by Judge Benedict, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, under his conviction for misappropriating the funds of the Sixth National Bank. The proceedings in court were brief. United States District Attorney Mitchell simply stated the fact of conviction and the penalty prescribed in moving sentence.

It is said that Secretary TRACY will soon give names to all the new vessels now under construction or authorized which are thus far known by numbers. It may be hoped, however, that he will for the present name only such of them as would not be affected by the contemplated change in the statute on the subject.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Hamilton Fish, Jr., put in his answer this morning to Speaker Sheehan's criticism of his course regarding the protest of the Catholic clergy against the Stadler Dance-House bill. There was an interesting sparring match between the gentlemen over the question whether the reply should be spread upon the Journal, Mr. Fish insisting that he had been accorded that privilege by the Speaker the day before.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 18. -- That the trotting-horse breeders will have full control of the registers is now assumed by the editor of the Kentucky Stock Farm, receiving to-day the following dispatch from Franklin, Penn.:

A friend of Attorney General MILLER has been guilty of some "indiscretions" touching that Cabinet officer's views on the nominations to the new Appellate Judgeships created by the late Congress, and these are reported by the Washington correspondent of the Chicago Tribune. There is nothing in Mr. MILLER'S past utterances, so far as we are acquainted with them, to make us doubt his friend's statement of his views.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- D.C. O'Malley of New-Orleans, for whom a body of citizens were in search with a noosed rope for alleged complicity with the Mafia, is said to be in Chicago. He left New-Orleans, and is reported to have been seen at the Grand Hotel in Cincinnati on Monday night in company with Seligman, foreman of the jury in the Hennessy case.

The sanitary questions involved in the proposed erection of an air garden over the Forty-second Street reservoir were discussed at a largely-attended meeting of the section of public health of the Academy of Medicine last night. Dr. H.D. Chapin, who presided, remarked in opening the meeting that sanitary conditions were usually the last things thought of in a public bill in the Legislature.

The death of Prince NAPOLEON is perhaps an event of more importance to French politics and to the general politics of Europe than at first appears. The character of the man himself was not very serious nor very important, although it was no doubt individual. The individuality of it consisted mainly in a lack of amenableness to discipline which amounted to an incapacity of working in conjunction with others.

District Attorney Fitzgerald of Richmond County was yesterday visited by a young Englishman, who related to him a strange story, stranger than any yet disclosed in connection with the Staten Island murder mystery, and one which, whether credible or incredible as to its details, gives a new turn to this unparalleled romance of crime.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- An ingenious person who is serving a life sentence in a Wisconsin prison has evolved a scheme to supply the United States Navy with all the able-bodied seamen it may need, and incidentally relieve the authorities of the various States from the care of a great many convicts.

BALTIMORE, March 19. -- Mr. John Norman, delegate from Maryland to the last general meeting of the Irish National League, says that the envoys sent to this country in the interest of Mr. Parnell win not be invited to Baltimore.

" More opium is smuggled into this country by a way of Puget Sound and the border of British Columbia than through all other ports," United States Senator Watson C. Squire said at the Hoffman House the other evening. "The little islands there and the long extent of unguarded boundary line make it the best place for smuggling."

One important step toward adjusting the all-rail and lake-and-rail rates from the seaboard to the Northwest was taken yesterday by the representatives of the roads interested, who were in session at 346 Broadway for the greater part of the day. Commissioner Goddard of the Trunk Line Association, Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association, and Chairman Midgeley of the Western Freight Association took part in the deliberations. Mr. Midgeley presided.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 19. -- Statements of a somewhat sensational character are made by the Hon. Judson Lamoure, Chairman of the State Republican Central Committee. He asserts that there is a gigantic conspiracy to turn the State of North Dakota over to the Democracy. Mr. Lamoure claims that this conspiracy has been entered into by members of the National Democratic Committee and members of the State Democratic Central Committee and certain professed Republicans.

NEW-HAVEN, March 19. -- More than two hundred entries have been made for the Winter games of the Yale Athletic Association and the Second Regiment-to take place in the armory Saturday evening, and without doubt the meeting will be the largest ever held here. The militia has shown little interest in the event this year, nearly all of the contestants being college students and members of the well-known amateur athletic clubs.

MAHANOY CITY, Penn., March 19. -- This city was thrown into the wildest excitement and confusion this evening by a terrific report which was heard for miles around. People were terrorstricken and ran from their homes into the streets for safety, believing that an earthquake had taken place.

LONDON, March 19. -- In the House of Lords to-day Lord Knutsford, Colonial Secretary, introduced a bill to revise certain provisions controling the Newfoundland fisheries rights of foreign powers. He hoped that in spite of the difficulties a compromise would he arranged whereby the colony's burdens would be lessened. He believed Newfoundland's protest was founded upon misapprehension.

Inspector Williams has a few ideas on the subject of poolselling. Yesterday he was kind enough to impart those ideas to THE TIMES. In the first place, the Inspector said he did not believe that poolselling could be wiped out so long as the Ives Pool bill is a slaw. "If ever there was any special legislation," he said, "it was when that law was enacted.

The attempt of Gov. HILL to have the money drawn from the Treasury of the United States on account of the refunding of the direct tax turned over to Treasurer DANFORTH as a special fund and distributed among the banks in the interior of the State as an inducement for political support was highly characteristic of the unscrupulous demagogue who is still holding on to the executive office of this State.

PITTSBURG, March 19. -- The Rev. John K. McClurkin, Professor of Theology in the Reformed Presbyterian Theological Seminary in Allegheny, has notified the Board of Trustees that he will resign at the end of the present term. The cause of his action lies in his sympathy with the suspended Reformed Presbyterian preachers who adopted the East End platform and were charged with following divisive courses.

Judge Beach, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday refused to uphold the objections made by David Tim, on behalf of Rachel Pollock, to the acceptance of the American Surety Company's bond as security on appeal in the suit of Mrs. Pollock against the Brookly Cross-town Railway Company. Judge Beach says that "the evidence presented does not warrant the court in exercising its discretion adverse to the sufficiency of the undertaking."

CAMDEN, N.J., March 19. -- In his closing argument to-day ex-Judge Westcott, counsel for Francis Lingo, the accused murderer of Mrs. Miller, resorted to a most sensational effect to carry conviction of the negro's innocence to the minds of the jury.

The Commission on Small Sites, consisting of Mayor Chapin, City Works Commissioner Adams, and Police Commissioner Hayden, met in the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday to select an architect for the new Fire Department Headquarters, but found that political influences were at work in favor of two different architects, so they adjourned without doing anything more than talk.
SCRANTON, Penn., March 19. -- Mrs. Eva Ray Hamilton passed through this city this morning on her way to New-York. After much persuasion she was induced to talk about the Hamilton estate.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 19. -- In the case of James Baird against Capt. Sir Baldwin Walker, a verdict was yesterday rendered for the plaintiff. This case has excited great interest both here and in Great Britain, and has been the cause of much diplomatic correspondence between the Newfoundland authorities and the British Foreign Office.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 19. -- The annual report of the Connecticut Bureau of Vital Statistics for the year 1889 was not issued until yesterday. The report shows that during 1889 there was one birth to every 42.7 of the population, one marriage to every 127.7 of the population, and one death to every 58.5 of the population.

Mr. JOHN SHERMAN affords a curious illustration of the irony of fate. For considerably more than a quarter of a century he has been conspicuous in the political history of this country. No politician in it has been more uniformly successful in getting offices, and no politician in the country has been more uniformly unsuccessful in making friends.

The Madison Square Garden was like Coney Island on a rainy day yesterday. There were pop-corn and hot sausage sellers, side shows and fakirs, but no customers. The unhappy walkers dragged themselves around, adding blisters to their feet. Few ducats fell into the treasury. A drum and fife corps was procured from somewhere, and it put a little life into the weary pedestrians.

In commenting on a report circulated in this city yesterday that in order to obtain gold for export silver certificates would be presented, the Government officers said that they had received no such application. They were rather non-committal as to what would be done if an application should be made.

GIBRALTAR, March 19. -- The revised official count of the lost and saved passengers and crew of the ill-fated Anchor Line steamship Utopia shows that there were 880 souls on board the steamer when she ran on the Anson. Of this number there were saved 290 steerage passengers, 2 saloon passangers, 3 Italian interpreters, and 23 of the crew, all the latter being Englishmen or men who had shipped at English ports

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Navy Department is now looking about for a ship on which to spend the money that was to have been expended on the Galena had she not been lost in trying to reach the Portsmouth Navy Yard. It is likely that the Portsmouth yard may lose this money altogether, and that a considerable part of it will be expended at Mare Island.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 19. -- Thomas H. Pratt, a dental student, was arrested this afternoon upon a charge of assaulting J. Hatfield Youmans, the editor of the Evening News. The assault was committed last night on the Cookman Avenue sidewalk of the News office. Young Pratt knocked Editor Youmans's head through the glass of the office window.

TRENTON, March 19. -- The bosses made a new move to-day on the liquor question. Explanations have already been made in these dispatches of the necessity that prompts the Executive of the State to desire to have the liquor dealers of the State at his mercy. The first scheme that was proposed was for a State Excise Board.

CANTON, Ohio, March 19. -- The Rev. Howard MacQueary has left the Episcopal Church. He received official notice to-day from Bishop Leonard suspending him from the ministry in the Episcopal Church for six months, at the expiration of which time, if he does not repent and recant, he is to be degraded from the ministry. Mr. MacQueary immediately forwarded has resignation to the Bishop, in which he says:

CHICAGO, March 19. -- A private cablegram from a well-informed acting officer of the Italian Navy received by L'Italia and dated at Spezzia, where the chief navy yard of Italy is situated, says: "The current rumors are that secret instructions have been dispatched from Rome to the Admiral commanding the squadron of the Mediterranean at this port in view of the recent turn of affairs in America.

The plea put forward in the Republican organs that the tariff must not be touched until a Republican House has been elected shows a curious misunderstanding of the situation. It is as if a dissipated and disreputable suitor asked a woman to marry him in order to reform him, with this additional feature that the Republican suit has already been rejected with every appearance of contempt as well as lack of confidence.

The latest attack on the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the fight which has been made to secure the opening of the rooms Sunday is by petitions which were put in circulation yesterday. They read thus:

Henry Aveling, an actor of considerable reputation, whose last engagement was with the "Paul Kauvar" company in Philadelphia, in which he played the title role, committed suicide at the Sturtevant House Wednesday afternoon by taking poison. Aveling's career has been a most checkered one. His act was caused probably by a fit of despondency brought on by intemperance and unhappiness in his domestic life.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 19. -- The reason for Gov. Hill's anxiety to get possession of the amount refunded by the Federal Government to New-York State under the Direct Tax bill became apparent yesterday. Immediately upon receiving the draft on the Assistant Treasurer in New-York the Governor indorsed it as follows:

RICHMOND, Va., March 19. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down an important opinion involving the question of the tenant of the homestead provided for under the State Constitution. The court holds that the homestead is not dependent upon the life of a minor child, but remains as long as the holder continues to make the place exempt his home.

ALBANY, March 19. -- Alarmed at the strong opposition which Senator Hill's liquor bill has awakened, the friends of that iniquitous measure have amended it in many particulars in the hope that it will silence the storm which broke out when it was introduced. To-day the Assembly Excise Committee gave another hearing on the bill.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 19. -- The reason for Gov. Hill's anxiety to get possession of the amount refunded by the Federal Government to New-York State under the Direct Tax bill became apparent yesterday. Immediately upon receiving the draft on the Assistant Treasurer in New-York the Governor indorsed it as follows:

Now that the Dominion Government has secured what it professes to regard as a victory in the recent elections, it is announced from Ottawa that Commissioners will in a few days proceed to Washington to open a discussion of plans for a treaty of reciprocal trade between Canada and the United States.

Such measures as a representative and influential body of merchants can take to prevent the enactment of vicious legislation were taken yesterday at a meeting of the dry-goods trade, at the Merchants' Club, in Leonard Street, with reference to the Linson listing and other tax bills of similar character now pending, with threatening aspect, in the Senate and Assembly at Albany.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 19. -- Judge Marr, in the Criminal Court this morning, handed the Grand Jury the report of Gabriel Villere, the Criminal Sheriff, with reference to the lynching of the eleven Italians last Saturday. After giving the names of the Italian prisoners and the processes under which they were held, the Sheriff says:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19. -- Charles N. Felton was elected Senator to-day on the ninth day and ninth ballot of the contest. At the conclusion of the roll call Estee had 40 votes and Felton 40. Rapid changes began, and when the result was announced Felton had 73 to Estee's 15. The Democrats stood solidly by White, giving him 28 votes.

LONDON, March 19. -- At a meeting to-day of the Institute of Naval Architects, Mr. J.H. Biles, a member of the council, warmly praised the latest American naval constructions, saying that they quite equaled and sometimes surpassed the European constructions of a like nature. Mr. Biles added that the latest American vessels were well worth careful study upon the part of English constructors.
LONDON, March 20. -- The betting on the Oxford and Cambridge boat race, which takes place to-morrow, is 11 to 4 in favor of Oxford.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- A large meeting of Italians was held here this evening to take action in regard to the shooting of their countrymen in New-Orleans. Chairman Emanuel Nardie made short speeches in English and Italian, in which he said they were there not to protest against the United States Government, but against mob law.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- A meeting of the National Commission of the World's Columbian Exposition in April does not, at this time, seem to be probable. There is no business of sufficient importance to justify a meeting.

Material for public hearings for the Rapid-Transit Commission has about been exhausted. At yesterday's meeting after three persons had been heard, President Steinway asked if there was anybody else who desired to be heard, and there was no answer. Thereupon he announced that if there should arise occasion for any further public hearings they would be announced through the papers.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 20. -- The Grand Jury continued in session all day to-day, but finally adjourned to Monday without making any presentiments. They made a brief reportexonerating District Attorney Luzonberg from all blame in connection with the selection of Juryman Seligman. The grand inquest are devoting their time to nnearthing the jury bribers.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Acting Secretary of the Treasury Nettleton was asked to-day whether the Treasury officials would pay out gold for silver certificates when they were presented with the request for gold. Gen. Nettleton promptly replied that it was not customary for the department to answer hypothetical questions, but when that question had to be met it would be disposed of without hesitation.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 20. -- The result of the annual oratorical contest between the two upper forms of the Lawrenceville Preparatory School, held in Memorial Hall, was announced this evening. The first prize was awarded to Roy S. Morris, '92; the second to John H. Thatcher, '92; the third to William T. Doty, '92.

The denunciation by the Paris correspondent of the London Times of the unseemly and revolting conduct of some of those present in the last hours of Prince Napoleon is as deserved as it is unqualified:...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 20. -- The city was startled to-day by the announcement that Mrs. Mary Quigley, sister of Arthur Day, had confessed on her deathbed that she participated in the crime of murdering Day's wife, for which Day suffered on the scaffold at Welland, Ontario, on Dec. 18. Mrs. Quigley made the confession ito her mother, Mrs. Day, who relates the story.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 20. -- Several more of the threatening letters written to Rochester clothing manufacturers by Chairman Hughes of the National Executive Board of the Garment Cutters and Trimmers of North America were made public to-day. On Oct. 23, 1889, Hughes wrote this letter from Denver to Stein Block:

The police made none of their farcical raids on the city poolrooms yesterday. After THE TIMES published a statement as to what might be expected from the raids, and especially as to what might not be expected, a halt was called. As an excuse for the delay a TIMES reporter was informed that the affidavits on which warrants were to be issued were not perfected.

The first representation of Hermann Sudermann's drama of modern life in Berlin was given last night at the Amberg Theatre. The cast embraced the stock company, Frauleine Leithner, Neumann, Bella, Schmitz, and Burg, with Herren Walter, Krueger, Horwitz, Friese, and Sinnhold. The play takes its name from a painting made by an artist who maintains relations with a rich woman to whose house various shady persons resort.

Another effort to secure gold bars for shipment abroad was made yesterday and again the Treasury Department declined to issue the bars. The steps in the proceedings were very nearly the same as those taken when the first refusal was made early in the week.

Mayor Grant and Controller Myers glared at each other and talked back to each other at yesterday's meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, thereby embellishing a tale that would be otherwise dull. The Controller's reference to the delay in beginning the construction of the new municipal building stirred the flame.

One of the stock arguments of the real estate speculators who are trying to help Mr. Gould to another slice of Battery Park for the use of his elevated railroad company is that the opposition to their scheme comes altogether from the newspapers and from the "hoodlums" and "rag-tag and bob-tail," by which terms they characterize the frequenters of Battery Park.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 20. -- A new step has been taken in the Noyes-Rockwell Congressional contest matter in the appointment of R.H. Lansing, a Rochester stenographer, to hear testimony for presentation in the House of Representatives of the Fifty-second Congress. The hearings were begun to-day, and the first witness examined was Col. Henry T. Noyes, the Republican contestant.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 20. -- Pittsburg and Allegheny people to the number of 3,000 or 4,000 are wrestling with the grip, which is sweeping over both towns with relentless vigor. Almost every workshop and business house in the two cities is short of both employes and managers on account of it. In the fashionable east end alone there are over 600 cases.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 20. -- The train which left the Austin station for the South over the International Road this evening carried among its passengers a young woman, Mary Inez McCabe, who, for the nineteen years she has lived here, had a thrilling career. She still limps from a fracture of the foot, received in making her escape from a Mexican prison on the 7th of February.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 20. -- Prof. R.R. Anderson, President Cleveland's Minister to Denmark, in the course of a long interview on national politics to-day said:

The first public movement toward the erection of a bronze statue in memory of the late John Hughes, Archbishop of New-York, was made at a meeting in the chapel of De La Salle Institute, 108 West Fifty-ninth Street, last night. Fifty well-known men were present. Judge Morgan J. O'Brien presided.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement met in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon and disposed of several matters. The first discussion was on reports made by Commissioner Heintz of the annexed district on certain applications that had been referred to him for street openings in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards.

LIVERPOOL, March 20. -- The first great event of the year in horse-racing circles was run today at the Liverpool Spring meeting. This was the Grand National Steeplechase for 2,000 sovereigns, inclusive of a trophy valued at 100 sovereigns, over the Grand National Course, about four miles and 856 yard.

DETROIT, March 20. -- Joseph Perrien, fiftyeight years old, wealthy, and a bachelor, was sitting at his fireside conversing with his nephew, Albert Hasselbacher, and his niece, Leoni Chambe, about 10 o'clock last night, when the door bell rang and note addressed to him was handed in by a young smooth-faced man of sallow complexion.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Shortly after the Keystone National Bank opened for business this morning the heavy iron doors were lowered, and the following notice was placed upon them:

CAMDEN, N.J., March 20. -- The jury in the case of the colored man, Francis Lingo, who was charged with the murder of Mrs. Annie Miller of Matchtown, Camden County, to-night returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 20.-The revenue cutter Dexter arrlved here this afternoon from Gay ttead, with Surgeon Von Wedekind, Boatswain Sutton, and twolvo of the crew of the Galena, besides a largo quantity of her stores, hammocks, , to be landed note. The above-menloned officers and men are under orders to proceed direct to .New York.

RICHMOND, Va., March 20. -- Besides the strike of the 150 machinist at the Richmond Locomotive Works, there are about 300 or 400 other iron workers out. To-day the 150 or 200 men employed by the Vulcan Iron Works went out. They demand that wages should be paid semi-monthly, as has been done heretofore. This the management opposed, and the men struck.

The lobster-canning controversy, which only the other day seemed in a fair way of amicable adjustment, under the agreement of France and England to refer it to arbitration, has become acute again. On Wednesday, in a Newfoundland court, a suit brought against Capt. Sir BALDWIN WALKER of the British corvette Emerald, for having shut up Mr. BAIRD'S lobster factory at Bay St. George last Summer, was decided for the plaintiff.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- The inventory of the estate of "Diamond Jo" Reynolds is being prepared in this city, and is about completed. Its results will surprise those who have noticed that, in different Probate Courts over the West, bonds amounting to over $500,000 have been filed for the administrators. The inventory shows the estate to reach almost $10,000,000.

BOSTON, March 20. -- Vincent Laforme, one of the three Commissioners of Public Institutions of the city of Boston, has tendered his resignation in response to a request by Mayor Matthews, it having been charged that the former's confirmation had been secured by the unlawful payment of money to certain members of the Board of Aldermen of 1889, whose names are not yet made public.

The Chickasaws have evidently gone too far in their recent efforts to hold themselves together as a distinct nation. A short time ago they passed a law declaring that any of their people who should become citizens "of any other nation or of the United States or any other Government" should thereby forfeit all political rights as Chickasaws, and all title to the common land and money.

It was 4 o'clock yesterday morning when the tellers of the Manhattan Club election for managers finished their work and discovered that the so-called Tammany ticket had got the worst of it. The managers elected for three years from April 1 were William C. Whitney, George G. Haven, Walter Stanton, John Hone, Jr., and David B. Gilbert.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 21. -- Twenty-one years ago Bernard Devine, who was living with his wife and one child at Olyphant, a few miles north of Scranton, left his home as usual with his pack on his back for a trip through the neighboring country. Devine was a peddler, and the unusual circumstances about his disappearance on this particular morning was the fact that he never returned to his Olyphant dwelling again.

DOYLESTOWN, Penn., March 21. -- Four prisoners, two men and two women, made their escape last night from the Doylestown Jail. The fugitives are John Spencer, alias John Ulrich, alias "Dutchie" Turner; Joseph Motts, Julia Motts, his wife, and Mary Fay, who were arrested on a charge of robbing Pennsylvania freight cars at Bristol.

LONDON, March 21. -- The forty-eighth of the famous boat races between the crews of Oxford and Cambridge Universities was decided this morning. It was won by a quarter of a length by Oxford. The time of the Oxford crew was twenty-two minutes.

" A mote dancing in a sunbeam -- the sun has set -- the mote is gone -- whither -- into a brother's eye, per-chance. Well, if he be a true brother, it is safer there than in the sun." -- Days Sayings, by an Utterer.

In Its efforts to get at the secrets of the Sugar Trust, the Senate Committee on General Laws yesterday struck a snag. H.O. Havemeyer, after sarcastically charging the committee with bothering witnesses who knew nothing about the matter, while he and his brother, who knew all about it and were willing to tell all the facts, had been idly dancing attendance on the investigation for seven days, was put upon the stand.

M. de Saint-Amand supplements Meneval's "Souvenirs Historiques" of Napoleon's second wife, but his book is particularly devoted to the last year of this unfortunate woman's stay in France. We use the word "unfortunate," because no woman ever was more the puppet of fortune. Posterity has, perhaps, judged her over-harshly, but her trials were heavy.

If we may believe a dispatch to the Philadelphia Times, Mr. HARRISON has been telegraphing over the country to Mr. MORGAN, the Indian Commissioner, that his resignation will be not only acceptable but accepted. The alleged reason for these not flattering messages to Mr. MORGAN is that that gentleman has been sanctioning and even suggesting unfair treatment of Catholic teachers in Indian schools.

One of the most striking features of the preparation for the race between Oxford and Cambridge yesterday was the coaching of the Oxford crew by a Cambridge oarsman -- Mr. RUDOLPH C. LEHMANN. Nor is this the first time there has been such a display of good feeling between the two universities. As far back as 1852 T.S. EGAN, a Cambridge coxswain, coached Oxford.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, March 21. -- Provision has been made so that the Senior Class can include she study of geology in its course. The chair was made vacant by the resignation of Prof. Patton some time ago. It will be temporarily filled by Prof. William B. Scott, Professor of Geology at Princeton.

CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN IN LONDON. -- Charlotte Cushman arrived in London unheralded by a single paragraph. The path might be steep and thorny, but toil would render triumph all the sweeter. This idea of winning renown by legitimate work without drawing on a ready-made reputation, dominated her every action.

It was more than intimated in this column a week ago that Mayor Chapin was being watched very eagerly by the local politicians while he tried to perform his great feat of straddling the County Farm bills. This fact has been clearly shown in the course of the last week by the actions of the delegations now in Albany endeavoring to lobby through these measures.
POOR ENGLISH. -- "He accepted the invite." It would be quite as correct grammar to say, "He accepted the give," or "the appoint."

NEWPORT, March 21. -- The latest cottage rentals are Admiral A.L. Case's cottage in Catherine Street to Mrs. J.M. Robinson of New-York; T.A. Havemeyer's cottage in Washington Street to Mr. Alfred Van Santvoord of New-York, and Mr. Daniel Hazard's cottage at Jamestown to Mr. W.H. Jenks of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- When Indian Commissioner Morgan was before the Senate for confirmation he was sturdily opposed because of his opposition to the Roman Catholic missionaries among the Indians. By the help of several Democratic votes he was pulled through, and the expected war on the Roman Catholics in the Indian missions did not take place.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 21. -- The western collection district of this State is honeycombed with illicit distilleries. Since the present Administration assumed control the efforts of the revenue officers have been redoubled to stamp out the illegal manufacture and sale of whisky and to arrest and punish the "Blockaders," as the guilty parties are denominated.

Of all the inaccurate articles on the measurement of yachts for racing published in the last year and a half, the conspicuously such appears in the current issue of the Spirit of the Times. Written by "America," a veritable "Father Time" in yachting, one can only read the extraordinary statements with amazement, for yachtsmen generally look to" America" for fact instead of fiction.

Seven years of honest operatic art ended yesterday. The record of those years is one of which any city may well be proud. It is one of which any body of stockholders in an opera house ought to be proud. That our stockholders are not burdened with a sense of its glory may be inferred from their readiness to cut it short because the general public refused to approve their novelties.

THE UNSOCIAL CHARACTERS OF ENGLISH CLUBS. -- The English club is a place to live in. In one of these clubs a member lives for 500 a year about as well is he could live for 5,000 a year in his own house. He, of course, wishes to make the club his own house, as far as may be. This fact explains the solitariness of these institutions.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., March 21. -- Among the arrivals at the Austral in the course of the week have been the following visitors: Cornelius B. Gold, child, and maid; Mr. and Mrs. George Milmine, Miss Lewis, Hal Bell, Robert Coddington, R. Benjamin, J.G. Nelson, E.E. Milmine, Miss Milmine, Mrs. Lincoln Gold, Mr. and Mrs. Payson Merrill, Herman Stein, and Dr. Horan Clark, all of New-York.

ROME, Ga., March 21. -- The conviction in San Marcos, Texas, of Col. George H. Snyder of the murder of his wife is the culmination of a tragedy which had its beginning in an ill-fated marriage in this city.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- The theatrical companies playing in Chicago this week have done a remarkably good business. There was only one novelty, and that was not of the best, although the performances pleased the large audiences which greeted Pauline Hall in "Amorita" at Hooley's. The opera has proved so much of an attraction that it will be kept on until the middle of next week, when the bill will be changed to "Erminie."

CHICAGO, March 21. -- One of the most efficient labor-saving devices ever worked is in use on the top of a sixteen-story building in process of erection. The building is constructed of iron and brick, the iron framework being pushed up two or three stories ahead of the lining of brick walls. The structural iron used in the frame is very heavy.

CATULLE MENDEZ, THE POET ELEGANT NASTINESS. -- Long soft light hair, thinning but slightly -- at fifty years of age! -- over the crown of the head, but unflecked with the least thread of gray. Smooth brow: large eyes veiled by drooping lids: a nose quite admirable in shape, its Hebraism apparent only in a slight peculiarity of the nostril's curve.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 21. -- This city is practically without a local government because of a dead-lock over the question of appointments. The origin of the trouble was the action of a minority faction of the Democratic Party, backed by the Elmira Gazette and Free Press and a few Republican Aldermen and independents, in making a slate and attempting to run it through at the first meeting of the new Council.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,993,900, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,225,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $25,108,450; 4 per cents, $108,660,450.

As examples of the best art products of the most artistic people that the world has ever produced, Japanese swords long ago attracted the attention of the modern connoisseur and collector. It is, however, only within a few years that it has been possible to make much progress in this collecting. The sentimental regard of the Japanese for these heirlooms has stood in the way of their acquisition by outsiders.

The fairies have been zealously working during the last few years to introduce their handiwork into every branch of the earth's trade. The semi-annual world's fair gotten up by the milliners is the best opportunity of bringing their goods to market, and they do not wait to be formally invited. Perhaps they have no Secretary of State to tell them when they have been slighted.

The news that Mr. Evarts will not occupy a seat in the Senate any longer has at last reached Detroit, and the Tribune (Republican) of that city has made it the subject for an editorial note. It says: "The retirement from public life of such a man as William M. Evarts is an event which the people of the United States cannot contemplate without regret.

PITTSBURG, March 21. -- A telegram from McKeesport, fourteen miles up the Monongahela River, says: "News reached this city this evening of a terrible shooting affair which occurred at Bull Run, a mining village in Mifflin Township, two or three miles from here. D.H. Gilkinson, one of Pittsburg's bravest detectives, is dead, while Detective Patrick Murphy, another prominent man in the county, is seriously, but it is not thought mortally, wounded.

The strange circumstances attending the death of Miss Helen Neilson Potts at the Comstock School for Young Ladies, in this city, Feb. 1 are still fresh enough in the mind of the public to attract an added interest when coupled with developments that made themselves apparent yesterday before District Attorney Nicoll.

NEW-HAVEN, March 21 -- Governor-elect Luzon B. Morris was asked to express an opinion today of the compromise bill offered by Senator Seymour in the Senate making Judge Morris provisional Governor, with authority to appoint only his personal staff, and giving Gen S.E Merwin an opportunity to take his case to the Supreme Court in ten days. He refused to be interviewed, however.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- The present mild weather has had the effect of bringing the athletes of Harvard out of the gymnasium, where they have been confined during the Winter, and allowing them to work in a more practical way. All the crews, 'Varsity, Senior, Junior, Sophomore, and Freshman Class crews, are now on the river, the Mott Haven men are using the outdoor running tracks, and the baseball men are on Jarvis Field.

The chief-topic of discussion in National Guard circles the last week was the proposition to create a Major General by special legislation, who should hold office for life, and be eligible to detail as Adjutant General, thus making the last-named office a permanent one, in direct contravention of the safeguards thrown around the place by the Constitution of the State of New-York.

HARTFORD, March 21. -- When Gov. Bulkeley reached the Capitol this morning he found the rooms which have been used as the headquarters for his special police and deputies daring the past nine weeks securely bolted.

The contemporary stage is not so richly supplied with actors of noble ambition that the loss of LAWRENCE BARRETT will not be severely felt. He was an alert and able man and his influence was all for good. Even the mistakes of judgment he made as a manager and producer of plays were due to his desire to keep alive the best traditions of the English drama.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Indian Commissioner Morgan seems to be in some danger of losing his place, and the report is believed here that the President has asked for his resignation. When he came up for confirmation in the Senate there was opposition to him, but with the assistance of Republicans and Democrats, who did not care much about the report that he was hostile to the Catholic missionaries, he was confirmed.

The fight over the five-million-dollar fortune left by the late Francis W. Losak to his family, which has been in the courts in various shapes for a couple of years, was before Justice J.O. Dykman holding a Special Term of the Supreme Court at White Plains yesterday. Mr. Losak died at Dobbs Ferry Feb. 13, 1889. He was once the partner of John Jacob Astor.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 21. -- Father Manoritta, the priest of the Italian parish church, is very indignant over an interview with Mayor Shakespeare published in the St. Louis Globe-Democrat. In it the Mayor advises Consul Corte against bad company, and says: "That little priest -- what's his name? -- Manoritta? -- is a bad man."

SCRANTON, Penn., March 21. -- The stories of Anna Dickinson's hopeless insanity, recently published in various newspapers, are extravagantly incorrect. Her case is entirely different from that of John McCullough, Bartley Campbell, and others, with whose illness hers has been inaccurately compared. THE TIMES'S representative talked with Miss Dickinson's sister, Miss Susan E. Dickinson, to-day, at her home in West Pittston, and found her quite hopeful of Anna's ultimate recovery.
LAKEWOOD, March 21. -- Hotel and cottage guests have made the most of the fine weather which invited them out of doors the greater part of the week.

Although Capt. Martin and myself were not aware of our proximity to other escaping prisoners, we subsequently learned that quite a number who had come through the tunnel the night before lay concealed along the Chicka-hominy this day. The misfortune of my companion and myself -- it could hardly be called a mistake -- was in getting into the swamp when the ice was so thin.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 21. -- Taxpayers will be interested in studying the results accomplished by the Commissioners of Adjustment under the Martin act, the provisions of which Bayonne adopted nearly four years ago. At that time over $1,000,000 was due the city in arrearages of taxes, assessments, and water rents. Payment of this money was stubbornly refused, while other people who paid their taxes were compelled to bear the extra burden.

The New-York committee of the Yale Infirmary or Home for Students held its second meetings at Mrs. Whitney's, 2 West Fifty-seventh Street recently. The New-Haven committee, composed of Mrs. Dwight, Mrs. Chapman, Mrs. Bacon, and Mrs. George Farnham, had been invited to attend the meeting to confer with the New-York ladies.

A MNOR iOR A SOUP. -- ViUiam L had a fine-sense of vhat was becoming at royal table. He vas so vell pleased t one of his little dinners with a savory soup compounded by his cook, Teze!iu that he sent for him and asked how it was named. "I call it dillaorout,'' was the reply.

LANSING, Mich., March 21. -- Representative White of Grand Rapids has introduced a bill for the reapportionment of the State by Congressional districts, which is favored by those who have given the subject close study. Of the twelve districts -- an increase of one -- six will be reliably Democratic, three sure Republican, while there is a good chance in two and a bare chance in one of the others for the Democracy.

THE HIPPOPOTAMUS. -- Although the hippopotamus may be less loathsome than the crocodile, Sir S. Baker writes that "there is no animal that he disliked more than the hippopotamus, if he was compelled to travel at night upon an African river in an ordinary boat." Even without this limitation the hippopotamus seems remarkably dangerous.

IN TANGIERS. -- The Arab shop is a mere box in the wall without windows, neither does it bear any name or number. The shop door is raised some distance higher than the street, and when this is open in the morning the merchant jumps in and squats down on a cushion within easy distance of his goods.
