HARTFORD, Conn., March 21. -- The Rev. Dr. F.A.M. Brown was installed pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in New-Haven Thursday evening. The installation sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. John Hall of New-York. The Rev. Dr. J. Aspinwall Hodge of this city, who has just celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his pastorate, extended the charge.

That not over veracious witness, Rumor, credits the amazing manual of dress and etiquette recently inflicted on the proverbially long-suffering public under the title of "Gentlemen," to a Knickerbocker Club man. Should the uncertain witness happen to be telling the truth in this particular instance, the clubman in question might have employed his literary zeal in another direction to better advantage.

The bill introduced at Albany Friday by Senator Lispenard Stewart, to be known as the Re-indexing bill, is intended to supplement legislation already secured in behalf of land-transfer reform. Last year's Indexing bill provided for indexing instruments recorded in the New York Register's office from and after Jan. 1, 1891, only.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- At a little after 8 o'clock this evening Special Officers Dubois and Kenney, on duty at the White House, were startled at hearing a great crash of glass, the sound apparently coming from a window in the Red Parlor, which opens upon the semi-circular porch overlooking the grounds at the south.

In the early masses in the Roman Catholic churches to-day the impressive ceremony of the "Blessing of the Palms" will take place, and at the conclusion of each of the stated services the sacred emblems commemorating Christ's entry into Jerusalem will be distributed to the faithful.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A New-York paper having put Secretary of War Proctor out of the President's Cabinet, a Washington paper finds that there is also some probability that Secretary Noble will retire, after an ineffectual effort to contend against Commissioner Morgan of the Indian Office, Commissioner Groff of the Land Office, and the President, to say nothing of several minor officers of the Interior.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Gen. Joseph E. Johnston died soon after 11 o'clock to-night at his residence on Connecticut Avenue.

The Prime Ministers of Queen Victoria have been nine in number. The Queen's reign has not been the very longest in English history; her grandfather sat on the throne a few years more than she has yet sat there while Henry III., for fifty-six years was paramount Lord of all the lands of the Engel folk.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 21. -- In September next it will have been twenty-seven years since Chattanooga and Chickamauga gave the names to a series of military operations that for conception, difficulty of performance, heroic courage of the troops engaged, and casualties as well as for results stand, in the estimation of good military judges, unmatched in the annals of modern warfare.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- One hundred and one years ago Congress passed an act "to promote the progress of science and the useful arts by securing for limited times to authors and inventors the exclusive right to their respective writings and discoveries." It became a law by receiving the signature of President George Washington April 10, 1790, and this date marks the beginning of the American patent system.

The MacQueary trial is ended, the verdict has been transmitted to the accused clergyman by Bishop LEONARD, and the Diocese of Ohio is relieved of the charge of tolerating heresy. Mr. MACQUEARY has sent his letter of resignation to the Bishop, declining to retract his alleged errors, and, when he acts upon it, this young clergyman is put out of the Episcopal ministry.
AN AFRICAN DIARY. -- 6th. -- P. is better, Mohammed Ali's ulcer is increasing, his foot looks as if it must drop off soon.

The brick business house 652 Broadway, which runs to "Shinbone Alley" and hugs what was once Constitution Hall, the headquarters of the Whig Party, was on fire last night, and but for the water tower which came from the quarters of Hook and Ladder No. 3 would have been destroyed. The building is five stories high and is owned by the Diefendorf estate.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21. -- In order to extend the influence of Princeton and bring more men to the New-Jersey university the undergraduates have greatly increased the number of clubs, consisting of men coming from the different localities throughout the United States, within the last year. Among the more active clubs are the New-York, Philadelphia, New-Jersey, Southern, and Western Pennsylvania.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 21. -- The Springfield concert of the Glee and Banjo Clubs will take place, under the auspices of the Children's Aid Society of that city, May 27, the evening of the Spring meet of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- While the colored citizens of Washington in general, and the colored militiamen in particular, are rejoicing because the order to disband the two colored battalions of the District National Guard has been rescinded, it is not at all certain that the negro soldiers will find their future military life entirely satisfactory.

The thirty years' litigation over the will of Nathaniel Gilman, one of the old leather kings in the "Swamp," who died in 1859 and left a large fortune, is at last settled, and in favor of the New-York executors as against the Maine executors.

The English papers, and among them some, like the Spectator, that ought to be better informed, are still talking about some intention on the part of the United States to coerce Canada into annexation, with hostile tariff legislation. We wish we could think of any way of dislodging this queer notion from the minds of otherwise sensible Englishmen.

The disturbed condition of Samoa, set forth in recent-tidings from that archipelago, suggests that the real value of the triple compact made at Berlin has yet to be tested. The Swedish jurist chosen to exercise the responsible office of Chief Justice arrived at Apia, when a large part of the term covered by the treaty had expired; but the wretched condition into which the land titles have fallen has yet to be repaired.

FREEZING OUT THE ANTS. -- The inhabitants of cold climates have little idea of the fierceness of the conflict which has been carried on from time immemorial between man and the ant tribe, and can hardly appreciate the extraordinary capacity shown by these tireless insects in their depredations upon the human race.

LONDON, March 21. -- If American readers, as can well be imagined, feel like complaining that they hear too much about Mr. Parnell, at least this consolation is open to them -- it will not last much longer. From the outset cool men had seen that it could only be a question of time when, in the course of his desperate and wild struggle for political existence, he would commit some fatal error.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- The Democratic City Convention for the nomination of a candidate for Mayor was the scene of an unexpected sensation this afternoon, when from 100 to 150 of the delegates, supporters of the candidacy of ex-Mayor Harrison, withdrew from the convention in Turner Hall and organized an independent convention in Ulrich Hall.

Nothing has happened for some time so to stir up athletic circles in this city as did the interview with himself that Secretary C.C. Hughes of the Manhattan Athletic Club sent out to the press Friday night. No one except Mr. Hughes himself seemed to understand why such a course should be taken by any member of the club.

The Republican County Committee will meet in Nilsson Hall Thursday night, and, if the report of the committee on contested seats in reference to the fights in the Fifth and Thirteenth Assembly Districts is satisfactory, permanent organization, which has been delayed nearly three months, will be effected. The selection of a permanent Chairman will be the first important business to be disposed of, and it is not yet definitely settled who the man will be.
BALTIMORE, March 21. -- The news of Lawrence Barrett's death was received with surprise and sorrow in this city. Only two days ago Manager John W. Albaugh received this letter:

NEW-HAVEN, March 21. -- The Winter meeting of the Yale Athletic Association and the Second Regiment at the armory to-night was a pretty exhibition of athletics. About fifteen hundred people were present. There was some disappointment because Lange of New-York was not in the mile walk and because George of the Manhattan Club, scratch man in the mile run, was also absent, but there were many good amateurs present and the events were well contested.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., March 21. -- The new developments in the Harris-Potts case have created great excitement in this religious resort, where Mrs. Harris, better known as Mary Helen Potts, was a general favorite. When Mrs. Harris died many of her intimate friends believed that there was a scandal connected with her sudden demise, and were considerably surprised when they learned that no autopsy would be held by the New-York authorities.

The Internal Revenue officers were hard at work yesterday trying to discover more evidence against ex-Alderman James Barker, the Tammany politician and formerly leader of the Tammany Hall forces in the Thirteenth Assembly District, who was arrested Friday morning by the United States authorities for running an illicit distillery under the guise of a vinegar factory.

A gale of wind and a deluge of rain made things lively yesterday at Tottenville, but that did not prevent a large number of Staten Islanders from flocking from all directions to listen to the second installment of evidence at the Wright-Ruttinger-murder-suicide-mystery inquest. The twelve good men and true were there on time, with water-soaked boots and dripping beards, but the venerable Coroner was late.

GEN. CROOK'S CHARACTERISTICS. -- At the date of which I am now writing Gen. Crook was an ideal soldier in every sense. He stood about six feet in his stockings, was straight as an arrow, broad-shouldered, lithe, sinewy as a cat, and able to bear any amount of any kind of fatigue. It mattered not under what guise vicissitude and privation came, they never seemed to affect him.

The "raid" upon the Boulangists in Paris at least attests the confidence of the French Government in the attachment of the French people to the republic. That is, thus far, its single redeeming point. Our ways of thinking and of acting are so different from those of Frenchmen that it is difficult for an interested man to draw a satisfactory conclusion from any political event that may happen in France short of actual revolution.

In the days when Mr. JAY GOULD controlled in this city "two newspapers, both daily," the editors he employed were constrained to accept his money and aid his stock-jobbing projects by circumstances quite different and distinct in the two cases.

Our Albany correspondent points out the disparity between the cost and the practical benefit of the numerous investigations that have been made in recent years by legislative committees in this State. There is no doubt that investigations are often ordered without sufficient reason and from no proper motive and that they are made needlessly expensive.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 22. -- Major James McLaughlin of Standing Rock, one of the most successful and experienced Indian Agents now in the service of the Government, has furnished a succinct statement of the present situation on the frontier. He says that the ghost dancing terminated with the war last December. There was a general attempt to discontinue that exciting pastime among the Sioux at Standing Rock Agency after the death of Sitting Bull.

Owners of property along Riverside Drive and vicinity affected by assessments for improving Riverside Drive and Park have organized a movement to resist in the courts the payment of certain claims that the city is now pressing. These claims are based upon improvements begun in 1879, and amount in the aggregate to $1,250,000.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 22. -- It is very plain that P.P. Elder, Speaker of the House of Representatives, is to be the Alliance candidate for Governor next year. He very frankly admits that he is laying plans that way. He made a desperate fight to be United States Senator, and at one time was clearly in the lead of all Alliance candidates.

The several schemes for creating corporations to construct bridges across the East River are an indication of an effective demand for further means of communication of that kind between New-York and Brooklyn. They also indicate a conviction that, under favorable conditions, it would be profitable for private capital to undertake the work.

A drama in real life is enacted every day in the selling of pools in this city. There are villains in it and dupes and some touches of comedy. If the scenes could be grouped, they would make a picture to alarm as well as to amuse. Suppose there are sixty poolrooms in full blast. It is easy to show that their expenses are $1,000 each per week, or $60,000.

Those who keep track of THE TIMES'S reports of local amateur athletic affairs must be impressed with the politics that is creeping into the Amateur Athletic Union. During the recent reorganization of that body there were a number of deplorable examples of ill feeling among the men who are in control, but nothing has occurred for some time as flagrant as the outburst of C.C. Hughes, Secretary of the Manhattan Athletic Club, last week.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 22. -- The whole disgraceful truth about the looting of the Arkansas State Treasury is gradually coming out. There is official authority, the report of the legislative Committee on Treasurer's Accounts, for the statement that the actual deficit will reach $369,746.83. The ex-Treasurer had tried to cut this down by tendering in partial settlement certain wildcat or worthless scrip of various kinds, but this cannot change the actual facts.

BOSTON, March 22. -- On the morning after the State election last November, Mr. Josiah Quincy, Secretary of the Democratic State Committee, sat at his desk scanning carefully the returns from the various polling precincts. Mr. Russell had been elected Governor by a handsome majority. Seven out of the twelve Congressmen chosen were Democrats.

A dastardly attempt was made early yesterday morning to set fire to the tenement house 243 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, between Second and Third Avenues, which if it had been successful would undoubtedly have caused several deaths. But for the fact that one of the occupants of the house was kept out by his business until 2 o'clock, the fire would in all probability have been as disastrous as its instigator wished.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., March 22. -- District Attorney Nicoll of New-York City has decided to investigate the case of the death of Mary Helen Potts-Harris, the beautiful young girl who died at the fashionable boarding school in that city from alleged morphine poisoning. Mrs. Potts, the mother of the dead girl, has been summoned to attend the investigation, which will begin to-morrow.

Before an audience which crowded the auditorium of the Broadway Theatre and three-quarters of the stage Col. Robert G. Ingersoll lectured on Shakespeare last night, eulogizing the dramatist as the greatest genius the world has ever seen, deriding the claims of the advocates of Bacon's authorship of the plays and introducing many bits of Ingersollian philosophy.

LONDON, March 22. -- Discount was firm during the past week at 2 1/2 for three months, and 2 for short. The reports of large drafts of gold going to Montevideo, in connection with the loan of 2,000,000 negotiated by Uruguay, tend to cause a hardening of the money rates. Business on the Stock Exchange was very inactive, and there will be no revival until after the Easter holidays.

TROY, N.Y., March 22. -- The Italians of this city met at Michael Griffa's to-night to protest against the recent lynching at New-Orleans. An exciting time followed. Angry speeches were made and the men fought among themselves.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 22. -- John F. Kilgour, the fugitive bluestone producer, who owns the Erie Railroad Company's famous excursion resort at Shohola Glen, and lately operated thirty quarries and two stonecutting works in the Delaware River Valley, and who mysteriously disappeared on March 3, has been heard from in Canada.

The unhappy fate of James S. Jameson of the Stanley expedition for the relief of Emin Pasha is doubtless responsible for the publication of this unwieldly volume containing Mr. Jameson's diary. Had he survived the expedition, or had the fate of the rear column been a happier one, we cannot conceive of circumstances in which the volume ever would have been made public either by Mr. Jameson himself or by the members of his family.

It looks as though Gov. RUSSELL of Massachusetts had very good ground for his action in the removal of Police Commissioner OSBORNE of Boston, but, however that may be, it is evident that the plan adopted five years ago of putting the Police Department of that city under State control has been a failure.

Practical Electricity will, in its Saturday issue, say: "The oft-repeated assertion that telephonic service cannot be afforded at a lower rate than that which prevails in most of our large cities, and the oft-repeated statement on the part of the American Bell monopolists that 'the larger the business the larger the expense' -- which is contrary to all known data of commercial science -- have of late received a most convincing setback.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Bad air may have something to do with the bad record of the Assembly this year. People can't be expected to be good and do good if they live in an unholy atmosphere. The air of the Assembly Chamber is certainly very rank.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 22. -- Every Kentucky breeder with whom THE TIMES'S correspondent has talked is jubilant over the bright prospects of the Register in the hands of the breeders, and many Kentuckians will attend the convention that will be held in Chicago April 22.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 22. -- The Legislative session is practically ended. The lobby, which has controlled the session, left the capital on the late trains last night, and at the final sessions to-morrow there will be but a slim attendance.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 22. -- The Rev. Howard MacQueary of Canton, Ohio, the alleged heretical Episcopal preacher who recently gave up that faith, preached to-day in the Independent Congregational Church, which invited him to do so some weeks ago. This church was organized by the Rev. J.G. Townsend, now of Pittsburg, who gave up Methodism for a new theology four years ago.

ST. LOUIS, March 22. -- Incoming passengers on a Missouri Pacific train and the throng in the waiting room at the Union Station witnessed a series of peculiar scenes in which a bride and groom were the principal actors.

It is announced that the Hon. BARNES COMPTON of the Fifth District of Maryland will move in the next House for a committee of investigation into the methods of conducting elections in the First District of Maine, now represented by the Hon. T.B. REED. It will be remembered that Mr. COMPTON is the gentleman whom Mr. REED'S "loyal" followers in the last House unseated in favor of Mr. S.H. MUDD.

ALBANY, March 22. -- A source of great and needless expense to the State is found in the investigations which are `ally ordered by one or the other of the two houses of the Legislature. A year ago the Senate sent to the Controller a request for a detailed statement of the moneys paid out for the expenses of investigating committees during the preceding ten years.

Something must usually be pardoned to the necessities of a writer with strong feelings and a somewhat weak case, and Mr. PHELPS'S rather sneering allusion to arbitration in his article on the Bering Sea controversy may not have been intended very seriously. Certainly whatever of haste or perversity there may have been in it is sufficiently punished by the annoyance of having this despised policy proposed by the Secretary of State.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 22. -- The people of this city are, it is rumored in political channels, to be treated to a surprise by Gov. Abbett in the appointment of Tax Commissioners to levy the city taxes under the special law bill 467, by which Elizabeth has been governed since it defaulted to its creditors several years ago. The Commissioners have been ex-County Clerk Dr. Henry R. Cannon, ex-Surrogate James J. Gerber, and Constantine Bickel.

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 22. -- Mr. Seargent, General Manager of the Grand Trunk Railway, was seen to-day in reference to an Ottawa dispatch published in the Toronto Empire of March 20 upon the subject of an alleged demand by the Grand Trunk Railway for $2,000,000 prior to the late elections.

TRENTON, March 22. -- Absolute master as he was of its deliberations and work, Gov. Abbett is far from satisfied with the results of the Legislature's Winter session. The one thing he hoped to accomplish to catch the popular eye he failed in when his servants in Senate and Assembly refused to pass the onerous and inquisitorial Tax bill that his fatly-reimbursed State Tax Commissioners prepared for them.

The new naval ordnance proving ground at Indian Head, below Glymount, on the Potomac, about twenty-five miles from Washington, will undoubtedly be the scene of several interesting trials of armor and guns during the present year. Indeed, the Annapolis ground has also been full of activity for a long time past, particularly since the great competitive armor tests of last September.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The Navy Department has advertised for proposals for some steel armor plates for the armored sponsons for Cruiser No. 6, and for forgings for two six-inch guns and four eight-inch guns. This is the first advertisement under the provision of the Naval Appropriation bill that requires all armor plate and gun forging contracts to be advertised.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Funeral services over the body of Gen. Joseph E. Johnston will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church Tuesday morning, at 11 o'clock, the rector, Dr. Douglass, conducting the ceremonies, after which the body will be removed to Baltimore for interment at the Greenmount Cemetery the same day. Only the simple burial service for the dead will be read at the grave.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 22. -- The Law and Equity Court of Louisville, Ky., has just decided the famous contested will case of the Baroness de Fahrenberg, holding that the will is valid and the devisees are entitled to the estate. This decision revives interest in a romantic story with many pathetic features.

BOSTON, March 22. -- The Rev. Minot J. Savage, at the Church of the Unity, this morning was eloquent in his denunciation of orthodoxy. He led up to his subject by a rapid review of the case of the Rev. Howard MacQueary.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The friends of the Chickamauga National Park in Washington are watching with interest the bill introduced by Gen. McMahon at Albany and intended to assist the promoters of the park undertaking by furnishing the assistance of the State authorities in supplying the monuments to mark the positions of the New-York troops at Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge.

ALBANY, March 22. -- The Republican Senators do not propose this year to accept suggestions from David B. Hill on the date of final adjournment. And with equal trustworthiness it may be published that the Senate, profiting by past experience, will not adjourn until the Governor has acted upon all the appropriation bills which the Legislature will pass. "No bills of this kind will be left with the thirty-day raft," said a Republican Senator to-day.

PORTSVILLE, Penn., March 22. -- A daring crime, for which no motive has yet been developed, was committed shortly before midnight last night on the public road leading from Mahanoy City to Shoemaker's Patch, one of the outlying mining villages. John Troutman and Abraham Jones, two young miners who had been spending the evening in Mahanoy City, were walking to their homes at the Patch together.

UNITED STATES STEAMER BOSTON, EGMONT KEY, Fla., March 18. -- Good gunnery is, in a naval force, the first requisite. Other things there are which are of high importance, such as steering and handling the ship and attacking with the ram or torpedo. The battery, however, remains the principal offensive weapon, and trained gunners will decide actions in the future as they have in the past.

Very brief funeral services were held over the remains of Lawrence Barrett yesterday morning. Few persons were admitted to the room where the services were held and a still smaller number went with the casket to the station whence the body was started toward Cohasset for interment.

As May 18, the time for Rear Admiral Braine's retirement from the service draws near, the navy awaits with eager expectancy some inkling as to his successor in the command of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Yesterday most significant news was given to a TIMES reporter by an officer who is generally well-informed. He said that Commodore James A. Greet, who is now President of the Board of Examination and Retirement, would be the man.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 23. -- William R. Brown, the newly-appointed Warden at Sing Sing Prison, is a native of Newburg, of which city for four years past he has been Postmaster, making one of the best officials the city has ever had. He was born in 1841. His father was the Hon. J.W. Brown, who was one of the great jurists of his day.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The people of New-York State will not vote next month on the prohibition amendment. The Democratic House, inspired by David B. Hill, decided that question to-night by rejecting the Van Gorder concurrent resolution, which names the second Tuesday in April as the day on which the amendment shall be submitted to the people.

Ex-Gov. T.A. Osborn of Kansas, now a State Senator and for many years a political foe of ex-Senator Ingalls, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He did not conceal his delight that Mr. Ingalls was no longer in the Senate. He said the basis of the hostility to the epigrammatic Kansan was deep and of long standing.

Some ingenuous person has been advertising in one of the morning papers an offer of "$25 bonus for pull in the D.P.W.," which is naturally interpreted to mean the Department of Public Works. What this candid Archimedes is going to do with his pou sto, which is the classical equivalent of the contemporary "pull," he does not disclose.

PITTSBURG, March 23. -- The murder of Detective D.H. Gilkinson at Bull Run, in this county, Saturday afternoon and the subsequent developments continue to furnish the sensation of the day in Western Pennsylvania. There have been half a dozen arrests made thus far, all going to break up the gang of burglars who have for more than a year been operating at Homestead, McKeesport, Duquesne, and other large towns in Allegheny County.

Action recently taken by certain Trust combinations has convinced some of our contemporaries that the laws of the several States relating to corporations should be overhauled and improved. The subject is one of growing importance, and some remarks made by the Philadelphia Times show that facts which should be taken into account may not be clearly seen by those who ask for new legislation.

That portion of the code of medical ethics which says that a physician must not submit to a newspaper interview was openly scoffed at by physicians of high standing at a meeting of the County Medical Society in the new Academy Hall last night. Two or three well-known members of the society boldly expressed contempt for the code of ethics.
" Mike Minden's has been raided! What's the matter?"

The scheme to unite the great railroad systems of the West and the Southwest under one general management is making some progress. The financial departments of the Union Pacific, the Atchison, the Missouri Pacific, the Southern Pacific, the Central Pacific, and the Pacific Mail Steamship Company are preparing detailed statements showing the condition and the earning capacity of their respective properties.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- For some time Mrs. McKee has contemplated a European tour for the Summer. During the visit of Mrs. Robert T. Lincoln and daughter in the city, more than a fortnight ago, they were entertained at dinner at the White House, and the European trip was discussed at length.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 23. -- David Starr Jordan, President of the Indiana State University at Bloomington, has been offered and accepted to-day the Presidency of the new university established by Senator Leland Stanford at Palo Alto, Cal., at a salary of $10,000 a year with a residence. The acceptance by President Jordan of this important office takes from Indiana its most distinguished educator.

The Brooklyn firebug has been captured. Instead of a discharged janitor, or low-bred criminal, or person animated by motives of malice or revenge, he turns out to be a beardless young man, the son of wealthy and respectable parents. He says that he assumed the character of an incendiary fiend under an impulse of the Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde sort, and says an overdose of quinine robbed him of his reason.

The great age of eighty-four reached by the late Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON becomes all the more noticeable by comparison with the much earlier deaths of so many of those who held very high rank and command either on the Union or the Confederate side in the civil war. Gen. R.E. LEE, his classmate at West Point, who was born in the same year with JOHNSTON, indeed, died just fifteen days earlier -- at 63.

ALBANY, March 23. -- Warden A.A. Brush, the competent manager of Sing Sing Prison, has been removed for no other reason than that he failed to deliver certain Democratic members of Assembly to David B. Hill last Fall. Every department in the State within reach of Hill's grasp is to-day being welded into a part and parcel of the Hill machine.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 23. -- Dr. C.W. Treverton of this city made a complete statement this afternoon of his connection with the case of Helen Neilson Potts, who recently died at the Comstock School in New-York City.

The report of the Republican County Committee's Committee on Contested Seats in the Fifth and Thirteenth Assembly Districts will be ready for presentation to the County Committee Thursday night. The committee held a secret session in the office of James A. Blanchard, its Chairman, yesterday afternoon, and discussed the details from a typewritten draft of the report.

Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision giving the Sixth Avenue Railway Company $68,000 damages in its suit against the Manhattan Railway Company. The property on which the damages are awarded is between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, in Sixth Avenue, $28,000; between Fifty-eight and Fifty-ninth Streets, in Sixth Avenue, $35,000, and at the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eight Street, $5,000.

The story told exclusively in these columns yesterday of the movement which is on foot to discipline Dr. W. S. Rainsford and Dr. Heber Newton for their too liberal views has naturally awakened a great deal of interest in Episcopal circles.

" Cats and dogs instead of good collateral." That is the reason given by a Director of the Washington National Bank of Broadway for calling upon Bank Examiner Hepburn to take possession of the institution to-day. As the board now figures it, the capital of the bank -- $300,000 -- has been impaired to the extent of something like $135,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The wisdom of making haste slowly begins to be illustrated in some of the utterances of the silver men. Not long ago there was a shriek from Virginia when Mr. Cleveland wrote his opinion that unlimited and independent free coinage of silver would be dangerous, and it was at once asserted by reckless persons that he could not be the candidate of his party in 1892.

Our wise and esteemed contemporary, the Journal of Commerce, looks upon the strifes of politics with the dispassionate judgment of a non-combatant, but it is by no means a disinterested observer. It has decided opinions of political action and party policy, and it seems to us to be best pleased with those issues and contests that least disturb the world of commerce.

For two months or more everybody, down in Wall Sweet has had confidential information that the Rock Island Railroad was in so bad a fix that it would have to reduce its dividend rate, if not pass it altogether. Yesterday was the day for the prophecies to materialize; and they didn't. The usual dividend was declared, and, despite a whole Winter season or sensational tips from the inside, not a single thing unusual happened.

HARTFORD, March 23. -- Ex-Congressman Brandegee of New-London, author of the Brandegee resolutions submitting the controversy in the Legislature over the election of State officers to the Supreme Court for advice, is here this evening, in consultation with Republican leaders, including Gov. Bulkeley, concerning the situation.

CORK, March 23. -- Timothy D. Healy had a very rough experience in this city to-day, being assaulted and seriously injured. He had attended the Assizes, being interested in a case in which his brother, Maurice Healy, had obtained damages for libel against a local member of the Parnellite party. Upon leaving the courtroom Timothy Healy was followed by a mob, which made several attempts to assault him.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 23. -- Ex-Gov. Lucius Robinson died at 12:55 o'clock this afternoon at his residence in Maple Avenue, this city. Death was caused by pneumonia, with which he was attacked a fortnight ago. The latter part of last week the Governor's condition was so precarious that his death was expected hourly, but Saturday he appeared to be better.

C. Mortimer Wiske's concert of German music given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening was on the whole a great deal better than any of his previous orchestral concerts. This is only comparative praise, but it is a pleasure to be able to write it. The improvement in Mr. Wiske's work was due to several causes. The chief of these was the merit of the music, all of which was worth hearing.
ROCHESTER N.Y., March 23. -- This afternoon the foLlowing manifesto was issued by the clothing manufacturers to their locked-out employes:

WICHITA, Kan., March 24. -- The jury in the case of the United States against J.C. Adams, charged with killing Capt. W.M. Couch, the famous Oklahoma boomer, brought in a verdict to-night of murder in the first degree.

The course of PARNELL in relation to the election in Cork is calculated to alienate much even of the diminished following that his previous acts had left him. In effect he backs down from his own challenge to stand for Cork against one of the anti-Parnellites. Such a contest would be even more interesting than that at Kilkenny.

If Gov. HILL desires to make a really excellent appointment to fill the vacancy upon the bench of the Supreme Court caused by the death of Judge BRADY, an appointment that would be a well-deserved promotion and would be generally approved by the bar and by the community, he cannot well do better than to select Judge INGRAHAM for the place.

A meeting of receivers of eggs was held yesterday afternoon at the Mercantile Exchange and it was determined to use the best endeavors of the trade to discourage the refrigerating of eggs by shippers. It is said that eggs preserved in icehouses are not of good quality, and being mixed with fresh eggs make business unprofitable to all concerned.

According to the programme outlined in yesterday's TIMES, A.B. Hepburn, the National Bank Examiner, early yesterday morning took possession of the Washington National Bank "in the name of the Controller of the Currency, the Hon. Edward S. Lacey," as read the notice posted on the door.

In order to clinch the action of the joint committee of the trunk lines and the Central Traffic Association in abolishing commissions on passenger business the Board of Rulings, composed of J.F. Goddard, G.R. Blanchard, L.P. Farmer, and F.C. Donald, has prepared the following form of circular, to be issued by the General Passenger Agent of each road:

An act was passed in 1886 authorizing the Commissioners of Charities and Correction of this city to provide municipal lodging houses for persons obtaining tickets at a police station, where they could obtain a bath, wholesome food, and a night's lodging, in return for which they should be required to perform "a reasonable amount of labor."

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 24. -- Sir Adolphe Caron, Minister of Militia, issued his annual report yesterday. The total expenditure last year was $1,296,810. The permanent forces, including the infantry schools and the batteries at Quebec, Kingston, and Victoria, B.C., absorbed $463,000 of this amount. Other leading items in the expenditure were: Ammunition and military stores, $198,553, and Royal Military College, $83,677.
TRENTON, N.J., March 24. -- The following are among the appointments of the Methodist Conference for the current year:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 24. -- The English brig Joseph Banigan came ashore near Hildreth's West End Hotel this morning. At 4 o'clock Patrolman Charles Rundquist, while proceeding north on his watch saw a dark object on the coast which he was satisfied was a stranded vessel, and immediately notified Capt. Asher Wardell of the life-saving station.

ALBANY, March 24. -- Unusual interest was manifested in the hearing before the Judiciary Committee of the Senate on the two joint resolutions proposing amendments to the Constitution, first, by Senator Laughlin, to make the terms or the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, all the elective State-officers and Senators four years, and member of Assembly two years.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 24. -- Fitzsimmons, the murderer of Detective Gilkinson, and Laura Snowden, the young woman who betrayed him to the detectives, continue to be the centre of romantic interest hereabout. Telegrams from Brockville, Ontario, leave no doubt that the man now in Pittsburg prison is Edward Carroll Fitzsimmons, that he was born of wealthy parents, educated in a Montreal college, and seventeen years ago became a rover and an adventurer.

The young Brooklyn firebug, Hugh C. Miller, was yesterday taken from Raymond Street Jail and brought before Police Justice Walsh for examination. His father was in court and was much affected. Ex-Judge James Troy entered a plea of "not guilty" in Miller's behalf and asked for a short delay in the examination. It was set for next Monday morning at 10:30 o'clock, and Miller was taken back to jail.

The first gun of the year in the round of college Commencements was fired last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The Medical Department of the University of the City of New-York has completed its first half century and made it the occasion of bestowing the degree of Doctor of Medicine upon 203 young men from all parts of the world.

ALBANY, March 24. -- The Senate to-day passed the amendments to the ballot-reform law, with a few alterations from the printed form, after an hour's debate. The bill now goes to the Assembly, and, as it is understood the Governor favors it in its present shape, it will, no doubt, reach the Executive Chamber without amendment, and will become a law.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Proposals will be opened at the Navy Department to-morrow for the sale of a lot of old vessels, so dilapidated that, under the 20 per cent law, they are no longer available even for foundations for ante-election repairs.

PITTSBURG, March 24. -- The epidemic of grip in Pittsburg, Allegheny, and adjacent towns has assumed alarming proportions. The mortality list has taken a jump, reaching in this city 444 for twenty-four days of March, against 377 for the entire month of last year. For the twenty-four hours ending at noon to-day 38 deaths were reported, a rate which, if kept up for a month, would aggregate nearly 1,200.

LYNN, Mass., March 24. -- The bench show of Massachusetts Kennel Club opened at Music Hall this morning. There are 350 dogs shown, among them being the seven-thousand-dollar St. Bernard, Sir Bedivere, owned by E.B. Sears; the man trailer, Jack the Ripper, from Kildare Kennels, Pittsburg, and Plinlimmon, Jr., E.B. Sears's rough-coated St. Bernard.

The curious condition of the average Republican mind, even when it undertakes an effort at independence, is shown by the treatment of Senator DON CAMERON in his State. Only last week the Republican Committee of Lancaster County passed, by a large majority, a vote of censure upon him because he had voted against the Force bill and in favor of the Free-Coinage bill.

As stated by THE TIMES yesterday, the Episcopal clergymen of the Diocese of New-York, without regard to their personal predilections and whether affiliating with the High Church or Low Church wings of the denomination, are disclosed by their action to be practically a unit in support of the protest directed against the alleged uncanonical practices of certain of their fellow-clergymen in inviting ministers of other denominations, Evangelical, Trinitarian, and Unitarian, to their pulpits.

An elaborate report on the street-cleaning problem was made in pamphlet form to Mayor Grant yesterday by the Advisory Committee recently appointed by him to examine the subject. This committee consists of Thatcher M. Adams, Morris K. Jesup, Charles F. Chandler, David H. King, Jr., and Capt. Francis V. Greene. When appointing the committee the Mayor asked for the committee's judgment on the following questions:

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Secretary Blaine received a letter from Gov. Nicholls of Louisiana this morning in regard to the recent killing of eleven Italians in the jail at New-Orleans, of which the following is a copy:...

PANAMA, March 16. -- The British iron-clad Warspite arrived at Callao on March 1. Those on board furnished information of which the following is a summary: They left Iquique on Feb. 26, subsequent to the different events which led to the capture of that port by the rebels and the first fire, which caused the destruction of property valued at $2,000,000.
ALBANY, March 24. -- That Senator Hill is worried over the opposition that has been manifested against his Excise bill has been evident since the first hearing on it.

Another inquest on the Astor House suicide is in progress, conducted by Coroner Levy. Yesterday the case was further mixed up by the production of a couple of letters which appear to be in touch with the Sumner-Norman interest and to suggest the possibility that another "actress" may identify "Wright," "Evans," and "Edgar" as E.C. Smith.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The funeral services-over the body of Gen. Joseph E. Johnston took place in this city this morning. By special request of the deceased, the ceremonies were devoid of ostentation or unnecessary formality. Just before 11 o'clock the body was taken quietly to St. John's Episcopal Church, accompanied by the family and near friends.

The people of this city owe a debt of gratitude to the Advisory Committee on the subject of street cleaning appointed by Mayor GRANT, which consists of Messrs. MORRIS K. JESUP, THATCHER M. ADAMS, Prof. CHARLES F. CHANDLER, DAVID H. KING, Jr., and Capt. F.V. GREENE. It has done its work thoroughly and submitted an admirable report to the Mayor.

ST. PAUL, March 24. -- Cold chills ramdown the back of the municipality of St. Paul to-day as it became evident that there was some sort of a scheme on foot in the State Senate to rob the city of the State capital.

The answer of Gov. NICHOLLS Of Louisiana to the dispatch of the Secretary of State concerning the lynching at New-Orleans puts the affair in a light in which it will be difficult to make it the subject of diplomatic representations. In the first place, Mr. NICHOLLS points out that nearly all the persons upon whom justice was irregularly executed were American citizens.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- A local paper says: "The old rumor that the Canadian Pacific is seeking an entrance to Chicago is being renewed, with every indication that the road will accomplish that result. But, instead of only getting a Chicago opening for its Canadian business, the road will play an important part in through New-York Western freight and passenger traffic.

Every man was a small boy once, and apparently in every man's manliness there is enough of the old-time small-boyishness left to induce him on occasions to cast aside the things that are for the things that were. One of those occasions is the annual advent of the circus.

In the important case brought by the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation, the Commercial Exchange of Philadelphia, and the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce against all the trunk line railroads of the country, before the Inter-State Commerce Commission. to restrain them from transporting imported merchandise from the ports of entry to interior places of destination at lower than the schedule tariff rates, the decision recently rendered by the commission has just been published.

The State Commissioners in Lunacy appear to be strongly opposed to the bill which has been passed by the Senate materially modifying the law for the State care of the insane so far as it applies to the Homeopathic Hospital at Middletown. The proposed change would interfere somewhat awkwardly with the operation of the new law, but we do not see that it seriously affects the principle of State care.

The Park Commissioners who gave the elevated railroad company a "license" to run its structure across Battery Park did an illegal act, and the Park Commissioners now in office are culpable for permitting its continuance. By plainly-worded law and by covenant of the Corporation of the city of New-York, Battery Park and Bowling Green are forever made public ground that cannot in any way, or in any degree, be turned over to private interests.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 25. -- The General Assembly took action to-day against changing the fundamental law and in effect perpetuating a requirement which is fruitful in second elections. The Senate had as special order for the day the joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the State providing that a plurality instead of a majority vote shall be necessary to the election of persons voted for under the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Representative Dockery of Missouri, who made a statement of appropriations before Mr. Cannon submitted his statement and apology, has been reviewing Mr. Cannon's work, and has made a comparative showing of the appropriations made by the Fiftieth Congress and the Fifty-first, or Reed's. Mr. Dockery, in explanation of his tabulated statement, says:

There was a mild approach to hilarity in the Real Estate Exchange yesterday afternoon when the Merchant Tailors' Association auctioned off a lot of judgments secured by its members against slow-paying debtors. Martin F. Hatch, the auctioneer, had the stand in the middle of the floor, and there was a crowd all around his perch.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- The firm of A. Whitney Sons, car wheel manufacturers, is financially embarrassed. The firm is now composed of John R. and James S. Whitney, the surviving sons of the founder. Rumors of the embarrassment of the firm were confirmed by James S. Whitney. Mr. Whitney declined to give any details of the matter beyond admitting the bare fact.

The wreckers of the Washington National Bank were not visible yesterday. President E.G. Sherman was still too weak from nervous prostration to appear, and John S. Silver apparently considered it a good time to keep out of sight.

BISMARCK, N.D., March 25. -- The farming season in North Dakota will open with all the conditions the most favorable that they have been at seeding time since 1885. Spring work is usually in progress at this time, but will be backward this season owing to the late storms. The ground is partially thawed out, but covered with snow in most places.

AMHERST, Mass., March 25. -- Pratt Gymnasium was crowded this afternoon with spectators to witness the twelfth annual Ladd exhibition in heavy gymnastics. There were fifteen events, all of which were hotly contested. The Class of 92, winning the largest number of prizes, was awarded the banner and prize. Following is a list of events with the names of the winners appended:

Peter E. Tarpey, schoolmaster, politician, editor, and slugger, and the man who is said to have chased all the editors in Westchester County into the woods, appeared before Judge Duffy in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday.

The State Board of Mediation and Arbitration has not commonly been considered by rational persons as a valuable addition to the machinery of the State. It was added at the instigation of "Labor," and it has commonly shown its regard for its creator by taking the side of Labor in all disputes, insomuch that Capital has declined to submit any disputes to its adjudication.

BOSTON, March 25. -- The question of holding an open regatta during the coming season was the topic of discussion at the special meeting of the New-England Yacht Racing Association, held at Parker's this evening. Commodore Arthur Fuller of the South Boston Yacht Club presided in the absence of President L.M. Clark.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The Navy Department has received advices confirmatory of the report that the wrecked tug Trlana has broken in two. This is understood to negative any hope of floating her. The reported sinking 0u the Galena into the sand is also regarded as an indication that that vessel also is doomed to destruction.

The cable dispatches not long ago contained an account of a public quarrel between Queen VICTORIA and the Prince of WALES. That this quarrel, if it ever occurred, has been made up is made quite plain by the announcement that Mr. ARTHUR WILSON has been appointed High Sheriff of Yorkshire and that he will soon be knighted.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Senator Laughlin was overwhelmed to-day by the gibes of many of his colleagues over a slight misunderstanding touching overcoats between him and the Marquis de Choiseul, who a couple of weeks ago married Miss Coudert, daughter of Mr. Charles Coudert of New-York.

Messrs. "Shang" Draper, L. Theodore Allen, "Hoboken Charlie" Newton, and "Butcher" Thompson, commission brokers, beg to inform their friends that, beginning this morning, they will receive subscriptions at their several places of business for stock in the Underground Anti-Bigot Protective Company, Limited.

ASBURY PARK, March 25. -- An impression prevails throughout the State that the new County Excise Commission act will do away with prohibition at Asbury Park, Ocean Grove, Avon-by-the-Sea, and Belmar, and compel the authorities of the towns enumerated to grant licenses to sell liquor.

As we ventured to hope, the advisory committee in the matter of street cleaning has gone to the root of much of the difficulty encountered in that apparently desperate work, and has stated that an absolute condition precedent to any adequate reform is a complete change in the method of selecting laborers.

For many years past the cry has gone out from an overburdened and overtaxed people for a reduction of tariff duties laid upon them under the exigencies of a costly war. When the tariff of 1867 was enacted internal revenue taxes were laid upon almost all articles of home production, upon manufacturing, banking, and commerce.

Until David B. Hill became Commander in Chief of the military and naval forces of the State of New-York, politics, save incidentally and by implication, was an unknown quantity in the National Guard or uniformed militia. With the incoming of Hill, however, politics came to the front as an important and controlling factor in the administration of military affairs.

The trial of Alphonse J. Stephani for the murder of ex-Judge Clinton G. Reynolds in his office in Wall Street May 15, 1890, was begun in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday before Presiding Justice Van Brunt of the Supreme Court. Insanity will be Stephani's defense. He is defended by Daniel Dougherty and William F. Howe.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The State Board of Mediation and Arbitration submitted a special report to the Legislature to-day on the lock-out of cutters by the Clothiers' Exchange of Rochester, together with sixty-odd printed pages of testimony taken by the board in its investigation of the trouble. The report, after stating the facts of the lock-out, says:

Opposition to the Forty-second Street reservoir beer-garden scheme is as living and persistent as men of all professions and persuasions can make it. The New-York Academy of Medicine at a meeting last week appointed its President, Dr. A.L. Loomis, and Drs. Abraham Jacobi, Francis Delafield, and Gouverneur M Smith a committee to go to Albany and make its protest to the Senate committee against the proposed nuisance.

We present to-day a bit of ancient history for the benefit of the Park Commissioners. A little delving in public records reveals the fact that many years ago the city sold property adjacent to Battery Park with a covenant that no part of that open ground should ever be appropriated to private uses.

The Chairmen of the various Assembly District Republican organizations, or rather the Executive Committee (that is to be) of the Republican County Committee, met last night in the Cumberland and made arrangements for tonight's meeting of the County Committee which will be held in Nilsson Hall. All the districts were represented. James A. Blanchard acted as proxy for William Brookfield of the Twenty-first.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 25. -- Dispatches from Kansas state that the worst snowstorm of the season is raging in that State. The trains from the West all came in late this morning -- that is, those that got in at all -- and their crews all have woeful tales to tell of the weather. The country from Eastern Kansas to Denver has disappeared under an immense fall of snow.

The difficulties in which the Interior Department is involved by the conduct of affairs at Green Bay Agency are really of two sorts. They began last Summer, when Mr. JENNINGS, who had for several years served as Indian Agent at Kenesha, being appointed under President CLEVELND, was removed, or not reappointed, and Mr. KELSEY was made his successor.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The first step has been taken toward securing a Harrison delegation from Virginia in 1892. For more than four years there has been war in the Republican Party in that State, with Mahone leading on one side and some of the negroes under the leadership of Langston, refusing to be led by Mahone, on the other.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 25. -- The Senate failed to reach a vote on the Seymour bill this afternoon and will renew the debate to-morrow. The measure can be carried only by a narrow majority, if at all.

BOSTON, March 25. -- Republican leaders from all parts of the State filled the Meionaon this morning, at the second annual convention of the Republican State League. Congressman Morse was elected Chairman, and pitched into Gov. Russell in this style:

Some of the McKinley papers made wry faces last Spring when they were asked to swallow certain paragraphs in the new Tariff bill, and the protests made by them before they were whipped into line are interesting now because of the admissions which are involved. The Boston Journal said on April 2:

Representative DOCKERY of Missouri certainly makes out a strong case against the accuracy of Mr. CANNON'S statement of the amount of the appropriations of the Fifty-first Congress. The latter gentleman was hardly ingenuous in wholly omitting the sum required for refunding the direct tax, one of the most inexcusable of all the extravagant appropriations of the last session.

BOSTON, March 25. -- Gov. Russell and the Executive Council are now squarely at loggerheads. By a vote of 8 to 1 the Councilors, with Lieut. Gov. Haile, refused this afternoon to consent to the Governor's removal of Police Commissioner Osborne.

The collapse of the Washington Bank does not seem to produce any strong impression in financial circles. There is, of course, no reason why it should give rise to any direct uneasiness. It was a small bank, recently founded, and was not a member of the Clearing House. Its clearing bank -- the Gallatin -- will suffer no loss.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- The creditors of the Messrs. H.J. G.R. Crump, the proprietors of the Colonnade Hotel, Fifteenth and Chestnut Streets, and of the fashionable Summer hotel. Devon Inn, in Chester County, to the number of about forty, assembled this afternoon at the office of Attorney John O. Bowman for the purpose of being enlightened on the affairs of the embarrassed firm.

HARTFORD, March 26. -- The only tangible result reached by the Senate this afternoon was the appointment of a committee to examine all the plans and measures that have been presented for the removal of the legislative dead-lock and to report on March 31. The proposition came from the Republicans, and was unanimously adopted by the Democratic majority.

Saturday evening, March 7, 1891, the Hon. Asher G. Caruth, who represented the Louisville (Ky.) district in the Fifty-first Congress, and has been re-elected, arrived home from Washington. That night he was interviewed by a correspondent of the New-York Sun and expressed it as his solemn conviction that David B. Hill was the man above all others to lead the Democratic Party to victory in 1892.

RICHMOND, Va., March 26. -- The reconciliation between Mahone and ex-Congressman Langston, whom the former has fought so bitterly, has caused a little flutter in Republican circles. This reconciliation is accepted to mean that Mahone has returned to politics and is harmonizing the working factions for the Presidential contest. Of course, both Mahone and Langston know the Republicans haven't a ghost of a chance of carrying Virginia for their Electoral ticket.

BOSTON, March 26. -- There was much excitement at the State House this morning. It all came about through a remark of President Henry M. Whitney of the West End Street Railway Company, who was addressing the Committee on Cities and Taxation in joint hearing assembled, in remonstrance against the compensation of cities for the use of streets by private corporations.

Kellogg's combination sale of trotting horses was continued at the American Institute Building yesterday afternoon with better results than on any day during the week. Fifty-six head were disposed of for a total of $21,745, an average of $388.30. The best prices obtained yesterday were as follows:

" A fall in the price of protected articles on which the duty has been increased," said the Tariff League's Bulletin a few days ago, "is a marked feature in the practical working of the new tariff." This was published in a paper supported by an association of protected manufacturers, many of whom asked the Republican tariff makers last year for higher duties.

Among the eight condemned naval vessels, for the purchase of which bids were opened the other day, were the Brooklyn, the Juniata, the Ossipee, and the Quinnebaug, all not very long ago on station service. They are examples of how the wooden navy is dropping away, and probably they will be followed before long by the Omaha, the Tallapoosa, and others.

ST. LOUIS, Me., March 26. -- The deposition of the Rev. Constantine P. Smith, priest of the Church of the Assumption, has been taken here to be used in a divorce suit now pending in New-Haven, Conn. George W. Alexander was a very prominent citizen of St. Louis, and died very rich. His wife and his two sons inherited his fortune. Two years after his death the wife married Robert S. Kennedy, a steamboat barkeeper.

The industry of grape culture, representing a total value in land improvements, machinery, and appurtenances of $155,660,000, and furnishing employment to 200,780 persons, is worthy of notice. Many facts of interest in regard to it are found in census bulletin No. 38. The total acreage of land devoted to the culture of the vine was in 1889 401,261, over 300,000 acres of which were in bearing.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 26. -- The announcement of a sliding scale in the Connellsville coke region, by which the great strike has been in a measure broken, and is likely to be ended entirely, is generally accepted as the work of Andrew Carnegie himself. Mr. Carnegie's firms are not only the largest consumers of coke hereabout, but the H.C. Frick Coke Company, of which he is an active member, controls nearly two-thirds of the region.

CONCORD, N.H., March 26. -- So far as is yet apparent, the attempt to organize the Alliance movement in this State, in whose interest Secretary Beaumont of the National Citizens' Alliance and Jerry Simpson of Kansas, representing the Farmers' Alliance, were extensively advertised to speak at Phenix Hall, in this city, to-night, is not likely to meet with any considerable measure of success.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- The grip is prevalent in Chicago to an alarming extent. Physicians pronounce it epidemic, and the returns made to the Board of Health show that the mortality of the city is greater than a year ago, during the worst period of the prevalence of the disease.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- The local speculative position in corn for the last sixty days has not been appreciated by many people. Prices have moved up chiefly in sympathy with the facts concerning the supply and demand of the cash article, but at the same time there has existed a compact speculative holding in the May option vastly larger than has been suspected.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 26. -- Some weeks ago a dispatch to THE TIMES on the subject of the phosphate interests in South Carolina described the feeling that the Tillman administration, in its desire for reform, would seriously injure the industry. Since then the administration has attacked the "octopus," as Gov. Tillman styles the phosphate industry, and the fears of conservative men have been realized.

BEADING, Penn., March 26. -- Arrangements have been made at the Scott Foundry here for the beginning of work on the eighteen-foot Brown segmental tube wire gun, as soon as the formal public tests at Fort Wadsworth, New-York, shall have been reported and duly approved by the proper authorities at Washington.

Mayor Grant, President Henry D. Purroy of the Fire Department, and the Board of Electrical Control's expert, Mr. Wheeler, had a long discussion in the Mayor's office yesterday as to the best way of getting down the duplicate wires and poles Mr. Wheeler had reported as existing. Mr. Purroy declared that most of the complaints against the fire wires were unfounded.

The Secretary of the Treasury has recently ordered a new classification of what is known to the trade as silk-striped cotton Italians. This stuff is used for sleeve linings. Importers say; that the operations of the tariff as to no other article better illustrate the iniquities of the new law. Many hundred thousand dollars' worth of these Italian goods are imported every year.

That is a very interesting interview which the Marquis DE VILLENEUVE now reports as having taken place in 1866 between BISMARCK and the late Prince NAPOLEON. Neither in 1866 nor at any earlier or later time was the late Prince NAPOLEON the sort of man whom BISMARCK might naturally have been expected to seek for a counselor or confidant, but the interview as now reported bears every internal evidence of being authentic.

It is understood that a number of Trenton citizens have sent a petition to Secretary of the Navy Tracy asking to have one of the new ships that are awaiting names given the honorable name of Trenton. This suggestion is not received with entire satisfaction by the department, because of the sad fate of the old Trenton in the Samoan hurricane.
RED BANK, N.J., March 26. -- Two confidence men made an unsuccessful attempt to play a bunko game on Capt. John A. Worthley to-day. Mr. Worthley is one of the town's oldest and wealthiest citizens.

ALBANY, March 26. -- The House has killed the bill of O.F. Lane of Otsego, which proposed to tax personal property at its face value and to give no exemption for debts charged against it. The bill was the special order of the day.

NORFOLK, Va., March 26. -- A special from Elizabeth City, N.C., to the Landmark, says: "Lieut. Failing of the Life-Saving Service, who is at the wreck of the British steamer Strathairly, reports the following saved: R. Turner, second officer; George Simpson, boatswain; Albert Smith, seaman; John Whalen, ordinary seaman; William McArthur, fireman; John Campbell, fireman.

The coming 1st of May will number among its moving events the departure of the seat of civil justice in the Sixth District, which comprises the Eighteenth and Twenty-first Wards, from the stable loft at Eighteenth Street and Union Place. Just where it will take up new quarters is not yet known, nor will it be until after the next meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- A meeting of the Illinois Railroad and Warehouse Commission was held at the Grand Pacific this afternoon, at which a delegation of shippers from the central portion of the State was heard in reference to the grading of corn. The shippers complain that much of their corn which is really No. 2 has been graded No. 3 by Inspector Price.

WHEELING, West Va., March 26. -- The annual financial statement of the Pittsburg. Wheeling and Kentucky Railroad was submitted to the Board of Directors to-day. It showed gross earnings of $270,830.80; operating expenses, $116,452.08; hire of equipment, $17,385.93; sundry freight account, $985.88; net earnings for the year, $136,006.18. After paying all fixed charges the surplus for the year is $105,111.18.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- The Harrison Democratic Committee completed its city ticket today. Louis Nettlehorst was nominated for City Treasurer, George T. Sugg for City Attorney, and Michael O'Connor for City Clerk. All these candidates, it is said, will accept the places tendered them. None of them is on the Cregier ticket.

The record of exciting meetings of the Republican County Committee was well-nigh broken last night. The committee met in Nilsson Hall to perfect an organization, a bit of necessary business that has been delayed for nearly three months owing to the fights in the ever-belligerent Fifth and Thirteenth Assembly Districts.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The following rules and regulations, being additional to those made under an act of Congress of August last, are prescribed by the Secretary of Agriculture for the inspection of live cattle, hogs, and their carcasses:
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Thursday, March 26:

ALBANY, March 26. -- The bill drawn by Major Balch of the Third Brigade and indorsed by Gen. Robert Shaw Oliver, providing for evading the Constitution in order to make the Adjutant General of the State a life officer on a salary, was crushed out of all semblance this afternoon before the joint session of the Military Committees of the Senate and House.

NEWARK, N.J., March 26. -- Many society people of Orange flocked to Judge Henry's courtroom in Newark to-day to witness the trial of the suit brought by Mme. Adele Cubier of New-York against Edward B. Aymar for the value of dresses made for Mrs. Aymar. Mr. Aymar is a Director in the Orange Athletic Club and his family moves in the highest social circles in the Oranges.

Hope of the settlement of the Connecticut dead-lock is revived once more by the appointment in the Senate at Hartford of a committee of two Republicans and two Democrats to consider all the various propositions that have been submitted in the two houses, and report thereon on Tuesday next.

In the death of James R. Mount, Wednesday, at the age of sixty-five, there was removed one of the most famous of the old New-York volunteer firemen. He was the very type of the fire volunteer, and his exploits were of the sort that made the reputation of the old department. In his day the deeds and daring of Foreman James Mount of Hose No. 14 were known to every New-Yorker.

SLIGO, March 26. -- Alderman Valentine B. Dillon, Jr., of the Rotunda Ward of Dublin and Alderman Bernard Collery of this town were to-day officially nominated by the Parnellites and by the McCarthyites, respectively, to succeed the late Mr. Peter McDonald as Representative of North Sligo in Parliament.

A circular has been issued by the Rio Grande Western Railway Company to its common and preferred stockholders announcing that, in view of the steadily-increasing business of the road, the Directors have declared a dividend of 1 1/4 per cent. in cash for the quarter ending March 31, payable May 1. New equipment to the extent of $450,000 is needed to prepare for the prospective further increase of business this year.

BERLIN, March 26. -- Prince Bismarck has gone to Altona, the headquarters of the Ninth Army Corps, commanded by Gen. von Waldersee, ex-chief of the German staff, upon a visit to that officer in return for the visit recently paid by the General to Prince Bismarck at Friedrichsruh.

The Mexican Land Grant Court established at the last session of Congress will have jurisdiction of a class of claims that have been greatly neglected for forty years. The treaty of 1848 provided that valid grants of land which had already been made by Mexico in the territory she then ceded should be respected and that the titles thereto should be confirmed.

ST. LOUIS, March 26. -- The Hearst funeral train, dyed a beautiful titian red, passed through the city this morning on the return trip. Just behind the funeral train came the Grafton excursion train, and on board the latter was Mrs. Helen M. Gougar, the noted Indiana temperance agitator. The Grafton excursion train has been following the Hearst train for five days.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- The position of the Chicago and Alton Railroad on the subject of paying commissions on passenger business ought to be well known all over the United States. Yet a local paper comes out this morning with the statement that "James Charlton of the Alton Road, who is in a measure the father of the proposition to cease these payments, says that the scheme to abolish them will certainly be a success.

" GESPENSTER." A play in three acts with but five actors held the attention of a largo audience of Germans at the Amberg Theatre last night. It was the Norwegian, Henrik Ibsen's, drama, "Ghosts," written in 1881 and soon afterward turned into German. Latterly, admiration for Ibsen has spread to London, and some of his plays have been translated and given in a tentative way in New-York and Boston

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 27. -- E.T. Legari, United States Commissioner and Trial Justice in St. Andrew's Parish, where are situated the phosphate mines, at which the New-York Tribune alleges gross outrages have been perpetrated upon Italian miners, has made an official report to Gov. Tillman.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 27. -- It was developed to-day that the State Temperance Organization has determined to make an attempt through the courts to secure a reversal of the opinion of the Supreme Court rendered in 1883 which declared that the prohibitory amendment to the State Constitution, adopted in June, 1882, was null and void on account of certain informalities in passing the Legislature.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 27. -- Gov. Davis has received a requisition from Morgan G. Bulkeley for the extradition of Thomas Garnett, a prisoner in Rhode Island State Prison, whose term will expire to-morrow. The prisoner had warning that he would be sent for, and so advised the Governor three weeks ago. The situation is like that presented to Gov. Hill.

LOWELL, Mass., March 27. -- The people of Lowell and Lawrence are seriously troubled as to where they shall obtain their drinking water in the future. There is enough of it, and there are millions of barrels to spare, but the water of the Merrimack River has been pronounced unfit for use unless it is boiled. Now, boiled water is not always convenient; most persons would rather have it raw.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 27. -- The Hon. Lawrence T. Neal has, after much beating about the bush, finally discovered that the rank and file of the Ohio Democracy were not at all alarmed by what a few gentlemen in Washington proposed, and he has quietly withdrawn, or rather announced that he would not be a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination so long as Gov. Campbell was in the field.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- When the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was considered by the Senate last month a provision was inserted authorizing the appointment of architects, draughtsmen, and civil engineers in the office of the Supervising Architect of the Treasury Department without regard to the civil service rules and regulations.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., March 27. -- Steam pumps have been put aboard the Galena, at Gay Head, and an effort will be made to-day to pump her out, to enable the wreckers to save material from the lower hold. A light northerly wind and smooth sea are on at Gay Head today. The coal and light articles have been removed from the tug Nina.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 27. -- Local poolroom keepers have determined upon the way in which they will fight the Stone Pool bill which passed the Legislature and will soon become a law. It is similar to the Tennessee law and prohibits the sale of pools except while race meetings are in progress in the State, and then only permits pools to be sold on those particular races.

In these days of long strides in marine architecture the meek and lowly New-York ferryboat gets its full share of the pace. Nowhere on the globe are types of these light-draught carriers seen in such abundance and in such remarkably efficient design as one finds along the North River slips from Barclay Street south to the slip of the Staten Island boats.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 27. -- W.C. France, who is one of the largest breeders of trotters in the country to-day, expressed himself as in favor of the movement looking toward the control of registration by the breeders, as the business has become too large and important to be under the control of a man or any little set of men.

DENVER, Col., March 27. -- Denver is making extensive preparations for the Trans-Mississippi Commercial Congress, which will convene in his city May 18. It will be the first regularly called convention of the people of the territory west of the Mississippi River ever held, and will be devoted to the discussion of questions of particular interest to the States and Territories to be represented.

There are yet several hundred veteran policemen and police pensioners and a few citizens who recall a crime which cost a police officer his life, a singular condition of municipal affairs, and a very strange murder trial whenever they pass old Odd Fellows' Hall at Centre and Grand Streets. At 4 A.M. on the 21st of July, 1857, Officer Eugene Anderson of the Fourteenth Precinct was patrolling his post there.

It is reported that Mayor GRANT desires to leave to the city a monument of his administration in the form of a proper and adequate municipal building. The ambition is legitimate and even laudable. It should be borne in mind, however, that the efforts of the last unmixed and unchecked Tammany administration in the way of public buildings were not calculated to commend the memory of that administration.

NORFOLK, Va., March 27. -- The Norwegian bark Dictator from Pensacola, Fla., to West Hartlepool, England, laden with pine lumber, with a crew of fifteen and the Captain's young wife and little boy of three years, came ashore in a strong easterly gale this morning, four miles south of Cape Henry and two miles north of Virginia Beach Hotel.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 27. -- This order has been issued by the Knights of Labor: To the Members of the Order, Wherever Found, Greeting:

LONDON, March 27. -- Lord Salisbury, just before starting for San Remo, held a long conference with Lord Knutsford and Mr. Currie, the permanent Secretary of the Foreign Office. A work of supreme difficulty, requiring the most delicate handling, was confided to Mr. Currie relating to engagements of England to protect Belgium.

It seems that some of the proprietors of the protected poolrooms are not satisfied to play fair in their game, in which they have about everything to win and mighty little to lose. One victim of Murphy's room at 144 East Fourteenth Street writes to tell how patrons of that place, where bets from $1 up are taken, are fleeced.

Mrs. Marietta Beach, a fair woman of twenty-eight or thirty, is about to bring criminal action against two well-known and prosperous physicians of Hoboken on the charge of conspiracy and kidnapping where she was the victim. The physicians are Dr. D.R. Atwell of 238 and Dr. Charles I. Simon of 364 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken.

BOSTON, March 27. -- Boston hangs her head a little to-night. The cause is a report of a special commission, transmitted to the Legislature by Gov. Russell, showing that a bust, long standing in Dorie Hall, in the State House, marked Samuel Adams, is really that of George Washington.

QUANAH, Texas, March 27. -- Wednesday evening as the State Rangers were in search of J.F. Morris, a double murderer who broke guard and escaped at Quanah on the night of March 21, they ran upon a couple of parties in the Pease River breaks. From their actions the officers were led to believe they were fugitives from justice, so they arrested them and brought them to town.

ALBANY, March 27. -- The Senate Finance Committee has reported the Stewart Appropriation bill for the World's Columbian Exposition, having clipped off $50,000, making it $200,000 instead of $250,000. A number of minor amendments were also added. Mr. Stewart promptly moved that the bill be ordered to third reading, and the Senate acquiesced.

NEWARK, N.J., March 27. -- Louisa Kleinenberg, a pretty eighteen-year-old cook, in the employ of Theodore D. Palmer of Monroe Place and East Park Street, Bloomfield, has treated the residents of that fire-plagued town to a novel sensation, and neither the Town Committeemen nor the Newark police, to whom the Town Committeemen appealed, know what to make of it all.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 27. -- British Columbia and the northwest coast on the Pacific Ocean are inhabited by a number of tribes belonging to seven or eight linguistic stocks; and Dr. Dawson, in his report on the Queen Charlotte Islands, published by the Geological Survey not long ago, gives a most interesting description of the Haidas, one of the tribes, or families.

NEWARK, N.J., March 27. -- The first known death in Newark from the new visit of the grip was reported to the health authorities to-day. The victim was Adolph Deserts, a jeweler, of Halsey Street. The disease was complicated with troubles of a bronchial nature.

There is a present prospect that the people of Brooklyn will have to pay no more for their illuminating gas than the maximum price allowed by law to be charged by New-York gas companies -- $1.25 per cubic foot. But that prospect is seriously threatened and put in jeopardy by a pending bill in the Assembly at Albany, behind which is concentrated the power and influence of all the gas companies of Brooklyn.
