As the day approaches for the annual Spring sessions of the Conferences of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this city and Brooklyn, the usual amount of speculation is rife in regard to the changes that will take place in Methodist pastorates. The matter is one of no small anxiety, not only to the clergymen themselves in a great many instances, but also to their congregations.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Feb. 23. -- The flagship Omaha, Rear Admiral George E. Belknap, United States Navy, sailed from Shanghai, China, Feb. 3, and arrived in Yokohama on the 15th. She came through the inland sea of Japan, experiencing heavy and cold weather, and when near Kobe picked up a Japanese junk, of whose crew two had been frozen to death and the others so badly frostbitten as to be unable to handle the junk.

The fact that the Fifty-first Congress appropriated over $1,000,000,000 for expenditures for the fiscal year of 1891-2 ought to set an intelligent people thinking. But the truth is that the intelligent people of America find it a bore to think. Yet, to ignore this enormity will be a disgrace to the 65,000,000 free citizens who inhabit this great Republic.

National Bank Examiner Hepburn completed his examination of the Washington National Bank yesterday and sent his statement to Controller Lacey. He said he had discovered nothing that would change his original statement regarding the impairment of the bank's capital -- $148,248. The answers to his circular letter to the banks about the items "due from banks and bankers," showed that the facts were as shown by the books of the Washington National Bank.

The municipal building question will probably be given a different shape early next week by the introduction of a bill at Albany authorizing the construction of the proposed building in City Hall Park, and further authorizing the tearing down and removal of all the existing buildings, including, if the Architectural Committee provided for it in the bill shall so elect, the Court House as well as the City Hall.

The commission appointed last year to look into the feasibility of consolidating New-York and neighboring cities into one great municipality and report the result of its investigations to the Legislature held a meeting yesterday morning in the offices of its President, Andrew H. Green, in the Park Bank Building, 216 Broadway.

Mr. George Parsons Lathrop and his talented wife, Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop, daughter of Nathaniel Hawthorne, have joined the Roman Catholic Church, having been baptized in New-York on March 19 by the Rev. Alfred Young, C.S.P., and confirmed two days later by Archbishop Corrigan. In a letter to Mr. James Jeffrey Roche of this city Mr. Lathrop reviews briefly the reasons for his change of faith, and these, doubtless, operated to influence his wife.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 27. -- An English syndicate of enormous wealth is trying to buy out the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railway Company, the largest and richest corporation of the kind in the South. Your correspondent learned this to-night upon reliable information. The English syndicate is the same one which has deposited .$2,000,000 in the Bank of England for the development of a new town in the Sequachee Valley, Tennessee.

The mind of Mr. BLAINE is never very transparent, but at present it seems a little more impenetrable than usual. We infer this from the fact that his organs in the press are almost absolutely silent in regard to the recent manifesto issued by Mr. HARSON regarding the nomination for the Presidency next year.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 27. -- One of those delightful exhibitions of consistency, for which the Hill wing of the Democratic Party is famous, was given in the Assembly Committee on Commerce and Navigation this morning. Mr. Jacobs's bill, which has passed the Senate, prohibiting the Union Ferry Company of Brooklyn from carrying out its contemplated course of raising the rates in commission hours was under consideration, and a motion was made to report it.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- Dr. William D. Gentry of this city claims to be the possessor of a microbe of the grip, the first ever captured of even heard of. The little wriggler is imprisoned on the glass slides of Dr. Gentry's big microscope, and was to-day carefully inspected by many a scientific eye.

The last Naval Appropriation bill, when it reached the Senate, was amended by a provision for selling one of the old single-turret monitors to the Pneumatic Gun Carriage Company, which proposed to substitute for the turret and its two smooth-bores a couple of eight-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages and then offer it for sale to the Government as thus improved.
A few days ago Mr. LYMAN, Treasurer of the Lowell Carpet Company and Vice President of the American Carpet Manufacturers' Association, published the following statement:

ORANGE, N.J., March 27. -- The long-looked-for declaration of intention regarding hotel and saloon licenses was made at last night's meeting of the South Orange Trustees. The Council room was crowded. William Rankin and James Fitzsimmons were champions of the saloon keepers, while Thomas Crooker advocated the defeat of license applications.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 27. -- The Legislature which recently packed up its traps and went home left a clear atmosphere behind it, and doubtless she two years that will intervene before another meeting of the General Assembly will emphasize the fact that the Democratic majority served the best interests of the State, and built a good foundation upon which to conduct the next campaign.

NEW-HAVEN, March 27. -- New-York's representatives on the diamond field opened the baseball season here to-day. As regards the result the contest was something of a disappointment to genial Manager Mutrie, but the boys did not show any strong desire to win. They simply regarded the contest in its true light -- a practice game -- and in consequence did not exert themselves.

The prodigious efforts required to enable the police to secure evidence against the young men who acted as clerks at Minden's poolroom, 1,313 Broadway, seems to have exhausted them, and they are now resting on their oars, satisfied, apparently, that they have done all that the law requires them to do.

A demand has been made from time to time, mostly in the West, for the election of United States Senators by a popular vote. Although this demand appears to be increasing, it is likely to be a long time before it acquires sufficient force to compel the necessary amendment of the Constitution, which in ordinary times is a difficult matter.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 27. -- More than a year's time has elapsed since Andrew Carnegie formally proposed to erect a two-million-dollar free library and art gallery for Pittsburg, and his check for $1,000,000 has been on deposit almost that length of time ready to start the work, but up to date not even a site for the buildings has been secured.

Germany put into operation Jan. 2 a species of stamp act that has become tremendously odious all over the empire. Charles Hubner, a German resident of this city, has just returned from a visit to his native place in Alsace, and he tells of the workings of the new act and the way the people regard it.

Anything in the nature of practical opposition on the part of the city officials to the attempt of Jay Gould's elevated railroad to "grab" Battery Park is yet to be discovered. The men whom Tammany put in power, the Mayor and the Park Commissioners, whose special province it is to guard against any such legislative enactment as this park "grab," are merely passive when questioned as to what they intend to do.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., March 28. -- A new Lehigh club has recently been organized in Pittsburg, Penn., with over thirty members. The only restriction to membership is that a man must have been a student at the Lehigh University for one term, and the address of any such men in Western Pennsylvania would be gladly received by the Treasurer, F.L. Grammer, '89, Box 254, Braddock, Penn.

Hudson County, after her Rip Van Winkle nap in this age of progress, has at last begun to rub her eyes and stretch her limbs. The result of her aroused activity is that all kinds of improvements are forging ahead with unexampled energy, and the county is enjoying such a boom as she never had before.

There was a lively encounter in the principal street of Sing Sing on Friday evening in which two brothers were engaged. The brothers were ex-State Senator Henry C. Nelson, now President of the First National Bank of Sing Sing, and Daniel D. Nelson, who has a position in the Department of Public Works in New-York. They are both strong men.

Mr. Henry Williams, Chief Inspector of Machinery in the Royal Navy, contributes to the April United Service Magazine an article on the "Coal Endurance of British War Ships." His suggestions group together the solutions of a number of problems that confront the navy of the United States almost as formidably as that of England.

The exposure in yesterday's TIMES of the underhand attempt of the Brooklyn gas companies to slip through the Legislature a bill restoring the price of gas to $1.50 per 1,000 feet brought surprise and indignation to thousands of gas consumers in the City of Churches. The officials of the gas companies whose nefarious scheme had been disclosed were very fearful lest the publication might kill their "job."

SCRANTON, Penn., March 28. -- When Lawrence Barrett played in Scranton a short time ago a friend said to him: "I am anxious to know whether the name you are so widely known by is a stage name or not. I resolved some time since that I would ask you at the very first opportunity, even at the risk of incurring your displeasure, and now I've done it."

The warm September days following Antietam lapsed into October, and the various corps of the Army of the Potomac still lingered about Sharpsburg. The advance camps stretched beyond the river into the London Valley, and Gen. McClellan's headquarters were established at Rectortown. Major Reynolds, my old battery commander, was Chief of Artillery on Gen. Wadsworth's staff, and I was for the time being detailed as the Major's clerk at division headquarters.

The fourth month of the year presents many attractions for those who follow with unwavering interest the ever-changing movements of the sun and his family of worlds, and, while not especially notable in an astronomical sense, it stilt has sufficient to engage the attention of the star gazer. The sun has now passed through a little more than half of its apparent journey between its southerly and northerly standing points.

When Capt. Martin heard the pickets announce themselves as belonging to the Twenty-first Virginia, he knew that the end had come to our flight. He was too lame and too much exhausted to think of getting away after he saw I was held at the muzzle of a rifle, so he came from behind the shield afforded by the uprooted tree and limped over to the fire.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 28. -- There have been few denunciations of the New-Orleans tragedy in this vicinity, either public or private. The cold-blooded murder of Paymaster McClure and Foreman Flanaghan on the Wilkesbarre Mountains by a gang of Italian brigands is still too fresh in the public mind hereabout to permit the squandering of much sympathy on those who met their fate for the killing of Chief Hennessy.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 28. -- Commissioner Midgley of the Lake Division of the Western Traffic Association has sent a telegram to Jay Gould demanding the discharge of the Missouri Pacific official who authorized their rate on sugar. The action is important, as it squarely puts to issue the question whether the Western Traffic Association and its fundamental principles are to be upheld.

The agitation of the mind of a portion of the Brooklyn public over the placing of the statue of the late Mr. BEECHER is not unnatural. Mr. BEECHER, during his long life in Brooklyn, was the object of much interest and admiration and even reverence, but also of unfailing disputes. It would be quite inconsistent with the effect of his rather stormy career that these should not be continued over the memorial of his life.
Allow me a small space in your columns for the insertion of the following, recalled lately to my memory by reading in your issue of Jan. 4 the particulars connected with the Lippard bottle.

Notwithstanding objections on the part of members of the Chamber of Deputies, who called attention to the fact that Greece claims all original statues and other works of art found on her soil, the $100,000 demanded for the purchase and excavation of Delphi were voted by 341 members against 61 in the negative. It looks very much as if the proverbial astuteness of the Greeks had not failed them in the case of Delphi.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 28. -- A sensation has been caused at the Treasury Department by the discovery of a counterfeit two-dollar silver certificate, so nearly perfect in all its parts as to be almost impossible of detection.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 28. -- No entry list ever published has created half the comment that the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association twenty-five-thousand-dollar Guaranteed Futurity has provoked. Thus far it is the greatest guaranteed stake in either running or trotting horse history, it is the greatest, not only in the amount of money offered, but also in the number of animals that will be named for its rich prizes.

The last local election resulted so satisfactorily to Tammany that its leaders have not bothered themselves very much about amendments to the ballot-reform law. Judge Peter Mitchell, Tammany leader of the Fifth District, has, however, been giving some attention to the matter and he has come to the conclusion that several amendments are needed.

BALTIMORE, March 28. -- For two days Baltimore has been struggling under the worst weather of the season. All the country around is under two feet of snow, and four baseball teams have been in the city expecting to play ball. The Bostons are especially delighted with this specimen of Spring in the South. It has been an incessant downfall of snow, with occasional showers of rain.

LONDON, March 28. -- What would be thought in America of a political party which insisted loudly upon recognition and support as representing a majority of the people, say in New-York State, and then, when the town elections came on, managed to elect only four Supervisors throughout the whole Commonwealth?

CARRIER PIGEONS FLYING TO AND FRO. -- Capt. Malogoli, the head of the Italian military carrier-pigeon depots, has, after immense and unwearying trouble, succeeded in getting his pigeons to fly backward and forward between Rome and Civita Vecchia (seventy-two kilometers.) This practical success has shattered the theories of various ornithologists, such as Russ, who have affirmed that pigeons cannot be made to fly in two directions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- Judge Penrose filed an opinion in the Orphans' Court this morning dismissing the petitions of descendants of Benjamin Franklin, who claimed the accumulated fund of about $100,000 held by the city in trust, and which will now most likely go to erect a normal school. Judge Penrose said in the course of his opinion:

AFRICAN TRACKING. -- Tracking is a science; some have a natural quickness and aptitude for it, others are of no use at all at it. The keen way, for instance, in which Farag Ala ca follow up a native track is wonderful; the slightest sign is noticed by him. The only other art that resembles tracking is "finding your way about in the bush."

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- The handsome new steel pleasure yacht Utomwa, which is being built for W.W. Durant of New-York City, was successfully launched to-day at Neafie Levy's shipyard in the presence of over five hundred spectators. The yacht was handsomely decorated with American flags and bunting.

Coroner Lavin of Westchester made an attempt yesterday to clear up the mystery surrounding the death of Jockey Tug Decker, but no definite conclusion was reached, though the testimony tended to strengthen the general opinion that the jockey met with foul play.

-- Juggernaut. A Veiled Record. By George Cary Egglesto and Dolores Marbourg. NewYork: Fords, Howard ' Hulbert. -- " What is Juggernaut " "Juggernaut ?" responds the banker. "That's the Hindu car that runs over people and crushes em, isn't it ?' "Yes. ' Well, now, let me call your attention to an interesting fac about that car.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28. -- James F. Brook, a member of the Board of Aldermen of Trenton and of the rubber firm of Brook, Oliphant Co., has been missing since Tuesday last, when he left for Boston with $500 for the firm's Boston house. He was last seen in New-York late that afternoon, when he said good-bye to his son William, who manages the Barclay Street agency in that city for the rubber firm.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Mr. Lacey, Controller of the Currency, to-day received the official report of National Bank Examiner Hepburn in regard to the Washington National Bank of New York, but refused to disclose its contents. He has, however, addressed a communication to Mr. Hepburn, suggesting that only two courses are open if a receivership is to be avoided.

The Excise Commissioners of this city, who have been so long under indictment for neglect of duty, are to be brought to trial to-morrow. It will be remembered that their chief offense consisted in a refusal to act upon complaints brought before them by the City Reform Club against certain saloon keepers who violated the law in keeping open saloons on election day in the vicinity of polling places.

The ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House in New-York City is as like that at the Paris Opera as anything we have. There is as much similarity as is possible between an ephemeral institution under private control and a permanent establishment maintained by the Government. At the New-York Opera a dancer is engaged for the season; at the Paris Opera she is engaged for life.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 28. -- The Glee Club, accompanied by the Mandolin and Banjo Clubs, left in a special car Thursday for a two-weeks' trip. It will go as far west as Ann Arbor, Mich.

For the closing of a Winter term marked by uncommon activity, steadfast adherence to high artistic aims, and well-deserved prosperity, Mr. Daly last evening put forward on the stage of his theatre a well-arranged version of Shakespeare's earliest comedy -- probably his first play -- "Love's Labor's Lost." The revival of this dainty, whimsical, fantastic work, never hitherto produced by any American manager except Mr. Daly, is intended to last a fortnight only.

Mandy stood on the doorstep, the breeze in her cap-strings, showing out her nearest neighbor, he Widow Ayers. But Mrs. Ayers was not a person easy to show out for after she had made a lengthy sitting call, she prolonged it by lingering on her feet. Her last word was a long word, and, like the postscript of a woman's letter, generally contained the kernel of the conversational out.

The effect of a recent decision of the Virginia Court of Appeals in the case of Hodges against the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad Company may involve important consequences unless the court reverses it in some subsequent decision. It may affect most of the great roads of that State. The point decided is that a railroad company cannot, without the consent of the owner or paying damages, construct a road within sixty feet of any house.

Some time ago a resolution was introduced in the Missouri House of Representatives providing for the display of the American flag on every schoolhouse and public building in the State. This resolution was referred from one committee to another, and it was not until the closing session of the House that a report was made on it. The report returned the resolution to the House and recommended the adoption in its place of the following:

ST. LOUIS, March 28. -- The druggists of St. Louis have just succeeded in perfecting an organization to regulate prices and trade in proprietary medicines, and to-day it developed that the local action is in concert with a general movement all over the country.

Since the hearing before the joint session of the Military Committees of the Senate and House in Albany last Thursday, it is generally accepted that the Balch-Oliver bill, for the making of the National Guard of the entire State into a division and the creation of a Major General, who should also be Adjutant General, for life by means of special legislation, has become a dead letter.

ALBANY, March 28. -- There is reported to be a movement on foot to make Andrew S. Draper, Superintendent of Public Instruction, the Republican candidate for Governor. It is well organized, but quiet, and persons who claim to know assert that it is making satisfactory progress.

ST. LOUIS, March 28. -- Prof. Halsey C. Ives, who has been selected to manage the Art Department of the World's Fair, has been connected with Washington University School of Fine Arts for seventeen years, since its inception.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 28. -- The final Winter meet of the Williams College Athletic Association was held this afternoon Silver medals in the contest were offered by H.B. Kendrick of Boston, and the silver cup offered by James Bullock, '81, to be won three times by middle-weight boxers, was competed for for the first time. Winners were as follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 28. -- Indoor baseball is the favorite athletic sport here, and the university team is carrying off its share of the honors. Frequent games are played, the grounds being in Washington Rink. The university team is made up as follows:

ALBANY, March 28. -- If William F. Sheehan believed at the opening of the year that he would improve his chances of securing the nomination for Lieutenant Governor next Fall by his actions as Speaker of the Assembly he made a mistake. He has conducted himself in the chair as if he were performing his last public service and desired to bring it to a speedy close.

Officers at the Brooklyn Navy Yard were greatly interested yesterday over a report from Washington, published in yesterday's Baltimore Sun, regarding the command of the North Atlantic station. It was reported two months ago that an arrangement had been reached with regard to this command by which Rear Admiral Gherardi was to be succeeded by Rear Admiral Walker, and was himself to succeed Rear Admiral Braine in command of the Brooklyn yard.
Anthony Comstock, he of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, was called a liar by Police Justice Hogan in the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon under the following circumstances:

There is no doubt within the corporate limits, not merely of Boston, but of what facetious journalist are in the habit of describing as its "sub-hubs" that that city remains the Athens of America, and that its opinion upon any questions of culture carries more weight, not only than that of any other American city, but than that of all other cities combined.

BOSTON, Mass., March 28. -- The Rev. George H. Young, pastor of the New South Church, corner of Camden and Tremont Streets, has resigned his position, the resignation to take effect some time in September. A rumor has been in circulation that the resignation has been brought about by the ill health of Mr. Young. This is denied by both pastor and congregation.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 28. -- Mrs. Potter Palmer has announced the Executive Committee of the World's Board of Lady Managers. Mrs. Palmer says she divided the country into four equal parts of equal population and selected six ladies from each part; that she divided them as equally as she could, and endeavored to select ladies who resided within twelve hours' ride of Chicago. The first meeting of the Executive Committee will be held April 6.

JAPANESE WOMEN. -- If a foreign sojourner must speak favorably of the men, how shall he avoid an apparent extravagance of praise in qualifying these sweet, these patient, these graceful, these high-bred, these soft-voiced, gentle, kind, quiet, unselfish women of Japan? They seem, taken altogether, so amazingly superior to their men-folk as almost to belong morally and socially to a higher race.

Although the ides of March are scarcely gone, the tall grass in Brooklyn is full of candidates for the Mayoralty. Some are in the woods, also, and some are in the open, and a few, at least, are concealed in the topmost tops of the highest trees, quietly taking their bearings.

" Pete" De Lacy did a thriving business in his cellar at 5 Barclay Street yesterday afternoon. He and his agents behind the glass cases were as busy betting on the races at Guttenberg and Gloucester as if they had had a book at both tracks, and were doing what they pretended to do, a commission business.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 28. -- Since the beginning of pleasant weather, the candidates for the baseball nine have had daily practice in the campus. Twenty-five men began to train in January, and the number actually competing for positions on the team has dedreased since then to twenty, as follows: Pitchers, Hamlin, '91, Dingwall, '94, Carter, '94; catchers' Graves, '92, Hubbard, '92, Weeks, '93.

THE WEALTH OF CATHAY. -- It is told of Confucius that on one occasion, having remarked to the driver of his carriage on the density of the population, the charioteer inquired: "Since the people are thus numerous, what must be clone for them?" "Enrich them," replied the master. In these two words Confucius expressed the leading desire of ninety-nine out of every hundred Chinamen.
" I am a wealthy manufacturer, your Honor," remarked King L. Karo of 162 Avenue B yesterday morning, as he gracefully leaned against the bar of the Essex Market Police Court.

A most encouraging sign for the baseball outlook for the doming season presented itself on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The reorganized New-York team played its opening game with the Jasper nine of Manhattan College and over 1,000 persons saw the contest. This is an unusually large crowd for an opening exhibition game, and the players and financial backers of the club were highly pleased.

In the first page of this work the author tells us that he lately applied to a leading London bookseller for a history of Ireland, and found that he "might almost as well have asked for a history, of Siberia." "He said that he could get a history for us," says Mr. Dowsett, "but that no one wanted them. 'In fact,' he added, 'people are sick of Ireland.'"

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 28. -- At a secret conference held in this city one week ago Secretary Charles Foster, Daniel J. Ryan, Senator Messir, Attorney General Wason, and one or two other leading politicians were closeted in the Secretary of State's office for several hours. All these gentlemen denied that their conference had reference to anything other than the reapportionment of the Senatorial districts of the State under the new census.
ORANGE, N.J., Match 28. -- Society in the Oranges has been at a standstill for weeks past, but Easter week will witness a reopening of the social whirl, and it promises to be a brilliant season.

The assault case in which Peter E. Tarpy is complainant and Patrick F. Breen and others are defendants drew to the Sixth District Police Court yesterday such of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Ward citizens as could spare a few hours to watch the development of the kind of political feud that is popular on the city's frontier.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 28. -- Last Tuesday evening the indoor meeting of the athletic association was held. Events were open to the Young Men's Christian Association and the sanitary gymnasiums of this city, as well as to the college men. A large number entered the lists and fought hard for the silver medals which were offered to the winner of each event. Twenty-five entered for the twenty-five yard dash, and eight heats were run.

Passion Week and Easter as Christians understand them originated in Jerusalem, and for centuries and centuries the events that, according to tradition and Scripture, occurred within those seven days in that city have been religiously commemorated and celebrated in the churches there in the presence of pilgrims from all countries of Christendom.

PARIS, March 7. -- The new programme of the Renaissance Theatre does not call for much comment. The authors of "Petite Poucette," Messrs. Ordonneau and Hennequin and Raoul Pugno, having the sure attraction of Mlle. Milly-Meyer, did not give themselves much trouble to develop a slim plot or to create new situations for the same.

CHARLOTTEVILLE, Va., March 28. -- The baseball club has been getting good outdoor practice this week. In two games played Wednesday and Thursday with the Boston Club of the American Association it showed up, both individually and collectively, in fine style. Two of last year's members matriculated in the course of the week, and at once went into training.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 28. -- A meeting of the Board of Trade was held to-night to protest against the various bills pending in the State Legislature changing or modifying the existing laws relative to assessing and taxing property, and particularly the so-called "Listing bill." Senator O'Connor and Assemblyman Deyo were present and made addresses defining their position.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 28. -- Republicans attempted to hold a convention here last evening for the purpose of nominating or indorsing a candidate for Mayor. They failed signally and nearly indulged in a free fight. The twelve delegates wasted an hour in excited debate full of disgraceful personalities. It was found impossible to effect even a temporary organization.

In the London Athenaeum of Feb. 28 was printed the following letter in regard to the Scotch origin of the American Livingston family, concerning which Mr. Theodore Roosevelt in his "History of New-York" writes unfavorably:

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore delivered his second lecture to teachers yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. He talked about Paris. His audience numbered about 800. The Hon. Adolph Sanger, the Hon. D.J. Seligman, the Hon. Charles E. Gorton of Yonkers, and President Lathrop of the Board of Trustees of Vassar were present.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 28. -- The Rev. Dr. J.L. Scott, a native of Delaware County, N.Y., and formerly pastor of the Presbyterian church at Bovina, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Columbia Avenue Presbyterian Church at Philadelphia, Penn., and will enter in the charge April 1.

The commission created last year to inquire into the question of uniting New-York and Brooklyn and their immediate surroundings into one municipality has been rather slow in announcing the result of its studies. It seems to have only got so far as to formulate a proposition for its own consideration, and it is doubtful if it will be ready to make a definite report to the Legislature at the present session.

THE LONDON BOY. -- What are these creatures shambling up the crescent? These are two message boys. And who is that troglodyte roosting on the railing? That is Drake's boy waiting on Peel's boy and Smellie's boy. Why does he wait? Because he never travels alone; secondly, because he has infinite time.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 28. -- The fortieth annual session of the Wyoming Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will assemble at the Wesley Methodist Church at Waverly, N.Y., on Wednesday next, April 1. Bishop Thomas Bowman of St, Louis will preside. The Conference is one of the strongest and most prosperous in the central States.

There were reported to the Health Department during the week ending at noon yesterday 895 deaths, 653 births, and 223 marriages. The deaths numbered 55 more than those of the preceding week, and 42 more than the average for the corresponding week during the past five years.
HANOVER, N.H., March 28. -- A modified form of la grippe is quite prevalent among the students, several of the men being obliged to temporarily suspend their college work.

ASHLAND, Penn., March 28. -- A wreck occurred last night between 9 and 10 o'clock a short distance from Barry's Station on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, in which three men were instantly killed and four seriously injured. The names of those killed are Engineer Andrew Walker, Tamaqua; Fireman John Oakes, Frackville, and Fred Meyer, Tamaqua, a passenger train brakeman, who was on the train.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 28. -- The Rev. F.E. Delzell of the Presbyterian church at La Plata, Mo., has accepted the pastorate of the Congregational church at Mansfield Centre, and will soon remove to this State. The Mansfield Centre church is one of the most influential in Eastern Connecticut.

I have been under the impression that the treatment of the insane at Gheel, Belgium, (described at length in your to-day's issue,) was all that could be desired, meeting the approval of the critic, as well as that of the philanthropist, and that the results obtained for many centuries were, and are, eminently satisfactory to the alienists and to a civilized nation like Belgium.

A gentleman who signs his communication "A Looker-On in Vienna" writes to THE TIMES to complain in forcible but courteous language of the remarks made in this column last Sunday about the stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera House. The gentleman says that the article was one-sided, because it failed to show proper appreciation of the obligations under which this public has been put by the stockholders of the house.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, March 28. -- The contest for the Bradley mathematical prize among the Seniors of Rutgers College resulted in a tie for the first time since the prize was offered. The prize was divided between E.C. Bryan and Marcus C. Sears.

Senator STEWART'S bill to make the Randall's Island House of Refuge a penal institution ought to fail unless better reasons for its passage can be found than any yet set forth. This bill provides that "hereafter no child under the age of twelve shall be sentenced or committed to the State Industrial School at Rochester or to the House of Refuge on Randall's Island on conviction for any crime or offense less than a felony."

Contrary to the impression produced by the extracts published in this country, the "Memoirs" of Talleyrand are both interesting and valuable. They are so despite the very clumsy and inadequate translation, which deprives them of nearly all the charm of the original and gives to scores of pages an unredeemed dullness of which the illustrious author was absolutely incapable -- varied as was his capacity.

The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby died at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, vanquished by the croupous pneumonia that he fought against so bravely for ten days. The end came quickly and comparatively painlessly. He was conscious to the last. Only his son Nicholas, Dr. Conrad, and the nurse were with him at the time.

ALBANY, March 29. -- To the avalanche of bills the House is now buried under the New-York City members have contributed with a lavish hand. Quantity rather than quality appears to have been their chief aim. Some days they have taxed the capacity of the bill box. Many of the most vicious measures of the session bear the names of New-York City men.

The Canadian Pacific Railroad Company has at last accomplished what it has been striving for years to accomplish. It has secured an entrance into New-York City, and is now a full-fledged New-York trunk line. The result was brought about on Saturday, after a conference between President Van Horne of the Canadian Pacific and President Chauncey M. Depew of the New-York Central.

Ex-Senator John B. Henderson of St. Louis, who was the permanent Chairman of the Republican National Convention of 1884 and has lately been prominent as one of Blaine's Pan-Americans, recently said: "As a Republican, I think the extravagance of the Congress just adjourned was an outrage upon the party and the people. However the appropriations may be justified, the fact that they reach $1,000,000,000 is of itself appalling.

A bill introduced in the Legislature will, if it becomes a law, place sixty-two members of the police force and the Superintendent of Telegraph, James Crowley, on the footing of war veterans; that is to say, they will not be subject to the provisions of the "sexagenarian clause" and thrust out of the service simply because they are sixty years old, although they may be hale and as useful as younger men.

We give in another column some remarks of ex-Senator HENDERSON of Missouri touching the extravagance of the Republican majority in the Fifty-first Congress. These remarks are of special interest because Mr. HENDERSON is not only an active Republican in good standing in his party, but because he was a very prominent member of the Pan-American Congress last year, and was regarded in that body as having intimate relations with the Secretary of State, Mr. BLAINE.

LANSING, Mich., March 29. -- The Patrons of Industry, who number 70,000 members in Michigan and 80,000 in the United States and Canada, have for their cardinal object the purchase of various commodities direct from the manufacturer and wholesaler. This particular function of the Patron organization finds operation through what is known as the Patrons' Commercial Union, which acts as middleman and retailer for the Patrons.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Plans are being completed in the Bureau of Yards and Docks for two fifty-ton traveling cranes of novel construction, one to be set up in the New-York Navy Yard and the other in the Norfolk Navy Yard, for use in handling heavy armor plates and putting them in place on the sides of ships.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 29. -- All Camden County was agitated to-day over another cold-blooded and brutal murder within its borders. The victim, Giovanna Dionore, a beautiful young Italian girl of seventeen, had been stabbed to the heart with a stiletto by Dominico Filippo Coco, a vengeful brother-in-law, who came near being lynched by Camden residents when he was taken into custody.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 29. -- Dr. Gentry of Chicago, who has announced his discovery of the grip microbe, is so late as to be out of the race. Dr. O.M. Meyers of this city made the following statement on Dec. 29. 1889, and it was published in the Democrat and Chronicle of the next day:

The Bathgate family, which has for many years figured prominently in the history of that portion of the city now known as Central Morrisania, has been well-nigh exterminated within the last three weeks by the prevalent epidemic of pneumonia. The first death to occur was that of Miss Margaret Anne Bathgate, on March 8.

SLIGO, March 29. -- To-day has been the liveliest day so far in the North Sligo election campaign. By 8 o'clock this morning the streets were alive with people listening to the music of several bands. The Parnell contingents, with their leader, were out by 10 o'clock, engaged in personal canvassing. In their zeal they even attempted to devote attention to Coney Island, in Sligo Bay, although there are only 25 voters on the island.

Walking along the sunny side of Lexington Avenue, past the Seventh Regiment Armory, the other day, a TIMES reporter encountered ex-Police Captain Nathaniel R. Mills, who way back in the sixties was a prominent figure in the Police Department. Now he is an inmate of the Chapin Home, in East Sixty-sixth Street, near Third Avenue.

The recent investigation concerning the prevalence of tuberculosis in the dairy herds near Boston caused the introduction in the Massachusetts Legislature of a resolution providing for an inquiry to be made by the State Board of Health, but the resolution has been rejected in the Senate. Commenting upon this, the Boston Herald says: "Two points are notorious, both of which bear on the necessity for action of this kind.

It was just two weeks ago yesterday that THE TIMES began its crusade against the poolrooms in this city. It is only fair to say at this time that considerable has been accomplished in spite of the fact that the fight has been carried on under conditions that seemed to render it almost hopeless. Those conditions can be briefly stated.

The present method of distributing rations to the Indians is clearly susceptible of improvement. It is too apt to foster careless and improvident habits, and in this respect may be compared to the fashion of paying the soldier or sailor at very long intervals, and under such circumstances that he is pretty sure to be wasteful.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29. -- The builders and boss carpenters of both this city and Camden will in all probability shortly become involved in a struggle with the members of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, whose headquarters are here. Concessions are to be demanded from the builders all over the country, and the struggle promises to become general.

Yesterday was a typical Easter, with a balmy Springtide air to tell of nature's resurrection and gracious sun to send its rays dancing through the stained glass of the churches and lend an added glory to the flower-decked altars. All the churches had special musical services, many augmenting their choirs with choruses and extra soloists, and some calling in a full orchestra to aid the grand organ.

At 1 P.M. yesterday all the commanders of Precincts, except, perhaps, those of the steamboat squad, the Twenty-fourth Precinct, the City Hall squad, the Broadway squad, and the Grand Central Station squad, were startled out of their Sunday propriety by the following general alarm from Police Headquarters:

NORFOLK, Va., March 29. -- A telegram from Hatteras Life Saving Station says a Spanish steamer bound from Galveston, Texas, is ashore five miles south of that station. The vessel is lying easy close to the beach, the Captain and crew are on board, and there is no present necessity for their leaving the ship. The engineer says the ship is light and is in no immediate danger.

The launch of the Monterey, which may now soon be expected -- the vessel being ready to take to the water, and the place she occupies being needed for another war ship at the Union Iron Works -- will prove of interest in several ways. She will be the first of our modern steel coast-defense vessels, since the Miantonomoh and her sister ships, though well armed, are of an old type.

Just as Car No. 400 of the Green and Gates Avenue line was going down Fulton Street toward High Street, Brooklyn, at 4:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon, two girls of about fourteen years of age attempted to run across the tracks in front of it. One got across all right, but her companion was knocked down by the off horse and thrown flat across the tract.

A bill has been introduced in the Assembly at Albany which would, if passed, go far toward solving the problem of taxation in this State. It adopts what might be called the "local-option idea" in taxation, which has been repeatedly suggested in these columns as affording a means of obviating the difficulties which spring from the difference of conditions that prevail in rural districts and commercial communities.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 29. -- Saturday night 7:30 o'clock a hole was blown in the port boiler of the steamer Farmer, which was on her way to this port from Brunswick. She was between Darien and Doboy when the accident occurred. The noise of the escaping steam caused panic among the negro deck hands, several of whom jumped overboard and four of them were drowned.

Jacob Schaedler, a German silk weaver, fifty-five years old, living with his wife and little girl on the top floor of a tenement at 710 East One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Street, committed suicide by shooting himself in the breast at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He had been out of work for three months and was despondent. His life was insured for $2,000.

As a study of life in a small town of Valencia the new novel by Valera does not yield in interest to "Pepita Ximenez," though a certain general likeness exists between the two. In both a priest is one of the chief characters; in both there is a question of the violation of priestly vows, and in both it is a charming woman who tempts the priest.

-- Mademoiselle Ixe. By Lanoe Falconer. New-York: Casell Publishing Company. -Mlle. Ixe comes to an English household as governess. The Merringtons are well-to-do people with unruly children, and all former instructresses, because they were too fat or too thin or were not tidy or to the taste of the children or of their mother, have been discharge.

LOUISVILLE, March 29. -- The programme of the Louisville Jockey Club has just been issued, and, if there is anything in promises, the coming meeting at Churchill Downs will be one of the most notable in the history of Kentucky turfdom. The meeting begins on May 13, and will continue nine days. There will be five races each day, one of which will be a stake, the other four being for five-hundred-dollar purses.

The first few warm days of Spring bring special delight to the amateur photographers. There is not much fun in manipulating the tripod or working a hand camera on a cold, windy day, and the pictures are often not satisfactory, too, owing to a lack of steadiness of the instrument, or cold hands on the part of the operator. Now the young camera men are beginning to get out and to do some systematic work.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 29. -- The fight over the appointment of a Collector of this port has begun again. James H. Young, who was nominated last September and failed to be confirmed, and who was nominated again last December and failed again, was told by the President soon after Congress adjourned in the presence of Congressman Cheatham that he would not appoint him a third time.

ST. LOUIS, March 29. -- Mrs. A.W. Gifford, wife of the President of the Tamaulipas Land, Mining, and Manufacturing Company, is reported to have gone insane on Christian science. The family lived in a brownstone front in Olive Street, and consisted of Mr. Gifford, his wife, and a young niece. The lady was an invalid, and her husband says he spent $25,000 in a vain effort to cure her.

TRENTON, March 29. -- Gov. Abbett's attempt to direct the management of local affairs from the State Capitol through the agency of his elaborate system of State Commissions has served to revive the recollection of his memorable fight against legislative commissions in the early seventies. The Republicans had secured control of the two houses and had redistricted the State so as to make a Democratic majority in the Legislature a political impossibility.

BALTIMORE, March 29. -- The dispatches from the South to the Hill papers stating that Senator German and his party have discovered an unexpectedly strong sentiment of a Presidential nature for David B. Hill in the Southern States find no corroboration in the advices that reach this city. A great many Southerners come to Baltimore, and the wholesale trade of this place permeates most of the Southern territory.

It is not an unusual sight in these days to see representatives of the City Government standing before the bar in the county criminal courts pleading to indictments, and such events do not awaken more than ordinary interest among the court attendants. But it is not often that the heads of departments have to meet a charge of misconduct.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., March 29. -- The Galena was floated off Gay Head at 10 A.M. to-day by the steam tugs William S. Slater, Confidence, and Elsie, and arrived here in tow at 2 P.M. She now lies alongside the wharf at the head of the harbor.

PITTSBURG, March 30. -- Strikers to the number of nearly a thousand attacked Frick's Coke Works at Morewood at 2 o'clock this morning. They destroyed some coke ovens and railway track, and broke windows in several houses. Several of the raiders were arrested and taken to Greensburg jail. Riots are also reported at Leisenring and Leith, and considerable property was destroyed.
CALCUTTA, March 30. -- The news of a massacre at Manipur, Province of Assam, was brought to Kohima, on the Assam frontier, yesterday, by two Goorkhas, who had escaped.

One year ago to-morrow the contract by which Cranford Valentine agreed to clean the streets of Brooklyn and to remove the garbage and ashes went into effect. For this work this firm was to receive $119,000 a year more than the sum for which another responsible concern had agreed to do it.

As the 2:57 train for City Hall from One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street on the Third Avenue elevated railroad was leaving the Ninety ninth Street station yesterday, the rear truck of the rear car ran off o the new switch being constructed at Ninety-eighth Street for express-train service, and for some distance the car was pulled along with the front truck on the main track and the rear one on the switch.

Five Mayors went to William M. Ivins's office yesterday and made excuses to the Senate Committee on Cities for not having answered the interrogatories sent out by the committee last year. They did so in response to subpoenas served on them Friday, after all other methods to get them to send their answers had failed.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Up to the closing of the Health Office to-day Mr. Tomlinson had issued 200 burial certificates, 91 of which were given for people who had died from diseases of the respiratory organs. Some of these were undoubtedly carried over from Sunday, as the Health Office is not kept open long on that day. Only 57 certificates were issued on Sunday.

The final passage of the Ballot-Reform bill by the Maine Legislature is a remarkable triumph of an aroused public sentiment over the power of politicians who were supposed to control the majority in the Legislature and who were desperately determined upon the defeat of the measure. It was not opposed by reason or argument, but by sheer partisan resistance.

ALBANY, March 30. -- The Legislature paid proper respect to the memory of Grattan H. Brundage, the member of Assembly from the First Steuben District, who died yesterday at his boarding house on Eagle Street, by adjourning this evening. As soon as the Assembly had convened and prayer was offered, Mr. Acker presented these resolutions:

It is not really disrespectful to the dead to say that the death of Dr. HOWARD CROSBY is a more serious public loss than it ought to be. Dr. CROSBY was not a man of brilliant genius or exceptional attainments. He was merely an accomplished man of good faculties, who was keenly interested in public affairs.

ALBANY, March 30. -- Jay Gould's battery grab bill is still with Mr. Blumenthal's Cities Committee, and is expected to be aired for a third hearing Thursday afternoon. Mr. Blumenthal said to-night that the only person he expected to be present to advocate its passage was the gentleman who drafted it, Charles H. Butler of New-York, who is supposed to have been retained in Mr. Gould's interests.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Washington news dispatches of a New-York paper representing that Secretary Foster had decided to displace Collector Erhardt and Appraiser Cooper, and afterward to investigate their management of the branches of the customs service committed to their care, have been promptly denied, as might have been expected.

Our Italian fellow-citizens may learn the difference between the persecution of a nationality and the prosecution of malefactors by comparing the account of the slaughter of offending Italians in New-Orleans and the mobbing of unoffending Chinamen at Pittsburg. In the former case the people of New-Orleans had concluded, when the law failed to vindicate the community from the assaults of an organization of outlaws, to take the law into their own hands.

The dead-lock in the Connecticut Legislature has continued for almost three months, and the prospect of breaking it does not appear to be very hopeful. In the meantime the necessary work of legislation and all provision for the support of the State Government has been prevented. The New-Englander and Yale Review, published at New-Haven, contains three articles by prominent lawyers of that city on the peculiar situation existing at Hartford.

When New-York City lost the services of Mr. Abram S. Hewitt, as Mayor for a second term, we were indebted to the Metropolitan Police for that consummation. With the business acumen that marked his appreciation of affairs Mayor Hewitt discovered and remarked publicly that quite as good men could be obtained for $800 a year to serve on the police force as those who were receiving $1,000 and $1,200.

Clad in Spring clothing and adorned with Easter cravats, the three Excise Commissioners, Alexander Meakim, Joseph Koch, and Edward T. Fitzpatrick, accompanied by twice as many lawyers, filed into Part III. of Court of General Sessions yesterday to undergo trial for malfeasance in office. Recorder Smyth has been sick for nearly a week, but he had recovered his health, yesterday so that he could come down to court.

The proceedings at the recent convention of the Republican League of Massachusetts in Boston had a very exhilarating effect upon the Boston Traveller. Our contemporary appears to have become acquainted then for the first time with THURSTON. The Traveller said: "Ohio and Nebraska made the Yankee Republican heart glad yesterday by their statesmanlike array of facts, their loyal spirit, their deadly-in-earnest purpose, and their genuine eloquence.

The actual trial of Alphonse J. Stephani for the murder of ex-Judge Clinton G. Reynolds was begun in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday before Presiding Justice of the Supreme Court Charles H. Van Brunt. Stephani sat at the end of the counsel table by the side of a Deputy Sheriff, who kept an exceedingly sharp watch on him.

The discussion of the west side driveway project before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday was informal and had no result. The report presented by Joseph J. O'Donohue and four other members of the Mayor's Driveway Commission of Fifteen was not read because Controller Myers was not present at the beginning of the meeting.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Fresh complications have risen to prevent an immediate settlement of the trouble caused by the cutting of passenger rates between St. Louis and Chicago by scalpers handling the tickets of the Jacksonville Southeastern Road. A meeting was held at Chairman Finley's office to-day by representatives of all the lines in interest to hear the report of the Chairman on the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The marriage of Miss Grace Weston Fuller, eldest daughter of the Chief Justice, to Mr. Archibald Lapham Brown of Chicago, took place at 8 o'clock to-night at St. John's Church. The Rev. Dr. Douglas performed the ceremony. On the altar the large gold vases were heaped with Easter lilies and long-stemmed roses, while about the walls on either side of the chancel were palms and growing plants.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- McVicker's Theatre, which was burned Aug. 26, 1890, was reopened to-night and a brilliant audience, which packed the house, assembled to honor the occasion. Florence and Jefferson in "The Rivals" shared the applause with the management of the theatre.

The stock market reflected the sunny weather yesterday. Something that looked like the germ of a boom was in sight. Some stocks went up two or three points, a number advanced as much as one point, and the general list at the close showed that, practically, every stock advanced somewhat. There hasn't been a day like this in months.

The Grand Jury, which is investigating the tunnel disaster, came into court yesterday and asked for instructions concerning the act of June 18, 1887, regulating the heating of passenger cars by steam. The law provides that any person or corporation violating any of the provisions of the act shall be liable to a penalty of $1,000 and to the further penalty of $100 for each and every day during which such a violation shall continue.

Jerry Simpson, "the Sockless," the Farmers' Alliance Congressman from Kansas, placed the Hon. J.B. Weaver of Iowa in nomination as the Presidential candidate of the Alliance in 1892 in conversation with a TIMES reporter yesterday. Mr. Simpson said, as he named the Iowa man, that he did not think the Alliance officials had organized any well-defined boom for Mr. Weaver, but it seemed to him (Simpson) that Weaver was the most available and probable candidate.

The return of that annoying and vexatious malady known as the grip, its prevalence among all classes of society, and the difficulty experienced in curing it by medicinal remedies makes highly pertinent for public information the following letter from Chauncey M. Depew in relation to Reich's Tokayer Ausbruch, which had previously restored Cyrus W. Field, Mrs. William Astor, and others:

The controversy about the dangers of steam heating as applied to railroad cars seems to be giving rise to apprehensions on the part of timid travelers on the theory that where there is so much steam there must be some fire. This circumstance renders it desirable that the matter should be disposed of from the practical standpoint.

PITTSBURG, March 30. -- "'Al' Johnson is not out of the woods yet nor will he pocket $30,000 when the National League settles with him, as most people think," said J. Palmer O'Neill to-day. "In the first place he must settle with the New-York, Brooklyn, and Chicago National League Clubs, each one of which demands $4,000 for its interest and $1,200 advance money, or in all $13,200.

There is one place in town where the offense of kleptomania is almost excusable. That place is the silk department in the dry goods establishment of James McCreery Co. at Broadway and Eleventh Street, where the largest retail stock of silks in the world is displayed in bewildering variety to the feminine eye. The stock on view this Spring is especially attractive.

A melancholy illustration of how the business of politics undermines the moral sentiments is afforded by Secretary FOSTER'S comment on an article concerning himself published in the Herald of yesterday. This article asserted with positiveness that the Secretary of the Treasury was about to perform a very base and mean act.

A great deal of very valuable information that is available to the District Attorney in the prosecution of poolroom keepers was yesterday given to THE TIMES by Anthony Comstock, the agent of the Society for the Suppression of Vice. Mr. Comstock's years of fighting against gamblers has familiarized him thoroughly with the laws that are pertinent.

In THE TIMES of to-day I read an account of the tests applied to Mr. J.H. Brown's wire-wound gun at the testing grounds at Fort Wadsworth. The article gives such as clear and intelligible description of the gun that I readily recognize it as a much older invention than of the present time.

AUGUSTA, Me., March 30. -- The Ballot-Reform bill has finally passed the Maine Legislature and is now a law. It was a hard-fought battle and every inch of ground was closely contested by the bulldozing and unscrupulous opponents of the Australian system. A strong lobby had been at work against the bill from the day the session began -- probably the most influential that has ever been seen in Augusta.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Bids were opened in the Ordnance Office of the War Department to-day for the construction of twenty-five carriages for twelve-inch breech-loading rifled mortars. Only two bids were received.

DALLAS, Texas, March 30. -- People here are very much displeased with the recent utterances of the Rev. Joseph Cook of Boston, to the effect that the spirit of intolerance was such that he had canceled his dates in this State, and also with the report that the same cause led Explorer Stanley to do the same thing. These reports have done Texas great injustice.

The history of the Washington Bank is made the subject of some very interesting and instructive comments by the Financial Chronicle in its latest number. That journal is well known for the conservative nature of its views and for the candor and circumspection with which it treats questions of this sort.

Commander Bicknell, Ensign Field, and nearly all the men composing the Galena's complement when she went ashore at Gay Head have returned to the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The court of inquiry that was hinted at when the accident was reported to the department has not yet been ordered, but the officers who were in charge of the ill-fated ship have determined to ask the department to name such a board at once.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Supreme Court to-day affirmed the judgment of the lower courts in favor of C.B. Converse in his suit for damages against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, Converse while attempting to cross the railroad tracks near Jersey City at night was injured by a section of a freight train, running on its own momentum, without a conductor or lights, having been detached from the first section of the train.

HARTFORD, March 30. -- The work of the Senate dead-lock committee was resumed this afternoon, and a report is expected when the Senate reassembles to-morrow. Senator Seymour of Norwalk, who could not attend Saturday's conference, was able to be present this afternoon. Nothing, however, that Senator Pierce of Bristol has authorized will be changed by Mr. Seymour, who assigned his colleague from the Fourth District to act for him in his absence.

The introduction of a bill by a Tammany Senator for the appropriation of $500,000 from the money received from the National Government in refunding the direct tax of thirty years ago has a suspicious appearance of claptrap. This money has been turned into the general fund of the State, where it belongs, and appropriations cannot be made from it as a separate fund.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Secretary Foster probably protested too much yesterday when he declared that he knew nothing about the report that he was to dismiss Collector Erhardt and also Appraiser Cooper, and that those gentlemen were to be rewarded for their alleged incompetency by appointment in the diplomatic service of their country.
Poles and wires in many of the down-town streets will have to come down to-day. Mayor Grant sent the following orders to Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy yesterday afternoon:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 31. -- With fair weather to-morrow, the vote for general officers and the Legislature promises to be among the largest over cast here, and the result will be interesting in many ways. As important as it may be considered in emphasizing the result of the November elections, the outcome will depend to an extent which can hardly be realized outside this little State upon local issues, factional contests, and personal antagonism.
At the recent annual banquet of the Boston Paper Trade Association there was read a letter from ex-Senator WARNER MILLER, in which he said:

ROME, March 31. -- The Most Rev. Dr. Walsh, Archbishop of Dublin, in an interview to-day expressed great satisfaction that in a long audience with the Pope he found his Holiness perfectly acquainted with the position in Ireland.

One of the best numbers for a year past is the April number of the Century. A description of fetichism in the Congo country by E.J. Glave, who has served under Stanley, makes an interesting contribution to this inexhaustible African topic. The account of the Panama route to California, as taken in 1849, is a picturesque piece of narrative, properly illustrated from contemporary sketches.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The quoted utterances of Senator Pugh of Alabama concerning Mr. Cleveland's chances of support in the South should he be the Democratic candidate for President next year are quite in line with what the Senator had to say when Mr. Cleveland's anti-free-coinage letter made its appearance, and are not likely to be of any more consequence.

The Bar Association last night, at an adjourned special meeting that could hardly be called representative of that body, passed the resolutions prepared by its committee on the amendment of the law, as epitomizing the objections to the proposed amendments to the judiciary articles of the State Constitution. These resolutions were as follows:
LONDON, April 1. -- The Daily News is the only paper of this city which contains any comments this morning on the recall of Baron Fava, the Italian Minister at Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- There are no lights "burning in the War Office to-night," but there has been a great deal of absurd talk about war with Italy, or Italian war on the United States, since it became known, at the close of business hours at the State Department, that Baron Fava, the Minister of Italy to this Government, had presented to Secretary Blaine his letter of recall.

The satisfaction that will be felt at the indictment of the Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company will not be due to a desire to see these gentlemen personally punished for misdemeanor but to the assurance it affords that those who control the management of a corporation can be held individually responsible for its violation of a law intended to protect the lives and safety of the public.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The dynamite cartridges which THE TIMES has so judiciously placed under the plans of Jay Gould have exploded, and the bill died in the Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon very suddenly and unexpectedly.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 31. -- This morning the attorneys for the defense in the recent Hennessy murder case appeared before Judge Baker and moved that their surviving clients, who are charged with the murder of D.C. Hennessy and have not yet been placed on trial, be admittee to bail.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31. -- Adolph Spreckels was seen this morning regarding the statement that Spreckels's sugar refineries and those of the Havemeyers had combined to divide the sugar market. He admitted that an understanding with the Havemeyers had been reached, but it did not relate to division of territory, and prices would continue to be regulated by supply and demand.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 31. -- An incident occurred this morning that has caused a big sensation, and is generally condemned as an attempt to compromise the Newport Observer, the only Republican paper published here. After leaving the office copies of the following document were folded into the Observer and delivered to subscribers as if emanating from that office:

Police Commissioner James J. Martin, leader of the Tammany forces in the Twentieth District, member of Mayor Grant's political Cabinet, and one of the magnates of the Wigwam, recently ordered Charles Steckler, leader of the Tammany forces in the Tenth District, Secretary of the Tammany Committee of Twenty-four, and one of the chiefs of the Stecklers of Stecklerville, to get out of his office in Police Headquarters.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 31. -- Sir Charles Tupper, after an interview with the Hon. George E. Foster, Minister of Finance, left this afternoon for Washington, and, it is understood, will be followed in a few days by Mr. Foster. Sir Charles's mission is to discuss with Sir Julian Pauncefote the whole situation between Canada and the United States, including the Bering Sea question, the fisheries disputes, and the general question of trade relations.

Mrs. F.R. Rives and Mrs. Frothingham, whose trunks were seized by customs inspectors at the Cunard pier, visited the Custom House yesterday, and their personal affects were released from custody. Mrs. Rives's trunk was forwarded to her home. There was very little in it which was subject to duty, except some linen, and the tariff charges on this were paid.
LONDON, March 31. -- Earl Granville died this afternoon. He has been ill for several weeks.

Albon Platt Man, one of the best-known members of the bar of this city, died at his residence, 106 East Thirtieth Street, Monday afternoon, in the eighty-first year of his age. His death was due to exhaustion following an attack of the grip complicated with pleurisy. Mr. Man was born in Constable, Franklin County, N.Y., Jan. 18, 1811.

Mayor Grant and Controller Myers have another contention on hand. It is all about the collection of the $2,292,159.73, principal and interest, which the city claims is due it as a reimbursement for the Union defense fund advanced in 1861. The Controller has made a contract with ex-Congressman John J. Adams whereby the latter will receive 7 1/2 per cent. for collecting the principal.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 31. -- New complications arose here to-day in the Mayoralty fight between Mayor John Newman and ex-Councilman William C. Parr. Notice was served upon City Clerk William C. Hamilton protesting against the future issue of official ballots with the Mayor's name at the head of the Republican tickets. Application for a mandamus was threatened. Daniel J. Murray, attorney for Mr. Farr, served the notice.

Interest in the trial of Alphonse J. Stephani for the murder of ex-Judge Clinton G. Reynolds continued unabated yesterday. The large Oyer and Terminer Court room was filled with as many persons as it could comfortably seat, and as Judge Van Brunt's orders were imperative that no more than could be seated should be admitted, many were turned away.

A dozen official heads were chopped off at the Custom House yesterday. They belonged to watchmen who had made the sad mistake of slumbering or of being away from their posts of duty when two Treasury inspectors made an early morning tour of the wharves.

The first biennial dinner of the New-York Alumni Association of Phillips Academy was held at the Hotel Brunswick last night, and the vigorous cry of Rah, rah, rah! Andover, Andover, Andover! Rah! rah! rah! was the keynote of the festivities. In this city there are about 1,000 graduates of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., and nearly 200 of them were at the dinner.

There was not conference between the poolsellers and their official protectors yesterday. This was a subject of deep regret in the dives when word was passed around that a general swoop might be expected without further warning. The gamblers understood this to mean that they must get their houses in order by disposing of all possible evidence that might tell against them in a court.

TRENTON, March 31. -- Attorney General Stockton (or, rather, Mr. Johnson, his assistant) has just discovered an error in an engrossed bill that may practically wipe out the new ballot-reform law. The just-adjourned Legislature was solicited to exempt towns of 4,000 population and smaller from the operation of the law, and for some inexplicable reason the Legislature passed a bill to that effect and sent it to the Governor and he signed it.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 31. -- The Senate Dead-lock Committee was granted an extension of time this afternoon on the ground that all expedients looking toward a settlement of the controversy had not been exhausted. Judge Morris was telegraphed to meet the Democrats here this evening, but up to a late hour had not put in an appearance. This has led to the idea that a conference is in progress either at Meriden or New-Haven.

After a thorough investigation of the tunnel disaster of Feb. 20, the Grand Jury yesterday failed to find any of the officers of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company chargeable with manslaughter, but they did find twelve Directors and officers liable for misdemeanor in allowing the deadly car stove to be used in the cars on the road.

Perrin H. Sumner, the Protean schemer and identifier, was thrust into a cell at Police Headquarters last night on a charge of subornation of perjury, made by one Cuthbert R. Saffery of 46 West One Hundredth Street. The arrest was made at Sumner's "real estate" office, 198 Broadway, by Detective Sergeants Reilly and Van Gerichten on a warrant issued by Justice O'Reilly on an affidavit made by Saffery.

CALCUTTA, March 31. -- Official dispatches received here by the Government officers confirm the report of the massacre of Ghoorkas at Manipur, in the Province of Assam, where about four hundred and seventy of these native soldiers were slain by hostile tribesmen of Assam after two days' desperate fighting.

ST. LOUIS, March 31. -- It has just leaked out, in spite of army discipline and military regulations, that Jefferson Barracks, just south of the city, was the scene of a sensation Sunday night which is still agitating United States Army circles. Five soldiers confined in the guardhouse overpowered the guard and escaped.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 31. -- Ex-Secretary of State Thomas F. Bayard was at his handsome residence, Delamere Place, in this city, this evening when THE TIMES'S correspondent imparted to him, the surprising information contained in the dispatches from Washington announcing the recall of Baron Fava by the Italian Government.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- C.A. Spreckels, a son of Claus Spreckles, said to-day that the reported agreement between his father and the Sugar Trust was without foundation. He added that his father would not make a deal with the trust; that the report had been repeatedly circulated and denied, and that there was no more reason for talking about the matter now than there was some time ago.

It was so cold yesterday that only a small crowd turned out to see the New-Yorks and the New-Havens play. The members of the home team did not exert themselves, favoring their arms as much as they could. The New-Havens are badly crippled, and had to play several men who will not be members of the team when the International League championship season opens.

The family council of the BONAPARTES which will take place soon, will relate exclusively to private matters arising under the will of Prince NAPOLEON, who left to his oldest son only what the law requires and gave all that he could to his second son, LOUIS. There is believed to be nothing in the will relating to the political claims of either son.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 31. -- If anything can put life into the hitherto moribund Republican Party of North Carolina, the acts of the Legislature recently adjourned will have that effect. The members as a body were the most ignorant that ever assembled in the Capitol. They were narrow-minded, bigoted, niggardly, and without public spirit.

There was a pleasing spectacle in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, a spectacle calculated to make the bosom of every citizen of New-York swell with pride. The three Commissioners of Excise, Alexander Meakim, Joseph Koch, and Edward T. Fitzpatrick, all eminently respectable-looking persons, stood before the bar of that court to answer to Recorder Smyth and a jury a charge of malfeasance in office, on which they were indicted by the Grand Jury.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The dirty water of the Legislature is beginning to flow, and it is not surprising that each day develops some new specimen of political depravity or financial debauchery. Last Friday the Assembly Committee on Commerce and Navigation had a hearing on the bill of Senator Jacobs, to prohibit the Union Ferry Company from raising its ferry rates during commission hours, as it proposes to do.

Controller Myers and Chamberlain Crain yesterday made an effort to discover why the property of the Union Ferry Company had increased $2,000,000 in value in two years. They found out that the increase was in a large measure bogus and made use of by the ferry company for the purpose of freezing out competition at the coming sale of the ferry franchise, which expires on May 1 this year.

ROME, April 1. -- Inquiries made at the Vatican this morning show that the Pope has improved in health since yesterday, when he was confined to his bed by stomach troubles. His Holiness to-day received Cardinal Rampolla and the Duke and Duchess of Mecklenburg-Schwerin.

About once in ten years a strenuous effort is made to secure a thorough revision of the tax laws of this State, but thus far comparatively little has been accomplished. A joint committee of the two houses of the Legislature prepared an elaborate listing system as long ago as 1862, and it was defeated.

Controller Myers's statement in reference to his contract with ex-Congressman John J. Adams to collect the Union defense fund claim from the Government called out a statement yesterday from Corporation Counsel Clark. He said:

ALBANY, April 1. -- The report of the Senate Committee on Cities will probably be presented to the Senate to-morrow by Senator Fassett. The committee and Messrs. Ivins and Boardman, its counsel, have been working it over and getting it into shape for many days. Messrs. Ivins and Boardman arrived here to-night and brought the report with them.

ALBANY, April 1. -- The innocent-looking bill by which the Brooklyn gas monopoly seeks further to despoil the people of the big city across the East River is now on the order of third reading in the House. It is entitled, "An act in relation to transportation corporations, excepting railroads," and its framer, Mr. Cooney, has pushed it to its present place by means that cannot be too severely denounced.

LONDON, April 1. -- It is reported here that a prominent Italian has warned Americans against the danger of touring in Italy this year, in view of the excitement and feeling caused in that country by the New-Orleans affair and Baron Fava's recall.

Yesterday was a busy day among wholesale grocers and jobbers, as the reduction in prices of sugars went into effect, and all were overwhelmed with orders. Both wholesalers and retailers have for some time past been carrying very light stocks.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 1. -- Signor Pasquale Corte, the Italian Consul, stated to-day that he had received an official telegram from Baron Fava, the Italian Minister at Washington, to the effect that he would soon leave for Europe, having obtained a leave of absence from the Government. He was glad to see that the Consul was right in pronouncing the telegram about the arrest of eighteen American citizens in Rome to be an April-fool joke.

A committee of the Association for the Improvement of the Harlem River has been appointed, consisting of Clark Bell, James Dyckman, Richard Lacey, George W. Sauer, James J. Coogan, and Dwight H. Olmstead, to wait upon the Dock Commissioner's at their meeting to-day to demand that the water front of the Harlem River be improved, according to the plans drawn for the building of bulkhead docks, from Madison Avenue Bridge to the Macombs Dam Bridge.

The battery of heavy artillery under organization on Staten Island will form a desirable addition to the National Guard of the State. Indeed, now that a start has been made in this direction, it seems only surprising that a portion of the citizen soldiery of the seaboard cities was not long ago assigned to this useful branch of the military service.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Secretary Blaine makes public to-night the letter of recall of Baron Fava and the note which he has since sent to Marquis Imperiali, the Charge d' Affaires, through whom all communications to the King of Italy must be made while that Government is without a diplomatic officer of greater importance at this capital.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 1. -- The Southern Alliance Farmer, official organ of the State Alliance, is bitter in its denunciation of Charles A. Dana of the New-York Sun, who "jumped" on the Alliance in a recently-published interview. Editorially the Farmer, in its issue of yesterday, says:

The New-York Conference began its annual session in the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Yonkers, yesterday morning. Bishop Fitzgerald presided. The Rev. C.W.
