Millard, Secretary of the last conference, called the roll and 237 members answered to their names. Mr. Millard was then re-elected Secretary and E.F. Barlow Treasure.

The correspondence between Baron FAVA and Mr. BLAINE, published this morning, shows very clearly the hasty and ill-judged nature of the action of the Italian Government, and nothing could be more satisfactory than the calmness and dignity, with a touch of toleration more benevolent than flattering, with which the Secretary of State has received that action.

Although there was a net decrease of the bonded debt during the month of March of a little over $4,000,000, there was an actual increase in the total net debt of $440,125.13. The receipts and expenditures of the Government begin to show the influence of the reckless legislation of the Fifty-first Congress.

A scheme of petty extortion practiced in the Coroners' office, which investigation discloses to be an abuse of long standing, is made public by S. Ottenberg of the firm of Ottenberg Brothers, Second Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

The Yale boys handled the Manhattan Athletic Club team without gloves on the Manhattan field yesterday. They scored run after ran with the precision of clockwork, and by superior field work prevented the muscular chaps from sending a man around the bases. In orther words, the Manhattan boys had to accept a defeat of the worst character -- a "whitewash."

The cornerstone of the new home of the Colonial Club, in Sherman Square, will be laid on Saturday afternoon with fitting ceremonies, including historical addresses by two of the members, the Rev. Dr. R.R. Booth and Gen. Egbert L. Viele. The building, which is to cost $325,000, and which will be ready for occupancy by May, 1892, will have a frontage of 115 feet on the Boulevard and 45 feet on Seventy-second Street.

New-York's League team won another game yesterday. The boys from Williams College were the victims, and the professionals won in an easy manner. They took a lead of half a dozen runs in the opening inning and increased the advantage as the game progressed.

The massacre of British native troops at Manipur is a result of what is apparently the most important revolt against the British power that has been made for many years. It is not, however, as a Parisian paper seems to hope, the beginning of a general uprising against the foreign ruler of the country.

The poolsellers walked about as airily yesterday as if, in their own expressive phrase, they "held four aces" -- Mayor Grant, District Attorney Nicoll, the Police Department, and the Guttenberg track. A combination like this, they boasted, was hard to beat. They talked about votes of thanks to their benefactors and spoke of "our friends" as glibly as if they were bosom intimates with Messrs. Grant, Nicoll, and the rest.
PATCHOGUE, L I., April 1. -- The forty-third annual session of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church convened here this morning. Bishop Cyrus D. Foss presided.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 1. -- The trial trip of the gunboat Bennington was begun this morning under very favorable conditions of wind and sea, but was interrupted by the breaking of the piston rod of the forward air and circulating pump.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., April 1. -- The-following telegram was sent to Secretary Blaine to-day by a number of patriotic cowboys: "A hundred thousand Kansas cowboys would like to spend the Summer in Rome. Can you furnish transportation."

Jay Gould's attitude toward the Western Traffic Association, which was organized with so much ceremony at the Windsor Hotel in this city a few months ago, is the subject of much suspicious comment in the West. Some Western railroad men covertly accuse Mr. Gould of scheming to break up that association in order that he may replace it with the much closer combination for which the Gould-Huntington-Atchison interests are working.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 1. -- By adopting the tactics of ex-Speaker Reed, the presiding officer of the Connecticut House of Representatives found a way this afternoon to enforce an adjournment until Wednesday, Nov. 11, 1891, leaving the State Departments, courts, schools, and public institutions without a dollar for running expenses after June 30.

Justice has again miscarried. The indictments for malfeasance in office against Excise Commissioners Alexander Meakim, Edward T. Fitzpatrick, and Joseph T. Koch had to be dismissed by Recorder Smyth yesterday because of the fatal flaw discovered at the close of Tuesday's proceedings. The flaw was of that familiar old style known as "a technicality," but it was of too serious a character to admit of the document being patched up.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- The Provision market was a very irregular one to-day. In Pork the market was so limited that rather violent fluctuations, followed either moderate purchases or moderate sales. The news was of both sorts. The local crowd at the outset was inclined to sell on the statements of stocks. It showed considerably more Pork and more Lard than counted upon.
MOOREHEAD, Ky., April 2. -- An interesting case to come before the Harlan Circuit Court at its present term is that of a jeweler named G.W. Smith. The case has its ludicrous side.

Although the bill to give to the elevated railroad company the use of an additional slice of the Battery Park received a black eye in the Assembly on Monday, the self-constituted agent of the elevated railroad company have not given up all hope of getting it through. C.H. Butler, the father of the bill, was flying around yesterday trying to rally his forces after the defeat, and F.B. Thurber assisted him.

Miss May Woolsey Bailey, daughter of Floyd Bailey, was married last evening at 8 o'clock at her home, 46 East Twenty-eighth Street, to William H. Smidt, by the Rev. Mr. Dennis, rector of Christ Church at Spar Kill, N.Y. The wedding was very quiet, as the families of bride and groom are in deep mourning, and only relatives and a few friends were invited.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 2. -- The second day's session of the New-York East Conference attracted a large audience, owing to the promised debate on the proposed legislation concerning the admission of women to the General Conference. Bishop Foss presided and much of the morning and afternoon session was devoted to the subject.

A large sum of money, almost $2,500, was added to the treasury of the Actors' Fund, through the medium of the benefit performance at Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon. This is the important point for the Fund, which naturally looks principally to the financial results of the entertainment. To the large audience in attendance, the artistic result was of more importance, and that was of a nature to amply repay every person who attended the performance.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 2. -- Dr. Thomas Legare, a prominent physician of this city, was arrested yesterday afternoon and committed to the county jail on the charge of attempting the life of Dr. J.L. Anerum, another physician of extensive practice in higher society circles of Charleston. The story of the affair is a sad one of domestic unhappiness, and is all the more unfortunate because of the high standing of all parties interested.
Capt. George W. Davis, General Manager of the Nicaragua Canal Company, received this cablegram from Greytown, Nicaragua, yesterday morning:

Justice Duffy wound up yesterday the barroom assault case of Tarpy against Chambers, Chambers, and Breen, that has been dragging along before him in the Sixth District Police Court for a fortnight, with a decision that pleased both factions. He discharged Patrick F. Breen and Patrick S. Chambers and held Michael D. Chambers in $500 bail on a charge of simple assault.

BALTIMORE, April 2. -- Miss Anne Esther Colston, a daughter of Frederick M. Colston of the banking house of Wilson, Colston Co., was married to-day to William Ellis Coale of the firm of Cunningham, Coale Co. The ceremony took place in Christ Episcopal Church, and the officiating clergyman was the Rev. Dr. Walter Williams, assisted by the Rev. Richard R. Graham.

ST. PAUL, April 2. -- The Minnesota Alliance Legislature, smarting under the attacks of the old party press, is seeking to get upon the statute books one of the most remarkable measures of the age. The proposed law seeks to compel editors to place at the end of each article the name of its writer.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, April 2. -- Receiver George H. Frey of William N. Whiteley Company has selected to appraise the East Street shops, the second largest in the world, A.R. Ludlow, G.S. Foos, and Fuller Trump, all manufacturers. Mr. Frey is engaged in corresponding with a number of persons and firms with a view to getting them to inspect the shops and make bids when the shops are offered for sale.

The Chamber of Commerce held its monthly meeting yesterday and transacted a good deal of business. Among the new members elected were Calvin S. Brice, Louis Fitzgerald, Norvin Green, Sheppard Knapp, Robert B. Roosevelt, and Walter Stanton, Jesse Seligman, William H. Webb, and Henry W. Cannon were appointed a committee to nominate officers and to report at the next meeting, May 7.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The marriage of Miss Bessie Rutterford, daughter of Col. and Mrs. R.G. Rutterford, to Mr. Richard A. Whittingham of Maryland took place at noon to-day in Epiphany Church. The Rev. Richard Whittingham, father of the groom, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. McKim. Herbert Whittingham was best man. The ushers were William Whittingham of Baltimore, Tatnall M. Chamberlain, and Mr. Grisoom of Philadelphia.

ALBANY, April 2. -- The exclusive summary in to-day's TIMES of the report of the Fassett Committee created a genuine sensation here. Nearly every member of the Senate Cities Committee promptly pronounced it a "fake," yet every committeeman had a full realization of the fast that every line in it was based on the most substantial grounds.

MOUNT PLEASANT, Penn., April 2. -- Ominous signs of the gathering of a storm in the coke region have been observed by experienced strikers here for some time, and at 3 o'clock this morning they focused and burst with sudden fury at the Morewood plant, which has been the centre of the contention between the strikers and their employers.

ROME, April 2. -- The Marquis di Rudini, the Italian Premier, to-day sent another cable message to the United States on the subject of the New-Orleans troubles. This message is addressed to the Marquis Imperiali di Francavilla, the Secretary of the Italian Legation at Washington, into whose hands the current business of the Italian Legation was placed when Baron Fava, the Italian Minister, presented his letters of recall.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Judge Altgeld was to-day presented with a point in law never before raised in this State. The question came up on the point whether a wife can maintain a civil suit for damages against her husband. The court, in unmistakable language, decided in favor of the wife. The decision grew out of the suit of Marf F. Williams against her husband, Aaron Williams, for $29,000 damages for slander.

BOSTON, April 2. -- Kelly's Cincinnati Club and the American Association nine of this city played a game here to-day. The Bostons won in the latter part of the contest by a streak of batting. Kelly's men played a strong up hill game and created a very favorable impression. Score:
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The President has made the following appointments:

The sums set apart in the last Indian Appropriation bill for systems of irrigation have attracted attention. For example, out of $946,000 to be paid to the Crows for lands bought of them, more than one-fifth is reserved for building dams, canals, and ditches on their reservation. The conclusion has been reached that if the Indians are ever to become farmers the Government must make their lands cultivable.

ALBANY, April 2. -- Timothy D. Sullivan, member of Assembly from the Second New-York, is an old newspaper man, and therefore fully alive to public enterprise. He has grasped the situation established by THE TIMES, and has introduced a bill to kick Jay Gould's elevated railway from the Battery Park, where for the last thirteen years it has usurped ground that belongs to the people of New-York.

Taking together the remarkably prolific and important army legislation of Congress and the many and great administrative changes effected by the Washington authorities, the last two years have been extraordinary in the history of the military establishment. Many of the new statutes and regulations have already taken effect, and the operation of all will be watched with great interest.

The managers of the New Jersey Jockey Club and the Linden Park Blood Horse Association having decided that it was injudicious to attempt to hold their racing meetings at their tracks in Union County this Spring, have sold their dates to the Hudson County Racing Association. The regularly-arranged programmes of both of those clubs will therefore be run off at the Guttenberg track.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 2. -- In the affair of the 14th of March the following alleged assassins of Chief Hennessy were shot to death in the Parish Prison by armed citizens commanded by W.S. Parkerson: Macheca, Scaffedi, Marchesi, Comitez, Romero, Caruso, Traina, Geraci, and Monasterio; and the following were hanged outside of the prison walls: Politz and Bagnetto.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 2. -- Creditable and honorable as has been the administration of Gov. John W. Davis, he has been slaughtered in the house of his friends and the entire Democratic State ticket with him. In a total vote of 45,457, or 2,336 larger than a year ago, Davis has a plurality of 1,253, and lacks but 950 of a majority.

Mrs. Lydia H. Marquette, a well-to-do French widow, was found in her bedroom on the second floor of 51 Willow Place, Brooklyn, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, with her throat cut from ear to ear. She was unconscious, and a pool of blood had accumulated under her head. She was discovered by a French girl, Angelina D'Argy, who had been attending Mrs. Marquette as a nurse.

At the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon Anthony Comstock proved that it was very easy to make out a case against the pool-sellers if it was necessary to do so. He had three of the men who are under protection up there, and Police Justice Taintor held all of them for trial in the Special Sessions under $500 bail.

The alarms which have been sounded by some of the settlers in the Dakotas and Montana as to the danger that the Sioux may go upon the warpath this Spring seem to have little basis. It is natural that there should be some apprehension of a renewal of the recent hostilities at the approach of a season far more favorable to carrying them on.

' At the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Friday, April 3. Jules Brugiere, under a foreclosure decree, Liecester Holme, Esq. referee, sold two three story-story brick dwelling with plot of land 37.8 by 99.11.465 and 467 West 14th St. north side, 100 feet east of 10th Av. for $28,500, to Richard S. Young

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3. -- In spite of the disagreeable day a large crowd assembled on the university grounds to-day to see the Princeton nine play their first game of baseball this year with the Williams College team. Both nines played an excellent game considering the cold and the poor condition of the diamond, Princeton winning by a score of 7 to 2.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 3. -- The storm last night did considerable damage along the New-Jersey coast. The temporary bulkhead at Sandt's Octagon House at Seabright was all torn out and the sea is now up to the hotel plazza. The gaps in the bluff here were enlarged. Only slight damage was done at Asbury Park, but a number of bulkheads at Monmouth Beach were badly damaged.

RED BANK, N. J., April 3. -- The Riverside Gun Club held its regular shoot this afternoon, the targets being Keystones. The wind blew a gale diagonally across the traps, and the scores were not up to the average. A summary of the events follows:

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- For several-years more or less earnest efforts have been made to get new quarters for the Government Printing Office. The present building is not large enough. It is so old and rickety as to be in an almost dangerous condition, and its interior arrangements are such as constantly to menace the health of the employee.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 3. -- An immense audience convened at the New-York East Conference this morning. Bishop Foss presided, and Presiding Elder B.M. Adams of Brooklyn presented his annual report. New churches had been built at various points on the south side of Long Island, including the Sands Street Memorial.

RICHMOND, Va., April 3. -- A delegation of employes of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad called on President Ingalis in this city yesterday and asked that an increase of wages he granted them. Mr. Ingalis told them that although the company was doing very well now it could not afford to advance wages until it had had time to make up for past losses.

The New-York Conference continued its session yesterday at Yonkers in the First Methodist Episcopal Church, being called to order at 8:30 o'clock. The devotional service was led by the Rev. Philip M. Walters of Dobbs Ferry. Bishop Fitzgerald took the chair as presiding officer of the business session.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Secretary Blaine received the answer of Premier Rudini to-day -- a day after its substance, and perhaps most of its language, had become public property by way of the telegraph from Rome.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 3. -- The performance of the Antigone by ladies of New-Haven at the Hyperion Theatre to-night was successful beyond any expectations that had previously been formed, and all who had part in the undertaking are happy and grateful. The audience was an uncommonly brilliant one, equal in this regard to the audiences which gather at the Glee Club concerts in the weeks of the Junior promenade and the Class Day exercises.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., April 3. -- Secretary of War Proctor, before his departure for San Diego yesterday, said that he did not think the present war flurry would result in anything serious with Italy. He did think, though, that effect of it would be to wake up Congress to the necessity of better coast defenses and a larger navy. Guns of not less than eight-inch calibre were required and from that up to twelve.

The Controller will decide to-day what action he will advise the Sinking Fund Commissioners to take in regard to the recent appraisal of the property of the Union Ferry Company. He has received from his associate on the special committee of investigation, City Chamberlain Crain, a report of the inspection of the ferry company's property in Brooklyn Thursday under the tutelage of Messrs. May and Englis, who made the

LONDON, April 3. -- A report prevailed in political clubs to-night that Lord Salisbury, on the instigation of the Marquis di Rudini, would offer to mediate for the adjustment of the difference between Italy and the United States. A high Foreign Office official, when asked to state the views of the Government, said that the question had not been discussed.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- The Hon. A.F. Walker, Chairman of the Western Traffic Association, delivered an address last night before the Sunset Club on the subject of the pooling of railway earnings, which he claimed should be legalized. "So far as the railroads are concerned," said Mr. Walker, "the objects of the pool are to assist the roads in establishing and maintaining just and reasonable rates for transportation.

Judge Job H. Lippincott, the presiding Judge of the Hudson County Court of Sessions, treated Hoboken and her officials to a genuine sensation yesterday. The story of the crusade of the ministers and church people of the city against the Sunday theatres has been told in THE TIMES as it has developed.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 3. -- After three months of heroic wrestling, David B. Hill has issued his pronunciamento on the apportionment of the State, and his bill to divide the State into Congressional districts, pursuant to an act of Congress, appeared in the Assembly to-day from his "featherweights" -- that ridiculous Committee on Enumeration and Apportionment which has been rattling around without accomplishing anything.

The St. Louis Globe-Democrat remarks that "the forthcoming trip of the President through the West and South can, if conducted with a reasonable share of tact and intelligence, be made profitable as well as pleasant," because Mr. HARRISON will have an opportunity to learn some things and to unlearn others.

Charles L. Perry, Auditor of the Custom House, has been suspended by Collector Erhardt until further orders. The notice was served upon Mr. Perry late Thursday afternoon in the shape of a formal letter from the Collector. The suspension is made on what practically amounts to a charge of incompetency.

The combined committee from the American Institute of Architects, the National Association of Builders, the National Association of Building Inspectors, the National Board of Underwriters, and the National Association of Fire Engineers, in session yesterday at the rooms of the National Board of Underwriters, 156 Broadway, decided to indorse no general building law as had been contemplated when the meeting was called. As a substitute, the

ST. LOUIS, April 3. -- The Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New-York is about to protect bondholders by foreclosing mortgages to the amount of $2,600,000 on the property of the St. Louis Ore and Steel Company. These are 6 per cent. bonds, $1,000,000 on the Pilot Knob Mine, $1,000,000 on the Vulcan Iron Works, and $600,000 in the coal mines at Grand Tower and Carbondale, Ill.

The recent semi-annual reports of the companies that supply gas to the people of London may profitably be examined in connection with the question whether the combination of companies in Brooklyn shall be enabled to escape the provisions of the law which forbids them to exact more than $1.25 per thousand after May 1.

MONTREAL, April 3. -- A dispatch from Halifax says that great excitement has been caused there by the confirmation of the rumor that Newfoundland will this season give Americans free bait and charge Canadians for it. Capt. Wrayton of the schooner Ocean Belle which arrived to-day from Fortune Bay, Newfoundland, says that he entered regularly at the Custom House there and secured 300 barrels of herring.

SCOTTDALE, Pa., April 3. -- Reports have been received here to-night, indicating a sudden and unexpected movement of strikers toward Morewood. The guard at that place has been trebled, and it is hardly considered possible the strikers would consider another raid in view of the fact that troops are generally centred there.

The election for North Sligo has been another trial of strength between the supporters and the opponents of PARNELL. It has scarcely been less noteworthy than the election for Kilkenny. Each side made very strenuous efforts, and the result is that the anti-Parnellite has been chosen over the Parnellite by a majority of 800, or about 14 per cent. of the total vote.

ALBANY, April 3. -- No person conversant with the methods of Jay Gould believes for an instant that the withdrawal of the McClelland Battery Park grab bill implied that the Wall Street wizard intended to abandon this project. The declaration on the part of the Manhattan Elevated Railway that it had nothing to do with the bill and didn't care for it was but one of those ruses for which Mr. Gould is famous.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 3. -- The third storm this year to cripple the telegraph and telephone service in this vicinity prevailed here last night and to-day. It proved more disastrous to wires than either of its predecessors. Nearly a foot of soggy snow fell, and as a result whole lines of telephone wires were prostrated. In some streets poles carrying from 200 to 300 wires broke, dragging the tangle of wires to the street.

The American Angler appeared this week in a new form in conformance with Editor William C. Harris's plan of separating the Angler from Hook and Line. The Angler will hereafter be devoted to the interests of fresh-water fishermen, and will not only contain the fishing news, but also pleasant sketches and descriptive articles of fishing resorts and subjects connected with the angling art and recreation.

ALBANY, April 3. -- "Cable Johnny" Brodsky's notorious New-York Cable bill has passed the Assembly. There was no lack of votes, and Brodsky need not have worried half as much as he did while the roll was being called. He galloped about the Chamber until the result was announced, and did an amount of logrolling that even Mr. Cooney, the great Brooklyn schemer, could not begin to accomplish.

SLIGO, April 3. -- The result of the polling yesterday for a member of Parliament to succeed the late Mr. Peter McDonald as the representative for North Sligo was announced this afternoon. The contest resulted in the election of the McCarthyite candidate, Alderman Bernard Collery of Sligo, over the Parnellite nominee, Alderman Valentine B. Dillon, Jr., of the Rotunda Ward, Dublin. Mr. Collery's majority was 806.

The Indian and Persian rugs, Russian ivories, bracelets, rosaries, and crucifixes, the Asian weapons, armor, drums, fifes, and curios collected by Vassili Verestchagin during his travels are on exhibition at the American Art Galleries previous to their sale at auction. With them are most of the paintings he exhibited some time ago in New-York, which have gone the round of the country and inspired the local art critics with many soulful comparisons.

There was great indignation yesterday among Brooklyn taxpayers over the passage in the Assembly of Cooney's outrageous Gas bill, which forces the people to pay $1.50 per 1,000 cubic feet, when they should have to pay only $1.25. The general impression was that the measure would go through the Senate, and no one seemed to have the slightest doubt about Gov. Hill signing it.

Commissioner of Police John McClave takes the poolroom exposures in THE TIMES as a personal matter, and yesterday he plainly showed that his Tammany skin was pierced. When approached by a TIMES reporter for a bit of information, he said bitterly: "Say anything for THE TIMES? No, Sir! THE TIMES has treated me disrespectfully, and it will get no information from me." The troubled chieftain turned on his heel and hurried into his room:

The federation of the Australian colonies of Great Britain into the Commonwealth of Australia is an event that has for some time been expected. To citizens of the world it is mainly interesting in its relations to Great Britain and her share in general politics. There is no use in denying that it betokens a separation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 3. -- A special from Newcastle, Penn., says: "To-day Sebastian Garbarrio, leader of the 350 Italians employed near Wampum, told a strange story, which he said should be communicated to the authorities at once. Gabarrio is a property owner in Wampum, and seemed to place considerable weight upon the information imparted.

When the March Grand Jury came into Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday to hand up their last batch of indictments and be discharged, they had the proud consciousness of knowing that they had passed on more cases than any previous Grand Jury. Foreman Cameron had a couple of short presentments to read, one concerning the tunnel disaster and a second referring to excise cases. The presentments were as follows:

Letters received in this city from Chile yesterday told the same story of business stagnation in that republic that has been brought by the mails for the last month. The revolution has had the effect of paralyzing trade. Some nitrate is shipped from ports in the hands of the insurgents, but the amount is not very great. For one thing, it is said, workmen are not easily to be obtained.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 3. -- The prospect now is that, instead of racing being carried on at the New-Jersey Jockey Club grounds here, the land, about sixty acres, will be devoted to farming purposes this year. Capt. James H. Corey of this city says he has made an offer to the club, which it will accept, whereby he agrees to pay $1,000 rental for the grounds for a year.

In its presentment concerning the system of signaling used in the Fourth Avenue tunnel, the Grand Jury said: "Some efficient system of audible signaling ought to be added, some connection with the danger signal which, in contact with the locomotive, should sound an alarm within the locomotive cab, as an unmistakable notification to the engineer that the danger signal is set against him."

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., April 4. -- There were a hundred college boys here during Easter week, seventy of them from Yale and the rest hailing from a dozen 'Varsities. College colors have brightened everything, from its ballroom decorations to the costumes of its loyal maidens.

The Union Club is the last club in the world to intentionally court public attention, but last Thursday evening it took a step which will furnish clubdom with a nine days' sensation. Nothing but the threatened relegation of the club to second or third place on the list of New-York's swell clubs could have moved the Union to increase its membership.

BERLIN, April 4. -- Negotiations have been resumed between Mr. William Walter Phelps, the United States Minister, and Chancellor von Caprivi on the question of the withdrawal of the prohibition against American pork products, and there are more hopeful prospects of an early and successful issue than recent reports have led the public to believe.

Amateur athletic affairs are dull enough these days. Just as soon as Secretary C.C. Hughes of the Manhattan Athletic Club cooled down and people became tired of talking about his attack on A.G. Mills, New-York Athletic Club, and James E. Sullivan, New-Jersey Athletic Club, there was little to interest anybody. It looks now as though everything would move along smoothly in preparation for the open games out of doors in May.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 4. -- The bad weather which began last week has continued throughout this, and its effects have been demoralizing to the baseball management. The two games scheduled with the Yale team had to be declared off, and all outdoor practice has been abandoned. Two games, also, with the Washington Association Club, set for Thursday and Friday, were lost.

Edwin Booth acted Hamlet in the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. The big auditorium was crowded by more than three thousand persons. The money taken in at the box office amounted to $2,564.50. Seats were sold at prices ranging from $1.50 to 75 cents. and admission with standing room could be obtained in some parts of the house for half a dollar.

RICHMOND, Va., April 4. -- The legislative campaign in Virginia this year promises to be unusually interesting. It is not probable that the Republicans will make any fight. The contest will be chiefly confined to the Farmers' Alliance. That element demands important legislation at the hands of the General Assembly, whose members are to be chosen this year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 4. -- It has been decided by the Trustees of Syracuse University to add another building to the imposing group "on the hill." Immediate steps will be taken to put up a structure for the Young Men's Christian Association and athletic purposes. The building will cost $30,000, and half that amount was subscribed by the Trustees. The remainder has been pledged already.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 4. -- Contrary to expectation, the negotiations for closer trade relations between Canada and the United States have advanced another stage. Sir John Macdonald in an interview this afternoon expressed himself as confident of the result. The delay of Sir Charles Tupper in starting for Washington, coupled with the apparent apathy of Secretary Blaine, augured unfavorably for the Dominion Government.

The announcement that Mr. WINDRIM, the Supervising Architect of the Treasury, has resigned his office will not surprise anybody who has paid attention to the conduct of that office. Mr. WINDRIM is one of the few architects of good professional standing who have consented to occupy a place that no such architect can consent long to retain.

SHIRE HORSES. -- The gigantic Shire horse still proves his right to exist, because he possesses the greatest amount of draught power in the smallest compass. Where it would be impossible to work six or seven horses together it is often quite possible to use three horses of superior size and strength.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 4. -- The baseball team which will start the season is: Kearnan, '94, pitcher; Belfield, '94, catcher; Gearhart, '93, first base; Throckmorton, '93, (Captain,) second base; Thompson, '94, third base; Woodcock, '92, short stop; Downey, '93, left field; McClung, '93, centre field; Ferguson, '94, right field; change pitcher, Petriken, '94; first substitute, Johnson, '94.

IDEALISM AND THE OPPOSITE. -- Not long ago I was in Staffordshire, along with an intelligent young tradesman whom I had engaged to drive me in his own dogcart. We passed through Lord Bradford's country; I explained to my friend the rise of the Bridgman family, and told him of the romantic way in which the present Earl of Bradford was enabled to see with his own eyes the corpse of his ancestor, Sir Orlando.

THE ANSAIREE FAITH. -- One of the most curious features of the Ansairee faith is their belief in a Trinity: Ali, the Father; Mohammed, the Son, and Salman el Farsi, the Holy Ghost. Ali, the Father, became man through his veil or representative, Mohammed, and Mohammed appointed Salman to superintend the affairs of this world after his return to his father's kingdom.

ANTS IN AFRICA. -- Silently, deadly, and irresistably move these battalions; out of the forest, down, into, across, and up the ditch, through the bomb, (wood stockade,) across the square, and into every nook and cranny conceivable they swarmed. The first notice (they generally came at night) would be a loud yell from some of the men.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 4. -- Despite the accessories in the way of balls and other smaller entertainments, Easter week has, contrary to expectation, not been brilliant. That it should have been even dull after so long a period of quiet would not have been strange had it not been for the special preparations made by society to insure a bright opening of the Spring.
It is now known that Mr. Nicoll has set his cap for the executive chair at Albany, and expects to be nominated by the Democratic Party for Governor three years hence.

RESUSCITATIONS. -- Under a clause in the act of Henry VIII. the company [barber surgeons] was entitled to receive every year the bodies of four malefactors who had suffered the punishment of death. The anatomies were performed four times a year, and the free surgeons as well as the apprentices were required to attend.

PARIS, April 4. -- A cable dispatch from Chile, signed by the leaders of the Congressional or revolutionist party, announces that the 2,000 Government troops recently defeated in Antofagasta took refuge in Bolivia, where they were compelled to lay down their arms. By this victory the insurgents became masters of the Province of Antofagasta.

Good new plays come so rarely into the reviewer's vision that it would be ungrateful, indeed, to complain when an unusual number of them come together. Four worthy plays divided the professional theatregoer's attention in Easter week, and three of them were new. The result is just a trifle bewildering. The mind laboriously trained to take quick impressions gets to be like the sensitive film of the camera.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Again it was announced this morning that the State Department would have nothing to make public to-day respecting the Italian correspondence. The excitement in departmental circles over Baron Fava's recall has subsided, and the incident will, it is believed, take its place in the ordinary calendar of open diplomatic matters whose disposition is usually characterized by deliberation and patient investigation.

The success of the tunnel out of Libby caused the Confederates to redouble their vigilance. They placed guards in the cookroom after dark, a guard was kept down in the hospital, and every hour after 9 o'clock a Sergeant and four guards, all carrying lanterns, made a tour of all the rooms in the prison. The latter precaution was not only unnecessary, but it disturbed the prisoners greatly.

Few Irishmen eminent in our time have had more romantic histories than John Boyle O'Reilly, but it is the peculiar distinction of O'Reilly that to romantic adventure his life adds the element of much personal worth. He was a man of whom it could be said that he was admired wherever known.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 4. -- Last Monday evening Prof. Luther delivered a lecture on "Descartes" before the Athemeum Literary Society. It was the third of a course to be given through the Spring before that body.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- A pleasant incident of Col. and Mrs. Lamont's stay in Washington was the visit of the children to the White House, where they went one rainy morning in charge of the nurse. While the little ones were in the East Room Mrs. Harrison heard of their presence and at once sent word for them to be brought up stairs.
ORANGE, N.J., April 4. -- Lent over, Orange society has aroused and the gay whirl of enjoyment has begun. There have been no very large gatherings this week, and the tendency is to small parties.

" Public sentiment is in my opinion the only thing that will induce the Legislature to pass the bills providing that the railroad companies shall pave the section of the streets between their tracks, and that the Commissioner of Public Works shall designate what sort of rail shall be laid by the companies where streets are repaved," said Commissioner Gilroy yesterday.

The piano manufacturers who assembled in this city a few days ago deserve the gratitude of all musicians, vocal and instrumental, for taking up the troubled question of pitch. There is no doubt, whatever, that a tendency exists to-day, and has existed for years past, to push the standard of pitch upward for the sake of attaining brilliancy.

Among those who have refused to be moved by the prayer of Mr. JOHN SHERMAN, uttered when the McKinley bill was passed in the Senate, that all protected manufacturers would refrain from making combinations, are the manufacturers of hinges. We quote the following from the Iron Age, an unquestioned authority:

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Two theatrical productions new to Chicago have been given here this week, and both came heralded as "metropolitan successes." They were Donnelly and Miller's farcical nautical opera "Ship Ahoy!" and Hamilton Aide's farce-comedy, "Dr. Bill." "Ship Ahoy!" has done a week of excellent business and will undoubtedly continue to draw large houses during the final week of its engagement, which begins to-morrow night "

LENOX, April 4. -- The Lenox cottagers are making preparations for the coming season much earlier than usual. Many of the cottagers come up from New-York and occupy their places in May, because May and June are quite as charming months as September and October among the Berkshire Hills. Several of the cottagers have been here the last week looking over their places and arranging for repairs and improvements.

CHAMPAGNE. -- There are two peculiarities about champagne drinking which are capable of explanation. The one is the rapidity with which the wine exhilarates, notwithstanding the small proportion of alcohol it contains. This is due to the carbonic acid gas evolved, which is inhaled while drinking, for it is the property of this gas to expedite the action of anything with which it is associated.

Instead of turning over to his employer, James F. Angel, a jeweler at 176 Broadway, the money he collected, Julius Harris forged Angel's name to a check for $25, which he got from Emanuel Strausky of 41 Clinton Street, and after cashing it kept the cash. The forgery and theft were discovered and Harris was arrested. In the Tombs Police Court yesterday he was held in $2,000 bail for the Grand Jury.

While the behavior of the guards on the bridge platforms and in the cars has on the whole improved within the past year, it is by no means nearly perfect, and there is one branch of their duties that still meets with absolute indifference -- the exclusion of drunken persons from the bridge cars at night.

News comes from Chicago that the traffic managers of those Western roads that have thus far heeded the request of the Eastern lines to cease paying commissions on passenger business, have practically decided to resume the payment of commissions in trunk line territory and to pay the commissions due for February and March.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 4. -- The transfer of Anna Dickinson from the Danville Hospital for the Insane to the more tranquil atmosphere of Interpines, at Goshen, has been the subject of several sensational stories, fabricated by unscrupulous persons, who asserted that they had interviewed the distinguished invalid on the train.

The cornerstone of the clubhouse in course of erection for the Colonial Club, at Seventy-second Street and the Boulevard, was laid yesterday afternoon with fitting ceremonies. A comfortable arrangement had been made by the committee in charge by which in case of unpleasant weather the speechmaking might take place in the chapel of the Rutgers Riverside Church near by.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4. -- The Easter recess began Tuesday in all departments of the university, and is to last one week. Almost all the students have left Cambridge for that period except the members of the 'Varsity crew and nine, who are in active training and expect to get in some of their best work during this cessation of college duties.

If the championship pennant of the College Baseball Association doesn't find a resting place in Princeton, N.J., this Fall there will be disappointment in the ranks of the followers of the orange and black. For some months there have been rumors afloat to the effect that Princeton's team this year, in the language of the enthusiastic student, was a "corker."

The intimation from Albany that the Battery Park grab bill is not permanently out of the way, but has merely been shunted, to be run on the main track again whenever Mr. Gould's lieutenants may find convenient opportunity, was so plausible on its face that people were quite ready yesterday to take it for granted. This way of doing business is recognized as wholly in Mr. Gould's line.

LONDON, April 4. -- To-morrow may turn out to be an important date in European history. The term of five years for which the Prince of Bulgaria was by the Sultan's firman also constituted Governor General of Eastern Roumelia expires on April 5. No doubt whatever exists of Turkey's willingness or present intention to renew the appointment and thus formally recognize the fact that the two Bulgarias have practically become one.

Two volumes of absorbing interest are these which Samuel Smiles has devoted to the correspondence and business career of that John Murray whose name is forever linked with the name of Byron. In the letters which Moore printed in the memoir of the poet none are more familiar than those addressed by the poet to his publisher.

The industrial stocks saved the Street from what would otherwise have been a week of complete stagnation. Except in them nothing was doing from Monday to Friday. They, however, maintained the vitality of the market, and at last the beginnings of a buying movement developed; signs appeared that various bull cliques were bestirring themselves again, and the market closed yesterday strong, with a hopeful feeling prevalent in respect to the coming week.

The case of the West Indies Asphalt Company of Stony Point, N.Y., against John O'Keefe, Commissioner of Highways of that town, for vandalism and attempted blackmail, came to an end on Saturday, March 28, when Judge Bartlett handed down a decision in favor of Mr. O'Keefe, his action in tearing down the company's building, situated on a public highway of Stony Point, being sustained.
BOSTON, April 4. -- The Herald to-night prints a special dispatch from Rome, Italy, which says:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 4. -- A special from Fayetteville, Ark., says: "The two men, Judge Baker and Dr. Howard, who robbed Major Dowell, Treasurer of the State Alliance, of $3,000, were released to-day and rearrested. A man named Lyons came here and proposed that, if Major Dowell would get the charge against Baker and Howard reduced to gaming, he would pay him the $3,000.

Dr. Ogden Bloomfield, a physician and surgeon about fifty-five years old, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartments in the flat house, 299 West One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street, on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue. The police suspect that he committed suicide. He came to this city less than a year ago from Syracuse and endeavored to establish himself in practice, but did not meet with much success.

The Postal Subsidy bill recently passed by the Senate and House of Representatives is officially headed "An act to provide for ocean mail service between the United States and foreign ports, and to promote commerce." It provides for a large subsidy to be paid to merchant steam vessels that fly the United States flag for carrying the mails from this country on their outward passages only.

In one of the city's large dry goods shops last week a little cash girl brought to one of the heads of departments in the course of the early afternoon hours of Tuesday a woman's purse. She had just picked it up, she said, on the floor, near the counter, and she remarked as she passed it over that she guessed it was "stuffed full."

WATERBURY, Conn., April 4. -- The failure of the Connecticut General Assembly to enact any legislation has engendered considerable disgust among the farmers of the State. Their dissatisfaction over the probable permanency of the Gubernatorial dead-lock is second only to that manifested by the lobbyists. The farmers were confidently expecting from the present session of the Legislature some important legislation in their behalf.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 4. -- The Universalist church at Cortland, N.Y., which recently lost its pastor, the Rev. Uri Mitchell, by defection to the Baptist fold, has secured another shepherd in the person of the Rev. H.W. Carr, pastor of the Universalist church at Canton, N.Y. The new pastor will enter on his duties at Cortland May 1.

AN ABYSS OF MISERY. -- Never yet in the history of the world had the lower orders of society been plunged into an abyss of misery so profound as that into which the working classes of England sunk in the first half of the present century. To aggravate the difficulties of our own industrial population, swarms of Irish, people with a standard of comfort almost incredibly low, crowded into the centres of English industry.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 4. -- Among the cottage people who have visited Newport this week are Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish, Miss McAllister, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Barger, Dr. R.J. Morrison, Mrs. W.R. Travers, Mr. Max Agassiz, Mr. J.S. Tooker, Mrs. Judge Horace Gray and family, Mr. William Post, Mr. David King, Mr. Stuyvesant Le Roy, Mrs. David King, Mrs. Edward King and family, Mr. George Gordon King, Mrs. Leach, and Mrs. E.W. Horton.

NEW BRUNSWICK, April 4. -- Lawyer Howard MacSherry, who lately took the part of Mathias in "The Bells" at the performance given for the benefit of the monument fund, is instructing the College Dramatic Club.

The hearings before a committee of the Massachusetts Legislature with respect to a petition of 1,300 physicians for legislation to restrict the use of arsenic in the manufacture of wall paper and textile goods have brought out much interesting testimony since we referred to them in THE TIMES a few weeks ago.

" Hard luck" is the word with the amateur photographers who are anxious to do some outdoor and field work. The elements seem to be frowning upon the fad, for during the last week there has been little chance for picture taking. When rain has not been pouring a bad photographic light has prevailed. So the usual round of lantern-slide exhibitions and society meetings have been their only attraction.

FLIGHT OF KANGAROOS. -- The rest of the herd immediately made off in our direction; but instead of scattering pellmell as other wild animals would have done under like circumstances, these queer denizens of a queer country fell into line and departed in regular Indian file, the big old doe leading the way, and the smallest diminutive pickaninnies bringing up the rear.

According to the Brooklyn Eagle, there is solid ground for hope that the Secretary of the Navy will before long ask the President to apply to the employment of laborer in his department the registration system that has been so successfully applied in Boston, and that has been so strongly urged upon Mayor GRANT by the Street- Cleaning Advisory Committee.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 4. -- While many fears have been expressed as to what the South Carolina Alliance will do within the Democratic Party lines, little has been said of the independent movement on its part until to-day, when the Superintendent of State Prisons, W.I. Talbert, was interviewed on the subject. Mr. Talbert is a Tillman Democrat of the most pronounced type.
ST. LOUIS, April 4. -- The local political campaign closed here to-night with some features decidedly out of the ordinary in contests of the kind.

If it is true that from the experiences of the past the lessons of the future must be drawn, the people of New-York may find food for reflection in a rumor that is now current. This rumor, which cannot be verified, but which seems to be warranted because it suggests a practicable step on the part of the city authorities, recalls the figure of Bill Tweed.

CLINTON, N.Y., April 4. -- By the settlement of the Fayerweather will contest, Hamilton College is assured of $100,000, and the speedy and amicable adjustment of the matter has caused much rejoicing among friends of the institution. Coming as it will with no trust or condition, the purposes to which it should be devoted are purely optional. The inquiry has been quite general as to what would be done with this gift.

CHARLES I. NEVER WROTE THE EIKON BASILIKE. -- In 1649 England was the scene of a remarkable literary imposture, in whose composition personal and partisan motives were apparently blended, which not only equaled its forerunners in attaining immediate success, but, when eventually exposed and confessed, won for its author a meed of glory instead of shame.

An undertaking in military affairs of uncommon interest has been arranged to take place at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, in the month of May. Col. John N. Partridge, commanding the Twenty-third Regiment, National Guard, has planned the details of a series of field exercises and manoeuvres to be carried out in conjunction by the militia and the regulars.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 4. -- This has been Lakewood's gayest and brightest week since it became a Winter resort. There was never another Easter in Lakewood like last Sunday. The floral decorations in the churches eclipsed all former displays of the kind. In The afternoon the drives were picturesque with handsome equipages and the by-paths and walks were like a flower garden full of life and motion.

The men in the smoking room at the club had been discussing modern fiction in that desultory fashion which fragrant tobacco encourages in inconsequent minds. "It gets there all the same," said Tommie Trivet, and the consensus had been that the novel of the day "got there."

Doubtless many of the allegations of hypnotic influence in connection with crimes are merely sensational rumors, that concerning the double suicide in Cincinnati being probably of this character. But the subject still keeps its hold upon the public mind. Dr. KINGSBURY'S answer in the Nineteenth Century to Mr. INNES'S recent article in the Contemporary Review takes a somewhat curious line.

We have refrained from saying anything of Gov. Hill's refusal to honor Gov. Bulkeley's requisition, because the affair seemed inextricably mixed up with politics. But having received several requests to express our opinion of the legal aspect of the case, we cannot decline to comply. The situation seems very simple Gov. Bulkeley was Governor before the late election.

Much sarcasm has been lavished by French journals on the exploit of CAREY J. WARBINTON, a young man of Omaha, who smote with the legs of a convenient chair a nude figure painted by BOUGUEREAU, called "The Return of Spring." He had seen some young women looking at it. At the trial of this iconoclast recently held in Omaha veracious bystanders testified that he boldly avowed his deed by exclaiming then and there:

BOSTON, April 4. -- Both of the Massachusetts Senators and Representative Walker were guests at the Massachusetts Club dinner this afternoon. Their speeches were in the way of setting forth the importance of the work which the Republicans in Congress had accomplished during the session just over, and of presenting the issues of the campaign of 1892.

Spain's preparation to raise a statue of COLUMBUS on the spot from which he started upon the momentous voyage of 1492 has suggested the propriety of erecting some sort of memorial also at his landing place in the New World. The examination already made by the Government engineers and architects around the Monastery of La Rabida, near Palos, indicates that that may be the region selected as a site for Spain's commemorative statue.

Spain's preparation to raise a statue of COLUMBUS on the spot from which he started upon the momentous voyage of 1492 has suggested the propriety of erecting some sort of memorial also at his landing place in the New World. The examination already made by the Government engineers and architects around the Monastery of La Rabida, near Palos, indicates that that may be the region selected as a site for Spain's commemorative statue.

BOSTON, April 4. -- A storm raged throughout New-England on Thursday night and Friday morning which has practically demoralized telegraph and telephone service and resulted in a great deal of general devastation. From the reports coming in from all directions the general condition of the wires is worse than that which resulted from the great blizzard in January last.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 5. -- A special from Scottdale, Penn., says: "The utmost tranquillity prevailed throughout the coke region to-day. The strikers generally spent the time in discussing the situation. Monday is usually the day for raiding, but there are no serious apprehensions in that line.

I most heartily concur with "Verax" in his thanks to THE TIMES, contained in his letter of March 31, and published by you on April 1, in regard to the abuses of the gas monopoly of Brooklyn, whose citizens can find no mouthpiece for their complaints in the press of this city.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The Republican Senators have only begun to awaken to the fact that David B. Hill has already started next Fall's campaign, and in every county in the State where he can establish sinews of war the work is going on. It is not to be denied that the six years' experience he has acquired in the Executive Chamber is now being utilized by him in every direction possible.

Some light is thrown on the preferences of the Democratic Party in South Carolina by our dispatch from Charleston this morning. It is clear enough that there is no "boom," nor the material even for the smallest kind of one, for HILL in that State. His name is hardly known to the great body of the people of the State, while it is received with enthusiasm by none of those who happen to know it.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 5. -- A blunder on the part of the City Council has just been discovered by the City Attorney, by which three men appointed as a commission to assess on the property owners the cost of paving two streets are made Commissioners to assess all improvements that hereafter may be undertaken in the city.

Joseph C. Loughery, aged fifty years, who had for many years kept an oyster saloon at 168 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, committed suicide yesterday by hanging. He had been suffering wish the grip. Recently he bought out ex-Supervisor Garrett Cullen's saloon at Myrtle Avenue and Prince Street. He owned considerable property.

MANASQUAN, N.J., April 5. -- The Republicans of Monmouth County are in arms against Postmaster General Wanamaker and the Administration in general for retaining in office Democratic Postmasters whose terms have expired. Last night the dissenters met in mass meeting here and openly denounced Wanamaker for his double dealing in the Spring Lake Postmaster case.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 5. -- The New-York East Conference reassembled at 9 A.M. yesterday, Bishop Oyrus D. Foss presiding. After the devotional exercises, which were conducted by the Rev. A.B. Kendig, the following ministerial candidates, who had completed their term of probation, were admitted into the conference: Winfield Manship, Francis A. Logen, James A. McMillan, and Henry L. Glover.

In spite of all the tariff tricks and jobs by which the three political shepherds of Ohio have sought to prevent the importation of foreign wool, the sales of Ohio wool are decreasing. That is the story told by the trade journals. The American Wool Reporter of the 26th ult. published the following:

The biography of Arthur Macmurrough Kavanagh well deserved to be written. Mr. Kavanagh, in a peculiar and striking way, was an eminent man of his time. He accomplished a total of life work which only a rare and gifted spirit could have accomplished. It mattered not that to the great world he was little known.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian Minister of Marine and Fisheries; George E. Foster, Minister of Finance; John S.D. Thompson, Minister of Justice, and C.C. Chipman, Sir Charles Tupper's private secretary, reached Washington at a late hour to-night from Ottawa, and went at once to the Arlington Hotel.

The twelfth regular season at Daly's Theatre will close next Saturday evening. It began Oct. 5, and during its continuance six productions have been made, "New Lamps for Old," which was acted 24 times; "The Last Word," 101 times; "The School for Scandal," 50 times; "The Prodigal Son," (pantomime,) 7 times, and "Love's Labor's Lost," which is still in course of presentation.

In the little hamlet of Elmsford, Westchester County, which twenty years ago was known as Hall's Corners, on the line of the New-York and Northern Railroad, and about midway between White Plains and Tarrytown, is a little wooden church, whose weather-beaten sides suggest to the beholder that it has stood there since long before the Revolution.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- It was only a very short time ago that Mr. Blaine's reciprocity bureau in this city was sending out figures about Brazilian trade for the year 1888, evidently for the purpose of announcing later on what can easily be discovered now, and that could have been discovered a year ago, that the trade of 1889 was greater than that of 1888.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 5. -- Much amusement has been caused recently in Democratic circles in South Carolina by the assertion of the Hill supporters that a strong sentiment in favor of the Senator-Governor's Presidential candidacy had been developed in the South. There is no doubt that during the last three years systematic efforts have been made in this State to work up a Hill boom, but they have received little or no encouragement.

The jury of selection has done a good thing in forcing down the limit of accepted works to half a thousand. The sixty-sixth exhibition of the National Academy of Design is far less unwieldy than usual. It has been impossible to exclude pictures by Academicians who are not artists, but means have been taken to reduce this contingent, while the poorest work of outsiders has been sternly rejected.

Our controversy with Italy in regard to the punishment of the New-Orleans rioters reveals a defect in our laws, not now for the first time revealed, but to which too little attention has been given. Our diplomatic case as against the "demands" of the Marquis DI RUDINI cannot be weakened or prejudiced by the frank admission that the violation of treaties should be made punishable in the United States courts by a law of Congress.

ST. LOUIS, April 5. -- The election takes place here Tuesday, and the campaign is closed. The situation is decidedly unique. The Republicans some time ago, in a spasm of virtue, and at the dictation of Joseph B. McCullagh, editor of the Globe-Democrat, undertook the task of self-reformation. The first step in that direction was to get rid of everybody and everything that smacked of Chauncey I. Filley.

Since the adjournment of Congress, four weeks ago, the Washington dispatches of many papers in various parts of the country have been full of allusions to the political bearing of the appointment of Mr. FOSTER to the Treasury and of the appointments still to be made in that department.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 5. -- If there is any virtue in calm deliberation and careful consideration of the subject in all its bearings, the election-reform legislation that the General Assembly of Delaware is expected to enact at its present session ought to result in a very complete and satisfactory system. The subject has been discussed for fully two months, but no attempt has yet been made to pass any bill with this object in view.

The Republican organization in this city is badly in need of repair. It is now and has been for some time in a very poor way. There is a painful lack of discipline in the organization, and harmony is almost an unknown quantity. No well-directed effort has been made to strengthen it in some time. The men who have office seem to be perfectly satisfied to let things jog along as they are.

The recent trip of the revenue cutter Lot M. Morrill from the North Edisto to Charleston by an interior route has been justly commented upon as testing an additional link in that chain of inner channels on our Atlantic coast, which may one day prove of great use in the defense of the seaboard.

An interesting and sensational chapter in the conspiracy to capture a portion of the large estate of Loring A. Robertson, the millionaire merchant, by the production of a woman who falsely claimed to be his widow, was made public by the arrest yesterday of the chief conspirators.

-- An edition of the "Journal of Sir Walter Scott" in one volume will be brought out this week by Harper Brothers. At the same time will appear L.E. Chittenden's "Recollections of President Lincoln and his Administration."

PARIS, April 5. -- The conflict between Italy and the United States continues to attract attention. Signor Raquem, a former Garibaldian, now editor of the Epoque, the organ of the Italian colony here, said in an interview to-day:

An application was made in one of the civil courts last week to have a "struck" jury drawn in a certain case. Such an application is seldom made. One of the counsel in the case in which it was made said that he had not known of a "struck" jury sitting in a case since William M. Tweed was tried before one. The Judge said that he had known of a dozen since then.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5. -- The State Board of Agriculture gives out the following official report on the condition of crops April 1:

Seven hundred flaxen-haired Scandinavians, bound for farms in the West, were landed yesterday from the Thingvalla Line steamship Hekla. Five hundred of them, accompanied by an agent of Max Strauss, the Land Agent of the Northern Pacific Railroad, boarded a special train for Niagara Falls last night. On arrival at the Falls they will be transferred to another train and taken to Chicago direct. The immigrants will settle in the West.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5. -- The final adjournment of the California Legislature, commonly termed the Legislature of a Thousand Scandals, affords a fitting opportunity for a review of the work of a body that has been fortunate enough to gain a national notoriety.

LANSING, Mich., April 5. -- To-morrow will occur the first skirmish between the Democratic and Republican Parties for supremacy in Michigan in 1892. The occasion is the Spring election, and the balloting assumes prominence because last Fall, owing to planned and fortuitous arrangements, the Democrats secured control of the legislative and executive departments of the State for the first time in its history.

LOWELL, Mass, April 5. -- The worst fire Lowell has had in many years occurred this afternoon. Boys set fire to a box of waste paper in the alley back of the Edson Block, and the fire dropped into H.C. Church Son's cellar. It spread rapidly, and the basement of this shop and C.J. Maynard Co.'s dry goods shop were soon ablaze.

The hearings before a committee of the Massachusetts Legislature concerning the use of arsenic in the manufacture of wall paper and textile goods have been closed, and the arguments were made on Friday last. The testimony of certain manufacturers of wall paper was taken in the last days of the investigation, and brief reports of it have been published by the Boston press.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 5. -- To-day Robert Watchern gave out a reply to the charges made against him in a recent interview by H.C. Frick, the head of the great coke company bearing his name, and a partner in that and other enterprises of Andrew Carnegie. Mr. Watchern was formerly Secretary of the United Mine Workers of America, and is now executive clerk under Gov. Pattison.

No better evidence could be produced to show the people of this city that the men whom they elect to govern them are governed by powers behind their respective chairs of administration than the record of the crusade that THE TIMES for the last three weeks has been carrying on against the sixty gambling dives which are running openly in defiance of law.

Apart from the mere question of purity, good wine is, perhaps, a matter of taste; nor is this a matter of fashion, but of good judgment, and if we find that a kind has received the commendation of connoisseurs we may at least try it with confidence.

The exegesis of Gov. HILL'S letter to Mr. POST'S free trade meeting has furnished a congenial occupation to newspapers that are friendly to the Governor and unfriendly to Mr. CLEVELAND. The process appears now to be complete. The exegetists have discovered and interpreted to the world all the obvious and hidden meanings of the letter, its broad philosophies, its political teachings, its warnings, and its rebukes.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Secretary Rusk said to-day that he had no official confirmation of the report from Berlin. "I am quite convinced," he said, of the disposition of the German Government to deal fairly with us in this matter and to take into account the figures I have given and the desirability for the people of both countries to maintain the friendliest trade relations.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- After paying out over $1,000,000 in refunding duties on ribbons and other articles declared by the Supreme Court to have been erroneously charged a 50 per cent. duty because they were "hat trimmings," dutiable at 20 per cent., the Treasury authorities concluded it was time to look into the situation a little.

ALBANY, April 6. -- The time for the introduction of bills, except by unanimous consent, expired to-night in the Assembly. In consequence, the bill box was flooded. Forty-one bills were introduced before 10 o'clock. Some of them were the most dangerous of the session. Others were plain, every-day "strikes," which will not be heard of again if the interests effected "see" the men who put them in.

On the eve of his departure for a European trip Senator WASHBURN of Minnesota yesterday gave to a reporter of THE TIMES some views suggested by the recent Italian incident He agrees with the suggestion recently made by us that the sifting process for immigrants should begin abroad, and that a certificate of character indorsed by a Consul of the United States should be required in every case.

ROME, April 6. -- Cardinal Lavigerie's toast at Algiers, and the events which rapidly followed that striking utterance, are still much discussed in Church circles. Everything clearly indicates the decided drift of the Catholic Church toward modern democracy. But those who have enjoyed the confidence of Pope Leo XIII. know that he has always considered it of prime importance for the Church to free itself from identification with the old dynastic parties.

The Grand Army of the Republic celebrated yesterday the twenty-fifth anniversary of its establishment. Its founder, Dr. B.F. STEPHENSON of Illinois, who died in 1871, a little more than five years after organizing its first post in that State, could hardly have appreciated what the future had in store for his famous enterprise.

At last a Brooklyn newspaper has turned its attention to Assemblyman Cooney's infamous Gas bill, which gives the local companies the right to charge $1.50 instead of $1.25 per 1,000 cubic feet after May 1. The Eagle yesterday printed an editorial on this important subject, but not one word war said about the actual robbery that will be perpetrated if Cooney's bill becomes a law.

The testimony of President COLEMAN of the Department of Taxes and Assessments yesterday before the Senate Committee on General Laws had little bearing on the nominal subject of the committee's inquiry -- the Sugar Trust -- but it had an important bearing on the general question of taxation.

A stout, well-dressed young man, considerably under the influence of liquor, wandered up one flight of stairs at the Police Gazette office yesterday afternoon and inquired for Cashier Stoddard. On reaching that person's desk he calmly announced his desire to remove him violently from the scene of action. Mr. Stoddard emphatically demurred, whereupon the stout young man pulled out a pistol.

Counsel for the owners and lessees of the property east of the bridge entrance in Park Row, which the Bridge Trustees wish to secure, oppose the report of the Condemnation Commission. Bergen Dykeman, counsel for the Bridge Trustees, have given notice that they will on Friday apply for a confirmation of the report.

We shall not believe until we are compelled to do so that Mr. HARRISON has any intention of removing Mr. ROOSEVELT from the Civil Service Commission, or that Mr. ROOSEVELT will abandon that thankless but honorable and useful office before the close of this Administration unless compelled.

PATERSON, N.J., April 6. -- The will of Domenica Dossena, which is to be offered for probate in this city to-morrow, is expected to develop an interesting contest. Dossena died week before last of heart disease, as he was about to fondle a pet dog which leaped upon him. He was born about fifty years ago in or near Milan, Italy.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 6. -- When Mr. Cleveland's silver letter first appeared it was like a thunderbolt from a clear sky. The Democrats of this State had come to the conclusion, from the statement of Senator Vest of Missouri and the apparent unanimity of the Democrats in favor of free coinage, that the views of Mr. Cleveland had also undergone a radical change.

There is a chance for relief from the nuisance of the poolrooms at last. District Attorney Nicoll says that they shall be closed if the powers of his office are sufficient to do it. The case against Michael Minden, who had a place at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, is to be pressed for trial to-day in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Everybody is wondering here to-night if the President has put a check rein upon Mr. Blaine in the reciprocity business. Sir Charles Tupper, Sir John Thompson, and the Hon. George E. Foster of the Dominion of Canada arrived here this morning in response to an invitation from Mr. Blaine.

Senator EDMUNDS, who still lingers in Washington, was "interviewed" yesterday on the Farmers' Alliance movement. There was nothing very striking in what he had to say, and unless the reporter failed to get his words accurately, the Senator's mode of saying it was less picturesque than he usually adopts in the Senate.

Lovers of literary oddities, much less searchers for news, do not naturally look for literature to entertain them in that embalmer of official facts, the City Record. The traditions of that periodical tend to discourage subscribers who want a diet of reading with dramatic interest in it. Supervisor Kenny has made a bold and long stride toward brushing the cobwebs from his paper by letting his newspaper instincts have occasional play.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Star this afternoon printed an interesting interview with Senator Edmunds on the present state of political affairs. A reporter found him in the Judiciary Committee room of the Senate, where he was occupied in disposing of various odds and ends of work before retiring to his home in Vermont for the Summer.

" Yes, it is true that we are trying the experiment of lighting the Fourth Avenue tunnel by electricity," said President Chauncey M. Depew of the New-York Central Railroad yesterday. "We have put in a few incandescent lamps and shah give them a thorough trial. If they are found to be practicable, they will be used throughout the entire tunnel."

The session of the Sugar Trust investigation held at the Hotel Metropole yesterday by the Senate Committee on General Laws was as serene as a Summer day. This was something of a surprise. It was expected that argument would be heard on the issue that made Saturday's session so stormy -- the power of the committee to compel the production of the Trust books.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 6. -- At 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon a break occurred in the rear levee, built to keep the water from the Ames crevasse out of the town of Gretna opposite the central portion of this city. By 6 o'clock at night the break had been almost closed, but the water had in the meantime flooded nearly half the town.

The opening devotional exercises in the New-York Conference at Yonkers yesterday morning were led by the Rev. O.D. Ramsay. The song service was the best of the conference thus far, being led by Chaplain McCabe, with Miss Macfarlan at the organ.

The Municipal Consolidation Commission met yesterday morning at 216 Broadway. A bare quorum was present, consisting of Andrew H. Green, J.S.T. Stranahan, Calvert Vaux, William D. Veeder, Edward F. Linton, George J. Greenfield, and F.W. Dovoe. George William Curtis had been invited to attend the meeting, but he sent this letter instead:

ALBANY, April 6. -- The railroads and Jay Gould in the Assembly and the cable gang in the Senate monopolized the attention of the Legislature to-night, the last day in which bills can be introduced under the rules.

HARTFORD, April 6. -- The Democrats have carried the city election here to-day by the largest majorities in twenty years, electing 6 of the 8 Aldermen and 22 Councilmen to the Republicans' 10. In the Board of Aldermen 5 Democrats to 3 Republicans hold over. The victors will have 11 of the 16 members. On joint ballot the Court of Common. Council will stand 33 Democrats, 15 Republicans.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 6. -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization of the Grand Army of the Republic was fittingly commemorated to-night by Plainfield's two Grand Army posts, Winfield Scott, No. 47, and Major Anderson, No. 109. Major W.B. Miller presided at the camp fire.

LONDON, April 6. -- The Standard to-day publishes a review of the agricultural outlook, in which it says that the steady rise in wheat revives the hopes of the English farmer, adding that wheat will probably reach the highest price in many years, the principal cause of the rise being the failure of foreign crops.

John M. Bowers and other lawyers, for the Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, who were indicted for misdemeanor in having maintained the fatal car stove in the trains of the road, which contributed so largely to the results of the recent collision in the tunnel, filed a ponderous document with the District Attorney yesterday.

For half a dozen innings the famous old Metropolitan team made matters decidedly interesting for the New-York players yesterday. They took a lead of two runs over the champions and seven innings had been played before the League men felt certain of victory. After playing a remarkably strong game the Mets went to pieces, when victory was within their grasp, and allowed the Giants to score seven runs in their half of the seventh inning.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 6. -- The city election held to-day proved to be a great surprise. The average Democratic majority in this city is about 1,000, but the Republicans elected William H. Marigold Mayor, defeating Zalmon Goodsell by about 250. William E. Grant, Democratic candidate for Tax Collector, was defeated by over 1,000 by Frederick Bommos, Jr., Republican.

CHICAGO, April 6. -- The city election to-morrow is exciting the liveliest interest. If the weather is good, there will probably be as large a vote as in a Presidential year. All of the principal candidates are claiming that they will be victorious, and, as proof of this, call attention to the large size of their meetings and the enthusiasm displayed at them during the last days of the campaign.

These are joyful days for the three political shepherds in Ohio, for they have induced the Treasury Department to double the duty on a large part of the wool that is used in making carpets anti cheap blankets. Some days ago we spoke of their appeal to the new Secretary for such an interpretation of the law as would disclose another job which they had put into the wool schedule.

DETROIT, April 6. -- The returns up to midnight come in, as usual on the first night of election, in a very scattering form, by townships of one, two, and three, supplying only indications rather than definite results, but from all parts of the State these indications are quite uniform, and in some cases very striking.

There appears still to be some danger that the bill introduced by Assemblyman Charles P. McClelland to authorize the authorities of Yonkers to construct a highway over the course of the Croton Aqueduct through that town, will become a law unless the interests of New-York City are more energetically presented than they have been hitherto.

The new immigration law has been remarkably fruitful in good results during the short period it has been in operation. If, under its provisions, the work of excluding undesirable immigrants is kept up as well as it has begun the law cannot but have the excellent effect of diverting from these shores the outcasts of Europe.

The commission created last year to inquire into the expediency of consolidating New-York and Brooklyn and the outlying territory into one municipality has put the matter in tangible shape by adopting the draft of a bill authorizing it to prepare a charter for the proposed consolidated city.

ST. LOUIS, April 6. -- St. George's Episcopal Church, the finest in the city, situated at Chestnut and Beaumont Streets, was recently destroyed by fire.
