The congregation want to sell the real estate and build a fine church in the fashionable West End. Robert A. Holland, the rector, is anxious to do this. The feeling is practically unanimous in the same view.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 6. -- The New-York East Conference reassembled this morning for the sixth day's session. The following ministerial candidates were continued on trial: Charles E. Barto, Harry H. Beatty, George W. Phillips, Edgar C. Tullar, George W. Lewis, and Carl F. Tornblade. The Rev. William T. Hill, who united with the conference in 1855, was retired to the superannuated list owing to impaired health.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7. -- Judge Acherton in the United States Circuit Court yesterday continued twenty-nine hat-trimming cases until the first Monday of June. The plaintiffs are John Wanamaker, Eyer Dickinson, Henry Tilger Co., and Kohn, Adler Co.

Henry M. Stanley and his party, consisting of Mrs. Stanley, Mrs. G.B.R. Tennant, Ernest Kendth, the courier, and Saleh bin Osman, arrived in New-York yesterday morning. They are at the Plaza Hotel. They will sail for England on April 15.

One wonders, sometimes, whether the State Legislature really is a representative body, whether the views that it expresses in its action would be found to be the views of a large majority of the voters of the State. If this be the case, it is a curious commentary on the effect of our boasted system of general education.

WHEELING, West Va., April 7. -- Since Sunday night, about 9:30 o'clock, there has been much excitement in this city and vicinity over the sudden and mysterious disappearance of Miss Amy Morgan, niece of Henry Morgan, Assistant Cashier of the Exchange Bank of Wheeling. The family resides two miles from the river on the Ohio side, at the extreme western end of Bridgeport.

The Princeton College players are making a greae record this year. They played a nip-and-tuck gamt with New-York on Saturday, defeated Columbia on Monday, and administered a "Chicago" defeat to the Fordham College men yesterday. From start to finish the New-Jersey representatives showed their superiority. Their steady game had a telling effect and completely astonished the Fordham boys.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 7. -- The Hill Democrats of this city are feeling rather glum since yesterday's transfer of the municipal government to the Republicans. The political tornado which swept the city was the result probably of dissatisfaction on the part of the independent voters and the Democrats who were not in the City Hall ring.

A hearing is to be given to-morrow by the Senate Committee on the Judiciary upon a bill to fix the sentences of persons committed in this city for intoxication, disorderly conduct, and vagrancy at six months, and to empower the Commissioners of Charities and Correction to discharge the persons so committed.
The following letter relates to an abuse that was corrected by official orders issued by General Manager C.H. Platt of the Grand Central Station yesterday morning:

Glasscock made his first appearance with the New-York team this season yesterday, when the Giants met the Columbia College boys. He was given a grand welcome. "Captain Jack" has been suffering from the grip for some weeks past, but he is on the road to recovery now, and, as he remarked yesterday, the fact of getting into harness again will have a tendency to make him forget his sickness.

ALBANY, April 7. -- Superintendent Preston of the State Banking Department issues the following summary, showing the aggregate of resources and liabilities of the banks of the state on March 21st instant, as exhibited by their reports to the department:

Count Emile de Keratry, the special envoy of the French Government to convey crosses of the Legion of Honor to two distinguished Americans who have been prominent in the fight for the copyright law, arrived here on Sunday on the steamship La Gascogne, and is now confined to his bed, suffering from the grip, at the Hotel Martin.

HARTFORD, April 7. -- Nothing out of the usual way was transacted by the Senate this afternoon, which met and adjourned without regard to the course pursued by the House last week. An attempt was made by Senator Shumway to effect an adjournment until November, but without success.

A thousand and one beautiful flowers were in bloom at the Lenox Lyceum last night and the air was heavy with rare odors. On the stage was a fountain, wreathed in flowers, the waters of which were illumined by blue and red electric lights. There was also a miniature lake, full of submerged electric lights of various colors, and, altogether, it was the best Spring' exhibition in the history of the New-York Florist Club.

MILWAUKEE, April 7. -- The election in this State to-day was for Justice of the Supreme Court. Political lines were not drawn. S.U. Pinney was nominated by a convention of lawyers and E.H. Ellis's candidacy was backed by Democratic politicians, but he was not formally nominated. Both candidates were Democrats.

MAQUOKETA, Iowa, April 7. -- Judge Brannon has rendered a decision regarding the taxation of national bank notes which is of national interest. The case is that of L.B. Dunham against the city of Maquoketa on appeal to the Jackson County District Court. In rendering his decision Judge Brannon said:

Importers of tin plate in this city find a great deal of amusement in the talk that is made by Republican journals about "American tin," which is in substance that, stimulated by the McKinley bill, the manufacture of tin plate has been so well established in this country that the manufacturers are actually underselling the Welsh people.

Now that the Italian incident is in a condition where the minds of all concerned may regard it without apprehension it is interesting to glance at the manner in which it has been discussed by the press of foreign countries. As was pointed out by our London dispatches yesterday, the tone of the foreign press has been almost uniformly unfavorable, if not unfriendly, to the American Government.

It is difficult to make an intelligible comparison of the two schemes of apportionment submitted by the majority and minority of the Assembly Committee on Enumeration and Apportionment, as the reports are not accompanied by sufficiently explicit information for the purpose. But a very slight examination shows that neither proposes an entirely fair division of the State, and that both seek party advantage rather than equitable representation.

The Librarian of Congress, Ainsworth R. Spofford, LL.D., read an interesting paper last night before the Historical Society at the library in Second Avenue, on "The Early History of the Press of the United States."

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- A good many persons who have been looking at the matter critically regard the sending back to Canada of the Commissioners who had been invited to come here to talk over reciprocity as a much more serious diplomatic offense than the Italian incident.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 7. -- Elections were held in Kansas to-day in all cities of the first and second classes. Although without general political significance, the results are regarded with considerable interest because the Citizens' Alliance had tickets in the field and was fighting all the old parties. The Citizens' Alliance is really a branch of the Farmers' Alliance.

Just prior to the adjournment of the New-York State Legislature of 1890 an act was passed for the "improvement" of the South Branch of the Saranac River and making an appropriation therefor of $5,000. The object of this appropriation was the construction of a lock at what is called the "Middle Falls," about midway between Round Lake and the upper end of Lower Saranac Lake.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., April 7. -- Lawrence Barrett passed several years of his boyhood in Lyndon, near here. The St. Johnsbury Caledonian gives some stories of his youth to refute the statement that he was then illiterate.

Of enthusiasm there was no lack at last night's meeting of the County Democracy's County Committee in the Cooper Institute. That there is plenty of "go" left yet in this battle-scarred organization was made manifest. J. Oliver Keene, who is short and stout and somewhat given to boisterous oration and other things, added excitement to the meeting by being obnoxious.

Goldwin Smith of Toronto told a TIMES reporter yesterday that the sudden termination of the supposed reciprocity conference between Sir Charles Tupper and the high officials of the Government at Washington would make it very uncomfortable for the dominant party in Canada. Mr. Smith was at the New-York Hotel. He said he had read of the hasty return of the Canadian High Commissioner with deep interest.

MONTREAL, April 7. -- The fears of a great flood here and in the country about and below Montreal were redoubled this evening, when it learned that the ice in Lake St. Louis, an expansion of the St. Lawrence above Montreal, had begun to move. This is a certain indication of flood. The ice began moving at Beauharnois, on the south shore, and tore away several small outhouses and flooded all the lowlands thereabout.

The Board of Rulings of the Trunk Line Association and the Central Traffic Association met at 346 Broadway yesterday and determined to institute a vigorous boycott against the Chicago and Alton Railroad for its neglect to conform to the order of the joint committee abolishing commissions on passenger business.

ALBANY, April 7. -- The Cable bill is almost certain to pass the Senate. Any one who witnessed the proceedings last night and again to-day could have seen that, whenever the occasion required, votes enough could be summoned in the upper house to rush the discredited measure to the Governor, who, the lobby claims, stands ready to affix his signature to it.

There is hardly an American now in the vigor of life who can remember when the name of BARNUM was not familiar to him, and there are very few Americans who do not feel that they owe him a certain debt of gratitude for brightening their lives or the lives of their children. It is really wonderful and unexampled, the career that closed yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 7. -- From the time Mr. Barnum decided upon Bridgeport as his home his interest was centred in what would best benefit the city. He invested largely in real estate, induced manufacturing concerns to locate here, and did much to beautify the city. He gave part of the land comprising Seaside Park, one of the most beautiful spots in the country.

The life of the bill to revive the old cable railroad scheme in this city was saved yesterday by a reconsideration of the vote of Monday night, when it might have been killed if the New-York Senators had done their duty. Now it is in the hands of the Railroad Committee, and there is a general belief at Albany that it will be reported and passed.

Senator Hiscock had hardly finished his breakfast at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday morning when callers began to send up their cards. Among them were Collector of the Port Joel B. Erhardt and Appraiser Marvelle W. Cooper. Cornelius N. Bliss was another caller.

As a step toward re-establishing the United States long-lost supremacy on the seas, the nautical schoolship St. Mary's was, theoretically, a long stride in the right direction; as an actual fact, the institution has not proved a shining success. But many bad features have been eliminated, and signs are not wanting that the ship will henceforth be a valuable school for the training of American boys for the merchant marine.

At Temple Beth-El, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, Miss Alice Forchheimer was married to Dr. W. Freudenthal. The ceremony was performed by Dr. K. Kohler, and took place at 5 o'clock. The music was under the direction of Mr. Samuel Franks.

THE TIME'S prediction that Lieut. Commander Bicknell, who was in command of the United States steamship Galena when she grounded off Gay Head March 13, would shift the responsibility for that accident to the shoulders of Master of Tugs T.M. Smith, was verified yesterday. There was a full court present when the inquiry into the causes of the mishap was commenced.
ALBANY, April 7. -- It was electrical day in the Legislature to-day, and Mr. Jay Gould's agents put in some good solid work. Members openly talked of the "boodle behind bills."
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 7. -- At 6:22 o'clock to-night the long sickness of P.T. Barnum came to an end by his quietly passing away at Marina, his residence in this city.

Under the old immigration law no provision was made for the exclusion of undesirable immigrants who should undertake to enter the country by crossing the Canadian boundary. The Board of Charities of this State showed in its reports, year after year, that immigrants who would have been rejected if they had sought entrance at this port were coming into this State from Canada, having landed at Halifax or some other Canadian port.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- A celebration intended to commemorate the one hundredth anniversary of the establishment of the American patent system will begin in this city to-morrow. The exhibition of models of patents, , will take place in the Patent Office, which has been elaborately decorated. The literary exercises, which will last three days, will be held in the Lincoln Music Hall.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- The Mayoralty election is very close. At 1 o'clock this morning the result is still in doubt. With seventeen precincts to hear from, Hempstead Washburne, the regular Republican candidate, leads De Witt C. Cregier, the regular Democratic candidate, by 162 votes. The missing precincts may give the victory to the Democrats.

OTTAWA, April 7. -- Government organs are asserting that negotiations with the United States on the trade question will be resumed as soon as President Harrison returns from his Western trip. On the other hand the Liberals regard the Washington mission as a complete fiasco. The Globe, a representative sheet, says:

Bankers of this city are going to take a hand in fighting the bill to reduce the legal rate of interest in this State from 6 to 5 per cent. This measure got through the Assembly last Friday by a vote of 69 to 4, but the bankers hope to be able to prove to the Senate that its passage by that body would be a grave mistake.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 7. -- The closing session of the New-York East Conference was held this afternoon. It was announced that the recent vote of the laity in the body concerning the admission of women into the General Conference resulted as follows: For the movement, 1,893; against it, 3,919. The total vote of the clergymen of the conference, increased by additions during the day, was 63 for and 160 against the project.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The resignation of Senator Edmunds, while it created no surprise here, has provoked many expressions of regret. No Senator cared less for popularity than Mr. Edmunds and in no Senator did the average visitor to the Capitol have greater confidence as to his motives and his honesty of expression on public questions.

After the final vote on the McKinley bill had been taken, Mr. JOHN SHERMAN, in his place in the Senate, urged the beneficiaries of the bill not to combine for the suppression of competition and the enhancement of prices. Even while he was making that appeal the manufacturers of barbed wire, in his own State and elsewhere, were beginning to make a combination.

The task assumed by Mr. BLAINE of promoting reciprocity while adhering to the non-intercourse policy of the Republican tariff increases in difficulty with every new effort required. "Carrying water on both shoulders" is in politics something that the supple Secretary has time and again shown himself capable of, but "riding two horses" is only feasible when the animals are going in the same direction.

The Brooklyn team won an easy victory over the Buffalo Club of the Eastern Association at Washington Park yesterday. It was the first game played by the Buffalo men and they were lamentably weak on account of lack of practice. Manager Powers has a good team. With a new days out doors the boys ought to get in shape and play in fairly good form. Ward's boys gave a pretty exhibition of ball playing.

At the home of her mother, Mrs. Sylvanus Reynolds, 48 East Seventy-third Street, last evening, Miss Elizabeth Applegate was married to Warren Gardner Demarest. The house was profusely and artistically decorated with ferns and flowers. The Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, pastor of the Bryant Park Presbyterian Church, officiated.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The illness of Representative Spinola, which has continued with varying severity almost since the adjournment of Congress, assumed an unfavorable aspect today, and the indications were that it would terminate fatally before many hours.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Because of that much abused precedent, Senatorial courtesy, the Senate failed to-day to kill the Erwin Listing bill, and after throwing it overboard and buffeting about for two hours a life-preserver was tied around it, and it was given until next Wednesday to live, when it will be discussed as a special order and then dropped into oblivion, where it belongs.

ROME, April 8. -- The Italie says that the Marquis di Rudini has renewed his instructions to Italian Consuls in the United States to counse calmness on the part of Italian residents, and that the Premier is confident that, in consequence of the departure of Baron Fava, the Federal Government will give Italy the satisfaction that is due.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 8. -- The Alliance of this State will be represented at the Cincinnati Convention by at least four hundred delegates, nearly all of whom will favor the formation of a national third party with Presidential candidates in the field.
CHICAGO, April 8. -- The official count will be necessary to determine beyond a doubt who was elected Mayor of this city yesterday. The count will be begun to-morrow.

BOSTON, Mass., April 8. -- The Harvard Overseers to-day rejected the Faculty's famous proposals for the shortening of the academic course. The matter came before the Overseers for final action in the shape of a supplementary report of the special committee on changes in the academic department and in its relations to the professional schools.

ALBANY, April 8. -- The alleged letter from, Smith M. Weed to John B. Riley, published in a sensational New-York paper to-day, furnished amusement to Mr. Weed's friends here, who promptly pronounced it a forgery before Mr. Weed was heard from. Mr. Riley, to whom the alleged letter was addressed, is at Plattsburg, and will not return to Albany before Monday.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 8. -- The Democratic Party of St. Louis yesterday won a complete and most gratifying victory over the combined forces of the Republicans and the municipal independents. The success was sweeping and emphatic, and was of such a pronounced character as to leave nothing to be desired. The triumph has a significance and a weight far beyond the mere election of the temporary standard bearers of the Democracy.

Gov. HILL has had his bill-compounder, Prof. COLLIN, draw a brand-new Excise bill, to be substituted for the liquor dealers' bill introduced by Mr. SCHAAFF. It will hardly be safe to trust the statement that this is merely a "carefully-prepared revision of the existing confused and conflicting excise laws."

The Excise Commissioners have gained very little by their escape from trial through a technicalty that had no sort of relation to the charge against them. Yesterday a new indictment was found by the Grand Jury, and it is probable that it has been framed with such care that no flaw can be picked in it.

NEWARK, April 8. -- The Democratic politicians are urging "Jim" Smith, the Essex boss and one of Gov. Abbett's Big Four, to accept the Presidency of the new City Board of Works, to which Mayor Haynes appointed him yesterday. The florid-faced manager has succeeded in getting himself talked about so much lately that he seems to think a local position important and responsible as that tendered him is beneath his dignity.

Cheers, words of praise, and a big silver punchbowl were bestowed upon the Hon. Ashbel P. Fitch, Congressman from the Thirteenth District, by his friends of the Harlem Democratic Club last night. Almost everybody in Harlem voted for Mr. Fitch last Fall, and this reception and presentation was organized partly for the purpose of mentioning that fact.

BRIDGEPORT, April 8. -- On every side to-day there is evidence of mourning for the death of P.T. Barnum. In nearly every store window and in banks and offices may be seen a likeness of the kindly face of the veteran showman, draped in black. Public buildings are draped in mourning and flags are displayed at half mast all over the city.

Steamship lines affected by the new immigration law do not seem disposed to yield ready compliance with the provisions of that act. Col Weber, the Superintendent of Immigration, refused admission to a number of passengers brought by the steamship Iniziativa. These were sent to that vessel to be returned to Italy, whence they came, and subsequently three of them made their escape.

The bridal bouquets and general decorations of the flower show at Lenox Lyceum in aid of St. Mary's Hospital for Children were viewed yesterday and awards made by the following well known ladies: Mrs. Richard Irvin, Mrs. Robert Goelet, Mrs. George W. Forsyth, and Mrs. William B. Beekman.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8. -- A New-York syndicate composed of a number of Fulton Market fish dealers is endeavoring to buy up all the shad caught in the Delaware River and thus corner the market. The syndicate is represented by Haddington Co., who do business in Fulton Market, and who have been making a tour of the different fisheries along the river, arranging the details of the scheme.

The indignation expressed by the Government and people of the Dominion at the reported discrimination of Newfoundland against Canadian fishermen is not difficult to understand. It even seemed rather singular when the Bait act of last year included Dominion fishermen under its restrictions as well as the French and the New-Englanders.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 8. -- Senator John Sherman responded to the invitation of the Republican members of the Legislature, and spent the day at Ohio's capital. Before his coming there was considerable speculation as to the outcome of the visit, some venturing the prediction that he would seize this as the opportunity to formally declare himself out of the race for a re-election to the United States Senate.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Senator Fassett's bill, which provides for the cession by the State to the National Government of jurisdiction over the land at Bowling Green, which T.C. Platt and others desire for the site of the new Custom House, was sent back to the Judiciary Committee, which reported it favorably to-day. Gen. McMahon showed the bill up in its true colors.

The Erwin bill "in relation to the assessment of real and personal property within the State of New-York," commonly known as the Listing bill, was considered in the Senate yesterday in Committee of the Whole and made a special order again for Wednesday next. This may be regarded as a typical measure for reaching personal property for purposes of assessment.

A cable dispatch from Liverpool yesterday brought news that the steamer Romulus had been seized at Coronel, Chile. She is a German vessel of 1,720 tons, and is owned by C. Anderson of Hamburg, and has been engaged in the South American trade for some time.

BOSTON, April 8. -- The annual report of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad is given out this morning. The outside system is treated independently, although in the monthly earnings reports it has been figured with the main system. The only change made is that land receipts are included in the accounts, so as to reduce the deficit for the year, as was done two years ago.

The testimony taken before the Commissioners in Ireland in the suit of Sarah Branogh against William B. Smith -- otherwise and better known as the suit of the Irish heirs of A.T. Stewart to recover a large part of the Stewart estate -- has arrived in this city, and is now in the custody of the Clerk of the United States District Court.

A certificate of incorporation of the Metropolitan College of Music was filed in Albany yesterday with the Secretary of State. Herbert W. Greene, Charles B. Hawley, Albert Ross Parsons, Dudley Buck, Harry R. Shelley, Emilio Agramonte, and George M. Greene are the Trustees for the first year.

Princeton's team met the New-Yorks again yesterday and the Giants carried off another game. The college boys, although beaten, played good ball, and the spectators were very favorably impressed with their work. In order to give all his pitchers a chance Capt. Dana made the three twirlers -- Young, Bergen, and Drake -- pitch three innings each. They each fared fairly, but the work of Young was watched with great interest.

SIMLA, April 8. -- A letter has been received here from the leader of the Manipuris declaring that Chief Commissioner James W. Quinton and all his colleagues who were taken prisoners at the time of the attack upon the British Residency at Manipur have been murdered. This news is believed here.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 8. -- Residents of Vermont are greatly surprised by the announcement of the resignation of Senator Edmunds, as he had not intimated to his most intimate friends that he contemplated such a step. Profound regret is expressed on every hand, and the opinion is freely expressed that in his retirement the State meets with a great loss.

As will be seen by our Washington dispatches, the resignation of Senator EDMUNDS has revived the rumors of the retirement from the Cabinet of the Secretary of War, Mr. PROCTOR of Vermont, to seek election to the vacant seat. It may well be that it was an intimation of Mr. EDMUNDS'S action that hurried the Secretary back from his tour of inspection upon the Pacific coast.

ALBANY, April 8. -- To-morrow the Assembly Committee on Public Lands and Forestry, which Gov. Hill hopes will make good his charges against the Forest Commission, will report for the consideration of the House the bill of the Adirondack Park Association, which Mr. Farquhar of New-York introduced March 5. The committee stood 7 to 1 in favor of this action, Mr. John Connelly of New-York being alone in his opposition to it.

BOSTON, April 8. -- An air of mystery has surrounded the forty-six-footer being built by the Herreshoffs ever since she was started. During the last two weeks this atmosphere has been thickening. It has been reported that the new craft was to have a large and curious sail plan, and that her over-all length was something tremendous.

BOSTON, April 8. -- The largest political gathering of the kind held in Boston for years was at the first dinner of the Republican Club of Massachusetts which was held in Muslo Hall this evening. Covers were laid for 810, besides the guests and speakers, and with the spectators in the gallery more than a thousand people were present.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 8. -- A Pittsburg paper this afternoon made the statement that Andrew Carnegie had come here this week to settle the coke strike. It went on to say: "Carnegie is now posing as a philanthropist and he cannot afford to have the public criticise him for permitting such serious trouble at his works, especially when men are being shot down like so many dogs.

Should everything run smoothly in the Court of Oyer and Terminer this morning the District Attorney's office will begin its crusade against the proprietors of the city poolrooms by the prosecution of the men arrested in Minden's place some days ago. The cases are set down for trial at that time unless ex-Surrogate Rollins shall be engaged elsewhere.

The Directors of the Washington National Bank are to meet to-day to prepare a statement to be submitted to the stockholders Monday. As told in yesterday's TIMES, there is now no hope among the Directors of reorganizing the bank. There is hope, however, that the loss to the stockholders will not be so great as was at first expected.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8. -- Lewis Booker, a prominent and one of the most popular business men in Richmond, was arrested to-night on warrants charging him with misappropriation of fiduciary funds belonging to the heirs of the Hannewinckle estate. It is thought that Booker's shortage will exceed $100,000. He was a member of the insurance firm of D.N. Walker Co.

The effect of the tendency in low-wage countries to adhere to old-labor processes and continue the employment of obsolete machinery is apparent when their manufactures compete with goods in the same lines produced by high-wage countries. What in other instances would be an advantage, here often becomes a disadvantage.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- President Harrison addressed the first meeting of the series to be held to celebrate the beginning of the second century of patents in the United States, in the Academy of Music this afternoon. Admission to the "public meetings," as they are called, in this celebration series is by ticket, and the tickets are sold at $5 each.

Dr. Greene of 35 West 14th St., New-York, gave another of his great course of free illustrated lectures in Chickering Hall last evening. The lecture was private to men, and the vast audience followed with closest attention the important and weighty utterances of this famous physician, whose wide experience and thorough knowledge of these subjects have made him, perhaps, the best known and most successful physician in this country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9. -- The caucus of Democratic members of the General Assembly has decided to push the Buchanan bill providing for the choice of Presidential Electors by Congressional districts. Two Democratic Senators, Howe and Lowery, oppose it, and it is believed it will not pass.

A new cable railroad bill has been substituted in the Senate for the measure which BRODSKY worked through the Assembly. From the brief summary given of its provisions, it would seem to wipe out the "securities" and many obligations heretofore issued, and all consents obtained in the past, and to require the company to start over again, after getting a new Rapid-Transit Commission to correct its articles of association.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 9. -- Almost the first proceeding before Judge Marr to-day was the arraignment of D.C. O'Malley. A great many citizens, among them a majority of those who signed the call for the mass meeting of March 14, were in court as the "private detective" stepped up to the bar.

Augustus St. Gaudens has been selected to make the designs for the statue to be erected to Gen. Sherman in this city. This was the result of the meeting of the Statue Committee held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce.

Mrs. Annie Besant, the English theosophist, socialist, and philanthropist, author of "Fruits of Philanthropy," and co-worker with the late Charles Bradlaugh, arrived yesterday on the steamship City of New-York.

Xaver Scharwenka, the prominent composer and pianist, gave an interesting concert yesterday afternoon at Behr's Hall. The interest of the afternoon centred in the performance of Scharwenka's quartet in F major for piano and strings. A good deal of pleasure is always to be obtained from hearing the works of this talented composer.

Senator Justin S. Morrill of Vermont, "the father of the Senate." was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Next Tuesday he will celebrate his eighty-first birthday, but in spite of his many years he said that he was in good health and was not suffering from the fatigues of the last session.

There are serious disadvantages in having the two branches of the Legislature, or the legislative and the executive department of the State Government, in control of different political parties. It produces a division of responsibility which often defeats important public action absolutely required by the Constitution.

I A fire broke out at 9 :Be o'clock yesterday morning ill the restaurant of I. Gordon, on tae ground floor of the wo-story and attic frame building 57 Bayard Street. It was discovered by the ]?olice, and some difficulty was experienced in roung the tenants who were fast esleep on the to floor of the house. Firemen castled four children of I. Kloth, clothing cutter, down ladders to the street.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The following is the official itinery of the tour of the President from Washington to San Francisco: On Tuesday morning, April 14, at 12:10 o'clock, he will leave Washington by the Richmond and Danville Railroad, passing through Charlottesville, Lynchburg and Roanoke, Va., and Bristol, Tenn., and then by the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad he will reach Knoxville at 5:30 P.M., where Tuesday night will be spent.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Gov. Hill's Liquor bill, which was first made public yesterday, has already gone to third reading in the Assembly. Many demoralizing exhibitions have been given by this Democratic body this year, but the one connected with the railroading of this bill easily excels all the others.

There was genuine surprise in the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday when it was announced that Naval Constructor W.L. Mintonye was to be detached and that his place was to be given to Naval Constructor Frank L. Fernald, who is now doing duty nominally at the Maro Island Navy Yard, but really at the Union Iron Works, San Francisco.

Miss Maud Jaffray, the granddaughter of Edward S. Jaffray and the daughter of Howard S. Jaffray, was married yesterday to Mr. Hollis Hunnewell of Boston, a nephew of Frederic Bronson and Egerton L. Winthrop. The ceremony took place in the house of the bride's grandfather at 615 Fifth Avenue, which had been magnificently decorated with flowers.

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 9. -- There are many persons who say that Secretary Proctor has had his eye on the United States Senatorship for a long time. Last Fall he found it convenient to be here during the session of the Legislature, and there were a good many shrewd observers outside of the machine who wondered what he was up to.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 9. -- The court of inquiry into the loss of the United States tug Triana at Cuttyhunk is still in progress at the United States torpedo station. The officers and men of the tug on watch at the time of the accident have been examined. Superintendent Kimball of the life-saving service is in attendance, as the cause of the accident is understood to be connected with the life-saving service.

The retirement of Senator EDMUNDS is doubtless a public calamity. It is an illustration of the degeneracy of our politics in general and of the Senate of the United States in particular, that it is more of a calamity now than it would have been at any former period of our history. In public life a man matures more slowly than in almost any other department and experience counts for more.

Judge Bartlett, in the Supreme Court Brooklyn, yesterday granted a writ of certiorari directing President Howell and the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge Trustees to review the proceedings which resulted in the dismissal of Bridge Policeman Warren Foster. It was on Feb. 7 that this officer was arrested in a Brooklyn street car for intoxication and disorderly conduet.

It would be interesting to know by what method of interpreting election returns Senator MORRILL reaches the conclusion that "the recent elections indicate that the sentiment has changed since the elections last Fall." The choice of city, town, and county officers in this and many other States during the last few weeks has had no relation to the McKinley tariff that ordinary political eyesight could perceive.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 9. -- The most interesting suit that has been instituted in the United States court in Connecticut for years was withdrawn this afternoon, preventing disclosures that would have disturbed many of the leading families of the State. The case was the sensation of Windham County when it was instituted in December.

The Class of '91 of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College held its graduating exercises yesterday afternoon in Chickering Hall before a big audience of parents and pretty girls. Forty-five young men had won diplomas, and as each one stepped forward to receive the precious sheepskin from the hands of Judge Bufus B. Cowing, the President of the Board of Trustees, he was greeted with tremendous applause and one or more baskets of flowers.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The Construction Corps of the navy had a general shaking up to-day. In addition to the order detaching Naval Constructor Feaster from the Maro Island Yard on account of the Alert matter, Constructor Frank L. Fernald, who will be in charge of the further repairs on that vessel, has been detached, on the completion of those repairs, and ordered to the New-York Yard, to succeed Constructor William L. Mintonye.

OTTAWA, April 9. -- In the early morning hours Sir John Thompson and the Hon. George E. Foster reached here from Washington. Their first utterances were complimentary of both President Harrison and Secretary Blaine. The two Canadian Ministers have fulfilled the Government's election campaign pledges regarding a visit to the American capital, and they can assure Parliament that the delay in negotiating a reciprocity treaty rests with the United States Government.
BALTIMORE, Md., April 9. -- The Republican State Convention, which was called to adopt a constitution for the government of the party, finished its work to-day.

ST. LOUIS, April 9. -- An Associated Press dispatch from London credits the St. James's Gazette with saying in connection with the charge that Gladstone received. American dynamiters, that Dr. O'Reilly and Mr. Atkinson of Detroit visited Mr. Gladstone while in England in 1889 as agents of Alexander Sullivan and the Irish Extremists in America.

The new law concerning immigration provides that certain "classes of aliens shall be excluded from admission." It defines these classes, and nearly all of the long eighth section relates to the inspection to which alien immigrants arriving by water at any of our ports shall be subjected.

The suit of the people against the Chicago Gas Trust Company in Illinois resembled in some respects the proceedings in this State against the Sugar Trust; but there were some important differences that should be noted. In this State the people sued for the annulment of a charter which had been granted to certain manufacturers who abused the privilege by taking their corporation into the Trust, which was not a chartered organization.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 9. -- There is rage among the Republican followers of the Journal, the party organ in Niagara County and this Congressional district, over the appointment of John A. Merritt, the Hiscock candidate for Postmaster, made to-day. The party leaders are particularly bitter and vindictive against the Senator and the Administration for its treachery, as it is called, in ignoring J.A. Ward of the Journal.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Gov. Hill has begun to put his canal machine in shape for next Fall's campaign. Thanks to the generosity of the Legislature he can start out with a fund of nearly $2,000,000. Mr. Hill means business this Fall, as his canal appointments made to-day unmistakably indicate. He is weeding out the dead brush along the line of the canal and introducing Hill shrubs.

The latest reports regarding the Farmers' Alliance show that the Sub-Treasury scheme, which was made a national issue by the convention in Florida, is dividing the members Alliance into two parties violently opposed to each other. In Mississippi, where at one time the Alliance bade fair to be a power in politics, its membership is said to have fallen off by over 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Senator Hiscock has about closed up the business that brought him here, and will go to New-York to-morrow. His opinions on The Custom House situation have been asked repeatedly, and he has expressed them guardedly, to find them in the newspapers in a form that made him appear to have undertaken the difficult feat of turning himself inside out.

Benjamin De Witt Horton, a wealthy retired dry goods merchant, one of the original organizers of the firm of T.K. Horton Co., committed suicide yesterday at his home, 67 St. James Place, Brooklyn. He arose shortly after 6 o'clock, after having passed a very restless night, and went into the sitting room, where his wife and daughter had preceded him.

ALBANY, April 9. -- The Republicans to-day were seized with a violent desire to fix a day for final adjournment. Before the session Senator Fassett held a long interview with Gov. Hill. At the close Mr. Fassett appeared in the Senate Chamber and displayed the most nervous activity in buttonholing Senators. For an hour he flitted back and forth between the Senate and Assembly Chambers like a butterfly.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 9. -- The Senate has formally repudiated the work of the Judiciary Commission which sat all last Summer and made a report recommending the retention of the Court of Appeals as at present constituted by passing the well-known Moak amendment, which was introduced in the Senate as a concurrent resolution as an amendment to the Constitution, increasing the number of Court of Appeals Judges to fifteen.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner Schultze in the case of Mrs. Hannah Whitelaw, the woman who died at the New-York Hospital from a fracture of the skull which it was charged was due to violence at the hands of her husband, a coachman named Thomas Whitelaw. The testimony showed that Whitelaw had often beaten his wife.

Jacob M. Patterson, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee, has appointed the following sub-committee to overhaul the roll of the Thirteenth Assembly District Organized Republicans: Frank Raymond, leader of the Twenty-third District; John H. Gunner, leader of the Twenty-second; John Nugent, leader of the Fourteenth; J. Thomas Stearns, leader of the Twenty-fourth Ward, and William H. Ten Eyck, leader of the Twenty-third War.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 10. -- The will of Mr. Barnum was read immediately after the funeral at Marina in the presence of the family, the executors, and representatives of the press. It took Attorney Curtis Thompson about three hours to go through the will and the eight codicils added to the original.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 10. -- The committee appointed by the Iowa Conference of the Evangelical Church of North America, now in session here, to investigate charges of disloyalty against a number of members reported to-day. The reading of the report led to a stormy debate Bishop Thomas Bowman of Chicago, leader of the so-called loyal faction of the Church, presided.

ALBANY, April 10. -- The Governor recommended to the Legislature to-day, in a message of considerable length, that the direct-tax money recently refunded to the State by the National Government be used to liquidate the outstanding bonded indebtedness of the State.

At the centennial celebration in Washington the achievements of inventive genius under the fostering care of our patent system in the last one hundred years have been surveyed and described from many points of view. Inventors, legislators, students, and administrative officers have vied with each other in pointing out the excellence of the laws and the wonderful growth of invention which has been stimulated and protected by them.
AMERICUS, Ga., April 10. -- Charles F. Crisp, prominent as a Democratic candidate for the Speakership, furnishes his answer to charges made against his record.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 10. -- The funeral of Adelbert Shaw, the Harvard student who was drowned, took place from the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. George R. Shaw, at Fishkill Village this morning. Among the many present were Capt. Perkins of the college boat club and Mr. Jenkins, his classmate, both of whom came on from Cambridge, Mass., with the remains.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 10. -- The Protestant Episcopal Council of the Diocese of Louisiana, considering the physical infirmities of Bishop John N. Gallehar, last night elected the Rev. Davis Sessums Assistant Bishop by unanimous vote.

ALBANY, April 10. -- The Senate was in no condition to do work to-day. The Republican members were feverish and restless, and as for Senator Fassett, he oscillated between the reporters, whom he abused for publishing the story of his deal with Gov. Hill, and his colleagues, whom he besought to support him in his motion to adjourn sine die on the 24th, the day set by David B. Hill.

The manifest intention of the immigration authorities to carry out to the letter the provisions of the amended Immigration act has at last awakened steamship companies to the fact that the new law is one which they cannot honor in the breach. Representatives of all lines engaged in the transport of immigrants held a meeting yesterday at the office of the Continental Congress, 19 Broadway, Col. Weber, the Superintendent of Immigration, was present by invitation.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 10. -- Anna E. Dickinson's story of the alleged cruel treatment she received at the hands of her sister Susan is regarded here as positive proof of her insanity. It is well known that for years Susan has been most devoted and self-sacrificing in Anna's interest, caring nothing for her own comfort and everything for her sister's.

The short but eventful cruise of the Galena in Long Island Sound, resulting in her wreck at Gay Head, appears to have been one of diversified interest. As though the nasty weather and the unseaworthiness of the ship were not enough unpleasantness, Capt. Smith of the Nina says that he was snubbed by Lieut. Commander Bicknell, who would not take him into his confidence.

The managers of the Chicago and Alton Railroad are, according to Associated Press dispatches from Chicago, in a very cheerful frame of mind, considering that they are to be boycotted not only by the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations, on account of their position on the passenger-commission question, but also by the Southwestern Railway and Steamship Association because of their proposed reduction in freight rates to Texas points.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 10. -- The annual report of the Department of Indian Affairs is issued. The material condition of the Indians in the seven Provinces of the Dominion is said to be of a very satisfactory character. They are as a rule self-supporting. The grip prevailed pretty generally among the Indians during the last Winter and Spring.

The four cases of malignant typhus fever which have developed in this city and vicinity during the last week have all been traced to an origin in Hamburg. James Taylor, the Scotch man who died in Bellevue Hospital last Sunday, was a recent arrival from Hamburg, as was also Fanny Goldberg, the Jewish woman who was taken from a tenement tailoring establishment at 117 Henry Street, Tuesday to North Brother Island quarantine station.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 10. -- The McHale bill to prevent women from wearing tights on the stage, which went through the Senate with such facility yesterday afternoon, was called up in the House this morning, immediately after prayers. It was first sent to the Committee on Education, and then recalled and sent to the Judiciary Committee to decide upon its constitutionality.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10. -- The story that Anna E. Dickinson was a sane woman when she was committed to the Danville Insane Asylum, and that her commitment was irregular, that the State lunacy laws were in her case flagrantly violated, and that Philadelphia physicians and officials were concerned in the injustice done her, is officially and particularly denied here.

ALBANY, April 10. -- Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce has discovered that David B. Hill is a hard master to serve. His life since he succeeded to the position which Robert A. Maxwell filled so efficiently and independently has been full of trials and tribulations.

Printed copies of the proposed amendments to the Ballot Reform act have reached the city and THE TIMES has been obtaining the opinions of ballot reformers upon them. Said Mr. Horace E. Deming, Chairman of last year's Ballot Reform League, yesterday:

SAN DOMINGO CITY, March 28. -- A special Commissioner, with power to treat on behalf of San Domingo, will leave here for New-York April 7 to conclude a reciprocity treaty with the United States on the lines laid down by Mr. Blaine and the McKinley bill.

LONDON, April 10. -- Mr. William Henry Smith, the First Lord of the Treasury, announced in the House of Commons to-day that the following gentlemen have been appointed by the Queen members of the Royal Labor Commission, which will inquire into the relations existing between capital and labor, and into the cause of strikes and the best means of preventing them:

MADISON, Wis., April 10. -- The Apportionment Committee reported to the Senate this evening. Out of 100 districts, 56 are certainly Democratic and 7 are fighting ground, with a probability of being Democratic. Under the Senatorial apportionment the work is so skillfully done that the Legislature of 1893 will stand 27 Democratic to 6 Republicans.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Within a few weeks three of the great buildings of the World's Columbian Exposition will be under way. The drawings, and specifications for the Government contractors are being prepared. Under the direction of Chief Burnham final estimates are being made on the buildings for Mines and Mining, Horticulture, and Electricity.

LONDON, April 11. -- The Telegram's correspondent at St. Petersburg says: "Shameiken, the man who was arrested Monday on suspicion of being about, to make an attempt on the Czar's life, belonged to the Scaevola Club of Kharkoff, the members of which are bound by oath to make continual efforts to murder the Czar. Most of the members of the club have since been arrested

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The Ordnance Bureau of the Navy Department has devised a hydraulic disappearing carriage for a ten-inch gun, which is claimed to be more simple in construction and less cumbersome than the pneumatic disappearing carriage. It is also much cheaper, as the pneumatic carriage requires machinery for compressing the air.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 10. -- It is now absolutely certain that the coke strike will be fought to the bitter end. This was the unanimous decision of to-day's strikers' convention. The convention was of special character, and this morning when business was begun fully eighty delegates answered to the roll call, every plant in the region having representation.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- General Passenger Agent Eustis of the Burlington Road was not a Little surprised to-day to receive a request from the Board of Rulings of the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations that he furnish that body with the names of the agents or Eastern roads to whom the Burlington has paid commissions since Feb. 1. Mr. Eustia most emphatically declined to give the desired information.

It is evident that some very crooked work has been resorted to in the bill amending the ballot act of last year, which has passed the Senate and is now in the order of third reading in the Assembly. One object in amending the law was to reduce so far as practicable the number of different ballots to be officially printed and distributed within the polling places.

A bill was reported in the Assembly at Albany yesterday which contemplates the consolidation of the Harlem Bridge, Morrisania, and Fordham Railway -- better known as the "Huckleberry Road" -- with the old and unused line of horse railway on the Southern Boulevard running from Lincoln to Boston Avenue. The consolidated road will be known as the Union Railway of New-York.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt is enthusiastic in his expressions of approval of Secretary Tracy's declaration in favor of reform methods in the selection of navy yard employes.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Representative Binger Hermann of Oregon, who was the first member elected to the Fifty-second Congress, has been talking about the political outlook to a reporter, and expresses his views with great freedom. He does not believe the defeat of the Free-Coinage bill will hurt the Republican Party.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The brief dispatch from Rome, carrying the report that a failure on the part of the United States to return at once a favorable reply to the last note of Rudini will lead to the immediate sending away from that capital of Minister Porter, and the withdrawal from Washington of all diplomatic officers from Italy, is received here with undisguised incredulity.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The decision of the Secretary of the Treasury in throwing open the existing fifteen vacancies in the grade of Third Lieutenant, Revenue Marine Service, to graduates of the six years' course at Annapolis has resulted in some twenty applications for commissions. The candidates are members of the Classes of '85, '86, and '87.

Seven men charged with having been engaged in running a poolroom in "Mike" Minden's place at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street await with a deal of anxiety the coming into court this morning of a jury of twelve men. These twelve have the fate of the seven in their hands. Their verdict of guilty may mean a fine of $2,000 or a year's imprisonment to one or more of them.

NEWARK, April 10. -- Gen. J. Madison Drake, the commander of the Veteran Zouaves of Elizabeth, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Whitehead to-day on a charge of having opened a letter addressed to Capt. James H. Corey and appropriated a check for $200, which was inclosed in it, to his own use. Capt. B.W. Hopper, an old army comrade, became surety in $1,000 for Gen. Drake's appearance for examination next Monday.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 10. -- The news that Anna E. Dickinson was at a New-York hotel, and had declared that she was not insane, but the victim of persecution, created considerable excitement at her home in Pittston to-day. Miss Susan Dickinson, her sister, was horrified at the report. As soon as she heard the story she took a train for Scranton to consult with a friend.

WASHINGTON April 10. -- The April returns to the Department of Agriculture make the condition of Winter wheat 96.9 and of rye 95.4. The season for seeding was favorable over the whole Winter wheat area, the soil was generally easily worked, the seedbed prepared with unusual care, and sowing followed by gentle rains, sufficiently to properly pack the earth and insure prompt and perfect germination.

The pamphlet by Mr. W. HALSEY WOOD, explaining the prototypes and symbolism of his Cathedral of St. John the Divine, is at once argumentative, didactic, and confusing. He more than claims originality; but at the same time he acknowledges obligations to "Early Gothic," English cathedrals, and to St. Peter's, Rome.

BALTIMORE, April 11. -- Probably the last dance of the season has been held, and with the closing strains of the waltz at Lehmann's Hall on Monday evening, when the concluding dance of the Bachelors' Cotillion Club was given, society took leave of the ballroom until the festivities of the Catonsville and Mount Washington Casinos shall open up, which will be late in June.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 11. -- The numerous fires which have occurred this week in the office of N.H. Shafer of this city and which have occasioned widespread alarm, owing to their mysterious nature, are now attributed to the action of a subtle chemical which the scientific incendiary who has not yet been discovered distributed about the place.

POOR PICTURES BY THE SHIPLOAD. -- Nearly every steamer from Italy now brings its contingent; for although the paintings are chiefly of the Dutch and Flemish schools -- which happen to be in vogue -- it is from Italy that there come just now most of these coveted but intrinsically valueless "masterpieces."

Prof. C.A. Young gave an interesting lecture on the moon last evening in the astronomical course which is being conducted under the auspices of the University Extension at Cooper Union. The audience was attentive throughout the professor's rapid summary of the peculiarities of our satellite, and looked with interest on the views of the moon's surface produced from raised maps photographed and used as stereopticon slides.

THE ELGIN MARBLES. -- Lord Elgin's original intention was simply "to procure accurate drawings and casts of the various monuments." But in the prosecution of this undertaking his artists and agents "had the mortification of witnessing the very willful devastation to which all the sculpture and even the architecture were daily exposed on the part of the Turks and travelers."

CHICAGO, April 11. -- The Board of Election Commissioners met to-day for the purpose of taking up the canvass of votes cast at the city election on Tuesday. The board first proceeded to hear evidence in the matter of the alleged misconduct of Dennis Sheehan, one of the judges of election in the Nineteenth Precinct of the Twentieth Ward.

FOREST LAWS. -- In early times, when houses were built of wood and all the ships were made of wood, and when wood formed the fuel for cooking and warmth, the cultivation of timber and the prevention of its waste were the subjects of very severe laws. From the time of Edward IV. there were enacted many statutes for the planting, securing, cutting, and ordering of woods, copses, and underwoods.

The long-expected steamship Anglia, with 155 survivors of the Utopia disaster, arrived yesterday. The vessel brought gladness to a few hearts and sorrow to others. Many friends and relatives of the victims of the disaster had assembled at the Anchor Line pier in Brooklyn -- some to welcome back the saved, others in the rain hope that the reported loss of their relatives would be disproved.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 11. -- There is to be a greatly increased interest in athletics at Syracuse University this year, and baseball, football, and lawn tennis will receive much attention. Two baseball clubs have already been formed outside of the regular team that will represent the university in the New-York State Intercollegiate League. Practice games are being played on the campus every afternoon.

Col. WEBER, the Superintendent of Immigration at this port, deserves the public thanks for his efforts to keep out undesirable immigration. It is quite natural that the steamship companies should object to being charged with judicial functions concerning passengers whose money they have collected and of whom they wish to be rid at the earliest moment.
ORANGE, N.J., April 11. -- Misses Kate and Cynthia Quimby of Oakwood Avenue gave dancing party Friday evening.

BERLIN, April 11. -- The electoral contest at Geestemunde, where Prince Bismarck's candidacy for the Reichstag is opposed by candidates belonging to the Socialist and Progressist Parties, has assumed the proportions of a great political event. The entire interest of the country centres in the result of next Wednesday, on which day the polling will take place.

Thomas Furnham, an Englishman, thirty-five years old, who says he is a carpenter and who lives at 30112 Elizabeth Street, near Bleecker, was arrested last evening by Acting Capt. Horbelt of the Tenth Precinct, charged with attempting to levy blackmail on Mr. Albert Emanuel of the firm of Gerstel Emanuel, manufacturers of bead trimmings at 63 Prince Street.

It is of no importance, the name of the little provincial city where Capt. Mercadier -- twenty-six years of service, twenty-two campaigns, and three wounds -- installed himself when he was retired on a pension.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- For the first time in the history of American fisheries a report of a successful attempt to take fish by beam trawling has been received, and its reception inspires the Fish Commission, and particularly Capt. J.W. Collins of that commission, with the hope that a new field for the development of the fisheries has been opened.

Those engaged in framing an indictment for the prosecution of the Excise Commissioners may get some interesting collateral material in regard to the methods of those officials from John Sutherland at his chophouse in Liberty Street. Mr. Sutherland has been engaged for thirty-six years in this city in providing for the inner man.
The members of the Legislature will do well to paste in their hats the following reasons why the Battery Park grab bill should be defeated:

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- It would hardly surprise any one to hear of the resignation of Provost Pepper of the university before many months have passed. There have been rumors to that effect from time to time, and it is stated on good authority that he will turn over the reins of government to another at the time of the centennial celebration of the university in 1893.

Some time ago Sir Reginald Barnwell, an English Baronet, visiting this country, directed his correspondents to send his mail to the general delivery at Baltimore. Reaching Baltimore, he went to the Post Office and inquired of the clerk at the general-delivery window if there was any mail for Sir Reginald Barnwell. After looking over the letters in the box marked "B," the clerk told him there were none.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- An expansive joint in a fourteen-inch, steam pipe in the main boiler house at the navy yard blew out about 10:50 o'clock to-day, seriously injuring Lieut. Commander Pendleton of the navy and John C. Hardester, an engine tender.

A POLYGAMOUS RACE. -- A more polygamous race can scarcely exist than the Yourouks of the Taurus. Every wife has a large family, and if it were not for the high rate of infant mortality they would increase and multiply alarmingly. A well-to-do Yourouk would think himself disgraced had he less than six or seven wives, or, more properly speaking, six or seven slaves.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore interested a large number of teachers yesterday forenoon with a lecture describing his tour through Southern France and the Pyrenees. The large lecture room of the American Museum of Natural History was comfortably filled in spite of the pouring rain. The lecture was profusely illustrated with colored lantern slides prepared from photographs collected by Prof. Bickmore during his journey.

THE CRY OF PLAGIARISM. -- We have infinitely more sympathy for the man in the pillory than for the rabble that pelt him; the one may have provoked our dislike, but the other provokes our loathing. The actual wrong that the plagiarist has committed is nothing compared to the injustice and inequality of his punishment.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 11. -- A shooting affray took place on the piazza of the Leon Hotel this afternoon between S.S. Harvey of Pensacola and J.E. Alexander of Deland. Harvey has been one of the active workers for John F. Dunn in his contest for the United States Senatorship, and Alexander is here in Call's interest.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 11. -- The assembly of the Baseball Association and Senior Class, which was held the evening of April 3, netted $60, which will be equally divided between the class and the baseball management.

During the week ending at noon yesterday there were reported at the Health Department 1,216 deaths, 703 births, and 332 marriages. This is the largest weekly mortality during the present year. It is 116 more than the preceding week, and 369 above the average for the corresponding week of the last five years. The increase is due to the prevalent malady of influenza, and the large number of deaths from pneumonia and bronchitis.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 11. -- The university reopened Tuesday after the ten days' Easter recess. About 400 students participated in the various excursions arranged by the authorities of Sibley College.

ST. LOUIS, April 11. -- Dr. E.W. Saunders, one of the most prominent physicians in this city, this evening made the startling statement that within the past three weeks he had been called to attend three cases of violent insanity, directly caused by attendance on and participation in the religious meetings of Mrs. Maria B. Woodworth, the famous female evangelist.

ROME, April 11. -- The principal topic of conversation to-day in political and official circles has been the latest report, put in circulation last evening, to the effect that unless the American Government made a very speedy reply to Premier Rudini's last note, Minister Porter would be politely requested to leave Rome and the Italian Legation would be recalled from Washington.

BEAUFORT, S.C., April 11. -- Work on the construction of the new Port Royal navy dry dock begin this month. It is expected that the first pile will be driven on the 30th inst. Nearly all the pile drivers to be used are now in Beaufort. These machines are of an improved pattern, capable of delivering forty strokes per minute.

A robust and energetic man elbowed his way into an elevated car the other morning and made for one of the cross seats, which he captured. A friend followed him, and, sitting down beside him, remarked in a half-earnest, half-jocular way: "I am surprised that a man of your usual gallantry should rush for the cross seats. Really, you ought to leave them for the ladies."

BOSTON, April 11. -- The Grand Junction Railroad crossing on Main Street, Cambridge, this morning was the scene of a very narrow escape from an accident that might have resulted in the loss of many lives.

Senator Orville H. Platt of Connecticut was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He is Chairman of the Committee on Territories. He said he saw three problems confronting the National Congress which were new in American history and a solution of which was difficult.

Mayor Grant will have a fat budget of offices to parcel out among the Wigwam's followers when Richard Croker gets back from Europe, and the Legislature has adjourned, and Gov. Hill has disposed of all the bills left in his bands by the lawmakers. It will be well along in May before Mayor Grant will begin to distribute his prizes.

BOSTON, April 11. -- In the Cambridge District Court this morning six members of the Harvard Polo Club were fined $60 each for keeping liquor nuisance. The names of the students are George D. Wells. Henry G. Barbey, Francis C. Bishop, James B. Eustice, Frank T. Griswold, and Robert T. Lawrence.

A young physician undertook, one evening recently, to act as escort to a duly chaperoned charming young woman of his acquaintance to a german in Brooklyn, at the house of a common friend. His residence and office are not far from Twenty-third Street, and he had just finished his toilet while his carriage waited at the door, when his telephone summoned him.

Initiatory to the Chancellorsville campaign the First and Sixth Corps of the Army of the Potomac advanced to the same point on the Rappahannock, below Fredericksburg, at which these troops had bivouacked before crossing at the battle of the previous December. As before, we came onto the ground by a night march, arriving at 4 o'clock in the morning, not crunching over the frozen snow as before, but in an April rain and fog.
Ensign H.A. Field concluded his testimony before the Naval Court of Inquiry yesterday. He said that the Galena and Nina stranded because the course ordered was not steered by the tug.

Mr. Willard acted at Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon and opening the parts of Lionel Leveret in the late H.J. Byron's trifling comedy called "Old Soldiers," and Dick Hazard in the old farce from the French called "My Wife's Dentist." With the evening performance Mr. Willard's first engagement in New-York, which began Nov. 10, 1890, was closed.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- Theatrical managers say that the grip or the fear of it has kept a great many people away from the theatres the last two or three weeks. Some houses have done very creditably, nevertheless. The Liliputians returned to Chicago, after a very brief absence, and repeated the success they achieved during their recent season at the Columbia.
SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 11. -- The Committee of Arrangements to receive Dr. Lamberton on his return from Europe is C. McK. Leoser, '91; W.W. Blunt, '92, and C.W. Throckmorton, '93.

James M. Lyddy, one of the shrewdest lawyers in this city, died late Friday night at the Murray Hill Hotel from the grip, with which he had been ill for about ten days. He had practiced law here for about ten years, and was widely known, as his shrewd practice had frequently brought him into positions of rather unenviable notoriety, and, in fact, kept him in such a position most of the time.

Ours is not a buffalo climate. Four survivors of that hump-backed race were brought to Golden Gate Park, and three of them died during the effort to become acclimated. No man ever heard of buffalo near the sea. Neither in Hakluyt's voyages nor in any other compilation of the log books of discoverers and navigators is there any mention of buffalo on a salt coast.

It was my intention to end the articles on Libby Prison with this, but when I come to think over my last weeks in that building I find it impossible to do so without leaving unsaid much that is necessary to complete the picture, the studies for which were indelibly burned into my memory during those most trying days.

The little tempest that is raging in a certain number of the Paris journals over the authenticity of the memoirs of TALLEYRAND is much more political than literary, though it had its origin with purely literary man. M. AULARD, the lecturer on the History of the Revolution at the Sorbonne, opened the attack in the Revue Bleue.

There is, perhaps, no matter of club ethics on which there is more pronounced difference of opinion among clubmen than the question of how far a club can properly take cognizance of the conduct of its members outside the walls of its clubhouse.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 11. -- On Thursday evening Dr. David J. Hill, President of the University of Rochester, was entertained at a banquet by the Williams Alumni Association of Western and Central New-York. Dr. Hill spoke on "Liberal Education," and, among other things, said: "I am very glad that reference has been made here to-night to a similarity between Williams and the institution which I represent.

The New-York Athletic Club revived glove contests between prize fighters at its gymnasium, 104 West Fifty-fifth Street, last evening. This is the first time in about three years that the club has publicly hired professionals to amuse its members. When she show was first announced the club was criticised for its action, but an explanation by its President, A.G. Mills, puts an entirely new phase on the whole affair.

ILLUSTRIOUS ADDITIONS TO THE FRENCH CUISINE. -- The regent himself invented the Rain a la d'Orleans, and his clever but dissolute daughter, the Duchesse de Berri, the filets de lapereau a la Berri. Then Mme. de Pompadour, who had so large a share in preparing the way for the French Revolution, invented the filets de volaille a la Bellevue for the petits soupers of the King at the chateau of Bellevue.

It is optional with the host and hostess whether wine shall or shall not appear on the dinner table. Whether it is good for it to be there or not is another question. By the word "wine," I mean the fermented grape juice and not distilled spirits Liquor or spirits designate, as a class, the alcoholic drinks, while wine is commonly applied to the non-alcoholic ones.

PARIS, March 27. -- M. Leon Gandillot is the author of the new burlesque comedy given at the Vaudeville called "Bonheur a Quatre." The play is in three acts, and with it is given the one-act play in verse the "Infidele" of M. Porto-Riche.

Who is the author of the dishonest and destructives clauses of Senator SAXTON's bill amending the Ballot act? Who wrote them or caused them to be written? Who got them inserted in the bill, and were they inserted openly, with the knowledge of Senator SAXTON, or secretly without his knowledge or full understanding!

THE STUPID MEN OF TO-DAY. -- Talleyrand, looking back, declared that he who had not lived before the French Revolution knew nothing of the charm of living. Now, however, in England at least, conversation, like letter-writing and a hundred other social joys of a quiet and leisurely age, is fled, and in their place we have telegrams, slang, and slovenliness.

CHARLOTTEVILLE, Va., April 11. -- On Saturday night, March 28, Mr. R. Spratt Cockrell of Florida was elected President of the Jefferson Society for the final term, beginning April 4. This honor has long been considered the highest that the students could confer on one of their fellows, and has been the prize for which every man ambitious of popularity and distinction has aimed.

NEW-HAVEN, April 11. -- Lieut. Charles A.L. Totten, military instructor at Yale University, author of notable publications on the identity of our race with the Hebrew race, discoverer of the exact date of Joshua's long day, and reader of Scriptural prophecy, now submits an "ominous exegesis" based on Scriptural texts, in which, by a mathematical computation, he has arrived at a prediction that the end of the world will come in March, 1899.

To appreciate the value of these letters one should know the writer's personal history. Emily Osborn was the only surviving daughter of that Admiral Byng who, for naval services rendered to England, was created Viscount Torrington, and who had the further distinction of being the father of fifteen children.

Every new report that the secret of photographing natural colors has at last been discovered is apt to be received by photographers generally with more or less skepticism. There are those of the craft who believe in the ultimate accomplishment of that result, which has been so assiduously striven for ever since the discovery of photography.

The second annual meeting of the New-York State Roads Improvement Association will be held at Jermain Hall, North Pearl Street, Albany, April 15, at 10 o'clock A.M. The meeting will be devoted to a general discussion of the matter of road improvement, but in order to insure systematic procedure the general subject has been divided into three parts, to be taken up at the pleasure of the meeting.

THE SILENT HOST. -- It was the dislike that Kinglake had to hearing his name given out before a crowd that led him to go early to parties; he was generally the first guest to arrive at a dinner. He told the following story of himself very amusingly. He had been invited to dine with Mrs. Sartoris soon after her marriage and before he had made the acquaintance of his friend's husband.

The Spring bull campaign has opened in good shape. The whole list, with but few exceptions, has had a strong upward turn; led in the railroad stocks by Burlington, and in the industrials by Sugar. The people who sold short during the dreary month of March, expecting to make a brownstone house out of every thousand shares sold, were desperately frightened.

LOUISVILLE, KY., April 11. -- The Kentucky Constitutional Convention to-day completed its work and adjourned, after being in session 199 days. It has cost the State about $200,000 and made very many changes in the old fundamental law. Some of these are recognized as wise, but many are untried and are considered of uncertain benefit.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, April 11. -- Rutgers College opened Wednesday, and President Scott announced that Prof. W.B. Scott of Princeton would devote four hours each week to teaching geology to the Seniors. He gave his first lessons this week, and occupies the chair made vacant by the resignation of Prof. Patton.

Several months ago we called attention to the peculiar case of a Grand Jury in Herkimer County refusing to indict a violator of the law simply because local sentiment seemed to sustain his conduct. It was the case of a dentist who persisted in practicing without being registered as required by law, against whom the State Dental Society had proceeded.

Vice President Morton called at the Custom House yesterday morning. Collector Erhardt was not in his office, however, an attack of grip keeping him away from business, and Mr. Morton's stay in the Government building was a short one.

BALTIMORE, April 12. -- A bill in equity has been filed against the Baltimore Equitable Society for insuring houses against loss by fire. It asks for the appointment of a receiver to distribute the surplus of the corporation, and, if it shall be found that the corporate life of the society has ended, that the receiver be empowered to distribute all the funds among its members.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 13. -- The Grand Jury, in its forthcoming report upon the Hennessy murder, the subsequent miscarriage of justice, and the wreaking of popular vengeance upon the Italian suspects in the Parish Prison, will for the first time, probably, give to the public the confession of Manuel Politz.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., April 12. -- During the next two weeks the entire estate of Charles R. Colwell, of Weymouth, will pass into the hands of a syndicate of capitalists of New York City. Articles of agreement between the syndicate and Mr. Colwell were filed in the Clerk's office here during the past week.

ALBANY, April 12. -- If Mr. Fassett attempts to-morrow night to force through Gov. Hill's proposition to adjourn on April 24, the Senate promises to witness a scene to be remembered. Five Republican Senators are known to be solidly opposed to the scheme, Coggeshall, Erwin, Donaldson, Richardson, and Sloan. If Senator Sheard has sufficiently recovered from his illness his voice is likely to be added to those who discountenance Fassett's deal with Hill.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 12. -- When Nelson P. Reed died a few days ago, United States Senator Quay lost his good right hand. The death of Mr. Reed is indeed likely to change the whole face of Republican politics in Western Pennsylvania, if not in the State at large.

Statesmen, philosophers, and moralists will be profoundly interested in the provisions of the Substitute Excise bill reported from Mr. EARL'S Assembly committee last Wednesday and ordered to a third reading on Thursday. The "demands" of any class or group in the community are always interesting when frankly, fully, and carefully formulated, and this measure, though not abounding in frankness, seems to be a full and painstaking exposition of the present needs of the liquor sellers.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, March 21. -- The Omaha sailed from Yokohama March 9 for Panama. On the day of sailing the flag of Rear Admiral Belknap was saluted with thirteen guns and hauled down. At the same time a salute of thirteen guns was fired from the Alliance as the Admiral hoisted his flag on board that vessel.

Senator Joseph R. Hawley made a long address before the Hartford Board of Trade Friday on the subject of coast defense. "If Great Britain saw fit to attack us," he said, "she would doubtless assemble her fleet at Halifax. This is about 420 miles from Boston, or a thirty-five-hour run. What could we do in such a short time as that?

Secretary PROCTOR, in his tour of the Western posts, reached Gen. MCCOOK'S department just as nine Apaches had been seized and put in irons at San Carlos. They were charged with murder, and some of them with aiding KID, the notorious outlaw, whose comrades have been thinned out by conflicts with the troops until, if any at all survive, there can be only a few of them left.
