SYRACUSE, April 12. -- Preparatory to the opening of the canals, which will occur May 1, the political end of the business is undergoing extensive alterations, with the ultimate view of controlling the organization in every canal county in the State in the interest of Gov. Hill and the canal ring, of which he is the head.

ALBANY, April 12. -- There are two alleged Freedom of Worship bills now in the possession of the Senate Judiciary Committee. One is the original measure of 1885, notoriously drawn in the interest of Catholic priests who wished to control the House of Befuge on Randall's Island and similar institutions. It appears this year with the name of Mr. Blumenthal of New-York attached to it. It passed the House last Thursday by a large majority.

A worthy successor of the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Street Railroad scheme has come to light under the name of the Fiftieth Street, Astoria Ferry, and Central Park Railroad Company. The promoter of the one is the promoter of the other, at least one of his present associates was in the previous deal, and the objects of both schemes seem to possess many striking points of similarity.

Senator SAXTON has made a curious and inexplicable compromise between his personal convictions and the exigencies of his legislative situation. Speaking of the Ballot act amendments, he says: "I am decidedly in favor of adjusting the question of independent nominations so that they may be made as easily as possible.

There is more than a possibility that nearly every poolroom in this city will be shut up today. The room keepers are thoroughly demoralized. They have abandoned entirely the bravado and bluster assumed by them when, four weeks ago, THE TIMES exposed their gambling dens and called upon the police to shut them up.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Whenever a paragraph gets into print that asserts a lack of agreement between the President and his Secretary of State on reciprocity, rules of order in the House of Representatives, or diplomacy, it follows, as night follows day, that a denial goes to the country for the Secretary of State with assurance that the President and Mr. Blaine are co-operating most cordially.

Our Republican contemporaries continue to find glaring defects in PORTER'S so-called census. The New-York Tribune's special correspondent in California points out some astounding errors in the census report on truck farming. For example, it was stated that there were only 590 acres of potatoes in the State, although one farmer in Los Angeles County has 640 acres.

When the Cunard steamship Etruria made fast to her pier yesterday Capt. Hains, the venerable Commodore of the line, completed his five hundred and first voyage across the Atlantic. Capt. Hains has had an eventful career. Born in Plymouth, England, his acquaintance with the sea began in 1838, when, as an apprentice, he joined the City of Adelaide of London. His apprenticeship was served on that vessel.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 12. -- Great preparations are being made by Storer Post, No. 1, G.A.R., for a reception and Colonial party, in the costume of that period, to be held Thursday afternoon and evening, April 30, upon the frigate Constitution, now at the Portsmouth Navy Yard.

ALBANY, April 12. -- Senator Saxton, the father of the ballot-reform law, takes exception to the statements of Horace E. Deming, Chairman of last year's Ballot-Reform League, and Henry R. Beekman, printed in THE TIMES yesterday, that the amendments to the law recently adopted by the Senate, and now in the House, constitute a most dangerous attack upon the cause of ballot reform.

Our Washington dispatches this morning describe the organization by which the campaign of education, in regard to the tariff issue, is to be carried on during the next year. The immediate chief in the work will be the Hon. Mr. WILSON of West Virginia, one of the most accomplished, able, and highly trained of the Democratic leaders, and the task could not have been placed in better hands.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 12. -- The Southwestern shortage in the hay crop is making itself felt here in a peculiar way. Agents from Omaha, St. Joseph, Kansas City, and St. Louis are in the Twin Cities buying every straw of hay they can get at the prevailing price, $7.50 per ton, and it is learned that their operations have not been confined to the two cities.

LONDON, April 12. -- Money was easy early in the week, but tightened on successive withdrawals of gold for Germany, amounting to 450,000, together with 200,000 going on Monday. The Last Bank of England returns of diminished reserve, combined with the effinx of bullion abroad, renders an early advance of the bank rate exceedingly probable. Discount hardened during the week and was quoted at 2 1/2 for three months and 2 for short.

PITTSBURG, April 12. -- Mr. Andrew Carnegie is here on business connected with the Pittsburg Free Library Building, for which he will donate $2,000,000. Once Mr. Carnegie was refused admission to the Allegheny Free Library, and although young in years, the affair annoyed him so much that he rushed into print, and finally conceived a desire to become a newspaper man.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 12. -- Two or three conferences have been held here recently with President Baskette of the Chattanooga and Augusta Railroad by Eastern capitalists, but owing to the closeness with which the meetings were guarded it has been impossible to get the precise results. At a conference held secretly at Atlanta last week the plan of a grand system began to show its development.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- From week to week since Mr. J.N. Huston of Indiana became Treasurer of the United States, with the announcement that he only accepted the place because it would demand so little of his personal attention that he could devote most of his time to his affairs at Connellsville, the newspapers here contained paragraphs intimating his speedy resignation.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The National Association of Democratic Clubs proposes to take a very active part in the campaign of education, which met with such great success last year, and which is to be carried on with more vigor than ever this year and next.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- Startling developments are expected in the coming eight-hour strike, which is to be inaugurated on May 1 under the direction of the American Federation of Labor. The miners of the largest coal-producing regions in this States are not unanimous on the question of striking, and a movement is on foot to withdraw the miners of this State from the number of those who are to be called out.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Not until Sergeant at Arms Valentine of the Senate had been in office several months was the national flag displayed upon the National Capitol at any other time than when the Senate or House of Representatives was in session. Convening of either house of Congress was the signal for raising the flag over its wing of the Capitol, and the moment an adjournment was taken the flag was lowered.

HENDERSON, N.C., April 12. -- Col. W.H.S. Burgwyn runs a private bank at this place. In the course of business he advanced the Henderson Tobacco Company $16,000. This firm was composed of Herbert Jenkins and John M. Shelby. Without the knowledge of Burgwyn, Jenkins and Shelby made away with nearly all the property of the firm and fled to Georgia.

The Indigo Print Liar has been brought out to take the place of the Great American Tin-plate Liar, who is a little tired, and he is crossing the country at a rapid rate, writing articles for Republican newspapers, and whispering into the ears of after-dinner speakers at Republican club banquets, all the while representing that the passage of the McKinley bill has caused a great drop in the price of indigo prints.

For the construction of mare's nests there is no mind like the solemn, argumentative mind of the British essayist. The London Economist has discovered that if we do not shortly amend our Constitution so as to give the Federal Government control of criminal prosecutions arising from the claims of foreigners in this country we shall have a series of "sterile wars" on our hands.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 12. -- When the ballot is had in the National Democratic Convention next year and the name of Kentucky is called, the Chairman of the Kentucky delegation will respond: "Twenty-six votes for Grover Cleveland." Not since the death of Henry Clay has any man had such complete possession of the confidence of the masses of this State as the ex-President.

Mr. Chittenden's recent magazine papers on topics connected with the Administration of Lincoln have called forth many requests for their expansion. In yielding to these appeals he has produced the present elaborate record of a period concerning which he saw so much and of which he formed a conspicuous part.

ALBANY, April 12. -- "They're mostly amateurs," said a veteran Capitol attache to-day, with reference to the persons who compose the lobby in Albany this year. He had been indulging in reminiscences, and could not conceal his contempt for the present representatives of the third house. "There's lots of 'em," he continued, "but they don't do business as the old crowd used to."

Saturday night the German comedians from Munich bade adieu to America after a sojourn of five months, part of which was passed in this city at the Amberg Theatre. They have been under the management of Gustav Amberg, while their leader and stage director is Max Hofpauer. Great has been the pleasure furnished by these actors and actresses to German-Americans, more especially to those of middle age to whom German is more easy than English.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 12. -- It was learned to-day that there was a very sensational scene yesterday evening at the meeting of the creditors of the defunct United States Savings Bank. The meeting was with locked doors, the scheme being to put one of the ex-officials of the bank, which failed a month ago, in charge of its affairs as receiver. Almost the entire stock of the bank is owned in Boston and Philadelphia.

With a loss of a part of their fees, the pension claim agents at Washington seem to have lost their wits. With grotesque disregard for the popular disapproval of the enormous expenditures of the Fifty-first Congress and for the impending exhaustion of the surplus revenue, the newspaper organ of these attorneys demands the enactment of additional pension laws that would require the expenditure of at least two billions!

The Brooklyn Jockey Club people do not propose to be behind their rivals in putting their track in prime condition for the coming racing season, and improvements are now in progress which will add greatly to the accommodation of the public. The grand stand is already large enough to accommodate the crowds that visit the track, except on extraordinary occasions, such as Brooklyn Handicap Day or Memorial Day.

It is a curious muddle in which the Canadian reciprocity business has involved some of the notabilities in politics on either side of our northern border. The negotiations which were agreed to by both parties, and which Sir CHARLES TUPPER made two journeys from Ottawa to Washington to open, have now been postponed to the 12th of next October.

TRENTON, April 12. -- The limit of time allowed Gov. Abbett to dispose of the bills left on his hands at the adjournment of the Legislature will expire with this week. By Saturday next every bit of the Winter's legislation will have to be on file with the Secretary of State, which makes it law, or in the State Library, which is equivalent to an irrevocable veto.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Chicago this evening suffered one of the most destructive conflagrations that have occurred here since the big fire of 1871. The loss is about $788,000. It was at almost the exact geographical centre of the city that the flames started, and like the terrible disaster twenty years ago they began in a stable.

As had been expected, the Yew-York Presbytery yesterday placed the stamp of its official recognition on the controversy that has been going on over the utterances of the Rev. Dr. C.A. Briggs, Professor of Biblical Theology at the Union Theological Seminary in this city. A committee of seven was appointed to investigate the matter of Dr. Briggs's inaugural address on "The Authority of Holy Scriptures."

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Since the return of Secretary Proctor yesterday morning, there has been great desire to obtain some authoritative statement from him concerning the rumor that he was about to resign for business reasons, and also whether or not he would consent to be a candidate for the Senate to succeed Senator Edmunds.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 13. -- Two sleeping coaches, the Ramulus and Vallejo, running between the city of Mexico, San Antonio, and Washington, D.C., via the Mexican National Railroad, reached here yesterday in a dilapidated condition. The Mexican train to which they were attached passed through a cyclone and hailstorm near Torreon, Mexico, Saturday night.

Ex-Congressman George W.E. Dorsey of Nebraska has been in New-York for two or three days at the Westminster Hotel. He has the grip. He told a Times reporter that he was in Montpelier, Vt., when the news of Senator Edmunds's resignation was received, and that it caused great surprise among all Vermont people.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 13. -- Count Reinhold A. Lewenhaupt died suddenly at his home, 1,017 Adams Street, in this city, shortly after 6 o'clock this morning. His illness was short and no one outside of his immediate family was aware that his life was in peril until the sad news of his death was announced. Dr. Bullock, the physician in attendance, states that Count Lewenhaupt had been indisposed for the past two or three weeks.

The gratifying success of the Association of Working Girls' Societies was celebrated with enthusiastic spirit by 2,000 young women in the large hall of Cooper Union last night. It was the seventh annual meeting of this interesting federation, and the facts and figures presented in the annual reports showed that much progress had been made in the past year.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Gen. F.B. Spinola died at 1:25 o'clock this morning after an illness which had lasted several weeks. His condition had so improved during the last few days that his friends had begun to entertain some hope of his recovery.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Mr. Ward of Albany, representing the minority of the House Committee on Excise, attempted to present in the Assembly to-night the minority report on the Hill Liquor bill which is now on the order of third reading. Mr. Ward is a meek gentleman, and the Speaker squelched him with the greatest of ease.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Mr. J.N. Huston of Indiana has at last retired from the burden of contradicting newspaper reports that he is about to resign the office of Treasurer of the United States. He has felt called, upon to do so much of this denying since he took the office that it has filled up a good portion of the time he has been able to spare from his private affairs.

NYACK, April 13. -- Fruit raisers in Rockland County and at other points along the Lower Hudson are elated over what they believe to be the unusually bright prospect for large crops this year. The weather has been so steadily cold during the Spring that the buds on fruit trees are not nearly so far advanced as they were last year, consequently they have not been injured by the frost.

ROME, April 13. -- Premier di Rudini, in an interview to-day in regard to the Dreibund, held that the renewal of the triple alliance was of secondary importance as compared with a constant agreement with England. On many occasions, said the Premier, the policy of the Dreibund harmonized perfectly with British ideas, yet Lord Salisbury, for special reasons, had never adhered to the Dreibund treaty.

Henry M. Stanley said last night that blackmailing on a big scale had been attempted recently, with King Leopold of Belgium and himself as the intended victims. It would not work, he said. This declaration Mr. Stanley made while speaking of some bitter charges made against King Leopold's government of the Congo State by Col. George W. Williams in "an open letter to Leopold II., sovereign of the independent State of Congo."

Having enjoyed among themselves for several days the disclosure of their latest tariff job -- the unforeseen imposition of a double duty on a large part of the carpet wool used in this country -- the three political shepherds in Ohio are beginning to write to the papers about it. Ex-Controller LAWRENCE uses the pen, while his two associates help him with suggestions.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- It is a sorry outlook for the meeting of the Advisory Board of the Western Traffic Association, which takes place tomorrow. All present indications are that the Gould lines will not be represented at the meeting. Jay Gould and his party are supposed to be in the vicinity of Fort Worth, Texas.

The Brooklyn Aldermen refused point blank yesterday to put up at public auction the franchise for laying conduits through which to supply houses, markets, and office buildings with cold air. This franchise was granted to ex-Sheriff Rhinehart and John Guilfoyle a week ago, and not a cent was asked for it. Then Lawyer Butcher, on behalf of a rival refrigerating company, waited on Mayor Chapin and told him that the franchise was worth $100,000.

In viewing the attempt of the elevated railroad to grab Battery Park there are several important considerations to be kept in mind. The company says it wants the park because only by using it can it get a loop at the southern end of the road and so facilitate transit.

The attention of the health authorities was called yesterday by Superintendent Ludlam of the New-York Hospital to a fatal case of what is believed to have been typhus fever. The patient was a homeless and friendless Hungarian, who had been in this country but two months, and who doubtless brought the infection with him from abroad, probably from Hamburg.

The new Supervising Architect of the Treasury, Mr. ERDBROOK of Chicago, does not seem to be known very extensively, even in his own city, by the buildings he has designed. It does seem, however, that he has an extensive experience in the administration of public works, and this ought to be of value to him in his new office.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission to-day decided the case of the Delaware State Grange of the Patrons of Industry against the New-York, Philadelphia and Norfolk Railroad Company, the Delaware Railroad Company, the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad Company, and the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in favor of the complainants.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 13. -- A unique and interesting phase of the State rights question has just been presented in a correspondence which has taken place between Gov. Tillman of this State and Secretary of the Interior Noble. The subject of the correspondence is the division of the State's share of the Federal appropriation for mechanical and agricultural colleges.

The so-called Freedom of Worship bill which was rushed through the Assembly last Thursday was not the measure originally introduced by Mr. BLUMENTHAL upon which a hearing had been given, but a substitute reported by the Committee on Revision, and substantially the old bill of 1885 over which there was a strenuous contest in the Assembly after it had been hastily passed by the Senate.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- F.J. Miner, a smooth-bucket-shop man, doing business at 119 Chamber of Commerce Building, has folded his tent like the Arabs and silently stolen away, much to the regret of a large number of gentlemen who have been doing business with him.

A citizens' movement to assist the authorities in working out the street-cleaning problem was definitely submitted to official and popular approval yesterday by the visit of a committee to Mayor Grant in the afternoon, and addresses by Mrs. Richard Irvin and Mrs. Francis P. Kinnicutt in the evening at the meeting of the NewYork Association of Working Girls' Societies at Cooper Union.

Meanwhile, since the feeling of respectful patriotism is common to the people of the whole country, it is hardly possible to avoid considering the political significance of the President's journey. Apart from the interested or disinterested zeal for a high tariff, there is absolutely only one sentiment of any great force in the Republican Party, and that is, to use a mild term, distrust of the people of the South.

There is not the slightest doubt that President HARRISON, in his Southern trip, will be everywhere received with the utmost cordiality and that every practicable manifestation of respect will be made. That the people of the South will honor the office without regard to the man who holds it is undoubtedly true, but they will give no sign of drawing such a distinction.

The Methodist ministers of Cincinnati took action at their meeting yesterday morning toward preventing the American Association from playing games of baseball in the city on Sundays. A committee was appointed to ask the Mayor to co-operate in enforcing the law against Sunday games. From the present outlook, Kelly's team is going to have a hard time of it.

Mayor GRANT has a Park Commissioner to appoint, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of WALDO HUTCHINS. The Mayor can make an appointment for politics, or an appointment for the parks and the public -- a good appointment, a passable appointment, or a bad one. We are inclined to think he will make a good appointment.

Samuel Fisher, the manager of "Mike" Minden's poolroom at 33 West Twenty-ninth Street, was taken over from the Tombs early yesterday morning, and was one of the first to put in an appearance in the Court of Oyer and Terminer when the courtroom doors were opened. A host of poolroom proprietors and employes were in the room with the veteran "Pete" De Lacy at their head.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 13. -- The reported al poinmenof E. tL Nebeeker, to sucoeed J. N. Huston as Treasurer of the United States, has created genulno surprise among the President's friends here, ad hey confess that they cannot understand it. The appointee has never been prominent in S1;at pollgios 5cl is hardly known outside of ountain County, in which he servedas Auditor some years ago.

The Union Ferry Company's application for a renewal of its franchise and the curious appraisal put on its property have resulted in litigation. Mayor Grant and the other members of the Sinking Fund Commission were served with a temporary injunction yesterday restraining them from offering for sale or selling the franchise now held by the Union Company, including those under which the South, Hamilton, Wall, Fulton, and Catharine Street Ferries are operated.

The return of Mr. and Mrs. Kendal, after their second profitable tour of American cities, was cordially welcomed at Palmer's Theatre last evening by an audience that nearly filled the house. The capable British players look as well as ever, and their acting does not inspire new comment. The play was "The Weaker Sex," a well-constructed, gracefully-writ ten comedy by Arthur W. Pinero that lacks a rational motive. Sentimentality dominates in "The Weaker Sex."

After a decidedly uninteresting game the New- Yorks defeated the Metropolitans yesterday. The work of the New-Yorks was of a grand character, but their opponents were lamentably weak, both at the bat and in the field, and on that account failed to repay the spectators for their journey to the grounds.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 13. At the opening of the Joint Democratic Caucus to-night, ninety- seven out of ninety-nine members were present.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 13. -- This city to-day suffered a great loss by fire, which occurred in the centre of the business portion. The burned buildings, the two most prominent in Broad Street, were the Arcade and the First National Bank. The Arcade was owned by ex-Congressman Amos Clark, and contained the Post Office.

The members of the Democratic Club celebrated the anniversary of the birth of Thomas Jefferson last night at the clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue, by a banquet. This banquet was given, not by the club itself, but by individual members of it, Thomas O. Bell and J.M. Levy having the matter in charge. The distinctive feature of the evening was the speech of ex-President Grover Cleveland.

As the end of the first session of the Billion Congress drew nigh and proof of great extravagance began to appear, the most influential Republican journals began to shiver and shake and to utter solemn warnings. If they had foreseen the billion what a chattering of teeth there would have been. But they saw enough to make them very blue, and they poured out good advice and dire predictions by the column.

LONDON, April 13. -- Ten thousand of the striking miners assembled to-day to protest against the action of the authorities in prohibiting a meeting which had been planned. The police attempted to disperse them, and met with so stubborn a resistance that the military were summoned. Even then the strikers were dispersed with difficulty, many of all concerned in the riot being injured. About a score of the rioters' leaders were arrested.

LONDON, April 13. -- A sensation has been caused in social circles throughout England by the fact that a warrant has been issued for the arrest of Capt. Edmund Hope Verney, member of Parliament for North Buckinghamshire, on a disgraceful criminal charge. The offense was committed last Autumn, Capt. Verney giving the name of Wilson.

Thirty years ago it was said by a distinguished Democrat who violently dissented from the policy which the Federal Government was then pursuing with some vigor toward the States in rebellion that the traveler through the Southern States would find men sitting on stumps by the roadside who knew more about the Constitution of the United States than the most experienced constitutional lawyer at the North.

An attachment against the Palisades Amusement and Exhibition Company has been secured in the Supreme Court by James A. Bailey, as surviving partner of Barnum Bailey, in a suit to recover $5,000. It is charged that the Palisades Company agreed to rent from Barnum Bailey "Montezuma; or, the Conquest of Mexico," for $20,000 for six months previous to Oct. 31, 1891.

" Brannigan's Morgue" will probably not be the new home of the Sixth Judicial District Court. The court is now at Eighteenth Street and Fourth Avenue, but will have to move May 1. The Sinking Fund Commissioners had to find a new place, and Edward P. Hagan thought that the old "Brannigan's Morgue" property, so called because of the bad whisky sold there, would be a good place for the court.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Upon the recommendation of the Civil Service Commission, with the hearty concurrence of the Secretary of the Interior and the Commissioner of Indian Affairs. President Harrison has ordered the classification under the civil service of the school Superintendents, their assistants, school teachers, physicians, and matrons in the Indian service, as intimated in THE TIMES of to-day.

The first session of the sale by Bangs Co., yesterday afternoon, of the Francis W. Doughty collection persuaded the coin dealers that their shop prices are too low. They found bargains, of course. An auction sale without bargains would not be an auction sale. But the dealers themselves, and for their own account, paid higher prices than they have made their customers pay, for the greater number of valuable pieces in the Doughty collection.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14. -- Winemakers of the west side of Santa Clara Valley have formed an association to secure better prices for their output. They will erect a cellar, winery, and distillery, in which they will handle the wines of members who have no facilities of their own. They will establish agencies here and in the East and will deal directly with consumers and retailers.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Ordnance Bureau of the Navy Department has drawn up a revised table showing the number of guns of all calibres to be carried on all the vessels of the new navy thus far built and building. The totals show that when these vessels are all in commission the United States will have a strong array of guns of all calibres.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 14. -- A secret conference of the active leaders of the Iowa Farmers' Alliance was held here to-day. Two matters were considered -- the advisability of naming a candidate for Governor to recommend to the Republican State Convention, and to see what steps are necessary to hold the present membership of the Alliance from the encroachments of the new organization, which is rapidly absorbing the old.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- The Provision market had the announcement from the yards that Hogs were 10@ 15c higher. Nobody was surprised when product started off at something of an advance. The market proved a dull one. At the close all sorts of product was exactly were it was Monday night. July Pork opened at $13.20 and closed at $13.10, July Lard at $7.17, closed at $7.15; July Ribsat $6.70 and closed at $6.62.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 14. -- Col. George Washington Williams, whose alleged blackmailing charges against King Leopold of Belgium and Henry M. Stanley in connection with the affairs of the Congo Free State are given in to-day's TIMES, is well known in this region. He came here first in 1880, making Republican speeches in the Presidential campaign, being heralded as the eloquent colored lawyer and orator of Cincinnati, Ohio.

The United States Army Board on Magazine Arms met yesterday morning at the Army Building, with Gen. August V. Kautz, Col. Robert H. Hall, Major George W. McKee, and Capt. Stanhope E. Blunt present. Capt. Freeman, another member of the board, is ill in Washington, and Capt. Anderson, the remaining member, is now Superintendent of the Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The fifteen heirs of John Guy Vassar will receive about $50,000 apiece from his estate under the decision of the Court of Appeals to-day. The Trustees of Vassar College just saved the bequest to that institution by compromising with the heirs before the case reached the Court of Appeals.

The Old Guard will celebrate its sixty-fifth anniversary Wednesday, April 22, by attending services in St. Thomas's Church, Protestant Episcopal, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, at 3:30 o'clock in the afternoon. Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band will play "The Star-Spangled Banner," and this will be followed by the evening services of the Episcopal Church.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 14, via Galveston. -- Statistics published by the Mexican Financier show that the United States is annually buying 80 per cent. of all Mexican exports outside of precious metals, and including precious metals over 66 per cent. The United States sends Mexico yearly $24,000,000 worth of goods, which constitute 56 per cent. of the imports of the country.

Mrs. Ann Lockwood, the wife of Jesse Lockwood of Purdy Station, Westchester County, died yesterday morning from the effects of an assault made on her by her husband last Thursday. He is seventy and she was sixty-five years old, and for twenty years they have been married and lived peaceably together.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Newspapers which have arrived here from Rio show that the inauguration of the first constitutional President of Brazil was a very simple but impressive ceremony. Three printed copies of the new Constitution were brought into the Chamber of Deputies Feb. 24, and signed by the 226 Senators and Deputies present.

PATERSON, N.J., April 14. -- The Republican victory in this city yesterday was unexpectedly sweeping in size and character. Nathan Barnert, who was elected Mayor six years ago by a good majority, and was again elected two years ago by a majority of 72, was this time snowed under by a majority of 486. The successful candidate is Thomas Beveridge, a coal dealer in the southern part of the city.

It now looks as though the open running of poolrooms in this city was a thing of the past. The sentencing of one violator of the law to three months in the penitentiary and $1,000 fine, coupled with the vigorous orders of Inspector Byrnes to Police Captains and Inspectors, telling them to close all poolrooms in the city or be held personally responsible, has had its effect.
ALBANY, April 14. -- Superintendent James F. Pierce of the State Insurance Department has presented his report to the Legislature, from which the following extracts are made:

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14. -- A great deal of interest is felt here in the quo-warranto proceedings which were instituted at New-Haven this afternoon in the interest of Judge Morris. Gov. Bulkeley remained at the Capitol with his executive secretary through most of the afternoon in order that the papers in the case might be served without trouble should the New-Haven Sheriff arrive during business hours.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 14. -- The Presidential train arrived at Roanoke, Va., at 8:50 o'clock this morning, having made the run from Washington on exact schedule time. There were no special incidents on the route. A brief stop was made at Blue Ridge, where a crowd gathered at the station and enjoyed the spectacle of the Chief Magistrate of their country and his family at breakfast.

PITTSBURG, April 14. -- The Presbytery of Allegheny, which is one of the largest of the Presbyterian denomination in Pennsylvania, to-day took up the case of Dr. Briggs, of the Union Theological Seminary, and without a dissenting vote called upon the General Assembly to act. The Presbytery is holding its Spring meeting and has an unusually large attendance.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The far-famed New-York Giants had to lower their colors to-day. They made a gallant struggle, however, but defeat was inevitable, and they were forced to succumb to it. It wasn't a championship contest, but defeat in any form is an unpleasant factor in the Giants' career and they did not take kindly to it. About 4,000 persons witnessed the game.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 14. -- A Russian war ship, belonging to the volunteer fleet fitted out by popular subscription, has been stopped by the Turkish authorities on duty at the Dardanelles. The Russian vessel was proceeding through that passage on her way to Vladivostock, Asia, near the northern limit of Corea, on the Sea of Japan.

Doubtless if any person of high taste were asked what is worse than a composition by Liszt he would answer, "Two composition by Liszt." What, then, is to be said of a piano recital, with a programme of twelve Liszt pieces? Such a recital was given yesterday afternoon at Music Hall by Arthur Friedheim, and it is not too much to say that after the first number all was vanity and vexation of spirit.

The seventh annual meeting of the Association of Working Girls' Societies, held at Cooper Union on Monday evening, was a very noteworthy event. This meeting becomes every year a more important factor in the life of New-York. The formal "proceedings" of the assembly may not have been especially suggestive or interesting, but that does not really much matter.

Is Austin Corbin reaching out after the Union Ferry franchises and properties as an addition to his Long Island Railroad system? Is he the person in interest behind the McClave injunction suit? Though the facts intimated have not been clearly established, there are several people in New-York and Brooklyn who profess to believe that this is a fact.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- At the meeting of the Cricketers' Association of the United States in this city to-night an important step was taken in the adoption of a resolution approving a proposition to arrange a series of games between the cities of Detroit, Chicago, and Pittsburg for the West, and Boston, New-York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore for the East, the series to be played for the national championship.

The remonstrance addressed to Bishop Potter, which is directed against the liberal practices of the Rev. R. Heber Newton and the Rev. W.S. Rainsford, and to whose preparation and circulation among the Episcopal clergy THE TIMES was the first to call attention some weeks ago, has not created a profound impression. It contains the signatures of upward of one hundred clergymen and fifty laymen of this vicinity.

The Nineteenth Century Club entertained itself and its friends last evening in the assembly rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Rev. Howard MacQueary, the alleged heretic who has been expelled from the Protestant Episcopal Church, delivered an address on "The Religious Problem." A discussion followed the address, in which Rabbi G. Gottheil and Mr. Raymond S. Perrin, Vice Presidents of the club, took part.

The letter of Mr. HARRISON to the "Western States Commercial Congress," now in session at Kansas City, will be taken by the politicians as another step in his plan for a renomination. The subjects with which he deals are undoubtedly of national interest, and one of them -- the currency -- is of national importance.

At the annual meeting of the Chicago club yesterday afternoon President A.G. Spalding declined a re-election and James A. Hart was unanimously chosen as his successor. Mr. Hart has had a wide experience in all the departments of baseball management, is thoroughly conversant with Mr. Spalding's methods, and it is unlikely that the policy of the club will be changed in any way.

A peculiar phase of the boycott declared against the Chicago and Alton Road by the Board of Rulings of the joint committee came to light yesterday. The New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad (Nickel Plate) sent the friendly assurance to the boycotted road that it would not join in the boycott.

The appointment of a committee by the New-York Presbytery to take in hand the alleged heretical opinions of Prof. CHARLES A. BRIGGS brings to a point the uneasiness of the conservative Presbyterians in this vicinity and at the West concerning his soundness in the faith, and it is undoubtedly the best way to deal with the opposition to him, which has been gathering head since the publication of his inaugural address.

NEW-HAVEN, April 14. -- The Gubernatorial muddle which has agitated the people of this and other States was formally ushered into court in this city this morning, when papers in the quo-warranto proceedings brought by Gov. Morris against Morgan G. Bulkeley were presented in the civil side of the Superior Court by State Attorney Doolittle, one of the counsel for Judge Morris.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The Senate has passed the iniquitous Mullaney bill reducing the percentages to be paid for the franchise of the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Street Railroad. Senators Cantor and Ives struggled desperately to kill it, but the cards had been too skillfully stacked. Cantor began the fight by moving to strike out the enacting clause.

The Kilkenny cats of the Board of Aldermen -- John Morris of the Seventh District and "Sojer" Flynn of the First District -- had another row at yesterday's meeting of the board. Mr. Flynn presented a protest signed by John Smith and others against the removal of the flower market from Canal and West Streets to Union Square.

Senator HAWLEY addressed the Hartford Board of Trade last Friday on the subject of coast defenses. He recited the familiar facts about our absolute helplessness against attack by a strong natal power. He portrayed the terrible fix we should be in if Great Britain or Italy or even Spain should send a few great ships of war on a hostile errand to Boston or New-York.

ALBANY, April 14. -- A few subsidized persons who desire to give Battery Park to the Manhattan Railroad Company appeared before the Assembly Railroad Committee in advocacy of the Clarke Battery Park grab bill to-day. Mr. Charles H. Butler of Westchester County, who is understood to have made an arrangement with the Manhattan people to put the bill through, headed the delegation.

DENVER, Col., April 14. -- Five of the most prominent citizens of Colorado have been indicted for bribery by the Grand Jury of Arapahoe County. They are Otto Mears, President of the Rio Grande and Southern Railway; Jerry Frank, the Hon. Fred Walsen, ex-Senator A.M. Stevenson, and the Hon. Edwin Mitchell.
ALBANY, April 14. -- The following is the majority report of the Assembly Forestry Committee on its investigation of the State Forest Commission:

The only security which the people of this city have against the attempt of the elevated railroad company to extend and strengthen its grasp upon the only pleasure ground they have near the lower end of the island lies in a refusal of the Legislature to permit the requisite authority to be given under any circumstances.

After much persuasion and newspaper prodding, the Board of Education has undertaken the correction of one of the most glaring defects in the organization of the public school system of this city. At its meeting yesterday the board gave its nearly unanimous approval to a proposed act authorizing it to reapportion the city into not less than twenty-four school precincts, to surpersede the present subdivision by wards.

TRENTON, N.J., April 15. -- At the session of the Presbytery of New-Brunswick to-day Dr. Patton of Princeton College, Dr. Green, the Rev. William H. Wolverton, and Elders Janeway, Shepherd, and Scudder were elected Commissioners to the General Assembly. After a spirited debate, in which the venerable Dr. McCosh of Princeton spoke in the affirmative, the overture to the General Assembly in favor of deaconesses was passed.

Landlord Walters, of the Albemarle Hotel, said yesterday that a project was on foot to build on Broadway, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, on the armory site, a twelve-story hotel of magnificent proportions and costly finish. The Albemarle property must be sold next Fall to allow a division of the Kinney estate. He expected to remain there until the expiration of his lease in May of next year.

The quarterly report of the Commissioner of Street Cleaning shows that he has begun with a rate of expenditure which will make it impossible to get through the year upon his allowance. It also shows that the policy of hiring carts is a very extravagant one. Money has been expended during the first quarter of the year with little apparent regard for the limit of the appropriation.

Following immediately on the announcement by Mr. TRACY of the policy of reform in the Navy Department, the extension of the civil service rules by the President to a considerable number of the employes of the Indian Bureau is a matter for satisfaction to the friends of civil service reform. The rules will be applied to all the various persons connected with the Indian school work and to the physicians.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Secretary Blaine completed his reply to the last letter from the Italian Government yesterday, and sent a copy of it to Marquis Imperiali last night for transmission to Marquis de Rudini. The belief is that Marquis Imperiali, who is merely a medium of communication, has already cabled the letter to his Government.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 15. -- If Gov. Hill had dropped into the Senate Chamber this afternoon he would have seen an array of capital that would have startled him. From every city in the State there were representatives of capital, labor, and the farming industry to protest against the passage of the Cameron bill to reduce the rate of interest from 6 to 5 per cent.

An article published in THE TIMES of April 10, entitled, "Dull Dry Goods Trade," contained the statement that merchants wore complaining of a worse condition of trade in all branches of the dry goods line than had been known in the same five weeks since 1860. Referring to this statement, a prominent New-York merchant said yesterday:

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 15. -- A terrible wreck occurred just about dark last night on the Asheville and Spartanburg Railroad, when a through freight from Asheville and a material train collided near the rock cut above Landrum. The freight had orders to wait at Melrose fifty minutes to allow the material train to pass. The conductor disobeyed the order and attempted to make Tryon.

The Senate amendments to the ballot-reform law passed by the Assembly yesterday and now in the hands of the Governor are, in some respects, worse than a repeal of the law. They are intended to defeat the purpose of the law and to make independent voting practically impossible. Under them an independent nomination could not be made with any hope of getting enough votes to elect.

Sixteen New-York and New-Jersey legal light gathered in Chancery Chambers in the First National Bank Building in Jersey City yesterday to see that the new will of George P. Gordon, the wealthy press manufacturer, was properly probated, if it was to be probated at all. Barker Gummere, ex-Mayor Gilbert Collins, and Gen. William F. Abbett were among those present.

ALBANY, April 15. -- In the language of the baseball enthusiast, the Albanys were not in it to-day. The chagrin of the defeat of Tuesday probably put the Giants on their mettle, and they started to-day's game with their characteristic dash. The result was that after a few innings had been played the local men were hopelessly in the rear, and the New-Yorkers won as they pleased.

Secretary Foster had a busy time yesterday looking after some private affairs which brought him to this city and inspecting the work on Government enterprises in and near this city. He spent the morning at Gen. Samuel Thomas's office at 80 Broadway, and among other things talked over the natural-gas enterprises in the West in which he and Gen. Thomas are interested.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Mrs. Mary Frances Halford, the wife of Elijah W. Halford, private secretary to the President, died at their residence, the Elsmere, at 8 o'clock this morning, of chronic bronchitis. She had been an invalid for many years, and for the last three years had been a constant sufferer from her old trouble, bronchitis, complicated with severe attacks of asthma.

BERGEN POINT, N.J., April 15. -- The city charter election held here yesterday resulted in a partial victory for each faction, Mayor John Newman, Citizen and regular Republican, was defeated for a third term by ex-Councilman William C. Farr, Democrat and irregular Republican. Farr's majority was 116.

PHOENIXVILLE, Penn., April 15. -- Farmers throughout Chester, Berks, and Lancaster Counties are much agitated over difficulties arising from the dehorning of cattle. For convenience in the management of the cows and to render theme less troublesome and destructive, most of the stock owners in Eastern Pennsylvania have recently adopted the plan of dehorning, and claim that it results in many advantages.
WASHINGTON, N.J., April 15. -- The Newark Methodist Conference closed its week's meeting here to-day. This resolution, adopted this morning, was a notable feature of the day's deliberations:

ATLANTA, Ga., April 15. -- During the trip from Chattanooga to Atlanta the party passed many historical points, including the battlefields of Chickamauga, Tunnel Hill, Resaca, Dug Gap, Kennesaw, and Peach Tree Creek. Short stops were made at each of these places, and the President shook hands with a large number of people.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Secretary Tracy is sued an order to-day in furtherance of his new scheme of civil service reform in navy yards. He declares all positions of foremen and master mechanics in the New-York yard vacant after June 1, and convenes a board of naval officers there may 1 to hold an examination May 11 of all applicants for the vacated places.

The voluminous report of the Senate Committee on Cities which is the result of its investigation into municipal government was submitted in the Senate yesterday by Mr. FASSETT, together with a number of bills intended to give effect to its chief recommendations. The most important conclusion reached by the committee is that to which we have already referred at some length, in favor of self-government for cities.

An attractive riding exhibition in aid of the New-York Kindergarten Association was witnessed in the Central Park Riding Academy last evening by a fashionable assemblage of about seven hundred persons. The programme, which was quite long, included several ingenious evolutions on horseback. The grand entree introduced nearly fifty members of the Central Park Riding Club under the leadership of Mr. E. Von Mayer.

Persons who tried to buy tickets over the Chicago and Alton Railroad from any of the Broadway agencies of the trunk line roads yesterday found that the boycott ordered by the Board of Rulings was in actual operation. No trunk line agent, so far as could be ascertained, would ticket a passenger over the Chicago and Alton Road.

In a letter recently received at the office of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company from Mr. Warner Miller, President, he gives the result of his first inspection of the canal works at Greytown as follows:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 15. -- The second day of the Western States Commercial Congress has developed a surprising state of affairs to its founders. There is no political significance in this congress, and yet it is full of politics. In the forenoon the Alliance men occupied nearly all the time until the noon hour, according to the plan mapped out by the Committee on Order of Business.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15. -- The second game between Princeton and Columbia was played to-day at the Varsity grounds. Good weather and a fairly large and enthusiastic crowd made the game as interesting as possible with the score so one-sided. In comparison with the last game played with Columbia, Princeton shows a decided improvement in batting, making twenty base hits.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- Miss Phoebe Couzins was to-day discharged from her position of Secretary of the Board of Lady Managers of the World's Columbian Commission by the Executive Committee of that body. Charges of extravagance, interference with the work, and unwillingness to carry out the wishes of the board were brought against her.

CALCUTTA, April 15. -- More serious fighting is locked forward to between the British troops and the insurgent Manipuris. Profiting by the delay of the British troops in advancing to the front, the Manipuris are erecting stone stockades, digging rifle pits, and in other ways preparing to give the British a warm reception.

The body of Congressman Francis B. Spinola arrived in New-York yesterday afternoon in charge of Deputy Sergeant at Arms of the House Kavanaugh and two or three assistants. It was taken at once to the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Fourteenth Street and Avenue A, where funeral services will be held at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- The Advisory Board of the Western Traffic Association met again this morning without a quorum. There was not a single addition to the eleven roads represented at yesterday's meeting. Dispatches were received from Jay Gould and S.H. H. Clarke of the Missouri Pacific in reply to telegrams sent to them yesterday by Chairman Marvin Hughitt.

The strongest testimony given against Policeman William Smith, on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Barrett and a jury for manslaughter in causing the death of his wife, Mary, by beating her on the head with his heavy night club, was given yesterday by his eight-year-old son Johnnie. Johnnie is an unusually bright little fellow, and appeared to appreciate fully the gravity of the situation in which he was placed.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Senators Manderson and Hawley and Representative Richardson of Tennessee, members of the Joint Committee on Printing, have begun an inquiry into the printing done for Congress and the executive departments, which is expected to result in some decided changes in the present system.

ALBANY, April 16. -- This has been bridge day in the House. Both the Sullivan and Brodsky New-York and Brooklyn Bridge bills passed this morning after a period of lively and effectual log-rolling on the part of their sponsors.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The body of Mrs. Mary Frances Halford, the wife of Private Secretary Halford, was removed from her late residence to Foundry Church at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The coffin was covered with floral offerings of many friends, including a pillow sent from the White House, upon which was inscribed in immortelles the words, "At rest."

Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, H. McK. Twombly, E.V.R. Rossiter, and President Ledyard of the Michigan Central reached Chicago yesterday afternoon on their special train and drove at once to the Auditorium Hotel.

An interesting and instructive object lesson in the methods employed by the Tammany machine to equip the forces of the Park police is furnished by the case of Thomas Cole, whose experiences as a candidate for appointment were brought to light yesterday for the first time. Cole is a poor man, earning $2 a day as a car driver on the Fourth Avenue Railroad.

The District Attorney was not ready yesterday morning when the motion to change the venue in the case of the indicted New-York and New-Haven Railroad Directors from the Court of General Sessions to the Court of Oyer and Terminer was called for argument at 11 o'clock by Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers.

" Ed" Heffner, who was recently quoted by Chief Inspector Byrnes as authority for the statement that Michael F. Dwyer, while a part owner with him in the horse Dan K. had bet on the horse to win and told his brother to bet against him, thereby cheating Philip, was at Police Headquarters yesterday with a grievance.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16. -- The Winner Investment Company, through its President, Willard E. Winner, made an assignment late this afternoon for the benefit of its creditors. No schedule of the assets and liabilities was filed, and nothing is known of them or can be learned at present. The company was capitalized for $700,000 originally, but about a year ago the capital was increased by a new issue of $500,000 of stock.

LONDON, April 16. -- The debate on the Irish Land bill was resumed in the House of Commons this evening. Mr. Morley moved an amendment to the effect that an advance of money should not be granted under the bill, except with the approval of the County Council in the district in which the holding for which the advance was asked might be situated.

TROY, April 16. -- After a close and interesting game the New-Yorks were forced to lower their colors to-day to the Troy Club. The defeat was due to the skillful pitching of McGuire and Shea. They handle the ball with rare skill, allowing the New-Yorkers to make only half a dozen hits. On the other hand, Rusie and John Ewing were touched up pretty lively, the Troys scoring 10, with a total of 18 hits.

ALBANY, April 16. -- The passage of the Hill Liquor bill by the House has so elated the friends of the saloon in that body that they are making unguarded statements, which confirm all that THE TIMES has said of the outrageous provisions of the bill. They no longer say that it will close the saloons on Sundays or otherwise increase the restrictions against the sale of liquor.

ROME, April 16. -- The reply of Secretary Blaine received attention in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. Questions in regard to it were raised by various members. Premier Rudini, in replying, said that the Italian Government had not yet received Mr. Blaine's note. He was not prepared to make a definite statement to the chamber of the views and purposes of the Cabinet until the note had been officially received and carefully read and considered.
Secretary of the Treasury Foster and Senator Chandler, Chairman of the Committee on Immigration, had a conference on immigration matters yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

It is to be hoped that BISMARCK may gain his election to the Reichstag. In the first place, as the most eminent of living Germans he ought to be in that body. In the next place, his special knowledge of many of the subjects that will come up for discussion is unequaled, and it would often be in his power really to illuminate the debates.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Census Superintendent Porter has completed a bulletin of statistics of urban population in 1890, by which it appears that that class of inhabitants numbers 18,235,670 out of a total population of 62,622,250. The percentage of population living in cities of 8,000 or less was 29.12 per cent. In 1880 it was about 7 per cent less.

The Prime Minister of Italy was questioned yesterday in the Chamber of Deputies at Rome touching the relations of Italy with the United States, growing out of the murders in New-Orleans. He made a reply which he was, no doubt, very glad of a chance to make. He said that "Italy could not admit the irresponsibility of the United States in regard to the acts of the single States of the Union.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 16. -- The Rev. Dr. Herrick Johnson of Chicago, the eminent Presbyterian clergyman, who is a member of the committee to revise the creed, came to Pittsburg yesterday to visit old friends. Asked about the case of the Rev. Dr. Briggs of Union Seminary, he said:

It is officially announced through the columns of the Spirit of the Times issued to-day that arrangements have been perfected between the Monmouth Park Association and the New-York Jockey Club by which a portion of the stakes of the former association will be run off at the Morris Park track.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 16. -- The Presidential party left Atlanta at 9 o'clock this morning by way of the Georgia Pacific. A great crowd filled the station, and before the train started the President and Postmaster General Wanamaker spoke, thanking the people of Atlanta for their hospitality. The Atlanta artillery gave the train a parting salute.

Thomas McCabe, a hostler in the Fourth Avenue Railroad stables, was drunk enough yesterday morning to be recklessly delirious but sober enough to get a good deal of fun shooting with a revolver at random at a number of citizens and policemen. He lived with a young laborer on the top floor of 236 East Thirty-seventh Street.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Hill to-day nominated Judge George L. Ingraham of the Superio Court to succeed the late John R. Brady as Justice of the Supreme Court, First Department. He announced that, in case Judge Ingraham's nomination was confirmed, he would nominate ex-Judge Henry A. Gildersleeve to succeed Judge Ingraham on the Superior Court bench.

A correspondent of one of our contemporaries who professes to know something about the workings of Mr. HARRISON'S mind asserts that the President would like to get rid of Secretary NOBLE if he could do so easily and safely, because this member of his Cabinet has displayed incompetence and has permitted many scandals to disgrace his department.

Brooklyn's team had another easy victory yesterday. The Metropolitans faced Ward and his men and were disposed of without any trouble. Barry pitched for the Mets and his curves were batted in all directions. "Hub" Collins, Brooklyn's crack second baseman, distinguished himself. He went to the bat six times, and on each occasion made a safe hit a wonderful achievement in the batting line.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16. -- By 5 o'clock this afternoon the Commercial Congress had fairly assumed all the appearances of a political convention. Much to the disappointment of the Republicans from Ohio, Minnesota, Iowa, California, and Kansas, who came here expecting a non-partisan conference, the committee on resolutions, composed of one delegate from each of nineteen States, had formulated and adopted a large part of its report by a vote of 11 to 8.

A verbatim report of the speech made in Boston a few days ago by Senator ALDRICH, which has been published by the chief organ of McKinleyism in that city, shows some curious and interesting assertions. Mr. ALDRICH may fairly be called the McKinley of the Senate, for he was the most prominent and industrious of the Republican tariff makers in that body. We find that in his speech he said:

Secretary Foster is not suffering from any lack of attention on his visit to this city. He had a good appetite yesterday morning, in spite of Col. Shepard's dinner in his honor the night before, and when he breakfasted at the Fifth Avenue Hotel he had as company Senator Hiscock and Thomas C. Platt.

BALTIMORE, April 16. -- The Manufacturers' Record of this week contains an elaborate review by Robert P. Porter, Superintendent of the Census, of the industrial and agricultural progress of the South in the last ten years, based on the official statistics of the census. Mr. Porter, referring to the wonderful progress of the South in the last decade, says:

The funeral, services of Gen. Francis B. Spinola were held yesterday morning at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, in Fourteenth Street, near Avenue A. Long before the arrival of the hearse and carriages the church was crowded. The pall bearers were Congressmen Amos J. Cummings, Ketcham, and Danphy of New-York, Congressman Andrew of Massachusetts, Congressman Yoder of Ohio, Congressman O'Neill of Pennsylvania, and Congressman Springer of Illinois.

Jay Gould's elevated railroad is playing a desperate game in the Albany Legislature this year. Its bills asking for a gift of Battery Park, ostensibly for "loop" purposes, but really for a storage station for its cars, have called forth more public condemnation than any other measures of the session. The first Battery Park "grab" bill was withdrawn by its introducer and died in the hands of its committee.

The Board of Trade and Transportation is not a body which commands universal confidence and respect. There is commonly a suspicion when it delivers an opinion upon public affairs that some interested person has "captured" the organization and is using it for his own ends. There is even a suspicion that the "board" exists mainly for the purpose of being thus captured.

Secretary TRACY has been as good as his word in regard to his plan for taking the navy yard out of politics, and even a little better. He has appointed a board of officers to carry out the plan, the members of which have the reputation of zeal, practical ability, and firmness. The navy yard here will be first taken in hand, and it is one of the worst, chiefly because it is the largest.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Gen. John Newton of New-York, Consulting Engineer of the Chicago Drainage Canal, resigned to-day. It is said several of the Trustees will also drop out unless the State Legislature will allow a shallower excavation than the one originally proposed.

Two East River Bridge bills were passed by the Assembly yesterday in a perfunctory sort of a way without any of the careful consideration which their importance demanded. One of them is said to be a modification of the Birkett bill, which was defeated in the Senate some time ago, and which was mainly intended to connect the elevated railroad systems of New-York and Brooklyn.

ORANGE, N.J., April 16. -- Dr. Charles Mortimer Bellows of Brooklyn was married this evening to Miss Stella Reynolds of East Orange at the residence of the bride's father, in Munn Avenue, in that village, at 7:30 o'clock. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James M. Ludlow of the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church of East Orange.

Perhaps some light is shed upon the recent revolt in Assam by the circumstances of the still more recent revolt in Benares. At any rate, the later incident strongly illuminates the character of British rule in India. It appears that "the holy city" is in open revolt, and that the cause of the revolt is the demolition of one of its venerated temples by the British authorities in order to make room for water works.

TROY, April 17. -- By just 1 run the New-Yorks managed to win to-day's game. The Troys played in line style, and on the whole made matters very interesting for the Giants. In the field they showed up wonderfully well, and, if they had done any batting would have won again.

GALESBURG, Ill., April 17. -- C.T. Salisbury, C.W. Flanders, John C. Glenn, John O'Rourke, and R.S. Bodman, the Board of Grand Trustees of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, whom Grand Master S.E. Wilkinson discharged, have filed in the Circuit Court here a bill in chancery against the Grand Master, asking that an injunction be issued restraining him from appointing a new board and from interfering with the old board in the performance of its duties.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- The arrest here Saturday of H. Allen, who was booked as a vagrant, will probably result in breaking up a g'gantic conspiracy to rob the Northern Pacific Railroad Company. Allen was arrested at the request of M.C. Sullivan of Thiel's Detective Agency, at Portland, Oregon. The same day Sullivan went to Seattle, where another man was similarly arrested and lodged in jail.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 17. -- Mayor Henry C. Dwight of this city has discovered from the land records here and will announce in his annual message to the Court of Common Council next Monday night that the State Capitol grounds, occupying thirteen acres in the very heart of the city, do not belong to the State, no deed having been conveyed by the municipality to the Commonwealth giving a title to the land.
LONDON, April 18. -- Mr. Parnell has issued the following manifesto addressed to members of the National League of Great Britain:

The account in yesterday's TIMES of the experiences of Thomas Cole, the car driver who paid $300 to John J. Shelley, a foreman in the employ of the Park Department, as the price of a place in that department, which Shelley was to obtain for him, created quite a sensation in the office of the department and among its employes yesterday.

The manufacturers of window glass are now engaged in reviving their Trust, which was temporarily laid on the shelf two or three months ago, owing to the unexpected withdrawal or opposition of one or two corporations at the last moment. Now, it is said there will be no opposition.

The application addressed to Gov. Hill by the representatives of the Reform Club, the Peoples' Municipal League, the Electoral Reform Commission, and by leading citizens of this city, for a hearing on the amended ballot law, elicited the reply yesterday that it was contrary to the practice of the Governor to grant verbal hearings on bills while the Legislature was still in session.

One of the leading industries, the silk industry of Europe, spreads far into the country districts from the respective centres. It is as well a peasant as a town industry. The work is still distributed into the individual homes, although power mills are run for some of the staple goods, ribbons, The silk and velvet industry of Germany, Switzerland, France, and Italy are conducted on about the same basis.
Ex-Congressman Charles Baker of Rochester was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Mr. Baker was Chairman of the House Committee on Commerce at the last session.

A case came before Lawyer John F. Brennan, as referee, at Yonkers yesterday morning, which revealed a curious state of circumstances concerning a granddaughter of Commodore Vanderbilt. It was an action brought by Engelke Co., Tarrytown grocers, against Mrs. Sophia V. Morse, the widow of a Baptist clergyman, to recover about $2,000 for groceries furnished to her and her daughter while they were residents of Tarrytown.

The man who has a nautical vein in his soul will find much that is interesting in the big ship Pinmore, which recently arrived from Calcutta with a cargo of jute. She now lies at her wharf near Counties Slip preparing for a voyage to Melbourne, Australia, with 5,000 tons of miscellaneous cargo. She is owned by J.D. Clink of Greenock, Scotland, where she was built three years ago.

There is another row brewing in the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company, a corporation which has seen some very pretty fights in the course of its existence. A very fair share of the time, as a matter of fact, has been occupied with struggles between factions.

ALBANY, April 17. -- The Sullivan bill, which was drawn in the interest of insurance companies like the American Casualty of Baltimore, of which Superintendent of Insurance Pierce has been the attorney, and which has been refused permission to do business in New-York State by reason of the character of its charter, has passed the Assembly.

The investigation of the Kaweah co-operative colony in California will probably smooth the way to the establishment of the new Sequoia Park, which was set apart by the last Congress. After the area including what was necessary to preserve in the region of the gigantic trees had been marked out for withdrawal from settlement, it became clear that the Kaweah colony of nationalists was already within the park limits.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 17. -- For the Republican nomination for Governor there are no open and avowed candidates. This is a condition of affairs that has not existed in Iowa before for forty years so soon before an election. This dearth of candidates can be attributed to the fact that there is more actual contention and strife among the leaders than there has been for years.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- A meeting of the Seamen's Union was held last night, at which Thomas J. Elderkin, who has returned from a trip along the lakes, said that great progress had been made in perfecting the organization. He stated that the union numbered about 7,000 men at different lake ports, and that men who made sailing a profession were coming into the association at every meeting.

Referee E.C. Perkins has filed his report in the County Clerk's office in favor of annulling the marriage of Joseph C. Lyon and Fannie C. Lyon, which took place in 1875. The ground of the finding is the fact that a previous marriage had taken place in 1855, in which the contracting parties were Mrs. Lyon, then Fannie C. Converse, and S. Hoxie Hibbard.

It has been shown in THE TIMES that the elevated road has violated the conditions of the permit by which it was allowed to invade Battery Park. One of these conditions was that no advertising sign or other device should be displayed upon the structure at that place. Such a sign is now flaunted there so conspicuously that no visitor to Battery Park can avoid seeing it.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Notwithstanding the bad weather of the week, much progress has been made in the work at Jackson Park in preparation for the World's Columbian Exposition. A force of about 900 men is kept continually at work. Eight miles of narrow-gauge track, on which the dump cars are moved about the grounds, is in place.

The Abingdon Square fire of night before last, apart from its spectacular supremacy, will be memorable among the great fires of the city for the destruction of the original and oldest storage warehouse in the city, a veritable old curiosity shop. Around this place there centered more pathetic associations than about almost any other building in the country.

Gov. HILL puts his refusal of a hearing on the bill amending the ballot law upon the ground that he does not give hearings on bills during the sessions of the Legislature, but only after adjournment, when there is no opportunity for sending them back for further consideration. He is willing to receive written briefs setting forth objections to the measure.

We find the following curious contribution to the literature of the tin-plate mystery on the editorial page of the Cleveland Leader, of the 6th inst., in a department of that journal where inquiring readers are instructed concerning the tenets of McKinleyism and other matters:

BENARES, April 17. -- The excitement in this city originating from the demolition of a temple in order to provide a site for a new waterworks increased to-day. All the shops were closed, and all the natives in the city and district suddenly stopped work and gathered in large crowds in and about the principal thoroughfares.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 17. -- The Presidential party arrived hero this morning at 9 o'clock, after an all-night run from Birmingham, Ala., across the northern part of Mississippi. No stops were made in that State, however, and the only incident of the run occurred at Jasper, Ala. That town was illuminated with many bonfires, and nearly 2,500 of the inhabitants gathered at the station to pay their respects.

Secretary Foster ended his visit to New-York yesterday afternoon and went back to Washington and the Treasury Department. Contrary to expectation, he did not visit the Custom House or the Appraiser's Stores before his departure, but he managed to get a good deal of information about those establishments of the Government.

BERLIN, April 17. -- The latest returns from Geestemunde, where the election was held Wednesday for a member of the Reichstag, are as follows: Prince Bismarck, 7,557; Schmalfeld, (Socialist,) 3.928; Plate, (Guelph,) 3,343; Adloff, (Freisinnige,) 2,619.

Secretary Foster ended his visit to New-York yesterday afternoon and went back to Washington and the Treasury Department. Contrary to expectation, he did not visit the Custom House or the Appraiser's Stores before his departure, but he managed to get a good deal of information about those establishments of the Government.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 17. -- While the first ballot for the nomination of a United States Senator was in progress in the joint Democratic caucus to-night Mr. Whitehurst of Hillsborough County announced that a Call man had approached him this morning with the remark that it would be worth $500 to him to vote for Call.

Wise trout anglers who put off their outing for the opening of the season till this week had a chance to chuckle at their friends who, clad in alsters and mufflers, began the Summer campaign of April 1, the first day that the fish could be legally caught in this State. Although some fish were taken at the start, they were only in the preserves and open streams.

Wise trout anglers who put off their outing for the opening of the season till this week had a chance to chuckle at their friends who, clad in alsters and mufflers, began the Summer campaign of April 1, the first day that the fish could be legally caught in this State. Although some fish were taken at the start, they were only in the preserves and open streams.

ST. LOUIS, April 17. -- The Episcopal Church in general here, and the Rev. R.A. Holland, the rector, and the congregation of St. George's Church in particular, are in the throes of a sensation. Fire recently destroyed the church, the finest Episcopal structure in the city. Dr. Holland wants to build a fine church in the fashionable west end, and has notified the congregation that if this is not done he will resign.

Ex-President Cleveland will probably visit Buffalo next month. His friends in that city are very anxious for him to be there then, and several of them have exerted their best efforts to bring it about. Among them are Herbert P. Bissell and Gen. Peter O. Doyle.

Five thousand interested and delighted spectators applauded the evolutions of the Berkeley School Battalion in the Seventh Regiment Armory last night. This was the eleventh annual exhibition of the school. Major Gen. O.O. Howard reviewed the battalion, which comprised eight companies of sixteen files front, in single rank, under command of Col. Townsend Morgan, with Lieut. Col. T. Tower Bates and Major Gerard P. Herrick as field officers.

BALTIMORE, April 18. -- The warm, bright weather of the last few days has induced many housekeepers to turn their attention to their country homes, and by the end of the next fortnight, if the same soft temperature prevails, a general moving will have set in among those who own country seats.

There is a sensible woman up town -- there may be more who are sensible in this respect, but this one stands out, in the writer's acquaintance, as a rarity -- who instructs her two daughters as regularly in the science of shopping as she teaches them cooking and healthful living. "I consider shopping a science," she says," and an important one in the household economy.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 18. -- The Spring term opened Wednesday, April 8, but the vacation of the Senior Class was extended to the following Saturday.

As a grand final demonstration of the "popular" demand for the extension of Battery Park, third track, ferry connection, and other facilities to the elevated railroad company, the ring in control of the Harlem Rapid Transit League has made every preparation to pack to-morrow night's meeting in the Hammerstein Opera House Building with the agents and creatures of the elevated railroad company.

There was a battle of champions at Eastern Park, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The successful nines of the National League and the College Association crossed bats, and the students had to bow to the superior skill of their professional brethren. It was a good game, however, and the spectators, judging from the manner in which they applauded the contestants, enjoyed the sport.

One of the most modest little men that ever lived has been forced to the front by the death of P.T. Barnum. James Anthony Bailey for ten years has been Mr. Barnum's partner. He can, without exaggeration, be called the creator of the modern circus. He has lifted the circus to a standard that renders almost ridiculous the laws that once were so necessary for its regulation.

South Brooklyn turned out yesterday to witness the launching of the excursion steamer that has been building for the last thirty days at the Devine Burtis shipyards on the Atlantic Basin. This vessel is built on nearly the same lines as the Grand Republic, and belongs to the same company as that steamer, namely, the Knickerbocker Steamboat Company of Brooklyn.

The two upper floors of the five-story Brush Building, on the southeast corner of Grand Street and the Bowery, were destroyed by fire last night, and the lower part of the structure was entirely soaked by water thrown by engines summoned by a first, third, and fourth alarm. Although the loss is not great the fire was an interesting one in many respects.

The indifference always shown by artists exhibiting work at the National Academy of Design in regard to the award of prizes has reached such a point this year that one, if not two prizes, will not be given at all owing to the abstention of exhibitors from using their ballot. There is something more than simple laziness in this.

May I call the attemtion of your readers to an instance of shameful race prejudice, in the hope that the sympathies of some one will be roused either to aid the present sufferer or to prevent a similar occurrence in the future?

My attention has been called to a report of remarks made by me in your issue of the 9th inst. headed, "Democrats Will be Democrats," which while correct in the main, draws an erroneous inference toward the conclusion. I am made to say that "I do not believe that the Alliance in North Carolina will nominate a State ticket at the new election."

Several hundred ladies and gentlemen derived pleasure and instruction from the twelfth annual reception of the New-York Microscopical Society in the American Museum of Natural History Friday night. There was a great variety of exhibits attractively arranged, and several officers and members of the society were present to explain the instruments and exhibits to the visitors.
