WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 18. -- Intelligence was received here to-night of a terrible accident on the Canadian Pacific Railway near Construction. Three men were employed blasting rock, and by a premature discharge of dynamite they were blown into fragments.

It is unfortunate for the Berkeley Athletic Club that the first athletic contest between Yale and Harvard for the cup offered by graduates of the two universities should be scheduled for May 16. This is the date chosen for the first of these Yale-Harvard series of annual matches at track and field athletics, and is also the date of the Berkeley Athletic Club's open games.

The mystery of Ann O'Delia Piss Debar, priestess, , is a mystery no longer, for one of her friends, the Hon. Mark M., better known as "Brick" Pomeroy, said last night that she was beyond doubt regaining flesh and nerve in the glorious climate of California. He saw a good deal of Ann this Winter.

The State Homeopathic Hospital, or, as it was formerly called, the State Homeopathic Asylum, was established by act of the Legislature of 1870 and was opened in 1874. The friends of homeopathy, in order to secure an asylum for the insane in which the treatment should be exclusively of the homeopathic order, entered into an agreement with the State substantially to contribute $100,000 for each $100,000 which the State should furnish.

Col. Ellison S. Keitt, who hails from "Enoree Plantation," South Carolina, has written a letter to the Newberry Observer in which he declares, with great emphasis, that what this country needs and must have is a "third" party. The sum and substance of the Colonel's epistle is in its concluding paragraph, which is well worth reproducing.

ELKTON, Md., April 18. -- Another scene in the Porters Bridge tragedy was enacted to-day, and to-night Frank Ferguson shares with Dr. George Bramm the hospitality of the Cecil County Jail in this city, and is strongly suspected of having been concerned in the burglary which resulted in the murder of Mrs. J. Granville Richards and the serious wounding of her husband.

Old Adam had a room to let. He was always called old Adam, though he was still a comparatively young man. "Old" was only a term of familiarity. Adam was handy and capable. He would do many things which made him a valuable workman and a useful neighbor. He occupied the top floor but one in the narrow, tall, rickety house in the corner of Abel's Rents.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 18. -- The Rev. C.S. Nash, Instructor in Elocution at the Hartford Theological Seminary, has been offered the Professorship of Homiletics and Pastoral Theology in the Pacific Theological Seminary at Oakland, Cal. Prof. A.C. Zones, who holds the Hosmer Professorship of New Testament Exegesis in the seminary, has also been called to the chair of History in the McCormick Theological Seminary at Chicago.

One of the bravest men that ever lived was Felix Huston of Texas, who in 1836 commanded the army in the field of the Lone Star State. Probably his nearest counterpart since was Gen. Joe Hooker. Huston was as oratorically magnetic and impassioned as Patrick Henry, E.D. Baker, or Thomas Starr King; as intrepid as Custor, Sheridan, or Kilpatrick, and as fond of wine and women as Luther, Magruder, or Van Dorn.

HANOVER, N.H., April 18. -- The Spring term opened April 9. The class officers of '91 for the ensuing term are C.F. Allison, New-Hampshire, President; R.L. Doring, Maine, Vice President; E.W. Tewksbury, Vermont, Secretary, aand F.P. Fish Treasurer.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Signal Office issues the following bulletin for the week ending to-day:

As the local politicians become more interested in the preparations for the big fight in the State in the Fall the question how this city will be represented in the next Democratic State Committee becomes interesting. At present the City's representation is made up of Richard Croker, Mayor Grant, Bourke Cockran, and Edward T. Fitzpatrick for Tammany, and Ex-Mayor William R. Grace, Ex-Mayor Edward Cooper, and, Maurice J. Power for the County Democracy.

Although you have been all along persistently opposed to all Freedom of Worship bills, I do not suppose you would be willingly unfair to those who have always been in favor of them, and that, consequently, you will allow me to reply in your columns to certain misstatements and misrepresentations published, under the heading of "The Old Sectarian Fight," in your paper of the 13th inst.

READING, Penn., April 18. -- The trout season was ushered in with beautiful weather on Wednesday. Although many fine creels were caught in the Schuylkill Valley in the more open stretches of the streams, yet anglers found that the opening was still a little early. Over a hundred fishermen lined the banks of Willow Creek on Wednesday. Some of them were rewarded with pretty large catches.

E.V. Skinner, General Eastern Agent of the Canadian Pacific Railway, has received a dispatch stating that the steamer Empress of India, on her trip around the world, left Yokohama on the morning of April 17. She is due at Vancouver April 27, when the steamship portion of the around-the-world trip will end. Passengers go overland by the Canadian Pacific Railway, that company having provided a steamship train for those not desiring to stop over.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Harcourt Amory, the treasurer of the Lancaster Mills, and Miss Gertrude, daughter of George B. Chase of Beacon Street, were married to-day in Emmanuel Church. The church was filled with representative people of Boston, Brookline, and other places, among whom were a considerable number of New-Yorkers.

ST. LOUIS, April 18. -- " How do I like America?" echoed Mme. Sarah Bernhardt yesterday. "I am simply charmed: My former visits to the United States were pleasant recollections, but it remained for this one to confirm the most favorable of my impressions and to confirm me in the conviction that, outside of La Belle France, there is no place like La Belle Amerique."

James Freeman Clarke's life does not offer many striking incidents to a writer of biography. It was an uneventful, happy life. After on has read Dr. Hale's volume, he will look back over the record and recall extremely little that departs from the common record of events in a devoted clergyman's varied activities.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $141,027,400, as follows: Currency 6s. $7,531,000; 4 1/2 per cent, $23,560,700; 4 per cents, $109,935,700.

In the limited time afforded them by the refusal of the Governor to grant an oral hearing in opposition to the bill to amend the Ballot act of 1890, the counsel of the various clubs, leagues, and societies which were mainly instrumental in passing the Ballot-Reform act have prepare a brief which they yesterday sent to Gov. Hill in the registered mail, stating the points of their opposition to the amendments.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 18. -- President R.A. Lamberton returned from his six months' tour in Europe Sunday, and was met at the station by the committee appointed for the purpose. The following evening about 400 students headed by a brass band proceeded to his residence on the campus. After a serenade, Elias Vendor Horst, the President of the Senior Class, spoke for the body of students, to which Dr. Lamberton replied.

A richly but not overdressed woman a day or two ago entered a well-filled Fourth Avenue car, and without so much as a look dropped into a seat vacated for her by a man who on rising had politely raised his hat.

Some light is thrown on the needlessly aggressive speech and behavior of the Italian Minister by our dispatches from Rome. The Government has just succeeded in carrying through the Chamber of Deputies a bill extending the age of liability to military service from thirty-nine to forty-two, or three years.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- An examination will be held by the Civil Service Commission at Washington, commencing at 9 A.M, May 12, to fill vacancies in the Supervising Architect's Office, Treasury Department, as follows:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18. -- A circus and wild west show which came to this city last Monday for a week's stand has gone, and in future will leave this city off its route. Thursday night the large crowd which was present began to jeer some of the performers. As the crowd became more and more excited it worked its way into the space reserved for the show.

Prince Napoleon's failure was greatly due to his not knowing or caring to know what sins sinful. French men and women never forgive. He lived notoriously on three actresses for several years, refused to send Fitz-Napoleons to good schools or to make them adequate provision, and allowed such women as Cora Pearl and Anna Deslions to make use if him as an advertisement.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18. -- Horsemen have been blessed with several days of good weather this week, and have taken full advantage of it, too. The number of horses in training here is being increased every day, and there are now over two hundred and fifty trotters quartered at the Lexington track. One of the most promising stables in training here this year is that of Brook Curry and Al Hutchings.

Cleopatra's Needle is decaying and will soon be nothing but a shapeless stone. We are now told that this is not the result of the London atmosphere, but that the granite was already disintegrating before it left Egypt. I doubt this. The needle existed without disintegration for several thousand years on the Nile, and, if it had been left there, it probably would have existed for many other thousands of years.

BOSTON, April 18. -- The number of deaths in this city has gone up this week to 235. Last year in the corresponding week it was 179. Of the deaths the present week, however, there were but two from influenza, one of which was complicated with old age and the other with bronchitis.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18. -- Within the last few days Trainer McMaster has reduced the number of applicants for the intercollegiate team considerably, so that it can now be predicted who will probably represent Princeton in the coming athletic contest. The men who are still trying for the team are practicing daily on the Princeton track, which has been put in perfect condition in the last week of favorable weather.

Those of us in the Libby Hospital who had been selected to go North were regarded as the luckiest men in the world by their less fortunate companions. Those who had to stay back wrote letters on every scrap of paper they could find, which we secreted about our persons and promised to inclose in envelopes and forward to anxious friends when we reached "God's Land," as the Union States were called by the prisoners.

OTTAWA, April 18. -- The Citizen, the Government organ, in an editorial article Wednesday intimated that an effort will be made at the approaching session of Parliament to have the export duty on sawlogs reimposed. A Detroit dispatch says 160,000,000 feet of logs will be rafted down from the Canadian pineries on Georgian Bay during the coming Summer to points in Michigan, there to be manufactured into lumber.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 18. -- A severe electric storm passed over this section to-day and within the city quite a heavy rain fell for a short time. The pyrotechnic display in the heavens was beautiful. After the storm it was noticed that on housetops and everywhere that rain had fallen was a thin coating of yellow powder resembling sulphur.

RED BANK, N.J., April 18. -- Trout fishing in Monmouth County is reported to be unusually good and some of the experienced fishermen have been very lucky. Among the best streams hereabout are the Eatontown Brook, Hockhockson stream above Tinton Falls, and Pine Brook. The largest catches are made in the Eatontown Brook, but the largest fish are taken in the other streams.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 18. -- The action of the Senior Class of Syracuse University in declining the invitation to hold its graduating exercises with the College of Liberal and Fine Arts has caused a great deal of feeling and criticism. Not only did it decline this invitation, but it passed a resolution requesting the university authorities to bestow the degrees at the graduating exorcises of the Syracuse Medical College Department, to be held June 11.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 18. -- Although the season at this resort has scarcely begun to wane, extensive preparations for next Winter are already outlined. Nathan Straus, President of the Lakewood Hotel Association, said yesterday that a number of additions and improvements would be made to the great hotel in the Summer.

RED BANK, N.J., April 18. -- A Board of Town Commissioners to run on the regular ticket was nominated this afternoon. It was at first proposed to act strictly in accordance with the provisions of the new ballot-reform law and nominate straight party tickets, but the lawyers and politicians got together and decided that the two political parties should confer with each other and mutually agree upon a ticket, which should be non-partisan.

NORWALK, Conn., April 18. -- Col. Samuel Daskam, first Selectman of this town and one of its most prominent citizens, paid a visit to New-York yesterday and returned homo $2,000 richer than when he left home. In 1852 Mr. Daskam was engaged in the jewelry business in Troy, N.Y., and had as an apprentice, a young man named Peter Sheridan.

Chicago, April 18. -- The Provisions market was a dull affair to day. Shorts were particularly encouraged because, apparently, there was no inclination to sympathize with Wheat. For some reason or other the pit became imbued with the idea that during the week the Cudahy Packing Company had been a very heavy seller. That encouraged some selling of the scalping sort. Prices, until within fifteens minutes of the close, were inclined down.

TRENTON, N.J., April 18. -- The local election for Mayor in this city last Tuesday has much much more significance than has been given it. The Republican Mayor, Anthony A. Skerin, who was renominated, was beaten by over 1,000 majority by Charles J. Bechtel, his Democratic opponent. The majority was overwhelming, and it had nothing to do with the personal popularity or record of the Republican candidate.

Peter De Lacy, gambler and poolseller is a man of his word. He is an outlaw who is to be respected. He is not a liar. He has said that the police force of New-York City could not and would not suppress him, whatever they might do with other poolsellers.

The children's carnival, yesterday afternoon, at the Lenox Lyceum, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, for the benefit of the Babies' Hospital, was a pronounced success. The plans, which the Directors of the hospital have been weeks in preparing, were fully carried out. About $2,500 was cleared. The performance of the little dancers was faultless. An orchestra of twenty-five pieces was on the platform hidden behind a profusion of palms.

The steamer Eider of the North German Lloyd Line was the scene of a double tragedy just before she left her dock in Hoboken yesterday afternoon for Europe. Early in the afternoon an excited interchange of words between a German man and woman had attracted the notice of the dock employes. The man was of middle age and poorly dressed.

Lanin, whose attacks on the Russian Government are increasing, takes up in a recent number of the Fortnightly Review the subject of "Russian Finance and the Racking of the Peasantry." It may be remembered that the late money crisis was due to a large balance held for the Russian Government, which was withdrawn from the Barings, and nobody is disposed to find any-fault with this action on the part of the Russian Minister of Finance.

The conviction of the manager of a poolroom in this city affords a hopeful indication that one of the worst forms of gambling, which has hitherto battled the authorities, may yet be suppressed. The selling of pools and registering of bets on horse races at the race tracks have been legalized by the New-York Legislature, but this was not intended to interfere with the prohibition of those practices at gambling places elsewhere.

People who fought the so-called "Freedom of Worship bill" in the Legislature of 1885 and since will be amazed to learn that it is pending in the Senate again. It passed the Assembly by resort to a piece of legislative trickery which gave the opponents of the bill no opportunity to be heard upon it. It was sprung as a substitute on the order of third reading and passed without having previously been heard of.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 18. -- The Rev. George A. Hall, State Security of the New-York Young Men's Christian Association, addressed the association here on Monday evening.

This will be the last week of the engagement of Mr. and Mrs. Kendal at Palmer's Theatre. It will be devoted principally to "The Ironmaster," but on Thursday and Friday nights "The Money Spinner," a play by Arthur W. Pinero, which they produced in London nine or ten years ago, and which was thereafter done here at Wallack's, when Rose Coghlan and Osmond Tearle were in the company, will be given with "My Uncle's Will."

A picked nine of New-York League and local players met the Manhattan Athletic Club's nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The picked team played a remarkably clover fielding game, and won easily. Rusie pitched part of the game, and then exchanged place with Short-Stop Hayes. The Manhattans played fairly well, but failed to bat when hits were needed. Score:

The satisfaction felt by all who are interested in the reform of the civil service at the advances that have been made by the Administration within the past week is entirely justified. The laborers in the navy yards and the employes in the Indian schools, together with the physicians of the Indian service, have been brought practically under the operation of the principle of the civil service law of 1883.

The Massachusetts Legislature's Committee on Public Health has been induced by the testimony recently taken concerning the use of arsenic in the manufacture of household goods to report a bill, and while this bill is not a copy of the one suggested by the 1,300 petitioning physicians it contains some of the provisions of that measure and shows that the committee was impressed by the very interesting evidence which the petitioners submitted.

A picked nine of New-York League and local players met the Manhattan Athletic Club's nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The picked team played a remarkably clover fielding game, and won easily. Rusie pitched part of the game, and then exchanged place with Short-Stop Hayes. The Manhattans played fairly well, but failed to bat when hits were needed. Score:

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Provost Pepper led a party of public-spirited Philadelphians to Harrisburg last Thursday to urge the passage of a bill abolishing the Sectional School Boards. This city's public-school system is burdened with Ward Directors elected by the people, who are, in the majority of cases, simply politicians, and yet control a vital portion of school management -- the election of teachers.

The tendency in modern times to the concentration of population is nowhere more marked than in the United States. Perhaps it is nowhere else quite so marked. Everybody has observed the tendency, but probably the statistics of the census will surprise even those who have given to the subject the greatest attention.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 18. -- A frightful wreck occurred on the Lake Shore Railroad at Kipton Station, about forty miles west of Cleveland, early this evening, in which six postal clerks and two engineers were killed. The fast mail No. 14, bound east, collided with No. 21, the Toledo express, just as the latter train was about to pull on the siding to let the fast mail pass.

While at parades the Police Captains appear to be proud of their spick and span uniform set off with brass buttons and gold lace, it is a curious fact that in ordinary circumstances they seem to be unhappy when they are compelled to appear in them in public. Various reasons may be assigned for this repugnance to wearing the livery of the force.

The concert of the Manuscript Society on Wednesday night furnished food for reflection on several points. The length of the programme, for instance, was a subject for discussion. Its performance occupied less than two hours and a half, yet it had the effect on the hearer of three hours of strained attention. The cause of this was simple and by no means difficult to understand.

These are haleyon days for the dressmaker, but the milliners are not "in it." For the former the sun of prosperity shines with hourly increasing fervor. The fin de siecle styles admit of no successful competition by amateurs. Never did the home dressmaker labor against heavier odds. The complicated preparation of the present gown, together with its simplicity of effect, defeats her.

PHILADELPHIA, Apri1 18. -- Ex-Congressman William L. Scott of Erie, who is recognized throughout the country as one of the most intimate personal and political friends of ex-President Cleveland, has lately been in consultation with leading members of his party throughout the State with a view to securing a united delegation from Pennsylvania to the Democratic National Convention in favor of Mr. Cleveland's nomination for President in 1892.

BUFFALO, April 18. -- S.S. Bullis of Olean owns immense tracts of land in the vicinity of Ridgeway, Penn. It was formerly hemlock timber land, but has now mostly been cleared. It is stated as an absolute fact that Baron Hirsch, the celebrated Jewish philanthropist, has concluded negotiations with Mr. Bullis for the purchase of a very extensive tract of land near Ridgeway, on which he will found a colony of Russian Jews.

GALVESTON, Texas, April 19. -- The President and the members of his party enjoyed a much-needed rest at Galveston to-day. While the people were desirous of showing every honor and attention to the Chief Magistrate, they respected his request to be allowed to pass the day in quiet and repose, and abandoned several demonstrations reserved for to-day.

PARIS, April 19. -- A report on the Panama Canal has been sent to the liquidator of the company, M. Monchicourt, by Lieut. Wyse, who has been negotiating with the Colombian Government to prolong the concession. The report was apparently prepared with the object of concealing, amid an endless maze of words and reiterated expressions about sanguine prospects, the actual hopelessness of any further enterprise in that direction.

In the thinly-populated and desolate region from Ninety-third to Ninety-ninth Street and from Lexington to Fifth Avenue known as "The Devil's Hole," a very mysterious murder took place late Saturday night. Thus far it has baffled the energies of the authorities of that precinct -- the Twenty-seventh-although Capt. Carpenter, Detectives Doyle and Krulisch, and a squad of policemen have scoured the neighborhood for a trace of the murderer or his object.

ALBANY, April 19. -- A unique certificate of incorporation was filed with the Secretary of State recently. It is that of the Loyal Lancers, whose headquarters are in Holland, Erie County. The objects are set forth in this fashion:

When Capt. O'Connor of the Oak Street Station was asked yesterday afternoon how it was that "Pete" De Lacy was allowed to go right on selling pools at the old stand at 33 Park Row, he graphically said "it wasn't" and went on to explain that he knew positively that neither De Lacy nor any other poolseller in the precinct had taken a bet since the morning of the Fisher decision.

ALBANY, April 19. -- With its machinery running night and day of late, the Assembly has succeeded in grinding a big grist of bills. Up to the hour of adjournment last Friday 659 had passed through the rollers and been sent to the Senate. The Assembly now has about 70 bills on the order of second reading and 181 on the order of third reading.

Like the Scotch covenanters, the Rev. R. HEBER NEWTON appeals to GOD and the Word against those who accuse him of uncanonical practices. Church creeds and church organization he subordinates to the supreme necessity of teaching what Christ taught, and as He taught it. The creeds, he said to those who heard his sermon at All Souls' yesterday, "are not divine revelations, let down out of the skies.

FRANKFORT, April 19. -- The oerae was quiet duri lng the week la.st and business was dull. he closing Vxicos of yesterday lnolude: Itunarlan gohl rents, 92; Itn!.n fives. 98; Russian Iours, 9g.-10; Spanish fours, 75.50; short exchange on 'London, 20.3; Dtvate dLtaoount. :vs.

Readers of London Figaro may have noticed recently that the brightest pages were contributed by some one who posed as a young woman from America who had come alone and independent to that city and was getting any amount of fun out of the queer ways, the cleverness, the dullness, and the odd speech of London people.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 19. -- The impeachment trial of Theodore Botkin, Judge of the Thirty-second Judicial District, commences to-morrow morning before the State Senate, sitting as a court of impeachment. Judge Botkin has arrived from Seward County, and will remain until the Senate disposes of his case.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- President Harrison is credited here with devoting a share of his time, while in the South, to finding out whether there is any chance to use white material in building up a more substantial party machine than now exists in that section.

WALLHALLA, S.C., April 19. -- This pleasant little town is the gateway to the Southern mountain region. The road from this place passes through a part of North and South Carolina and Georgia to Tennessee, and the route is through several thriving towns and villages which are centres of a thrifty population. The region has been noted as the strongest outpost of Republicanism in the South.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton had a very large congregation at All Souls' Church yesterday morning, a fact partially due to the popular interest in the discussion in which the preacher is involved regarding certain differences between his own views and certain tenets of the Protestant Episcopal Church. It was expected that he would explain his position in his sermon.

There was a case of the dreaded typhus fever among the steerage passengers of the French Line steamship La Bourgogne, which arrived from Havre Saturday night. Early yesterday morning Dr. E.C. Skinner, the Deputy Health Officer, boarded La Bourgogne. While inspecting the steerage his attention was called by the ship's surgeon, Dr. Gervais, to Jacob Coure, an Assyrian, twenty-three years of age.

The Academy of Design is not doing well this Spring in the matter of sales of pictures. A good many are lent for the occasion by owners, many more are portraits which are not for sale, and then the number of pictures is unusually small. Saturday morning found only $7,000 to the credit of sales during eleven days. Buyers seem to rely more than ever on exhibitions and auctions made by individual artists.

The opponents of McKinleyism could scarcely ask for more effective aid than that which is given to them by the crazy high-tariff politicians in Ohio who control the Wool Growers' Association. They could well afford to pay Judge LAWRENCE a large sum for every letter he writes and publishes, and for every admission and boast that he and his associates were the authors of the tricks and jobs in the wool schedule.

A man who gets into the Railway Mail Service has before him work of a character which he knows or will soon learn means no shirking on his part. He cannot be a railway mail clerk and take life easy. There is no branch of the Postal Service which requires a man to keep in more perfect training and perhaps gives him so little time to use for his own pleasure.

BOSTON, April 19. -- A fire occurred early this morning in the Chipman Building, corner of Court and Hanover Streets. It is a five-story brick structure, and is principally occupied by Balley Rankin, jobbers and retailers of carpets. On the first floor were S.C. Thompson, dealer in musical instruments; Burrage Co., men's furnishing goods, and Kettelle Brothers, jewelers.

The decision of the Brooklyn Board of Education to apply to the Board of Estimate for $1,000,000 to be spent in erecting new public schools during the year beginning Sept. 1 is merely a continuation of the policy outlined in President Joseph C. Hendrix's annual report and now being pursued.

ST. LOUIS, April 19. -- The disappearance of Page McPherson, the well-known broker and society leader, is rapidly developing into an exceedingly disgraceful affair. McPherson disappeared over a week ago, and his friends and relatives have made strenuous efforts to cover up his shortcomings by simply refusing to answer any questions.

BALTIMORE, April 19. -- Before 3 o'clock this afternoon Duchesne Post, with drum and fife corps and the post guard, in all, 225 men, under command of Capt. Nolen; a detachment of the Ellsworth Camp of Sons of Veterans, commanded by Capt. Ladd, and a section of Lincoln Post, No. 7, marched to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad station.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 19. -- The congregation of the Fulton Street Methodist Episcopal Church here has rebelled against the action of the Newark Conference in sending them the Rev. J.H. Johnson of Stapleton, S.I., in place of the Rev. William E. Simpson of the Columbia Conference, Oregon, who was chosen to fill the unexpired term of the Rev. Dr. Lewis R. Dunn, who resigned to accept the secretaryship of the American Sabbath Union.

The Southern papers have had a great deal to say the last few days about McGrath's letter to the Alliance men of the South, in which, it will be remembered, the writer tells those to whom his letter is addressed that unless they are willing to come into a third party, the Alliance men of the Northwest will go back to the Republican Party.

The tug Dorothy, named after Mr. W.C. Whitney's daughter, arrived in this city Saturday, on its maiden trip, from Norfolk. This tug was built by the Newport News Shipbuilding Company for the New-York and Northern Railroad. The remarkable thing about the Dorothy is that she is the first tug ever built with quadruple expansion engines.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Several years ago the Pension Office rejected the application of Squire Walter of Ohio for a pension as the dependent father of George Walter, a soldier, who was drowned while bathing in the Potomac River a short distance from this city. It was held that the soldier's death did not occur while he was in the line of duty.

In the regular Sunday brawl in "Little Italy" yesterday afternoon, Carlo Morro, a laborer of 311 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, was stabbed and mortally wounded. The row occurred on the sidewalk in front of his house, and the stabbing was done by Fernando Magrano, who had no hand in the original quarrel, but entered it just for excitement.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., April 19. -- In the Connellsville region to-day the affairs of the great strike wear a threatening appearance. It seems altogether probable that the Tenth Regiment, the 500 members of which went to their homes three days ago, will be called back to-morrow.

The busiest bureau of the Health Department is that of contagious diseases which is under the charge of Dr. Cyrus Edson and has its headquarters at 309 Mulberry Street. The entire house is set apart for the bureau, and besides the offices there is a room for children and persons who are vaccinated and a dispensary, which is a boon to the poor in the Summer months.

Lieut. WYSE has at last submitted to the liquidator of the bankrupt Panama Canal Company a report concerning his negotiations in Colombia for an extension of the original concession. The press dispatches indicate that it is an attempt to avoid by means of a maze of words an admission that there is no hope of carrying the work to completion.

The text of the address of the Newfoundland Legislature to the British Parliament, which has just been made public, shows that the document is little more than a simple protest against reviving imperial authority for the execution of the treaties with France in the absence of that colonial legislation which Newfoundland herself declines to supply.

The sensation of the week in the racing world has been Inspector Byrnes's attack on race track and horse owners, whom he denounced in vigorous terms. It was a forty-eight hours' wonder, and the reason for it has been looked for by the persons directly interested, and looked for in vain. The sensation it created has nearly died out and people have about ceased to wonder as to what it all means.

The following contributions to the fund for the archaeological survey of Egypt are gratefully acknowledged: $100 each from the Hon. Frederick L. Ames and Mrs. Augustus Hemenway; $25 each from the Hon. John F. Winslow, Mrs. James Arthur Beebe, William Endicott, Jr.; Mrs. Samuel Mather, John L. Gardner, and Mrs. William Thaw; $10 each from Dean E.A. Hoffman, D.D.; Mrs. "H.S.R.," and O.B. Frothingham, D.D.; $5 each from Gen. C.G. Loring, Miss Emily Hinds.

According to a "Virginia Republican" in Washington -- a character not unlike that of the "intelligent contraband" in the same city in war times -- Mr. HARRISON is revolving in his mind a scheme of reconstructing the Republican machine in the South with a view to securing the Electoral votes of one or more of the Southern States.

Gen. JOHN GIBBON'S retirement for age, which occurred yesterday, takes from the active list one of its ablest and most experienced officers, whose career in the Army of the Potomac as a brigade and division commander, and afterward in the Army of the James as Commander of the Twenty-fourth Corps, gave him a national reputation.

James V. McMahon, a young man of excellent business reputation and comfortable means, the son of James McMahon, Vice President of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank in Chambers Street, was found dead in one of the sleeping rooms at the Manhattan Club, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday morning under circumstances that seem to point clearly to suicide.

Senator Henry L. Dawes of Massachusetts was at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. He is Chairman of the Committee on Indian Affairs, and for ten of the thirty-four years he has served in the two branches of Congress he has been a member of that committee. He has visited many of the reservations, and is acquainted with many of the chiefs and head men of the tribes.

MADRID, April 20. -- The reciprocity convention between Spain and the United States, as drafted by Premier Canovas del Castillo, representing Spain, and Gen. J.W. Foster, representing the United States, is based, as far as the United States is concerned, upon the third or reciprocity section of the new American tariff law.

It is expected that steps will be taken to-day to afford westward-bound immigrants facilities to reach any point on the Chicago and Alton Road which they may desire to reach. If Manager Doane of the join ticket agency in the Barge Office, after consultation with Passenger Commissioner Farmer, declines to ticket immigrants through to Alton points, Superintendent Weber will probably allow the boycotted road to post a ticket agent in the Barge Office.

LANSING, Mich., April 20. -- Melbourne H. Ford of Grand Rapids, Congressman for the Fifth District of Michigan, died of apoplexy to-day at his home. Mr. Ford was a graduate of Annapolis and after several years in the navy settled at Grand Rapids, where he became a court stenographer. His political life began in 1885, when he was elected to the lower house of the Michigan Legislature.

The proposed Constitution of the "Commonwealth of Australia" is not so cordially welcomed in England as it was expected that it would be, and when the matter reaches the Imperial Parliament -- which be some time hence -- it will be made the subject of vigorous discussion. Unquestionably the attitude of the English at home toward the colonies has been very generous.

The advertising signs which were flaunted from the structure at the Battery for the benefit of visitors to that park are still there. Their revenue still contributed yesterday to the elevated treasury. The offense of the elevated road in this instance is not confined simply to the big-lettered advertisement of one of the newspapers which favors Gould, but it includes also various advertisements for Spring medicines, liver cures, baking powder, whisky, perfume, and hams.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 20. -- The joint Democratic caucus at roll-call to-night had ninety-six out of the ninety-nine members present. The resolution pledging the members, of the caucus not to make an election of a United States Senator until nomination had been made in the caucus under the two-thirds rule came up for consideration and was passed unanimously.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 20. -- The Presidential party arrived here at 9 o'clock this morning promptly on time. For the first time since their departure from Washington they were welcomed in a heavy rainstorm, and the effect of the liberal street decorations was spoiled by the steady downpour, which necessitated the abandonment of all outdoor ceremonies.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 20. -- To-day was prolific of excitement and small riots throughout the region. The women generally are leading and most bitter in their attacks on the deputies. Heretofore they have been silent, but when evictors attacked their homes the foreign women especially were driven wild. During several squabbles to-day a couple of deputies were struck with stones and one was out on the arm while pushing his way through a crowd.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 20. -- A special from Lebanon, Ind., to the News says: "The trainmen on the Indiana Midland who went out on strike Saturday on account of non-payment of wages overdue have induced every man on the road to join them and not a wheel is being turned except an engine and mail car, which will double the length of the road.

Ex-Mayor William R. Grace was back at his office in Hanover Square yesterday after his return from a delightful Winter vacation spent mainly in Southern California, where the climate did him a world of good. He left this city Feb. 3 with several members of his family, and returned late last week. During his trip he visited the States of Florida, Louisiana, Texas, California, and Colorado.

The long-drawn-out suit of Victor S. Flechter against Nahan Franko for criminal libel was called yesterday in Part III, of the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Cowan. This suit was begun last July as the outcome of an article in a musical paper, alleged to have been written by Franko, charging Flechter, who is a violin dealer and importer, with various unfair and fraudulent practices.

It is to be hoped that the Senate at Albany will insist upon the proposed investigation of the administration of the canals of this State. The very fact that Gov. HILL and his supporters so strenuously oppose any inquiry into the subject is in itself a reason for having it made, for it indicates a fear of exposure.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Gov. Hill has received a large number of protests from property owners along Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue against the Dinkelspiel bill to permit the Thirty-fourth Street and Eleventh Avenue Railway Company two years' longer time in which to obtain the consents of the property owners for the construction of the road.

At the meeting of the Congregational Club in the St. Denis Hotel last evening "Marriage and Divorce" was the subject of the after-dinner talk. The Rev. Dr. Samuel W. Dike, Secretary of the American Divorce Reform League, advocated the adoption of uniform divorce law.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 20. -- In the Wabash Railroad Company's hospital here is a case of bona fide bone grafting, the human limb being supported and strengthened by bone taken from a live chicken. John Dougherty, a section hand, while working in the Chicago yards June 14, 1890, received a slight injury to his left shinbone by scraping the skin off while placing a piece of timber on the ground.

Secretary William M.F. Round of the Prison Association of New-York has prepared a report on his visits to the jails of the State, which he send to the Legislature at Albany in a day or two. He is preparing a bill to send to Albany which provides for several important changes in the management of jails. Chief among the new provisions are these:

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Republican Party organs have been doing what they can to make capital out of a recent interview with Senator Francis M. Cockrell of Missouri concerning the extravagant appropriations made by the last Congress and what may be expected from the Fifty-second Congress, with its Democratic House and its Republican Senate.

BUFFALO, April 20. -- One of the prettiest games of ball seen in this vicinity for some years was the contest to-day between the Giants and the reorganized Buffalo Club. From start to finish it was anybody's game, and not until the last man was retired in the ninth inning could the winner be picked. Over 2,000 persons witnessed the struggle, and their joy knew no bounds when the Bisons won the game.

The talk of Mr. Proctor's retirement from the President's Cabinet suggests how he came to be put there. It was, of course, because he was a Harrison man in the convention at the start. But back of that is the fact that he was not a Harrison man because he loved Harrison much, but because he looked upon him as an available rod to whip Blaine off with.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room Yesterday, Monday, April 20:

The annual report of State Engineer Bogart is a pamphlet of forty-four pages, the contents of which have already been summarized in THE TIMES. In three paragraphs aggregating less than 190 words, under the head of "Waste Water," Mr. Bogart disposes of a subject which ought to be worth a good deal more space and a good deal stronger language. This is what Mr. Bogart has to say:

No event of recent politics, or of the politics of the immediate future, is so calculated to puzzle the philosopher and inspire the humorist as the dinner projected to be given to WILLIAM MCKINLEY, Jr., in this city on the 29th inst. The American Protective Tariff League is the projector of this banquet, which is probably unprecedented in human history.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- United States District Attorney Milchrist went before Judge Jenkins in the Federal court this morning and made complaint that certain employes of Swift Co., the packers, had refused to answer questions as to discriminations in railroad rates in favor of that firm put to them by the Federal Grand Jury on the ground that by so doing they might incriminate themselves.

In an interesting address on the tariff question before the members of the Reform Club in their lecture hall last evening the Hon. E.J. Phelps said that in his opinion the bottom idea of the Farmers' Alliance movement was that the agricultural masses of this country are aroused against the enormous taxation placed upon the necessities of life.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Lighthouse Board has made all the preparations for changing the buoyage in New-York Harbor, so that it will accord with the established system of having all the buoys on the starboard hand of channels, entering from seaward, nun buoys, painted red, with even numbers, and all on the port side can buoys, painted black, with odd numbers.

HARTFORD, April 20. -- It is now clear that the question of jurisdiction will be the first one to be raised in the quo warranto proceedings at New-Haven this week, and that the initial contest will be made on that issue. The New-Haven leaders of the Republican Party have been willing to waive the question, but the advocates of Gov. Bulkeley in this section will not consent to that course.

Miss Agnes Huntington began a week's engagement at the Harlem Opera House last evening in Planquette's pretty operetta, "Paul Jones." The audience which assembled to greet the lady was large, brilliant in appearance, and prolific in demonstrations of pleasure. It is not possible to say anything in regard to Miss Huntington's performance which shall differ essentially from what was said in these columns on the occasion of her appearance at the Broadway Theatre.

A double suicide, most carefully planned and systematically carried out, was discovered last evening to have taken place in Room D 8, on the third floor of the Grand Union Hotel, at Fourth Avenue an Forty-second Street, some time between 9 o'clock Sunday morning and 8:30 last night. The victims were a young man of twenty-five and a young woman of about twenty-two who registered on the hotel book as "P. Behraul and wife, New-York."

As an invited guest I was present at the last meeting of the Commonwealth Club, at which the club discussed the question of opening the Museum of Art on Sundays. Much was said on both sides by able speakers, and I was particularly interested in the remarks of one of our prominent citizens who weighed both sides of the question in a most impartial manner, leaving the decision with the hearers.

Notwithstanding the promise made by Chief Inspector Byrnes Sunday night that he would make a searching investigation yesterday morning into THE TIMES'S allegations that "Pete" De Lacy took bets as usual last Saturday on the Guttenberg races, after which investigation something, would drop, nothing was done by the acting Superintendent.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, April 1. -- The Alliance has returned to Yokohama from her visit to the imperial dock yard at Yokosuka, and will remain until the arrival of the Monocacy, when Admiral Belknap will transfer his flag to the latter vessel until the arrival of some new flagship from home. The Monocacy is now in Kobe, where she arrived March 24.

The phonograph was discussed and tested at the meeting of the New-York County Medical Society last night much to the enjoyment of as many members of the society as could find room in the hall at 12 West Thirty-first Street.

ROME, April 20. -- The newspaper of this city are complaining bitterly of what they term the "leisurely manner" of Mr. Blaine in replying to the communications of the Italian Government relative to the New-Orleans affair. They seem to forget in Italy that, using the usual means of communication between Governments, it takes three weeks for Italy and the United States to exchange communications.

PARIS, April 4. -- Yesterday afternoon was press day at the Pastellistes. In the evening came the thousand or more by invitation, including the President and Mme. Carnot. This is the seventh exhibition of this society, and in the methods of their organization they certainly keep up with the times. They have decided each year to invite some foreign artist to become their guest.

When you try to track backward into the history of anything in common usage you will be lost in groping through the gloom of antiquity. Take bills of lading and dispossess yourself of the idea that they are mercantile implements, fashioned yesterday, or, say, only a thousand years or so ago. Man is no more suspicious to-day than he was yesterday, but he never was an idiot.

Sir Charles Dilke's return to Parliament seems now almost assured, and he will owe his success to Mr. W.T. Stead. Had the matter been left to the Reform Club and the constituency concerned, I believe there is no doubt that such pressure would have been brought to bear upon the candidate and the caucus who has adopted him that his candidature would have been withdrawn on some plausible pretext.

Unusual precautions have been taken by the keepers of some of the animals in Central Park to prevent them from having the grip this Spring. The monkeys are very susceptible to throat and lung diseases, and at this time of the year, and especially in view of the rainy weather, pneumonia is feared unless extraordinary preventive measures are taken.

Waiting for the jury to come in is often a tedious matter in the criminal courts. To the accused it is a time of torture, for in the silence of an almost deserted courtroom his mind is in active operation and free from distraction, the fear of a conviction constantly uppermost. Little comfort can a lawyer give his client upon such an occasion.

The dispute between Fanny Davenport's managers and the customs officers over the "Cleopatra" effects brought to this country a few months ago has been settled. Three hundred and forty dollars were paid to the Collector yesterday by ex-Judge Dittenhoefer, who represented Miss Davenport.
EL PASO, TEXAS, April 21. -- The Presidential party arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning, having made the run of 640 miles from San Antonio over the Southern Pacific Railroad promptly on time.

The property owners of this city and Brooklyn who have damage claims against the elevated railroads, which the iniquitous Laughlin bill threatens to wipe out, do not intend to have that measure sneaked through the House as it was through the Senate. It is not at all likely that the Tammany Assemblymen will dare to give the bill a practically unanimous support, as did the Tammany Senators.

Europe pocketed a pretty penny on the Produce Exchange yesterday. Foreign operators who have been on the right side of the wheat market throughout the recent rise took a good share of their profits in the course of the day. In the trade here the general notion was that the Continent had been far more wide-awake to the money-making possibilities of the situation than England had been.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Commander Reiter, who was involved in the Barrundia affair, is to be restored favor. Because the Commander did not protect Gen. Barrundia he was displaced from the command of his ship, the Ranger, and received a sharp letter of reprimand from Secretary Tracy. That was Nov. 6 last year, and since that date the Commander has been sojourning at his home in Pittsburg, Penn., under waiting orders.

The Stecklers and Tammany have parted company. Charles Steckler, leader of the Tenth Assembly District for the Wigwam; Judge Alfred Steckler of the Fourth Judicial District Court, and Louis Steckler, Corporation Attorney, all mailed their letters of resignation as members of the General Committee and the Committee on Organization of Tammany Hall last night, and Thomas F. Gilroy, Chairman of the Committee on Organization, will receive them in his morning mail to-day.

It has been the custom of the predecessors of Mayor GRANT for some years to give the Republicans of the city one representative upon the Board of Park Commissioners. As the board is composed of four members, it is but fair, so long as politics is considered at all with reference to it, to have all political organizations represented.

GREENSBURG, Penn., April 21. -- Miss Maggie Schutt of Derry, Westmoreland County, died one day last week. She was sixty-five years of age, and since her father's death, twenty years ago, had been living out as a maid of all work, for a long time having been employed by a family named Bennett.

The trouble resulting from a lawyer defending himself when charged with a crime has been shown clearly in the trial of Charles J. Peshall, in the Court of General Sessions, for criminal libel in causing to be printed in the Forest and Stream an article charging A.P. Vredenburgh, Treasurer of the American Kennel Club, with juggling the accounts of the organization.

LONDON, April 21. -- The annual meeting of the Grand Habitation of the Primrose League, organized in honor of Lord Beaconsfield and with the purpose of propagating the Conservative doctrines which he advocated, was held at Covent Garden Theatre, this city, this afternoon. A large assemblage of Conservatives, which included many of the best-known men and women in England, was present.

An adjourned meeting of the State Fish and Game Commission was held yesterday at the office, at Fulton and Gold Streets, but as only a minority of the board was present, only routine business was transacted. President Blackford has, by the death of William H. Murtha, become acting President of the People's Trust Company of Brooklyn, and his duties there prevented him from attending yesterday's meeting of the Fish and Game Commission.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, April 21. -- No kidnapping case since that of Charlie Ross has attracted as wide attention as that of the two little Niles boys, Paul and Louis, of this city, aged respectively, four years and sixteen months, while a suit was pending in court between their father and mother, who had separated, for their possession.

When the Democrats take their places in the House in the Fifty-second Congress they will make in numbers a very formidable array. For every Republican there will be in round numbers three Democrats. The Democratic force, therefore, in appearance will be great enough to produce marked results.

The impression made by the last revolt of the Grenadier Guards against the discipline imposed upon them must be, upon the whole, rather comic than serious. One battalion of this regiment was exiled to Bermuda a year ago as a result of a mutiny which nobody, in or out of England, thoroughly understood except the persons immediately concerned.

The impudence of the elevated road in continuing to ignore the very courteous warning of President Gallup or the Park Department that the advertising signs placarded on that structure at the Battery should be removed leaves the Park Commissioners in the position of officials whose authority is derided. There is just one course for the Commissioners to take properly to assert their self-respect.

President Charles S. Whitney delivered his valedictory address at the annual meeting of the Maritime Association of the Port of New-York yesterday. While hopeful for the restoration of American shipping, he said that the association represented the commerce of the port rather than the merchant marine of the country, and that as that commerce had been fully maintained so had the association, as its representative, fully maintained its position.

BOSTON, April 21. -- The schooner James H. Woodhouse of Boston, Capt. Kelly, which left Boston Jan. 30 for San Domingo, arrived here at 8 P.M. in tow of the tug Elsie. Capt. Tard of the tug Elsie reports that he picked the schooner up at 9:30 this morning eighteen miles east by south from Highland Light. The Woodhouse was dismasted, and had been drifting around the past three months under jury masts.

Judge Phelps, in Baltimore yesterday, decided the Childs baseball controversy in favor of Childs and against the Baltimore Club. The injunction restraining Childs from playing with the Cleveland Club is dissolved upon the ground that Childs's contract had been altered without his consent by the withdrawal of the American Association from the national agreement, to the protection of which Childs was entitled under his contract.

Senator LAUGHLIN, in a personal explanation in the Senate yesterday, claimed that the bill introduced by him and passed by the Senate last week with reference to the recovery of damages from railroads for injury to property was intended primarily to give people in Buffalo a right of recovery against railroads which they do not now possess, and was not introduced for the benefit of the elevated railroads in this city and Brooklyn.

LONDON, April 21. -- The troubles in the Second Battalion of the Grenadier Guards, which caused its exile to Bermuda, was followed to-day by a meeting of the Third Battalion, which is quartered at Chelsea Barracks in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day, in an opinion by Commissioner Veazey, decided the case of John P. Squire Co. against the Michigan Central Railroad Company, the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, and the Boston and Albany Railroad Company, involving the rates of transportation on live hogs, live cattle, and meat products, in favor of the complainants.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- The annual report of General Manager Charles E. Pugh of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the year ending Dec. 31, 1890, just issued, furnishes a great mass of important details. The report covers the operations not only of the main line between Philadelphia and Pittsburg, but likewise those of the United Railroads of New-Jersey, the Philadelphia and Erie Division, and the Delaware and Raritan Canal.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 21. -- The National Convention of Wholesale Grocers met to-day at the Southern Hotel, with forty representatives present from about twenty States, and effected a permanent organization by the election of H.D. Lee of Salina, Kan., as President. This step was followed by an address of welcome delivered by William S. Scheppe, President of the Wholesale Grocers' Association of St. Louis.

ST. LOUIS, April 21. -- About 5 o'clock Sunday evening a man registered at Hotel Austria, a cheap place, as George Cook. He retired and was seen no more. At noon yesterday the chambermaid found the room vacancy. The furniture was in great disorder, the bed a blood-soaked mass, and a half-consumed bloody undershirt in the stove.

Dr. Jennie M. Lozier made the principal address at the twenty-eighth annual Commencement of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women in Association Hall last night. She spoke of the steadily-enlarging scope of woman's occupation, and looked hopefully forward to the time when her sex would be debarred from no function which their brains and strength enabled them to perform.

LOUISVILLE, April 21. -- Mr. Josiah McRoberts of Washington, D.C., and Miss Florence Speed, niece of the late James Speed, Attorney General in President Lincoln's Cabinet, were married here this afternoon, Miss Speed is the grandniece of he poet Keats. Mr. McRoberts is a lawyer. The couple will make Washington their home.

CINCINNATI, April 21. -- No better weather could be desired than is favoring the first day's meeting of the Republican League of the United States. Delegates arrived in great numbers on the morning trains, and the various headquarters were busy with the preliminary arrangements as well as with an exchange of views with regard to the man who shall be chosen for the Presidency of the league.

LONDON, April 21. -- It is currently reported that the conferences which have taken place between the delegates from Newfoundland on one side and Lord Salisbury and Lord Knutsford, Secretary of State for Colonial Affairs, on the other side have been of a satisfactory nature.

" Pete" De Lacy is in a state of mind. He wants a monopoly of the business of closing racing in New-Jersey. He got all the credit for making the trouble between the New-Jersey authorities and the New-Jersey Jockey Club and the Linden Park Blood Horse Association last year. When there was talk of organizing a citizens' committee in Hudson County, "Pete" decided to once more come to the front as a reformer.

HARTFORD, April 21. -- The Democratic majority in the Senate this afternoon made short work with the question of reappointing Republicans on the Board of Trustees of the State Insane Hospital at Middletown. The Hon. Robbins Battell of Norfolk, one of the most conspicuous citizens of the State, was one of the victims of the new policy, a Democrat, William Bissell of Salisbury, being substituted in his place against the protests of Republicans.

If the subject has not already passed from public interest, I should like to call the attention of your readers to the curious and instructive history of the Stephani case which was decided a few days ago.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, April 1. -- In a series of articles just concluded, the Koku-min-no-Tomo, the official and influential organ of the Japanese Government, reviews at great length the position of Russia and England on the continent of Asia and the probable future effect on Japan.

ALBANY, April 21. -- While Gov. Hill is predicting that the Republican Senators will break to-morrow, and thus give the Democrats a triumph in the canal investigation fight, the friends closest to the Governor are predicting that a special session of the Legislature will be called as soon as the thirty-day bills are disposed of, or during the second or third week in June.

Probably no incident in the long journey of President HARRISON presents a more striking combination of significant features than his reception at El Paso, Texas, on the border of Mexico. Among those who took part in the ceremonies in his honor were United States troops, veterans of the Union Army, veteran officers of the Confederate Army, Mexican military and civil officers of high rank, Mexican infantry, negroes, and Indians, presumably Mexican.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Senator Chandler speaks guardedly in uttering his declaration for Harrison, and he evidently has a reserved opinion. In an interview with a Star reporter he said:

CLEVELAND, April 21. -- The funeral of Bishop Gilmour occurred with much pomp and ceremony at St. John's Cathedral this morning. Fully 2,500 people assembled in the building, and as many more who were unable to gain admission stood on the outside. The remains, which were dressed in the full robes of the episcopate, rested in a black casket on a canopied catafalque immediately in front of the main altar.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences began here to-day in the National Museum. Prof. S.P. Langley of the Smithsonian Institution read a paper on the subject of flying machines which attracted much attention.

Secretary TRACY has chosen a very circuitous and not a particularly creditable way of making amends to Commander REITER for a gross injustice. He has given him what is known in the navy as an easy berth by detailing him to the command of the Thetis. This piece of favoritism is not an act of reparation.

Manager Doane of the joint railroad ticket agency in the Barge Office consulted with Passenger Commissioner L.P. Farmer yesterday in relation to the trouble caused some of the Westbound immigrants by the boycotting of the Chicago and Alton Railroad. Mr. Farmer had no authority to change the present situation, and the matter will therefore be laid before a meeting of the Trunk Line Passenger Agents to-morrow.

The recent sharp advance in the price of breadstuffs directs attention to the condition of the crops here and abroad. The price of wheat for May delivery is now about $1.25 per bushel in this market, and the price of corn is in the neighborhood of 80 cents. Comparisons with the prices of one year ago may be more easily made with respect to quotations at Chicago.

HARTFORD, April 21. -- Bishop McMahon of the Roman Catholic Diocese in this State has established three new parishes, the most important of the three being effected by dividing the parish of Wallingford. The new field, which will be known as the Hamden Parish, has been assigned to the Rev. John T. Winters of Colchester. The vacancy caused by this transfer has been filled by the appointment of the Rev. B. Lee of Thomaston.

The fight made by certain members of the Catholic clergy against vicious excise legislation is not yet ended. Within the last few weeks these clergymen have held several meetings and they have prepared a strong protest against the substitute excise bill which passed the Assembly on April 15, and which is now pending in the Senate.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, March 30. -- Admiral Besnard, commanding the French squadron in Chinese waters, has received orders from the French Minister of Marine to place the gunboat Vipere at the disposal of the Czarowitch upon his arrival at Hongkong.

LANSING, Mich., April 21. -- The Patrons of Industry, who hold the balance of power in the Michigan Legislature, have been growing impatient at the way their pet measures have been kept in committees. To-day they had a secret caucus on the matter. They decided not to pass any of the redistricting bills until all prominent measures had been given consideration.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- When Auctioneer Henkels this afternoon began the final sale of the personal effects and relics of George Washington there was a large crowd of book buyers and collectors present. The catalogue announced that Lawrence Washington desired to state that the relics of Washington were all that remained in the possession of the Washington family, and that their authenticity was undeniable.

Nearly every physician, every scientist and every sufferer has been asking this great question: What is the Grip? Some have asserted that it is a dangerous microbe which comes into the system, breeds several millions every second, and soon overruns the body with disease. Others have said that we are passing through a region of star-dust, and that the minute particles are drawn into the body with every breath.

A new form of petty swindling has been disclosed by the arrest of Henry Lepper, twenty-four years old, a waiter in the Cosmopolitan cafe, at Chambers Street and West Broadway. He had 1,000 checks printed, similar to those in use in the restaurant, and when he collected a check of a customer would turn in a counterfeit with a less amount of money to the cashier.

SIMLA, April 21. -- Dispatches received here, from the British forces advancing upon Manipur brings news of a further defeat of the insurgent tribes. From the meagre accounts of the affair which the commanding officer has been able to telegraph, it seems that a large force of Manipuris had been hovering for some days around Gen. Lockhart's camp.

LONDON, April 21. -- The natives of Portuguese Guinea, west coast of Africa, have revolted and have hoisted the French flag. The garrison on the island of Bissao has been overpowered and all the Portuguese officers and soldiers have been massacred.

DETROIT, Mich., April 21. -- Trouble has been brewing between the Detroit Consolidated Street Railway and its employes for some time past, which culminated this morning in 150 conductors and drivers refusing to go to work. Some of the lines are completely tied up, while others are running very irregularly under police protection. The first attempt to start a car was made at 7:30.

Abram B. Tappen, Grand Sachem of the Tammany Society, was appointed Park Commissioner by Mayor Grant yesterday in place of the late Waldo Hutchins. Mr. Hutchins's term would have expired May 1, and on that date Mr. Tappen will probably be appointed for the full term. His appointment was hastened by the departure of Paul Dana for Europe, which left the Park Board without a quorum.

Philip White, a saloon keeper doing business at the corner of Sussex and Greene Streets, Jersey City, while drunk last night tried to shoot down Daniel McWilliams, a wealthy towboat owner, and came within an ace of succeeding in his attempt. The shooting occurred at the corner of Exchange Place and Hudson Street, a short distance from the Pennsylvania Ferry house.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 21. -- The State Board of Transportation, comprising the Attorney General, Auditor, Secretary of State, Commissioner of Public Lands and Buildings, and the State Treasurer, met to-day and elected an entire new Board of Railroad Secretaries to succeed Gilchrist, Garber, and Gilkison. The new board comprises P.A. Dilworth of Adams County, J.W. Johnson of Lancaster, and J.N. Koontz of Hayes.

ALBANY, April 21. -- The New-Yorks stopped here on their way home to-day and met the local club before a large assemblage. It was a pretty game, and the New-Yorks retrieved themselves somewhat by scoring a clever victory. The Albanys tried hard to win, but the odds were against them and they had to succumb.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- Senator M.S. Quay, the Chairman of the Republican National Committee, is resting quietly at his home in Beaver County. He will remain there for a few weeks and will then pay a visit to Harrisburg, incidentally droping in on the State Legislature now in session.

Fifth Avenue was given over to the Old Guard yesterday. It was the sixty-fifth anniversary of that famous organization, and also the occasion of Major George Washington McLean's finishing his fiftieth year as member and officer of it.

In returning an unimportant bill to the Assembly without his approval yesterday, Gov. HILL indulged in a spiteful fling at the Senate in these words: "The action of the Senate in refusing to transact any legitimate business until the resolution for a partisan investigation of the canals shall have been adopted or acted upon prevents the recalling of the bill for amendment, and hence I am compelled to veto it."

As it was reserved for the Democratic administration in Brooklyn to appoint a negro for the first time on the police force and to compel his associates, chiefly Irish, to treat him with decency, so it has fallen to Mayor CHAPIN to appoint the second colored member of the Board of Education -- in this case a lawyer -- said to be of fair ability and good reputation.

The General Passenger Agents of the Trunk Line Association have emphasized their indifference to the wishes and demands of the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company by postponing, without explanation, the meeting that was to have been held to-day to consider the trouble caused at the Government Barge Office by the Alton boycott.

Miss Clemencia de Ribas, daughter of the late Florencio de Ribas, Minister from Venezuela, was married to Dr. George Howe Winkler yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William H.P. Faunce. The bride wore a white satin gown trimmed with crystals and chiffon, and the maid of honor, her sister, Miss Anita de Ribas, was dressed in white India silk.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 22. -- The statement that David D. Withers, who is the active manager and the chief moving spirit of the Monmouth Park Association, has discharged all the men employed upon that famous race track and sent the teams of working horses of the association to Philadelphia to be sold because the association had abandoned its races there for the coming Summer seems to have no foundation.

When the Park Board permitted the Manhattan Company to run its elevated line through Battery Park the company solemnly pledged itself to do certain things, not one of which has it made the least pretense of doing.
LONDON, April 22. -- Mr. Balfour has written a letter, in which he comments at length upon Mr. Gladstone's recent criticisms on the Irish Land bill, Mr. Balfour says: ...

BUFFALO, April 22. -- A meeting of the representatives of the railroads interested in the through passenger schedule of the Niagara Falls short line and West Shore Roads between Chicago, Boston, and New-York was held at the Hotel Iroquois to-day. Matters left over from the time convention recently held in New-York City were discussed.

The news comes that one more forty-six-foot yacht will compete in the leading races this year and that another may compete. One of these will surely be in the Newport races in August, and there is a bright prospect of the other's being built. The one which is certain to compete is the Fife boat Uvira, which was built at Southampton, England, last year, for a Halifax yachtsman.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The House gave the Senate an indication of its temper this morning by shelving the bill of Senator O'Connor, which appropriates $50,000 for the construction of sewers at the Binghamton State Hospital. It was on the order of third reading, and Mr. Deyo of Broome made a plea for its immediate passage.

INDIO, Cal., April 22. -- The Presidential party entered the State of California at Fort Yuma at 4:50 o'clock this morning. The President was presented with a large quantity of beautiful flowers and fruits. The entire party was asleep at the time, so they did not see the Presentation Committee.

The newspapers of Rio de Janeiro have recently published some interesting information concerning the policy of the Government of Brazil during the last year with respect to land, railroads, and immigration. On Dec. 19 the Jornal do Commercio printed a list of railway grants made by the Government, aggregating about 12,500 miles, with a guaranteed capital of $320,000,000 and a nominal interest charge of nearly $20,000,000 per annum.

ALBANY, April 22. -- This afternoon 135 Brooklyn taxpayers, all devoted to Fred Uhlmann, who engaged their transportation from New-York to Albany, marched up State Street toward the Capitol in double file, wearing blue badges, on which was inscribed "New-York and Brooklyn Bridge Delegation, 1891."

The first of a series of meetings to be held by State Railroad Commissioners Rogers, Rickard, and Baker at which Brooklyn taxpayers can protest against the adoption of the deadly trolley system of electric propulsion by the surface railroad companies was held yesterday in the Common Council Chamber in the Brooklyn City Hall.

The first concerted movement on a national scale in the Republican Party with reference to the campaign of next year is the National Convention of Republican Clubs, which closed its session at Cincinnati yesterday. The clubs took a very active part in the party work in 1888, not only in the election, but in the selection of the candidate, only the latter was not to the advantage of the same man as the former.

Coroner Schultze yesterday held an inquest as to the murder of Charles alias Frank Mauro, who was stabbed on Sunday afternoon by Ferdinando Lagrano in front of the house where he lived, 311 East One Hundred and Fourth Street.

One of the greatest stumbling blocks in the path of the working classes toward a higher position was the theory of the employing classes that cheap labor, i.e., ignorant labor, was an important element in successful competition between nation and nation. In England, especially, the battle fought against education of the working classes was a long and bitter one.

Theodore Thomas was made aware of the fact that he is appreciated by a large number of New Yorkers last night. A dinner was given him at Delmonico's which ought to make his hair curl, but probably will not. The dinner was organized by a committee of Mr. Thomas's oldest admirers, most of whom sat at the principal table with him, thereby presenting an imposing array of gray hair.

The local politicians discussed little else yesterday except the resignation of the three Steckler brothers from Tammany Hall. Chairman Gilroy of the Committee on Organization received the letters of resignation in his morning mail and accepted them. Corporation Counsel William H. Clark received the resignation of Corporation Attorney Louis Steckler and promptly accepted it.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 22. -- The Senatorial dead-lock continues and legislative business is suspended. The Senate has abandoned all committee meetings. The Assembly has lost all interest in its work, and there is no activity or business displayed around the Capitol except by the lobby.

There is every reason to believe that within a short time the residents of Brooklyn will have another park wherein they may enjoy themselves. Early in the present session of the Legislature a bill was introduced authorizing the city of Brooklyn to issue bonds to the amount of $500,000 for the purpose of securing ground for a new park.

It will probably be admitted by everybody whose opinion is worth taking upon such a subject that the coins of the United States considered as objects of art are far from satisfying. This, however, has never been the opinion of the Director of the Mint. Of course, if it had been, that functionary would have taken some steps to amend the faults which he perceived.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- At the Washington sale held in this city yesterday, Mr. W.E. Benjamin, a New-York book and autograph dealer, purchased for $1,400 what was catalogued as follows: "This most interesting of Washington relics is the attested copy from the original will made under the supervision of Gen. Washington for the use of his executors.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22. -- The speech of ex- Gov. Foraker at the convention of Republican leagues in Cincinnati yesterday has created a profound sensation in political circles, and nothing else has been talked about here to-day. The ex-Governor arrived in Columbus early this morning for the purpose of making an argument in the Supreme Court.

V'ASHnGa'O:S, April 22. -- Secretary Foster i5 admitting In pretty plain terms that the Government has about come to the end of its read money, and he lS contriving ways to provide for the shortge. The country is to be offereg' small silver in place of lper currency, and it h expected to like it.

ALBANY, April 22. - As soon as the Senate met this morning Lieut. Gov. Jones announced the pending question to be the motion of Senator McCarren that the Committee on Canals be limited in its investigation to the charges made against the Superintendent of Public Works by Mr. George P. Smith of North Tonawanda.

Mr. Richard Mansfield begins his long engagement at the Garden Theatre on Monday evening, May 4. During the first week he will be seen in "Beau Brummell." His new play, "Don Juan," now being actively rehearsed, will be produced on Monday evening, May 11. It is said by those who have had the pleasure of hearing the play that it is a most charming piece of work.

With the exception of the famous New-York-Detroit and Brooklyn-St. Louis matches the largest crowd that ever witnessed a game of baseball assembled on the new Polo Grounds yesterday to see the opening contest of the League championship between the New-York and Boston representatives.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Senator Sherman has been recently mortified by one of the appointments made by President Harrison in the South. Just before Mr. Harrison started on his "swing around" trip he indorsed on the back-of an application for the appointment of Emil A. Weber to be Postmaster at Donaldsonville, La., the words, "Let this commission be made out."

There was a decided falling off yesterday in the wheat trading on the Produce Exchange. Altogether, transactions amounted to only about 11,750,000 bushels. Of that total July represented 3,500,000, December about 3,200,000, and August about 1,500,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- The Corporation of Harvard has approved of plans for establishing a course in normal training. This course will be widely different from that pursued in normal schools, and will only be open to college graduates and graduates from scientific schools who intend to occupy positions as teachers in the secondary schools -- that is, high schools and academies.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 23. -- A charming wedding took place here in the First Presbyterian Church at 8 o'clock this evening, when Miss Beulah Pharo Ketcham, only daughter of the Rev. Kneeland Platt Ketcham, pastor of the church, was married to Eugene Hamlin Hatch. The church was decorated with choice flowers. The bride was conducted to the altar by Edward St. John, one of the Elders of the church.

BOSTON, April 23. -- The Herald this evening prints a long interview with J. S. Clarkson, President-elect of the Republican League, who is making a brief stop here while en route to Paris to join his family.

Owing to a disagreement between Austin Corbin and "Deacon" William Richardson, the people of Brooklyn stand a pretty good chance of having no rapid transit at all on Atlantic Avenue. The residents wanted a depressed road, and fought long and hard for it, but could not induce the Rapid Transit Commission to provide for one.
