Corbin and the Long Island Railroad were too powerful, and they got a charter for an elevated structure.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES deserves great credit for the warfare it has been waging against the poolrooms in this city. Its zeal and persistency in this cause have produced good results. The police have been stirred up to unwonted activity in this direction, and all the poolrooms have been closed for the time being.

The rescinding by the Board of Trade and Transportation of its resolution favoring the extension of terminal facilities to the elevated roads at the expense of a public park was not done before it was needed for the reputation of that body. This is a question upon which a man who looks at it from the point of view of the public can come to but one opinion if he really considers the question.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- The same party of book dealers, private buyers, and bibliophiles who for the last two days have been doing some sharp buying at the auction rooms of Thomas Birch's Sons, were again on hand this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock, when Auctioneer Henkles commenced the sale. Among the interested lookers-on was Mr. Benson J. Lossing, the historian. Mr. Lossing was accompanied by Mr. Ferd J. Dreer.

PORTLAND, Oregon, April 23. -- Gov. Sylvester Pennoyer was asked to-day whether he would follow the example of Gov. Markham of California and meet President Harrison and officially welcome him to Oregon at the State's southern boundary. With great dignity the Governor replied:

ALBANY, April 23. -- The eight days' dead-lock between the Republican and Democratic Senators was temporarily suspended to-day by a trick of the presiding officer, Gen. Jones, and unless all signs fail the Senate Chamber in the morning will resemble a bear garden. The trick was devised by Gov. Hill, who found Gen. Jones a willing tool to pull his chestnuts out of the fire.

In the bill, introduced by Assemblyman Timothy D. Sullivan for an increase in the rates of wharfage in this port there is a raid on the commercial and transportation interests of the city which is roundly denounced by the representatives of both these interests. When Sullivan was applied to for information as to where the bill originated he evaded the question.

Mrs. Emory H. Taunt, widow of Lieut. Taunt, whose death in the Congo Free State was telegraphed to the Department of State in January, has received a letter from the Rev. James Teter, Methodist minister and American missionary at Banana, giving details of her husband's death and funeral. He says:
ROME, April 23. -- At about 7 o'clock this morning a tremendous explosion shook this city to its foundations and spread terror and dismay on all sides.

CINCINNATI, April 23. -- At an executive session of the old and new Executive Committees of the National Republican League, held late last night, President Clarkson was empowered to appoint a sub-committee of nine members, who shall have the same powers as the Executive Committee, except as to fixing the time and place of the next meeting and taking action on the matter of the incorporation.

The failure of Morton F. Copeland, wholesale dealer in boots and shoes at 92 Reade Street, was announced yesterday morning and caused a genuine surprise. Early yesterday morning a force of fifty men began to move Copeland's entire stock into the auction rooms of L. and C Wise, next door, and at 3 o'clock in the afternoon everything except the safe had been removed.

Of all the legitimate plans which have been tried in the past to raise money for charitable purposes in this vicinity, perhaps none has been so original as the scheme now proposed by Mrs. A. Alexander, of Castle Point, Hoboken; Mrs. F.H. Weeks, 11 East Twenty-fourth Street; Mrs. W.V. Chapin, 20 East Forty-fifth Street; and Miss Houghton, daughter of the Rev. Dr. G.H. Houghton.

ST. LOUIS, April 23. -- The Rev. Dr. Howard MacQueary of Canton, Ohio, was at a hotel here this evening and conversed unreservedly concerning his suspension over six months ago by the Ecclesiastical Court of the Northern Diocese of Ohio. He said: "My plans are inchoate. I have received two informal calls -- where, I am not at liberty to state.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The reports of the convention of the Republican League sent from Cincinnati by the general press associations do not begin to be so interesting or so full of information as those sent by the special correspondents of the Philadelphia Press, but even the press reports are sufficient to provoke at the national capital a good deal of interesting political comment.

The law for the taxation of collateral inheritances, originally passed in 1885 and amended in 1887, has been transformed by an act which was introduced by Senator VEDDER and has now gone to the statute book as a law "to tax gifts, legacies, and inheritances," levying a tribute upon estates that go to direct as well as indirect heirs.

HORNELLSVILLE, N.Y., April 23. -- The sixty delegates who yesterday began the first State Alliance meeting and devoted their time to listening to various speakers got-down to business to-day. Yesterday afternoon National President L.I. Polk presided and last night he made a public address advocating the free coinage of sliver. He was on hand again this morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 23. -- An important decision has just been handed down by the Court of Appeals which settles definitely the proprietorship of a large tract of territory in Western New-York and involves some very interesting facts relating to the pioneers' story of Erie County. The Seneca Nation of Indians has sought through the court to eject Harrison B. Christy from a portion of the territory in dispute.

At the annual dinner of the Alumnae Association of the Women's Medical College and Hospital at Sherry's Wednesday night, a move was made toward securing for women the right to vote for Excise Commissioners in New-York. About eighty women practitioners were present. Dr. Julia E. Bradner of Middletown, Orange County, gave an address on "Woman in the Medical Profession," in which she opened the subject. She said, closing her address:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 23. -- The Plainfield friends and relatives of Dr. Henry A. Armstrong are making another determined effort to have him released from the Morris Plains Insane Asylum. The recent proceedings in the case of Anna Dickinson have encouraged them in the belief that the celebrated army surgeon may once more be given his liberty, and a writ of habeas corpus is to be applied for at Jersey City.

The first fruits of the economic policy of the last Congress are now about to be served up at the Treasury, and they promise to be, if not absolutely bitter, at least a little puckering to the taste. In the course of the next five weeks or less Mr. FOSTER must make up his mind what he will do with the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds that fall due on the 1st of September.

Any Democrat who was disposed to sympathize with the political aspirations of Lieut. Gov. JONES on the ground that he was straightforward and above board in his methods and opposed to the tortuous tricks and cheap demagogy of Gov. HILL will be likely to lose his respect for the Lieutenant Governor after the exhibition of yesterday in the Senate.

RIVERSIDE, Cal., April 23. -- The Presidential party arrived at Riverside at 5 o'clock this afternoon after a delightful trip from San Diego, over a route abounding with beautiful scenery. Short stops were made at Ocean Side, Santa Anna, Orange, and at South Riverside. The President received a cordial welcome at each of these places and expressed his thanks in brief speeches.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., April 23. -- The President and party spent two very pleasant hours in San Diego this morning. The entire population turned out to receive the Chief Magistrate and paid him every possible honor. The programme included breakfast at the Hotel del Coronado, a street parade, and public exercises on the Plaza.

ST. LOUIS, April 23. -- Lon V. Stephens, Treasurer of Missouri, whose alleged interview with ex-President Cleveland has caused so much comment, has returned from New-York. In reply to a question, Mr. Stephens said:

Miss Gertrude Griswold gave a concert at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. The young lady's singing has been described so often in these columns that comment is unnecessary at this time. She was applauded by a considerable assembly of friends.

ALBANY, April 23. -- For the second time this week Gov. Hill's wishes have been disregarded by the Democratic Assembly. Tuesday his State Roads bill was mercilessly slaughtered. To-day the Forest Commission, against which he preferred serious charges through a sensational newspaper, and which has been under investigation three months, was whitewashed by a majority of the House.

We notice that at the banquet to be given in honor of Major MCKINLEY in this city Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER, ex-advocate of free trade and actual Superintendent of the Census, is to respond to the toast, "The Fruits of Protection as Shown in the Eleventh Census." If Mr. PORTER could be induced wholly to "unpack his heart" on this subject, he could make a much more interesting speech than he is likely to make.

HARTFORD, April 23. -- The counsel for Gov. Bulkeley in the quo warranto proceedings, which will come before Judge Prentice of the Superior Court at New-Haven to-morrow, will take advantage of the law and ask for a postponement of the answer to be made to the writ that was served last week. The law allows thirty days in which to make answer, after which the writ is returnable.

PARIS, April 23. -- According to dispatches received here by the Chilean delegation having its headquarters in this city, the insurgents of Chile have fought another battle with the Government troops and defeated the latter. This last battle was fought at Iquique on April 19. The loss suffered by either side is not stated.
QUEBEC, April 23. -- A dispatch from St. Paul's Island says that the steamer Charrington from Mediterranean ports passed inward at 8 A.M. to-day. This is the first inward vessel of the season.

The little St. John's Episcopal Church on the main Street of Pleasantville, Westchester County, was yesterday morning the scene of one of the prettiest weddings ever held in the county. The bride was Miss Gabrielle Greeley, daughter of the late Horace Greeley of Chappaqua, and the groom was the Rev. Frank Montrose Clendenin, pastor of St. Peter's Episcopal Church at Westchester.

There was a short, sharp conflict yesterday morning between the police and a mob of Italian stone masons on strike in the region above the Harlem Bridge. The police came off victorious and captured fifteen prisoners with a fine assortment of murderous-looking weapons. No one was hurt.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 24. -- There was more excitement at the near-by coke works to-day, as a result of the many evictions, than there has has been for many months. Deputy Crawford, with a large body of assistants, and guarded by Company C, began throwing out a dozen families at White's this morning, including one in the notorious "Soup House."

Not for years has there been so large a meeting of the Union Club as that held Thursday night, when the members assembled to discuss whether a committee should be appointed with power to select and purchase a site for a new clubhouse. For some time this matter has been the one subject of talk among the members, and the importance of a settlement of the question has been at once realized.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 24. -- A sensation was created in the Democratic caucus late Thursday night. Mr. Mays of Jefferson got the floor and read a note which had come into his possession that afternoon. It was addressed to John L. Bryant of Jefferson County, and offered to give him $100 cash if he would get one of the Jefferson County votes away from Call. Bryant is not a member of the Legislature.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Considerable progress has been made this week in preparing for the World's Columbian Exposition. The strike of laborers lasted only three days and was unsuccessful. The men wanted $1.75 instead of $1.50. Topographical maps of the grounds have been completed and all the buildings staked off. Contractors have moved 225,000 yards of earth, 900,000 yards being the amount estimated to be moved in all.
ROME, April 24. -- The investigation made by the military authorities into the origin of the explosion yesterday shows that it was caused by the accidental explosion of some shrapnel shell capsules.

Orders have been sent here from the Treasury Department to reinstate Edward C. Leseur, the glove examiner suspended by Appraiser Cooper Dec. 10. They were received by the Appraiser yesterday, and Leseur will accordingly go back to work after a vacation for which he will receive pay at his regular salary of $2,500 a year.

RUTLAND, Vt., April 24. -- Dr. W. Seward Webb, Vice President of the Central-Hudson Railroad, has returned from a prospecting tour for a route of the proposed railroad from New-York to Montreal. He says the route will be through the heart of the Adirondacks, but it will require the prior possession of the Fitchburg Railroad from Troy to Saratoga to be completed by constructing a short road between Melrose and Reynolds.

The Racing Board of Control had its first meeting for the purpose of issuing licenses to trainers and jockeys at its temporary quarters, at Madison Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday. The members present were D.D. Withers, J.G.K. Lawrence, Philip J. Dwyer, John Hunter, and James Galway. The two other members of the board -- John A. Morris and A.J. Cassatt -- were not in the city.

The veto by the Governor of the bill giving the consent of the State of New-York to the purchase by the United States of lands at Sand's Point and Hewlett's Point was promptly followed by the introduction of the same measure in an amended form, and the Assembly has as promptly passed it.

Some weeks ago, immediately after it was discovered that by a trick of phraseology in the wool schedule of the McKinley tariff a duty of 300 per cent. had been imposed on common goat hair, which was admitted free of duty under the old law, ex-Controller LAWRENCE of Ohio boasted in a published letter that he and the two political shepherds associated with him were responsible for the job.

Has not the time arrived for the publication of a little truth about Mr. SHERMAN'S so-called Anti-Trust law by our high-tariff contemporaries? Disturbed by the open defense of combinations designed to suppress competition in a letter sent to the recent Commercial Congress by H.K. THURBER, a prominent Republican, the Cleveland Leader makes some remarks on this subject, and says:

Nobody can doubt that the bill providing for an investigation of the management of the canals of this State, which Mr. GUENTHER says "emanated" from the Assembly Committee on Canals, really had its origin in the Executive Chamber at Albany. It was the Governor that instigated the opposition to the Laughlin resolution in the Senate, suddenly setting obstructive tactics in operation after the roll call on the resolution had begun.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Great was the disappointment in the Senate to-day when the Lieutenant Governor announced, at the opening of the session, that the pending question was "the motion of Mr. Ives to postpone action on the Laughlin Canal investigation resolution till next Tuesday." The much-expected parliamentary fight was off.

The date set for the final adjournment of the Legislature falls on Thursday next. There are, therefore, less than four working days of the session left, and there is no probability that any act except that determining the State tax levy will pass the Senate. There is a good deal of legislation pending which the politicians at least regard as very important, and there is every prospect that an extra session will be called.
BERLIN, April 24. -- The death of Field Marshal Count von Moltke has just been announced.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24. -- Matthew Hume Clay, the young forger who signed his aged grandfather's name to notes so freely last year in Winchester and Paris, was to-day sentenced to eight years in the penitentiary. He pleaded guilty to having forged four notes, and received two years for each offense.

BOSTON, Mass., April 24. -- Our missionaries in Ponape, or rather our missionaries who were in that particular island of the Caroline group, are probably not among the class who shout for James G. Blaine, poor souls, having been forced long months ago to flee from their fields of spiritual labor by the Spanish military authorities.

The great soldier who has passed away at a great age will be remembered not only as the man who has had more to do with "changing the map of Europe" than any man since NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, but as the most exact incarnation at once of the spirit of the German people and of the spirit of modern warfare.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 24. -- G. Wharton Ritchie, who was arrested in Havana to-day, was the defaulting receiving teller of the Commonwealth National Bank who on the 23d of last February fled with $8,330 of the bank's funds. Since his flight he has been closely followed by agents of the Guarantee Company of North America, his sureties.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 24. -- As though their official life hung in the balance, the State Forest Commission continued with its work, and at Wednesday's session completed the purchase of over 2,000 acres of land in Essex County at not to exceed $1.50 per acre. The landlies in the tract west of Road Patent and in Totten and Crossfield's purchase.

Commissioner L. P. Farmer of the passenger department of the Trunk Line Association called upon United States Superintendent of Immigration Weber at the Barge Office yesterday in relation to the Chicago and Alton boycott. Mr. Farmer made a suggestion which Col. Weber thought was very reasonable, and he promised to submit it to the Chicago and Alton representative in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Comment upon the Republican League Convention continues to be interesting, but not altogether complimentary to the good sense or consistency of the proceedings. All accounts of the convention agree that the enthusiasm was for Blaine, Foraker, McKinley, and Harrison in about the order of the mention of those names.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Secretary Foster is looking for a new private secretary. When he took office he found Mr. Charles M. Hendley, who had been the secretary of Mr. Windom, at the post, and soon learned that he filled it with nice discretion and with great acceptability to the Secretary and to all persons who had business with the Secretary.

The feature at Harrigan's Theatre last night was the audience. Six hundred students of Columbia College took possession of the house. Whenever the orchestra struck up 600 pairs of lips kept it company without accompanying it.

The amusing Mr. CLARKSON, sometime Assistant Postmaster General and now President-elect of the Republican League, has been giving a somewhat joyous interview to a Boston paper. He declares that "the failure of young men to participate in politics is a weakness of the Republican party in New-England," and that "the Democrats have as leaders the sons of the founders of Republicanism."

A murder which in many of its details recalls the crimes with which "Jack the Ripper" horrified London was committed late Thursday night or early yesterday morning in a small room in the squalid lodging house known as the East River Hotel, on the southeast corner of Catharine and Water Streets. The victim was an old, gray-haired, and wrinkled woman, who had for years past haunted the neighborhood.

TROY, April 24. -- Edward Murphy, Jr., is said to be the implacable foe of County Clerk Daniel E. Conway, against whom charges have been preferred to the Governor. Mr. Conway incurred the enmity of the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee because he manifested independence of spirit and spoke his mind freely about Murphy.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The project for a pension list for aged and disabled civil employes of the Government is being revived by a number of Government clerks, and a plan is being formulated which they believe will receive the approval of Congress.

West Africa once more claims attention through simultaneous outbreaks of Senegambian natives against the British and the Portuguese. In the region of Cape Verd are three principal rivers flowing westward to the ocean, of which the northernmost, the Senegal, is held by the French; the next, the Gambia, with the town of Bathurst at its mouth, by the British; the southernmost, the Rio Grande, by the Portuguese, who also have the island of Bissao opposite.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- The Phillies defeated Brooklyn rather easily this afternoon. Terry was wild in the first inning and the home club secured a lead of four 4 as the result of their bases on balls and as many hits. Esper pitched effectively until the eighth inning, when he was touched up for three doubles.
L. Piggott of San Antonio, Texas, who is charged with defrauding a banker of that place of $40,000, was arrested at a hotel in Halifax, N.S., yesterday. He will be extradited.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Dr. Ranney consulted a lawyer this morning who told him that under the amendments proposed by Gov. Hill to his bridge bill a bridge could not be built in 500 years. So the doctor decided to let the bill go by the board, and Mr. Sullivan did not offer the amendments.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 24. -- A bloody fracas, which will probably result in the death of Chief of Police Frank Wilkinson, occurred at daylight this morning at the low dance house and saloon of John Gronendyke. The saloon keeper and his woman, returning from a dance, quarreled, and the outcries of the female attracted the attention of the Chief of Police, who rushed in to quiet the disturbance.

The attention of the Grand Jury now in session is called to the Park Commissioners of this city and to the Directors of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company as fit persons for indictment. The charge against the Manhattan Directors is that they are trespassers upon Battery Park and maintain a nuisance at that place. Against the Park Commissioners the charge is that they are guilty of neglect of official duty.

Every breeze that blows from the West brings news of the astonishing growth of Chicago. All the world has heard the story of the Chicago man who took down his gun to shoot some wolves that were howling in his front yard, but forebore to shoot because it was against the law to discharge firearms in the city limits.

There was some talk of interference with the racing at Guttenberg yesterday by the agents of the Law and Order League of Hudson County, but none developed, though there was a pretty general belief among the bookmakers that something was done in the way of securing evidence against them. Just what it was no one seems to know exactly.

Those whose faith in the eventual triumph of the ready-made costume fails not, nor falters, despite of many disappointments, and who persistently, season after season, seek yet again for an opportunity to save time, which to them is money, by the purchase of clothing available for immediate use, will find the present outlook very encouraging.

INK. -- The ink first used probably was some natural animal pigment, such as the black fluid obtained from various species of cuttlefish; but the limited supply of this material soon led to the use of a mechanical mixture of water, gum, and lampblack, and the characters were painted, rather than written, by means of a broad-pointed reed.

Dean Church undertook the writing of this volume on the Tractarian movement of fifty years ago, very much in the spirit that one performs a duty he feels that he owes to himself and to his dearest friends. A formative part of his own life gives color to his pages, and they record a momentous experience in the lives of many other Englishmen of whom the world has heard.

Mr. John Ward Stimson, President of the New-York Institute for Artist Artisans, lectured yesterday at Columbia College to a large and thoroughly appreciative audience on "Modern Art Education, Its Principles and Methods." The lecture was illustrated by numerous views taken from nature. President Seth Low introduced Mr. Stimson as an effective, gifted, and enthusiastic champion of the true principles of art.
The appearance of the Columbian is awaited with considerable anxiety by the students. It should have been issued about Christmas time. Yesterday it was rumored that the paper was actually in press.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 25. -- Mayor Normand and E. P. Bender of Three Rivers had an interview with Sir John Macdonald to-day in reference to the dead meat scheme, which the promoters are endeavoring to resuscitate. The project contemplates the importation in bond of cattle from the United States, which it is proposed to slaughter at Three Rivers, whence the meat will be shipped to England in steamers specially provided with cold storage.

The largest audience that has attended any of the lectures at the Museum of Natural History this year faced Prof. Albert S. Bickmore yesterday morning. The large hall of the museum was crowded, many teachers from out of the city being present. The lecture was on "Northern and Central Italy," with especial attention given to Venice and Florence, from which cities many of the views thrown upon the canvas were taken.
Having fixed your mind upon some untried or tried and favorite trout stream, and the time when you will start, the excitement and preparations begin.

There seems to be some misapprehension among those who have never made inquiries concerning the matter as to the price of amateur photographic outfits. Often the question is asked of the picture takers, "How much does it cost!" while others labor under the idea that the camers alone will cost them something like $100 and the necessary accessories a large amount more.

BOSTON, April 25. -- Boston is about to enter upon a peculiarly congenial week. The town is already supposed to be able to discriminate finely between matters pertaining to the esoteric and to the exoteric undertaking, and moreover to define to a hair the various phases of occultism that attract the attention of the enlightened.

The second of these two volumes brings the correspondence of Washington down to May 1, 1782, the first opening just after the memorable assault of Gen. Wayne, "a brave, gallant, and sensible officer," on Stony Point. In the first letter in volume VIII, Washington informs his friend the Rev. Dr. William Gordon that "Mrs. Washington, according to custom, marched home when the campaign was about to open."

The prospects for the lacrosse team, which early in the season promised so well, are at present anything but brilliant. Several good players have been lost for various reasons, and the absence from college of almost the entire Senior Class while engaged on thesis work leaves only three classes from which to draw lacrosse material. The Freshman Class has, however, developed some excellent material, and it stands an excellent chance of winning the interclass championship.
I can probably furnish to the readers of THE TIMES Daniel Webster's earliest experience in managing a difficult legal case. I give it on the authority of my father, for the scene dates back to 1805.

According to Le Temps the Newfoundland fisheries question has lately reached a critical stage. When the news reached St. John's that, until a final agreement could be reached between France and Great Britain, the status quo would be maintained, the people of the town were loud in their complaints against England, saying that Newfoundland would be betrayed to France or be made an object of barter, as happened to Helgoland.

BOSTON, April 25. -- An enthusiastic crowd whose number was swelled by some half dozen members of the New-York Racquet and Tennis Club, witnessed the match of racquets on the Boston Athletic Association Court to-day between Albert Wright of the New-York Club and Tom Pettitt of Boston. Wright had the prestige of a former victory.

The local politicians are not at all pleased over Mayor Chaplin's decision in reference to establishing a new park on Ridgewood Heights. In fact, they charge his Honor with getting under false pretenses the support for the bill which enables him to devote $500,000 to that purpose. This is the bill that became a law Thursday, and which was introduced by Assemblyman Kelly.

BISMARCK, N.D., April 25. -- In the course of a conversation with a prominent Democrat in this city to-day, your correspondent obtained some spicy gossip regarding political movements on the Democratic side of the house. He said that there was a general apprehension among the Democrats that the National Republican Committee would checkmate any move to capture North Dakota in the President year.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 25. -- The statistics showing the work of the Congregational Church in this State in 1890 were completed yesterday by the Rev. W.H. Moore of this city. The total number of churches in the denomination Jan. 1, 1891, was 306, being a gain of 4 during 1890. Of these churches 121 had settled pastors, 88 pastors without settlement, and 46 were supplied by ministers who are not pastors.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 25. -- The Rev. Father John Sword, rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church, at Thirteenth and Holmes Streets, has tendered his resignation as priest of that church organization. The matter will come before the vestry for acceptance or rejection at the meeting Monday evening.

I had long pressed my friend to tell me the true particulars of a certain adventure which he had taken part in during his recent travels in Asia and of which his acquaintances whispered mysterious hints.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The following is the weather crop bulletin issued by the Signal Office:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25. -- The new course in normal training which the corporation of Harvard University has recently established is the outgrowth of the work done in an elaborate system of Summer schools which has been carried on at this institution for several years. Each succeeding year the work has been extended with the increasing demands for the training offered, and last year about three hundred students were enrolled.

The business in the real estate market during the last week did not keep up to the promises of the week before, and brokers and dealers had reason again to complain that the season was slow. They are by no means inclined to despair of lively business during May and June, because negotiations are in progress that promise well for those months.

The Platt Republicans who have been so diligently pushing the Hildreth and Fassett Custom House Site bills in the two branches of the Legislature, were on the still hunt until the deadlock occurred to resurrect the Assembly bill from committee, whither it was sent by the casting vote of Speaker Sheehan.

Members of the New-Rochelle Yacht Club read with interest THE TIMES'S account of the meeting of its committee on measurement and classification of yachts for racing, but a few of them have asked what THE TIMES meant by suggesting that the club follow as closely as practicable the rules of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

DENVER, Col., April 25. -- One of the most atrocious crimes ever perpetrated in the West came to light this morning. Some months ago Mrs. Josephine B. Barnaby, widow of J.B. Barnaby, a millionaire merchant of Providence, R.I., took a trip to California for her health. Mrs. G.S. Worrell, wife of a prominent Denver real-estate dealer, accompanied her.

The Hon. Frank Jones of Portsmouth, N.H., and the Hon. A.W. Sulloway of Franklin, N. H., were at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. For twenty years they have been closer than brothers, associated both in business and politics. They sat side by side yesterday and alternately answered questions with reference to New-Hampshire politics.
The cast of the pastoral performance of "As You Like It," to be presented at Castle Point, Hoboken, on the lawn or Mrs. E.A. Stevens, June 16, will be, with possible slight changes, as follows:

FRENCH BEER. -- The annual consumption of beer per head of the population in France has now risen to 21 liters, (about 14 quarts,) which, on the top of 119 liters of wine, (however light,) 20 liters of cider, and 4 liters of spirits, is a respectable allowance enough. For Germany the figures are said to be 93 liters of beer, 6 of wine, and 10 of spirits -- and such spirits!

LANCASTER, Penn., April 25. -- The Dunkard Brethren, or German Baptists, held the first of their annual series of love feasts near West Hanover yesterday and to-day, preceded by their regular Conference on Thursday. There are at least 40,000 members of this peculiar sect in Dauphin, Lebanon, Lancaster, and Berks Counties.

Evidently the elevated management had received notice yesterday that the advertising signs in Battery Park must be taken down. Early in the afternoon men were set at work with ladders and screwdrivers to remove the advertisements of the liver cure, oat meal, hams, perfumes, and grip averting people whose wares have been placarded at the foot of the stairways in the park.

An amusing this is likely to happen soon in local Republican politics. Unless a change in the plans is made, that curio known as Elliott F. Shepard will be sent as Executive member from the Twenty-first Assembly District to the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee. As a political leader, the Colonel will be unique.

PARIS, April 25. -- The rival Salon of the Champ de Mars, which opens the middle of next month, has had a good effect on the old Champs Elysees Saloon -- it has caused the Society of French Artists to pay more attention to the aesthetic appearance of the exhibition rooms in the Palais de l'Industrie, which, until this year, has presented a pretty shabby interior.
ORANGE, N.J., April 25. -- The Misses Churr of Halsted Street gave a tea from 4 to 7 o'clock yesterday afternoon in honor of Miss Powles of Washington.

LONDON, April 25. -- Mr. Poultney Bigelow, who accompanied Emperor William during last year's manoeuvres, gave to-night these interesting reminiscences of Gen. von Moltke, who was also a guest of the Emperor at the time:

The stand taken by Harvard in favor of a dual athletic league with Yale and the encouragement of the scheme by a few graduates of the two universities will be better understood if one considers the facts which have led up to the present situation in athletics between the three leading universities -- Yale, Harvard, and Princeton.

Boxes at the Madison Square Garden for the "Allegory of the War in Song," to be given under the auspices of the Grant Monument Association May 2, were sold at auction at 240 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Much interest was manifested, and the sale was regarded as satisfactory by the management. Mrs. Grover Cleveland secured first choice of seats at $25, and she selected Box 43.

LAKEWOOD, April 25. -- Although Lakewood is now in the beauty of Spring attire, the season is rapidly drawing to the close. There are still a good many guests at the hotels and cottages, but their numbers are decreasing rather than increasing.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 25. -- The Rev. Elliott Griffis of Boston lectured to-night for the benefit of the Athletic Association to a large audience, and to-morrow (Sunday) will preach at the college chapel. He is the guest of President Scott. The seventh of the Graves sermons will be preached on May 2 by the Rev. John G. Van Dyke of Kingston, N.Y.

The day following the departure of the prisoners from Libby a number of Confederate officers came to Hospital Number Ten and announced that the flag of truce boat was going down the river again. Capt. Gordon and myself, who had been doing all we could to help the poor fellows from Belle Isle, who were lying all around us on the floors, expected to go down with the others as we had done before.

WALLA WALLA, Washington, April 25. -- D.J. Hunt, the murderer of Private Miller Wednesday night, was lynched last evening by soldiers from the garrison and fell in the Court House yard riddled with bullets, four of which entered his head.

SYRACUSE, April 25. -- The death of Prof. C.W. Bennett of the Northwestern University at Evanston, Ill., was a matter of much regret among the Faculty of Syracuse University, with whom he was formerly associated. On Thursday, at the chapel exercises, Chancellor Sims spoke feelingly of Prof. Bennett's relation with Syracuse University from the opening of the institution until 1885, a period of about fifteen years.

Senator Preston B. Plumb of Kansas was at the Hoffman House Thursday. He said that he, would insist on keeping politics out of his daily life from this time until Congress meets again. In answer to questions he said:

The latest batch of British fishery correspondence made public shows by official documents why the Government, after assenting to Newfoundland's conducting separate negotiations with the United States in fishery and commercial matters, refused to allow these negotiations to be pushed to the point of a separate convention.

NEW-HAVEN, April 25. -- The annual report of Librarian Van Namo of Yale University contains a record of gifts of 3,200 books and 3,775 pamphlets to the library last year, and of the purchase of 2,920 books and 360 maps. The most important of the gifts is that made by the late Rev. Dr. Henry M. Dexter, who presented 1,850 volumes to the library.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. --The Phillies won their third straight game from Brooklyn this afternoon by a little lucky hitting in the seventh inning, when they secured two runs after two men had been retired. Both pitchers were in prime fettle, and each was accorded admirable support. O'Brien and Collins were each fined $10 in the fourth inning for talking back to the umpire.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- The Commissioners of the Western Traffic Association have issued an order advancing second-class passenger and excursion rates from Pacific coast points to the eastern terminals of the Transcontinental lines. At a meeting of the Passenger Rate Committee of the Transcontinental Association Feb. 1 the Southern Pacific submitted a proposition to make the second-class rate from the Pacific coast $5 higher than at present and six months' excursion rates $10 higher.

An iron-clad sent to the bottom by a torpedo is the latest incident in the struggle between the Chilean insurgents and the Balmaceda Government. News of the action and its result was received yesterday by Flint Co. of this city in a cable dispatch from Valparaiso, which briefly announced that the Blanco Encalada had been sunk by the Almirante Lynch in a fight near the port of Caldera.

Architects are so dependent on the persons or corporations who are their employers that it is impossible for them to move in advance of the average of culture among the people. Draughtsmen, glass stainers, painters, and even sculptors, can break a path by following the promptings of their own genius and wait for the ruck of amateurs to overtake them and their meaning.

FRESNO, Cal., April 25. -- The President and party arose at 6 o'clock this morning while their train was crossing the Tehachapi Mountains on the way to the valley of the San Joaquin, and had a splendid view of the celebrated railroad loop at that point. The first stopping place of the day was at Bakersfield, where the party arrived at 8:30 o'clock. The train remained there ten minutes.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- The Illinois Central took forcible possession last night, at midnight, of the strip of land on the lake front leased for ten years in 1874 for a freight yard by the Baltimore and Ohio and which the latter company has since refused to vacate, claiming a right to renew the lease. The Illinois Supreme Court a few days ago decided in favor of the Illinois Central.

The Republican State Central Committee of Ohio has called the State Convention of the party for June 16 and 17 at Columbus. The indications at the meeting of the committee are said to have been decidedly favorable to the nomination of MCKINLEY for Governor, and it is believed that the task of presenting his name to the convention will be assigned to the irrepressible FORAKER.

LONG BRANCH, April 25. -- Much interest is displayed here in the coming municipal election on May 12, when a board of seven Commissioners is to be elected. What makes the occasion one of more than usual interest is the fact that the present board has been notoriously neglectful of the public desire for improvement, while its meetings have been marked by violent quarrels in which vile epithets have been freely exchanged.

There is among business men a strong-feeling in favor of the reappointment of Tax Commissioner Michael Coleman. Expression of this feeling has already been given in more than one quarter. At a special meeting of the Mechanics and Traders' Exchange, called to recommend the reappointment of Mr. Coleman, the following resolutions were passed:

The Boston and Albany Railroad proposes to withdraw from the boycott of the Chicago and Alton Railroad. So far as the participation of that road in the boycott has extended, it was not a success. The management of the Boston and Albany is now preparing an official circular to its agents withdrawing from the boycott.

JOHN GILPIN. -- When "The Task" appeared in 1784 the public gave it a cordial welcome, and Cowper was thereafter classed among English poets. His popularity was not due to his best work, yet it led to that work being appreciated. Between the publication of "Table Talk" and "The Task," he had written "John Gilpin," and become famous.

The murder of the old woman in the East River Hotel Thursday night is still as deep a mystery as ever. The best detectives of the city force, headed by Inspector Byrnes, are working like beavers to clear it up. Information as to what they are doing and what they have done and hope to accomplish they refuse to give.

While clouds, especially the higher forms, have a general tendency to move in the same direction as storms, that is, from west to east, it has been decided that they are a very poor guide to follow in special instances, and they fail especially at times when such assitance is the most needed.

Charles Macklin died in 1797, only two years before the death of George Washington, in the days of newspapers, and although he had retired from the public view eight years before, yet he was frequently seen almost until the end of his life in some of the older coffee houses of London and in the greenrooms.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 25. -- The Athletic Association has received $166.66 from the Inter-Collegiate Athletic Association. This amount is one of the equal shares distributed among the colleges of that association for the benefit of track athletics.

ON AMERICAN RAILROADS. -- In country like America, where interests are so diverse and the laws of different States differ in many respects, it is impossible to expect that a rigid control by Congress can be kept, as in Europe or England, over large public properties such as railways. The increment of value behind these properties is enormous, but it is impossible to predict into whose hands the control of these properties may fall.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- The week has been notable for the bound which E.S. Willard made into public favor. The first week of his engagement at Hooley's was successful in many ways. But the play, "John Needham's Double," did not appeal to playgoers, and it was not until they saw him in "The Middleman" that Mr. Willard succeeded in riveting attention upon himself as a very meritorious actor.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., April 25. -- With the great strike of the 15,000 workers of the Connellsville coke region in its tenth week, the difficulty is no nearer settlement than when the men first threw down their tools. The situation is full of interest to students of industrial affairs. Persons familiar with the cosmopolitan population of the region estimate that about 70 per cent. of the coke workers are of foreign birth.

MODERN PHASES OF ENGLISH WORDS. -- The subjoined words have, I believe, undergone changes chiefly in the acquisition of new powers, during the last few years. In some cases I may be mistaken, although I have tested the experience of other persons. But record of the kind is of value, and the short list will perhaps suggest noteworthy additions.

The Hon. Chauncey M. Depew and the other Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company indicted for allowing the cars of their road to be heated with stoves, to which attention was called by the disaster in the Fourth Avenue tunnel, will not have to be humbled by a trial in the Court of General Sessions, where common criminals are tried.

The story that C.P. Huntington proposes to make his home on the Pacific slope is discredited by his business associates in this city. Mr. Huntington is building a residence at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street which will cost him in the neighborhood of $1,500,000, and he has frequently asserted that his chief aim in life was to get a comfortable home and enjoy the remainder of his life with his children.

One of the largest devilfishes ever caught in the sound was caught near Port Madison yesterday by some fishermen. When first caught it would measure, spread out, fifteen or twenty feet across from tip to tip of its fangs. On each of its eight fangs were over 200 suckers, making in all upward of 1,600 apertures for the absorption of food.

When the admirers of the Administration resent the notion that any of the obligations of the Government are to be "dishonored," they only resort to the time-honored, but not respectable, device of setting up a man of straw in order to knock him over. There is no fear anywhere that the Government will not in some way meet its obligations, including the $54,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cents due Sept. 1.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26. -- The fight against the renomination of Gov. James E. Campbell, that has shown itself at various times during the past few months, has again broken out with renewed fury, and its formidable proportions may be judged from the fact that the opposition comes from all sections of the State, and is confined to no particular locality, but is more general than those mildly opposed to the Governor believed or imagined.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Arrangements have been nearly completed for the purchase of three of the largest manufacturing plants in Illinois. The properties in question are the Deere Mansure Company, manufacturers of corn planters; the Deere Co. Harvester Works, and the Moline Plow Company. All are situated at Moline, and are the most extensive plants of their kind in the United States.
ZANZIBAR, April 26. -- The British war ships Pigeon and Brisk have left the harbor, with sealed orders. It is believed their destination is she Pungwe River.

Capt. William H. Clinchy of the East Twenty-second Street police station was Acting Inspector at the Central Office the other night, and as he stood on the steps of the Police Headquarters Building in Mulberry Street he indulged in reminiscences.

About eighty merchants and firms doing business in Wall, Broad, Water, Pearl, William, Front, and South Streets, Exchange Place, Old Slip, and Hanover Square have joined in a petition to the Legislature for the passage of an act to restrain the Department of Docks from granting permits for any dumping bridge on the East River between Whitehall Street and the Brooklyn Bridge.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The body of Count von Moltke was viewed by the public to-day from noon until 5 o'clock in the afternoon. The bier, which is placed in the ballroom of the Staff Building, is draped with white silk embroidered with silver, and a coverlet designed by the decreased for the purpose covers the body as far as the breast. The body has been embalmed by Dr. Beuster.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 26. -- Thoughtful Canadians cannot fail to observe the growing friction between the French and English speaking population of Canada. Lower Canada, with its 2,000,000 French inhabitants, is practically a nation within a nation. There is developed a national sentiment which does not glory in the achievements of the English race.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 26. -- The statements of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies for March, compared with the same month last year, shows for the railroad company gross receipts, $1,551,400.11; increase, $42,653.10; gross expenses, $958,034.07; decrease, $15,324.88; profit in operating, $593,366.04; increase, $57,972.98. The fixed charges cause a deficit of earnings of $52,233.82; decrease, $38,978.06.

Talmage's Brooklyn Tabernacle, at the corner of Greene and Clinton Avenues, was dedicated yesterday by its pastor, Dr. Talmage, and about score of brother ministers. The building was crowded to the outer doors at each of the three services of the day, and hundreds visited it just to look at the magnificent auditorium. It was estimated that 35,000 people took part in the dedication day services.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- There was a disposition on the part of some of the Texas people in Washington to discredit the report sent to THE TIMES on Thursday that Senator Reagan would resign and give Gov. Hogg an opportunity to appoint a Senator in his place.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 26. -- The appointment of Horace A. Chilton of Tyler to fill the vacant Senatorship caused by the selection of Mr. Reagan as Chairman of the State Railway Commission has not conduced to harmony.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The President evidently made a mistake when he selected Mr. Foster for Secretary of the Treasury. What was wanted, at the time he was compelled to choose a successor to Mr. Windom, was a man who could discover new resources in a Treasury overtaxed by a Congress that was determined to make a billion record, but which as not trying to provide a billion of income.

The tramp Patrick McDonnell, who recently gave himself up to Chief of Police McCabe of Poughkeepsie, saying that he had murdered a man named McCloskey in a saloon row in this city, and who was brought here by Inspector Byrnes under suspicion of having murdered Thomas Donegan who was found dead in a Mulberry Street alley Sunday night a week ago, was arraigned in the Tombs yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Secretary of War has under consideration the method to be pursued in the selection of civilians for appointment to Second Lieutenancies in the cavalry and infantry arms of the service. The President will have a number of such appointments to make late in the Summer, thanks to the large number of retirements and the consequent promotions made under the new retirement laws.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The last week of the legislative session begins with every indication of the continuance of the dead-lock which was begun on Thursday week, April 16. The question is daily asked so often. How is it that the Republicans, with a majority of six, are unable to break the dead-lock? that a simple explanation of the situation is necessary.

The action taken a few days ago by the Health Department with respect to the discovery of several cases of tuberculosis in a dairy herd in Putnam County is encouraging, because it proves that the recommendations submitted two years ago by the pathologists of the department have not been ignored. The veterinarian of the department had made a report concerning the condition of a herd in Carmel, owned by ALVAH HYATT.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Mr. D.N. Richardson, editor of the Davenport Democrat, talks earnestly about the estimation in which the Iowa Democrats hold Mr. Cleveland, and his most emphatic utterance about the outlook is that "Cleveland is the Democrats' only hope in 1892. He is the only national Democrat. I do not see any other possibility next year."

ALBANY, April 26. -- Never in the history of this country has the right to investigate alleged abuses and to inquire as to the best methods of legislating for the welfare of the people been surrendered by the legislative branch of the Government. Upon it alone rests the duty of legislation and of ascertaining, by investigation or otherwise, what legislation is necessary for the public good.

While the three political shepherds in Ohio who made the McKinley wool schedule are procuring the enforcement of the cunning clauses and changes of phraseology by which they sought to make some of the duties prohibitory, the price of Ohio wool continues to fall and the demand for Australian wool increases. A marked preference for the wool of Australia and a slackening demand for the similar fleeces of Ohio are prominent features in the trade.

-- Word comes from Paris that Littre's great dictionary of the French language is "threatened with a serious rival." Messrs. Delagrave, the publishers, have begun the issue, in parts, of what is called a "Dictionnaire General de la Langue Francaise," by Messrs. Adolphe Hatzfeld, Arsene Darmesteter, and Antoine Thomas.

Coney Island was awakened from its long Winter's sleep yesterday by the establishment of direct connections with this city by way of the Sea Beach Railroad and Bay Ridge Ferry. The simple announcement of this fact was sufficient to draw great crowds, who thronged the ferry as early as 10 o'clock and who remained at the famous resort until the last train left, at 7:12 o'clock in the evening.

LONDON, April 26. -- Money was sensibly scarcer last week. Discount was in fair demand at 3 1/2 for three months, and 3 for short. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account was 4. The Bank of England is withdrawing supplies from the market, adding tightness to the situation, and all indications point to a further rise in the rate. The Stock Exchange is experiencing a decided expansion of business.

CINCINNATI, April 26. -- This evening a telegram was sent to President Harrison on the Pacific coast and to Mr. John Harrison in Kansas City, that their sister, Mrs. Bettie Eaton of North Bend, had been mortally injured to-day by being thrown from carriage.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26. -- When the train bearing the Presidential party arrived at Oakland last evening it had completed a journey of over 4,000 miles, and ever since it left Washington it had arrived at every place promptly on schedule time. Not the slightest accident had occurred on the whole trip.

BOSTON, April 25. -- While Boston Congregationalists gladly note that the storm centre of theology has passed from Andover to New-York, and are eagerly awaiting the developments in the Episcopal and Presbyterian Churches, nevertheless they are not wholly without vexatious problems themselves. The lectures given by Profs.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Chapter 125, Laws of this year, directs Isaac H. Maynard, Charles A. Collin, and Eli C. Belknap, Commissioners of Statutory Revision, to republish verbatim, preserving the original spelling and punctuation, the statutes of the Colony of New-York from the foundation thereof to the adoption of the first Constitution of the State.

The recent publication in orders from Army Headquarters of the names of officers and men who during the years 1886 and 1887 distinguished themselves by specially meritorious acts and conduct has now been followed by a similar publication for the year 1885. That the renewal of this custom, with a due attention to arrears, is thoroughly justified, these recitals themselves sufficiently show.

There was no startling development in the East River Hotel murder yesterday. The police seem to be absolutely at sea. They will say nothing, perhaps because they have nothing to say. They display an irritability that is in itself strong evidence that they are completely baffled.

The demand for glassware to be used at the dinner of the Protective Tariff League will not interrupt the labors of the gentlemen who are perfecting the new Table Glassware Trust. A dispatch from Findlay, Ohio, published yesterday, contained the following statements:

A meeting of all roads interested in freight rates from New-York to St. Paul and Minneapolis has been called by Commissioner Goddard for Thursday of this week at the offices of the Trunk Line Association, for the purpose of smoothing down the feathers ruffled up by the cutting of rates by the "Soo" line, in conjunction with the Canadian Pacific and the West Shore.

Albert A. Jones, a well-dressed man of forty-five years, who has been in business as a broker at 120 Broadway, Room 50, for some time, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning charged with stealing $1,336 from George Brack of the firm of H.B. Kirk Co., Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street.

The proceedings had yesterday at the breaking of ground for the Grant Monument were appropriate and impressive. Nevertheless, the status of the project is not creditable to the city or to the country. It is nearly six years since Gen. GRANT died. The monument to his memory ought now to be well advanced in construction, and ample funds ought to be available for its completion.

HARTFORD, April 27. -- The Senate this afternoon reinstated Gen. Graham of Middletown as the commanding officer of the National Guard in this State, the vote on reinstatement standing 14 to 9. The report of Senator Seymour's committee sustaining the action of Gov. Bulkeley in deposing Gen. Graham was discussed for most of the afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 27. -- At the meeting of the Evangelical Alliance this morning, the Rev. Dr. John Mathews in the chair, a most important move toward the establishment of a law-and-order league was taken. This league is to have two objects -- first, the enforcement of existing laws on Sunday observance, and, second, to combat the alleged encroachments of Romanism.

PITTSBURG, April 27. -- The eight-hour movement of the bituminous coal miners got another setback to-day, this time at the hands of the railroad mine operators within a radius of forty miles of Pittsburg. At a meeting held in Alexander Demuster's office it was unanimously agreed to run their works the coming year at the price of 74 cents per ton for mining, dating from May 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27. -- On receipt of a dispatch from Cincinnati this morning conveying intelligence of improvement in the condition of Mrs. Eaton, the sister of President Harrison, it was announced on behalf of the President that the programme of entertainment arranged for to-day and the remainder of the week would be observed, unless other and less favorable news of Mrs. Eaton's condition should be received.

ROME, April 27. -- A correspondent of the New-York Associated Press to-day had an interview with a high ecclesiastical personage, who is in an exceptional position at the Vatican, and is perfectly acquainted with the Papal views on the school question in the United States.

As the first and the last naval engagement in which modern iron-clads have had an opportunity to show what they could do, the attack upon Alexandria by the British fleet in July, 1882, has been a subject of much study and discussion, but that battle must now yield the palm for interest and instructiveness to the extraordinary achievements of the Chilean torpedo boat, the Almirante Lynch.

After suffering the stigma incident to four successive defeats at the hands of the Boston club, the Giants paid a visit to Eastern Park in Brooklyn yesterday to meet Ward's Wonders. The Giants knew that they had to retrieve themselves, and they went prepared to make a grand struggle. And they did. It was one of the hottest games on record, and the New-Yorkers won by one of their famous spurts in the last inning.

Around the temporary tomb of Gen. Grant on the green elope of Riverside Park, over 10,000 people gathered yesterday to honor the great soldier's memory, the occasion being the breaking of ground for the foundation of the grand mausoleum which is to be the final resting place for his remains. The day was the sixty-ninth anniversary of the birth of the hero of Appomattox, and therefore a most appropriate day for the ceremony.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27. -- Secretary Mahler of the Kansas Agricultural Board received a letter from a banker to-day, stating that a small greenish insect of unknown variety had been found in the wheat of Russell County, and that much of the grain was turning yellow and dying. The Sheriff of Tyce County also reported that some of the fields there were also turning yellow from the same cause.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The hearing in the lottery cases before the United States Supreme Court was to-day postponed to the October term in order that the arguments might be heard by the full bench.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Minister Phelps is represented, by a gentleman who has just returned from Berlin, as being very confident of an early removal of all the obstructions upon American sales of pork in Germany, and he got the impression that nothing but the excessive zeal of Secretary Rusk interfered with a resumption of that trade at an earlier date than it will be possible now to secure it.
Charles Coghlan knows his sister. In "Lady Barter" he has made for her a part which fits, not perfectly, like the lovely olive satin gown she wears in the second act, but yet extremely well.

I beg to call your attention to a singular construction which has recently been made by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in relation to the act providing for bounties on sugars produced in the United States, passed Oct. 1, 1890.

An extremely-amusing entertainment was furnished last night in the rooms of the Ohio Society. The comedy faction of the Republican Party of this town, known as the Business Men's Republican Organization, had called a meeting of its General and Executive Committees, and fifty-nine men presented themselves. As the organization has been regarded as in a dying condition it was considered a great mass meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Director of the Mint Leech is out again to-day with a financial statement, and it is not wiser than his statement of Saturday. He evidently contemplates laying hands upon funds in the Treasury that have been regarded as trust funds, not available for current expenditures.

The Evening Post objects to the property qualification which THE TIMES has suggested as proper to be required of immigrants who come in this country upon the ground that it is impracticable. The Post had already proposed that every immigrant, or perhaps every adult made immigrant, should be required before being admitted to prove his knowledge of the English language, and this proposition we understood it to withdraw as also impracticable.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., April 27. -- The coke strikers were in high glee to-day over propositions from Isaac Taylor and B.F. Keister Co., operating 900 ovens, for a conference looking to a resumption of work at last year's prices. The United Mine Workers' officials will assent to the conference and endeavor to secure a resumption of work forthwith. The Frick and McClure Companies, the two largest in the region, however, show no indication of yielding.

The sixty-first annual Commencement of the Collage of Pharmacy took place last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The five galleries of that spacious building were filled with friends of the graduates, and the space in front of the stage was banked with their floral tributes. Two especially lovely floral emblems were solid squares of white lilies, on which, in red roses, were"1826" and "1891."

Such a record as the Almirante Lynch has made for herself is not likely to be duplicated by any torpedo craft for many a year, for, according to the cable messages from Chile which reached this city yesterday, the swift little cruiser and her consort sank not only the ironclad Blanco Encalada, but sent another armored ship, the monitor Huascar, to the bottom the same day.

The Theiss boycotters, or their associates, of whom the public seemed well rid five years ago, have begun to make return for the leniency shown them by the authorities by returning to their former tricks. Their old grievance rankles them Bent on revenge and forgetful of what they owe the city, they have set out now to play the tyrant once more.

One of the mysteries of our time is the capacity of this public for ignorance of the art of singing. Miss Lillie Berg gave a concert at Recital Hall last evading, at which assembled a large number of well-dressed persons. They indulged in hearty applause when Miss Berg sang, and they appeared to do it in good faith. Some of them also sent flowers to the stage as testimonials of their appreciation.

The Grant Birthday Association, organized mainly through the efforts of the late Gen. W. T. Sherman, celebrated the anniversary of Gen. Grant's birthday last evening with a dinner at Delmonico's. The large banquet hall never had a more brilliant appearance. The balcony was draped with an American flag, and ranged along the other side of the room on easles were large oil portraits of Gen. Grant, Gen. Sheridan, Abraham Lincoln, and Gen. Sherman.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 27. -- Ex-Congressman Judson C. Clements, who was appointed by Secretary of War Proctor to be Commissioner to examine titles and negotiate for lands in Chickamauga Park Reservation, said to-day:

ALBANY, April 27. -- The call for the special session of the Legislature is drawn, and the time is fixed for Thursday afternoon, April 30, at four o'clock. The subjects that are supposed to be under consideration by the Governor for submission to the extraordinary session are these: The Enumeration, Apportionment, and Excise bills; several New-York measures and bills for the better communication between New-York and Brooklyn.

Two of the medical experts for the defense in the Stephani murder trial, Drs.Allan McLane Hamilton and C.L. Dana, have seen fit severely to criticise the action of the jury through letters to the press. As a member of the jury that found young Stephani guilty, I desire to call attention to several inaccuracies that appear in Dr. Dana's letter in to-day's TIMES.

At the meeting of the County Medical Society lsat ndght an aldross was made by Dr. Thomas E. Sattrthwalto on "Pulmonary Tumors In Their Clinical Aspects" Dr. Charles ttenry Brown read a paper entitled, ,' Domonstra on of the Practical Generation of Ozone ad a Consideration of I zs Utfilty in Therf, pentics." sis paper provoea an animated discussion.

MONTREAL, April 27. -- This morning a well-dressed man, about thirty-two years of age, got-off the Central Vermont train and went to the Albion Hotel, where he registered as James Miller, New-York. He asked the clerk where he could buy lottery tickets, and was directed to the store of Z. Turpin, a barber who deals in tickets.

It is a curious and striking instance of the confusion of mind into which modern Republicanism has thrown its followers that the party in Massachusetts is just now deeply agitated by a dispute whether ROGER WOLCOTT was a Mugwump in 1884. If he was, it seems to be settled among the faithful that his criticism of QUAY may be disregarded.

DENVER, Col., April 27. -- The death by poisoning of Mrs. Josephine Barnaby of Providence, R.I., is the sensation of the hour. A startling discovery has been made by Prof. Sewall, who, when seen, said:

Who is Secretary of the Treasury just now, Mr. FOSTER or Mr. LEECH? Ordinarily that is a question that would interest only these two gentlemen, but since Mr. LEECH has taken to taking nonsense in regard to the "available" money in the Treasury it interests the country, and very deeply. If Mr. FOSTER be really the Secretary, he would do well to close his subordinate's much too open mouth.

The State Board of Mediation and Arbitration has just submitted to the Legislature its fourth annual report. It contains some interesting statements regarding strikes and tenement-house industries, but it furnishes comparatively little evidence of the usefulness of the board. It has done some mediating and investigating, but practically no arbitrating, and seems to have accomplished very little in the way of preventing or composing "labor troubles."

The method of appointing teachers in the public schools of the city of New-York is singularly out of date, and not only inadequate to securing such teachers as the pupils ought to have, but turns out poor teachers in a very large proportion of cases and keeps them in positions long after their incapacity has been clearly proved.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Hon. Stephen B. Elkins, who was the Blaine manager at the convention of 1888, and ultimately nominated Harrison, who had been his lawyer in Western railway litigation, has used his personal influence with the Administration to stop the negotiations over the Bering Sea seals, which were about to terminate successfully.

The same tremendous air of mystery and the same depressing lack of information characterized the operations of the police yesterday in the attempt to find the murderer of old Mrs. Brown in Catherine Street. The shoals of detectives and ward men worked just as hard as at any time since the ghastly discovery in the East River Hotel.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 27. -- Mr. Henry B. Winship, the financial head of the J.B. Barnaby Company, in speaking of Mrs. Barnaby's death, is reported as saying: "There was a murder. In my judgment, the motive of gain inspired it. A mother's life is safe in her daughter's keeping, especially when one daughter is in France and one in Montana.

Mrs. Thomas R. Keator died at the residence of her husband, 30 West Fifty-ninth Street, Monday evening at 7:30 o'clock. She had been ill only since Friday of last week, when she was prostrated with an attack of pneumonia. On Saturday the doctors, who were in constant attendance, thought that she had passed the crisis and would recover.

Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court yesterday signed an order under which the property at the southeast corner of Chambers Street and College Place, belonging to the estate of Thomas Hope, will be sold to W.J. Merrall and Charles L. Acker for $190,000. Thomas Hope was the founder of the firm of Acker, Merrall Condit. There was some question as to whether his executors had the power to convey the premises named.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 28. -- Judge Rumsey handed down a decision to-day involving a nice legal point and declaring Sheriff Van Buren of Oswego and Frank Hopkins, a lawyer of Syracuse, guilty of contempt.

Your paper has contained such vigorous a intelligent articles on the public schools of this city that it is read with interest and pleasure by many of our teachers. Great was the astonishment, and scarcely less the indignation, caused by the article appearing in the issue of to-day. It seems incredible that any Commissioner could have been guilty of that unmanly slur about the "decrepit old woman" and the ridicule of her personal appearance.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, April 28. -- John Overton Love, one of the most prominent Indians in the Chickasaw Nation, has been in Washington endeavoring to get the Government to send troops to drive out the 7,000 people now living in the nation, who, the full-bloods claim, have no right there. Love returned three days ago and said he had accomplished his purpose.

The lively operetta by John Strauss was revived last evening in German at the Amberg Theatre. That stand-by, Carl Streitmann, enjoyed a benefit, accompanied with many architectural efforts of the florist and with applause and recalls galore. The audience was not as numerous as usual, but it maintained that high degree of warmth which is to be expected from German audiences in New-York.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 28. -- Mrs. Ann Hyde of Fishkill was 102 years of age to-day. Only her most intimate friends were permitted to see her. Her health the past year has been of the best.

Nearly every physician, every scientist, and every sufferer has been asking this great question, What is the Grip? Some have asserted that it is a dangerous microbe which comes into the system, breeds several millions every second, and soon overruns the body with disease. Others have said that we are passing through a region of star dust, and that the minute particles are drawn into the body with every breath.

John T. Hill, President of the Ninth National Bank, died March 1, and was mourned as a good citizen and an honest man. Last night, in formal statements by the National Bank Examiner and a committee of the Clearing House, he was declared to have been a defaulter to the amount of $400,000.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., April 28. -- Representatives of Yale and Harvard College crews met this afternoon to confer with the local committee and railroad officials in regard to renewal of the agreement to row races on the Thames course for the next five years. The agreement was amicably reached except those portions relating to chartering an observation train to college crews and giving each crew $250.

ROME, April 28. -- A representative of the New-York Associated Press has had an interview with a prominent dignitary of the Roman Catholic Church regarding the forthcoming encyclical letter of Pope Leo XIII, on the social question. This gentleman is especially well qualified to give an opinion on the subject, as he not only holds a high ecclesiastical rank, but gave the Pope much assistance in drawing up the long-expected document.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A long report has been received at the Navy Department from Acting Rear Admiral McCann, commanding the United States naval force in the South Pacific, giving an account of the progress of events in the Chilean rebellion up to March 24. This is the first official report of the military and naval operations in this war and gives some interesting details.

A very pretty home wedding took place yesterday afternoon at the house of Mr. E. Cornelius Benedict, 10 West Fifty-first Street. The bride was Miss Martha Benedict, Mr. E. Cornelius Benedict's daughter, and the bridegroom was Mr. Ramsay Turnbull, son of William Turnbull of this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton of the West Presbyterian Church.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., April 28. -- The situation in the coke region is more harmonious to-day than it has been for several weeks. No undue excitement is reported and those returning to work are not being molested. Master Workman Wise returned from Columbus this noon and confirms the report that the eight-hour day move has been postponed.

ST. LOUIS, April 28. -- The price of meat has gone up and is still advancing, and packers, butchers, and dealers say that they think it will continue to advance till about the middle of June or first of July. At present the prices of dressed meats, excepting pork, range from 9 1/2 to 12 1/2 cents a pound at wholesale for first-class grade.

The County Board in Chicago, Ill., has ordered that the Country Treasurers in office within ten years pay to the country all sums received by them as interest of public money in their hands. George R. Davis, now Director General of the World's Fair, is one of those to whom this order applies.

BOSTON, April 28. -- The annual meeting and dinner of the New-England Tariff Reform League was held at the American House this evening. Gen. Hazard Stevens presided, and the principal guest of the evening was the Rev. William R. Lord of Dorchester. Secretary Emerson W. Judd presented his annual report and reviewed the work of the year.

There is nothing incredible, and nothing that ought to be surprising, in the interesting dispatch from Rome that gives an account of the Pope's forthcoming encyclical letter on "Labor." The policy of the Vatican has been foreshadowed by the utterances of Archbishop GIBBONS in this country concerning the Knights of Labor and by the conduct of Cardinal MANNING in England concerning the London strikes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 28. -- The National Board of the United Mine Workers of America concluded a session of several days this morning and adjourned. The meeting was called to hear statements from the Presidents of States miners' organizations relative to the proposed strike on May 1 for the enforcement of the eight-hour labor day. The reports were almost unanimous against the movement and an address to the United Mine Workers of America was adopted.

TYLER, Texas, April 28. -- Tyler and East Texas are a unit in rejoicing over the appointment of the Hon. Horace Chilton to fill out the unexpired term of the Hon. J.H. Reagan, resigned, as United States Senator.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 28. -- There were more people on the track here to day to witness the opening of the Spring meeting than were ever before on a race track here, the crowd numbering fully 10,000. The event of the day was the race for the Two Thousand Sweepstakes, which was won by Ida Pickwick, who was at 5 to 1 in the betting, Ed Corrigan's Ethel being a hot favorite for the event.

After another close and interesting game the Giants won again from the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday. It was a contest of the most interesting character, and the follower's of both teams applauded as loudly as their lungs would permit. From the opening to the closing inning both teams were within hailing distance of each other, and several times the scores were even.

Poor BLAIR! His sad story is told in the brief announcement that the Chinese Government has noticed the Department of State of its unwillingness to receive him. It is not that the Emperor, though an amiable person and much exposed to bores, has drawn the line at BLAIR, and objects to being talked to death.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., APRIL 28. -- The fact that Mr. George W. Vanderbilt of New-York has become the owner of a large tract of land in this part of North Carolina and is building a costly mansion upon it was some time ago made public through the newspapers. Hereabout the fact is much talked of. Old residents and real estate boomers mention it with satisfaction as proof positive of Asheville's great natural attractions.
A friend of the Evening Post sent the following postal card to this office a day or two ago, saying that he had received it as an advertisement through the mails in the regular way:

ALBANY, April 28. -- After two weeks of pettifogging and of obstruction in the enactment of necessary legislative business, in the course of which he has been driven from one ditch to another until his course was completely indefensible and his position untenable, Gov. Hill this morning capped the climax of his regime by giving the smallest exhibition of peanut politics that this or any other State has seen from the foundation of our Government.

John W. Devine, a lineman in the employ of the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company, met with a horrible death yesterday morning while at work on a pole in front of 270 Fourth Avenue, near Twenty-first Street, removing dead wires. A wire which he was cutting came in contact with an electric-light wire, and he received a shock and fell headlong from the pole to the sidewalk and was picked up dead.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Eastern racing season was begun to-day at the Benning's track near this city, a great crowd being present to enjoy the sport. Among the throng were an unusual large number of ladies, and Senators Sherman and Eustis were the most prominent members of the political contingent assembled at the clubhouse.
