ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 28. -- The graduating class at the Naval Academy this year is happy in the assurance that nearly all of its members will find vacancies in the service The prospect for appointments has never been so bright, as vacancies in the lower grades are more numerous this year than at any time since the passage of the vacancy law of 1883.

The trunk line representatives have still more trouble on their hands. While trying to look pleasant and find some encouraging signs in the boycott against the Chicago and Alton Road, they are harassed, first by protests against the West Shore-Canadian Pacific out on St. Paul rates, and now by the renewed complaint that the Lackawanna Road is getting more than its apportioned share of the immigrant passenger business.

HAVANA, via Key West, April 28. -- The brigands are getting to be as numerous and daring as ever, having committed recently a number of robberies and sequestered in the vicinity of Santa Clara two countrymen, Antonio Rodrigues and Rafael Luna, besides showing some of their party within a few leagues of Havana with the evident intention of committing further depredations.

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court had a hearing yesterday in the ease of Mrs. Harriet E. Beach, the wife of Alfred E. Beach, editor of the Scientific American. Mrs. Beach, under the pernicious influence of Mme. Dis Debar, was alleged to have become so palpably insane that it was necessary to commit her to Bloomingdale Asylum.

LONDON, April 29. -- A man calling himself James Barthwick Arnold of 317 West Market Street, York, Penn., ought to furnish the Federal officials of his district some occupation if they can lay hold of him in time. For the past month a large number of swindling letters from him have been received here by various English people, some of which are now in the possession of our Consulate.

DETROIT, April 29. -- Work on the new railroad tunnel under the river at this point is to begin at once on the Canadian side, about a mile back from the river. The tunnel will cross the river a short distance below the present Michigan Central transfer ferry and will open on the main line on the Detroit side of the river about one mile back from the shore.
The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Union Pacific Railroad was held in Boston yesterday. President Sidney Dillon presided and Mr. Jay Gould represented a majority of the stock.

Capt. Davis, General Manager of the Nicaragua Canal Company, received a cablegram yesterday from ex-Senator Warner Miller, President of the company. The message was dated at Greytown last Monday. It stated that the party was in good health. They left Greytown April 8, with twenty-five members of the expedition, proceeding to the end of the railroad, ten miles from Greytown.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Civil service reform may not play any very important part in the contest for Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Fifty-second Congress, but the friends of the merit system will watch the fight with a good deal of interest.

Two prosperous-looking men, who bear the appearance of Western farmers, were arrested Tuesday afternoon by Central Office detectives. They are charged with having swindled a number of banks in the West by means of worthless drafts. The men are registered as Andrew J. Conover and James Hall, but they have masqueraded under the names of Albert Huntley, H.F. Lauster, and various other names.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Ex-United States Senator Henry W. Blair, who arrived in Chicago this morning on his way to China, will return to Washington to-morrow. To-night he received a dispatch from Secretary Blaine containing nothing but a request to that effect.

One hundred and two years ago to-day Gen. Washington was inaugurated in this city as the first President of the United States, and two years ago the memorable centennial celebration of the event took place, the procession passing under the triumphal arch erected after designs by Mr. Stanford White at Fifth Avenue and Washington Square.

ST. PAUL, April 29. -- The book on "The Railway Problem," by A.B. Stickney, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Road was sent to press to-day, and the views of Mr. Stickney are so radical that they will cause wide debate in the railway world. His position regarding State control of railways will excite greatest criticism, and is thus expressed:

KANSAS CITY, Mo. April 29. -- A special to the Star from Topeka, Kan., says: "The Chicago, Kansas and Nebraska Railroad was sold this morning by the United States Marshal to satisfy the mortgage of $26,000,000 against she company in favor of the United States Trust Company of New York. The road was bought by Edward W. Sheldon of New York, facing for the trust company, for $25,232,000, he appraised value of the road.

So far as the public is concerned the Ninth National Bank is all right again. Bank Examiner Hepburn concluded his work over the bank's accounts yesterday, found them in good shape everything considered, and formally declared the bank solvent. Only a few depositors withdrew their accounts yesterday while other accounts were increased.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 29. -- The first meeting of the Seventh Canadian Parliament since confederation was held to-day. The business was simply the formal election of the Speakers of the Senate and the House of Commons, after which an adjournment was made until to-morrow afternoon, when the speech from the throne will be delivered by the Governor General.

A youth named Hemming, with an Apollolike form and a handsome mustache, pitched against the New-Yorks yesterday. Last season he was eminently successful in winning games for Ward's Wonders, and Capt. John thought it advisable, in lied of the fact that Lovett and Caruthers had failed, to give his man Hemming a chance.

NEW-HAVEN, April 29. -- Dr. J.W. Seaver, the college physician and instructor in athletics at Yale, has made a comparative study of the users and non-users of tobacco in the present Senior Class for the past four years, and from his measurements he forms the following table:

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Secretary Foster, it is to be feared, does not understand the finances better than Mr. Leech, who has waked up the country to the fact that it is proposed to use, as "available assets," not only the reserve held to redeem legal tenders, but the silver held as security for the silver certificates.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The board ordered by the Secretary of the Navy some time ago to devise the best method of fitting the armor to to naval vessels, consisting of Naval Constructor Philip Hichborn as President, Naval Constructor J.J. Woodward, and Prof. P.R. Alger, has made its report, covering the whole subject.

Less than a week remains for the opponents of the deadly trolley system of overhead electric wires with which the various Brooklyn railroad companies propose to line the crowded streets of that city, to concentrate their forces and present their case to the State Railroad Commissioners. These officials will hold a second public meeting in the Brooklyn City Hall on Wednesday next, and it will probably be the last.

In the new number of the North American Review there is an article by Sir Charles Tupper on the Canadian question, the appearance of which, considering the position of the writer, puts an end, at all events, to all misgivings on the part of Canadians as to the lawfulness of discussing the question before Americans and to all cries of treason upon that score.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 29. -- Sarah Cassidy, a respectable Irish servant girl at Port Jervis, started for Portland, Oregon, to-night, to claim a handsome fortune left to her by the will of deceased brother. She is accompanied by her attorney, Special County Judge William Crane. The brother in question emigrated from Queen's County, Ireland, to this country when a young man, about forty years ago.

The latest information from Albany is that the Governor, after conference with his political advisers, has decided to call the extra session for 4 o'clock this afternoon without designating the subjects to be considered, and that when he gets ready he will recommend various measures, including the Statutory Revision Commission's bills, the Birkett Bridge bill, the Enumeration and Apportionment bills, the rumsellers' excise bill, and various other selected measures desired by his friends.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Racing was continued at the Benning's track to-day in the presence of a good crowd, and the sport was of a lively and exciting character. Favorites were bowled over one after the other in all the races, two of the winners being 30 to 1 shots, while 4 to 1 was the shortest price against any of the successful horses.

The latest "accident" from a wire used for electric lighting shows anew what threats to human life these wires continually make. The victim, as usual, was a lineman, but a lineman employed by a telephone company, the wires of which are not highly dangerous, and are not dangerous at all to the experts who handle them.

At the time of the sudden death of Arthur Coit Gilman at his home in Flushing, L. I., Dec. 15 last, it was rumored that he had committed suicide, and that he had stated shortly before that he was greatly worried over business matters. Mr. Gilman was a member of the large coffee and tea importing house of J. H. Labaree Co., 125 Front Street.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 29. -- Mysterious and unpleasant allusions have been made in connection with the Barnaby murder case concerning Mrs. Barnaby's "friends from the woods," and an attempt has been made by Dr. Graves to give the impression, through published interviews, that these "friends in the woods" might be able to give some assistance in arriving at a solution of the mystery of the affair.

It is to be hoped that the opposition to the introduction of the trolley system in Brooklyn will be energetic and skillful enough to prevent its introduction. The decision of the question lies primarily with the State Railroad Commission, which will hold a meeting to hear arguments for and against the system on Wednesday next, and that will probably be the last chance for the opposition to make itself felt.

I have endeavored to outline the elements which combine in giving character and value to manufactures, aside from the material part of the work that may be in them. I have found it necessary to show the superiority of Europe over America in possessing a stock of working people born and trained to the trade in which they are engaged.

LONDON, April 29. -- The Academy show which the press viewed to-day may be called a quasi imitation of the entertainment running at the Prince of Wales Theatre, "L'Enfant Prodigue." It was really a celebration of the return of Luke Fildes to English genre from the wine and husks of Venetian commonplace.

J.S. Clarkson, the new President of the National Republican League, with an even dozen of his lieutenants, held a council of war at league headquarters, 202 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. It was an executive session and lasted from noon until 7 o'clock, when it adjourned to attend the Protective Tariff League dinner at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Benjamin P. Hutchinson left the city unexpectedly Tuesday night, and his present whereabouts are unknown. He was in Evansville, Ind., to-day, and is now supposed to be at some place between Chicago and Pensacola, Fla., to which point he purchased a ticket late on Tuesday night. Detectives are endeavoring to locate him for the purpose of keeping him from harm, as his relatives and friends say he is demented.

The marriage of Miss Amelia Worthington Kellogg to Dr. Eugene Hodenpyl of Brooklyn took place yesterday afternoon in the blue parlor at the Plaza Hotel. The decorations in the parlor were beautiful. The mantelpiece was banked with roses, lilac blossoms, and lilies; the fireplace was filled with white hydrangeas, and the altar was in an arbor of roses.

Considering that the banquet given last evening by the American Protective League in honor of Major McKINLEY and his bill was avowedly an occasion of glorification, it is remarkable that the tone of all the speakers should have been distinctly apologetic. Though the league and its friends have won their tariff law, they have lost the House Representatives, and with it political supremacy in the country.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 29. -- The marriage of Miss Marion Rebecca Armiger, the daughter of James R. Armiger, to Eugene Stewart Champlin, son of E.S. Champlin of New-York, took place this afternoon at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Graham officiated. The church was decorated with palms and cut flowers. Miss Marion Champlin, a sister of the groom, was the maid of honor.

There was not a vestige of homespun in the garments worn by the participants in the banquet of the American Protective Tariff League last night. The 500 good American protectionists who assembled in the banquet hall of the Madison Square Garden were shamelessly clad in imported broadcloth and fine linen. Their hearts were warmed and quickened by American wines, however, and, encircled by the smoke of domestic cigars, they listened contentedly to high-tariff speeches.

To-morrow, May 1, will be moving day, but for four days past householders in New-York, Brooklyn, and Jersey City have been making changes in their residences. For some reason or other many more people have left New-York to go to Brooklyn, Jersey City, and Hoboken than have come from those cities to New-York.

Some schoolgirls interested in the work of the College Settlement will hold a Russian village festival at Sherry's the afternoon and evening of May 1. There will be a sale and music in the afternoon and dancing in the evening. The patronesses of the entertainment are Mrs. H.H. Baxter, Mrs. John G. Curtis, Mrs. Arthur Murray Dodge, Mrs. Richard Irvin, and Mrs. James W. Pinchot.

If WILLIAM H. SEWARD could have foreseen half the scandals and discredit in which his purchase of Alaska was destined to involve our Government, we may be sure that, as a patriotic citizen, he would have been strongly inclined to withdraw from what was then regarded as a very profitable bargain for the United States.

Special Treasury Agent Jay C. Cummings made an important seizure at the Appraiser's Stores Tuesday. It was the result of an investigation which had been going on for six weeks, and which, the customs officers say, had brought to light a systematic attempt to defraud the Government out of large sums of money. The scheme involved the old plan of undervaluing goods imported into this country.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- Counterfeit coffee is the latest addition to adulterants. It is a manufactured bean, identical in appearance with genuine green or roasted coffee, and dealers in this city have recently been flooded with it. It is almost impossible to detect the fraud with the eye: It is apparently a hard-baked composition, molded by machinery in the same manner as druggists' pills.

The trial of the Excise Commissioners Alexander Meakim, Edward J. Fitzpatrick, and Joseph Koch on the new indictment found against them in the Ahrends case, after Recorder Smyth directed an acquittal on account of a technical defect in the indictment, will be put off indefinitely by action taken in court yesterday.

It will be observed that when Jay Gould got himself interviewed on the other day on the subject of the battery grab it was not the widening of the structure that he assumed to be the real object of the present movement at Albay, but the old loop grab.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 29. -- The police arrested to-day a man named James McDonald, charged with assaulting a boy while he was intoxicated. When they searched his person they found a number of checks drawn to his order. Three were on the Girard Life Insurance and Annuity Company of Philadelphia, and another was on the Commonwealth Guarantee Trust and Safe Deposit Company of Harrisburg, Penn.

BUFFALO, April 30. -- The National Association of Railway Surgeons began its fourth annual meeting in this city this morning. There are about 150 railroad surgeons present. A large number was expected, but it is said that many were kept away by the illiberality of some of the railroad lines. At the last session in Kansas City nearly 800 were in attendance, and the year previous at St. Louis there were about 500 visitors.

While the court of inquiry which is trying Lieut. Commander Bicknell at the navy yard was pursuing the even tenor of its way yesterday afternoon an idea struck Capt. R.F. Bradford, who is President of the court. In a surprised tone of voice he ordered the court cleared, and the spectators filed out, wonderingly. Then Capt. Bradford and the nine gold-laced officers who are assisting him put their heads together.

The Lewis S. Cox Company, manufacturing stockinet jackets at 72 to 76 Walker Street and at Philadelphia, has become financially embarrassed, and James L. Hayes of Newark has been appointed receiver on the application of Lewis S. Cox, the President. As the company was incorporated under the laws of New-Jersey, the appointment of receiver was first made at Trenton, and then in New-York.

Sharrott and John Ewing pitched for the New-Yorks yesterday and the fielders did the rest. It was a dull, uninteresting game and the Brooklyns won in the easiest possible manner. For eight innings the New-Yorks had a chance to win, but the ninth settled all doubts that existed in the minds of the spectators. At that juncture Brother John was hit pretty freely and the boys from across the bridge took a commanding lead. Score:

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 30. -- The condition of affairs at Fortune Bay is becoming rather serious. The announcement came from there late this afternoon that a fleet of thirty-eight vessels, all fishermen from American, Canadian, and French ports, are returning from St. Pierre, armed and ready to meet with violence any obstruction which may be offered to their progress.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 30. -- The new Monmouth Memorial Hospital Building, at Pavilion and Sairs Avenues, opposite the Central Station, was formally dedicated this afternoon in the presence of 500 people. The Committee of Arrangements comprised Mrs. Hugh J. Hastings, Mrs. H.B. Bannard, the Rev. J. Ward Gamble, and Dr. Joseph W. Taylor.

The citizens of Brooklyn will be in a gleesome mood to-day on learning that the Legislature has adjourned without giving the Brooklyn gas companies what they asked and fought for. From this date only $1.25 per 1,000 cubic feet of gas can be charged legally. Heretofore the bottom figure has been for the most part $1.50 per 1,000 cubic feet, and often the price has been higher.

Some very active work was done yesterday by the opponents of the death-dealing trolley electric railroad which it is designed to introduce into Brooklyn, and the State Railroad Commissioners will learn on Wednesday next, when they meet in the Brooklyn City Hall, that the people of that city will not submit to having their lives and property endangered at the dictation of the surface railroad companies.

It behooves all who are hesitating about joining the new naval militia to decide speedily. The First Battalion has now reached a position which enables its members to be very particular in regard to admissions. The struggles of the organization to obtain a footing are at an end, and it will soon emerge from its privacy and enter upon active service.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 30. -- A colonial party was given this afternoon on board "Old Ironsides," otherwise known as the old frigate Constitution, and this evening a brilliant ball on the decks of the old ship concluded the unique event.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, April 24. -- The comedy which the United States and Haiti have been for some time presenting to the world has played itself out. It only remains to speak the epilogue and to ring down the curtain.

After a lively session of railroad Traffic and Freight Managers in the offices of the Trunk Line Association yesterday, the West Shore and Canadian Pacific Roads agreed to abandon their reduced freight rate to St. Paul, and the tariff was restored on the old basis. Possibly this may restore harmony for a while between the all-rail and the lake-and-rail lines to the Northwest.

The wedding of Miss Florence Frances Webb and Mr. Francis Hegeman Sutton, which took place last evening at St. Thomas's Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, was a very brilliant affair. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Webb and the granddaughter of the late Gen. Johnston. The bridegroom is the grandson of the late Gilbert T. Sutton.

BOSTON, April 30. -- The Bostons had the game well in hand to-day up to the eight inning; then the Phillies lit on Nichols, and in the rest of the game touched him up for nine hits and, aided by errors by Long and Stovey, made eleven runs, only four of which were earned. It was a wretched ending to what opened as a brilliant game by the home team. Attendance, 2,055. Score:

TOPEKA, Kan., April 30. -- Investigation reveals the real cause of the dying wheat to be not Hessian fly or chinch bug, but the Alliance. The Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture and Chancellor Snow of the State University have just returned from a trip through the counties in which it had fleen reported that the Hessian fly had made appearance.

PARIS, April 30. -- The Salon in the Champs Elysees opened this afternoon. It was "Varnishing Day," and, as usual, all Paris turned out. Distinguished painters, sculptors, authors, composers, actors, and politicians crowded the long galleries and square saloons, while the Spring gowns and bonnets -- many of them got up for this special occasion -- of the ladies rivaled in bright colors the pictures on the walls and attracted quite as much attention.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The Legislature that adjourned to-day was a remarkable one in many respects. It was well said that a coach and four could have been driven at any-time through the Assembly, while the New-York City delegation of Senators, with the exception of Senator Stewart, were so thoroughly muzzled by the Tammany Hall organization or under such abject fear of Gov. Hill that their individuality was lost and their influence as lawmakers nullified.

BALTIMORE, April 30. -- The city Finance Commissioners, Mayor Davidson and Messrs. Pratt and Spence, held a special meeting at the City Hall to-day to take into consideration the affairs of the Western Maryland Railroad Company. The indebtedness of the Western Maryland Railroad Company to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore to Dec. 31, 1890, aggregates more than $8,000,000.

The Rev. Dr. George W. Bothwell, now at the Brooklyn City Hospital with a cork in his lungs, was a trifle better yesterday morning. He was too weak, however, to see any one but his wife, the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage, and the doctors. The doctors said that his chances of recovery had not increased. They wanted to perform another operation, but Dr. Bothwell was too weak.

LONDON, April 30. -- The influenza epidemic is now ravaging East Kent. In addition to the human beings who have been victims to the disease, the epidemic has attacked the horses in the East Kent hunt stables, with the result that several valuable hunters have already died from its effects.
CHICAGO, April 30. -- A term in prison awaits W.R. Dassler, the young man who was a candidate for North Town Collector on the Republican ticket and at the same time a defaulter to the Government.

YORK, Penn., April 30. -- There came to this city about five weeks ago a man who gave his name as James Barthwick Arnold and took up his residence at 317 West Market Street, known as the City Hotel. He said that he hailed from London and was a solicitor for several estates in that city.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Favorites won four of the six events at the races at the Bennings track to-day, and consequently it was a well-pleased crowd that left the track at night.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 30. -- At intervals during the last few days Lakewood has been almost surrounded by forest fires, most of which are believed to have been incendiary. Although the village has not been invaded by the fires, the damage in value and area to surrounding property has been great, involving, according to careful estimates, fully $60,000.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30. -- The Democratic State Central Committee and a large number of the influential party leaders of Iowa were in conference here to-day regarding the time and place of holding the next State Convention. All the members of the committee were present, and so were Congressmen Seerley of the First District, Butler of the Fourth, White of the Sixth, and Bowman of the Ninth.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The Senate Committee on General Laws submitted to the Senate this morning a report of 5,000 words on the Sugar Trust Investigation. After reviewing the testimony taken, the report says:

BOSTON, April 30. -- The convention of the Episcopal Church in the Diocese of Massachusetts to-day elected the Rev. Dr. Phillips Brooks of Trinity Church, Boston, to the office of Bishop, to succeed Bishop Paddock. The following is the official result of the ballots: Vote of the clergy, whole number, 154. Necessary for a choice, 78.

BOSTON, April 30. -- The annual report of the Mexican Central Railroad Company for 1890 shows a surplus for the year over all charges of $495,779, although subsidy collections for six months only were included in the income account. Operations for 1890, compared with 1889, show as follows: Gross earnings, (Mexican silver,) $6,425,694; increase, $88,468.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 30. -- The one hundred and fourteenth session of the Legislature went out of existence like a Summer cloud. The most cordial feeling was displayed in both houses to-day. The Senate dead-lock continued up to half an hour of final adjournment, when the Tax Levy bill was passed and a number of nominations were confirmed.

When the manufacturers of window glass revived their combination a few days ago and increased prices about 15 per cent., they also paid some attention to questions relating to wages. It appears that the wages of workmen in the Western factories are higher by 10 per cent. than those paid by the manufacturers in the East.

Those who have been trying to believe that Mr. BLAINE would conduct the State Department under the present Administration with dignity and avoid the scandal of making the power of the Government subservient to private interests must be sorely disappointed at the revelations that have been coming to light in the last few days with reference to the negotiations for the protection of seal life in Bering Sea.

The British naval authorities continue to discuss with great interest our new navy, and in a tone that indicates their keen appreciation of its possibilities. Their chief attention seems to be concentrated on Cruiser No. 12, which, according to the United Service Gazette, "has been virtually christened by the highly-suggestive name of the Pirate." The fact is that our statutes will not allow this fast craft to carry that significant appellation.

The reason assigned for the absence of Edward H. Ammidown from the high-tax dinner at the Madison Square Garden Wednesday night -- that he was called to Europe by the illness of a son -- will need corroborative proof before it will be accepted as true by the law firm of Horwitz Hershfield, who had planned an appointment with Mr. Ammidown in Supreme Court, Chambers, before Judge O'Brien Thursday morning.
CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 1. -- The Connellsville Courier, which is the recognized authority in affairs touching the coke trade, says in to-day's issue.
MADRID, May 1. -- Rivas's and Palmer's ship yards at Bilbao have been burned. The fire is said to have been of incendiary origin, and one arrest has been mads.

ALBANY, May 1. -- The record of the Democratic Assembly from the Hill standpoint was issued to-day from the Executive Chamber. It goes to the people over the signatures of the men appointed yesterday by the Democratic caucus, but it was prepared under the Governor's supervision and bears his earmarks throughout.

TROY, May 1. -- A remarkable scene was witnessed in the County Clerk's office to-day. County Judge Griffith, Sheriff Tappen, and Clerk Conway were about to draw the Grand and trial jurors for the May Circuit and Oyer and Terminer. District Attorney Kelly sat at a table without the inclosure apparently engrossed in a newspaper. Near him was ex-Supervisor Moore. Ex-County Clerk Greenman was also present.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The elegant young rogue who gave his name before Magistrate Milligan, Thursday, as J. B. Graff, and who was committed to Moyamensing on the charge of attempting to obtain money on false pretenses from Mme. Marguerite S. Guerpillon and her daughter, who live at 919 Spruce Street, will find himself confronted at the rehearsing before the same magistrate at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning with some startling evidences of his swindling career.

Gov. HILL sees fit to make a public statement of his reasons for not convening the Legislature in extraordinary session. The sum and substance of them is that there is no assurance that the Senate would pass certain bills which were passed by the Assembly at the regular session and some of which, it is to be inferred, would be recommended for consideration.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Secretary of the Treasury Foster issued to-day the statement of the public debt on April 30, and it comes forth in the same shape in which it has appeared since it was remodeled by Secretary Windom, who slightly changed the form adhered to by his predecessor after it had been reconstructed by Secretary Manning.

The Brooklyn gas companies are going to refuse to reduce the price of gas from $1.50 to $1.25 per 1,000 feet, although the law making such reduction compulsory in cities having over 800,000 inhabitants -- as Brooklyn has -- went into effect yesterday. That portion of the general law which makes this rate of $1.25 the maximum rate for Brooklyn reads as follows:

ROME, May 1. -- King Humbert this morning drove through the quarters-inhabited by the working men and women. He was desirous of becoming personally informed of the feeling of the working classes, and was greatly satisfied with the result of his drive. He received a great ovation from the people who crowded the streets to greet him.

Mr. Charles Oberg, the Eastern Passenger Agent of the Chicago and Alton Railroad, said yesterday that in consequence of the boycot declared against that road by the trunk lines and the Central Traffic Association, the Alton was getting more business at this point than ever before. Each say's business is greater than that of the preceding day. These statements are reiterated by the Broadway ticket scalpers.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 1. -- The general corporation laws, prepared by the Commissioners of Statutory Revision, which were placed upon the statute books last year, went into effect to-day. These laws are a codification and revision of all corporation laws and amendments thereto passed since 1848. The amendments to these laws, which were smothered in the Senate on account of the dead-lock, were regarded by some as absolutely necessary to make these laws perfect.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1. -- Nine thousand five hundred people saw the opening game between Cleveland and Cincinnati. The contest was too one-sided to be interesting. Both Duryea and Rhines were batted hard, the latter going into the game at the end of the fourth inning. Latham's double play unassisted and his home run were the features of the contest. Score:

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Brokers on the Board of Trade expect to see the elongated form of Hutchinson loom up in the grain pit of the board to-morrow. He has been found at Evansville, Ind., to which town he was traced the day after his departure. The Chief of Police of that backwoods town arrested Mr. Hutchinson without warrant or orders from his family.

Gennaro Zuccavello, the detained Italian immigrant who walked away from Supreme Court, Chambers. Thursday, where he had been taken on a writ of habeas corpus, has not yet been found. Ambrose H. Purdy, Zuccavello's counsel, and Mr. Benedict, representing Col. Weber, Superintendent of Immigration, differed as to which of them ought to be held responsible for getting Zuccavello into court again.

It is stated in dispatches from Halifax that steamship agents and immigration officers at that port have very little to say as to the assertion that large numbers of immigrants intending to enter the United States are landed at that port in order that they may avoid the inspection provided for those who arrive at our own ports.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Five pitchers took part in to-day's game, and the New-Yorks won after an interesting struggle. Clarke was injured in the opening inning, and O'Rourke was called in to catch. He couldn't hold Rusie's fast delivery, and Welch was put in. Later on Welch couldn't check astreak of heavy batting indulged in by the home players, and Mt. Staten Island Sharrott relieved him.

While Mr. MCKINLEY and ex-Controller LAWRENCE were making the wool schedule of the new tariff there was presented to the Ways and Means Committee a petition asking for free wool, signed by 530 manufacturers and merchants engaged in making or selling woolen goods. One of the results of this movement was the formation of the Wool Consumers' Association, which vigorously opposes McKinleyism in the wool schedule.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Polish, as well as bravery, seems to be demanded in officers of the army, if they expect to he treated with graceful consideration. In the recent Indian campaign the Ninth Cavalry, composed of black troopers, distinguished itself so highly that the Secretary of War determined that there should be recognition of the services of the men.

An explosion of powder in a little one-story wooden structure in the rear of the building at 902 Union Avenue, near East One Hundred and Sixty-second Street, caused the death of four persons yesterday and severely injured another.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- A report that cannot be verified finds its way about Washington that Mr. Blaine will agree to the last proposition of the British Government, by which Lord Salisbury stipulates that no British poachers shall enter Bering Sea if the United States will see to it that no American poachers and no killing on the seal islands shall be allowed for a term of years decided to be necessary.

The neglect with which exhibitors at the Academy of Design have treated the Hallgarter prizes, never troubling themselves so much as to come and ballot for winners, has filled the cup of grievance for the more progressive artists to overflowing. There was a very brisk meeting on Thursday night in which artists expressed themselves with the vigor acquired by years of holding forth in ateliers.

BALTIMORE, May 2. -- The sale of tickets for the amateur performance of "The Pirates of Penzance" has been successful beyond all expectation. On Monday the box office opened, and before the middle of the week not only was every seat disposed of, but it was found there had been such an oversale of tickets that the theatre could not possibly accommodate their holders even with standing room.

BOSTON, May 2. -- The Hon. E.M. McPherson, the Commissioner of Foreign Corporations, has been looking up the record of the Eastern Investment Company and as a result of his investigations has ordered the concern immediately to cease doing business in Massachusetts. The rise and progress of the institution, as shown by official documents, are full of interest.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Stories about counterfeit money find ready market, and Washington has been the place of origin for many years of many stories of this kind that have greatly misinformed and perhaps unnecessarily alarmed the newspaper readers of the land. Writers who have imperfectly understood the accounts given to them in the Secret Service Bureau have at times been responsible for stories of this kind.

AMHERST, Mass., May 2. -- The official Commencement Day programme is as follows: Entrance examinations at Walker Hall, 9 A.M. June 18 and 19. Sunday, June 21 -- 10:45 A.M., baccalaureate sermon, 4 P.M., praise service; 8 P.M., address before the Hitchcock Society of Inquiry and the Young Men's Christian Association by the Rev. Dr. R.S. Storrs. Monday, June 22 -- 4 P.M., Hardy Prize Debate, (Seniors;) 8 P.M., Freshman and Sophomore Kellogg Prize declamation.

The failure of the Governor to call an extra session of the Legislature will be a serious misfortune for this city in one respect. It leaves the people practically without hope of improvement in street cleaning, as there is no authority for the expenditure required for the adoption of the new system recommended by the Mayor's Advisory Committee.
Mayor Grant made these appointments yesterday afternoon:

THE GREAT FIND IN EGYPT. -- On Feb. 6 a discovery was made in the necropolis of Thebes second only in importance to the discovery of the royal mummies at Dehrel-Bahari by M. Maspero in 1881. About half a mile from Dehr-el-Bahari a pit has been found containing several hundred magnificent mummies.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2. -- On its return from Sacramento this afternoon the President's special train stopped a few minutes at Benicia, and a floral tribute in the shape of a cannon was presented to the President by the school children, who were drawn up in a body. In accepting the flowers, the President said:

After all the fuss -- we can hardly give it a more dignified name -- made for the last fortnight about the "available" resources of the Treasury here comes Mr. FOSTER, with his statement for the close of April, and practically sweeps away the various assertions, assumptions, and suggestions made by his incontinent subordinate the Director of the Mint.

In Circuit Court No. 2 in Baltimore yesterday Judge Phelps filed his opinion in the case of the Baltimore Baseball and Exhibition Company against Clarence Childs, refusing the petition to amend the original bill, which was decided adversely to the Baltimore Club some days ago. After reciting authorities bearing upon the case, Judge Phelps says: "The matters of the proposed amendment were especially known to the plaintiff before the bill was filed.

IN THE TIME OF THE RENAISSANCE. -- The highest office in the household of a great Italian personage in the sixteenth century was, however, that of the "Scalco." He was not, Frugoli tells us in his "Escalcaria," or treatise on the subject, the Spanish "Mastro Sala," or the French "Mestre d'Utel," although he combined their special duties with his own.

A special drawing-room car attached to the 10 o'clock express on the New-Haven line yesterday morning contained a select band of professional men animated by one purpose, that of learning how to arrange a collection of casts in the best and most economical way, so that the public and students of the fine arts may get from examples of old sculpture the greatest amount of good.

Daniel Draper, Director of the New-York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park, is making an exhaustive study of the question: "Do the grip and the pneumonia which develops from it depend upon the direction of the wind?" In answering this question Mr. Draper as many facts from his own observatory and from the Health Department which he is dovetailing together in an effort to ascertain if they substantiate his theory.

LONDON, Ky., May 2. -- The present session of Judge Lilly's Circuit Court at Manchester in Clay County presents a most appalling state of affairs, there being no less than twelve men held in custody on the charge of murder. John and Andrew Wilson are held for the murder of T.G. Baker. At the present term, they both were given a new trial that resulted in each case in a hung jury.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The United Stats Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $140,924,000, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,655,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $23,268,450; 4 per cents, $110,001,450.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 2. -- The old Spanish house on Royal Street, in which Paul Morphy, the great chess player, lived and died, was sold at auction to-day for $6,000. It was the oldest building on the street, over 120 years old. It was purchased by Paul Morphy's father, Judge Alonzo Morphy of the Supreme Court, just fifty years ago for $90,000.

THE GERMAN LABOR INSURANCE. -- There are several reasons which militate against insurance for pensions by our wage earners. One is want of adequate security. No workingman can be sure that a society into which he enters at twenty-one will be able to fulfill its obligations forty-four years later, when he becomes a claimant for a pension. Nothing but a national guarantee can give such security.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 2. -- The Junior Division of the Journal Club has elected the following officers: President -- J.H. Brinkerhoff; Vice President -- F.H. Booth; Secretary -- F.W. Hicks; Executive Committee -- President Brinkerhoff, Dr. S.F. Clarke, and H.A. Turner.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., May 2. -- An interesting and sensational story reached this city to-day, by way of Boston, which was supposed to directly connect Dr. T. Thatcher Graves with the mailing of the package of poisoned liquid from Boston to Mrs. Barnaby at Denver. The story had but one fault; it was untrue.

The opening of the new Salon at Paris to objects of industrial art is only one indication of a tendency in France, England and Germany which the United States must weigh. In these lands that time has long gone by when the public classed easel paintings and sculptures only among the fine arts. France has at Paris her Musee des Arts Decoratifs, with affiliated museums in the larger cities of the republic.

Some young men from Philadelphia last evening gave New-York an idea of the possibilities of the amateur stage, when the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania presented what they discreetly called "The Musico-Dramatic Offense, 'Miss Columbia,'" at the Academy of Music. There were less than seventy-five of them, but the enthusiasm they aroused may possibly unduly exalt the city of Brotherly Love in its own estimation to a dangerous degree.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, April 4. -- In the Saga Prefecture on the 11th of March a reinterment of a person buried in 1878 took place. In opening the grave it was found that about one-half of the coffin had decayed from immersion in water that had drained into it. A part of the body thus exposed looked curiously white and undecayed and felt us hard as stone.

The recent friction between Portugal and England relating to the stopping of supplies passing up the Pungwe River by the Portuguese authorities brings into notice the advance made by English settlers into Mashonaland. Mashonaland offers certain inducements other than agricultural or trading in rum with the natives, for gold is found there in quantity.

LONDON, May 2. -- All at once May Day has become a sinister date in the European calendar. Future historians, writing at a distance from which all the amazing bustle and cross marching of the great forces of our time may be studied in a proper perspective, will be much puzzled, I fancy, at the transformation which this opening day of May underwent during the present generation.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The following statement, prepared at the Treasury Department by Mr. Whelpley, the Assistant Treasurer of the United States, shows the percentage of assets the Treasury holds against demand liabilities, exclusive of the amount known as "trust funds," for which the full amount is held:

-- Mme. d'Orgevaut's Husband. By Henry Rabusson. Translated from the French by Frank Hunter Potter. New-York: Dodd, Mead Co. -- M. Rabusson, in this romance, rather strains the maxim, "Noblesse oblige." He places too high a figure on rank if his Prince Paul de Duhn is the type. Mlle. Luce de la Blanchaye was the daughter of a country noble, and the de la Blanchayes were ruined.

Last week the sulkies took their first spin in pursuit of the elusive dollar with two brief programmes in the south, one at Savannah, Ga., and the other at Albuquerque, New-Mexico. Neither is of any special import except as the starting signal for the great annual trotting tournament that has come to outstrip in point of extent and general interest all other American sports.

Gold shipments have again given Wall Street a chill. Something over $3,000,000 went out the past week, and one might suppose that a direful calamity had happened to the country. If money goes west in response to the demands of trade, or if it goes east, the only question of speculative interest at this centre is how far the movement has or will affect interest rates.

Our London correspondent, in his cabled letter, makes a very striking point upon troubles created on May Day by the demands, or the apprehended demands, of Labor. This is that Germany alone was exempt on Friday from the disturbances that were felt everywhere else on the Continent of Europe.

The victim who has "been there" will look with suspicion upon the words "Teeth extracted without pain," and yet, if authoritative reports are of value, the day of painless extractions is at hand. Medical electricity has come to be an established fact, and it is to a party of enthusiasts in this branch of science that the owners of cuspids and molars for generations to come will owe their relief.

THE SPARROW. -- For the common house sparrow, as distinguished from the so-called hedge sparrow and the tree sparrow, nothing can be urged in its favor. Destroy them utterly, is my advice; and I have reason to think that Miss Ormerod has come to the same conclusion. Experience has shown that their ill-advised importation into Australia and North America has wrought incalculable harm to cultivated vegetation.

The opening of the new Music Hall, at Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, which is to take place on Tuesday evening, will be an event of considerable importance in the musical annals of New-York. It is, of course, too soon to say whether the new building will prove adequate to the requirements of such an institution, but there is good ground for believing that it will.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2. -- Two things distinctly mark the college life at Harvard from that of other institutions, namely, the absence of class feeling and an almost corresponding absence of club rivalry. All the other universities and colleges are deeply influenced by the character and accomplishments of their different societies and owe a large amount of their existence to the advantages of good fellowship almost as much as to their educational standards.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, April 8. -- On the 3d inst. the Monocacy arrived from Shanghai and the following Monday Admiral Belknap shifted his flag from the Alliance to her. She will probably remain flagship until some larger vessel is sent from home to take her place.

Newspaper readers will remember that a few years ago there appeared an amateur newspaper at Syracuse whose editorial page was capped with the name of George F. Ives. The paper measured only 4 by 6 inches, and in the descriptions of it that appeared in newspapers that are not amateur there was some account of the lad who had chosen to employ his school vacation in order to try his hand at practical journalism.

May promises to be an unusually busy month among the amateur photographers. There are many meetings and exhibitions in store for them, while for outdoor work there is no better season of the year. The American Photographic Conference, which is composed of delegates from various amateur societies in the United States, will meet during the latter part of the month, and it is safe to prophesy that delegates will not leave their cameras at home.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 2. -- Ever since the return of Private Detective D.C. O'Malley from his flight or his enforced seclusion consequent upon the terrible tragedy enacted at the Parish Prison on March 14, the same line of procedure which the defense in the Hennessy case ingeniously pursued from the moment the Chief of Police was assassinated has been followed.

BOSTON, May 2. -- The so-called reformers of religions have worked their will in Boston this week, under the leadership of the intrepid Mrs. Besant. This apostle of the recondite, by the way, has caused Boston a distinct pang by insisting that her name be not spoken with the broad a, exclusively used by Culture, but must be made rhyme with "pleasant."

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore illustrated his lecture to teachers in the Natural History Museum yesterday with some very attractive and striking pictures of the great rocks of the world as left by nature and as quarried by man. The subject was "Limestones and Marbles," and the lecture was for the most part devoted to interesting descriptions of coral reefs, noted caves of this and other countries, historic buildings made of limestones or marble, and Gibraltar.

Now that Mother Earth has opened her big parasol of leaves to shield her from a sun whose warmth at last is noticeable, parasols in general begin to be interesting. This year's productions do not show enough new ideas to excite special enthusiasm, but there is steady buying, with which, probably, the merchants are content.

The big newspaper sign which has been flaunted from the elevated structure in Battery Park has been removed. This completed the technical compliance with the order issued by President Gallup that no advertising devices should be displayed from the elevated structure in Battery Park. It was hardly more than a technical compliance, because the station situated at the edge of the park is still placarded with various advertisements.

Parables, fables, and short well-known tales probably never took so prominent a place in Europe as they did in the Middle Ages. Christianity was narrow, suspicious of the heathenism that was latent in all lands and jealous of the prestige won by Mohammedanism, not to speak of Judaism and its ancient claims to superiority in learning.

DUBLIN, May 2. -- William O'Brien, during his leisure moments in Galway Jail, is writing a novel. The scene of the story is laid in the west of Ireland, and the period is the sixteenth century. The heroine is a portrayal of Grace O'Malley.

One of the shortest-lived church difficulties on record has been settled in Harlem by the pastor's handing in his resignation to take effect Oct. 1. For four years the Rev. Dr. George Hutchinson Smyth has been ministering to the spiritual needs of the members of the Second Collegiate Reformed Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-first Street and Lenox Avenue.

THE DYING HUANACO. -- It is well known that at the southern extremity of Patagonia the huanacos have a dying place, a spot to which all the individuals inhabiting the surrounding plains repair at the approach of death to deposit their bones. Darwin and Fitzroy first recorded this strange instinct in their personal narratives, and their observations have since been fully confirmed by others.

A hurrying crowd was pushing its way down the broad steps of the elevated platform at the City Hall elevated station last Wednesday afternoon. A handsomely-dressed woman, accompanied by a tall man of the sporting class, moved leisurely along, trailing a foot and a half of her skirts behind her. A big, clumsy boy in his eagerness to reach the street planted a heavy foot on the trailing skirt, almost throwing the woman over backward.

TRENTON, N.J., May 2. -- James M. Seymour, Supervisor of the State prison, whose residence is in Newark, proposes to put on exibition at the World's Fair in Chicago some of the most valuable and interesting relics of Christopher Columbus and his times that the big exposition will contain. Probably the most interesting of Mr. Seymour's collection, at least so far as the public is concerned, is a box which he has had for years.

BOSTON, May 2. -- A bill in equity brought by the Manchester and Lawrence Railroad against the Concord Railroad to compel the latter to account for the property obtained while the two roads were being operated together and involving from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000, is being tried in Boston before William C. Russell of Boston, Judge H.H. Wheeler of Brattleborough, and Robert Harris of New-York, referees, appointed by the court to take and state the account.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Chicago has pronounced its verdict indorsing the high opinion of the Eastern press and public of William H. Crane in his latest comedy, "The Senator." Mr. Crane's first week in his new play at the Chicago Opera House has been phenomenally successful, and there is no doubt that the remainder of his season here will prove even more remunerative.

SHAKESPEARE'S PERSONALITY AS A PLAYER. -- So little is known of Shakespeare's personality that it were absurd to hazard any opinion with respect to, at least, his physical fitness for a histrionic career. That he was of a fair presence and possessed of an abundance of natural vigor is a not unreasonable assumption, especially when his likeness, as represented in the Droeshout copy, is studied for a little.

The retirement as organist at St. Mark's Episcopal Church of Edward J. Fitzhugh, whose place is to be taken to-day by William E. Mulligan, formerly organist at St. Leo's Church, in Twenty-eighth Street, is of more than ordinary interest to musicians in this city and Brooklyn. In some respects Mr. Fitzhugh was the most extraordinary organist who ever played in a church in this city.

The men who are running Republican politics in Kings County just now find it very hard to believe that Russell Harrison knew what he was talking about when he announced semi-officially that Blaine would not be a candidate in 1892. These gentlemen have been playing all along for Blaine, and they have organized the local machine entirely in his interest.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Master in Chancery Boyerson filed his report in the Circuit Court to-day in the celebrated case of ex-United States Senator Charles B. Farwell against the Great Western Telegraph Company to set aside the claims of Selah Reeve, the Commercial National Bank, George F. Harding, and John Clark Hilton, and to vacate an assessment of 35 per cent. against 1,200 stockholders of the company to meet an alleged indebtedness of $350,000.

The residents of Brooklyn have really become agitated over the infamous proposition of the various surface railroad companies to introduce the trolley system of overhead electric wires, and a big crowd of protestants is certain to be on hand when the State Railroad Commission meets in the Brooklyn City Hall on Wednesday next.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., May 2. -- President Harrison and party were met early this morning by a reception committee from Sacramento and escorted from Davisville to this city. As the train drew into the beautifully-decorated Union Station in Sacramento a salute of twenty-one guns was fired and an immense crowd greeted the President with cheers.

BERLIN, May 2. -- The prospect of Prince Bismarck's early reappearance in the Reichstag has given an impetus to the Government's plans for the conciliation of the various parties, so as to render them ready to coalesce in the Government's interest. The Centre and Freisinnige Parties and the Guelphs and Poles in turn receive Government inducements.

JACKSON, Miss., May 2. -- Gov. J.M. Stone, the farmer Governor, has furnished a letter to the New Mississippian in response to the request of the officers of the Farmers' Alliance of Webster County for his views on the Sub-Treasury plan. After stating that he is not a candidate for United States Senator, he says:

Crime-stained as it is to-day, and ghastly with murder every step of its tortuous secret career the "Mafia" sprang into being from an inspiration of patriotism, but its very birth was heralded by a libation of blood.

When the new immigration law went into operation a month ago a number of steamship companies protested against being held responsible for the custody of immigrants debarred from landing. The stand taken by Col. Weber, the Superintendent of Immigration, soon convinced them that they would avoid much fruitless trouble and expense by yielding compliance with the requirements of the law.

Two classes of persons demanded the passage of the new Military Code which failed to get through the Legislature last week without permitting the members of the National Guard hearing on the merits of the measure -- those who were to profit personally and politically thereby add those who were to shine by the reflected light of the enlarged and perpetuated power of the present military administration at Albany.

May Day, or moving day, terms synonymous to so many city residents, was marked by the celebration of an unusual event at the Mansion House, in Brooklyn, Friday evening. While the great mass of restless tenants were settling into new abodes a party at the Mansion House was celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of a guest's residence at that hotel.

In excavating at Nimroud a number of drains were found covered over with pointed and elliptical arches, each layer being built slanting so that it rested on the one immediately beneath it. This method of building renders a timber-centre or scaffolding unnecessary to support the stones until the keystone is in place. Experiments with this plan are now in progress in this country.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 2. -- The poor work of Umpire Powers, the weakness of the Clevelands at the hat, and their stupidity in fielding gave Cincinnati the game to-day. The attendance was 3,000, the day being threatening. Score:

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Washington Jockey Club closed the first week of its Spring meeting very successfully with a large attendance and a good day's sport. The weather was fine and the track in fair condition. The horses ran consistently on their form and favorites won two races, second choice horses two, and an outsider, King Alta, the first race. King Alta was sold to Charles Satler for $1,550,$550 above the entrance price.

The New-York Sun delights to assume especial Democratic organship. It boasts of its devotion to the Democratic cause, and assumes to criticise the loyalty and orthodoxy or newspapers and public men who were battling for Democracy when its editor was conducting radical Republican newspapers or serving under Stanton to secure the suppression of Democratic papers.

A glorious day's sport was enjoyed yesterday by 2,000 people, many of them well-known society people, on the Hempstead Farm, Meadow Brook, L.I., the attraction being the first pony races and steeplechases of the season under the management of the American Pony Racing Association. The affair was a success in every sense of the word.

LENOX, Mass., May 2. -- It begins to look in Lenox as if Summer were approaching, and the usual preparations for the season are going briskly on. The shrubbery begins to show a delicate green and the lawns and grounds about the cottages are being put in fine condition. A number of the cottagers have recently been in town to look after their places and make arrangements to occupy them at an early date.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 2. -- The baseball nine has continued its victorious career the last week, defeating Syracuse University 27 to 6 in seven innings and Rochester University 29 to 6 in six innings. The team played its best game Friday, defeating Stevens Institute 13 to 0. Only two hits were made off Priest and he struck out ten men.

THE WINE-DRINKING BABY. CAPRI. -- When wandering one evening toward the Villa di Tiberio, I stumbled on a curious scene. A mother sat on a wall by the roadside with her infant in her arms, while the father, a strapping young farmer, poured wine from a black bottle down the eager throat of the baby.
" Come at once. Mr. Thomas Warrington is dangerously ill and wishes to see you."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 2. -- The Rev. Ure Mitchell, who recently resigned the charge of the Universalist Church at Cortland and went over to the Baptist communion, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Baptist Church at Horseheads, N.Y., and entered on his new duties last Sunday.

The tripartite alliance between Gov. Hill, Tammany Hall, and the rumsellers is in imminent dancer of disruption. The rumseller is disgusted with his cronies. The liquor dealers have discovered that they have been sadly "bunkoed," and are whetting up their political hatchet for use in the future. After having been promised great things by the Governor and Tammany they find that the Legislature has adjourned and left them as badly off as ever.

Proprietors of flat houses have been offering all sorts of conveniences with their apartments to attract house hunters for the last two years, until now a woman will not look at a six-room flat that is not steam-heated, lighted by electricity, possessed of a gas range and a patent refrigerator, decorated in high-art tints, and adorned with lace window curtains.

THE PAPUANS. -- Every foot of land with the cocoanut, or mammy apple, or banana tree upon it belongs exclusively to some individual of the tribe, either male or female; is jealously guarded, and poaching is promptly punished, women's rights being recognized and protected strictly.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 2. -- The Brown Minstrels, under Mr. A.C. Mendenhall, '91, gave entertainments at the Providence Opera House Friday and Saturday evenings and Saturday afternoon. Mr. Mendenhall has arranged several minstrel performances every year since he has been in college, and the histrionic ability of the college has been turned chiefly in that direction. The Glee and Banjo Clubs assisted this year, and were well received.

Whether Mr. Douglass, who is of mixed race, inclines in his intelligence more to his white father than to his colored mother need not be nicely balanced, yet in some respects he differs materially from the African stock. He never has been imitative in his manner of thought. Let it be said to his credit, he has been rather impracticable in his politics.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, May 2. -- There has been a change in the Targum management, P.C. Field, '92, being made business manager and H.E. Bruere associate editor in place of Field.

There can hardly be any doubt that Judge VAN BRUNT will grant the application for the dismissal of the indictments against "the last of the boodlers," the returned exiles, MOLONEY, DE LACY, and DEMPSEY. The application was not opposed by the District Attorney, because, in view of the dismissal of other indictments and the failure of the latest trials, he had no hope of obtaining a conviction.

LA GRANDE CHARTREUSE. -- The Grande Chartreuse consists of a large mass of irregular buildings which, as they are surrounded by a wall, can only be seen well from a height. The most interesting room in it is the chapter room, which contains the portraits of all the heads of the order, beginning with St. Bruno, whose statue by Foyatier is over the chair where sits the pere general.
TROY, N.Y., May 2. -- Thomas Ryan of 372 River Street, died recently. He was for years engaged in the confectionery business, and by way of distinction was known as "Tommy Ryan, the Candy Man."

Frank Kratschmar, fifty years old, of 352 East Eighty-seventh Street, was shot and, it is believed, mortally wounded last night by Alexander Hupe, while seated at dinner with his family. Hupe is in the employ of the Edison Electric Light Company, and something over a month ago went to Boston on business of the company, leaving his wife and two little children occupying a flat at 1,575 Avenue A, of which Kratschmar was the landlord.

Senator Shelby M. Cullom of Illinois was at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. He has been interested in legislation on railroad questions, State and national, since 1873, when, as Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Illinois Legislature, he appointed the committee which framed the law creating the State Railroad Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2. -- The annual Spring university meeting of the Harvard Athletic Association was held on Holmes's Field this afternoon and was unusually successful. The former records for the two-mile bicycle race and the mile run were completely shattered. In the former event four of the contestants rode within the old record, and the winner, F.S. Pratt, '94, crossed the line in 5:46 1-2.

The Polish citizens of New-York are making great preparations for the hundredth anniversary of the adoption of the national Polish Constitution May 4, 1791. They will have a parade to-morrow morning that they promise will be well worth seeing, they will amuse themselves with national games and dances at Sulzer's Park in the afternoon, and they will hold a patriotic mass meeting at Cooper Union in the evening.

An ambulance surgeon from the Harlem Hospital, in response to a "hurry" call at 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning, found Mrs. Georgiana Gerhardt, in her rooms on the top floor of the flat house 2,335 First Avenue, in an unconscious condition. She was suffering from carbolic acid poisoning. She had swallowed an ounce and a half of the stuff. The woman was taken to the Harlem Hospital, where she died two hours later.

The Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford, at the morning service at St. George's Protestant Episbopal Church, in Stuyvesant Square, yesterday preached a strong sermon in reply to the attacks which have been made on him of late for permitting clergymen of other denominations to speak from his pulpit. He took his text from Isaiah, xxxii., 8:

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- That Italians shall not be a foreign horde, but become American citizens, is the purpose for which an important organization to be known as the Italo-American League is to be formed in this city.

According to the latest advices from Washington, Mr. BLAINE is about to inform Lord SALISBURY that his proposition for an agreement to establish a" close season" for seals on the Pribilof Islands will be accepted. If the acceptance be made in good faith and the agreement be formulated with sufficient promptness, the whole Bering Sea question will be relieved of its most obvious embarrassments.

LONDON, May 3. -- The attendance at the labor meeting in Hyde Park to-day is variously estimated at from 200,000 to 300,000. The procession in connection with the meeting included workers at all the trades, and was miles long. Its route as by way of Westminster, Victoria Street, and Grosvenor Place. It was interspersed with bands, and many banners were carried.

The Boston Post discusses with feeling the desertion of Boston for New-York by artists of some standing. A correspondent explains: "In that cosmopolitan market [New-York] their work is not only better appreciated, but finds a more ready sale. The competition is less severe and buyers far less exacting and hypercritical. It is a lamentable fact that our native artists receive, generally, very little encouragement."

Marie Foster, a pretty French girl, twenty-four years old, was shot in the face under the right eye and seriously wounded last evening by Francois Pettit, a young Swiss, in her room at the boarding house 209 West Twenty-second Street. Immediately thereafter Pettit shot himself through the right eye, causing what is likely to prove a fatal wound.

The crowing of roosters, the bleating of sheep, and the grunting of pigs in the Harlem River Park and Casino Gardens at Second Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street yesterday heralded the opening of the fair and Volksfest of the Butchers and Drovers' Society of this city. A large crowd was present both afternoon and evening, and the outlook is that the fair will be a great success.

Henry Simms, the young housesmith who killed himself last Saturday night in the room of James Hart at 63 Charlton Street by shooting himself in the temple with a revolver, had been seemingly perfectly contented and happy up to a few months ago. He was sober and industrious, and lived with and helped to support his mother and two sisters in a cozy flat at One Hundreth Street Hind Columbus Avenue.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 3. -- A Paducah (Ky.) special to the Commercial Gazelle says that between 5 and 6 o'clock last evening a hurricane with heavy rain and hail swept into that town from the west. The funnel-shaped cloud characteristic of tornadoes was present. In a few minutes the streets were rivers of water.

TRENTON, May 3. -- A newspaper man who ram afoul of Senator McPherson somewhere in New-Jersey a few days ago surprised him into an interview, and quotes him on the approaching Gobernatorial campaign and on the United States Senatorial contest which is to follow it. The interview is mere notable for what the Senator failed to say than for what he said.
In an editorial article relating to the possibility of selling in South American countries goods manufactured in this country, the New-York Tribune said last week:

One reason why New-York City should cover more territory is the intimate relation between a city's death rate and the density of its population. The more people to the acre the more deaths to the thousand. This is a primary maxim in sanitation, and, so far as we know, is undisputed. New-York is both the most crowded and the most unhealthy large city of which there are any trustworthy records. Here are some comparisons:

An unusual sight in the Court of General Sessions is a man who defends himself when brought to trial. Many thieves plead guilty and do not care for the lawyer whom the court assigns to them, and some will not even answer the questions of assigned counsel, but when the indicted person stands trial he is usually glad to have a lawyer to do the talking for him.

We do not know as we should be prepared to go so far as the Mail and Express and declare Mr. HARRISON'S speech at San Francisco on Saturday to be "a great speech." But the admiration of the organ is necessarily official, and a certain tone of courtier like exaggeration can be forgiven. The speech was, however, a very good-natured one, and not unhappily expressed the sentiments proper to the occasion.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- B.P. Hutchinson of the Board of Trade, whose disappearance from Chicago caused a sensation, was to-day again around his usual haunts here. He left the train in the suburbs last night, and going to a boarding house eluded reporters till after the morning papers had gone to press. Then he came down town to his little sleeping apartment in the rear of his business office.

PARIS, May 3. -- The details of the labor trouble at Fourmies have heightened the political importance of the incident. The fact that six women, several children, and eight men were killed on the spot, while twenty were seriously wounded, several fatally, gives the affair the character of a massacre. The soldiers were merely exposed to stone throwing, but they replied with successive volleys from their new Lebel rifles, inflicting frightful wounds on their victims.

Though under strong and manifold temptations, the diplomats and jurists and journalists of the United States have thus far resolutely refrained from calling the Marquis DI RUDINI a bumptious ignoramus. The London Times called him a novus homo, which is about as bad, because the Marquis can probably understand the meaning of the words.

The number of bills left for the Governor's consideration at the adjournment of the Legislature was unusually small -- 102 -- and of these scarcely a dozen are of any special interest or importance. The General Appropriation bill is among them and also the amendment of the registry law.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3. -- The opinion largely prevails among Revenue Marine officers that Secretary Foster is determined to advance the Revenue Marine branch of the Naval Service. Since assuming control of the Treasury Department the Secretary has thrown open all existing vacancies in the line of the Revenue Marine to Annapolis graduates.

The framers held a meeting yesterday, and denied that they want to see the eml)loyers' contract to learn what prices they got for their jobs. They imply want to know whether these sub-contractors to get contracts for the inside as well as for the outside work. The framers' outside work, they say is very hard and dangerous, while the woodwork inside buildings is much easier.

ST. LOUIS, May 3. -- Mayor Edward A. Noonan has made his appointments to all the city offices, and decent Democrats, and in fact all decent people, are disgusted. The law provides that all city appointments shall be made in the middle of the Mayor's term of office, and officers shall hold over, unless removed, to the middle of the next term.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 3. -- The Sixty-ninth General Assembly of Ohio will adjourn to-morrow. The record upon which the battle for the control of the Seventieth Assembly and the election of a successor to Senator Sherman will be fought is now complete.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- According to the accounts of the people who are most interested in having the catching of seals prohibited next Summer at the Pribilof Islands, the great difficulty now in the way of an international agreement is the impossibility of inducing the lessees of the sealing privilege to forego the privilege in order to protect the seals from, extermination.

GOV. HILL has not been conducting himself in the last four months like a man who had made up his mind to give up the leadership of his party in the State and retire upon the dignity of a United States Senator. Propriety required that when he had got himself elected to the Senate he should resign the Governorship.

PANAMA, April 25. -- During the month which Terminated on the last of March thirty business establishments were declared in bankruptcy in Santiago. Among this number the following names appear: F. Javier Urzua, Ignacio Sotomayor, Francisco A. Barranechaer, Avelino Vidalori, Jose Harresch, Jose Eugenio Paredes, Benigno Saa, Miguel Trucios, Jose Domingo Salas Co., Antonio Defillippi, and Luis Calderon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3. -- It is evident that the opponents of Gov. Campbell's renomination favor a late State Convention, believing that if plenty of time is given the Governor he can be strangled in the convention, but as such a programme would also be advantageous to the Governor, it is a question whether the anti-Campbell faction would be more formidable later in the season than at the present time.

Sir Thomas More's life has been often written, first by his son-in-law, William Roper; then by Stapleton, who wrote in Latin; by Cresacre More, grandson of Sir Thomas, and by others. Father Bridgett ranks Stapleton's work as "by far the best" of all these, and yet, while that work has been translated into French. Father Bridgett is not aware of any English version.

The street-cleaning farce goes merrily on. The contractors and City Works Commissioner John P. Adams may be enjoying it, but the people of Brooklyn are miserable spectators. Mayor Chapin remains apparently indifferent, although every morning upon arriving at his office he is compelled to wipe from his eyes the particles of tilth taken in during his walk down from the park slope.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- During the investigation of the present system of carrying on the public printing which has been begun by the joint Committee on Printing of the two houses of Congress, some statistics have been given the committee which are calculated to open the eyes of everybody concerned, especially the public, to the enormous proportions the public printing has reached.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 3. -- In the last two weeks a number of newspapers in the North of a more or less sensational character have been working themselves up into quite an unnecessary state of excitement over the alleged deflection of a large part of the Democratic Party of South Carolina to Republicanism. A recent meeting at the State Capital to organize a State Republican League is the cause of this undue agitation.

ROME, May 3. -- The Green Book on the New-Orleans lynching comprises twenty-four dispatches, dated from March 14 to April 28. It shows that the Italian Government from the commencement persevered in asking that criminal proceedings be taken against the lynchers and that an indemnity be paid to the families of the victims.

For the first time in many years the flag of Spanish naval vessel was seen in New-York Harbor yesterday. It floated from the mizzen peak of the Nautilus, the Spanish schoolship, which stood up the North River late yesterday afternoon and came to anchor off Twenty-seventh Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4. -- Judge Pugh, in the Common Pleas Court, to-day rendered an important decision in the case of John C. Larwell against Stevenson Burke and Charles Hickox. The suit grows out of the celebrated Hocking Valley deal several years ago, by which Burke and his associates watered the stock to the extent of $8,000,000, selling out afterward but leaving the water for the purchasers to carry.
CHICAGO, May 4. -- "Should Gresham, in 1892, be nominated for President, Harrison would secretly use every possible means to prevent his election."

REDDING, Cal., May 4. -- President Harrison and party made the first portion of their journey in Northern California to-day in a mild rainstorm, the first experience of that kind they have had in the Golden State. The President rose early this morning, and was the only member of the party to greet the crowd that gathered about the train at Tehama.

The Bostons finally won a game from the Brooklyn Club at Eastern Park yesterday. It was a most interesting game. For five innings one run would have changed the result, and on that account the spectators were kept in a ferment of excitement. The Bostons, however, played the steadler game, and on that account won. They also did the better batting.

The State Railroad Commission will meet in the Common Council room in the Brooklyn City Hall at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning to hear any residents of that city who care to protest against the introduction of the trolley electric railroad system into their crowded thoroughfares. From present appearances there will be many more such protestants than the commission will have time to hear unless several additional meetings are held.

The sequels of May Day in Europe have been more important and more threatening to the public peace than the events of the day itself. In France, the commandant of the troops at Fourmies assumes the whole responsibility for their action, and declares that they fired upon the mob only when they were in actual danger, and after the mob had been three times ordered to disperse.

PITTSBURG, May 4. -- A special from Scottdale says: "The coke region to-day was shaken from centre to circumference by reports of such another scene as has been feared for weeks, since the dreaded Morewood killing. At Leisenring, No. 3, last night a man named Mahan was shot dead and another seriously injured.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 4. -- The strike of the carpenters at this place was quite pronounced to-day and very few hammer taps could be heard. There are about two hundred carpenters here altogether, but it is said only fifty-five are union men. For this reason the builders say they do not feel like conceding the demand for nine hours a day without a reduction of wages.
