Wall Street report, in dealing yesterday with the unlucky speculations of John T. Hill, the late President of the Ninth National Bank, had it that he operated through the brokerage firm of A.W. Kilborne Co. of 40 Wall Street. Hill, the story ran, was caught in the panic of 1884, and lost a good deal of money. He was again caught in the panic of last November, and saw his losses increased.

PARIS, May 4. -- It was announced yesterday that a section of the Left would join with the Socialist and Boulangist Deputies in demanding a vote of censure to-day against M. Constans, the Minister of the Interior, on the ground that the latter was responsible for the slaughter of the men, women, and children shot down by the troops at Fourmies on Labor Day.

" THE NEW-YORK TIMES," says the Philadelphia Press, "is trying to show that American wool manufacturers do not use wool. Then how does it happen that as much raw wool is consumed here as in Great Britain? Where does it all go to?" We quote this as an example of the fairness of the Press.

Now that the Battery Park grab bill is safely out of the way until another Winter, a citizens' movement has started to restore the Battery to its legal and proper use as a pleasure ground. The experience of the last few months makes such a course imperative. Those who have been fighting the influences of the elevated management, both in this city and at Albany, are of one opinion about the purposes of the squatters.

The collapse of a score of so-called beneficial associations in Philadelphia has directed attention to the corporation laws of New-Jersey. The hospitality of these laws toward all sorts of organizations had already become notorious, but the suspension of these associations throws new light upon the methods by which a charter can be procured in that State.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 4. -- Important papers are, it is said, to be presented to Parliament which will show that Sir John Thompson and Mr. Foster visited Mr. Blaine at Washington by appointment with that gentleman and at the very hour of the day he had chosen for them. This will render a new explanation of the refusal even to talk over trade matters necessary.

The most important meeting of the Council of the University of the City of New-York held in many a day took place last evening at the University Building, in Washington Square. Plans for enlarging the scope of the university were discussed, and important action taken toward making it the great institution which its present situation and circumstances prevent it from being.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- It does not appear, in the judgment of the State Department people, that the note of the Marquis Ruduni to the Marquis Imperiali, who is now the representative of Italy in the United States, published this morning, has changed the situation either for better or worse. The Marquis Imperiali said this morning: "You must let the communication speak for itself.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Bering Sea seal question has been the subject of daily conferences between the Secretary of State and the Secretary of the Treasury for several days, and the special agents of the Treasury who were ordered to proceed to San Francisco on Saturday are still here, evidently awaiting the conclusion of the conferences of the two Secretaries.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Much interest attaches to the regular May meeting of the Western Passenger Association, which begins to-morrow, for the reason that every road expects the Chicago and Alton to raise a great disturbance. Everybody may be greatly fooled, unless it becomes necessary for the Alton to defend itself by measures to which it has not heretofore resorted.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 4. -- The Bruce and Kidd combination sale of thoroughbred yearling took place here to-day. The attendance was good and the bidding very spirited. Thirty-six head sold for $23,290, average, $627. Following is a list of the sales:

One of the most sensational incidents which has happened in college athletics for some time was made public yesterday. It is the action of Yale in canceling her baseball dates with Harvard on account of the recent rulings of Harvard's Committee on the Regulation of Athletic Sports.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 18. -- A tramp of forty miles through a tropical forest mostly jungle is an experience from which the average New-Yorker would shrink with something like dismay, yet our party has gone through it without injury to the health of a single member and with much less discomfort than was anticipated at the start.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Board of Ordnance and Fortification will meet at the War Department this week. The most important matter that will come before it will probably be the allotment of a sum of money for the construction of a disappearing gun carriage for a ten-inch gun, on the plans of Col. Buffington of the Ordnance Corps.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 4. -- "Tony" Pandolfin, an Italian, thinks he is marked for death by the Mafia. He was stabbed mysteriously yesterday, but kept the matter from the police until to-day. This evening, when seen by a reporter, he was a badly frightened man, but after considerable coaxing he told this story of the stabbing:

The formal opening of the Metropolitan Museum, which took place last evening, showed, by the number and the character of the attendance, how firm a hold the institution has taken, in spite of mistakes in its management, of which one at least is continuous, upon the interest of the people of New-York.

The annual meeting of the Grant Monument Association yesterday brought out a good attendance of Directors and developed something like a boom of interest in the work of swelling the fund to provide for continual work upon the monument until it shall be finished according to the full design.

Charles Pratt, the founder of the Pratt Institute of Brooklyn and one of the Standard Oil magnates, died in his office at 26 Broadway at 6:52 o'clock last evening from heart disease following an attack of indigestion. He left his home in Brooklyn at the usual hour yesterday morning and spent an hour at the Pratt Institute to which he was about to add two additional buildings.

Jesse H. Lippincott of 10 Wall Street made an assignment yesterday to Frederick S. Wait, giving preferences to the Rochester Tumbler Company of Pittsburg for all legal claims now due, to Harriet E. Lippincott and Anna M. Lippincott of Pittsburg for $6,760 each, to Sarah E. Vance for $6,760, and to J. Adriance Bush, an attorney of 10 Wall Street, for $5,000.

The work of the Rev. Adolph M. Radin among the Jewish prisoners in New-York and in the State, Mr. Radin being the visiting Chaplain of the Jewish Ministers Association of this city, presents numerous interesting facts. In the Tombs Prison, the unwholesome character of which building need not be here expatiated upon, Mr. Radin found among a total of 490 persons, 22 Jewish prisoners, of which 19 were adults.

The relations existing between Gov. Hill and Lieut. Gov. Jones are of a far more friendly nature than the public is inclined to believe. Their views on most public matters are wide apart, to be sure, and so are the methods they resort to in order to intrench themselves more securely in public favor. But for all that there is a bond of sympathy uniting them which has a very practical phase.

Citizens are patrolling the village of Woodside, L.I., every night to guard it from burglars and incendiaries. Numerous robberies and fires have taken place there recently which it is thought are chargeable to an organized gang of thieves and incendiaries. On Wednesday night a mass meeting will be held to organize a regular police force.

The one hundredth anniversary of the adoption of the national Constitution by the Polish Congress of Nobles on May 3, 1791, was celebrated yesterday by over 2,000 Polish residents of this city and vicinity. The celebration began with services in the Church of St. Stanislaus, which were conducted in accordance with the programme printed in yesterday's TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- To-day's contest was just the reverse of Saturday's. The Philadelphias out-battled and outfielded the Giants, and won easily. Thornbon's work in the box is the cause of the New-Yorks' defeat. He pitched steadily throughout, and only allowed the visitors to make half a dozen hits.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Acting Rear Admiral John Walker, commanding the squadron of evolution, was in the city this morning, having left the ships at Norfolk. He had a long talk with Secretary Tracy, in company with Engineer in Chief Melville, in regard to repairs on the vessels that he thinks are necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- A new electrical storage battery, with a motor designed for especial use in street cars, was tested at Germantown to-day in the presence of several electrical engineers. They pronounced the tests satisfactory. The machinery is the patent of J.B. Entz, W.A. Phillips, and Montgomery Waddell of New-York, all of whom were for some years connected with the Edison Manufacturing Company.

The principal use of the newly-organized Street-Cleaning Society will be to bring public opinion more forcibly to bear upon the authorities of this city for the attainment of cleanliness in the streets. As one of the speakers at yesterday's meeting said, it will serve as "an ear trumpet to convey the complaints of the people to official ears."

A citizens' organization, founded to work on practical lines, is now going to attempt to help the apparently helpless but probably indifferent municipal authorities to keep the streets of this city in a condition consistent with decency. The headquarters of the new Street-Cleaning Aid Society at 222 West Thirty-eighth Street were opened yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- If "loyalty" to the Republican Party is to be tested by the measure of a Republican's advocacy of the renomination of President Harrison, ex-Representative Farquhar of New-York is not loyal. He evidently shares the opinion of Senator Stewart that the Republican leaders are menacing the growth of the party by undertaking to punish all Republicans who are guilty of thinking or speaking independently.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4. -- The first interscholastic tournament of the Harvard Lawn-Tennis Association, which was begun on Saturday, was brought to an end to-day. It was originally intended to play off all the matches on Saturday, but the men were too much exhausted to complete the semi-finals, and the remaining semi-final match and the finale were played off this forenoon.

Recollections of the fall of the North River Bank last Autumn were refreshed yesterday by the arrest of Edward E. Gedney, the President of the bank, and Frank R. Ingersoll, its cashier, upon a charge of making a false statement concerning the resources of the bank for the quarter ending June 14, 1890.

The detention of another Russian vessel for one day in the Bosphorus, after the strong protest of the Russian Ambassador against the previous act, must intensify the ill feeling then created. The demand of M. NELIDOFF for pecuniary indemnity and for the dismissal of the Turkish Commandant who brought the Russian vessel to, under the threat of opening fire, adds a serious feature to the incident.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 5. -- The Chester will of Mrs. Josephine A. Barnaby was filed late this afternoon. It was drawn in Chester, Penn., Jan. 8, 1891, and her signature was witnessed by Florence M. Worrell and David F. Rose. The latter is the attorney who sent in the caveat in the case asking a stay of proceedings in the Municipal Court.

PARIS, May 5. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Ribot, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, replying to a question in regard to the blockade of Chilean ports, said that all the powers had protested against the blockade of the ports of the Chilean Republic. Two French war ships had been sent to Chile in order to protect French merchant vessels on that coast.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 5. -- The publication this morning of a letter from Yale, in which she refuses to play the baseball series with Harvard, furnished the subject of engrossing discussion at the college. To the majority of the students it came as a complete surprise, while a few more closely connected with the management of athletics knew that something was brewing.

The meeting of the Park Commissioners announced for to-day will not be held for another week. Commissioner Straus and the members of the Citizens' Committee, who intended to bring before the board the matter of the elevated railroad and Battery Park, were misled into supposing that the meeting would be held to-day because meetings of the board usually occur every other Wednesday.

One of the lessons which American manufacturers are learning from their experiences with the tariff law is that in order to make headway against foreign competition less tariff and more education -- more art in production is what is wanted. The American manufacturer has found that it is one thing to produce inferior goods and quite another thing to get the American people to take them.

The negotiations which Admiral GHERARDI has been conducting with Haiti for securing to our country St. Nicholas Mole as a naval station are due to the generally recognized necessity of having such a foot-holding Gulf waters. This policy is quite distinct from a general mania for annexing territory, although it might in some cases pave the way to the latter, and has often been opposed on that ground.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 5. -- Although there are between 3,000 and 4,000 idle workingmen in St. Louis, as a result of the 1st of May strikes for shorter hours or increased pay, the first signs of riotousness made their appearance to-day. Quarrymen went on a strike last Friday and the quarry owners have been fairly successful in securing non-union workmen.

The members of the Produce Exchange, which includes many friends and admirers of Mr. Stuart Robson, have organized the largest theatre party on record. It will number between 1,500 and 2,000 persons, including many prominent in business and social circles. The party is so numerous that it will be obliged to see Mr. Robson in "The Henrietta" in two sections.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- It is learned here that the Government of the United States has instructed Mr. Eagan, our Minister to Chile, to offer to mediate between the combatants in that country in the interest of peace and good order, and that France and Brazil, the other great republics of the world, have joined in the proffer of their good offices in the interest of the perpetuity of republican principles of Government.

Dr. 0. C. Jackson of Jamaica, L. I., breeder of Shetland and Welsh ponies, has a pony mare called Fairy, who has beaten all records. Although but one year. eleven months, and four days old a the time, she, on May 4, foaled a filly, and both are doing well. The mother is but 37 1riches In height, and her teal, which weighs eighteen pounds, is 14 inohos in height.

The often-adjourned motion for an injunction to restrain the Sinking Fund Commissioners from letting the Union Ferry Company franchises and privileges came up before Chief Justice Daly of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday. Edmund W. McClave, the plaintiff in the suit, was represented by Edward Lanterbach and Edgar M. Johnson, and for the ferry company organized by the Hollins syndicate Joseph II. Choate and Grosvenor P. Lowrey appeared.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 5. -- The Canadian Government's dispatch to the imperial authorities on the proposed convention between Newfoundland and the United States has excited a good deal of interest among Canadians, and has set them again thinking of their chances of securing reciprocity with the Americans, and discussing their chances of securing it without the assistance of Newfoundland. The Mail (Independent) says:

PHILADELPHIA, May 5. -- t_n a decidedly clever manXler the Giants von their game here today. They fiayed lthou an error of any deserlption, ran the bases in good stle, made some pret"ty scrlfice hits, ad touched up he Ditching of Gleaon in a Hvely ms.en In ahor the _'ew-Yorks played in chamlionsht iorm.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Judge Waterman rendered a decision in the Apellate Court to-day of interest to commission men. In the court below, some time ago, the commission firm of Foss, Strong Co. recovered judgment for money advanced and services rendered in attempting to run a corn corner. This decision was reversed to-day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 5. -- Low prices ruled at the Bruce Kidd thoroughbred sale which closed here to-day, fifty-one animals of all ages selling for a total of $18,065, an average of $354. The principal sales were as follows:

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 5. -- The early part of the journey of the President and party into Oregon to-day was made in steady fall of rain, varying from a drizzle to a light storm. This discouraging state of affairs did not seem to damp the enthusiasm of the inhabitants, and they paid the Chief Magistrate every honor at each place visited.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 5. -- The Supreme Court of Nebraska to-day rendered a decision in the Boyd-Thayer Gubernatorial contest, ousting Boyd from the office and turning it over to Thayer. At the November election James E. Boyd, a Democrat, received a plurality over John M. Thayer, a Republican, for Governor. Thayer took immediate steps to keep Boyd out of office.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5. -- The seventy-ninth annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary was held this morning in the seminary chapel. The Rev. Abraham Gosman, D.D., of Laurenceville, President of the Board of Directors, presided. The President introduced Dr. George Alexander of New-York City, who addressed the graduating class in a few appropriate remarks. Dr. Gosman addressed the class on behalf of the Board of Directors.

The organs of McKinleyism publish some very curious assertions about tin plate. A few days ago the Cleveland Leader, which directly represents McKINLEY himself, declared that the price of tin plate had not "advanced since the passage of the McKinley law," although it was then notorious that there had been an advance of about 25 per cent. since last May, the price beginning to rise with the passage of the McKinley bill in the House.

From the Leonard Scott Publication Company the Scottish Review, the Quarterly Review, and the Edinburgh Review have been received. In the Scottish Review the articles are "Modern Socialism," "A French Envoy in 1745," "The Tellamarna Tablets," "Economic Principles and University Reform," "The Spread of Gaelic in Scotland," "The Spanish Inquisition" and an excellent review of Lux Mundi.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Some of the recent decisions of the Treasury Department officers of questions relative to the interpretation of the McKinley tariff law indicate that the authorities are fully aware of the depleted condition of the Treasury and propose to get every dollar possible out of the paragraphs of that law.
LONDON, May 5. -- Lord James Edward Sholte Douglas, brother of the Marquis of Queensberry, committed suicide to-day by cutting his throat with a razor.

BUFFALO, May 5. -- Four members of the United States Senate Committee on Trade Relations with Canada arrived in this city from Niagara Falls last evening. They are Senator Hoar of Massachusetts, Chairman; Senators Dolph of Oregon, Hale of Maine, and Gray of Delaware. The public hearing began this morning at the Merchants' Exchange.

Senator John G. Carlisle of Kentucky, accompanied by Mrs. Carlisle, is at the Gilsey House. One object of his visit to New-York is to attend a meeting of the sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee which is to conduct an investigation into the workings of the new tariff law. Mr. Carlisle is the only representative of the Democratic Party upon the sub-committee, and the only one who holds other than high protection ideas.

The tenants in the Reeve apartment house, 131 East One Hundred and First Street, near Lexington Avenue, are in a state of excitement owing to three incendiary fires discovered in the house within a month. The house is a fivestory structure, completed two years ao, and has accommodations for ten families, two on each floor. The cellar is common to all the tenants and tt is easy of acceas to strangers.

After six weeks' investigation of the circumstances connected with the trial and aquittal of the assassins of Chief of Police HENNESSY of New-Orleans and the tragical consequences at the Parish Prison on the 14th of March, the Grand Jury of the Parish of Orleans has finally submitted a presentment of the result of its inquiries.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 5. -- The present Grand Jury is composed of an exceptionally intelligent and respectable body of men as follows: W.H. Chaffee, Foreman; George H. Vennard, D.R. Graham, O. Carriere, David Stuart, G.A. Hogsett, Jr., T.W. Castleman, E. Gauche, W.L. Saxon, G.C. Lafaye, A.S. Ranlett, John H. Jackson, H. Haller, Paul J. Christian, W.B. Leonhard, and Emile E. Hatry.

The book programme for the Spring meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Cqub, which begins a week from next Friday, will be issued to-day. I is gotten up lu Secretary 5IcIntyre's usual clever style, with eondll, ions suited to bring out all the class of horses that wlll be ready o race at the meeting. The following dates have been fixed for the running of the several stakes:

The account in yesterday's TIMES in reference to the successful experiments in Philadelphia with a new storage battery surface car was widely read among Brooklyn railroad men yesterday, but none of them would exposes his views on the subject or admit that it tended to solve the problem of electrical propulsion for surface cars.

If the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are sincere when they say that the only reason why they do not open their treasure house to the public on Sundays is because it will require money which they cannot afford to spend, the museum will be opened after the Trustees' meeting on May 18. They say that to open the museum on Sunday afternoons will entail an expense of $12,000 a year.

The Court of Appeals agrees with the General Term in the opinion that the Mayor, Controller, and Corporation Counsel of Brooklyn are poor lawyers and unskillful interpreters of statutes; and it holds that Mayor CHAPIN'S secret agreement to buy the plant of the Long Island Water Supply Company for $1,250,000 is void and must never be executed.

ALBANY, May 5. -- The proclamation which was issued from the Executive Chamber last Friday giving the record of the Democratic Assembly has been met all over the State with derisive comments. As a vote catcher it has failed utterly. Before the Summer is over, the Republican State Committee will issue a counter-proclamation that will show this effort of Gov. Hill's in its true light.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Ream stood all day in the Provision crowd and continued his bear manipulation. The weakness in Grain made it an easy matter to continue the decline under way when the market closed Monday. More liquidation of long stuff was forced than on any other day yet. New-York bulls especially showed distress. Country holders also showed, considerble discouragement.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 6. -- The startling similarity between the fragment of Mrs. Florence M. Worrell's chirography available -- her signature as witness to the will of Mrs. Barnaby, drawn in Chester, Penn., in which her husband is given $10,000 -- and the writing of the inscription upon the bottle from which Mrs. Barnaby is alleged to have drunk the poison in Denver, has caused great surprise and much discussion to-day.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday it was reported that Grammar School No. 25, in Fifth Street, had been ordered closed from 11 o'clock on Tuesday until next Monday morning on account of illness with scarlet fever of some of the pupils.
PORTLAND, Oregon, May 6. -- President Harrison and party were tendered a reception at the Exposition Building last night. The crowd numbered over 10,000 people. In his address the President said:

Foreign men-of-war do not seem to be any more exempt from collision with peaceful traders than are our own cruisers. Yesterday he Spanish schoolship Nautilus, at anchor in the North River, was run into by a tug with a coal-laden canalboat in tow.

The property owners of Brooklyn showed yesterday that they fully appreciated the dangers attending the operation of surface street cars by he dangerous trolley system, and over 200 of them appeared at the City Hall when the State Railroad Commissioners met at 10 o'clock to hear protests against the application of "Deacon" Richardson for permission to substitute the trolley for horses on his Seventh Avenue and Atlantic Avenue Lines.

NORFOLK, Va., May 6. -- A large number of prominent lumbermen from New-York State, Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and Virginia were in session here to-day at the Atlanta Hotel. The object of the meeting was to form the Carolina Dressed Lumber Association, for the purpose of protecting the interests of all the planing mills and to get proper remuneration for their production.

Your criticisms of Senator Aldrich's speech at the tariff dinner were interesting and instructive, yet I cannot but regret that you should have expended so much pains upon the subject, under the impression that the Senator's statistics were worthy of confidence. Mr. Aldrich is highly intelligent and well informed, but his statistics can never be depended upon. Of this, his last speech is a signal illustration.

Senators Aldrich of Rhode Island, Carlisle of Kentucky, and Hiscock of New-York discussed for several hours yesterday the best methods of of getting information as to the effect on the country of the tariff law passed by the last Congress. These Senators comprise the sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee, authorized to investigate this question.

MADISON, Wis., May 6. -- The Democratic majority of the legislative committee, appointed to apportion the State into new Congressional, Senatorial, and Assembly districts has reported to the Legislature, and doubtless its report will be adopted without change. By the terms of the Congressional apportionment the Democrats will get six and the Republicans four of the ten new districts.

Since we believe that the policy of the Republican Party with reference to the tariff is mistaken, and that its management has fallen into the hands of men who are largely corrupt as well as in error, we might regard the spectacle of Mr. J.S. CLARKSON posing as its special champion with a good deal of cheerfulness, for we can imagine nothing that would do more to prevent the success of the party.

The disturbances in Benares, of which the cable has recently brought brief reports, draw attention to one of the oldest cities in the world and, in the eyes of millions of men, the most sacred. Like most disorders in India the basis of the present trouble is religious, the moving cause being the demolition of a temple to make room for new water works.

LIMA, May 6, via Galveston. -- At 4 A.M. on April 23 the Chilean insurgent warship Blanco Eucalada was suddenly attacked in Caldera Bay by the torpedo cruisers Lynch and Condell, which launched seven torpedoes against the iron-clad, the last one striking. She was tied to a buoy in the bay at the time and was unable to withstand the attack properly. About 180 of the crew were drowned.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Lieut. Gov. Jones has removed his headquarters to Binghamton, and his literary bureau may be expected to be running full blast again in a few days. Mr. Jones will greatly miss the facilities afforded by the Senate Post Office, and it will undoubtedly be a sad moment for him when his "hold-over" stock of postage stamps is exhausted and he is obliged to plank down the cash for a fresh supply.

" In the Spring time," says one of the Mc-Kinley papers," the free trader's thoughts turn to England, because in that country it would probably cost half as much for him to paint his house as it does here." And then it tells the wretched free trader (meaning any person who believes that the duties in the McKinley tariff are too high) that painters' wages are higher in this country than they are in England.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 6. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad was held here to-day. Senator H.B. Payne presided. William K. Vanderbilt and other prominent share owners were present. W.K. Vanderbilt, S.F. Barger, and Hamilton McK. Twombley of New-York, and C.M. Reed of Erie, Penn., were re-elected Directors.

The members of the Citizens' Committee who have in hand the movement to oust the elevated road from Battery Park were much encouraged by yesterday's developments. Some of them have found a little time to canvass the matter among business men and others, and they were able to report late in the day that the movement meets with general favor.

At the instance of Jay Gould's physician, Dr. Joseph P. Munn of 18 West Fifty-eighth Street, Inspector Byrnes and Detectives Frink and McClusky stationed themselves near Dr. Munn's house on Tuesday night, and, when a signal was given, entered and arrested Charles J. Dickson of Pueblo, Col., a crank who had come on to kill Mr. Gould if he did not comply with the terms of a mythical organization, Christ's Followers.

William Redick, a young Hoboken mechanic, was committed to the Hudson County Jail yesterday to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of arson. Redick lived with his wife and children in the big tenement house 96, First Street. A week ago fire broke out in his apartments, and the tenants narrowly escaped with their lives.

Ever since John Y. McKane was expelled from the Kings County Democracy the local bosses have used every effort to cut down his power in the town of Gravesend. They even went to Albany and brought influence to bear on the Legislature and on Gov. Hill. The result was that every bill bearing on Gravesend was killed in the Assembly or vetoed by the Governor.

LONDON, May 7. -- The News says: "The report of the New-Orleans Grand Jury is cold comfort for Italy. The only satisfaction which it is now in America's power to offer is a close pursuit of the corrupt jurymen."

NEW-HAVEN, May 6. -- Private intelligence has been received here of the suffering of Prof. Theodore Sherman Palmer and his party of twenty professors and scientists from the Agricultural Department at Washington in their recent exploring expedition in Death Valley, Lower California. Prof. Palmer is a great-grandson of the former President of Yale College, Jeremiah Day, and he has many relatives here.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- Cleveland went all to pieces in the first inning to-day and kept it up all through the game. Chicago played almost faultlessly and battled Gruber at will. The feature of the game was a one-handed catch by Dahlen of a hot liner from Davis's bat. Score:

PORTLAND, Me., May 6. -- The Commercial Union Telegraph Company has made arrangements with its striking messengers, giving them old rates, but making new rates of 3 1/2 cents for all messages beyond certain limits. The Western Union messengers are still out.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A matter deeply affecting every railroad in the United States was to-day decided by the Inter-State Commerce Commission -Judge Cooley delivering the opinion -- in the cause of the New-York and Northern Railroad Company against the New-York and New-England Railroad Company. Ex-Secretary W.C. Whitney and Col. Daniel S. Lamont are largely interested in the New-York and Northern, and were active in pressing this case against the New-England Company.

TACOMA, Washington, May 6. -- The President and party entered the State of Washington in a driving rainstorm, which greatly interfered with the arrangements for his reception at various stations along the road. At Tacoma the train was met by the Governor of the State, the Mayor of Tacoma, and a committee of citizens. The line of march was handsomely and appropriately decorated.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The second day's season of the forty-second annual meeting of the American Medical Association at Albaugh's Opera House began with a big attendance, as the cold weather broke up sightseeing plans and drove the visiting physicians into the warm auditorium.

A fire broke out in the Doncaster Iron Foundry, West Avenue and Flushing Street, Long Island City, at 10:40 o'clock last night, which is supposed to have been caused by a spark from a casting which had been made just before the shop closed. It must have smoldered for some hours, but when it appeared it blazed so fiercely that the whole place was totally destroyed in a few minutes.

The Racing Board of Control had a meeting yesterday afternoon at the office of the Coney Island Jockey Club, its own rooms not being ready for occupancy. The principal business was the reception of a communication from "Ed" Heffner, in which he absolutely repudiates his charges of dishonesty against the Dwyer Brothers, which Inspector of Police Byrnes charged him with having made, when the Inspector was angry because the city pool rooms had been closed.

There was an abundance of harmony at the meeting of the advisory board of the Western Traffic Association in the Windsor Hotel yesterday. Mr. Jay Gould, who snubbed the board so mercilessly when it met in Chicago a few weeks ago, attended yesterday's session and was treated with the utmost consideration. Therefore there was harmony.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., May 6. -- United States Marshal Gard last night seized the Chilean steamer Itata, now receiving supplies in the harbor, and placed Capt. Mauzeum under arrest, but he was afterward released. Telegrams have been passing between this city and the department at Washington which brought about the above results. A United States Marshal is in charge.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The report of the New-Orleans Grand Jury upon the killing of the Italians was a fruitful theme for discussion among people at the Department of State to-day. It may be said that the findings of the Grand Jury excited no surprise, for some such conclusion of the case was expected.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 6. -- The Cornells defeated the Unions here to-day. The Schenectady students lost through their inability to bat the ball at opportune moments. Score:

ALBANY, May 6. -- The Governor has signed: Chapter 328, authorizing Utica to raise not exceeding $6,000 for the completion of the construction of an iron viaduct over Ballou's Creek at Rutgers Street.

President J.S. Clarkson of the National Republican League sailed for Europe yesterday on the City of Chicago. His departure put an end to the secret conferences of the officers of the league which have been going on for several days. The conference began Tuesday night, and ended at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Some changes in the programme outlined a week ago were made at the last moment and announced yesterday.
PHILDELPHIA, May 6. -- The Evening Telegraph, in its editorial comment on the New-Orleans Grand Jury finding, says:

Michigan Republicans talk about contesting the constitutionality of the act passed by the Democratic Legislature providing for the election of Presidential Electors by Congressional districts. There is no manner of doubt about its constitutionality, and the plan would have much to commend it if it were to be adopted by all the States at once.

HAVANA, May 6. -- The 1st of May, being the first day of the "Mes re Flores," was very generally celebrated at the churches, which were lavishly decorated with flowers and well attended by those who generally keep the feast dedicated to "La Renia de los Cielos."

The Railroad Commissioners continued their hearing in Brooklyn yesterday on the application for their consent to the adoption of the trolley system of traction for cars in certain streets of that city. Among the opponents were several representatives of churches, schools, and hospitals, whose property, not being subject to taxation, is not included in that of which the owners' consent is required for a change of motive power.

LANSING, Mich., May 6. -- Gov. Winans, in his inaugural address, neglected to recommend an appropriation of $50,000 to aid Detroit in entertaining the National Grand Army of the Republic at its encampment next August. A canvass early in the session showed that a majority of the members, reflecting the opinion of the State, were utterly opposed to the measure.

A testimonial dinner was given at the Merchants' Club last night to William F. King by the representative men of the dry goods trade. It was both a testimonial to Mr. King for his effective services at Albany and in other fields and a celebration of the defeat of vicious legislation.
